column2: The Morris Jerseymen gives particulars of the death of BETSKY, Wite of NEWTON WOODRUFF, of Han over, Morris Co., who is supposed to have committed suicide on Tuesday last. In the afternoon Mrs. WOODRUFF took her youngest child, eight years of age, and remarked that she was going fishing. She returned in a few minutes with the child, and saidthere were some men near the river she was afraid of.

JOHN ABLE, know as a gambler here, was shot dead this afternoon by a man named JOHN EVERSON, in front of the Washam House. ABLE asked EVERSON for some money that he owed him, and the reply was a pistol ball through his body. The affair created great excitement amongst the citizens, who, assem bled at the jail, determined to hang EVERSON, but through the persuasions of the May or and others,they were calmed down.

From the Detroit Tribune. On Saturday night about 10 o'clock an organized and premeditated onelaught or a most determined character was made upon some low dance-houses in the Tenth Ward. The gang of men numbered at lent 100, and was headed by some of the prominent citizens of the Ward, as also by several aspirants, we are told, to the honors of an Alderman's seat and aSchool Inspectorship.

P. ANGUARA, United States Counsel at Barcelona, Spain, has sent to the State Department at Washington, the following important communication: "The Spanish government having prolonged until the 31st December next the exemptions previously accorded to all vessels arriving in Spain from foreign ports with flour, grain, beans,

When the world was younger but certainly not much wiser than it now is, men treated misfortune as a crime. The question of the Pharisec, " Lord, who hath sinned, this man or his parents, that he should be born blind?" condenses the moral and the medical philosophy of many centuries.

SHOCKING MURDER IN PHILADELPHIA.--About 9 o'clock on Saturday evening, a disturbance took place among some low characters in Carberry's Court, running South from Catharine street, below Fifth. During the fight EDWARD MULDOON, a newly elected constable of the Third Ward, interfered to stop the disturbance, and while in the performance of his duty he was stabbed in the stomach with a knife in the hands of one of the party.

MURDER IN CORNWALL.--JOHN TOLE, of Can terbury, came to his death at the house of Mrs. DAY ENPORT, at Cornwall, Orange County, under the fol lowing circumstances: A man came into the hots and demanded liquor, which Mrs. DAVENPORT refused to give him. He then caught up a pump-handle and aimed a blow at Mrs. D., when TOLE stepped in between them, and received the blow on the head.

LAURA KEENE'S THEATRE.--A new piece, called " Love's Telegraph," was produced here last night with success. It is an English adaptation of a French commedietta, and in a literary point of view presents no especial merit except that of general neatness.The title suggests the idea of the plot.

A few days since we gave expression to our fears that, notwithstanding bids had been called and received for the contract to carry the over land Pacific mail, the Postmaster-General had already prejudged the case, and absolutely de termined that this service should be performed by JAMES E. BIRCH, of California, and vidthe extreme southern route.

BALZAC tells a story of an old Judge in Touraine, learned in the law and yet strange to say, not wholly unlearned in human nature, who used to put one invariable question to every criminal that was brought before him. No matter what the age or appearance of the ac cused might be--no matter what the crime ofwhich he stood impeached,

The Bristol oakum works, owned by Messrs. DEVOE, DIMON Co, were discovered to be on fire at 3 o'clock this morning, and were soon totally de stroyed by it. The origin of the fire is unknown, The buildings were insured for $10,000, among the Hartford and North Western, Western Maesachusettsand Slater Mutual Insurance offices.

The Republican State Convention met in this City to-day. After the organization had been per fected, an informal vote was taken fora candidate for Governor, and Hon. N. P. BANKS received 291 votes out of 464. The result was received with greatapplause.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER preached to his congregation last evening on the responsibility of the Church and of individual Christians for the public Sentiment of the community. In the course of it he spoke of the tight of the palpit to speak against any wrong, even if it had got into the aanctuary of politics,in connection with which he said he had recently
A race for $2,000 a side came off this afternoon between the Dulton horse, owned here, and the Tay lor horse, owned in New-York. The distance wastwenty miles, in harness.

The Masons of this District were joined by their brethren of Richmond and celebrated St. John's Day by a visit to Mount Vernon. The ceremonies at the tomb were of a deeply solemn character. Among the incidents was the christening on the premises of twochildren, to bear the name of WASHINGTON.

The pacification of Central America, and the probability of a revival of the old Confederation, give additional interest to everything relating to the commerce and resources of that interesting part of the world. Sir H. BARKLY'S report to the British Government shows that the commercial position of that settlement is steadily improving, there being a slight increase in the value both of imports and exports.

The Santa Fe mail has arrived, bringing dates to the 30th of May. Three hundred and fifty troop under Colonel BONNEVILLE. had entered the Gila Apache country for the purpose of punishing the Indians for the numerous outranges committed by them upon the whites.

The Committee of Investigation on the affray which occurred in the State-House yesterday, have reported that the parties were excited over the re. marks made in the House by Mr. BROOKS, and those of Mr. DUNHAM to Mr. BROOKS; that Mr. DUNHAM had apologized to the House through the Committee, and that Mr. BROOKS would apologize directly to the House.

Ex-Alderman HERRICK, Naval storekeeper, found yesterday morning upon visiting his office that a drawer of one the desks has bean opened during the night, and five watches stolen. The watches were silver, patent levers, valued at $40 each, and be longed to the United Stated. Mr. HERRICK laid the subject of the theft, yesterday afternoon, before Mr. MASTERSON of the chief's Office and the latter detailed an officer to hunt up the stolen property.

A grand Tournament and splendid rural entertainment came offsets Friday in London County, at Rocky Ford. It was given by the Chivalry of Upper Fauqier and London to the fair and beaquteous women of those counties, It is 969 years ago since tournaments first because the fashion and many a wrudasader from thud for his gallantry,

FIRE IN NINTH-AVENUE.--A frame building in Ninth-avenue, between Forty fifth and Forty-sixth streets, occupied as a feed store by BRIDGES ROBERTS, and owned by Mr. FEITNER, was, with an office adjoining, destroyed by fire between 1 and 2 o'clock yesterday morning. Mr FEITNER'S loss is estimated at $800 ; insured for $500 in the Greenwick Insurance Company.

THE CROPS.--A gentleman traveling in the interior, writes as that, though backward, the crops in the valleys of Tennessee look remarkably well and promising. There was a greater increase in the quantity of land sown to wheat throughout East Tennessee than ever before.

YELLOW FEVER IN SOUTH AMERICA.--The following is an extract from a letter dated at Montevideo. April 14: "In the beginning of last month the yellow fever broke out in a most malignant form, and upwards of 4?0 have already fallen victims to the disease which has spread over the city.

There is a disposition evinced in certain quarters to exonerate the Mayor from all share in the riot and rebellion of the 16th inst., since he has produced a batch of affidavits showing his ignorance of the nature of the Coroner's errand when he first called at the City Hall with the warrant of arrest issued by Judge HOFFMAN.

OUR CLAIM AGAINST VENEZUELA-We find in El Foro, of Caracas, of the 6th of June, the following statement in relation to the claim for indemnity, brought by the United States against the Venezuelan Government, for depriving certain American citizens (Messrs. SHELTON, SAMPSON TAPPAN, of Boston) of their right of the guano Bird Islands, which they has discovered in an abandoned condition, and bad occupied and "annexed." El fore says:

ITALIAN OPERA.--It will be seen by a card published below that Mme. LA GRANGE, the most estimable and admirable artist we have ever had on these shores, has leased the Academy for a short season of Opera, commencing on Monday next. We trust that the enterprise will prove a successful one. BRIGNOLI, AMODIO, COLLETTI, ARNOLDI and other popular artists are in the company.

THE MARINE SURVEYORS.--We have been requested by a distinguished authority to correct our statement that "the Marine Surveyors are sustained by the Chamber of Commerce and Board of Under. writers, and under their direction re ??till going on in the discharge of their duties in the surveying of ships and cargoes"

Col. CUMMING will probably receive his com mission tomorrow, and also his instructions from the President. The Secretary of State to Utah, has not yet been appointed. The instructions to the Governor of Utah will be of a very positive and stringent character, as the President is determined to preserve the domestic tranquillity of the country.It will be in vain for the Mormons to vail their brutol.

A WIDOW MURDERED IN ST. LAWRENCE COUNTY BY A SCHOOL TEACHER.--The Ogdensburg papers give particulars of a murder in Louisville, St. Lawrence County, for which the accused was examined on Saturday last, EDWIN ELDRIDGE, of Louisville, was arraigned, charged with the murder of Mrs. GOULD, a widow. The evidence showed that ELDRIDGE resided at Louisville in December last,

The French Empire is now upon its trial before the tribunal of the popular will. That the trial will not, and cannot be a fair and impartial trial, we need not say, Yet the arrangements which have been made for holding it go far towards determining us ;to believe that the verdict will after all be essentially a fair verdict--that it will reflect the dominant

ANOTHER JUDICIAL ALLY.--Mr. MICHAEL CONNOLLY, who is a Police Justice at the Tombs, was a highly respectable cigar merchant before he was elevated as an expounder of criminal law by an enlightened constituency; and he has abundantly proved the prophesies at his friends that when on the bench he would make offenders "smoke."

Governor CUMMING left this afternoon for St. Louis, on his way to Kansas. Hu will return in ten days, and will then receive his commission and in structions. By the act establishing the Territory of Utah of 1850, right is reserved to Congress to abolish the Territory at its pleasure. It provides that said Terri tory may be divided or attached to any other Stateor Territory.

BEWARE OF DOGS.--This is a scriptural caution, and we have no doubt but that it was especially intended for the season vulgarly known as the "dog days." At this time of the ear dogs go mad, and newspaper columns throughout the country are filled with accounts of "fatal results" from their bites. Our municipal authorities take the matter in hand,

I sent you a few weeks age a statement from the Treasury, showing the distribution of the Government areasure on deposit in the different States. I am how able to lay before your readers some of the most important, curious and interesting statistical information that has yet been published. It will prove invaluable to politicians.

FEMALE NORMAL SCHOOL--The Commencement speeches of the Female Normal School at the Academy of Music, last evening, were particularly good. The Academy was crowded, inside and out, at an early hour, thousands being unable to obtain admission. The appearance of the house from the rear of the stage, which was occupied by young ladies dressed in white, was exceedingly fine.

A splendid banquet was given, this evening, by the dealers in Glass, China and Earthenware, of this city, to their brethren of other cities, at the LapierreHou o. One hundred and fifty persons partook of it.

ARSENAL MANAGEMENT.--We have already stated in the TIMES that auction sale of the State Arsenal in this City, has been further postponed by the Commissioners of the Land Office to the 24th of July. By that time the sixty days allotted to the

DRISCOLL--HUBBARD,--In Brooklyn, E. D., on Thursday, June 25, at the residence of the bride's father, by rev. Mr. Janes, FRANK S. DRISCOLL, of NEW-YORK, to KATE W., eldest daughter of G. D. Hubbard, Esq. POTTS-PHELON--In West Hoboken, N. J., on Wednesday, June 24, by Rev. H. S. Carpenter, of Brooklyn, JOSEPH C. POTTS, Esq., of Trenton, N. J. to MARIA H. PUELON.

NEW-YORK UNIVERSITY DINNER.--The under graduates of the New York University assembled in jovial conclave at the Clinton Hotel, corner of Broadway and Eighth street, last evening, to partake of a bountiful repast provided for them--to eat and drink to the temporary increment of their own obesity and the future prosperity of their Alma Mater. It was originally intended that the Faculty and Alumni of the Institution should join with them in the Anni.

The Maine Republican State Convention at Bangor to-day, nominated LOT M. MORRILL for GOV ernor, by a vote of 585 to 16. Resolutions were adopted admonishing the Free States to be more zealous of their rights; advising stronger Tindication of State Sovereignty: pointing to the Supreme Court Drod Scott decision, and the Democratic Party as threatening to liberty and popular rule;

THE SWEEPERS AT WORK,--We had, yester day, the first actual feeling of Summer, with out feeling any of the usual ill effects of hot weather. But we bad, also, what was much more unexpected, though not a whit the less pleasant, the first sight of a squad of street sweepers that has blurred our eyes in a longtime.

MEETING OF THE "SMALL" COMMITTEE.-- The "Regular" or Wilson S?? General Committee had a meeting at Tammany Hali last evening,--Chairman PIED presided. The various Wards were called and reported the officers of their organization, and the names of the General and Young Men's Committees agreed upon.

In the matter of the Application of Daniel D. Conover to compel the delivery to him of the Books, Papers, , of the Street Commissioner's Office.--At precisely 11 o'clock Mayor Wood entered the Court-room, accompanied by his counsel, and took a seat on the bench with Judge PEABODY. The Court was soon after opened, and the Mayor took the witness stand. Mr. Field resumed the examination as follows:

The New-Hampshire Legislature, to-day, passed resolutions denunciatory of the Dred Scott decision, and in the House, this afternoon, the negro disability clause was expunged from the militia bill. A heavy thunder-storm broke over Boston this evening. The lightning struck on the Common and one or two other places, but no serious damage wasdone.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Accidents on our City Railroads are almost of daily occurrence, and yet by a simple alteration in the construction of the cars they might be entirely prevented. The remedy is so apparent that it is very strange it has not been adopted by the Railroads for their pecuniary interest as well as for the cause ofhumanity.

At a meeting of citizens last night, a jury was formed havINg six representatives from each Ward. ABLE, the murderer of EVEESON, was found guilty of his murder in the first degree. Twelve of the Jury were in favor of lynching ABLE, and the rest for dis posing of him lawfully. A resolution was passed requiring all the gamblersto leave the city in ten days, or be forcibly expelled.

THE INDIAN MURDERS.--We have already given an account of the attack, by a band of one hundred Cheyenne Indians, on a company of emigrants on their way to California--the killing of four men, and the wounding of two men and one woman. We now learn that the party consisted of C. B. WEAVER and wife, A. P. Weaver, R. WEAVER, M. LEWIS, SAMUEL

La Marche, on Wednesday last, offered a singular interest to the amsteurs of the turf. On that occasion the French Jockey Club offered the English Jockey Club their hospitality and their competition in a Military Steeple Chase, which was only to be ridden by gentlemen, still more, by gentlemen of the army. The jockeys laid off their caps and breeches for that day, and appeared on the ground as simple spectators.

A paper which, to serve a purpose, feels generally at liberty to draw on its imagination for learning as well as facts, employs the phrases, " despotic usurpations against our municipal liberties" and "despotic and inse. lent interference in our municipal affairs," to characterize the legislation at Albany for this City.

Sergeants TWEED and WHITE, of the Metropolitan Police, called, last evening, at the Second Ward Station-house. Sergeant TWEED said he had been sent to assume command of the District, and desired to read on "order" to the men.

CORNELL--In this City, on Wednesday, June 24, after a short illness, WILLIAM H. CORNELL, aged 44 years, 3 months and 24 days. The friends and relatives of the family, and those of his brothers, John L., Stephen H., Charles G. and Robert G. Cornell, of his son-in-law, Samuel S. Wandell, and his brothers-in-law, Wm. A. Freeborn, Henry D. Grant, Samuel Rohier,

The Act of 1850, establishing the Territory of Utah, contains a provision whereby Congress can, at pleasure, abolish the Territory, or attach it to any other State or territory. The Act was passed with the express understanding that polygamy would not be tolerated.

The Board of Aldermen, The Board of Aldermen met last evening, -Alderman CLANCY, President, in the Chair. The following is a verbatim copy of a resolution offered by Alderman FULLMAR, and adopted by the Board: " Whir as the Appropreation for Roads for 1857 was seventy five thousand Dollars and"

The Court of Appeals still has undergoing the process of incubation the decision of the constitution' ality of the Metropolitan Police bill. I do not think that, collectively, the Judges themselves know what the decision will be-or that any deliberate consulta tion has yet been had between them. But, neverthe less, it appears to be well settled here that the constitutional question will be decided in the affirmative.

The Main Line was sold this evening by auc tion, at the Exchnnge. There was a large attendance, and the Governor was present. It was purchased by J. EDGAR THOMSON, President, in behalf of the Penn sylvania Railroad, for $7,500,000,--one bid only being made. Loud cheers were given for the Governor and the Pennsylvania Road at the conclusion of the sale.

The Interior Department has received informa tion that the Superintendents of the several branches of the Pacific Wagon Road are prosecuting the work with energy, and will hurry its completion. The subject of the Overland California Mail wasagain considered by the Cabinet to-day.

THAT NORMAL FISH.--The Graduates of the Female Normal School of this City, received their di plomaa on Thursday evening, in the presence of one of the largest audiences that ever assembled in theAcademy of Music,

A special meeting of the New-York Academy of Medicine was held on Wednesday evening, Dr. MOTT in the Chair. A letter from Dr. ANTISELL, of Washington, in reference to the hotel ep.demic, was referred to the Section on Theory and Practice. The Communication from Dr. BAILEY, late Inspector of Drugs for this port, which had been referred to the President, was ordered to be read at the next meeting of the Academy.

The subject of military education is just now exciting a great deal of discussion in England, and though, to a foreigner who casts a careless glance over the newspapers,it may seem simply and purely a question of momentary and of professional interest, it nevertheless possesses an importance not only far greater than the name indicates, but far greater than many ofthose who handle it even dream of.

A BOY SHOT.--A son of Mr. WILSON, residing near Limestone Hill, Orange County, came to his death on Tuesday, under the following circumstances: A loaded gun had been kept in Mr. WILSON'S barn, with the lock set ready for firing. The ?? and his youngest brother were sent, to the barn for egge,

There is an old gentleman in one of the city pauper institutions at South Boston, who was for many years the President of one of the largest insurance companies in the country. He was for a whole generation the associate and friend of the Thorndikes, the Brookess, the Ly??ce, the A??orys, the Cabots, the Perkiness, and other merchant prieces of Boston.

A HOUSE TORN DOWN FOR FIREWOOD.--The ricketty two-story frame house No. 12 Thames-street, belonging to the Clinton estate, was yesterday torn down by a mob for firewood, It was formerly occupied as a tenement-house, and of late as a cooper's shop, but a few weeks ago it was left tenantless, since that time the washboards and lath have been gradually disappearing at the hands of the chiffoniera,

TRICKS OF THE DIRT CARTMEN.-One of the great causes of the dust in the streets is the dirt cart man. In his tender compassion for his horse, when he carts a load of sand from a cellar, he manages to have the tail-board of his box-cart so low that by the time he arrives at the dumping ground" one-halfof the few bushels he started with is jolted out.

BOAT CAPSIZED AND TWO MEN DROWNED.--Two men named BENNETT and TIFFANY, both fishermen, were drowned on Wednesday afternoon, at Athens, Greene County, It appears that TIFFANY, with a man named HALLENBECK, left the villages in the boat for the fishing grounds of Mr. ROSSMAN, both intoxicated, though they succeeded in getting there safely.

No news from the Court of Appeals nor any promise of the time when there will be any news. If we do not get the decision next week, the probabilities are that we shall have to wait until after the 4th of July, before we can know what is to be the fate of the Metropolitan Police.

Conover to compel the delivery of the Desks, Papers, , of the Street Commissioner's Office,--This case was continued yesterday according to adjournment. The room was densely crowded with as attentive audience. At 11 o'clock to Court was opened, and Mr. Field, counsel for Mr. Conover, proceeded to open, in substance as follows:

There is no ignoring the fact that a large preponderance of public sentiment is in favor of a central route for the California overland mail service, and the Pacific Railroad, of which it is the pioneer, and by which it must someday be superseded.

The rapidity with which all vegetation has advanced this season has been very favorable to the apparance of our City tree. Though in the City Hall Park, and in a few of the finest streets of Brooklyn, there are exceptions, generally they are unusually free from worms. In a more genial season they make their appearance at the same time with the young leaves.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Your report, in stating some of the material facts of the case now pending before the United States Court of Claims at Washington, in relation to my War LORD, ??ronsously says an arbitrary settlement was made of the issue of 10 per cent, supplemental stock. Such a settlement was attempted by the Treasury, which was resisted, when the President in

The largest yacht yet built in this country has been constructed for Mr. JOHN D. JOHNSON, of the New-York Yacht Club. She was built at Setauret, L. I., by JOSEPH HOWLAND, under the superintendance of Capt. THOS. B. HAWKING, of Part Jefferson; she is to be schooner rigged, and the sails will be made by R. H. WILSON, of Port Jefferson, who made the sails of the yacht America.

The returns of Monday's election come in very slowly, but enough are received here to show that the whole affair has proved a most complete fizzle The number of votes polled here was 225. The whole number of votes in this county (which is the most populous in the State, and could poll several thousand votes) does not exceed 500.

The weather, during the past week, has been ??sually cool for midsummer, and a large quantity of rain has fallen at intervals. With the exception of corn, the growing crops are doing well, and the promise of an abundant barvest is good.

TERRIBLE POISONING CASE IN VIRGINIA. --The Petersburg (Va.) Express details a terrible poisoning case in the family of Mr. EDWARD GILL, in Caesterfield County. The family is composed of Mr. and Mrs. GILL, and, up to four weeks ago, six children, as follows: Miss FRANCES, aged about 16 years; AURELIUS, about 13; WILLIAM, about 8; MARY, 6; ELLA, 4; HATTY, an infant.

ARRESTED FOR IMPROPER CONDUCT IN THE STRELTS.--The Police of the Third Ward, by order of Capt. BENNETT, arrested twelve ill behaved young men on Thursday night, for improper and ?? behavior in the public streets.

WESTERN RAILROADS IN TROUBLE.--We learn upon what we believe to be unquestionable authority that legal proceedings are about to be instituted by Robert and John H. Kinzle and others interested against the Illinois Central and Michigan Central Railroad Companies for the recovery of fifteen acres of ground on the bank of Lake Michigan, south of the river, upon which the freight and passenger depots of these companies are built.

We are permitted to make the following extract from a letter received by a merchant of this City, from his correspondent in Norfolk, Va., giving details of a case of remarkable rascality, concerning which the Norfolk papers furnish little information, The writer, a well-informed authority, says:

SEGUINE'S POINT.--The rainy weather has delayed operations somewhat, upon the buildings at Seguine's Point, but it is now expected they will be ready for the reception of patients in the course of two weeks. The Commissioners paid a visit to the place yesterday, and found all things progressing quietly.

The Georgia Democratic State Convention met at Milledgeville on Wednesday, Resolutions were passed in favor of the Cincinnati platform, expressing confidence in Mr. BUCHANAN, and condemning Governor WALKER'S policy in Kansas. The resolution in relation to Governor WALKER reads as follows:

ANNIVERSARY MEETING OF TH ECCLEIAN SOCIETY.--The graduate and under-graduate members of the Eucleisn Society assembled in its rooms in the University Last evening, to listen to addresses from the older members, and talk over old times. PENJAMIM VAUGHAN ABBOTT, Esq., delivered the anniversary address, selecting for his topic, "the moans of attaining eminent success in life."

THE AFFRAY IN PRENTICE'S HAT FACTORY. THOMAS MORRELY., who had his skull fractured Thursday afternoon at PRENTICE'S hat factory, by a blow given by JAMES McDONNELL, was yesterday much better, and there are now strong hopes that he will ultimately recover.

" The Athelings," a novel of English life--literary, fashionable and domestic--which has been running through Blackwood's Magazine for several months, has been variously attributed to Mrs. OLIPHANT, author of "Zaidee" to BULWER, To Miss MULOCK, and to MARY HOWITT.
FUNERAL OF EX-ALDERMAN CORNELL.--There was a very large attendance at st. Mark's Church, yesterday afternoon, at the funeral of Ex Alderman CORNELL.

THE END OF THE UNITTED STATES BANK.--Last week all the old books, papers, drafts, checks, letters, etc., that had been preserved on file as vouchers in the long course of the immense business of the United States Back were sole in a heap in Philadelphia, and Purchased by a paper maker to be reground and Manufactured into new stock. The whole mass weighed over forty tons.

POLICE MATTERS.--The Police Commissioners transacted only private business yesterday and made no new appointments. Four of the Municipal force of the Second Ward, viz : KLINE, ORPHEUS, WINTRINOHA, and TRACY, went over yesterday to the metropolitan Board, and four more from the same Ward are expected to do the same to-day.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: A leading article in your paper of 24th inst., took my attention. The crisis in shipping is likely to prove of growing importance to the public. My at tention has leaned toward this subject for some time past, and I have thought, on reading your article, that I might place a few ideas in juxtaposition, asbriefly as possible, at your service.

The Mormons in the neighborhood of New-York are circulating in the most lively manner. President CANNON has been preaching Mormonism during the past week, in the vicinity of Northfieldand other points in Connecticut.

WITNESSES BEFORE THE NAVAL COURTS OF INQUIRY.--The Secretary of the Navy has written the following letter in relation to the traveling expenses of witnesses summoned to give testimony before the Naval Courts of Inquiry: NAVY DEPARTMENT, June 22, 1857.

What event have been crowded into this man's life when he was born, FREDERICK the Great, now a historical character, was on the throne;

As the time appointed for launching the mammoth steamship Great Eastern approaches, it becomes a matter of interest to know at what American port she sill terminate her first voyage across the Atlantic.

The heroine whom we were so slow to recog nize when she was in the midst of us, is win ning honors now from all the world. When Mrs. PATTEN reached New-York with the hus band whose life she had saved by her care, and the ship which she had preserved by her courage--she was suffered to take her way again to her home in Massachusetts, almostuncheered by the voice of uttered sympathy;

The regular monthly meeting of the Executive Committee of this Association, was held last evening at 8 o'clock, at the residence of JOHN H. GEISCOM, M.D., No. 42 East Twenty-ninth-street, Present, the Chairman, Dr. GEISCOM, and Messrs. ISRAEL RUSSELL, RICHARD REED, R.N. HAVENS, STEPHEN CUTTER, SALEM H. WALES, JOHN H. KEYSER, SOLOMON JENNER, WM. HEGEMAN and JAMES C. HOLDEN.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: SIR: The following abstract from the letter of a gentleman known in the literary sud religious world of London, may not be uninteresting to your readers, and the friends of the Niagara: Did you hear of Our river picnic? It was a most enjoyable day--I Shall never forget it.

A SNAKE REMOVED FROM A WOMAN'S STOMACH--The Legansport (Ind.) ?? states that Dr. A. MEYERS, of that city, who has acquired some celebrity as the inventor of the trap ffor the removal of tape worms, has recently performed a cure that is worthy of more than ordinary mention.

A NICE YOUNG MAN.--A very "nine young man," of gentlemanly manners and pleasing address, who has been figuring in this City the past four weeks, was clutched on Wednesday afternoon by two policemen-KINNER and SMITH, of Chief MAT??ELL's office, and conveyed to prison.

This event took place Thursday morning at St. Peter's Church, Twentieth, Street, near Ninth. avenue. After religious services. conducted by 'Bishops KIPP, of California, and POTTSE, of New-York, the annual address was delivered by Bishop KIPP, in which he warned the young graduates of the difficulties which would surround them in their future religious career.

EMIGRANTS FROM AFRICA.-The most re markable instance we have lately seen of the performance or that not very difficult opera tion, commonly called " whipping the devil round the stump," is afforded by the Charleston Mercurz, in an article on "Emigration fromAfrica."

ANOTHER SPIDER BITE.--A blacksmith in New ton Upper Falls, named STANLEY, while at work a fow days since, felt what he supposed was the bite of a mosquito upon his arm, and being very busy, did not give any attention to it for several minutes, but finally noticed that it was a small spider, its body not being larger than a pin head, which he crushed, andthought nothing of it.

A match between the Second Eleven of St, George's and the Bridgeport School, came off yesterday at Hoboken, and was won by the young gentlemen from Bridgeport, the St. George's taking the first innings.

The period for the annual inundation of Ameri cans into Paris has arrived. Like fair weather birds, they only emigrate in the Spring. Compared to last year, the influx is more than doubled-but last year suffered from the reaction of the Exhibition. Soon these will be scattered over Europe--some sweltering through the scorching sun of Italy, to climb Vesuviusor the dome of St. Peter's;

POISON OF A WHOLE FAMILY AT SLAVES.--The family of EDWARD GILL, of Chesterfield county Va., have for a month past suffered from a mysterious sickness, The Petersburg Express states that about a month ago one of Mr. G.'s little children died, and that subsequently himself, wife and five children were taken sick, and another child died.

A most serious disturbance took place yesterday afternoon on Avenue C, which resulted in the serious injury of several of the Thirteenth Ward Police, and in all probability will result in the death of Captain McKENNEY. At about 4 1/2 o'clock an alarm of fire was sounded in the Sixth District, and immediately Captain McKENNEY, with eight of his men, proceeded to the fire. As they were going up Avenue C they noticed a Hose

The U.S. Mail steamship Philadelphia, A. G. GRAY, Commander, left New-Orleans June 20, for New York via Havana; arrived at Havana on the 23d, and sailed at 6 P.M. of same day for New-York, where she arrived last evening. The Philadelphia landed 20 passengers at Havana, and brings 123 passengers and $16,000 in specie for New-York. There was little of interest occurring in Havana.

DICKENSON--BALOH,--In this City, on Thursday, June 25, at the Bleecker at. Church, by Rev. Wm. S. Batch, Mr. LYNUS P DICKENSON, of Toledo, Ohio, and Miss EMMA E. BALCH, second daughter of the officiating clergyman.

The following in the WEEKLY REPORT OF DEATHS in the City and County of New-York, from the 20th day of June, to the 27th day of June, 1857: Men, 70; Women, 38; boys, 114; girls, 102; total, 324. Adults 108 Children, 216; males, 184; females, 140; colored persons, 8.

About 8 O'clock last evening a terrible catastrophe took place at No. 308 Main Street. An Explosion occurred in a room in a three-story brick building, occupied by Mr. JAMES PRYOR, a scenic artist and manufacturer of properties, and in an instant the whole interior of the house was land in rains.

DESTRUCTIVE FIRE IN PETERSBURG, VA.--The Intelligencer of Saturday says, about 2 o'clock yesterday morning, the the large new brick building in Stanford, known as the "Old Dominion" Mills, was discovered to be on fire, and before the engines could render any assistance was, with its entire contents, consumed. The house was insured for $20,000.

General CASS arrived here yesterday morning, and resumed his duties. He is looking remarkably well. It is rumored that several changes will be made of heads of Bureaus and clerks in the Treasury Department, which has caused a great fluttering and trepidation among the bees in the hive.

THE SPOILS IN THE STREET COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE.--There appears to be some hitch in the distribution of the prizes in the Street Commissioner's office according to the terms of the reported agreement between the Mayorand the Aldermen.

The Canadian screw steamship Indian, with advices from Liverpool of the 17th instant, passed the Writer du Loupe on her passage to Quebec and Mon treal at an early hour on Saturday morning. The steamship City of Baltimore, from Liverpool at 1 o'clock the afternoon of Wednesday, the 17th of June, arrived here at an early hour this morning.
Before Hon, Justice Peabody. In the matter of the Application of Dintel D. C of the street Commissioner's Office-This case continued yesterday.

FIENDISH.-Friday night, at 11 1/2 o'clock, the locomotivo of a freight train on the New-York and Erie Railroad struck a rail lying across the track, three miles from Jersey City, and two cars were thrown off the track. The steamboat express passenger train was coming close behind, but was stopped, and in consequence of the delay did not arrive until about 1 o'clock Saturday morning.

The Mormons do not all live at Salt Lake, as some persons seem to suppose, although one of the chief aims of Mormon missionary enterprise seems to be to "gather the Saints together in Zion,-in the valleys of the mountains, "as they term their settlements in Utah.

The steamer Montreal, one of the regular steamers running between Quebec and Montreal, left this port, at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon, having on board between four and five hundred passengers, of whom a majority were Scotch, and other emigrants recently arrived from Europe. Nothing unusual occurred after leaving the wharf until the Montreal had reached a point (Cape Rouge)about 12 or 15 miles above this city,

Miss ANNIE M. ANDREWS, the young lady whose voluntary services to the sick during the prevalence of the Norfolk pestilence have made her name famous is preparing for the press a volume descriptive of the "Heroes of the Pestilence," which will be published by the HAEPEES early in the Fall.

THE ACCIDENT ON THE ST. LAWRENCE,--We publish this morning a telegraphic account of a most terrible accident that occurred on Friday evening to one of the St, Lawrence steamboats.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--Madame LA GRANGE'S short season of Italian opera commences at this house to-night. The work selected for the occasion is BELLINI'S "Puritani," the principal roles of which will be sustained by Madame LA GRANGE, Signor BRIGNOLI, Signor AMODIO, and Signor COLLETTI.

We find the following paragraph in the San Francisco Herald of the 5th inst., from which it appears that the inhabitants of that part of New Mexico known as the Gadsden Purchase are desirous of having their strip of country set apart as a new Territory, to be called Arizona.
The contingency for which the friends of General WALKER have doubtless been delay ing the grand public demonstration they haveprepared for their hero, has at last arrived.

The U. S. Steam Frigate Wanash, beating the broad pendant of Commodore H. PAULDING, arrived yesterday in 9 1/2 days from Aspinwall to Sandy Hook. This is a good passage for a side-wheel steamer, and a remarkable one fer a frigate whose steam power is auxiliary. She has proved herself to be a very fast ship, going 13 an d 14 knots under canvas, and10 knots under steam alone.

EXTENSIVE FORGERIES.--DAN W. KIND, of Sufeld, Conn., a cigar maker, has been detected is a complicated series of forgeries, amounting to $15,000 to $20,000. Besides forging the names of various persons as makers of notes, he forged indorsements of LUOIUS HATHAWAY, Sheriff S. B. KENDALL.,

The Canadian screw-steamship Indian, with four days later advices from Earpe, arrived at Quebec on Saturday. No news of importance is reported. Parliament was engaged in tile consideration of the Jews' Oath end Disabilities Bill, which, on a best question, was sustained by a vote of 341against 201.

How strangely new the Old World seems to one who has lived always among things fresh and fair. "Of one blood are all nations of every tongue and kindred," and yet how different! These are our thoughts as we wind lazily up the Weser. It is a muddy, sluggish stream, our little beat is more sluggish still, and we are among a people who have never learned the use of being ina burry.
BENEFITS OF TRAVEL.--It is an old saying that there is nothing like travel to take the nonsense out of a man; but travel not only benefits the traveler himself, but those whom he visits.

CAMMEYEE.--In this City, on Saturday, June 27, LEAH wife of the late Cornelias Cammeyer, in the 49th year of her age. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, on Tuesday, the 30th inst., at 4 o'clock P. M., from the residence of her brother, Robert B. Tremper, No. 26 Government St., without further notice.

THE FORTY-FOURTH ASTEROID. -- A circular from the office of the Astronomical journal dated at Cambridge, contains a latter from Mr. HEBMANS GOLDSCHMIDT to the editor, dated Paris, June 3, announcing the discovery, on the night of May 27, of a forty-fourth planet, between Mars and Jupiter. This is the sixth which has been discovered by Mr. GOLDSCHMIDT.

WHAT WILL HE DO WITH IT ?--The title of BULWER LYTTON'S new novel, which stares our citizens in the face from all the brick-piles, board fences, and old rookeries, in the City, seems like a pointed interrogation aimed at our City Inspector, who is making an effort to rec move the filth from our streets, but has nosuitable place to deposit it in.

MECHANICS INSTITUTE.--The Philosophical Club of the Institute met last evening at their rooms, No. 20 Fourth-avenue, Prof. MAPES in the Chair. The subject of the uses, commercial value, and growth of wood was continued. The discussion, last evening, was principally confined to the mannerin which water is taken up by the vessels of the tree, and the mode of drawing carbonic acid from the atmosphere by theagency of the leaves,

The United States mail steamer Illinois, C. S. BOGGS, U. S. N., commanding, left Aspinwall June 19, at 9:20 P. M., and arrived at Quarantine at 8 1/2 o'clock Saturday evening. She brings the California mails of the 5th inst., $1,852,867 in treasure on freight, and 736 passengers.

About noon to-day, as some children on Staten Island were in the woods opposite Stipleton, in quest of strawberries, they discovered the body of a dead man. The upper part of his head had been shot off by a pistol while in his own hand, as was manifest from appearances; the print of the pistol was visible on his shirt-breast, and his fingers borestains of the powder.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--The experiment of a summer season of Italian Opera is a dangerous one in the present depressed condition of all kinds of amusement, but the inauguration, last evening, seem ed to promise success. The house, although not un comfortably full, displayed a fair array of payingraces, and was animated and fashionable.

The steamship Niagara, from Liverpool on the 20th inst., arrived here at 8.20 this evening. Her dates are three days later than those already received. The steamships Columbia and Anglo Saxon arrived out on the 18th inst. There had been a spirited discussion in the House of Commons in regard to the destruction of Greytown.

The Metropolitan Commissioners were very busy yesterday in the discharge of their official du ties. They made thirty-one appointments, and dis missed the subordinate members of the Second Ward force. Thus, all who were members of the De partment when the old law went into power, and who refused to recognize the new Commissioners,have been formally dismissed.

THE ATLANTIC-STREET STABBING HOMICIDE. The Coroner's Jury in this case rendered the follow ing verdict last evening: " That FRANCIS DELAMORE came to his death on the 22d inst, by reason of putrid typhoid fever, the result of mortification of the left forearm, caused by a wound inflicted with a knife in the hands of JAMES DUNN, on the corner of Hicks and Atlantic streets, Brooklyn, on the 13th inst." DUNN is yet at large.

JACOB BARKER'S CASE.-In the report of Mr. BARKER'S case in the Court of Claims, which appeared some days since in our columns, it was intended to present merely the case before the Court, not historical reminiscences generally, al though highly interesting in themselves, of Mr. B.'sfinancial achievement.

It has not often happened that an attempt to bring about a radical reform among any class of men has been commenced under more fa vorable auspices than the proposed change in the system of shipping merchant seamen, which was set on foot by the New-York Chamber ofCommerce.

On Saturday morning, early, our citizens were alarmed with the awful intelligence of the destruction of the Montreal, with a living freight of several hundreds of passengers. We immediately conveyed the sorrowful tidings to the public in an Extra, and, as the day proceeded, furnished such particulars as we could collect from time to time.

SAGACIOUS AND FAITHFUL.--A Norfolk exchange paper states that a gentleman of the city having business at the Navy Yard proceeded thither on horseback, accompanied by a Newfoundland dog-As it is contrary to the regulations of the yard for any but, foot passengers to enter, unless by a special permit, he dismounted at the gate, the dog remaining with the horse.

The following regulations nave been received from the War Department, and are published to the army: 1. When from excessive fatigue or exposure, the commanding officer may deem it necessary, be may direct the issue of whiskey to the enlisted men of his command, not to exceed a gill per man for each day. 2. Tea may be issued in lieu of coffee, at the rate of one and a half pounds per hundred rations.

The Cunard steamship Niagara, with news to the 20th-three days later-arrived at Halifax last night, but her news reaches us too late to ad mit of comment. Shortly after 11 o'clock last night our city was visited by one of the most, violent thunder showers which has occurred hero for some time, accompanied, by continuous flashes of vivid lightning, and for sev eral hours the rain pour d in torrents, deluging the streets in water, and notwithstanding the outlet fur nished by the sewers, submerging in several pieces thewalks, and running into exposed cellars.

FRAUDS IN CONTRACTS.--We do not believe that our City will always be given up to the merciless depredators who have so long de frauded us of our rights, burdened us with taxes, and rendered the very name of a Metropolitan office-holder a byword and a reproach.

COMMON PLEAS.--The argument and appeal calendars for the 1st Monday of July next will not be called until the 1st Tuesday of July. Trial Term Adjourned for the term. Next term in October. SUPREME COURT--Circuit.--Nos. 781, 303, 380, 604, 845, 867, 740, 991,1007, 1009, 1017, 1222, 1025, 1026.

THE ATTACK ON THE THIRTEENTH WARD POLICE--CONDITION of CAPT. McKINNEY.--Capt. McKINNEY, of the Thirteenth Ward Municipal Force, who was so badly injured on Sunday afternoon in Twelfth-street by a mob, is lying very low at his residence in Suffolk street. No visitors were permitted to see him yesterday, and it is feared even yet that he cannot recover. The other officers who were beaten at the same time are doing well.

MEETING OF THE BOARD OF EXCISE COMMISSIONIES.--The Board met yesterday at 3 o' clock. P. M., in the Common Pleas Court Room, Part First. Present, Commissioners JOHN KERE, W,M. JAY HASKETT, AND ROBERT D. HOLMES. The minutes of the list meeting were read and approved. On motion of Mr. HASKETT, J. BLAKENEY AULD was appointed permanent Clerk.

The Free-State settlers of Kansas have been very greatly and very grievously wronged. They have been both injured and insulted. They have been treated as no free-born citi zens of the United States were ever before treated by their fellow-countrymen. Their territory has been invaded; their dearest rights have been denied to them; their mostsacred instincts have been outraged.

ORGANIZATION OF THE DEMOCRATIC REFORM GENERAL COMMITTEE.--The "Union" alias "Reform," alias "Anti-Wood" Democratic General Committee, met and organized last evening at Tammany Hall. There was a full attendance. After the necessary formal business, the Committee proceeded to ballot for permanent officers. Several candidates were named for Chairman.

In the year 1848 all the world was crazed with dreams of a sudden Summer of freedom and glory and greatness. Then France shook off the incubus of lies which for eighteen years had swayed her destinies; then Hungary "stamped her strong foot, and swore she would be free !" then Italy, from the Alps to the African Sea, raised again her ancientcry: "Away with the barbarians!"

Commissioner DENVER, of the Land Office, re ceived a letter the other day which he could not read: So he sent back the following pithy note; " I have to acknowledge the receipt of a letter supposed to be signed by you; and, after reading a portion, guess ing at a portion, and passing by the remainder as unintelligible, have referred it to the Secretary of the Interior."

The Berlin correspondent of the Manchester Guardian, says that accounts have been received from Oopenhagen which threaten to bring the German-Danish question more rapidly to a solution,and for the time being to augment its complication.

OPENING OF NEW LAND OFFICES.--We learn that the necessary measures are being taken by the General Land Office to open at the earliest practicable period the new land offices in Minnesota Territory, one of which is located at Ojibwa, on the Mississippi, and the other at Buchanan, on Lake Superior.

General CASS arrived here to-day, and about noon visited the State Department. He looks remark ably well, and appears to be in very good spirits. He is here in time to counsel and encourage his colleagues in the Administration, and reassure Mr.BUCHANAN in regard to Kansas affairs. They are all much embar rassed by the hostile demonstrations of the South against their Kansas policy, as manifested by Gov.WALKER's addresses.
The election canvass continued very animated but presented no new feature. The Demonstic Party was still divided and likely to continue ??.

Concerning the Street Commissioner. THE BOARD OF ALDERMEN. The Board of Aldermen met last evening, Alderman CLANCY, President, in the Chair. The Report of the Committee non-concurring with the Board of Councilmen in the reorganization of the Croton Water Department, and creating a new bureau, was called up, and after some amendments, was adopted. The Report reorganizing the Law Department was adopted.

The downward tendency in prices noticed in our last advices of 23d inst. continued throughout the past week, and in the more speculative of the railroad shares became at one time a panic. The transactions have been large, and the decline very great. For in. vestment there has been very little doing; as a conse quence, operations in State Stocks have been limitedwith very little alteration in prices.

The 103d Annual Commencement of old Columbia was held yesterday, in Niblo's Theatre. Not-withstanding the somewhat inauspicious state of the weather, a very brilliant audience crowded the house. The lady friends of the students were present in large numbers, to lend their countenance to the occasion. Though the exercises were protracted to nearly five hours, the interest, apparently, was unaated to the end.

OPPOSITION 0F THE SAILORS' LANDORDS TO THE NO-ADVANCE PRINCIPLE.--The keepers of sailor boarding-houses are very naturally alarmed at the recent move of our ship-owners to abolish the system of advance wages to sea men; and they have formed themselves into a secret association to oppose the action of theChamber of Commerce.

An act of the Legislature abolishing days of grace upon all notes and bills payable at sight, or on a specified day after sight, at any place within this State, takes effect, by its terms, on July 1. There is no prior enactment upon the statute books of this State limiting the time within whichnotes and bills are payable.

Some of the descriptions of scenery and of Mormon customs have not before been given. M. GAILLARDET starts out with a sketch of the history of the Mormons,

THE FIRST STATE PRISON.--Few of our readers probably know that there is yet standing within our City the first " State Prison " ever erected in the State of New-York, and one of the first built in the United States. This old State Prison still stands in the Ninth Ward, on the block bounded by Washington, Amos, West and Charles streets, and is now occupiedas a brewery.

No wonder thieving flourishes in this City while there are so many places in which the thief can dispose of his booty; places sometimes large and sometimes small, and many of their proprietors, in fact the largest number, licensed by the City authorities, not, to be sure, as "Receivers of Stolen Goods," but as pawnbrokers, dealers in second-hand goods, keepers of junk shops, and of junk carts and junk boats.

Our dispatches from Washington this morning wil be found interesting, in reference to Central American affairs. In addition to the intelligence contained in them, we learn from private sources that as soon as an interview is had with Mr. JAS. B. BOWLIN, our Minister from Bogota, the Govern ment will immediately decide on the course to bepursued with New Grenada,

From the Charleston Mercury, Saturday. We cannot mention without emotion the death of this distinguished man, which occurred in Colum. bin yesterday morning. Mr. CHEVES was a native of Abberville District, and born in the year 1776. In his early life he filled a large place, not only in the history of our city, but inthe history of the country.

A PRIZE FIGHT PREVENTED.--About two hundred " roughs " assembled yesterday at Jones' Wood, to witness a prize fight between two men, named SWEENEY and LYNCH. They had placed their stakes and stretched their ropes, when Officer CONNELL appeared among them, and desired them to retire, threatening them with the vengeance of the law ifthey failed to comply.

THE DISGUSTED FILLIBUSTERS.-Gen. WALK ER'S whereabouts in the City for the week past has only been known to his intimate associates. Upon leaving the La Farge House, where he held his levee for three or four days after his arrival, he expressed his wish to have his stopping-place kept secret, except to particular persons;

The will of the late GEORGE HAYS, Esq., of Philadelphia, after making some bequests to his nephews and nieces, and $5,000 to the Northern Home for Friendless Children, gives the remainder of his estate for the purpose of founding a home and retreat for disabled, aged and infirm deserving American Mechanics.

There is a story told of an Irish witness, who being asked before trial by the lawyer pro during him, what he was prepared to prove, replied-" Whatever is necessary." It looks as if some such rule were laid down in the con nection of the defence in the Conover and Develin case by the presiding genii of the City Hall.

From the Memphis Bulletin. Yesterday afternoon, about 5 o'clock, the public were shocked and enraged at hearing of the death of one of our best and most worthy citizens, JOHN Ev ERSON, who was shot and instantly killed by JOHN ABEL, a son of JOE ABEL. From all the information we could gather, but little or no cause or provocation was given by the deceased to Justify the horrible deed.

From the Union, of Tuesday. Yesterday, in the Criminal Court, Judge CRAWFORD presiding, the case of Wm. Warnach, James Williams, John Webster, Wm. Wilson, Isaac Stoddard and Wm. Williams, indicted for riot in the Seventh Ward on the 1st day of June, was taken up. Messrs, Bradley, Sr, Carrington, Martin and Smith appeared for the defendants.

CRIME AT SING SING.--Burglary at Sing Sing sounds like carrying coals to Newcastle. Still, cer. tain rascals yet unknown have recently entered and pillaged the houses of several citizens of that village " in the dread waste and middle of the night," with out even so much as the fear of the neighboringprison walls before their eyes.

STEVENS.--In this City, on Tuesday, June 30, WILLIAM APPLETON, son of William and Loouisa W. Stevens, age 1 1 year 1 month and 11 days. CENTRAL PARK COMMISSIONERS.--The Board of Commissioners of the Central Park met as usua yesterday, at their rooms, in the Bank of Commerce Building. The business transacted was not particu larly interesting, consisting merely of reports of Com mittees on unfinished business-and the organization f measures for future action--mostly with regard toobstructions now existing in the Park.

DUTIES OF THE HEALTH WARDENS.--Each Warden is required by the City Inspector to report himself daily at the Bureau of Saitary Inspection between 9 o'clock A. M. and 12 M. and report what has been his action the day previous, and receive such complaints as may have been made at the office,and immediately examine the same.

The Democratic State Convention held here to day was largely attended. ISAAC W. TABOR, of Houlton, presided. M. H. SMITH, of Warren, was nominated for Governor, by 296 out of 585 votes cast. The nomination was then made unanimous. Ex-Senator BRADBURY and other distinguished gentlemen addressed the Convention.

WOMANLY ACCOMPLISHMENTS.--A recent English publication on the science of bread making, states that in the County of Suffolk, England, every woman knows how to make bread; and, in the town of Bury, which has 60,000 inhabitants, there are but two publicbakeries.

SANDY HOOK LIGHT-HOUSE.-In 1762, JOHN CHUGER, PHILIP LIVINGSTON, LEONARD LISPENARD and WILLIAM BAYARD, by direction of the Legisla ture of the Colony of New-York, and as Trustees for the Government, purchased four acres of ground on the point of Sandy Hook, and there erected a lighthouse and out-buildings.

CHAMPAGNE--"THE BEST BRANDS" MADE IN NEW-YORK.--At the present time in this City there are thirteen establishments which manufacture Champagne, or, in other words, convert still wines into sparkling ones; for no process has yet been discovered for producing an artificial wine which possesses the flavor and other qualities of the product of the grape.

PORTRAIT OF NAPOLEON BONAPARTE.--There is now on exhibition at Messrs. WILLIAMS STEVENS, in Broadway, a portrait of the great BONAPARTE, painted in Paris, in 1815, by Mr. R. E. W. EARL, then a young American artist, on a visit to the French Metropolis, who died a few years afterwards at the Hermitage, in the arms of ANDREW JACKSON, his early patron and friend.

* * Senator SUMNER left here this morning for London. The voyage was of service to him, but after his arrival he became much worse and for some weeks seemed likely to suffer a serious relapse. finder the advice of his physicians he started upon a tour through the South of France, and traveled a good deal on horseback among the, Pyrenees,which he found exceedingly beneficial,

JUDICIOUS REGULATION,--Among the many reasons why the Metropolitan Police Commis sioners ought and will win the public confidence, their open and above-board mode of transacting business is not the least. The Coroner's Jury, in the case of the propeller Inkermann, (by the explosion of which, at Toronto, in May, ten persons were killed,) have rendered the following verdict; That said explosion was created by the introduc tion of spirits of wine, oatmeal, and sal ammoniac into the boiler of the said propeller Inkermann, byDOHENY, the Engineer in charge.

A most interesting and important debate has been going on in the House of Commons for the last two hours on the subject of Greytown, pursuant to the motion of Lord CLAUDE HAMILTON, as mentioned here this day week, but which could not be put till tonight. Lord PALMESTON, backed by the Attorney General, declared it to be contrary to international law to demand reparation for proceedings which both characterized as cruel and indefensible ;

From the st. Louis Republican. The immense drug store of BARNARD, ADAMS Co., at the northeast corner of Second-street and Washington-avenue, was destroyed by fire about 9 o'clock yesterday morning. Once started, the fire was fed and increased, until the flames soon over-ran every part of it. We never saw a building of itsenormous size so soon reduced to a heap of ruins.

NEW ARSENAL IN BUFFALO.--The Commissioners appointed by the Legislature to locate new arsenals at different points in the State, have lately been to Buffalo to look after, and formally accept of the land donated by the Common Council of that City for arsenal purposes The ground has a central location, and touches Batavia-street on one of its sides, Its estimated value is $40,000 ;

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: The Revolutionists have not made any further progress since last accounts, VIVANCO and the frigate Apurimac is still south at Islay. it is said he has got there 3,000 troops, but they are not willing to embark.

HOFFMAN.--In this City, on Thursday, July 2, LEIGHTON, youngest son of the late Martin Hoffman, aged 15 years. His funeral will take place at 4 o'clock this (Friday) afternoon, from the Church of the Ascension. The friends of the family are invited a attend, without further notice.

The Decision of the Court of Appeals on the Metropolitan Police bill, sustaining the constitutionality of the law, was delivered yesterday forenoon, by Judge DENIO. The Court, as we announced several days since would probably be the case, stood six in favor of the constitutionality of the law.

There was a tremendous hail-storm at Fredericks burg between 4 and 5 o'clock yesterday, accompanied by terrific thunder. Some of the hailstones were as large as hen's eggs. All the windows on the wind-ward side of the houses were demolished, and all the magnets except one in the telegraph office were burnt. The destruction of trees and crops, it is supposed, is immense.

A train over the Marietta and Cincinnati Rail road, while crossing the trestlework, 12 miles West of Marietta, yesterday morning, one car was thrown cff the track and fell a distance of 53 feet, and was smashed to pieces. Thirty persons were in the car, of whom four were killed and twenty woundedAmong the dead is WM. G. RICHARDSON, of Boston.

CRUEL SWINDLE.--The various ways in which unsuspecting people are swindled in this City is bringing disgrace upon New-York. and especially its Police, because they are often accessories to these outrages. Last Saturday, on going down to Pier No. 1, in an omnibus, a young sewing girl inquired of some gentlemen where she should find the Boston steamer.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: The trouble of servants has reached a height that is unbearable. Whore is the remedy to be Sound? Few employers have, I fear, sufficient nerve to take any stop of importance towards their emancipation from the thraldom which all experience.

Penn., at which place they will be received and entertained by Humane Company No. 1. The New-York Company will muster about thirty men. Their carriage is one of the prettiest in this City.

The gratitude of every inhabitant of the metropolis is due to the Court of Appeals for the prompt and timely rendering of the decision on the Metropolitan Police Bill before the occurrence of our National holiday. There was but too much cause to apprehend a collision between the Mayor's men and the members of the new Police,

DEATH BY AN ACCIDENTAL FALL.--An inquest was held yesterday, at No. 50-Worth-street, by Coro ner PERRY, upon the body of Dr. NATHANIEL GROOME, a colored man, who came to his death by concussion of the brain, from accidentally falling down a flight of stairs at the place above mentioned, where he resided. "Doctor" GBOOME was quite a character, and verywell known in his neighborhood.

EMIGRATION ITEMS.--The travel of emigrants over the Pennsylvania Railroad, for the six months ending yesterday, has been unusually large, amounting, in the aggregate, to 10,506, having with them 352,529 pounds of extra baggage. Of the number, 7,765 went to the northwestern States and Territories--most of them with substantial means, and a few with considerable wealth.

BRIGGS, of the Commercial Restaurant. A reso lution, offered by Alderman HARDENBURGH, requiring that applicants shall conform to the State law inobtaining licenses, was lost.

BURNING THE DEAD.--The Paris Academy of Medicine has set the papers to writing and the people to thinking earnestly of the return to the practice of burning the dead. They say that in the Summer time the Parisian hospitals are crowded with the vic tims of pestilence engendered by the foul air of thegraveyards in the neighborhood.

The final and credited announcement that the genrt of Appeals had decided in favor of the Constitutionality of the Metropolitan Police Law, created great excitement and dismay among the remaining members of the Municipal force yesterday morning. YOUNG, of Westport, and Elder J. A. BOUTON, his counselor, Two first-rate men, and servants of God. Under the presidency of Brother YOUNG, the Church has flourished;

The speech of Senator DOUGLAS, at Indianapolis, has brought out a reply from Hon, A. LINOOLM, of Indiana, which was delivered in the House of Representatives at Indianapolis, on the 90th inst. Mr. LINCOLN spoke follows: FELLOW-CITIZENS: I am here to night, partly by the invitation of some of you, and partly by my own inclination.

BROOKLYN SCHOOL MATTERS.-The various departments of Public School No, 7, on York-street, under the direction of their Principals, Mrs. MURPHY, Miss PORTER and Mr. BUCK, had a good time yester day with their friends. The Primaries, with their teachers, gave a special reception and review, and were dismissed early, aftersome very pleasant singing and other exercises.

Thomas L. Price, Esq.: DEAR SIR: I wished to have seen you again before I left St. Louis, but was compelled to depart before your return from the East. I am so absorbed in my work that I can call no time my own. My publishers have an immense capital invested in the abridgment, and I cannot, in justice to them as well as myself, permit any part of their force to be idle.

WHAT WE HAVE TO BE THANKFUL FOR. If there is any truth in the old adage that misery loves company--and we are inclined to believe that, like most old saws, there is a good deal of truth in it-it must be some consolation to us, always aggrieved New-Yorkers, to know that the citizens of Liverpool and London have their permanent subjects of complaint as well as ourselves.

The Summer is a dull season for new books; publishers withhold their choice works for the Spring and Fall; but there is still a large number of new publications which find their way to our table, and there are a few of them which are en titled to a much longer notice than we can possiblybestow upon them here.

SUYDAM. -- In this City, on Friday morning, July 3, MAY, youngest daughter of Samuel A. and Elizabeth Suydam aged 3 years and 2 months. The relatives and friends of the family, the Phoenix Chapter of Royal Arch Masons, and members of Howard Engine Company, No. .31, are respectfully invited to attend her funeral, from the residence of her parents, No, 48 Mortou., Without further invitation, on Sunday afternoon, at 2 o' clock.

DISTRESSING CALAMITY--FOUR YOUNG LADIES DROWNED!--About 5 o'clock Friday evening, a party, consisting of three young gentlemen and four ladies, were taking a sail upon the large pond situated in the easterly part of Webster, Mass., when one of the gentlemen loss his hat; the course of the boat was altered for the purpose of picking it up, but without changing the position of the sail;

A SHOCKING MURDER.--A correspondent of the ?? and Dispatch says that a terrible murder was committed within three miles of Gordonsville, in Louisa County, on Saturday last. A ?? named HALL, with his family, had moved to the place of the murder three days before its committal, and hired a negro girl aged 15, from Mrs. MARIA THOMPSON, of Louisa. .

A NEW SWINDLING GAME.--Three Dutch peddlers leased the store, and bought the stock of: goods, belonging to S. S. OTIS, at Ulsterville, Ulster County, and took possession a fortnight since. Two of them immediately left for this City, to procure a new stock of goods, and on Friday night the third took leave, wishing, as he stated, to pay a visit to agentleman residing a mile or two from the place.

GREAT DRUM. - Amongst other appliances which have been sought to augment the musical effects at the approaching Handel Festival is a monster drum. The tone is full and resounding, and more resembles that of a bourdon organ-pipe, both in quality and continuance, than that generally obtained from an instruments of percussion.

BELL-JARVIS--In this City, on Thursday, July 2, at St Thomas's Church, by Rev. Bishop Kip, of California, MOLYNEUX BELL to Miss ANN F. JARVIS all of this City.

NEW-YORK LAWS ONE HUNDRED AND EIGHTY YEARS AGO.--About the year 1674, the laws of the Colony of New-York were first collected, and a copy of them made at that time, may still be found in the archives of this State. They were generally known as "The Duke's Laws," having been promulgated while the Duke of York enjoyed the Sovereignty of the colony.

To the Editor of the Note-York Daily Times: About twenty-five years ago one of the Soverign states of this Union asserted its independence of Congress in the construction of general laws. It claimed the right to a separate judgement upon the question of the constitutionality of a law. In pursuance of its opinion, and to give it effect, is proceeded to organize an armed opposition to the exertion of the resisted law.

G. C. VERPLANOK, Esq., President of the Commissioners of Emigration. Sin: The rapid change apparently going on in the class of vessels used in the business of transporting passengers subject to be landed at this depot, renders it proper that your special attention should be directed toward it, especially as the change in progress is decidedly in favor of foreign bottoms.

BURTONS'S THEATRE.--The deservedly popular spectacle of the "Naiad Queen" was produced here last night for the holiday folk. The costumes are good, the scenery in Mr. HEILGE'S peculiar style, the dances plentiful, and the music abundant, but badly played by the orchestra.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: The TIMES of the 29th ult., commenting on the late fearful calamity of the burning of the Montreal, says: "The frequency of such wholesale massacres in Canada, during some few years past, must deter American travelers from visiting a country which, in other respects, offers many inducements to our Summer tourists."

Messrs. Editors of the Times--Sir: Having seen the opinions of several of WALKER'S returned soldiers published in this morning's Herald, I desire to give my opinions, and seven months' experience in that country, to the citizens of New-York through your columns--should you deem them worthy of notice.

Mayor WOOD issued a general order, yesterday, to his Captains to dismiss their forces from further duty, in consequence of the decision by the Court of Appeals. The order was read to the men during the forenoon. They were greatly astonished, but Surrendered their badges in quiet and left for theirhomes.

CRICKET AT ALBANY.-A Inatch between the Poughkeepaie and Amsterdam Clubs was commenced yesterday, on the Albany ground-the Poughkeepsi ans taking the first innings, making the unenviable Score of 21 runs. The Amsterdam gentlemen then took the bat, making the decent score of 37 runawith six wickets to go down.

The umbrella and India-rubber dealers must the making immense fortunes this season. All who have been unfortunate enough to invest money in say other king of goods have made a losing specification. New-York is as fine a watering place as one could desire. The hydropathists are in aestacies, for every body is forced into the water treatment, nolens volens.

Some farmers have last as many as six and eight horses, and others there and four, and so on.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: The present rate of increase of population in England is such, that it doubles itself each half century. Now, aa many have died in England in the last half century through unnecessary wars, and more have left its shores through a necessary emigration, we may assume that this increase is below the normal rate of the increase of the AngloSaxon race.

STEAMSHIP ADRIATIC.-The Adriatic is now under the control of Mr. COLLINS, who has taken solo charge, fast approaching completion, and it is expected she will be ready to depart for Liverpool by the middle of September. 'Those portions of her engine which were experimental, and could not be made to work, have been removed, and are being re placed by such improvements as have stood the testof practical experience.

From the Philadelphia Evening Bulletin, Friday. The packet-ship Tuscarora, with 537 steerage passengers, reached her birth at Walnut-street wharf, this morning. All the passengers, with but a single exception--an Irish woman--were Mormons. We visited the ship this morning soon after her arrival, and found the deck swarming with the new recruits for BRIGHAM YOUNG'S COLONY at Salt Lake.

DOUBLE QUARANTINE.--Complaints are very common among the ship-owners that after their ves sels have been compelled to perform Quarantine; and have received the Health Officer's permit to proceed, if found necessary to store the cargo in Brooklyn, they are obliged to obtain another permit from the Brook lyn Board of Health to discharge the cargo, and thatfor every such permit they are charged one dollar.

We have three days' later news from Europe, by the arrival of the new steamer Lebanon, bringing us files of the Paris papers up to the 23d of June. The elections had closed in France. The laboring classes in Paris had exhibited much interest in the election, which was understood to have boon favor able to the Government candidates. The resultshad not been definitely ascertained.

The Fourth of July was celebrated on Saturday very much in the usual fashion. Despite the rain the glorification commenced early on Friday evening, and from that time till after midnight on Sunday the air was resonant with the bang, pop, whiz, crack and crash of all sorts of explosive material in the hands of the patriotic. The day itself could scarcely have been pleasanter.

It was expecting too much to imagine that the prowling ruffians who infest this City should not avail themselves of the disorganized condition of our Police force to create a disturbance on the Fourth. It requires the utmost care and diligence, even at the best of times, to keep the ruffianly partof our population in order;

Hon. WILLAM L. MARCY was found in his room to-day at noon, quite dead. He appeared to be in his usual good health this morning. We have not heard any cause assigned for his sudden death. The U. S. Mail Steamship Columbia, Capt. BARRY, from Liverpool about eleven o'clock on the morning of Wednesday, the 24th of June, arrived here last night, The screw-steamer Glasgow, from New York, arrived at Glasgow on the 20th of June. The steamship Arabia arrived at Liverpool at 8 o'clock, morning of Saturday, the 21st June--having been detained off the bar eight hours for want of water.

Yesterday the steamer Peter Tellon landed at Jefferson Barracks throe companies, band, and a detachment of Company A, Fifth Infantry, in command of Brevet Colonel C. A WAITE, with the following commissioned officers: Brevet Colonel WM. CHAPMAN, Captain R. B. MAROY.

THE FOURTH IN THE CITY.-With the ex ception of the disgraceful riot among the " Dead Rabbits" and the " Bowery Boys," on Saturday, the anniversary of our National holiday was celebrated with more spirit and good feeling than usual in this City. No un usual preparations had been made to keep upthe old spirit of the day,

THE WHEAT CHOP--APPEARANCE OF THE WEEWIL.--We regret to learn from a gentleman of Caleconia, Livingston Co., that the wheat midge, or weevil, as it is commonly talled, has made its appearance up the valley, and it is very probable that it may be found in our own immediate vicinity if locked for Our informant states that the first he saw of the ?? was on Thursday evening last.

Our city was visited last night by another terrible and destructive conflagration, one which alarmed the whole community. Since the organization of the steam fire department, such things have been so rare in our city that the people were led to hope we were fully provided against a serious damage by fire: but the conflagration last night presented sufficient proof that no force, however powerful, can be entirely railed upon.

A brief telegraphic announcement conveys to us the intelligence of the sudden death of one of the most eminent statesmen of New York, WILLIAM L. MARCY was found dead in his room, in Ballston, on the morning of the Fourth, to which he had retired apparently in the enjoyment of his usual health.

MEETING OF THE FRIENDS OF NICARAGUA.- A meeting of the Officers of the Nicaraguan Army, and those who have taken an interest in the cause, was held at SHERWOOD'S Saloon, corner of Broadway and Worth street, for the purpose of devising what means should be taken in order to relieve the sufferings of those who have returned to this City,

The Bombay and Calcutta papers, received by late mails, contain accounts of a mutiny which, breaking out in the 19th regiment of native infantry in Bengal, was spreading like an epidemic through the native cantonments of the British Army in Northern India. The mutiny began in February at Barrackpore-a large military village and a seat of the Governor General, rear Calcutta.

Hon. WILLIAM L. MARCY, late Secretary of -State, was found dead in his room on Saturday, the 4th. The cause of his death is not yet deter mined, and he appeared to be in his usual good health in the morning. It is expected that his funeral will take place at Albany, on Wednesday,on which occasion there will be a military display.

When the sun set on the Fourth of July, the people were saying, "What a stupid, quiet, noiseless Fourth it had been." There being no telegraph containg at the Metropolitan head-quarters, and no newspapper published after the early morning editions, the City as in a most marvelous ignorance of the fact that rioting had commenced as early as 1 o'clock of the morning in the Sixth Ward,

The death of Governor MARCY appears to have been occasioned by heart disease. The Albany Atlas of yesterday states that he visited Albany on Friday, and was then apparently in excellent health and buoyant spirits. It was only within a short time of his death that he became conscious of a palpitation of the heart, and the symptoms of that disorder had not been such as to occasion alarmto himself or his friends.

From the Charleston Southern Presbyterian. While our sympathies lie in general with the aggrieved and "exscinded" party, we are not sure but a full share of responsibility rests upon them. It is not so clear no our minds that there has been any unconstitutional act of "usurped power" on the part of the majority--though we fully admit that it affixed a stigma upon the South and its institutions which was uncalled for and intolerable.

To the Editor of the New - York Daily Times: In reply to the suggestions of " H. A. W.," in your money article of July G, I wish to state that the Legislature did mean to do just what the law accomplishes, and nothing more. They did not contemplate altering any well-settled usage of the commercial community, and therefore did not meddle with grace on promissory notes, or drafts on individuals drawn on time.

The experiments made this year of wheat-grow ing in middle Texas have succeeded well. Black prairie land being deemed the best, producing up wards of twenty bushels to the acre, of heavy wheat. Strange as it may appear, we may and can have in this region, sugar cane and wheat, cotton and tobac co, corn and oats, oranges and apples, all growingupon the same plantation. And shortly, the camel.
