The Fourth was celebrated here with unusual demonstrations. The weather was fine, and business was entirely suspended. The public buildings and many private residences were handsomely decorated. The procession was very large and made a fine dis play, the principal feature of which was the steam fire department. In the evening there was a granddisplay of firewmorks.

Lord NAPIEIR had a speciall interview this morn ing with the Secretary of State in relation to the dis patch received by this Government from Lord CLA RENDON, disclaiming any intention of acquiring ter ritory on or near this Continent. Affairs in Centre America were also discussed. The Consular appointments will be made this week.

BOGUS MONEY DEALERS CAUGHT.--On Friday evening last Mr. HUDSON, one of the conductors of the Hudson River Railroad, while his train was stopping at Peekskill, observed two men standing near the station house, whom he recognized as having a few days previous, given him a counterfeit five on the Marine Bank of Buffalo, in payment of fare. UNKNOWN MAN FOUND DROWNED.--An unknown man, about 25 or 35 years of age, was found on Sunday in the river at the foot of Twenty first-street. It was not recognized, and appeared to have been in the water about, four days. Deceased was about 5 feet 6 inches in height, long black whiskers. blue overalls and white pants. Coroner GAMBLE held an inquest upon the body yesterday. Verdict--Drowning. g.

Kansas dates to the 3d instant are received. A Democratic Convention met at Lecompton on the 2d instant. Judge ELMORE presided. COW PENS AND COWS' MILK.--The resolution adopted one week ago in the Brooklyn Common Council, authorizing the erection of cow-stables recently destroyed by fire in the Seventh Ward, was last evening reconsidered and referred to the Health Committee for report next Monday evening.

We have very little time for making up our correspondence, so completely overwhelmed with company have we been since our arrival in England. There is no cessation of visitors, and as the duties of the ship must, under all circumstances, be attended to, we have hardly time even for sleep. Our Captain is indefatigable, and few younger men would go through what he has gone through, and come out of it as fresh.

There is certainly a moral of some sort to be deduced from all great disturbances, riots and emeutes.. Hardly one occurs in any part of the world which does not convey a lesson to some body. Very few people are supplied with as many lessons of the sort as we are. We have riots and disturbances of all sorts, grievous anddisgraceful enough in their way.

He prides himself upon his compositions it is very clear, and he has al ready issued enough to make a very considerable volume.

The steamship Artel arrived at the sameport on the evening of the 26th, and the Washington at an earlyhour on the following morning.

Since last evening a letter has been received by the Committee of Arrangements from EX-Presidents FILLMORE, explaining as the reason for his absence from the funeral that he is suffering from inflammation of the eyes. Ex-Presidents VAN BURRN and PIEROE, and Hon WM. H. SEWARD, have telegraphed their acceptance of the invitations sent them, and will be here to-night.

" Mushroom " cities are only indigenous in Amer. ica, and are not, by apy means, the least curiosity the country affords. TO the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: SIR: Anglo-Saxonism has become such a very frequent topic in the newspapers, that men be gin to inquire what does it mean? The subject is new even in England, where the common people pride in the name of Briton and would not know what you meant if you called them Anglo-Saxons The French conquerors, erroneously called Normans,repudiate the term Saxon.

The American bark Panchita turned up yester day, with a fresh, but not very enviable history, hav ing arrived at this port from the Congo River, Africa, in charge of two English officers and twelve men be longing to the British sloop-of-war Sappho, by whose commanding officer, FAIRFAX MOROSLE, she was seized on the 10th of May upon the charge of beingengaged, or about to engage in the Slave-trade.

Capt. PERRY of the brig Abby and Elizabeth, from Port au Prince yesterday morning, reports :-On morning of the 12th of June, about 12:30 A. M., a des tructive fire broke out at Port au Prince in an apothecary's store, which destroyed about 100 houses and stores (in the business part of the city) and property to the amount of $1,000,000, Spanish. Three persons were burned to death.

The existing mail arrangement between Philadelphia and the West, and other points, to which the North American recently directed public attention, thereby enlisting the action of the Board of Trade, have now assumed a shape that promises a satisfactory solution of these vexatious embarrassments, and a correction of the evils that were so justly complained of.

A NEW REMEDY FOR A SERIOUS DISEASE.--Dr WALTER CHANNING, in a late number of the Boston Medical and Surgical Journal, has a paper on medical spiritualism. A medical medium whose exhibitions he attended had in consultation three distinguished doctors, called from the spirit sphere.

The Board of Commissioners of the Central Park met at their rooms on Tuesday at 3 o'clock, Present, Commissioners COOLEY, IIOGG FIELDS, ELLIOTT AND BUTTERWORTH. The minutes of the last meeting were read and approved.

Since the 1st of July, when the new arrangement among ship-owners and agents respecting advance wages to seamen was to go into effect, no crews have been shipped on vessels bound to Liverpool or other ports contemplated by the reformers.

COMMISSIONERS OF EMIGRATION.--The Commissioners met two hours before the usual time on Wednesday. A resolution was adopted in reference to the death of the late Hon. W. L. MARCY, moved by the President and carried unanimously, recognizing the services and kind feeling of the deceased towards the Commission.

The obsequies in honor of Hon. WILLIAM LARNED MARCY, at Albany, yesterday, were grand and imposing. The procession took one hour in passing a given point, and was, altogether, the largest ever witnessed in the city.

VAN BRUNT.--In this City, on Tuesday evening, July 7, at the residence of her son-in-law. J. Carhart, Mrs BEISKY VAN BRUNT, aged 68 years. Her remains were taken to Troy, N.Y., for interment. COBNELL-In this City, on Monday, July 6, KYCER C. COBNELL, at No 319 3d st., aged 41 years. The remains were interred in the Cemetery of the Evergreens.

The resolution which was offered in the Board of Aldermen on Monday night, author izing the Mayor to send a Special Ambassador to London, at an outlay of $2,500, to induce the agent of the Great Eastern to send that naval monster to this port, was last night passed, and will doubtless be concurred in by theBoard of Councilmen.

Just before the Sappho raised anchor on the coast of Africa (Lieutenant ODRVAINE states) a vessel, suspected of being a Slaver, was seized by the British cruiser Promtetheus. The captured vessel carried Spanish colors, but she was unmistakably an American vessel, as her build and her crew plainly showed. The name of the seized vessel was The Adams Grey.

About 11 o'clock last night a riot took place in Thirteenth-street, between a party of rowdies belong ing to the Eleventh Ward, known as "The Blues,' and a party from the Seventeenth Ward, known as"The Forty Thieves."

We have witnessed with unfeigned regret the spirit in which nearly the whole Southern press has received and treated the inaugural address of Gov. WALKER, of Kansas. From the Know Nothing op position press we had little else to expect, but it is rather more serious to see that the Democratic presses are by no means unanimous in the view they take ofhi conduct.

The centennial anniversary of the " decisive battle" of Plassy, which first gave England a hold upon India, was celebrated last month by laying the foundation of a monument to the great CLIVE in his native town, and by leading articles in all the British journals, exulting over the greatness and permanency of the British Empire in India, and the complete subjugation of the whole Mogul Empireto British rule.

MARES reports having off the Western Islands, experienced a severe gale, which dismasted the ship, and sprung the rudder-head, and considerably damaged the bell ;

ACADEMY OF Music.--The revival of "Son nambula" last night was a great success. The house was excellent, and the performance extremely spir ited--which is saying a great deal for "Sonambu la," defective as it is almost sure to be in soma respect.

QUARANTINED.--The following vessels were yesterday sent from the upper to the lower Quarantine for anchorage: Brig St. Michael, from St. Domingo City; she lost a man coming home. Brig Peruvian, from Trinidad, which lost two mates in port, and two men on the passage.

The Board met on Tuesday afternoon at the Court Room of the Common Pleas: Present, Messrs. K??, HASKETT AND HOLMES. The following licenses were granted to storekeepers: Samuel Knapp Bros., No. 46 Harrison-street, $30. Coles, Hodges Weeks, No. 36 Broadway, $30.

There is a large audience gathered in Albany to-day, to pay tribute and give fitting burial to the last remains of WILLIAM LEARNED MARCY--a more numerous and apparently sincere array of mourners than I have ever before met, save when the body of HENRY CLAY was on its last pilgrimage to Ashland.

[FROM OUR SPECIAL CORRESPONDENT.] PRAIRIE DU CHIEN, Wis., Wednesday, July 1, 1857. My last notes upon the crops were forwarded from Urbana, Ill. From that points to Chicago there is a very fair show of core, oats, and particularly of grass. I saw but very little wheat.

FREE ACADEMY EXAMINATIONS.--The regular examination of the pupils of the Free Academy has closed with a higher average grade in scholarship than in any former year. There were several slow coaches who will be obliged to drag their old loads a little longer, but Dr. WEBERTER sends fewer notices of such sloths to parents this year than usual.

To believe too little is as bad as to believe too much. Your skeptic, who suspects a snare in every civility, and surmises villainy in every smiling virtue, generally manages his mundane affairs quite as lamely as your sentimentalist who is forever expanding to a breath of sympathy, and forever ready to exchange green-cotton umbrellas, and swear eternal friendship upon a hint of congeniality.

JULY 8.-George Conway, captain of the ship Switzerland, was arrested on a charge of having committed a rape on Jane Haggard, an English girl, about twenty years of age, on the 15th of April last, during the voyage of that vessel from Liverpool to this port. The complainant states that the Captain induced her into his stateroom, and that he there committed the offence complained of.

About the middle of June the members of the Police were paid up to the 23d of May. The number of persons paid at that time was 1,100, embracing every man on the rolls of the old Police, and including all who had indicated their adherence to the new Police Commissioners, as the names of all these persons where on the rolls returned to the Comptroller's office.

The history of SOLOMON NORTHRUP--a free citizen of New-York, who spent many years in Southern Slavery--is fresh in the memory of our readers. We yesterday heard narrated another slave history rivalling it in interest, though in many respects of a very different character.

A sad affair occurred in Hoboken, N. J., on Wednesday night which has caused a good deal of excitement in that locality. At 11 o'clock Wednesday night as Mr. OSCAR DE GRAND-VAL was leaving the house No. 15 Washington-terrace, where he had been spend. ing the evening, he was attacked by a young Caban named FREDERICO CUEVA, who struck him several times with a cane.

The Federal Treasury year begins, by regulation of law, on the 1st of July and ends on tile 30th June. Tile great Foreign Trade Account for the year 1857, conforming to this regulation, has just terminated.

We find the following paragraphs in the Tampa Peninsular of the 20th ultimo: Company II, 4th Artillery, now stationed at Fort Cross, Capt Sable, is ordered to take post at Fort Dulany, Punta Rassa. Company C, 4th Artillery, arrived at Fort Brooke from Kissimmee on the 16th instant, and left on the 18th on the steamer Ranger for Fort Myers.

In reference to the report of the massacre of Col. SUMMER'S party by the Indians, the Washington Union of yesterday contains the following: "No intelligence confirmatory of the above has been received at the War Department, and no confidence is placed in the report. It is hardly possible that so large a body of United States troops could be taken by surprise and completely annihilated, especially troops well acquainted with the Indian made of fighting."

SIR: The Editor of the New-York Tribune seems lately to have taken the English language under his especial protection. How well qyalified he is to assume the office of Protector, may be learned from an elaborate editorial on the uses and abuses of English Grammar, in his issue of Wednesday last.

In your issue of this morning, the decision of the Postmaster-General in favor of the Southern Pacific Route, via El Paso and Fort Yuma, for the overland California mail, is elaborately attacked, and some statements made which are so entirely erroneous as to require an instant correction.

The intervening spirit of sectionalism is the same, whether its proscriptiveness has the North or the South for the theatre of its mischievous and circumscribed action. Sectionalism affects to recognize the Principle of popular sovereignty. But the recognition is generally followed by something more dangerous and offensive than opposition to all who attempt to reduce the principle to practice.

CASE OF THE PANCHITA.-The proceedings in relation to the Bark Panchita, published elsewhere in our columns to-day, possess an interest beyond the mere matter of damages. The owners of the vessel have not only sued the British officer who brought her into our port, but have also, through their counsel, called upon the Government to demand indemnity from Great Britain for the loss they have sustained by seizure of the bark.

A BROKER COWHIDKD IN WALL-STREET--GARRET T. TERRUNE, a Broker, doing business at No. 7 Broad-street, was cowhided in Wail, near Broad-street, yesterday forenoon by a man who charged him with insulting one of his (the cowhider's) lady acquaintances. TERHENE, after being severely "punished" about the face, retreated into a restaurant.

Two More Victims-One Special 'Policeman. Two other hawe fallen victims to the late riots. One, THOMAS SPARKS, a special policeman, died on Thursday evening, at his residence, No. 109 East Sixteenth-street, from a blow on the head with a club. The other, -- MYERS, also a resident of one of-the upper Wards, died, yesterday, from gunshot wounds, received in Bayard-street during the first affray be. tween the Bowery Boys and "Dead Rabbite."

CENTRAL PARK COMMISSIONERS.--The Board of Commissioners of the Central Park met at their rooms yesterday at 3 o'clock. Present--Commissioners Cooley, Hutehins, Fields, Strong, Hogg, Gray and Green. Minutes of July 7 where read and approved.

The total receipts of flour and grain for the week equal about 615,000 bushels, while the shipments fall below 420,000, showing a gain to the stock of over 196.000 bushels on the week's movement. This gain is distributed as follows: Flour gains 3,00O barrels, Wheat 59,000 bushels, Corn 96,000, Oa's, 24,000. FLOUR--Flour has exhibited no important change during the week.

The case of AUGUSTE PAROT, arrested in this City several months ago on a charge of having been concerned in the celebrated French Railway Frauds is in the main famuliar to the readers of the NEW-YORK DAILY TIMEFS. It has been a strange case conducted before the Courts, and the recent proceedings are as unique as any that have gone before.

POLITICAL SERVILITY AT THE SOUTH.--Independence of opinion is about as dangerous a commodity for a man to keep about him down South, as it is in Naples or Paris. The tyranny of the Slaveocracy is not a whit more tolerant than that of the Spanish Inquisition two hundred years ago.

Conover to obtain possession of the books, papers, , of the Street Commissioner's office.--By some misapprehension Mr. Brady mistock the hear at which the Court would assemble, thinking that it was at 12 instead of 11 o'clock. GENERAL JACKSON'S GOLD BOX.--The joint Committee on the award of General JACKSON'S gold box, sat in the City Hall on Friday--Alderman MONAGHAN in the Chair. A communication signed by upwards of eighty names, comprising all the officers of the First Regiment of New York Volunteer, was read, in which it was strong'y urged that the box aught to be given to Colonel WARD B. BURNETT, and warmly eulogizing his services.

Ship Owners must either pay better wages, so that riggers and longshoremen will be in luced to go to sea, or they must carry boys. In two or thres years the supply of men will then be in excess of the demand, and the whole system will then be unlar their control. Many ships now go to sea without a boy on board.

Having sojourned for a few weeks along the "big. muddy," as the Missouri River is appropriately called, a few observations may be acceptable from its distant borders. now the scene of so many extensive city and towa enterprises and speculations.

Our special Kansas correspondent, in a letter dated Lecompton, June 30, states that Governor WALKER had just returned from Paoli, where he had been to attend the land sales. The Governor, the Secretary, and Governor BIGLER, of Pennsylvania, made speeches at Paoli to the people with the most satisfactory result.

The session of the Police Commissioners yesterday was a very short one. A large number of applicants were examined, and the following appointments were made: G.J. Warren (Late Police Magistrate) to be detailed as Properly Clerk. Edward Genet and Wm. H. Allen, patrolmen. Andrew W. Sutherland, doorkeeper.

Since the selection of the site for the Peabody Insitute, architects of all the principal cities have been engaged in preparing designs, and it is not improbable that the strueture will be one of the finest in the country.

MORE REBELLION.-We have another instructive instance of the influence of the bad example set by Mayor WOOD in disregarding the constitutional authorities of the State, in the refusal, yesterday, of Mr. DEVELIN, the usurping Street Commissioner, to obey an order of Judge PEABODY.

TERRIBLE STHAMBOAT DISASTER IN WISCONSIN.--Yesterday afternoon the steamers Pearl and Berlin City left this place at the same time, the former for New-London, the latter for Berlin. In going up the liver tegether, they, of course, raced, and when about a mile this side of Butte de Morts, the Pearl being about ten rods ahead, the boilers of the City exploded with terrific force, tearing her all to pieces.

SLOW.--The Quarantine Commissioners still talk over the steam tug by which the Health Officer is to board vessels on their arrival from sea, but they don't get the tug yet, and probably won't. Tugs enough are to be had, but to be tied by Quarantine laws, as they would have to be, is so annoying that an exorbitant demand is asked for the purpose.

From the St. Louis Republican. A Steamer from Omaha reports the arrival there of sixt Mormons who made their escpe from Salt Lake city about the 20th of April. They report that many person were disssatisfied with their position there, and would ahandon the place so soon as to presence of United States troops gave them an opportunity.

The funeral will take place at No. 32 West 20th-st this aterncon, at 31/2 o'clock. the friends of the family are invited to attend, without further invitation. MEECRUTT--In this City, on Thursday, July 9, P.F. MESCRUTT, Sen, in the 68th year of his age.

There are all sorts of ways of celebrating festivals, and all sorts of people celebrate them, but we think the State officials of Indiana have chosen the oddest, way and the oddest people to celebrate the glorious Fourth of July that inigenuity has yet it upon.

REAPOINTMENT OF OLD POLICEMEN.-The Metropolitan Board of Commissioners have vet to make known their intention in reference to the policy which they intend to pursue touching the appointment of members of the old police. But we can hardly believe that they will embarrass themselves by deciding that no reappointments can be legally made.

An interesting case came up yesterday for examination before Recorder SMITH, at his private office, wherein two Constables, WM. THOMPSON and HENRY WENT, are charged with taking more fees than are allowed by the law. The complianant in the case is a Mr. EULIUS G. SALHENGER, who keeps a clothing and tailoring establishment at No. 386 Grand-Street.

Deputy Sheriff H. STERN yesterday morning, at 10 o'clock, proceeded ot the Astor House, where Licut. ODXVAINE and Surgeon IRELAND are staying, for the purpose of arresting them upon the warrant issued an Thursday by Judge INGRAHAM, for the alleged wrongful seizure of the Bark Pancnita on the coast of Africa. The parties were in their rooms.

The Houston Telegraph, of the 1st inst., says: We are experiencing warm weather these days, but weather which will tell on the crops. The recent rains have extended some distance into the interior. The rain of Sunday night reached Austin and Washington counties, and perhaps extended further.

The St. Joseph Journal of 2d instart centains the following: "Captain DIKON came down on the United States steamer Hink, yesterday morning, and reported the loss of many of our soldiers, in a conlict with a very large body of the Cheyennes and Atrapanoes, two hundred miles west of Fort Kearney.

Frankfort is at the same time one of the oldest and most modern of the cities of Europe; a part of it the most unseemly and another part the most beautiful. "It has become commercial and plebeian," says the'aristocratic English traveler, "and bears no comparison with a hundred others in all that' is grand in architecture and noble in art.

In the early part of the month of June, facts were put in our possession tending to prove almost beyond a doubt that a minister of a Cunberland Presbyterian Church, of Allehency City, was gail'y of having seduced a young girl from Missouri, who had been placed under his care by a parent to educate. We therefore published the bare fact, leaving out all names, however.

The Utiea Herald of yesterday contains an accoutn of one of the boldest robberies recently recorded. It was perpetrated at Saquoit, sik miles from LONG, some time since drew $3,000 from one of the banks, on his wife's check.

Upon FERNANDO WOOD must rest a large share of responsibility for the scenes of riot and blood which disgraced our City a few days since. Months ago he usurped powers belonging exclusively to the Judiciary, set up his judgment against that of the Legislature, decided the new Police Law to be unconstitutional, and resisted its execution by force.

Extensive improvements are making at Bellevue Hospital. An additional story is adding to the main building and to each of the wings. When completed the central building will be four stories high, with a capacious basement. The wings will be each three stories high, not including the basement.

From the Springfield Republican The record of crime, within the past few months, has contained an unusual vaerity of attempted or successful family poleonings, and the number of these cases is evidently on the increase. The last instance has just been developed at Randolph, a town in Norfolk County, about ten miles south of Quincy.

FATAL ENCOUNTER IN KENTUCKY. -- A correspondent writing from Summersville, Green Co., Ky., under date of the 6th inst., furnishes us an account of a difficulty which occurred near that place, which resulted in the death of FELIX G. BEAUCHAMP. Our correspondent says that a difficulty occurred between ROBERT J. PEACE and WM. M. SKAGGS, about some trifling matter, when BEAUCHAMP, who was the brother in-law of SKAGGS, interposed and begged the parties to desist.

The Commissioners of the Metropolitan Police have clearly got over the worst of their work, and we presume will be fully able to oppose in a week hence a complete and well-organized body of men to the machinations of WOOD, and the thieves, swindlers, burglars, and blackguards of all hues, by whose aid he is systematically endeavoring to destroy the peace of the City.

In the maner of the application of Daniel D. Conover to obtain possession of the books and papers of the Street Commissioner's Office.--This matter came up this morning on an order to show cause why the certiorari, granted by Judge DAVIES on Friday, should not be vacated. Although the order was returnable at 10 o'clock, as usual there was some delay, and the proceedings did not commence until after 11 o'clock.

THE DEATH OF YOUNG STOWE.--The Manchester American has the particulars of the death of young STOWE, son of Professor and HARRIET BEECHER STOWE, by drowning, at Hanover, N. H., on the 9th inst. He went into the water with several of his classmates, to bathe. and after being in a few minutes became exhausted and cried out for help.

WILKINSON.--In this City, on Saturday morning, July 11. suddenly, of pneumonia, BYRON WILKINSON, in the 50th year of his age. The friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, from his late residence. No. 38 3d at., on Monday, July 13, at 31/2 o'clock P.M. JERVIS.--In this City, on Sunday, July 13, of consumption. Mrs. MLIZA JERVIS, in the 35th year of her age.

MELTING WEATHER.-Yesterday was an oilfashioned July day; if it was not the commencement of a heated term, it was a heated term in itself. The corn, the grapes, the wheat, the apples, the melons, the peaches, and everything else that has been suffering from an insufficiency of heat must have made up for lost time the past two days, and taken such a start that they will not be much behind time In ripening.

Order of reference vicated, and new trial ordered. Costs to abide the event. The Canadian Screw Steamship Company's steamer Anglo-Saxon passed this point at about 11/2 o'clock this morning, en route to Quebec, where she will be due at about 11 o'clock. Her dates from Liverpool are to Wednesday, July 1. The Anglo-Saxon left Liverpool at 11/2 o'clock in the afternoon. The City of Washington, for New-York, left at about the same hour.

The following is the WEEKLY REPORT OF DEATHS in the City and County of New-York, from the 4th day of July, to the 11th day of July, 1857: - Men, 74 women, 67; boys, 161; girls, 122; total, 424. Adults 141; children, 283; males, 235; females, 189; colored persons, 9.

The long-threatened, much-talked-of, and finallyscouted rumor of a contemplated attack upon the new Quarantine station at Sequine's Point by the disaffected property-bolder and indignant oyster-vender of that region has finally come off, and all further doubt--if doubts exist-as to the intentions of the insurgents may now be dismissed;

A NORTHERN MAGAZINE.-We alluded last week to a new literary enterprise which is about to be commenced in Boston. The Boston Journal gives some further particulars in relation to it. The Journal says: "Such an effort, resolutely formed and strongly based, is now soon to be developed by the wealthy and enterprising publishing house of PHILLIPS, SAMP. SON Co., of this city.

TERRIBLE ACCIDENT IN CHICAGO.--The Chicago Times of the 7th has the following: On Saturday evening, during the fire in Clark-street, the wife of Mr. N. G. SMITH, residing in the West Division, was instantly killed in the most shocking and awful manner. Mr. SMITH was standing at a window in his shop, on the third floor of DAISION'S building, corner of Lake and Clark streets looking out at the fire.

To those who entertain the idea that our present City Government is one of the most corrupt, inefficient and rascally that any municipality was ever afflicted with, it may be some consolation to know that the great great grandfathers of the present generation were afflicted with just such another unbearable state of affairs, though, seeing that Mayor WOOD was then unborn, it may seem altogether incrcdible that such should have been the case.

In one respect Germany, or part of it, is the Aslest country we have yet seen. The cars and steamers certainly do not go at such a break-neck pace as they do in America, but by some mysterious management they deliver letters with a promptness and regularity we never deemed possible, coming as we do from a land where the delivery of letters is the exception and not the rule.

The Steamship Star of the West, With news from California to June 20, and bringing later advices from South and Central America, the West Coast of Mexico, the Sandwich Islands, Oregon, arrived about 1 o'clock this morning. The news From California is generally unimportant, the principal excitement being political, incident upon the changes--progressing and prospective--going on in the Federal offices. The Star of the West brings $1,521,676. A great stagnation is reported in the markets.

THE ASSAULT ON MR. TERHUNE.--We published on Saturday an account of a cowhiding affair in Wall street, one of the parties being a broker, the name of the other was not given. We are assured that the statement was only true so far as this, that Mr. TERHUNE, on Friday afternoon, while passing through the street was struck with a loaded cane by a man whom he did not know.

STABBING AFFRAYS--An athletic Irishwoman named MARY QUINN was yesterday brought before Justice CONNOLLY for stabbing ELIZABETH BENSON in the arms and breast with a knife. She did it in a grocery store in Water-street on Saturday afternoon in self-defence, she says, as she was first attacked by BENSON and another woman.

AMERICAN INSTITUTE OF ARCHITECTS.-Under this title an association has been formed by our most prominent architects for the purpose of promoting the scientific and practical perfection of its members, and elevating the standing of the profession. For this purpose they will have regular meetings for the discussion of subjects of professional importance;

The Administration is triumohant over Secession and Nullifcation. Governor WISE supports the Kansas policy of Governor WALKER, and the opposition is now confined to Georgia, Mississippi and the Tenressee stronghold of Know-Nothingism. Instructions are to be forthwith sent to our Minister in Mexico for the negotiation of a new Treaty, which will include the grant to us of a perpetual right of way over the Tehuantepec Is-hmus. X Y. Z.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--To-night an opportunity will be afforded to hear Madame LAGRANGE in the role of Luorezia Bergio, it being the last night of the remarkably successful season. It is to be hoped that the success of Madame, LAGRANGE will inducing to undertake another season.

The Vintage has already established itself firmly among our National industries. The Wine Crop has taken its due place among the long list of crops-the Cotton crop, the Wheat crop, the Negro crop, the Hay crop, the Tobacco crop, the Hog crop, and all the rest of them - which go to make fat the ribs and plethoric the purse of Uncle Samuel.

As cotton is an indigenous plant in India, three cannot be any doubt that, under certain circumstances, that country is capable of producing it in any quantity which may be demanded. The East India Company has been attempting, for more than sixty years, to extend and improve the cultivation of cotton in its territories.

The Board met at the usual hour, President CLANCY in the Chair. The minutes of the last meeting were read and approved. Alderman BANTA, of the Ninth Ward, presented the bill of Dr. Carter for medical attendance at the Ninth Ward Station-house. It was referred to the Committec on Police.

Captain WALLING and Mr. JOSEPH QUICK, Jr., one of the policemen, came up from Seguine's Point on Monday. Captain WALLING, on Saturday, went over to Keyport for provisions, and upon his return, about dusk, be observed two rockets sent up-one from Eeltown, and the other from near the Great Kills.

The Empire City, Captain JNo. McGOWAN, left New-Orleans on the 5th inst. and Havana on the 9th At Havana there is nothing specially new. The Spanish fleet is reported preparing for sea, " destination unknown." There is very little yellow fever prevalent for the season, and not of an epidemic type. The prices of sugar and molasses remain unchanged since last advices.

THE FLATBUSH-AVENUE AFFRAY. -Coroner REDDING with a jury continued the investigation yesterday at the City Hall, Brooklyn, as to the causes attending the death of FRANCIS MEHADY, who died from knife-wounds inflicted at the Mount Prospect House, Flatbush-avenue. Nearly all of the testimony thus far goes to show that BERNARD BUTLER, the party accused used the knife in self-defence, and he will undoubtedly be discharged by the Coroner's Jury.

WALKER'S WOUNDED AT BELLEVUE.-When the steam-flgate Wabash arrived at this port with that portion of WALKER's army which had been detained as prisoners-of war by the Nicaraguin Gov. ernment, previous to the treaty of May 1, by which they were liberated, those of the wounded and infirm among them who were not cared for by their friends were sent to Bellevue Hospital.

All day yesterday the City was filled with rumors of serious rioting in the seventeenth Ward The out break of Sunday night was only quieted for a time. Instead of getting about their business, the German population, with which this portion of the city is crowded to overflowing, gathered in knobs all day, and discussed what they described as outrages of the Police.

One of these patents was issued to one Deniston Nov. 20, 1845. He afterwards sold one-third to one Remson,

In Goshen, Orange County, an uncle and nephew, both named SHAW residing near Howell's Depot,bad a bitter feud. About a year ago the uncle gave the nephew a severe "lamming." At the first favorable opportunity the nephew squared up the acCOUNT in the same coin. Both applied to the courts for redress, and a Board of Arbitrater was appointed, consisting of Judge M'KISSOOK, G. W. TUTIIILL and WM. MURRY.

AN NEXPECTED DISCHARGE.--At Norfolk, Va, on the afternoon of the 2d of July, an old can non which had not been cleaned out since the Revolutionary war, was primed, and the match applied, when to the surprise of all present., an unexpectedly smart explosion took place from the mouth of the piece, something whizzed across the street, and there was a crashing of the wood in the door of the United Fire Engine House opposite.

OFFAL AGREEMENT.-- An arrangement has been effected with the Jersey City Common Council Committee on Health, by ANTHONY SAUER , for the removal of dead horses and other dead animals, blood, offal bones and other refuse matter and other nuisances from the City, without cost to him and without expense to the city.

By the Arago, arrived at this port last night, we have the details of the news received by telegraph from the Anqlo.Saxon, and published in tile TIMES of Monday. There is a full account of the serious mutiny in India, and of tile fatal accident on the North Kent Railway, by which eleven lives were lost, and some thirty or forty persons injured.

The bark Wm. G. Lewis was arrested as a slaver yesterday when outside of the buoy at Sandy Hook. She has been watched for three or four days by two of Marshal RYNDERS' deputies. Yesterday she gave them the slip, but Deputy O'KEEFE was in a small boat when the bark went past him in tow of the steam-tug H. Lawrence.

DEATHS FROM DROWNING.--A young man named Moses MILLIEETE was drowned yesterday by accidentally falling off the canal boat H. H. Richards, at Pier No. 7, East River. Deceased was employed on the canal boat. He was 19 years of age, and a native of the United States. An inquest was held upon the body by Coroner GAMBLE. Verdict--" Accidental drowning.'

The United States Mail steamer Arago arrived last evening, bringing news to July 1, the same as received by telegraph from the Anglo Saxon and published in the TIMES of Yesterday morning. We repeat the important news in detail. The Emperor of Russia arrived at Hamburg on the 27th, and left for Hanover on the 28th. King OSCAR has left Stockholm to benefit by ??bathing at Serve.

Doubtless the great majority of readers turn away from the strife about the Street Commissionership, exclaiming with Stephen Blackpool, in DICKENS' Hard Times-it's all a muddle: for certainly there is progressing between DEVELIN and CONOVER, as pretty a game of legal chess as the law journals ever reported, and one which may result in a stale-mate under operation of the next election.

A SOUTHERNER SWINDLED BY THE PATENT SAFE. -On Saturday, Mr. BUSH, a South Carolinian, of telt stature and swarthy hue, just arrived in town, stood on the Astor House steps, observant of the bustle and business of Broadway. While thus engaged, he was accosted by a respectably dressed man, who inquired if Mr. B. was a Southerner. The answer was in the affirmative.

We have been passing through the age of gold, which ought, according to the natural order of things, to have followed and not preceded the era of silver. But the day of the pale face among the precious metals is about to dawn. Our El Dorado has become an old affair, and now we are about to receive an Argentine sister into our Republic.

The intelligence which we publish this morn ing in a letter from India, and which is confirmed by other sources, indicates a state of affairs in that country which probably finds no parallel in the whole history of the British Empire in the East.

The residence of Rev. P. S. CHAUNCEY, No. 12 West Thirty-second-street, was entered early yesterday morning, and $300 worth of silver ware was packed up ready to be carried off: but fortunately Officers QUIDEE and GREASON, of the Twenty-first Ward Police, observed the burglar in the act of climbing over the fence, and arrested him with the property in his possession.

I am writing this on board the steamer Alma, which left Calcutta on Monday, the 18th inst., bound to Suez with the mails and passengers for England. We are now steaming down the Coromandel Coast, against a heavy head sea, and are within one hundred miles of Madras, where I shall leave he ship to prosecute of short journey into the Neilgherries.

A gentleman who resides in Franklin-avenue, Brooklyn--JOHN T. HILDERTH, Esq,--furnishes the following account of a visit to the cow stables that the Brooklyn Common Council allow to be perpetuated and rebuilt. In their enlightened judgements, they are no nuisances.

The Louisville Price Current says: "The accounts of the approaching crops of Tobacco are very favorable. Nearly all the plants have been removed from the seed beds, and are growing finely in the fields. Planters have taken the advantage of the frequent rains we have had lately, and neglected other matters to give an early start to their Tobacco.

About 1 o'clock on Sunday morning last, a fight came off between the- firemen of Poughkeepsie, ending with serious results. It appears that at a late fire in that city a fight took place between two firemen, one being badly beaten. The fight on Sunday is said to have originated from this affray.

INTERESTING TO PHYSICIANS.--The Supreme Court of the Eight Judicial District have rendered a decision in an action brought by Dr. JOHN D. HILL against the Erie County Medical Society, to compel it to restore him to the enjoyment of his privileges as a member of the society, from which he had been expelled because of an alleged infraction of the tariff of prices adopted by the society.

SALE OF FERRY LEASES.--At 1 P. M. yesterday, at the City Hall, leases for ten years were offered for sale at public auction of Hunter's Point Ferry and Horne's Hook Ferry. Not over a dozen persons were present, including the Comptroller, one of his clerks, and the auctioneer-three indispensable parties to supervise and conduct the sale.

This term, in the dairy districts, is applied to the killing of calves soon after birth. There is no ready market for veal at remunerative prices, and the calf is knocked in the head at the age of three days. The milk of the cow for four or five weeks is worth more for butter and cheese than it would be to fatten the calf for the butcher.

GENERAL JACKSON'S GOLD Box.--The Aldermanic Committee, whose duty it is to report on the proper person to be the recipient of General JACKSON'S gold box, had another meeting yesterday, and heard the testimony of two gallant soldiers of the New-York regiment in the Mexican war in favor of their own claims.

THE NEWBURG MURDER--ANOTHER IDENTIFICATION.--The Bellows Falls (Vt.) Times of July 8 says that the mysterious murder at Newburg, N.Y., which caused so much excitement throughout the country--the body having been identified twice, and as many times proved to be entirely wrong--seems to be assuming its third phase, in a manner which will interest people in that vicinity.

It is unquestionably true, that the early settlers of any country have to contend with disease and sickness in various forms.

The Paris correspondent of the Globe telegraphs the following TUBIN, THURSDAY. The steamer Cagliari, bound from Genoa for Tunis was seized by a band of armed Italian insurgents, who landed on the Island of Ponsea, and liberated some prisoners. The Sapril, Neapolitan frigate, captured the steamer, and the troops were pursuing the insurgents.

A dispatch from Gen. WALKER, who is in NewOrleans, was received here to-day, requesting his officers to report immediately, and to hold themselves in readiness to recruit, in anticipation of a speedy departure for Nicaragua.

To Me Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Our Police system justly attracts the attention of the whole community. A good City Police, efficient for all lawful purposes, yet not dangerous, in turn, has proved a problem of difficult solution everywhere, but is especially such in our City, where the question is, how to give the Police peculiar efficiency, while the highest possible degree of individual liberty is enjoyed by every inhabitant.

The Annual Commencement of the Harvard College, to-day, attracted a large audience, and the customary exercises were quite equal to those of former exhibitions. The National Lancers performed escort duty. Among the distinguished gentlemen present was Lord NAPIER, the British Minister.

Hostilities had already commenced between the Leonista and Charnorista parties.

THE TRIAL TRIP OF THE GREAT EASTERN.-It is announced that the Great Eastern, though she may be launched in September, will not be prepared to make her first trial trip before next April, so that there will be no necessity of sending an ambassador by our Common Council, to prevail upon the owners to send her to this port, yet awhile.

SINGULAR CAUSE OF FIRE--- On Saturday last, SAMUEL M. Dockum, at his furniture manufacturing room in Daniel-Street, emptied a hair mattress from the sack, and rolling up the ticking--about ten yards in a compact form, placed it on top of an old secretary which had been sent in for repairs. The later article was laid against the side of his workbench, slightly elevated above it.

We publish in another part of this morning's paper, a remarkable letter from Fort Scott, Kansas Territory. Our correspondent describes a visit to the plantation of a gentleman who owns and keeps within the Territory. over one hundred slaves. The patriarchal establishment of this slave-owner is, in all respects, a model one, and the very interesting narrative given by our correspondent, exhibits "Squatter, Sovereignty" in quite a new light.

She will proceed to the navy yard for stores, and then go on a cruise. The United States ship Plymouth, Commander DAHLGREN, went to sea from Norfolk on Monday.

[An abstract of Mr. EVERETT'S address will be found on the second page.] The First Congregational Church, where the public exercises took place, was crowded in every part.

SEAMEN'S ADVANCE WAGES--BOSTON BACKS DOWN.--An intelligent correspondent of one of our principal shipping houses writes from Boston under date of the 15th, and says: "The no advance system, so far as Boston is concerned, is a dead failure."

Availing myself of a few days' sojourn at the National Capital, I have been at some pains to ascertain the precise position, here of several foreign questions in which the United States have direct or contingent interest. Among these there is none, probably, which attracts more attention just now than that connected with the future of the Nicaragua Transit.

The deceased, PATRICK METOALF, was a watchman in the lumber yard of GILLESPIE, WHITE Co, which occupies a large portion of the southern end of the island. From the Plattsmouth (Nebraska) Jeffersonian. A train, consisting of about one hundred persons with twenty wagons, passed through this place on Friday last, on their return from Utah to the states. They formed part of a company of two hundred persons and forty teams; but some distance black the remainder took the road for Leavenworth. They left Salt Lake about the 20th of April, and were onthe road a little over two months.

It may now be considered that the right of way for the trade and commerce of the United States over the Tehuantepcec Isthmus, and the speedy con struction of the road, are secured beyond peradven ture. The final arrangements by the Governmentwere concluded, yesterday, for this purpose.

FUNERAL OF THE SON OF PROFESSOR STOWE.--The funeral of Professor STOWE'S son, who was drowned in the Connecticut River, at Dartmouth College, on Thursday last, was attended at the Theological Seminary, Andever, on Saturday. The exercises were conducted by Rev. H. W. BEECHEE, of Brooklyn. After a by?? sung by the Lockhart Society, prayer was offered by Rev. CHAS. BEECHEE.

CHANGE OF GRAND LARCENY.--DORATHA JUNG, a German woman, was, yesterday, arrested by Officer DICKSON, of the Sixth Ward Police, charged with having, at various times, stolen about $300 worth of jewelry from the store of Mrs. C. LINHEER, No. 577 Broadway, in whose family she lived as a domestic. She is also charged with having robbed MADAM DEITCH, of Leroy-place,

The Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute of this city was founded in the year 1825 by the late STEPHEN VAN RENSSELAER. It is in every respect, save name, a college-a college of engineers; its graduates go forth to the world prepared to build railroads, canals, water-wheels, work mines, remove bars from riversin short, as complete engineers and architects.

We published yesterday the oration of Hon. EDWARD EVRBETT delivered before the Alumni of Hon. Edward on Thursday, and now give from the Boston Traveller the continuation of the day's proceedings. The festival tables in Harvard Hall were arranged not as at the last Triennial Festival of the Alumni, but with the President's table directly opposite the door.

Thursday was a great day at Stony Point. The citizens of Rockland County and the adjacent country, assembled in great force to witness the lay ing of the corner-stone of a monument to be erected to the memory of the heroic WAYNE and his com rades, who, on the memorable 15th of July, 1779, stormed the fortress that at that time crowned theheight, and killed or took prisoner the entire British

THE ENSLAVED PRISONER OF WAR.--AC TION BY LORD NAPIER.-We gave publicity a few days ago to the strange and interesting narrative of DIMMOCK CHARLTON, a native African, who claims to have been taken prisoner of war from on board the British brig Peacock, when she was sunk by the American schooner Hornet in the war of 1812, and to have been sold and kept in Slavery inGeorgia ever since.

A young man went out hunting for deer in the woods near Lanmark, C. W., recently, and, as an experiment, he clothed himself in a deer-skin, and took a stand where those animals were known to pass quite often. While thus intent upon securing some game, another hunter came near making game of him: for, happening to see what he supposed a fine deer through the thicket, the new-comer took deliberate aim at itand fred.

SIMEON DRAPER yesterday resigned to Gov. KING his position as head of the Metropolitan Police. The news created very general surprise. There had been no previous indication of such a step, and under the existing circumstances-the public mind unusually excited, and thieves and vagabonds and pre. judiced men openly defying the Police-such a step on the part of the President of the Board was looked upon with alarm.

KETTLEMAN.--In his City, on Friday, July 17, of consumption, Mrs. PHEBE, wife of John Kettleman, Esq., aged 28 years and 9 months. The relatives and friends of he family are invited to attend her funeral, from her late residence, No. 285 West 19th-st., between the 9th and 10th avs., on Sunday, the 19th inst., at 2 o'clock P. M., without further notice. Her remains will be taken to Greenwood Cemetery.

FEER ACADEMY--EXAMINATIONS FOR ADMISSION. Some two hundred or more of the new admissions from the Grammar Schools, met Dr. WEBSTER and the Faculty in the large hall of the above Institution, day morning, at 9 o'clock. The principal improved the opportunity by giving not only the pupils, but the parents also who werepresent, some sound advice.

LOWELL, NOT LOVELL.-As Mr. JOHN LOWELL is well-known as the editor of the Boston Law Reporter, we presume that every reader would at once discover that he was the lawyer to whom we alluded as one of the reputed authors of the analysis of the Dred Scott decisions, and not Mr. " Lovell," which we were made to say bya typographical error.

The excitement of the people of Cedar, caused by the nest of horse thieves in this county, is now beyond all bounds; 500 men can be called together in two hours notice. Three men have now been executed by the posse, and if CLUTE is taken he will make the fourth. The posse have now rid the country of the whole gang. JOHNSON,

LORD NAPIER'S SPEECH AT CAMBIRIDGE.- Judging from the reports of the proceedings at the triennial meeting of the Alumni of Harvard sign, College, on Thursday, and from the names of plied the many distinguished persons who took part ing to in the festivities of the occasion, it must have been one of the most brilliant college festivalsthat has ever been held in this country.

RESIGNATION OF COMMISSIONER DRAPER.- The difficulties and perplexities of the Metro politan Police Commissioners have been still further increased by the resignation of Mr. DRAPER, the President of the Board. But the embarrassments of the Commissioners are of secondary consideration; the prime object to be considered is the effect of the resignation onthe present excited mind of the public.

WAEREN, of the United states Topographical Engineers, and upon inquiry ascertain that he is engaged in the prosecution of an important survey, in which not only the citizens of this region feel a deep interest. but one which alike touches those of the (Great West; and the more especially atthis time,

Important advices from Kansas reach us by telegraph from St. Louis, given on the authority of the St. Louis Democrat. It is stated that Governor WALKER has issued a proclamation, which ap pears to be specially aimed at the people of Lawrence, declaring his determination to put down all opposition to the Territorial laws by force, and warning the Free-State men not to organize, underthe Topeka Charter.

The negro, JOHN D'ORSAY, was executed yes terday morning, within the limits of the City Prison for the murder of ANN McGIVEN, alias Anne Hopkins, a woman of the town, in Worth-street, a few months since. The execution was witnessed by a few, and was conducted in good order.

Two things have happened here this week which may be regarded as formally opening the po litical campaign. The Democratic State Committee met on the 14th, and agreed upon the call of a State Convention, to assemble in Boston on the 16th ofSeptember. On the 15th was published a call to the

BROOKLYN WATER-WORKS.--The Commissioners of the Brooklyn Water-Works made a visit of inspection to the aqueduct and reservoir yesterday, in company with some of the members of the Brooklyn City Government, and a few other invited guests, among whom was ALFRED CARSON, the engineer of the Croton Aqueduct.

Information has reached here of the movements on ?? by a few individuals in your City to sell out the regular organization of the Democratic party to FERNANDO WOOD, for a price agreed upon. The leading parties to this arrangement are, 1st STEPHEN P. RUSSELL, who halls from Lancaster, pa., and has squatted long enough in New-York to obtain (through his claimed relationship with Mr. BUCHANAN) an election as delegate to the Reform Committee.

Yesterday was a model Sunday in all the Wards of the City, except the Seventeenth, in which the riotous disposition was not altogether quelled, though there was no actual outbreak. The observance of the law, enforcing the closing of liquor-saloons on Sunday, was pretty general, the violations being principally on the part of keepers of lager-bier cellars of the lower class.

The steamship Vanderbilt, from Havre and Southampton on the 8th inst., and the Atlantic from Liverpool on the same day, arrived at this port yesterday.The news from Europe, brought by these vessels, is four days later.

The U. S. M. steamship Black Warror sailed from New-Orleans on the 12th, Havana on the 15th, and arrived at this port early yesterday afternoon. From Havana, we learn that a Spanish sailor was reported to have been killed in a row with the crew of the American bark Albertina, on the night of the 11th.

LUDWIG GUMPEL, a German, was shot on Saturday afternoon by his partner, WILLIAM GEHRIGH, in their lager bier saloon, No. 25 William. street, and is believed to be fatally wounded. It appears that they had a quarrel, during which they agreed to divide the furniture and separate.

BY the Texas at New-Orleans we receive papers from the City of Mexico to the 3d and from Vera Cruz to the 7th inst. The absorbing question of the day, says the Trait d' Union, is the pending difficulty with Spain. Innu. merable rumors were in circulation, but the only thing positively known was that negotiations between the Spanish Government and the Mexican Envoy had been suspended. The temporary Hospitals at Seguine's Point are a failure. We doubt very much if the shanties over echo to the groans of dying yellow-fever patients. The accommodations certainly are not yet such a dying men need, nor such as to insure a rapid or pleasant recovery to convalescents.

Gov. WALKER'S proclamation to the people of Lawrence is received here. Its issue grew out of the fact that a Committee, acting in behalf of the citizens of Lawrence, had framed for submission to the popular vote a City Charter differing essentially from that granted by the Territorial Legislature, thereby bidding defiance to the Territorial Government.

About the middle of the afternoon report was made that the Dead Rabbits were coming up to Mackerelville in the Seventeenth Ward, to have a fight with the Forty Thieves and the Atlantic Blues; at firet it was considered but another attempt to get up a sham fight, with a view to craw the Metropolitaus into the contest, and then to join forces and give them battle.

The brig D. D. Evans, Capt. WARREN, of Brewster, Me., arrived on Wednesday, from Nuevitas. On Saturday Capt. WARREN made complaint against his cook and steward, a colored man, named ANDREW SUNG, for an assault upon him with a carving knife, in some port whore the vessel touched.

A BOAT CAPSIZED--THREE LIVES LOST.--Yesterday morning three persons--Miss G. F. STONE, Mr. F. CONWAY and C. W. DICKENSON--left the foot of Ninetieth-street in a sail-boat for Harlem, where they intended to spend the day.

It is good economy in the State to treat the public creditor with consideration as well as justice, and according to some uniform system of settling accounts. The United States might have saved hundreds of millions, if at an early day a judicial bureau, or court, had been instituted, to take the place of the practice, so imperfct and corrupting in its influences, of direct Congressional action on claims against Government.

The Interest of Politicians on Saturday came back from the Police matter to the Street Commissionership. In the morning Judge DAVIES rendered his opinion in the motion to quash the certiorari previously granted by himself.

The position assumed by President BUCHANAN in relation to Nicaragu n affairs appears to be very clearly stated in our Washington correspondence published a day or two since. Every discreet thinker must be gratified by the assurance that our Government will not depart from its policy of non-interference in the personal fight between the several claimants of the Transit grant.

ITALIAN OPERA.-TO-night Mme. LA GRANGE takes her farewell benefit , and bids adieu to her American friends. It is said that she will return to Europe at an early day, but this rumor we Ianoy is unfounded. Recently she has received very flatteriag proposals from Havana.

The big R. W. Packer, Capt. MAYO, has arrived from Port-an-Prince, bringing dates to the 1st inst. Captain MAYO reports that the sickness was increasing and business very dull. COFFEE and LOGWOOD were very scarce.

At 81/2 o'clock, last evening, the chaims of the bridge in the Barclay-street Ferry slip, at Hoboken, gave way, and the bridge sunk so rapidly that several persons were precipitated overboard, and many others were wet considerably.

Leaving Iowa, where my last was dated, I visited Western Illinois, and passed over the entire length of the Chicago and Burlington Railroad, from Quincy on the Mississippi River, to Chicago, a distance of 268 miles For the first 100 miles, from Quincy to Galesburg, there is nothing special to be noted.

We gave in our paper, some days since, a report of proceedings and of an examination had before Recorder SMITH, in the case of Constables THOMPSON and WEST, 'arrested on a charge of gross official misconduct in connection with an execution placed in their hands from one of the City District Courts, against a Mr. SALENGER.

The impression is incorrect, which has lately been inculcated by a portion of the press, that no Democrats are to be appointed on the new Police. On the contrary, every Democratic application for the place of Policeman, has, thus far, been favorably received, and, when examined, favorably reported on.

The steamship Vanderbilt, D. L. WILCOX, Esq., commanding, from Havre and Southampton at 8 P.M. on the 8 ult., with 120 passengers, $200,000 in specie and 1,000 tons merchandise, arrived at her dock at 11 o'clock yesterday morning.

The acts of the Legislature of 1857, came to us in two large volumes, accompanied by a declaration in these word., "I hereby certify that the following volume of the Laws of this State was printed under my direction. J. T. HEADLEY, Secretary of S:ate."

SUPREME COURT-SPECIAL TERM. Before Hon. Justice Davies. DECISIONS. THE PAULDING CASE. Saturday morning Mr. Young renewed his motion for permitting the referee to take further testinmony in this proceeding at Tarrytown, where a large number of the witnesses reside.

ARREST FOR ARSON.--PATRICK NALLY, an Irish laborer, was arrested on Saturday, charged with wilfully firing the dwelling house No. 269 West Sixteenth-street, from which, as a non-paying tenant, he had been ejected. The fire was discovered at 12 o'clock Friday night, and after it had been extinguished, straw, shavings, , were found stuffed between the weather-board and lath and plaster of the house.

The vine-growers appear to have successfully encountered the oldtum with sulphur in the few places where the disease has appeared, and great hopes are entertained of the fortheoming vintage. The price of wine is well kept up at Bercy, notwithstanding the favorable accounts from the wine producing departments.

The news is confirmed that the President has received a dispatch from Governor WALKER, of Kansas, that he had issued a proclamation commanding peace and had sent a large military force to Lawrence to quell disturbances.

The resignation of President DRAPER had not been officially made known to the Commissionern up to a late hour last evening, and doubts as to the correctness of the report were expressed by them, not with standing the publication of his letter of resignation.

As sure as Brooklyn people go on board the Tenth-street Ferry when the wind is south or westerly, nine-tenths of them set to talking over the Board of Health and its purity. There is something in the air that suggests the topic. If it does not issue from the much talked of establishment at the foot of Division-avenne, it must come from Mr. CORNELL's dead-horse depot close by-the wharf of embarkation for Barren Island.

We publish elsewhere an account of the proceedings of the Minnesota Constitutional Convention since its organization. The quarrel between the Democratic and Republican members ended in the secession of the former, and the latter are now in session alone. Our account is received from slips of- the St. Paul Times, sent on in advance of Publication, for which courtesy we are indebted to the editor of that enterprising paper.

ROBBERY OF GOLD--ARREST ON SUSPICION.-- ADAM YOUNG, A German, was arrested on Sunday night, on suspicion of having robbed the trunk of Mr. T. Ling, stopping at No. 232 William-street, of $2,950 in gold coin. Mr. LING is a stranger in the City, and on Friday evening fell in with YOUNG and two other men, who induced him to go to a gambling-house, where they soon won $400 of him.

Fifty years ago, the Court of Directors of the Honorable East India Company sent out dispatches to their agents, urging them to enforce the laws against "adventurers." There might have been wisdom in such dispatches at that time; but new they would be considered as the embodiment of foolishness.

GERMAN PICNIC--MONUMENT TO BARON STEVEN.--The Central German Committee, of which WM. E. BARDER, Esq., is President, held a grand picnic on yesterday afternoon at Canard's Garden, York-ville, for the purpose of raising funds to erect a monument to General Baron F. N. STRUNEN, OF Revolution. any memory. The amount proposed to be raised is $2,000, which one-half has already been collected.

Yesterday afternoon at 4 o'clock the Grand Jury of this county brought in true bills of indictment against JOHN G. BRESLIN and WILLIAM H. GIBSON, late Treasurers of State, for embezzlement. At the Street Commissioner's office there was not any trouble of account yesterday. Deputy TURNER was present before 9 o'clock, but left soon afterwards at the request of Mr. CONOVER. A number of Police were there on duty in plain clothes, and remained on duty all night. There were a great many people about the office during the day,--many of them called in, expecting that there would be trouble.

THE CHIEF ENGINEER AND THE BELL-RINGERS. There has been considerable talk lately, inside and outside the Fire Department, in relation to the dismissal of fire-bell-ringers. Many have supposed that the Chief Engineer had made an indiscriminate onslaught upon the bell-ringers--proscribed them all. Engine Company No. 49 had a recent meeting, at which resolutions were passed, strongly denouncing the Chief Engineer, and intimating that he had lost the entire confidence of the Fire Department.

The London correspondent of the Boston Traveller, in a letter dated the 3d inst., says: "You will be glad to hear that Mr. SUMNEE still continues to improve, and that though overwhelmed with invitations form his many friends, he indulges in the pleasures of London life with the greatest caution.

We publish elsewhere, this morning, an account of the disgraceful proceedings which marked the recent attempt to organize a Constitutional Convention in Minnesota. It will be seen that two Conventions are in session, each claiming to be regular, and each proceeding accordingly to the execution of the business for which the Convention was called.

Gen. WALKER reached Mobile on the steamer Czar, from Montgomery, on Sunday evening between 7 and 8 o'clock, accompanied by Capt. FAYSOUX, but left the boat so quietly that a committee appointed to wait upon him, was informed a few moments after its arrival, that he had gone to the Battle House. The Committee immediately repaired to the hotel and ascertained that he had registered his name and retired to his room,

The last injunction granted by Judge INGRAHAM, restraining CONOVER and others, is, taken all in all, the greatest piece of professional bungling which has been perpetrated in the course of these Municipal controversies. Mr. O'CONOR's name is appended as one of the counsel, but we apprehend he had little to do with this particular matter, and that "Glorious DICK" alone is entitled to all the honors of the achievement.

AMERICAN INSTITUTE.--The 29th Annual Fair of the American Institute will open at the Crystal Palace on the 15th of September this year, and will close on the 28th of October. The Palace will be open for the reception of goods from September 7th to September 15th, but heavy goods and articles from a distance will be received at any time before the opening of the Fair.

Owing to the crowded state of our columns, we were unable last week to publish the documents connected with the proceedings at the meeting of the Church of the Puritans held last Thursday evening. The first of these documents it will be seen is the Protest of the Deacons, which was received by the Church, ordered on file, and a Committee appointed to reply to it.

In consequence of application made to the city authorities, in the course of Monday last; by Mayor TALBOT, of the town of St. Thomas, County ??, for a posse of police to aid the local officers in levying the municipal assessments, Constable EDWARD REYNOLDS and four men of the city force left Quebec, with the Mayor of St. Thomas, by Monday evening's train, for that place. ce.

THE MAYOR'S LAST MESSAGE.--There is something excessively amusing in the lugubrious tones of the Mayor's Message which was sent to the Board of Aldermen last evening, accompanying Mr. DEYELIN'S narrative of his ejection from the Street Commissioner's Office, and his arrest and confinement in the Eldridge-street prison.

The main body of the troops destined for the Utah Expedition, will not be detained on account or the Kansas difficulties. They are expected to take up their line of March to-day from Leaven worth. Advices from Minnesota give the particulars of the capture of the son of INK-PA-DU-TA, who murdered Mrs. NOBLES, and who held Miss GARONER his prisoner. He was mortally wounded, and afterwards bayoneted on the 30th ult.

Having spent the 14th and 15th inst. in St. Anthony and St. Paul, I left the "fast" capital of the "fast" young Territory of Minnesota at 5 P.M. yesterday, en route (via Prairie du Cnis?) for Madison, Wis, The weather for the past week has been warm and showery, the mercury ranging from 800 to 950.

The injunctions against Conover. COURT OF COMMON PLEAS--SPECIAL TERM. Before Judge Ingraham. The Mayor, ., vs. Daniel D. Conover and others.--The orders to show cause why Daniel D. Conover and others should not be restrained from removing or causing to be removed, the books, maps, , belonging to the Street Commissioner's office, came up for argument pursuant to the return day.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Whatever matters are of sufficient public interest to be set forth in your columns, should certainly be stated truly, and as you doubtless wish to avoid being made the medium of misleading the public, take the liberty to give you the means of correcting some errors of fact which appear in a letter from Albany, published in your paper of yesterday, July 16.

The Board met, yesterday, at 2 P.M, in the Common Pleas Court Room, part II. All the Commissioners were present. The minutes of the last meeting were read and approved. On motion of Commissioner Holmes, it was resolved that a bock be procured in which the names of all persons with regard to whom protests against graning them licenses shall be received shall be entered in alphabetical order.

OPENING TELEGRAPH LINES ON SUNDAYS.--The Montreal Witness, a respectable religious journal, takes us to task for our censure of the Canadian Telegraph Companies for refusing to transmit, on the Sabbath day, the names of thesufferers by the late St. Lawrence disaster.

From the tone of the letters written at Syracuse, we judge that the exhibition of the mowers and reapers, made under the auspices of the United States Agricultural Society, has, to a great extent, been a failure. ELMENDORF,--In this City, on Tuesday morning, July 31, JOHN HENRI, infant son of John A. and Fanny Elmendorf, aged 6 months and 21 days. The relatives and friends of the family are invited to attend the funeral this (Wednesday) afternoon, at 4 o'clock, at No. 159 West 17th st., without further notice. Damage trifling. The Second floor of the building, occupied by STERN EDMAN, cloths and cassimere dealers; goods injured by water.

In Ceylon, and several districts of India, grows a moderate-sized tree, with thick, shining leaves and a short, crooked stem.

A few days since a diabolical attempt was made to cause the death of the family of Mr. MIGASAH Low, a respectable citizen of the town of Essex, in this State. A mournful calamity happened on Saturday afternoon at the "Flume House, 'in the White Mountains. The flag-staff was struck by lightning about 5 o'clock, killing outright Mr. BLANDON, the having just arrived. Others were injured, among whom, and most seriously, was Mr. TYLEE, the proprietor of the house.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Your interesting exposition of a case of sharp practice on the part of our constables some ten days ago, a s well as the editorial calling for a reform of the gross defects of the law on reference to the duties and responsibilities of our Constabulary, induces me to present a case to the point, and to unite in the demand for redress.

THE WOUNDED RIOTERS AT THE HOSPITAL.--Of the twenty-eight persons taken to the Hospital from injuries received at the riots on the 4th and 5th of July, twenty-two are still remaining. Some of them are in a dangerous condition.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: In an article in the Evening Mirror of July 16, headed "To The Public," and signed "E. J. SAN DEES," with reference to Gen. HENNINGSEN and Nicaraguan affairs, I notice a misstatement, and it is my duty, as one present, to correct it, before the public, as it does great injustice to a brave and meritorious officer.

GOY. WALKER'S ENTRY INTO LAWRENCE WITH FIGHT COMPANIES OF DRAGOONS. LAWRENCE, K. T., Saturday, July, 18, via ST. LOUIS, Tuesday, July 21. Governor WALKER entered Lawrence yesterday with eight companies of dragoons, under command of col. cook, He has camped close to town, in a threatening attitude.

GREAT THEOLOGICAL INSTITUTION.-At the last Southern Convention of Baptists, the establishment of a Theological Institution for all the South was urged, and on a broad foundation. South Carolina Baptist have offered $100,000 toward the enterprise, if the denomination in other States will raise as much more.

This morning a German named KOHLER strangled to death his wife, and afterwards proceeded to the house of NICHOLAS T. HOETON, a respectable and influential citizen, of the firm of HOETON MAGY, set fire to his house, and then stabbed him, killing him instantly.

SHIP MOULTRIE ASHORE. CHARLESTON, Tuesday, July 21. The ship Moultrie, from Cardiff, with a cargo of railway iron, is ashore off the Ship Bar, She is leaking badly, and is in a critical condition. LOSS OF THE BRIG GIDDINGS.

CATASTROPHE AVERTED.--On Wednesday of last week, a farmer living on the line of the Indianapolis and Cincinnati road, above Greensburg, saw a tree fall across the track, and knew that within fifteen minutes the express train would sweep over it from behind a curve that shut the obstructionfrom sight until too late to hold up.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: This afternoon I found it necessary to procure some Post-office stamps. I went to the department of the Office assigned to the delivery of that article, and not having any other money except paper money, laid down $1 in 5 and 3 cent. pieces.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: SIR: The "Englishman" who expressed his ignorance, even of common arithmetic, has, I presume, melted away during this hot weather, and an Anglo-Saxon taking his place, attempts to answer my query, How am I to know an Anglo-Saxon at sight? The description given in reply accords with the Celtic Greek beau ideal, excepting that the Saron takes to himself a Roman nose.

We go ahead, in ship-building, in State planting, in railway laying, in speech-making, in fact, in all the elements of prosperity, and upon all the paths of power. This is conceded. In the heart of Sullivan county, remote from cities, and pretty nearly untrod of men, is a wild and romantic region, of which I have undertaken a Summer's exploration. Mountains are about me, shutting out the view of any naughty deeds the world may be doing outside. Few people are near to bother me, and I am in the most blissful state of ignorance of anything that may have happened in town.

I long into the waterfrom an elevation of 15 feet. His brother, perceiving he did not rise, rushed into the water and dragged him out. He was taken home in a carriage and medical assistance was obtained.

On Monday evening, early, a riotous demonstration was made by antagonistic parties at the Broadway market, who, it is said, rally under the names of "Five Points" and "Double-Pumps." The disposition was so manifest that a number of persons left the market.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: I have just seen, in your paper of the 10th inst., the truly "remarkable narrative" of DEMOCK CHARLTON. I have known DEMOCK for twenty years or more, but never heard of his story of being a British subject until within two years.

THE MARINE COURT AND THE COMPTROLLER.--An action was brought before Judge McCARTHY, in the Marine Court, (Leggett vs. The Mayor, c.,) to recover $416 for 5 months' pay as a clerk in the office of the Street Commissioner. In 1856 the Common Council authorized the appointment of nine clerks in that office, each with an annual salary of $1,000.

By the Brig Isaac Career, PARTRIDGE, master we have dates from Laguna to the 25th of June. The health of the place was very good at the above date. There was no sickness whatever in the vicinity of Laguna. The vomito had made its appearance at Vera Cruz and Campeachy.

F., for the last two days, and the lines are working so hard that it is doubtful if her news can be got through to-night.

FATAL RAILROAD ACCIDENT.-Tuesday mornings a little girl, named ELIZA DESMOND. about 10 years of age, was on her way to school, and while crossing the railroad track between Warren and Prospect-streets, she was accidentally struck by the pilot in front of the locomotive of a Morris and Essex train, and so badly injured that she soon afterwards died.

To the Editor of the New York Daily Times: I notice in this day's TIMES an article signed "Equality," on the subject of early closing of stores. The body of EUGENE ANDERSON, the policeman murdered Tuesday morning by the burglar CANGEMI, at the corner of Centre and Grand streets, was seen yesterday by a great number of people. It still lies in a front room of Officer UNDERHILL'S Dwelling, No. 189 Elm-street, from which place, as previously announced, it will be buried in Greenwood on Sunday, at 1 o'clock P.M.

By private letters from Mexico, dated the 3d inst., we learn that a Spanish invasion of that Republic was fully expected by the Government. We are further advised by disinterested correspondents at the Mexican capital that the defensive preparations now going on are of a formidable nature, and that Spain, if she prosecutes the war, will meet with a very stubborn resistance, if not with actual defeat.

HORTON Co., manufacturers of enameled grates and marbleized iron, had been brutally murdered at his private residence, on Ohioavenue, Vine-street Hill, in the suburbs of the city.
