RADICAL ABOLITIONISTS.--The Nominating Convention of Radical Abolitionists, which was to have been held in June, has been deferred till a more convenient season. Meanwhile, the leaders of the party, who advocate political action, in opposition to the Garrisonians who do not vote at all, are making arrangements for a grand rally in the Fall to devise ways and means for more extensive operations in the next campaign.

Dr. DUFF's letter, in our columns yesterday, gives the strongest picture we have seen of the alarm created in India by the recent outbreaks in the army. We are happy to believe that the ardent temperament of that distinguished man, and his solicitude for the safety of his son, may have led him unduly to magnify the danger.

This venerable Dutch city has been brim-full for the past few days, and crowds of her alumni and friend, strangers and natives, have rushed in to attend the Sixty-second Commencement of old Union. Hotels have lodged their guests upon the floor, and given them indifferent fodder.

" In justice to our 'absent friend,' RAYMOND, O the TIMES, we may state that the recent article in that journal, which has brought out such a volley of thunder from Archbishop HUGHES, is said to have been written by an apostate Catholic Priost, who is one of the regular TIMES writers. The Archbishop doubtless knows his foe, but chooses to aim his shafts at the nominally responsible head."

BRUEN.--In Williamsburg on Thursday, July 23, EMMA FRANCES, youngest child of John Theophilus and Frances Maria Bruen. aged 5 months and 26 days. The friends and relations of the family are invited to attend her funeral, this day, (Friday.) at 4 o'clock P. M., at No. 22 Rugh st., Williamsburg, without further notice.

Before Justices Osborne and Connotly. The Court-room was very full, and so was the calendar. The assault and battery and petit larceny cases were about equal in number. One or two cases were brought before the Court, of a nature too disgusting for publication. Seven men pleaded guilty to a violation of the Quarantine law, and will be sentenced on Saturday.

TRIAL OF MOWING MACHINES IN MASSACHUSETTS.--On Monday there was a trial of mowing machines at Salem, under the auspices of the Essex Agricultural Society, for a premium of $50, offered by RICHARD S. FAY, Esq.

Official dispatches were received here to-day from Kansas, including a letter from Gov. WALKER. defending himself from Southern strictures, and detailing the condition of affairs in Lawrence, in justification of his present conduct. Gov. WRIGHT, Minister to Berlin, has arrived here to receive his instructions, and will leave for Prussia on the 1st of August.

The mantle of horrors appears now to have fallen upon Cincinnati. We publish this morning accounts of two occurrences which have just transpired there-one, a double murder and attempted suicide, accompanied with arson; the other a wholesale poisoning of innocent children by means of lozenges scattered in the street.

A DISTINCTION WITHOUT A DIFFERENCE.It is a matter of dispute, just at present, what has become of Mr. DEVELIN, quasi Street Commissioner. Some little time ago his Honor, Justice PEABODY, by warrant, committed him to "close custody." Thereupon, as the public were informed, the Mayor's Street Commissioner was conducted by Deputy-Sheriff VULTEE to Eldridge-street Jail and lodged there.

RETURNED TO NEW-ORLEANS IN DISTRESS.The ship Delhi, Capt. KNAPP, hence for Boston the 7th inst., returned last evening in distress, having sprung aleak Saturday night, the 11th inst., 100 miles from the Southwest Pass. The ship bore northwest at the time of the discovery,-weather squally. Capt. K. immediately sounded his pumps, and found two and a half feet of water in the hold.

SALE OF THE ARSENAL PROPERTY AGAIN POSTPONED.-The State Arsenal was advertised to be sold yesterday at the Merchants' Exchange, at 12 o'clock but at that hour Mr. A. J. BLEECKER announced that the Commissioners of the Land Office had ordered a still further adjournment to the 2Oth of August, at the same hour and place.

The North American Review for July. It may fairly enough be a question how far critics and reviewers have really served the interests of literature-for honesty and capacity, whether separately or in combination, have been no more commonly found among these than among any other order of men.

DETECTION BY ETHER OF A SHAM IDIOT.--The application of the process of etherization has just been resorted to in Belgium as a means of acquiring judicial information. After a considerable robbery committed at Brussels, in November last, two men, named LERCH and DAUBNER, were arrested and brought to trial.

Proceedings of the Topeka Convention--The Consumption to be Submitted to People, The Lawrence Republican says that the State Conveation finished its session at Topeka Tuesday, July 16. Every district and neighborhood almost, in the whole of Kansas, was fully represented; almost two hundred delegates were present.

DEMOCRATIC REPUBLICAN GENERAL COMMITTEE.--At a meeting of this Committee, held last evening, the following preamble and resolutions were adopted: Whereas, On the 1st day of January, 1857, this body was organized as the Regular Democratic Republican General committee;

Proceedings of the Board Yesterday. Yesterday morning, at 10 o'clock , the regular hour appointed for the meeting of the Police Commissioners, the three members of the Board, Messrs. NYE, BOWEN and STRANAHAN, were in attendance at White-street. General NYE had been at the office some time discharging the routine matter developing upon him in the various Committees.

Lieut. GEO. M. TOTTEN, of the United States Navy, died at Mendham, N. J., on Saturday last. Lieut. TOTTEN had been in the Navy for a period of about thirty years, during which time, up to the commencement of his last illness, he was actively employed.

GREAT FIRE IN COBOURG, C. W.-We learn from Captain WILDBB, of the American and Canadian Express, that a destructive fire occurred in the town of Cobourg, C. W., on Tuesday morning. The Albion Hotel, RAGAN's livery stable, and all the buildings between SMITH's brick block and the Globe Hotel, on the north side of King-street, were burned.

Every five years there is taken an enumeration of the moral, social, physical and industrial condition of the citizens and State of New-York. The classification with which we are presented is of a character to induce an universal examination; yet we know there are but few to whom it is a matter of interest or study.

The proposal to import negroes from Western Africa into the West Indian Islands, as free laborers, to which we have before alluded, is one will find favor in the eyes of a great many well-meaning, but thoughtless, people: or worse still, will furnish an admirable cloak for the bad deeds of a great many knaves.

During the thunder storm in Brooklyn, Thursday evening, the home of Mr. STEPHEN C. JACKSON, corner of Layfayette avenue and ?? street, was struck, much damage being done to the building, and one man killed instantly--Mr. ROBERT McKNIGHT, who had ??ought shelter from the storm in the doorway.

The Democratic (COOPER) General Committee met last evening at Tammany Hall, and remained in session until 12 1/2 o'clock this morning. The attendance was very full. The Committee on By-laws reported, among other sections, that a majority vote of all the members should be necessary to authorize a change of the present organization. This report was adopted after a long debate, only 18 voting in the negative.

From the Worcester (Mass) Spy. We had the curiosity to examine, a few days since, the last will and testament of the late JESSE W. GOODRICH, for many years an attorney at law, and editor of a newspaper in this city, entitled the Cataract, devoted to the temperance reform, who has recently deceased. Mr. GOODRICH was a bachelor,

The said MATTHEW KINCAID, known familiarly as little MATTHEW,

Our farmers are now busily engaged in securing their wheat crops, which, for superiority in quantity and quality, will far surpass any previous year. Rye and oats promises abundant yield. The corn crop will be large and abundant, in consequence of the abundant rains with which the farmers have been blessed--in brief, crops of every description will far exceed any previously raised in the State.

The ship Ellen Austin arrived at Quarantine on the 12th inst. from Liverpool, bringing 559 emigrants eight of whom were sent to the Marine Hospital, sick with small pox. The vessel and passengers were detained at Quarantine. On the 13th inst., three cases more broke out and were sent to Hospital.

MASON--PANGBORN.--In Jersey City, on Thursday April 30. by Rev. R. Vanhorne, Mr. WILLIAM M. MASON to Miss LUCY M. PANGBORN, both of New-York. ALLYN--PITKIN.--On Thursday, July 16, by Rev. Ansen F. Munn, of East New-York, L. I, Mr. E. W. ALLYN to Miss GEORGIANA L.. youngest daughter of John R. Pitkin, Esq., of Woodhaven, L I.

ANOTHER RUNAWAY POND.--The ponds in Vermont appear to have a natural disposition to run away. The old folks will remember how, about 50 years since, a natural pond in Glover, broke through its northern embankment and made tracks for Canada by the way of Memphremagog Lake.; tracks which are visible to the present day.

The instructions for Mr. FORSYTH will go out on the 1st proxime, and reach him on the 12th. President COMONFORT will have but three weeks in which to act on the complicated propositions before the inauguration of the Constitutional Government. There is little chance for a treaty very soon.

After the stormiest and most turbulent month we have ever known in New-York, all the elements of discord and excitement seem to be suddenly subsiding and leaving us in a state of most unnatural quietude.

A SINGULAR CIRCUMSTANCE--SAGACITY OF A Doo.--Yesterday afternoon, a gentleman, who was walking along the line of the Columbia Railroad, about two miles west of the Market-street Bridge, noticed that his dog acted in a very strange manner. The animal ran backwards and forwards between his master and some bushes, and appeared very anxious that he should follow him into the thicket.

The Salt Lake mail, with dates to the 2d inst, arrived at Leavenworthon the 19th. The Territory was in a peaceable condition, and general prosperity prevailed. Rumors of the expedition fitting out by the Government had reached Utah, but attracted little attention. The emigrant trains were pregressing rapidly. brass was abundant on the plains.

In commenting, a day or two since, upon the vagaries of the Montreal Telegraph Company, in refusing the use of their line on Sunday to transmit to anxious relatives the names of the sufferers in the terrible railroad accident, we confined ourselves to condemnation of what was, after all, but one of a thousand obnoxious results, flowing from a most obnoxions principle.

UNITARIANISM IN TRANSYLVANIA.--The American Unitarian Association have recently been paying special attention to the necessities of their brethren in Transylvania, and an appropriation has been made in their behalf from the Association's funds. The number of Unitarians in that country is estimated at 47,000, and their form of service is the same as that maintained in all Protestant dissenting churches.

If our municipal legal controversies continue much longer, we shall require a catalogue raisonne of all that has taken place, classifying and numbering the various in junctions, orders, writs and motions, according to time and the circumstances of each, to avoid falling, like the rest of the community, into a condition of utter bewilderment respecting these important matters.

Our farmers are ready to commence haying as soon as the weather will permit; grass generally very good. A great many farmers in Portage County have mowing and reaping machines. A trial of mowing machines came off last Wednesday near Ravenna, the county seat. The premium was divided between MANNY'S and BALL, AULTMAN Co.'s machines.

COLLISION BETWEEN FERRY-BOAT AND ANCHORED VESSEL--FOG. Robert L. Lane et al. vs. The Steamboat Bedford.--This was a libel filed by the owners of the schooner Mary D. Lane to recover damages occasioned to her by a collision with the steamboat which occurred near the Wall-street Ferry, upon which the steamboat, was running, on the morning of Dec. 17, 1853.

Miss SMITH NOT ON THE ASIA.--It having been announced by telegraph that Miss MADELEINE SMITH, who was tried for the murder of M. D'ANGELIER, at Edinburg, by poison, and acquitted, was a passenger by the Asia, much curiosity was manifested on the arrival of that vessel at the Cunard Dock, by a large number of persons, anxious to see one who had become as famous in Europe as Mrs. CUNNINGHAM had in America,

Mr. Sickles continued his argument. Liquors at all hazards, to prevent the good people of ??-from being poisoned in the mysterious manner peculiar to the Line of the Borgias.

By the arrival at this port, last evening, of the Steamship Asia, we receive advices from London and Liverpool to the 11th inst., the same date as those-brought to St. Johns by the Circassian. The British House of Lords, as already announced by telegraph, had thrown out the bill for the admission of the Jews to Parliament by a majority of 34.

The Pennsylvanian says that an attempt was made to appease Col. FORNEY by the office of the Liverpool Cansulship, "which should be made to him worth $25,000 per annum," $10,000 to be paid in cash. The sum beyond the legal salary of the office was to be modestly veiled under the name of compensation for newspaper correspondence. This would make $100,000 for the four years of Mr. BUOHANAN's administration; and it was refused.

THE MINNESOTA INDIANS.--The Government this morning received a dispatch, we hear, from Governor MEDARY, in Minnesota, requesting permission to master volunteers into the service of the United States as a defence against the savage bands now at the Upper Sioux Agency.

REMARKABLE CASE OF CANINE SAGACITY.--A certain broker has a dog, remarkable for its intelligence. Every Saturday morning the dog received from its master a one-dollar bill, which it carried carefully to market, and with which it paid its meat bill for the week.

The President and Cabinet are much concerned at the attitude taken by the citizens of Lawrence, or rather at the determination manifested by the Free State party to adhere to and maintain the Topeka Constitution. The citizens of Lawrence, through their Committee, take the initiative in the contemPlated support of the Topeka Government, in opposition to the Torritorial Government. It is the commencement of the troubles which have been so loug coming to a head.

In the case of Commonwealth vs. The Commercial Bank of Pennsylvania upon appeal, in the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania, LOWRIE, J., uses the following language: "Objection is made to several of the counts, because they simply charge the bank with "discounting" promissory notes as rates exceeding that fixed by law, and without averring that such discounts were made upon loans of money.

THE LATE MURDER OF OFFICER ANDERSON.-MICHAEL D'ANGELI, suspected of being an accomplice with CANGEMI, the murderer of Policeman ANDERSON, in the burglary at the shoe-store of Mr. SAMMIS, corner of Grand and Centre streets, where the officer was shot, yesterday called at the office of the DistrictAttorney, and surrendered himself.

THE MINNESOTA INDIANS.--We learn that orders have been issued for the troops at ?? McHenry and Mackinaw to proceed to Minnesota to join the troops of Forte Ridgely and Snelling, in view of apprehended disturbances among the Indians in Minnesota. The Government will not authorize Gov. MEDARY to muster volunteers for the service, there being no necessity for the such a proceeding.

Before 10 o'clock yesterday morning, Commissioners NYC, BOWEN and STRANAHAN were present at their office in White-street, ready for the transaction of business. The usual crowd of loungers and expectants were also in and about the building. But the two Mayors and Commissioner CHOLWELL were not present. ot present.

We are sorry to find that the Charleston Standard, in noticing an article published by us on the 8th inst. in reply to an editorial in the Standard of the 1st, accuses the TIMES of "perverting the statements of the Standard to the most remote meanings," and of "indulging in unwarrantable inferences."

THE EGYPTIAN STEAM YACHT "THE TRAVELER OF THE SEA"--(The name of the Pasha of Egypt's new yacht)--is now nearly completed. She is built of iron, filled in with wood from the lower deck to the rail, an? consequently, is very stiff and compact in her upper works. Her bed-places, keelsons and bearings for her boilers and engines, make her, if possible, even stronger below. So far as we are qualified to judge,

McKIM'S ATTEMPT TO ESCAPE,--The Hollidays-burg Whig confirms the report that McKIM, the murderer, attempted to escaped. It was also discovered that he bad cut nearly through two heavy staples which were the means of keeping his cell-door secure. How to got at the means by which be accomplished these hasty feats of iron cutting were yet to be found out.

No State of the Union is richer mineral spritgs than is New-York. Nor can any boast greater variety of these fountains of health, for we have them in abundance-warm or cold, sulphurous, saline, alks. line, chalybeate, acidulous or aperient. The fame of Saratoga as a resort for fashionable seekers after health and pleasure is world-wide.

The R. M. steamship Asia, from Liverpool at 11 o' clock on the morning of July 11, arrived at this port last evening. The advices by the Asia are of the same date ?s those brought to S? .J has by the C??cssian. The steamships Fulton and Arago arrived at Southampton on Thursday, the 9 and the steamship Kangaroo arrived at Liverpool on the same day.

PEARLS IN MAINE.--The brooks in Maine are being pretty thoroughly overhauled d for muscles and pearls. M. W. MERRILL, of Rockland, has obtained two hundred pearls of various sizes. Captain DAVID PATTERSON, of the same town, has about three hundred, and other parties have smaller quantities. Pearls have also been found in Kensington, N. H.

There appears to be increased activity, during the last two months, in the London publishing trade, Several important works have appeared within that period, and a variety of announcements gives good promise of forthcoming treasures. One or two things may be mentioned as worthy of notice.

We have advices from Utah to the 2d of July. The Mormons had received tidings of the military preparattions of the Government, but the news had excited little alarm. The tone of YOUNG'S organ is confident and boastful. Federal ofice-holders are affectionately informed that Utah is not a desinrable abiding place for them, and that " they:will ??ot find it congenial to their health."

Mr. FIELD, at the opening of the Court, on Saturday, asked permission to make the following statement in reply to the published points of Mr. O'CONOR: Devlin is, in fact, not entitled to prosecute the writ of habeas corpus at all. "He is detained by virtue of the final judgment of a competent tribunal of civil jurisdiction."

CAMPBELL --In this City, on Sunday morning, July 26. after a short illness, GEORGE T. CAMPBELL, in the 34th year of his age. The friends of the family and those of his brothers. Thomas N., James and William S. Campbell, are respectfully invited to attend his funeral, tomorrow (Tuesday afternoon, at 41/2 o'clock, from his late residence No. 6 East 24th st, near 4th av., without further invitation.

The exhibition has closed, after a five days trial of Mowers and Reapers, much more satisfactorily than it opened. On Friday morning, the last test of the Dynamometer was applied to the Mowers. They all went through without breaking the instrument, so that the Committee of Judges were able to make com plete notes of the motive power which each machine require to work it. They kept a close watch,

Last Monday morning, about one hundred violations of thu Sunday Liquor Law being reported by the General of Police to the District-Attorney, the latter functionary immediately addressed to-each delinquent a printed notice that unless by Saturday morning, either the different Inspectors of Police or himself wore furnished with assurances-of perfect compliance with the law, for the future, suits for the violations would be commenced.

About 11 o'clock Saturday night the private watchmen employed to watch the stables belonging to the Brooklyn City Railroad Company, on Thirtysixth-streetand Fourth.avenue, near the new entrance to Greenwood Cemetery, discovered a man dressed in the gars of a sailor running from the st. bles towards the woods.

The following is the WEEK BY REPORT OF DEATJ'S in the City and Conty of New.York, from the 18th day of July, to the 25th day of July, 1857: Men, 67; women, 59 ; boys, 191; girls, 154; total, 741.* Adults, 126; children, 845; males, 258; females, 213; colored persons, 9.

THE LATE HOMICIDE AT MANHATTANVILLE.--Corner HILLS, on Saturday, concluded his inquisition upon the body of JOHN RYLANDS, an Englishman, 45 years of age, whose death is supposed to have been caused by violence, received at the hands of some rowdies, at the corner of Broadway and One Hundred and Thirtieth-street, on the Light of the 14th inst.

The recent fresher in Dry Run at Deerfield. Ohio, washed the poisonous matter from the distillery on the Run into the Miami River, and caused the death of tens of thousands of fish. Two tons, it is calculated, were thus destroyed. The mill race, a mile below, was choked up with dead fish.

From the Commercial, 24. We visited Commercial Hospital yesterday evening, and had a long interview with JOSEPH LOEFNER, the murderer. He was visibly better than he had been at any lime since he was first taken to the Hospital, and appeared to be recovering with singuIar rapidity.

Some of the Southern papers, which profess to be organs of the National Administration, have been doing their utmost of late to destroy the confidence which all honorable Northern men desire to cherish and keep alive in the impartiality and the right-mindedness of the actual Executive of Kansas.

The New-Granadian Minister, Gen. HERRON, had a conference with Gen. CASS yesterday. His powers and instructions are ample. The Bird Island Claim is to be pressed by this Government. [FROM AN OCCASIONAL CORRESPONDENT.]

BERGE--WERNEKE--In this City, on Saturday, July 25 at the Church of St. Francis Xavier. 16th-st; by Rev. M. Driscol. Mr. CHRISTIAN BERGE to Miss CAROLINE C. WEENEKE, both of this City. WOOD--SPRAGUE.--On Tuesday. July 21. by Rev. J. M. Macauley. Mr. STEPHEN A. WOOD, of this City, to Miss ANNA A. SPEAGUE, of Williamsburg, L. I.

The recent emeutes in Italy, of which accounts have been received by the last European mail, are, in every point of view but one, occurrences which every friend of liberty, as well as of Italy, must deplore.

THE SUNDAY LIQUOR LAWS.--The authorities have no more difficult problem in city government to solve, than that offered by the laws in respect to Sunday. The immense influx of continental immigration has brought all the holiday ideas of the day which prevail in Germany and France, and not a few infidel notions, that together conflict with the home feelings about Sunday descended from Puritan ancestors.

PROSPECTS IN THE POLICE BOARD--On Saturday afternoon a list of all the new appointments made by the Board thus far, was furnished by Superintendent TALLMADGE to the Mayor upon his requisition. The Mayor and his assistants propose to review the list, and he will make the result a basis of action by the board for the proposal of some dismissals.

IN ALLEN-STREET.--Between 12 and 1 o'clock, yesterday morning, a fire broke out in the veneer shop of the mahogany yard of PATTERSON and GILCHBIST, Nos. 31 and 33 Allen-street. The flames soon spread throughout the building. The stock was damaged to the extent of $2,000 and the building about $50.

The St. Louis Republican has intelligence from Great Salt Lake City, brought to St. Louis in 15 days by Mr. MUEDOCK, conductor of the mail. Dates are to July 2. General prosperity and uninterrupted posse prevailed. Some rumors of the military preparations making for the expedition against Utah were current, but did not excite much, if any, alarm.

A QUIET SUNDAY.--The City yesterday was perfectly quiet, and our stay-at-home citizens enjoyed the unusual luxury of a day of rest from all sorts of mobs and riotous gatherings. This is the more gratifying as there was one of the largest funeral processions during the day that has ever been seen in New-York, in which a very considerable number of the Police of the District took part.

EUGENE ANDERSON, the Metropolitan Policeman who was murdered on Tuesday morning last, while in the discharge of his duty, by the burglar CANGEMI, was buried in Greenwood Cemetery yesterday evening. The attendance was very large and the City interest very great indeed.

It will be seen that the Mormons of Salt Lake, having driven all the Federal officers out of Utah, are now engaged in attempts to excuse their conduct by bringing charges of crime against the objects of their persecution. This is an old trick, repeatedly played by the followers of brigham YOUNG.

A novel idea has been conceived by a Broadway piano-forte dealer, which, if ever put into definite shape, will and one more singularity to the already singular City of New-York. Having secured the large locality on the corner of Broome-street and Broadway as a music mart, he has finished a portion of the premises in the semblance of a drawing-room.

The struggle which took place on Friday evening last in Tammny Hall, on the one side to capture the regular organization of the Democratic party and transfer it bodily to FERNANDO WOOD, and on the other to manitain the integrity and independence of that body, was the most me mentous that even occurred within the walls of the old Wigwam.

At the Board of Health on Saturday, the following communications were received: To the Honorable, the Commissioners of Health, of the City of New York: The undersigned would respectfully represent to your Honorable Board that he is master of the Bark Oakland, which arrived at Quarantine from Havana on the 20th inst., laden with sugar and tobacco, and having lost one man on the passage, and having sent another to the Marine Hospital.

CAPTAIN WILCOX OF THE VANDERBILT RESIGNED.--We learn that Capt. WILCOX, the able and popular commander of the steamship Vanderbilt, has resigned his command, in consequence of private business requiring his attention on shore. In the command of that steamship, Captain WILCOX has won the esteem, respect and confidence of the traveling public,

CLARK--DOUGLAS--In this City, on Sunday, July 26 by Rev. John Quincy Adams, Mr. MARTIN VAU BURRN CLARK of this City, to Miss RACHEL HEWITT LOUGLAR, of Cape Mar N. J. WOODS--TANNATT.--AT Harlem, on Wednesday, July 22, by Rev. J. S. Lord, Mr. GEORGE H. WOODS. Esq., of Minneapolis, Minnesota Territory, to Miss KATIK TANNATT. of Salem, Mass.

JAMAICA vs. BROOKLYN. --The rumor, which seems to be pretty well founded, that the Grand Jury of Kings County, acting upon the suggestion of the Common Council, have presented as a nuisance the running of steam loccomotives upon Atlantic street, has added new flames to the fire of excitement all along the line of the Long Island Railroad.

My last letter was dated from Leavenworth. Business has brought me to Lecompton in the meantime, but the little intelligence I have to communicate is not the less reliable. The troops (somewhere between five and six hundred in number) left Fort Leavenworth yesterday (Thursday) morning about 8 o'clock. They marched all day, and at nightfall an-camped on the banks of the Little Stranger,

By the arrival at Quebec of the Canadian Steamship Company's Screw steamer North American, we are in possession of four days later intelligence from Europe. The most interesting and important new is that brought by the Indian important news is that brought by the Indian mail, which had arrived in London.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Tiems: Finding the public laboring under the impression that I was the brother of CANGEMI, who was arrested as the murderer of the lamented Officer ANDERSON, after waiting a few days for the public excitement to subside, I surrendered myself to the District-Attorney on Friday last, who, after my examination, being satisfied that I have had no connection with CANGEMI, has directed my discharge.

The Canadian Steamship Company's screw steamer North American, from Liverpool on Wednesday, the 15th inst., arrived at this port on Sunday night. The advices by this arrival are four days later than those by the Circassian at St. Johns, and Asia as New York, and are of an highly important character. The R. M. Steamship Europa, Capt. LEITCH, from Boston July 1, arrived at Liverpool on the evening of the 11th.

In consequence of this decision several of the partions consented to a final decree,

The recent declaration of Lord CLARENDON through the British Minister, in regard to the future policy of the British Government relative to the American Continent, are believed to have been offered in good faith, and are accepted and confided in to a great extent by this Government. They are consistent with other public declarations recently made by Lord PALMERSTON, and with the well-known sentiments of other British statesmen,

The Republican State Committee had a meeting on the 23d and nominated STEPHEN H. PHILLIP, of ESSEX County for Attorney, Genearl, vice THOMAS D. ELIOT, decined Mr. PHILLIPS is a son of the late STPPHEN C. PHILLIPS, who was lost in the Montrasl disster, is about 30 years old, and is of a rauk at the Bar much beyond his years.

It is very difficult for journalists to decide how best to deal with domestic quarrels and private misforunes which demand the intervention of the law. The general principle of our jurisprudence, which requires that a certain degree of pubcity shall be given to all legal proceeding which involve the life or the liberty of the citizen, is unquestionably a sound one.

MILITARY DECISION.--At the General Term of the Supreme Court, recently held at Newburg, a decision was given adveise to MUNSON J. LOOKWOOD, who claims to be Brigadier-General in the Second Division New-York State Militia. Judge STRONG dissented. Lockwood has expressed a determination to carry the case higher. The merits of this dispute seem not to be generally understood.

LANE, residence No. 202 Monroe-street, business, ship smith, No. 244 South-street; and JESSE A. From the Syracuse Journal, July 24, The locomotive Binghampton, which drew the freight tram that loft Binghamton yesterday at 3:15 P. M., exploded about half a mile north of Chenango Forks , about 5 o'clock, instantly killing the fireman, one of the brakemen, and very badly, if not fatally, injuring the engineer. The engineer, GEORGE M. MY??, of this city, and son of DAVID MYRES, was terribly burned and mangled.

MISS FLORA MCFLIMSEY.--This celebrated young lady, who is more talked about just now than either Miss MADELEINE SMITH or Mrs. CUNNINGHAM BURDELL, has become associated with another young lady by the name of PECK, the daughter of a clergyman, who claims, in fact, to be the parent of the lady who had nothing to wear. The U.S. Mail steamship Illinois, C. S. BOGGS, U.S.N., commanding, left Aspinwall, July 19, at 6 P.M., and arrived a Quarantine at 11/2 P.M. on the 27th, making the passage in 7 days and 191/2 hours. The Illinois brings the California mails of July 4, $1,458,043 in treasure on freight, and 459 passengers. Pacific Mail Steamship company's steamer Sonora,

DULLNESS AT THE WATERING PLACES.--There is a general complaint from all the various watering places and Summer resorts all over the country of unusual dullness and a paucity of visitors. But we doubt if this be owing to the circumstance of people staying home the present season more than in past years. The cause of the dullness at the watering places has been attributed to hard times.

TRIAL TRIT OF THE JOHN S. DARCY.--Yesterday at 2 o'clock P. M., the new ferry-beat John S. Darcy went on her trail trip down the bay nearly to Sandy Hook and up the Hudson River a short distance with about 400 guests on board. The occasion was one of much social enjoyment. The John S. Darcy is 190 feet in length, 32 feet beam under the guards, 60 feet over the guards,

The following very curious circumstance is narrated by a highly-respectable Episcopal clergyman of this State, who vouches for its correctness: Rev. H.C.H. DUDLEY, formerly a clergyman of the Methodist Church, was lately ordained by Bishop DOANK, of New-Jersey, to the Ministry of the P.H. Church, and is now officiating in Newark.

From the Cincinnati Gazette. CUMMINS, ROCKCASTLE COUNTY, Ky., July 22.--Last Sunday, as Rev. JOHN G. FEE was preaching, at this place, an armed mob forced their way into the church, seized him and two other ministers who were with him, Rev. J RICHARDSON and Rev. J. M. McLEAN, and after abusing and insulting them, finally decided that they should be taken out of the County.

COURT OF COMMON PLEAS. Before Hon. Judge Ingraham. The argument in this case proceeded yesterday morning pursuant to adjournment. Before Mr. O'Conor commenced his reply Mr. Field wished to submit some further authorities, and tirat the case of "The People ex rel, Darlington vs. Overton Sheriff," which was a question of practice reported in 12 Howard 550,

The trials will commence on the 17th of August, 1857. All per. eons intending to offer arms for trial are requested to

The storm of last night seriously interfered with the working of most of the telegraph lines leading from this City. The Boston line was interrupted all the evening, and we were unable, up to the hour of going to press, to obtain any intelligence from Halifax of a later date than yesterday afternoon, when the Cuoand steamship Europa, with three days later news from Europe, had not arrived. The National line to New-Orleans worked

WALKER'S SOUTIIERN FILLIBUSTERING TOUR.-General WALKER, accompanied by Col. SLATTER, of this city, took his departure for Mobile, to day, on a tour devoted to the purpose of rousing up the hearts of the people between that point and Richmond, Va., to furnish the "sinews of war" which he needs to go back and consummate the task he has undertaken of Americanizing Nicaragua.

From the Union. The following General Order was received this morning by the War Department: General Orders, No. 2. HEADQUARTERS OF THE ARMY FOR UTAH, FORT LEAVENWORTH, July 15, 1857. I. The General commanding announces to the troops of his command the following assignments of staff officers to the army for Utah.

Yesterday afternoon a rumor was afloat that a negro man named JIM, who had accompanied his master (Mr CHARLES PARLANGE) from New-Orleans to this city, had left his master for the purpose of testing the sweets of freedom. It was alleged by Mr. PARLANGE that the said "Jim" had taken with him two tin boxes, one of which contained money.

The U. S. Mail steamship Philadelphia, ALFRED G. GRAY, Commander, arrived at this port yesterday morning. She left New-Orleans at 9 A. M., of the 20th, for New York, via Havana, arrived at the latter port on the morning of the 23d, and sailed again at noon of the same day.

An odd discussion occurred in the House of Lords towards the close of the last month, arising on a bill proposed by Lord CAMPBELL, giving larger powers of summary search,seizure, and punishment, in the matter of vending obscene books and prints.

The mail from the United States of the 5th of May only reached us on the 27th ult., being brought by the steamer Panama, in consequence of an accident to the steamer Columbus. Among the passengers from your City were were Mr. W. R. C. WEBSTER, the contractor for the Transit, and Mr. J. C. HARUIS, of the firm of CHARLES MOEGAN Co.

About 11 1/2 o'clock on Monday night, the dead body of Mr. AUGUSTUS VAN LIEW, who resided at No. 12 Hubert-street, was found by Officer CLABBON, of the Eighth Ward Police, lying dead on a cellar door of a house in Mercer-street, near Canal. His remains were conveyed to the Eighth Ward Police Station, where the friends were notified, and removed the remains to his late residence.

FRIGHTFUL TORNADO IN MIDDLESEX COUNTY -- HOUSES AND BAENS LRVELED. -- A tornado, similar in character to that which visited Medford a few years since, ravaged a portion of the towns of Tewksbury and Wilmington on Friday afternoon. Much damage was done by tearing up trees, demloishing buildings and fences, and prostrating fields of grain. It occurred at 5 1/2 o'clock.

MILITARY EXPEDITION.--We learn that four companies of the second infantry have arrived at Fort Ridgely, from Fort Randall, on the Missouri. The troops marched across the country, and arrived at Ridgely last week. An expedition will be started in pursuit of INK-PADU-TA'S band, as soon as the necessary orders can be procured from Washington, directing a movement of that character.

The Postmaster-General of France has notified the Post Office Department of the recent establishment of two lines of French mail packets in the Black Sea, conveying the mails weekly-the one from Constantinople, by Varna, Sulina, Tultcha, and Galatz, to Ibralia, in Wallachia; and the other from Constantinople, by Sinope, Samsum, and Keresoun, to Trebizonde, in Turkish Armenia.

We published yesterday an interesting letter from one of our Washington correspondents, the object and scope of which was to show that Great Britain has determined and is acting upon a radical change of her policy with respect to this continent,-that she has not the remotest design of extending her dominion in this direction, or of increasing her political influence with our neighbors, as against the interests of the American Union.

Mrs. EVA COPENHAGEN, who died recently in smythe County, Va., aged 88 years, leaves one hundred and five grand children, one hundred and thirty great grand children, and one great great grand child. Georgia papers announce the death of General THOMAS FLOURNOY, as his residence on the Sand Hills, Gen, FLOURNOY, says the Augusta Chronicle, was a man of a former generation.

WRECK OF SHIP THOMAS M. ROGERS.--Information has been received at Washington, under date of July 7, from W.S.H. NEWMAN, United States Consul at St. John, Newfoundland, of the arrival at that place of a part of the crew of the ship Thomas M. Rogers, of Bath, Maine, which vessel sunk at sea on the 21st of June last.

A BUFFALONIAN CHARGED WITH FALSE PRETENCES.--W.M. C. SMITH, late a merchant of Buffalo, New-York, was yesterday brought to this City, in custody of an officer from Buffalo, to answer a charge of false pretenees preferred against him by JOHN WARRIN, Esq., doing business at No. 24 Maiden-lane.

From the Cincinnati Gazette. We gave in yesterday's paper an account of the street fight in Louisville, between GEORGE D. PRENTICE and Mr. DURRETT, of the Courier. It seems that a Mr. GEORGE D. HINKLE, near whose office the difficulty occurred, was wounded in the leg by a bail from one of PRENTICE'S pistols, PRENTICE fired four times.

There was another failure to obtain a quorum of the Board of Metropolitan Commissioners, yesterday morning, from the usual cause--the absence of Mr. CHOLWELL, and Mayors WOOD and POWELL. It was stated again that Mr. CHOLWELL would have been present had it not been that he met with some accidental delay. Of course there was no important businese done.

From the Cincinnati Gazette of Monday. A man, by the name of JOHN H. BURNS, was committed by Mayor THOMAS, on Saturday, indefault of $500 bail, to answer the charge of bigamy at the Court of Common Pleas. BURNS came to this city nearly two years ago, from Ireland, and obtained a situation as book-keeper with GIBSON Co., plumbers, on Vine-street.

The Newark Mercury says: Mr. GEORGE II DOANE, (son of Bishop DOANE,) formerly assistant Rector at Grace Church; in this city, whose " perversion" to Romanism was a theme of remark a little time ago, returned from Europe last week in the Asia. He was in this city on Saturday. We understand that he came directly from Rome, where he has remained during the most of the period of his absence.

From the Evening Journal of yesterday. A death from bona fide yellow fever has taken place in Philadelphia, and being opposed to secresy in such matters, we have no hesitation in making it public. On Thursday afternoon last, 24th instant, the bark E. K. Kane passed the Quarantine station, and arrived at Mead Alley Wharf. She was ten days from Havana, with mdse. to captain,

They were met at the Steamboat Landing by D. D. TOMPKINS, Engine Company No. 8, and welcomed in a truly hearty manner. The most destructive storm of hail ever known in that locality passed near Red Hook, on the Hudson River, on Wednesday last. The storm took a northeasterly direction, and extended over a district about ten miles long and two wide. Whole crops of wheat, oats, barley, , were entirely destroyed.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: To furnish three meals a day of plain fare, without dessert, wine or luxuries, costs, in New-Yorks wo hundred dollars each person, servants (though not their wages) included. Thus, in a family of twelve people, of all ages and sexes, the cost will be twenty-four hundred dollars, independent of the house rent, wages, fuel and light.

HEAVY FAILURE--MYSTERIOUS DISAPPEARANCE,--Information reached this city on Tuesday, that J. H. SHOUSE, of Woodford, made an assignment, and disappeared. SHOUSE was considered a wealthy man, and speculated in almost everything. He was in this city on Saturday, and borrowed from a relative, who is a merchant, $5,500.

It is a thousand pities that Miss MADELEINE SMITH was not a passenger in the Asia last week. The City is getting dull. Murders have ceased to stimulate us. We have become hardened to crime and danger. We should not mind being garroted a little for the sake of a new sensation. Mayor WOOD palls upon the taste, and the Epic warfare of the two Polices is now a tale of yesterday.

General CASS has not yet taken up the subject of our relations with Venezuela, and my supposition that the Government will press upon that State the demand for an adjustment of the claims of SHELTON and others, is founded upon the fact that the Government last March instructed Mr. EAMES to urge the subject, and that he has done so, without bringing it to any point.

A young girl of fourteen, LOUISA LEE, left her home, in London, C. W., on account of some misun-. derstanding, and went to Detroit, where she sought employment as a teacher, domestic or in sewing, determining to support herself by any respectable work she could obtain. She did not succeed, and resolved to open a school on her own account, and, with this

The skeleton found of Mount Washington. N. H., was discovered about 1 o'clock P. M., Sunday, the 19th inst., by AMBROSE TOWER. It was about half a mile from the Summit House, and 50 rods from the path leading from the Glen House to the east side of the mountain. The remains have not yet been legally identified as those of BENJAMIN CHANDLER, of Wilmington, Delaware, but no one doubts they are his.

Rev. Mr. SIMPSON, who occupied the state-room of Miss HENDERSON during the passage of a steamboat from St. Louis to Pittsburg, has been tried by a presbytery of Western Pennsylvania, and acquitted of criminality, but censured for indiscretion, one of the witnesses was Miss HENDERSON hereeif, who admitted that he occupied a part of her berth, ?? that she desired his presence to escape from the advance of the second clerk.

From the Boston Traveller. In the Police Court, on Thursday, Mr. JOHN HENRY BETE English gentleman, was arraigned, and waiving an examination, was held to $600 for trial on a charge of bigamy. The complaint was whose story is somewhat singular. The case was about two years since before the lower tribunals of New York City for examination, and at that time formed the subject of a large number of newspaper paragraphs.

RESCUED.--Yesterday afternoon, as Mr. SOLOMON CRAFT, of Philadelphia, with his son and daughter, between fifteen and twenty years of age, were in a boat near Bounty's Dock, above Astoria, it capsized, Mr. CRAFT alone clinging to the boat. His son and daughter were saved by two young men named ALPHA CHILD and WM. N. PINHNEY, who saw the affair from Fort Point, and plunged in to their aid.

A CHILD DROWNED BY AN INSANE GIRL.--A sad tragedy occurred at the Poer house, Tamworth, N. H., on Sunday last, as we learn from the Manchester Mirror. The Superintendent, of the Farm, Mr. WHITING, was absent, and Mrs. WHITING, after getting her infant child to sleep and laying it in the cradle, fell asleep herself. When she awoke, an insane girl, an inmate of the house, was in the room, crying.

CAIBO, EGYPT. Among those many plans that I had formed before leaving home, was one which had a prominent place in all my thoughts of this city of Cairo. TILE WASHINGTON NATIONAL MONUMENT Association.--The Board of Managers of the Washington National Monument Association have held two meetings. A Month or two since a committee was appointed by them to make a searching investigation of the actual condition of the treasury of the Association. That committee promptly refused to perform the duties assigned to them.

The Charleston Courier, which is a very quiet and " conservative" journal, and generally means as little harm as it is possible for a South Carolinian journal to mean, has favored the world with a distinct statement of the duty which the South expects every man, and particularly Governor WALKER, to do in Kansas.

The weather with us the last week was decidedly unfavorable for securing hay and grain-there being scarcely a day but what more or less rain fell. Now is the time for harvesting our rye, (which is quite extensively raised in our locality,) and if the wet weather should continue through the present week much of it doubtless would be badly injured. Hay,

THE YALE NAVY.--The annual regatta of the Yale Navy took place Saturday last. Three boats were entered-the Nereid, six oared, and manned by members of the senior class; the Wenona, also sixoared, and manned by members of the junior class; and the Olynofta, eight-oared, and manned principally by members of the scientific department.

to the Editor of the daily times Sir I feel sorry to perceive so maney false statements in your papers of different dates made by lutenant ODEVAINE respecting the Barck Panchita and Crew. Sir Luetenant ODEVAINE spoke the truth in one of his statements respecting the prise Crew not being drunk on ale, but the guner in charge was beasly

CONVICTION AND SENTENCE FOR POISONING IN VERMONT.--The Vermont Caledonian gives the particulars of the conviction and sentence of NATHANIEL H. STILES for an attempt to poison CHAS. L. FAIRBROTHER. The evidence showed a very extraordinary state of facts. GEO. SULHAM, an accomplice, who was the principal witness, testified that STILES put a orachm and a half of strychnine into a half-pint of pin, the whole of which was drank by FAIRBROTHER.

The Congress of this country is in session, but not showing very great activity. It assembled on the 1st inst. A case of conspiracy has been under investigation for some months. It is highly probable that plots for disturbance were in hand in October last. Too difficulty consists in obtaining evidence. The parties im plicated are LABRAINE, EIVAGUIBBE, GARFIAS.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times; In your issue of the 8th inst. you have an article on "Labor and Cotton supply, " in which you discaes the possibility of white men laboring at the South, with prospect of success. Few intelligent persons acquainted with the Southern country, doubt the feasibility or profit of freo white labor, but the question is, has it been tried, and with what success?

OUR WESTERN TERRITORY-A LONG TRIP OF 2,520 MILES.--In our river column this morning will be found the manifest of the steamer Twilight, which, having loft this port on the 31st of May, laden with Government stores and Indian goods, for the mouth of the river Aue Tramble, a distance of two thousand five hundred and twenty riles, reached her destination on the 7th inst, and returned to St. Louis

MAD FOR LOVE.--HANNAH WALTMAN, a young, handsome and accomplished German woman, was found wandering in the streets, last Saturday even. ing, raving with insanity. A police officer hindly took her into custody, and lodged her in the Ninth-street Station house for safe keeping. During the night she raved with frantic vehemence and excited fears that

To the Editer of the New-York Daily Times: On the fourth page of your paper of this morning, in an editorial concerning the authorship of Nothing to Wear, you take occasion to remark that " the whole squabble about Miss Flora McFlimsey and Nothing to Wear has very much the look of an advertising dodge."

THE HEALTH OF TIIE CITY.-There were two rumors on Monday of deaths in Brooklyn from cholera and yellow fever. But the reports were very ambiguous and rather contradictory. The case of yellow fever proved to have been bilious fever, and the case of cholera was probably not much nearer that disease.

THE CABINET MAKING A PILGRIMAGE TO MOUNT VERNON.--We hear that the excursion of the members of the Cabinet, accompanied by their families and a few friends, to Mount Vernon, on Saturday last, was a delightful one. The company were the guests of the Secretary of the Navy. Among them, by the by, were Mr. HENRY, the President's Private Secretary; Miss LANE, his niece;

General HERRAN, the New-Granadian Minister, has caused it to be understood here that he had full powers from his Government to negotiate a settlement of the questions at issue between his Government and the United States. He has, upon the strength of these supposed powers, hold several interviews with General CASS, and discussed the subject with a view to an arrangement.

REWARDS FOR THE MURDER OF NORCROSS.--I will be remembered, that soon after the murder of NORCROSS, various amounts of reward were offered for the arrest and conviction of the murderer. Massachusetts promised $1,000; the Governor of Pennsylvania $500, with a promise to increase it to $1,000, under certain provisions; the authorities of Hollidaysburg, $300, and the friends of the victim $200.

KELLY--In this City, on Tuesday, July 28, EMMA LOUISE, infant daughter of Daniel D. Kelley. The relatives, friends and acquaintances are invited to attend the funeral, from No. 151 West 43d-st., this (Wednesday,) afternoon, at 3 o' clock, without further invitation. LEGGETT,--In this City, on Tuesday, July 28, KELLY LEGGETT, in the 4-th year of his age.

THE NEWS FROM INDIA.--The telegraphic heading of the last news from India, via Quebec, looked more alarming than the dispatch itself. "The Mutiny Spreading," said the one; "The Crisis was past," said the other. In a few days we can judge for ourselves, when the mail arrives. As the case now stands, we abide in the

The out-look on the frontier in the direction of the Sioux Agency, has for the past three weeks been very ominous, and a letter in the Pioneer of yesterday confirms our apprehensions of a fight with the Indians of that neighborhood.

Before Judge Ingersoll. PRACTICE--ALTERATION OF A PROCESS-RETURN. Judge INGERSOLL came in town this morning at hold Court for the return of process. When the processes had been returned, Mr. Donohue, one of the counsel for the bark Panchita, libeled for being engaged in the slave-trade, said that, the process against the bark was made returnable this morning, and they desired to have it returned, as they wishen to take some proceedings in the matter.

A FAMILY QUARREL, RESULTING FATALLY.--CHRISTOPHER HEFFERNAN, residing in Columbia-street near Hamilton avenue, died last Tuesday in consequence of injuries inflicted on Monday, the 20th inst., by his stop-son, who is a boy of about 16 years of age.

STAREING AFFRAY IN CENTRE-STREET.--On Tuesday afternoon JOSEPH JOHNSON was stabbed at No. 62 Centre-street by a colored girl named JOHANNA ERKSON. The stab took effect in the left breast, severing the mammary artery.

Our reports refer to these regular markets. Irregular sales are sometimes made at Bergen Hill, N. J., and from the Hudson River Beats. s.

Gen. HERRAN'S propositions for an adjustment of the differences between New-Granada and the United States are acceptable. The President will not leave for Bedford Springs until this negotiation is terminated.

Hon. DAVID WILMOT. Union candidate for Governor of Pennsylvania, has resigned his judgeship for the purpose of having a clear field, and giving his whole time to the Gubernatorial contest. He has also challenged General Packer to meet him on the stump, to discuss the various political topics of the day.

St. Paul dates to the 26th inst. are to band. An express from the Sioux agency had arrived there and reported that 10,000 Indians were defying the United States Troops, and that a renowal of hostilities was unavoidable. The settlers were lying to the forts for protection. Gov. MEDAEY was endeavoring to preserve the peace.

LACOUR.--In this City, on Tuesday, July 28. of Inflammation of the bowels FLLA P. LACOUE, daughter of Joha and Elizabeth P Larour, aged 5 years and 4 months. The relatives and friends of the family are invited to attend the funeral from the residence of its parents, No. 183 Stanton St. at 2 o'clock P.M. on Friday. Its remains will be taken to the New York Bay Cemetery for interment.

The proposition which General HERRAN is understood to have submitted, for a settlement of the difficulties between New-Granada and the United States, must strike the thoughtful reader as supremely ridiculous in one point.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: The readers of the TIMES may not be aware that the Act of 1830, ch 295, which declared it to be unlawful to pass, circulate or receive bank notes issued by foreign corporations under the denomination of $5, is still in force.

We have been waiting for some days to see what the South says of "the shooting affair" between GEORGE D. PRENTICE, editor of the Lonisville Journal, and G. DURRETT, editor of the Courier. One has always a natural desire to know what the "ehivalry" think of the made in which a duel is conducted, before one makes up one's own mind on the subject.

I told you yesterday that Yale College wants money. But the College has another want, and of a very different character. It wants a BABBER A tonsorial professor ought to be added to the Faculty immediately.

FREDERICKA BUSH, a German, was arrested here to-day, for causing the death of two children by starvation. They had been placed in her charge by their parents. One of them died on Sunday, and the other yesterday. The Coroner is investigating the matter.

On the 4th and 5th of the present month the Sprimalists of Obio held a Convention at Ravenns. During the discussion a Mrs. Lawis, of Gleveland, delivered herself by saying that one was in favor of universal freedom, and that loving whomsoever she chose was a part of that freedom and to confine her to love one man was an abridgement of her rights.

The steamship Europa, with advices from Europe three days later than those brought by the North American at Quebec, arrived at Halifax last night, but her news did not reach us until a very late hour.

PUBLIC MEETING AT GUYANDOTTE.--At a large and respectable meeting of the citizens of Guyandotte and vicinity, held at the Town Hall according to previous nation, on Tuesday, July 21, 1857, Mr. A. J. KEPMAN was appointed President, and Dr. T. C. BUFFINGTON, Secretary.

RETURNED BY MAIL.--About two weeks since Capt. KELLY, of Newark, the commanding officer of the Liberty Rifles of that city, was in Jereey City, and lost a valuable gold chain and seal during a row, Two young men named J. Q. ADAMS and J. McCUTOHEON, were committed to jail on the charge of taking them from him.

Hon. JOHN GLEN KING, of Salem, Mass., died at his residence, On Sunday, July 27, at the age of 70. He had been for many years a leading member of the Massachusetts Bar, and had held many offices of public trust. He was one of the counsel employed by the Massachusetts Legislature in the "Prescott Impeachment Case" of 1821, in which he sustained himself with distinction against DANIEL WEBSTER.

The sleep-of-war Cyane arrived here to-day in twenty-four days from Aspinwall, bringing as passengers fifty-three of WALKEE'S men, entirely destitute. Among WALKER'S officers, arrived by the Cyane, are Major DELANY and Lieuts. SIMPSON and SNYDER. When the Cyane left Aspinwall, the United Statesship Remove lay there with 240 other allibusters,

A DREADFULLY THRILLING TRAGEDY SPOILED.--The Herald tried the experiment yesterday of getting up a panic in a different direction from its customary course. It deserted Wall-street and went into the rural districts, and, instead of slaughtering bulls, murdered in cold blood an interesting young lady on Staten Island.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: SIR: The criticisms contained in one of your editorials, a few days ago, upon the manner in which J. T. HEABLEY, Secretary of State, has performed his task of superintending the publication of the Session Laws, passed by the last Legislature, by no means exhaust the subject. All such books ought to have a carefully and thoroughly digested index at the end.

The Government has come to the determination to make a peremptory demand against Venezaela for he settlement of the claims of our citizens in the Bird Island affair. No special amount will be demanded, but on the recognition of the justice of our reclamation by Venczucla, a commission will be appointed to receive evidence, and sottle the claims on principles of justice.

From the Manchester, N. H., American. On Saturday afternoon, about 4 o'clock P. M., a teamster driving near BAYLEY BLOOD'S locomotive works, saw a young woman struggling with upraised hands, and disappearing under the water in the canal. The alaim was at once given, and the City Marshal summoned to the spot. The stream was exceedingly turbid from the heavy showers of the morning, so that nothing could be seen below the surface.

Judge NELSON'S written opinion on the application of R. D. SILLIMAN, of Troy, to restrain the Hudson River Bridge Company from building their bridge at Albany, under the act of the Legislature of this State in 1856, was received this morning.

A few items of additional European news by the Europa are given in another part of this morning's issue. It is attempted to saddle Russia with the charge of instigating the Indian mutinies, but, ambitious and unscrupulous as Russian Diplomacy is, it can scarcely be held responsible for this insurrection. A mutiny among the sepoys, as every traveler in India well knows, is of frequent occurrence,...

Five Brave Men Attack one Unprotected FEMALE,-On Tuesday night, NARGARET WHERTY, a servant girl, was passing through Twenty-sixth-street, when five young men attacked her, when near Fourth-avenue, and demanded her money. She answered that she had none, and two of the gang then seized her by the arms and held her while another stole a gold breastpin from her shawl. The girl screamed for help and the scoundrels fled.

The United States transport Schooner Tortugas, Captain WILSON, arrived yesterday afternoon from Garden Key, Tortugas. By this arrival we learn that the bark Pacific, Captain GARDINER, from New-York, with a valuable cargo of asserted merchandise, bound to mobile, was ashore upon the eastern point of East Key Shoal, six miles from the light house. Captain WILSON, of the Tortugas, was the first boarder from the key,

FIRES IN BROOKLYN.--The vat-house of the American Oil Company, Red Hook Point, accidentally caught fire at 3 o'clock yesterday morning. Before the firemen could reach the spot the flames communicated with a quantity of oil in casks, stored in a yard adjoining the premises where the fire originated, and the whole was consumed. Loss $6,000--no insurance.

The most remarkable feature of America is the Basin of the Mississippi. As yet the popular mind does not clearly comprehend its dimensions, and the understanding of its physical characteristics is indistinct and vague. It is bisected through its centre by a supreme artery, which above St. Louis has received the name of the Missouri, and below, the Mississippi River.

LAND FUNDS ACCOUNTS WITH STATES.-An Account has been adjusted by the commissioner of the General Land Office between the United States and the State of Missouri, for the three-per-cent. fand accruing to the later during the years 1855 and 1856, under the provisions of the Act of Congress approved March 8, 1820, and a balance of $79,030 09 found to be one the State of Missouri.

Hon. DAVID O'KEEFE, of this City, died on Thursday last, at Far Rockaway, Long Island, of paralysis, with which, for more than a year, he had been afflicted. Mr. O'KEEFE, though only about 30 years of age at the time of his death, was very widely known, and filled many offices of honor and trust. He was twice elected to the Assembly from his native Ward--the Thirteenth--and once from the First

At this season of the year accidents upon the water are very frequent, and it is especially important that all classes should be familiar with the best means of treating persons who appear to be drowned. Want of knowledge, in this respect, has often allowed the sufferers to die, where, with skill and care, the lamp of life might have been relighted.

MURDEROUS ASSAULT UPON A FEMALE-Officer ERESON; of the Eighteenth Ward, while pacroling his beat on Wednesday night, heard screams proceeding from one from of a row of tenement, houses, and on entering discovered a man named JAMES DUGAN beating and kicking his wife, who was lying upon the floor almost exhausted. The officer immediately arrested DUGAN, and procured a physician to attend his wife.

THE MORMONS.--The Peoria (III.) Transcript notices the arrival, at that place, of about four hundred Mormons, on their way to Salt Lake City. Most of them are English, and on being conversed with expressed dissatisfaction at the prospect thus far, and intimated a determination not to proceed to Utah. The Liverpool Albion informs us that a few weeks since, about nine Mormon elders visited Rockdale, fcr the purpose of holding services in the open air.

RESIGNATION OF FIRE COMMISSIONENS.--We have already said that Messrs. WEIGHT, BROWN, GRAFT and SCHENCK, four of the five Fire Commissioners, have signed their resignation, to take effect on the let of September. For their withdrawal from office various motives are assigned. Mr. SCHENCK intended to retire on the 1st of May last, but was persuaded to remain in office for a short time longer.

GERMANY. It is reported that a meeting of the Emperors of Russia, Austria, and France is to be brought about very shortly on Bavarian territory, and various movements are adduced in confirmation of the rumor. The King of Prussia had returned from his visit to Vienna. It is believed in Germany that his visit has been connected with a reconciliation between Russia and Austria, which the King is highly desirous of effecting.

Mr. J. ALFRID NOVERLLO, the well-known music publisher of London is now on his first visit to America. He Visits us, says the Musical Review, with purposes of recreation and to examine our institutions with his own eyes. He is the on of the distinguished composer VINOENT NOVELLO, and brother of CLARA NOVELLO, who, we are encouraged to hope, may visit us during the coming season, affording opportunity of listening to the greatest oratorio-singer living.

In France, where wine is an almost invariable accompaniment of a dinner, drunkenness is comparatively rare. At least, in proportion to the respective populations, the United States contain ten times as many habitual sots as are to be found within the dominions of LOUIS NAPOLEON. The fact is explained in part, perhaps, by comparison of the character of the liquors consumed in the two countries.

Correspondence of the Providence Journal. Newport, of a Summer, was never less gay, and yet, strictly speaking, there was never more real enjoyment here. There is less excitement, less stir, but more real comfort and a highor appreciation of ?? should constitute the pleasures of a vacation in the country. The hotels are all open, and the company is about equally divided among them.

EXTRAORDINARY SALE OF LAND AND NEGROES.--The estate of ALEXANDER MOORE, of Halifax County was appraised immediately after his death, 1850, at between $21,00 and $22,000. The executor, WOODSON DUGHES, Esq., kept the estate together ?? October , 1856, when he made sale of the whole property at public auction, for cash, or for bonds. Well secured, bearing interest from date.

THE ASTOR LIBRARY.-The Astor Library is to be closed during the month of August, on account of some alterations directed to be made in the building by the Trustees. During the last six months about 1,500 volumes have been added to the Library. Dr. COGSWELL, the Librarian and Superintendent, expects to make some very important additions to the Library before it is reopened again to the public.

If any man were sifted with the power of foreseeing the events of his own life, probably the strangest part to him would be, not the occurrences themselves, but the means by which these events were reached. We each prophecy to ourselves success, or else ruin and disaster, but when the issue comes, it never comes in the way we had marked out.

The Commissioner of Indian Affairs received yesterday, by the Western mail, another letter from R. S. STEVENS, Esq., Superintendent of the sales of Indian Trust lands in Kansas Territory, dated Paola, July 15. The sale of the Wea, Kasknekia, Paoria and Piankeshaw Trust lands had been concluded on the 14th. In a few days a detailed account would be forwarded to the Indian office,

TRANSFER OF THE PENNSYLVANIA PUBLIC WORKS--The last act of the drama was finally executed, this morning, by the signature of A. G. CURTIN, Esq., Secretary of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, to the deed conveying the main line of public improvements to the Pennsylvania Railroad Company.

From the Courrier Des Etats Unis. THALBERG, returned to New-York from his triumphant tour in the interior, is reposing gracefully and quietly on his laurels. At the present he dreams only of a far niente season at the sea-side, and if, from the force of habit, he must indulge in some musical recreation, it is not with the pianoforte.

Our Produce Markets have been but moderately active during the past week. The weather has been pretty favorable for out-door movements. Yet, buyers have manifested no disposition to purchase much ahead of their pressing necessities-especially in view of the stiffness of holders of the leading articles. The news from Europe has worked against moat kinds of Produce.

CORN TRADE BETWEEN FRANCE AND EGYPT.--The Courrier de Etats U?? announces that an association has been formed in France, with a capital of 2,000,000 francs, having for its object the direct importation from Egypt of wheat, corn, cereals, alimentary pastes, Since the reduction of duties on these articles large supplies have been derived from the United States, chiefly in American bottoms.

PICNIC OF PUBLIC SCHOOL. NO. 1, OF STAPLLTON, STATEN ISLAND.--The first annual excursion of this School took place yesterday. About 9 o'clock. some 400 of the children left the school-house, preceded by Robertson's Band, and retired to a grove in the vicinity o the old Quarantine Hospital, where they enjoyed themselves finely.

THE GREAT ENGLISH RACER ECLIPSE.--Prof. Low, in his work on domestic animals, thus alludes to Eclipse; Eclipse was got by Murske, a grandson of Bartlett's Canders, out of Spiletta, He was foiled in the year 1764. during the eclipse of that year, from which circumstance he took his name.

VALUABLE ORIGINAL PORTRAIT.--By the last steamer from Liverpool, Gen. WM. H. SUMMER, of Jamaica Plains, received an original portrait of Gen. THOMAS GAGE, Governor of Massachusetts at the commencement of the Revolution, and whose name is familiar to all acquainted with our country's history. The portrait is of life size, and was taken when the General was in the prime of life.

From the N.O Pucayune of July 25. The Galveston Civilian in noticing the arrival of Dr. ROYALL in that city after wandering some 3,000 or 4,000 miles during the last six months, in the country west of the Buzes, says: "We regret to find that his impressions of the crop are mainly unfavourable, though some sections have been much more fortunate than others.

EXCITEMENT IN GOLDSBORO', N.C.--The excitement in Goldsboro', relative to the shooting of Dr. DAVIS, was increasing at last accounts. Handbills, warning all Jows and Germans to leave the town by the 4th of August, were posted up last Monday morning, and the Mayor called a meeting of the citizens Tuesday afternoon to get an expression of public sentiment upon the subject. .

A RUSSIAN STEAMER TO BE BUILT IN EAST BOSTON. -- We understand that PAUL CURTIS, Esq. one of our most successful shipbuilders, concluded a contract yesterday to build a steamer of 720 tons, for the Russian Government. She is to built of the very best material, and we have no doubt that she will add to he high reputation of her builder, and reflected credit upon the mechanics of East Boston.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times; Knowing that you take some interest in the state of things of our metreopolis. I beg to call your attention to the abominable condtion in which all the affairs connected with the Custom-House are at present.

The Board of Metropolitan Police Commissioners met yesterday morning, Gen. NYE in the ??, and a large crowd of spectators. who, as they are permitted to do usually, occupied the rooms required by the reporters. The first paper offered was the following from Mr. WOOD:

There have been two great principles in jurisprudence evolved by the proceedings in the Police case and the Conover case. Oue is that every course of action, small or great, public or private, which any individual in the community objects to, ought to be stayed by injunction. The others, that no man who has an intimate personal or political friend on the Judicial Bench can be legally committed to prison.

The complication in our Muricilpal litigation is jielding, it would seem, at length, to time and the force of circumstances. Perhaps the subject matter is almost used up, or the parties litigant have pretty nearly exhausted judicial resources, by using their Honors quite as much and as often as was proper or convenient. Then, the counsel want their August vacation, Whatever becomes of Mr. DEVLIN and his franchise de facto; and they should have it,

From the Washington Union, July 31. The Commissioner of Indian Affairs received yesterday from J L COLLINS, Superin'endent o: IInoian Affairs for the Territory of New Mexico, the monthly reports of the Indian agents, LABODI and CARSON. These reports are made out for the month of May.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Under the above head,I read in your paper of this date nearly two columns of matter respecting American Horses that are entered to run for races in England; I have also read a similar tirade in a sport.

UNION OF THE BRITISH NORTH AMERICAN PROVINCES--REPRESENTATION IN THE IMPERIAL PARLIAMENT.---We notice an article in the last number of Black wood's Magazine, in which the points is discussed whether or not the colonies ought to be represented in Imperial Parliament. This question is not a new one; it was first raised in 1831, by the late JOSEPH HUME, and was then at once negatived.

IMPORTERS GRUMELING AT DELAY IN GETTING GOODS FROM THE CUSTOM-HOUSE.--There is a good deal of grumbling just now among importers, at the delay to which they say they have to submit before they can get their goods from the Custom - House. It is alleged that goods are not un'requently retained in the warehouses from three to four weeks, which, it is claimed,

The call made in the House of Commons by Col. LINDSAY for the letter of the late Secretary MARCY to the Count DE SARTIGES, of the 28th of July, 1856, on the declaration of the Paris Conference that "Privateering is and remains abolished," seems to have had for its object to ascertain how far the letter of Mr. MARCY committed this Government on that subject.

MILITARY--ARRIVAL HOME--The "City Grenadiers," Capt. LONDON, returned home last evening from their visit to Philadelphia, where they have been since Wednesday. They arrived by the Camden and Amboy boat, and were received at the Battery by he "Highland Guard." Capt. MANSON. "State Grenadiers." Capt. BRODIE, and by an Artillery Company under Capt. McMANUS.

The Democratic Convention, charged with the duty of choosing the nominees of the party for the Sate officers to be elected at the ensuing Fall election, motion this city yesterday. After organizing. a Committee was appointed, which, on consultation, recommended that no formal Domination for Governor should be made, but that the Democracy of the State support Hen. JOHN C. GROOME, of Cecil Country, for that office.

HUNTING FUGITIVE SLAVES.--CAIRO, III., Monday, July 27--On Sunday morning, a party of Missouriahs, supposed to be near fifty in number, came over from the Missouri shore to search for fugitive slaves--some ten of fifteen chattels having recently escaped from that part of the State.

HEAVY LARCENY AMONG IMMIGRANTS.--Mr. OHAEL HIRSCH, a tailor by trade, was arrested yesterday morning, by Officer TAMMANY, of the First Ward, charged with larceny, in having refused to deliver up money which was put in his hands for safe keeping. The accused is a recently-arrived emigrant, and among others who had come out in the same slip with him, were stopping at No. 5 Carlisle - street.

A COUNTRYMAN ROBBED IN AN ALLEY-WAY.--JOHN LESTER, resident of Mulberry-street, was arrested yesterday by Officer FULLER of the Sixth Precinct, and committed to the Tombs, on a charge of having on Wednesday night, with an accomplice, robbed one NEIL ROONEY, resident of Throg's neck, Westchester County.

A COUPLE OF NOBLE VISITORS.--Among the passengers by the steamer Europa, at Boston, are two young English noblemen, who have probably come over to make the tour of the States. They are Lord ?? and Lord HENVEY. The first in the son heir of Earl SPENCER, a descendent of the great Duke of MARLBOROUGH, and a nephew of Viscount ALTHORN, the distinguished statesman who was Chancellor of the Exchequer in the Melbourne Administration.

From the Christian Examiner for July. The scientific circles at Cambridge have been recently interested in an observation of Professor PEIECE, not yet published, upon the form of the Continents.

To the Editor of the New York Daily Times: In your paper of this morning, giving an account of the presentation of a testimonial to me, you ask the question, "Did the politics of Mr. WEBB prevent him from sharing in the testimonial," apparently doubtful whether the arrest was made through the action of the officer or myself.

MORE EMIGRANTS.--The packet ship J. Jones came up to her wiert yesterday morning with a fine sot of passengers. They are mostly from the northern districts of Or Ireland. The ship sailed from Londenderry. Both male and female passengers went the most healthy aspect. Juaging from their appear once, they are from amount the respectable industrial and agricultural class.

PAYMENT OF WATER-RENTS.--The office of the Croton Aqueduct Department was crowded yesterday with parties coming to pay their water rents. The special rush was caused by the fact, that after the 1st of August 5 per cent is added to al unpaid rents: upon those unpaid up to the 1st of November 10 per cent additional is charged.

The Commissioners yesterday paid a visit of inspection to old Quarantine, in company with a number of invited guests; the party consisted of ?? F. Purdy, Wilson G. Hunt, Cyrus Curtis,--Garrique and Andrew Cardigan, Commissioners; and Hon. Augustus Schell, Collector; Hon. John Kelly, M. C; Hon. Elijah Ward, M. C; D E Delevan, Joseph Mash, Joel Wolfs, Waldo Hurchine, and Gideon J. Tucker.

There was an immense jam all day Saturday at the Custom-House of parties anxious to learn about the removals and appointments to office by the Collector. The following is the official statement of the removals and appointments thus far, as approved by the Secretary of the Department:

The President has determined to retain the following Federal officers in the Territory of Utah, viz: Judge STILES, Marshal DOTSON, and District-Attorney JOHN M. HOOKADAY. No charges have been filed in the Interior Department against the late Surveyor-General BURR,--and the Administration have entire confidence in his integrity.

Another shocking murder was perpetrated in this City, between 12 and 1 o'clock yesterday morning. A young men named THRODORT L. TOMPKINS, was beaten to death in the low house of prostitution No. 3 Moloeny street, by the barkeeper and other of the place TOMPKINS, accompanied by two other young men from Hoboken, named FRANCIS WEBB

The following is the WEEKLY REPORT OF DEATHS in the City and County of New-York, from the 25th day of July, to the 1st day of August, 1857: Men, 73 women, 40; boys, 2:9; girls, 190; total, 531. Adults, 322; children, 409; males, 292; females, 239; colored persons, 12.

Lieutenant-General Sir CHARLES NAPIER. the most efficient soldier ever in the East Indian service. has left on record the opinion that "Mutiny is the greatest danger threatening India--a danger that may come unexpectedly and with a power to shake the very foundation cf our Eastern Empire."

Private advices from England are to the effect that the British Government has agreed to guarantee $3, 000 sterling per annum in addition to the $7,000 granted by Newfoundland for direct steam communication between England and St. Johns, Newfound-land; and that, as Mr. CUNARD declines terminating his mail contract for St. Johns until its expiration in 1863,

The members of the Board of Metropolitan Police Commissioners were all present at 11 1/2 o'clock on Saturday, and at that hour proceeded to business. The ?? that was reported was the bill of Sergeant BRIAN, who has been acting as an Inspector of Police, and who claimed the pay for the fulfillment of those duties. With an intimation that the claim was valid, the matter was referred to the Finance Committee.

The Captain and Lis wife, the crew and six passengers were saved. The crew and the six passengers were landed at St. Pierre,

A meeting of the manufacturers of linseed oil in Southern Ohio and Western Indiana, was held in Cincinnati last week, and after some discussion the meeting adjourned to meet in Dayton last Saturday. The Cincinnati Price Current says of it: Sixteen oil mills were represented. A resolution was adopted unanimously, that the rule of selling linseed oil by weight, as prescribed by the law of this
