It will be evidence of treason--weather high, or law, or middling, I really don't know. Here it is: MAYOR BLOOD'S MESSAGE. Gentlemen of the Board of Aldermen:

During Friday night and Saturday, a large number of merchants and business men form St. Louis and the West, arrived in Philapelphia and Look lodgings at the Girard Hose. The party numbers about one hundred--three hundred others being on their way.

By the arrival of the brig T. M. Magheic we have Berenda papers of the 21st July. On the morning of the 18th four men of the 25th Regiment at George's attempted to desert in a sulboat. Suspicion attached to an American whaling schooner then lying in the barbor, as privy to the movement and an embargo was put upon her sailing for that day.

The Europa's mails reached this City from Boston at an early hour on Saturday morning. We publish below our foreign correspondence, and select from our foreign files much additional news of interest. It is stated that the soundings obtained by the British surveying steamer Cyclops--which has been engaged in checking for the Atlantic Telegraph Company the soundings taken by the United State steamer Arctic-are very satisfactory,

A recent dispatch from one of our special correspondents at Washington announced that certain questions of constitutional administration had arisen in the Cabinet discussions of a plan for giving future security to the Panama transit. The accuracy of this information is entirely confirmed through other reliable sources.

NEW WAY OF MAKING CORN BASKETS.--A Vermont Yankee has invented and patented a new plan of making corn baskets, which looks well--on paper: "The body of this basket is made entirely of upright splints or staves, without braiding in cross strands. These splits are nearly an eighth of an inch in thickness,

We observe that there is a growing desire among our large dry goods importers and commission merchants to reform the ruinous system of fort credits, on which their business has been conducted for many years past. Formerly the credits allowed to wholesale buyers of dry goods ranged from six to eight months.

JAMME---In this City, on Saturday, Aug. 1, after a long and painful illness, ROSE JAMME, in the 56th year of her age, Her funeral will take place this (Monday) afternoon, from her late residence. No. 20 Watts st. Her friends, and those of her some, Louis and George, are respectfully invited to attend.

Dr. TYLER, who for thirty years has occupied the chair of Didactic Theology in the Theological Institute of Connecticut, has resigned. The infirmities of age present the only motive lo this movement. The Doctor is now more than seventy-five years old, He is to receive an annuity of five hundred dollars

By the following communication it will be seen that some of our ship-owners are quite systematically at work trying to introduce into our port infected or putrid cargoes, in violation of our Health Laws. The move in question was entirely unsuccessful. It is true, they brought their vessel without trouble to the wharves of Green Port,

PLEASANT WORK FOR HOT WEATHER.--The Police Commissioners having the welfare of the City greatly at heart, and being bent on discharging the responsible duties of their office, met together on Saturday and amused themselves by balloting two hundred times for a Commissioner to fill the place left vacant by the resignation of Mr. DRAPER.

FORNEY'S NEW PAPER.--The first number of The Press, Mr. FORNEY'S new paper, was published in Philadelphia on Saturday morning. It is in the old fashioned folio form, and makes a very neat appearance. The editor says "he is not ambitious of printing a mere party paper ;" but he avows his intention of advocating the principles of the Democratic party, and expresses his

The Patent Office lacks a head, and before Monday a number employes, about sixty, in the various branches of the Department of the Interior, will be a head shorter than at present. As the Patent Office is one with which the people have an initmate, frequent and direct connection both in its mechanical and agricultural branches, it is necessary that the Commissioner should be a man, not only of integrity, but of stability and politeness.

Colonel NOBLE, , the Constructing Superintendent of the wagon road to the South Pass, is now in this City. The expedition is, for the present, suspended, the encampment west of the Big Sioux having been broken up on the 18th instant, on account of the violent opposition offered by the Yankton Sioux Indians to the further progress of the party,

The excitement in reference to the late riot has abated, partly owing to the successful examination of the rioters in custody, and party to other causes of excitement. The rioters, whose names: I transmitted to you yesterday, were to have been tried before-Judge O'SHAUGHNESSEY, but the vigilants not having confidence in him, or rather having more in Judge COROOBAN, procured a change of venue to the latter gentleman's Court.

The Legislature adjourned yesterday, after a session of 18 days, in which time it did about as much work as might comfortably have been done in 18 hours. With the session expires the Legislature itself, and the system under which it had existed for almost seven generations. So that "there is an end of an old song," might have been the exclamation of the members, if they had been inclined to joke about the matter.

INK-PA-DU-TAH'S BAND TO BE GIVEN UP BY THE SIOUX NATION.--The St. Peter Free Press of the 23d inst. has later intelligence from the Sioux Agency. The sioux Indians have given up the Indian who stabbed the soldier, and he is now a prisoner in the Fort. Should the soldier die, the Indian will be summarily shot.

THREE EUROPEAN STEMERS IN A DAY.--The steamships Atlantic, Vanderbilt, and Harmonia all sailed for Europe on Saturday at noon, each with a large number of passengers and a good freight list--the Atlantic for Liverpool, the Vanderbilt for Havre, and the Harmonia for Hamburg. Among the passengers by the Atlatic were Governor JOSHEPH A. WRIGHT,

We publish in another part of this morning's issue London and Paris correspondence, and copious extracts from our foreign files by the Europa. The African slave-trade continues to occupy a large share of public attention in England, and two articles on the subject, one from the London Post, a ministerial print.

CAIRO. The romance of Eastern life has long since ceased. The veiled women still haunt the streets, and you may dream as you please of the hidden beauties that no one may see; but some accident twill expose the face of the woman whose dark eyes have enthralled you, and lo ! she is hideous.

From the New Orleans Picayune. The mails of the steamship Texas, Captain FORBES, from Vera Cruz the 21st inst., reached us last evening. By this arrival we have papers from Vera Cruz to the 21st, from the City of Mexico to the 17th inst., fourteen days later. The election for President of the Republic, under the new Constitution, took place on Monday, the 13th inst.

STORY OF A FISH AND OF A SKULL.--A most singular incident occurred in Burrell township a short ??, which is worthy of notice. Two sons of Mr. JOHN H. JSITT were in the habit of setting "night-lines" in the Allegheny river, in order to become possessed of the finny tribe. One morning a very mysterious looking thing was observed from the short, as being attached to one of the lines out some distance.

From the Baltimore Patriot of July 30. Much interest was elicited this morning, at the auction-rooms of S. H. GOVER Co., by the sate of the cane and spy-glass that belonged to Gen. GEORGE WASHINGTON. A large and inteligent ?? was present, to whom the elequent speaker, Mr. GOVER, gave a history of the relics,

Before Judge Ingrsham. The Mayor, , vs. Daniel Conover and others.--The application to restrain, by a perpetual injunction, Mr. Conover from using or removing the books and papers belonging to the Street Commissioner's Office, came up for further argument on Saturday morning at 11 o'clock.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.-The Academy of Music vill not reopen to-night, as at first announced. Difficulties between the management and the orchestra occasioned a postponement until Thursday, when the "Choral Opera" will be produced, with all the necessary appliances for comfort and elegant enjoyment.

DROWNED WHILE BATHING.--A number of young men wen in to bathe on Sunday evening, at the foot of King-street, North River. After the part had swam about some time, they missed one of their number, ---MOGINNISS, aged 20 years. They sought for him in all directions, but could not find him.

All diplomatic action in reference to pending difficulties has been suspended until the return of the President. Judge BOWLIN, late Minister to New-Granada, will remain here until the affairs of that Republic are finally settled.

FORTUNATE ESCAPE.-- Yesterday afternoon at about 5 o' clock; as a woman named ELLEN CASEY was taking some clothes off a line from the top of house No. 156 Charles-street, she over-reached herself, and was precipitated into the adjacent vacant block from a height of 37 feet.

The adjourned meeting of the citizens of the Fifth and Eighth Wards convened for the purpose of perfecting the organization of a Committee of Safety, was called to order by Mr. JAMES L. WAUGH, the Chairman, at the Fifth Ward Hotel, last evening.

A NICE DISTINCTION.--The Richmond Enquirer claims for Virginia the character and position of a conservative peace-maker, standing politically and geographically midway between the extremists of the North and the South, and serving as a barrier to prevent a hostile meeting of the two belligerent forces.

The Board of Supervisors. VALUE OF REAL AND PERSONAL ESTATE IN NEW YORK MESSAGE FROM THE MAYOR. The Board of Supervisors met yesterday afternoon, President STEERS in the Chair. The following communication was received from the mayor, and ordered to be printed in the minutes: NEW-YORK, July 30, 1857.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: A Correspondent signing himself "C," complains of the delay in getting his goods after duties being paid fifteen days. We beg to state our grievance of the same nature. The bark Whistling Wind, from Rotterdam, with wines, for us, arrived June 4, 1857. These goods were most all sold to arrive,

Attention Aliens! Gentle Summer murmurs whisper in my ears that JAMES W. GERARD, Judge CLERKE, Judge RUSSELL, Fire-Marshal BAKER, Hatter GENIN, Captain LEONARD, DICKEY BUSTEED, DICKEY CONNOLLY, GEORGAY PURSER, Mayor HARPER, Col. FREMONT, and President BUCHANAN, are natives of British and Irish soil, and have never been naturalized.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: SIR: Accept my thanks for the space which you have courteously afforded to my replies to "Englishman" and "Anglo-Saxon." A new Saxe-Gotha champion appears, who heads his letter "Saxon and Colt."

RATHRONE--In this City, o Monday morning Aug. 3. CAROLINE A., wife of A. II. Rathoone, aged 20 years. The restives and friends of the family ?? respectfully invited to attend her funeral, this (Tuesday) afternoon, at 3 o'clock, from her late residence, No. 122 West 25th-st.

The Moniteur is in fault if I return again to the Subject of the French election. It appears that the Emperor was not only astonished,but highly displeased at the result, after the Minister of Interior had promised a totally different one;

The Police Commissioners met again yesterday, and after voting 172 times, adjourned without effecting a choice of Commissioner in place of Mr. DRAPER. Messrs. BOWEN, NYE and STRANAHAN cast their votes, as on Saturday, for CYRUS CURNIS. Mayors WOOD and POWELL changed their votes from ROYAL PHELPS to DAVID BANKS, and Mr. CHOLWELL charged his from DANIEL ULLMAN to ERASTUS BROOKS.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Now that our Police force are being organized with a view to be of some benefit to the inhabitants of this crime-ridden Metropolis, would it not be a good idea to adopt a feature of the Philadelphia Police system, and that is, the policemen wear their badge at all times, whether on active duty or not except in cases where they are on detective duty.

ANOTHER FIRE IN ST. LOUIS.--About 10 o'clock last night a fire broke out on Second street east side, between Vine and Locust. The scene of disaster was the extensive Scale and Safe Manufactory and Hydrostatic Works of Messrs. BEARD BRO., situated between the Frederick House and LONGUEMORE and HALBER'S Wine and Liquor Store.

A correspondent writes us, that through the instrumentality of Hon. H. M. RICE, late Delegate to Congress from Minnesota, all the public lands in that Territory have been withdrawn from settlement by preemption for four months, in order to enable private corporations to locate the best lands for railroad purpnoes.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: It is known to those who are obliged to use the New-Haven Railroad that the depot has been removed from Canal-street to Twenty-seventh-street, and that no provision has been made to transport passengers through the City.

RAPID RISE IN FORTIFICATION LANDS.--In the Appropriation Bill of the last session of Congress, $150,000 was set apart with which to commence building a fortification on or near a promontory called Wilkins' Point, on Long Island, opposite Throg's Neck.

The great Prize-Fight for $1,000 a side, between BRADLEY AND RANKING, of Philadelphia, of which re sporting papers have had 50 much to say, came off at Fort Albin, (Canada,) a few miles from Buffalo, on Saturday last. The betting on the ground was at $100 to %50 on BRADLEY, the heaviest and better known of the combatants.

The terinnial festival of the Westfield Normal Association has attracted many strangers to our town yesterday and to-day. The graduates of this school, which was originally opened at Barre, are perhaps other of the associate Normal institutions of the State, and they cherish its interests and its memory with a kindly enthusiasm which brings them together in great numbers on the occasions of this festival.

A HOP AT BATH.--A pleasant affair came off at the Bath Hotel, Sea Side, L. I. on Saturday night. The guests of the house, who are visiting Bath equally for health and enjoyment, thinking doubtless that they would advance more rapidly on the road to the latter by a series of "hops," determined during the week to india'e their Terpsichorean entertainments at its close. Some facts have come to my knowledge recently which should be presented to the public for their perusal, that they may understand the operation of the "patent thrust" game, by which honest faithful and capable public servants are sometimes pushed out of official position, in order that private schemes, which they refuse to countenance, may be promoted at the expense of justice and the public good.

On the morning of the 9th of June last; between 1 and 2 o'clock, a fire broke out in a small frame dwelling situated in Fifty-third street near the Feathavenue, owned, and occupied on the upper floors at that time, by one James Shepherd and wife; the lower floor was occupied by an old German named Christian Geyer. The promises ware very soon consumed.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: I see it stated in your agricultural reports that large portions of the Winter wheat in Illinois was killed out. Though the Winter was as severe or more so here than in that State, the Winter wheat came up in fine condition in the Spring, and is now nearly ripe, heating promise of an abundant crop.

The Washington correspondent of The Press, Colonel FORNEY's new paper, says that "there can be little doubt that the erection of a new Presidential mansion will be one of the measures that will receive the favorable action of the next Congress."

There have been no arrivals of vessels form lokly ports The Hesperus has been permitted to one up and discharge. There was quite a row on Saturday night among he stevedores, who being debarred from visiting their homes while employed upon vessels in Quarantine, look up their lodgings in the empty hospital buildings, as the next most desirable form of relief ?? their confinement on shipboard, to spend the Sabbath.

The Police Commissioners met at their office in White-street, at 10 o'clock yesterday morning. Every member was in his seat at the appointed hour. Commissioner NYE occupied the Chair, and called ?? meeting to order. The reading of the minutes of the previous meeting were dispensed with.

The body of ALFRED S. MOSES, the unfortunate man murdered at the Sea View House, by JAMES P DONNELLY, the bookkeeper of that hotel, was buried on Sunday morning, before daylight, at Chapel Hid Churchyard, five miles from the Highlands. Even at that unusual hour, a large crowd attended, including the relatives of the deceased in carriages.

The astonishing growth of Central Wisconsin, embraoing the Lake Winnebago country and its tributaries, including Fox (or Neenah) and Wolf Rivers, together with Wisconsin River, almost exceeds belief, having, within the short period of ten years, sprung into importance, this section of the State being now in the most flourishing condition.

To The Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Being in the vicinity of the residence of Rev. ISAAC PECK, and feeling some interest in the discussion of the question of authorship, now oscillating between the brows of Miss SARAH PACs and WILLIAM ALLAN BUILER, I have been at the trouble of writing out some information which may be additional to that now in the possession of your readers.

FATAL ACCIDENT,--PHILIP CARR, residing at the corner of Van Brunt and Carroll Streets, met with an accident on Sunday afternoon, which caused his immediate death. He fell from the fourth s ory of the house , No. 16 Summit-street.

THE GREAT McFLIMSEY CONTROVERSY.-The question of Miss Flora McFlimsey's paterpity is still enveloped in mystery. There are two parties who take opposite sides in the great controversy , one being vehement for the claims of Mr. BUTLER, while the other gallantly defend the claims of Miss PECK.

About one hundred importers met, yesterday, at 2 P. M., at the Exchange, pursuant to a call, to de vise some means to obviate the present delay and an noyance to which they say they are obliged to submit in obtaining their goods from the Custom-House. ? Mr. CHARLES KEDTGEN called the meeting to order. and moved the appointment of JOHN H. BROWN, Esq., as chairman.

About 11 1/2 o'clock on Saturday night a difficulty occurred at the house of DANIEL MOODY on Gas street, near Harrison. between LEWIS and JOHN SHERMAN and THOMAS CONNERY, in which the last names was severely cut with a large carving knife.

POISONING IN LOUISVILLE,--We have mad several slight allusions to a poisoning case, in the upper part of the city, but have refrained form particularities, with a knowledge that a full investigation of the case would be made by the Coroner. The testimony before the Coroner's July, summoned to hold an inquest upon the body of the late Mrs. JOHN COMSTOCK, was closed yesterday, and the Jury returned a verdict of death by poison.

On Saturday last, about three o'clock, the officers of the State Prison at Sing Sing missed a convict named JAMES KING, who was or should have been at work in the cooper slop, at the north end of the prison grounds, Immediate search was made for him, and, somewhat earlier than usual, the remainder of the men were called from work and locked up.

Messrs. LIBBY WHITNEY. proprietors of Lovejoy's Hotel, obtained a decree on Friday against two persons calling themselves STEPHEN LOVEJOY and PATRICK M. FALLON, who claimed to be the lessees or proprietors of a public house at No. 160 Greenwich street, know as the "Lovejoy House."

From the St. Louis Republican, July 81. The neighborhood of Second and Green streets, was thrown into great excitement yesterday morning, by the sudden falling of the front part of the two upper floors of Messrs. MONKS GHIO'S liquor and cigar store. casualty occurred at 11 1/4 o'clock, while these connected with the establishement.

THE POLICE COMMISSIONER.--There was a slight change of performances at the Office of the Police Commissioners yesterday, the two Mayors having dropped Mr. PHELPS and taken up Mr. DAVID BANKS, and Mr. CHOLWELL having substituted Mr. ERASTUS BROOKS for Mr. ULLMANN. The three Republican Commissioners stuck to Mr. CURTIS.

THE CUSTOM HOUSE--No new removals were made at the Custom-House yesterday. The axe is suspended yet over the necks of a host of Inspectors. The casual reader might have concluded, from the way it read in our paper of yesterday, that the list of the fifty night-watchman were new appointees. This is wrong.

An interesting case of Usury, made interesting to the mercantile community from its peculiar circumstances, was decided lately by Judge Hoffman, in the Superior Count. The facts were as follows: The parties who set up the ?? of ??,were Wm. Mootry, (who had his name altered by law. to MOULTRIE.) it lawyer, having his office at the corner of William and Pine-streets, and Thomas palmer, now Secretary of the East River Insurance company, Wall-street.

The lovers of the romance of crime were yesterday evening gratified with a new chapter of the Burdell history, which reflects a lurid light upon all the past of that dismal mystery, without however clearing up either its origin, its mainspring, or its progress.

STILL ANOTHER MURDER IN PITTSBURG.--Between 6 and 7 o'clock on Friday evening, our city was the scene of another homicide, to add to the long list which has disgraced our annals within a few years. Murder, certainly, in this vicinity. appears to be assuming the features of an epidemnic. We will attempt to give a synopsis of the facts connected with this latest tragedy, leaving conclusions to our readers.

THE THREE DIS-GRACES OF THE BOARD OF POLICE COMISSIONERS.--Whatever doubt there may have been heretofore respecting the intention of the two Mayors and Mr. CHOLWELL, in the Board of Police Commissioners, it is very evident, from their conduct yesterday, that they were banded together to defeat any action of the Board in which they cannot have a controlling influence.

London Money Market. London CONSOLS closed on Tuesday at 91 7/8@92 for Money and 93 for account. Liverpool Cotton Market. LIVERPOOL, Tuesday. At our Cotton Market to-day, which was very firm, the sales were 10,000 bales, 1,500 being on speculation and for export. The following transactions took place; 2,000 bales Surats at 5 1/8d@6 1/4d. 600 Egyptians at 10 1/2 d.@11 1/4d.; 566 Brazils at 8 1/2d.@9 5/8d. and 6,900 American at 6d.@9 3/4d.

From the National Inteligencer. I have just seen a letter addressed to you by Gen. WOOL, from Troy, New York, on the 16th of this month. Respect for the General's position requires me to notice some of the statements of this letter, though pity for an old public servant, whose memory, age and disease have impaired, might urge me to pass it unnoticed.

Some time since it was stated in the English papers, that a clerk of the South Yorkshire Railway and River Don Coal Company, England, who carry on business in King William-street, London, had plundered his employers of about ??900, and fled.

WINDMILL SHIPS.--The Diario de la Marina sates that Signor CARDIA, of Cuba, proposes a new system of propelling vessels by the building of windmills on the decks of his ship, with great wings, from which the motion is communicated to side-wheels similar to those of steamships.

Texas advices, received by telegraph from New-Orleans, make the startling announcement that Hon. THOMAS J. RUSK, United States Senator from that State, committed suicide on the 29th ult., by shooting himself through the head with a rifle. No cause is assigned forth act, Positive as is this

I. O. OF O. F.--The annual session of the R. W. Grand Encampment of Southern New York, was held Monday at its rooms in Odd Fellows' Hall, in this City. The following officers were elected and installed: P. C. P. Theodore Fremont, of No. 20, G. P. P. C. P. John Cook, of No. 1, H. P. P. C. P. William Murphy, of No. 20, G. S. W.

From the Detroit Free Press. A shocking occurrence took place on the Hamtramck Marshes on last Tuesday, in which a boy eleven years old was actually eaten up alive by a bear, within sight of the city. The circumstances of the case are as follows: A man named JOSEPH RADEMACHER a German, living on Macomb-street, between Rivard and Russell, went out on Tuesday morning, in company with a little brother.

Capt. BLAKE has received preparatory orders to relieve Capt GOLDSBOROUGH, on the 15th of September, as Superintendent of the Naval Academy at Annapolis. Capt. CLUNEY has received preparatory orders to succeed Capt BLAKE in the Superintendency of the construction of the Stevens' war steamer at New-York.

The era of peace and quiet which Kansas has experienced since the cessation of actual hostilities last Winter is now said by men who are not regarded as alarmists, to be rapidly drawing to a close. It is undeniably true that during the past few weeks party hostility has received a violent impetus. The following order has been issued by General LANE:

Signor GUIDI, the well-known Italian tenor singer, formerly a resident of Boston, and more lately of New-York, Springfield, New-Haven, and Chicago, died a few days ago, in Albany, of consumption, and in poverty. He leaves a wife (a Boston lady) and several children.

LEVERIDGE --In this City, on Sunday, Aug. 2. Suddenly, MARY LAVINIA daughter of Benjamin C. and Lueretia F. Leveridge, in the 6th year of her age. The Friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend her funeral, from the residence of her uncle, J. W. C Leveridge, No. 11 Rutgers place, on Wednesday after ucon, at 2 O'clock.

The Board of Governors met at the Refunds on Tuesday, the President in the Chair. When the requisition for twenty ?? gallons of brandy for the patients at Sallevue Hospital was read by the Clerk, a discussion arose among the members of the Board to the propriety of the quantity being reduced to ten gallons. Governor SMITH strongly urged the ??, while Governor MOLONY opposed it.

From the Philadelphia Sun, 4th. On Tuesday evening DOMINICK BRADLBY arrived at his don of iniquity, at the southwest corner of South and Penn streets, and soon after an immense crowd of ruffians assembled about the place. A fellow named MURPHY, said to be a waiter in the Girard House, made himself very conspicuous in the window, and introduced DOMINICK.

THE VIGILANCE COMMITTEE MOVEMENT.-Some of our cotemporaries appear to be considerably alarmed at the formation of Vigilance Committees for the protection of their property and lives by the citizens of two of our Wards. But a Vigilance Committee, per se, is not necessarily an affair from which any evil consequences are to be apprehended, but just the reverse.

THE LATE U.S. DEPUTY SURVEYOR.-- A CURIOUS CHAPTER IN THE HISTORY OF THE CUSTOM HOUSE.--JAMES WRITING, who for the past four years has held the office of Deputy Surveyor at the Boston Custom House, gave up his trust Saturday, according to the terms of his resignation, placed in the bands of his superior. FLETCHER WEBSTER, U.S. Surveyor, a month or two since.

During the past two months, a gentleman connected with the Agricultural Department of the TIMES, has made an extensive tour through the Western States, embracing a journey of some six thousand miles, for the purpose of observing the general condition of agriculture, and especially the prospects of the incoming harvest.

THE COMMISSIONER OF PATENTS.--The employees of the Patent Office Bureau, of all degrees, have united in a letter to Mr. Commissioner MASON, its head, tendering the expression of their regret that he has resigned. Though brief, their address is characterized by much feeling, and is expressed in very appropriate language.

Insects are busy at this season of the year, and the fruit grower should be busy in trapping them. It is a good plan to put a strip of board across an open vessel of water, four or five feet across, and set a lantern lighted upon the board at evening. The insects seeing the light, will crowd around it, and aligut in the water.

On Saturday last, a man by the name of BAUGH, in a quarrel with a negro, who was working with him in a harvest field, near Chester Springs, in Chester County., at abbed the negro with a pitchfork. A. Constable in the neighborhood attempted to arrested him, but from the resistance offered by BAUGH thought it prudent not to do so.

It is surprising to see how little faith farmers in the East have in the productiveness of their own business, and how much more ready they are to invest capital in the enterprises of others, rather than n their own. If a new bank wants capital they are ready to furnish any surplus they may have for the stock.

THE CAPITAL AT WASHINGTON.--It is not generally realized by our citizens that the eastern side of the Capital is the principal front, and that the western side is in fact the rear. The main entrance to the centre building is from the eastern front: and so will be the entrances of the new wings, The principal statuary of the centre building is on the eastern front: and so will be that of the new wings.

DEATH OF A NOTORIOUS MAIL ROBBER.-BYRON STUART McDONALD, the mail robber, died, on Friday morning last, in the State Penitentiary, very suddenly, in a fit, "Lord Byron," as he was styled, was a printer, and used to traverse the country, subsisting by imposition and crime.

DESCENT UPON A FARO BANK AT NEWBURYPORT,--A Newburyport correspondent of the Boston Traveller gives the particulars of a descent upon a gambling institution in that city on Saturday night: "Marshal WESCOTT and Constable WELCH, of Newburyport, on Saturday night last, paid a visit to the banking institution kept at the "Mechanics' Saloon,: on Pleasant-street, opposite the Bartlett Mills. dg.

PALL OF ROCK NEAR THE HORSESHOE-THERE PERSONS INJURED. The Rochester American of Monday gives the following particulars of the fall of rock at Niagara, previously reported by telegraph: "An accident of a serious character occurred at Niagara Falls yesterday afternoon about 4 o'clock.

From the Boston Transcript. Nearly a year ago, a clergyman was stationed over an Episcopal society in one of the most flourishing towns in Massachusetts. His reputation for ability and eloquence had preceded him, and the expectations of those who had not listened to his efforts in the metropolis, where he had been preaching, were raised to the highest pitch.

The entire month of July passed away without the Board of Councilmen having taken any final action upon the specifications which have already been adopted by the Board of Aldermen in relation to cleaning the streets of the City.

We have another arrival from Mormondom. An emigrant train, containing a large number of women and children--one hundred persons in all--has just reached this city, after a wearisome journey of sixty days. The train consisted of fifteen teams, and brought through a large and valuable collection of beaver and buffalo furs.

The United States steam frigate Reanoke arrived here from Aspinwalt yesterday morning, bringing with here 204 men who had formed a part 9 WALKER'S unfortunate Nicaraguan army, When the men reached Aspinwall, where they had good fortune to be taken on board the R?/ by Captain MONTGOMERY, they were in the most deplorable condition.

The public were quite startled yesterday by the announcement that Mrs. CUNNINGHAM, alias BURDELI, had been rearrested. On this occasion she was not charged with murder, but with feigning the birth of a child under the following circumstances: For some time Mrs. CUNNINGHAM has given out to the world that early inAugust she expected to be delivered of a child-the fruit of her union with the late Dr. HARVEY BURDELL.

About 6 o'clock on Saturday evening last, our citizens were startled by the simultaneous sounding of the steam whistle at the Rolling Mill and the Company's Furnaces, in such a way as to betoken that danger was threatening the Works. At the same time a dense cloud of black smoke was seen to ascend from that locality, which gave additional force to the alarm.

From the Cincinnati Times. A Veteran pauper, sunburnt, disheveled: unwasned and filthy, whose only name was ALMER, was examined in the Probate count in this city yesterday, as to his mental condition, He stated he was a native Kentuckian; that a man around whose house he lorered put-him in a skiff and oarried him to a steamboat, which brought, him to the city to stay "a spell."

The bogus Burdell Baby was as much a matter of interest yesterday as the day before. Mrs. CUNNINGHAM, still a prisoner at her house No. 31 Bond street, kept up the sham with groans and cries, as if really she was suffering the after-pains of childbirth.
THE POLICE COMMISSIONERS.--The various coincidences which have hitherto marked the movements of the two Mayors and Commissioner CHOLWELL yesterday came to a climax by their union upon a vote.

STREET COMMISSIONER DEVLIN DISCHARGED. -Judge INGRAHAM has discharged Mr. DEVLIN from the imprisonment upon paper which for a fortnight past he has "suffered." His opinion is very long, but its rhetoric and legal statements are more creditable than were those of Judge RUSSELL, who led the way in discharges of prisoners committed by other magistrates.

COURT OF COMMON PLEAS-CHAMBERS, Before Judge Ingraham. In the matter of CHARLES DEVLIN on habeas corpus.--Judge INGRAHAM delivered his opinion in the above case yesterday morning, in which he discussed the whole subject of the Street Commissioner controversy.

A disastrous gale on the 226 of July caused ?? of life among the fisherman, on the north shore of the Province of New-Brunswick. The Miamichi Gleaner, of that date learns that sixty boats have been lost, supposed to be owned by parties living between Negune and ??, and that fifty one dead bodied have been picked up between these two places.

A shocking affair occurred in Clarkson yesterday. A Mrs. MARSHALL, who has been for some time damaged, being left alone for a time yesterday noon with her children, attempted to murder three of them by pouring hot water into their ears. One is a boy 7 years old, who after the attempt was made upon his life made almost superhuman efforts to escape, and was fortunately successful.

PITCER.--A gentleman who was on board the steamer Long Branch, and saw the accident of the drowning of Mr. EDWIN PITCHER, on Monday last, contradicts most positively the charge of neglect on the part of the officers, which have been published in connection with that circumstance. Mr. PITCHER was sitting upon the rail,

The Cunningham excitement has not abated one jet. In Bond-street yesterday, if the police in attendance had not been vigilant, a large crowd.--to all appearance as large as at the time of the Connery Inquest,--would have collected.

Dinner to Hon. Henry C. Murphy. A personal testimonial was last night given Hon. HENRY C. MURPHY of Brooklyn on the occasion of his going out as our representative to the Hague, of a very creditable character to that gentleman. It was a dinner by the leading citizens of Kings County, the greater or part of whom were his political opponents. The festival took place at the Mansion House.

A shocking affray occurred at Cold Spring on Tuesday last, between two men named MICHAEL TALLEN and JOHN McKEAREN, which will result in the death of the latter. It appears that TALLEN (who is a member of the Engineers' Company at West Point) married a sister of McKEAREN'S, TALLEN and his wife, report says, have both been shamefully used by the brother.

RATE OF TAXATION. The Board of Supervisors met yesterday afternoon, Supervisor MONAGHAN in the Casir. There was some debate on the report on the Tax Lavy, occasioned by a motion to add $100,000 to the reported tax levy, which was reported.

ITALIAN OPERA.--Mr. ULLMAN, the enterprising lessee of the Academy of Music for the coming season, was among the passengers by the Persia. He announces that Mme. FREZZOLINI will arrive here in about a week, and that on the 1st of September the new season will open at the Academy.

Rumor has gained currency within a few days that British agents are quietly engaged in the business of enlisting soldiers in this country for the purpose of replenishing the ranks of their army in India, the late defection among the native troops having rendered it necessary to increase their forces in that country with a more loyal class of soldiers.

Lord NAPIER has held frequent interviews recently with Gen. CASS, upon the subject of Central American Affairs, and there seems to be a probability of some arrangement at an early day for the final and satisfactory disposition of the Bay Islands question, and Mosquito Protectorate.

The Royal Mail Steamship Persia, Capt. JUDKINS, from Liverpool, about 11 1/2 o'clock A. M., on Saturday the 25th of July, arrived at this port yesterday morning, The steamship Ericsson sailed from Liverpool for New-York on Wednesday the 22d July. The steamer City of Baltimore, arrived at Liverpool at 5 o'clock on the afternoon of the 21st.

Tragedies are crowding upon us. About 1 o'clock yesterday morning, the grocery and dwelling No. 72 West Eighteenth street was entered by two burglars, who proceeded to a room occupied by Mr. ALEXANDER BOYD, brother of the proprietor of the grocery, and attempted to light a match.

One of the most stupendous bubbles blown in modern times, was the accessory Transit Company of Nicaragua. When its surface seemed fairest, and its inflation was proceeding with the greatest success, this journal did ot fail to caution its readers against the explosion sure to come.

The Police Commissioners assembled at their headquarters at 10 o'clock yesterday morning. They were all present. Mr. CHOLWELL, on taking his seat said, by way of explanation, that he was absent on Tuesday, because he understood that when an adjournment was made the previous day that no business was to be does until Wednesday--that the Commissioners would simply meet, and then adjourn over the trial of Deputy CARPENTER.

WEEKS--In this City, on Fourth Day night, 5th of 8th month, at his residence, No. 169 East 13th st., JESSE K. WEEKS, aged 66 years and 11 days. His relatives and friends, and those of his sons, Daniel S. Moses H. and James Edward, and son in law, Aaron Carpenter are respectfully invited to attend his funeral, from Friends' Meeting House, Hester st., on Sixth Day, (Friday) afternoon, at 2 o'clock.

The Le Sere Tehuantepec Company reject the Sloo grant as their basis, and await a new treaty, independent of that. Mexico will no doubt agree to the propositions which Senator BENJAMIN took our for Mr. FOBSYTH, and this will invoke the repudiation of the Sloo grant by Mexico.

The official returns from St. Louis County give ROLLINS a majority of 1.848, being a gain of 546 on FILLMORE'S vote. In Cape Girardeau County ROLLINS' majority is about 100; in Morgan Count STEWART'S is 98; and in Lincoln County 309.

Advices from Leavenworth, Kansas, state that much excitement exists there growing out of the robbery and murder of a man named STEPHENS. tow men, named BAINES and QUARLES, were arrested charged with the murder and their confessions disclosed the existence of a regularly organized band of robbers and murders.

The Democratic State Convention met here to-day, and nominated R. B. PAYNE for Governor, W. H. LYTTLE for Lieutenant-Governor Mr. WHITMAN for Judge of the Supreme Court, Mr. MORRIS for State Treasurer, J. REINHART for Secretary of State, and A. L. BACKUS for Superintendent of the Board of Public Works.

A TEN STRIKE FOR TAX-PAYERS. -Deputy Sheriff VULTEE, with his accustomed suavity, yesterday levied upon certain City property to answer an execution against the Mayor, Aldermen and Commonalty, on a judgment of one hundred and ninety-nine thousand and two dollars.

ASSAULT UPON AN EDITOR.--THE ASSAULTER DANGEROUSLY STABBED.--The editor of the Lowell Trumpet, a small weekly paper. having recently, says a correspondent of the Boston Herald, inserted an article attacking the widowed sister of Mr. WM. WAUGH, Slater, of that city, Mr. WAUGH undertook to personally chastise the editor at his office.

The Standing Committee of the Association for the Promotion of Education, to day reported the following officers for the ensuing year: President- Ho. L. B. WOODWORTH, of New-York. Secretary- R. L. COOK of New-jersey. Treasurer- JNO. WHITEHEAD, OF New-Jersey.

WESLEYAN UNIVERSITY--RESIGNATION OF DR. SMITH, AND ELECTION OR REY. DR. CUMMINGS.--At the annual meeting of the Trustees and visitors of the Wesleyan University, at Middletown, Conn., on Thursday evening, Dr. A. W. SMITH, LL.D., tendered his resignation, his health not being adequate to the onerous duties of the office of President.

AN INTERESTING MASONIC BIBLE.--The Freemasons of the 46th British Regiment, now stationed at Windsor, England, have in their possession the original Bible belonging to Lodge No. 227 of the Irish Constitution, once in existence in that Corps, upon which GEORGE WASHINGTON--afterward Commander-in-Chief of the army of he United States--was initiated into the rites of Freemasonry.

MurphyEminently fitted by education, ability and experience in public affairs for the high duties with which he is intrusted, he carries with him upon I is honorable mission to a foreign Court equally the merited confidence of the Government and the affectionate regards of his fellow-citizens."

The office of the American Express company, in this city was entered last night, and one of the satisfied on its contents, to the amount of from $3,000 to $10,000. The office is ?? in the Kendall buildings, on the corner of Main and Sixth streets, Mr. 'TOUZALAN, the Agent, was in the office until 11 o'clock in the evening, and left everything secure.

THE ARREST OF COUNTERFEITES IN INDIANA.-Some days since a statement was made of the arrest in Indiana, of a number of counterfeiters, said to be holding elevated positions in society, and of great consequent excitement thereupon in the State. Nothing further has been heard from there as yet, although "astounding developments" were expected and talked of.

The Committee appointed to decide upon the evidence adduced as to who is the most fitting person to receive the gold box bequeathed by General JACKSON, have determined that it shall be given to Lieutenant-Colonel GARRETT W. DYCKMAN, formerly Captain of Company K. and subsequently Major of the New-York Volunteers.

Binghamton is overflowing with teachers. Trains come in from the East, West, North and South heavily freighted with the elect of the schools; and judging from appearances, one would say that the schoolmaster was abroad in every other part of the State and only at home here.

Information of a favorable nature has been received from the friendly Little Crow Indians, who were sent to take INK-PU-DU-TAH'S band of murderers. They were at the latest dates at Hole in the Wall Mountain, expecting to find the outlaws at Skunk Lake, and confident of the success of the Expedition.

ASHES--Are in moderate demand, at steady rates Pearle, $7 12/2 @7 25: pots, $7 75@$7 81 1/2 $100 lbs. BOOTS AND SHOES----The demand is pretty brisk, coming mainly, from Southwestern dealers. Stocks are fair, and factors are fire sellers, though there is no anticipation of depression in prices, in view of the high rates which hides and leather are bringing.

LOST RAILROAD TICKETS.-The Court of Cuyahoga County has recently decided that a passenger who loses his ticket cannot require a Railroad Company to pass him over their road without purchasing another. The ground for the decision is that the ticket being negotiable by delivery, any one picking up the lost ticket could ride upon it,and hence the Company would be subjected to frequent impositions.

LERDA TEJADA, of Mexico, accompanied by his works on monetary and commercial statistics and the history of Vera Cruz, the latter containing fine portraits of COLUMBUS and CORTES.

A destructive fire broke out this morning a o'clock in the store of G. T. CALDWELS, St. Anthony street, and before the flames could be extinguished the entire square, with the exception of the First Presbyterian Church, was consumed,

The Board of Police commissioners met again yesterday morning, all the members present. As soon as the minutes of the previous meeting had been read, the Board took up the regular order of the day-the election of a Commissioner to fill the vacancy.

Senator SEWARD was seized for a debt of something over two hundred dollar. While in the Gover?? in the City Hall yesterday, by the authorities of the County, and soon afterwards "Oid HAYS," the celebrated and highly respected thief-catcher, was pounced upon by a constable, taken away and incarcerated in an auction store, notwithstaoaing the many appeals on his behalf.

There is a town in Massachusetts called Westfield. This is a piece of intelligence for which we expect our readers to be grateful, for, we venture to say, there is not one in ten of them ever heard it before. Yet, it is a pleasant town this of Westfield.

From the Albany Evening Journal, A man named CARL HAUSS, while felling tress at knowlton's Mills, on the Berlin Mountain, Rensseleer County, came to his death as follows: He Proceeded to the woods, and, as was shown by the testimony upon the inquest, felled one tree, which shipped clean.

Professor BARKER and Dr. DEWEES, arrived at No. 31 Bond-street, yesterday morning, at 10 o'clock, They immediately announced themselves and the object of their visit, and were shown up to Mrs. CUNNIGHAM, whom they found in bed in the front room on the second floor, and apparently in great suffering.

To the Editor of the New-York Dailt Times: I inclose you, by to-day's mail, the "Friend of China and Hong Kong Gazette," of the 9th inst., in which you will see a comment upon an article taken from your paper.

The Kansas Herald of Freedom, of the 3d inst., states that Gov. WALKER had received advices from the Commandant of Fort Really, that a large force of Cheyenne Indians had rescued that station, and that an attack was hourly expected. The fort has no fortifications, and is garrisoned by only half a company of infantry.

CHURCH RECOGNITION.--An Ecclesiastical Council convened, on Thursday afternoon, in the Seminary Chapel, at Bergen, for the purpose of formally recognizing the First Baptist Church, recently organized in Hudson City.

According to the telegraphic dispatches, the Democrats have made a pretty clean sweep in Kentucky, having elected eight certain and prob ably nine of the ten Congressmen, a majority the Legislature and a State Treasurer, the latter by some 8,000 or 10,000 majority.

A very serious accident occurred on the Wilmington and Weldon Railroad yesterday afternoon, by which several persons were more or less injuredone or two, it is thought, mortally. POLYGLOT BIBLRS.-The Journal of Sared Literature, in publishing an historical account of the various Polyglot Bibles now in existence, characterizes the London Polyglot as the most complete of them all. It was commenced in 1653, and published in 1657, in six folio volumes, edited by Bishop WALTON, with the aid of POCOOK, LIGHTFOOT, SAMUEL CLARX, and other learned Englishmen.

In the portions of the State through which I have traveled, little or no interest seems to be manifested in the forthcoming Southern Commercial Convention to assemble at Kuoxville, Tennessee. The farcical character of all previous assemblages of this sort has begat an utter indifference with respect to it.

The Cunningham Baby excitement yesterday, was a little allayed, in the absence of new facts, touching the marriage, the murder and the birth. In a few days.--perhaps in a day or two--some new developments will starile the public quite as much as did the advent of the baby.

HORRID NEGRO MURDERS IN ST. LOUIS.--Another murderous atrocity transpired at St. Louis on the 3d inst., in which two, if not three, victims are included in a violent fate. The scene of the butchery was a negro dwelling on the east side of Tenth-street, inhabited by one JOHNSON, a free mulatto, and his wife and mother-in-law.

About 1 o'clock yesterday the residents of Griswold-street, between Harrison and Polk, were started by hearing a great noise and disturbance in the rear of a double frame house which stands a few feet back from the sidewalk. The house is occupied several German families of the poorer class.

Dr. PALMER, of Albany, preached a sermon, after which the communication service was held, the sacrament being administered by Professors PHELPS and STOWE.

The Board of Metropolitan Police Commissioners met yesterday morning, but not publicly nor formally. The matter of filling the vacancy in the Board was considered until after 1 o'clock, when they separated, without having united upon a candidate. They will meet again to day.

According to the decision of Judge INORAHAM upon the habeas corpus discharging Mr. DEVLIN, that gentleman, under his appointment from the City, is Street Commissioner, and unless some other judicial functionary be found to interpose, by injunction or ?? will, before many days, be duly installed and in full possession of the office, the diploma of his Excellency GOV. KING to the contrary notwithstanding.

SAVED FROM DROWNING.-While two young lads, both of them the sons of gentlemen doing business in New-York, were sailing la ely upon Mattetuck Creek, L. I, the boat took a flaw of wind, and was thrown so far over that both fell into the water. Both were good swimmers, but from being entangled, they were unable to recover their boat, which was soon swept out of their reach.

Mr. ALEXANDER BOYD, who was shot on Tuesday morning last, by two burglars, who had broken into his residence, at No. 12 West Eighteenth-street, died about 6 o'clock yesterday morning. ATTEMPT TO COMMIT SUICIDE.--As the ferryboat D. S. Gregory was entering the slip of the Jersey City ferry on the New-York side, at 21/2 o'clock yesterday afternoon, a man jumped overboard three hundred yards from the shore. He struck out, however, and swam with his might, keeping afloat until the ferry-boat Colden, which was coming out at the time picked him up. He did not give his name.

The house of CATARINE FORMAN, on Franklinstreet, was this morning the scene of one of the most bloody butcheries which has ever occurred in our city. The victim is a woman of half negro and half Indian blood, by the name of SUSAN BROWN, wife of WM. BROWN, a negro of the blackest die and of the very worst character.

RETURNED MORMONS.-The Council Bluffs Non pareil says that a company of returned Mormons are new encamped near that place, and that they intend to make the Bluffs their future home. They have tried the " Land of Promise," and found promises more plenty than deeds, or, at least, than good deeds.

From the Albany Argus, 6th. The Democratic State Committee is to meet at Congress Hall, in this city, to day, at 12 M. The following gentlemen constitute the Committee: First District--John Kelly, Peter B. Sweeney, New York.

They will not enter into a Convention respecting Tehuantepec, independently of Conventions on other subjects.

About 3 o'clock this afternoon the drying build ing connected with the Chadwick Patent Leather Manufacturing Company Works, took fire, and together with the adjoining building, containing the office and warerooms, was almost entirely consumed. The loss is estimated at $20,000, and is fully covered by insurance.

NATHAN NICOLS, of Walton, an inmate of the Delaware County Poor House, committed suicide earls Tuesday morning, by nanging himself with a cord thrown over a rafter, In a shed a little distance from the house. Mr. NIOHOLS was sent to the County House about a year ago, on account of his insanity.

STFAMBOAT EXCURSIONS AND ACCIIDENTS.The occurrence of two rather awkward mishaps to large pleasure parties in the vicinity of Hell Gate dur. ing the past week, who were upon steamboat excursions, will be likely to deter others from passing through that dangerous locality, except in good, reliable steamners.

A'NEGRO ASSAILING A WHITE MAN.--An atrocious attempt was made Sunday morning by a free negro named TOM LONG to assassinate E. B. KEEN, Esq., of Pittsylvania, a highly respected citizen and one of the Delegates elect to the Legislature. LONG, it seems, had formed a plan to take his wife and children who are slaves to a Free State.

No Subject is more frequently discussed here in political circles, at the present time, than, that relating to the abolition of privateering. It certainly is worthy of careful and deliberate consideration. The late Secretary MARCY succeeded, not without difficulty, in bringing the Administration to acquiescence in his proposition for its abolition.

LADIES' FIRE PROOF DRESSES.--Within a short time two young ladies have been but death, owing to light muslin dresses, catching from a lucifer match--one in London, the ?? Colchester. It ought to be generally known the ladies' light dresses may be made fire proof at a nominal cost, by steeping them, or the linen ?? used in making them, in a diluted solution chloride of zinc. .

THE POSITION OF DOCTOR UHL. IN THE CUNNINGHAM-BURDELL AFFAIR.-There appears to be considerable misapprehension in regard to the position of Dr. UIIL in the Burdell business. He has not been censured, that we are aware, for having disclosed the secret of his patient, but for having aided her to consummate her intended crimes, only to betray her.

ALEXANDER BOYD, who was murdered by burglars in the Sixteenth Ward last week, was buried in Greeewood yesterday afternoon. The funeral took place from the late residence of the deceased. No. 72 West Eighteenth-street. It was a very large one, and was attended by all classes of citizens. People began to assemble within and about the house as early as 12 o'clock.

The dates from Hong Kong were to the 10th of June. The Chinese fleet was destroyed by the British in two severe engagements. The Chinese fought their guns with unexampled constancy. The British had S3 men killed and wounded, Major KEARNEY being amongst the former.

The County Commissioners met on Tuesday last in the several counties to district them for the apportionment of representatives, In Suffolk County the Board of Aldermen of Boston are County Commissioners, and they did up their work very promptly, effecting it by a vote of ten to one. The county is divided into 13 Districts. The first 12 are composed of the 12 Boston Wards.

The telegraphic advices from Trieste in auticipation of the Overland Mail reached London on Tuesday night. The dates from Calcutta are to the 21st June; from Madras, 2S, and Bombay, lst July. The mutiny was spreading among the troops in the Bengal army.

About 21/2 o'clock on Sunday afternoon the large manufactory of JOHN CHADWICK Co., in Newark, N. J., was discovered to be on fire. The business eonducted there is chiefly the manufacture of patent leather and enameled cloth. The building is situated in Front street, and is four stories high, with frontage of about 180 feet.

A NOVEL CONSPIRACY CASE---ANNA MEIBTER CAROLIFE MULLER and CAROLINE WERNER were placed on trial, charged with conspiracy to obtain money and valuables from various persons, by deceitful and fraudulent practices. The evil practices consisted in representing that ANNA MEISTER was a prophetess from God. The Commonwealth alleges that the defendants, CALOLINE MUELLER and CAROLINE WERNER were the agents of ANNA MEISTER.

The developments of the last two days in the Burdell Baby Case, are not of great importance. Mrs. CUNNINGHAM still remains at No. 31 Bond-street, closely confined to her bed, the latter more from choice than from necessity. She is undoubtedly an invalid, suffering from cucumbers and chagrin, and to-day will as undoubtedly be able to move, if she is bailed, or compelled to move, if she is not.

STAMFORD, CONN, FEMALF SEMINARY.,-The annual examination at this institution took place the present week, commencing on Monday and ending on Wednesday, when its first graduating class received their diplomas. The various exercises afforded the most gratifying evidence both of thorough teaching and good scholarship.

Liverpool Cotton Market. The newspapers report the Cotton Market generally unchanged and steady. Messrs. RICHARDSON, SPENCE Co., however, reported advances of 1s 6d. The sales of the three days were 26,000 bales, of which 2,500 were on speculation and 2,500 for export.

NAVAL.-The trial of the Colorado's machinery at the Navy-Yard Wharf was concluded on Saturday. It was fairly and effectually tested, and proved itself to be in all its parts as perfect a specimen or a stean engine as it is possible to construct. It worked to the admiration of all who had charge of it, and they could not discover the slightest fault or blemish throughout.

VISIT OF GENTLEMAN FROM MASSACHUSETTS TO THE NEW-YORK INSTITUTIONS.--Several gentlemen connected with the Massachusetts State Almshouse at Tewkesbury, came to this City, on Friday, to visit the institutions under the management of the Board of Ten Governors. They had been to Hartford to see the Deaf and Dumb Asylum, and to New Haven o see the Almshouse and Orphan Asylum previous to their coming to New-York.

COUNTERFEITS.--Counterfeit tens on the Bank of Rhinebeck are now in circulation. The following is a description of the counterfeits: On the lower right hand side is a sailor standing by the windlass of a ship, the denomination ten dollars is all one style of letters--German Text, while the genuine has the word ten in full faced heavy letters, and the word dollars in German Text.

From the Trenton American. By the returns made up to the 1st of January of this year, we filed that the Railroad and canal, after paying all current expenses, and heavy losses growing out of the Burlington accident, and after paying interest on all outstanding bonds, and six percent on its capital block, were left with $219.848 60, as surplus for the preceding year, or more than 7 percent additional.

ANTE-REVOLUTIONARY MEMENTOS AT BELLEVUE HOSPITAL.-The vein attached to the cupola of Ecilevue Hospital was taken down on Saturday, to make some repairs to the cupola. This vane is the identical weathercock that used to ornament the top of the old Federal Hall, which stood on the site of the present Custom House. The date "1700" is on the vane.

ACCIDENT FROM FIRE-ARMS.--HENRY C. MERRITT, Esq., of Carmel, while out hunting on Saturday, was seriously injured by the discharge of his owagun. He was hunting near the town of Kent, Putnam County, and while passing through a thicket his gun was accidentally discharged, the contents striking the arm, tearing the flesh and blood versels in a shocking manner.

Since our last advices of the 4th instant, we have had an improving market for shares. The speculative Stocks have fluctuated considerably, while the more solid class of securities have remained heavy. All, however, show an advance upon the closing prices of last week. The market closes weak and inactive. State Stocks are firm and active.

PORTAGE LAKE MINES.--The mines of this district are attracting considerable attention just now among mining men, and strong hopes are entertained that they will prove vey productive. The result thus far has been satisfactory, and the people of that vicinity are making active preparations toward establishing more frequent and regular communication with the lower country than they have heretofore enjoyed.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: We learn from a, European communication this morning, that the Norwegian Government are having a fine submarine cable made, intended to be laid for a distance of about fifty miles along the coast, for the purpose of aiding the fishermen in the catching or herrings.

The United States Mail steamship Fulton, from Southampton on the 29th ult., arrived at this port last evening. The news by the overland mail, as published in the London Times, does not materially differ from that which appeared in our impression Of yesterday. It was telegraphed, on the 28th tilt., from Trieste, so that the mails would probably reach London in time for the Niagara, now due at Halifax.

The Horatian doctrine that "poets are born, and not made," like most other doctrines, is both a truth and a lie. It is a truth, because no artistic training can ever educate a Gradgrind into a Raphael. It is a lie, because "mute inglorious Miltons" do surely die and turn to dust in village churchyards, for want of a world to awaken their hearts and to open their lips.

The third Annual Convention of the American Dental Association was commenced at the Meionaon on Tuesday noon. The Association consists of members of the profession throughout the United States. At the hour of meeting, about one hundred gentlemen were in attendance. The Convention was called to order by Dr. CHAPIN A. HARRIS, of Baltimore, President of the Association.

Let it come to be understood that, in the service of Government, honesty is not the best policy, and Washington will soon swarm with candidates for the Penitentiary. Nothing can be more important to the public service than that its subordinate officers should feel assured of earnest support in every official act suggested by honest considerations of duty.

Daylight at last begins to break upon the darkness of the Chinese question, and it is not wholly unreasonable to hope that we have reached at least the beginning of the end of a question which has been ripening for more than two centuries.

WALLACK'S THEATRE- The closing week of the changement of Mr. and Mrs. John WOOD opened las. evening with a how burlesque, the "Corsair," this Piece is scarcely equal to the "Shylock" which has ?? been played with great acceptance, failing in the delicate hits, bits of humor and accuracy of appointment for which the latter was famous, The fault, however, was in the piece itself, rathe than in the actors who interpreted it.

THAT SNUFF-BOX AND THE NEW-YORK VOLUNTEERS -- The excitement among the remains of the new. York Regiment of Mexican Volunteers, in relation to the decision of the Committee, awarding Gen. JACKSON'S gold snuff-box to Major DYCKMAN, is rather on the increase. The Major has his friends among them, and so have nearly all the other Officers.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: In Miss BEECHER'S Letters to the People on Health and Happiness, it is claimed that the health of the American people is perishing at a fearful ratio, and that while other nations, both in school and at home, train their children to be strong and healthy, we are training ours to be puny, sickly and deformed.

THE PITTSYLVANIA TRAGEDY--The wife and children of the negro that shot Mr. E. F. KEEN, of Pitteylvania Country, on Sunday morning, were caught on Monday last about a half mile from their master's house, on their return home, but nothing has been seen of the negro man yet. The woman says that while they were traveling the children ?? caying for water.

THE BATTERY.--The work of filling in the Battery, which was begun six years ago, is likely to occupy from tow to three years longer before it is completed. Mr. II. CONKLIN was the first who took the contrast, and he was joined three months afterwards by GEORGE LAW, who filed the necessary Bonds for the fulfillment of contract.

The second annual meeting of this Club for the election of officers took place last evening, in the lecture room of the Stuyvesant Institute, No. 659 Broadway. The President, Mr. F. VAN AMBURGH, called the meeting to order, and the Secretary, Mr. J. T. PHILLIPHS, read the minutes of the last meeting.

APPLETON OAKSMITH'S DEBT.--In accordance with the notice of application for the discharge of APPLETON OAKSMITH from his debts, on the ground of insolvency, some of his creditors appeared before City Judge RUSSELL on Saturday morning, but the matter was, without any action being taken, postponed until Wednesday morning next.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Under the head of "Financial and Commercial, the Herald of July 29 has a strong article favorable to the La Crosse and Milwaukee Railroad, and going to show that that road must eventually have a monopoly of the carrying trade between Minnesota and Northern Wisconsin and the Eastern States.

The R. M. steamship Canada, from Liverpool at 8 P. M. on Saturday, Aug. 1, arrived here at 33 o'clock this afternoon. Her dates are three days later than those already received. The steamer Anglo-Saxon, from Quebec, and the steamer Lebanon, from New-York, arrived at Liverpool on the 29th ult.

The Canada arrived at Halifax yesterday, bringing three days' later news from Europe. The intelligence is very interesting. The preparations for laying the Atlantic Telegraph cable were corn plete. All the vessels of the Expedition had arrived at Cork, and were to leave for Valentia on the 31st July or 1st August, with the intention of comnencing operations at that point on the 3d or 4th inst.

ASHES-Market steady; sales 40 bbls, at $7 121/2@ $7 25 for Pearls, and $7 75@7 811/4 for Ports. COFFEE-The demand is moderate, but there is no yielding in prices. Sales 500 bags Rio at 111/2c.@12c., 4 months. COTTON-The market is quiet, and transactions much restricted by the firmness of holders. Sales 600 bales at ??. for middling Uplands, 155/5c. for Mobile, and 15 3/4c, for New-Orleans.

The Cunningham baby case made a decided movement yesterday, and it is now certain that Mrs. CUNNINGHAM will not be admitted to bail. Mr. STAFFORD, her sole surviving counsel, failed in the writ of cartiorart yesterday before Judge DALY, and later in the day he failed equally before Recorder SMITH. It is expected that M. s. CUNNINGHAM will be removed to the City Prison to day.

TOBACCO IN VIRGINIA.--There are fifty-six manufacturers of this staple in Richmoud, whose united capital amounts to four or five millions of dollars. More tobacco is raised in Virginia, and opened, inspected and sold in this city, than perhaps any one place in the United States. It is here that the choicest specimens of the weed assume the shape which commends it to the regard of devoted chewers everywhere.

THE LOTTERY-POLICY BUSINESS IN PHILADELPHIA.--Those persons who are conversant with the lower Wards, and some of the most active business portions of the city, are perfectly well aware of the existence of known and recognized offices for the sale of lottery policies, and it is somewhat singular that the eyes of the police are not more frequently turned to the matter.

We ventured the opinion, the other, day, that the mutiny of the native army in Bengal is not a sudden impulse, occasioned by any superstitious feeling among the Sepoys; but the result of a deeply organized conspiracy to overthrow the English power in India.

The public have heretofore imagined that all fraudulent transactions were monopolized by Government officials, lobby agents. railroad speculators, and the chevaliers of the Stock Exchange. But there has recently been discovered a series of stupendous frauds in a direction altogether unlooked for.

The U.S. Mail steamer Central America, WM L. HERNDON, U. S. N, Commander, from Aspinwall on the 3rd inst, with the mails and passengers and treasure brought down from San Francisco by the John L. Stephens, arrived at this port at 10 o'clock last evening.

Last evening the meeting of the Democracy unnecessarily postponed from Monday night in consequence of the rain, was held in Tompkins-square. The object of the meeting, like that of similar meetings recently held in various parts of the City, was to protest against the recent acts of the Legislature in reference to municipal matters. There were two stands, at one of which the speaking was done in German.

THE INTERMINABLE STREET COMMISSIONER'S CONTROVERSY.--We have no doubt that our readers are heartily tired of this protracted litigation, and that they would like a respite, at least during the dog days. We desire, however, to call attention to a matter connected with these proceedings, which seems to merit much more than a passing notice.

A $30,000,000 BOOK.--Last Saturday evening the New York Typographical Society received a rare and curious geographical work, accompanied by the following note: To the Librarian of ths Free Library, of th NewYork Typographical Society: RESPECTED SIR: I have had in my possession for years past these tour volumes--bound in two--of PITT'S English Atlas, printed in London in 1683, being 174 years ago.

The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend his tuneral, from the residence of his father, Charles Feitner, No. 583 9th. av., corner of 46th-st., on Thursday, 0 o'clocl A. M., without further invitation.

Yesterday afternoon President STEARNS delivered the Baccalaureate address to the members of the Graduating Class. His text was taken from the twentieth verse of the second chapter of Galatians, and the discourse was devoted to the consideration of the influence which the spirit of Christ exerted upon the learned professions when it becomes the governing principle of those engaged in the practice of them.

THE SLAVER N. HAND.--It is now positively stated, by those who profess to know the facts, that the brig N. Hand, which left this port in July, 1856, with provisions for the famishing people of the Cape de Verd Islands, and afterwards went to Africa on a state voyage. actually funded a cargo of slaves on the south side of Cuba, near the port of Santa Cruz, in the month of October, 1856.

NATIONAL CHESS CONGRESS.--For the first time in the history of American chess, we are soon he have grand Convention of all the principal players in the States. This convention will come off in New-York City next October. The first object aimed at is the formation of a code of laws and regulations; the second, a Chess Tournament.

The jury in the case of ANNA MEISTER, CAROLINE MUELLER and CAROLINE WARNER, tried for conspiracy to defraud various persons, came into Court yesterday after having been out two days, and rendered a verdict of "not guilty," but the defendants to pay the costs. This is a virtual conviction of criminal practices, though the particular offence of conspiracy was not proved.

The Secretary rend the third article of the Constitution, which fully explains the object of the meeting.

But the management of the Goodwood Races is beyond suspicion.

UNION FERRY COMPANY.--Some idea may be formed of the extent of the business of this Company in the fact that they own twenty-one boats, fifteen of which are run on the ferries all the time, employ 48O men, and consume annually on their boats an average of 25,000 tons of coal, which, at $6 per ton, would be $150,000.

From the Union. Subjoined is a copy of the letter received yesterday morning by the Commissioner of Indian Affairs from Mr. K. PRITOHETTE, who was recently sent to Minnesota as the special agent of the Indian Department. MANKATO, (Blue Earth Co.,) Minn. July 31, 1857.

The season is one of universal abundance, and, in most sections of the country, superabundance, in the greatest of all material blessings, good crops. There remains no peg to hang a doubt upon on this subject. The croakers of the Spring and early Summer months have been completely silenced.

Private letters received in this City confirm the report of the suicide of General RUSK, of Texas. The Panchita case has been discussed between Lord NAPIER and Gen. CASS. Mr. SOULE visits Mexico as the agent of SLOO, for the purpose of defeating the project of LE SHEE and BRNJAMIN. It is understood that the Administration is determined to foster the plan of steam-navigation.

IMPORTANT TO IMPORTERS AND DEALERS IN RUBBER WEB. - Judges SPRAGUE, of Massachusetts, PITMAN, of Rhode Island, NELSON, of New-York, and GRIER, of Pennsylvania, United States Judges, have granted injunctions (in all about fifty suits) against importers and users of Elastic Web, made in violation of the rights of the Congress Rubber Company.

The yacht race that is to come off to morrow in our harbor, is attracting numerous visitors from all parts of the country. The squadron numbers forty. one yachts, including some of the most celebrated afloat. The boats are to start at 10 A. M., and the race is to be governed by the rules of the New York Yacht Club.

SCIENTIFIC DISCOVERY.-M. FOUCAULT, of Paris, the inventor of the famous pendulum experiments, has constructed an apparatus to demonstrate that motion produces caloric. A thick bar of iron, bent into a horse-shoe form, is converted into an electro magnet between its two extremities is supported a disk of copper, to which a rapid rotary motion-300 or 400 revolutions a second-is communicated by the intervention of toothed gearing.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: I noticed, with much regret, in your journal of Wednesday, the 5th of August, an article copied from the Boston Transcript, and headed "Plagiarism in the Pulpit," in which a "clergyman stationed over an Episcopal Society in one of the most flourishing towns in Massachusetts," is accused of preaching as his own some sermons of Mrs. SPURGNON and of ROBT.

The schooner Montezuma of Troy, from the Bay ?? St. Lawrence,arrived here to-day with 240 barrels of Mackerel. On the 11th inst., when ninety miles east of Cape Ann, she fell in with the schooner Texan, from New-York for Eastport. She had been capsized, and was bottom up. The Montezuma succeeded in rescuing he crew, and brought them to Gloucester.

Some time ago the particulars were given here of the arrangements in virtue of which the Royal West India Mail, whose boats already ply between England and Aspinwall, agreed to amalgamate with or otherwise absorb, the newly chartered Royal Australian Mail, whose vessels were to have performed the Anglo Australian postal service via Suez, but lamentably failed to do so.

THE JOINT FISHERY COMMISSION.--The Toronto Colonist states that the members of the Joint Fishery Commission, under the Reciprocity Treaty with the United States, consisting of Gen. G. CUSHMAN, of Benger, the United States Commissioner, and R. D. CUTTS, Esq., of Washington, his Surveyor, with M. H. PEELEY, Esq, Her Majesty's Commissioner, and GEORGE H. PEELEY, Esq., his Secretary and Surveyor,

From the Troy Budget. About 12 o'clock Sunday night a fire broke out in one of the upper stories of the liquor and commission store of EDWIN BOWMAN, No 235 River-street. The building occupied by Mr. B. was entirely destroyed; so also was the building adjoining south, No. 323 occupied by C E WARNER, wholesale provision dealers, and No. 321, occupied by WILSON CHURCH, druggists.

FOUND DROWNED.--On Wednesday the body of a man-evidently a seaman-was found on the beach upon the farm of HENRY LUDLUM, Esq., Centre Island, nearly opposite Lloyd's Dock. The deceased was dressed in a blue shirt and check pants, with a belt and new sheath knife. The latter is in possession of the Coroner.

Charles Hawkins vs. The Major, Aldermen and Commonalty of the City of New York.-- HOFFMAN; seized upon an execution issued on a judgment in the District Court for the Third Judicial District, against the defendants.

The President arrived home, yesterday, in remarkable health. In consequence of the great accumulation of affairs since his absence, an informal meeting of the Cabinet was held immediately. Domestic affairs only were considered. In regular meeting of the Cabinet, to-morrow, the affairs of Granada, Venezuela, and the Mexican Tehuantepec transit will come up and be acted on.

MILLS STOPPED.--The number of cotton loom that havE been stopped in New England, in consequence of the high price of cotton and the low price of goods, is about six thousand, and orders have been given to stop many more, as fast as the yarn runs out. We heard, yesterday, of two largo mills that will run only till the cotton now in process of manufacture is exhausted.

From the Albany Evening Journal. Messrs. S.P. G. H. ELy, well-known millers of Rochester, have suspended, not because of any losses in their legitimate business, but because of large investments in the Lake Superior Mineral Regions. Among other investments was $250,000 in a Railroad from Marquette to the Mines. They had sold this road for $300,000, but the purchasers have

LOOK OUT FOR MAD DOGS.--A mad dog running down Wa1l-street just about noon yesterday. produced terrible panic among the Brokers. One woman on the sidewalk narrowly escaped being bitten. A crowd followed him, but at a very respectable distance, booting, howling, and yelling. A Motropolitan Policeman applied his full force on the rabid animal's head-the Metropolitan's locust being the medium of its communication. The poor brute .

One of the most remarkable and important phenomena attending the growth of cities, and which is hardly noticed by political economists, is the steady and persistent rise in the value of ground occupied by stores and dwelling-houses. The largest and safest investments are in this kind of property.

EXTRAORDINARY ESCAPE.--The St. Johns (Canada) News says: "A freight train of cars, arriving form Montreal on Monday evening last, was propelled violently against some stationary cars, at one end of which stood a nurse of Mr. WALMSLEY, mail conductor, who had charge of an infant child, belonging to that gentleman.

The several applications of Mr. STAFFORD to Justice DAVIDSON, JUDGE DALY and Recorder SMITH, for the admission of Mrs. CUNNINGHAM to bail having failed, and there being no other means of prolonging her detention at No. 31 Bond-street, yesterday morning, between 11 and 12 o' clock,

The grand yacht regatta took place in our harror today. The day was pretty generally observed as a holiday in this city, and the race was witnessed by thousands of spectators. The harbor was full of execution parties attracted higher by the regatta. The following is the result: First Class--The Race, owned by M. H. GRINNELL.

AN ARRESTED MURDERER IDENTIFIED.--Marshall BUTTS, of Covington, arrested, some days ago, a person for some party offence in that city, and afterward had reason to believe him one JOHN FLY, who murdered, on the 29th of June last, a young man named DAVID M. THOMPSON, in Murfreesborough, Tenn., and for whom the young man's father, JOHN THOMPSON, of October County, in Miss, had offered a reward of two thousand dollars.

The Canada's mails reached this City from Bos ton at 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon. We publish below extended details of the important and highly interesting news, of which a telegraphic summary has been received. When within 60 miles of Boston the Canada, on Wednesday evening at 8 o'clock, passed the Europa, outward bound. The steamships saluted each other with rockets in splendid style.
