He arrived on the Joseph Holden, from Alexandria, yesterday, and has eaileo in to ?? us theat he was present at the ?? ofGEDERAL RUSK on that day.

Advices have been received here from Bogota to the 8th ult. Congress had adjourned. Before adjourning, however, the bill that had passed to a third reading in both branches of Congress, providing for the establishment of certain national privileges in this State, a translation of which you received per last steamer, after some unimportant modifications, finally passed and become a law.

KILLED BY A SECOND-AVENUE RAILROAD CAR -An old man, NIOHOLAS HUSSEY, a native of Ireland died yesterday at his house, Oliver-street, (No. 2L On the 21st of July he was run over by a Second-avenue car, at the corner of Eighth-street Mr. HUSSEY was in his 64th year. Yesterday, Coroner CONNERY proceeded to the late residence of deceased, and commenced holding an inquest upon the body.

RESULT OF THE ELECTION--PEACE IN YUCATAN. In the Prensa of Havana, we find dates from Mexico to the 28th of July. The revolutionists in the neighborhood of Lake Chalapa, who were intended for service in Lower California, rebelled against the military leaders of that country. Considerable skirmishing had resulted, and the mutineers were still at large on the 6th.

The great Irish patriot, JOHN MITCHELL, of Knoxville, Tennessee, has been favoring the world with his views upon Southern prospects; through the medium of a couple of letters, one of which, the shortest, we published on Tuesday, to his "dear MARTN," late another Irish patriot, temporarily sojourning in Australia, now a barrister,

Aaa good deal of locl excitement andinflammatory feeling toward Quindaro has recently been excited, and now exists in the adjacent portions of Missouri. Reports are circulated and have obtained belief that the slaves acroes the river are enticed to come here by the citizens of this tewn. and when pursued and identified, are still kept from their owners in defiance of law.

The Pacific Steam Navigation Company's steamer Valparaiso arrived at this port on the 21st ult, with dates from Valparaiso to June 30, Iquique, July 1; Callao, July 12, and Paita, July 16. She brings $400,000 in specie, principally in silver bars, for England.

IMPORTANT ARREST.-From representations made by responsible parties, Justice COLE was iuduced to issue a warrant for the arrest of one JOHN S. LOOMIS, of Brooklyn, on a charge of false pretences. Friday afternoon the warrant was placed in the hands of Constablo MALOY, who left in the night boat.

The predictions of the American Press and of some of our most influential capitalists have been fully realized, and the grand bubble of Cuban Stock operations has burst, and ruined hundreds of people who were considered to be in affluent circumstances a few months ago. The worst feature in the general ruin.

The Democrats of The City assembled in massmeeting last night at Tammany Hall, in obedience to the following call: Resistance to Legislative oppression. Recall repeal?? Repeal?? Mass meeting of the Democracy. The Democractic Repubitcan Electors of the City and County of New-York, friendly to regular mominations and the usages of the party are requested to assemble at Tammany Hall on Thursday evening, August 13,

ARRIVAL OF THE EUROPEAN MAIL-Spread of the Indian Mutinies-Bloody engagement at CantonThe American horses beaten at the Goodwood race in England, ARRIVAL OF THE CALIFORNIA MAIL-Two weeks later from California, Oregon, Sandwich Islands, New-Granada, Central America and the South PacificMasacre of apostate Mormons in Utah-Award of Transit Grant by Costa Rica.

The Canada arrived at Boston yesterday morning at 4 o'clock, and her mails, dispatched south in the morning train, reached this City yesterday afternoon. When within sixty miles of Boston, at about 8 o'clock on Wednesday evening, the Canada passed the Europa outward bound. The two steamships saluted each other, and there was a brilliant interchange of sky-rockets.

PROSPECTS Of A QUIET TIME.--After the two months of excitements we have just passed through, there is at last a prospect of a very decided calm. Mayor WOOD has left the City for a fortnight; Mrs. CUNNINGHAM has been taken to the Tombs; the two Street Commissioners are in a state of dead lock, without the chance of another certiorari, quo warranto,

It was a very hot day yesterday. The mercury in the thermometer was standing at 86 F. in shade, while in favored localities it went ten or dozen degrees higher. Still there was a flue breeze on the water, and suburbans were not aware of the fact that it was so terribly hot after all.

THE LARYNX OF MOSES.--At the meeting of the Pathological Society, Wednesday evening, the larynx of MOSES, the man who lost his life in the late Navesink tragedy, was exhibited by Dr. FINWELL. The same gentleman exhibited, too the larynx of ANDERSON, the murdered police.

THE GOOWOOD RACE.--Porter's Spirit of the Times attributes the defeat of the American horses, in the Goodwood contest, to the incapacity of their trainer, PALMER, who is celebrated for bringing his horses to the ground so fat that they cannot do themselves justice. It predicts that they will still win the, day, after running unsuccessfully long enough to get themselves in good condition.

Further particulars of the revolutionary attempt in Peru are received. A battle had been fought at Yumina between the revolutionists and the forces of Gen. SAN ROMAN; the conflict lasting for seven hours without any definite result. The total loss was 40 killed and 100 wounded.

We reached Ossiout, the chief city of Upper Egypt, this morning, at 9 o'clock, and before mailing our letters I propose to write again, if but briefly, of our adventures on the Nile. Game is abundant. I have never seen such flocks of geese and ducks.

TICKET SWINDLING AND ROBBERY.--A poor Irishman from Elizabeth town, N. J., who had gathered up all his little means, designing to start for the Nest to improve his worldly condition; arrived in New-York yesterday, intending to purchase a ticket for Milwaukee. He fell into the hands of a runner,

MORE MAD DOGS;.--ONE KILED INA MUSIC STORE.--Yesterday morning a mad dog, which had been chased down Broadway rushed up stairs to the first floor of No. 389 Broadway, occupied by Mr. J. A. NOVELLO, as a music store. The dog crouched in a corner of the store, behind the counter, ?? literally pouring from his lips.

Mr. MCVEY, the Superintendent of School Buildings, has his hands pretty full, as will be seen by the following statement of the amount of work now being performed under his direction. NEW SCHOOL HOUSES.

The thermometer at nooi to-day marked 92 de. greens. AT BALTIMORE. BALLTIMORE, Friday, Aug. 14. To-day was the warmest of the season. The thermometer stood at 94o in the shade, at noon. This evening it stands at 89o AT ALBANY.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--The series of Promenade Concerts, under the direction of Messrs. STUART BOURCICAULT, attract large and fashionable audiences at this best of all places for lounging in the hot Summer nights. There is a feast for the eye, the ear and the palate for those who choose to partake.

CAPTAIN CANTY, the newly appointed Minister from the Costa Rioan Government, arrived in the City by the Central America on Wednesday last One of our repairers called upon him, at the Clarendon Hotel: the morning succeeding his arrival, and gathered from him some interesting facts connected with Nicaragua matters that have never been published.

The great Yacht Regatta has just ended. The vessels started from Butler's Flats about half-??. Seventeen vessels wont around the entire course, which is thirty-three miles' allowing for tacking, the distance passed over was fully forty-four slides The Minnie, sloop, of the 2d class, rounded the outer stake boat first, and made the shortest time for entire distance--forty-four miles, in four hours fifty one minutes three seconds.

The Lowber Market Property -- Mr. Flagg's Position. Comptroller FLAGG says that he resists the Lowber purchase because it is unquestionably a fraud, and for other reasons. In various communications to the Common Council he has uniformly given his advice against the purchase of additional market property, until the principle is settled of leasing all public markets to the highest bidder, thus placing them beyond the control of the Corporation.

Occasionally, slight attention is given to the Commission of Records. now in active execution of its duties, by some one, curious or discontented, who desires information as to the character find results, so far, of its labors, or imagines a " mare's nest" in the large outlay which the Commission has necessarily induced.

Yesterday was decidedly a gala-day with the inhabitants of South Danvors, who held a social picnic, for the purpose of having a parting interview with GEORGE PEABODY, the great London American banker, and their former fellow townsman, previous to his embarkation for England.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Returning from Central America, on Wednesday evening last, the 12th inst., I find that during my absence, under the head of correspondence from Washington, some of the New-York papers have been publishing foul libels against me, charging, among other and numerous falsehoods, that I have been a convict in a penitentiary at Baton Rougs:

ABOUT BISHOPS. The London Times has been devoting its skill to an analysis of the character of Bishops, Young Bishops, it says start with the idea, prevalent in nurseries and around ladies workstands, that Bishops can "do" things; that they can manage to reform abuses, set thing right, make the clergy do their duty, and so forth.

New-Orleans papers of the 8th inst. are to hand. Lieut. Hood, of the Second Cavalry, with seventeen men, had a desperate encounter with a band of forty-five Lipans and Camanches, of the 20th of July, at the head of Devil River. The fight was a hand-to-hand one. Nine Indians were killed and ten wounded. Lieut. Hood had one killed and one missing, and he

COLORED CITIZENSHIP IN THE STATE OF MAINE.--The Senate of the State of Maine, on the decision of the Dred Scott case being made, propounded a question to the Supreme Court of that State, in March last, whether the free colored residents of the State were citizens or not.

RICORS OF THE SEASON.-The heat yesterday was excessive; though the thermometer ran up under its influence, everything else ran down, particularly fancy stocks in Wall-street, It was altogether the hottest day we have experienced during the Summer, and a few more like it will nearly deplete the City, while the hotels at the watering places will be crowded.

About 3 o'clock yesterday morning. Officer FIELD, of the Sixth Precinct Police, observed a young butcher, named JOHN TILTON, and another man, attempting to break into a store on the corner of Duane and Staple-streets. The officer hid behind a pile of...

Churches and Pastors. Mr. BEECHER'S Church is shut up until the second Sunday in September, the pastor being in the county fishing and studying birds, delivering addresses to the Alumni of Andover, and considering the comparative merits of brown-stone fronts and old fashioned farm-house as a mean of grace.

The Business Committee reported, to day, against Free-trade and direct taxation; against the South receiving goods from States not upholding the Fugitive Slave Law; against any discrimination of the Government in favor of foreign mail lines from Northern ports; in favor of the exemption of one slave to each slaveholder from seizure for debt; in favor of

The Government is again disappointed by the non-reception of advices from WM. CAREY JONES. Not a word has been received from him mince he left. The Administration has received no information of the reported grant of the right of way on the Isthmus by Costa Rica and Nicaragua, to Messrs. WEBSTERS HARBIS. No claims of Costa Rica, founded on right of conquest, will be admitted.

The Eleventh Annual Meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science was opened this morning. The day was a beautiful one, clear and blight, and not oppressively warm-just such weather as tends to put every one into good humor, and prepare them for either labor or enjoyment.

REITMEYER-MORIARTY.-In this City, on Monday Aug. 10, by Rev. Mr. Dunbar, C. A, W. REITMEYER to Miss Mary L. MORIARTY, eldest daughter of A. P. Moriarty, Esq. GILLIE-JAMISON.-In this city, on Thursday, Aug. 13, by Rev. A. H. Wright, DANIEL GILLIE, Esq., to Miss JANE JAMISON, both of New York.

Every lover of sound learning will of course be rejoiced to hear of the increasing prosperity of Amherst. The collection of a fund for the improvement of the library, and the erection of a building for the use of the Alumni in their annual meetings, and of the two literary societies, was agitated several years since. Finally it was determined to attempt the improvement of the library first.

The several vessels of the Telegraphic fleet have assembled here; the cable is all shipped; the preliminary investigations and experiments have all been made: to-morrow we still from Valentia Bay, and on Monday next the European end of the great Cable will be mile fast to the Irish shore.

A GENTLE HIT AT MAYOR WOOD.--Mr. SICKLES improved the opportunity afforded him on Thursday night, in his anti-Albany speech at.Tammany Hall, of doing his friend Mayor WOOD a good turn by reminding the unfortunate members of the old Police, that they were indebted to his Honor for being now out of employment.

THE COSTA RICAN AND NICARAGUAN TRANSIT ROUTE.--We publish, in another part of our paper, this morning, a letter from Mr. W. R. C. WEBSTER, partly in relation to certain slanders which have been circulated about him by his enemies during his absence on the Isthmus, but mainly in reference to the Costa Rican Transit Route, the grant of which, he states, he has secured from the Central American Governments.

Last night a tornado passed through the town of Reading and vicinity. It was nearly half a mile in width. Several dwellings and outbuildings were damaged, orchards were uprooted, and considerable damage done to the crops, etc. No loss of life is reported.

A GOOD OPPORTUNITY TO GET RID OF A NUISANCE.--AS the creditors of the City are levying on the ornamental furniture of the City Hall to satisfy their judgments, a capital opportunity presents itself to get rid of some of the trumpery which may be found in the Governor's Room.

The Kansas correspondent of the Democrat says that Judge CANE has published an opinion, stating that the payment of taxes is essential to the preliminary rights of voting. The Sheriff of Douglas County has given notice of his intention to collect the taxes.

The steamship Europa arrived here from Boston at 10 1/2 o'clock last night, and sailed again for Liverpool at midnight. A light south wind is blowing. DEPARTURE OF THE CIRCASSIAN. ST. JOHNS, N. F., Friday, Aug. 14.

The Conover case has been marked from beginning to end by all sorts of singularities and indecorums, from the Mayor's riot down to Mr. BRADY'S harangue. We think the most objectionable feature in the proceedings has, however, decidedly been the demeanor of counsel-demeanor which reflects no credit either on the manners of New-York gentlemen, or on the tone of the New-York bar. Again we are called upon to recount a tale of blood, which may result in the death of sue of our citizens, JOHN ELLIS. formerly watchman of the First Ward The circumstance occurring but a short time before our going to press prevents our giving the matter in detail, or ascertaining the correctness of various runlors which have come to us. We give the facts as narrated to us.

The celebrated house, No. 31 Bond-street, is still occupied by the Misses CUNNI - GHAM. On Thursday night GERGIANA, by tears and petitions, prevailed upon Mr. GRAY, the Warden, and Mrs. Foster, the Matron of the City Prison, to be allowed to sleep with her mother. Last night AUGUSTA slept with her.

The people of Missouri have just preached the most eloquent sermon on the Slavery question which has yet been heard in these United States. A sermon we call it, for deliberate utterance of a great popular conviction, by a body of independent citizens, has a solemnity beyond the average solemnity of mere discourses from the sacred desk,

Among the passengers by the Canada. at Boston. was Miss. H. G. HOSMER, a young lady of that city, who has resided in Rome for the past five years, pursuing the study of the art of sculpture. A specimen of the production of her chisel is one the way to this country.

PAT MATTHEWS and JEM HUGHES, both men of celebrity in fighting circles, laid out for a flight in the public house of GEORGE W. WALTERS, (corner of Broadway and Great Jones-street,) about 1 o'clock yesterday morning. Captain DILKS hearing of it, ordered a couple of Sergeants over, who, with their men, captured the belligerents, and took them to the Fifteenth Ward Station-house.

By an arrival at this port from St. Domingo, we learn the particulars of a revolution which had broken out at Santiago, South side of St. Domingo,. on the 10th of July against President BIAZ, and that a battle had taken place in the interior between the insurgents and President BIAZ, during which 150 men had been killed. The president had 1,000 men before the city of St. Domingo.

We have intelligence of this sad event (says the New-Orleans Picayune, of the 4th instant) by a gentleman who left Nacogdochea, the late residence of General RUSK, on the 30th ult. He arrived on the Joseph Holden, from Alexandria, yesterday, and has called in to tell us that he was present at the funeral of General RUSK on that day.

Mr. COTTRELL, United States Commercial Agent at San Juan, has communicated to the Government important particulars as to the treaty of boundaries between Costa Rica and Nicaragua. It is an adjustment which this Government tried in vain to effects No objection can be made to it, or to the new grant of the Transit Route, unless it is based on the right of conquest.

The nuisance at the corner of Columbia-steest and Hamilton avenue, complained of by WM. FERGUSON, was referred to the Alderman of the Ward to abate.

The Madison papers contain a communication from Attorney General SMITH and Treasurer KUE?S, of the Board of School Land Commissioners, from which it appears that a regular row occurred at the swamp land sale, at Chilton. H. C. HOBART seems to have been the instigator, and an Irishman named MALONE, the instrument of carrying out the disturbance. After the close of the sales, and while the purchase-money was being received.

SMITH, on her way from New-York to New London.

Captain BROWN, of the Fall River line of Steamers, which was coming up the Sound, and the propeller J. N. Harris, Capt. LEONARD SMITH, bound from New-York to New-London. To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Allow me to suggest, through your valuable paper, a few ideas as to the formation of a perfect Custom-House. In the first place, the present forms, ??., now in practice, are far from facilitating the merchant or clerk in a speedy delivery of the goods. Let us go back to the forms in use during Mr. LAWRENCE'S Collectorship.

The Republican Convention, lately in session at 'Columbus, after renominating Gov. CHASE by acclamation, passed, among others, the following resolutions: We insist that the lawful process by the State Courts for the maintenance of right, and the prosecution and punishment of crime committed within the limits of Ohio and against her sovereignty, shall be executed without let or hindrance by Federal officials.

The Summer season at the various places of heatrical amusement is now at an end. For many has been a trying one,--WALLACK'S being, we believe, the only theatre that has been sustained with profit during the warm weather. The RAVELS, with their special entertainment, form, of course, an exception to this remark. They possess the secret of pepetual success, and never fail to play to crowded enches.

BLIND JUSTICE.-Justice is nowhere more blind and unequal in her mandates than at the Police Courts. A man named EDWARD KENNEDY, an Irish tailor, was brought yesterday afternoon before Justice BRENNAN, at Essex Market Police Court, by Officer JONES, of the Seventh Precinct,who preferred a charge against him. "I arrested this man at 1 o'clock this afternoon, in Cherry-street," said the officer, "for disorderly conduct.

At just about the time you copied the accounts of the "Grasshopper Plague" in Minnesota, July 18, they began to migrate in myrads southeastward, and though they are now frequently visible in the air far above us, none, except a few whose wings are not yet fully grown, are seen on the ground, and all fear of further injury from them is past.

A JEALOUS WOMAN STABS AN UNFAITHFUL MAN.---MARY JOHNSON, an Irishwoman, was arrested early yesterday morning on a charge of stabbing an oysterman named STEPHEN JOHNSON. The parties are not married. JOHNSON has an oyster store near Catherine Market. The cause of this conduct on the part of the woman appears to have been jealousy.

SECOND DAY. Tempora mutantur. The weather has changed today; we have all "seen better days." as CHARLES LAMB had. The rain comes down in torrents, but there is no postponement on account of two weather, and at 10 o'clock the meeting is opened by the Vice-President. The first business was the election of 56 new members proposed by the Standing Committee, which was done at a blow.

The Representatives of the New York Fire Department held a special meeting at Firemen's Hall, Mercer-street, last evening. There was a very full attendance. The meeting was called to order about 8 1/2 o'clock by the President, who stated that he had convened the meeting is consequence of a communication of the Commissioners of the Fire Department, which communication would be read by the Secretary.

To the editor of the New York Daily Times: I judge from your remarks this morning, that you are disposed to excuse the steamboat Metropolis for running down the propeller J. N. Harris, on Saturday morning in the Sound. I have no doubt that your opinion is sincere.

FIGHTING. -- A large party of men employed upon the tunnel got into a row in Jersey City early on Sunday morning, while intoxicated. The police attempted to stop the row, when the Irishmen turned upon them. The police being reinforced, rallied and drove off the rioters, but not until after firing two or three shots at them.

A "Reader of the TIMES" inquires if a landlord can eject a tenant for refusing to pay an increased amount of rent for a past month, upon premises rented at a certain rate per month for an undefined period.

ITALIAN OPERA.--Signorina VESTVALI commenced a short season of Italian Opera at Burton's Theatre last night, under favorable auspices, and was received with great applause by her numerous admirers and old friends. The opera selected for the occasion was "Lucretia Borgia," and the cast embraced the names of VESTVALI, LOUISA CARANTI BRIGNOLI, AMODIO and COLLETI.

CHINESE SUGAR CANE.--It is stated that over 100,000 acres of land in the United States have been platnted with the Soroho, or Cinese Sugar Cane. This is a wonderful result, when it is considered that only two or three years have elapsed since it was first introduced in the country.

EUGENE SUE died in Paris early in the morning of Aug. 3. The bare fact of his decease is stated in the London papers, of the 4th instant. Whether he died suddenly, or bad fallen instant prolonged disease, we are not informed. Thus, in little more than a fortnight; France lose two of her distinguished men. BRKANGER died July 16.

DEATH OF ME DELANE.--M F A DELANE, formerly managing editor of the London times, who visited and extended his travels largely in the United States last year, died on the 20th ult. at the house of his son, near Norwich, England, in the 64th year of his age--Express.

New-Orleans papers of the 9th have been received, but contain nothing important. A letter from Plaquines says that the sugarcane was growing rapidly, ad that the new crop of sugar would be in the market by the middle of October--three weeks earlier than usual.

The Dundec Advertiser records the demise of THOMAS DICK, the well known author of the Christian Philosopher, and other kindred works. Dr. DICK, who was in the 83rd your of his age, expired at Broughty Ferry, near Dundee, on Wednesday last. He was born in the Hilltown. Dundee, on the 24th of November, 1774, his father being MUNGO DICK, a small linen manufacturer.

GREAT CRICKET MATCH.--CANADA VS. THE STATES.--This match, which commences to -morrow morning, at Toronto, Canada, artracts great attention from cricketers throughout the Union, hundreds of whom go up to witness it. A match of this kind is played but once a year.

The City Inspector is of opinion that the expense during the quarter of cleaning the thirteen Wards under his management, will not exceed $60,000; and that the entire cost for the whole City ought to be $100,000 less than each past year it has been. The thirteen Wards left under his care comprise some of the most densely populated and filthy districts of the City.

How THE STEAMER BALTIC WAS DETAINEDA FALSE IMPRESSION.-The stoamship Balic, which was to have sailed at 12 o'clock on Saturday, did not take ber departure until 2 o'clock P. M., on Sunday. Handbills were posted about the City on Saturday, assigning as the reason for the detention, the " lowness of the tide." thereby crearing an impression not very favorable to our harbor.

THE CROTON AQUEDUCT RESERVOIR IN THE PARK--Sealed proposals for the construction of the new grand Reservoir of the Croton Aqueduct, in Central Park, were to have been opened on Saturday, at the office of the Croton Aqueduct Department.

We receive in the letter of our Chinese correspondent the rather starting intelligence that the Government of the United States has decided to take possession of the Island of Formosa, as security for the payment by the Chinese Government of the indemnity demanded for damages done to American interests during the disturbances at Canton.

A NEW SUPERSTRUCTURE FOR RAILROADS. -The depreciation of railroad property, by what is called the "wear and tear" of materials has always been an obstacle to the complete success of our railroad system. EXTRAORDINARY DISCOVERIES AT ROME.Every day brings to light in the nooks and corners of the old world, something new. Winged lions, gigantic bulls with claws upon their feet, and griffins with human heads, are among the wonders which the prying curiosity of modern explore. ers has brought to the knowledge of the present age.

FORT KEARNEY, SOUTH PASS AND HONEY LAKE WAGON ROAD.-Information has been received by the Interior Department, and by private advices to the General Superintendent of the Pacific wagon roads, from the expedition to construct the Western di. vision of the Fort Kearney, South Pass, and Honey Lake road under John Kirk, superintendent.

Deputy Superintendent CARPENTEE is now engaged in apportioning the police force in this city, so as to give a proper number of men to each precinct. This work will be completed during the week, and Probably on Friday orders will be issued to the officers in charge of the various precincts.

The most startling attempt known of late years to circulate counterfeit, money took place on Tuesday night, and was attended with remarkable success. About forty or fifty persons, as near as caa be ascertained, were engaged in flooding the City with counterfeit, $5 bills on the Lee Bank of Massachusetts. and last night it was supposed, from inquiries which had been instituted, that nearly or quite $10,000 hud been thus circulated.

The Arabia brings the news of the death of Dr. BLOMFIELD, late Lord Bishop of London. The prelate who has now died as a man, died as a Bishop last year, when a great commotion was excited by the simultaneous demand made by himself and the Bishop of Durham for liberty to retire upon pensions of which their Lordships calmly dictated the amount and the duration.

The Royal Mail Steamship Arabia, Captain Stone, from Liverpool, at about 11 o'clock morning of Saturday, the 8th August, arrived at this port at 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon. The steamship Arxgo arrived at Southampton on the morning of Thursday, the 6th.

From the Commercial, 18th. Ajdisgraceful and somewhat bloody riot and outrage was perpetrated yesterday afternoon, by the riotous Irish population inhabiting the vicinity of Sixth and Culver streets, upon two police officers while they were discharging their duty Between 5 and 6 o'clock, Day Policeman KIMBALL, of the First, and GARDNER, of the Thirteenth Wards, arrested JOHN O'BRIAN, for assaulting and beating the keeper of an Irish doggery on Sixth near Culvert street.

The vacant consulates at Antwerp, Basle and Sharghae are to be filled this week. The President has taken into his own hand the appointment of a Commissioner of Patouts. At present the leading candidates are FRANCIS W. SHERMAN, of Michigan, a lawyer, and Judge PALMER, of Conecticut.

The Arabia, at this port last evening. brings three days' later news from Europe. No later intelligence is received from India. The English papers are filled with detailed accounts of the atrocities committed by the insurgents, but no particulars of importance are furnished in addition to those already published. The mutiny continued to create anxiety, and the Government had chartered vessels for the conveyance of troops to India.

THE COMMON PLFAS AN INFERIOR COURT.--In close relation to the pending war of Injunctions, has occurred the inquiry--whether the New-York Common Pleas as a Court, is inferior to the " Supreme Court " of the State, or not ? It has been always so regarded by the profession. In many respects, indeed, the two Courts have concurrent jurisdiction.

Yesterday a decision was rendered by the General Land Office, adverse to the preemption claim of a colored man to a tract of land in Wisconsin-the ground taken being that of the Supreme Court in the Dred Scott case, that a free negro whose ancestors were brought to this country and sold as slaves is not a citizen. This de. cision applies to all other similar cases.

A bold and daring burglary was committed last night at the office of the Mutual Insurance Company, in the store of Mr. SAMUEL PIERCE, in this place. A large from safe was blown open by gunpowder and about $250 stolen therefrom. The room was bespat tered with blood, and traces of it were found in the street near the store. It is supposed that the explosion was premature and that the thief was severely idjured.

ASSAULTING POLICEMEN.--Yesterday evening some officers of the Sixth Ward were conducting two prisoners who had been drunk and disorderly at the Five Points to the Station-house, when they were assailed by a party who attempted to reseue them. Men and women struck at the officers, who found it necessary to use their clubs in self defence.

The bogus ticket-sellers did not drive as thriving a trade as usual yesterday, previous to the departure of the steamship Central America, for California. Travelers are evidently becoming enlightened from the stories which heretofore have been published in the TIMES of the swindling Practiced in the sale of Passage tickets. The craft, nevertheless, are not lacking in industry in the pursuit of fresh victims.

THE LAST PERFORMANCE OF HUME, THE MEDIUM.---We translate from the Baden Cronique an account of the last exploit of Mr. HUME, the Yankee spiritual medium abroad. Mr. HUME, who is at Baden for five or six weeks, is very much sought after in aristocratic circles, and prefers them to the public saloons, where he is the object of an inconsiderate and annoying curiosity.

POSTAL ARRANGEMENT WITH HAMBURG.--We are requested to state that a postal Convention has been concluded between the United States and the Hanseatic Republic of Hamburg, the mails to be exchanged by means of United States or Hamburg mail steamers, running direct between New-York and Hamburg.

Two hundred and fifty-seven years ago, Queen ELIZABETH of England gave a charter to "the Governor and Company of Merchants of London trading into the East Indies." The business of this Company--which was the original of the present East India Company--was to send ships to India loaded with such merchandise as was likely to have a "ready vent" among the Indians;

Between 1 and 2 o'clock this morning a fire broke out in the extensive omnibus stables of Messrs. HART, THOMAS Co., on Magazine street, between Harmony and Pleasant streets. Fourth District, which resulted in their entire destruction, together with fifty mules, and, as rumor hath it, three or four men who slept in the hay-loft.

A NOVEL GUNPOWDER PLOT.-An old man, named WILLIAM EVANS, was before Alderman ENEU, last evening, on the charge of attempting to blow up the Exchange generally, but more particularly the office of OUTERBRIDGE, HARVRY CO., No. 20 in that building, and the persons who were therein, Including the prisoner himself.

The late George Frederick Muntz, M. P., was 68 years of age, and a successful merchant. He was one of the leaders of the Birmingham Political Union at the time the old reform bill under want discussion: and in 1887 he became the subject of a prosecution for a riot that took place at a church-rate meeting. Of this accusation he was found guilty, but the verdiet was quashed on appeal.

MESSRS. EDITORS: Some of the company of Dakotas, sent after INK-PA-DU TA and the others who perpetrated the murders at Spririt Lake, have returned, and report that after seven days march, they arrived at Skunk Lake, about 100 miles, as measured on Nicollet's map, Southwest of this place, and, after a very severe chase, succeeded, without any loss on their part, in killing three men and making prisoners of two men and one child.

POLITICAL.-Gov. CHASE, having been nominated by the Republican Party of Ohio for reelection, made a campaign speech at Cincinnati on the 20th. He devoted considerable attention to the defalcation of GIBSON, the State Treasurer, for which he said the Republican Party could not be held responsible, inasmuch as BRESLIN, a Demo crat, took every dollar of the money.

Officers ROSE, BLOOM and RICKETS succeeded last evening in making a grand haul of bogus bauk bills, and arrested JERRY COWDEN, a notorious lawbreaker, in whose possession it was found. The prisoner had been long under police surveillance, but no crime sufficient to justify his apprehension could he fixed upon him, and he was suffered to loaf about the streets without manifesting any visible means of subsistence.

DEPRAVITY OF A SON--JESSE ROLLINS. ?? Haverhill, N. H., had $1,940 stolen from ?? Thursday in that city. He had sold his place in Haverhill, and with his oldest son had left Worcester ?? for Auburn, to look at a place which he was intending to purchase, leaving the money in a carpet-bag in ?? sleeping room. The sum named was all he possessed $800 of it was earned by the oldest brother.

RUNAWAY MATCH BY A METHODIST MINISTER.--Considerable stir has been occasioned in the village of Port Chester and vicinity, in consequence of Rev. Mr. PORTEUS, of the Methodist Episcopal Church, Stanwich, Conn., having eloped with a Miss PINE, daughter of JAMES PINE, of King street, near Port Chester, a young lady of about 19 years of age, and of prepossessing appearance.

REMARKABLE ESCAPE.--Very early yesterday morning, a man was discovered from the street asleep in the roof-guttering of a house on Broadway, between Jefferson and Madison streets. The discoverer was a farmer coming in his wagon to market. He had much difficulty in getting into the house without breaking in.

The Canadian Screw Steamship Company's steamer Anglo-Saxon, arrived at this port this morning. She left Liverpool at about 2 o'clock P. M. on Wednesday the 12th instant. The route of the Anglo-Saxon was too far north of the line selected for the Atlantic cable, to lead to any expectations of her falling in with the Telegraph Cable fleet.

The Government has determined to assume, as a basis of its negotiations in regard to the Nicaragua Transit, the precise position of Nicaragua before hostilities commenced, without any reference to the action of Costa Rica.

The force with which stoes wre driven against the stored near the water's edge, actually started the bungs from the bogsheads. The Naval Hospital is considerably injured.

THIRD DAY. The meeting of the Institute was opened to day with prayer by Rev. W. L. GAGE, of this city. The first subject presented for discudsion was " The relative merits of' Public High Schools and Endowed schools."

SHARP AND TRUE.--A story has been going the rounds of the papers about a gentleman who, when asked by his wife to take her into the country, frankly told her that his means did not admit of such indulgence, but that all the advantages of a rural residence could be secured by cutting off the gas and the Croton, and sleeping in the attic. That gentleman has a discerning spirit and a ripe judgment.

SINGULAR CASE AT LAW--A MOTHER REFUSED POSSESSION OF HER OWN CHILD.--A very lengthy and tedious case was tried before the Probate Court day before yesterday, in regard to a child, a boy, FRANK HOUSE, who had been bound out by his mother, MARY HOUSE, to a woman named ALICE SMITH; the mother claiming her son upon the ground that ALICE was an improper guardian for FRANK.

ON THE NILE, Near Assouan. My last was dated or concluded at Thebes. I shall not here speak of the magnificence that surrounded us there, nor of the splendor of the sunset on that evening of the Sabbath, or the glory of his rising the next morning. I stood on the summit of the lofty propylon of the great temple of Luxor to see his coming. I was alone.

SPIRITUALISM IN BRUNSWICK, ME.--Two persons in Brunswick, Mo., have recently become insane, and, as it is stated, in consequence of their belief in, or practice of, the rites of Spiritualism. In the same village, the other day, a gentleman lost his pocketbook. The robbed party visited a clairvoyant, and she made a communication indicating almost unmistakably the person who committed the theft.

THE OCCUPATION OF FORMOSA.--We understand, from the best authority, that an American merchant named ROBINET, doing business at Apes Hall, has for some time, by permission of the Chinese authorities, kept the American flag flying over his establishment.

A FOUL AND CRUEL MURDER--Our community has been startled by the intelligence that between 2 and 4 o'clock, on yesterday morning, a most revolting butchery was committed upon the person of LEW. IS WILLIAMS, a cab-driver of this city. WILLIAMS was an elderly man, remarkable for the sobriety and correctness of his deportment, and known to have had about his person from seventy five to one hundred dollars. The circumstances so far as ascer.

x NIBLO'S GARDEN.--Mr. BROUGHAM's Benefit on Saturday evening was a complete success, and at tracted an unusually crowded attendance, even for this universally patronized house. The performance of BoURCICAULT'S comedy of "London Assurance" went off with great unction, and was hugely enjoyed. After this Mr. BROUGHAM came forward and made a " Farewell Speech"-an effort which, being out of his usual line, was scarcely up to the customary standard.

At a Republican ratification meeting, held in Cincinnati on the 20th Governor CHASE made a speech in which he referred to the Rescue cases and said: We have a right to have our State laws obeyed, We don't mean to resist federal authority. Just or unjust laws, properly administered, will be respected. If dissatisfied, we will go to the ballot box and redress our wrongs.

Political leaders seem to be greatly disturbed at the exceeding demoralization, as they style it, of political parties. They are alarmed at the reluctance of the masses-at their refusal, even-to respond to the requirements of party discipline. They issue their edicts-they erect their platforms-they summon the lo al hosts who have hitherto followed their banners to a renewal of the conflict-but their commands fall unheeded upon dull and inattentive ears.

THE EFFECTS OF FAST DRIVING.--Last evening, about 8 o'clock, as a chaise, containing two gentlemen, was passing down Hamilton-avenue, near the ferry, it came in contact with a double-horse carriage, precipitating the occupants of the chaise on the sidewalk. One of the gentlemen struck his head against a lamp-post, which rendered him insensible for a few minutes.

WATERING PLACES.--With the exception of Newport and Hampton Beach, the various Summor ?? places on the New-England coast have been well patronized this season, notwithstanding the depression of business and the coolness of July and August.

Public attention is now concentrated on the forthcoming elections in October. Considerable diversity of opinion prevails among the Free-State Party as to the course of action to be pursued by them when the election-day arrives. Some strenuously urge on the whole Free-State force the propriety of ignoring the elections altogether, and of adhering, through every chance of fortune, to the Topeka State Constitution and organization.

Since our last report the weather nas oeen the for pushing herd grass and most crops, there being little rain, but generally cloudy. More sunshine would have benefited the growing Corn. The harvesting, now about over, has been comparatively little interrupted by storms, and Wheat has been gathered in better condition than usual.

Some weeks ago, in a conversation in the Examiner office, a gentleman of this city remarked that he had in his possession an old porcelain mug, with an effigy of Gen. WASHINGTON on horseback, and the inscription beneath, "GEORGE WASHINGTON, Esq., General In-Chief of the United States Army and Marshal of France." A discussion thereupon arose as to whether WASHINGTON had ever received the baton of a Marshal of France.

The grave had scarcely closed over BEEANGER, when another of the great writers of France was stricken down. Tuesday morning the telegraph brought us the news of the death of EUGENE SUE, at Aunecy, in Savoy, where he has lived since the coup d'etat of 1851. EUGENE SUE was born at Paris on New-Year's day, 1801, and is the descendant of a family distinguished through several generations.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: I find that the leading Mormons in Utah, and that creature of BRIGHAM YOUNG'S, who edits the Mormon, in New-York, have boldly asserted that, as fast as the timi rolls round, the foreignborn subjects are duly naturalized in the Courts of Utah Territory. We have important intelligence with reference to the progress of the Great Atlantic Telegraph Expedition. The screw steamship Edinburg, Capt. CUMMINS, from Glasgow, 9th of August, via the North Channel on Thursday, 13th, arrived at this port yesterday. She: reports that on the 14th inst, 800 miles west of Ireland, she passed two steam vessels, supposed to be the two English steamships carrying the Telegraph Cable.

CRIME ON EMIGRANT SHIPS,--MARY JANE BRETT, a passenger on the ship Cambia, from Liverpool, complained on landing at Castle Garden on the 18th ult., of ill usage on the ship during the voyage. Her statement amounted to the charge that soon after leaving Liverpool the second-mate had seduced her under an alleged promise of marriage, and that during the rest of the voyage he had repeated elicit connection with her.

An inportant decision has just been rendered by Judge WILLIAM B. WRIGHT, of the Supreme Court, in the case of JAMES BROWN vs. the Troy and Boston Railroad Company, which is of great importance both here and elsewhere;here, obn account of local associations, and throughout the State from its connection with the contest now going on between Railroad Corporations and citizens and the high ground it takes in favour of the former.

THE INDIAN MUTINY.--Rev. Dr. DUFF, the distinguished Missionary in India, has published a pamphlet upon the causes of the mutiny in Indian. He thinks it absurd to attribute it to the attempt to enforce the use of greased cartridges-though he believes it quite likely that this was the occasion seized upon for an outbreak.

The European mails, to the same date (Aug. 12) as the Anglo-Saxon's intelligence published yesterday, reached us last evening by the City of Washington and North Star. The English papers give in full the last dispatch transmitted through the Transatlantic Cable, three hundred miles at sea, conveying the tidings of the perfect success of the enterprise up that time.

A NEW WAR.--The Philadelphia Press opens its batteries against Harper's Magazine for defaming American women, in speaking of them as bold-faced, loose-tougued, daring, ungracious, flaunting, loud-voiced, bronzed, bold-eyed Amazonians. The Press denies all these sweeping charges, and calls upon HARPER for proof.

WAGSTAFF.--WAGSTAFF, who was killed by THEODORE. S. NIMS on Saturday last, has universally been reported to have been a "Tombs lawyer," or "Shyster," practicing about the Police and other criminal courts of this City. This is a mistake.

Last evening, an adjourned special meeting was held of the Board of Councilmen--the President, JONAS N. PHILLIPS, Esq, in the Chair. The immediate object was to ake action in reference to the judgment in the Lowber case against the City authorities. After the minutes of the preceding meeting had been read and approved, several petitions were referred to appropriate committees.

MORTIMER LIVINGSTON. Esq., of this City, died yesterday, suddenly, at his Summer residence on Staten Island, in the 53d year ot his age. Mr. LIVINGSTON'S conspicuous position in the commercial and social world of New-York, will arrest a more than common attention upon the announcement of his decease.

lion. RICHARD KIDDER MEADE, Minister to Rio de Janeiro, will leave next month for Brazil. His instructions, which are now being prepared, are very important, and relate to the negotiation of a new commercial treaty, and the reduction of the rates of the high Brazilian Tariff. Mr. RANNEY, of North Carolina, will be appointed Secretary of Legation to Brazil.

Signorina VESTVALI may congratulate herself on a season of uninterrupted prosperity: short, perhaps for the ambition, but satisfactory for the exchequer of the fair managers. Many managers have done more, and reaped less. With the present week the experiment comes to an end, and Signorina VESTVALI will try her fortunes else where.

The prologue to the great drama which is yet to be played out over the prostrate empire of the Sultans has just been recited in the House of Commons by Lord PALMERSTON. It was uttered with the fluent grace and infinite dexterity of declamation which belong to that accomplished political whip, but it does not seem to have been very gratefully received by our English friends.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: SIR: In to-day's issue of the TIMES I observe an article from W. W. DBUMMOND, wherein my name is called ?? question, and reflecting upon my character. Therefore, wishing to reply briefly to the same through the columns of the TIMES, I trust you will not hesitate to accord me the privilege.

Much comment has been naturally excited by the recent transfer by the War Department of the Fort Snelling reservation to Mr. FRANKLIN STEELE, for the sum of $90,000. It was well enough that the reserve should be sold. The Government should not have continued to bold in military mortmain eight or nine thousand acres of valuable land in the neighborhood of the growing commercial centre that embraces St. Paul, St. Anthony and Minneapolis.

PUBLIC INSTITUTIONS.--The Boston Mercantile Library has 16,075 volumes of books, and takes 151 newspapers and 45 magazines. Its membership numbers 1,835. Mr. EVERETT'S oration before the Association in February last, netted $1,263. Mrs. KEMBLE'S Shakespearian Festival, in the same month, netted $1,014. The entire lecture receipts, last season, were $6,963, which netted $3,427. The new hall yields an income of $1,397 annually.

The adjourned meeting of the members of the British German Legion, resident in this City, was held last evening st KHEN'S Saloon, No. 19 Chambers-street, Mr. LEBOHENFELDT in the Chair. On this, as on the former occasion, it was interesting to witness the mutual recognition of old comrades who, having parted in the Crimea or in England, now met again in this far-distant land.

TARDY BURIAL.--A complaint was made yesterday to the City Inspector, that a person had died at No. 38 Mulberry-street, on Friday last, and that preparation had not been made to bury the body. The daughter of the deceased "had means," but was drunk and waiting for relatives to come and attend to the matter, she said. The stench had become extremely offensive to the whole neighborhood yesterday morning.

The Semi-Annual Meeting of the American State Council convened in Gothic Hall, Adams-street, Brooklyn, at 12 o'clock M., yesterday. Before this hour had arrived, one hundred and seventy-five delegates, representing a majority of the Councils in the State, reported themselves to the Secretary in the ante-room, to whom they presented their credentials, and, if correct, received the special pass-word, which enabled them to pass the Sergeant-at-Arms stationed at the hall door.

SUICIDE BY A LADY.--Mrs. HARBYER NORTON, a native of New-York, aged 26 years, committed suicide on Sunday night, at her residence, No. 296 West Thirty-Second-Street, by taking laudanum. Coroner Hills held an inquest yesterday, at whichit appeared that she was married to her second husband three months since, and that the marriage did not prove a happy one.

THE SLAVER JUPITER.--A schooner named the Jupiter, carrying American colors, is reported to have been seized on the 15th of last month, at Aghway, on the west coast of Africa, with a number of slaves on board. Whence is this Jupiter! Is she a New-Yorker? and who owns her? Some of the wise ones say that she is though no such schooner is registered at the New-York Custom-House.

The Field family record is summed up by an exchange, as follows: Few families of brothers exhibit more talent and enterprise than the Fields, natives of Stockbridge, Mass., but now all occupying prominent positions before the country. Cyrus W. Field, long known as an extensive dealer in paper in the City of New-York, has lately rendered his name familiar to the world by his prominent connection with the Ocean Telegraph.

ADMINISTRATION OF DR. BURDELL'S ESTATE. The heirs of Dr. BURDELL have agreed upon WM. BURDELL and GEO. D. BULIN as the parties for whom they will apply to have letters granted of administration upon the estate of Dr. BURDELL. WM. BURDELL is a brother of the deceased and resides in Ohio. Mr. BULIN is a brother-in-law of Dr. BURDELL and resides in this City.

MUDER AT SOUTH DANVERS, MASS.---The Boston Journal has particulars of the murder at South Danvers. Saturday night there had been at the house of JAMES FITZGIBBON, What the Irish call a christening. About 30 persons, principally men, were present, and they remained there until nearly 2 o'clock, at which time they began to disperse. Among those present were NICHOLAB BARRIGAN and his wife.

MORMON ENTERPRISE.--The new "Deseret Alphabet" is completed, and a fount of Pica type has been cast in St. Louis. specimens of the type are published in the St. Louis papers, but they are unproducible in types that common people use. The type-founders have supplied the Mormons with moulds and other apparatus for recasting their old metal.

There was a pretty general stampede in Wall-street yesterday, and Bulls and Bears Longs and Shorts, were so intermingled in the pell-mell that it was difficult to distinguish one from the other. The rushing and crushing of fancy men and fancy stocks rendered the scene rather interesting to an outsider who could feel entirely sure that his own underpinning stood in no danger.

Dr. RAE appeared before the Ethnological Section of the American Association, while in session in Montreal, and was requested to give an account of Lis Arctic travels. In complying, the Doctor stated that he labored under the disadvantage of being taken by surprise in this matter, and will not therefore be expected to say much. The Doctor then exhibited some relies of Sir JOHN FRANKLIN'S party, which he happened to have about him, and explained.

A meeting of the First Regiment New-York Volunteers was held last evening at the Mercer street House, their headquarters. The object of the meeting, as specified in the call, was to make arrangements for the reception of the Peensylvania Volunteers, who intend visiting this City on the 14th of next month, to unite with the New-York Volunteers in celebrating the Tenth Anniversary of the Capture of the City of Mexico.

The first necessity of political parties is what is technically styled an issue. There can be no fighting when there is nothing to fight about. For those who live by fighting, therefore, a causa belli is the one thing needful. No cool observer can help seeing that just now all political parties are considerably embarrassed by the lack of such an issue.

There was another crash in Wall-street yesterday. JACOB LITTLE failed again, and his example was imitated by several others. They were all, however, of the fraternity of StockGamblers, and failed mainly because they found it more convenient to do so than to pay their losses or fulfil their contracts.

BRIDGING THE HUDSON.-The Albany Atlas and Argus contradicts the report sent to this City by Telegraph that the Company chartered to bridge the Hudson at Albany had abandoned the project, in consequence of Judge NELSON'S decision, and were about to tunnel the River.

FRAUDS UPON THE NEW-YORK CUSTOM HOUSE BY PHILADELPHIA IMPORTERS,-- Intelligence was received, a few days since, at this Custom House, in this City. that a series of frauds had been perpetrated upon the Custom House here by an importing house in Philadelphia. THE ARSENAL PROPERTY.-We understand that the City Chamberlain, under the direction of Comptroller FLAGG, yesterday paid into the Manhattan Company, to the credit of the Treasurer of the State of New York, the sum of $275,000, in payment of the Arsenal property on Sixty-firststreet.

SUPREME COURT--SPECIAL TERM.--AUG. 26. Before Judge Peabody. John P. Treadwell, Virgil Whitcomb Charles Lamb vs. John M. Lawler.--A civil suit has been commenced against John Lawler, who was charged with embezzling his employers' funds, while acting in the capacity of book-keeper for them at the St. Nicholas-Hotel.

AFFAIRS AT THE NAVY YARD.-There is considerable work now going on at the Brooklyn Navy Yard and quite a number of vessels are undergoing repairs. The old Frigate Sivannah is in the Dry Dock and is being razed down to her copper. The old timber are most of them sound, but the model is of the most clumsy description-- regular old tub.

A meeting of merchants was held at the Merchants' Exchange yesterday afternoon, for the purpose of expressing a sense of the loss which has been sustained in the death of MORTIMER LIVINGSTON. WILLIAM WHITLOOK, Jr., called the meeting to order shortly after 3 o'clock, and upon his nomination JAMES BROWN, Esq., was appointed Chairman, FREDERIOK L. TALCOTT, Esq., was chosen secretary.

At a late hour yesterday afternoon Deputy Superintendent CAEPENTR obtained information that a new counterfeit had been prepared, and that It was to be very extensively palmed off upon the unsuspeeting public last evening. After much trouble Doputy CABPETER succeeded in obtaining possession of a copy of the new bill, which he only did by investing a genuine $3.

FATAL RAILROAD ACCIDENT.--A heart rending accident occurred yesterday afternoon at Peekskill. A gentleman named THOMAS SEWELL, a retired merchant of Baltimore,in attempting to get into the cars at Peekskill, while the cars were moving, fell upon the track, and, before the train could be stopped, three cars had passed over his body.

SCOTT-At Plainfield, N. J. on Tuesday, Aug. 25 after a lingering illness. MOSES WARREN SCOTT, Esq., in the 9th year of his age The relative and friends of his family, and those of his mother in law, Mrs. Whitehead Cornell, are respectfully invited to attend his funeral, from the house of the latter. No 83?? Monroe place. Brooklyn, at 4 o'clock, Thursday Afternoon, without further notice.

AN ARTFUL DODGE--THE REPORTERS OFF THE TRACK.--We learn, from very good authority, that many of the rowdies wounded in the great Sixth Ward riot, on the last Fourth of July, were conveyed stealthily to St. Vincent's Hospital, corner of Eleventh-street and Seventh-avenue, where they were placed under the care of Dr. MICHAEL A. FINNELL, the Resident Surgeon.

IMPUDENCE IN A HOUSE THIEF.--PETER RINGLEY, a young German who perambulates the City with a basket containing a few buttons and other small articles, under the pretence of being a peddler, was arrested by officer HAMBLIN, of the Third Precinet, charged with stealing coats, pants, vests and other articles of clothing, worth $50, from the boarding house of Mrs. WILSON, No. 59 Murray street.

About one hundred delegates, representing nearly all the New-England Banks, met here to-day to take preliminary measures for a Bank of mutual redemption, to take the place of the Suffolk Bank redemption system. Mr. BATES of the Westfield Bank, presided. It was announced that the half million of dollars capital required by the charter had been nearly all subscribed.

A HORSE-RACING CHALLENGE TO ENGLAND.--The Savannah Georgian is authorized by responsible gentlemen to make the following challenge--which is open to the world--viz: To run a match race of four miles and repeat, at such times as may be agreed upon, post entries for $100,000 a side, the horses to carry weight for age, to be run over the Ten Broock Course at that place. Lieutenant-General SCOTT has arrived here, in obedience to a telegraphic clepatch sent him. Today he is in consultation with the secretary of War in reference to military movement in Kansas and Utah.

The steamer America, at Halifax yesterday, reported that the first attempt to lay the Telegraphic Cable across the Atlantic had failed. The cable on board the Niagara parted at a distance of 335 miles from the Irish coast, and the vessels had returned.

At the close of the camp-meeting for Greensboro Circuit, Caroline County, Md, held at Boonsboro and which closed a few days ago, there was witnessed one of the greatest Pro-Slavery outrages which has ever occurred in the State of Maryland.

The body of a young woman, named Mrs. ELLEN TILLMAN, was found yesterday floating near the foot of Wall-street, in the East River. Apparently the corpse had been in the water two or three days. An inquest was held upon it by Coroner MILLS, and a verdict of "Supposed drowning" rendered. The body, however, was not identified until after the inquest.

The National Emancipation Convention met here yesterday afternoon, and temporarily organized by choosing Mr. ELLIOTT, of Indiana, Chairman, and Mr. DENNI??ON, of Buffalo, Secretary. After arranging for the appointment of the usual Committees, the Convention adjourned until this morning. The attendance was not large.

A LONG TERM.--A convict was discharged from sing sing prison on the 5th inst., who had spent thirty years in the State prison, He was sent to the old City prison in 1823, for the term of fourteen years. He was one of a chain-gang sent to Sing Sing in 1828, to build that prison. At the expiration of his term he was out about three years, then sent back for ten years.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: The most effectual way of touching the compassion of railroad companies seems to be through the public Press. Appeals to directors, , for abatement of nuisances and protection of passengers, are of no avail.

NAUTICAL EXPERIMENT.--The steamboat Mazappa was chartered to convey a party of shipowners, sea captains, underwriters, and other invited guests on Thursday morning to Sandy Hook, to test the utility of Capt. CAVSNDT'S tripod for ascertaining latitude and longitude in foggy weather. Capt. C. perfected the invention during his last trip in the steamship Washington.

PAVEMENT FOR ROADWAYS.-The Acting Commissioner of Patents has received from the Department of State a copy of a letter from Consul EPPING, describing the manner of paving mads in Old-enburg with bricks made of a peculiar clay, which, it is suggested, may be found in this country, and which may be made applicable to the same purpose in marshy districts.

A terrific hurricane passed over a portion of Wisconsin on Friday night last. At Woodland, on the La Crosse railroad, the station house was blown down, ears blown from the track, and others set in motion. The station-master, Mr. Fox, while endeavoring to stop one train of freight cars set in motion by the wind, Was run over and killed.

GOVERNOR ROLLINS ON BACHELORS.-The fol lowing is a specimen of the free-and-easy style with which Major ROLLINS, the recently-elected Governor of Missouri, has been addressing the people of that State: "All I have to say is this, if you should elect me Governor, I think the administration of the State, and the city government under my friend WIMER, will go on harmoniously and swimmingly together.

HARDLY NECESSARY.--The Boston Daily Advertiser says: "We scarcely need to direct our readers' attention to the reckless manner in which business is conducted in the City of New-York." We should say it would hardly be worth while to do so, while the Advertiser has State-street s much more conveniently at hand to point a moral with.

RELIGIOUS SERVICES AT THE ALMSHOUSE.--A communication was lately sent to the Common Council of Jersey City, by members of the Roman Catholic Church, complaining of the religious services at the Almshouse on Sundays, as sectarian Several of the Aldermen stated at the time that such was not the case, as they had been present at different times and listened.

A YOUNG WIFE DESTROYING HERSELF FROM JEALCUSY.-Mrs. MATILDA KALTENBACHER, who resided with her husband and two sisters in the building No. 186 Court-street, took poison on Sunday night, about 11 o'clock, and died from its effects yesterday morning. Mrs. J. had been married about two years, and was the mother of one child.

A disturbance occurred in the lager bier saloon of ERNEST ERHARD, No. 62 Reade street, about 8 o'clock last evening. A man named HUGH P. HOARE entered the place and demanded payment for a hat which he said was destroyed by one of the girls of the saloon when he last visited the place. Payment was refused, and HOARE became so noisy that the landlord and others present attempted to expel him.

THE CITY FINANCES. -- Six hundred and twenty-six thousand dollars of revenue bonds fall due on the 15th of September, but as the tax books, which are now in the comptroller's office, having the tax arrears written in will soon be open for the convenience of property holders, this gum will likely be paid off without the issue of more bonds.

The last accounts from the East report that Delhi is still in the hands of the insurgents, and likely to remain so for a considerable time longer; but the British Government are making vigorous preparations to reconquer and reestablish their empire in India, and no one can doubt their ultimate success.

The steamship .4 merica arrived at Boston yesterday afternoon, and a portion of her mails was dispatched by the evening train on the Now- Iaven Railroad, and arrived in this C ity about 1 o'clock this morning The very full summary of the America's news received by telegraph from Halifax, comprised everything of importance.

Agreeable to announcement the friends of Compensated Emancipation convened at the Melodeoh yesterday afternoon, at 3 o'clock P. M. The objects of the meeting were briefly stated by Elihu Burritt, being the same as expressed in substance in the Call which we have heretofore published.

Before Judge Hoffman. THE METROPOLITAN BANK Vs. JOHN THOMPSON. Judge HOFFMAN granted the order of arrest against Mr. Thompson upon the affidavit of James L. Jaques, Vice-President of the Metropolitan Bank Mr. Thompson is still in the custody of Deputy Sheriff Steme.

A BRIEF PANIC.-The Wall-street panic of the present week, if very severe for a while, has proved one of the briefest we have ever known. It had scarcely begun before it was at an end. Even JACOB LITTLE, who is rather accustomed to such things, found he was more scared than hurt, and, after failing a whole day, concluded to go on again. The organ of Parker Vein and Potosi an.

Kansas is Low suffering from an attack of rumors and threats--a dreadful complication of disorder. The crisis occurs in October, and fears are expressed that the patient will be seized with another fit of convulsions before we can look for a perfect recovery.

From the Baltimore Sun. About ten days since. a man accompanied by two females, one of whom was represented to be his wife, and the other his sister, arrived in this city and stopped at one of the principal hotels. On Monday of last week they left the hotel, saying that they were going to Washington, instead of which they went to a house on North street, where the man had engagedd board for them.

CONSUMPTION OF COTTON IN OLDENBURG, GERMANY.--An intelligent correspondent, writing to the State Department, calls attention to the increase in the consumption of cotton in Oldenburg, Germany, since i?s accession to the Zollverein. Previous to 1854 (the correspondent adds) very little cotton was consumed in this county.

The St. Paul Daily Times says: "We have been shown the device of the Seal and Coat of Arms adopted by the Republican Convention for our future State. it represents a waterfall--supposed to be that of Miunehaha--within a shield, symbolizing the abundant and varied water-power and privilege in the State.

A NEW ADJECTIVE WANTED.--The Telegraphic News Agent at Halifax, in sending over the Wires the announcement of the disaster to the Atlantic Cable, says: "Unfortunately the cable broke," and one of our provincial cotemporaries yesterday remarked that he regarded the disaster as " most unfortunate."

DARING ROBBERY OF A VESSEL, BY RIVER-TRIEVER--THE CAPTAIN SHOT.--About 4 o'clock, yesterday morning, two river thieves boarded the sloop Thomas B. Casey, Capt. B. I. FORD, lying at anchor in the East River, off the foot of Joralemon-street, Brocklyn, and succeeded in stealing the Captain's watch from his pocket, and also a valise containing clothing and papers of value.

HARRISON-MYERS.-In this City, on Thursday, Aug. 27, by Rev. Dr. Dowling, Mr. THOMAS J. HARRISON to Miss LIZZIE H. MYERS, of this City. LEONARD-MORTON-In this City, on Thursday, Aug. 27, by Rev. Dr. Osgood, Mr. CHAS. H. LEONARD, of this City, to ELIZA L., youngest daughter of the late Wm. R. Mortou, formerly of Cincinnati.

BANK MANAGEMENT.-Would it not be well for stockholders of Banks to give a little more attention to the discount policy very generally pursued by their Directors? To a very great extent many of our Banks have been devoted to the convenience of the Stock gamblers, and of speculators generally, to the serious detriment of the sound and legitimate business of the City.

RECOVERY OF THE CHICAGO DEPOT GROUNDS OF THE ILLINOIS CENTRAL ROAD--Our readers will recollect that some two months ago it was announced in the papers that a suit was about to be commenced in this city by GEO. C. BATES, Esq., of Detroit, against the Illinois Central Railroad, for the land on which their passenger and freight Depots in this city are situated.

Union of the City Democracy. The Cooper Democratic General Committee met last evening at Tammany Hall. There was a large attendance; EDWARD COOPER, Esq., the Chairman, presiding. After the usual routine business had been dispatched, Capt. RYNDERS rose to a question of privilege.

From the Toronto Globe. It will be interesting to men of science, who have been perplexed with the philosophical anomalies of this strange instrument, to learn that Mr. M'CARROLL, of this city, Surveyor of Customs, is said, on high authority, to have thrown great light upon this abstruse paradox, if not to have solved the deep problem to its fullest extent.

The causes of the accident to the TELEGRAPHIC CABLES are perfectly apparent from the statements already published upon the subject. It seems that while the Niagxra was proceeding steadily and safely, paying out the cable at the rate of about four miles an hour, one of the Engineers thought it was going out too fast, and in order to check it applied the brakes to the drums over which it was passing.

The sun of an American literary celebrity has set. RUFUS WILMOT GRISWOLD is no more. A lingering illness, under which he has labored for a number of years, last evening assumed a fatal termination, and he breathed his last at his residence in this City, at 6 3/4 o'clock, at the age of 42.

CURIOUS ARSON CASE. IN PHILADELPHIA.--About 1 o'clock this morning an old two-story brick and frame dwelling, No. 46 Frankford-road, opposite Queen-street, Sixteenth Ward, was discovered to be on fire. The flames were seen by a woman opposite, who gave the alarm by springing a rattle. The flames quickly communicated to an old frame shanty adjoining, upon the south, and belonging to Mr. GEO. CADWALLADER. The frame, which was unoccupied.

THE GHRMAN RIOTS.--Officer CROFUT, of the Seventeenth precinct, who was badly injured during the Mayor's not at the City Hall, is again, according to Captain HARTT'S report, in a critical condition. His brain appears to be affected, and he complains of shooting pain along the spine. Officer DE GROUCHE, who was hurt in his shoulder and left knee during the riot in the Seventh Ward, it is believed, will lose his left leg.

COMING BACK.--The watering-place season, this year, has been a decided failure, let the cause be what it may. A blight seems to have fallen upon the business, and the few pleasure-seekers who went to Newport, Saratoga, and so forth, in quest of enjoyment. are all hurrying back again; compelled partly by the cheerless aspect of the howls, and partly by the coldness of the weather.

SALE OF PUTNAM'S MONTHLY.--We understand that Putnam's Magazine was yesterday Sold to the Proprietors of Emerson's United States Magazine, and that it will hereafter be incorporated with the publication under the name of Emerson's Putnam, or something of that sort.

ANOTHER EMBEZZLING YOUNG MAN.--The Cincinnati Gazette of the 27th, says: A young was of this City, (abase name we withhold) recently residing in New-York, of highly respectable parentage, cultivated mind and polished manners, was arrested day before yesterday upon two charges of embezzlement, one preferred by Messrs. STABLING, CUSHING HEGEMAN, and the other by STEWART, CUSHING HEGEMAN both mercantlle firms of New-York.

ANOTHER FAST "YOUNG MAN."--Mr. EDWIN A. BROOKS, of Fulton street, is the victim this time. Some months since, finding that his increasing business could not be accommodated in the building No 150 Fulton street, Mr. BROOKS established a branch at No. 156. and placed there one of his clerks, LEWIS P. NEWELL, as salesman.

The Fourth Annual Meeting of this Teachers, Association was held in this place, on the 12th, 13th, and 14th inst. Theme were about two hundred teachers present, and the exercises were interesting. One who had been familiar with similar gatherings at the East could not but observe that nearly all of the teachers who took an active part in the meeting were formerly teachers from New-York State, or from New. England.

The United States mail steamship Philadelphia, ALFEKD G. GRAY, commanding, arrived at the port Yesterday, from Havana, on the 23d inst. We are indebted to the Pureer for packages. The Philadelphia landed 40 passengers and $100,00 in specie at Havana, and brings 30 passengers and $102,000 in specie for this port.

E. O. PERRIN, Private Secretary of Governor WALKER has arrived here. He left the latter's camp, at Lawrence, ten days ago, and reports that all was peaceful and quiet, and that there was not the least intimation of war or bloodshed. Governor WALKER uses the army as a posse comitatus when the civil an thorities cannot make arrests "for breaches of the peace. The 1,500 troops in Kansas will remain there until after the election.

From the Washington Union. The Secretary of the Treasury has, on appeal decided that the Collector of the port of New-York properly charged a duty of 24 per cent. on an article described as "an embroidered cut velvet ?? upper," being cotton velvet elaborately ?? and cut in slips or patterns of the size and shape of slippers.

We have received filed of the Correio Mercantil of Rio do Janciro to the 15th July. The Correin gives some particulars of the German emigration to Brazil. We translate: it appears that a Mr. HORN, whois at Potedam organizing the system, has made arrangements for transporting over 1;000 emigrants, chiefly Saxons, by steam to Rio de Janeiro, whence they are to be sent to the River Mercury.

THE WOOL, CLIP OF ILLINOIS.-The entire clip of wool grown in this State this season is estimated at four millions of pounds, nearly all of which has ere this passed from the growers into the hands of dealers and manufacturers. The average price at which buyers have purchased it, is about forty cents per pound, making the entire clip of the season worth $l,600,000; quite an important item.

ADVERTISING FOR PLANS.-When a man is goingg to indulge in the luxury of building himself a house, or laying out extensive pleasure grounds, or in the duty of erecting a costly monument to commemorate the virtues of a deceased friend, he never thinks of advertising for plans or designs.

One of the largest meetings ever held in this city, or, indeed, in this Province, was held last night in the St. Lawrence Hall, to take into consideration the Hudson's Bay Territory question. The meeting was more than ordinarily respectable, being largely made up of the merchants, business people, and coiet property owners of the city.

Two horrible occurrences took place during the course of last night at West Troy, either one of which is sufficiently targical. Is seems that Mr. ROBERT MORRISON, proprietor of the Skiff Ferry, between this city and West Troy, kept near the landing at the latter place, two tame bears chained to a snake.

GUY, which left Baltimore on Wednesday afternoon, with some 200 ladies and gentleman aboard, on an excursion to Annapolis, when a short distance from that city, between 5 and 6 o'clock, ran into a brig in tow of the steamer Belvidere.

This afternoon the Santa Fe mail reached as, and the gleanings of my correspondence and the papers you have herewith. The season has been unusually dry and cold, and the crops look very badly. So little rain has fallen that the little stream near Santa Fe is dried up. The arrival of the merchant trains enlivaned the country a little, and for awhile all was bustle and confusion.

NEWARK BAY LIGHT-HOUSES.--An appropriation of $40,000 having been made by Congress for the construction of the light-houses and foundations on Bergen Reef and Passaic Lights, the work is now progressing under the charge of Captain McALISTER, of Albany, to whom the contract has been awarded. The foundations are constructed of a very hard stone--next in hardness to flint-brought from the North River.

We give this morning an interesting letter from our special correspondent in Halifax, detailing the preparations made in the Provinces for the reception of the Telegraphic fleet--preparations thrown away, it is true, in consequence of the disaster, but which nevertheless, show the spirit with which the Colonists entered into the spirit of the enterprise.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: How would the following plan work in laying the Atlantic Telegraph Cable? Have two district cables-one paying out on the starboard and the other n the larboard side of the ship, and connect them at reasonable distances; say every half-mile.

CHARGE OF BURGLARY--CAUGHT IN THE ACT.--Shortly after 12 o'clock on Thursday night, a man giving his name as JOHN TAYLOR, was caught in the engine room of Mr. EDWARD KAEST'S foundry, No. 68 Duane street, which, as is alleged, he had burglariously entered by foreign open a rear door by means of false keys of picks.

FRENCH WAR STEAMER TONNERRE.-This Unfortunate vessel, some weeks at Quarantine with yel. low fever on board, weighed anchor yesterday, homeward hound. She will have a sad report to make. Out of a hundred men, eighty were, from first to last, attacked, and sixteen fell victims of the scourge, three on the passage from Vera Cruz, and thirteen afterwards. The lives of five of these last, however.

Contrary to public expectation, the complicity of MAZZINI in the late conspiracy against the Emperor, was clearly shown on the trial of his hired instruments at Paris. You will see these details in the journals, and I need not therefore attempt any analysis here. It was no less a matter of surprise that a man occupying the position of a great revolutiopary leader should have concocted so bungling a programme.

THE CRYSTAL PALACE.--We looked in at the Crystal Palace, yesterday, after the severe storm of Tuesday night, with a view to discover how true were certain statements, in which the Palace building is spoken of as a miserable wreck, open on all sides to the action of wind and rain.

BURGLARY AT SING SING.--On Thursday night last the dry goods store of McCORD YOUNG, at Sing Sing, was entered by burglars and relieved of about $2.000 worth of silks, satins, shawls, broadcloths, The thieves effected an entrance by pry ing off a shutter of one of the front windows and breaking through a pane of glass.

The America's mails arrived in this City early yesterday morning. A portion of theo details of the European news was given in our Morning Edition of yesterday. Further particulars of the disaster to the Atlantic Telegraph Cable will be found in another column, together with a letter from our Halifax Correspondent.

Gov. CHASE made a speech a Cincinnati on the 20th inst, in which he referred at considerable length to the recent defalcation in the Treasury of the State. He paid: Fellow citizens: I am not here to night for the purpose of amusing you with a sounding political arrange, but I came to address myself to your consciences and enlightened judgment.

TWO MEN KILLED.-The Richmond South says: We learn that a very serious accident, attended with loss of life, occurred on the farm of Mr. HENRY, living on Fish Creek Hills, in Marshall County, last Monday. It appears that that section of Marshall country was, like this section, visited with a severe storm last Monday afternoon.
