MURDER.--A most bloody and unprovoked murder occurred last evening, in a coffee-house kept by Mrs. SIDDONS, at the corner of Euphresine and Libberty streets. The perpetrator of the deed was JAMES NORAN, and the victim was JOHN RENON. They were countrymer, and had been playing cards together during the afternoon, when a dispute arose concerning the game, RENON complsining that NOLAN was not playing fairly.

A VERY BAD FAILURE.--Among the failures of the present season most to be deplored, after the Atlantic Telegraph failure, is that of the Delaware peach crop. Peaches are among the principal solace of Autumn, and to be deprived of one of our accustomed luxuries at a season like this, puts one's philosophy to the test.

THE NEW HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES.--Although the senate wing of the Capital is steadily advancing in every story, the House wing is receiving most actention. A large number of hands are employed in laying the floor of the Representatives' hall, which will apparently not taken many days to complete.

FRUIT TRADE OF BOSTON.--The receipts of fruit t this port have been larger this season than for many years, and the sales of the various kinda of reen and dry fruit have been very extensive, and to all parts of this country and the British Provinces. Boston greatly leads all other cities in its importation of Levant and mary other kinds of Mediterranean produce.

A crowed was collected early in the day in the vicinity of the Trust Company building, but the parties were engaged in securing the gra?fication of an idle curiosity.

This has been a day of recovery. The Indian news, although it confirmed the report current last evening, appeared satisfactory when taken in conjuction with the details regarding the checks inflicted upon the mutineers at all points, the amount of the force before Delhi, the pacific behaviour of the general population, and the continued faithfulness of the Bombay and Madras armies.

Our neighbors in the Island of Cuba, who have been passing through a long paroxysm of the same disease by which Wall- street was attacked in the beginning of this week, seem to he now in a fair way of recovery. Excessive speculation, excited by the promising debut of the Cuban Credit Mobilier, had been followed by an intense revulsion of doubt, distrust and financial disability.

HORRIBLE DEATH OF A BOY.--Yesterday afternoon, a boy, apparently net more that 14 years of age, was found by the police lying upon a cellar aoor on Howard street. He appeared completely stupefied by liquor or some drug, and as no one could identify him, or account for his condition, he was placed in a furniture car and taken to the station, where he was locked up in a cell.

KILLED IN ATTEMPTING TO OBTAIN A WAGER--An inquest was held on Saterday by Coroner CONNERY, On board the schooner Helen, lying at the foot of Wall-street, upon the body of BENABO McKENNA, Who was killed by falling from the masthoad. MICHAEL GANEY, a longshoreman, died early on Saturday morning, at the Hospital, from injuries received the night previous on the Becond avenue railroad, corner of Oliver and Chatham streets. GANEY was intoxicated, and a little inclined to be disorderly, and, in this condition, got on one of the cars; and when the conductor came around to collect the fare, this passenger refused.

The new school of Presbyterians met here in Convention yesterday. The usual officers were chosen, and a Committee on Resolutions was appointed. It was stated in debating a resolution on organization, that a number of churches which sympathized with the Convention were not represented from motives of delicacy

We publish this morning a great variety of interesting matter relating to the deplorable accident of the Atlantic Telegraphic Cable. From these accounts, and from the letter of an intelligent correspondent on board the steamer Niagara, it would appear that the expedition must have failed, even thought the cable had not parted when it did.

A dispatch was received last night from New-Orleans by M. O. ROBERTS, Esq., announcing that the California steamship lllinois, about whose non-arrival some anxiety has been experieneed, went ashore on Colorado Reef, where she remained for three days. She was finally hauled off by the Empire City and another steamer, and proceeded to Havana, which port she would leave on the 30th for New-York.

She has a cargo of marble, wine, There was a pilot on board, but had not charge of the vessel, She had forty. two passengers, who came up to the City this morning, overland, and are now at the Castle Garden depot. MORE ANTI-SLAVERY DISTURBANCE IN KENTUCKY.--We have been informed that Rev. J. G. FES, the celebrated Anti.Stavery preacher in Kentucky, went into Rockborth Country--the Country from which he was driven two or three weeks since--on last Sabbath to listen to a sermon delivered by a Presbyterian minister. The rabble at Mount Vernon, hearing he was in the County, started to seize him.

FUNERAL OF WASHINGTON M. SMITH.--The funeral ceremonies of W. M. SMITH took place in Dr. PHILLIPS' church, on Sunday afternoon. The church was filled, and the religious services were performed by Chancellor FERRIS, who made a brief prayer, after which he read several appropriate passages from different parts of the Bible, and upon them based an impressive discourse, into which he wove an interesting biographical sketch of the deceased.

The steamship Empire City from New-York and Havans, Aug. 27, arrived here last night, with the California mails of Aug. 5. The United States mail steamship Illinois, from Aspinwall for New York, with the mails and $1,600,000 in treasure, went ashore on Colorado Reef, whence she was got off with much difficulty, by means of assistance from Havana, but fortunately sustained but little damage.

ANECDOTE OF JOHN RANDOLPH.-He was traveling through a part of Virginia in which he was unacquainted. During the time he stopped a night at an inn near the forks of the road. the inkeeper was a fine gentleman, and no doubt one of the first families of the Old dominion. Knowing who his distinguished guest was, he endeavored during the evening to draw him into a conversation, but failed in all his efforts.

THE PARK--A DEN OF THIEVES.--The Park always badly neglected, in every respect, was never more so than now. Vehicles of every kind pass through it during the day without may interference, and at night it is thronged with the lowest and most vicious of both sexes. It is in fact, about as bad as Broadway after 9 o'clock at night.

THE LAW COURTS FOR: SEPTEMBER.--The business of some of the Law Courts will begin to increase the present month. Judges and lawyers are returning from the country, and the Courts will soon be very busy again. The only Trial Term that will be held this month is the Circuit of the Supreme Court, which will commence on the second Monday.

The first Convention veer assembled on this continent for the purpose of devising measures for the compensated emacipation of the Southern Slaves, concluded its session yesterday in this city. From thee Leabenworth Times Extra. Saturday, August 22, 1857, will always be a memorable day in the histrory of Atchison. For although the events of that day are not distinguished by anything worthy or honorable, they are of a nature not easily to be forgotten. The remembrance of some public outrage or wrong is as keenly felt as that of something memorable or note-worthy.

The Money panic, which was last week kept within the precincts of Wall-street, yesterday assumed the more threatening phase of a Bank excitement. From the New-York Exammer. Governor MARCY was always true to his convictions on the Slavery question. " Slavery is yours," said he to a Southern gentleman, who was endeavoring to commend the institution to his favor, " and you have the political right to retain it as long as you please, and to estimate it as a blessing; but we of the North want none of it; to us it would be an unmitigated cause."

UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT-SEPT. 1. Before Judge Botts. The United States District Court was opened this morning. The formal business of the Court was disposed of and the Court adjourned until next Tuesday morning at 11 o'clock.

An Educational Convention has been held at Richmond, at which Governor WISE was invited to speak, and inhis sppech made some remarkable developments. He declared that he had found that, for several years, from thirty to thrity-five per cent, of the Literary Fund had gone into the pockets of private officers,"and doing no other good on earth, that he could ascertain, but to aid the retail trade of the country."

The Democratic mountain has been in labor for the past ten days. All the Democratic doctors have been giving their closest attention to the interesting condition of Motier Tam. many, but it appears that their diagnosis of the symptoms was entirely erroneous.

Perhaps you will think it is not my business at this distance, to talk of the dirty streets, and the mal-administration of the City of New-York, so I will hasten to tell you why I attack this subject. A New-Yorker asked me the other day if I thought of coming homesoon?

THE ALLEGED ROBBERY OF UNSIGNED BANK NOTES.--The following statement appears in the Boston papers of Monday: A statement has appeared in several of the morning papers of this date, to the effect that bank-notes to the amount of at least $50,000 have recently been stolen from the office of the New-England Bank Note Company, and are now proably in circulation.

On Monday afternoon Deputy-Superintendent CARPENTER received information that a heavy defalcation had taken place in the Bank of the Mechanics' Balking Associaation, Wall-Street, and that Mr. EDWIN VAN BLARCOM, long the Paying teller of the Institution referred to, was suspescted, and strongly, too, of being the delinquent.

A large meeting of citizens of Copiah County, Misss., was held at Gallatin on the 6th inst., Hon. STEPHEN H. JOHNSON, in the Chair--to cousalt on the proper couree to be purbued relative to late developments which implicate cerrain residen's of the county, as being engaged in practices particularly objectial to individual and popular interests.

Among the old indictments recently revivified by the law authorities of the Territory, was one against CHARLES ROBINSON, the soi-disant Governor, for usurpation of office. In the general amnesty granted to all political offenders by the prosecuting officer, in the Spring of the current year, it was supposed that the case of ROBINSON was included.

If any evidence were wanted of Miss KEEZE's tact in management, It was certainly afforded on Tuesday night in the election of two pieces so entimely opposite in their merits as "Angeline" and " A Conjugal Lesson" for first performances on the same night. Nothing in the world ever needed to be propped up with something stronger than "Angeline," a one-act drame of the most dismal French schools destitute alike of literary and constructive merit.

Of all the failures which have disturbed and excited the community during the last ten days, the greatest and we trust the last, occurred yesterday, in the recoil of the Panic-manufacturers from the steady front presented by most of the Banks, and by the great business world outside the agitated circles of Wallstreet.

The first contest between Flora Temple and Lancet has just taken place. The conditions were: Mile heats, best two in three, with Flora Temple in harness and Lancet under the saddle. The following is the result: First, Flora Temple; second, Lancet; third, Miller's Damsel; and fourth, Red Bird Time, 2:28 and 2:27. Ten thousand people were on the ground.

This morning the Convention began at an early hour to transact important business, The preamble and resolutions presented last evening by the Business Committee, of which Dr. BOYD is Chairman, were taken up as the first order of the day, and discussed seriatim. The Convention, in the early part of the discussion, went into Committee of the Whole.

SECOND DAY'S PROCEEDINGS. The Association of Presidents, Superintendents and others connected with railroads, now holding their first meeting, at the room of the American Institute, No. 351 Broadway, assembled yesterday for the second day of their session, at 10 1/2 o'clock. After the usual preliminary proceedings, the Business Committee reported the order of business for the day.

RUN OVER-DANGEROUSLY INJUIRED.- On Tuesday night, ROBERT ARMSTRONG--a man employEd to water stage horses at the South Ferry-atempted to get from the top of a stage, corner of Broadway and Worth-street, while much intoxicat. ed, and fell to the pavement. Before he could get out of the way, an omnibus of the Fifth-avenue line came along and run over him.

THE MOTION DISCHARGE THE HABEAS CORPUS DENIED, WITH A RESERVATION. SUPREME COURT-SPECIAL TERM. Before Judge Peabody. In the matter of the petition of Mrs. E. A. Cunningham for a writ of habeas corpus.--The argument in the case of Mrs. Cunningham, who asks to be released from imprisonment, was continued yesterday.

REMARKABLE RUN OF BAD LUCK.--A down-town merchant received, a remittance from one of his correspondents, in the shape of a draft on the Ohio Life and Trust Company for $83,000, on the very day on which that institution closed its doors.

THE ASTOR LIBRARY.--The Astor Library, after being closed a month for repairs and additions to the building, was opened again to the public on Tuesday. An enlargement of the Superintendent's room has been the principal alteration made. About 1,000 new books, some of rare value, have been added to the library during the month. The total number of books now in the Library is about 97,000.

Baldwin, and niece of Hon, Fernando Wood, all of this City. KING--RUSSELL-In this City, on Tuesday morning, Sept. 1. by Rev. John Brash, Mr. JAMES H. KING to JANE ELLEN, daughter of Samuel Russell, Esq., all of this City.

DON'T MENTION IT.-The Evening Post says: " Great indignation is expressed among all classes of people at those journals which continue to publish idle rumors of apprehended failure and misfortune.. It has been proposed to call a meeting of merchants at the Exchange to give public expression to the prevalent feeling on this subject."

ATTACK ON THE BRITISH ARISTOCRACY.The Tribune, yesterday, devoted a leader to the immoralities of the British Aristocracy, based on a wicked attempt on the part of a clergyman to put a painted window in his church to the memory of a deceased lady. But the Tribune makes strange work of it, in mixing up the living with the dead. Our indignant contemporary says:

Before Hon. Justice Peabody. Joseph Fells VS. Felicita Vestvali and Henry Vestvali--The plaintiff was employed by the defendants as operatic agents in August, 1853, to employ for them singers for the Vestvali Opera Company, and for the transaction of other business. Henry Vestvali being the manager of the troupe and Felicita the prima donna.

Returns of the election come in slowly. So far as heard from 17 Republicans are elected and seven Democrats. The vote for Governor in some of the principal to was is as follows: Woodstock---Fletcher, Republican, 317; Keyes, Democrat, 54. Hartford---Fletcher, 239; Keyes, 75.

BROOKLYN BOARD OF EDUCATION.--This Board met at 5 o'clock P. M. on Tuesday, President SMITH in the Chair. The minutes were read and approved. The evening g School Committee were authorized to open the evening schools at such time as they may deem expedient, and make all other necessary arranger ments to carry the intentions into effect.

The Canal Board held a meeting to-day, the first in several weeks. The Comptroller, Secretary of State, State Treasurer, State Engineer, and Canal Commissioners WHALON and SHERRILL were present. The rate of Canal tolls on stavo bolts and butts was fixed at one mill and three-tenths.

The following is the memorial of Professor SILLIMAN and forty-two others of Connecticut,addressed to His Excellency JAMES BUCHANAN, the President of the United States: The undersigned, citizens of the United States and Electors of the State of Connecticut, respectfully offer to your Excellency this their memorial.

THOMAS--In this City, on Wednesday, Sept. 2, ELIAS THOMAS, in the 74th year of his age. The relatives and friends of the family are invited to attend his funeral, at 9 o'clock on Friday morning 4th inst.. without further invitation. from the residence of his son in law, B. S. Cargill. No. 64 West 26ith t.

ATTEMPTS AT SUICIDE.-MARY STANDARD, a woman residing in Flushing-avenue, Brooklyn, attempted to commit suicide by jumping overboard from a ferry boat, foot of Grand.-street, East River. She was speedily rescued and taken before Justice WOOD, who detained her for the present. No cause for her conduct was assigned. JOHN TONGHEY, of No.

Views of the Naval Officers-Sanguine Hopes - Imperfect Brakes-No Decided Action Yet-Letter from Corus W. Field. The Steamer Vanderbilt, at this port yesterday, from Southampton, puts us in possession of further interesting particulars concerning the Atlantic Telegraph.

The steamship Vanderbilt, Capt. EDWARD HIGCINS, arrived at this port yesterday afternoon, from Eav?? and Southampton. She brings London dates to Aug. 22, three days later than the Atlantic's news. The Vanderbilt brings the unneually large number of 350 passengers, with $100,000 in specie and 1,100 tons of valuable merchandise.

The steamship Varderbilt arrived at this port yesterday from Southampton, bringing dates to Aug. 22. Her news is three days later. The latest intelligence from India was received by telgraph on the day of the sailing of the steamer, and confirms the former statement of the capture of Cawnpore by the insurgents and the massacre of the European inhabitants of the place.

The brig San Michaele, of Genoa, which was seized for violations of the Revenue laws a few days since, is in process of being condemned and sold: the captain and mate have run away, and the crew, who have been discharged with the exception of one who remains to collect their dues, sailed for Genoa on Tuesday in the brigantine San Joan.

PRESERVING A REVOLUTIONARY RELIC.--Hon. JOHN JAY has recently purchased the house situate in the town of Lewisboro', Westchester County, in which Major ANDRE, the spy, was confined subsequent to his interception at Tarrytown by PAULDING, WILLIAMS, and VAN WEET. The building is a one-story plain structure, with a basement or high cellar underneath, and is in a good state of preservation.

The Amphitheatre of the Exhibition was crowded with horses. A majority of the premiums for saddle, carriage and matched horses were awarded to Kentucky. Vice President BRECKINRIDGE and many other distinguished persons were present.

The Memorial of Professor Silliman and Forty-two others, and the Reply of President Buchanan. Owing to the lateness of the hour at which the President's letter in reply to Prof. SILLIMAN came over the wires, we were unable yesterday to give the whole of it in but a portion of our Morning Edition. We therefore republish it this morning entire, with necessary corrections from an official copy.

THE ENCAMPMENT AT POUGHKEEPSIE.--Colonol PRATT was the Field Officer yesterday. The Brigade was reviewed in the afternoon by Brigadier General WRIGHT, OF New. Jersey, The General was received at 3 o" clock, according to the military form. The City Blues from Paterson, N. J., appeared yesterday on the ground. They number 50 muskets, and are commanded by Capt. GRIFFITHS.

Gov. KING left here for New-York to-day, and the Lieutenant -Governor and Comptroller go down to-night, to meet the Commissioners of Emigration at the Astor House, and to-morrow morning, with the Quarantine Commissioners, they all proceed to Soguine's Point, to make an examination prior to a discussion as to the final location of Quarantine.

THE NEW GRAND RESERVOIR.--The contest in regard to the Croton Aqueduct has assumed a triangular shape. It appears that the lowest bidders for the work, DINSMORE WOOD, have amended their bid, as by the ordinances they are allowed to do, and now claim to stand rectus in curia as absolutely the lowest bidder.

The exhibition, to-day, has been attended with a great deal of interest. The assemblage upon the grounds was about the same as yesterday. Nine fire companies entered the contest for the premiums on distance, with the following result: First Class--"Franklin," of Geneva, first premium, $500, played 199 feet 11 inchces.

The U. S. Mail Steamship Idinois, C. S. BOGGS, U. S. N., Commander, arrived at his port early yesterday morning. She left Aspinwall a: 9.30.P. M. on the 19th of August. On the night of the 23d, ran ashore on Colorado Reef, near Avenas Cay, where she remained till the night of the 26th; arrived at Havana on the afternoon of the 27th, and left at 1 P. M. on the 29th.

The Old Dominion," it seems, has not forgotten. the royal memories of her prime, when her name was born on the coins of the Virgin Monarch and the proud ELIZAIIETH gloried in being styled of "England, France, Ireland and Virginia, Queen."

The steamship Asia arrived early yesterday morning from Liverpool. She brings the same dates as he Vanderbilt, but the full files of papers received by her, which failed to roach us by the Vanderbilt, contain important intelligence in relation to the Atlantic Telegraph.

She is built or WILLIAMS GUION's line of Liverpool packets, and is considered one of the most substantial vessels ever built in this yard. She is of 1,400 tons, and has her maces and topmasts in.

Your Bird since its last chant has verity be-. come a bird of flight-though it would doubtless flutter with intensest indignation should it be deemed a flighty bird when thus soreding its pinions before your admiring readers.

WASHINGTON, Thursday, Sept. 3. Mr. AMES, our Minster to Venezuela, received his instructions to day in reference to the Bird Island affair. They are of a peremptory character. He will leave in a few days. Our New-Granada negotiations are almost brought to a close. The Convention stipulates for no cushion of territory. but the privilege of a naval depot is reserved.

CENSUS OF MINNESOTA.--It will be recollected that Congress, at its last session, passed an act authorizing the people of the Territory of Minnesota to form a Constitution and State Government, preparatory to their admission into the Union on an equal footing with the original States. In accordance with this law, delegates to the Constitutional Convention were elected, and two Conventions have been held.

IMPORTANT DECISION -IN-LOTS AND OUT LOTS. -The claimants of certain in-lots and out lots in and adjoining St. Louis and other towns and villages mentioned in the act of Congress of May 26, 1824, were required to come forward and prove up their claims and the extent of the tract within 18 months.

Mr. STUART, the enterprising and capable Manager of this chaste and popular little Temple of the Drama, opened its welcome portals last night There was, of course, a large and fashionable audiencewhoever knew it to be otherwise on the opening of a pet place of amusement--and the impression creased oy the performance was certainly calculated to insure a succession of similar desirable reaulte.

THIRD DAY'S PROCEEDINGS. The Railroad Convention met again yesterday morning at the same place, No. 351 Broadway. There was a larger attendance than on either of the previous days. The Business Committee reported the following proceedings as the order of the day: 1. Appointment of a Committee on Finance and Correspondence.

MASSACHUSETTS FACTORIES STOPPING.--Many of the mills have discontinued work one-sixth of the time, and others have entirely suspended. The factories in Newmarket have yielded to the pressure of the timer, and are still and silent. So at Great Falls, N. H., two of the mills have stopped for two months.

Forty-three respectable citizens of Connecticut, being considerably dissatisfied with the manner in which Governor WALKER is at present managing matters in Kansas, thought proper to write a letter, expressive of their views and feelings, to President BuGHANAN.

PAYMENT OF INTEREST.-During the war of 1812 the United States became indebted to Maryland about half a million of dollars. The principal of that debt was paid off in various sums, at different times between 1818 and 1822, but no interest was paid. In 1825 Congress passed an act authorizing interest to be computed and paid at the Treasury.

Fernando Wood, Mayor of the City of New-York: SIR-During your absence I took measures to prevent a sale of the personal property of the City under an execution in favor of Robert W. Lowber.

THE SUB-TREASURY AND THE CRISIS.With the gradual restoration of a calmer feeling in the financial world, it becomes daily more and more important that all proper steps should be taken to assure a firm basis to the renewed operation of the credit system in our commerce.

The Illinois brings news from Havana to Aug. 21. The Diario, of the 28th August, expresses great confidence that most of the new discredited stocks in that market, will eventually revive and vindiea their character, " Not a few," it says," when the now not distant moment shall come in which the market shall recover its natures equilibrium, will regret that they sold at a loss, or neglected the opportunity of buying at an advantage."

The colored Odd-Follows made a highly imposing parade to-day, on the occasion of laying the corner-stone for their new Hall. Lodges were present from New York City, Harisburg, Reading, Newark, Camden and all the neighboring towns. About a thousand people altogether.

THE AMERICAN INSTITUTE held its monthly meeting Thursday evening. Several members were admitted. It was reported that preparations for opening the fair were nearly completed; the steam power (100 horse) is entirely so. One of Hon's Lightuing Presses will be in operation in a few days.

WILLARD P. DANIKLS, President of the Niagara county Bank at Lockport, was robbed last nigh, on the Central Railroad cars, of a pocket-book containing drafts to the amount of $80,000, mostly on business firms of Albany and New.-York.

The eighty-ninth commencement of Brown University has been in course of celebration this week. The initiatory ceremonies commenced on Tuesday in the annual meeting of the Phi Beta Kappa Society for the election of officers, the Convention of the Alumni, and the meeting of the Philermenian and United Brothers' Society. THE SICKNESS ON BOARD THE ILLINOIS.--There is, apparently, great cruelty and injustice see in the Health Officer at Quarantine, in compelling the passengers by the Illinois to remain on board that vessel, but, we think that the public will approve the caution of the Health Officer in guarding against every possible danger at this season of the year. There have several eases of fever out on board the Illinois and two have proved fatal.

Eastern Tennessee has had the reputation, for some time past, of being an all but Free-Soil district. Its inhabitants have enjoyed the character of being tolerators rather than admirers of Slavery, of cherishing the good old American doctrine that Slavery is an evil, of which it were well we should rid ourselves at the earliest possible moment, having a due regard to the welfare of the blacks and the security of the whites.

Long ere this reaches you the telegraph will, doubtless, hare informed you of the proceedings of the Free-State Convention which met three days ago at Grasshopper Fails. The proceedings are represented to have been harmonious, and the policy reccommended as in the highest degree judicious.

A GREEN POLICEMAN.--At a circus performance in Brooklyn, Wednesday evening, Policeman CULAHAN, of the Fourteenth Ward, arrested one of the performers who entered the ring in character as an intoxicated person.

Before Hon. Justice Peabody. Charles A. Rapallo vs. The Mechanics' Banking Association,--Much interest is manifested in this case, the Court room being much crowded each day. Upon the matter coming up today, Judge PEABODY declared his conclusion that a Receiver should be appointed. Some thirty names had been recommended to him at his house, in the street, and in the Court room.

The trial of ABIGAIL GARDNER, for the murder of her husband, HOSES JAMES GARDNER, last Postmaster at Hingham, by administering arsenic to him, has occupied the Supreme Judicial Court, in session at Plymouth, nearly the whole week.

REYNOLDS.--In this City, on Friday morning, Sept. 4, of consumption, O.J. REYNOLDS, aged 45 years. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend his funeral, from his late residence No. 162 Prince st, on Sunday, 6th inst, at 2 o'clock P.M. without further invitation. His remains will be taken to Greenwood Cemetery for interment.

The Presbyterian Convention, which has been a session since Thursday last, has this moment adjourned---so nearly at the hour of midnight that your correspondent hardly knows whether to say "Sept. 1," or "Sept. 2."

The Union says of Mr. Hawthorne: "This distinguished author has resigned the consulate at Liverpool, which place he has killed for four years with great ability and credit to himself, as well as most satisfactorily to the Government, and to those of his countryman with whom he has been brought into contact.

THE NEW-YORK "VOLUNTEER ASSOCIATIONS" - A large number of the East Regiment New York Volunteers met at the Mercer House last evening, pursuant to a call signed by WILLIAM PEEL, EDWARD REYNOLDS, CHARLES M. BROWKE and ST other Volunteers. Capt. CHAS H. IONIS called the meeting to order, and CHAS, M. BROWER acted as Secretary.

The fireman's grand muster came off in this city to-day. The weather has been delightful and the city thronged. About sixty companies were present. The grand procession, composed of nearly 3,500 firemen in uniform, with a great number of bands of music, and with their apparatuse. Tastefully decorated, stated at 91/3 o'clock this morning, and marched round the City Hall, making a brilliant appearance.

EXCISE COMMISSIONERS,--The Board continued its sessions yesterday for the granting of licenses. Present--Commissioners HOLMES, KERR and HASKETT A petition was presented by MICHAEL CALLAHAN setting forth that a license had been granted to JEERMIAH CALLAHAN, in July last. Whereas he was the party applying, and that the license should have been made out in his name.

Some 18 sick persons were landed from her, a portion of them having been sick since they left. Aspinwall, and others being attacked since the steamer sailed from Havana, where she put in after her unfortunate grounding upon Colorado reef.

FOUR CLERKS RELIEVED FROM SUSPICION OF LARCENY.-- For some time past a series of small rob beries have been committed at the dry goods store No. 143 Exchange-place, and some thirty dozen superfine linen handkerchiefs have been among the articles stolen. The proprietors of the store suspected the rogue to be one of their clerks.

The English journals comment with warm and natural satisfaction upon the temper which has been generally manifested by the Press of this country in treating of the Indian troubles of Great Britain. "While the unemployed politicians of Paris," says the London Times of the 19th of August, "are for the twentieth time prophesying the decline of English greatness, a juster appreciation of the Indian crisis s?eres to prevail in the United States."

FUNERAL DISCOURSE.--St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Jersey City will be reopened to-morrow, on which occasion the Rector, Rev. J. J. BOWDEN, will preach a discourse upon the death of the late Miss ROBINSON, who was lost on board of the propeller J. N. Harris, at the time of the recent disaster to that vessel upon the Sound.

THE ENCAMPMENT AT POUGHKEEPSIE.--The Eighth Brigade Encampment, hold near Poughkeepsie this week, has been one of the most attractive military exhibitions ever witnessed in this country. Amongst the companies invited and who appeared upon the ground, were the "City Blues," from Paterson, N.J., the 20th Regiment, from Ulster County, and the "Washington Continentals," from Newburg.

Academy of Medicise--September Meeting. The regular monthly meeting of the Academy of Medicine was held in the small chapel of the University on Wednesday evening, Dr. MOTT, President, in the chair. A motion to increase the annual duos from $3 to $5 was proposed by the Treasurer, and by rule laid over till next meeting.

To-day the great sale of stock imported from Great Britain and Ireland, in July last, by the Bhoois Importing Association, came off. Several thousand persons were present, and newspaper reporters were as plenty as files at a dinner table.

My first visit to this city was some two weeks since. On entering the town from the East, the elegant residences, with their tastefully adorned grounds, o closely resembling those commonly met with in he suburban towns of New-York City, presented to me such a home-like picture, I could hardly realize that I was not in the immediate vicinity of your own City.

The locomotive, tender and baggage car of the Thursday evening Long Island train for Brooklyn was thrown off the track six miles east of Jamaica. Mr. GEORGE WILLIS, of North Brooklyn, and his son GEORGE, were standing on the platform of the first passenger car, and were severely but not fatally injured. No other passenger was injured.

For some years past the attention of the public has been annually called to consider the necessity of providing for the removal of the Quarantine station of this port from its present locality. Since the establishment was fixed where it now is, there has grown up around it a population asdense as that of many of the upper Wards of this City.

The Kansas excitement may now be said to be fairly at an end. The most rabid of the fire-eating journals in Virginia are silent upon the subject, seeing, no doubt, that such an agitation would not be consistent with the possibility of their existence under the pressure of an overwhelming conservative sentiment.

TWO FIRES IN NEW-ORLEANS. NEW ORLEANS, Friday, Sept. 4. Two fires occurred here this morning, the first at MOLONY BROTHERS, on Magazine-street; and the second at a coffee house, on St. Charles-street. The loss by both is about $70.000, and the insurance about $16,000.

She had the same thickness of veil, and the same strong look, occasionally covered by a handkerchief.

This most abortive of all Parliamentary sessions comes to its appropriate lame and impotent conclusion on Tuesday next, when the houses are to be prorogued; not by the Queen in person, who is new voyaging about the Channel, dropping in at Cherbourg and elsewhere along the French Coast, but by commission.

A violent thunder-storm passed over this city and vicinity yesterday. The sky was of a curious violet color, and gusts of wind and rain demolished severalfences, , within the city limits. At 6 o'clock it began to be bruited here that the Suspension Bridge was blown away, and we immediately dispatched a reporter to the spot.

THE NAVAL COURTS--CASES TO COME UP.--ON Monday the three Naval Counts will be fully organized for the prompt transaction of business. The remaining cases have been prepared by Mr. CARLISLE, so as to be acted upon more systematically and yet with more dispatch than before the recess:

For the, first time a successful attempt has been made to obtain the news from a European steamer passing Cape Race. A telegraphic dispatch, published elsewhere, announces that the Araqo with four days' later intelligence, passed Cape Race about noon on Thursday last. She will consequently be due at this port to-day. No political news of importance is reported.

On Thursday evening, an affair took place in the St. Ann's Suburbs, which terminated in the death of a man named DEMPSNY. It seems that, for sometime, a picquet of two or three officers has nightly gone the rounds of that ward with police, in search of soldiers absent from roll-call in the evening.

FAARRAR--In this City, on Saturday, Sept. 5, SIMON FARPER, in the 38th year of his age. The friends of the family, and those of his son, George C. Farrar, ?? intied to attend his funeral, this day, (Monday.) at 1 o'clock P. M., from the Church of the Messiah, No. 728 Broadway. The remains will be taken to New Hampshire for interment.

MUTINY AMONG THE BRITISH TROOPS IN CANADA.--We are sorry to hear that the 39th Regiment is by no means at this moment in a proper state of discipline. The approaching removal to Quebec, and excepted order to sail for India, are viewed with great ?? and desertions have of late become so numerous, as to render conf?? in barracks for some days past necessary.

A serious collision took place on the Camden and Atlantic Railroad to day, between an express and a freight train. The disaster occurred near Whitehorse, N. J., eleven miles below this city. WM. SINER a merchant doing business here, and the engineer and a fireman of the express train were killed and thirteen wounded, some ofhem seriously.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: In your issue of this morning I find it stated that I was discharged from the Second Ward Station-House by Justice BRENNAN. This is entirely a mistake on the Part of your reporter, as Justice BRENNAN placed me in the custody of an officer, to appear in the morning before the Police Court at the Tombs.

Mrs. CUNNINGHAM BURDELL has one quality, usually considered a good one, that of perseverance. Her greatest enemy must admit as much in her favor. No sooner is one lawyer worn out in her service than she finds means to procure another. After exhausting the Bar of New-York, that of Boston comes zealously to her rescue. The virtuee of perseverance," however, is not always successful.

There are now, it is stated, about 1,700 men employed in this yard; the number sometimes reaches 2,500. The ship New-York, the keel of which was laid in 1821, is not yet completed. She is a largeship. The steamship Powhatan, the propeller Colorado, frigate United States, brig Perry, and the Pennsylvania, the latter a receiving ship, are now lying near the wharves.

The United States Mail steamship Arago, Captain LINES, from Havre and Southampton on the 26th of August, passed Cape Race at about noon of Thursday, the 3d instant. Theo Arago will be due at NewYork on Monday next. Her advices, which are four days later than those received by the Vanderbilt and Asia at New York, were obtained by a fishing smack, and brought to this port.

A NEW SCHOOL HOUSE.--The large new first class school edifice, No. 20, on Chrystie-street, near Rivington, in the Tenth Ward, will be opened for regular daily school sessions to-day, Sept. 7. The area of each floor contains 7,500 square feet, divided into assembling rooms on each floor, fifty by seventy-one foot, with eight class rooms, twenty by thirty feet, capable of seating sixty-five pupils each.

The President's letter to the Connecticut clergy. men continues to produce excitement among all classes of politicians. It is rumored that it is to be followed, in a few days, by the pubilcation of a pamphlet, semiofficial, on Kansas State Rights, and a full defence of the Administration and Governor WALKER.

NEW CLOCKS AT THE CITY HALL.--The eleven clocks which are hereafter to furnish correct time in the City Hall, regulated, through galvanic apparatus, by a clock in the Mayor's office, were yesterday set upon their niches in the rooms of the various departments. The frame of each clock is about two feet in diameter. The dials are white, with black lettering, and the inscription, "HALL'S Patent, Sept. 26. 1854.

The Board of Excise Commissioners met yesterday at the City HaL to grant licenses, -present, Commissioners HASKETT and HOLMES. No business was transacted beyond the reading of the minutes of the previous meeting, as not a single individual applied for a cense. Adjourned to this day at 1 o'clock.

The unusual course pursued at Quarantine in the case of the steamer Illinois and her passengers, has excited a natural anxiety in the public mind, and has suggested a query as to the nature of the disease which has rendered it necessary, in the opinion of the Health Officer, to detain her 600 passengers within the Quarantine limits for so long a time, and to send the steamer to the lower anchorage.

THE ATLANTIC TELEGRAPH.--Communications continue to pour in upon us from all quarters giving suggestions, many of which are ingenious, and many merely repetitions of ideas already published, for laying the Cable securely when another attempt shall be made. But there would be no use in publishing these communications even if we had abundant space for them. They could have no influence where they could be of any service.

FLOUR--Better grades lower. Sales 1,300 bbls., at $5@$5 25 for superfine and $5 37@$6 for fair to very choice extra. WHEAT lower--Sales 12,000 bushels; Chicago Spring at 87 1/2c., @90c, closing at the inside prices. CORN lower--Sales 30,000 bushels, at 59c. @co. c, closing at the inside prices. OATS lower--Sales; 5,000 bushels, at 36 1/2e. WHISKY has advanced--Sales 200 bbls., at 22c.@22 1/2c.

AN APPENAL TO THIE RURAL DISTRICTS.--A most remarkable document was presented in the Board of Councilmen last night, purporting to be an "Address of the Mayor, Aldermen and Commonalty of the City of New-York, to the People of the State." It was made by a Special Committee, appointed for the purpose of drafting it, was ordered to be printed, and made the special order for Thursday next.

The United States Mail steamship Arage, from Havre and Southampton on the 26th ult., and the screw steamship Kangaroo, from Liverpool on the same day, arrived at this port yesterday. The mails by these vessels are of four days' later date than those received by the Asia and Vanderbilt.

The Charleston Courier, in animadverting recently upon an extract from these columns, professed an entire inability to perceive why the public opinion and the public sentiment of Christendom should be so bitterly opposed to any discussion of the institution of Slavery on its abstract merits.

The U. S. Mail Steamer Arago, Capt. LINES, arrived here yesterday morning from Havre and Southampton with advice to Aug 26. The Arago brings 210 passengers, most of them first class, the usual mails, $100,000 in Specie and 400 tons Merchandise.

CITY TAXES.--The Tax books were delivered yesterday morning into the hands of the Receiver of Taxes, and receiving pay for Taxes commenced directly afterwards. The amount of money paid in yesterday was $37,000, of which $15,000 was paid by the Shoe and Leather Bank. This is a much smaller sum than has been received for years on the opening-day of Tax-paying.

SUPREME COURT--SPECIAL TERM. Judge BIRDSEYE opened a Special Term of this Court in Brooklyn yesterday. N. P. O'BRIEN, Esq., Counsel for James PECAN, whose hay was taken a way District of Brooklyn, moved for judgement in the amount of damages claimed.

QUARANTINE MATTERS.-There was no fresh cases of disease at Quarantine yesterday, inside or outside of the walls, and the surviving patients from the Illinois were doing well There was one exoeption only, to this, who would probably die, making six deaths out of the whole number landed from that steamer.

The official report from Quarantine, yesterday, was very favorable as respects the condition of the yellow-fever patients from the steamer Illinois. With the exception of one case which may prove fatal, all the remaining cases were improving, and would recover.

The Banks' Young Men's Mass Convention assembled at his place shortly after 11 o'clock this morning and was well attended. About 1,200 persons were present. DISTRICT COURT--SMEGGLING.__JOHN THOMAS PRENTICE, first mate of the American Steamship Arago, was arrested on Monday evening, charged with smuggling laces and embroideries, to the amount of upwards of $5,000. The American Board of Commissioners of Foreign Missions commenced its forty-eighth annual meeting, at the Boneficent Church in this city, at 4 o'clock 1'. Mf. Hon. THEODORE FRELIN CHUYSHN presided. After prayer, J. M. GORDEN, Treasurer, presented his report. The receipts of the year, from all sources, have been $389,932, and the expenditures $91,788. The debt has been reduced from $36,191 to $2,847.

FIGHT BETWEEN ST. PAUL CALVALRY AND CIHPPEWA INDIANS.--We mentioned the depacture, on Monday last, of the St. Paul Light Cavalry Company to Cambridge, to remove from that vicinity a number of Chippewa Indians, who have been commisting depredations in the neighborhood of Sunrise Settlement.

INDIVIDUAL, LIABILITY OF BANK STOCKHOLDERS.--The clause of the New-York State Constitution in regard to the individual liability of the stockholders of all Banks of issue, not only for their circulation, if not fully secured at the Bank Department at Albany, but for the security of their deposits, is genera] and conclusive.

SELECTION OF GRAND JURORS.-Under an act of the State Legislature, passed Jan. 13, 1853, the Chief-Justice of the Superior Court, the firs Judge of the Court of Common Pleas, the Mayor, City Judge and Recorder are constituted a Board to prepare a list of names from which to select the grand Juries of the year. The Board held its first meeting yesterday at 2 P.M., at the Mayor's Office.

The man who comes to a Newport hotel in search of quiet is about as great a victim of misplaced confidence as can well be imagined. In the first place, the quiet man is always put directly over the ball-room; and, in the second place, he receives all those little distressing attentions, called stares, which dressed-up automatons are in the habit of bestowing upon human beings.

ALLEGED MURDER IN PHILADELPHIA.--At an early hour yesterday morning a German woman. about fifty years of age, was found lying in bed at her residance at the northest corner of South and Seventh streets. with her throat cut. Her natee was CATHARINE VOLDERS. Suspicion fell upon the husband of the deceased, and he was arrested and charged with murder. The Coroner commonced an investigation.

WRATH OF THE BRITSH LION.--A recent number of Punch has a large picture, in which the state of feeling in England towards India is forcibly represented by a fierce lion springing upon a Bengal tiger, which is crouching upon a woman and her infant child. The lien is England, the tiger is rebel India, and the woman and child the Anglo-Indian subjects who have been sacrificed by the cruel Sepoys.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: The Republican Convention of the Second Assembly district met here to-day for the purpose of electing delegates to the State and Judicial Conventions. The Session commenced at 2 o'clock P. M., and has but just terminated after an animated debate of nearly two hours' duration, so that time is but left. me to give you the leading business points.

REPORTED FAILURES.--In panicy times, like the present, the utmost caution and prudence should be observed in relation to rumors of mercantile failures. It is sufficiently bad to make known the actual failures and suspensions that take place; but irreparable mischief may be produced by circulating the idle rumors floating about in relation to the difficulties of solvent houses. Last evening, the Republican Associations of the various words in this City below Fourteenth-street, held elections for delegates to the Republican City Convention, which is to meet on Thursday next at No. 659 Broadway, to select the delegates from each Assembly District (below Fourteenth-street) tp the Republican State Convention on the 23d inst.

THE SURROGATES' COURT--WILL OF THE LATE RUKES W. GRESWOLD.--Yesterday was an unusually busy day at the Surrogate's office. The business was mainly, however, of a routine nature, and embraced applications for registry of wills, and orders touching the sptilement and administration of estates. The only thing of public interest was the offering for prolate the will of the late RUTES W. GBISWOLD.

The Judge announced this morning that he would hear motions, and various members of the Bar immediately proceeded to give reasons why their particular motions should not be heard this morning.

To the Editor A New-York Daily Times: We left the city of Dubuque, at 10 o'clock this morning, for St. Paul's and the neighboring localities. The steamer is very heavily laden with merchandise, household goods, farming utensils and passengers. The number of my fellow travelers is about two hundred. The shores of the river are here (fifty miles above Dubuque) billy and rocky.

ONE OF THE JURIES.--A man, arrested for intoxication, was tried before justice CORNWELL and a Jury, in Brooklyn, on Monday last. Four witnesses awere positively that the defendant was intoxicased at the time or immediately after the arrest. For the defence, five witnesses swore that they did not see the accused intoxicated the day of his arrest--neithor one of whom saw him at the time or immediately subsequent to the arrest.

JONES.--In this City, on Tuesday morning, Sept. 8, ISAAO RUTHVEN JONES, in the 29th year of his age. His relatives and friends, and those of his brothers-in. leave. A. R. Cuxshurn and Dr. C. Dixon Vailey, are respectivvily invited to attend his funeral, this (Wednesday) afternoon, at 5 o'clock, from his late residence, No. 240 West 22d st., without further invitation.

DESTRUCTION OF ARAMINK PRINT WORKS AT CONSHOHOCKEN, PA.--At an early hour this morning a fire broke out in the extensive Print and Bleaching Works, situated on the banks of the river Schuylkill, opposite Conshohocken. They were destroyed-nothing but the bare walls remaining. The buildings were large and valuable.

FATAL AND MYSTERIOUS STAERING.--The Commissioners of Emigration received information on Wednesday that an Italian organ-grinder, named CHESERO TAVELONI, was lying dangerously wounded, at No. 36 Baxter-street. The Commissioners' wagon was sent for him, and he was taken to the New-York Hospital.

A MONSTER--In a Miramichi paper we see an account of a huge Greenland whale that was lately fallen in with by fishing schooner Samuel Gilbert, of Gloucester, Mass. about 20 or 25 miles off land, and by that vessel towed into Tracadio harbor, where in new lies. The whale is 75 feet long, and 25 to 30 feet through, the head 30 feet long, and the lips 20 feet.

Delivered at the Ratification Convention in Worcester, Mass. At the Young Men's Ratification Convention in Worcester, on Wednesday, Mr. BANKS made the following speech: It is now nearly two years since the Representatives of the people in the Northern States found themselves arrayed in the House of Representatives of the United States, against the party, North and South, which had supported the repeal of the Missouri Compromise.

TOBACCO IN CONNECTICUT.-The farmers in this vicinity commenced cutting the most for ward of their pieces of tobacco last week, Some of the more back ward pieces, however, need eight or ten days more of warm weather to perfect them. The slight touch of frost which was apparent this (Monday) morning and the cool air of to-day, has alarmed some of the producers and they have gone to work vigorously.

Judge Bailhache, a venerable citizen of Illinois, died on the 22d inst. from the effects of the injuries he received, by being thrown from a carriage at Alton on the 1st inst. Judge Bailhache was one of the moat widely known and respected citizens of the State.

The packing building of WILLIAM BUSSELL'S powder mills in this place" was blown up about 8 o'clock last night . The hands employed in the mills had all left for the night excepting the watchman. It is supposed that the building was fired by two boys, about eight years old, who were playing with matches near it; and one of their a ten of H. E. BRADFORD, was instantly killed, and the otter fatally injured.

THE GREATEST STEAM INVENTION YET.--The Baton Rouge Gazette, under the above heading, has the following: WM. ST. MARTIN, of this city, has invented an engine which can be constructed, boiler and all, for about $50. The machine is so simple that we might with propriety say it is merely an escape pipe, taking up no more room.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Tuesday, Sep. 8, 1857. The annual meeting of the American Board of commissioners for Foreign Missions, (or, more briefly, is the "A. B. C. F. M.") is now in progress in this city. The number of members and visitors, now in town to attend its sessions, is unprecedented. It is estimated that one thousand ministers are present,

MILITARY FIGHT AT WEEHAWKEN.--Last Monday two volunteer military companies left this City to go on an excursion to Weehawken, and left the foot of Spring-street on the steamboat Rodman M. Price. On their arrival at Weehawken one company went to Pollock's Pavillion, attached to which is a target ground. The other company took up their quarters at a rival hotel, kept by a man named WILSON.

THE, GREAT REPUBLIC AT THE OPERA.We like the expansive American mind. We enjoy the " Great Republican" magniloquence, and its magnificence as well. Heroes, as rough as our b'ars, and as wild as our pararers: have no terrors for us. But we must be al lowed to express a preference in favor of canpacious scenes in which to taste these enjoyments.

A STRANGE CASE OF POISONING.--The Warsaw (R I) Telegraph publishes the following: "A family residing in South Gardner, Mass., were recently poisoned by eating meat after it had been stung by a wasp. The particulars are as follows: The lady having boiled a piece of corned beef, placed it in the window to cool. It had been there but a few moments.

A State Convention of National Americans was held at Music Hall to-day. Hon. WILLIAM S. KING presided, and 900 delegates were present. Speeches were made as Hon. W. S. KING, Hon. DANIEL WARREN, A. A. LAWRENCE, and other prominent members of the party. At the ballot for a candidate for Governor, HENRY J. GARDNER had 593 votes to 108 for A. A. LAWRENCE ; and Gov. GARDNER's nomination was then made unanimous.

The delegates to the Democratic State Conven tion at Syracuse assembled for organization at 11 o'clock, yesterday, and were called to order about 12, by PRTER CAGGER, a member of the State Central Committee. CAGGER nominated Hon. WILLIAM TAYLOR, of Onondaga, as permanent President, arid he was elected with very little opposition.

The Republican City Convention for electing Delegates to the State Convention, to be held at Syracuse on the 23d inst., assenbled last evening at the Republican Committee rooms, No. 659 Broadway. The Convention was called to order by M. N. JOMES, of the Third Ward, who nominated AUGUSTUS F. Dow, of the Ninth Ward, as temporary Chairman.

ANOTHER OUTRAGE.--A German was found insensible yesterday morning, in a field at Bay Ridge, Brooklyn. His skull was fractured, and there were other evidences of violence about his person. It is supposed that he was waylaid, robbed and drugged into the field by the villains, who supposed undoubtedly that he was dead. He was taken to the Hospital by Inspector COMES, of the Eighth Precinct.

TROOPS FOR KANSAS.--The concentration of troops upon the frontier by the government is still going on. Two of the companies of light artillery, which have been for some time at Fortress Monroe, Old Point Comfort, came up in the Norfolk steamer on Friday, and were landed here at Fort McHenry, and yesterday evening they went forward by the Baltimore and Ohio railroad on their way to Fort Leavenworth, Kansas territory.

Labor is the basis of wealth. The terms, dollars, pounds, , are merely conventional, applied by common consent to various coins made of the precious metals, which represent, for the convenience of exchange or trade, a certain amount of value, i. c., labor applied to material substances.

The second day's proceedings of the Democratic tate Convention at Syracuse, contrary to expectation, opened quite harmoniously. A caucus of the New-York Delegates had been held in the morning, at which a list had been agreed upon to be presented to the Convention, consisting of eight from the Cooper and eight from the Wilson Small Delegations, the seventeenth man being selected by the sixteen.

The latest news from India does not materially change the dismal aspect of affairs for the British, the success of the faithful native troops at Cawnpore being the only favorable gleam of intelligence from that quarter. It is now nearly three months since the rebellion assumed a formidable shape, and yet, up to the last accounts, the English have been unsuc cessful in every attempt to arrest it.

QUARANTINE MATTER.--The steamship Illinois was yesterday discharged from Quarantine, and she came up last evening, and went to Hunter's Point to go upon the ways for repair. She has been perfectly freed from all impurities, and is pronounced by the Health Officer perfectly free from infection.

CONGREGATIONALISM IN MASSACHUSETTS.--There are now 472 Calvinistic Congregational Churches in the State of Massachusetts, aud only twenty six towns in the Commonwealth without a church of that order. The variours churches have 350 pastors, and 60 stated supplies. There are 150 ministers reported wih.

There was some considerable talk this morning that the Delegates from New-York would be able to settle their difficulties before the hour for assembling of the Convention, so that they would appear as a unit in the deliberations of that body. Some effort was indeed made toward producing that result, but I hardly think any of the parties were very much in earnest.

The mall from all points South, as late as due, is to hand. The Charleston Courier has later dates from Bahamas. The Second West India Regiment had ar. lived there from Jamaica. At Bagged Island salt-raking was being vigorously prosecuted, but at Turks' Island nothing was doing. Col. WEATHERALL, of the First West India Regiment, was dead.

THE METHODIST QUARTERLY--A recent editorial article in the Methodist Quarterly Review, by Dr. WHIDON, against Slavery, has created some sensation in the Methodist Church and some remark in the Methodist newspapers,--for the reason that it takes the strongest anti-Slavery position ever as sumed in the editorial department of that Review The Northern Independent hails the article as a most gratifying circumstance,

HOW THE NOMINATIONS WERE RECEIVED AT TAMMANY HALL AND THE PEWTER MUG.--There was no expression at Tammany Hall last evening, in renation to the nominations made by the State Convenion at Syracuse-there were no cheers given, nor lights lit, nor was there any throng of disputants.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: The great match between the St. George's and the New-York Cricket Clubs, was terminated abruptly, on Thursday evening, by the New-Yorkers refusing to send in their last man. The cause assigned was that it was fifteen minutes after the hour (6 o'clock) at which the stumps were drawn,

Receipts of the week--3,400 bales, against 12,600 bales in the same week of last year. Stock in port--11,000 bales. FLOUR is steady, with a large export inquiry. WHEAT steady. CORN firm, at 70c.@75c. Court No. 2 consists of Captain McKean, captain Pape and Captain Van Brunt; and Charles Aoert, Judge Advocate.

About 8 o'clock yesterday morning, as the ferry boat Onalaska, of the Peck.slip line, was on her way from Williamsburg, she came in collision with the ferryboat George Law, of the James slip and South Tenth. street ferry, causing serious damage to the Onalasha, and putting in jeopardy the lives and limbs of some three or four hundred passengers.

HOWELL, Division Engineer for the Middle Division, were discharged from service, and OSVILLE W. STORY and C. W. WENTZ appointed in their places. The defeat of Mr. TEN BROECK'S horses in England, besides creating ten times as much fuss as the whole affair was worth, has led many people to repeat with greater emphasis than ever the old question: Has the practice of racing any really useful effect upon the breed of horses? There are many who unhesitatingly reply in the negative,

The session for this afternoon was unusualy short. The crowded state of the house at the hour of assembling, together with the increasing heat of the weather, rendered the andience impatient. After an hour or more had been spent in addresses these tokens were wisely taken into account, and an early motion of adjournment was moved and passed without dissent.

The President has recognized CHARLES EDWARD KORTHIGHT as Consul of her Britannic majesty for Pennsyivania, to reside in Philadelphia; and DENNIS DONOHOE as Consul of Her Majesty at Buffalo. The British Consul for New-York has not yet ask. ed to be officially recognized; JOSEPH R. BROWN has been appointed Indian Agent for the Sioux Indians of Minuestota vice FLANDEEAU. resigned.

Yesterday, we had the pleasure of an interview with Elder SAMUEL W. RICHARDS, of Utah, who arrived in this City on thursday evening, after the remarkably short trip of twenty-eight days from Great Salt Lake City. Our dates from Utah by this arrival reach to the 13th of August. Elder RICHARDS left Salt Lake City in company with four others.

SHOTWELL.--In this City, on Thursday, Sept. 10, Mrs. MARY SHOTWILL, in the 90th year of her age, and a native of this City. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, from the residence of her son-in-law, W. C. Magee, No. 91 West 21th-st., on Sunday afternoon at 1 o'clok. Her remains will be taken to Greenwood Cementery for interment.

Our report in another column of the condiof money affairs. at the close of the third week of the existing pressure, is not, in all respects. a satisfactory one, and yet, in the substantial evidences of increasing strength to the market, there is much to encourage the belief that the embarrassment must, or ought. soon, to pass away.

Southern papers from all points as late as due have been received. In Havana, Cuba, the vomito was anabated. The reports of the crops in the interior of the island were very flattering. The report that the vomito was in Sagua La Grande is denied. A cargo of Minie Miles had arrived from Spain.

A Committee of twenty were appointed at the Grasshopper Falls Convention, as prepare and publish an Address to the people of the United States. It is prepared. Although not yet submitted for the approval of the entire Committee, there is no doubt that it will be adopted without alteration, as given below. It is the joint production of General LANE and Mr. CONWAY.

After the close of the Communion Occasion this afternoon, the annual election of officers of the Board for the ensuing year was held. There has been very little change in the list of officers for several years past, until now. But to-day both the President and Vice-President declined a reflection.

IN CHAMBERS-STREET.--A fire occurred in the dry goods store of WILLIAMS POWERS, No, 92 Chambers-street soon after 7 o'clock Saturday evening. It originated among some Colton-batting in the rear of the basement and was very soon extinguished; but the damage done by the fire and water is estimated as high as $10.000. The loss is fully covered by insurance.

PRESENTATION OF THE GOLD SNUFF-BOXR--THE ARRANGEMENTS--THE SCOTT LEGION, JOHN VAN TYNE, returned on Saturday at 11 1/2 A. M., bringing with him ANDREW JACKSON, JR., who is to present the Gold Box to Lieut. Col. GARRET DYCKMAM to-day, in front of the City Hall. Alderman MONEGAN proceeded, on the part of the Joint Committee, to Jersey City to receive Mr. JACKSON.

DISORDERLY HOUSE.--Inspector TURNBULL of the Eighth Preeinet, on Saturday night made a descent, with a party of police, upon the house of ALEXANDER HOAG, corner of Grand and Mercer streets, a resort of prostitutes, and arrested HOAG and several females, who were taken before Justice FLANDREAU. HOAG was held to bail in $500 to answer a charge of keeping a disorderly house, and the women were discharged.

The number of men in all departments, now employed in the Navy Yard is 1,740. The foundation for the new building for Bureau of Provisions and Stores is all excavated, and a considerable portion complete. It is to be 300 feet long by 160 feet wide, and like the other buildings, two stories high. The new purchase is nearly all filled up and the sewers nearly completed.

The long-established Banking-House of Messrs. PRAIN NOURSE suspended payment this morning, owing to difficulty in raising money on their securities. They have made an assignment, and it is represented that their assets largely exceed their liabilities.

There have been of late but few arrivals of vessels with sickness at Quarantine. On the 13th the brig Plata arrived from Trinidad de Cuba, which lost one man by fever on the third day out. The ship Askins, from Havre, with 190 passengers. had one case sent to the Hospital.

GROSS CARELESSNESS IN THE USE OF RUENIOGFLUID--PROPRIETOR OF A DRUG-STORE SEVERELY BURNED.--The alarm of fire at 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon was caused by the explosion of a can of Burning-fluid in the drug-store, corner Governeur and Monroe streets. Dr. GALVAN, the proprietor of the store, was filling a lighted lamp with fluid from a can in which there was nearly a gallon of fluid.

To the Editors of the New-York Times: The Syracuse Correspondent of the NEW-YORK TIMES of Sept. 10 stated that " Mr. CROSWELL waited upon DEAN RICHMOND, Chairman of the State Central Committee, and stated that, as the Convention was clearly against his friends, they would not make any struggle for the officers of the Convention, but would yield the organization to the side represented by Mr. RICHMOND."

Our State election came off to-day. Eighty-ontowns have been heard from, and they give the fol lowing vote: For Governor--MORRILL, Republican, 20,244; SMITH Democrat, 14,592. Republican majority, 5,652.

To the Editor of the New-York Times : I have been credibly informed that important offices in the gift of the President of the United States 'in the General Land Office have remained vacant for a number of years, and that the President had no knowledge till within a few days that there were such offices, and that it was his duty, by and with the advice of the Senate, to fill them.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The proceedings in the matter of a complaint against me, made by Mr. JOHN GIBBS, have been so elaborately set forth in your columns to-day, that a brief explanation seems due to myself and the natural solicitude of my friends.

With a new week we confidently trust that a new temper will begin to manifest itself in the transactions of our business world. The panic which for the moment paralyzed the purely speculative branches of enterprise and checked the natural flow of the more legitimate tides of commerce, is now confessedly at an end.
The steamship Philadelphia brings Havana dates of the 9th inst., and San Francisco advices of the 20th ult, The yellow fever was increasing at Havana. The San Francisco markets were active.

The United States Mail steamship Baltic, from Liverpool on the 2d inst., arrived yesterday. The news from Europe, which is four days later, is not of an important character. Nothing further had occurred with reference to the Atlantic Telegraph, but it seems to be definitively understood that the laying of the cable will be postponed until next Summer.

Nothing of importance has transpired to-day in financial circles. There is some demand for money, but strictly prime paper maturing up to February has been done at 9 1/2@10 ?? cent., though the preference is given to acceptances due this side of January. Other good paper is passed at 11@12.

The American Convention meets here to-morrow. Not a large number of the Delegates are here, but those who have arrived are principally the prominent men of the organization. A good spirit is manifested among the Delegates, and there is an apparent desire to nominate a strong ticket of new men.

NEW-YORK; STATE LIBRATY.--During the month July the State Library building was closed, and within that period the interior has been thoroughly renovated. BOGART.--In this City, on Saturday, Sept. 12, Mrs. JANE BOGART, widow of Abraham, BOGART, in the 77th year of her age. The relatives and friends of the family are invited to attend her funeral, from the residence of F. J. Austin, Esq., 91st-st., near 3d-av., this afternoon, at 3 o'clock, precisely.

Before His Honor Judge Roosevelt. The extraordinary Court of Oyer and Terminer, called by the Governor during the past season, was adjourned in August to yesterday. At 11 o'clock Judge ROOSEVELT took his seat in Circuit, and proceeded with the usual business, of the term. This being disposed of for the morning the Court of Oyer and Terminer was opened in due form.

SUBSIDENCE OF THE PANIC. - There is one good thing about a panic, and especially a financial panic ; from the very nature of the phenomenon it cannot last long. Panies never become chronic. and if they are mischievous in their effects, they are soon over. The financial panic of the present season reached its culminating point last week, and the subsidence is now very perceptibly felt.

The public anxiety to know what turn affairs would take in the matter of-the proposed removal of the Quarantine station, will be relieved to a great extent, by the perusal of the following official documents. They consist of a report from Messrs. HALL and BOWNE, a minority report from Mr. BENSON, and the answer and recommendation of the Governor, Lieutenant-Governor, and Comptroller, upon the whole subject.

MUSICAL FESTIVAL AT BINGHAMTON,--A large gathering of teachers of music, singers, and the lovers of harmony generally, is expected at Binghamton. N.Y., on the occasion of a Musical Festival appointed there for the 28th of this month, to continue four days, under the conductorship of WM.B. BOADBEAY, of this City, assisted by Mr. C.W. BEAMES and Miss.MARIA S. BRANERD.

Yesterday morning Officers WALSH, BURCHELL, DAVIS, WILLETS, HOUSTON AND DELAY, of the Court of General Sessions, made an important seizure of the obscene publications of the man GEORGE ACKERMAN, the publisher of the filthy sheet called Venn's Miscellany. ACKERMAN, it will be remembered, was arrested last week, and brought before Justice OSBORNE at the Special Sessions on Saturday last.

The Order of United Americans held their Annual Session in this City on Monday evening last, at No. 257 Bowery. The attendance was very large, every Chapter in the State being represented. The following is the list of officers elected for the ensuing year. G. S.--W. B. Lewis, of Marion. No. 11. G. 1st C.--W. E. Blakeney, of Decatur, No. 10.

THE FAIR AT THE CRYSTAL PALACE--The Twenty-Ninth Annual Fair of the American Institute was opened last evening at the Crystal Palace, and the event was commemorated by an appropriate address delivered by HENRY MEIGS to a select audience in the Picture Gallery. The objects on exhibition in the Fair are yet few and of no very novel character.

He said: GENTLEMEN: It is my duty to preside over your deliberations until this body is organized, and in so doing I beg the kind indulgence of the Convention.

The Royal Mail Steamship Persia, Capt. JUDKINS, which left Liverpool at about 10 o'clock on the morning of Saturday, the 5th inst., arrived at this port yesterday morning. The steamship Fulton arrived off Cowes on the morning of Sept. 3. The steamship Antelope appointed to leave Liverpool for St. Johns, Newfoundland, on the 7th, instead of the 5th, as advertised.

Inconclusive, and in some instances consistent, as are the narratives of the progress of affairs in India which we have received by the Baltic and the Persia, it is yet Sufficiently clear that the tide has begun to turn, and that henceforth we shall be called upon to chronicle, not the progress of the mutiny, but the story of the reconquest of Hindesian.

DARING MIDDAY ROBBERY IN BROADWAY.--About 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon. Mrs. HILLS residing at No. 102 Fourteenth-street, was passing through Broadway, near Ninth-street, when a thief named KURLEY snatched her ?? and watch, and in an instant turned down Ninth-street with them in his possession. The lady pursued him, crying "Stop thief."

The steamer Wm. Jenkins, from Boston, arrived here to-night, and reports a heavy gale in the bay on Sunday, Monday and last night. She passed at anchor the steamer Caledonian, from Charleston, having been run into the previous night. She had got her propeller foul with her haw?er and would proceed as soon as clear. She reported having on board the engineer and fireman of the steamer Norfolk,

Hon. THOMAS H. BENTON continues to improve and is now considered past danger. Judge BOWLIN has resigned his office as Minister to Bogota. Second-Assitant Postmaster DUNDAS has gone to New-York, on business connected with the facilitation of the California overland mail.

SIMSON--In the city, On Monday evening, Spet. 14, ROBERT SAMPSON, in the 31st year of his age. The friends of the family are respecfully invited to attend his funeral, on Thursday afternoon, at 1 o'clok, from his late residence, No. 27 Avenue D. The remains will be taken to Cypress Hills Cemetery.

The Cunard Steamship Persia, with three days' later European intelligence than that brought by the Baltic, arrived at this port yesterday. There is no news of importance to report. Nothing of an official nature has yet been promulgated by the directors of the Atlantic Telegraph Company, but it appears certain that no fresh attempt will be made to lay the cable until next Summer.

That singularly solemn ass, "the British public, " is never weary of proclaiming the merits of British morality, and of chanting the praisesof the British home. From the Land's End to John o' Groat's, a strong faith prevails that outside of the four seas that girdle Britain, marriage is a mockery, and domestic bliss a lost Area dian dream.

We give below a report of the proceedings yesterday morning in the trial of JAMES P. DONNELLY, charged with the murder of ALFRED S. MOSES, on the 1st day of August last, at the Sea-view House, Nevisink, N. J. The trial takes place at Freehold, the county town of Monmouth County, in which Nevisink is situated.

Before Judge Nelson, COLLISION IN NARROW CHANNEL. H. Fitshugh et alvs. The Steam Propeller Commerce.-NELSON, C.J.-The libel in this case was filed by the owners of the barge Isabella against the Commerce for a collision on the North River, near Castleton, some ten miles below Albany. The steamboat Indiana was ascending the river on the east side with a tow of ten boats.

ARREST OF ALLEGED HIGHWAYMEN.--About 9 o'clock on Monday evening Mr. JAMES FERGUSON, a very respectable gentleman, was passing along West-street, near Hamersley, when he was violently assaulted by two men who sprung upon him from behind a pile of lumber where they were lying in wait. Mr. FERGUSON struggled with the villains, but being overpowered and hurled to the sidewalk, was robbed of his gold watch.

Before Justice Davison. A fire occurred on the morning of the 9th of June last, between the hours of 1 and 2 o'clock, in the dwelling owned and occupied by one James Shepherd. The entire premises were destroyed, and in the ruins was found the charred remains of Shepherd's wife.

The denomination of Judge DENIO by the Democratic Party of this State is certainly thus far the most important incident in the current political canvas. We regard it as one of the most honorable aets ever performed by any political party in this State,--and we hope to see it stamped with the emphatic indorsement of the popular vote.

It has run such a career as must inevitably attach to an enthusiasm that is without judgment-it has attained the crisis that must surely be precipitated where action is not guided by experience, nor impulses controlled by discretion.

The storm which raged along the Southern coast on Saturday. Sunday and Monday last, was more serious in its effects than was at first supposed: some ten or a dozen vessels are already reported ashore, upon the coasts of North Carolina and Virginia, and several steamers have been crippled and compelled to put into the nearest port in distress. By an arrival from Turk's Island we have files of the Royal Standard to the 29th inst., containing interesting details of the revolution now in progress in the Dominican republic of St. Domingo to remove President BAEZ and restore SANTANA.

M., the line of procession formed on Railroad-avenue, under Col. H. B. TODD, Grand-Marshal of the day.

The Forty-third Anniversary of the Battle of Baltimore was celebrate with much spirit at Baltimore. At Washington City there was also a celebration. The Association of Veterans paraded,. and, according to the report of the Baltimore Sun, marched to the Executive mansion, but learning that President BUCHANAN was absent at his country residence, with a passing salute they marched on through the beautiful grounds to the War Department.

The non-arrival of the steamer, and the failure' yesterday, to receive any intelligence from her, added somewhat to the public anxiety on her account. The number of her passengers is not known, or who they are; the amount of her treasure-list is said to be over a million of dollars, and those who have cause to expect friends by her, as well as all others interested, manifest much concern for her safety.

A romantic drama of the atrocious school was produced here last night. It is called "Judith of Geneva," and If we are not mistaken, is of German origin, althrough fathered on this occasion by Mr. THOMAS MORTON. The plot is claudicated by means of a sucession of startling situations, in most instances powerfully and skillfully introduced, but withou much regard to the logical perceptions of his audience,

The Convention which was elected on the 15th of June last by a portion of the people of Kansas, to discharge the important trust of framing a constitution under which the Territory should claim to be admitted as a State, met here to-day. With but few if any exceptions, the counties which elected delegates to that body were more or less fully represented.

DREADFUL ACCIDENT ON THE ?? RARROAD.--A passenger by the stennper St. Jokus, on yesterday, nforms us that a dreadful areident occurred on the Fernandina Railroad on Wednesday morning. It seems that in the absence of regular passenger-cals, platform-cars were used to transport passengers, and, in order to protect the passengers from the smoke and sparks of the engine, the cars were placed in advance of, instead of being dragged by, the locamotive.

THE CATHOLIC QUESTION.-On Tuesday evening in the Jersey City Common Council, the Committee appointed to investigate the subject of worship at the Almshouse, rendered two reports. Alderman ERWIN and KASHOW rendered a majority report, and Alderman CORNELISON a minority report.

Our Lecompton correspondence brings advices of the meeting and organization of the Constitutional Convention of Kansas. Gen. CALHOUN was elected President; but it is not anticipated that any important business will be done until after the Territorial election in October. That election is for members of the Legislature and for a delegate to Congress-the main interest of the struggle turning upon the latter. The Democratic candidate is Gov. DEATH FROM POISON--SUSPICIOUS CASE--GEO. KLINE, a German, died on Tuesday night, at the Bellevue Hospital, from the effects of arsenic either taken by himself, for the purpose of self-destruction, or administered him by mother. He was admitted to the Hospital while suffering from the effects of delirium tremens as well as arsenic, and during his ravings accused his wife of having poisoned him.
