The Sharper represented that he was the agent for the Railroad company, and would pracure SIMPSON his ticket for $350 less than he could buy it himself.

THERE ARE NONE so DEAF AS THOSE WHO WILL NOT HEAR.-The Richmond South says, in an article on Ex-President TYLER'S letter to the Knoxville Convention: "We no longer hear an argument against the Slave-trade on the score of humanity." This may be true enough in the case of the South;

The Committee of the American Tract Society have published a Circular, containing a very important announcement of their recent action. It will be remembered that for two or three years past there has been a very strenuous effort at tile North to induce or coerce the Society to publish tracts upon Slavery as one of the sins against which a religious society was bound to make earnest and indignant protest.

RENNARD--In this City, on Thursday, Sept. 17, WILLIAM KENNARD, aged 14 months, son of Priscilla A. and the late George W. Kennard. Funeral services at his late residence, No. 146 church-st., this afternoon, at 4 o'clock. His remains will be taken to Oak Hill Cemetery on Saturday monring.

There is nothing more horrible recorded in modern history than those massacres of English women and children in Bengal, the narration of which is continued to us by every Indian mail. Though these helpless victims of Mahommedan frenzy are not our immediate kindred, they are members of the Anglo-Saxon family to which we belong, and are related to us by all the ties of Christianity and a refined civilization.

STEAM FIRE-ENGINES.--It is said that negotiations are again pending for the introduction in our city of the steam fire-engine. To any one at all familiar with the experience of Cincinnati in the use of this protective agent, it must be matter of surprise that New-York has so long failed to avail itself of so valuable an auxiliary to our present fire-engine system. Cincinnati with its side-hill location its consequent uneven streets.

Hon. CLARK BISSELL, Ex-Governor of Connecticut, died at Norwalk on Tuesday. Gov. BISSELL had been in public life for forty years. In 1829, he was appointed a Judge of the Supreme Court of Connecticut, but resigned after ten years' service, and resumed the practice of law. He was elected Governor of the State in 1847 and 1848.

I have just arrived here from Mysore, where I spent ten days with the Resident at the Court of Rajah of Mysore. I attended two durbas at the Palace, and saw everything worth seeking, and learned everything worth knowing, both at Mysore and Seringapatam.

SIR: In the conversation we lately had at Augusta, concerning the reintroduction of Slavery into Central America, we agreed that much of the opposition to my course in Nicaragua was due to tile act annulling the decrees of the Federal Constituent Assembly. It may be a matter of interest to you, as well as to others, for me to explain the motives which led to that measure;

A. DUDLEY MANN, Esq., writes to the Philadelphia Press that he has no doubt whatever concerning the success of his effort to establish direct lines of steamers between Europe and Southern ports. He says the holders, who are limited to a share of $100 each, are multiplying rapidly from day to day. It asks no aid whatever from the Government.

The Secretary of the Treasury has confirmed the appointments of the Collectors of New-York and New-Orleans, of Inspectors, A private letter from Mississippi states that officers are rapidly recruiting men for WALKER's army, destined for Nicaragna. Colonel SLATTER, of New-Orleans, is doing the financiering and talking for General WALKER, who expects to leave early in November.

This beautiful city of Eastern Connecticut was never more attractive at this season than we find it to-day. The constant rains of the Summer have kept the lawns and gardens, the shrubbery and the trees, for which the streets here are famous, in the freshest green, The woods upon the surrounding hills, and the fields, are now as verdant as Spring time. I was unable in my last letter to allude to two decrees of some little importance, and which have been recently issued. The following is the gist of them: To remove a slave from one estate to another it is requisite by the first of these decrees that the fact of his removal be indorsed by the local authority-a line of $10 being inflicted for each contravention of the above.

POLITICAL.--We noticed two or three weeks since sundry rumors prevalent in the central and western part of the State concerning the intention of Hon. O. B. MATTESON, of Oneida, to resign his seat in the present Congress. We learn now from the best authority that Mr. MATTESON has decided not to resign.

A visit to the Exhibition just open at the Crystal Palace, even in its incipient presentation, will repay the time expended. Certainly to the sight-seer, there is nothing as yet particularly attractive, yet a close examination of many of the results of our national invention and skill, will justify the remark made there in our hearing. "We are a great people, Sir-a great people."

MILITARY ELECTION.--FIELD, of Hoboken, Commander of the Highwood Guard, has been elected Brigadier-General of the Hudson Brigade, to fill the vacancy occasioned by the promotion of Gen. E. R. V. WRIGHT to the rank of Major-General of the Division.

FORGERY BY A BOY.--JOHN HENRY WILSON, all errand boy in the employ of Messrs. WILLARD, FELT Co., No. 14 Maiden-lane, was yesterday arrested by officers McCORD and ELDER, of the Deputy Superintendent's office, charged with forging the name of the firm to a check on the Artisans' Bank for $300.

A HOPEFUL SIGN.--The Kausas correspondent of the Tribune communicates the following scrap of intelligence, concerning the doings of the Convention: P.H.C., the "Republican reporter" of Governor WALKER and the N.Y.TIMES, was elected Reporter of the Convention. He had a Border Ruffian opponent, but distanced him by thirteen votes.

DOCK MASTERS.--Superintendent TALLMADGE on Wednesday issued the following order in reference to Dock Masters, which we hope to see rightly enforced: OFFICE SUPERINTENDENT OF METROPOLITAN POLICE, NO. 88 White-st., New-York, Sept. 15. Complaints having been made to this Department that certain persons representing themselves to be Policemen, are by virtue thereof exercising the dalies which formerly pertained to Dock Master,

We have already expressed our opinion of the recent attempt, on the part of a portion of the Democratic Party, to ostracise Judge DENIO on account of one of his decisions. Fortunately for the State, and especially for the system of an Elective Judiciary, the Democratic Party itself nipped this project in the bud. We are very glad to find that our views upon this subject are concurred in by the Evening Post.

THE ROCK ISLAND BRIDGE CASE.--In the United States Circuit Court, at Chicago, Judge McLEAN presiding, the suit of HURD and others, owners of the steamboat Effic Afton, against the Rock Island Railroad Bridge Company, was brought to trial on the 8th inst. Mr. WEAD opened the case to the Jury, and Mr. LINCOLN replied.

INSPECTORS AND CANVASSERS AT OUR CITY ELECTION.--The Tribune has fallen into several errors in respect to the law governing Inspectors and District Canvassers at the approaching Charter election. It states that the Common Council appoints the Inspectors; but the law applicable to them has not been changed, and those elected last year serve during the day of election in taking the ballots, unless there occur vacancies, which the Common Council have always filled.

A THOROUGH VILLAIN.--A series of outrages have been lately perpetrated in the vicinity of Waterford, Erie County, Pa., by a German named MICHAEL DANGLER, who has since been arrested and committed to jail. On Monday, the 31st ult., Mr. WM. HEWITT, residing two miles west of Waterford, discovered that a time horse of his had been shot in the pasture.

BURNED TO DEALTH.--JOSEPH PHALON, a boy of 9 years of age, was fatally burned on Wednesday evening at the residence of his parents, No. 239 East Eighteenth-street, by the explosion of a can of burning fluid. It appears that while he was filling a lamp, his younger brother came behind him and threw a lighted match into the can.

THE ATLANTIC TELEGRAPH--CAUSE OF THE BREAK.--We hope that before the subject of the Telegraphic Cable is dismissed from the public mind, we may have some explanation of a very decided discrepancy in two accounts that have been published from high authority as to the immediate cause of the recent failure.

HOMEOPATHIC CONVENTION.--The members of the School of Medicine in Kings County, assembled Thursday evening, to the number of twenty-five, at the office of Dr. MACY, corner of Court and State streets, Brooklyn, to take due preliminary steps towards organizing a County Association for mutual protection and benefit.

One of the most certain engagements that any management can make is undoubtedly with Mme. LA GRANGE, a singer who has proved herself not only capable, but eminently willing and reliable, on all occasions and in all seasons. A large audience assembled last night, at the Academy of Music, to welcome this popular favorite back to the scene of her many triumphs.

THE FINALE OF AN ELOPEMENT.--Quite an excitement was created at an carly hour this morning, at one of the hotels, by the woman. The circumstances of the case were as follows: About eight days since a fine looking young German, about 21 years old, with a rather handsome young married woman, cloped from New-York and came to this city.

GIDEON J. PILLOW, of Mexican war notoriety, has placed his name before the country as a candidate for United States Senator from Tennes. see, as appears over his name "to the People of Tennessee." This address will probably call forth comments from several officers in high places in the American army.

The Boston Advertiser tells of a curious case of identity: The barber of one of our principal hotels was astounded the day before yesterday. Two gentlemen of New-York, brothers, who are well known in financial circles, and are distinguished for the very remarkable resemblance they bear each other, came together to this city and sojourned at the hotel in question, where, we believe, they still remain.

A thoroughly Hibernian meeting was held in this City on Thursday evening last-a meeting so thoroughly Hibernian in all its characteristics, that it really ought not to be suffered to " overcome us like a summer's cloud, without our special wonder." An average Hibernian meeting does not. we regret to say, partake of the nature of news for a New-York public.

ARREST OF ALLEGED FUGITIVES.-- BREAKING OUT OF PRISON.--Officers BATES and EADIE, of the Twelfth Precinct, arrested two fellows, known as MIKE WILLIS and GEORGE QUINN, both Irish boys, 20 years of age, charged with being fugitives from justice from White Plains, Westchester County, where, it is alleged, they broke out of prison on Wednesday last.

DEATH OF THE "MORMON."--The Mormon, of this City died with this week's number. The valedictory of the editor assigns no reason for the discontinuance of the paper, but intimates that Mr. APPLEBY, who has conducted it since the departure of President TAYLOR for Utah, will devote himself until Spring to the fortherance of the interests of the faithful in the Atlantic States.

When criticising the meagreness of the show of Kentucky animals at the National Agricultural Fair, i one of my former letters, I gave you notice that I should go to Lexington for the purpose of verifying my suspicion that the fine stock was still in Kentucky, but, sectional jealousy had militated against its exhibition at Louisville.

His company found Colonel SUMNER'S command quartered for the time being, on the Arkansas river. The soldiers from whom he received full particulars of the late fight, were very much dissatisfied with their condition. n.

Meeting of the Cooper Democratic General committee--They Indorse the State Nominations, ask for Support, and propose that the Rival Committees Reter their Claims to the State Committee for Final Arbisration. A Special Meeting of the Cooper Democratic General Committee was held at Tammany Hall last evening.

Since I wrote you last we have had three State Conventions in Boston: the two American Conventions, on the 10th, which finally resolved themselves into one and nominated the same candidates; and the Democratic Convention, which was held yesterday.

In the course of a communication in the TIMES, a few days since, the following passage Occurs: "Little over a year ago, a clerk in our Post-Office was suspected of opening letters to purloin money from them. The guilt was rendered transparent by the ingenious stratagem of placing in his way a letter with marked money in it. He fell into the trap.

To the Public of New-York: I again present myself as a candidate for Mayor If elected, I will first strive to ascertain what has become of the $600,000 Record Fund, and who pay the Ten Governors the enormous percentage that enables them to dress so finely, and grow so fat. I shall permit Governor PINENEY to be State's evidence.

LEWIS and Miss HARRIET WHEELER have united as conjugal mates; that they recognize no legal contract whatever;

THE EAGLES OF PRUSSIA AND AMERICA. -- Mr. HILL, a member of the Legislature of Missouri, from Carondelet, who arrived in this city on Wednesday, in the Steamer Harmonia, from Hamburg, requests us to contradict a statement copied into the New-Yorker Staats-Zeilung, from the St. Louis Herald, to the effect that he, Mr. HILL, being a native of Prussia, had been arrested and imprisoned in that Kingdom as a deserter from the Prussian military service.

That section of the Temperance Society opposed to Mr. DELAVAN, have resolved to call a State Convention at Syracuse on Tuesday, Oct. 6. The call of the State Society, for a Prohibitory Convention, at Rochester, on Sept. 30, is not recognized by them. The October Convention is called under the authority of a committee, of which Mr. RICEARDSONs is Chairman, formed at a Convention some two years since.

Tile Mormon, a weekly newspaper, established in this City some three years since as the organ of the followers of BRIGHAM YOUNG, is discontinued. The Mormons are now left destitute of a mouthpiece in the Eastern States.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR: A wish to be useful urges me to sugges through the columns of your journal, to the Mayor and authorities of the City, a step that may preven much morel mischief. It appears that not less than six cartloads of the vile obscenity, seized the other day, is deposited in the cells at the City Prison.

THE MARINE UNDERWROTERS.--The action of the Board of Underwriters yesterday morning, on hearing of the disaster to the gold steamer, was prompt and commendable. It evinced the right spirit under calamity.

In consequence of the reprehensible conduct of the managers of some of the Southern telegraphic lines, we are unable to present as many particulars of the loss of the Central America as we had reason to anticipate. Our agent states that a full report of the disaster was ready for transmission, but those ill charge of the lines refused to keep them open, although an arrangement that they Should do so had previously been made.

The Convention ?? 10 o'clock. The interval since the adjournment on the previous day had been spent in assiduous and energetic efforts by the friends of both the candidates for the Presidency, to influence the members in favor of their respective nominees. The minutes of the previous meeting were read and approved.

CLARK--SLOAN.--In this City, on Thursday afternoon, Sept. 17, at St. George's Church, by Rev. Dr. Tyng, GEO. LYON CLARK to FAMILY AUGUSTA, daughter of the late William Dunbar Sloan, all of this City. MAGNIN--GIBSON.--In this City, on Tuesday, Sept. 15, at Trinity Chapel, by Rev. John Henry Hobart, D. D., DAVID J. MAGNIN to MARY LOUISA, daughter of Wood Gibson, of this City.

An attempt to poison a whole family was made at Gorham, Ontario Co., on Monday. Mr. CHRISTIAN FISHER and family were the sufferers. Arsenic was found in the tea-kettle ; by whom placed there is not known. Mrs. FISHER was nearly killed ; the rest recovered. Mr. LEWIS GUNN, of Suffield, Conn., recently captured a brown eagle in that town, which measured seven feet.

George W. Patten vs. The steamboat Illinois.--The libel in this case was filed by the owner of the cahal boat John W. Williams, to recover damages occasioned to her by a collision, which occurred white she was being towed from Albany to New-York by the steamboat. The Court below held that the steamboat had been guilty of no negligence, and dismissed the libel, from which decree the libelant appealed.

NO INSURANCE ON THE CENTRAL AMERICAN LOSSES OF THE COMPANY.--Mr. KIRBY. of MARSHAL O. ROBERTS' office, says that they have no insurance on the Central America. The Company have never insured any of their steamers, preferring to save the money for themselves which they would be obliged to expend in insurance policies and take the chances of shipwreck and other losses.

HARRY HOWARD NOMINATED FOR MAYOR.--Whilst the trial of Adriatic Engine Company, No. 31, was proceeding in front of the City Half, on Wednesday afternoon, a number of firemen there organized a meeting, at which HARRY HOWARD was presented to the people of the city for the office of Mayor.

One horror, at least, is wanting to the terrible picture which the loss of a great steamship, crowded with passengers, and within a single day's sail of her port of destination, presents to the public mind. We have not been held in a miserable suspense of doubt and fear, to speculate for weary days and weeks, upon the extent of the disaster.

IRISH SYMPATHY AND ITS OBJECTS.--For once our Irish brethren have made a mistake. They have generally been pretty successful to any movement for exeiting indignation against Great Britain. A meeting of "sympathy" with almost anything and anybody has hitherto been tolerably well attended, if it gave occasion for proclaiming eternal hostility to the British lion and an undying determination to sap the foundations of British power.

LIVERPOOL COTTON MARKET. The newspapers report the Liverpool Cotton market buoyant, but quotations generally unchanged. Messrs. RICHARDSON, SPENCE Co., however, quote an advance of I--16d.@1/2d. ?? pound in the current qualities of American. The sales of the three days were 30.000, includig 5,000 on speculation, and 1,000 for export. STATE OF TRADE. The advices from Manchester are favorable. Prices ruled firm.

ARREST OF PRESCOTT F. HARRIS, LATE OF THE "BROADWAY BELLE."--Some time since, Paeseort F. HARRIS, publisher of an obscene sheet called the Broadway Belle, was tried and convicted in the General Sessions of continuing to publish the sheet after he had promised the Court to stop it. Previous to being sentenced, however, he managed to get a way from the City, and has been absent up to yesterday.

THE ADRIATIC.--At length this steamer is completed--all except some "trilling details," which, to is feared, cannot be arranged as soon as was expected, and which have necessitated the postponement of her sailing once more.

DISAPPOINTED IN A WEDDING TOUR--FRANCIS SMALL AND JANE GIBSON, servants in the family of Mr. JAMES LOW, residing at No. 20 East Twenty-second-street, were arrested on Thursday, charged with robbing their employer. The twin had been courting for some time, and finally thought they would get married and take a wedding tour to Ireland, or rather, take the tour first and get married afterwards,

They are the same advices as those which left Aspinwall in the ill-fated steamship Central America.

To the Editor of the New-York Times. In your paper of yesterday an announcement was made of a meeting of the firemen, held in the Park. Rominating HENRY H. HOWARD for the position of Mayor of this City. and my name was used as having presided over such meeting. You will oblige me by stating that I any not aware of any such meeting being held.

THE NEXT MAIL FRM CALIFORNIA.--SOME of our contemporaries have announced that the steamer Star of the West might be expected to arrive here o he 25th inst., with California passengers and mails at he 5th September. This is an error, calculated to excite a great deal of uneasiness in the minds of many, if the vessel named should not arrive at the time designated.

MORMONISM IN THE CITY EXPLODED.-We have already mentioned the demise of the Mormon newspaper published in this City. The Church has also, been suspended. A considerable number of the " Saints" gathered together yesterday to attend the usual Sunday service at tile accustomed place in Broome-street,but the doors were closed and the proprietor of the hall informed the crowd that there would be no more preaching there.

One perusing the papers of the past week would come to the conclusion that the taking of inkermann was a trifling natter compared with the taking and destruction of AHARMAN. Now there are two sides to all such questions; and, not withstanding the unfavorable light in which I have been represented by the press, I beg you will allow me a hearing before final condemnation.

By the arrival at this port yesterday morning of The United States Mail steamship Empire City, Capt. McGOWAN, from Norfolk, on the 18th inst., bringing eighty-three of the rescued passengers and crew of the unfortunate Central America, we are placed in possession of many additional and important facts relative to the fearful catastrophe, which has brought desolation to so many hearths, and filled so many hearts with woe.

The People vs. James P. Donnelly.--Judge VREDENBURGH stated the opinion, of the Court, that evidence concerning antecedent facts unconnected with the occurrence under investigation was inadmissible. The circumstances of the homicide were the only ones to which evidence might be adduced. The examination of Peter F. Schenck was resumed, He saw some money counted over in Moses' room;

The North Atlantic Steam Navigation Company's screw-steamship Antelope (in place of the Circassian. hartered for India) has arrived at this port, from Liverpool on Tuesday. the 8th inst. The R.M. stearnship Canda, from Boston vid Hallfax, arrived at Liverpool on the 5th inst. The screw-steamship Argo. from New-York. arrived at Sonthampton on the 5th.

Advices front Vera Cruz are received to the 7th inst. The correspondent of the Picayune, writing on that day, says: I "By express,just arrived in thirty-six hours from the capital, we learn that the Tehuantepec negotiators have been successfull-an arrangement having been signed day before yesterday, granting all or nearly all asked for by them.

The public will probably remember the name of Mr. GEORGE AKARMAN as that of the man who was not long since convicted of dealing in obscene literature, and mercifully let off upon promise of amendment, and paying a fine of fifty dollars,--but who in less than a week after was found pushing the same business with greater eagerness and assiduity than ever.

The United States Mail steamer Black Warrior, D. W. SMITH, Commander, from New Orlaans on the 12th, and Havana on the 15th inst., arrived at this port on Saturday at 1 P. M. The late panic in commercial circles of Havana has subsided, but business is still dull. Stock of sugar about 200,000 boxes, and holders refuse to sell at the reduced prices.

The first view of the new Jerusalem of the Mormons is but little calculated to satisfy the ardent enthusiasm of a devoted believer. After days, weeks and months of weary travel, exposed to hunger and thirst, the heat of the sun, and the cold of tile mountains, drenched by rains, half drowned in deep and dangerous fords, blinded by wind, dust and hail,

The most interesting feature of the news, in relation to the loss of the Central America, yesterday, was the arrival of Mr. ASHBY, late Chief-Engineer, and his defence of his conduct. We publish three distinct statements made by him, this morning, from all of which it will be seen that be claims to have acted in obedience to orders throughout, and to have done all in his power to keep the engines in motion.

The Convention met to-day aim adjourned till the 19th of October. The object of this adjournment is two-fold ; first, to give the various standing committees time to prepare their reports ; second, to await the result of the election on the first Monday in October. The proceedings thus far have been purely formal.

Since our last advices, of 15th inst., we have had a dull and falling market in all the speculative Securities of the Stock Exchange. In the more solid shares, and in State Stocks, the variation in prices has been small, and in some cases a trifling improvement has taken place. Operations during the week have been comparatively small, and principally for cash.

Gen. CASS is indisposed, and was not at the State Department to-day. He went to Church yesterday, and took cold in the evening. Messrs. SCHELL., SANDERS and SICKLES are here---the former concerning appointments. It is said that Mr. SICKLLS has received an autograph letter from the President, sustaining a certain position taken by him.

BROADWAY THEATRE.--Mr. CHAS. MATHEWS made his first appearance last evening in his great character of Sir Affable Hawk in the "Game of Speculation." It was in this comedy that Mr. MATHEWS took his farewell of the English stage previous to his departure for the United States. His impersonation of the leading character of the piece is the perfection of acting.

STOCK GAMBLING.-The recent movement of the Stock Exchange in prohibiting time sales of stock for a longer period than thirty days, is commented on in various sections as a step in the right direction. The Albany Atlas, however, thinks that no remedy can be effectual in checking the gambling tendency of the Stock Exchange, which does not limit he transactions at the Board to sales of stock actually owned by the seller or his principal.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Your article on "Kansas Politics and Prospects," of the 17th, contains much wisdom and some comfort to the friends of free soil, and if we cold realize, or rather put full faith in the conclusions you so happily arrive at, I see no reason why we should not be joyful also, especially as we are assured from many quarters that the Free-State electors greatly preponderate.

A very quiet convocation of distinguished personages was convened, yesterday, at the Ship-yard of WM. H. WEBB, Esq., to celebrate the anniversary of the birthday of the Grand-Duke CONSTANTINE, of Russia, by the formal raising of the sternpost of the immense steam propeller frigate, to be named in his honor the General Admiral.

DONIZETTI'S charming opera of the "Elisir'Amore," was produced here last night to a very crowded audience. It is strange that an opera so perfectly fresh and Rossind-like should be so seldom performed, especially as the story is one which everyone can understand even by pantomime.

Yesterday morning, PATRICK DUFFY and WILLIAM DRANK, charged with the wanton murder of the negro SALTERS, were brought before Judge RUSSELL, at private chambers, on a writ of habeas corpus. Mr. JONAS B. PHILLIPS, their counsel, applied for their discharge on bail, the amount to be fixed by the Judge, on the ground that the papers before the Grand Jury only showed that a manslaughter had been committed.

ARREST OF PLIN WHITE CHARGED WITH FALSE PRETENCES.--PLIN WHITE, who figured some years ago as a defendant in a false pretence case involving a very large amount of money, and the pecuniary Sergeant S. J. SMITH, of the Jefferson Market Police Court, charged' with having by false and fraudulent pretences created the firm of H. S. J. H. STEVENS, brokers in Brokers in Broadway, out of the sum of $47.000.

Before Judge Nelson. DEISIONS IN EQULTY. John McCraken vs. James H. Prentice et al.-- This was a motion for a preliminary injunction in restrain the defendants from using a process for stiffening hat bodies, for which the plaintiff had obtained a patent.

THE TRACT SOCIETY.-Some of the ultra ProSlavery papers at the South are by no means soothed by the recent movement of the American Tract Society, in regard to the publication of tracts upon Slavery.

You have doubtless, by this time, full particulars of the loss of the Central America, as brought by the brig Ellen, which arrived at this port on yesterday, with 44 of the survivors of this awful wreck. The long prevalence of easterly winds in this latitude, prior to the storm of Saturday and Sunday last, averted many calamities of a like character along the Southern coast.

We publish in another column a letter from a correspondent, in reference to the extraordinary communication which we recently received from Mr. BROWNLOW, of Knoxville, in which the writer deals with a phase of the negro-burning transaction, upon which, in our former article, we did not comment.

The trial of MICHELE CANGEMI, the alleged burglar and murderer of EUGENE ANDERSON, commenced yesterday morning, in the Court of Oyer and Terminer, before Judge ROOSEVELT. A panel of 250 juror had been summoned, but 91 of these failed to attend. They were promptly fined $5 each. GANGEMI, "the observed of all observers," was dressed in a new suit of clothes, and looked as unlike a burglar or murderer as could be imagined.

There was no abatement in the general desire to obtain all possible information in relation to the sinking of the steamship Central American, and the safety or probable death of those who were on board. All who were rescued by the bark Ellen or the brig-Marine are now known.

we continue to-day the publication of Statements from the survivors of the central America, Concerning the circumstances and causes of that sad catastrophe. Each contributes something to the general mass of information. and it is by grouping the disjointed facts thus revealed into a connected narrative, that we are to arrive at some clear and definite judgment in regard to it.

It was, therefore, very difficult to sell paper; the ??king houses were all willing to sell, but would not buy at any price. We continue the publication of such statements as seem calculated to throw light upon the cause of the disaster to the Central American. This is now the point to which the attention of the public is directed, and we are glad to see that steps are taken by the Company and the Board of Underwriters to sift thoroughly all the circumstances connected with it.

Whatever serves to develop the intentions of the South on the subject of Slavery deserves public attention. As an indication of Southern policy I cannot but regard the last published letter of WILLIAM WALKER in support of his scheme for reestablishing the institution in Nicaragua with profound interest.

CONFIDENCE WANTED!-As a general thing we have no special admiration of the "confidence game," either as practised by professional swindlers or by the more speculative portions of the business community. But just now,--in the severe financial pressure that afficts the whole community, a little more confidence on the part of creditors is greatly needed and would be especially serviceable in affording relief.

THE REMOVAL OF THE STEAMBOAT LANDINGS-THE GOLD SNUFF-DOX-THE CRYSTAL PALACE, MONDAY, Sept. 21.--The President, J. CLANCY, in the Chair. The minutes of the last meeting having been read. Alderman BLUNT presented a preamble and resolution relative to the Jackson Snuff-Box, the substance of which was that great injustice had been done to Mr. Andrew Jackson, Jr.. by the resolutions passed by the Board at their meeting of the 14th inst.

The City continnes to be deeply excited in regard to the loss of the Central America. Every incident connected with the sad calastrophe is read with eager interest, and the utmost anxiety prevails to discover the causes of so remarkable and unprecedented a disaster.

By the arrival at this port last evening of the City of Baltimore, we receive details of European news to the 9th instant. The British reenforcements for India are now to be increased to 40,000 men, making altogether a force of 80,800 European troops in the country. At the time the City of Baltimore left Liverpool, the next news from India was anxiously looked for.

The public at large will rejoice at the settlercent of the difficulties which have been so long pending between our Government and that of New-Granada. The termination of such a contest is more important than its terms.-and the provisions of the treaty just concluded will not he subjected to any very critical or captious scrutiny.

HENRY---KYLB.---In this City, on Monday. Sept. 21. in the Second Reformed Presbyterian Church, 11th-st., by Rev. J. Cristy, D. D., Mr. JOHN HENRY to Miss RERECCA KYLB, both of this City. PICKERING---FIELDING.---At Franklin, N.J., on Sunday, Sept. 20, by Rev. Wm. C. Nelson, JOSEPH T. PICKERING, of New-York, and MARY FIELDING, of the former place.

At the outset of the pending controversy, relating to Mr. LOWDER'S judgment against the City, the TIMES directed public attention to the contents of the record, and called upon the parties interested, or implicated in the charges of fraud, , so profusely made, particularly the Corporation Counsel, for an explanation of their course.

DARING STREET ROBBERY.--About 4 o'clock, on Sunday afternoon, Mr. MATTHEW TAGGART, residing at No. 73 Prince street, was passing through Pearl street, and when near Oak street, five young men and boys surrounded him, and one of them cut with a knife his gold guard chain, and ran off with the chain and gold watch. Mr. TAGGART cried "Stop thief," and three of the party were arrested, and identified by him.

ACCIDENT TO THE STEAMER ISAAC NEWTON.--This really unfortunate vessel met with another mishap on Saturday night, on her way up the river. About 10 o'clock, when off Butter Hill, her walking beam broke, making a tremendous crash, blowing out the cylinder head, and otherwise disabling the engine.

BURGLARY AND HEAVY ROBBERY IN NEW-LONDON-On Friday night of last week the dry-goods store of Mr. W.P. BENJAMIN, of New-London, Conn., was burglariously entered, and robbed of costly silks o the value of about $4,000, Previous to the commission of the offense, the burglars provided themselves with a large tool chest, which they had stolen from a carpenter's shop near, and in this they packed their plunder.

To the editor of the New-York Times: You will allow me to say, that it is rather unjust to class Irishmen generally, in this or any country, with Col. DOHENY and his associates in the late meeting of sympathy with the Sepoys. That was a nonsensical affair, and merits all the ridicule your editorial casts upon it.

The Republican Convention in very largely attended, more outsiders being present than have been in attendance at both of the preceding Conventions. I do not notice among the delegates many of those who have heretofore occupied prominent positions a the old Whig and Democratic Parties, but the outside presence is very largely made up of men of much prominence in the State.

SMASH-UP ON THE NEW-HAYEN RAILROAD.-- At about 7 1/2 o'clock yesterday morning, as the New-Haven train was passing Fordham, on the downward trip, the engineer saw that the switch was out of order, by being displaced from its proper position, and immediately reversed the engine and signaled to the brakemen, or otherwise the loss of life would have probably been serious.

The Second National Exhibition of imported blood and American breed of horses, under the auspices of the Hampden County Agricultural Society and the authorities of the city of Springfield, commences Sept. 30 and continues four days. the premium list is also open to exhibitors from the Canadas and the Eastern Provinces.

BOGARDUS.--At Bioomingdale, on Monday, Sept, 21, CORNELICS S. BOGARDUS, Esq., late Naval Officer of this port, in the 46th year of this age. His funeral will take place at his late residence, corner 103d-st., and 8th-av., this (Wednesday) afternoon, at 3 o'clock. The friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend. Stages provided for the purpose will leave corner of Broadway and 32d-st., at 2 o'clock precisely

METHODIST CHURCH SOUTH.--From the general minutes of the Church, just published, it appears there are 23 conferences. 2,171 traveling preachers, 163 superannuated preachers, 4,000 local preachers, 309,382 white members, and 60,770 on probation: 30,190 Indian members, and 296 on probation.

The screw steamship City of Baltimore from Liverpool at noon on Wednesday, the 9th of september, arrived at this port last evening. The English Underwriters had settled and paid the claims brought against them on account of the Atlantic Telegraph Cable. The proposition to employ the cable for a line to India was still in abeyance.

In full Cabinet meeting to-day, the Tehuantepec question, with Mexico and Nicaragua matters, were discussed. The way being clear, additional instructions will be sent to Mr. FORSYTH for final negotiations with Mexico. Nothing more than the right of way, without acquisition of territory, will be negotiated for.

We had intelligence from the plains last evening, by express from BOOTH ALLISON'S trading post, Walnut Greek. About nine days ago, FRANCIS BOOTH, one of the proprietors of the concern, was most brutally murdered in his own house. A short time previous their trade had been most unusually good, and they had accumulated a large amount of money.

NAVAL.-The steam frigate Susquehanna, attached to the Mediterranean squadron, but which assisted in laying the Atlantic Telegraph, has been ordered to Key West for duty on the home squadron. The steam frigate Niagara has been ordered to New-York.

A destructive fire occurred in Keokuk, lowa, on Saturday last, the loss resulting from which, is estimated at $100,000. It originated in the wholesale grocery of HARCOURT. PAGE Co., consuming it and the wholesale grocery and flour store of W. H. AUSTIN, together with several other smaller business houses. Among the losses was a German newspaper establishment, the value of which was estimated at $6,000.

NAVAL.-The steam frigate Susquehanna, attached to the Mediterranean squadron, but which assisted in laying the Atlantic Telegraph, has been ordered to Key West for duty on the home squadron. The steam frigate Niagara has been ordered to New-York.

General CASS denied that Lord NAPIER ever had an interview with him on the subject of American citizens going to India to aid the Sepoys. No further appointments to fill the Foreign Missions will be made until the meeting of Congress, when the names will be sent to the Senate for confirmation.

SEVERE PUNISHMENTS.--Judge RUSSELL Sentenced a man yesterday, who had been convicted in his Court of knocking down a man and robbing him of fire dollars, to the State Prison for forty years. The Judge was doubtess quite right in his determination to make an example of the man, who, it seems, had been once before convicted of the same offence.

It is Stated in the last news from England, that the Marquis of DALHOUSE has placed the whole of an annual pension of L5,000 Sterling, bestowed upon him by the East India Company for his services as Governor-General, at the disposal of the London Committee for relieving the sufferers by the Sepoy mutiny.

A large number of delegates have arrived here since last night, and the convention is likely to be quite full. On organization, matters still seem quite afloat, though some caucuses were held this morning.

" The Barber of Seville" was played here last night to an overflowing house, and one which certainly went away satisfied--thoroughly satisfied with the performance. With the exceptions that the chorus and the Basilio were not quite up to the general high standard, it was in every respect one of the best performances we have listened to in this city.

The disaster to the Central America continued to be the general theme of discussion yesterday, but nothing additional of public interest transpired in any quarter. The universal feeling seems to be that the stoppage of the engines was the primary cause of the catastrophe, and that this is, therefore, the main point which demands inquiry and explanation.

The United States mail steamer Ariel, LUDLOw, commander, from Bremen ria Southampton Sept. 9, arrived at this port last evening. The Ariel brings London papers of Sept. 9, one day later than those received by previous arrivals. No news of importance is reported The substance of the expected India mail had not been telegraphed.

The Southern mail from all points, as late as due, has come to hand. The Charleston Courier says that the brig Queen of the West, of New-York, for Havana, has put into that port for repairs. On the 12th inst., when at sea, she passed the French ship Mathumir, of Havre, and also an American bark, with their salls badly damaged.

" We see that the NEW-YORK TIMES is out with a long article, urging the Republican State Convention to adopt Judge DENIO as the Republican candidate for reelection to the office he now holds, on the ground that the Independence of the Judiciary is of more moment than the gratification of political preferences." The Advertiser will excuse us for saying that it does not "see" any such thing.

A large number of the holders of Erie Railroad Stock, met an No. 13 Broad-street, yesterday, in answer to a call from the President of the Company; the object being to afford them a correct account of the condition of the Company, and make such suggestion as he deemed important. The meeting was organized by the appointment of JAMES BROWN, Esq., of BROWN, BROTHERS Co., President, and W. T. JOHNSON, Secretary.

JUDGE DEMIO'S LETTER OF ACCEPTANCE. UTICA, Monday, Sept. 21, 1851. GENTLEMEN: I have received your letter of the 15th of this month. informing due that the late Democratic Convention have nominated me for reelection to the office which I now hold.

DESTRUCTIVE FIRE IN PHILADELPHIA.--About 1 o'clock this morning an immense rope-walk belonging to Messrs. CHESTER DA Costa, on Salmon-street, below Lehigh-avenue, in the old District of Richmond, was set on fire. The flames spread with great rapidity through the structure--over a quarter of a mile in length--and soon communicated to a smaller "walk" used for the manufacture of twine.

We have to notice the most destructive fire which has occurred in our city for several years. It commenced yesterday morning, about 1 1/2 o'clock, in a stable in Philips-street, between Radeliffe and Morris Streets, and the wind blowing briskly from the southwest, carried the flames ?? through the block to King-street, consuming, among other buildings, the old Bull's Head Tavern, with all its appurtenances.

The St. Lawrence is now the only ??-of-War we have on this coast. We require the services of a small steamer for the river Plate, and two sloops-of-war for the protection of our citizens in person and property. The Falmouth was sent to New-York in consequence of her being badly fitted out. Who is to consequence that? The city of Rio is now very healthy,

On Wednesday evening of last week the Fourth-avenue was quite as unsafe as the road from Rome to Naples. Between the hours of 6 and 9 P. M. no less than five persons were assaulted, insulted and robbed upon its sidewalks. One gentlemen, walking with his wife, was bese in the immediate vicinity of the Clarendon Hotel;

TRURLOW, and a daughter of Captain TRURLOW, (name not given,) started on Tuesday morning, 15th inst., from the north west harbor of Deer ??, Me., in an open boat, bound to Ellsworth.

This statement was, as you say in your card, smuggled through your press, "through the misrepresentations and fraud of the author, and your well denominate it in your card, as "an infamous and shamefully exaggerated publication."

The Board of Aldermen met last evening, President CLANCY in the Chair. The resolution from the Board of Councilman, appointing a Joint Committee to report the names of suitable persons to act as inspectors and canvassers at the coming election, was adopted.

Of the many schemes devised in France for the greatest good of the greatest number, since his present Imperial Majesty ascended the throne, not one has had so fine a run as that known as the Credit Mobilier. Everything else having been centralized, the ceatralization of capital, under the supervision of the Government, was an idea too thoroughly Napoleonic in its character for us to expect the present regime not to work it out.

Before Hon. Justices Mitchell, Clerks and Davies. EXAMINERS APPOINTED. Yesterday, John B. Scoles, John L. Lawrence, and Jas. S. Slayter, Esqs., were appointed Examiners of applicants for admission to the Bar.

From the Montgomery (Ala.) Mail. One of our subscribers, from Pike County, informed us yesterday of a most horrible and atrocious case of poisoning in that County, just below the line of montgomery, and in the neighborhood of Bruceville. The annals of crime will hardly show a more extensive and diabolieal piece of villainy.

W. L. AYLING, an actor well-known to New-England theatre-goers, died at Lowell on Saturday. He was formerly Manager of the Lowell Museum, and was one of the stock company at the old Tremont in Boston. His age was 41; he leaves a widow and two children.

The New-Hampshire ?? states that on Friday last Mr. James B. Alken of Franklin, and Mrs. Sophia C. Thompson, of Holderness, were arrested upon a complaint or causing an operation to be performed on Helen M. Shaw, for the purpose of producing an abortion. Alken was engaged to be married to Miss Shaw, and she finding herself enciente, informed him of the fact, with the view of immodiate marriage.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The Ohio State Fair closed yesterday, that day being the day for the awarding of premiums. The Fair ground is on the outskirts of the city, being pleasantly situated near the so-called Hamilton Road, with which everybody who has visited this city is conversant. Thursday afternoon, in particular, the pike would have reminded a New-Yorker of Broadway.

MINNESOTA.--Gov. RAMSAY, Republican candidate for Governor of the new State, made a speech to the Nominating Convention, declaratory of his firm adhesion to the Free-Soil platform. He regarded Slavery as the great question of the day, and avowed strong opposition to the extension of the peculiar institution over the Territories.

The latest discovery is a specimen of salt rock handed us yesterday by Mr. NETTLETON, clerk of the steamer ??. It was taken from a hill, or mountain, of the same material,

The Fall canvass has fairly opened. The three political parties have completed their nominations:-their candidates and platforms are before the People, and for he space of six weeks the public ear will be stunned with the conflicting clamors of the combatants. It is a fortunate circumstance that the assertions and claims of political parties do not command the confidence or the assent of the public at large.

We find in the last number of the Culpeper Observer the subjoined letter, addressed to General WASHINGTON by a citizen of Fauquier County, Va., in the year 1781: ELK RUN, FAUQUIER COUNTY, Va., Jan. 20. 1781. DEAR SIR: Gen. ARNOLD, with 1,800 men, Is now encamped three miles west of this spot.

VIRTUE DISTINGUISHED.--The gentlemen commuting with the New-Haven Railroad Company have made up a purse of $1,000 for the widow of the late Mr. JOHN COOPER, a conductor of a Norwalk train, who, in his official capacity, was much esteemed. The Company contributed $250 of the amount, and it will be paid for the support of her family in installments of $8-weekly.

Great excitement has been produced among the shipbuilders by the decision of the Naval Board in ?? of Mr. ?? Mr. McKAY, of New-York, has protested against it. The Naval Board is considered very able, and Capt. HAR?? is certainly a competent judge.

With a view to the correction of any erroneous practice that may prevail in regard to the certifying claims against the United States for the return of duies alleged to have been illegally exacted on foreign merchandise imported under the revenue Jaws, the attention of Collectors of Customs is called to the subject.

THE CULTIVATION OF COTTON IN AFRICA.--The British Government has recently published some interesting dispatches from its Consul. Mr. CAMPBELL, at Lagos, in regard to the cultivation of Cotton in Africa. He states that the whole of the Toruba and other countries, south of the Niger, as well as several districts north of that river, have been for many years cotton-growing countries;

BUDD.--In this City, on Wednesday morning, Sept. 2 ELIZA A., wife of William A. Budd. The friends of the family, and other brother Richard H. N. Martin, are invited to attend the funeral services at her late residence, No. 161 East 18th-st., on Friday afternoon, at 4 o'clock. without further notice. CARLISLE.--In this City, on Thursday, Sept. 21. JOHN F., son of James F. Carlisle, aged 1 year and 14 days.

Miss JULIANA MAY, an attractive American lady, who has recently returned from Europe, where she bus been pursuing a course of thorough musical instruction, made her debut here on Tuesday night, (Niblo's Saloon,) and was greeted by a fair audience. Miss MAY sang three solos and assisted in a couple of concerted pieces, thereby affording her hearers ample opportunity of forming a judgment of her probable powers.

DOCTORS DIFFERING.--It is very curious to notice the wide difference of opinion which preails, in different sections of the country, in re?? to the effect of Governor WALKER'S policy in Kansas. A large number of our most zealous Anti-Slavery presses at the North insist, with the most ve??emence, that he is determined to make a Slave State, and that this is certain to be the ?? of his policy.

SPIRITUALIST MEETING--Mrs. EMMA F. J. BULIENE'S lecture at the Stuyvesant Institute, last evening was attended by a quiet audience of about a hundred persons, who listened with attention to the trance discourse and other exercises for about an hour. Mrs. B. is apparently about 25 years of age, of an attractive person, dressed with taste, speaks with much fluency, gesticulates gracefully, prays eloquently, but sings shockingly;...

Fellow-Citizens of the State of New-York: Two dangers threaten our institutions--Slavery and official corruption. The Democratic Republican Party is hostile to both, and will never cease to combat both so long as they exist. The influence of Slavery has been injurious to the Country every since it began.

The public papers have commented very widely upon certain statements published by Rev. Mr. SAWYER concerning a negro owned by Col. NETHNRLAND, of Tennessee, purchased from Rev. Dr. Ross, and alleged to have been inhumanly whipped under circumstances of peculiar atrocity.

GEORGE W. NEWELL, Esq.--Dear Sir:--I will comply to the best of my ability with you request for me to give a sketch of the last two weeks of the life of your brother-in-law, the late WILLIAM L. MARCY. I have postponed doing so until now, party from the pressure of other engagements, and partly from the apprehension that such a sketch as I should make would be inadequate and unsatisfactory.

REMARKABLE TRAGEDY.--The Dallas (Texas) Herald, narrates the following: It becomes our duty to record one of the most desperate and heart-rending tragedies that has ever been enacted in this region of country. JOHN ROBINSON, living some four or five miles from Birdville, in Tarrant County, on Friday morning of last week, without previous provocation.

CUSTOM-HOUSE APPOINTMENTS.--The following appointments have been made to the respective offices in the Custom-House, vice Somebody, removed, whose names are withheld: Inspectors--John Griffin, Walter Joyce, and John W. Bennett, late Captain of Police in the Third Ward, and head of the Central Park Police.

A Writer in the Sidney Morning Herald urges the immediate formation of another expedition to search for the lost German traveler Leichardt. who, several years since, undertook to explore Central Australia, and has not since been heard of Various stories have been told of this murder, and others of his being kept prisoner by a ferocious tribe of Natives in the Interior, but no credit is attached to any of them.

HAT AND CAP MAKERS. JOURNEYMEN HATTERS.--The advent of the great Magyar revolutionized the hat-trade of this country. The felt-hat, which people adopted because it sat gracefully on the hero of the day, has ever since been in increasing demand, from considerations of convenience and economy.

The Convention of Colored Citizens, consisting of Delegates from the Free States, assembled to take into consideration the conduct proper to be pursed, at the present time, by the free colored population of the United States, towards releasing their brethren in the Southern States from Slavery, met again yesterday morning, pursuant to adjournment, at Spring street Hall. The attendance was not large.

DISUNIONISM.--The Anti-Slavery Standard of this week contains a call for a Convention of delegates from the Free States to meet in Cleveland, Ohio, on the 38th and 29th of October next. "to consider the practicability, probability and expediency of a separation of the Free and Slave States, and to take such other measures as the condition of the times may require."

To the Editor of their New-York Times: After all human ingenuity is spent in devising means to prevent the too frequent fatal, and often criminal accidents on board steamers, which are annually occurring on the inland waters of the United States and Canada, by explosion and fire, ample means should be provided for the safety of those who, often without a moment's warning, are compelled to choose between being destroyed by fire or water.

GOV. WALKER passed through our town yesterday on his way to Lecompton, and stopped an Rout or two with G. W. BROWN, of the Herald of Freedom, but, the inhabitants outside of BROWN'S office had no communion with him. Several applications made to him by some of our most respectable citizens for information upon points of interest, have received no reply.

A CURIOUS PRAYER.--The following singular prayer, offered by a dissenting minister, Mr. D---, at Town-end, near Concord, is taken from the Newport Gazette, of July 17, 1777: "O Lord! thou hast been the God of our Fathers; why wilt thon not be Ours?

The Produce Markets have been very much injured by the pressure for money during the week. The receipts of the leading articles were on a pretty large scale.--and receives were anxious sellers. These circumstances worked against any prominent improvement. Yet, Breadstuffs were freely dealt in, especially by exporters,--whose orders could be executed as prices here fell within their limits.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: A woman, of about 25 years of age, with a brown colored traveling dress, wearing a veil, called at one or, more stores, and represented herself as a person from Columbus, Ohio, who had left, with a person, that place under promise of marriage, and as she rejected improper intentions on his part, he paid his bill and left her destitute.

The partisan journals of the State have already begun to echo the "clash of arms," and the splendors of military phraseology appropriate to an approaching election are already dawning upon the dusk of more familiar and pacific discourse in the columns of our cotemporaries.

BURGLARY--ROBBING A COUNCILMAN.--JOHN SMITH and RICHARD FOSTER, boys of 17 and 19 years of age, were arrested by the Twentieth Precinct Police charged with entering the liquor store of Councilman THOMAS J. DUNN, corner of Thirty-seventh-street and Eighth-avenue, about 1 o'clock on Friday morning, by means of false keys, and stealing therefrom cigars, decanters, and other small articles.

To the Editor of the National Anti-Slavery Standard: Sir: I have your issue for August 29th before me, a large weekly sheet published by the " American Anti-Slavery Society," in New-York, and now in the 17th year of its "reign." I have perused the paper through, and I find, in its editorials, seelections, and contributions, it is the most infinitely infernal production I have ever perused.

The Boston Traveller of yesterday publishes a full statement from Capt. STONE, of the schooner El Dorado, the vessel which was last seen near the wreck of the Central America. The Traveller says: The schooner El Dorado, STONE, arrived here from Galveston 22d ult., reports that on the 11th inst., lat.

The Mails by the Canada, from Boston, reached this City last evening. There is little intelligence in addition to that already published by telegraph. We print in full the article from the London Times on our financial troubles.

HOWE--HAUGHWOUT.--In this City, on Thursday evening, Sept. 24, by Rev. Dr. Adams, FRANK E. HOW, of Boston, to SARAH, only daughter of E. V. Haughwout, of this City. GAWTRY--WALKER.--In this City, on Thursday, Sept. 24. by Rev. Dr. DeWitt, WILLIAM M. GAWTRY and Miss ANNE E. WALKER, daughter of Isaac Walker, all of this City.

A FEMALE SHOT IN A WATER-STREET DANCE HOUSE-DELIBERATE ATTEMPT AT MURDER.-Shortly before 12 o'clock, on Thursday night, a deliberate attempt was made to take the life of ANN THOMPSON, a girl of bad repute who boarded in the dance house of SANDY MULLHOLLAND, No. 315 Water-street.

The discussion growing out of the election of Judge DENIO, not only causes solicitude to be expressed, from many quarters, for the " independence of the Judiciary," as being in peril, but, also, has rallied the malcontents who are hopeless of an Elective Judiciary,regarding the experiment of one in this State as already a failure.

LIEUTENANT HERNDON.--The highest qualities of this officer were knwon only to his intimate friedns. Slight in figure, he was modest and unassuming in appearance. In his family he was most affectionate, and thougtful of all but himself. One who saw him there might almost doubt his presence and power of command.

SCOTT.-In this City, on Thursday evening. Sept, 24, LYDIA C., wife of John M. Scott. The friends and relatives of the family are respectfully invited to attend her funeral, from Calvary Church, (Rev. Dr. Hawk's,) without further invitation. FURMAN.--In this City, on Friday, Sept. 25. after a lingering illness, ELIZABETH, wife of Job Furman, in the 80th year of her age.

The political steam is getting up, with prospects of Mr. BANKS' success steadily improving. The fierce hostility of the Democracy to GOV. GARDNER, as manifested in their State Convention, has worked to his injury, as many persons thought that a friendly feeling would be manifested towards him in that body;

A vast interest has rapidly grown up in this country, which, to the amount of some one thousand millions of dollars, represents not not only the wealth of heavy capitalists, but also the earnings of saving mechanics and the dependence of needy widows.

" ONE MORE UNFORTUNATE." The sun; was fast disappearing behind the Hoboken Hills at the close of a sweltering day in August. A sigh of relief seemed to ascend to Heaven from a half million of weary souls as the Day God rolled his fiery chariot Westward, and twilight, with her soothing, revivifying influence, approached to act the part of Nature's great nurse in fanning the fevered brows of heat-oppressed and overworked citizens.

Yesterday, Mr. CHATFIELD applied to Judge PEADODY for a certiorari to remove the indictment against Mrs. CUNNINHGAM from the Court of Oyer and Terminer to the Supreme Court, on the ground that public feeling in this City was so greatly prejudiced against her that she was not sure of a fair and impartial trial.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: There is one topic, suggested by the recent awful calamity of the Central American, which as yet has not been alluded to by the press; I mean that of life-preservers. No event, for years, has illustrated so fully the importance of supplying vessels of all sizes and descriptions with then.

We have from Kansas Governor WALKER'S proclamation in regard to the October election. It will be seen that in this document the Governor expressly and explicitly repudiates the doctrine so officiously set forth by Judge CATO, that none but those who have paid the Territorial tax are entitled to vote, and that for this position he has the direct authority of the President, the Secretary of State, and the whole Cabinet at Washington.

A NEW DIVORCE CASE-AN EX-SENATOR IN TROUBLE. Henry G. Romertze vs. Elizabeth Romerize.This is a divorce case which it is said, may rival the Cox case in celebrity. The complaint recites that on the 6th of March, 1853, the plaintiff was married in this City to the defendant.

The President will return to Washington on Monday. The Cabinet In private conference to-day. General CASS confirms the doctrine on expatriation, that any citizen may emigrate to a foreign country and expatriate himself. There is no law to prevent a citizen; in the exercise of this right, from going either armed or unarmed.

Third and Crcsnut streets are again the ?? of excitement. Crowds surrennded the Savings Institutions before 9 o'clock A.M. They decline paying out deposits, requiring two weeks' notice. The Banks were besieged before 10 o'clock. The Pennsylvania Bank reopened, and is transacting business, but paying no specie.

The People Vs. James P. Donnelly.--This morning the prisoner sat beside his counsel; he evinced no excitement. During the speech of the prospeuting officer he picked to pieces the cork of a little vial that stood on the table near him and thus vented whatever of nervousness the occasion generated. His gray-headed father sat near him. an I his friends and college-mates, who had testified to his good character, were scattered throughout the Courtroom.
SECRETARY COBB--THE MONEY CRISIS--The Secretary of the Treasury has done the community of merchants, bankers and other business people a real service through the present trial in money affairs.
The art of Photography is advancing rapidly and steadily towards perfection. The imperial photograph has been generally deemed the finest achievement in the department thus far,

The Cunard screw steamer Jura, at the date of our best advices from Europe, was expected to sail from Cork for St. John, N.B., on the 14th inst., and should bring two or three days' later intelligence, including, probably, very important news from India.

THE CENTRAL PARK FUND,---It was feared that the present uncomfortable condition of the money market would render it extremely difficult for the Comptroller to find bidders for Central Park Fund Stock, at 6 per cent. And on Monday last those who deared thought they had good ground for so doing, for at 2 o'clock, when the bids were to have been opened, no bidders appeared.

A complaint was filed with Justice WELSH, at his private office, Saturday afternoon, subsequent to the adjournment of the Police Court, against CHARLES RANSOM and WILLIAM STEELE, charging them with keeping a gambling house at No. 8 Barclay-street. Mr. ALEXANDER BOARDMAN, of No. 50 Bowery, made the affidavit of complaint, which sets forth that the parties named were the keepers and proprietors of a gambling house at No. 8 Barclay-street;

HAVILAND--MERRILY.--In Brooklyn, on Tuesday, Sept. 22, according to the order of the Society of Friends, EDWIN HAVILAND to LOUISA, daughter of Nathaniel S. Meritt, all of Brooklyn. JONES--LOCKWOOD.--At Matteawan, Dutchess County, N. Y., on Thursday, Aug. 13, by Rev. Henry Ward Beecher SAMUEL T. JONES of Brooklyn, N. Y., to PAEAP. C. LOCKWOOD, of Wilton, Conn.

TEXAS POLITICS.--Ex-President ANSON JONES has published a letter consenting to be a candidate for the United states Senate in place of SAM HOUSTON, whose reflection, he says, would involve an acknowledgement of a power of humbug on his part and of gullibility on the part of the people of Texas, greater than he is willing to concede.

OUR PUBLIC AMUSEMENTS,--The tightness in the money market does not affect the spirits of our people so far as to keep them away form places of amusement. Perhaps they may feel the need, all the more, or something to keep their spirits up after the anxieties and tribulation of the day.

MY DEAR BROTHER THOMAS:--It is with much pleasure that I write you these few lines, hoping that they will find you all alive and well. I can assure you that I am much better in health now than when I wrote to you before. I can now go about without a shade over my eyes.

WALLACK'S THEATRE--"The Maid's Tragedy," altered from the tragic play of BRAUMONT and FLETCH?? was produced here on Saturday night. Much curiosity has been excited by the announcement of the production of this ancient work; much speculation to know how its louse plot and utter grossness could be modified to the squeamish palate of the present day.

ATTEMPT OT UNITE THE REPUBLICAN AND AMERICAN PARTIES ---There was a private attempt made to unite the Republican and American parties of the City, at the Lafarge House, on Friday evening last, by about fifty persons. ALD. DELAMATEE officiated as Chairman, and the following ticket with it recommended to the public:

A FLAGMAN KILLED BY THE CARS,--A man tarred THOMAS CONNELLY, employed by the New Jersey Railroad and Transportation Company as flagman, was run over by the cars at the warren street crosssing, about five o'clock on Saturday afternoon and almost instantly killed. The train was backing, towoard the depot, and he was standing upon the rack talking with another man, and did not observe approaching cars. Both his legs were out off about.

The money pressure continues severe, and having brought down the Philadelphia and Baltimore Banks on Saturday, produced almost a dead lock in Wall-street negotiations. It is not expected that the New-York City Banks will change their basis of business, and the consequence is great confusion in the domestic exchanges.

From the Evening Post. Rushing 'round the corners, Chasing every friend, Plunging into banks-Nothing there to lendPiteously begging Of every man you meet. Bless me ! this is pleasant, "Shinning" on the street.

Dr. Lugenbeet, long connected with the American Colonization Society, died at Alexandria, Va., on Tuesday night. Dr. Lugenbeel w?? formerly obvsician 'o the colony in Liberia. but for some years pas?? has been one of the home agents at Washington. Peter Ayres, one of the original Shakers at Shaker Village, N. H., died at that place on the 14th inst., aged 97.

In the TIMES of Saturday morning we published Governor WALKER'S Proclamation to the People of Kansas, upon the Election in that Territory which is to take place on Monday next. for members of the Legislature and a Delegate to Congress.

SEIZURE FOR ALLEGED SMUGGLING.--The little tug Quarantine propeller Robert C. Smith was on Friday seized by the Custom-House officers at Quarantine, upon it charge of smuggling cigars from on board vessels lying at the lower anchorage.

THE PUFF POLITICAL--The writing of Puffx has come to be a distinct department of literature. The venders of pills and other commodities which it was deemed desirable to keep before the people. originated the system. Some general topic is first introduced, and by an easy and skillful transition it is turned to the specific object in view.

PRISON DISCIPLINE-There Seems to be a full in the interest taken by practical and scientific men in the subject of person discipline, both here and in Europe, but the subjects is not abandoned, nor is the area of discussion limited to the United States, England and Frances, as it was at one period, Germany and Italy have taken a part in it.

MY DEAR DR. TWEEDIE: Alas, alas! the work of savage butchery still progresses in this distracted land. Not a day passes without some addition, from one quarter or another, to the black catalogue of treachery and murder.

ROBINSON,-In this City, on Sunday. Sept. 27. ANN. wife of Samuel Robinson, aged 31 years. The friends of the family, also the members of Jackson Lodge No. 5. A. P. A.. and the members of Naval Ladge, No. 69 F. and A. M.. are requested to attend the funeral from her late residence, No. 320 8th-av.. this(Monday) afternoon, at 2 o'clock.

Before Judge Nelson. DECISIONS. Isaac M. Singer et al. vs. George M. Wooster, et al.--This was a motion for an attachment against the defendants, the proprietors of the "Ten-Dollar Sewing Machine," for an alleged disobedience to the preliminary injunction issued in this case, which injunction was dissolved a few days since.

Engine Company No. 22 having gone to Hartford connecticut, to enter the lists in the grand firemens contest, which took place recently in that city, was ordered to return to New-York by the 8 P.M. New-Haventrain, Saturday night.

POLITICAL.--We observe that sundry papers, in quoting from our columns a paragraph announcing that Hon. O. B. MATTESON had decided not to resign his seat in Congress, speak of the TIMES as Mr. M.'s organ. We apprehend Mr. MATTESON would regard this as a piece of gratuitous and gross injustice.
