EFFECTS OF INTOXICATION UPON A MOTHER.--Or Friday an Inquest was held by Coroner Hills, at No. 445 Greenwich-street upon the body of PATRICK TUBERDY, a child five months old, who died under very painful circumstances. It appeared from the evidence Coat at an early hour on the previous morning the infant was discovered lying on the basement steps at that address, and in a state of complete insensibility.

Attorney General BLACK, in response to questions submitted to him by the Secretary of State, relative to the compensation of Consuls, says, the constitution put on the act of Congress by the late President and Secretary of State, under the advice of the Attorney-general, was that a Minister or Consul who was in service on the 30th of June 1855.

ACCIDENTS.--A laborer named BARTEL ROYLAN, fell about 8 o'clock Saturday morning, from the third story of a building in Greenwich-street, near Bank and sustained a fracture of the leg. He was removed to the Hospital ....WM. DONOHUE fell about noon Saturday, through the scuttle-hole of a canal-boat, at the foot of Seventh-street, East river. He was sent to Bellevue Hospital.

A recent Scottish traveler in this country, upon whose book we yesterday commented, describes his passage from Washington to New-York as a transition " from the sham to the real Metropolis of the United States." These adjectives resemble SOUTHEY'S pet phrase of the "Satanic school," when applied to BYRON and his followers--they will stick.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR: Having a few days since addressed you on the subject of "Saving Life on Lakes, Rivers and Bays," in case of wreck or steamboat disasters, I now wish to call the attention of te public to the best mode of saving life on ocean steamers, in cases similar to the steamships Arctic, San Francisco and Central America, to say nothing of the President, City of Glasgow,

The money difficulties in Wall-street and among the merchants yesterday were quite as severe as at the close of last week. The embarrasments were even greater in negotiating loans and discounts on the Street and in selling Foreign Bills of Exchange made against the export of produce.

ASHES--Unchanged. Small sales, including Pearls, $6 75; and Pots, $7 75 ?? 100 lbs. COFFEE--Is very quiet at previous rates: Java, 16 1/2C.@17C.; Laguayra, 12 3/4 C.@13 1/4 C.; Jamaica, 13C.; Maracaibo, 13C.; Rio, 10 1/2 C. @ 12 1/4 c.; St. Domingo, 10 3/4 C. cash; Native Ceylon, 13C. ? lb. b.

From the National Intelligencer. My attention has been called to a letter addressed to the people of Tennessee by Gen. PILLOW, in which he criticizes my campaign in Mexico with the boldness of a master in the art of war, and at the same time eulogizes his own services therein, with a hearty good-will that leaves nothing to be added.

There is a slight run upon the Savings Department of the Albany Banks, by the small depositors, this morning, but we have not a single instance of withdrawal of balances, except in the Savings Departments, or of pressure for specie by bill holders. The banks Seem all quiet and Confident here.

THE GANSEVOORT PROPERTY.-The Committee of the Board of Councilmen on Markets, Councilman W. H. COLLIER, in the chair, was summoned by advertisement to assemble in the Council Chamber at the City Hall on Monday afternoon at 2 o'clock. The Committee have already had three meetings in reference to the Gansevoort property.

The next Charter Election takes place on the first, Tuesday in next December,--one month after the State Election. The object of the Legislature in thus postponing it was to separate, as much as possible,--or rather to give the people of this City the power to separate--our Municipal election from State and National politics.

AID AND COMFORT TO THE ENEMY.--A correspondent of the London Daily News states, as a fact within his own knowledge, that a mercantile house in Calcutta has actually sold a thousand Minie rifles to the Natives, and that no attempt has been made by tho local government to check the sale. which is still proceeding.

The Committee on County Offices met yesterday afternoon for the purpose of examining sundry bills of M. D.'s, for services in connection with the investigation into the causes that led to the death of HARVEY BURDELL. The total amounted to $1,050. The first bill presented was the following: The Supervisors of the City and County of New-York. To J. W. S. GOULEY, M. D., Dr.

The trial of JAMES P. DONNELLY for the murder of ALFRED S. MOSES, on the 1st of August last, at the Sea View House, Nevisink, NewJersey, has resulted in a verdict of guilty against the accused. Those who have carefully followed this interesting investigation, will have arrived at the conclusion that the finding of the jury was fully warranted by the facts presented.

A BURGLAR ARRESTED.--The dwelling-house of Mr. Frederick P. Harriott, No. 34 West Twenty-second-street, was entered on Saturday night by burglars, by forcing open the back basement door, and $200 worth of clothing was carried off. The burglars succeeding in effecting an entrance into the house and escaped with the goods without rousing anybody.

General HERRAN, the Minister of New-Granada, professes to think he yielded too much to General CASS in the treaty recently signed, settling the questions between his Government and that of the United States.

BURTON'S THEATRE.--Miss CHARLOTTE CUSHMAS -an artiste who enjoys the satisfaction of being perfectly appreciated in two hemispheres-made her ap pearance here last night, and was welcomed by a full audience. Her reception was,as it deserved to be,cor dial and clearly well-considered. The play selected for the occasion was MILMAN'S "Fazio," and Miam CUSHMAN'S performance of the heroine was, if possible, more intense, better pointed and graceful than ever

Before Hon. Justices Mitchell, Charles and Davies ARGUMENT ON THE CERTIORARI. In re Habeas Corpus of Emms A. Cunningham.--I will be remembered that shortly after Judge Peabody decided to admit Mrs. Cunningham to bail, judge Roosevelt granted a certiorari to review this proceeding.

MECHANICS' AND TRADERS' SAVINGS INSTITUTION--No. 482 Grand-st., corner Willet-st., open Mondays, Wednesdays, Thursdays and Saturday. Six per cent, interest allowed on sums from $5 to $500; 5 per cent. on sums over $500. All sums deposited previous to the 15th of July will draw interest from the 1st. ALFRED T. CONKLIN, President. JAMES P. HAIGHT, Secretary.

The comptroller's Semi-Annual Report. STARTLING INCREASE IN THE EXPENDITURES OF THE CITY GOVERNMENT. Comptroller FLAGG sent in to the Common Council last night the semi-annual report of the City Finances, which he is required to make by the Charter of 1857.

THE MEXICAN CAMPAIGN AGAIN.--The manifesto by which General PILLOW hoped to be elected to the Senate of the United States from Tennessee, has elicited from General SCOTT a brief letter in direct contradiction of some very important statements which had been ventured by the Tennessee politician. General SCOTT denies point blank General PILLOWS' statement that he paid $10,000 to Mr.

The Cunard-screw steamship Jura, chartered by the British Covernment to convey the 76th Regiment to England, arrived at this port at 9:40 A. M. to-day. She left Cork on the 17th inst., five days subsequent to the Canada'sdeparture from Liverpool, and should have brought four days' later news from England and the continent.

The undersigned has read with the most painful emotions of the loss of the steamer central America, and sincerely deplores the sad rate of her passengers suddenly cut off, "in health and hope." by one of those fearful hurricanes which in the past few years have made so many hearths desolate, and so many hearts to mourn.

CHRISTIAN MISSIONARIES IN TURKEY.--A MEETing for the aid of the Missionary cause in Turkey was held on Sunday evening, at Rev. Dr. ADAMS' Church, Madison-square. The building was filled with an attentive and interested audience. An address was delivered by Rev. Dr. SHAUFFLER, who has

MONK-JARVIS.--In this City, on Sunday, Sept. 27, at the residence of the bride's father, No. 30 1st., by Rev. R. R. Thompson, Mr. W. H. MONK to Miss CASSIE D. JARVIS. youngest daughter of George Jarvis, Esq., all of this City. Ulster county and Western papers please copy. HIGBIE-MADDEN. --In Brooklyn. on Sunday. Sept. 27. by Rev. Wm. Lawrence. Mr. HENRY HIOBIE to Miss AMELIA HADDEN, all of Brooklyn.

The Board of Aldermen met last evening, President CLANOT in the Chiir. The first resolution of Interest was one calling for the opinion of the Corporation Counsel, in relation to the power of the Common Council over the piers occupied by the North River steamboats.

FUNERAL SERMON AT ALLEN-STREET.--On Sunday evening, pursuant to advertisement, a sermon was preached by Rev. Mr. LUCAS, Pastor of the Allen-street Presbyterian Church, in reference to the late sudden death by drowning on board the propeller J. N. Harris, of Miss ROBINSON, who was a member of that church. There was a crowded and very attentive congregation.

The traffic in liquors is one of the heaviest branches of New-York trade, and in spite of the efforts made to check consumption, it is rapidly increasing. It employs heavy capital, engages animmense tonnage, and produces enormous income. The aggregate statistics of this traffic furnish interesting material for comparison and calculation.

DELIGHTFUL SAIL. THE BEAUTIES OF NATURE AND ART TO BE SEEN AT A VERY LOW PRICE. FOR FLUSHING AND COLLEGE POINT. The beautiful and fast-sailing steamer ENOCH DEAN. Captain WILLIAM H. REYNOLDS, will, on and E?ter Monday, June 1, run daily (Sundays excepted) as follows: Leave Flushing at 8 o'clock A.M., and 2 o'clock P.M. Leave College Point at 8:10 A.M. and 2:15 P.M.

SEAMEN'S WAGES.--Seamen are now comparatively plenty; wages to Liverpool are :$20; to London and Havre $18; to the Mediterranean and South America $15, and one month's advance. The English steamers are troubled with desertions. Out of a crew of thirty-eight belonging to the screw steamer Indiana, on her last arrival at this port, twenty-one deserted and sir came up missing at roll-call on Saturday.

A fire occurred at Grand Rapids, on Friday last, destroying many of the blest business houses. The loss is estimated at $100,000, and the insurance $50,000 to $6O,0OO. FIRE AT POTTSVILLE, PENN. POTTSVILLE, Penn., Monday, Sept. 28. The Castle William Colliery of Messrs. ROGERS, SINNOCKSON Co. was entirely destroyed by fire today.

HAMMILL--In this City, on Sunday morning, Sept. 27, WILLIAM H. HAMMILL, Hon of the late Rev, Wm. Hammill, aged 65 years and 3 days. His relatives and friends are respectfully invited to attend his funeral, on Tuesday morning, Sept. 29, at 9X o'clock, from his late residence, No. 181 Duance-st. FINK.--In this City, on Sunday, Sept. 27, ARNEST C., only son of ARNEST Fink, in the 18th year of his age.

NEW-YORK RACES.--FASHION COURSE., L. I.--TUESDAY, Sept. 29.--GREAT FOUR-MILE RACE.-Four-mile heats: winner to receive $5,000. JNO. HUNTER enters ch. g. Nicholas I, 4 years old, by Glencoe, dain Nannie Rhodes, by Wagner

TERRIBLE AFFAIR IN GEORGIA.--A man by the name of HORNSBY, residing about thirteen miles from Brunswick, had, with some of his associates, been charged with stealing his neighbors' stock, and had been notified by them to leave the settlement by Tuesday last HORNSBY not complying, several men set out for his house, on that day, for the purpose of forcing him to leave.

A MAGNIFICENT SCHEME--It may be interesting to our readers to know that Prince DEMINOFF has purchased NAPOLEON'S Villa in the Campagna. This Russian ?? is converting it into it Napoleonic museum. It will be splendid, with its halls of marble and fairy salons, in which all the deeds of the Emperor will be depicted on the walls at fresco.

RANK DEFALCATION IN CANADA.--Mr. LUCAS, teller of the Gore Bank, London, (Can.) has defaulted to the amount of some thousands of dollars, and has decamped. The London Free Press says: "People were startled at this intelligence, for the absconding individual had ever been regarded as a man of estimable character, and possing none of those extravagant follies which have so often led the Mc. GAFFLYS and CUMMINGS of the world astray.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The President financial revulsion which is upon us can be traced directly to the culpable negligence, dishonesty and fraud of the railway management of the country. There has been invested in the construction of railways in the United States not far from $800,000,000.

Before Judge Nelk?? SEIZURE--JURISDICTION. NELSON, C. J.--The United States vs. The Steamship Washington.--This is a libel of information, filed to procure a forfeiture of the Washington for a violation of the revenue laws.

FRENCH RAILWAYS.--An elaborate view of the railway system in France has been published by Goliganni from which it appears that the gross receipts in 1856 were no less than 611,210,000, of about one seventh of the whole imperial revenue.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In the autograph of a Wesley Minister just Issued in Canada, we notice the following calculation, which is very curious. It was communicated by a Frenchman to an English friend.

GALLANT ACTION BEFORE DELHI.--I must tell you of a noble action of HILLS, of the Artillery He was in my term at Addiscombe, and one of my greatest friends. Three days ago he was on picket with his two-horse artillery guns, when the alarm was sounded, and an order sent him to advance, given under the impression that the enemy were at some distance.

??--In this City, on Tuesday, Sept. 29, of congestion of the brain, JENNIE, daughter of Silas H. and Harriet Buttrich, aged 4 years, 7 months and 3 days. Notice of the funeral will be given to-morrow morning. QUANTIN.--In this City, on Monday, Sept. 28, after a long and painful illness, HARRIET, wife of Heari Quantin.

New-Orleans papers of Wednesday of last week are to hand by the arrival of the mails as late as due. Copious rains had fallen in Western Texas. In two engagements with the Indians near El Pa?? they had been badly beaten, and the campaign was considered ended.

The American State Committee met at the Delavan House to-day, and elected LORENZO BURROWS, Chairman : L. S. PARSONS, Vice-Chairman : JOHN N. WILDEE, Treasurer : and HENRY Q. LANSING and C. L. SKEELS, Secretaries.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: At our last election, a very decided majority of the electors preferred a substitute for Mr. Wool, in the Mayoralty. But they frittered away their strength upon four or five candidates, and Mr. WOOD was redlected.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The Press of Sept. 2 Says: "The Erie Canal is now almost ridiculously inadequate to meet the demands upon it, with all the aid afforded by two parallel lines of railroad." In another issue it says: "The Erie Canal, inadequate as it has now become to meet the growing wants of the West;"

FOSTER--WATERS.-In this City, on Tuesday, Sept. 29, by Rev. T. L. Harris, HORATIO FOSTER, of this City, to MART A., daughter of Rev. G. Waters, of Rahway. N. J. HEATH-CHILD-In this City, on Saturday, Sept. 26, by Rev. Dr. DeWitt. JOHN H HEATH. of Newburg, N. Y., to EMMA L., daughter of Lewis Child, of this City.

NATIONAL CONVENTION OF ODD FELLOWS--The United States Grand Lodge of Odd Fellows as sembledin annual Convention at Baltimore, on Friday. Favorable reports were made of the condition of the Order in Nebraska, New-Mexico. Washington Territory, and the Sandwich Islands, and of the encampments in Arkansas, Minnessota and Nova Scotia, Sandwich Islands and Vermont.

The semi-annual report of Mr. Comptroller FLAGG upon the state of the Civic Exchequer, which we yesterday published, can hardly be said to belong to the class of light literature. It is a very grave and solemn document, compiled with care after a minute collation of many bundles of filed and dusty papers by a most methodical and practical gentleman of nature years, and of a well-established character for veracity.

Hampoen Park. a tract of 60 acres of land, pur. chased and fitted up by the Hampden Agricultural Society, at a cost of $40,000, was inaugurated to-day in the presence of some 12,000 persons. The opening address was made by Hon. Gao. BLISS, the inaugural address by Rev. HENR WARD BEECHER, and tie closing address by Mayor PHELPS.

Before. Hon. Judge Roosevelt. The evidence of the prosecution and defer in the case of Michael Cangemi. on trial for the murder of the Policeman Engene Anderson, having closed on Saturday, the Court and Jury reassembled yesterday to hear the summing up of counsel, and, if possible to arrive at a verdiev and conclude the affair.

WILLIAM J. WATKINS, the Associate Editor of FRED. DOUGLAS' paper, ??held forth last evening at the Bethesda Church in Sullivan-street, (colored,) in reply to some strictures in a late number of the Tribune, which were considered unjust and invidious towards the colored population of New-York.

SLIGHTLY AWKWARD.-- Everyone, of course, remembers that Lord RAGLAN, according to the Times and its correspondent, was "never to be seen." We will give a little anecdote upon this point, vouching for its authencity. An officer of rank was one day conversing near the hospital with a brother officer, with whom Mr. RUSSELL had most intimate relations, and from whom it was general believed in camp he received certain "inspirations."

The Commissioner of Patents is sending out circulars with the view of ascertaining the amount and cost of cotton consumed in the United States during the fiscal year ending the 30th of June last, and the qualities and values of the different classes of goods into which it is manufactured.

The Cincinnati Gazelle has a story of a singular case of bigamy, desertion and avarice. A man, Charles Fox, an old resident in that city until four or five years past, brought suit against a woman residing on the side of Mr. Adams you detention of property--a house and lot--which he claimed to be his.

The Evening Post publishes an exceedingl able and timely communication upon the ne cessity of maintaining the independence o! the Judiciary by the recleetion of Judge DENIO, in whose person it is menaced with corn plete and disastrous overthrow.

ANlVERSARY OF THE ABOLITION OF SLAVERY--GOLD MINES--THE SALT CROP-WRECK OF AN ENGLISH BRIG. Advice from Nassau (N. P.) are received to the 20th of September. The papers notice the celebration on the 1st of August, at Nassau, of the anniversary of the abolition of African Slavery in the British Colonies.

The American Sunday-School Union has recently discovered that notes and acceptance amounting to nearly $89,000 have been circulated without their authority. A card has been prepared disowning them, and asserting that the Board is not responsible for their payment.

To the Editor of the New - York Times: I was very glad to see your article in Saturday's paper upon railway management, and I quite agree with you in the opinion that the time has now come for a through reformation. Let the stockholders look to their interests more closely, and insist upon a wise and economic administration of these great works, and we shall soon see far different results. ts.

President JOHN TAYLOR, formerly editor of the Mormon, now in Utah, sends back a letter descriptive of the life of the Mormons on the Plains, which we are permitted to publish. President YOUNG is laboring with the "Saints" in Denmark, and give an account of the progress of Mormonism there, in a communication which we also publish below:

COOL AS ICE--THE WAY THEY DO IN OSWEGO.--The Chicago Tribune says that the officers of one of its financial institutions had forwarded some produce, received by him as collateral, to an Oswego house to sell. The Oswego concern did not come up to ??, and the Chicago financier proceeded to that city in person, to demand a response, either in the specifies or coin.

By the arrival at this port of the steamship Philadelphia, we have later intelligence from Havana. We continue to receive well authenticated reports of the increasing prevalence of the Slave-trade. It never was more flourishing in its palmiest days. Latterly, an American ship, loaded with Africans, was captured by a Spanish cruiser;

Mr. MACAULAV'S ANTECEDENTS.--He was "lucky" in having a father before him who had access to all the high Whig circles. Old ZACHARY was not a bad progenitor for an ambitious young orator. Many of the interesting social anecdotes which flew so rapidly from Mr. MACAULAY'S lips testify the fact of his early initiation into political circles.

The United States steamship Philadelphia, S. P. GRIFFIN, Commander, from New-Orleans at 8 A. M. of the 20th inst., and Havana on the afternoon of the 23d, arrived at this port yesterday morning. The Quaker City, SHUFRLDT, Commander, from Mobile on the 22d and Havana on the morning of the 25th, also arrived here yesterday.

The Board of Police Commissioners held a secret meeting yesterday, all the members present except Mr. CHOLWELL. The following is all that was done that was made public: Mr. BOWEN offered a number of petitions from policemen for permission to receive rewards.

Mr. JOHN E. THAYER, a wealthy and well-known Broker of this city, died this morning. The United States steam frigate Merrimac anchored in the stream to-day and will leave to-morrow for the Pacific station, The second annual parade and muster of the Boston Fire Department took place to-day.

A TRAGEDY AT JHANSI.--It is all true about poor FRANK GORDON. He ALICK SKENE, his wife, and a few peons, managed is get into a small round tower when the disturbance began: the children and all the rest were in other parts of the fort--altogether 60.

HEAVY ROBBERY IN PHILADELPHIA.--The silk store of Curtis Co., Chesenut-street, Philadelphia, was broken into by burglars last Saturday night, and $8,000 worth of goods stolen. Information was sent by telegraph to Police-Superintendent Tallmadge that one of the parties suspected of having been concerned in the burglary had fled to this City.

As a general thing Governor WALKER'S proclamation is received throughout the country as a strong indication of his personal desire, and of the purpose of the National Administration, to secure to the people of Kansas, in the election of next Monday, a full and fair opportunity to vote.

Great indignation is felt here by the public and the personal friends of his Excellency Mr. MASON, United States Minister at this Court, in consequence of a paragraph said by some American papers to have originally appeared in the London Court Journal.

ENGLAND AND AUSTRALIA.--The Australian steamers have all been unfortunate this year, and have been badly beaten by the clippers. The Cape and Calcutta line, started last year, with a mail subsidy of $10,000, has also been abandoned; the ships were good ones, with moderate power, and were well managed, but could not make passages equal to the clipper Indiamen.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR: I see in your paper of Saturday an article on life-preservers. Life-preservers are a very good thing in their way, as was shown on the occasion of the Central America, but the kind of life-preservers that ships ought to be supplied with, aside from the boats, which are so apt, to get stove, and which are often shrunk and leaky, are rafts.

Before Hon. Judge Rookvelt. At the assembling of the Court yesterday, the jury sent word to the Judge that they had been in conference all night, and had failed to agree. They requested to be allowed to examine the minutes of the rag-picker's evidence. This was granted by consent of counsel for defence and prosecution.

The propeller Louisville, belonging to the Northern Transportation Company, was burned last night ten miles front here. The boat and cargo are a total loss. One fireman was drowned. She was insured for #22,000. FIRE AT WOODSTOCK, VT. WOODSTOCK, Vt., Wednesday, Sept. 30. The Gas House in this place was destroyed by fire this morning.

M, of that date found the vessel had spring a leak; started the pumps and got her almost clear ; at 12 o'clock the wind and sea increasing, the

The fag-end of the season: all the roads of Virginia lead away from the White Sulphur. Execrable roads they are too, and a weary, starved disappointed dispersion of wayfarers, is that which travels them homeward diversely at this fag-end of the season. For the Virginia Springs, with one or two commendable exceptions, boast not worthily of those comforts characteristic of Northern watering places.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Confiding in your regard for truth, I take the liberty of contradicting the report published in your paper of Monday, from the pen of JOHN DAVIES, against the inhabitants of utah. JOHN DAVIES left Great Salt Lake City on the 17th of April, on foot, with two or three persons as he affirmed, but they were not alone, escaping from the Mormons;

THE JERSEY CITY AND HOBOKEN BANKS.-The Banks working under the General Security Law of Now-Jersey, are required to deposit with the State Treasurer stocks of the States of Virginla, Kentucky and Massachusetts, or (by special enactment) Jersey City Water Stock and Newark City Scrip, to the full amount of their circulation.

The Ministers of the Central American States are uniting successfully to urge an honest repression of filibuster ventures, representing to General CASS in strong written and oral language the Imperative duty of our Government to put a stop to the dishonorable proceedings intended to be repeated by WILLIAM WALKER and copartners against tile peace of Nicaragua and Costa Rica.

The second National Horse Exhibition opened here to-day under very favorable auspices. At the grand entree over 300 horses appeared upon the track. The collection embraces what Is deemed the best class of horses ever brought together in America. The attendance was rather better than the first day of the show of 1853.

THE CENTRAL PARK COMMISSIONERS.--The Board of Commissioners of the Central Park met yesterday. The President presented a communication from SAMUEL. J. GUSTIN, Esq., accepting the appointment of Nurserymen and Superintendent of Planting and recommending trees to be purchased from American nurseries for Fall planting, and an importation of small trees from Europe for Spring planting.

KIRBY--Rider.--In this City, on Tuesday, Sept. 29, at Calvary Church. by Rev. Dr. Hawks, Mr. EDGAR KIRBY to Miss MART JANE RIDER, Only daughter of Francis Rider, Esq., all of this City. BRADHUEST--NOYES.--In this City, on Wednesday, Sept. 30. by Rev. Mr. Howard Smith, Mr. HENRY M. BRADHUEST to ELIZABETH T. NOYES, all of this City.

A few minutes after 5 o'clock P. M., yesterday, the steam holler of the Knickerbhocker Plaster Works of J. R. (n. o, Nos. 500 and 510 West-street, suddenly exploded, demolishing the structure and two dwelling-houses adjacent, and causing the death of one person, and severely Injuring over thirty others. The explosion was heard for several blocks distant, and the utmost excitement prevailed for a time In the neighborhood.

On the morning of theo 21st of July last, between 4 and 6 o'clock, a burglary was committed in the shoe-store of Mr. SAMMIS, situated at the corner of Grand and Centrestreets. The burglar, or burglars, entered the store through the door on Centre-streot, which was broken open for the purpose. They carried off about six or seven dollars in pennies, together with some ladies' and gentlemen's shoes or gaiters.

We have received, by the bark Anlagonist, advices from Buenos Ayres to the 14th of August. The passport system had been abolihed by the House of Representatives, and it was expected that the measure would soon be confirmed by the Senate. The Governmentt of Buenos Ayres were proposing to extend the Western Raillroad to Moron, and to build another from the Capital to San Fernando.

The Treasary Department is sill engaged doling all it can in a legitimate way to relieve the money pressure. Applications for the redemption of a large amount of United States Stocks are steadily on the Increase. United States Stocks amounting to $100,000 wern received hero to-day for redemption.

To the Editor of the New-York Time : SIR: In your article in last Tuesday's paper on the Nevisink trial, it is alleged that the sleeve-butions of MOSES, the deceased, were found in my son's room all bloody. This Is not true. According to the evidence produced on the trial, they were found In MOSES' room, andnot DONNELLY'S. By correcting the above you will oblige.

The deferred Regatta of the New-York Yacht Club takes place to-day, all the principal yachts being entered. Some new vessels also enter. The fleet starts as usual from a slake-boat at Hoboken, and sail round the buoy of the S. W. Spit All yachts not ready to start at 9 o'clock are to be excluded from compelling in the race. An exciting and interesting time is expected, provided there is a breeze.

THE AMERICAN MINISTER IN FRANCE.--The Richmond Enquirer publishes, in a letter from Paris, a note from the Editor of the London Court Journal--stating that the paragraph alleging that Judge MASON had committed the impropriety of putting his arm upon the chair of the Empress, which has gone the rounds of American papers, credited

The severe financial pressure compels very nearly all tile great manufacturing establishments of the country either to suspend or greatly to curta I their operations. Two Companies In Now-Brunswick wihin a few days have discharged over three hundred hands. The Print Works In Manchester, N. I., have de cided not to run their mills Fridays and Saturdays which is equivalent to curtailing their business onethird.

TO WHAT BASE USES !--"Shade of WASHINGTON !" was our involuntary ejaculation as we saw today, a comely female Hibernian peerling furtively around the old red sand-stone statue of the Father of his Country, in the Park. Watching her operations, we saw that she was getting her "ould man" a commodious and retired place to eat his dinner from a tin-pall which he had "convenient."
There are thousands of men in New-York to-day--we might say, for that matter, hundreds of thousands--who have passed the last three weeks on a bed of thorns, and t whom the next will bring no relief.

I feel it due to the memory of my father, that the readers of this journal. at any rate, should not misunderstand the position in which he left his family. Fifty rumors, one and all erroneous, have been circulated on this private subject--become a public one by the false light such rumors have cast upon my father's character. My father left property sworn at Doctors' Commons at ?1,500.
The representatives of the several States of Central America have united in asking our Government to prevent the descent of another army of invaders from the United States upon their coast.

Kansas, I am inclined to believe, has well high accomplished the first state in her "strange, eventful history." Her childish days are nearly over. The "mewling and puking" are almost at an end. Deo gratias. The result of the October election may now be predicted with certainty. It is a matter beyond cavil or contradiction.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC-There was an excellent attendance last night to witness the performance of VERDI's ever fresh "Enmni." The cast included the names of LA GRANOE, VESRVALI, MACCAERRRI, and GASSIER. Of these artists It is only necessary to say that LA GRANGE was, as usual, excellent; VESTVALI painstaking and elaborate, but not entirely successful; GASSIER a little deeper than his voice permitted, but excellent; and MACCAFERRI very acceptable.

Mr. EDITOR: Returning from one of the Courts of our Circuit, at a late hour yesterday evening, your daily, of that date, was placed in my hand, and I was equally surprised and displeased to find in it a letter from Gen. Wm. WALKER, addressed to me and taken by you from the New Orlenns True Delta. Although adverse, at all times, to newspaper notoriety. I cannot permit this publication to pass unnoticed.

DISTRESSING ACCIDENT.--A deeply distressing accident took place on Saturday afternoon, at about 51/2 o'clock, just South of Benning's bridge, whereby a most worthy and promising young man, Mr. EUGENE BURN, second son of Mr. David H. Burn, of this city, late surveyor-General of Utah, lost his life, he was returning from shooting in company with two young friends,

MILK SEVEN CENTS A QUART.--To-day, a large number of our milkmen put up the price of milk t 7 cents a quart. The reason adduced for this rise in price at the end of a season of unequaled abundance of pasture and extraordinary hay-harvesting, is the increased charge for milk-freight over the Harlem Road, with a threat of a like increase on the Erie and other roads.

A KEG FOUND CONTAINING SIXTEEN HUNDRED FRENCH COINS!--An extraordinary story reaches its which we give as we received id. The report is that two men named WARD and HALL, were at work down the lake shore, some miles from this city, getting out hoop-stuff, when they discovered a small keg buried in the sand. This they dug out, and opening it, found it contained 1,600 silver places. .

CIRCULAR TO LAND OFFICERS.-- The following circular has been issued by the Commissioners of the General Land Office: By the Joint resolution of Congress, approved March 3, 1857, valid preemption claims on the 15th and 30th sections heretofore reserved for schools in the Territories of Minnesota, Kansas and Nebraska, will be recognized where the settlement has been or may be made prior to the survey.

The Annual Convention of the Episcopal Church of the Diocese of New-York was opened on Wednesday morning with Divine Service in St. John's Church. The proceedings commenced by a voluntary on the organ, Dr. HODGES presiding. The creed was then recited by Rev. Dr. PITHIN, of Albany, and the remainder, including the litany, by Rev. Dr. W. F. MORGAN, of St. Thomas' Church, in this City. The first leeson was read by Rev. J. D.

Marshal RYNDERS has replied officially to Mr. McKEON's letter of suspicions in relation to the movements of the filibusters in the City of New-York, The Maurhal says he Is on the look-out for them; and as there are few men who are more familiar with the whole matter than he is, it is probable that any illegal movement would be arrested by him at Its commencement.

From the Syracuse Journal of Monday evening, About 6 1/2 o'clock on Sunday morning, fire was discovered in the counting-room of the Onondaga Bank, and an entrance was promptly effected by the firemen, who soon succeeded in extinguishing the flames. The fire apparently caught under the counter of the Bank, and burned a portion of the desk, besides blacking and scorching all the wood work in the room.

RAILROAD ACCIDENT AT CORNING.-- Information was received this morning that the night express train of the New-York and Eric Railroad going West on Tuesday night run into a train of the Buffalo and Corning Railroad, Which was standing on the main track at Corning, N. Y. The train lies a perfect wreck. No lives were lost.

The Grand Jury this morning brought in indirtments in the following Cases: The U. S. vs. Louis Simond.--An indictment for smuggling barometers, compasses, telescopes, and opera glasses. The U.S. vs. John Thomas Prentice.--An indictment for smuggling laces.

The following remarkable developments regarding the murder of Doctor HARVEY BURDELL, have been published in the News Letter through a spiritual source. The interviews took place at three several times, at intervals of six weeks, to test his recollection of facts. It will be seen that the narrative is in the form of an affidavit, and we assure our readers there is no humbug about it. let the lovers of the marvelous read:

II.--THE CRYSTAL PALACE FAIR.--The Department of Machinery.

His Honor read it aloud to an ?? on the tiptoe of expectation: To His Honor, the Judge of the Court of ?? Terminer. nd Terminer.

The organs of the several political parties are exerting themselves to the atmost to lash the public mind into a passion about the coming election. The stock of epithets and coarse abuse which is kept on hand for these periodical uses, is brought forth and brushed up for fresh service, and charges which, if true, would consign the persons against whom they are brought to enduring infamy.

From the Philadelphia Eevening Bulletin of yesterday. We regret to announce the defalcation of Mr. FREDERICK W. PORTER, of this city, who has for thirty years held the responsible post of Corresponding Secretary of the America Sunday School Union, The following card has been issued by this Instituion, explanatory of the defalcation: A CARD.

Lord BROUGHAM delivered an address recently at the meeting of the Mechanics' Association at Manchester, from which we make the following interesting and instructive extract: " I am about to address a few words partly to the working men themselves-those classes from which come the pupils who have been rewarded this evening, and partly to the employers of those classes and the patrons and supporters of these in. stitutions. First, with respect to the institutions

POLITICAL.---The Democrats in the Fifth As ?? District, (Ninth and Eleventh Wards of Brooklyn,) have placed in nomination for Assembly, ?? CAMPBELL, at present representing the Eleventh Ward in the Board of Supervisors. The Convention of the third District have not yet ??reed upon a candidate. Another trial will be made on Wednesday next.

THE RUMORED SAFETY OF CAPT. HERNDON. The town was startled yesterday afternoon with the intelligence of the safety of Captain HERNDON, and sixteen more passengers of the Central America. The greatest excitement prevailed to learn the circumstances connected with the rescue of the gallant officer who so nobly distinguished himself at the time of that terrible catastrophe.

From the London Spectator. The Great Northern Railway meeting, on Saturday, was as stormy as any railway gathering ever reported; abuse, nicknames and insults were freely handled about; the meeting treated the Chairman with contempt, and he returned the compliment with interest.

VIRGINIA POLITICS--The Richmond Enquirer states that Gov. Wise is not a candidate for the united States Senate in opposition to Senator HUNTER. It sustains this assertion by submitting sundry reasons why Gov. WISE should not enter upon such a canvass.

The Buston Gazette tells this story of business sagacity: One day during the past week a firm gave it check to one of their creditors for two thousand dollars, which he presented at the bank, where he was informed that it was drawn for five hundred dollars more than stood to the firm's credit.

The world has been so busily occupied with the effect produced, or to be produced, upon the great commercial enterprises and the powerful capitalists of the country, by the actual disturbance of all financial relations, that very little attention has been bestowed upon the mischief which the panic and the panic-mongers are doing in the homes of the mechanic and laboring classes.

From the New-Orleans Crescent. It is not altogether a new thing to our readers that, while a portion of the Southern people have been making strenuous efforts to introduce Kansas into the Union as a Slave State, the rapidly-growing Anti-Slavery influence in one of the Southern States has been almost entirely overlooked. We allude to Texas, the western portion of which is rapidly filling up with emigrants from Germany and other parts of Europe.

The subjoined circular has been issued by the Commissioner of Patents: UNITED STATES PATENT OFFICE, WASHINGTON, Sept. 20, 1857. SIR: In making the annual reports of this office, it is desirable that there should be given, in a condensed from, the amount and cost of Cotton consumed in the United States during the fiscal year ending June 30, 1857, and the quantities and valuations of the different classes of goods into which it is manufactured.

We trust that we are not very apt to rejoice over the misfortunes of our fellow-men. We do not think that such a proclivity can be reckoned among our vices. And yet we must own to an emotion of satisfaction when we saw it announced that NATHANIEL. HAWTHORNE was to depart out of the Liverpool Consulate.--whether of his own free will, or of the free will of Mr. BUCHANAN, we do not care.

The Horticultural Society ended their Fall Exhibition at Niblo's last evening by a double feast, first of music and then of fruits. The finale satisfied eye, and car, and palate. The Mendelssohn Union, our youngest and most flourishing musical society, gave a Concert with the best pieces of MENDELSSOHN, HAYDN, BEETHOVEN and COSTA, and added EISFELD'S charming little composition, " Voice from the Lake."

DANGERS TO THE SOUTH.--The Columbia. S. C., Times, in common with several other Southern journals, is commenting very severely on the conduct of two citizens of South Carolina. Mr. PERRY and Mr. MEMMINGER, who have recently sent their sons to he educated at the North. Mr. PERRY resents this attempted interference with this personal and domestic affairs, but the Times remakes him with increased severity for being so untrue to the South.

The money pressure in this City yesterday was marked by no heavy mercantile failures, and a regular and confident bank movement: notwithstanding which the depression at the Stock Board was greater than ever, and the sacrifices made to raise money through that medium very severe upon the sellers.

DERANGEMENT OF GEN. HASKELL--We learn from the Tennessee papers that Gen. WM. T. HASKELL, of that State, has become hopelessly insane. This gentleman fought bravely in the Mexican War, particularly distinguishing himself in the battle of Cerro Gordo, where his regiment suffered severely. He was subsequently prominent in a controversy with Gen. PILLOW, that redoubtable officer being charged with an unnecessary exposure of the Tennessee volunteers and imbecile conduct.

COMMISSIONERS OF EMIGRATION.--The Commissioners of Emigration held their usual weekly meeting on Wednesday, the President, GULIAN C. VERPLANOK, Esq., in the Chair. A conversation arose upon a communication from the "Shoe and Leather Bank, " the financial depository of the commission.

Extract of a letter from Judge B. R. Cartis, dated September 14, 1857. "If I had consulted only my own wishes, I should probably have retained the place. If I had added to these the implied obligation. (the force of which I feel,) to retain permanently an office, whose tenure has been made permanent for wise reasons, I ??should not have resigned it, save from considerations which seemed to me Imperative.

Jonathan Lemmon vs. The People ex rel. Louis Napoleon Houaparie.--This case, which has already attained an extended notoriety, after many postponements and adjournments, came up for hearing this morning.

Explanatory and Vindicatory Cireciar from the Secretarien. To our endeared Follow-workers, the Agents, Superintendents and Colporidurs of the American Tract Society: BEETHREN BELOVEN: There arise occasions when it is important for those cugaged in a widely, expanded enierprise to enjoy a more full and free interchange of thought and affection than is possible by a brief and infrequent correspondence.

ARREST OF TWO NOTORIOUS BURGLARS--ARDUove AND UNFLAGOING PURSUIT BY THE OFFICERS--CLUE TO SEVERAL RECENT BURGLARIES--RECEIVERS OF SIOLEN GOODS OVERHAULED.--EX-Officers Campbell, Martin, Duflon and Rue, of the Sixth, Seventh, Tenth and Seventeenth Wards, have for several weeks been searching the City to secure two notorious burglars named George Minnie and Charles Bloom.

THE BOILER EXPLOSION--CORONER'S INQUEST To-MORROW--THE WOUNDED, one death has yet occurred from this explosion, that of the woman KATE DCOANNE. The engineer is still living, and talks coherently about the engine and boiler which he had in charge. He is in a critical condition, being much bruised and unable to move. He has two physicans in attendance on him.

Yesterday, the contest left undecided between the yachts of the second and third class New-Bedford, in August last, was resumed in on waters. The day was not very favorable to ?? enjoyment, the wind blowing from the South in a light, fitful fashion, more agreeable to the ?? sloops, than to the men of schooners, ?? though to everybody.

Two hundred thousand dollars worth of United States Stock came in this morning for redemption. To-day the various Federal officers throughout the country, including the Judiciary, are paid their quarter's salary.

The following is an extract from a letter to ELWOOD WALTER, dated Key West, Sept. 24: I am pleased to inform you that the late gale did not reach as far South as the Florida Reef. The yellow fever, which made its appearance here in the early part of the month, is still in our midst.

DON'T TEMPT BOYS.-Several correspondents warn us of boys who come recommended with the names of good men, get trusted to collect bills or to carry money to bank and then to disappear. On looking up their references, the referees know nothing of them. It is presumed that they operate for older scamps, for whont there are vacant cells at Sing Sing.

We have news from El Paso to August 25. The Compaign against the Indians is ended, some of the officers have already returned, and the companies are only awaiting transportation to march for their old quarters. Two engagements look place, in both of which the Indians were badly beaten, having lost some fifty killed and thirty prisoners, with all their camp equipment.

A few days since JOSEPTH H. BUDD of Rondout was arrested for committing a series of peculations, in money and goods to a large amount, upon his employer, DANIEL B. STOW, of that village, engaged in the saddlery business, as well as upon several inerchants on the strand.

THE LEMMON CASE.--We have received several communications concerning the Lemmon case, which is now before the Supreme Court in this City. Some of them argue the case on its merits,--others urge he great political importance of its being decided in a particular way and others still denounce the Law Courts, both State and Federal, for the decision which it is assumed they will render.

A grand banquet was given here this afternoon by the managers of the Provincial Fair, which is now being held here. The Governor-General, with his suite, was present. Several members of Parllament, Ex-Governor HUNT, of New-York, and many other distinguished persons were also present. It has rained incessantly to-day, and the visitors are dispersing to their homes,

Annual Meeting in St. John's Church. THURSDAY--SECOND DAY. At 9 o'clock the Convention met for business which was preceded by morning prayer, Rev. W. L. JOHNSON, D>D>, and Rev. THEODORE S> RUMSEY, Conducted the service. The Provisional Bishop then took the Chair, and the minutes of the proceedings of the previous day were read and approved.

It was announced, some time since, that the Morinous had prepared a how alphabet for use in Utah. Two founds of the type have been past in St. Louis, of different sizes of letter. By the favor of the type-founders, we present a complete specimen of the small plea fount which has been finished and shipped to Great Salt Lake City.

E. C. BAILEY, Esq., retires from the office of Postmaster to-day. and will hereafter devote himself to the editorial and business management of the Boston Daily Herald, of which he is proprietor, The entire community acknowledge him one of the most efficient Postmasters we have ever had. NAHUM CAPEN, Esq., succeeds to the office.

The Dallas (Texas) Herald has the following details of a terrible tragedy: JOHN ROBERTSON--who was convicted and sent to the Penitentiary three years ago, in consequence of some difficulties between himself and wife-agreed on Thursday to a separation, Early on Friday morning, two brothers of the wife, JAMES and GEORGE ANDERSON, repaired to ROBERTSON'S house, with a Wagon, for the purpose of removing their sister's ?? to her father's.

CONDITION OF THE STEAMER KNICKERBOCKER --We fear that accident which befell the STEAMER KNICKERBOCKER, night before last, will prove more serious than was yesterday anticipated. From her appearances this morning it is evident that her hall is broken uft of the water wheel, but how badly will not be known until she is placed on the floating dock. Her hog frame is separated in various places, but preparedly aft of the wheel.

WILLETS--CROSSMAN.--In this City, on Thursday, Oct. 1. at the residence of Dr. James R. Wood, Mr. EDWARD WILLETS, son of Samuel Willets, to CORNELIA A. CROSSMAN, daughter of Alfred B. Crossman; of Huntingdon, L.I. ?? Long Island papers please copy. MOSS--NATHAN,--In this City, on Wednesday, Sept,30, by Rev. J. I. Lyons, LUCIEN MOSS, of Philadelphia, to SABAH, daughter of Benjamin Nathan, of this City.

We have waited for the past week, in the hope that some other hand would pay a fitting tribute to the young first officer of the Central America, the gallant companion of Capt. ??DON, in life and death. Mr. VAN RENSSELAER was the son of Hon JOHN S. VAN RENSSELAER, OF Albany, a member of a family whose name is identified with every period of the history of our State.

NELSON.--In this City, on Thursday, Oct. 1. JOHN W. NELSON, eldest son of Hon. Samuel Nelson, in the 37th year of his age. His remains will be taken to Cooperstown for interment. OAR.--In this City, on Friday morning, Oct. 2, of consumption. JOHN, only son of David and Anne Orr, aged 15 years, 9 months and 21 days.

A gentleman, John H. Pidgeon, who had been boarding at the Henrle House, on Third-street, Clanal, being financially distressed and having been frequently disappointed in obtaining employment is the city, concluded to leave this world, and, retiring to his room, swallowed laudanum, and was next morning found dead in his bed. .

EFFORTS MAKING TO RAISE THE STEAMER KNICKERBOCKER.--The work of raising the steamer Knickerbocker was commenced this morning. Three moveable stream pumps, and one stationary one on board the steamer Mercury, are at work pumping the water out of the boat. BRAINERD LAWLER are also in attendance with barges, timber, chains, screws and a gang of men, ready to assist the moment she is off the bed of the river.

MESSRS. GREENWOOD BUTLER--DEAR SIRS: I visited the Museum yesterday, Your Aquaria are the most wonderful, instructive, and delightful of novelties. To the invalid, whose eyes may not rove beyond his chamber walls; to the teacher, who would lead the little feet by pleasant paths to the tree of knowledge; to the uneducated, as well as the trained, eye, it must be a ceaseless joy.

American Senatorial Conventions. The American Party have been holding Conventions in the Fourth, Fifth, Sixth and Seventh Districts, for the nomination ofcandidates for Senators in the ensuing election. The Fourth Senatorial Convention met at the corner of Broadway and Lispenard-street, on Thursday night, when several candidates were proposed, but no nominations were made, and the meeting adjourned to the evening of the 15th inst.

EMBEZZLING GOODS--THE "MOST HONEST" CLERK THE GUILTY ONE.--Thos. R. Finley, who has been employed about a year as clerk in the dry goods store of Mr. M. Egan, No. 332 Bowery, was arrested yesterday charged with embezzling $2,915 worth of goods from his employer. For several months goods had been missing from the store, but the proprietor was unable to fasten the guilt upon any of his clerks.

The Royal Mail steamship Arabia, Capt. STONE, from Liverpool at 10 o'clock on the morning of the 19th September, arrived at this port at 8 o'clock yesterday morning. The Arabia arrived out at Liverpool at 3 A.M., on the 13th, and the City of Washington arrived at the same port at midnight on the 16th. The North Star and the Jason arrived at Southampton on the 17th.

It is like old times again to have Lord BROUGHAM addressing a Mechanics' Institute. He is on his own ground there, and is monarch of all he surveys. What he says of himself, too, is perfectly true--"I am myself, and have been all my life, a working man;" and, therefore, on that ground as well, no man has a greater right to address the operations of Manchester.

THE EXPLOSION IN WEST-STREET.--A Large number of men continued at work yesterday in removing the rains of the late boiler explosion in West--street. A portion of the boiler has only been made bare, but enough to show that it is a complete wreck. It is so jammed and injured that it is very doubtful whether it will be possible to ascerlain what its condition was prior to the explosion.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--The opera of the "Puritans" was given here last night to a good house. The caste was the same as last season, and that, it is needless to say, is one of the best we have had, or are likely to have, for some time, Messrs. BRIGNOLI, AMODIO, COLLETTI, and Mme, LA GHANOE, were in excellent voice, and the opera went off in the most acceptable way.

HUDSON COUNTY DEMOCRATIC EXECUTIVE COMMITTEE, -A meeting of this Committee was held in Jersey City, on Thursday evening with Mr. S. M. CHAMDERS in the Chair. A resolution was passed instructing the Secretary to request the Chairmen of the various Ward and Township Committees, to call meetings in their respective places, on Thursday evening, October 8th, to appoint delegates to the Assembly and County Conventions, The Committee adjourned to meet on Tuesday evening next.

The U.S. Mail steamer Granada left yesterday for Havana and New-Orleans, with eighty cabin and one hundred and one steerage passengers. There were many Cubans among them returning home, after a Summer residence at the North, and many residents of New-Orleans also escaping from the approaching cold weather to their Southern homes.

The Arabia brings tile English commentary upon the first of the present financial troubles in this country, The same steamer, it will be remembered, went out the day succeeding the noted Tuesday of September 1, when the panic in Wall-street took the turn of a bank excitement.

By the arrival at this port yesterday, of the Cunard steamship Arabia, we received London and Liverpool advices to the 19th ult.--three days later than those brought to St. Johns, N. B., by the Jura, and published in our impression of Tuesday Inst. The London journals notice extensively the financial reverses that have lately overtaken us.

THE CENTRAL AMERICA RELIEF FUND--A meeting of the Committee in aid of the suffering passengers and crew of the Central America was held yesterday at the Atlantic Insurance Building. Additional subscription to the amount of $110 were handed in.

UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT--OCT. 2. Before Judge Be??. The case of The United States vs. Joseph Santos, Vincent Beiro and C. M. De Cunba, who were indicted for being engaged in titling out the brig Merchant for a slaving voyage, was called up this morning, having been adjourned until this morning on account of the absence of Santos, without whose presence the District.

On Thursday evening the debate, on the proposed amendment in the Third Article, was resumed. Addresses in support of the change, and adverse to its adoption, were delivered by Hon. Luther Bradish , Dr. Higbee, Dr. Height, Mr. Leonard, Dr. Tyng, Mr. Hudson, Mr. Weaver, Mr. Halsey, and others, but no definite action was taken, the subject being left open for discussion the following day.

MEETING OF THE EXCISE COMMISSIONERS.--The Commissioners met yesterday at 1 P. M. in the Common Pleas Court Room, Part 2. Present: Commissioners HASKETT and HOLMES. The minutes of the last meeting were read and approved. A store-keeper's license (No. 639) was granted to JOHN SAVAGE, No. 299 Fourth-avenue, upon payment of the fee of $30. Commissioner HOLMES offered the following resolution, which was adopted:

The Anglo-Saxon race and civil liberty in modern times, owe more to prominent and strongly-marked individuality of character, than to any other incidents in their growth and history. We are what we are mainly because, from the battle of Hastings to the battle of Bunker's Hill, our ancestors were careful to make the individual man something of vastly more importance than the State.

NEW-YORK RACES.--FASHION COUSE, L.I.--Running.--Friday, Oct, 2.--Proprietor's Purse, $600, three-mile heats, Entries: JAS. TALLY enters ch, h. Shocco, 4 years old, by Tally-ho; dam, Belsy White. P.C. BUSH enters ch. f. Parachute, 4 years old, by Yorkshire; dam, Heraldries, by Herald. The attendance upon the course was slim, those who were present predicting a "crack" race. on account of the reputation of the Bags.

ULLMANN--JENKS--In this City, on Wednesday, Sept. 30. at Grace Church, by Rev, R.G. Dickson, DANIEL ULLMANN, of Racine, Wis., to MARY E. JENKS, of this City. POMEROY--LEONARD--At Rocky and Lake. on Thursday, Oct. 1, by Rev. Mr. crane, JOHN B. POMEROY, of this City, to AUGUSTA, eldest daughter of Hon. M.G. Leonard, of the former place.

Mr. CHARLES MATHEWS took his farewell benefit at the Broadway Theatre last evening, prior to his departure for Boston. He appeared in three pieces--as Marplot, in the "Busy Body;" as Charles Beesuing in "Twenty Minutes with a Tiger;" and as Brownsmith in his own farce of "Little Toddlekins." To say that his acting was inimitable is simply to repeat the verdict that an immense and very enthusiastic audience accorded.

I.-THE FINANCIAL CRISIS.--A complete account of the Financial Panic--Its Causes, Progress and Incidents--Condition of the Money Market in New-York--Affairs in Philadelphia--Suspension of the Philadelphia Banks--Effects of the Panic at the East, South West--Carefully condensed for this paper. II.--THE CRYSTAL PALACE FAIR.--The Department of Machinery. III.--KANSAS.--Review of Gov. WALKER'S last proclamation.

A most extraordinary trial--one that may fairly rank among the causes celebres of the day--has just taken place in Cayuga, Canada West. On the night of the 18th of October, 1854, an atrocious murder was perpetrated in Haldimand County under the following circumstances: A gang of five highwaymen, who had previously committed many depredations in the neighborhood, appeared, after dark, at the residence of JOHN H. NELLES, a highly respectable citizen of the County.

The American State Central Committee of Maryland has issued a very long address to the people in regard to the coming election. It is devoted mainly to local questions, especially to events connected with the recent riots in Baltimore, the responsibility for which it charges upon the Democratic party.

FIREMEN GOING TO PHILADELPHIA.--The train which left Jersey City, Yesterday afternoon, over the New-Jersey Railroad, was an unusually heavy one, requiring fifteen cars to accommodate the passengers. Among the passengers were the members of Lady Washington Engine Company, (No. 40,) of New-York, accompanied by Shelton's Band, and Passaic Engine Company, of Patterson,

The most important event of the past fortnight is the doings of the Supreme Government in connection with the right of transit of the Isthmus of Tehuantepec. On the 3d instant the Supreme Government annulled the grant for this transit given on the 5th February, 1853, to Mr. A.G. SLOO.

To-day the Maine State Fair closed its third exhibition by a trotting match for 4200 premium. The conditions of the race were best two in three, free to all horses raised and always owned in Maine. The premium was taken by Lady Burnham, owned by A. BODGE, of Winthrop. Time: 2:45; 2:44; 2:46.

The following letter, from a very reliable and respectable gentleman, will, we trust, cause increased circumspection on the part of those who purchase slaves from traders. It will be remembered that the murder of McMILLAN, in Memphis, by BOLTON, grew out of the exposure of the fact that BOLTON had sold, as a slave for life a negro who was to be free in a few years.

TREATY CONCLUDED WITH THE PAWNEES.--Gen. GEO. W. DENVER, Commissioner of Indian Affairs, came down on the Omaha from Nebraska to Weston, on route for Washington. He reports having made a full and satisfactory treaty with the Pawnees at Table Creek, in the vicinity of Nebraska City, on the 24th of September.

The Superintendent of Police has published an order, which will be found in another column, calling attention to the rule which declares that" no member of the Police Department will be permitted to connect himself, directly or in any way, with a society, club, committee or organization of any kind, the object of which is the political advancement of any party,

An Allentown (Penn.) Dutch Reformed clergyman has married fifteen hundred and sixteen couples since May 1823--thirty-four years. They must increase and multiply in that region. Mr. McCarthy, of the Geographical Society of Paris, has undertaken a journey to Timbuctoo, alone. lie speaks with fluency a number of the African dialects, and Arabic.

MEDICAL BILLS IN THE BCRDELL CASE-The Committee from the Board of Supervisors, having under consideration the bills of the several medical men who rendered professional services during the Burdell inquest, met again on Saturday. We published the bills and what they were for, a few days ago. Professor BARKER and Drs. CHL, J. R. Wood and McTT were present by request.

THE LATE GREAT FIRE AT GRAND RAPIDS. MICHIGAN.-- A very destructive conflagration occurred at Grand Rapids on the 25th ult. The district burned comprises the business houses of Granger Co., boots, shoes and dry goods; Preston, clothing; Shepard Putnam, drugs and medicines; De Camp Eldridge, do.; Ringnette Brother, boots and shoes; Perkins Woodward, do.;

A few days more and we shall be In an election chaos, On all sides there is nothing else thought of or talked of, A few of the Free-State leaders and agitators are endeavoring to represent the prospects of the party as exceedingly disheartening.

The long-expected steamship Star of the West arrived at this port yesterday from Aspinwall. Her detention is attributed to the long passage of the California on the Pacific side: We obtain from our San Francisco exchanges a list of the treasure brought down on the previous trip, and lost in the ill-fated steamship Central America,

A year ago this time they were turning out some 300 a day newly-naturalized citizens at the. Naturalization-Office in the City Hall, Now they are making but about 15 a day, notwLthstanding the near approach of election. To get out one's first papers there is a charge of a quarter: for the second they charge fifty cents.

WESTCHESTER COUNTY FAIR.-The Thirteenth Annual Fair of the " Society of Agriculture and Hortilculture of Westchester County," was held this year at Sing Sing and closed on Thursday, having been opened on Tuesday the 11th. The grounds selected for the occasion comprised a portion of the "State Farm," and afforded an exceedingly fine scenat view, particularly of the Hudson River.

The United States Mail steamship Star of the West, ALFRED G. GRAY, Esq., commanding, arrived this port yesterday morning, from Aspinwall. The Star of the West left Aspinwall, Sept. 24, having been detained until that time, awaiting the arrival of the mails and treasure, per steamer California, from San Francisco, Sept. 5.

The murderers of the Captain and three other persons on board the brig Albion Cooper have been sent to Portland, Me., by the American Consul at Hayana. They confess the crime, and narrate all the details with great coolness. During the passage from Havana the prisoners were separated from each other, but all conversed freely with the second male of the vessel upon the subject of the murders,

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--To-night the comic open of the "Elixir of Love" (which the Doctor Dulcaman?? of the occasion pronounces to be Larger-Bier) will b?? repeated for the second and last time. Altogether this opera was one of the most agreeable production?? of the season, and afforded much pleasure to the public and the critics. In it, Mile. FREZZOLINI and Signor LAROCETTA shine to best advantage. .

The news published to-day from California is, in one respect, by far the most important which has reached us from that quarter in many months. In the late election the people have decided by an overwhelming majority to pay the State Debt, which had been previously declared illegal by a decision of the Supreme Court.

LIVERPOOL COTTON MARKET. The Liverpool COTTON Market was unchanged, closing on Tuesday quiet, but steady. The sales of the three days were 14,000 bales, nearly all to the trade. LIVERPOOL BREADSTUFFS MARKET. FLOUR was generally quoted steady, though some authorities say 6d. lower. WHEAT had Declined 3d.

Caution to the Ladies of Brooklyn. To the Editor of the New-York Times: A girl of prepossessing appearance is going about imposing upon the ladies of Brooklyn. Her plan is to ascertain from the servant, or otherwise, the name of some acquaintance of the lady of the house, and on seeing her represent that she has been sent by the friend whose name she has obtained,

From the Boston Courier of Yesterday. The Pemberlon Mills, at Lawrence, are already closing up their work, and discharging their help. A Lawrence paper says that there have been rumors upon the street in regard to the stoppage of the Bay State and Atlantic Mills, but there is thus far no indication that such a calamity is to befall the city.

BURTON'S THEATRY--There was an common house here last night to witness Miss ?? celebrated impersonation of Meg Merries, in "Gay Mannering." It is unquestionably one of the most powerful pieces of melo-dramatic acting on the stage, a night mare creation which live-for years and years in the brond daylight of memory.

When Commodore VANDERBILT steamed into Southampton water three or four years ago, in his yacht, the North Star, having on board his numerous family, with a retinue of servants, a private chaplain, historiographer, and so forth, John Bull opened his eyes with amazement at the magnificence and grandeur of the private American Citizen, of whom he had never heard before.

The scene of it. a tenant house belonging to Captain A. SHANELINE, and occupied by a man named THOMAS KILBY, his wife MARY KILBY, and their three young children.

Alfred-Ashfield, are respectfully invited to attend his funeral from the residence of his father. No. 107 West 36th-st., this day, (Tuesday,) at 2 o'clock P. M.

From the Boston Post of yesterday. Although there were a number of failures on Saturday, we suspect the mercantile public in general got through the day much better than they anticipated. Almost all regular bank customers had their share of the 10 ?? cent. discount, and were easily lifted over the heaviest pay day of the month.

The mail from all points. as late as due, is to hand, but it brings no news of importance. Four companies of the 4th Artillery had arrived as New-Orleans from Florida. The export duties on tobacco at Vera Cruzba been repealed.

In my recent address to the people of Tennessee, giving the secret history of Puebla negotiations with the relations I bore to the Government, and to the "Trist Mission," and the part I performed in defeating those negotiations, I was careful to avoid everything of a personal or party character.

The Montreal Steamship Company's screw steamer Anglo-Saxon, from Liverpool on the 23d ?? has passed this point on her way to Quebec, where she will arrive this afternoon. A brief dispatch only has been landed here, and the balance of the news will be transmitted from Quebec. The European advices generally by this arrival are unimportant.

The Quindaro Chindouan of the 1st says that nearly a thousand Missourians have entered Kansas, between Quindaro and Weston, to settle there; but well-informed parties in Missouri say that it is for political purposes. Evidence of concerted action along the whole border is becoming apparent, but violence is not apprehended.

The City was startled yesterday by the apparition of three more men rescued from the steamer Central America. They came looking almost like skeletons, gaunt, sick, exhausted. They were found drifting in one of the steamer's life-boats, some 478 miles Northeast of the spot where the Central America went down, and nine days after that sad affair the Brig Mary picked them up, on her voyage from Cardenas (Cuba) to Cork, Ireland.

LOSS OF THE BRITISH BARK CLIO.--The bark clio, Captain HAROUS, sailed from Quebec on the 30th of August, with a cargo of timber bound to Newcastle. They experienced very heavy weather, and from the 7th to the 15th of September had a continuation of galcs. On the 13th, while scudding before the wind, the vessel was boarded by a heavy sea, which filled the decks.

A communication was received from the Central Park Commissioners announcing that, although they were in possession up till the 29th September, of some of the avails of the stock issued under an ordinance of the Board of Aldermen, (and which, on the 25th of August was approved by the Mayor,) yet that extensive operations had been instituted and carried on at the Park for the last six weeks.

The United States Vs. Charles Landser and Otto Schlormer.--An indictment for aiding in passing false invoices.

The London (Can.) Free Press says: "The Bank of British North America appeared in the Division Court yesterday. In the course of business Mr. HCOH ROSE, of Dundas-street, took a bill for $2 issued by the above-named Bank. In the course of its progress through the world it had lost the lower side on which the signature should appear.

We have Yucatan dates to September 15. The revolution against Governor PANTATEON BARRERA had not yet been put down and a skirmish between the parties was daily expected. The Campache rebels kept up the semblance of a Government, and had regularly organized an army under Major-Genera GNACIO ZAVA LLE.

A WANT IN OUR PUBLIC EXHIBITIONS.---Public exhibitions are just now greatly in vogue. The season is propitious for them, the yield of the crops is plentiful, and abundant facilities are afforded for enriching the catalogues of the Agricultural Societies. So the Agricultural Shows spring up in all directions, and attract great crowds of gazers,

We learn that the Utica Steam Cotton Mills have suspended operation until the 1st of November. This throws 330 operatives out of employment. The Mannanuck Mills, in Pennsylvania, have stopped.--throwing 2,00 workmen out of employment. In Lynn, Mass., a very large number of person employed in the shoe business have been discharged.

At the Church of the Puritans, on Sunday evening, Rev. Dr. CHERVER delivered a sermon, the announcement of which, by advertisement, caused the building to be thronged to overflowing. The subject was--The Hand of God seen in the Shipwreck and the Financial Crisis. Attorney-General BLACK, in a recent decision, says that a person who claims land in California under a grant from Mexico, is entitled to have a patent for H issued out of the General Land Office, whenever he shows that his claim has been finally confirmed by the Commissioner of the District Court, or by the Supreme Court, if he, at the same time, accompanied that proof with a survey certified and approved by the Surveyor-General.

CANAL EXTENSION.--On the north or Seats branch of the Capitol extension the interior work and decorations, together with the connection with the centre building, are advancing steadlly, but the main force is now employed on the House of Representatives, or southern wing. We find the stairway to the Senate Chamber More than half-done,

PARALYSIS OF EXCHANG.--A City merchant, to illustrate the character of the prevailing difficulties, mentioned yesterday that he had $10,000 due him in Chicago, which the debtor had on hand and was anxious to pay,--but he found it impossible to buy a bill of exchange on New-York ! If he were to send the money in bills by Express, it would only be received here at a ruinous discount.

THE GANSEVOORT PROPERTY.--The Committee by Markets of the Board of Councilmen met in the City Hall, on Monday afternoon. Mr. ROOSEVELT appeared and delivered and elaborate opinion and argument to the effect that the Gansevoort property is legitimately the property of the city, and therefore cannot be bought by the city to be used for the purposes of a market. The sale of 1852 he declared to be illegal.

To the Editor of the New-York Times : The morning papers are incorrect in stating that the Abolitionist Convention, at Syracuse, tills week, made a nomination of State officers, if they mean the Convention of Radical Abolitionists. I learn that the Old Liberty Party met at Syracuse the same or the next day, and prepared a ticket, on which my name stands for the office of Comptroller.

In almost every department of industry there has been a curtailment of operations within the last few weeks, attended, generally, by the discharge of many persons employed upon them.

Mr. WILLIAM RICHARDSON, Chairman of the State Temperance Committee, called the Convention to order in the first Methodist Church at 12 o'clock this morning, and named C. C. LEIGH, of New-York, temporary Chairman; Rev. E. W. JACKSON, Secretary of the State Society, was named Secretary.

CORONER'S INQUESTS.--Coroner GAMBLE held an inquest yesterday at the Central Park Station-house, upon the body of CHESTER BIBIJE, a cigar peddler, who, on Sunday night fell into an excavation on the Eighth-avenue, near Seventy-eighth-street, and was killed. He was charged with embezzlement, and was committed to the Tombs to avoid his trial.

LATER FROM FLORIDA.--We have dates front Tampa to the 12th inst. An unfortunate affray transpired at Fort Myers on the 6th inst. It appears there was a misunderstanding between a few regular soldiers and volunteers, which led to blows. During the senffie which ensued, Sergeant THOMAS P. THE BANKS.--Some of our correspondents, it will be seen, urge upon our City banks the duty of receiving, the notes of all country banks, acting under the general banking law. at par for a limited time-say for three or six mouths. It is understood that Mr. SLIDELL will not go to Paris. His family are known to greatly desire it, and there is surely no family that could more creditably represent us at any Court; but Mr. SLIDELL holds a position in the American Senate and before the country which he will not abandon through any temptation.

The Academy of Music crowded last evening, in response to a call from the Young Men's Democratic Union Club, to meet and indorse the nominations made by the Democratic State Convention. The private boxes were filled with ladies, and the rear of the stage was lined with men more or less noted in the ranks and as leaders of the Democratic party.

THE GATHERING OF THE CHESS-PLAYERS.--A National Chess Congress--the first of the kind held in the United States--opened yesterday morning at Descombes' Rooms in Broadway. The rooms are admirably fitted for the purpose, and are furnished with some twenty sets of tables, boards and chess-men. The attendance of players yesterday was fair, though not so large us it is expected to be before the week is out.

The financial crisis In Virgilia is severely fell, though as yet there are few if ally failures of much consequence. The fact that the State is peculiarly agricultural, and, as a consequence, less susceptible of injury from a crisis like the present, alone saved her people from ruin. She has suffered in the ratio of her commercial operations as much, perhaps, as any other community;

SHIPBUILDING IN MAINE--At Damariscotra there are two ships on the stocks. Messrs. J. J. DAY Co., are building one of 1,2000 tons for parties in this City. MEICALY, NORRIS CO., have also one of 800 tons, which they are building for their own account. A clipper schooner of 80 tons, is being built for a packet between Damariscotta and Boston.

The trade and commerce of this City have been suddenly deprived of about eighteen mlllions of what is termed discount accommodation at bank. The average curtailment for six weeks has been hard upon three millions a week. Private money lenders have withdrawn from active use from five to seven miliions more.

Pearl-muscles have been discovered in the Dano Reiver, in Texas, One gentleman, living near Fort Marlon, has employed ten men to dig for these muscles, and has obtained ten thousand pearls, one of the size of a rific-ball. Specimens have boon sent to New-Xork and New-Orleans, to ascertain their real value.

When an opera company is at the point of dissolution, there is sure to be a performance of "Don Giovannl," by way of final kick--to show perhaps that it dies in the true faith. This time the performance, for a wonder, is not postponed to the last night ; we have the kick in advance, and it will be repeated for the last mortal time on Friday.

A POPULAR, BUT A DANGEROUS FALLACY.--There is a good deal of mischief done in the commercial world by the popular belief that all values may be converted into specie ; and it is doubtless owing to this strange hallucination that in times like the present people rush madly to the banks to get their notes changed into gold.

Sweet are the uses of adversity, and it is among the consolations to be derived from such seasons of commercial pressure as the country is now suffering from, that we shall be the wiser for them after they are over, and less likely to suffer from them again. There is a good deal of idle talk about the commercial revulsions of 1817, 1827, 1837

The Royal Mail Steamship Niagara arrived here at o'clock this morning. She left Liverpool at 1 P. M. on the 26th ult.; her dates consequently are three days later than those already received. The steamer North American arrived out at noon on the 23d ult.

The American and Republican Conventions to nominate County Officers in Kings County, were held in Flatbush last evening, the Americans at STELENWORTH's HOTEL, the Republic arts at Mrs. SCHOONMAKER'S, a short walk from each other distant. The Americans organized by electing CHARLES R. ATWATER, Chairman, and R. T. DOUGLASS and GERRARD M. STEVENS, Secretaries.

FIRE IN WORTH-STREET.--AT 1 1/2 yesterday morning, a fire broke out in the steam saw and planing mill of BROOK MILLER. NO. 123 and 127 Worth street . Fortunately the fire was discovered before it had made much headway, and was specially extinguished. The first and second floors only were occupied by BROOK MILLER. Their loss was about $500 and is covered by insurance.
