JOHNSON, of the Norwegian bark Ellen, who acted so humane a part in the rescue of the passengers of the Central America, is receiving the reward of well-doing in the shape of various gratifying testimonials from the Government, as well as from Individuals, who seem determined that a really noble act shall not fail

Daily, now, tho effect of the hard times are felt In the large manufacturing establishments--on hundreds of mechanics, "shop girls," sewing women and day laborers, who did not feel them the day before. We continue, to-day, our review of those departments of labor where large numbers of men and women are employed in prosperous times.

By a late arrival in this City of parties direct from Santa Fe, we have dates from that place to the 1st September, with late and interesting intelligence from the Plains. The difficulties with the Indians on the Plains have been aggravated by the ill-success of Colonel SUMNER'S late conflict with them.

The brig Jerome Knight, Capt. HIRAM PERKINS, was wrecked on the 23d ult. off the coast of North Carolina. The vessel belongs to Messrs. WHITON, BROWN WHEELRIGHT, in Boston, and had left Wilmington, N.C., loaded with lumber for Marseilles and a market. She was a staunch-built vessel, only a year and a half old, and already rode out two or three violent gales.

There were several Conventions hold at Concord, in Middlesex County, on the 1st instant. The Republican Convention of the Fifth Councilor District nominated Mr. W. J. EAMES, of Malden, for Councilor. lie used to be a leading Whig. The American Convention nominated Mr. J. P. PEABODY for the same place. He was formerly a prominent Democrat at Lowell, wher he now re. sides.

Senor YRISSARI had an interview with the President to-day in relation to his reception as Minister of Nicaragua. The Navy Department has recently sent out instructions to the commanders of several vessels of the home squadron with regard to intercepting armed parties designing to invade Mexico, Nicaragua and Costa Rica.

STEAMER KNICKERROCKER AFLOAT.--Five steam pumps were set in motion yesterday afternoon, on this fine vessel, and in less than an hour-and-a-half she floated. They were kept in motion five hours, when canvas was drawn under the vessel, which nearly stopped the leak. As soon as she floated the deck settled back to nearly its original position, and the several joints made in the hog fame are now nearly closed.

A gentleman who left Leavenworth, Kansas, on Monday at noon, says that the election was progressing very slowly there. The Free-State men had complete possession over the polls, and were casting all the votes. If all the votes were not polled by Monday the election would be continued until Tuesday.

THE POLICE COMMISSIONERS--The following paragraph appears in the Courier and Enquirer: "The Police Commissioners held no meeting yesterday--the Republican members, for obvious reasons, being unwilling to meet, in the absence of Gen.?? from the City. An adjournment was made until Friday, but it is not probable that a meeting will take place until next week."

The Committee on Depositories and Finance, of the American Sunday-School Union, have published a "Brief Statement" in regard to the defalcation of M FREDERICK W. PORTER, their late Corresponding Secretary.

The Independent, commenting on the defalcation of the Corresponding Secretary of the Sunday School Union at Philadelphia, says their" Card impeaches the wisdom and fidelity of the managers no less than the Integrity of the Corresponding Secretary's, since it shows that the secretary was allowed to give notes for the Union in his official character without the formal authorization of tile Board, und without any restraint whatever,"

About 4 o'clock this morning a violent shock of an earthquake was felt here. Seven minutes later another shock, less severe, was felt. They made the most substantial buildings tremble, and overturned small articles in dwellings. The shocks were also felt at Springfield. IIl.

Hon Louis McLANE died yesterday at his residence in this city, in the 72d year of his age. He was the son of ALLIN McLANE, a distinguished officer in the revolutionary war and was born in the village of Smyrna, Kent County, De., on the 28th of May, 1784.

We are still without any knowledge of the results of the election in Kansas. Our dispatches are so contradictory that it is impossible to arrive at any conclusion. Returning from Baden Baden to Paris by the Strasbourg Railway, we stopped at the Camp of Chalons, the present residence of the Emperor of France. The camp is fifteen miles from Chalons, and seventeen from Rheims, in the heart of the Champagne country.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: MR. EDITOR: I have read in your paper of to-day the report of the proceedings of the State Temperance Convention at Syracuse with mingled emotions of surprise and sorrow. Only thirty-five persons in attendance at a State Temperance Convention, when all present were invited to take part in the proceedings! Where were the people of Syracuse? There more than thirty. five hundred temperance voters in that city.

The Royal Mail steamship Niagara, from Liver-pool via Halifax, was telegraphed below at eight o'clock this evening, but. in consequence of the lowness of the tide, has not yet reached her dock. She will, however, probably, come up by midnight, and her mails for the South will be forwarded to New-York by the land train via New Haven, to-morrow morning, where they will be due at 5 P.M.

THE FIREMEN'S PROCESSION--FIGHT WITH PISTOLS IS GRAND-STREET.--During the Firemen's parade or Wednesday night, on the occasion of the reception of the Lady Washington Engine Company No. 40 on its return from Philadelphia, an interruption occurred at 12 1/2 A. M. at the corner of Grand and Elizabeth streets, in the course of which several pistols were fired and one man came near being fatally shot and several slightly injured.

STOWAWAYS ON THE CALIFORNIA STEAMERS.-- A great annoyance to the officers of the California steamers is the practice of loafers stowing themselves away on board in some out-of-the-way hole or corner of the ship for the purpose of evading the vigilance of the officer whose duty it is to look up the tickets, and so going scolfree to the Isthmus.

While a dance was going on inside the shoue, a party of three men created a disturbance outside, and one of them fired a billet of wood through the window at the party inside, one of whom came out to remonstrate when he was set upon by the trio and beaten until be became Insensible

In these golden Autumn days we are now enjoying, while tile air is so full of genial sunshine, and tile heavens bend over us so soft and tenderly, we must not forget that they are but a brief prelude to tile rigors of Winter, and that they will very soon be succeeded by freezing blasts and pitiless storms.

SUICIDA.--A butcher named GEORGE MEE, living in South Fourth-street, Jersey-City, committed suicide on Wednesday by taking laudanum. He put the poison into a glass of water and then, stepping into an adjoining room where his wife and (a lady visitor were sitting, tipped the glass to them, proposed their health and swallowed the dose without exciting their suspicions as to his Intentions.

PASSING COUNTERFEIT MONEY.--A well-dressed man, on Wednesday afternoon, entered the store of Mr. Purdy, in Broadway, near Broome-street; after purchasing a few articles, offered in payment a $10 bill on the Bank of Rondout, New-York. The cashier was a little doubtful as to the genuineness of the bill, and sent it to a broker to ascertain its character.

Hon. JAMES WADEWORTH, of Buffalo, has been nominated by the democrats of the Thirty-first District for reelection to the Senate. The Republicans of the Eighth Judicial District have nominated NOAH DAVIS and MARTIN GROVER for the Supreme Court.

POLITICS AND THE PANIC--It is not easy to see how the present financial difficulties can be made an element of strength by either of the existing political parties at the coming election. In spite of the effort to do so, there is too much common sense among the masses to allow of their being humbugged by any such nonsense.

REPORT OF COMMODORE PAULDING TO THE NAVY DEPARTMENT. FLAG-SHIP WABASH, OFF ASPINWALL, Sept, 18, 1857. SIR: On the 26th of August, under the orders of the department of June 1st, I organized a party and set out on a reconnoisance of the Isthmus between Aspinwall and Panama, with reference to the "practicability of constructing an inter-oceanic canal across the Isthmus of Darien" at this point.

A very interesting case of alleged robbery came before Recorder SMITH, at his private office, yesterday. On Wednesday evening complaint was made to officer DICKSON, of the Sixth Precinct, in command of that Station-house, that a German, or rather Hungarian Jew, named NATHAN LEVINS, who had been but two weeks in this country, had been robbed of C940 in Bank of England notes.

The Postmaster-General has appointed six agent at an annual salary of $1,000 each, for the through express mail from Baltimore to Clucinnati,

PUBLIC OMNIBUSES.--The Board of Aldermen has adopted a resolution directing omnibuses to be driven at a uniform speed. While our authorities have this matter in hand, they would do well to take some steps in regard to the overerweding of public vehicles of all kinds.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In the TIMES of Thursday, in the notice of the WEBSTER VS. SPENCER slander suit, I am named as the plaintiff's attorney. The fact is the reverse, I appeared for the defendant, SPENCER. Your statement of the case placed me in an embarrassing position,

Mr. CHOIWRLL had been there, but had gone out of the room. As his return was necessary to a quorum, he was sent for; but for some time could not be found. Finally, however, he was discovered in a private room up stairs,

" Don Giovanni" was played last night for the second time, and attracted a large house. There was a change in the cast. Owing to the indisposition of Mme STRAKOSCH, Mme. SIEDENBURG filled the role of Donna Ohvia, and filled it very creditably. In addition to the attraction of the opera, Mr. VIECXTEMPS layed a concerto on the violin in his happiest and most admirable vein.

MESSRS. EDITORS : My name has been mentioned in the newspapers in connection with the approaching election of United States Senator, and I have my-self received many communications on the subject. It is, perhaps, proper that I should make public my determination not to b a candidate.

A NEW SCHOOL-HOUSE INAUGURATED. ---The President of the Board of Education, A. H. GREEN, Esq., City Superintendent RANPALL, and his assistants, with Commissioner SLOTE and his associate School officers of the Tenth Ward, inaugurated yesterday, with public ceremonies, the splendid new School edifice lately erected on Chrystie-street, in the Tenth Ward.

There is a good deal of melancholy mirth apparent in the streets to-day, tough as the times are, and as universally as they cramp us. And why shouldn't there be? In times of great opidemics, after people get a little used to it they have their grim jokes and are jolly in spite of themselves.

SURROGATES COURT. Before A. W. Bradford. The mater of the estate of the cook of the Central America came before the surrogate yesterday morning, on the application of Susan his wife, for letters of administration. She states that she was married to him in San Francisco, and was on board the Central America with him when she was wrecked. She slight hopes that her husband might have been saved by some vessel.

SCHOONER SUNK AND LIFE LOST. Mr. ELLWOOD WALTER has received the following dispatch: HONTON, Friday, Oct, 9. The steamship Niagura (Br.) at 8 o'clock last evening, when entering this harbor, and while of ?? Light, struck the schooner Harrict Maria, from Reston bound for New-Orleans, with an assorted cargo and is passengers.

HORRIBLE TRAGEDY IN ARKANSAS.--We learn from a creditable source that, on last Monday night, the 14th last., a widow lady, Mrs. HILL, and a negro woman were murdered near Herlin, Arkansas, by two negro men. After perpetrating the horrible deed, the bodies of the poor unfortunate victims were thrown into the house by the murderers and miserable wretches, which was set on fire and burned to the ground.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I noticed, in your issues of the 2d inst., a communication headed "Patent Wrong," and signed "Common Sense," and came to the conclusion that the writer did not display much of the latter in the article. Will the gentleman please to consider that the members of each Target Company occupy our streets but for a moments in one locality, once in a year,

THE LIQUOR LAW.--We sec by the Albany Argus of the 6th inst., that Judge HARRIS and Judge WRIGHT have decided that it is not an indictable offence to sell liquor on Sunday, unless the party so indicted is licensed as an innkeeper.

SANFORD.--In this City, on Thursday, Oct. 8, after ?? long and painful Illness, MARIA IL., second daughter of Harriet and the late Capt. menemon Sanford, aged 25 years, 2 months and 6 days. Her relatives and friends, and those of the family, are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, from the residence of her mother, No. 305 East Broadway, on Monday, Oct. 12, at 1 o'clock P.M. lock P.M.

To the Editor of the New-York Times; SIR: I feel obliged to you for directing your reader's attention to the fresh edition of DYMOCKER'S unhappy history; but I must beg to disclaim the honor which you have done me in connecting my name with the British Government.

A RELIC FROM DELHI.--We had the privilege the other day of examining a very curious relic from Delhi--that city of the Great Mogul which now fills so large a space in the mind of the civilized world. It was the very last thing that we should have expected from the City of Mosques and Indian splendors.

General NYE has returned to the City and to the Board of Police Commissioners. We learn the fact from a note which he has addressed to us, and which will be found in another column of the TIMES. Gen. NYE complains that we have done him injustice, in alleging that he was actively connected with a political party,

A REFUGE FOR THE ENGLISH ARISTOCRACY. We notice in some of the English papers serious forebodings that the aristocracy is in danger of physical deterioration, from the lack of a proper field of healthful and manly exercise during the parliamentary recess. The moors are losing their attractions, game is rapidly disappearing from the hills of Scotland,

To the Editor of the New-York Times: It is no longer of any use to disguise the fact that a time use coming, in which Labor will be worse crushed to the wall than at any previous period within the recollection of most men. Capital has long ago felt blows of sickening power and violence, and, in too many instances, fallen beneath the.

Our files of London papers by this arrival, extending from the 23d to the 26th of September inclusive, contain little additional intelligence. BLOOD AND WHAT BECOMES OF IT.--Anthitheses are not always favorable to truth, but Mr.(we beg his pardon) Lord MACAULAY'S famous antithetical glorification of British society is an exception to the rule. It is indeed the strength of England that her" Aristocracy is the most Democratic, and her Democracy the most aristocratic," in Europe.

Last night I saw the Summer rise And leave the fields, where, all the day, She, moving 'mid the reapers, sang A cheerful harvest roundelay; Or where she sat all night awake, Lest foes should come her weath to take.

AN EDITOR CHARGED WITH ENCOURAGING GAMBLING.--Mr. Nathaniel R. Stimson, Editor of the New-York Day Book, was arrested on Saturday morning, charged with encouraging gambling in his paper. Mr. A. Oakey Hall, Distriet-Attorney, made the affidavit upon which the warrant of arrest was issued.

GOLDEN WEATHER-It is no small consolation that, in this time of gloom and panic among the banks and merchant, we are blessed with the most delicious weather. The days are warm and golden, and the nights calm and bracing.

SAD ACCIDENT NEAR BOSTON LIGHT--ONE MAN DROWNED.--LAST evening, about 8 o'clock, as the steamer Niagara was entering Boston harbor, she came in collision with the Orleans packet-schooner Henristla Maria, Capt. SAML. SMITH, from Boston, bound home, sinking her in a very few minutes.

Mr. TRACY, under the auspices of the New-York Children's Aid Society, has, if we are rightly informed, brought into this State, where they have been supplied with comfortable homes, over three hundred houseless and extremely poor children and youths of New-York City.

POLITICAL MATTERS IN KINGS COUNTY.--The different Assembly Conventions of the American and Republican parties, were held on Saturday evening last. The Conventions adjourned without making any nominations, not being able to agree upon the candidates. Arrangements will probably be made the present week so that both parties will unite on Assemblymen.

I have never heard the question discussed whether a ship at sea, aleak, with air tight decks and sides, could sink. The decks and sides of vessels are made air-tight for the protection of the freight, as are also some of the hatches.

The last ray of hope has been dispelled by the late arrival of news from India, and we must now record, with feelings of the profoundest sorrow, that there is every reason to believe the four missionary families of the Presbyterian Board at Futtehgurh have perished in the massacre.

An affray took place last night in Allen's drinking saloon, at the corner of Court and Stoddart streets, between two sporting men ?? THOMAS MEAD and JERFMIAH AGIS. MEAD shol AGIN dead. It is said to have been self-defence. MEAD was taken before the Police Court this morning, and charged with the murder of JEREMIAH AGIN.

The missionary service held last evening in Dr. POTTS' Church, corner of University-place and Tenthstreet, was attended by one of tile largest and most intelligent congregations which the missionary cause has anywhere convoked.

The following is the Weekly Report of Deaths in the city and County of New-York, from the 3rd day of October to the 10th day of October, 1857: Men, 77; Women, 102; Boys 158; Girls, 121: Total, 458,* Adults, 170; Children, 279; Males, 235; Females, 223; Colored Persons, 6.

DEATH OF A DUELIST.--Kentucky papers announce the death HARROD HOLEMAN, for many years the publisher of a newspaper in Frankfort, and public printer of the State, and connected with the most stirring political events of the State in former days. He once fought a bloody and fatal duel, and was himself a cripple for life from it. This duel took place five-and-thirty years ago. It grew out of a militia training.

The Southern mail from all points as late as due has been received. The Tallahasse Sentinel states that Governor PERRY was inaugurated there on the 5th inst. The inangural was short and contained pledges of official in fluence for the advancement of the cause of education, and the completion of railroads inaugurated by the State.

THE ERA OF SHINPLASTER.--Ever since the repudiation of the old Continental currency the people of this country have had a very natural disgust for what is called shinplaster money. and the very mention of a suspension of specie payments by the Banks conjures up visions of the ?? little paper abominations which, in such times, are made to do duty for good and silver.

An esteemed friend in the Interior of the State has called upon me to declare publicly, whether, if elected to the Senate of the United States, I would serve. The terms of this call are so kind and complimentary, that delicacy forbids my being instrumental in making it public.

We are happy to be able to state that our Board of Police Commissioners has resumed active operations. Its members are all in town.

General JAMES HAMILTON has consented to accept a seat in the United States Senate, to serve out the unexpired term of the late Judge BUTLRI. We are glad of this, and trust the Legislature will elect him to that position, for he is a man of brilliant talents, and will confer honor and dignity upon that high position.

The time is inauspicious for resuming the duties of a regular correspondent at this point, for the reason that financial embarrassments absorb everything else here at present, and effect a complete stagnation in the news market, And so it will probably remain until the meeting of Congress, I will endeavor, how.

Tile women of America have of late been paying the penalty of their position. From the extreme of obsequious gallantry in regard to them, we are passing to tile opposite excess of vituperative injustice. We are treating them, in fact, very much as the African savage treats his Fetish.

Mr. BENTON is generally believed to be convalescent, but this is an error. A severe paroxylsm is over ; his physicians have pronounced him better, and his family are cheered ; but he knows that he holds but a slender lease of life, and he has friends who divine this conviction, though he does not express it.

COAST SURVEY.--From the printed directions in regard to the operations of the Coast Survey for the years 1857 and 1858, it appears that extensive preparations have been made for the continuance of the great work. This includes primary and main triangulations and astronomical and magnetic observations and reconnaissances.

FIRE IN PRINCE-STREET.-At If A. M. on Saturday a fire broke out in the grocery store of KARL KUHLMAN, No. 60 Prince-street. The fire occurred in the back basement and was caused by carelessly having ashes in a wood chopping bowl. The damage was trifling, and fully covered by insurance in the Greenwich Insurance Company.

How will they manage with their depositors, and what are the people to do for a currency? Again: what is to be the ordinary money standard of trade and exchange in such case?

I am growing incredulous about this stereotyped phrase of "everybody out of town;" I think it is a fact manufactured by the pens of our brother chronigueurs to get an excuse to go themselves to the country, "to follow the news up," as they say.

THE ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--The first season of opera at this house come to a close on Saturday night, and it has, we believe, been eminently successful. In a couple of weeks another series of performances will be given. Last evening (Sunday) there was another sacred concert, and as on the first occasion, as fire and fashionable attendance.

We find the following recorded in the Ithaca Journal of the 7th instant: A boy whose father, Jos NORTHRUP, and his mother died some years since, has been sick for six or seven months. He lies perfectly helpless, and his case altogether is a remarkable one. Ills limbs are swollen remarkably, and on his legs are several sores.

In wall-street and among the merchants, the pressure on Saturday brought down a number of prominent firms, and drove to protest two of the leading Railways--the New-York and Erie and Illinois Central.

From a gentleman just arrived from Kansas, it has been learned that Jefferson County is largely Republican, and Calhoun County doubtful. The following precincts of Leavenworth County give Republican majorities: Easton, 45: Wyandotle, 50: and Leavenworth 200. Delaware and Kickapoo give Democratic Majorities of 50 and 450.

WETMORE-In this City. on Saturday afternoon. Oct. 10. ELIZABETH R. PITCHER, wife of Theodore R. Wetmore. aged 29 years. The relatives and friends of the family are invited to attend her funeral from the residence of her father-in-law, A. R. Wetmore. No. 19 Washington-square. on Tuesday afternoon at 3 1/2 o'clock, without further invitation. Her remains will be taken to Albany for interment.

Saturday was a blue day. A great many workmen, mechanics and clerks, as they got their week's wages, were discharged. Such men do not carry a very cheerful light to their homes, and there were consultations over economies yet to be practiced in thousands of homes where it is a pittance that the most rigid economy can save.

On the morning of yesterday, at twenty minutes past 4 o, clock, nearly the whole population of this city and region were starlled from repose by the roar and commotion of a violent earthquake. The first concussion about midnight.

AN OMISSION WORTH NOTING.--The London Saturday Review, noticing a history of the Press, by a French writer, whose information concerning the American Press seems to be at least ten years behind the times, thus notes one of its shortcomings: "It is one of the greatest omissions in M. CLARIGNY'S volumes, that he takes no notice of the NEW-YORK TIMES, the newest, the ablest and the most respectable of the journals of America."

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The word "defaleation" has become a very common word in these last days, and carries with it, to the minds of most readers, the idea of intentional fraud, may, a high degree of rascality. It is, then, just for our papers, religious as well as political, to print as a heading to their articles, in bold capitals, "Defaleation in the American Sunday School Union."

The news from India yesterday, received by the Atlantic, although somewhat confused by conflicting details, yet on the whole defines with tolerable precision the relative positions of the English forces and of the mutineers, at the date of the latest telegraphic intelligence from the East.

EFFECTS OF THE "PRESSURE" ON POLITICS.--It is hardly time yet for the full fury of the political campaign to burst upon the public bat the indications are at present that the coming election will be one of the most came and spiritless that has ever been known in this State. The minds of the people are too much occupied with matters that come more directly home to their bosoms and business.

SMITH.--In this City, on Sunday evening, Oct. 11, at the residence of S. T. Peters, JENNETTE EDGAR, daughter of Lemuel Smith, aged 8 years and 11 months. The friends of the family and of her grandfather, J. H. Stephens, Esq., of Newark, are respectfully invited to attend her funeral on Tuesday, at 2 o'clock, at No. 51 East 22d. St.

OUR CITY POLICE--The Albany Evening Journal expresses the opinion that our present Police Force is quite large enough for all practical purposes. and says: " We do not see that the TIMES, in its arraignment of tile Metropolitan Police, points to any practical evil, any neglect of duty. any violations of law or order, or any want of public necessity for a larger force"

FATAL ACCIDENT.-Mrs. PATRICK NEWMAN, residing at No. 62 Pacific-street. Brooklyn. while holding a child, ten months old, in her arms, yesterday, fell down a flight of stairs head foremost. The child was almost instantly killed, and Mrs. NEWMAN had her shoulder-bone broken. and was otherwise injured. She was taken to the city Hospital.

The Metropolitan Police Commissioners met yesterday afternoon, all the members present, and Gen. NYE in the Chair. Mr. BOWEN brought up the subject of renting a new building. laid over at the last meeting. Mr. CHOLWELL had not yet visited the house corner of Broome and Elm streets; neiiher had eithe rof the Mayors. so the whole subject went back to the Committee with power, as before.

PENNSYLVANIA. A State election takes place in Pennsylvania to-day. Three parties are in the field: Democratic, Republican and Know-Nothing. State elections are scarcely ever very animated the year after a Presidential election; but the present financial pressure occupies the thoughts of most men to the exclusion even of politics. The candidates for Governor in Pennsylvania are WM. F. PECKER (Democratic,) DAVID WILMOT (Republican,) and ISAAC HAZLEHURST

The Board of Supervisors met yesterday afternoon. Supervisor McSPEDON in the Chair. The first matter of interest was the bills for refitting the Essex Market, amounting in all to near $2,000. Supervisor TUCKER opposed the bill on the ground that there had been no authority given for fitting up so extensively. He considered it a reckless expenditure of public money.

If this is so, the whole country has substantial reason for satisfaction.

WHAT WILL. THEY DO WITH IT?--Wall-street, yesterday, presented a remarkable appear ance. The entire street, from Broadway to the Merchants' Exchange, was so densely packed with men that it was almost impossible to worm through the excited mass of humanity, while every bank entrance and doorway were also crowded, and curious spectators of the scene wore perched on the galleries of the Exchange, and gazing down from the windows of the houses.

The election passed off very quietly in this City There were no disturbances, and only a small vote was polled. The few scattering returns in from the interior show nothing definite. Williamsport, Lycoming County, Packer, Democrat, 469 ; Wilmot, 278 ; Hazlehurst, 139.

IMPROVEMENTS IN THE MACHINERY OF BUSINESS.--In making any calculations as to the duration of the financial pressure which the country is now passing through, no reliance can be placed upon the experiences of past commercial revulsions.

A new romantic pantomimic fairy spectacle called " Dorcas," (rather a chilling title in these nipping times,) was produced here last night with complete success. It is a Ravel piece, and plentifully spiced ith tile tricks and transformations for which they are celebrated, and to which have been added some new ones of Interest.

Yesterday was the critical day, and the patient's fever turned. Eighteen City Banks suspended specie payments before 3 o'clock, and after that hour by resolution, all the rest followed in their steps. The run upon two of the Savings Banks was heavy, but they both bore it well.

BROKEN BANKS vs. SPECIE.-The Providence Transcript says: "A gentleman coming to Providence in the cars a few days ago offered to the conductor in payment for his fare a Providence bill. It Was refused. and the laconic reason given, ' We don't take Rhode Island money.' The passenger then produced a $20 gold piece, and the conductor began to make the change in bills.

RUTGERS.--In this City, on Monday, Oct. 12, NICHOLAS G. RUTGERS, in the 37th year of his age. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral on Wednesday, at 4 P. M., from the Dutch Reformed Church, corner of La Fayette-place and 4th-st., without further invitation.

Hon. RICHARD U. SHERMAN, of Utica, has been nominated for the State Senate by the Republican of that District. General J. A. WILLARD, of Lowville, has been nominated by the Republicans of Jefferson and Lewis County District for the State Senate.

DEATH OF GEORGE WASHINGTON PARKE CUSTIS.--It becomes our painful duty to announce the decease of the venerable GEORGE WASHINGTON PARKS CUSTIS, the last of the members of the family of WASHINGTON. Mr. CUSTIS died at Arlington, near this city, after a brief illness, on the morning of the 10th inst., in the 77th year of his age.

From the London Saturday Review. Although it is far from certain that the panic in New-York and the Atlantic American States has been altogether produced by the progress of genuine commercial mistrust, its existence is not to be questioned.

NANTUCKET TELEGRAPH.--The Nantucket people are not unfrequently cut off from all communication with the Continent for a week and ten days at a time during the ice-blockade in Winter. To provide against this unpleasant contingency a telegraphic cable has been laid from the west end of the Island across Musgeget Channel, a distance of seven miles, to connect at Edgartown, Martha's Vineyard, with the telegraph to Boston and New-Bedford.

DARING BURGLARY BY TWO BOYS--SINGULAR ADVENTURE--A during burglary was committed during the forenoon of Sunday, at the store No. 33 Chambers-street, occupied on the ground floor by MORTON, JIWETT BUGBY, hardware merchants, and in the upper in clothing.

A fatal affray lately occurred in the Florida army. Lieut. March and Sergeant Monroe had high words, when Major Dozier interfered. The Sergeant attacked the Major, and Dr. Rogers ran in between them and was also struck. The report of a pistol was heard. and Sergeant Monroe fell dead. It is not known who fired the shot. All parties were put under immediate arrest.

The Nantucket County Agricultural Fair opened to-day. The attendance was large and the exhibition superior to anything before seen on the Island. To-morrow Governor GARDNER, Hon. N. P. BANKS, and other distinguished gentlemen are expected to be present, when a banquet, with speeches and a ball in the evening, will add to the attraction of the exhibition. The Fair reflects great credit upon the Islanders.

A SINGULAR CASE OF VICISSITUDE.--A few months since, the partner of a commercial house in this City, was taken to a lunatic asylum, utterly deranged, as was said, by his unparalleled prosperity in business. During the year previous his firm had cleared $1,300,000. He died in the asylum, and his own estate was valued at $2,500,000. all invested in the concern of which he was a partner.

The British expedition to the Red River region reached the terminus of its journey on the 5th September. The Indians along the route are, with few exceptions, a miserable set. The settlement is described as a succession of numerous small villages and detached houses scattered along both banks of he river about 35 miles.

To the Editor of the New-York Times : SIR : A mid the general despondency in commercial circles, it may be interesting, and perhaps consoling, to know that the agricultural community have this year succeeded in adding to their resources, Month as well as South, a new plant, valuable not only for home uses, but as a future article of large export and commercial value.

FAIR PLAY A JEWEL IN POLITICS.--The Journal of Commerce of yesterday, has the following : "TAXES.--The State tax this year will be one hundred and twenty-five per cent, larger than it was last year. This heavy additional burden is the fruit of Black Republican legislation and government. If, therefore as a City cotemporary suggests, the panic swallows up all thoughts of the election, there will be a decided mistake committed.

THE CHESS CONORESS.-The second week off the Chess Congress, at Descembe's Rooms, shows in. creased interest and a larger attendance of players. The rooms were very cheerful last night, the tables all occupied, and the Grand Tournament continued. The Minor Tournament began on Monday, with eight sets of players, as In tile first one, Play is live.

The reporter of the Hamilton Morning Banner, writing from Merritsville, says that the man now under confinement in that pace on the charge of having murdered constable RITCHIE, has been recognized by Captain LEWIS, of the propeller Victoria, as McHENBY, a sailor under his command in the brig Potwtan, in 1850.

Official information has been received that hundreds of persons have left Leavenworth for the purpose of settling on the lands of the Delaware Indians, whose rights the United States are pledged by treaty to protect. Instructions will be sent to tile Indian Agents in Kansas to enforce e the law. If their efforts fail, the United States troops will be employed to expel the intruders.

We have at last reached the crisis of the financial panic. The City Banks have suspended specie payments,--not by concerted. action and as a measure of relief to the business community, but upon sheer compulsion. They have fought gallantly, not to say obstinately, against this necessity. They pro.

A Texas paper states that a man named William Amterson was hung last week somewhere near the line between Atascorn and Live Oak counties, near where he lived. He was taken from his bed in the night. by some eight or ten persons, leaving behind his wife and two children.

A dreadful scene of crime and debauchery occurred at Yorkville, Canada, a few days since. The Coroner was called to hold an inquest on the bodies of one Edward O'Conner and wife, in a hovel in the town. The man and the woman had been dead for some time, and on further search the body of a newborn child was discovered on a shelf.

THE NICARAGUAN EXPEDITION.--The Government has forwarded instructions to the Federal officers in Texas, requiring them to exercise due diligence to defeat the filllbustering enterprises against Nicaragua, now on foot in that State. They are directed to avail themselves of all legitimate means at their command to enforce the Neutrality Laws.

By the passengers on the Northern Light, which arrived here this morning from St. Paul, we learn of one of the most dreadful steamboat accidents, which ever occurred on the Upper Mississippi--evidently showing a negligent or wanton criminality on the part of the steamboatmen seldon equaled on any river.

SELLING OEF AT A SACRIFICE.--The price of everything is coming down under the panic. All merchants and business men want money, and prefer to sell their goods at a sacrifice rather than fail. A great number of Dry Goods merchants, as our advertising columns show, are following the example of LAMBERT Co., and ARNOUX, the well-known fashionable tailor in Broadway, takes the same step in the clothing line.

Great mischief has been done, beyond a question, since the panic commenced, by the thousand wild and exaggerated stories which have been circulated of the number of failures and suspensions that have taken place among our business men and money institutions. The plain truth is bad enough;

MY DEAR--: Weeks have now passed since I have seen a letter or a newspaper from home. During this time I have been travelling away from news, and I am now famished. On my arrival at Antwerp, I trust to find letters at last.

About a year since, a young lad named SAGE disappeared suddenly from his father's house, near Middletown, Conn. Soon after the disappearance of the lad, one PATRICK NUGENT, residing on a farm belonging to young SAGE'S father, was arrested on suspicion of having foully disposed of the lad; but was acquitted for want of proof.

RETIRE IN TIME.--One of the important lessons taught by the present crisis to business men is to retire In time. Many a man has been laid low by the present difficulties, who might, years ago, have retired from active business with an independent fortune.

Pork, beef, butler and eggs, remain at their former prices in Philadelphia. In groceries decline is encouraging. Sugar can move be purchased for ten cents, which a few weeks since was selling at 15 cents per pound. Molasses has declined almost one-half.

It is not often that the French Press falls upon a subject to which it can deliver itself up without restraint, and with a certainty of commanding at the same time the interest of its readers. The interview of Stuttgardt furnishes the elements for both these results.

From the Cohoes Cataract. As several incorrect statements have been recently published, respecting the influence of the panic on the several manufacturing establishments of this village, we have taken the pains to get the facts, and we hope our contemporaries will correct their statement.

EXCITING SCENE IN THE COURT OF SESSIONS--ESCAPE OF A PRISONER UNDER TRIAL.-Among the charges brought before the Jury in the Court of General Sessions, yesterday, was one against a dashing, intelligent, but shameless young man, named LUCIUS AUGUSTUS MENDIS, recent a bookeeper with Messrs, MARKS POZNANSKI, in William-street, for uttering five forged checks, for $550 each, on the Island City, and Tradesmen's Banks, of this City.

MORTALITY IN BROOKLYN.--Report of Deaths in the city of Brooklyn, from the 3d to the 10th of October, 1857, Males 59, Females 63. Total 122. Men 17, Boys 42, Women 21, Girls 42. Diseases.--Consumption, 14; Convulsions, 14; Marasmus, 10; Diseases of the Brain, 9: Dysentery, 7; Cholera Infantma, 6; Scarlet Fever, 5; Inflammation of the Lungs, 5; inflammation of the Bowels, 5:

CORLIES.--In this City, on Wednesday morning, Oct. 14, MARGARET J., wife of Edmund W. Corlies, of this City, aged 26 years. Her remains will be taken to Shrewsbury, N. J. The steamboat Ocean Wave leaves foot of Robinson. St. on Friday morning, 16th inst., at 6 1/2 o' clock. The friends of the family are invited to attend her funeral at the residence of J. Hubbard Corlies, at Shrewsbury, without further notice.

General SMITH issues special orders for the convening of a Court Martial, at Fort Leavenworth, on the 1st of November, for the trial of Colonel SUMMER. The charges are not stated. On the nigat of the 1st inst., some Pawnce Indians stole fourteen males. four horses and a number of cattle, from Fort Riley. A party of troops have gone in pursuit of them.

THE FOG.--The two boats running on the South Tenth-street, Williamsburg, ferry are in ill-luck. On Monday the George Washington struck the wharf in Brooklyn and broke her rudder, obliging them to haul her off for repairs. Yesterday morning quite a serious disaster befell the George Law. Upon her first trip in the morning at 5 o'clock, in the dense fog, she struck the bows of the ship Arramingo,

It is stated that several manufacturing establishments in Newark, which suspended operations under the money pressure, will resume and reemploy many of their old hands. The Cuyahoga Steam Furnace Company at Cleveland had made an assignment. Its assets ex-ceed liabilities by $100,000. A few weeks since 100 operatives were discharged from this concern, and 100 more are thrown out of employment by its failure.

The steamship Granada from New-York via Havana 10th inst., has arrived. She connected at Havana with the steamship Northern Light from Aspinwall for New-York, and brings the California mails of the 20th ult. The Northern Light has one million and a quarter in treasure.

The Richmond, Va., South is needlessly excited by a paragraph which appeared in a letter from our Richmond correspondent a few days since, concerning the reclection of Senator HUNTER. It suspects the TIMES of being engaged in a conspiracy to prevent the return of this distinguished gentleman to the United States Senate,

DEATH OF A REPORTER.--EDWIN COLSTON, many years a reporter for the NEW-YORK Press, was interred on Tuesday in Greenwood Cemetery. He died on Sunday morning last, at the residence of his mother, in Williamsburg, from asthma and bronchitis, with which he had been suffering for many months.

Yesterday was an important day. It is too soon to give results. Lawrence was not the point where foreign interference was anticipated. The weather has been dull and rainy for three days, and yesterday morning it was still lowery, and the heavens hung in black. The air became chilly, and the roads muddy; consequently, many were kept from the polls, especially in the country,

GOV. FLETCHER'S Message to the Vermont Legislature is brief. It opens with an acknowledgment of the Divine favor, and then gives attention to the Educational interests of the State. The establishment of a Board of Education, by the last Legislature, is commended, and a recommendation Is added that an organized system of operations be immediately devised. The militia system of the State is effective.

By way of New-Orleans we have received a telegraphio summary of a fortnight's later news from the North and South Pacific. The Northern Light, due at this port to-day, will bring a million and a quarter in treasure. The full vote of California in the recent State eleotion is announced. WELLER (Democrat) received a majority of 11,000 votes over both the Republican and Know-NothlinG candidates.

THE WEATHER, STEAMERS, wind yesterday morning was again from the northeast, accompanied by the dense fog which had prevailed since Monday afternoon. The ferries have been running with about the usual regularity. We do no hear of any collisions or accidents.

The conduct of Louis XVIII. and CHARLES X. certainly proved that the Bourbons in exile had "forgotten nothing and learned nothing," and the grandees of their Royal house have not enjoyed a very brilliant reputation for common sense since the events of 1830. But the Bourbons were fools, not because they were Bourbons, but because they were conceited.

PARTISAN INJUSTICE.--The Richmond Examiner, in an article exulting over the failure of business men at the North whom it styles Abolitionists, classes HARPER BROTHERS among them, and speaks of them as "the originators and reputed owners in part of the NEW-YORK TIMES."

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR: I noticed. in the European news in your paper of to-day, a notice that " the Earl of FIFE had been made a Peer, under the title of Baron SKENE." I have always been under the impression that a baron was the lowest in rank in the peerage, and that an earl was two grades higher, and, of course, a member of the peerage.

There were riots here last night. The Turner Hall, a German tavern, was attacked by a political club. Windows were smashed in several other sections of the City last night. The American procession were fired into by Democrats, and the houses from which the shots were fired were sacked. A number of persons were wounded, including four police officers.

In steamship Augusta, from Savannah--George Ellis Foy, Miss Habersham, Miss Hubbell, Miss Greenwood, Mrs. Casseday, Miss Mitchell. W. W. Caldwell, W. W. Parker, R. G. Stacy, George Owens, W. G. Drake, S. w. Jones, R. T. Boyd, C. B. Hobart, L. L. Stryer, J. M. Wellbone, M. J. Rice, and 22 in the steerage. In ship Mary Robinson, from Bombay--Mrs. Crocker, child and nurse.

Hon. William P. Preble died at Portland on Sunday morning at the age of 76. He was one of the most distinguished citizens of Maine. Judge Preble was educated at Harvard College, and graduated in 1866, in the class with Dr. Coggswell, of the Astor Library, Alexander H. Everett, and other distinguished men. Previous to the war of 1812 he was appointed District-Attorney of the United States, and became a leader in the Democratic party.

To the editor of the New-York Times; Will you permit an old man, who has gone through three panics, and two general bank suspensions, to give a little advice to your numerous readers? 1. To business men who are in debt.--Reduce as speedily as possible your liabilities. Enter into no new projects.

Movements are on foot for an Extra Session of the Legislature. One Committce has been sent to Albany by the Banks, and another by the merchants, for the purpose of urging the Governor to convene one immediately. The object, of course, is to procure some legisla. tion which shall relieve the Banks from the penalties to which they are subjected by existing laws,

All bills on solvent' State Banks are current henceforth, but people did not know it till late last night-otherwise there would have been a less confounded confusion in town about our currency. Had it been know that an Albany bill was to be held henceforth as good as a city bill, and a Buffalo or a Montauk bill as good as either,

Mr. JOHN MITCHEL denies the truth of the statements published by Mr. FLEMING and referred toby us a few days since, concerning their en counter in tile streets. The following correspond ence gives his side of the story, and also adds a sequel to the whole affair: KNOXVILLE, Saturday, Oct. 3, 1857. To JOSEPH MABRY, Esq.: M DEAR SIR,--I perceive that FLEMING'S published account of the little affair the other day is full of falsehood.

I notice in your paper of Sept. 19, an account of the fight between six companies of the 1st Cavalry. (under Col. SUMNER,) and the Cheyenne Indians. I wish to state a few facts concerning the affairs. Col. SUMNER'S command, consisting of six companies of Cavalry and three of the 6th Regiment, struck a heavy Cheyenne trail on the 24th of July.

STANLY--GREVIT.--In this City, on Wednesday, Oct, 14,1857, at the reidence of the bride's parents, by Rev. Thomas Armitage, M.C. STANLY to EMMA L. GREVIT, all of New-York. NORTON--TRUMBELL.--On Tuesday evening, Oct, 13, at the First Presbyterian Church, by Rev. Dr. Cutler, HENRY D. NORTON, of San Antonio, Texus, to MARY L. TRUMBULI of Brooklyn.

Parties in Washington familiar with the contemplated movements of General WALKER with reference to Nicaragua, are confident in the opinion that men are at this hour leaving in Southern ports in considerable numbers, with a view to enlisting under his banner for another effort to "Americanize" Central America.

In compliance with a call of the Board of Directors of the New-York and Erie Railroad, a meeting of the Stock and Bondholders of that Company was held last evening in the Lecture-room of Clinton Hall, Aster-place, for the purpose of raising a cash subscription sufficient to enable the Corporation to resume its payments. The attendance was quite large. Mr. CHAS. A. DAVIS was chosen Chairman, and Mr.

Those who can see no hope for the City and the country outside of a dash at special legislation to save the Banks of New York from the people of the State, may find it worth their while to consider the famous story of the Abbe GALIANI'S Neapolitan Chevalier. The Chevalier was coming out of church when he met a friend, who told him that the Victory was dead.

The Money Market and Banking Difficulties have very seriously impeded operations in Domestic Produce during the week. The demand has been restricted to the Immediate requirements of buyers,--chiefly for home use. Receivers have been eager sellers, and prices have fluctuated considerably, Towards the close some relief was experienced from the more settled condition of financial affairs; and with a reviving inquiry, the tendency in prices of the leading of Breadstuffs was in favor of factors.

By the steamship Vanderbill, which arrived at the port yesterday from Southampton, we receive four days later intelligence from Europe. The news is not important. NAPOLEON had returned to France after meeting ALEXANDER at Stuttgart. The imperial interview seems to have been a cold affair.

ONE GOOD RESULT.--It is to be hoped that tile suspension of specie payment by our Banks, and the consequent suspension of the run upon our country Banks, will have the effeet of bringing to market a very large portion of the enormous harvests of tile Western States.

THIRD ANNUAL REGATTA OF THE EMPIRE CITY ?? ??.--This affair came off at Yorkville, off Conrad's Garden, on Tuesday, Oct. 13. The following were the prizes: First race--four-oared boats, no restrictions, first prize, $100; second prize, $40; third prize, entrance fee, $10. Second race--single pair sculls, no restriction to boats, first prize, $10; second prize, $15; third prize, entrance fee, $5. Third race--Seventeen-feet working boats, two pairs sculls.

A belligerent husband in England, who recently advertised his wife, had to pay C1 for her maintenance for four weeks. The follow collected the money in farthings, and was doling them out to the relieving officer, but when he got through 2s. worth the officer told him he had enough, and that that trick would not do ; he must pay in acceptable coin. or go to prison. The former alternative was preferred.

ANOTHER NEW THEATRE.--There was hardly room, we should have supposed, for another theatre on Broadway, but a new one was opened last night in WOOD'S new marble building, on the site of the old Lyceum of Natural History, which, in completeness of construction, and elegance of decorations and fittings-up, excels all the other houses of the kind in the City.

Mr. ISARRI, who claimed to represent the de facto Government of Nicaragua, has realized the uncertainly of human hopes. A few days ago it seemed to be a settled thing that he was to be received, and his Government recognized at one. He was unable, however, to present satisfactory credentials, and all his hopes are blasted.

The Judges of the Supreme Court are severely censured In some quarters for the opinions which they promulgated on Wednesday concerning the Laws relating to Bank Suspension. Members of the legal profession maintain that their action was undignified and without precedent, and that a Judge has no right to give opinions except in pronouneing decisions upon actual trial.

In our impression of yesterday we stated, on the authority of a telegraph from St. Louis, that General South had issued special orders for a court-martial, to be held at Fort Leaven-worth, on the 1st of November, for the trial of Colonel SCMNER. The charges are not stated, but in general terms, one specification is understood to be,

" SUCH BARGAINS!"-Probably the most prosperous and exultant person in the whole community just at present is the well-known Mrs. Toodles. Not having any very pressing debts on hand, she goes about town to see everything that is offered for sale which she thinks it would be " handy to have in the house ;"

A COMMENTS.--Mrs. GROOM, residing at No. 203 Pearl-street, Brooklyn, was seriously hurt on Wednesday night, by the explosion of a fluid lamp. Dr. GEO. A. BENNETT was called in and every aid possible was rendered, but little hopes are entertained of her recovery. The husband of Mrs. GROOM was also badly burned in his endeavors to extinguish the fire.

In the town of Malden, Mass, 500 persons are thrown out of employment by the financial troubles. The Oswego Cotton Factory suspended business on Saturday, cutting adrift a large number of workmen. The Gornald Mills at New-Bedford are again in all operation, employing the full number of hands.

THIEVES ARE BOLD NOW-A-DAYS.--Yesterday afternoon, while Dr. V. K. GARDNER Was inside one of the plate-glass front stores on Broadway, a thief entered his carriage, that was standing at the door, drove off, and has not been heard of since. A few weeks ago, Dr. SAYRE'S horse and carriage were stolen in like manner at noon. on Broadway.

We have been gliding steadily now for more than seven weeks into such a slough of despond as no people, we venture to assert, ever found itself plunged in, under similar circumstances. Gold is esse is plenty enough; gold in passe is plentier still. The past three or four years have been years of unexampled prosperity.

Well, you see we have suspended at last, and Mr. AMASA WALKER can rejoice over his superior knowledge of what was to be. That something would happen in course of this week was confidently predicted as long ago as last Saturday, men saying that the seven days then immediately to follow would be the hardest ever known here.

By way of England we receive advises from Rio de Janeiro to the 1st of September. At Rio the coffee market remained quiet-about 40,000 bags sold since previous advises. Stock comprised about 200,000 bags. Good first was quoted 5,200 to 5,400 per arroba, and superior 5,500 to 5,600. The flour market continued without animation.

The United States steamship Vanderbite, Capt. E. HIGGINS, from Havre and Southampton on the 3d inst., arrived at this port Yesterday morning. The Vanderbilt brings $20,000 in speice. The mail steamer Arago, from New-York , arrived off Cowes on the evening of the 2d, and proceeded to Havre.

From the Washington Union. While we are discussing the Policy of the present including system of the country, pointing out its ??, and illustrating its evil results, it may be well to turn aside for a moment to compare the condition of ?? in other periods of our difficulties with the present.

DUNSCOMB--SHELLEY.--In this City, on Thursday, Oct. 15, at the residence of her parents. by Rev. W. Quin Mr. A. H. DUNSCOMB to Miss ANNE M. SHELLEY, all of this City. CUTTER--SMITH.--In this City, on Tuesday, Oct. 13, by Rev. John Spaulding, ABRAM K. CUTTER, of Boston, to ?? F., daughter of Washington Smith, Esq. WOODFORD--CAPEN.--In this City, on Thursday, Oct. 15, by Rev. Dr. Tyng, at St. George's Church. STEWANZ.

Mayor Wood Unanimously Renominated. One hundred and eight delegates from the twenty-two Democratic Ward organizations met at Tammany Hall last evening at 7 1/2 o'clock, to nominate a candidate for Mayor, and were organized by the appointment of Dr. A. V. WILLIAMS as Chairman, and CHRISTIAN B. WOODRUFF and SAMUEL WEBSTER, of the Tenth Ward; as Secretaries.

SIMONSON.--In this City, on Thursday morning, Oct. 13. ISAAC SIMONSON, of inflammation of the lungs, aged 56 years and 10 months. Relatives and friends of the family, also the Metropolitan Police Department, of which he was a member, are respectfully invited to attend the funeral from his late residence, corner of Broadway and 52d-st., on Sunday.

The old lady who thanked her stars that she had borrowed money enough to pay all her debts, did not meet her sisterhood with half so radiant a face as man yesterday met his brother man. The weather was unpropitious. In ordinary circumstances it would have given any one the blues.

The Court assembled at 10 o'clock, his Honor, PETER VREDENBURGH, presiding, assised by Associate Judges FORMAN, THROCKMORTON and GIFFORD. After a call of the Jury panel and officers, Mr. PARKER, the prosecutor, moved that JAS. P. DONNELLY, found guilty at the present term, for the murder of ALBERT S. MOSES, be placed at the bar for sentence.

The Board of Councilmen met on Thursday evening--the President, J. N. PHILLIPS, Esq., in the Chair. A motion was made by Councilmen BOOIE to reconsider the vote as to the location of the polling place in the First Ward. The motion was carried, and an amendment substituted.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The propriety of calling an extra session of the Legislature, for the purpose of obtaining relief from the pressure or panic which in the brief period of two months has entirely prosi?ted the commercial and financial interests of the State, is a question entitled to a more careful and deliberate consideration than it appears as yet to have received.

We have dates from Santa Fe to Step. 1??. The election of delegate to Congress took place on the 7th. MICHAEL ANTONIO OTERO was elected over judge BAIRD. Mr. OTERO represents the "Native" sentiment of the country, being a New-Mexican by birth. Judge BAIRD is a native of the United States. A correspondent of the Philadelphia Press, writing from Santa Fe, says:

PACKEE and all the rest of the Democratic ticket is likely to be between forty and fifty thousand, and in each branch of the Legislature the Democrats will probably have two-thirds of the members. We subjoin a summary of the reported majorities in various counties:

MILITARY.--The 55th Regiment New-York State Militia, Col. State Millitia, Col. SEGAL, had their annual inspectler. parade yesterday, in Hamllton-square. This Regiment is composed of the Light Guard, State Guard, Tigers, and Four small companics of the Garde La. fayetle. The 10th Regiment, Col. HALSET, and the 12th Regiment, Col. COOKS, paraded in Tompkins-square, and the 5th Regiment, Col. COOKS, paraded in Tompkins square, and the 5th Regiment, Col. SONWARISWALDER, in the Washingion Parade Ground.

FRIGATE MERNIMAC.--The departure of the Mirrimac from Boston has been delayed until to-day when, without doubt, this noble frigate will leave for the waters of the Pacific. It is possible that the Merrimacinay never again visit us, as a navy Yard has been established on Mare Island, San Francisco Harbor, where our national vessels can be overhauted and repaired, and where the ruzec Independence is said up in ordinary.

REPORTED FILLIBUSTERING SUCCESSES SO FAR.--General WALKER has been visiting the editors of the New-Orleans papers, giving an account of his successes in enlisting men and means for a new fillibustering campaign. He claims to have enrolled three thousand men for his new army, and collected funds to the amount of $200,000.

A terrible accident occurred on the Central Railroad last evening about 8 o'clock, near Beaver Meadow Brook, six miles west of this city. The accident was caused by the washing away of about 80 feet of the embankment. The mail train, consisting of one baggage car, a mail car and four passenger cars were all, excepting the last car, thrown down an embankment of twenty feet.

It is now two months since we anchored in this port. The British screw-line-of-battle-ship Brunswick and steam-sloop Tartar have both gone to sea, leaving us the only man-of-war in the harbor. Our ship is in the most superb order, both inside and out, and excites the admiration of all who see her. English naval officers are lavish in their praise, both of the beauty of the ship and the order in which she is kept.

To the Public: Some few weeks since a communication signed "Summer," appeared in the columns of the Union and American, advocating my election as Speaker of the House of Representatives, at the approaching session of the Legislature. This article was written and published without any consultation with me, or knowledge of its contents on my part, until it appeared in the newspaper.

United States Mail steamship Northern Light, E. L. TINELEPAUGH, Esq., Commander, left Aspinwall at 10 P. M., on the 5th Inst., and arrived off Havana on the night of the 9th. Left Havana at 10 A. N. on the 11th, (having taken on board 300 tons coal) and arrived at Quarantine at 11 P. M. on the'lOth. She brings the California malls of Sept, 21-$1,664, 200 in reasure on freight, and 728 passengers.

It is very natural that a people laboring under such financial difficulties as those which have now overtaken the extensive and complicated commercial relations of this country, should look about them in every possible direction for a sufficient cause of their troubles, in the hope of thus discovering an adequate remedy.

Crities, both English and American, have given themselves a great deal of trouble in attempting to account for the almost absolute dependence of the English and tile American stage upon tile dramatic genius of France, Theo Olympic and the Lyceum, Wallack's and Laura Keene'a, are all alike sustained by forced contributions" upon. the abundance of the Gymnase and the Vaudeville.

The medical season has fairly opened. The preliminary Fall Course in each of the three Medical Colleges of the City draws near to its conclusion, and the regular four months course opens in each next week. At the Twenty-third-street College of Physicians and Surgeons, the attendance on the preliminary course averaged sixty: yesterday eighty were present.

ANOTHER PRESDYTERIAN SPLIT.- Splits are becoming common in the Presbyterian body. Last week the synod of Missouri, consisting of four presbyteries and fifty-seven churches, held its annual session in St. Louis, and after a long discussion on Slavery, resolved to form itself into an independent body. It refuses fellowship with the New School body. on account of its action at Cleveland last summer, and declares that it cannot go with the Richmond Convention.

STRANGE IT TRUE.--We find the following paragraph in the Stamford (Conn.) Advocate: "It is certainly with pleasure that we announce the probable fact that P. T. BARNUM is again "on his legs"--that he is to-day a richer man than he was before his connection with the Jerome Clock Company.

FIVE-MILES FOOT RACK.--A five-mile foot-race, for $500 aside, between PATRICK DUCKLEY, of Lynn, known as the Lynn Buck, and NAPOLEON CAMPANA, of New-York, Known as the Young Sport, came off on the Franklin Park, Saugus, yesterday afternoon, The rare was won easily by BUCKLEY, though a start of 100 yards was allowed his competitor.

Later news from Utah reaches us by way of California. An improbable rumor of the defeat of the United States troops by the Mormons, had reached Carson Valley. A letter from that locality, dated Sept. 10, gives the report as follows: "Within the last week or ten days there has been a teat stir among the Mormons in this place and vicinity.

An atlactk of fever is always followed by a reaction. It never leaves the system pre cisely as it found it. The analogy holds in re. gard to polities. A period of excitement is always followed by a period of indifference. It is impossible to keep the public mind always in a condition of fervid and aroused attention.

Motions and decisions. Mrs. Cunningham Withdrawn her Petition--Appearance in Court. SUPREME COURT.--SPECIAL TERM.--OCT. 15. Before Hon. Justice Roosevelt. Yesterday the counsel for Mrs. Cunningham appeared, and desired to withdraw her petition for an appeal from the decision of the Surrogate, which was presented on Thurday.

Secretary TOUCEY has determined to have the new steam sloops-of-war divided into four compartments each, by water-tight bulkheads. It is this modification of the original plan which has delayed the signing of the contracts a warded to Mr. WESTERVELT for the hull, and Mr. MURPHY for the machinery of one of these sloops. They will go to New-York to-morrow, however, with everything satisfactorily closed up.

Democratic Primary Nominations. The Democratic Judicial Convention met a Tammany hall last evening, and make the following nominations: Supreme Court -- Long Term. -- Daniel P. Ingraham. Supreme Court -- Short Term.-- Josiah Southerland. Common Please -- Henry H. Hilton. Recorder.--George C. Barnard.

AN INJUSTICE CORRECTED.--We published some days since, in a telegraphic dispatch forwarded by the Agent of the Associated Press at Utica, a statement that a complaint had been made against HARVEY DOOLITTLE, Esq., Cashier of the Agricultural Bank at Herkimer, for embezzlement, false wearing, and other misconduct in connection with the management of the Bank.

Arrival of the Daniel Webster--Prompt Action of General Sonohn to Suppress the Slave-Trade--Arrest of Two Governors and Minor Officials--Suppression of Smugling--Success of the Revolutions in San Domingo--Expected Expulsion of President Baez.

Faneuil Hall was crowded last evening, both on the floor and in the galleries, in response to the announcement that Hon. N. P. HANES would address his fellow-citizens, and would touch upon the causes of the financial distress. A number of ladies occupied seats in the galleries.

As foreshadowed by your correspondent several days ago, DANIEL B. MARTIN was yesterday removed from the position-of Engineer-in-Chief of the Navy, and SAMUEL ARCHBOLD, of Maryland, appointed to the vacancy.

Mr. Lefevre, a wealthy sugar-planter at Lafourches, La., died recently without issue, leaving an estate of $700,000. Half was left to a nephew and half to a broker in New-Orleans, who had transacted Mr. Lefevre's business. The broker was astonished to find himself the recipient of $350,000, but refused to receive the money on such terms;

The Syracuse Standard has full particulars of the dreadful accident which occurred on the New-York Central Railroad on Thursday evening, Two persons were killed and eighteen injured. The Standard says: The Forward passenger-coach and baggage-car, as well as the engine and tender, were or overturned in the water, and it seems almost a miracle that any of the inmates could have escaped.

PUTTING THE REVOLTED SEPOYS TO A PROFITABLE USE--Though England very justly pants for vengeance on the revolted Sepoys, yet it is evident that so vast a number of rebels cannot be put to death, when they shall once more fall into her hands. They are too numerous to be confined, and too dangerous to be allowed to go free.

A meeting of the "People" was called by advertisement for Saturday evening last, at Constitution Hall, Broadway, between Bleecker and Bond sterols, the handbills, was " to take into consideration the present financial crisis, and dovise measures for the prompt amelioration of business difficulties and the prevention of suffering during the Winter."

From the Philadelphia Press. We are informed by a gentleman acquainted with the doings in the New-York Custom-House, that there have been seized and forfeited, during the last six months, goods that had been smuggled into that port, or entered by fraudulent invoice, of the value of near $200,000, most or all of which was detected through the vigilance of Surveyor HART.

WELCH.--In this City, on Sunday, Oct. 18, at his residence, No. 35 Leonard. st., JAS. If. WELCH, aged 58 years. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend his funeral, on Tuesday, the 20th inst., at o'clock P. M. WILLIAMSON,--In this City, on Saturday, Oct, 17, of congestion of the brain, WILLIAM, second son of the late Alexander Williamson, aged 17 years and 21 days.

WALLACK'S THEATRE.--The excellent drame of "Past and Present," produced at this Theatre on Friday evening, will be repeated to-night; its success having induced the management to delay until Wednesday the production of the new comedy of "Caprice; or, Lover and Husband," in which Mr. LESTER will appear for the first time since his indisposition.

It will be remembered that Officers Robb and Wildey, of the Deputy Superintendent's Office, arrested, a few days since, in Williamsburg, William Stanley his wife, and Johnny McGraw, charged with passing, in this City, a number of counterfeit $10 bills on the Rondont Bank.

The U.S. Mail steamer Black Warrior sailed from New-Orleans on the 11th, arrived at Havana on the 13th, thence at 10 A.M. on the 14th, and arrived here at 7 P.M. yesterday. A cargo of 179 Asiatics had been landed at Havana from a Norwegian bark. She lost 70 on the passage.

EXHIBITION OF WORKS OF THE BRITISH AND FRENCH SCHOOLS OF PAINTING.--An exhibition of paintings by living British artists is to be opened this week at the new rooms of the National Academy, in Tenth-street, which is the inauguration of one of the most important movements that has been made here in the cause of art.

An alrocious and unprovided murder was committed last Saturday night about 10 o'clock in Tenth avenue, near Twenty first-street. The murdered man was JOHN SWENSON, a Scotchman. He occupied, with his family, part of the house No. 310 West Twenty-Seventh-Street, and w?? employed in the paper manufactory of Mr. CHRYSTY in Twenty-third-street, near Tenth-avenue.

The Columbus Journal has received returns upon which it estimates a majority of 65 votes for CHASE, the Republican candidate for Governor, but with Paulding and Meigs Counties to be heard from. These counties have since been heard from, and they respectively give CHASE a majority of 169 and 200 votes.

On the banks of the Mississippi, in Shelby county, eighteen miles from Memphis, Tenn., two men named SLAUGHTER and MERRIWEATHER, became engaged on Monday last in a dispute with two men cutting wood there, which ended in a horrible fight.

The returns of the election in Kansas are still incomplete, and the character of the newly-elected Legislature is involved in doubt. Advices from Lawerence to the 10th, claim a Free-State majority in both branches, but it is added that in many precincts the judges are throwing out voles upon the ground of alleged informality, and that they are very likely in this way to secure a pro-slavery majority.

The St. Louis will then sail instead of the Northern Light, advertised for to-day. By the arrival of the steamship North American at Quebec, we receive four days later advices from Europe.

BROOKLYN TRUANT INSTITUTION--INTERESTING TO BAD BOYS.--The Common Council Committee, Alderman VAN BRUNT, CLARK, RALPHS AND JENKINS, having the matter in charge of establishing in institution, under the law of 1853, for the care of truant children in Brooklyn, have so far attended to their duties as to be nearly ready to commence operations. The old Penitentiary building at Flatbush, leased by them for this purpose, will be ready for occupants in about two weeks.

ANOTHER SITE FOR THE POST-OFFICE.--It is intimated by our Washington correspondent that parties have gone on to the seat of Government to recommend the Five Points as a suitable site for the new Post-Office. This is not altogether a new suggestion, but we believe no serious attempt has been before made to locate the Post-Office in that neighborhood.

The Northern Light on her passage homeward was In some danger of sharing the fate of the Central America. Twenty-three hours out she ran on a coral reef three miles from Old Providence, a small island in tile Caribean Sea, in lat. 13? 21' N., and about a hundred miles east of the Mosquito coast. The steamer lay on the reef some eight or nine hours before she succeeded in getting off.

The election has passed off peaceably in all the Precincts heard from, which are all except the southernmost parts of the Territory. PARROT elected, undoubtedly, by several thousand majority. The election has gone Democratic in the counties of Leavenworth, Johnson, Marshall, Atchison and Jefferson, which gives a small Democratic majority in the Territorial Legislature.

DAY OF THANKSGIVING.--A correspondent of the Evening Post writes to the editor as follows: MR. EDITOR: It seems to be peculiarly appropriate to the events of this year for the several States to fix upon one and the same day for Thanksgiving. Maryland having taken the Initiative, and appointed the last Thursday in November, (20th.) It is to be hoped that all the other States will fix upon that day,

THE MURDER IN TENTH-AVENUE.--Two persons have been arrested on suspicion of being implicated in the murder of SWENSON, Saturday night, in Tenth-avenue. The names of the arrested parties are HAS, McNAMEE and EDWARD ELANEY. They are both boys 18 years of age. The former lives in Twenty-first street, and once drove an ice-wagon, but for the past two months has been doing nothing.

The Anniversary Address before the America Institute was delivered in the Crystal Palace last evening by Hon. NATHANIEL P. BANKS, of Massachusetts. A large audience was present. Mr. BANKS was introduced by Mr. WARNEY, Chairman of the Board of Managers, and spoke as follows: The year which is about to close will constitute an epoch in our industrial history.

The first exhibition of the Massachusetts Board of Agriculture, Hon. M. P. WILDER, President, opened to-day at the City Fair Grounds. The weather was exceedingly cold and boisterous, but the attendance was good. The exhibition embraces cattle, horses, sheep, swine, and domestic fowls of nearly every variety; also agricultural products and implements.

Since the murder in Tenth-avenue last Saturday night, Acting-Inspector Carpenter, of the Sixteenth Ward, and his officers have been making assiduous search for the murderers. The name of the arrested boy is Daniel Cunningham; he lives at No. 90 Tenth-avenue.

The Half-Time Era-More Men Discharged. The sudden cold snap of yesterday brought to their true bearings a great many people who were flattering themselves that the times were not so very hard after all. An accident occurred on the New-York and Erie road last night, of which we have not full particulars, owing to the disposition of some persons connected with the road to conceal the matter from the press. The particulars, as near as we can learn, are as follows: The emigrant train West, ran into freight train No. 2. East, a little west of Hornellsville, about midnight, and several persons were killed and wounded.

SUICIDE.--JOHN BURG, who kept a disorderly house at 12 Walker-street, while playing cards Monday night in his place, suddenly arose, left the room and went into the basement; soon after, the report ?? a gun was heard. On going below they found BURG sitting bolt upright against the door, holding a double-barreled gun in his left hand.

There are many features connected with this affair of a painfully thrilling character, and more than usually novel.

WALLACK'S THEATRE.--The latest dramatic novelty at this house, PLANCHE'S " Past and Present," will be repeated here tonight. In it Mr. BLAKE plays the principal character, and it is altogether such a thoroughly meritorious performance that we recommend every one to see the piece before it is withdrawn. The other members of the caste are equally excellent, lacking only Mr. BLAKE'S opportunity.

The Board of Governors met on Tuesday, the President in the Chair. The supply of eggs having been cut down upon a previous requisition, Dr. Whitilesey, of Randall's Island, addressed the Board explaining that the seemingly large requisition was expended upon feeble children, to each of whom one egg was given daily. The Board very humanely ordered the future supply at to be diminished.

FIRE IN READE-STREET.--The alarm of the at 7?? o'clock last evening was caused by a fire in the basement of the New-York and Erle Railroad buildings on Reade, Duane and West streets. The basement is occupied by POWELL RAMSBALL, provision dealers. They sustained a damage of about $200. Probably insured.

A New Presbyterian Church. The corner-stone of the Greene-avenue Presbyterian Church was laid on Monday at 4 P. M. The order of exercises were prayer by Rev. Dr. LORD, Pastor of the second Presbyterian Church; singing an original hymn; address and laying the corner-stone by the pastor of the Church, Rev. LORENZO WESCOTT;

The Royal Man steamship Europe, from Liverpool on the ? inst., with news three days later than was brought by the steamer at quebec, arrived ?? Halifax about 11 o'clock last night. He advices had not reached us up to the time of going to press.

We have received the following particulars of the sinking of the steamer Tropic, which occurred in the Missouri river, near Waverly, on Thursday last. The steamer ran against a snag. crushing her wheel and tearing away a portion of her hull, when she immediately sank in 30 feet of water.

BAPTIST LECTURE-ROOM,--On Sunday the Central Park Baptist Church, located in Fifty-third-street, between Eight-avenue and Broadway, dedicated the Lecture-room of their new Church edifice. A sermon was delivered in the morning by Rev. Dr. ARMITAGE; in the afternoon by Rev. STEPHEN REMINGTON, and in the evening by Rev. A. KINGMAN NOTT successor to Rev. Dr. CONE. The following is the report of the Treasurer. Deacons JONAS SPARKS.

THE REVULSION AND THE GOVERNMENT.--The Government is taking measures to ascertain the effect of the revulsion upon the foreign commerce of the country and upon the consumption of imported good. With this end in view the Collectors of the Customs have been instructed to get the opinions of intelligent merchants upon the probable amount of importations for the next twelve of eighteen months;

DETENTION OF THE JAMES ADGER. CHARLESTON, Wednesday, Oct. 21. The Steamship James Adger is detained her by a heavy sea on the bar, but will leave for New-York at 8 o'clock to-morrow morning. THE AUGUSTA AT SAVANNAH. SAVANNAH, Tuesday, Oct. 20. The steamship Augusta has arrived here, after a passage of 60 hours from New-York. THE ATLANTA AT CHARLESTON. CHARLESTON, Wednesday, Oct. 21.

THE CALORIC ENGINE AGAIN.-It will be seen by an advertisement in another column that the, Caloric Engine is again brought to the notice of the public in a form calculated to test its utility. Mr. J. R. KITCHING, as agent for the patentee, commends it as by far the most economical power that can be employed In very many of the domestic and mechanical uses of common life.
