This most essential and useful regulation seems to have been, we know not for what reason, subsequently stricken out, and the result has been,

To the Editor of the New-York Times: After having seen a good portion of the United States, on both the Atlantic and Pacific slopes, I have at last seen that portion which I consider most inviting t men in moderate circumstances, who desire an independent country home for their families.

BANGS.--In this City, on Wednesday afternoon, MARY ELIZA, eldest daughter of Rev. Nathan Bangs. The funeral services will be held this (Thursday) after-noon, at 4 o'clock, at the residence of her father, No. 40 irving-place, at which the friends of the family are invited to attend, without further invitation. SULLIVAN.--In this City, on Tuesday, Oct. 20, Mrs. ISABELLA SULLIVAN, in the 66th year of her age.

Since my last, affairs in China have assumed to marked change. Times are very dull here, and will probably remain so for some time. In the former war, the American ships and merchants were the medium of the immense Canton and China trade, and might have been so in the present, had they not been involved, by the Commodore of United States forces, in the war themselves. it is.

Immediately after tile suspension of specie payments by our banks twenty years ago, theo merchants met together to send a deputation to Albany, just as they did the day after the present suspension, and the mechanics and Workingmen of the City had a meeting to denounce the riginators of the financial difficulty just as they have not done now.

MEETING OF THE WHIG GENERAL COMMITTEE.--An adjourned meeting of the Whig General Committee was held last evening, at No. 108 Fourth-avenue. The Committee appointed to wall upon the gentle-men nominated by the Committee, reported that the nominations had been cheerfully accepted, and the report was adopted. A long and animated discussion then arose upon the nomination of a candidate for Recorder, pending which the Committee adjourned. The parties thus far nominated by the Committee, are:

To the Editors of the Union and American: The card of Gen. SCOTT, recently published in the National Intelligencer. Was evidently intended to produce the impression that the statement in my address to the people of Tennessee, to the effect that he had caused to be paid to SANTA ANA $10,000 under the Puebla negotiations, was untrue.

The Steamship Cahawba has arrived at this port from New-York, via Havana, 18th inst., with over half a million in specie. The health of Havana was good, and business was more active. Sugars had declined, the stock consisted of 180,000 boxes.

A WILL CANCELLED BY CUTTING OUT ITS SIGNATURE.--An interesting decision was given by Judge Sir J. DODSON, in the Prerogative Court, London, on the 1st instant, in regard to the cancellation of a will. The testatrix executed a will in 1850, bequeathing the bulk of her property to two sisters. After her death a codicil was produced, dated Aug. 4, 1854, and duly attested, conveying the property,...

Vale Cemetery, at this place, was duly consecrated to-day with imposing ceremonies. The St. George's Lodge, and the Mohawk Royal Arch Chap. ter of Freemasons, and three Lodges of the Indopendent Order of Odd Follows, in full regalia, took part in the ceremonies, and, with the Common Coun cil and citizens, marched in procession to the grounds. The exercises at the Cemetery wore solemn and Impressive. About three thousand persons attended the consecration.

MEETING OF THE STOCKHOLDERS, CREDITORS AND BONDHOLDERS OF THE DELAWARE AND LADKAWANNA RAILROAD COMPANY.--An adjourned meeting of the Deleware and Lackawanna Railroad Company, including the stock and bondholders of that road, was held last evening in the Mercantile Library building. Some two hundred persons were in attendance, including a large number who had come down the road from Jersey and Pennsylvania for the occasion.

DESPERATE SHOOTING AFFRAY IN NEW-ORLEANS. On Tuesday week a bloody affray took place in New-Orleans, at the jackson Railroad report. The partles were Wm. J. LOOAN, who keeps the Poliean cating-house on St. Charles-street, and JAMES II, WINGFIELD, formerly chief of the fire department of this city, but more recently a resident of one of the villages on the jackson Railroad. Both fired a number of shots.

The Cunard steamship Europa arrived at Halifax at such a late hour on Tuesday nightm that only a poition of her news was received in time for insertion in our morning edition of yesterday. We give it od-day entire. Our financial revulsion is severly felt in London and Paris.

Captain MONTGOMERY has been ordered to relieve Captain PIERSON as a member of the Third Naval Court. The case of Lieut. FLAGG is finished, and that of Commander RITCHIE has been taken up. His counsel objects to Commander GOLDSBOROUGH as a member of the Court because the latter was the principal witness against him on the recent Court Martial.

The R. M. steamship Niagara sailed to-day at noon, with forty-five passengers for Liverpool and fourteen for Halifax, She takes out no specie. Her cargo consists of 300 bales of cotton, 100 boxes of indigo, and 50 tons of ivory. Her total cargo is 879 packages.

SMITH-KIPP.--In this City, on Tuesday, Oct. 20, at Market. St, Church, by Rev. T. L. Cuyler. Mr. SAMUEL J. SMITH to Miss IMOGENE H., daughter of Quinby Kipp, Esq., all of this City. DIX--KINGSLEY.--In this City, on Monday, Oct. 12. by Rev. Dr. Potts, JOHN D. DIX, Esq., of Clifton, Staten Island, to Miss LORINDA M. KINGSLEY, daughter of Mr. H. S. Kingsley, of Northampton, Mass.

BROADWAY THEATRE.--The ballet performance at this house last night was prefaced by TOM TAYLOR'S comedy of " Still Waters Run Deep." We have not heretofore spoken of the dramatic part of the entertaimnent provided by Mr. MARSUALL, for the reason that, although good of Its kind, and likely to please a vast variety of palates, it is a kind which does not frequently invite special consideration.

The Tribune is very severe upon use for declining to surrender or columns to vituperation of Mayor Wood. It urges that he is a candidate for reelection,--that it is absolutely essential that the people should be made acquainted with his character, and that it is the duty of every honest Editor to "echo his crimes" and prevent his election.

It would scarcely be true to say that the failure of this new steamer to sail for Liverpool on the 12th ult., as advertised by her owners, took the public by surprise. So long a time has elapsed since she was first announced as ready, and so many disappointments have since occurred, that no person now puts any great faith in promises made on her behalf.

At 1 P. M. yesterday the Police of the 22 different precinets assembled in the Park, in front of the City Hall, preparatory to their parade. Commissioners BOWEN, STRANAHAN and NYE, and various members of the Common Council, were present and reviewed them.

JAMES roegers, the murderer of JOHN SWENSON, was arrested at Woodbridge at the residence of his brother-in-law, about 8 o'clock this morning, by ALEX. R. CODDINGTON, Esq. He Is now confined in tile Middlesex County Jail in this city. He freely confesses the crime, and states that he has been in the woods in the neighborhood of Woodbridge for tile last two days.

The murders and other acts of violence that have been perpetrated here during the last sixty hours show how small is the effect of stringent legislation in the way of preventing crime. Two men have been murdered and five others stabbed since Saturday at about sunset, SUTTON, who killed HILTON and wounded DONOVAN and TODD, proved himself a regular Malay,

THE COOPERS. No class of mechanics is destined to feel the hard?? this Winter more severely than the journey men coopers. Their labor is lucrative; in ordinary times they cap earn sufficient to keep themselves and their families comfortable, and show away besides a doctor's fee and enough to support them for awhile when Illness or hard times compel them temporarlly to desist from labor.

It seems to be generally understood that WALKER is meeting with considerable success in obtaining recruits at the South for a now crusade against Nicaragua. Report says that he has already enlisted nearly 8,000 mou, and that his departure is postponed only for a short time in consequence of temporary lack of funds.

The following appeared in a portion of yesterday's Morning Edition: HALIFAX, Tuesday, Oct. 20. The Royal Mail steamship Europa, Captain ??, from Liverpool, on the afternoon of Saturday, the 10th inst., arrived at this port at 11:20 o'clock this evening. She has [pound]63,160 in specie. There is nothing later from India.

THE BARK JOHN SWAZEY ASHORE--CREW SAFE. NANTUCKET, Wednesday, Oct. 21. The bark John Swazey, from the coast of Africa, for Salem, laden with palm oil and ivory, before reported ashore, is full of water, and weather is too rough to render her any assistance. Her crew are safe.

The report which has just issued from the Railway Department of the Board of Trade, though not altogether an exhilarating document, contains rome crumbs of comfort for the desponding proprietors of railway stock. The ample statistics which are appended to it, liken almost all similar returns for several years past,

Under the influence of milder weather to-day the attendance at the Agricultural Fair was very large. During the forenoon, premiums were awarded on Cattle. The stock on exhibition embraces Devon, Ayrshire, Hereford and native. This part of the show was extensive and unusually good.

Councilmen FRANKLIN, last evening, submitted to the Common Council the following report from the Special committee to which this subject had been previously referred: TO THE HONORABLE THE BOARD OF ALDERMEN AND COUNCILMEN OF THE CITY OF NEW-YORK. The Committee to whom was assigned the duty of examining into the public accounts and the books of the Finance Department respectfully present for your consideration this their report.

In another part of this morning's TIMES will be found the report of the Special Committee appointed some time since by the Common Council, to examine the public accounts and the books of the Finance Department of the City. It is brief and imperfect,-pretend.

Mayor WOOD sent in to the Common Council last evening a document which will command attention. It relates to the prospects of famine among the City Poor during the coming Winter, and calls upon the City Authorities to take measures to prevent riot and bloodshed by alleviating the misery from which these may be expected to spring.

Dr. Benj. Brandreth is the Democratic candidate for State Senator in the Eighth (Westchester County) District, John W. Ferdon, the present senator, is the American and Republican candidate. John Gauson, of Fire County, and Linus W. Thayer, of Wyoraing, are the Democratic candidates for Judges of the Supreme Court in the Eighth Judicial District.

DANISH CONSUL-GENERAL,--We understand that M. DE RAASLOFF has been appointed charged affaires and Consul-General for Denmark in the United States. He has resided in this country for several years past, and has become widely known as a gentleman of high character and marked ability. .

ELECTIONEERING CLAP-TRAP.--It would be simply amusing, if it were not also melancholy, to read the preposterous representations made by the party press for the purpose of influencing votes at the coming election. The Albany Atlas and Argus fires up in the work of the canvass to a degree which, in contrast with the stagnation which prevails all around it, is really exciting. It reprints, from the TIMES.

HICKS.--In this City, on Wednesday, Oct. 21, at his residence, No. 30 Union-square, JOHN H. HICKS, aged 65 years. The relatives and friends of the family are invited to attend the funeral, at St. Bartholomew's Church, Lafayette-place, on Saturday afternoon, 24th inst., 3 1/2 o'clock, without further invitation. LAGRAVE.--In this City, on Thursday morning, Oct. 22. after a short and painful illness, ALFRED F. LAGRAVE, in the 39th year of his age.

FIRE IN BROOKLYN. - At 6 o'clock last evening a fire broke out in the frame dwelling No. 57 Nassau-street, the upper story of which was much damaged by fire, and the lower stories and furniture received considerable - damage from water. The whole loss will exceed $500. The building is owned by HENRY RADFORD, and occupied by BERNARD RICE.

LITERARY.--HARPER'S Magazine for November has been issued, and is one of the best numbers over published. It is announced that in the December number will be commenced THACKEBAY'S now novel entitled The Virginians. The Esmonds make their appearance in the first number, from which something of the general tone of the new work may be inferred.

The United States Mail steamship North Star, Captain LEFESRE, from Bremen on the 3d, Havre on the 6th, and Southampton on the 8th inst., arrived at this port yesterday morning. The screw steamship Kangaroo, from Liverpool on the 7th inst., also arrived yesterday; but the advices by both these vessels have been anticipated by the Europa at Halifax.

FELLOW-CITIZEN: In a government formed as is our own, and resting upon popular suffrage for its beneficent administration, not to say Its very existence, no person clothed with the prerogative ofa voter can Innocently intermit the oxercise of the Important duty to which he is called by the recurrence of an election.

THE POLICE COMMISSION---At the meeting of the Police Commissioners yesterday, the vacancy was filled by the election of SIMEON DRAPER, the motion being made by Mayor Wood and receiving the unanimous vote of the Board.

The number of lives lost at the Chicago fire proves to have been nineteen. The following is a revised list: 1. John A. Raymond, Worcester, Mass, 2. D. C. Emerson, Lawrence, Mass. 3. Matthias Marsh, Member of Hook Ladder Company No. 2.

A GROSS CASE or PUBLIC PROFLIGACY--The Common Council has passed an ordinance renting at one dollar per annum, thirty-two lots of very valuable City property on Fifth-avenue to the Roman Catholic Orphan Asylum,--and the measure only awaits the Mayor's signature, (if it have not already received it,) to become a law.

A REMARKABLE SHIPWRECK.--We have road a good many thrilling accounts of terrible disasters at sea, and loss of life by shipwreck, but have never heard or read of anything which equals the brief account given by the Russian admiral of the loss of the line-of-battle-ship Le Fort, which foundered in the Baltic on the 22d of September last.

Another meeting of the Board of Commissioners of the Metropolitan Police was held yesterday in their office in White-street. All the members were in attendance. The minutes of the proceedings of the previous day were read and approved. Mayor POWEIL, of Brooklyn, presented an application for the appointment of three persons, whose names he gave, to act as special policemen in carrying out the provisions of the Truant law in Brooklyn.

A DISPUTED CASE OF SALVAGE.--The steam boat Wave, Captain GERMAIN, while going out on a cruise early Monday morning, discovered a sloop outside of the Hook, with her sails lowered and one anchor down; it had been blowing a gale the previous night, and the tag ran down for the sloop to see if she wanted a tow. No one appeared when she was hailed, and they boarded her.

A Criminal suit has been commenced against Capt. AUSTIN of the Ship J. A. Westerrvelt, one of the Red Cross Line of Liverpool packets, by a passenger upon her last voyage to this port. Captain AUSTIN was arrested by Deputy-Marshal O'KEEPE, and the examination of the case came on yesterday before United States Commissioner BRIDGHAM, LEOPOLD C. NEWMAN, Esq.,

The New-School Presbyterian Synod of Virginia is now in session in Washington. It exercises jurisdiction over the greater part of that State, the western shore of Maryland and the District of Columbia.

AEREST OF FUGITIVES FROM JUSTICE.--THOS and MALCOLM GRAHAM, of Brooklyn, were Thursday held to answer a charge of burglary committed in Boston in April last, and another in Worcester. The accused resided in Gowanus with a mother and sister. A few days since they charged the mother and sister with attempting to kill them. In retallation, the mother exposed the acts of her children. They were arrested, and Thursday taken to Massachusetts.

We select, from our foreign files, and publish this morning, divers articles on the effect of the great financial revulsion on the other side of the Atlantic. Unfortunately, when these articles were written, the worst was not known, but affairs were bad enough to excite serious apprehensions for the future.

REPUBLICAN NOMINATION FOR RECORDER.--The Republican County Convention met last night at Stayvesant Institute for the purpose of selecting a candidate for the office of Recorder in place of Edgar Keleinum, who has declined. Alexander Spaulding was nominated with a few scattering votes against him. On motion the choice was made ?? Mr. Spaulding is the fusion candidate of the Republican and American Parties. es.

WM. CROSIER, cook of the schooner Charles Sumner, lying at Muskegon, Michigan, while at a dance in a Irish groggery, was murdered by a man named JOHN POWEES, who was abetted by another man named WM. YOUNG, CROSIER, while at the dance, and drunk, as all the rest of the party were, broke several panes of glass out of window.

A fire in the State Prison at this place to-day destroyed the is ops at the North and of the Yard, and threatened ?? a late be destruction of the whole building. The less on the stock in the shops is estimated at $25,000. The fire was the work of an incendiary.

We are met in full view of the outlet of one of the most considerable of those inland seas which form so marked a feature in the geography of our continent.

STEAM GOING A WHALING.--It is said that the whaleship America, which sailed from New-Bedford on Wednesday of last week, took out a steam whale boat. The machinery consists of two oscillating engines placed in the stern, which drive a paddle-wheel. This boat can be propelled at the rate of twelve miles an hour--two more than the usual speed of the whole.

The not improbable rumor of the recall of Viscount CANNING from the Viceroyalty of India, is but one of many indications that the Government of England is now fully alive to the Importance of the struggle in India, and fully determined to put forth the whole force of the empire in the suppression of the Mehammedan mutiny.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Wise financial systems, State and National, unist furnish the people a safe and uniform currency, always equal to the standard of gold and silver, the legal ineasure of values. As to this, there can be but one opinion. The framers of the National Constitution prohibited the issue of State bills of credit as money, and made gold and silver the only tender for debts and dues.

TO HON. SHELTON F. LEAKE.--Dear Sir: I received on yesterday your letter propounding to me certain interrogatories, to which, without further delay, I proceed to reply. They are in substance nearly the same, with the questions upon which the Enquirer for some time past, has been demanding my answers.

FIVE HIGHWAY ROBBERS ARRESTED.--Patrick Gallagher, John Bray, Philip Maguire, John Kavenah and Edward Maguire, were arrested late Friday evening in the Eighteenth Ward, charged with being the parties who, on the 16th of last September attacked David Voorhes and John Wray at tile corner of Fourth-avenue and Twentieth-street, and after robbing them, severely beating and leaving them insensible on the pavement.

COL. LOGAN. I am now in this place, waiting for orders from Gen. WALKER, previous to moving further. The boys are beginning to come in, but they will not leave until we receive further instructions from Head quarters. I expect by next Tuesday's mail something definite. Tell those who are willing to join us in the expedition Not to be bluffed off by the hostde appearance of the great man at the While Hruse.

A CONVENTION OF CANDIDATES.--Some enterprising politicians in Tennessee have addressed a long sting of questions upon all possible subjects, to half a dozen gentlemen who expect to be candidates for the United States Senate. These gentlemen have held a Convention and unanimously agreed not to answer these inquiries until after they receive the nomination of their party caucus.

It seems that Holland is at last resolved to follow the example of her neighbors in abolishing Slavery in her colonies in the West Indies. We read in the Curacaosche Courant, of the 22d inst., an official publication of the Home Government preparing the inhabitants for the emancipation of slaves in Curacao, Bonaire, Aruba, St. Eustatius and Saba.

The camp of Chalons is just now the centre of attraction for ?? fashionable world. The Empress and the Imperial Baby, the ladies of honor and the Marshals of France, have all taken up their ?? at the camp, and are sharing the life of the soldier after the most approved military style. .

By the brig Ocean Bir., which leaves this port today, I have an opportunity of sending you the latest news from this region. The Americans in Nicara era have been expelled from the country by a degree o' MARTINEZ and JEREZ, issued in Monagua in the fore part of this month.

ACTION UNDER THE FUGITIVE SLAVE LAW.--In the United States District Court, at Columbus, Ohio, on the 21st inst., Judge LEAVITT charged the Grand Jury in relation to the provisions of the Fugitive Slave law--remarking that a complaint founded upon the seventh section of that act would be submitted for their investigation.

There will be six ballot boxes used at each election district in this City at the coming State Election, which takes place one week from next Tuesday, and the votes in each will be counted in the following order. First--Box No. 2.--This box contains the State ticket, headed by the names of the candidates for the office of Secretary of State.

The Virginia Synod of the Presbyterian Church have adopted the report of the Committee presented yesterday, recommending a withdrawal from the General Assembly, in consequence of the action of that body on the Slavery question. The vote was 32 against 3. The nays were Messrs. SUNDERLAND and HASKELL, of Washington, and DUNNING, of Baltimore.

The news by the Baltic is highly favorable to the English in India. The tide is evidently turning in their favor, and we may expect to hear by the next India mail that the strength of this great rebellion has been broken, and the country effectually restored to British control.

CONTINUANCE OF HOSTILITIES--DRKADUL OUTRAGES BY THE INDIANS-SLAUGHTER OF MEN, WOMEN AND CHILDREN. By the brig Mountain Eagle, Capt. MILLIKEN, from Sisal, we have dates to the 26th September. The Campeachy armed brig Union was still sailing back and forth in the port of Sisal.

Mrs. Dr. Rush, a lady celebrated in the fashionable world, died, as telegraph has already announced, at Saratoga last week, after an illness of two months, She was the wife of Dr. James Rush, of Philadelphia, and daughter of the late Jacob Ridgeway. She spent several years in Europe, and was the charm of the social circle in which she moved.

My dispatch of Friday overning in relation to Mr. HASKIN'S efforts to secure employment for the mechanies at the Brooklyn Navy-Yard, was bungled in the transmission. It is the Brandwine, and not the Savannah, which the Secretary of War proposes to have altered, into a propeller, with a view to keeping the men employed, who have completed the Inst-named vessel.

The trotting match between the Taylor and Dalton horses, Doctor and Broker, at Bridgeport, Conn., on Friday last, was won by the Dalton horse, in 1 hour, 32 minutes and 36 seconds. The Taylor horse broke badly during the race, and on the last home-stretch ran by the other, coming in a neck ahead. His running, however, disqualified him for taking the purse, and the judges decided in favor of Broker. oker.

JOHNSON.--In Brooklyn, on Saturday, Oct. 24, WILLIAM D. JOHNSON, aged 35 years. The funeral will take place from his late residence. No. 288 Dean st., on Tuesday, at 11 o'clock A. M. The friends of the family, and of Truman Smith and Jas. H. Welsh, are respectfully invited to attend, without further invitation. The remains will be taken to Newark, N. J. for interment.

Fanuil Hall was well filled to-night by the supporters of the Hon. N. P. HANKS. The meeting was presided over by JOHN P. PUTNAM, Esq., assisted by CHARLES HALE, S. A. BRADBURY and numerous others. The Secretaries were J. R. MARSH and A. H. HARDY. Addresses were made by the President and by Hon. GIDEON HAYNES and others.
SETTLED.--In the Sixth Assembly District in Brooklyn the Democracy placed in nomination two candidates: EDWARD DRIGGS and JOHN HANFORD. Mr. DRIGGS withdrew, and leaves a clear held for Mr. HANFORD.

ATLANTIC STEAMERS.--The Vanderbilt went to sea on Saturday, with an enormous crowd of passengers--nearly six hundred. The Atlantic was to have sailed at the same hour, but a serious fracture in her machinery was discovered at the last moment, which will detain her three or four days.

We have stirring financial news by the Baltic. On the arrival out of the Persia from this side, the Bank of England Directors met on Monday, Oct. 12, and advanced the rate of discount to seven per cent., making a rise of 1 1/2 per cent. in four days.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--Every one will be delighted to hear that. this popular place of amusement reopens for the Winter season on Wednesday next. The times are not sufficiently hard to reconcile us to an entire abnegation of Italian opera, and we are sure if conducted with spirit the management will enjoy the best patronage of the public.

A horrible murder, by slaves, occurred last week in Alabama. Mr. R. E. STEWART, a planter residing ten miles from Livingston, was assassinated while in his bed. His overseer, eighteen years old, late on Friday evening reported to the Sheriff of this County, D. L. AYRES, that his employer was missing, and that he had apprehensions that Mr. STEWART had met with a sad fate.

CAMDEN AND AMBOY RAILROAD TRANSPORTATION LINE. Through freights, to the South and West, of dry goods and merchandise had fallen off during October, as compared with the three weeks of the same month last year, about 20 per cent., as near as they can judge in anticipation of the monthly accounts. The freights inward, for the first eighteen days of October, have fallen off about 15 per cent.

Mrs. Ruff, the wife of a citizen of Mount Pleasant township, Westmoreland county, Penn., comitted suicide on the 5th inst., by hanging herself in a room adjoining her bedroom. Cause, insanity from religious excitement. Heathely Randall, of Bowdoinham, Me., committed suicide by drowning himself in the river at Bowdoinham village, on Saturday last; he was 42 years of age, a man of steady habits. .

The following is the Weekly Report of Deaths in the City and County of New-York, from the 17th day of October to the 24th day of October, 1857: Mon, 77 ; Women, 84; Boys, 140; Girls, 126: Total, 467, Adulls, 161 Children, 266; Males, 217; Females, 210; Colored Persons, 8.

THE TRIAL OF CUEVA, the young Spaniard, for the murder of OSCAR DR GRANDVAL, of Hoboken, will be commenced in the Hudson County Court, Judge OGDEN presiding, this (Monday) morning. The case will be conducted for the State by Attorney General DAYTON and Prosecuting Attorney LITTLE. The Counsel for the prisoner are Messrs. SCUDDER and ZABRISKIE.

Captain VAN VLEIT, from Utah Sept. 14, arrived here inst night. He reports having met the troops composing the Utah Expedition, Sept 22, two hundred and thirty miles beyond Fort Laramie--all well. He also met Colonel JOUNSTON, Oct. 18, ninety miles from Fort Laramic, and Governor CUMMING, Oct. 8, ninety miles beyond Fort Kearney.

FIRE AT GRAND OR TOUR, ILLINOIS--LOSS $60 000.--The extensive plow factory of Messrs. ANDRUS BOSWORTH, at Grand de Tour, III., was boned on the 13th inst. They had on hand about $20,000 worth of plows, that were all ready for market, all of which were consumed, together with all of the expensive and labor-saving machinery that they had in operation.

The wind yesterday morning was from N. N. E., with occasional rain. During Sunday night it blew at intervals from N. E. very heavy. The vessels at anchor in the North Biver and at Quarantine dragged their anchors, but without receiving any damage. The tide, in consequence of the N. E. wind, was very high, flooding a number of the plers on the east side of the town.

CASTLE GARDEN--ARRIVALS OF EMIGRANTS CHOLERA AT QUARANTINE.--The number of passengers reported arrived at Castio Garden during the year, to October inst., was 116,071. The number in September was 20,187, including 861 American citizens returned from abroad. The number of passenger vessels arrived was 69. The number of vesscis arrived in October to the 24th inclusive was 44, bringing 11,789 passengers.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: My attention has been called to an inquiry in your issue of the 23d inst., over the signature of "Raiment," as to the proper places to send cast-off clothing, , for distribution among the needy. You answer the inquiry by naming the "Children's Aid Society," a most excellent Association and admirably conducted;

In ship Sebarlion Cabot, for Melbourne, Australia-Thompson Sloan, N.Y.: Mrs. Rodman, Mr. and Mrs. Jones and family, Buffalo: Mr, and Mrs. Murphy. Mr. and Mrs. Pendergast. C. Coyn, Tenneesse: Mrs. O'Brien and daughter, Mrs. C. Leroy. Mr. And Mrs. Jones and family, Miss Davis. Mr. and Mrs. Robinson, New-York: Mr. and Mrs. Willetts and family. Mr. Tate, Buffalo: Thomas Taylor. Thomas Howard. J. J. Drew, John Cogan M. Thompson. W. Eger, P. Welsh, T. Mulcanby.

Among the multiplicity of reports hourly reaching us of frauds in the late elections, the interference of Missourians, soldiers voting, and other grave charges against Governor WALKER, we have thought it but just to the Governor and the public that we should inquire late them, and give our readers the result of our own investigations.

The Massachusetts Corporation run their works four days in the week, and have stock in hand to last till January. The Boston Traveller contradicts the report that the Directors have voted to stop. The Salisbury Manufacturing Company have reduced the pay of operatives 15 per cent.

The Board of Aldermen met last evening. Aldermen McSPRDON in the chair. The first paper of interest was the following. COMMUNICATION FROM STEPHEN R. BRANCH. To His Honor the Mayor, and Common Counsel of the City of New-York--GENTLEMEN: Your petitioner respectfully represents that your Finance Committee received him with cordiallity, for which he is extrentely gratetful,

ORIGIN OF THE CHICAGO FIRE.--The testimony produced at the Coroner's Inquest on the bodies of the victims of the Chicago fire, develops some starting facts. It appears that the upper floors of the stores burned on Water-street were occupied by young men as sleeping-apartments. A number of those young men were clerks in the stores.

A man named John Fee, living near Bullock's Creek, S. C., in a fit o anger, shot his horse and some cattle and hogs, and on Sunday set fire to his house, which he had previously locked. His three motherless children, aged from 5 to 14 years of age, are supposed to have perished in the flames. A peace warrant was issued against him by a neighbor, and an officer went to serve it;

MORALITY IN BROOKLYN.--The deaths during the week ending Saturday last membered 87, of which 52 were meles and 36 females Of the whole number 19 were men, 33 boys, 12 women, and 23 girls. DISEASES.--Marasmus, 11; convensions, 8; Consumption, 7; Disease of brain. 7; Inflammation of lungs, 6; Debility, 4; Diarrhoea, 4; Congestion of lungs, 3; Dynsentery, 3; Searles fever, 3; Stillborn, 3;

If the political season was never, as people say, known to be so dull as In the present Fall campaign,--if, In other words, the panic has killed polltles,-we can readily believe that for the last three days the weather has garroted the panic. It may recover again-It undoubtedly will; but It has suffered a severe encounter, and got the worst of It.

The so called health-seekers of the spas of Germany begin to return to town, evidently more recuperated in blood molecules than in molecules of gold. The totally bankrupt form a large majority of the homeward emigration. NEW HISTORICAL WORK ON THE REIGN OF THE LATE CZAR NICHOLAS --A work on the advent to the throne of the Czar NICHOLAS I., edited by ?? KORFF, Secretary of State, Councillor of the I mire and Director of the Imperial Library at St. Petersburg, has recently appeared in the Russian Capital, where it has made considerable sensation. .

Governor WALKER'S requests to have the United States troops detained in Kansas during the coming Winter indicates his fear that their services may be required and, therefore, that the troubles in the Territory are not altogether at an end.

The importance of having clean, wholesome and healthy bread, produced economy and dispatch, cannot be overrated, and as our attention has lately been called to the apparatus of M. ROLLAND, which is now used extensively in France, and also throughout the continent of Europe, and to a limited extent in this City, we have deemed it pertinent to present the features of its claimed superiority.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Among the most intimate of my friends during my three years' traveling in Russia, was the Counsel or of State and celebrated naturalist, NURDHAN, of Odessa, by birth from Abo, In Fin and, and his brother, at that time, (1840 to 1843) Adjutant of Admiral MENSBIUKOFF, now Admiral himself.

SITE FOR A NEW-YORK POST-OFFICE.--We hope that some steps will be promptly taken towards the selection and purchase of a site, and tile erection of a building, for a New-York Post-Office. The whole matter rests In the hands of the President, who is authorized by law to purchase a site at a price not exceeding $500,000.

MISSING.--Our advertising columns have already noticed the very singular disappearance of Mr. E. H. HOWELL, of this City, who has been missing since Monday, the 19th Inst. He was about forty years of age, of medium height, and were dark clothing, with a brown Raglan overcoat.

The Columbue Statesman of Saturday says; "About 7 o'clock, last night, a fire commenced in the north range of work-shops in the Ohio Penitentiary, and had made such progress before It was discovered, that it was impossible to arrest it until the entire range was in ruins.

There seems little reason to doubt that the Free-State Party have carried the Territorial Legislature in Kansas, as well as the Congressional Delegate. It is conceded on all sides that unless the fraudulent vote in Johnson County is allowed to give that District to the Democrats, they have no chance of controlling either branch of the Legislature,

The monthly meeting of this Association was held on Monday evening at the Chapel of the University. Mr. CEPHAS BRAIMARD was called to the Chair, and Mr. EUGINE THOMPSON was elected Secretary. After the usual introductory exercises new members were proposed. The Corresponding Secretary stated that a meeting of Goo had been held in Lawrence, Mass., and addressed by the Mayor.

The success of the Free-State men in Kansas would now see?? to be fully assured, both in the election of Mr. PARROTT as Delegate to Congress, and in the return of a majority of both branches of the Legislature. A protest, which we publish elsewhere this morning, signed by several prominent citizens of Kansas,

It follows as a matter of course, in all times of difficulty, that an immediate investigation should be made into the causes of the disorders from which the community suffers. Divers are the sources to which the present financial troubles have been traced, and among them long credits have been supposed by many to be the most profile of disasters.

From the Buffalo Commercial Advertiser. The following extract from a letter from an officer in the army will be read with interest: FORT KEARNEY, N. T., Sunday, Oct. 4, 1857. The Commandant for the Department of Utah passed here Thursday a week since--a very pleasant gentleman indeed, Col. A. S. JOHNSON, of the 2d Cavalry Regiment, now in Texas.

We notice in the proceedings of the Convention of New-York Country Bankers at Syracuse a few days since, that an apprehension was expressed that the accumulation of Country circulation in and near the City would prove inconvenient, perhaps, disastrous to many of the Bankers on the resumption of specie payments.

The following letter, addressed to the Commissioner of Patents at Washington, contains in.. formation of a good deal of general interest, in as much as it shows that granulated sugar may be produced from tech Chinese plant recently introduced into this country, and which had already been proved to be of so great value for the molassen it yields as well as for fodder for cattle:

LOCAL, FOREIGN MISSIONARY SOCIETY,--The thirtieth anniversary of the New-York and Brooklyn Foreign Missionary Society, auxiliary to the American Board of Commissioners of Foreign Missions, was held on Sunday evening in the South Presoyterian Church, Brooklyn.

It is now very nearly ten years since the whole of Europe was shaken by a revolutionary earthquake. The laboring classes of the Continent, exe ted to frenzy by the declamations of philathropists who loved their race not wisely but too well, and who sympathized with the sorrows without comprehending the nature of mankind,

From the Chicago Times, Saturday. Masters of vessels which arrived at this port yesterday bring the sad intelligence of the total wreck of the Canadian steamer Remdeer, Captain PATTERSON, and the loss of all but two of the lives on board. The Remdeer ran between this port and Montreal. She cleared from this port on Friday, the 16th inst. with 13,000 bushels of wheat, consigned to parties in Montreal.

THE BLUE RIDGE TUNNEL.--In reply to statements that the tunnel through the Blue Ridge at Rock fish Gap, Va., is too small to admit the passage of the cars, and that it will take from three to eighteen months to enlarge it sufficiently, Mr. CROZET, the engineer of the work, publishes the following explanation: "The tunnel is elliptical and closes in towards the top.

Up many flights of crazy stairs, Where oft one's head knocks, unawares; With a rickety table, and without chairs, And only a stool to kneel to prayers, Dwells my sister. There is no carpet upon the floor, The wind whistles in through the cracks of the door; One night reckon her miseries by the score, But who feels interest in one so poor? Yet she is my sister.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I find, in the Times of this morning, that Mr. JAMES REA avows himself the author of the charge of cruelty made in a previous communication against Captain PARAMALEE, of the ship Middlesex, during he voyage from Liverpool in February last.

THE STREET COMMISSIONERSHIP.--The decision of Judge PEABODY, which was rendered on Friday last, in relation to the Street Commissionership, puts the office into the hands of the Governor's appointee, Mr. CONOVER, who is now in charge; but the Attorney-General having granted permission for a writ of quo warranto,

The steamship Borussia, from Hamburg on 1st of October, arrived at this port yesterday morning. On the 6th inst., in a fearful hurricane when north of Scotland, the Borussia broke one blade of the propeller and proceeded to Greenock to repair.

The Washington States has the following: "It is reported that BRIGHAM YOUNG and his people have determined to resist the outrange of the United States troops into the Mormon Territory and threaten to burn the grass on the prairies, and, if necessary, to destroy their own city in order to deprive the ?? of shelter during the Winter. The report accords with threats from Young which were thrown out in Mormon newspapers.

A CENTRAL RELIRVING HOUSE.-A very sensible movement has been made in Boston, with a view to the relief of the poor during the coming Season, which might be imitated here with great advantage to all classes of the community. The plan in question is the etalishment of a central house, or office,

MY DEAR FRIEND: Long ere this note come to hand you will have heard of the terrible state o things in India. I would have written to you sooner concerning it, were it not that I was anxlous to ascertain the fate of some of our dear missionary brothren in the Northwest, whose lives we knew were in mminent peril.

Before Judge Thourpeon. Pfeiffer of Tafel vs. Joseph Firkles.--The plaintills are lawyers at Stuttgard, and sue the Iandlord of the Shakespeare Hotel, in this City, to recover about 500. In 1849 it appears that Firkles was indicted in Stuttgard for an insult to the Majesty of the King, for which he was arrested and imprisoned.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: With reference to the publication by the Committee of the Corporation of my name among others as a debtor to the City, will you allow me to say: That I held by election of the people the office of Collector of Taxes for the First Ward, from 1833 to 1844, at a stated salary.

There was a meeting of Democrats of the Sixth Senatorial District at Jefferson Market Assembly Rooms, last evening, to ratify the nomination of RICHARD SCHELL (brother of the Collector) for State Senator, Speeches were made by Ex-Senator MOMURRAY, T. F. MEAGHER, HIRAM WALESIDGE, Col. MINO and others.

In steamship Borussia, from Hamburg--Alfred Tackermann, Helene Maan, F. Hoffman, W. H. Westervelt. H. Funhe and family, G. Crumer, A. M. Keller and family, A. Eidelberg. In steamship Roanoke, from Norfolk, Petersburg and Richmond--W. E. Alcock, Wm. J. Evans, D. Salomon, W. G. M. Davis, Miss Langley. W. H. Morris, P. Smith, Wm.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I find in your paper a communication over the signature of "Carlos," a pretended Nicaraguan, insinuating that Mr. IRISARRI, Minister from Guatemala and Salvador, and also appointed representative of Nicaragua, has been sold, as well as General JERRE, to Mr. WHITE.

From the States. The following dispatch was telegraphed to the Postmaster General a few minutes before we went to press: NEW-YORK, Oct. 24.--It is said that the Atlantic has broken her machinery, and will not be able to sail, Mr. VANDERBILT offers to take the mails and de ver them at Liverpool on the same terms as are allowed to the Collins line. The Vanderbilt has steam up and is waiting your answer. .

The Executive Committee appointed to distribute the Central America relief fund have decided to make donations to the Captain, officers and crew of the brig Marine, of Boston, as follows: Captain, $600; first officer, $100; second officer, $80; first cook, $70; second cook, $50; four seamen, $20 each; also a gold watch to the Captain, and a silver medal to each of the officers.

Crawford, the Sculptor. The steamer Baltic brought the painful intelligence, which has been anticipated the past two months, of the death of our distinguished country-man. THOMAS CRAWFORD, the Sculptor. He died in London on the morning of the 10th of October, in the 44th year of his age, and we learn that his body will be sent to New-York by the steamer Avaga.

We have previously noticed the resolution of the Virginia Synod to withdraw from further connection with the General Assembly of the New-School Presbyterian Church. The Synod subsequently resolved to cooperate in the organization of the "United Synod," to meet at Knoxville in April next. Among the prominent debaters was Rev, Dr. Boyd, who has occupied a leading position throughout this controversy.

If it were possible for any one to doubt the hardness of the times, and the almost general suspension of business, the skeptic, whoever he might be, would only to take a survey of the business portion of the City south of Wall-street. He might fancy at first that the Mayor had enforced the City ordinance against encountering the sidewalks, for nowhere in such streets as Broad, Beaver, Pearl, Exchange-place.

The Republican publishes a discourse delivered by HEBER C. KIMBALL, of Salt Lake City, Aug. 30, in which strong grounds are taken against the United States Government, and a determination is expressed to resist their troops to the last extremity.

WORTHY OF CONSIDERATION,---The average annual imports of cotton and woolen manufactures are about fifty millions of dollars ; the average annual imports of iron, manufactures of iron and steel are about twenty-five millions of dollars ; the average annual imports of manufactures of silk are about twenty-five millions of dollars ; total one hundred millions. There is no actual necessary for importing a dollar's worth of cotton and woolen goods, because we manufacture them ourselves;

LAURA KEENE'S THEATRE-- A play of remarkable denseness, and unusual specific gravity was produced here last night. It is called "Birds of Prey," and comes from the pen of M. WRAY, who. according to the play-bill, in "a young dramatic author of great promise,"...fortunately, for us, located in London.

THE TWO WOODS--The Tribune paid an unintentional complement to Mayor Wood, yesterday, by comparing him with WILLIAM WOOD, who was the built of Dean Swift's drapier's Letters. The Tivine says. "We beg leave to remind our excellent mayor of the hubbub which a namesake of his occasioned Ireland a century and more ago,

FIRE IN JAMES-STREET--TWELVE HORSES BURNED.--About 2 o'clock yesterday morning a fire broke out in the rear of No. 93 James-street, in a row of frame stables, owned by JAMES CAMPBELL, and occupied by several cartmen. When the firemen arrived at the place there was such a dense smoke in the alley-way leading to the stables that they were unable to effect an entrance and the stables were accordingly entirely destroyed.

DEPARTURE OF THE DREANOUGHT FOR IRELAND--A DANCING VNONGEL--The clipper ship Dread nought, Captain SAMULES, sailed for Liverpool on Saturday, with the largest cargo of passengers ever known to return on an emigrant ship--350. The Dreadnought has become famous for short passages, which may partly account for her fall complement' but the band of music employed on board to "discourse" sweet music, and play the old familiar tunes

We have received a letter from a gentleman in Kentucky, setting forth at considerable length various circumstances which induce had to want a wife. As his object is partly to relieve the distress which just at present prevails to so great an extent among the honest, industrious females of this City, we feel bound to aid his endeavors by all the means in our power;

PASSING COUNTERFEIT MONEY.--Two men, giving their names as James Davenport and Charles S. Wheaton, were arrested yesterday for attempting to pass counterfeit $ 10 bills on the Gloucester Bank, Mass. James Davenport, the first party arrested, attempted to pass one of the bills at the hostery store of James K. Peyton, No. 204 Bowery.

The returns of the lowa election come in very slowly, though enough is known to insure the.success of the Republicans. In forty-six counties, from which the official vote has been received, LOWE, for Governor, is 2,237 ahead. Complete returns from Minnesota show the election of SIBLEY, Domocrat, for Governor, by a majority of 123.

THE POST-OFFICE DEPARTMENT AND THE FOREIGN MAIL--The Atlantic sailed yesterday, with the mails which ought to have gone on Saturday,--and which could have gone by the Vanderbilt, but for the extraordinary action of the Post-Office Department at Washington.

BANKS AND BANKING.--The Philadelphia Press, commenting upon the suggestion that the present financial difficulties show the necessity of a national Bank, says: "The only effect of this movement in favor of reviving a mammoth bank will be to direct the people's attention to such an alteration of the Federal Constitution as will remove this whole business of making a currency from the State,

The Administration has acceded to Governor WALKER requeetfor the retention of the military forces In Kansas all Winter, and orders will be issued accordingly. Capt. VAN VLIRY, of the Army, arrived here tonight, with Information for the War Department relative to the Mormon movements of resistance to the United States troops.

The Coroner's inquest in the case of HENRY DODD, who died recently at the Hatfield House, in Grand-street, from the effects of a beating by a gang of rowdies, was resumed yesterday, by Coroner CONNERY. A large number of witnesses were examined, a majority of whom knew nothing of the affair.

DEAR SIR: We, the President, officers and members of the Liverpool Garrick Club, desire meet respectfully to tender you our hearty thanks for the very admirable lecture on "The Pulpit and the Stage delivered by you at the Academy of Music, in the City of New York.

The storm which commenced Saturday night, raged unabated yesterday. Rain fell almost all day, though at distant Intervals the clouds seemed ready to break away. The wind was northeast, however, at midnight, just as it was in the morning, with no promise of a clearing up.

Yesterday was the second day of the trial of this young Cuban, before the Hudson County Court, New-Jersey, Judge OODEN presiding, Though the rain was severe all day, the Court-room was crowded, many Iadies being in the audience, CUEVA was press. ent, apparently an Interested but not an anxious spectator. His father was present, too, but deep anxiety .

ACCESSIONS TO THE UNION.--It is very probable that early in the approaching session of Congress three new States will apply to be admitted into the Union, and become coequal and coordinate members of the Confederacy. The aspirants for this honor are the Territories of Oregon, Minnesota and Kensas. Of these Minnesota alone has finally adopted a Constitution--the Conventions of the other two being now at work framing their fundamental law.

The telegraph announces that the declared intention of Governor WALKER and Secretary STANTON to reject the returns of the votes from Oxford, in Johnson County, and thus defeat the fraud which was there attempted, has "created an intense excitement among the Pro-Slavery men" in Kansas.

A GRIEVANCE THAT NEEDS ATTENTION.--The Common Council owes it to the public, as well as to STEPHEN H. BRANCH, to put an end to his eternal petitions for the money which he claims at their hands. If it is due him, let it be paid; if not, let that fact be shown and certified once for all.

POLITICAL.-The Republicans of Kings County hold their Mass Ratification Meeting in Museum Hall, corner of Fulton and Orange streets, Brooklyn, Thursday evening, lion. ADIJAH MANN, Jr., Gen. H. B, DURYEA, and other distinguished speakers, will address the meeting,

Madame DE BIENVILLE, an American lady who has acquired a musical education and a husband in France, gave an entertainment last evening at DOSWORTH'S Rooms. Madame BIENVILLE is a profile at on the plano-forte, which she has studied in the conservatories of Paris and Marseilles. She is more than an ordinary player and from natural taste and enthusiasm inclines to the classical in art.

HOUGHTON--In this City, on Tuesday morning, Oct. 27, HENRY HARRISON HOUGHTON, (of the firm of H. H. Houghton Co., No. 1 Maiden-lane,) aged 36 years, 8 months and 27 days. Notice of funeral in to morrow's (Thursday's) papers. STODDARD.--In this City, on Monday, Oct. 26. CAROLINE M. STODDARD, wife of Neah Stoddard, in the 39th year of her age.

ANOTHER MURDER IN BALTIMORE.--Last evening another of those sanguinary scenes with which our city has recently been disgraced, occurred at the High Street Hotel, of Mr. THOMAS DUKEHART, on High-street, near Baltimore. As at present advised, we have no account of any cause of a difficulty, but the result was the shooting into death of Mr. JEROME WAME, by, it is said, Mr. JOHN CLAGETT.

At Portland, on Friday night, two brothers, Coin by name, who have recently been confined in Alfred Jail for an assault, attempted to enter the house of a widow in Limerick. She raised a window and called for help, to which Mr. JOHN BROWN, a farmers, responded, and on going to the assistance of the woman, was stabbed so that he died almost instantly.

SUPPOSED INCENDIARY FIRE AT CINCINNATI--About 7 o'clock on Friday evening last an explosion took place in the extensive Sugar Refinery of KILBERT, MCKENZIL, Co., on Pearl-street, between Plum and Western-row, Cincinnati, and flames were immediately after seen bursting from the fifth story of the building. Mrs. LOFTY keeps a carriage, So do I; She has dapple greys to draw it, None have I; With my blue-eyed laughing baby, Trundling by, I hide his face, last she should see The cherub boy and envy me.

There is a region of Missouri of rapidly rising fame and importance, gaining for itself a State and a National reputation, which we will define as the "Region of the hemp culture." Specially favored by nature?? geographical locally, climate, navigation. and superintive fertility, this region has become the seat of a hemp culture which has a strong, ?? and National foundation.

The Farmer of the popular imagination is a man possessed not only of all the sturdy virtues which ennoble humanity, but also of all the solid elements of wealth which make a nation prosperous. The farm is regarded as the chief prop of society and the backbone of the country.

A remarkable case of the careful preservation of bank bills came to light in Middletown, Ct., about two weeks since. John Cone, who resides near Haddam, appeared at the counter of the Middletown Bank with 1,000 of its bills, and asked for the specie, which was promptly given to him.

An annual Agricultural Exhibition, inaugurated a few years ago under the auspices of a society denominated the "Virginia and North Carolina Agricultural Society," is being held here at present, and will close to-day. The period usually chosen for this exhibition is the week preceding the State Fair at Richmond, and to this is owing any little success which it may have acquired.

We continue to receive great numbers of communications in regard to the approaching City Election. We beg our correspondents to understand that, if we decline publishing them, it is not. for lack of merit in them and still less from any want of Interest on our part in the Election of MAYOR and other municipal offi cers,-but merely because we do not deem the present moment best suited to a profitable discussion of the subject.

The Business Directory gives the names of seventy-two distilling-houses within the City limits. Not one-tenth of this number, however, are genuine distilleries. Many establishments that hang out the sign "Distillery," "Liquor Rectifying," and all that, really are only three-cent rum-shops--retailers of bad wines, that sadly "need a bush."

RETURN OF A MORMON FARMER FROM THE SALT LAKE--A yeoman, who joined the Mormons two years ago, has lately come back to Ormskirk. he has had wonderful adventures, meeting with tribes of Indians and was astonished to see the women riding on little horses as they did in the days of Queen ELIZABETH, or like the rougher sex in modern days.

REID FORGERIES AT WESTCHESTER.--This community, was thrown into a high state of excitement on Monday morning of last week, by certain of our citizens finding themselves the victims of a series of hard and impudent forgeries, perpetrated by C. M. LAYMAN, somewhat celebrated recently as one of the constables concerned in the attempt to arrest WM. BAUGH, of West Pikeland, and which it will be remembered terminated in the killing of BAUGH.

The contest for the prizes offered by the Chess Congress to the best players is at present in the following condition. In the Grand Tournament the players are reduced to four, all of whom are winners of prizes. They have been drawn as follows : 1 Mr. MORPHY against Mr. LICHTENHEIN. 2, Mr. PAULSIN against Mr. RAPHAEL.

The Utah expedition is making fine progress, the advance being by this time within 300 miles of Salt Lake City. The following items concerning its movements will, no doubt, be found interesting: On the 5th of September the advance, consisting of eight companies of the 10th Infantry, numbering some 600 men, in command of Col. ALEXANDER, left this Fort, having rested here three days.

We suppose that our people will have to prepare for sundry reproofs and other hard things from their late friends in Europe. Some of the passengers by the recently arrived steamers intimate that British and Continental indignation is already being bottled up in regard to the American panic, and tile market of which European industry is to be deprived thereby.

THE BLACK ART.-Every one has seel or heard of the great ROBERT HOUDIN. Besides being the prince of conjurors, he is an able mathematician and mechanician, and his electric clock, made for the Hotel de Ville, of his native town of Blots, obtained a medal at the Paris Exhibition.

The Board of Governors of the Almshouse held their ordinary weekly meeting of the Rotunda, on Tuesday. The President, C. GODFREY GUNTHER, Esq., in the chair. Next Tuesday being election day, the Board decided to meet on the day before,--Monday instead of Tuesday.

This popular place of amusement (really popular for there was a better attendance last night than we have seen at a theatre for some months) proceeds steadily from one triumph to another. We have recently recorded the success of "Past and Present," with the truly splendid acting of Mr. BLAKE. Then came "Caprice," a charming comedy, with an excellent part for Mr. LESTER, and now the "Invisible Husband."

By letters from our London correspondent. received by the Persiu, we learn that the British Government has decided to appoint a Special Minsister to negotiate a settlement of the remaining differences betweenEngland and this country in regard to Central American affairs. The appointment will take place early next year, and possibly sooner.

A dismasted ship showing the signal numbers of the Comoro, from Sumatra for Boston, is at anchor two miles northeast of Cohasset. She lies easy. The Board of Underwriters will send a steamer to her assistance immediately. WRECK OF THE BRITISH SHIP KOSSUTH, ETC. WASHINGTON, Wednesday, Oct. 28.

An affray occurred yesterday upon the cars near Chambersburg, between Mr. McKIBBON, member of Congress from California, and ISAAC CRAIG, his brother-in-law. The latter has incurred the enmity of his whole family by the seduction of his wife's sister, a deaf and dumb girl, several years since. The parties met accidentally for the first time since the occurrence.

The controversy concerning the Street Commissioner is taking a curious shape. It will be remembered that Mr. DEVLIN took possession of the office, and held it a day or two at the outset of the contest. The clerks and heads of bureaus appointed by him brought an action some two months since in Justice O' CONNOR'S Court against the Corporation for their salaries.

GEORGE R. COWEE, EDWARD PRICE and JACOB STANTON have been arrested here in connection with forgeries embracing the circulation of some unsound bank notes, stolen a few months since from the New-England Bank-Note Company. The amount thus spuriously circulated does not probably exceed $7,000. The parties were held to bail for trial.

Captain VAN VLIET had an interview with the President to-day, and detailed at length the condition of affairs at Salt Lake, and the treasonable disposition of the Mormons. The Captain went out as Quarter-master of the Utah Expedition, to endeavor to contract with the Mormons for Army supplies, and to procure reliable evidence for the President relative to the condition of affairs there.

Budington, Mr. SANFORD JOHNSON, of Chicago, III., to MISS MART BETTS.

By way of England we have received advices from Buenos Ayres to Sept. 1, Montevideo to Sept. 6, and Rio Janeiro to Sept. 14. No political news from Buenos Ayres. Business in general dull, and hardly any freight for vessels. The Money market had a downward tendency. Latest quotation: Spanish dollars, 24 currency; doubloons, 324 each.

The steamship Persia passed Cape'Race on Sunday morning last at 2 o'clock, and, with the light bearing north five miles, she stopped her engines, and threw up rockets to attract thc attention of the News Yacht of the Associated Press, but as that craft was not in sight, the news parcel was thrown overboard, according to directions, and she passed on, arriving here at 11 o'clock yesterday,

POLITICAL -- The Republicans of the Fifth Assembly District held a Mass Ratification meeting last evening at the Bleecker building, at which the nominations of JAMES C. PINENEY for State Senator, and J. B. STEVENS for Assemblyman were indorsed. The meeting was large and enthusiastic, and was frequently enlivened by music and applause.

CORRECTION.--We are assured that the statement made of the lad arrested on Tuesday for stealing books from the Apprentices' Library, to the effect that Mr. BEADEURN, to whom he sold them, "used to tell him what books to get," is utterly false.

AN OPPORTUNITY FOR THE OMNIBUSES.--We have been deluding ourselves with an idea, for some time past, which the public, we believe, have also been rolling like a sweet morsel in their imaginations, that the omnibuses would make a reduction in their fare as soon as an opportunity offered for them to do it gracefully.

Another meeting of the Directors and Stock and Bondholders of the Eric Railroad was held last night in the Lecture Room of Clinton Hall, Astor-place. The attendance was very considerable. Mr. CHARLES A. DAVIS took his seat as Chairman. Mr. LATHERS was presented to the assemblage to resort, progress. His reception was very enthusiastic.

Notwithstanding the postponement of the Disunion Convention, over 100 delegates from nine or ten States met here, and organized to-day. MARIUS ROBINSON, of Ohio, was appointed President, and Vice-Presidents were selected from each Free State. Business Committees were appointed. Addresses were made by Mr. PARKER, of Pitisburg, AEBRY KELLY FOSTER, and others.

To the People of Kansas: By the 32d section of the organic act establishing this Territorial Government, it is provided in reference to the election of a delegate to Congress, that "the person having the greatest number of votes and a certificate thereof shall be given accordingly."

THE HARLEM RAILROAD COMPANY--USE OF STEAM BELOW FORTY-SECOND-STREET.--It is now nearly three years since the Common Council adopted an ordinance prohibiting the Harlem Railroad Company from bringing their steam engines below Forty-second-street, and giving them eighteen months to make arrangements for its discontinuance.

Postmaster-General BROWN, having made an offer to the city authorities of New-York of two hundred and fifty thousand dollars for a Post-Office site in the Park, Mayor WOOD addressed a communication to him, in reply, stating positively that it could not be had, and that the Common Council passed a resolution declaring that they had no power or authority to sell the Government any property for such a purpose.

COSTLINESS OF PUBLIC BENEVOLENCE.--We do not apprehend there is much danger of Mayor WOOD'S stupendous scheme for relieving the wants of the poor, by having the City government enter into the retail provision trade, and thus raining the thousands who now derive their subsistence from it, being adopted.

It is not in this country alone that the necessity of curtailing the cost of living has forced itself upon the attention of the political economist and the conservators of the public morals; neither is it in this country alone that the greater share of the blame for the extra-vagancies of the times has been ruthlessly thrown upon the shoulders of the weaker sex.

The Board of Commissioners of the Metropolitan Police of Broome and Elm streets. This is a capacious and elegant structure, formerly known as the Mondon Hotel, and is admirably adapted for its present purposes. All the members were in attendance, General NEW, as presiding officer, being in the Chair.
CARSON-MOORE..-In this City, on Tuesday, Oct. 27, by Rev, Dr. Cooke, JOSEPH CARSON, of Baltimore, to MATILDA G., only daughter of William Moore, Esq., of St. Croix, W.I.

A steam-boiler in HEYWARD'S India Rubber Works exploded this morning, and the fine buildings constituting the works were destroyed. Two hundred people were at work in the establishment at the time. Many of the girls jumped out of the windows, and some of them were injured, but not very seriously. The boiler was thrown three hundred feet, and in its course carried away the side of a house where the family were at breakfast.

Gov. LIGON issued a proclamation this morning placing the City under Martial Law, and ordering out two divisions. Some 7,000 men and their commanding officers are ordered to enrol at once and report for service by Saturday, and hold themselves in readiness to preserve the peace on Wednesday next, the day of the general election.

The Board of Aldermen met last evening, President CLANCY in the Chair. Alderman DRAKE presented a petition from the residents on and near the route of the Hudson River Railroad, for City cars to be placed on that road, The petition was referred, Petitions were received from the Historical Society and the Church of St. Ann, for two gas-lamps In front of each of their buildings. Referred.
