TWO BURGLARS ARRESTED.--The hardware store No. 96 Duane-street, it will be recollected, was entered a few nights since by two burglars, one of whom stabbed Officer DEGETT while attempting to arrest him, and, together with the other, made good his escape. The officers of the Fifth Ward have since been on the look-out for the burglars,

Messrs. GEO. W. WARREN, BARRY CO., well known dry goods dealers on Washington-treet, and WM. A. BROWN, Jr., Co., dry goods importers in Pearl-street, are reported as having failed. L. L. SADDLER, formerly and for several years the Manager, under F. O. J. SMITH, of the morse Telegraph Line between this City and New-York, and subsequently Treasurer and Secretary of the Union Telegraph Company, died suddenly last night.

Hon. CALER CUSMISO made and elaborate and able speech at a Democratic meeting in Boston on Monday night last,--from which we make the following extract, discussing the Kansas question and the Dred Scott decision: FELLOW-CITIZENS: We all know there is a body of persons in this Commonwealth, who devote themselves to the idea of raising the black men in the United States to an equality of political rights with the white men.

Arrival of the Graunda with $356,358 in Specie. The United States mail steamship Granada, GRIFFIN, from New-Orleans on the 20th inst. at 8 A.M., and Havana on the 24th at 7 1/2 A.M., arrived yesterday morning. The Granada has experienced heavy and adverse weather during the entire passage.

THE UNION SEMINARY.--We learn that a portion of tile students of the Union Theological Seminary are suffering from the cutling-off of their usual supplies for the Winter. The Central Education Society cannot make its usual grant of $25 per quarter, the opportunities to teach in the City are diminished, anti the Sunday School Society, crippled by its late mishap at Philadelphia, cannot furnish its usual facilities.

I understand that Governor WALKER'S request to have the United States troops continued in Kansas during the coming Winter, was preferred chiefly in consequence of information that the Pre-Slavery men, exasperated by the result of the late election, are preparing to resort to desperate measures of fraud and violence for the recovery of their lost vantage ground.

The Free-State citizens of Kansas, having determined to hold a meeting in Lecompton, for the purpose of repudiating the action and agency of the bogus Constitutional Convention, a large number of citizens, amounting to several hundred, from all portions of the Territory, assembled at that place on Monday, the 10th inst.
COMMISSIONERS OF EMIGRATION.--The Commissioners of Emigration met in Worth-street on Wednesday, the President GULAM C. VERPLANOK, Esq., in the Chair.

THE HISTORICAL SOCIETY LIBRARY REMOVAL--The Historical Society takes possession of its new building, on Second-avenue, next Thursday evening, with grand ceremonies and speech-making. The building which is of portsmouth stone, the same that the new TIMES building is being constructed of , is fireproof, and cost some $75,000. Not a dollar is due for its. The Library has been closed during October.

STEAM ON THE FOURTH-AVENUE.--On the pending question of the right of the Harlem Railroad Company to run steam on the Fourth-avenue below Forty-second-street, no action has yet been definitely taken. This morning Superintendent TALLMADON will present to the Board of Police Commissioners the opinion of District-Attorney HALL that the offence committed by the Company in running their locomotive to Thirty-first-street is cognizable by the Police.

KANSAS MATTERS. -We have received further news of considerable interest from Kan. sas this morning. The proclamation of Gov. WALKER and Secretary STANTON, rejecting the fraudulent votes of Oxfort Precinct in Johnson County, seems to have roused the ultraists of the Border-Ruffian school to desperation.

The Telegraph, yesterday afternoon, brought us the extraordinary but not altogether inexplicable intelligence that the Governor of Maryland had put the capital city of that State under martial law, and had ordered a force of seven thousand men to hold themselves in readiness to "preserve the peace on Wednesday next, the day of the general election."

THE HOROKEN HOMICIDE.--The trial of FREDER ICX CUEVA, for the murder of OSCAR DE GRANVAL, was continued in the Hudson County Court yesterday. Mr. SOUDDER opened the case for the defence. The first witness was FRANDERICK PERYLLAID, recalled. He told the circumstances of the case with little variation from his former statement. JOSEPH M. ALVORD was called.

The City of Baltimore is to be placed under martial law. Governor LIGON yesterday morning issued a proclamation to this effect, and ordering out two divisions of troops. About 7,000 men and their commanding officers are ordered to enroll at once and report for service by to-morrow, and hold themselves in readiness to preserve the peace on the day of the general election, which takes place on Wednesday next.

By the arrival of the Southern mail we have New-Orleans papers of the 23d, as late as due. The ship Criterion reports having seen a large ship, painted black, with a full poop, ashore on Moselle Shoal, Bahama Banks, on the 19th inst.

The Democracy of the City and County of New-York, met in Tammany Hall last evening, for the purpose of ratifying the Nominations for County Officars. For more than an hour before the time for organizing, band discoursed music from the balcony; and the Marshal's gun did good service in the Park. Before 7 o'clock, there was a very large concourse in front of the Hotel, and at 7 1/2 o'clock,

Mr. E. H. HOWELL, late Grand Master of I. O. of O. F. Southern District of New-York, last seen on Monday, 19th inst. Wore brown Raglan overcoat, dark plaid pants, aged about 40 years, sandy hair and whiskers, first joint right hand fore finger gone. Fearing mental derangement, two hundred dollars reward will be paid to any person returning said HOWELL. Address THOMAS PALMER, No. 83 Duane-street.

GREAT DAMAGE ON THE LINE OF THE OGDENSBURG RAILROAD, ETC. ROUSE'S POINT, Thursday, Oct. 20. The heavy rain storm which commenced on Sunday and continued until Tuesday, has caused immense damage between this place and Malone, On the line of the Ogdensburg Railroad, the track is swept away in several places.

Some of the correspondents of the press Persian in representing Her Britannic Majesty's Minister here as actively engaged in suppressing fillibusterism, by issuing orders to the British squadron in the Gulf of Mexico to Intercept all expeditions of the kind an to send the parties back to the United States. Such reports are exceedingly annoying to Lord NAPIER who has no authority to issue any such orders,

We have received a copy of the resolutions adopted by the meeting held at Lecompton on the 20th of October, to protest against the rejection by GOV. WALKER and Secretary STANTON, of the fraudulent votes cast in Oxford, Johnson County, We publish them because they will enable the public to see upon what grounds this action of Gov. WALKER is to be resisted by the Pro-Slavery faction with whose plans and purposes it has interfered.

POLITICAL PARTISANSHIP.--Hon. GEORGE ASHMUN, a well known and able politician in Massachusetts,--long an active Whig and personal as well as political friend of Mr. WEBSTER, has written, in reply to an invitation to attend a "Banks" meeting in Boston, a letter which expresses some views quite out of the usual channel.

KRAUTH.--In this City, on Thursday, Oct. 29, AUGUSTUS II, KRAUTH, senior proprietor of the New-York Mercury, aged 19 years. The Friends of the family, also the members of New-York Typographical Society, and the members of Enterprise Lodge, I. O. of O. F., are respectfully invited to attend the funeral of the decensed, from his late residence. No. 249 Broome st., on Sunday afternoon, at 2 o'clock. His remains will be interred at Cypress Hills Cemetery.

HUDSON COUNTY OYER AND TERMINER. The Court assembled at 9 1/2 A. M. yesterday. The audience was large, most of it ladies, and manifested a deep interest in the proceedings. The case will probably be closed to-day. The counsel for the prisoner expect to commence summing up this afternoon, and the Jury will probably retire on Monday afternoon.

THE CHESS CONGRESS.--The final contest for the first prize in the grand tournay, in which Messrs. PAUL MORPHY and LOUIS PAULSEN are antagonists, has progressed into the second game, Mr. MORPHY won the first on Thursday ; at 7 P.M. the same day, the second was commenced, and, when we lett last evening, was not yet concluded.

A tour, yesterday, among the Charitable and Criminal Institutions on the Islands, gave us convincing proof that the effect of the hard times has spread into that locally. Not only does the Penitentiary show a large increase in the number of convicts sent up for small crimes, such as theft, assaults and batteries, and the like, but the Workhouse and the Almshouse are full to overflowing.

FIRE.--About 3 o'clock yesterday morning, Private Watehman DOWNS discovered a fire in the carpenter shop of GEORGE DOYLE, in South Ninth-Street. He, together with Officers HIPPLE and MORTON, extinguished it before any material damage was done.

The Governor's proclamation and the correspondence between him and the Mayor still excite public attention. The military officers are enrolling men for various companies, but the work progresses slowly. The Governor is still in the city. BALTIMORE, Friday, Oct. 30--P. M.

The correspondent of the Associated Press at Washington, informs us that previous to the election in Kansas specific instructions were sent out to Governor WALKER on the subject which precluded his right to purge the polls as he has done in the case of the Oxford Precinct of Johnson County.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Since the present financial crisis has set in, some firms have availed themselves of the pressure of the times as an excuse for reducing the wages of their clerks, whose services they had engage I by the year. Besides the illegality of the net, I wish to call your attention to its practical injustice. Clerks, it has been said, should . .

Suicides are uncommonly abundant this Fall Hardly a day passes without the record of two or three. We observe the following not before noticed: At St. Louis, on Saturday last, the body of a young woman was found in a pond at the foot of Miller-street. After some trouble, it was identified as that of BERTHA LEITE, a German girl, 24 years old, lately from New-York,

THE STREET COMMISSIONER.-We publish, in another column, a communication in reply to a paragraph in the TIMES of Thursday, concerning the recent decision of a Justice's Court, that the clerks and employes of Mr. DEVLIN were entitled to payment for their services, and the fact that no appeal from this decision was taken by the Corporation Counsel.

THE ?? OF HENRY DODD.--The inquest in this case was resumed yesterday by Corner CONNERY. A large number of additional witnesses were examined, but the only material fact elicited was that the deceased was strick by a person dressed in the uniform of the ?? Guard. ard.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR: An article appeared in the TIMES on Thursday last, relative to the street Commissioner's case, and the suits brought by the clerks and heads of bureaux, appointed by Mr. DEVLIN, against the Corporation to recover their salaries, which was as unjust to the Counsel to the Corporation, as it is erroneous in its statement of facts. In that article the following language is used:

The following is part of a letter recently written by Mr. ASHUMUN, in reply to an invitation to attend a Banks meeting in Boston: SPRINGFIELD, Saturday, Oct. 24, 1857. SIR: Your letter, in behalf of your Committee, inviting me to be present at the meeting of the friends of Mr. BANKS in Faneuil Hall on the 15th, came during my absence,

To the Editor of the New-York Times: We are upon the eve of the most important Judicial Election which will have transpired within the State under the present Constitution. Allow me to submit, through your columns, my views of the principles by which the citizens of this State should be governed in making their selection of Judges.

The Democrats of Newburyport have nominated on. CALED CUSUING for they representative in the State Legislature. He accepts the nomination. The examination of EDMUND E. PRICE, on the charge of forgery against him, took place in the Police Court to day.

We were glad to notice a decided improvement in the attendance at this house last night, and this too, with a bill which contained only a new farce as a special attraction. One-act pieces are completely underrated in this City, at least by the managers. There is a prevalent superstition that nothing but a three-act drama or comedy can succeed.

THE ADRIATIC.--It will be seen by a letter which we publish in another column, that the troubles of the Collins Company, in regard to the Adriatic, are by no mans ended. Messrs. DICKERSON SICKELS complain of a very flagrant beach of contract on their part, in regard to the completion of her machinery, and declare their intention of appealing to a Court of Justice for redress.

MORTALITY AT SEA.--The Hamburg ship Rudolph, Captain DICKMAN, arrived on Thursday, in 36 days from Hamburg, having 123 passengers consigned to F. KARCK; there have been 17 deaths during the passage, of cholera and ship fever.

Another shocking affair occurred in Philadelphia on Wednesday night, in Loxley's Court, a small opening at the termination of an alley running out of Spruce-street, below Dock. A women named ANN QUICLEY, who with her husband occupied the basement room of the building, was found lying dead upon her bed, the husband lying drunk beside her.

SUMMARY OF ARRESTS AND STATION-HOUSE LODGERS.--The following table exhibits the number of arrests made by the Police for the twenty-four hours ending yesterday, and also the number of lodgers at the different Ward Station houses for the previous night:

The Police Commissioners met yesterday at 1 1/2 P.M., pursuant to adjournment. All the members were present. Gen. NYE, the Chairman, stated that in relation to a certain reward that had been offered by some person in Connecticut, for the recovery of stolen goods,

The Telegraphic correspondent of the Associated Press sends word that Gov., WALKER'S course in rejecting the fraudulent votes of the Oxford Precinct is condemned by the Administration, and that both he and Secretary STANTON will probably be removed.

THE GOVERNMENT AND THE FOREIGN MAILS.--The Washington States vindicates the Postmaster-General from our censures in regard to his failure to forward the Atlantic's mails last week by the Vanderbilt. Its argument is substantially the same as that given in the letter of our Washington Correspondent yesterday.--namely,

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR: In the TIMES of the 22d inst., an editorial on the Adriatic is published, for the truth of the material parts of which you vouch "the machinists of the Novelty Works," which does us a great injustice; and on the 29th you repeat a substantial part of the same erroneous statement.

The Breadstuff trade alone exhibited increased vigor during the past week. The receipts were more extensive, and receivers readlly met the requirements of buyers; hence the transactions were havier. The demand was mainly from home dealers, many of whom are securing their Winter supplies, while they can do so at comparatively low prices.

Before Hon. Justice Roosevelt. In the maller of the petition of Caroline Wood-man.--Some time since there was published in the TIMES an account of a scandalous affair at the New-York Hotel. Mr. Woodman, a boarder there, returning suddenly to his room, one evening, discovered his wife and a Mr. Gardner Furniss, together under decidedly suspicious circumstances.

The Washington Star, of Tuesday, says: "President Buchanan was walking on the Avenue yesterday afternoon, as blustering as the weather was, without even the protection of an overcoal. We never saw him look in better health, or move with more elasticity of step."

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I would ask it there is any systematic plan being put in operation as regards the employment of domestics? I heat of housekeepers who are diminishing the number of their servants, but not lowering the wages of the those they retain. May it not be hope I that this plan will not be pursued; but that the usual number will be retained--increased even--but at a reduction of wages.

Of the thousands who daily read the TIMES, not even scores have looked into the ample vaults that extend two-thirds of the width of Beekman-street underneath the pavement, and seen the pair of giant presses that roll off copies of our paper faster than a man can count them, from midnight to breakfast every morning.

There can be no ground at the approaching election in New-York and Brooklyn for charges of fraudulent canvass of votes, if all the formalities of the law are observed. By the amendments to the election law passed at the last legislative session, and applicable to those Cities, very great safeguards are given to the elector and his franchise.

The Cabinet has decided to build the remaining sloop-of-war at Boston. Thus New-York, Boston, Philadelphia, Norfolk and Pensacola are each to get one. The machinery for the Pensacola vessel will be constructed here. Much solicitude is felt relative to the threatened difficulties at the Baltimore election next Wednesday. next Wednesday.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The Washington correspondent of the TIMES, in his dispatch of the 23d inst., remarks that tho Arizona memorial is not new--and that Congress, at its last session, refused to take action in regard to the Territorial organization, because the Gadsden purchase was too small and too sparsely settled.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The remarks in your paper of Oct. 28, about the delinquencies of farmers, sets out upon a somewhat ex paric view, and overlooks a point or two that, in justice to that class of tollers, might be liberally admitted. In the first place, nobody but a city editor could suppose a farm to be a "region of eternal abundance, innocence and quiet."

The Tribune demurs to our statement that he treatment which Governor WALKER has received at the hands of the Free-State men in Kansas has been "neither generous nor just." It believes this charge to be entirely unsupported by facts, and by way of reply puts to us sundry questions touching the conduct of Governor WALKER.

To the Editor of The Syracuse Standard: Can it be possible that there is an intelligent citizen within the broad boundaries of Onendaga County, who can for a moment be deceived by the senseless and dishonest cry on this subject 1 [of the State Tax.] Is there one who does not understand it in all its length 1 But I proceed to comply with your request.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The book-keeping taught in our schools is very defective in the matter of Corporation accounts. It is almost always confined to mercantile or business transactions. Hence it is that so many companies, as well as governments, find it difficult to get accountants who understand corporation accounts.

The screw steamer Edinburgh, (Br.) Capt. CUMMING, left on Saturday for Glassgow with 37 first and 149 third cabin passengers. For cargo she had 4,500 bbls. flour, 2,800 boxes cheese; 208 bbls, apples, 13,200 bushes, The steamer Jason, Capt. BEITTON, sailed at the same time with 30 cabin and 102 steerage passengers. The Kangaroo,
CRAWFORD--In this City, on Saturday, Oct. St. Mre. CATHARINE CRAWYORD. aged 40 years.

The subjoined assignments to duty of officers of the corps of engineers have been made by the Secretary of Warm and will be carried into effect under such special instructions as may be given by the chief of the corps: Lieut. R. E. De Russy to take charge of the works at Fort Monroe, Virginia, and other works now under the control of Brevet-Colonel J. I., Smith.

In the year 1833 Mr. E. O. DALAVAN, by personal application obtained the, signatures of Presidents MADISON ADAMS and JACKSON, to a declaration against the use of ardent spirits. Each successive President has added his signature to the instrument excepting Gen. HARRISON, to whom it was not presented.

Whene'er a noble deed is wrought, Whene'er is spoken a noble thought, our hearts, in glad surprise, To higher levels rise. The tidal wave of deeper souls Into our inmost being rolls, And lifts us unawares Out of all meaner cares.

SUICIDE OF AN INSANE WOMAN.--On Saturday evening, Mrs. ELIZA SNYDER, residing at No. 52 Crosby-street, committed suicide by hanging herself on one of her bedposts. For several days past she had evinced occasional symptoms of insanity, but her friends had no suspicion that she would attempt self-destruction,

KANSAS MATTERS.--Private telegrams have found their way into the papers, stating that Gov. WALKER had been compelled to flee from Lecompton by threats of personal violence,--that he had gone to Secretary STANTON'S plantation, two miles off, and that the people of Lawrence had invited him there, offering to secure him against violence from any quarter, but that he had, instead of accepting the offer, sent for Col. SUMNER with his dragoons .

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR: I send you the military history of Major DEAS, the officer your correspondent at Washington has done such gross injustice to. I merely send this, trusting you will insert it in your paper, to let the public know that the Major is not a "young and inexperienced officer," and also out of respect to the Major, who is a whole-souled and worthy man.

The streets are thronged with people in the neighborhood of the Mayor's office and the police stations. There are many rumors and all sorts of speculations. The Governor still adheres to his proclamation. The officers of the volunteer companies report that nearly all the men belonging to them refuse to do duty, except under the orders of the Mayor.

The President could not be seen yesterday by anybody, so that it was impossible to obtain directly from himself any information in relation to his view of Governor WALKER'S policy In Cabinet. The statement that he thinks of removing the Governor is generally discredited, although it is understood to have emanated from the office of the Union which, however, is not to be regarded as the accredited organ of the Administration.

At 9 1/2 o'clock the examination of Dr. VARICK was continued, but elicited nothing new bearing on the case. After the examination of various witnesses, who testified to the peaceable character of CURVA, the evidence in the case was closed, and Mr. LITTELL, the District-Attorney, summed up, occupying over three hours.

COURT OF GENERAL SESSIONS--The November Term of the Court of General Sessions commences to-day, Judge RUSSELL presiding, with a comparatively light Calander, as follows: Bastardy, 2; Forgery , 9 Grand Larceny, 29; Burglary, 9; Felonies, 7; Robbery, 6 Murder, 3; Manslaughter, 2, Windows, 6, False Pretenses, 2,; Arton, 1 Rape, Slugn Shot, 2 Abandonment, 1; Receiving Stolen Goods, 2 Total. 83.

JOHN-STREET M. E. CHURCH.--The Eighty-ninth Anniversary of the laying of the corner-stone of this, the first Methodist Church in America, was celebrated yesterday in the old church In John-street. The corner-stone was lald Oct. 31, 1788, about which time EMERY and Col. WEED, of the British army, who officiated in his soldier costume, were the principal preachers.

THE PRICE OF MILK.--MILKMEN IN CONCLAVE -- There was another rally on Saturday evening of the City milkmen at Military Hall, in the Bowery, to compare views, discuss the proposed rise to seven cents a quart, to quarrel about their treatment by the Harlem and Eric Railroads, and to combine to protect the trade.

On landing at Bleberick we were assailed with that strange jargon of many tongues which is fast converting the borders of the Rhine into another Mediterranean. More French and English than German--but only German approaching to purity.

In appears that we were correct in doubting the statement of the NEW-YORK TIMES, the LORD NAPIER was to be virtually superseded to settle that Central American question over his head. It is to Central America that Sir WILLIAM GORE QUESSLY is likely to be accredited but be may visit Lord NAPIER at Washington before he proceeds to his destination.

We have received full files of Mexican papers to the 17th ult., inclusive, brought by the steamship Texas to New-Orleans. As already announced by telegraph, the following is President COMONPORT'S new Cabinet: Senor FUERITZ Minister of Foreign Affairs; JUAREZ, Minister of the Interior; RUIZ, Chief Justice; PAYNO, Treasury.

In the history of the British Press three names stand conspicuous, those of JAMES PERRY, of the Chronicle, the late Mr. WALKER, of the Times, and DANIEL STUART, of the Post and Courier. The history of PERRY is curious and interesting. He was born at Aberdeen about a hundred years ago. When a lad,

The following is the Weekly Report of Deaths in the City and County of New-York, from the 24th day of October to the 31st day of October, 1857: Men, 85; Women, 73; Boys, 142; Girls, 101: Total, 401, Adults, 158; Children, 343; Males, 227; Females, 174; Colored Persons. 9.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The Press of this City has spoken earnestly and urgently, in behalf of the thousands of shop girls who have been summarily deprived of the means of earning their daily bread, and various plans have been suggested for affording them the means of getting comfortably through the coming Winter.

TAKING TIME BY THE FORELOCK.--A Washington correspondent of the Richmond Enquirer urges the nomination of HENRY A. WISE as the Democratic candidate for the Presidency in 1860. He thinks it "well to direct the attention of the country at once to Mr. WISE as the successor of Mr. BUCHANAN. It will give men some hope and some confidence in the future.

GOVERNMENT NEGLECT OF NEW-YORK.--The people of Providence are rejoining on the completion, in their opulent little City, of new Post-Office, which has been built by the United States, at a cost of $246,000; $25,000 of the amount appropriated by Congress remaining unexpended. The building is described as being thoroughly fire-proof, constructed of granite, iron and brick, and in every way well adapted in the purpose for which it is to be used.

MAINE ITEMS.--The waters of Amonoosuck River have been so much swollen by the late rains as to carry away the tressel-work of the railroad bridge at Northumberland, N. H., and to cause apprehensions four for the safety of the entire structure. Work on the Waterville Bridge (which is completed, with the exception of the last pier) has been suspended an account of the rains. Mr. BROWN,

It steamship ?? for Bremen, Havre and Southampton--Rev. Mr. Leslateur, New-York: J. G. Willis and lady. Senior De Jean, Don Alphonzo de Schwartz, Miss Latinier, J. H. Lagram. C. H. Hench, Miss Annie Kirst. R. S. Miller Mrs Rathbane, J. Bellinger, Charleston: R. Mescis and lady E. Berg, California. Miss Emily Lacombe, L. F. ??.

The first number of a new magazine which comes before the public with the pretension of the Atlantic Monthly is entitled to something more than the more notice which necessity limits us to bestow upon the long-established individuals of the periodical tribe.

The semi-annual. Convention of the General Ticket Agents of the various lines of Railroads, East and west, was convened at the Tremont House in this city on Wednesday last, and continued in session until last evening. This is probably one of the most important conventions of the character ever held, as upon its deliberations depended to a great extent the prosperity of the railroad system throughout the country.

There is an idea afloat that it will be necessary to pass another bankrupt law, some time in the course of the next session of Congress, to extricate the merchants and traders from the load of difficulties brought on them by the recent panic. In other words, there are great numbers of people looking forward to have their debts paid by Statute enactment.

The mail from all points South, as late as due, is to hand. The receipts of Cotton at Houston, Texas, since the 1st of September, have been 13,000 bales. The stock there on the 21st ult, was 5,300 bales. A letter from Brownsville says that Judge WATROUS' silver mine is no longer a doubtful affah. Sixty hands are employed in working it, and the silver is plenty.

At the Bank meeting to-day, thirty-seven of the Banks in the State were represented. The meeting was called for the purpose of adopting some plan which would enable the Banks to afford a circulation for the benefit of the business community.

The Court opened yesterday morning at 9 1/2 o'clock, and the Judge, Jury, prisoner, counsel, and even the spectators, looked refreshed by the recess that had been afforded by an intervening Sunday. As the case draws nearer to a close, public interest appears to increase, and there was yesterday a larger audience in attendance than upon any day since the commencement of the trial.

ASHES--Quiet at former prices. Pearls, $6 50; Pots, $7 25@$7 37 1/2 ?? 100 lbs. BOOTS AND SHOES--The Boston market, during the past week, was very tame. Southern and Western buyers were exerting themselves only to obtain extensions on their maturing notes, and many of them succeeded. This class of purchasers were first in much favor. Very little production was reported, and there were no exports to San Francisco.

DOILAY, -In this City, On Saturday, Oct. 31, CAROLINE LOUISA, youngest daughter of the late Leonard Ogilby, Esq. The friends of the family, and of the late Dr. Ogilby and Rev. F. Ogilby are invited to attend the funeral, at 3 O'clock P.M. on Tuesday, Nov. 3, in the Church of the Holy Aposties, 9th -av. and 28th st. The remains will be taken to Trinity cemetery. MASTERSON:--In this City, on Sunday evening, Nov. 1.

FLOUR unchanged, but tends downward. Sales 1,300 bbls, at $473 for superfine Wisconsin; $5@ $5 25 for extra Michigan, Ohio and Indiana. WHEAT steady, Sales 30,000 bush, at 80c, for Chicago Spring. CORN firmer. Sales 4,000 bush, at 60c. OATS steady. Sales 8,000 bush, at 34c. afloat. WUISEY firmer, Sales 100 bbls, at 19 1/2c. FREIGHTE dull at 16c., for Wheat to New-York.

SUPREME COURT.--SPECIAL TERM.--Nov. 1. Before Hon. Justice Roosevelt. This extraordinary case was resumed to-day before Judge ROOSEVELT. A large auditory was in attendance. On the suggestion of Mr. Busteed, the hearing was had in the room ordinarily devoted to the aittings of the Supreme Court Circuit.

NEW LIGHT-HOUSES ON LONG ISLAND.--Four new light-houses are to be added to the coast illumination on Long Island, some of which have been completed, and others are in progress. The frequent occurrence of wrecks upon the court of Long Island, about midway between Montauk and Fire Island, has been attributed to the absence of a good coast light between these two points.

There was a grand parade of the Order of American Mechanics this morning on the occasion of the dedication of their new Hall. About 2,000 men were in line. The banners were of a gorgeous description. Accompanying them were wagons with printing presses at work, throwing off the programmes of the procession; coopers making barrels, marble-workers working on a monument, and shoemakers, last-makers and but manufacturers working at their trades.

POLITICS AT A DISCOUNT.--We doubt if ever before so little excitement has preceded an election as that which occurs to-day. Whether it is owing to the financial difficulties of the times having neutralized all other excitement, or that the people have become indifferent to party movements and squabbles, it is very certain that politics, just now, are at a heavy discount in this City.

From the Citizen. One of the effects of the present commercial crisis is an ebb in the hitherto flowing tide of emigration. To see a ship later with emigrants from America to Ireland is a novel sight. On Saturday last the clipper ship Dreadnaught sailed from this port for Liverpool, with three hundred and forty passengers, the largest number ever taken in a sailing vessel from this country to Europe.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The last report of news from British India was accompanied by a short statement relative to the Dutch East Indies, which, in view of the great interest awakened by events transpiring, in the former country, probably attracted very little attention. It was stated that serious apprehensions of revolt in Java were entertained by the European residents.

Mrs. CHARLOTTE ASHK, an intelligent and worthy free colored wodian, has a daughter who is a clave in Mississippi, whose freedom she desires to purchase. Her owner offers to sell her for $1,400, and Mrs. ASHE has succeeded in raising $600 of the amount. She is very highly commended by Hon. EDWARD EVERETT, in whose family she lived for some time, as in every way worthy of confidence and aid.

It will be seen by their Proclamation, which we publish in another column, that Gov. WALKER and Secretary STANTON have rejected the returns from McGee County also, on the same ground as those of Oxford Precinct in Johnson County, namely, that they were "simulated and fictitious."

Gov. WALKER has issued a second Proclamation in relation to the Election frauds in Kansas. He rejects twelve hundred more votes, returned from three precincts of the McGee County; the number of legal voters in which is lese than one hundred, The Constitutional Convention, which met at Lecompton on the 19th obtained a quorutn on the 22d, and elected C. J. McILVAINE as Clerk.

From the National Intelligencer A CARD (2.) In a recent political address General PILLOW charged that Mr. TRIST, with my assistance, had, in Mexico, administered a bribe to President or General SANTA ANA, ?? By a card in the National Intelligencer promptly replied that I was morally certain Mr. T. had not paid a cent in the way of a bribe, to any body whatever in Mexico,

The chapter of events for the past fortnight, I regret to say, is not of the most cheering character. Each day new proofs of the dissolving condition of this country come to hand. About one half of the United State of Mexico are actually experiencing the evils of predatory was or are in constant fear of such visitations.

While Mr. BUCHANAM will not remove or publicly censure Governor WALKER, he does, nevertheless, privately express disapprobation of his course in the Oxford affair. He says he has written a private letter to WALKER, charging him with violating his instructions, and rebuking him therefor.

FLORENCE--GLEASON.--In this CRY, on Saturday, Oct. 31, by Rev. Wm. F. Morgan, OSCAR FLORENCE to Miss THEODOSIA, daughter of the late Elliah Gleason, Esq., all of this City. KOLLMEYER--AOKERMAN.--In this City, on Thursday, Oct. 29, by Rev. Dr. Armitage, ALFRED B. KOLLMEYER to Miss JOSEPHINE A. AOKERMAN, both of this City. KIMBALL-RICE.--On Thursday afternoon, Oct, 29, by Rev. Dr. Montgomery, Miss HETTY E., daughter of O. B.

Few serious operas are to light and pleasant as ROSSINT'S "Semeramide." It is an agreeable tragedy, which puts us in good hereof, and sonds us home with a variety of lively lanes hamming in our ears. For this reason it is highly acceptable, and will bear repetition, under certain circumstances, better than any other. The most important conditions are that the Arsace and the Semiranis be good.

A horrible affair occured last week in Iowa. The Stoughton (Wis.) Independent has a letter describing it. Mr. ADAMS, Editor of the Ware County Sentinel, was married a short time since to a Miss JENKINS, who had previously been engaged to another man, by the name of HARLEY, HARLEY, on the morning of the wedding-day, had threatened Miss JENKINS with revenge, if she persited in marrying his rival.

PARADE OF THE UNEMPLOYED-MEETING IN THE PARK- Between one and two thousand of the unemployed laborers of the City met yesterday morning and paraded the streets, headed by a man with a drum, and another with a banner on which was written:

Since our Proclamation of the 19th inst., rejecting the so-called election returns from the Oxford Precinct in Johnson County, another very similar case has been presented for our official action. It is that of pretended returns from three precincts of McGee County, in this Territory, containing an aggregate of more than twelve hundred votes. This county is located in the extreme southeastern portion of Kansas,

Before Judge Ingersell. S. W. Calvert vs. Heman J. Redfield. This was an action against the defendant as Collector of the Port, to recover certain extra duties imposed by him on every-stone imported by the plaintiff, which on appraisement was advanced in value more than 10 per cent, above the invoice. The importer was dissatisfied with the appraisement, and wrote to the Collector requesting a reappraisement and inclosing the fees therefor.

SALES OF STOCKS AT PHILADELPHIA.--Monday,--First Board.--$1,600 N. Pennsylvania Railroad 6s, 45 1/2 : $3,00 do., 45 1/2; $1,000 Schuylkill Navigation 6s, '83, 61; $8,000 Pennsylvania 63, 80 1/2; $500 City Railroad 6s, 78 1/2; 130 Reading Railroad, 15; 600 do., 14 1/2; 165 do., 14 3/4 ; Beaver Mendow Railroad, 46; 3 Camden and Amboy Railroad, 82 1/2; 4 Bank of Pennsylvania, 10.

Elections are to be held in fire States to-day: but in only two of them for State Officers. These two are Massachusetts, in which a full ticket, including Governor, is to be elected: and New-York, where no Governor or Licutenant-Governor is to be chosen, but all other State Officers. New-Jersey will vote for members of the Legislature and for County Officers: the Governor holds over until 1860.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR: In your paper of Wednesday, Oct. 28, there appeared a letter from your correspondent, "Dick Time." on Tuscany. Having resided for many years in that beautiful and prospectons country, I cannot agree with your correspondent in the gloomy views which he expressed on the subject of Itallan character, enterprise and industry.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR : Several articles have appeared in your paper directing public attention towards the mismanagement of Railroads, but in none of them which I have seen has such a remedy for the abuses pointed out been suggested as, it seems to me, experience dictates.

FIRE IN WEST FORTY-FIRST-STREET.--NARROW ESCAPE OF A WOMAN AND CHILD.--At a quarter to 6 yesterday moving a fire broke out in the frame building No. 59 West Forty-first-street, occupied on the first and second floors by Mr. FREDERICK SOUNEIDER as a lager-bier saloon and concert hail.

BLYTHE ISLAND.--It was recently stated that the Secretary of the Navy would refuse to carry into effect the provision made by Congress, at the last session, for the purchase of Blythe Island for a naval depot. But this, it is now said; is a mistake, like may other reports in regard to a redaction of expenditures.

The last week of our State contest closes with a respectable degree of liveliness, though nothing like what I have seen in other times is now visible. The papers contain accounts of the doings of conventions and meetings, and from their columns you might draw the conclusion that we are in the enjoyment of a lively contest, which we are no.

The trial of young CUEVA for the murder of OSCAR DR GRANVAL before a New-Jersey Court of Oyer and Terminer, has created a sensation in the city of Hoboken. The previous respectability and social position of the parties, the extreme youth of the prisoner and the very singular issue raised in the case renders it one of general as well as local interest.

Last evening three persons named BREEN, and SLAVIN and his son, the supposed murderers of the MACKENEIH family of six persons, on the 24th ult., were arrested at their camp in the woods, and brought to this city and placed in jall. They offered no resistance. The Coroner's Jury had returned a verdict of "Willful Murder" against the above parties.

The steamship Quaker City, Captain SHUFELBT, from Mobile the 27th and Havana at 5 P.M. on the 20th, arrived here yesterday afternoon, four days from the later port. The Quaker City made the run from Mobile Bar to Havana in 40 hours. From Havana there, is nothing of interest to report.

The Ordnance Department, having reported that there is a sufficient number of the new model ridemus el-calibre 3/4-inch bore--on hand to arm ?? regiments, and that the armories will manufacture arms, with the necessary accountments and ammunition, will be issued to companies and regiments in Kanasas, Florida, West of Arkansas. Texas, Department of the Pacific.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I inclose copy of a letter from Peoria III., which I think deserving of immortality, I had at first designed to give you the name of the "council," but on second thoughts, have concluded that it might perhaps gratify him, and therefore withhold it. M. PEORIA, Illinois, Friday, Oct, 23, 1857.

PUBLIC LIFE ABROAD.--The following letter written by the celebrated Eastern traveller, Mr. LAYARD, 19-a personal friend, is published in the English papers: No. 120, PIGCADILLY, Oct. 17, 1857. MY DEAR MACKAY: I am off for In lia next week. My object--to visit the seat of the rebellion, to form my own views upon its cause and results.

THE BOUNTY-LAND BUSINESS.-The condition of the bounty-land business under the acts of 1857, 1850,1852 and 1855 is full of general interest. Under the act of 1847 there were issued to the 30th ulitmo 87,715 warrants, covering 13,130,320 acres, of which 79,999, acres were located. Under the act of 1850,188,994 warrants were issued, covering 13,155,360 acres, of which 164,326 acres were located.

CENTRAL PARK COMMISSIONERS.--The commissioners may yesterday at 7 o'clock. The Treasurer was directed to pay to regular employees on the first of each month. The Superintendent was authorized to solicit proposals for trees and plants, to be delivered in the Central Park, net to exceed $2,500. The Committee on Trees and Plants were authorized to hire four yoke of oxen, and to buy three plows.

NEW-YORK HISTORICAL SOCIETY.--The ??augu ration of the new and handsome fire-proof building, erected by the Historical Society on Second avenue and Tenth-street, was celebrated last night with appropriate and prolonged speeches. Addresses were made by the President, HOR LUTHER BRACISH, by GEORGE BAHOAROF, Rev. Dr. ADAMS and Rev. Dr. BEZHUNE.

The United States Mail steamer Arago, Captain LINES, arrived yesterday morning from Southampton, with the French and English mails and advices from London to the 21st October. The Arage brings 300 passengers, the usual malls, $220,000 in specie and 250 tons merchandise.

The Elections yesterday passed of with very little excitement. We give below the returns, as far as they reached us up to the hour of going to press. In this State, the result is doubtful in the City, there is a large Democratic majority, both for State and County officers.

Perhaps no single circumstance has given rise to so long-continued and wide-spread crimination as Gov. WALKER'S connection, or apportionment. many of the journals published in Kansas, and not a few: Easton Journals, have complained most bitterly of the Governor, If not for some palpable injustice on his part, yet for his complicity with an outage which virtually disfranchised a large lumber of the citizens of Kansas.

Comparatively few of the cartmen renewed their Heenses on Saturday, the last day upon ?? they could do so, except upon payment of an additional fee of $ 2 50. The applications for renewal were fewar by fifteen hundred this year than they were last. There were, up to Saturday, 5,610 accused cartmen in New-York.

The New-York correspondent of the London Daily News, raider date of Oct. 6, writes to that paper a most terrific letter in relation to our "financial flurry," which might probably v do mole harm across the water if the unreliableness of the writer were not so apparent.

You will confer an obligation by a correction of this statement, inasmuch as the TIMES building is of The chester stone from our quarries in New-Burnswick

Three slaves belonging to THORNTON WITHERS, en route from St. Louis to Parkersburgh, Va., were seized here yesterday when on board a steamboat at the whart, through a writ of habeas empus issue 1 by Judge BINGOYUS, and were placed under the charge of DARIUS EGGLESTONE, by order of the Court, Mr. WITHERS awore out a habeas carpus before Judge CARTER,

Unis as an authentic account of the relations subsisting be-. tween a young man of this City and a married lady of New-Orleans, relations which, as it was alleged, had been established in Paris un.

ALLEGED FORGERY.--Rosewell Hovey, who lives in Brooklyn, was arrested yesterday, charged with having forged the name of J. Grundy as indorser to a check for $250 on the Shoe and Leather Bank, drawn by W. W. Gilman, on which he received the money.

The Elections yesterday in New-York, Massachnsetts, New Jersey, and other States, passed off quietly. The result in this State we are not yet ale to determine. In Massachusette, the Republicans have had everything their own way. In New Jersey, a new Legislature was elected bat the Governor, and the Telegraph does not inform us of the result. The returns from other States are equally incomplete.

INSTALLATION SERVICE.--On Tuesday evening the Third Presbytery of new-York met the church and congregation in the Presbyterian church (colored) in Prince-street. formerly under the case of Rev. Dr. PENNINGTION, for the purpose of the installation of Rev. HENRY HOLLAND GARNET as their future pastor. There was a tolerably full attendance, the audience being nearly equally divided, being the colored and while varieties of our race.

The Convention of Georgia Manufacturers, which met at Atlanta a few days ago, resolved to request the proprietors of Southern factories to run their mills at half time for the present, or till such time as consumers are willing to pay remunerative prices. The reasons assigned for this action are, the inadequate prices of cotton goods, and the uncertainly of future demand.

THE COOPER INSTITUTE.--The Peter Cooper Institute is entirely enclosed, and it is expected that it will be ready for occupation in the early Spring. Most of our readers are familiar with Its external appearance,--a towering edifice of Romanesque architecture, built of brown stone, with four fronts, on Third-avenue, Seventh-street, Fourth-avenue and Astor-place, respectively. Its base line measures on Fourth-avenue 195 feet, and on Astor-place 165 feet;

The election, yesterday, passed off very quictly, and the result, so far as known, is not essentially different from what was anticipated. In the City the Democrats have carried everything. Their candidate for Secretary of State has a plurality over the Republican candidate of 17,985,

UNION COURSE, LONG ISLAND,--Trotting, Tuesday, Nov. 3. Match against Time, Mr. KING'S black gelding. Time 2:52, H. WOODRUFF drove the same horse in 2 minutes 40 seconds. UNION COURSE, LONG ISLAND,--Trotting, Monday, Nov. 2. Purse and slake $450, mile heats, best 3 in 5, to wagon.

The actual pressure on the commercial world, severe as it is, is yet more impressive for the proportions which it has assumed than for any special and unprecedented terrors which belong to its nature, or for any inscrutable mystery which attaches to its origin.

VESSEY--In this City, on Monday evening, Nov, 2, MARY ANNA VESSEY, wife of James Vessey, in the 531 year of her age. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend her funeral, this day, (Wednesday,) at 2 o'clock P. M., at her late residence, No. 10 Renwick-st. MANY.--In this City, of scarlet fever, ELIZABETH ELLA, daughter of Benjamin S. and Martha J. Many, aged 3 years and 6 months.

ELECTION FRAUDS IN MINNESOTA.--It does not yet clearly appear whether Mr. RAMSEY or Mr. SIDLEY is the new Governor of Minnesota. Our latest accounts claim a Republican victory and the election of Mr. RAMSEY. The returns, however, come in with wretched slowness, as election news usually does: It is the same with Minnesota as with Ohio and Iowa, the returns from which are very bunglingly arranged.

THE HERNDON TESTMONIAL - The ladies of this City, who are engaged in organiaing a fund for the purpose of doing fit honor to the memory of the gallant and lamented commander of the Central America, have invited Mr. J. HOWARD WAISHWRIGHT, of this City, to deliver a lecture in aid of their noble enterprise.

The principal Market Places are the WASHINGTON DROVE-YARDS, 44TH-STREET; BROWNING'S, on Sixth-street; CHAMBERLIN'S, on Robinson-street; and O'BRIEN'S, on Sixth-street. Our reports refer to these regular markets. Irregular sales are sometimes made at Bergen Hill, N. J., and from the Hudson River Boats.

Our correspondence from Central America, received by the Star of the West, brings important intelligence. We are informed that an officer in the Costa Rican service, under instructions from his Government, has taken possession of the San Juan River, and, having announced its blockade to the authorities at Greytown, has refused to allow boats or other Nicaraguan craft to pass up or down.

RICHARD CARTER, President of the Anthracite Bank of Tainaqua, was shot dead this morning in the parlor of the St. Lawrence Hotel, by THOMAS WASHINGTON SMITH, of Cecil County, Maryland. SMITH fired first four balls from his revolver, and two more after CARTER had fallen on the floor. CARTER was a mid-die-aged man, wealthy, and has a family.

GIRLS FOR THE WEST.--The branch office of the Children's Aid Society, for helping unemployed trades-girls to the West, opens to-day for business. PETER COOPER'S liberality has furnished the Society with an office in the Union Buildings, on Third-avenue, near Astor-place. This movement is not designed to forward girls at service or now in employment, but only to aid those who are out of work, and with but small means left.

The returns of the election in this State come in slowly. The result in 42 Counties--all yet heard from--gives the Democrats a majority of 12,446 on the Store ticket. We publish elsewhere a table of majorities by Counties and lists of Senators and Members of Assembly elected. In Massachusetts, Mr. BANKS has a plurality of nearly 24,000.

The Steamer Northern Light leaves for Aspinwall today, at 2 o'clock, with about 500 passengers and the California mails. About 250 United States troops go by this steamer to the Pacific, under command of Colonel CASEY, who is accompanied by his wife and two daughters. The troops have engaged a large part of the accommodations in this steamer,

THE OFFICERS ELECTED. We give below all the returns of the State election that had reached us up to the hour of our going to press. Instead of giving them in detail as they reached us, we have presented them in tabular form, and by majorities only, which we have compared with the majorities in the same counties last year.

SCOTT.--In this City, on Tuesday, Nov. 3, of consumption, JAMES W. SCOTT, printer, of Be fast. Ireland, in the 36th year of his age. He has been attached to the Herald office for the last six or seven years. His friends and acquaintances, and printers generally, are invited to attend the funeral from No. 16 City Hallplace, corner of Duane-st. this (Thursday) afternoon, at 1 o'clock.

Lieutenant MOWRY had an interview with the President to-day relative to tile proposition to create te Territory of Arizona, The President received him kindly, and invited him to a future conversation --expressing a decided Interest in the subject.

RAMPANT AMERICANISM.--It must be very discouraging to the sincere friends of the "American Order" to read the report of the violent proceedings of their party at the election in Baltimore yesterday. It appears that Governor LAGON better understood the spirit of the Baltimoreans than did the Mayor of the City.

NEW BUILDINGS.--The new brown-stone front building which Mr. B. M. WHITLOOK is erecting at No. 15 Beekman-street, on a lot 25 by 100 feet, will be of the same style, height and finish as that adjoining owned by him. It will cost about $23,000, and be comploted in the course of two months. It will be ocoupled by W. L. McDONALD as a carriage respository, At No. 17 Beekman-street, (next door,) CHAS.

THE NEW ELECTION LAW.--We hear but one voice in regard to the practical operation of our new Election law. It is universally approved. The glass ballot-boxes commend themselves to approbation. Every voter has the satisfaction of seeing for himself where his ballot goes to, and the tall conviction that there is no chance for having a secret drawer filled with votes for use in case of need.

The Second Rehearsal of the Brooklyn Philharmonic Society was held yesterday afternoon, at the Brooklyn Athenicum. The room was well filled, the greater portion of the audience being ladies. BEETHOVEN'S symphony, the "Herolea," was fluely rendered by the efficient orchestra, under the lead of Mr. THEODORE EISPELD.

VICISSITUDERS OF TRADE.--Among the many instances of the ups and downs of commercial life which have been exhibited by the present "pressure," there is none more striking than that of the Grocers' Sugar Refining Company, which, but a few months since was one of the most prosperous concerns, apparently, in the City. Last sear it.

Kansas letters of the 29th state that only 33 of the 60 members of the Constitutional Convention were present, and nothing of general interest had been done. Governor WALKER and Secretary STANTON were at Lawrence on the 29th, and nothing was said about leaving the Territory.

The State Election is over, and public attention is already turning to the canvass for City officers, which occurs a month hence. There was very little interest in the party contest of Tuesday last, and beyond the natural feeling of curiosity, the only concern felt in the result turns upon the indication it affords of the probable issue of the election for Mayor.

The United States mail steamer Cahawba, J. D. BULLOCK, Commander, from New Orleans via Havana, having left the latter port on the 30th ult., arrived at this port yesterday morning. There is nothing new at Havana. It is reported that several loads of Africans had been landed.

The R. M. steamship Canada, Capt. LANG, arrived here at 8 o'clock this morning. She left Liverpool at noon on the 24th ??; her dates are consequently three days inter than those already received by the Arago all New-York, and the Indian at Quebec. The steamer Antelope, from Portland, arrived out at 3 o'clock on the afternoon of the 23d ult. The steamer Indiana, from New-York, arrived at Southampton on the 23d ult.

If we had not historical records to assure us and give us hope, we might fall into a very gloomy state of foreboding for the peace and happiness of our country, when we hear of the savage encounters that are almost daily taking place in every direction, between members of families and private individuals, in the attempt to glut their revenge for imaginary or real wrongs.

COMMISSIONERS OF EMIGRATION.--The Commissioners of Emigration met in Worth-street on Wednesday, the President, GULIAN C. VERPLANCK, Esq., in the Chair. A communication was received from the Quarantine Commissioners stating that no notice had been taken of a former communication to the Board in reference to the buildings at Quarantine.

TRIAL OF CUEVA--VERDICT OF MANSLAUGITER.--In the Hudson County Court of Oyer and Terminer, yesterday, Judge OGDEN presiding, A. O. ZABRISXIE, Esq., connsel for FREDERICK CUEVA, on trial for the murder of OSCAR DE GRANVAL, resuming his argument in behalf of the prisoner, at the opening of the Court, at 9 1/2 o'clock, spoke for an hour and a half, and made an affecting appeal to the Jury in behalf of his client.

VERDI'S Opera "Rigoletto" is certainly one of the mastor's best works, yet it has not been given since Mr. OLE Bull's famous operatic experiment, when that distinguished impresario accomplished a season of something less than one week with signal discomfiture.

Before Hon. Judge Roosevelt. The hearing of further argument on the Habeas Corpus case of Mrs. Caroline Woodman was resumed to-day before Hon. Judge ROOSEVELT in the room generally occupied by the first part of the Court of Common Pleas in the City Hall. The public attendance was quite large.

The U.S. Mail steamship Star of the West, A. G. GRAY commanding from Aspinwall on the night of the 24th ult., vid Havana, arrived at this port yesterday morning. The news from San Francisco has been anticipated by the arrival of the Quaker City from Havana.

ERIE RAILROAD MEETING.--A very numerous meeting of stock and bondholders and others was held in Commercial Hall, Montgomery-street, Jersey City, on Thursday night, for the purpose of devising means to place the Erie Railroad in a better pecuniary position. Mr. SEUDDER look the Chair, and Mr. J. B. CULVER was appointed Secretary.

THE POLITICAL POWER OF SLAVERY--Our readers doubtless remember the series of articles copied into the TIMES from the Charleston Standard some months since, urging the renewal of the African Slave-Trade. They were written with earnestness and ability, and made a very considerable impression upon the public to which they were addressed.

The results of yesterday's election may be summed up thus: BANK'S plurality, 24.000; GARDNER'S vote, 37,000; BEACH'S 31,000; Seattering, 200; BANKS' vote, 61,000. The whole vote is almost 30,000 less than the gubernatorial vote of last year, and nearly 40,000 less than the Presidential vote.

The announcement that Costa Rica has taken possession of the San Juan River, and so assumes to control the Nicaragua Transit route, will make a little interesting work for the United States Government, the Administration being distinctly pledged not to permit Costa Rica to assert any such control over the route in question.

Our returns are sufficient to show that the Democrats have carried the State. They have elected the Executive Officers--securing a majority in the Canal Board, and have possibly also carried the Assembly. The Senate remains in the hands of the Republicans.

A SINGULAR STORY.-The Washington States of yesterday, contains a curious story of the alleged invention of a very formidable weapon of war, which was used by the Russians in the Crimea, and is now said to have passed into the hands of the Mormons.

It has been found impossible to get the news yacht of the New-York Associated Press fully equipped until the present time, but for the future she will be found constantly at her post, about eight or ten miles due south off cape Race light, and fully equipped for the duty assigned for her.

A MELANCHOLY CONTRAST--ALDERMEN IN LONDON AND NEW-YORK.--There is reason to fear an immediate and extensive emigration of Aldermen from London to New-York. For the members of that fat and fatherly fraternity in the British capital are groaning under a systematic violation of their vested rights,

We are gratified at being able to announce by authority the fall, satisfactory and honorable settlement and payment of all disputes and accounts and suits that lately existed between the M. and M. Bank and Messrs. O'CONNOR. Bros. Co., Bankers of this city.

The Historical Society of this City have just done a very creditable thing. They have built themselves a fine house, and have paid for it. In their house we have an architectural ornament added to our City, and in their financial arrangements we have the pledge of the stability of an organization which possesses within itself many elements of usefulness.

The steamer of the 1st Inst. had scarcely left with my long letter to you of that date, when the Valdina came in from the North with the news of one of those, in these days, frequent out rages upon our flag and commercial interests--I shall endeavor to be as brief and at the same time truthful in my account of this affair, as circumstances will permit.

A MAN WHO OBJECTS TO SERVING GOD IF THE DEVIL BIDS HIM.--The Cleveland Plaindealer, a strong partisan opponent of Governor CHASE, objects, in the following paragraph, to thanking God for anything at his instigation: "CHASE'S Thanksgiving Proclamation has come. He thanks God for everything, the people for nothing. He says not a work about the great falling off of the Fusion vote on the Reserve,

TO THE PEOPLEL OF KANSAS. We have, at the late election, carried every county in Kansas by the legal vote. Every scheme that malignant ingenuity could invent, has been resorted to by our opponents, to defeat the expressed wish of the people. Fraudulent returns have been manufactured at different points and returned to the Secretary's office, so glaring, that the authors of the vile forgery dare not openly sustain them.

At this season, when the eyes of the benevolent are turned to our charitable institutions, we trust the Old Brewery Mission at the Five Points will not be overlooked. Its friends appeal earnestly, yet with confidence, to those who hither to aided them. That aid was never more needed than now.

The returns of the Election in this State are still far from complete. The state is probalbly Democratic, but the Republicans have elected 18 out of the 32 Senators, securing a continuance of their majority in that body. The Assembly is probably Democratice; we have returns electing 103 members of whom 51 are Democrats and 52 Republicans, with about half the Assembly Districts to hear from.

The Election in this State has gone to the Democrats by about 8,000 plurallty over the Republicans, so far as heard from. The returns yet to come in will not materially affect the general result. The Democrats have also probably elected a majority of the Members of Assembly.

Yesterday the unemployed laboring population--or rather an unreflecting portion thereof, assembled at Tompkins Square, and after war is in the Park, in much larger numbers than on Monday last, when their first demonstration was made. They paraded yesterday the same banner, with the inscription "Work--Arbelt" upon it, (the latter word being the German term for work.)

The spectacular drama of the " Sea of Ice" was produced at this theatre last night, with a success which promise a long and profitable run. Few dramas have had, such a chequered career as this. It has been lavishly Produced in all the principal cities of America and England, (10 say nothing of France whence the original is obtained.) In some places it has been received with enthusiasm;

When Col. LEE, of New-York, was collecting subscriptions for the equestrian bronze statue of WASHINGTON, now standing a monument of patriotism and art at the corner of Union-park, he had occasion to visit an old ??mudgeon in the neighborhood, and pulling out his subscription paper, requested him to add his name to the list. But old Lucre declined respectfully.

This odious affair was brought to an abrupt termination yesterday afternoon. It has ended as it began-in a disgusting imbroglio of falsehood and folly. The unhappy woman whose name and character have been crucified upon these scandalous proceedings has passed under the care of a near relative,

PORTER.--In this City, on Wednesday evening, Nov. 4, after a brief illness, DE COSTI PORTER, eldest son of Wm. V. and Abby De Costi Porter. The relatives and friends of the family are invited to attend the funeral services, at the Church of the Redeem er. In 85th st., between 2d and 3d avs.. this (Friday) morning, at 11 o'clock.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In your editorial of the 4th inst., relating to the Woodman case, I notice your remarks relative to the "neglectful and hecdless husband." Permit me to make a slight correction, which I assert from my personal knowledge in the matter.

DEMONSTRATIONS OF THE UNEMPLOYED.A very large meeting was held in the Park yesterday of persons whom the pressure of the times has thrown out of employment. Several speeches were made, marked by a violent tone and a menacing purpose.

The law passed by the last Legistative ??? Ticket-swindling a felony punishable with fine and imprisonment, produced a temporary suspension of hostilities, and for a short time after its promulgation ?? wholesome fear kept the runners, and ?? ticket venders in check. The armistice, however, is again suspended, and hostilities have commenced with greater fierceness, If possible, than even before.

At a temperance meeting held last night at Salisbury Centre, after an address on the past twelve years of temperance matters in this State, by Professor McCor, the following resolution, moved by J. D. CHAMPION, seconded by D. A. NORTHRUP, was unanimously carried:

FALL FROM A SCAFFOLD.--About 10 o'clock yesterday morning MAURICE COX, a sign painter, accidentally fell from a seaffold in front of the drugstore No. 469 Pearl-street, New-York. He was engaged in painting a sign on the third story of the building, and was instantly killed by the fall. Deceased resided in Bedford-avenue, near Myrtle-avenue, Brooklyn, where he leaves a wife and child.

THE POLICE COMMISSION.--One of the Evening papers stated that Mr. SIMEON DRAPER communicated to the Board, at its session yesterday, his declinature of the office to which he had been elected. This is a mistake: as will be seen by the report of the proceedings, no such communication was received from Mr. DRAPER.

COURT CALENDAR--FRIDAY, Nov. 6. SUPREME COURT--Circuit.--Nos. 2037, 2160, 544 1/2, 2099, 302, 3105, 362, 640, 2194, 1696, 118, 1780, 1293, 214, 2310, 834, 1384, 2110, 2095, 352, 260. UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT.--Nov. 5. Before Judge Betts. PRACTICE--POSSESSORY ACTION--ATTACHMENT.

IN CHERRY STREET.-At 5 1/2 o'clock yesterday morning a fire broke cut in the building No. 273 Cherry-street, Occupied by A. T. KIMBALL Co. for the manufacture of foundry material. It was since time after the fire was discovered before an alaria was given, and the whole building, a live story structure, was unemployed in flames before the fire ongines arrived on the grounded.

The Second avenue Railroad Company has about 120 conductors and drivers in its employment, and the same number of blacksmiths, hostlers, switch. men, Forty ears run below Forty-second-street, and twelve above to Harlem--fifty-two in all. The number of horses in the stables of this Company at present is 500.

We give below tables showing the political complexion of the Legislature, so far as ascertained. Our table of majorities, in the present incomplete state of the returns, we consider it unnecessary to repeat this morning, as we have received nothing which materially changes the result already arrived at.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Will you please caution the public to be on their guard against the many impostors that will be making application for assistance the coming Winter? Advise them to adhere to the rule never to give without first making inquirey and learning the previous history of the applicants, no matter how plausible their story may be.

At 9 o'clock last night some fifteen Irishmen suddenly appeared on St. Thomas-street, between Melicerte and Terpsichore, divided in three different squads, one of which passed down the middle of the street, and one on each sidewalk. The faces of all were either blackened or masked, and they were armed with pistols, knives and slung-shot.

Yesterday a meeting was held in the Astor House by the Hardware Merchants of the City, for the purpose of hearing communications from representatives of the Trade elsewhere, of considering the report of the Committee appointed to prepare a statement of their views on the subject of long credits, and of devising measures whereby to counteract and relieve the existing monetary difficulties.

THE LAST HOMICIDE IN PHILADELPHIA.--Hardly a week had elapsed after the brothers McKIEBIN shot at brother-in-law in Chambersburg, in Pennsylvania, and were permitted to go at large on trifling ball, when a gentleman, named SMITH, walks into a hotel in Philadelphia, and deliberately shoots a Mr. CARTER while conversing with him in a public room.

THE CENTRAL PARK.--The Mayor assured the committee of unemployed laborers who called upon him yesterday that the Common Council would authorize the immediate resumption of work upon the Central Park. We trust this assurance may prove to be well founded.

The Canada's mails, with dates from London and Liverpool to Oct. 24, reached this City, from Boston, yesterday afternoon. We continue to give, from our foreign exchanges, copious extracts on the financial pressure as the all-absorbing topic of the day.

O'BRIEN--KEESE.--In this City, on Thursday evening, Nov. 5, at St. Anne's Church, 8th-st., by Rev. Thomas S. Preston, JOSEPHKNIGHT O'BRIEN to VIRGINIA C., daughter of the late John D. Keese. ALLEN--BAYLIS.--In this City, on Thursday evening, Nov,. 5, at St. George's Church, by Rev. Dr. Tyng. ALEXANDER H. ALLEN to LAURA H., daughter of Henry Baylis, Esq., all of this City.

An active interest is already becoming manifest in the approaching Charter Election. It is very evident that a much larger vote will be polled in that contest than in the one just closed. There is infinitely more at stake,--for the people of this City have a much more direct and important interest in the Government of the City than in that of the State.

A few years ago, a certain individual who had failed in some mercantile pursuit, having nothing else to do, set to work traveling back fort between two of the principal Atlantic cities, carrying a few small parcels in an ordinary carpetbag, executing a few commissions and doing a few other errands.

After the closing of our report of the meeting at Dr. CHEEVER'S Church on Thursday evening, Mr. R.N. HAVENS offered the following resolutions as a substitute for Mr. HUNT'S motion to print the report of the Special Committee:

THE BULLS AND BEARS IN MOTION AGAIN.-Wall-street cannot be quiet long at a time. It seemed, but a few weeks since, as though the Bulls and Bears had been so completely used up by their efforts to resist the "pressure," that it would be a very long time before they would find themselves on their feet and in working order.

The announcement we were enabled to make in the TIMES of the 29th ult., as to the appointment of a special British Minister to the Central American Government, and as to the probability of the individual to be selected for that office, has been confirmed in every particular.

We copy from several of our Southern exchanges comments upon Gov. WALKER'S rejection of the "simulated and fictitious returns" of votes that were never east, in Kansas. The tone of these comments is full of significance.

The Southern mail from all points as late as due has been received. The dates from Galveston, Texas, are to the 27th ult. The crops in San Augustine and Sabine Counties were excellent. The cotton crop was later than usual. Below several vessels were loading with cotton to go direct to European ports.

The following letter, sent by Mr. DRAPER to the Police Commission, shows that he has finally decided to decline the membership, to which he was elected by unanimous vote of the Board; NEW-YORK, NOV. 5. GENTLEMEN: I received on the 22d utt. information from the Clerk of your Board that, on the nomination of the Mayor of New-York, I had been ananimously elected to fill the vacancy existing in the Board of Police.

Superintendent TALLMADGE has asked of the Police Commissioners authority to arm "ten prudent and discreet patrolmen with revolvers," as a means of increasing the efficiency of the Police, and of counteracting the consequences of the very small number of men of which the Police force is composed.

RUN OVER IN BROADWAY.--An aged gentleman, named HUDSON, was run over and seriously injured in Broadway last evening. He was crossing near the corner of Fulton-street, when his coat was caught by the end of a projecting stage pole; he was turned round, thrown down, and trampled by the horses the wheels also passed over his leg, badly crushing his knee.

DEFALCATION OF A TELLER OF THE GROCER'S BANK.--The fact has come to light that Mr. GEORGE A. CLARK, Paying Teller of the Grocer's Bank, was a defaulter to that institution in the sum of about $70,000. The development of the fact has been brought about through the examination made into the affairs of the Bank since the appointment of a Receiver.

EMIGRATION FALLING OFF.--The ship Baltic, Capt. ZEREGA, of ZEREGA Co.'s Liverpool Line of Packets, arrived yesterday with 29 passengers, all told. The ships of this line generally come full, and the Baltic is a favorite ship, bringing generally more than any others. She sailed Oct. 6, after the intelligence of hard times began to reach the other side, which has no doubt had the effect to discourage emigation.

The President has proclaimed the binding force of the treaty between the United States and Peru concluded on the basis that "Free ships make free goods, and the properly of neutrals on board enemy's vessels is not subject to defention or confiscation, unless the same be contra band of war."

FIRES IN BROOKLYN--At 12 o'clock Thursday night a frame dwelling-house on Fifth-street, near Third, was damaged by fire to the extent of $500. The owner is JOHN SMITH, whose loss is covered by insurance in the Citizens' Insurance Company. At 2 o'clock yesterday morning an unoccupied frame-house, at the corner of Bergen-street and was destroyed by fire. Loss $1,200. Insured for $700 in the Phenix Insurance Company.

CAPTAIN: I have the honor to report, for the information of the Commanding-General, the result of my trip to the Territory of Utah. In obedience to special instructions, dated Head-quarters Army for Utah, Fort Leavenworth, July 28, 1857. I left Fort Leavenworth July 30, and reached Fort Kearney in nine days' traveling, Fort Laramie in ten, and Great Salt Lake City in thirty-three and a half.

THE SUPPOSED SUICIDE OF MRS. MOORE.--An inquest was held yesterday on the body of Mrs. CATHARINE C. MOORE, who was found dead in her bed at No. 172 Forsyth-street, on Wednesday, It appeared from the evidence that the deceased had for some time been in the habit of taking lawlanum, but had never been known to threaten her own life.

The truth that "everybody's business is nobody's business," has of late received abundant illustration in these United States. Hardly a day passes over us without leaving its record of some flagrant folly or some outrageous crime, which protests, more eloquently than any words, the shameful incompetence of our public authorities, and the dangerous disorganization of our social machinery.

Mr. ULLMAN recommences his attractive series of Sunday performances to-morrow at the Academy. Selections will be given from a variety of oratories--the solos being rendered by Madame LA GRANGE, Madame D'ANGRI, Miss ANNIE MILNER, Messrs. LABOCETTA, GASSIER, PERRING and others.

The Canard steamship Canada arrived at Boston late on Thursday night. Her mails reached this City yesterday afternoon. The most important feature in the intelligence, as already announced by telegraph, is the financial pressure in Europe. We give copious extracts on the subject from foreign journals.

Tile Fair of the American Institute at the Crystal Palace closed last might with the announcement of the premiums awarded by the several Committees. Tile Fair opened on the 24th of September, and it has been, in all respects, a success.

THREE BODIES FOUND DROWNED.--The bodies of three unknown men were found drowned yesterday; one at the foot of Laight-street, North River; another at the foot of Christopher-street, and the third in the dock foot of Burling-slip, East River. The first one was that of a man about 40 years of age, five feet eight inches in height, with brown hair and sandy whiskers, dressed in a black frockcoast, gray pants and plaid plush vest.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR: I am an English mechanic. I have worked in the Old Country, and have seen may such "hard times" as we anticipate here this Winter. I came to this Country to avoid the bitter experience of such times I experienced there. I have met many good friends in Americans.

PUBLIC WORKS AT SANDY HOOK.--The preparatory works under contract at Sandy Hook, where extensive fortifications are projected, are in a state of on forwardness, and will be completed before the Winter acts in. They consist of two Barracks, one Storehouse, an Office, and Carpenter's and Blacksmith's Shops.

We are still without authentic returns from a large portion of the State, hence we do not repeat our tables this morning. From several counties we have only estimates of the result, which may or may not be reliable. The actual canvass of votes proceeds very slowly, and some days will probably elapse before the returns are made.

THE CRYSTAL PALACE.--This establishment remains in the possession of the American Institute, which Association have determined to keep it open daily for the display of machinery, new inventions, etc. Having a good motive power, and other most excellent accommodations, this presents superior facilities to manufacturers and others to exhibit and test and products of their skill.

GEN. WALKER TO SECRETARY CASS. The following is the letter addressed by General WALKER to the Secretary of State, dated Sept, 29, 1857: SIR: It is currently reported that the ministers of Costa Rica and Guatemala have asked for the active interposition of the United States for the purpose of preventing me and my companions from returning to Nicaragua.
MORTALITY IN BROOKLYN.--During the week ending Saturday last, there were only 58 deaths in the city of Brooklyn, Males, 38; females 20; men, 12; boys, 26; women, 8; girls, 12.

Notwithstanding Mr. DRAPER'S tardy declination, the Police Commission is again filled. On saturday afternoon, Mr. PELATIAH PERIT was elected, upon the nomination of Mayor Wool, to fill the vacancy in the Board. We trust that he will accept the post, or that he will not, at all events, wait until after the next election to decide whether he will do so or not.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: As you know every hang, please tell me and the public whether a milkman can lawfully sell me what he calls and changes as a quart of milk, when there are only three quarters of a quart?

Her friends, and the friends of the family, are respectfully invited to attend the funeral services, at her late residence, No. 96 West 43d st., this day, ?? M. The Government of Great Britain is usually supposed to be at least as capable of carrying out measures involving a great multitude of details as our own. In some of the requisites for operations on a large scale, it is better off than ours. None of the its officials, except the very highest, are liable to the loss of their places by political changes.

DIAMONDS AT AUCTION.-The U. S. Marshal on Saturday, sold at the auction rooms of SAMUEL OSUCOD CO., a lot of Diamonds alleged to have been forfeited to the United States, for violation of Revenue laws, as smuggled goods, previous to the financial crisis they were valued at $27,000. There was a good deal of competition among the bidders. but they were sold at "panic" rates.
