The Convention is hard at work. They have not done much yet that could demonstrate their partisan characters. To-day they have been working at the general election law. Besides a year's residence, they require payment of a Territorial of State tax in a voter. Soldiers of the army are allowed to vote. Judge EXMORE'S report on the judiciary occupied all the forenoon. It was a very good one.

The present Boards of Aldermen and Councilmen go out of office on Monday, January 4, when the new City Government comes into existence, and are to be succeeded by a Board of Aldermen of seventeen members, instead of twenty-two, as at present constituted, and one of Councilmen of twenty-four in place of sixty allowed by the present Charter.

At the commencement of the season German society predominates at the watering places of the Rhine. They commence to arrive at the end of May, In June the Russian and Dutch arrive, welcomed on bended knees by the croupiers of the rouge-et-noir as the harbingers of a season of joy and plenteoueness--to the banks.

ANOTHER BALTIMORE MURDER.--A young American named THOMAS PIERCE, belonging on the Point, was instantly killed last evening at the house of CATHARINE SHRIVER, on Caroline-street, near Lancaster. He with another man and two women were sitting at a table playing cards, the door leading from the street to the room being slightly ajar.

The Board of Police Commissioners met on Saturday and accepted Mr. DRAPER'S letter declining to take his seat as a member of the Board. They then proceeded to ballot for a substitute. Mayors Weep and POWELL and Mr. CHOLWELL voting for JOHN WHEELER, and the other three members for OYRUS OURTIS.

LARGE PAYMENTS BY THE OHIO TRUST COMPANY.--Immediately after the suspension of the Ohio Life and Trust Company, some ten or twelve different suits were commenced by creditors of the Company, and money in the possession of various banks in Kentucky, was attached.

REMOVAL OF STEAMBOAT LANDINGS.--The proposition to remove the landing places of the Sound steamers from their present locations to some point above Grand-street on the East River, and to remove the landing places of the North River steamers above Canal-street, was again before the Aldermen on Thursday night, and the report in favor of the measure is to be taken up to-day.

We publish this morning the details of one of those revolting cases of criminal ruffianism, which, for the good name of our city, we most devoutly wish that the duties of journalism did not require us to lay before our readers.

The election returns are all received, and show the election of JAMES L. BARTOL to the bench of the Court of Appeals, to supply the vacancy occasioned by the appointment of Mr. MASON to the collectorship of this port. The Demecrats have gained largely in the counties, and one in Congress by the election of J. M. KUNKEL to Congress from the fifth district.

UNDERGROUND ELECTRIC TELEGRAPH WIRES.--Mr. HIGHTON has recently made some reports to the British Electric Telegraph Company upon the condition of their wires. For the isolation of these when laid under ground gatta percha is used as an enveloping material, and its durability is a matter of great importance.

INDIAN BUREAU.--Commissioner DENVER has received a report from A. H. McKISICK, Wachita Agent, dated Fort Smith, Oct. 21. Mr. McK. writes that the tribes of Wachitas and Keechies, numbering together some twelve hundred souls, are anxious to conform to the wishes of the Government, and to cultivate the soil, instead of depending for subsistence upon the precarious chase,

Farly Saturday morning the unemployed began to assemble in Tompkins-square. Some of them lay around on the grass, and others stood in knots together, talking over their prospects with doleful looks and frequently with violent expressions. For the most part, however, they spoke good-humoredly of their misfortunes, frequently laughed, and, with the exception of a few who looked really famine-stricken, appeared to have all had something for breakfast.

There was a discussion in the Academy of Medicine, at Paris, last August, upon the passage of tubes into the windpipe, technically on catheterism of the larynx and trachea. This operation was two years ago discussed by the Academy of Medicine in this City, having been brought before them by a paper upon the subject, read by Dr. HORACE GREEN.

THE MEETINGS OF THE UNEMPLOYED --There's nothing like a mass meeting to draw off popular discontent. It operates precisely like the safety-valve of a steamer, or a lighting-rod in a thunder-storm. The meetings of "The Unemployed" have done a great deal of good in this way.

The President has no official advices of the appointment of a special Minister from Costa Rica to the United States Government, but is satisfied of the recuracy of the 'TIMES' statement that one is to be appointed. It is not anticipated, however, that this special Minister will be able to do anything towards unraveling the snarl into which the affairs of the Niceragun Transit Route have become involved.

Now Autumn lies in thought beneath Her scarlet tents, by valley streams; Or idly strays, among the hills, Within her gold and purple dreams, Behold on husker sit entranced, The half-stripped ear within his hands; While he who went to gather fruits, With empty basket musing stands!

To the Board of Managers of the American Insitute: GENTLEMEN:--I have just read in one of the daily papers that at the close of the Fair yesterday, SMALL SILVER MEDAL was awarded to my invention of the "Self-Generating Gas Safety Lamp" for "cheepness, simplicity, durability and safety."

Captain McKibbon, the oldest pilot in the port of Mobile, was killed on Tuesday last, in a most frightful manner. He was on board the Colonel Clay, which v as conveying the malls and passengers for New-York to the Quaker City, and was walking across the upper deck by some accident he fell over the spot where the crank was in full play.

A poor Swiss woman named THERESA SPITZLEIN fifty-five years of age, was ravished and murdered at a late hour on Friday night, by four liendish rowdles, under most aggravated and revolting circumstances. The poor woman paid six cents a night for the privilege of sleeping on the floor in the back celar of a low loger-bier saloon at No. 32 Greenwich - street, kept by CHRISTIAN MARTIN.

RICHMOND COUNTY ASSEMBLYMAN.--At the closing of the polls in Richmond, and for two days following, it was reported, and generally understood that JAMES GUYON, American, was elected to the Assembly instead of Dr. HUBBARD, Democrat.

JOHN ROSS, Chief of the Cherokee Nation, has sent his Annual Message to the Council. He recommends that particular attention be paid to the School system, and that measures be adopted to cancel the public debt. Of the relations of his people to the Federal Government, he speaks with great earnest. ness.

A STRIKE OF IRISHMEN AT HARTFORD.- It has been found necessary, by the officers at the Railroad Deport in Asylum-street, to reduce the pay of the workmen on the wood trains 20 per cent., and the laborers were offered, yesterday, 50 cents a day.

JACOBSEN--PINDAR.--In this City, on Saturday, Nov.7, at the Church of the Incarnation, corner of 28th-st, and Madison-av., by the Rector, Rev. Henry E. Montgomery, OTTO F. JACOBSEN, of Tarrytown, N. Y., to ANNA E., daughter of the late Charles K. Pludar, of this City.

THE CARTER TRAGEDY AT PHILADELPHIA--FUNERAL OF THE MURDERED MAN. The Philadelphia Evening Bulletin, of Saturday, says: We learn from Tamaqua that the intelligence of the murder of RICHARD CARTER, Esq., at the St. Lawrence Hotel, by THOMAS WASHINGTON SMITH, created a great sensation in that place.

From the Courrier des Utals Unis, (Democratic.) Mr. FERNANDO WOOD has given himself, as a candidate for reflection, the rudest blow that he could receive. Like all men exclusively preoccu. pied with personal designs, he has taken the wrong road, while he believed he was making a short cut for the attainment of his object.

From the Buffalo Express. Edited by A.M. Clapp, Esq. It is now beyond a doubt that the young, vigorous and promising Republican party of the State of New-York has been covered with defeat. Its proud majority of 80,000 has been overturned, and some 20,000 more added to the success of the enemy.

Governor WALKER's intention was to come East directly the Constitutional Convention of Kansas adjourned; and as that Convention had been, at the latest accounts, in session for several days without a quorum to do business, It is not likely he will reach here on Saturday, the 7th instant, as it was expected he would.

SATISFACTORY.--The Tribune says that in the recent Amazonian horse-whipping affair in Broadway, Miss LOUISA GASSEO, who sings in the chair of one of our fashionable churches, was the principal performer and Mr. EUGENE THORN took the secondary part.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Your columns have furnished me with the sad details of the loss of the Central America, and, although by the time this reaches you, the public will have almost forgotten the sad event,--having been intimately connected with the commander and officers of that ship, I feel it a duty to their memory and to their mourning relatives to add my humble tribute to their worth.

As a general thing, when a man is fairly landed "in the gutter," he has sense enough to lie still. Unless he is an unusual fool, he knows that the more he struggles and flounders the more thoroughly he will be covered with mud, and the more complete and conspicuous will be his disaster.

QUARANTINE.--The large fleet of vessels with signals hanging in the mizzen-rigging have disappeared from quarantine, and nobody now holds his health while passing that locally from fear of inhaling the yellow fever. There are no vessels now arriving subject to quarantine.

THE PORT WARDENS.--Much of the opposition hitherto shown to the Port Wardens in the exercise of their functions has ceased. The old Marine surveyors have pretty much withdrawn from the held Capt. CANDLEE, the principal man, resides in New-Jersey, an comes to town but seldom.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.-- A star performance--whatever that may mean--of the "Trovatere' take place here to-night. Madame LA GRANGE, Madame D'ANGHI, and Messrs. BIONARDI, GASSIER. and ARDAVANI, (a new baritone; his first appearance,) in the principal parts. The Sunday performance at this house last evening was a complete and Merited success.

On Monday week, as the passenger train was leaving Wapsie station for the East, on the Chicago, lowa and Nebraska Railroad, between twenty and thirty Irish laborers who had been discharged, boarded the cars, and swore they would ride to Clinton free of charge. Conductor Smith remonstrated, and the Irish persisted. At length he attempted to force them from the cars.

LUNDY,--In this City, on Monday, Nov. 9, CHARLES G. LUNDY, in the 24th year of this age. His friends, and the friends of the family of his father-in-law, Boltis M. Fowler, are respectfully invited to attend his funeral, on Wednesday morning, 11th last.. at 10 o'clock, at the 13th st, Presbyterian Church, (Rev. Dr. Burehard's.) Thus, the inhabitant of a colony is always more loyal than the resident of the Court, or at least he should be, according to the natural order of things.

A meeting of the stockholders of the Pennsylvania Bank was held this morning. Mr. WILLIAM C. PATTERSON, who has been appointed to succeed Mr. ALLIRONE as President, was called upon to make a statement. He said no statement could be made but would be falsified in twenty-four hours. No statement could be made to which he would be willing to put his signature.

WALLACK'S THEATRE,--A new Comedietta, the joint production of Messrs. DION BOURGIGAULT and CHARLES SEYMOUR, as brought out at this Theatre last evening, before a capital house. The piece is entitled, "Wanted a Widow, with Immediate Possession." It pictures the experiences of a gentleman in difficulties touching money and marriage.

Mather Williamson, Appellant, vs. New-York Central Railroad, Respondent--SELDEN. J.--This is a suit in equity, the object of which is to obtain a perpetual injunction, restraining the defendants from continuing to use and occupy with their Railway a portion of a certain highway or street in the village of Syracuse, known as Washington-street, and to recover damages for past occupation.

In both branches of the Common Council last evening claborate reports were presented and adopted upon the Mayor's Message, recommending the purchase and sale by the City of provisions to the poor. Both are able and sensible documents, and that of the Aldermen is especially worthy of perusal and reflection.

I have just read in the New-Orleans Delta the reply of General PILLOW to the letter of General SCOTT, written in answer to some charges against him, contained in General PILLOW'S recent address to the people of Tennessee. In the personal controversies between these gentlemen, as well as that between Generals PILLOW and HITCHCOCK, I desire to take no part.

The Boar of Commissioners of Public Works met to-day and elected ten Directors on the Part of the state in Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company. Lion. JOSHCA VAN SANT, JOHN S. GETTINGS, JAMES M. SCULLY and E. M. MEALY, were removed, and JOHN EVERETT, JACOB SHOWER, B. C. HOWARD and Wm. G. HARRISON, elected in their places.

KANSAS AFFAIRS--The Kansas Constitutional Convention has adopted a clause concerning slavery which leaves nothing doubtful upon that subject. It recognizes the institution as already established in the Territory, and prohibits the Legislature from getting rid of it.

Examination before the Coroner-The Accused JAMES TOOLE and WILLIAM HAGAN, two of the parties charged with being Implicated In the recent rape and murder of Mrs. SPITZLEIN, at No. 32 Greenwich street, were yesterday forenoon brought before Coroner CONNERY for examination. TOOLE it will be remembered was arrested on the night of the murder, while HAGAN on Sunday night voluntarily surrendered himself to the Police.

The Kansas correspondent of the Tribune gives the following as the clause of the Constitution in regard to Slavery as adopted by the Convention at Lecompton: PREAMBLE. The right of property is before and higher than any Constitutional sanction, and the right of the owner of a slave to such slave and its increase is the some and as inviolable as the right to my property whatever.

To-day I must commence with a complaint against that constant enemy of Americans in Paris, the English Post-Office Department. Certainly our sufferings have been ameliorated within the last few years, but there is yet an abuse of which our Post-Office Department ought to take cognizance.

GOV. JOHNSON A Biennial Message to the Legislature of Georgia, discusses the affairs of the State with great minuteness, and is not so verboss on the subject of Federal relations as the majority of Southern messages are wont to be. The Governor begins with a review of the State finances. Money matters appear to be in a very comfortable condition. All the liabilities of the State have been promptly met.

One of the most important decisions ever made by the Court of Appeals in this State will be found reported in another column of this morning's TIMES. It relates to the right of a Railroad Company to lay its crack through a public street or road. without the consent of the owners of adjoining property--and as it denies that right entirely.

To-day the Fort Ripley Reserve, consisting of fifty-seven thousand acres of land, goes to the same Democratic borne at four cents an acre!

Mme. LA GRANGE'S concert last night, at the Mozari Rooms, was about as well attended as such entertainments are likely to be. We hope that Miss SIMON will be substantially benefited, and placed in a position to complete her musical education. The pecuniary success of a concert of this kind is not determined by the attendance; at least we hope not in the present case.

Our "respectable" citizens have for a long time kept up the most plantive lamentations over the degeneracy of our City Government. They mourn over the degeneracy of the times,--the prevalance of crime and disorder,--the exclusion of our "best men" from office, and the monopoly of all political power and all places of responsibility by the reckless and unprincipled.

PRIZE FIGHT.--A pugilistic encounter, under the rules of the prize ring, for a few dollars, took place about 5 o'clock on Sunday morning, on Berrian's Island, in the East River, nearly opposite Randall's Island. The principal bruisers, stake-holder, judges, referce, time-keeper and bottle-holder, as well as a large portion of the audience, halled from the Fourth Ward.

It has new become probable that the calenlations of these who have anticipated a serious aggravation of the monetary crisis in this country and in England, from the effects of the conflict in India, will be disappointed as thoroughly as the expectations have been of these who prophesied a paralysis of the British power at an early stage of the difficulty.

MURDER ON BOARD AN AMERICAN VESSEL IN A FOREIGN PORT.--Deputy Marshals O'KEEFE and HOGAN, on Saturday last, arrested four of the crew of the schooner Pilot's Bride, of New-York, lately arrived, and had them committed as witnesses in the case of the murder of the mate of that vessel by a Portuguese named JOSEPH SILVIE, while she was lying at Porto Cabello.

The heavy rains of the past two days have caused great damage in this vicinity and farther up the Genesee Valley. At and within two miles of Janesville, eight dams and six bridges were carried away last night. The Geneseo River is now quite as high as it was during the flood last Spring, and the water is still rising. The Central Railroad track was last night much damaged by the flood.

Bids for a loan of half a million to the Canal Fund were opened here to-day. It was awarded at an average of $6 21 per cent. premium. The whole amount is taken in New-York, except $25,000 at $105 46. by JOHN SILL, of Albany. WHITEHOUSE, SON MORRISON New-York, take $200,000 at $106 05, and G. S. ROBBINS SON take $175,000 at $105 50 @$107.

I have referred, on several occasions, to the state of the arts in this city, as they appear in the galleries, the palaces and public squarces. For the most part, this subject is comprised in the history of the past and in the relics of centuries long gone by.

By the schooner Star, Capt. GAMMON, arrived this morning from Sisal, we have two weeks later advices from Yueatan--to the 14th ult. from Merida, the capital. The political war continued, without any decided success on either side, thought it would appear that the advance of the revolutionists had been arrested. Our papers by this arrival, however, are all in the interest of the Government party, and their statements, perhaps, must be received with some caution.

A murder was committed at Fairfield, was shot and instantly killed by Major Rion, of Winnsboro. Player had offered an insult to Mrs. Rion, which her husband promptly resented, having first asked an apology, which was rejected. Major Rion stands ready to surrender himself.

DEMONSTRATIONS OF THE UNEMPLOYED-It is only charitable to the workingmen, who have been making their useless demonstrations in the streets, to suppose that if they had anything better to do they would do it. There are some few mouthing demagogues among them, it is very probable,

Ordinarily the week that follows an election is a noisy time, the victors crowing lustily, while tile vanquished add to the uproar by their absurd endeavors to show how they have been cheated. Not so now. We have been as quiet as if we acknowledged the rose for our emblem. With some few unimportant exceptions, the Republican presses treat their crushed foes with kindness. As to the vanquished, they are quiet enough.

The American Mayoralty Convention which me on Monday evening, issued an address upon the necessity of nominating some man for Mayor who would be the representative of no party, but the candidate of the people at large. They made out their case very clearly,--and then proceeded to nominate Mr. COOLEY, as the American candidate.

The young daughter of a respeciable physician, residing in Brooklyn, was married a few days since in a denist "just over the way." ?? stances which have made the affair the subject of much comment. Time lady is only 17 years of age, and after a brief acquaintance with the dentist, a mutual attachment sprang up between them.

A fire broke out in the Lard Oil Factory of HENRY LRWIS on Sycamore-street, in this city, this morning. LOSS $10,000; no insurance. The rear part of the building was occupied by E. B. TOWNSEND, Pork Packer, and was but slightly damaged.

The St. Paul Pioneer and Democrat, of the 3d, claims to have heard from the Pembina region, and reports seven hundred majority there for SIDLEY, (Administration Democrat,) electing him Governor by 250 majority. It claims also 3 majority in the Senate and 6 in the House.

We assure our readers that we are not speaking new of any wild project which it is always easy to conceive when once in the domain of social or political fantasy. The possibility of uniting England and France by means of a submarine tunnel has been practically and scientifically considered by a skillful engineer, M. A. THOME DE GAMOND.

The unemployed met, yesterday morning, in Tompkins-square to the number of four or five thousand, an advertisement in the daily papers having conversed the meeting at 11 o'clock. On a Lamppost at the side of the fountain, or rather the dried up basin, which was once a fountain, where the meeting was held, a banner, presented by a Mr. WITTEN. ??, was exhibited.

THE CUEVA CASE--SENTENCE TO BE PASSED To-DAY.--The Hudson County Court, Judge OGDEN presiding, reopened yesterday morning at 10 1/2 o'clock. After the usual preliminary business. Mr. LITTELL, the District-Attorney, moved that the case of CUEVA be taken up for final disposition. Whereupon the Judge sent for the prisoner, and he soon after made his appearance, accompanied by his father, and took his seat within the bar.

He crew from the Commercial Bank, $1,000 in bills--$160 of which he handed to a friend, to be paid to a party at Avon.

Senior Mignel T. Tolon, formerly editor of a Spanish paper in this City, and one of the leading spirits among the Cuban patriots, died in Cuba a few weeks guide. Mr. Tolon was a native of Matauzas, and in politics always sympathized with the Liberal Party. For the part he took in the Lopez enterprise he was banished from Cuba, and the greater part of his term of exile was spent in the United states.

THE REALLY SUFFERING.--The following paragraph is from the police returns of yesterday: STARVING TO DEATH.--Officer BROOKS, of the Tenth Precinet Police, yesterday found a German family, consisting in all of five persons, residing in a Level at No. 44 Orchard-street, literally staring to death.

A correspondent of the St. Paul's Times gives currency to a highly important rumor, of the truth of which he expresses no doubt, to the effect that five hundred United States troops, supposed to be a detachment of the Utah expedition, had been attached and massacred by a large party of the Teelowan Indians at some point near the Missouri River.

DAMAGE TO THE CENTRAL RAILROAD TRACKDELAY OF TRAINS, ALBANY, Wednesday, Nov. 11. The rain-storin west of this place has proved very destructive. Several culverts on the Central Railroad are broken. The bridge over the Genesee, at Rochester, was for a long time considered to be in danger. All trains for the West have been delayed.

The large dailies of Chicago have reduced the size of their sheets, in consequence of the dullness of advertising. At Davenport, Iowa, the dailies have diminished the size of their pages by mutual agreement. In Milwaukee, the American has be on united with the News, (Democratic.) At Buffalo the wages of compositors have been lowered by the newspaper publishers.

A trial has just come to a close in France which surpasses in singularity any of the curious causes celebres which abound in the judicial annals of the grand nation. It contains so many novelties both in its origin and in the manner in which it has been conducted, that we feel we should not be doing justice to our readers if we allowed it to pass as an obscure item of foreign intelligence.

The Managers of the Home for the Friendless tender their grateful thanks to Mr. J. S. MARTIN and others in Washington Market, through whose liberality two hundred and fifty pounds of meat was received on Wednesday, accompanied by the following note. This gift is specially opportune at the present time, as the wants of the Institution are most pressing. May the kind donors be rewarded by "the blessings of many ready to perish."

PRINTERS IN TROUBLE AT MOBILE.--THE "RATTING" SYSTEM--At Mobile, a few days ago, the publishers of the Tribune brought suit against certain members of the Mobile Typographical Union, for conspiracy to injure them in their business.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: A remarkable example of the circumstances into which the most bonest and well-meaning of political teachers may be or occasionally hurried by too evident and impassioned devotion to a pet theory is being at this moment afforded by the position of the two great industrial interests of this country. No idea has been more forcibly presented to the minds of the masses of the northern states.

The President, in pursuing the policy of rigid retrenchment in every department of the Government expenditures, expects to keep the estimates of appropriations for next year's expenses (to be submitted to Congress at its meeting) within forty millions of dollars, against eighty-five millions appropriated last year.

GEORGIA.--Governor BROWN, of Georgia, in his inaugural, devotes himself mainly to State affair, the railroads, education, banks, He declares his purpose to order proceedings for the forfeiture of the charter of every bank that shall suspend specie payments, deeming the law on that subject imperative.

The American Convention of the Third District on Tuesday night nominated JAMES MURRAY for police Justice, in place of Judge BROWNELL,. the present incumbent of that office, and HENRY J. IRVING for Civil Justice. In the Fourth District, BARNABA'S W.OSBORN was renominated for Police Justice, the same evening, and WILLIAM VAN Corr for Civil Justice.

The Laborers in Tompkins-square--The Rowdies have a Good Time. The passage of the Central Park appropriation, or something else, had the effect to reduce the numbers assembled yesterday at Tompkins-square. They began to gather at an early hour in the morning, but by 10 o'clock there were not over two thousand persons present, all told.

We are in the constant receipt of communications suggesting the names of available candidates for the Mayoralty against Mayor Weon. We must decline their publication, not because they are not well written, and still less because the names suggested are not worthy of respectful consideration,-but simply because we see no good result to follow such publications.

The ship Howadji, of Newburyport, was struck by Lightning on the 3d of November, and entirely destroyed. Her crew were rescued by the ship Gutenberg, of Hamburg, which arrived at this port late last night.

DETECTION OF RIVER THRIVES.--A POLICEMAN FILING ON THEM AND HITTING ONE.--A little before 1 o'clock yesterday morning, Officers Cook and Washburn, of the Ninth Ward, discovered two river thieves in a small row-boat alongside the sleep W. D. Naples, tying at the foot of Lerey-street. As soon as the theives saw the officers they took to their cars and commenced pulling vigorously into the river.

From the New-Orleans Bulletin. No man in his senses can expect an essential improvement in our cities, a diminution of crime, until the laws are enforced against criminals, their instigators and apologists: and this cannot be reasonably expected, when the past and present are duly considered, until our preventive and punitive systems are modified to meet the exigencies of the times.

MOORE.--In this City, on Wednesday, Nov. 11, WILLIAM MOORE, aged 62 years and 5 months. The relative and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend his funeral, from his late residence, Nov. 638 Greenwich-st., this (Thursday) afternoon, at 1 o'clock, without further invitation. THORP.--In Brooklyn, on Tuesday evening, Nov. 10, GOUID H., Jr., only child of Gould H. and Eman C. Throp, aged 3 months and 10 days.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The loss of the Central America and the noble, self-sacrificing spirit of her brave commander has enlisted the sympathies of the whole community. But I fear there is some misunderstanding in reference to the appropriate expression of feeling on the subject which needs explanation.

EXCISE BOARD--FORTIETH SESSION.--Commissioners KERR and HASKETT opened the Board, and granted two licenses. The President examined before the Board Insepctor Hutchings, of the Fifth Precinct, in relation to the application of Mrs. Pastor. He said her house was as orderly as the St. Nicholas, and upon this a license was granted to her.

Governor HARRIS devoted his attention almost exclusively to the subject of Slavery, upholding "State Rights" very zealously. The steamship Tennessee has arrived from Vera Cruz, 7th inst., with advices from the City of Mexico to the 4th by the mail, and the 6th by telegraph. The Tennessee brings over half a million in specie, and highly important intelligence.

This statue, which is the first considerable achievement of a gifted young lady, who deserves better thinks of us than to be baptized by the ridiculous title of "The Americal Sealpiress," has just been brought to this City from Boston, and is now on exhibition at the rooms of the Academy of Design, in Tenth-street, near Broadway.

On a bank a child lay sleeping, By a singing, crystal brook, Which, untiring, still kept leaping, Piercing in its path each nook; Vain was all its noise and rattle, For the child slept sweetly still--Hush'd his merry laugh and prattle, By the gently rippling rill.

VALENTINE was unanimously nominated for Alderman of the Ward.
Advices from Fort Laramie to Oct. 22, state that Colonel Coox's command, the Second Dragoons, were four miles this side the fort, and had enoountered a snow storm five days previously.

THE MEXICAN DICTATORSHIP.--The change that for some weeks past has been anticipated in the political condition of Mexico has at length taken place. On the 4th instant the popular rights guaranteed by the new Constitution were suspended, and President COMONFORT was clothed with Dictatorial powers.

THIRD-AVENUE RAILROAD.--The Fourth Annual meeting of the Stockholders of the Third-avenue Railroad was held at he office of the Company, in Sixty-first - street, on Wednesday afternoon. THURLOW WEED, Esq. presided as Chairman, and HENRY S. BURGER officiated as Secretary. .

The Cunard steamship Arabia, from Liverpool on the Sist ult., is now due at this port. The news will be one week later, and during that period intelligence of our Bank suspension will have reached England. As people on the other side of the water were fully prepared, by previous advices, for the worst, we do not expect to hear that our suspension of specie payments will be attended there with very alarming consequences.

DESTRUCTIVE FUGE AT WATERFORD, N.Y. ALBANY, Wednesday, Nov. 11. A destructive fire occurred at Waterford, Saratoga County, at 4 o'clock this morning. The extensive flouring built of Messrs. MORSE, EDDY, Co. together with the storehouse attached, and its contents, were entirely destroyed. Ten thousand bushels of Wheat and four hundred barrels of Flour were in the storehouse.

A meeting of Drovers was held at the Girard House, last evening, the object of which was to take measures for concentrating all the patronge of the western drovers upon some one railroad, with a view to reduce the present high rates of freight. EMERSON TRAVESTIE--The highest compliment that an author can have paid him is for his celemporaries to travesile his writings. This distinction Mr. EMERSON is now having thrust upon him. His poem entitled "Brahma," in the new Boston Monthly, is such an exquisite piece of meaningless versification, that no sooner is it real than the desire to parody it becomes irresistibis.

The Lecompton correspondent of the Republican says that a majority of the Convention, headed by CALHOUN, MOORE and HENDERSON, propose to submit the Constitution to the people in the following form, via.: A Constitution with Slavery and a Constitution without Slavery, the vote to be taken about the 20th of December, and every actual resident at that time time to be allowed to vote.

We have no desire to generate a national crusade against the infatuated disciples of the Mormon delusion. Gross and odious as are the practices in which the fanaticism of that wretched people finds expression, it would be equally unworthy of our higher civilization and of our purer faith, if we should seek to obliterate their errors by exterminating themselves.

Lastreveiring a large and highly intelligent audience, among whom we noticed several of our most eminent lliorary men and diviaes, assembled in the lecture-room of the Mercantile Library to hear a lecture from Mr. J. HOWARD WAINWRIGHT, on the "Sea and Sailor of Antiquity." The subject itself was full of interest, but the circumstance that it was delivered in aid of the "Herndon Testimonial Fund" rendered it still more attractive.

DESTRUCTIVE HIRE IN CULPEPER, VA. WASHINGTON, Thursday, Nov. 12. At about 4 o'clock this morning two newspaper offices and five stores in the village of Culpeper, Va., were destroyed by fire. The loss is estimated at $30,600.

From the Chicago Times, (the organ of Senator Douglas,) Nov. 10. The Convention assembled in Kansas to frame a State Constitution is in session, and has framed a large portion of an instrument. The Committee upon the subject of Slavery has reported a provision, which has been adopted by the Convention, though it has yet to be voted on as forming part of the whole.

A ROW ON A HUDSON RIVER RAILROAD TRAIN.--A party, consisting of half a dozen drunken men, got on board the Express train from this city, at Peekskill, and refusing to pay their fare, commenced a hideous uproar, ending with the smashing of windows, lamps and seats, and assaulting the passengers, who were compelled to fee into the other cars for safety. MULLIGAN--FULLER.--In this City, on Wednesday, Nov. 11, by Rev. Thomas H Taylor, D. D., WILLIAM MULLIGAN, of St. Louis, to EMILY, daughter of Dudley B. Fuller, of this City.

BANQUET TO MR. BANKS AT WALTHAM.--The townsmen of Hon. N. P. BANKS, Governor elect of Massachusetts, gave him a public banquet at Waltham on Tuesday. Over three hundred persons were present. GIDEON HAYNES, Esq., presided. Mr. BANKS, being called upon for a speech, returned his acknowledgments, and spoke briefly on political subjects.

The ship Hewadji, from Boston for Liverpool, which was struck by lightning on Nov. 3 and lost, was insured here for $142.000, as follows: Merchants' office. $27,500; Boston, $21,000; American, $20,000; China. $17,000; Boylston, $17,000: National, $16,000; Mercantile, $8 50; Ahlance, $10,000; Franklin, $5,000; New-England Mutual, $700, and Neptune, $400.

The total number of unions in the year 1855, was 21,551. Letters from several points west, received this morning, bring details of the disastrous effects of the freshets. Some passengers have arrived here from Rochester. They got down to Lyons on the new road by rail, and thence crossed In carriages to Genova on the old road. They had a hard passage.

SLACK,--In Brooklyn, on Wednesday, Nov. 11, THOMAS SLACK, Sr., aged 63 years. Friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend his funeral, this day, (Friday. at 2 o'clock P. M, from his late residence, No. 50 East Warren-st., Brooklyn.
The Cunard steamship Arabia, from Liverpool the 31st, has not yet been signalized. The weather is clear and calm, and the steamer's lights could be seen at a great distance.

The movements in Breadstuffs during the past week have been quite heavy. The interior furnished large supplies, and as receivers manifested no disposition to reserve them, buyers purchased freely, especially for export, at generally well-supported prices, the market closing briskly and baounntly for the loading commodities, the available stocks of which, here are moderate for the season,

BROOKLYN COMMON COUNCIL.--AN INEBRIATED ALDERMAN,--An adjourned meeting of the Brooklyn Board of Aldermen was to have been held on Wednesday evening, but a quorum of sober members could not be obtained. Nineteen Aldermen were on hand at a reasonably early hour, and waited more than an hour for the twentieth to make a quorum, An officer was finally dispatched to bring in the first Alderman he could find.

The Granada, by the arrival of which at New-Orleans we received this intelligence, was detained at Quarantine, which prevented the transmission of the California news in season for this morning's TIMES.

There was a noticeable falling off in the number of those who have been in the habit of congregating in front of the City Hall as the Unemployed, yesterday. There were a few standing around in groups, but not more than may often be seen on days when no general cry for work or bread is heard.

The steam-boiler in the plumbing establishment of Mr. WHEELER BIERS, corner of Water and Gilbert streets, exploded shortly after noon to-day, The first story was occupied by Mr. BEERS himself, and the upper ones by Mr. HENRY WALES, as a coffee and spice mill. The building is a complete wreck.

THE PUFF DIRECT.--The Daily News, speaking of Mayor WOOD, concludes a very long article thus: "To conclude, he is a man of a statesman-like mind, of the type of ALEXANDRA HAMILTON of our own country, and possessing the energy, courage and executive talents of men of the order of WILLIAM PITT, of England."

REFORMING THE CREDIT SYSTEM.--The recent movement of the Hardware Dealers, which had for its object the regulation of the credit system, does not appear to have been responded to by any other class of our merchants.
A telegram from New-Orleans informs us that General WILLIAM WALKER has started for Nicaragua. He appears to have effected his departure in a calm, orderly, and business-like way.

Before Judge Ingerson. Drake and others vs. Heman J. Redfield, ex-collector.--This action was brought by the plaintiff to recover $2,620 40, claimed to be an excess of duty paid upon sugar. The evidence for the plaintiffs showed that the appraisement had been made on samples of sugar, whereas the law requires that one package out of every ten should be appraised.

Henry P. Brooks, the opponent of Henry Winter Davis, for Congress in the late election in Maryland, has given notice of his intention to contest that gentleman's seat. The ground of contest is the alleged fact that the supporters of Brooks were prevented from voting for him by violence, while by fraud the vote of Mr. Davis was increased.

Last week Joel Schoonhozen, 100 years of age, was discharged from Sing Sing State Prison, having been pardoned y the Governor. He was committed for the for arson, He is a native of Orange County, and reached the age of a century in prison on the 4th of July late saw Washington at Newburgh during the war.

A fire at Hamilton; Can., on the 7th ., breaking out in PERRY'S Stables,, on Catherine-street, destroyed LAVENDAR'S flour store, McKAY'S saloon and other properly to the amount of $10,000 over the insurance. Supposed to have been the work of an incendiary.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Few things can be more distressing to a genuine American soul, than to find the working-classes aping the incendiary processions and conspiracies of old despotic countries, and, like the wretched rabble of European capitals, charging every social distress upon the Government.

A novel has lately been published by BENTLEY, in London, entitled Quinland; or, Varieties in American Life, which has been rather favorably noticed in English journals. Who the author of Quinland may be we have not heard surmised.

THE POLICE COMMISSION.-The world turns on its axis again! After an interregnum of over four months, the Police Commission is again in working order. Mr. PELATIAH PERIT accepts the place, and the note in which this is signified to the public indicates a purpose on his part to devote himself with fidelity and rigor to the discharge of its duties.

We have dates from Rio de Janeiro to Oct. 1, In the Journal de comercio of Sept, 30 we find the following: "It has been reported for some days back that the gravest disorder had broken out on board the United States frigate St. Lawrence, anchored in this port. One of our colleagues this morning thus notices this rumor:

CARPENTER.--In this City, on Thursday, Nov. 12, LEONARD W. CARPENTER, of the firm of Carpenter Randolph, aged 33 years. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, on Sunday, 15th inst., at 2 1/2 o'clock P. M., from his late residence, No. 29 1/2 West 20th-st. His remains will be taken to Plainfield, N. J., for interment.

Your correspondent's foreshadowings are realized. General WALKER is fairly off on another expedition. In Cabinet meeting to-day his movements were discussed. Dispatches were received from the District-Attorney of New-Orleans giving the essential facts.

The Arabia brings as the news of the death of Gen. CAVAIGNAC. He died suddenly of aneu??ism of the heart, while shooting over his estates, on the 30th of October. A little less than nine years ago, on the 10th of December, 1848, this illustrious man, whose sword was then the sceptre of France, laid down that sceptre with all the dignity of true honor,

Before Hon.Judge Russell. The trial of James Rodgers for the murder of John Swanston, in the Tenth-avenue, on the 17th October last, was continued yesterday. Stephen McGiurcy, examined by the District-Attorney--I am 19 years old; I know Rodgers, the prisoner; I was in his company on the night of the homi??; I met him at 6 1/2 o'clock in Tenth-avenue and Sixteenth-street;

SUICIDE OF AN AMERICAN GENTLEMAN IN PARIS.--Our Paris correspondent, this week, informs us of the death, in that city, under very painful circumstances, of a gentlemen well known in the commercial circles of the Southern States.

The ship North Wind, Captain GORE, has put in here in distress, having experienced a severe typhoon near the Baher Island. She was bound from Foo Chow to London; she is now discharging her cargo, which is considerably damaged. The wreck of her must has cut up the copper under her bottom very much.

LOSS OF THE STEAMER REINDEER. CHICAGO, Friday, Nov. 13. The steamer Reindeer, running between St Louis and Alton, struck a snag at the mouth of the Missouri River, last night, and sunk in nine feet of water. She was uninsured.

Among the new Patents issued on the 10th inst. were the following: To Captain EDWARD CAVENDY, of New-York, for a method of determining Approximate Latitudes at sea. To RICHARD M. HOE, of New-York, for a method of feeding paper to printing-presses.
The Judges of Election for thin City have made returns of an election held on the "fourth Wednesday of November," while the Constitution requires the election to be held on the "first Wednesday."

A Card from Mr. Cooley. I had the honor on the evening of the 9th inst., to receive from the whole body of the American Mayoralty Convention, assembled at my own door, the announcement from the lips of its President, that I had been unanimously nominated a candidate for Mayor of the City of New Nork.

Report of their Committee. The following is an official report of the progress made yesterday by the Committee of the Unemployed, that is authorized to seek out the most destitute among the unemployed and report their names to the Mayer for immediate relief.
The Royal Mail steamship Arabia, Capt. STONE, which sailed from Liverpool at 81/2 o'clock on the morning of Saturday the 31st ultimo arrived at this port at about 6 o'clock yesterday morning.

In steamship Arabia, from Liverpool--Mr. Kingeford and lady, Mr. Steinkanber and lady, Miss McLaughlin, Miss Charlotte Clement. J. S. Brander and lady, Mrs. Henner, Miss E. Crowther, Dr. Dudley. lady and niece. Miss Collins. Miss Ackland, Miss Pettibone, Miss Taylor, P. C. J.

THE CUBAN QUESTION.--If our Washington Correspondent is correctly informed, A. BELMONT, Esq., is to be appointed American Minister at Madrid, mainly for the purpose of prosecuting the negotiation for the purchase of Cuba. President BUCHANAN seems determined to push this project which he has so much at heart.

Dr. JOSEPH T. CURTIS, a distinguished homeopathic physician, residing at No. 49 East Twentieth, street, committed suicide about 11 o'clock yesterday morning. He was a man much esteemed in his profession, a student of GRAUNN, and one of the first who practiced on the Hahnnemanie theory in this City.

The Constitutional Convention is making rapid progress in their action, as you will perceive by the documents which are herewith transmitted. I forbear making any comments, leaving that in hands more able than mine to do justice to the subject.

Col. WARREN SCOTT made a strong argument to-day against the verdict against DONNELLY. He showed by the records that it was contradictory. He also cited authorities to show that it was contrary to law, because each count in the indictment charged.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR: Your attention is respectfully called to a statement in the TIMES OF THE 11th instant, in which Mr. PATRICK DOLAN, of Bridgeport, Conn., is suspected of poisioning his wife.

From the Journal of Commerce. But when reduced to its ?? simple elements, the question seems easy of solution; for in reality the chief paint at issue is the contenance of the "Albany usurpation."

The commerce a a??ces by the Arabia, yesterday, made same of our worthy fellow-citizens feel a little foolish. We had been waiting with breathless anxiety, for the explosion of the bomb-shell we had sent over something like a month ago.

We publish, on another page of this morning issue, the conclusion of the trial of JAMES RODGERS, a youth of seventeen, for the murder of JOHN SWANSTON. The prisoner has been convicted on the fullest, clearest, and most relative evidence.

BRIGGS--STEPHENS--In this City, on Thursday. Nov. 13 by Rev. S. D. Brown, Mr GEO. H. BRIGGS to Miss CORNELIA STEPHENS. all of this City. WILLIAMSON--CRAWFORD.--In this City, on Wednesday, Nov. 14, at No. 151 West 38th st.. by Rev. James Thompson. Mr. ARCHIBALD WILLIAMSON to Miss MARGARET CRAWFORD. both of this City.

In the Journal de Comercio, of Rio de Juneiro, we find from Buenos Ayres to Sept 15, and Montervideo to Sept. 18. In Montevideo the coming election was creating stirring times. Parties were very much exasperated against each other, and all idea of concilliation was repudiated. Bloody events were expected to take place during November.

The following is a dispatch to M. O. ROBERTS Esq.: SOUTHWEST PASS OF THE MISSISSIPPI, Thursday, Nov. 12, 1857. The steamship Granada, from New-York for New -Orleans, the Philadelphia, from New-Orleans for New-York , and the Sl. Louis, from Aspinwall for New-York, entered the harbor of Havana on the 9th Inst.

On the 4th of September the siege-train of General WILSON reached his camp before Delhi; on the 8th ponderous balleries opened their fire, and on the 13th the British troops were summoned to the assault of the breached and crumbling walls of the city of the Moguls, in a "general order" as commendable for the manly humanity of its temper as for the high-spirited determination of its tone.

ENLARGED ACCOMMODATIONS AT MR. BEECHER'S CHURCH--The crowds that throng to hear Mr. BEECHER at his church, in Orange Street, come so constantly, that permanent moans of accommodation for them have been rendered indispensable.

The Canard steamship Arabia, with London and Liverpool advices to the 31st ult., one week later arrived at this port yesterday morning. Contrary to general expectation. the news of a Bank suspension in the United States has created no uneasiness on the other side.

The meeting of cilizens opposed to the reelection of FERNADO WOOD is advertised in the City papers, and in large posters, for this afternoon at 8 1/2 o'clock, in front of the Merchants' Exchange. The call of the meeting is indorsed by a thousand signatures of citizens, who append their residences, and who will be able thereby to have communication from the committees which may hereafter engineer the opposition.

We receive, by way of St. Johns, a brief summary of four days later European intelligence The Ariel. from Southampton on the 11th inst for New-York, passed Cape Race on the night of the 13th, and was boarded by the yacht of the Associated Press. No political intelligence of interest is reported.

A lively time was experienced at Lynn last week. A public meeting of citizens was held to devise means for relieving the pressure of the times. Resolutions, containing severe denunciations of the shoe manufacturers for sending shoe away to the country to be made up, brought out an acrimonious debate. After a bitter debate, the resolutions were rejected,

General WALKER's departure for Nicaragua still continues the topic of conversation in all circles, and the President professes to be exceedingly annoyed at his successful escape. The Administration are now fully aware that WALKER has plenty of opportunities for getting safely into his proposed field of operations. It is only surprising that they did not discover the fact before.

We are likely to have at last a City PostOffice. This department of tho General Government, of more universal importance than any other, in this largest City of the Continent, has hitherto been obliged to roost in old churches, or in other buildings equally unfit for the business to be done.

SUEZ AND PANAMA, AS VIEWED BY A GERMAN.---A new feature of the Suez Canal project has been developed by a critic in the Zeil, a Prussian journal. After enlarging upon the advantages England would derive from its completion, in maintaining her ascendancy in India, he passes to the cotton question---the nucleus, he says, of her material development, her national wealth,

NEGRO STASTIC--Last Sunday night, 7th, a family of negroes belonging to GEORGE W. FAIRFAX, of Preston County, Va., and consisting of father and mother and five children, look three horses belonging to their master, and made good their escape into Pennsylvania.

Gov MCRAE'S valedictory message to the Legislature of Mississippi is devoted wholly to State matters. Federal relations are not even alluded to. The leading point of the Message is its reference to Banks, institutions which the Governor looks upon with an evil eye. In regard to them he says: "As remarkable as it may seem, with the past history of the banking system in Mississippi fresh in our memories,

We have an institution here called La Petile Bourse, a fungus on the body of the great Bourse. The police are trying to sappress this morbid excrescence of the moneyed corporation; and this fact leads me to speak of it. All your readers, perhaps, do not know what this institution is, much less why the authorities should seek to suppress it,

Cexovar, Esq., as Street Commissioner, and sent to the Board of Aldermen on Thursday evening, of contracte for Government Work, duly advertised, opened and awarded, and only waiting the action of the Common Council and Mayor to put them in immediate operation.

The ship Jeremiah Thompson remains as yet in the same condition, with the exception that the ports on the larboard side have been stopped up, and six steam-pumps are now on board of her, all in readiness to free her from water as soon as the open ports under water can be stopped. There are forty men employed upon her, with submarine divers, and it is expected that they will commence pumping to-day.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I cannot quite concur in the opinion you express that the sentence of CURVA is "eminently just and proper." Under all the circumstances, I cannot but regard his being set at liberty upon such easy teries, as another example of the excessive leniency with which our tribunals nowadays deal with offenders of his class.

We have a variety of confused intelligence from Kansas concerning the political action of the Constitutional Convention. We copy from the correspondence of one of our Western exchanges a series of "shrieks" about certain impending perils, which are to plunge the Territory into sudden revolution, or prostrate its liberties under the fact of tyrants.

Immense Anti-Wood Meeting in Wall-street. On Saturday, at 3 1/2 o'clock, pursuant to an advertisement, an immense assemblage of citizens was convened in Wall-street, at the Merchants' Exchange, for the purpose of nominating a people's candidate for Mayor in opposition to FERNANDO WOOD. The call and list of subscribers to it were submitted by Mr. CHARLES GOULD, who nominated Mr. HENRY NICHOLL for Chairman.

The Liverpool COTTON market opened more steady. but closed the 3d Inst. with a declining tendency. There was, however, no change in prices slace the departure of the Arabia. The sales of the three days were 15,500, of which 2,000 were ?? speculation. The goods market at Manchester was dull an gloomy; sale unimportant.

THE MURDER IN TOPSHAM, MR.--The murder of a man named ELIPHALES BERRY, at Topsham, Me., on Monday evening last, has been already mentioned. BERRY, in company with a number of young men, had been to Brunswick, where they had been drinking pretly freely. They were returning home, with a jug of liquor in their possession,

Leuns Cass, Secretary of State: SIR: On the 1st of May last, in Nicaragua, I was charged by President WALKER with negotiating, drafting and subsequently carrying into execution the convention of Rivas. That negotiation was entered into and the capitulation was made solely with a United States officer, Capt. DAVIS, of the U. S. ship-of-war St. Mary's,

THOMAS CRAIG, who was convicted of altering the date of a promissory note, and passing the same, there by defrauding the discounter, has been sentenced to four years' imprisonment in the penitentiary. J. F. MANDY, a situation-master on the Great Western Railroad, was convicted of wrongly allowing an express to pass, and so causing a collision,

Mr. BEECHER prefaced his morning service yesterday by a discourse on Music. He read notices of two Concerts, to take place in Brooklyn on Wednesday evening, and, viewing the bits of information the notices contained in the light of the a text, delivered an excellent homily on the uses and beauties of cultivated music.

From the New-Orleans Picayune. By the schooner Red Fox, Captain COLE, we have advice from Tampico to the 30th ult., from the harbor to the 31st--very late. The Red Fox bring $63,622 in specie. Our files of Tamaulipas papers contain but little intelligence of general interest.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--To-night DONIZETTI'S opera of "Lucrezla Borgla" will be played, with LAGRANGS, D'ANGRI, BIGNAEDI, GASSIER, and other prominent members of the company in the caste. The afternoon performance on Saturday was a deserved success. The house was crowded, and at least fourteen hundred ladies were present. Owning to the Indisposition of Madame LAGRANGE, Mile.

The brig Falmouth, of New-York, arrived on Saturday from Grand Bossa, West Coast of Africa. She brought two of her crew, MANUEL MINES and ANTONIO JOSE, charged with making a revolt on board of said brig, in conjunction with two others named HENRY DANIELS and MICHAEL RUSSELL, who were left in Monrovia, in charge of the American Consul, to be sent home by the first American vessel.

INTRODUCTION OF WATER.--The Water Commissioners appointed by the Legislature to introduce the Paesalc water into the city of Hoboken, some time since advertised for proposals for a loan of $00,000, to enable them to accomplish the object, but before the advertisments had been published the requistic length of time, an injunction was obtained against them, by which they were restrained from acting.

A report reached this neighborhood on day before yesterday, that five hundred American soldiers had been cut of by a large party of Teetonwan, near the Missouri River. The news was brought here by a man from near the upper end of Big Stone Lake, whose son-in-law (one of the upper Sissitonwan) had just returned from a camp of the Ihanktonwan, on the Missouri River, where he heard the news.

LAUNCH OF THE RUSSIAN CORVETTE-The steam corvette, of twelve guns, built for the Russian Government, by Wm. H. WEBB, was successfully launched yesterday at 9 1/2 o'clock A.M. There was a large concourse of people in the yard and upon the adjoining plers to witness the spectacle, and several hundred were also on board.

FUNERAL OF DR. CURTIS.--The funeral of Dr JOSEPH T. CURTIS, who committed suicide on Friday last by shooting himself through the heart, took place yesterday at 3 P. M., at his late residence No. 19 East Twentieth-street. There was a large attendance of the friends of the deceased. Rev. Dr. CHAPIN conducted the funeral services, after which the body was interred in the Second-street Cemetery.

The London Times of the 2d inst. contains a long biographical notice of one of the "merchant princes" of the great Metropollis, who has had most extensive relations with this country. Mr. JAMES MORRISON, the eminent millionaire in question, died at his seat, Basildon Park, on the 30th ult., aged 68, and worth $20,000,000,

A NOVELTY IN OUR NAVAL NOMENCLATURE.-The principle upon which our new towns and Territories are named has never been satisfactorily explained, nor do we know precisely who are responsible for the christening of the counties of our new States; but in giving names to our national vessels the case Is very different.

The screw steamship City of Washington from Liverpool, at noon, on Wednesday, the 4th of November, arrived at this port yesterday afternoon at 1 o'clock. She left Liverpool on the same day that the Ariel left South Hampton. On Saturday, the 31st ultimo, the absorption of Consols by the public steadily continued, and the closing price for the day was 90 1/2.

Judge DAVIES yesterday granted an injunction against the Mayor and other officers of the City, restraining them from paying any money, under a contract made by the Board of Police Commissioners with S. C. JULLIE, for the glass ballot-boxes that were used at the last election.

PROBABLE HOMICIDE.--At 3 o'clock yesterday morning, while a young man named Henry Hamilton, residing at No. 130 West Twenty-fifth-street, was taking some oysters, in company with "his girl," in John Johnson's drinking saloon No. 388 Canal-street, another young man, named John Maroney, came into the establishment, when a dispute arose between the two concerning the young lady.

Feeling the immense importance attached to the action of the Constitutional Convention now in session at Lecompton, I visited them yesterday to note their proceedings. Gen. CALHOUN had vacated the Chair and called Mr. LITTLE, of Bourbon County, to preside. The Committee on Internal Improvements had just reported,

We trust the Legislature, at its coming session, will make some needed amendments in the Metropolitan Police Law of last Winter. To a certain extent that law was an experiment,--and while, in the main, it has worked well, experience shows that it can very easily be made to work better. Under the old systerm our Police Department had fallen into complete contempt.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: On Saturday afternoon, Nov. 14, as I was riding up town in omnibus No. 977 of the Broadway and Forty-Second-street line. I witnessed an example of insolence in the driver which I think should be made public. A lady pulled the string at Seventh-street and the stage relaxed its speed, but did not stop.

BROADWAY THEATRE.--Mr. CHAS. MATHEWS commenced a fresh engagement last evening. The weather was not favorable to a crowded house, but the promise of the entertainment attracted a larger audience than could be boasted at any other establishment in the City. The comedy of "Not a Bad Judge" was the principal piece on the bill.

Having been informed that a suit has been instituted against Mr. DECHERT for a most atrocious slander, in charging a very respectable gentleman with an attempt to poison him while a guest in his house, nothing could induce the undersigned to take any notice whatever of his recent card published in the Tribune, but the necessity there appears to be that his gross misstatements of facts should be corrected,

The Committee of the Unemployed who are seeking out and examining cases of destitution, and reporting them to the Superintendent of the Poor, made the following report yesterday morning of their proceedings since Saturday: On Saturday, at 10 o'clock, the Committee met at Union-square, when they divided--one half proceed.

EFFECTS OF VIOLATING THE SUNDAY LIQUOR LAW.--John Auferanger, a German, who keeps a grocery and a bar attached at No. 779 Greenwich-street, kept his place open on Sunday and dispensed liquors from his bar as irediy as on other days. Three young men named Wm. Lee, John Walkins and Wm. Beatly took some drinks in the evening at the bar and afterwards got to quarreling.

THE CITY SEXTON OF CHICAGO ROBBING GRAVES.--Great excitement has been produced in Chicago by the detection of MARTIN QUINLAN, the city sexon--a Catholic Irish Democratic office-holder--in the act of riding the graves of the dead, and shipping them off in wagons. ELI YORK, a medical student, who resides in Southern Illinois, was arrested at the same time, but Dr. BRAINAED, the President of the Medical College, became bail for him. .

The U. S. M. steamship St. Louis, WM. H. HUDSON, Commander, from Aspinwall Nov. 4, at 9 3/4 P.M., arrived at Havana at 9 ? A. M., on the 9th. Left Havana at 9 A. The Adritic returned to port yesterday morning, from her trial-trip of three days at sea. The company on board consisted simply of the owners, a few Naval officers, and persons interested in the construction of the vessel. Among the number were Mr. COLLINS, Mr. ALLIN, Chief Engineer MARTIN, U. S. N.; Lieutenants TAYLOR and TEMPLE, U. S. N.; Captain CAVENDY and Lieutenant BELAVENETZ, Russian Navy.

LOSS OF THE SCHOONER BALTIC, AND THE CAPTAIN AND CREW. NORFOLK, Monday, Nov. 16. A dispatch to the Herald says the schooner Baltic, from St. Jago, Cuba, bound to Baltimore, Currituck Beach. The Captain and all hands have been lost. A body (supposed to be Captain STEVENS') with the ship's papers on it, was washed ashore.

You will have tomorrow morning the statement, by some of your contemporaries, that the present Government of Nicaragua has been recognized, and that YAESARI was received to-day as Minister, and the excaty signed. This is positivory premature.

A Ladies' Fair Is now being held in the new Catholic Church, just created in Fourteenth street, near Avenue A, tile object of which is to raise a fund to be appropriated to defray a portion of the expense Incurred In building this magnificent edifice. The Church-which was projected by ladies of the Catholic faith-is 125x65 feet in dimensions in the clear, with brick walls 16 Inches thick.

The Santa Fe mail arrived at Independence on the 8th inst. Business was dull at Santa Fe, and money scarce. The party encountered a snow-storm this side of Fort Union. Grass and water were abundant on the plains.

COURT CALENDAR-TUESDAY, Nov. 17. UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT.--Nos. 13, 31, 24, 25, 41, 46, 48, 19, 37, 8, 21, 99, 14, 27, 6, 38, 39. SUPREME COURT.--CIRCUIT.--Nov. 16, Before Hon. Justice Davies. THE GANGEMI CASE. The People vs. Cangemi.--This case was brought on for a second trial this morning. A panel of one thousand jurors were impanneled.

A destructive fire broke out last night about 9 o'clock, in DRAPER'S mill, and before it could be sub?? destroyed most of the buildings in the pavine at the foot of the locks, together with the celebrated Spalding mill, owned by N. H. WOPPE Co., of New-York.

BROWN.--In this City, on 3d day (Tuesday) morning, GIDEON BROWN, in the 64th year of his age. His friends and the friends of the family, are invited to attend his funeral from the Friends' Meeting-house, corner of Rester and Elizabeth sts., this (4th day) morning, at 10 1/2 o'clock.

WESTERLY GALES.--Several vessels arrived, yesterday, from Europe, all of which report having experienced heavy westerly gales during the passage. The steamship Glasgow, from Scotland, brought 117 passengers; the Hammonia, from Hamburg, 405; the Ellen Austin, from Liverpool, 568--she had four deaths; and the Charles Cooper, from Antwerp, 270.

AN EXTRAORDINARY THANKSGIVING PROCLAMATION.-Gov. McRAE, of Mississippi, has issued an extraordinary Thanksgiving Proclamation. He thinks it possible that Providence should be thanked, but apparently isn't altogether certain of it:

The Board of Governors of the Almshouse, met at the Rotunda on Tuesday. C. GODFREY GUNTHER, Esq., in the Chair. Appropriations were made to enable the children of Randall's Island to enjoy themselves the Thanksgiving day. The subject of building a separate female Penitentiary was referred.

The 'Farmers' Club resumed their fortnightly meetings at the American Institute on Tuesday. There was not a very numerous attendance. On the table was a specimen of Japanese squash, grown by Mr. LIVENGSTONE and presented to Judge ?? from seed obtained from the Japan expedition.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR: In consequence of the unprovoked attacks of an unprincipled public journalist of this City on my character and good intentions, regarding the part I have taken to get up concerts in aid of the poor unemployed work-people of New-York,

At an inquisition taken at Northfield, in Richmond County, S. I., Feb. 5, 1857, before Coroner AMOS PEARCE, upon the body of a child named ANNA HILTON, the Jury found "that she came to her death by being beaten in a brutal manner, and from exposure and want of proper food at the hands of Mrs. MATILDA DECKER."

PHYSICAL AND METEOROLOGICAL - A new Comet, a faint telescopic apparition, was discovered at Cambridge (Mass.) Observatory on the evening of the 11th. Its place was near Theta Draconis. The discoverer was Mr. HORAON P. TURTLE, Assistant at the Observatory.

A NEW PHASE OF THE MORMON DIFFICULTY.-It will be seen by the highly important dispatches which have been received by the War Department at Washington, that BRIGHAM YOUNG has assumed the powers of an independent sovereign, and formally declared war against the United States.

The last news from Spain is considered as a sure indication of a speedy revolution, which cannot possibly be postponed more than two or three months. This will explain the aversion of the principal politicians of that country to assume the responsibility of forming a Cabinet.
We have had our first touch of Winter. Friday evening one could sit comfortably with as little fire as you'll find in a modern poem, and despised the luxury of blankets. Saturday morning, at sunrise,
By the arrival of the mail we have Galveston dates to the 7th inst. The ship Nebraska had bilged on the bar there, and the ship Fannin was also aground there and in a critical condition.

BROOKLYN COMMON COUNCIL.--An adjourned meeting of this Board was held on Monday evening, President PIERSON in the Chair. Board of Education.--The Committee on Schools, Arts and Sciences reported, and nominated as members of the Board of Education to fill vacancies occasioned by the resignation of EDWARD COPELAND and W. S. DILLINGHAM, the names of ROSWELL C. BRAINARD and EDWARD A. LAMBERT.

From the Chicago Times. At a recent dedication of a new Democratic Hall in Chicago, Senator DOUGLAS, in answer to repeated calls, appeared upon the stand amid loud and prolonged cheers from the assembled multitude.

The Railroads having, in accordance with a resolution of the Cleveland Convention, discharged all runners, the discharged runners of all roads centering at Indianapolis held a Convention in that city on Tuesday week, and resolved on an attempt to break down the combination formed at Cleveland.

DOCTRINAL.--The Washington Union has preserved the most guarded silence concerning affairs in Kansas for the last fortnight. Its last number, however, has a very long article designed to show that "the emancipation of the slaves of the Northern States was a great outrage," perpetrated by the majority, in depriving the minority of their properly without their consent.

Mormon affairs were again considered by the Cabinet to-day. The President will suggest to Congress extraordinary measures to suppress the Mormon rebellion. The sloop-of-war Saratoga, now at San Juan, will be relieved soon by a steamer.

DEAR SIR: You are informed as to the action of the Board of Police, on Saturday, in connection with the ordinance prohibiting the use of steam by the Railroad Companies, on Fourth-avenue, below Forty-second-street.

A spectacle was exhibited yesterday morning at the rooms of the Children's Aid Society, which all the philanthropists and economists of the community ought to have seen, and which we now take particular pleasure in bringing before the mind's eye of those who were denied the satisfaction of looking in person upon it.

EXTRAORDINARY TRAGEDY IN NEW-ORLEANS. On the 5th inst., in New-Orleans, a young girl named MARY WEDER, who resides on Annunciation street, went down town yesterday to visit a female friend, the wife of a man (a native of the Celestial Empire) named JOACHIM THOMAS.

Mr. FRANCIS VINCENT, the proprietor of an importing wine and liquor store at No. 15 William-street, was murdered, in his own store, a few minutes after ten o'clock last night. An old gentleman, named WILLIAM HILTON, who was present and witnessed the tregedy,

THE TIDE TURNING.--It was to be expected that the stringency of the times could not last forever. It is not surprising to see that the factories in all parts of the country are resuming work. This news is now coming in daily, from various manufacturing districts, as the tidings of the stoppages did in the worst days of the panic.

A new comedy in three acts, by Messrs. F. D. GOODRICH and F. L. WARDEN, called "Romance after Marriage, or the Maiden Wife," was produced here last night. The same authors will be favorably remembered for a more lengthy effort at Mr. BURTON'S theatre las season, and we are happy to state at the outset, that this new work justifies the favorable estimate we then formed of their capacity.

There is evinced in the Southern papers just now a very general disposition to extract from the miseries of tile present financial panic at the North, some grains of comfort for the supporters of the "peculiar institution." BELL--MATTHEWS.--In Brooklyn, on Monday, Nov. 16, by Rev. J. Kenneday, D. D., JOHN F. BELL to Miss ELIZABETH A. MATTHEWS, adopted daughter of Horace May, M.D.

UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT. Before Judge Retts. LIEN--PLEADING--STATE LAW--REFERENCE. William W Tapper ct al. vs. The Steamship st. Lawrence--This case came up on exceptions to a commissioner's report. The order of reference was taken by consent of the parties, with the reservation that "any questions of law that may arise on said reference be reserved for the consideration of the Court."

Through the intervention of a friend, one of those fortunate individuals who has only to sign his name to be heard in high places, I was included this year in the number of happy mortals who were invited to join the annual visit down among the immortals, or in other words down into the Catacombs; for it is a curious fact, that at Paris the immortals go down and not up.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR: I am curious to learn how that portion of the American Press which so confidently anticipated that the Cambridgeshire Handicap would be carried off by one of Mr. TEN BROECZ's horses will account for their signal defeat in that race.
The steamship Niagara with three days' later news from Europe, is now in her eleventh day out from Liverpool and due at Halifax. Nothing had been seen of her at a late hour last night.

WORKING-GIRLS LEAVING THE CITY FOR THE WEST.--About forty of the unemployed working-girls of the City left for the West yesterday afternoon, under the charge of Mr. C. C. TRACY, who was also accompanied by a company of homeless boys, from the Central Office.

The fifty-third anniversary celebration of the New-York Historical Society occurred last night in the Society's new building, corner of Eleventh-street and Second-avenue. The lecture was delivered by Dr. J. W. FRANCIS, who kept the audience enchained for an unparalleled period by his narrative of personal

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR: I think I have succeeded in discovering the meaning that lies hid in that Sphynx-like poem in the Atlantic Monthly, entitled " Brahma." Under the name of the great Indian divinity, it is very plain, to me at least, that the poet meant a certain personage somewhat nearer home.

The Board met at 7 o'clock P.M., present Commissioners COOLBY, BUTTERWORTH, GRAY, HUTOEINS, FIELDS, GREEN AND HOGG. Minutes of Nov. 10 read and approved. A communication from the Chief Engineer of the Croton aqueduct Department was received and referred to the Committee on Draining, with power.

THE BULLS IN TIME ASCENDENCY ONCE MORE.-The transactions at the Stock Board, yesterday, give evidence of an extraordinarily buoyant feeling in Wall-street. The sales of Stocks and Bonds are not large, but at prices greatly in advance of those ruling a week or ten days ago.

DEAR TIMES : What shall I do ? everybody is talking about me and questing me as a personification of everything foolish and extravagant In a woman ; and now that horrld Westminster Review, of whose opinion you seem to think so much, has taken up the same story, only he has not mentioned my name.

The Committee appointed at the Mass Meeting of citizens held at the Merchants' Exchange on the l4th inst., to confer with other Committees representing various political organizations, and report the name of a suitable candidate for the Mayoralty,

A letter from Fort Leavenworth, in the Buffalo Courier, gives the substance of official dispatches received at that post from Colonel JOHNSTONE, commanding the Utah expedition. These dispatches contain fuller information of the attack of the Mormons upon the army trains. Seventy-five wagons were burnt instead of seventy-three, containing not rations, but tents and clothing.

TRADE BETWEEN THE UNITED STATES AND ENGLAND.--The accounts of the British Board of Trade for the month of September show an increase of both imports and exports, as compared with the corresponding period of last year;

From the New-Orleans Delta, 10th. A CARD.--I have heretofore refrained from any notice of the numerous publications, false and ??belous as some of them have been, respecting the unfortunate relation which has existed between Mrs. CAROLINE WOODMAN and Mr. GARDNER FURNESS, of New-York.

From the Lockport Advertiser, Extra, Wednesday, About 9 o'clock last evening an alarm of fire was sounded by the "look hands," and in a short time the firemen were laboring industriously upon a fire which was raging in DRAPER's flouring mill in the ravine.

PARKER--CONACHER.--In this City, on Thursday, Nov. 10, in the Baptist Church, West 25th-st., by Rev. A. H. Wright, ISAAC PARKER. Esq., and Miss EUPHAMIA M. CONACHER, both of this City. VANDERVEER--GASMAN.--At Astoria, L. L., on Wednesday, Nov. 18, in the Presbyterian Church, by Rev. Mr. Stead, ADRIAN VANDERVEER, of Flatbush, L. L . to MARIA LOUISA. daughter of William Gasman, of Newton.

Pekin Gazettes were received here a few days since, bringing us news from the capital up to July 29. We are apprised in the Gazette of the 26th of the important fact that His Imperial Majesty, the Emperor, has given his approval to all of YEH'S doings at Canton. A short note from YEH was published in the above, from the translation of which I take the following interesting extract:

It is decided to send no Minister to Nicaragua until after the meeting of Congress. The new Treaty will be sent out by YRISSANI on the steamer of the 20th. The Treaty does not undertake to settle the boundary question between Costa Rica and Nicaragua, as alleged, but contains a declaration that nothing in it shall be construed to prejudice the just claims of the former.

Col. ALEXANDER was within 30 miles of Fort Bridger, which place is occupied by Mormon troops, when he received the following letter from BRIGHAM YOUNG, through the commander of the "Nauvoo Legion;" GOVERNOR'S OFFICE, UTAH TERRITORY, GREAT SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 29, 1857.

THOMPSON. - In this City , on Tuesday, Nov. 17, HENRINTTA B., wife of Frederick C. Thompson. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral. from her late residence No. 17 st. Luke's place. (Leroy-st.,) on Friday, the 29th inst., at 1 o'clock P.M. LENT.- In this City, on Tuesday evening, Nov, 17, William C. LENT in the 66th year of his age.

STILL MORE STABBING.--Shortly before 1 yesterday morning, two colored men, named EDWARD MATTHEWS and WM. MARSHALL, got into an altercation in West Broadway, near York-street, which ended in MATTHEWS stabbing MARSHALL three times in the breast, and inflicting serious if not fatal wounds.

The Mexican mails reached this City yesterday morning. Our files of papers from the capital extend to the 5th inst. The news is the most important that has been received for a long time. As already announced by telegraph, Congress has granted extraordinary powers to President COMONFORT, and thereby virtually admits its inability to carry on the Government in the present crisis.
