To The Editors of the Enquirer: GENTLEMEN: You have seen proper to interrogate me, through the Enquirer, as to the position I occupy touching the election of a Senator of the United States; and, believing that they are in good faith, fair and not unfriendly, I promptly reply to your questions as publicly as they are put.

The Mexican news, of which we this morning publish very full details, presents a deplorablo picture of the condition of the neighboring Republic. Indeed, it is hardly possible to believe that a country, with claims to civilization, could be so utterly devoid of law,

The Royal Mail steamship Niagara, from Liverpool at 1 o'clock P. M. of Saturday, the 7th inst., arrived at this port at 12 1/2 o'clock this A. M. She brings ?33,000 in specie for Halifax, and ?86,958 for Boston. The steamship Vanderbilt, from New-York Oct. 24, arrived at Southampton at 9 1/2 o'clock A. M. of the 5th inst. She grounded off Cowes, owing to a thick fog, but got off without damage.

GOVERNOR WISE UPON THE KANSAS QUESTION.--Governor Wise, of Virginia, has written a long and characteristic letter, which will be found in another column, upon the question of national politics, connected with the re-election of Senator HUNTER.

HARD TIMES AT THE ACADEMY.--Italian opera is a tender infant, and will not boar the rude kicks ofWall street. Mr. ULLMANN has propped it up as long as possible, but in spite of his efforts Italian opera is In a very shaky condition. To speak more plainly, there is danger of the present season at the Academy coming to an abrupt end.

The "Mormon question" can no longer berelegated to a secondary rank among the political difficulties of the day. The preposterous theology of the late JOSEPH SMITH, and the ungrammatical exercitations of the living BRIGHAM YOUND, have taken a positive place in the domain of fact, and demand a hearing at the muzzle of the rifle and at the point of the bayonet.

SUSPICION DESTROYED.--In the papers of last week was the statement that an individual named DOLAN, residing at Bridgeport, had been placed under arrest for the supposed destruction of his wife by poison. The facts are, that DOLAN came to New-York by direction of a priest of the Roman communion, and selecting Dr. FINNELL, of this City, (whose experience in post-mortem investigations is well known,) an examination was made of the body.

From the Washington Union (Official) of yesterday, The vexed question is settled--the problem is solved--the dread point of danger is passed--all serious trouble about Kansas affairs is over and gone. Kansas comes into the Union on the principle of the great act which organized her and Nebraska as territorial governments. Another star is added to the Republican constellation,

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.-VERDI'S "Rigoletto" was repeated last night to a very good house, and was given, on the whole, much bettor than last week when it was produced. Signora TAFFANELLI presents so many points of excellence as a vocalist, that we can afford to overlook little defects in acting. She is by far the best Rigoletto we have had. Madame LA GRANON was the heroine, vice FREEZOLINI resigned, dismissed or sick.

From the Charleston Mercury. Possibly we are extreme, because we have proposed and advocated a Southern party organization within the Democratic party of the South, for the protection of the interests and institutions of our endangered section. And what in this is extreme ?

THE MAYORALTY.-Two candidates are already in the field against Mayor Wood. Both are good men,-able, intelligent, upright and patriotic. JAMES E. COOLEY, the nominee of the American Party, has not yet formally accepted their nomination, and has indeed indicated his unwillingness to be the candidate of any mere party.

Mr. Andrew White, one of the early proprietors of the Albany Evening Journal, died in Albany on Tuesday. Mr. White was a native of Pennsylvania, removed to Albany while yet a boy, and at the establishment of the Evening Journal, in 1830, became one of its proprietors.

A letter from Shanghae, published on theo first page of tills morning's impression, will not fail to attract attention. Our correspondent, who has every facility for obtaining and transmitting reliable Information, intimates that, for the first time, the Emperor has given formal expression of his opinions on the war, and has fully indorsed the acts of his High Commissioner YEH.

CHARGE OF RECEIVING STOLEN GOODS.--Messrs. Lathrop, Ludington Co., dry goods merchants, a Nos. 23 and 25 Park-place, two or three days since discovered some of their goods in the auction rooms of Wm. Topping Co., in Broadway, near Pine-street. On inquiry, they learned that Mr. Myer Stern,

THE SCHOOL-BOOK NUISANCE.--In Brooklyn pupils in the public schools are required to pay for the text-books. This would be no hardship, if there were any reasonable limit to the number of text-books required. But, for some cause or other, a boy is put through more books in a year than there is any real necessity for in a whole college course.

By the arrival at Halifax yesterday of the Cunard steamship Niagara, we receive three days' later news from Europe. Financially, the intelligence is important. The Bank of England had raised its rate of discount to nine per cent., but, notwithstanding this the demand for money continued unabated. The pressure was very great, and had almost risen to the point of a panic.

THE "WORTH" CEREMONIAL.-The sub Committee of the joint Committee of the Board of Aldermen and Councilmen in relation to the inauguration of the Worlh Monument met yesterday in the library of the City Hall. Several designs were submitted by Mr. WILSON, to whom is confided the constructing of the catafalque for the transmission of the body. The Committee examined them and decided upon a modification of those presented.

DISCORD.-There is very little harmony of sentiment or purpose in the ranks of the City Democracy just at the present moment. The organ of " regular nominations" is waging a very bitter war upon "JIM SMITH" and DANIEL F. TIEMANN,-as well as upon lion. D. E. SICKLFS, RICHARD BUSTEED and other Democrate of the straitest sect.

The announcement, by telegraph, that General WALKER was arrested on the night of the 10th inst., is confirmed by the New-Orleans papers of the 11th. He was arrested at his lodgings in Custom-house-street, by a Deputy Marshal, armed with a writ issued by Judge McCALAB. The writ was issued on the affidavit of P. E. WALDEN, HENRY CRANE and O. H. POLK, of the New-Orleans Custom-House,

The Country Banks of New-York begin to day to redeem their circulation daily in this City through the Metropolitan Bank. This is done by prearrangement with the City Banks, which have recently taken at par and reserved for future presentation, unless immediately called for by the Country, seven and a hall millions Country Bank Notes.

NINE PER CENT.--It is surprising how easily the public mind becomes accustomed to the most startling phenomena. When tile news came not many weeks since that the Bank of England had put up the rate of interest to 5 1/2 per cent., allwall-street was terrified at the announcement.

The General Produce Markets fluctuated but slightly during the past week. Flour and wheat were freely offered and purchased at essentially unchanged quotations. A scarcity of corn occasioned a dinisisted business therein, at, however, advanced prices, Rye, Barley and oats were in inoderate supply and demand at steady rates.

The Charitable Concert for the Woman's Hospital is deferred until Tuesday night, Nov. 24, at Mozart's Hall, No. 663 Broadway, opposite Bond-street, In consequence of there being two other musical entertainments on the 19th. Ticket-holders are assured that they will lose nothing by the delay, as a far richer programme will be the result.

The steamship Niagara arrived at Boston about 3 1/2 o'clock yesterday afternoon, and the mails were dispatched by the steamboat train by way of Stonington. Owing to the heavy gale which prevailed on the Sound, it is not probable that they will reach this City before 8 or 9 o'clock this morning.

I learn from an intelligent gentleman, who has pent two or three years among the Salt Lake Mormons, a fact or two tending to confirm the suspicion that the recent horrible massacre of over 100 California emigrants, by the "Santa Clara" Indians, was perpetrated under the influence of the Mormon headers.

Thirty Now Policemen Appointed. The usual weekly meeting of the Board of Commissioners was held at their office yesterday--the following Commissioners being present: Mr. BOWEN, MR. CHOLWELL, MR. STRANAHAN, Mayor POWELL, MR. PERIT and General NYE.

From latest European Journals. DISGRACEFUL PROCEEDINGS ON BOARD AN AMERICAN VESSEL.--A Correspondent of the Manchester Guardian writes: "On Saturday, the depositions of GEO, JELFORD, pilot, and PETER MITCHELL, seaman, on board the New-York bark John Brookman, were taken before the Sunderland magistrates, as to proceedings on Friday afternoon, on board the vessel, while lying in Sunderland Roads.

What was understood to be a nomination of Mr. COOLEY, by the Anerican Convention, those gentlemen explained to mean merely a pledge of their support of him in the event that he should be nominated

WAS HE A FELLOW OF THE ACADEMY ?--A respectable lady called at the Inspector's Office yesterday, to obtain a permit to inter her child, who died on Wednesday, of small-pox. When asked for the doctor's certificate, she stated that the attending physician (Dr. WINCHELL, residing at No. 222 West Thirty-fifth-street) refused to grant a certificate unless she paid him first his demand of $8 for services rendered.

R. LYLE WHITE, Esq.--Dear Sir: The battle is lost, as men ordinarily estimate results. It will discourage the weak and doubting--the venal will seek shelter in the camp of the enemy. The men of courage and faith will stand firm, with confidence unshaken in the final triumph of the Right.

Senator SUMNER, on arriving here in the steamer Niagara this afternoyn, was received by Hon. HENRY WILSON, Hon N. P. BANKS and Mr. PHELPS, and escorted to his residence, where a large crowd had assembled to greet him. After receiving congratulations from his many friends, Mr. SUMNER made a few remarks to the assemblage, and retired amidst loud and enthusiastle cheering.

The weather here during the day was very clear and mild. The atmosphere this evening is thickening, with indications of rain. Wind S. W. NEW-HAVEN, Thursday, Nov. 19--10 P. M. The weather here to-day has been cloudy, with heavy winds. PHILADELPHIA, Thursday, Nov. 19--10 P. M.

Gov. WINSTON'S Message to the Alabama Legislature, congratulates the people of the State on a high degree of prosperity, exhorts them to be thankful therefor, states that the greater portion of an enormous debt has been liquidated, and recommends, a continuance of the policy of paying what they owe.

BURGLARIES IN BROOKLYN.--Tuesday night, the store of YOUNG TALLMADGE, corner of Hamilton-avenue and Commercial-street, was entered and robbed of a barrel of flour. House No. 100 Union street, was entered the same night, and a rifle, revolver, and a small sum of money carried away.

From Le Fellet The make of dresses is an important question at the present moment. If things take their natural course, basqure saem destined to be quite laid aside; they are now searealy ever allowed in full dress, but are sufficiently adopted in walking and home dress to insure their tolerance for one more season. This affords a gord opportunity--for those ladies to whom they are unbecoming--to discontinue them.

The Collins steamer Atlantic, Capt. ELDRIDGE., which, it will be recollected, was detained at this port till Tuesday, 8 o'clock, A. The Baltimore Sun of Tuesday says: On Sunday evening last this village was the scene of a tragical affair, which resulted in the almost instant killing of BENJAMIN DAVIS and the dangerous wounding of JAMES CUNNINGHAN, both citizens of the place, by a man named GILLESPIE, who is supposed either to have been insane or under the influence of liquor at the time in he committed the deed.

Assassins are having their saturnalia. Every night now brings its murder, each more revolting and more during than the other. Neither ago nor sex nor position seems to afford any security, and no place is sacred. Old women in collars, fast young men in supper rooms, tavern keepers behind their own counters,

A fire commenced in J. R. HENDRY'S carriage manufactury about 7 o'clock last evening. That was totally destroyed, with a large quantity of work, finished and unfinished. The shop and contents valued at about $2,000. Several carriages were saved. Five buildings adjoining HENDRY'S shop in the west, known as Rotten Row, were destroyed. These buildings connected with HENDRY'S dwelling house and grocery, which was destroyed, with the contents. Building and contents valued at $4,000.

It was not a little singular that the news of the death of General CAVAIGNAC, which occurred on Wednesday afternoon last, was not known in Paris ?? Friday. Of all the journals only one, the Siccle, contained a notice of the death on Friday morning, and yet the dead body of General arrived in Paris Wednesday night.

From the Washington Union. We published on yesterday the result of the action of the Kansas Convention, and accompanied it with the expression of our gratification on this auspicious conclusion of an angry and threatening issue. In this feeling we are confident that we shall have the cordial sympathy of National Democrats and conservative men throughout the Union.

According to announcement, the Revenue Cutter Harriet Lane, built for the U.S. Government, was successfully launched from the ship yard of WM. H. WEBB, at 11 1/2 o'clock A. M. yesterday. She slid from the ways amid the cheers of hundreds of spectators, and when fairly afloat, drew forth expressions of admiration of her light and graceful proportions. She was towed to the dock near the Allaire Works, to receive her machinery.

Colonel S. Cooper, Adjustant-General, U. S. A.: SIR: I have the honor to report that I have assumed command of the troops of the United States, consisting of part of the army for Utah, which are now eneamped at the point. These troops are the 5th Regiment of Infantry, eight companies of the 10th Infantry, and the batteries of Artillery (6 and 12 pounders) commanded by Captains PHELPS, 4th Artillery, and RENO, Ordnance Department, respectively.

The R. M. steamer Niagara, form Liverpool via Halifax, arrived at this port at 3 1/2 o'clock this afternoon. Her mails were dispatched by the steamboat train rid Stonington, but owing to the heavy gale upon the Sound to-night, it is unlikely that they will reach the New-York Post-Office before 8 or 9 o'clock Friday morning.

YALE COLLYGE,-The annual catalogue of Yale for 1857-8 shows a list of 123 Freshmen, 117 Sophomores, 107 Juniors, and 100 Seniors-total 44? students. In the Theological department, there are 22; in the Law department, 31 ; Medical, 29; Arts. 36total in the department schools, 118.

The affairs of Kansas are again approaching a crisis. A State Constitution has been framed, upon the leading feature of which--the Slavery clause--the people are to vote on the 21st of December: it is then to be transmitted to Congress for its action; if the State should be admitted into the Union,

FIRE IN LIBERTY-STREET.--The wholesale saw establishment of S. B. WILLMOTT, No. 4 Liberty-street, near Maiden-lane, was discovered by Officer KNIGHT, of the Second Ward, to be on fire, about 9 ?? o'clock last evening. An alarm was given, and the various fire companies were soon on the spot, but the flames had extended to the upper part of the building, which was occupied as a willow-ware store, which gave great activity to the fire.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Just returned from Europe, I am told, to my great surprise, that several persons have been heard, (luring my absence, to attribate to me the authorship of a certain letter in the DAILY TIMES against Archbishop HUGHES, subscribed "Equitas," and sent to you with a false private signature.

OBSTACLES TO CITY IMPROVEMENTS.--There is always something in the way to prevent the consummation of any plan that may be proposed for the improvement of the City, or the benefit of the people. It is more than ten years since the proposition for a new City Hall was brought before the public and the importance of providing safe and convenient

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--There was an enormous house here yesterday afternoon; a house much nore crowded than on the previous matinee. The attendance was composed principally of ladies, and the gayety of the scene was certainly charming. VERDI'S opera of the "Trovatore" was given in excellent style, and elicited much applause.

ROBBING A LADY IN THE STREET -- A young man, giving his name is ROLLARD LATON, was arrested Wednesday evening, charged with snatching from the hand of Mrs. ELEANOR PAULDING, residing at No. 24 Charlton-street, a reticule, containing a check for $50 and other articles. Mrs. PAULDING was passing the corner of Christie and Grand streets, when the youngster made a successful grab at her reticule, dashed off with it. She cried "Stop thief."

The Russian Government has, acknowledged, in a very handsome manner, the value of the services rendered by the American corps of physicians in its army during the Sebastopol campaign. Dr. EDWARD B. TURNIPSEED of this City, who entered the Russian army with the rank of Surgeon-Major, in the Summer of 1854, and who served successively at Jassy, Bessarabia, Odessa and Sebastopol, has received the decoration of the Russian Order of St. Anne,

Riker. The Republicans of the Seventh Senatorial District have nominated the following for Councilmen: Charles N. Decker, Twelfth Ward; John Osborn

The Democrats of the Fourth District have nominated ROB. MCINTIRE for Police Justice. Of the Sixth, they have nominated DANIEL CLARKE. The "democratic Americans" of the Sixteenth Ward, assembled last evening at Schaefer's Hotel, in the Seventh-avenue, and nominated Alderman PETER FULLMER, as the regular candidate for Alderman,

THE PANIC AND THE TELEGRAPH.--The panic which overtook us last month in our headlong career of prosperity, has spread across the Atlantic, and, from the accounts which have reached us by the Niagara, appears to the operating there precisely as it did here. Its course and effects have been as mysterious and unavoidable as the first visit of the cholera.

An inquest was held yesterday by Coroner GAMBLE on board the steamboat North America, lying at the foot of Warren-street, on the body of a man who met with a sudden and terrible death on board the boat, during its passage Thursday night from Rondout to this City.

The steamboat Cataract burst her boiler at Lisbon, on the MISSOURI River, on the 17th, killing five persons and sealding fifteen others. Among the killed is WILLIAM BRUCE of Hartford. THE HENRY B. BEACH ON FIRE. BALTIMORE, Friday, Nov. 20. The steamer Henry B. Beach, of Cromwell's line, caught fire in the fire-room last night, and narrowly escaped destruction. The firemen extinguished the fire.

The mails by the Niagara reached this City yesterday morning. We continue to publish copious extracts from foreign journals on the great financial pressure, now more severely felt in Europe than at any time since its commencement. The articles from the London Times on the advance in the Bank of England's rate of discount to 9 percent, will be read with interest.

Death of Another Victim--Several Suspected Parties Arrested--The Murders Supposed to be Spanish Convicts--Coroner's Inquest Continued. SUSAN DEMPSEY, the Scotch girl, one of the parties stabbed in the Water-street dance-house, on Thursday morning, has since died at the New-York Hospital, from internal hemorrhage.

The public reception of NEAL Dow last evening, filled Tremont Temple, and hundreds were unable to get in. The audience was mainly composed of ladies and Sons of Temperance in regalia. The addresses were made by Hon. HENRY WILSON, Rev. Mr. MCCURDY, NEAL DOW, and others. The railroad train for New-York vid Fall River, got off the track at Bridgewater last night,

The alarm was sounded immediately and the firemen were soon on the ground.

KENNEDY,--In this City, on Thursday morning, Nov. 19. HEZEKIAH P. KENNEDY, in the 50th year of this age. The friends and relatives of the family are invited to attend his funeral, on Saturday afternoon, at 1 1/2 o'clock, from his late residence, No. 82 Rivington st., without further invitation; also, the members of the Light Guard Company are respectfully invited to attend, in citizens dress. The bark Antelope, from Rio Janeiro on the 17th. October, arrived here last evening. She left the Grey Eagle, for Philadelphia, and the Juniper, for New-York, loading at Rio. The bark Margaret Ridlep sailed on the 13th Oct. from Rio for New-York. Coffee was scarce, and the receipts light and mostly old and of inferior qualify. Holders were firm, making moderate sales at 511200 to 511250 for inferior, and 511350 TO 511450 for better lost.

ARRIVAL OF THE BLACK WARRIOR. The U. S. M. steamship Black Warrior, R. W. SMITH, Commander, from New-Orleans 12th, Havana 15th inst., arrived at this port yesterday morning. Business in Havana is very dull. Sugars are declining, and we note but few transactions. Stock at Havana and Malanzas 170,000 boxes. .

The Committee of the New-York Councilmen, appointed to negotiate the sale of a site to the Government for the Post-Office, arrived here last night. They had an interview with Postmaster-General BROWN to-day, and presented the subject, with maps, explanations, Mr. BROWN appointed another interview for to-morrow.

The response to the call of the Committee appointed by the Exchange meeting, held on Saturday, last, to agree upon a candidate for the Mayoralty, to meet yesterday afternoon at the same place, was numerous, harmonious and enthusiastic. The time announced for hearing the report of the Committee was half-past 3.

From the Daily News (Mayor Wood's organ) of yesterday. Certain officials of the General Government, we learn, are busy in their efforts to disturb the harmony of the Democracy, and defeat, if possible, the regularly nominated Democratic candidate for Mayor. A sense of honor, if nothing more, should induce these gentlemen to act with and not against the party, to support the united action of the regularly constituted

A woman with a romantic history attached to her life, made an unsuccessful attempt to drown herself in Cincinnati last week, She is a native of New-York, and at 17 married an old bachelor, who died in a year, and left her $10,000. The money was in the hands of his brother, who cheated her out of it. Two years after, she married a widower, at whose death she came into possession of $30,000.

In accordance with the adjournment on Thursday, some two thousand of the unemployed yesterday gathered in front of the City Hall, for the purpose of further considering what plan of action would best tend to afford them employment. It was expected that Mr. GORDON,

WISCONSIN.--It is yet uncertain whether CROSS or RANDALL is Governor of Wisconsin. The Democrats have for two weeks claimed the election of CROSS, but the returns indicate that the choice lies within a hundred votes either way. The Madison Argus, of the 15th, says: "The result is narrowing down to as' close a thing as has ever been witnessed in this country."

In steamship Black Warrior, from New-Orleans and Havana--E. Halloran and lady, Miss Anna Keene, W. Peckham, N. S. Henry, Mrs. Smith, E. M. Burrows, S. McGahee, C. Stevenson, N. Santos, J. M. Montado, daughter and son, A. Eaton, Mr. Hilmu, L. McLellan, Messrs. Saratiga, Hanon Pico, J. W. Lawton, Faire, W. H. Simmons, Bernado, Amenzal.

The public sentiment concerning the Mayoralty election is rapidly taking a form which promises a sharp, well-defined and decisive contest. Partly in consequence of the judicious change made by the new law in the time for holding it, and partly in consequence of the official career and character of Mayor WOOD, political partisanship is utterly discarded in this canvass.

OUR POLICE DEPARTMENT.--The Board of Police Commissioners are fairly at work. The new member, Mr. PERIT, devotes himself to the business of the Board with a vigilance and industry which indicate very clearly the public motives which led him to accept the post. He resists all attempts to postpone or delay the business of the Board. upon whatever pretext they may be made.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--The last night of the present season, (how often we have to write the same words,) gave us the "Sonnambula," thus terminating a brief and disastrous campaign with the opera that inaugurated it. The cast, with the exception of the Armina, was the same ; the heroine in this instance, however, was Madame LA CHANGE, a change which was by no means to be regretted.

A NEW DODGE.--A new dodge for robbing houses has been practiced quite extensively in Brooklyn lately. A female thief goes to a house agent and takes the keys of an unoccupied house, under the pretence of wishing to examine the premises with a view to hiring, but in reality to rob the house. Several house have been stripped of the door knobs, bells, locks and gas fixtures recently, in this manner.

The United States steam frigate Niagara, Capt. HUDSON, which sailed from Plymouth, England, on the 5th inst., arrived this morning,, all well, making the passage in a little over fourteen days. The Niagara has encountered continuous westerly gales nearly the whole passage, but the performance of the noble ship is spoken of with admiration by the officers.

SEIZURE OF STOLEN GOODS.--A few nights since the shoe store corner Sixth-avenue and Fifty-fourth-street, was broken into by burglars, and about $500 worth of boots and shoes stolen. Mrs. Curry, the owner of the store, gave information of the robbery to the Police of the Twenty-second Ward, and Officers Harrold and Hyatt were given the case in charge.

CONVINCED AT LAST.--Our provincial contemporaries in Boston and Philadelphia concede to New-York at last the title of "Metropolis." The daily record of our murders, burglaries, and crimes of every sort, has conquered their reluctance to award us our just deserts.

A CHANGE FOR THE UNEMPLOYED.--The Russ pavement on Broadway, near Thirteenth-street, has been upside down for many weeks, at a great expense of horse flesh, omnibus wheels, and patience both of drivers and passengers. This morning there was one laboring man seat standing near the ruins, who looked as if he might make a "demonstration" on the granite blocks lying at his feet during the day.

The officers of the steamships Galveston and Opelousas were arrested to-day, it being held that it was the neglect of their duties and want of proper management that caused the late sad disaster. The ship Enoch Train, for Liverpool with a cargo ?? inaground.

The Union meeting of the Ladies of the Industrial Schools, held at 11 o'clock on Friday morning at the University Chapel, was largely attended, the principal portion of the audience being ladies. Mr. C. I., BRACE delivered an address on "The Progress and Effects of the Industrial School Movement," a portion of which was as follows:

The Southern mail from all points as late as due has been received. The message of the Governor of Texas shows that the amount in the state Treasury subject to draft is $700,000; and that the School Fund amounts to $2,200,000. He recommends a State University. The entire State tax amounts to $57,327, being an increases of eleven per cent. over last year's.

The notorious Parish Will Case, which has been so long before the Surrogate, and the particulars of which have been so often reported, will be brought to a close to-day. Mr. CUTTING will conclude the final argument for the executor which he commenced on Friday and continued through Saturday, in a four hours' speech this morning.

GREAT STORM AT THE WEST--ADVENT OF GOLD WEATHER. BUFFALO, Saturday, Nov. 21. The storm yesterday and last night was very severe. The amount of snow which fell was not large, but it drifted badly. The track of the Buffalo and Niagara falls railroad, between Buffalo and Black Rock, was so washed by the waves of the lake that trains cannot pass.

SUPREME COURT--Circuit.--Nos. 16, 20, 2001, 1410, 1621, 1981, 649, 686, 2351, 2319, 1701, 324, 1808, 1624, 346, 347, 350, 351, 354, 356. SUPREME COURT. Assignment of Courts and Judges in the City of New-York, for the years 1858 and 1859. GENERAL TERMS. 1858. 1st Monday of February--Judges Davies, Clerke, Sutherland.

The 60th Aniversary of the Society for the relief of widows with small children, was celebrated at Rev. Dr. POTTS' church, Thursday noon. The annual report was read by Miss GARNAGE. The last year cases of extreme suffering have been far less than they have often been heretofore during the year.

The U. S. mail steamship Atlantic arrived at this port last evening, bringing intelligence four days later from Europe, and two weeks later from India. We learn from a telegram, received in London on the day of the Atlantic's departure, that at the capture of Delhi, which is fully confirmed, the British lost, in killed and wounded, half their attacking force.

BALTIMORE, Friday, Nov. 20.--The steamship H. B. Beach, which arrived here yesterday from New-York was partially burned last night at her wharf. The vessel is damaged about $1,000. Three feet of water in her hold. Her cargo is nor likely much damaged. CLEVELAND, Friday, Nov. 20.--A terrible snow-storm along the whole chain of lakes yesterday and to-day. The propeller Jersey City, bound down, with a cargo of flour, struck going into Dunkirk.

A Husband Kills his Wife and Step-Son-In Law and Hangs Himself. A frightful tragedy occurred at Port Jefferson, Suffolk County, Long Island, on Saturday morning, by which three persons lost their lives and a fourth was seriously, perhaps fatally, injured. At half-past seven o'clock in the morning Mrs. WATERS, s. STORDE.

THE NEW BALLOT-BOXES.--Mayor WOOS his affidavit says that there could have been no swindling in these glass ballot-boxes, because the right of supplying thorn was thrown open to public competition, but that no one clse bid.

The United States Mail steamship Atlantic, Captain ELDRIDGE, which sailed from Liverpool at 4'o clock on the afternoon of the 11th of November, arrived at this port evening. The news is four dayslater. The steamship Asia arrived at Liverpool at 6:30 on the morning of the 9th Inst.

The news, welcome to the civilized world, of the fall of Delhi comes to us now, not only confirmed in all the fullness of particulars, but reinforced by the not less welcome intelligence of the relief of Lucknow. The heroism of General HAVELOCK has been crowned with the reward dearest to a hero's heart--the consciousness that the gallantry which has made himself illustrious has also achieved a great and permanent good for his country.

The following is the Weekly Report of Deaths in the City and County of New - York, from the 14th day of November to the 21st day of November, 1857: Men, 73; Women, 56; Boys, 104; Girls, 87: Total, 320.* Adults, 120; Children, 191' Males, 177; Females, 143; Colored Persons, 3.

BURTIS.--In this City, on Sunday, Nov. 22, WILLIAM A. BURTIS, in the 62nd year of his age. The friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, on Tuesday, 24th Inst., at 3 o'clock P. M. from No. 218 West 14th St. RAYNOLDS.--In this City, on Saturday, Oct. 21, after a long and severe illness, JOHN M. RAYNOLDS, late merchant, aged 42 years.

The Atlantic, which arrived last evening, with dates from London down to the 11th inst., brings us financial intelligence which, although measurably exciting, is neither unexpected nor inexplicable, and should not seriously affect the favorable reaction now going on in our own affairs.

ALARMING.--The Daily News on Friday complained very bitterly that several of the prominent office-holders under the General Government were exceedingly indifferent, if not actually hostile, to the reflection of Mayor WOOD. The Sunday Atlas echoes the complaint and adds, that "the example of the high officials alluded to seems to be contagious among subordinates." This is startling, certainly.

AN EXTORTIONATE HOTEL - KEEPER BROUGHT TO JUSTINE.- John G. Engirt, proprietor of the Farmers' Hotel, No. 121 Cedar-street, was arrested Saturday afternoon, charged with assaulting officers and threatening to shoot them with a revolver. Adam Part deposed that the stopped at the Farmer's Hotel on Tuesday last, when it was agreed with the proprietor that if he remained one day he should pay 81 50, but if for a longer period $1a day.

DESTRUCTIVE FIRE AT ROCHESTER--PIREMEN KILLED, ETC. ROCHESTER, Saturday, Nov. 21. At 4 o'clock this morning a fire broke out in the Eagle Bank block. The block was owned by JAMES CHAPPELL, and occupied by the printing establishment of the Democrat, the Eagle Bank, O. A., HYDE Co., PALMER Co., jewelers; J. DISBROW, tobacconist, United States Express Office, a brbershop, and numerous law and other offices.

THE KANSAS CONSTITUTION.--The Tribune does not agree with us in the position that, after the admission of Kansas as a State, the People will have a perfect right to call a Convention and amend or alter the Constitution whenever they please.

The Workingmen's Committee in Trenton report, as the result of their Inquiries, that the large manufacturing establishments of that City are again at work, with few exceptions, and are employing the usual number of operatives. The concerns which employ females are not Included in this statement. Some hundreds of girls are still destitute of employment in Trenton.

THE SCHOONER PLYING CLOUD ASHORE--SEVEN OF HER CREW LOST. CHICAGO, Saturday, Nov. 21. The schooner Flying Cloud, bound from Chicago to Buffalo, went ashore on Miller's Point thirty miles below this city, to-day Seven of her crew are lost. VESSELS ASHORE AT GODERICH, C. W. GODERICH. C. W., Saturday, Nov, 21.

HEWITT.--In this City, on Sunday evening, Nov. 22, FRANCIS HEWITT, in the 49th year of his age. The funeral will take place from his late residence. No. 82 Bleecker st., on Wednesday, 25th inst., at 11 1/2 o'clock A. M. His relatives, friends and members of the American Chapter, No. 8. O. U. A., are respectfully invited to attend, without further notice.

The steamer Republic, arrived from Louisville on Saturday night, reports that during the storm of Wednesday sixteen Coal boats sunk in the Ohio?? and Mississippi Rivers near Chiro, one hundred men were lost in them. The loss of coal is about 30, 000 bushes, valued at $36,000, The crews were principally from Louisville and Pittsburgh.

STRINGHAM, DAVID KEON, G. COOPER, H. W. RUGG, JOUN FORBES, N. S. BUTLER CO., AMOS BRONSON, R. E.

A very singular thing is being brought to light at the Minnesota Mine, Lake Superior. By examination among the broken rocks on the side of the bluff. pieces of veinstone, with copper and silicate, were picked up at one point in considerable quantities, and it was thought best to pull away the adjacent rubbish and examine for the out-crop of the vein.

FLOUR Steady. Sales, 1,000 bbls. WHEAT quiet. Sales, 10,000 bushels at 53c. CORN steady at 50c. Shipments to Buffalo--1,000 bbls. Flour; 9,300 bushels Wheat. Receipts 10-day--1,300 bbls. Flour; 38,000 bushels Wheat; 2,000 bushels Corn. NEW-OBLRANS, Monday, Nov. 23.

A CANADIAN VERDICT -- SPECIAL, PROVISION FOR A FAMILY. -- We find in the Toronto Globe some interesting details of another action against the Great Western Railroad Company, to recover damages for the death of Mr. ALEXANDER GRANT caused by the terrible accident of the Desjardins Bridge. The action was brought by Mrs. ELIZABETH GRANT, the widow of the deceased,

The announcement that the Adriatic was positively to sail at noon, yesterday, drew thousands to the dock at the foot of Canal-street, and out upon all the pier-heads along the North River to witness her departure. An hour before the time of departure arrived the sheds upon, the dock, and all the available standing-room which would afford a view, were occupied by dense masses of people, when waited with great interest to see her off.

On Sunday night a lecture on the "Education of Catholic Youth," was delivered in the Roman Catholic Church in James-street by Archbishop HUGHES. The building was crowded. inasmuch as in addition on the position of the lecturer there was the claim on the public of the object of his appearance, which was ?? charitable one.

The meeting at Tammany Hall last night to ratify the nomination of Mayor WOOD, was very large and decidedly enthusiastic. It indlcated an earnest and determined purpose, on the part of those who took part in it, to secure, if possible, his reelection. We present In another part of this morning's TIMES a full, fair and accurate report of its proceedings, including the address and resolutions that were adopted and the speeches that wore made.

ARCHBISHOP HUGHES AND THE PUBLIO SCHOOLS.--Archbishop HUGHES took occasion on Sunday night, in delivering a lecture in aid of a public charity, to denounce the system of Public Education adopted by this State, and to urge the Catholic parents who hoard him not to send their children to them.

The Virginin Medical Journal has a leader upon the union of the two medical schools in that State. One of these is situated at Richmond and the other at Charlottesville, being, In fact, a department of the State University.

A County ratification meeting of the Democracy was held last evening in Tamm my Hall, the purpose being the indorsement of FERNANDO WOOD as the candidate for Mayor, and of the other candidates on the Democratic Charter ticket for Governor of the Alms-house and Supervisors.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Can you tell a poor fellow, living in the country, why life is held at so cheap a rate in New-York? Now, where I live, we think a good deal of human life, and are much shocked at the frequency with which it is recklessly taken away.

The weather here is mild. The wind for the past thirly-six hours has blown from the South. There are some rumors of ice in the Canal at the West, but there is no known obstruction to navigntion as yet. ALBANY, Monday, Nov. 23. The weather here is mild with a drizzling rain. Navigation is unobstructed.

Postmaster-General BROWN to-day agreed to take the lower angle of the Park for the site for your Post-Office, and close the contract immediately, if the City will wait for the purchase-money until after congress meets.

CANDID AND TRUE--The Herald, in searching for the causes of the extraordinary increase of crime in this City within the past few months, mentions one that is undoubtedly true. It says that our criminals say to themselves: "Look at the newspapers, and you will see that the Mayor and all these fellows who want office, are no better than ourselves.

TRN PER CENT.--It is as Impossible to guard against the effects of a panic in the public mind as it is to foresee the freaks of a lunatic ; and of all panics, a commercial panic is the most difficult to manage or resist. It must have its way, even though that way be utter ruin and universal disaster.

To the Editor of the New- York Times: We see that the Street Commissioner Proposes to employ a number of laborers in repairing our City pavements ; but before this is done would It not be well to endeavor to devise some mode of reconstruction them which shall give us a pavement that will not be continually needing repairs.

WILLIAM RANNRY, the celebrated artist, whose works will be remembered as prominent features at the annual exhibitions of the National Academy of Design, died last week at his residence in West Hoboken, New Jersey. The incidents of his life, though simple and characterized by no marked vicissitudes, imply a resolute determination in tile pursuit of his art, rarely met.

From the Washington National Era. This conduct of the Governor, [in rejecting the Oxford and McGee returns,] considering his antecedents and political relations, is rather remarkable. He must have foreseen the consequences. The rejection of these returns would transfer the legislative power of the Territory to the Free-State Party, and strengthen its organization.

HORRIBLE RAILROAD ACCIDENT.--Somewhere on the line of the Baltimore and Philadelphia Railroad, between Wilmington and Perryville, the 11 o'clock P.M. train of Tuesday night ran over and killed a man. but at what particular point has not yet been ascertained. The accident occurred without the knowledge of the engineer or conductor, nor was it known until the train reached Perryville.

The Board of Aldermen met Monday night, Alderman CLANCY, President, in the chair. The minutes of the previous meeting were road and approved. A petition from the Unemployed Workingmen of the Thirteenth Ward, asking that they be provided with immediate work, for the relief of their destitution, signed by over 100 persons, was referred to the Committee on Finance.

The 14th Regiment of National Guards of Brooklyn, about 150 in number, Captain SPRAGUE, proceeded to Greenwood Cemetery, yesterday forenoon, and received in charge the remains of General Wears, which they conveyed to this City. At the foot of Whitehall-street they were met by Company F of the 71st Regiment, Captain TOMPKINS, consisting of 50 men, as an escort.

The Academy of Music was crowded last night, in obedience to the following call: The PEOPLE IN COUNCIL.--The citizens of New-York in favor of an honest and economical administration of our Municipal Government, and in favor of elevating DANIEL F. TIEMANN to the Mayoralty, will assemble at the Academy of Music on Tuesday, Nov, 24, at 7 1/2 P. M.

DARING ROBBERY.--A man entered the jewelry store of CHARLES HENIGS, corner of Hicks and Middagh streets, Brooklyn, Monday evening, and asked to see some gold rings. The clerk produced a box, when he asked to see some more. While the clerk was after another lot, the customer seized those which had been laid out (valued at $250) and made oil.

MYSTERIOUS DISAPPEARANCE.--We regret to learn that Mr. JAMES BARROW, Jr., (son of Mr. JAMES BARROW, long a vestryman of Trinity Church,) has disappeared in a manner calculated to excite the livelleat fears of his family and friends. He was last seen on Saturday evening, 21st inst., near the corner of Broadway and Thames-street, on his way to the 6 o'clock Staten Island boat, since when he has not been heard of.

Before Judge Betts. FALSM INVOICES. Victor Flenry was put on trial this morning, charged with attempting to pass false invoices through the Custom-House. The original invoice was not produced, and the Government fulled to supply secondary evidence of it, so that under the direction of the Court the Jury found a verdict of Not Guilty without leaving their seats.

IMPORTANT WITNESS ARRESTED--CONTRADICTORY STATEMENTS. Information was received by the Coroner on Monday afternoon that a sailor, who boarded at a sailors' boarding house, in Cherry street, had stated that he was in Mr. VINCENT'S place ten minutes before he was murdered, and could identify the murderers. Several officers of the Fourth Word, accompanied by Officer SHANGLE, of the Coroner's office, started, Monday night, in search of the sailor,

Mayor WOOD'S supporters do not show as much courage as he does. With characteristic self-confidence the Mayor himself declares his desire to make the contest purely personal in its character. He proclaims his readiness to moot all his accusers face to face; promises at some future day to convince the public of the purity, the unselfishness, the vigorous integrity, the public spirit and the preeminent success and brilliancy of his Administration;

THE WOOD MEETING.--We have already noticed the curious fact that the self-styled "Democratic" advocates of Mayor WOOD'S reelection wore forced to go out of the City In order to find Democrats of any character Or Influence to favor their movement.

The Five Points' House of Industry will hold as in former years, its annual Thanksgiving festival. A plain, substantial dinner will be provided for the inmates of the Institution, and the children connected with its Day School. The throng of thieving Vagabond girls and boys, who have sometimes, by their importunities, obtained admission on these occasions, will be positively excluded,

THE MAYORALTY.--It is reported that the "Straight-Out Americans," opposed to WOOD and Fusion, intend making a nomination, on Wednesday evening, for the Mayoralty.--Journal of Commerce. While the Journal is about it, suppose it notices sundry other "rumors" that are afloat in the community.

There is a vague notion afloat in the public mind that FERNANDO WOOD is invincible. His supporters talk in mysterious tones about his prodigious strength and the certainty of his carrying everything before him, in spite of all opposition. Persons who have been imposed upon by this sort of talk will do well to look back to the record of votes cast when he has been a candidate hitherto.

A MINISTERIAL CRISIS IN CANADA . - The ? Premier, cool, TAHOE, has retired from office, rendering necessary a dissolution and reconstruction of the Cabinet. The Governor- General has Commissioned Hon. JOHN A. MACDONALD to form a new Government. Cool, TRACE'S term of public service dates back to the last war.

At the Board of Governors of the Almshouse, yesterday, little business was done. The following petition from STEPHEN H. BRANCH was received, read and referred: To the Honorable the Board of Ten Governors: GENTLEMEN: Your petitioner respectfully represents that he is reduced to beggary by the Corporation of New-York who used his intellectual energies nearly two years, and borrowed $2,000 from him, and have refused to pay him since 1850

THE VINTAOR IS THE WEST.--The vintage in the West this year has been remarkably successful. At the German colony in Missouri, where the vine is largely cultivated, the yield is unprecedented, about one hundred thousand barrels having been grown during the season. The Germans in Western Texas are about to undertake the culture of the grape on an extensive scale.

We have received and publish in another part of this morning's impression, a brief telegraphic summary of four days later news from Europe. The Vanderbilt, from Southampton on the 14th Inst., passed Cape Race on Sunday afternoon. She brings financial intelligence of great importance. The severe monetary pressure in Great Britain had ended in a panic.

RIDING THE PUBLIC.--The City has been sued for Mayor Wood's carriage hire It seems that he ordered from one person carriages during he last eleven months, to the amount of $1,161, and directed it to be charged to the City account.

The disciples of TOOKE and NEWMARCH are doubtless at this moment jubilating over the attitude of the Bank of England. For they are doubtless believing and claiming that the pressure of the present crisis has vindicated all their predictions, and proved the inadequacy of Sir ROBERT PERL'S Bank system to the functions it was expected to perform.

THE TIEMANN ORGANIZATION.-We are glad to learn that the friends of Mr. TIEMANN are working together in the moat harmonious manner, and that the anti-Wood organizations are under the control of the right sort of men in all parts of the City.

We left Dakkeh at midnight, or a little after, of the 30th day of January. Were I writing descriptions of all that I have seen in Egypt. I would linger a long time in sketching this temple of Dakkeh, which is in excellent preservation, and is one of the finest specimens of the later temples of Egypt which now remain,

The following are the names of more of the lost Passengers of the steamboat Rainbow: Mr. McGAFFIN, of Kentucky. Three children of Mrs. WHITTAKER, of Vicksburg. Mrs. WHEATLEY and child, of California. One lady cabin passenger, and three lady deck passengers, names unknown. The third and fourth cooks. WILLIAM ROCHESTRH and E. PROTHER, stewards.

TAKING HIM AT HIS WORD.--Though Mr. COCHRANE expressed a willingness to vote for WOOD if he were the "devil Incarnate," so long as he was the regularly-nominated candidate of his party, yet the Mayor's own desire to make his election a personal matter will absolve not only Mr. COCHRANE, but a good many other staunch Democrats, from the stern necessity of voting for the incarnation of everything they abhor.

The schooner Waurican, of Buffalo, with a load of wheel, is ashore at Port Burwell. The schooner Mazeppa went on the breakwater here during the gale last evening, but received very little damage. The Schooner Europa is ashore a few miles up the bay with her bottom out.

Mayor Wood has more petards on hand than he can manage, One of them exploded last night, and gave him a hoist from which it will take him some time to recover. He has been busy for several days in endeavoring to secure the nomination for an American candidate, in hope to divide the strength of his opponents.

The steamship Tennessee has arrived here from Vera Crux, with dates to the 21st inst., and from the city of Mexico to the 19th. The country was in a most distracted condition, and another general revolution was impending. Communications were passing between the Revolutionists and General SANTA ANA, whom, undoubtedly, they intend for President.

The Hannah Moore Female Academy and the Episcopal Church in Reisterstown, 15 miles distant from this City, were destroyed by fire last night. All the inmates escaped unharmed. BURNING OF A PHILADELPHIA FERRYBOAT. PHILADELPHIA, Wednesday, Nov. 25. The ferry steamer Oscar A. Thompson is now burning at her pier at Gloucester Point. The Providence Banks.

Hon JAMES G. BIRNEY, long an able leader in the ranks of the Anti-Slavery Party, died at 4 o'clock yesterday morning, at Eagleswood, bear Perth Amboy, N. J. His age was 64. Mr. BIRNEY was a native of Kentucky. His father was an Irishman, who had acquired considerable wealth, and occupied a high social position. Mr. BIRNEY received his education at Nassau Hall in New-Jersey,

THE POLICE FORCE.--A good deal of anxiety has been created by the injunction issued by Judge DAVIES against the Board of Police Commissioners, forbidding them to appoint any additional members of the Police Department except members of the old force.

Governor WALKER arrived here to-night. The Treasury estimates of appropriation for the next fiscal year have been made up, and despite every effort to reduce them, the total amount estimated is about seventy millions. The estimate for the War Department alone is twenty and a quarter millions-being largely increased

The steairship Alabama, from New-York, arrived here this morning. She experienced heavy weather on the passage. The Alabama towed the bark Pacific to the Charleston Bar. THE MEMPHIS AT CHARLESTON CHARLESTON, Wednesday, Nov. 25.

THE BONDED WAREHOUSE BURGLARY.--The burglar who, on Tuesday night, broke into one of the Bonded Warehouses in Broad-street, and was captured as reported in Wednesday's TIMES, was yesterday locked up in the Tombs for trial. He refers to give the names of his two associates. Their original intention, he says, was to take away such silks and coslty dry goods as they could lay their hands on,

To the Commissioners of Emigration. GENTLEMEN: We are in receipt of a copy of a note, purporting to come from Messrs. CARRIGAN, CURTIS and GARRIGUE, (they forming a Committee of your Board to whom was referred a former Communication from us,) and which is certified by your Secretary as having been unanimously concurred in by your Board.

About midnight a very severe and sudden change took place in the weather here, the wind changed to the northwest and blew a perfect gate for the balance of the night, the thermometer falling rapidly. This morning the mercury marked 11' above zero. The change appears likely to defeat the hopes entertained of keeping the Canal open two weeks longer between here and Rochester, and of the resumption of navigation to Buffalo.

THE CANALS--BOATMEN SUFFERING.--The Lyons Republican says, the canal at Montezuma is in a sad plight and there is but little prospect that navigation will be entirely resumed this season. The water is several feet over the towing path for about six miles through the Montezuma marsh, and several steam-tugs are towing the boats across the marsh.

THE MURDER OF SAMUEL CARMAN--We learn that a letter has been received in Queens County, from Illinois, stating that a Dutchman in that State, under arrest for theft, has confessed to the commission of a murder in Queens County, I., I., about the line of the murder of the lamented SAMUEL CARMAN. He states that he perpetrated the murder with an axe with which he fractured the back of his head.

The remains of the gallant and lamented Gen. WORTH were yesterday deposited under the ground upon which the Monument to his memory is to be erected, with appropriate and imposing ceremonies. They lay in state, in the Governor's room at the City Hall, during the preceding night, guarded by twenty-eight men--four from each company--of the 7lSt Regiment.

On his return to England, after his Summer visit to this country, the late Earl of ELLESMERE said in the House of Lords, that if he were asked to name the most military nation in the world, he should say the United States. He based his conventions partly on his observation during his brief sojourn in this country, and partly on the spirit manifested by our people during the Mexican war.

The statement that a Special Minister has been appointed by France to unite with Sir WM. GORE GUSELEY and the American Minister to Central America in the settlement of the open questions with the States comprising the latter, is discredited here--at least in the shape in which it is presented.

INCREASE OF MENDICANTS.--During the past fortnight there has been a very perceptible and painful increase in the number of our street mendicants. There are at all times too many of these unfortunate solicitors of charity, but they have now become most alarmingly numerous, and the incessant appeals made by these people for assistance have the effect of rendering the public Indifferent and callous to their plaintive cries. They give us no rest;

By letter to Elwood Walters, Esq., for Board of Under writers. GALVESTON, Sunday, Nov. 13. The ship J. W. Fannin, (previously reported.) was got afloat last night, at 6 o'clock. She is now at her wharf, leaking badly; her cargo is very badly damaged. The ship Nebraska is just visible above water. We have had very bad weather for the past week. KEY WEST, Friday, Nov. 13.

THE SINEWS OF WAR.--The Anti Wood organization is compact, harmonious, energetic and efficient. Measures have been taken to secure the attendance of active and resolute challengers at every poll to prevent the influx of Illegal voters, which is expected from Brooklyn.

The Vanderbilt, whose important commercial advises we published yesterday morning as received by telegraph from Cape Race, is now fully due at this port, and may be expected at any moment. The Sandy Hook line was not in working order last night. By the arrival of the Terseness' at New - Orleans we receive a telegraphic summary of two weeks later news from Mexico.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--There will be a very attractive morning performance at this house to-day, and those of our country cousins who have never heard an opera well given may avail themselves of the opportunity with decided profit. The entertainment begins with the entire opera of "La Somnambulk," in which Mme. LA GEANUE, Signor LABOOETIA, and Signor GASSIER appear.

FLOUR--The market is active in view of the prospect of the closing of the canal. Sales 3,500 Lbls. at $1 75 @ $5 50 for common to extra State, and $5 50 @ $6 50 for common to extra Western. Buck WHEAT FLOUR at 15s. @ 16s. $100 lbs. No sales of WHEAT or CORN, except in car lots by railroad. BARLEY has been very active for the past few days.

A fever of very interesting characteristics is prevailing throughout the middle of Long Island, and especially on the Northern cost, which has already plucked several blooming daughters from their bereaved parents, and consigned as many stalwart youths to other spheres of labor and enjoyment When first taken the patient exhibits a palpitation of the heart, flushed face, stammering of speech and a tenderness over the region of the heart.

Yesterday was cold and clear and sunshiny--just the day for Thanksgiving. The air was sufficiently invigorating to make one alive to all that was to be enjoyed; just cold enough to put one's church-going inclinations mildly to the test, and to give a relish to the turnkey, which is never realized to the full, except on a clear, cold day.

The General Produce Markets have ?? slightly during the week. Breadstuffs were freely ?? and purchased up to Saturday evening, without any remarkable change in prices. On Monday and Tuesday the demand was very tame, and though the receipts were moderate, the tendency of the market was downwards.

Governor WALKER had a long and very friendly interview with the President to-day. They discussed Kansas affairs at length, especially relative to the propriety of sustaining the action of the Constitutional Convention in not referring the entire instrument to the people. The distinguished gentlemen, though differing radically, parted friends, appointing another interview for the discussion of the same subject.

YESTERDAY.--As all our provincial cotemporaries have been greatly exercised by the few sporadic cases of murder and violence which have recently taken place here, we hope they will not fall to notice, and be comforted by the fact, that yesterday, the festival of Thanksgiving was kept up here with as much rational and quiet enjoyment as in any village in New-England. There were no mobs, no murders,

SUICIDE IN HOBOKEN.--Mrs. POND, a lady about 35 years of age, wife of CHARLES Z. POND, one of the proprietors of the Atlantic Hotel, at Hoboken, committed suicide on Tuesday night, by taking arsenic. When it became known to the members of the family that she had taken poison, medical aid was immediately summoned, but it was found too late to save her life.

The United States steamship Vanderbilt, EDWARD HIGGINS, Commander, from Havre and Southampton at midnight of the 14th inst., with 305 cabin passengers, and $250,000 in specie, arrived at Quarantine at 3 A. M., yesterday morning. The Africa, from Liverpool, 9 A. M. of the 14th has also arrived.

The steamship Vanderbilt arrived at this port at an early hour yesterday morning. We publish elsewhere the important financial news of which we were previously advised by telegraph. The articles from London journals on the panic, and the effect of the suspension of the Bank Charter Act, will be read with interest. We give full particulars of the extensive failures that have taken place throughout Great Britain since last advices.

From the Cincinnati Commercial. 24th. Our special dispatches announce the destruction by fire of the Louisville and Now-Orleans packet Reinbow, near Napoleon, Arkansas, The loss of life is variously estimated at from fifty to seventy-five, The Rainbow was built at Louisville, three years since, for the Louisville and Henderson packet trade, but entered the Southern trade last season.

The principle has been pretty generally adopted in England, in legislating on bankruptcy, that the great, and in fact the only object to be kept in view, was the surrender of all the debtor's assets, and their fair division amongst the creditors. In the earlier bankrupt acts the idea evidently still prevailed that the debtor, above all, in cases where he had been guilty of misconduct, even before bankruptcy, deserved to be punished.

A "FREE-LOVE" ESTABLISHMENT BROKEN OF IN OHIO--The Sandusky (O.) Register states that on Monday last a descent was made by the authorities upon a Free-Love concern at Berlin, Erie County, and E. S. TYLNE, A. W. SMITH, MARY DAME, MARY LEWIS, SOPERONIA POWERS, THOMAS HOMEE and THOMAS WEIGHT, were brought before the Mayor of Sandusky, on charge of adultery.

From latest market reports, it appears that potatoes were selling in Dublin at four shillings and sixpence the hundred weight, while in London they had a brisk sale at twelve shillings. The victorious HAVELOCK has been raised to the rank of Lieutenant-General, and invested with the order of the Bath as a Knight Commander. Those honors are doubtless but the first blossoms of the harvest of distinction which awaits him, If he should be so fortunate as to escape the fatality which up to this time has relentlessly pursued those English leaders in India.

CAPSIZED.--The schooner L. S. Levering, CORSON, from Boston for Philadelphia 24th inst., of Eaton's Neck, L. I., saw schooner John Bowman, of Philadelphia, capsize in a sudden flaw of wind. The crew, four In number, succeeded in getting into their boat, and were soon picked up by the L. S. L. and carried Into Huntington Harbor, where the captain and mate were landed; the other two men were brought to this port.

COTTON GROWING IN CENTRAL AMERICA.--The soil is equal to the best in the Mississippi Valley. The virgin lands, which are very easily brought under cultivation, can be purchased at from $1 to $2 per acre. As to the price of labor, the wages of 400 Indians amounts to about $1 per month each. Six months suffice to plant. cultivate and gather the crop.

SERIOUS BURNING.--Mrs. WEBBER and two children, residing in Fifty-second-street near Eighthavenue, were seriously burned on Wednesday evening by the explosion of a can of burning fluid, which took place while Mrs WEBBER was filling a lighted lamp. Two officers of the Twenty-second Ward heard the screams of the sufferers and saved their lives by tearing their clothing from them.

ICE IN THE HARBOR.-The sudden return of frosty weather has suggested the necessity of taking some steps to provide against the delays, losses and other inconveniences suffered last Winter by the aecumulation of ice in this harbor. Several vessels, too, were cut through last Winter, and sunk by the drifting ice, while lying at anchor in the stream ;

CRAWFORD, in company with his wife and daughter, returns to his post after an absence in Europe, and a brief tour in this country, which

A GARROTER FLATTENED.--About 10 o'clock last night, as Mr. ALPHA CHILD was passing through Second-street, near Second-avenue, he was seized by a stout, well-dressed ruffian, who placed one hand over his mouth and the other around his neck, nearly choking him, and demanded his money, telling him if he spoke aloud he would kill him.

The WOOD meeting at the Academy of Music, last night, was immensely large and very entiusiastic. Long before the tine appointed for its commencement, every foot of space in the house was. occupied, and several thousand persons, unable to obtain admission, gathered in companies around various speakers, who from balconies of houses, in Foerteenth-street and Irving-place, undertook to address them.

Before Judge Betts. PALSE INVOICES. Frederick Strauss was put on trial this morning, charged with having passed a false invoice through the Custom-House, with intent to defraud the revenue. The Government, however, made out no case which put the accused upon his defence and the Jury, by direction of the Judge, rendered a verdict of not guilty. For the United States, Mr. Joachimssen.

FIRE IN DOYERS-STREET--NARROW ESCAPES EIGHT POOR FAMILIES BURMED OUT OF HOUSE AND HOME.--At a few minutes after 4 o' clock, yesterday morning, a fire broke out in No. 10 Doyers-street, occupied on the first floor as a grocery store and the upper stories as a tenant-house.

PRLOUZE.--In this City, on Thursday morning, Nov. 26, suddenly, HARRIET MARIA PRLOUZE, aged 65 years. Her funeral will take place from the residence of her friend, Mrs. Wright, No. 209 Varick St., this (Saturday) afternoon, at 2 o'clock. Her two sons, William and Henry, are respectfully invited to attend. Her remains will be taken to Greenwood.

To the Editors of the National Intelligencer: GENTLEMEN: Many papers desirous of the establishment of a National Bank are quoting what General JACKSON said in favor of such an institution at the beginning of his Presidency.

WORKS OF STRADELLA DISCOVERED.-An important musical discovery, says the Paris Pays, has just been made at Venice, in the library of St. Mark. It was generally believed, up to the present time, that there remained nothing of STRADELLA'S compositions but the famous hymn which he was singing in the Sixtine Chapel at the moment when the three assassins dispatched against him by the patricians of Venice were about to murder him.

The Jury impanneled to inquire into the murders committed on the morning of the 19th inst. at the dance-house of MARK DEISCOLL, No. 277 1/2 Waterstreet, met at 3 P.M. yesterday at the Coroner's Office. Coroner CONNERY announced to the Jurors that he had several officers constantly engaged since their last session in looking up new witnesses, but they had not been successful in finding any.

At the Cabinet meeting to-day, the President stated Governor WALKER'S position on Kansas affairs. The Cabinet unanimou ly unite with the President in favor of sustaining the action of the Constitutional Convention, in respect to the reference of the Constitution to tne people, and so condemn WALKER.

EFFECTS OF THE ATMOSPHERE ON POLITICS.The wonderful equanimity with which the people of this City bear up under the most expensive and inefficient municipal government by which any community was ever afflicted, is the constant subject of marvel of strangers, and particularly of Englishmen who visit us.

OUR JURORS.-Yesterday the Appleton Oalsmith case in reference to the insurance for some muskets lost in the Victory, on their way to Nicaragua, came on to trial in the Superior Court. A Jury were impanneled and the case commenced, when it was found that one of the julymen could not understand any English.

The efforts of the "passional attraction" sophistry are remarkably exhibited in the of Mrs. Lawis, one of tile Free-Lovers whose colony at Berlin, near Sandusky, Ohie, was broken up a fortnight since by the Police. Dr. HARLOW LZEIS, the husband of the woman, has sued for a divorce, on a charge of adultery with one TYLER.

From Washington, we learn that the Cabinet unanimously unite with the President against the position of Governor WALKER, and in favor of sustaining the action of the Kansas Constitutional Convention. This, it is considered, effectually closes the door to a reconciliation with WALKER'S position.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--The Annual Benefit in aid of the New-York Fire Department Fund takes place to night at the Academy of Music. The programme is one of the most remarkable ever offered, and on its own merits should insure a crowded attendance. We need not add that there is a duty to be performed in attending this benefit as well as a pleasure to be reaped.

LIBERTY IN SWEDEN.-During one of the discussions in the Swedish Diet on the royal propositions relative to religious liberty, M. DK Kock, the Chancellor of Justice, said that, if the proposition were not voted, the tribunal would be compelled to pass sentence on seven Swedish women, accused of the crime of having, three years ago, quitted the Evangelical Church and embraced the Roman Catholic faith.

The weather here for the past 24 hours has been very moderate. Advices from points West, between here and Rochester, state that every effort is being loade to break the ice and move the boats East. If the present weather continues most of the produce between here and Rochester will be got through.

In the month of July last, nearly all our City cotemporaries gave over the English supremacy in India, as something irretrievably lost. The Herald, as its manner is, poured forth a torrent of slang declamation, showing the Sepoys to be the chosen ministers of an avenging Providence.

THE FIRE TELGRAPH.-The Fire Telegraph, having its central location at the City Hall, was put in operation on Thursday for the first time. MORSI'S system is to be used, instead of the slow and cumbrous system formerly in use, and which still is in vogue in the telegraph under the management of the Police Department.

The cotton fields of Red River, Texas, were greatlydamaged by the late storm.

THE LAST OF THE BOSWELLS.--The last male descendant of BOSWELL, the friend and biographer of JOHNSON, has just departed this life, and the name and title of BOSWELL has become extinct through the death of Sir JAMES BOSWELL, of Auchinlech-house, county of Argyll, which happened on the 4th instant, in his 51st year.

The meeting of Mlayor WOOD's supporters at the Academy of Music last night was a large and imposing demonstration. It differed from the Opposition meeting of Tuesday night less in numbers than in the character of those composing it and in the spirit which animated their proceedings.

Nine hundred men are now at work on the Central Park, and 200 more will be set to work on Monday. The whole force will then be 1,120 men. -This force will soon eat up the $30,000 advanced by the Comptroller, and as the Commissioners will not employ any men without the money in hand to pay them, it becomes a serious question with those employed there where the next job will come from.

Mayor WOOD said the Republicans and Americans were fairly represented among the Canvassers and Inspectors of Election, and asked to have one-third of the poll clerks.

ANOTHER ASTEROID, -- The London Athenaum of Nov. 7 says: "Dr. R. LUTHER, of the Observatory of Bilk, has discovered another new planet, the 50th [51st.] belonging to the system of Asteroids between Mars and Jupiter. The correctness of Dr. LUTHER'S discovery has already been confirmed by the Royal Observatory at Bonn,"

ARRIVAL OF THE GRANADA--DEARTH OF NEWS--TRADE AND EXCHANGE. The United States Mail steamship Granada, Captain GRIFFIN, which left Havana on the afternoon of the 23d inst., has arrived at this port. The Granada left New-Orleans on the 20th inst., and arrived at Havana on the 23d inst. at sunrise.

NEW PATENTS ISSUED--The following patents to New Yorkers are among the issues bearing date Nov. 24: John M. Batchelder, Cambridge, Mass., and Luther L. Smith, New York--For improvement in the preparation of engraved metal plates for printing. G. I. Barton and A. E. Roberts, Albany--For improvement in hay and manure forks.

One of the most startling indications concerning the election of to-morrow, is found in the extraordinary efforts made by the partisans of Mayor WOOD to break down the precautions provided by law against illegal voting. Under the old law certain officers called poll clerks were created and authorized to take part in counting the votes at every poll.

The New-York and Havre line steamer Fulton, Capt. WOTTON, passed Cape Race last evening at five o'clock. She left Havre on the 17th inst., and Southampton at three o'clcok on the afternoon of the 18th. She has 71 passengers and $220,000 in specie, and a very large and valuable cargo of French merchandise.

The interview between the President and Gov. WALKER yesterday, resulted in no change in their positions on the Kansas question. WALKER is immovable in his bold stand for the rights of self-government. The President is seriously concerned because of its thickening difficulties, but indicates no disposition to yield to WALKER'S views.

For the last three weeks the United States of American have suffered the anxieties and to rors of the greatest monetary convulsion which has ever occurred in their history. Like all similar panics, it was long foreseen and earnestly predicted by the few wise men who could see three inches before them. The many disregarded the warning, as was but natural;

The United state mail Steamship Fulton passed Caps Race last Friday evening, an routc for New York with four days' later news from Europe, and 3220,000 in specie In consequence of the suspension of the Bank Charter Act, the London money market was linre, and the demand discount at Bank less pressing, Financial affairs wore generatly in an improved condition, and Consols had advanced.

WOOD WORKINGMEN'S MEETING. A meeting of the working people in favor of FERNANDO WOOD'S reelection was held on Saturday night, at Tammany Hall. At first the attendance was exceedingly meagre, but gradually it increased, until the Hall was about two-thirds full. Mr. CHARLES SMITH, well-known as a speaker at the meetings of the "Unemployed," occupied the Chair.

The time for talking and writing about the Municipal election has nearly gone by. In the course of the next twenty-four hours our citizens will be called upon to prove their regard for the good name of their City, and for their own most vital interests, by deciding what manner of man shall represent them in their corporate capacity and manage their common interests for the next two years.

The Spanish Minister, Senor TASSARA, who has been passing a few days in this City, returns to his post at Washington to-morrow. Though one of the youngest of the diplomatic chiefs residing in this country, being now but thirty-three, Senor TASSARA is a gentleman of high ability and accomplishment.

PERFECTLY DIABOLICAL.---The Academy of Music in Irving place is in danger of getting a fearfully bad name; not to put too fine a point upon it, a perfectly diabolical reputation. On Friday night was performed there, probably for the last time, JOHN COCHRANE'S "Devil Incarnate," and to-night is to be give, for the first time, ERRER'S Robert to Diable." Mr.COCHRANE'S "devil" undoubtedly draws the best houses of the two.

HON. H. NICOLL--Dear Sir: As you presided at the first meeting held this Fall in this City opposed to the present maladministration of the public affairs of this metropolis, I address you for the purpose of correcting certain statements, made by Mr. WOOD at the meeting held at the Academy of Music on Friday evening last. Mr. WOOD parades a long list of figures, which are well calculated to mislead.

IS THE THOMAS WATSON A SLAVER.--We have noted the seizure, by a British vessel of war, of the ship Thomas Watson. The offices of the vessel deny the charge against them, and make this statement: Ship Thomas Watson left this port on then 3d of December, 1856, with a cargo of general-merchandise, for the coast of Africa, for the purpose of barter or exchange for palm oil ivory, gold-dust,

The Jury impanneled to inquire into the murder of Francis Vincent, at No. 15 North William street, on the night of the 17th instant, met on Saturday morning at 9 1/2 o'clock, pursuant to adjustment, at Coroner's office, Coroner CONNERY informed the Jurors that no further witnesses had been obtained, and suggested that nothing remained but for the Jury to agree at once upon their verdict upon the evidence that had been Adduced.

THE BRITISH STEAMER CREOLE ASHORE. Sr. JOHN, N. B., Saturday, Nov. 28. On Monday last the British steamer Creole went ashore at Granville, Nova Scotia, during a gale, and received such damage as required her to be surveyed, and then condemned. She is insured in New-York.

The United States Mail steamship Northern Light, C. L. TINKLEPAUGH commanding, arrived at this port yesterday, from Aspinwall on the 21st Nov., with 603 passengers, the usual Pacific and California mails, and $118,652 78 in treasure, as follows: For New York $1,744,672 78; for New Orleans, $366,350, and for Havana, $7,650.

BOGUS VICK-PRESIDENTS.--It ought to be made an indictable offence to use a man'S name as an officer of a public meeting of any kind without his consent; and we are not sure that an action for slander would not lie against any one taking such an inexcusable liberty with another's name.

RESUMPTION OF NAVIGATION ON THE ERIE CANAL. AlBANY, Monday, Nov. 30. The weather continues to be very mild, and the favorable accounts received from the West inspire us with a hope that all the produce now afford upon the Canal will get through to tide-water, and that navigation may be entirely resumed.

ANOTHER NEW TERRITORY.--Among the passengers by the Northern Light, yesterday, JAMES M. CRANE, Esq., of California, who on his way to Washington as the representative of the people of the Great Basin, or Carson Valley, who are desirous of having the portion of Utah lying near the boundary of California, erected into a new Territory, separate from Mormon dominion.

The War Between Casta Rien and Niearngun. We gave yesterday, in our Central American Correspondence, particulars of the outbreak that has recently occurred between Nicaragua and Costs Rical. Among the official documents sent us by our correspondent were letters from Col. CAUTY, commander of the River San Juan, demanding, on the part of Costs Riea, the surrender of that river and its forts from the Nienraguan authorities.

Last evening Mr. CARL FORMES made his debut before an American audience, and was received with torrent of applause by an exceedingly overcrowded house. A few such gatherings will bring happiness to the heart of Mr. ULLMAN--which of late has been filled with troubles, cares and perplexities.

Mr. George R. Gliddon, formerly U.S. Consul in Egypt, died at Panama on the 16th inst., aged 50. He was an Englishman, but passed a large part of his life in Egypt, where he became an enthusiastic explorer of the archaeological remains of the country, and made valuable contributions to craniology.
W. S. TUCKERMAN, formerly Treasurer of the Eastern Railroad, Poston, was arrested last night at New-Haven, for mail robbery. He is now in jail and confesses his gusllt.
