BROAD HINTS TO WORKING-MEN--Mayor WOOD'S organ has a very peculiar way of doing its patrons a service by informing the working-men of this City that they cannot obtain employment if they are even suspected of being "Wood men."

The following is the Weekly Report of Deaths in the City and County of New-York, from the 21st day of November to the 28th day of November, 1857: Men, 104; Women, 69; Boys, 130; Girls, 101; Total, 404. Adults, 179; Children, 231; Males, 234; Females, 170; Colored Persons, 12.

On Friday afternoon a woman, named Mrs. WALTERS, called at the Second Precinct Police Station, and made complaint to Capt. WEED that her brother, ALEXANDER CHALMERS, a sailor, had been forcibly taken to and detained on board the packet Jacob A. Westervelt, which was then lying in the stream, and about to sail for Liverpool.

MILITARY.--A meeting of the officers of the Hudson Brigade was held at Odd-Fellows Hall on Friday evening-Brigadier Gen. HATFIELD presiding--at which a Committee of two from each Company was appointed to take into consideration the propriety of adopting a brigade uniform. If the Committee decides that it is expedient, they will report a bill of dress to the Brigade Board.
We learn from sources that admit of no doubt, that a very serious difference of opinion exists between Governor WALKER and the Administration, in regard to the action of the Lecompton Convention.

The opposition to Mayor WOOD rests mainly upon a profound conviction in the public mind that he is not a man of integrity. Public rumor, public speech, the public prints and the records of our Courts of Justice teem with declarations, sustained by evidence, of his lack of that high-toned honesty which we trust our citizens will always consider indispensable in the Chief Magistrate of this great City.

THE WATER-STREET MURDER. - Coroner CONNERY yesterday examined FRANCIS VASDEI, at the Tombs, charged with being the principal in the recent murders in the Water-street dance-house of MARK DRIECOIL. The prisoner stated that he was a native of Spain, 24 years o age, a solider by profession and resides in Brooklyn.

UNITED STATES CIRCUIT COURT,--Nov. 30. Before Judge Nelson. A Grand Jury was summoned for this morning but as Judge NELSON was occupied with the argument of a patent case, they were discharged until ?? day next, without being organized.

The speech delivered by Mr. FERNANDO WOOD to a meeting of German citizens, held on Saturday night at the Volk's Garten in the Bowery, ought of itself to secure his defeat to-day at the polls of this City. On Friday evening, at the Academy of Music, the actual incumbent of the Mayoralty felt himself to be on his good behavior.

The friends of Mayor WOOD, driven to desporation by the dangerous condition of their patient's health, are putting up their prayers to ESCULAPIUS. "Minions of tile moon," as they are, and votaries of Mercury, they have discovered or fancy that they have discovered a notable well on the character of Mr. TIEMANN, by virtue of which they expect to recombine the dissolute energies of their fainting FBRNANDO.

I am enabled to deny, on the best authority, the statement that the President has had the least idea of discountenancing the movements of the Federal officers against Mayor WOOD. Considering them best qualified to determine what sort of character is desirable in a Mayor, the is quite content to leave them to follow their own inclinations.

The election, to-day, will show very conelusively whether the people of this City can, and will, take care of their own interests, or not. They have to choose between two candidates for Mayor,--one of whom is a man of integrity and character, and nominated by men of all parties, solely upon grounds of the public welfare, while the other stands exclusively as the representative of a political party.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: MY DEAR SIR: The similitude between valetudinarian nations and sick men, was somewhat worn before the late Czar NICHOLAS gave it a now sort of imperial sanction. Quite as full in the parallel, when a diseased public credit is concerned.

IN COMMERCE-STREET.--On Saturday, at 3 1/2 P. M., a fire broke out in the two-story wooden dwelling house No. 29 Commerce-street, occupied by THOMAS RILEY. The fire originated from a defective stovepipe passing through the roof. The entire upper part of the building was burned.

MORTALITY IN BROOKLYN.--During the week ending Saturday last, the Health Officer, Dr. CLEVELAND, reports 95 deaths: Males, 51: Females. 44; Men, 21; Boys, 30; Women 19; Girls, 25. DISEASES.--Consumption, 14; stillborn, 9; disease of the brain, 7; inflammation of the lungs, 6; convulsions and scarlet fever, 5 each; premature birth, inflammation of bowels, 4 each; congestion of lungs, chronic diarrhoea, marasmus, small pox, trismus, old age, apoplexy, typhoid fever, sprue, 2 each; ; bron.

The public announcement of the serious antagonism between the Administration and Governor WALKER, relative to Kansas affairs, has attracted he gravest attention. No one questions the facts as presented. By general consent the condition of antagonism is accepted on all hands.

A REMARKABLE THIEF.-There is nothing remarkable in theft, unhappily, nor is it very remarkable that a thief in one case will be a thief in all ; but there is a general belief that a stupendous thief, who betrays the trusts reposed in him, who swindles chartered companies of magnificent sums, and SWindles the public on a large scale, cannot, or will not, be guilty of low, vulgar robbery, or petty larceny.

SUICIDE IN A LAGER-BIER SALOON.--A young man named KERN, who for two months past has been a partner with ADAM BEB, in the restaurant corner of Beekman and Nassau streets, committed suicide Monday night by inhaling the fumes of charcoal. After all the persons had left for the night, KERN closed the place at the usual hour and went deliberately to work to put an end to his existence.

GOV. McWILLE'S ADVICE.--GOV. McWILLE has been inaugurated Governor of Mississippi, and favors the public with a violent inaugural message. He believes there is a set purpose in the North among the chiefs and leaders of Abolitionism to overthrow the social organization of the South by means of their power in the Federal Government; and be urges the South to be prepared to resist it at all costs and in every contingency.

FIRE IN FIFTY -FOURTH -STREET, - Shortly before 12 o' clock on Monday night, a fire broke out in the three- story frame building in Fifty-fourth -street near Seventh-Avenue, consuming the building entirely. Mr. SULLIVAN Owned the building, and his loss is about $300, which is covered by insurance. WM.

The British schooner A. Canale, arrived from Nassau, reports that the ship Bolina, from Thomaston for New-Orleans, was lost off Bekry Island on the 12th of November. All her officers and crew were saved.

THE NEW CANADIAN MINISTRY.--The Canadian press is merry over the Constitution of the new Cabinet, which, it seems, is composed almost wholly of lawyers. Of the twelve members, eleven are lawyers and one is an auctioneer.

It was mentioned a few days ago, by Telegraph, that the steamship Tennessee had arrived at Now-Orleans with twenty-three political exits from Mexico, and that the country was on the eve of a violent revolution. It appears that the extraordinary powers heretofore published had been granted to the President.

A CASE OF SCANDAL--A DERELICT CLERGYMAN.--A short time since a man by the name of WENT-WORTH went to Nashville. Tenn., to reside. He is said to have passed himself off for a genuine preacher, but while in want of a congregation he engaged himself as proof-reader in the office of one of the Nashville papers.

The United States mail Steamship ?? Capt. WOTTON, arrived at this port last evening, from Havre and Southampton, bringing London dates to Nov. 18. The leading features of the news she brings were given on Monday, in our telegraphic dispatches from St. Johns--the steamer having been intercepted off Cape Race by the news yacht of the associated Press.

THE REMAINS OF CRAWFORD.--The remains of the great American Sculptor, CRAWFORD, which arrived at this port on board the ship Southampton, were removed, yesterday afternoon, from the ship by the undertaker of St. John's Church, and conveyed to the residence of the brother-in-law of the deceased, Mr. CAMPBELL. The funeral service will take place from St. John's Church on Saturday.

The New-Haven Register gives full particulars of the detection and arrest of WAR S. TUCKERMAN: A most important arrest took place in this city on Sunday evening, for extensive mail robberies committed within a few weeks past. These robberies embraced the entire letter mil on several occusions, made up at Philadelphin, New-Oricans and other points, for Boston, at least one mail from Boston for New-York, and several others of less importance.

Charles R. Deming has been arrested at Indianapolis, charged with purloining money letters from the Post-Office. He was in the employ of the Sentinel newspaper, and had a key to the Sentinel's letterbox. Decoy letters were used to catch him. He was raised in Lafayette and was the son of a man of high character. For a time he was mail agent on the New Albany and Salem Railroad.

From the Lecompton Democrat. We think the Convention has committed a capital error. It was in their power completely to redeem themselves in the eyes of the people, and to cure all the defects of their original election. They ought to have risked themselves frankly upon the popular support, appealing to the patriotism and justice of the people to sustain their acts.

MAYOR WOOD'S POLITICAL POSITION.--It is supposed by many that Mayor WOOD'S defeat terminates his political career,-that he cannot recover from the blow thus inflicted, and that he must now disappear from the political field. We suspect that those who indulge this hope will find themselves mistaken.

THE ELECTION AND THE DEMOCRACY.--The Daily News is determined to be unhappy. Although one of the staunchest of Democrats has just been elected Mayor, it still announces in a lugubrious paragraph, that the "Democracy is defeated."

GAS EXPLOSION AND NARROW ESCAPE.--About 1 o'clock, yesterday, the people in the vicinity of Odd-Fellows' Hall, corner of Grand and Center streets, were startled by a terrific explosion. An alarm of fire was instantly given, and a number of Engine Companies and a large throng of citizens,--women and children, were speedily at the spot.

A Fugitive Slave Case and a Habeas Corpus. The usual monotony of Brooklyn was broken in upon yesterday by a rumor that a fugitve slave was lodged somewhere in the City, and was to be sent back to his master. The natural course of things led to inquiries at the City Court for the Particulars of the case.

THE BASIS OF SLAVERY--EXPLANATION OF THE UNION. From the Washington Union. The Chicago Times and store one or two other papers of like pro?ness to find fault with the Union, are grievously exercised over one of our late editorials, because, as they interpret it, we advance a novel and alarming doctrine as to the extension of Slavery into the Free States.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Your reporter was in error in stating that I had an altereation with Dr. CHADSER at Tammany Hall last evening, and that he was put off the platform. I have known Dr. CHADSEY as a consistent Democrat for many years, and we never had an unpleasant word together at any time. Please correct the error, and oblige, Yours, c. ISAIAH RYNDERS.

IMPORTANT MAILS MISSING.--The Havana mail for the State of Maine, which arrived in New-York on the 20th, has not been received at Portland. It contained about 500 letters, a hundred of which were for the merchants of Portland, and doubtless contained many remittances. The mail from Portland for New-York on the 21st, going by the land route on that day, has not been heard from.

The second performance of "Robert le Diable," last night, attracted an audience almost as numerous as on the first representation. But in the upper regions it was not so buzzy, and there was, therefore a better opportunity of listening to the music. The most noticeable feature of the present rendering of this opera is its smoothness. There are, as we said only once before, no week points. The cast, without being overpoweringly great, is sufficient.

The Board of Governors met on Wednesday, Dee President, C. GODFREY GUNTHER, Esq., in the Chair. Upon the rending of the minutes, Governors TIEMANN, TOWNHEND and W. C. PINOKNEY being present, Governor OLIVER asked whether it would not be better to adjourn, inasmuch as the members did not seen inclined to take their seats at the table.

PREGARIOUS CONDITIONS OF THE LEVIATHAN.--Another abortive attempt to launch the Leviathan was made on the 19th of last month, but the monster was not moved an inch. It was not expected that she would have been fully launched, the engineer intending only to move her some forty feet nearer the river; but it seems she could not be moved at all.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR: I observe by an article in your paper headed "The ??nsheltered Poor," that a large number of persons in your City are nightly without lodgings, and that the Police Commissioners have not at disposal adequate places for their reception, and have addressed the Common Council upon the subject. This appears well.

The regular meeting of the Academy was held last evening at the small chapel of the University. Dr. VALENTINE MOIT Presiding. At a little after 7 o'clock a quorum of members was present, and the minutes were read. No section was ready to report except that on Anatomy, the secretary of which stated that since the Summer vacation it had been impossible to get the member together, but they hoped for better things.

THE HOBOKEN WATER QUESTION.--The Hoboken Council held a special meeting on Monday evening, at which they appointed Messrs. GEO. W. MORTON, WM. G. PLUMMER and JOHN C. KONLSAAT as Water-Commissioners, in the place of Messrs. EDMUND CHARLES, CHARLES CLINTON and JOHN IRELAND, who were recently removed by the Council; and another special meeting was held on Tuesday evening, at which the hands of the new Commissioners were presented and approved.

A meeting was held at Lawrence on the 19th ??., for the purpose of considering the action of the late Constitutional Convention. Resolutions were adopted declaring the Lecompton Constitution a gross violation of the expressed wishes of the people of Kansas; a fraud begotten of fraud; solemnly pledging themselves to resist to the last all attempts to thrust it upon them;

The Mexican schooner Edsuardo, arrived at this port, spoke on the 25th ultimo the Campeachy armed schooner corrina , thus obtaining thee weeks' later news from Yucatan. Sisal had been bombarded and captured by the revolutions.

The Democral publishes the Kansas Constitution, but it contains nothing on the subject of Slavery not heretofore published. The Santa Fe mail has arrived here. The news by it is unimportant. Lieut. WRIGHT, of New-York, died suddenly at Albuquerque on the 26th October.

The position of the Kansas question is creating profound excitement in the Democratic Party. The Republicans have been at fever-heat upon the general subject so long that they are more disturbed now than usual; having from the beginning, moreover, expected nothing from the Administration, they are not disappointed. But the Democrats have more at stake,

There was considerable excitement at 6 1/2 o'clock last evening in the Ninth Ward, caused by the fall of the Interior of the new four-story brick building just erected at the corner of West and Bethune streets. The noise caused by the crash was heard some distances, and created a fourful commotion in the vicinity. In a few minutes hundreds of persons were gathered around the building,

Col. FORNEY'S Press of yesterday has the following: "The Governor of Kansas reached Philadelphia yesterday noon, and is the guest of his relative, ST. GEORGE. TUCKER CAMPBELL, Governor WALKER leaves for New-York this morning, and will be with us again in a few days. He is in great health and spirits, and fully and entirely committed to the doctrine of popular sovereignty, and to the principle that the will of the majority shall prevail.

In the result of the election of Tuesday this City has gained not only the precious loss of a dangerous and disreputable Chief Magistrate, and the substitution in his place of a decent and respectable citizen, but something of wider and deeper import than any change in the incumbency of any single office whatever.

Senator DOUGLAS arrived tonight. He talks freely with reference to the Kansas question, sustaining Gov. WALKER boldly. Indeed, your Chicago letter, published on Tuesday, could not more exactly express his sentiments if written by himself. The impression gains ground that the President will avoid taking a position in the Message either for or against the action of the Convention.

PERSONAL--Dr. CHARLES MACKAY has accepted the invitation of the Mercantile Library Association to deliver before them his course of lectures on Ballad Literature, already read with brilliant success in Boston.

THE LARGE CITY VOTE.-We learn from good authority that there have been at least ten thousand persons naturalized in the Superior Court and Court of Common Pleas within the last year ; and of this number, at least six thousand are now residents of the City, and voted at the election on Tuesday.

The Cunard steamship America, from Liverpool on the 22d ult., arrived at Halifax yesterday morning. A telegraph, published elsewhere, gives the particulars of her advices. Further suspensions and failures of large business houses had occurred in Great Britain; but, according to the Times, matters were mending.

To help the poor to help themselves is the root of all profitable charity, and, while every institution which serves the public by positive munificence deserves the encouragement of good citizens, those are particularly worthy of aid and comfort which tend to sustain the energies as well as to console the prostration of the needy and the suffering.

Mr. TIEMANN'S 2,331 majority ?parted a gentle glow to the surface of society yesterday. Most men looked happy as they came down to their business, and as there was nothing throughout the day to vary the result that was announced in the morning, the whole town wore a bright holiday look.

The robbery was perpetrated at a house in the central part of the city, where the victim, with others,

Navy-Yard, Brooklyn. Up to the 1st of December there were some 1,800 men employed at the Navy-Yard ; at that time ?? were discharged, principally from the Engineer's Department, because the appropriations were giving out. Of this number many were employed upon the new stores, on which work has been suspended on account of the setting in of frost.

The Postmaster of San Francisco has given notice that many letters arrive at his office from the Atlantic States vid Panama, which are found adhering so closely together by sealing-wax, that it is impossible to separate them without mutilating, and in many case entirely destroying, the addresses.

ABOUT FOOLS.--We find in one of our exchanges the following classification of a portion of our population: "A dry sort of genius once undertook to name and classify the different sorts of fools in this world as follows: First, the ordinary fool; Second, the fool who is one and don't know it; Third, the fool who is not satisfied with being a fool in reality, but undertakes, in addition, to play the fool."

ARRIVAL OF EX-PRESIDENT PIERCE AT NORFOLK.--Ex-President PIERCE, with his estimate lady, arrived in our city yesterday morning, after a pleasant trip down the Chesapeake in the steamer North Carolina. He was welcomed by a national salute from the receiving-ship Pennsylvania, and a salute from the Norfolk Light Artillery Blues, Capt. CORPREW.

DEATH FROM DISEASE OF THE HEART.--A resident of Baltimore, Major MATTHEW WHEELER by name, was found dead in bad, at the public-house, no. 77 Cortland-street, yesterday morning, Mr. WHEELER usually put up at this place on visiting the City, Coroner GAMBLE held an inquest on the body, and a verdict of "Death from disease of the ?? was rendered. Diseased was 56 years of age,

The Commercial of this morning learns that the planing mill and axe factory of MEAD Co., at Ironton, Ohio, was destroyed by fire on Tuesday night. Loss $5,000; no insurance. The fire is attributed to an incendiary. Several other houses were likewise set on fire the same night.

CAUTION AGAINST THE USE OF SEALING-WAX,--It is stated that notice has been given by the Postmaster of San Francisco that many letters arrive at his office from the Atlantic States, vid Panama, which are found adhering so closely together by sealing-wax that it is impossible to separate them without mutilating, and, in many cases, entirely destroying the addresses.

At a meeting at Leavenworth, Kansas, on the 21st ult., resolutions were adopted similar to those passed at Lawrence on the 19th, and speeches were made by Messrs. VAUGHAN, PHILLIPS, HUTCHINS, MOORE, and others. Mr. PHILLIPS advised rallying around the Topeka Constitution, calling it the Magna Charta of Kansas liberty.

The steamship America arrived at Boston last night, and her mails will reach this City at 5 o'clock P.M. to-do It is now understood, in Washington, that the Administration, during the sitting of the Constitutional Convention in Kansas, had a secret agent engaged in advising its members, and through whom portions, if not, the whole, of the schedule, as published, were dictated by the Executive.

NEGRO MINSTRELS SUDDENLY BLANCHED.--The visitors at Christy's Minstrel Hall on Wednesday night were entertained with fragments of a play that was not down in the bill. Judging from the voices that were heard by all in front of the curtain, GEORGE CHRISTY and Mr. BOWERS behind the scenes were mutually giving each other a very satisfactory pummeling.

In the TIMES of yesterday, we gave particulars, as far as were then known, of the arrest in Brooklyn of a man alleged to be a fugitive slave, who had escaped from Georgia and arrive in New-York by the steamer Florida, Captain CROWELL. To-day we publish some additional particulars committed with this transaction.

HORSE-MEAT SAUSAGES IN PHILADELPHIA.--For several weeks past, the proprietors of some of the beer-shops up town have been purchasing their supply of sausages from a couple of Germans, named DUNN and HOFFMAN, who hawked the delicacies about, and who professed to sell a very superior article at a very low price.

States Uironoit Court at Clncinnati, by JAMES LAX CO.,of New-York. against soveral banking institutions of Ohio,in which the parties claim damages in the aggregate to the amount of $397,000.

The TIMES is quite right in doubting the truth of the representations that have been made of the President's position on the Kansas question. They have done him, as well as Gov. WALKER, great injustice. The Message will express a distinct approval of Gov. WALKER's entire official course in Kansas.

JOHN CUMMINGS SENTENCED TO BE HUNG--THE CASE OF MCCANN. ALBANY. Thursday, Dec. 3. JOHN CUMMINGS, convicted on the 3d of December, 1856, of the murder of FERDERICK STUMPY, was this morning sentenced to be hung on the 28th of January.
NEW-YORK ARTISTS.--The correspondent of the Boston Transcript writes: "HUNTINGTON is at work in London, on his large picture of 'American Men of Science.'

The R. M. steamship America, from Liverpool on the 21st ult., vid Halifax, arrived below at about 5 o'clock this evening, but owing to the unfavorable state of the tide, she did not reach her dock until 9 1/2 o'clock.

The Southern mail, of two days, has been received. The sugar cane, in Rapides Parish, was seriously injured by the frost last week. The late JAMES BATTLE, of Mobile, bequeathed $600-000 to his widow, the Battle House to his grandnephew, and $10,000 each to the Orphan Asylum and the Methodist Church.

Gen. LAMAR'S family, who accompanied him hither from Texas, in the expectation of going with him on his mission to the Argentine Confederation, have returned home, now that the General expects to go on the special Mission to Central America.

Yet the partisans of Mayor Wood are clamorous for the removal of Mr. BUTTERWORTH, the Super.

The particulars of the murder of a young man named CHARLES W. GITCHELL, at Hook's Point, on Saturday, Nov. 14, have been given. GITCHELL had been in the employ of Mr. Hook. A difficulty occurred between Hook and his son-in-law, SMITH, concerning the removal of a fence which interfered with the arrangements of the latter.

It is now stated, and we believe upon good authority, that he will do nothing of the sort,

FELLOW-CITIZENS: I feel very happy for the opportunity of addressing the people of Leavenworth. I never seek the opportunity of speaking, but am always ready to lend my voice where the good of Kansas is the object. Gentlemen, we have come to the last move on the chess-board of Kansas politics.

The Boston Daily Advertiser is considerably puzzled to reconcile the early good conduct of TUCKERMAN, who has been arrested for robbing the mail in New-Heaven, with his villainies in swindling the Eastern Railroad Company, and his last atrocious conduct, for which he is now under arrest.

MEYERREER'S Opera of "Robert to Diable" will be given to-night for the third time. OPERA IN HAVENA. MARETZEE and his company have commenced operations in Havana. The house was crowded from pit dome, and the enthuslasm was unbounded. The opera selected for the occasion was "Lucrezia Borgia," Madame GAZZANICA playing her principal role. Her success appears to have been enormous.

The Democratic General Committee met inst. evening in No. 4 Tammany Hall, and enjoyed a very exciting season. SICKLES, resigning his position as a member of the Committee, on the ground that his duties as a member of the next Congress

SHOOTING IN THE FIRST WARD.-- At a late hour Wednesday evening JAMES LEONARD, residing at No. 16 Greenwich-street, was shot by WM. BURNS, Ex-Licut, of the First Ward Police. An exciting talk concerning the late election induced it.

ANTI-RENT OCTRAGE IN SULLIVAN COUNTY.--On Monday, the 9th ult., Mr. IRA PORTER was dispossessed by Sheriff LEROY of the premises then occupied by him under a lease owned by JOHN HUNTER, Jr., and Mr. JAMES L. ?? was put in possession. On the morning following he found the letters, warning him to leave.

Last Thursday, Nov. 26, was Thanksgiving Day in that State. It was generally observed as a holiday, and trade was suspended in this City. Hence, the week just closed comprised but five business days. Throughout the week the weather has been unusually mild, and, in consequence, the receipts of produce have been pretty heavy, especially of Flour and Wheat. Canal navigation has been partially resumed,

The London Times publishes the following private letter: "About the 1st of this month Brigadier NICHOLSON went out with a force and completely routed a large force of the enemy, taking 13 guns. About this time the siege-train of heavy guns arrived from the Punjab. Up to this time we were acting almost entirely on the defensive.

A MCKEESPORT TRAGEDY---ANOTHER MYSTERY CLEARED Up.--The Pillsburg Journal, of Wednesday, says; 'The contession of HENRY FIFH and CHARLOTTE JONES of their complicity in the Wilson murder, solves many mysteries connected with that fearful crime, and among them it discloses where the money stolen from the aged couple was hidden.

Dr. CHARLES MACKAY, the popular English Song-writer, delivered his first lecture in this City last night at Mozart Hall, No. 663 Broadway. The lecture was initiatory to a course of lectures on the Song and Ballad Poetry of England, Scotland and Ireland. A numerous and highly respectable audience assembled to beat him, among whom we noticed several of our prominent citizens.

KANSAS MATTERS.--The notorious "JIM LANE," who turns up regularly in Kansas whenever there is any prospect of a fight, or any possibility of creating one, has been making a blood-and-thunder speech to the most ultra and reckless of the Free-State population.

CONGRATULATIONS FROM OUR PROVINCIAL NEIGHBORS.--We have never before had such touching proofs of the lively interest which our provincial neighbors take in the affairs of this metropolis, as since the defeat of Mayor WOOD. Our cotemporaries on all sides are perfectly jubilant over the result of the election, and some of them devote long leaders to the subject, evincing a most intimate acquaintance with our municipal affairs and our prominent men.

MINERAL RESOURCES OF GREAT BRITAIN.--According to official statistics, the total production of coal in Great Britain in 1854, exceeded 64,000,000 tons, or double the amount estimated. In order to form some idea of the extent of this production, it may be compared with that of the coal-producing countries of Europe.

Forrest's suit against Wheatley of the Arch-street Theatre in Philadelphia, to restrain him from the production of "Jack Cade," is again before the Courts. A letter is produced from Judge Conrad, author of the play, written in 1852, requesting permission from Forrest to publish it in a volume of his poems. Forrest did not comply with this request, claiming, us now, full ownership of the manuscript. The price paid was $1,000.

A SCHOOLMASTER IN TROUBLE.--DANIEL SULLIVAN is the teacher in the Catholic school attached to the Cathedral on Franklin-street. He was brought before Justice DRULLARD, Yesterday, charged with cruelty to a pupil.

EGYPT, January. It was morning--and a glorious morning too--when we awoke at Phila. The wind had blown steadily all night long, and we had come down rapidly, so that it was just daybreak when I stood on deck and saw before me that exquisite view, I thing the most beautiful in all the world, of the Island of Osirls, among as rocky guardians.

EXTRAORDINARY DEVELOPMENTS IN REGARD TO THE BOARD OF HEALTH OF PHILADELPHIA--FORGERY AND SWINDLING. From the Philadelphia Evening Bulletin, Thursday. It is known to most of our readers that the Finance Committee of Councils has been lately investigating the business of the Board of Health of this city, with reference to some embezzlements and other offences which it was supposed had been committed by some of its members.

Weather cold and cloudy, but no ice making yet. There ?? none in the harbor or the Canal. Wind W. N. W. OSWEGO, Thursday, Dec. 3. Navigation in the Welland Canal is fully resumed. CHICAGO, Thursday, Dec. 3.

A VERY LIGHT VOTE.-Among the officers voted for at the Novembor election was a Judge to fill the vacancy created by the death of Judge OAKLEY. As the vacancy exists only until January, the competition or the place was not very sharp. The official returns show that the only votes cast were ROBERT FINN, 92; ISAAC L. TAYLOR, 84; E. A. STANSBURY, 14; Scattering, 67.

The argument in the case of the patent for making hat bodies, arising in the Connectient District, and which has been on hearing for some time back before Judges NELSON and INOERSOLL, was closed yesterday. Judges NELSON goes to Washington tomorrow to attend at the Supreme Court, and was not therefore in Court this morning, and the Court was held by Judge INOERSOLL, who remains for that purpose.

From the Detroit Tribune, 1st. We are informed that several detectives, among whom we have only the names of officers SPRAGUE AND WILCOXSON, took a supply of small arms, handcuffs, and went to Ann Albor for the purpose of catching a couple of fugitive slaves, who were at work at near by. They had arranged for an amicable partition of the reward.

CHAMBER OF COMMERCE.--The monthly meeting of the Chamber of Commerce was held yesterday at the Merchants' Bank, PELATIAU ?? Esq., in the Chair. There were but few present. On motion ANSON G. PHELPS, Esq., was chosen a member of the Committee of Arbitration. Mr. CAIEB BARSTOW moved that a committee of Three be appointed to draft a memorial to the next Legislature for the repeat of the Usury Laws.

More TICKET SWINBLING.--Three German Immigrants, named CHRISTIAN MULLER, WILBELN MILLER and CARL HENCKE, appeared on Thursday afternoon before Justice DAVISON, and preferred charges of fraud against one J.C. SCHETTE, whom they allege sold them tickets for passage to Cluicinnati, Ohio, via Erle Railroad, which tickets are charged to be begins and of no use.

The principal Importers of and dealers in drugs, dye-stuffs, , met on Thursday at 11 o'clock, at the auction salesroom of GERARD BETTS, No. 106 Wall-street. The meeting was convenued in obedience to a call issued a week since, for the purpose of discussing the general interest of the Trade, and to recommend a decrease of the Credit System, rendered necessary by the late revolutions in the business of the country.

WALKER'S enemies, but been coldly received on all sides.

LOST OVERBOARD.--As the ship Stage Hound, of Boston, from China, was passing Sandy Hook in-ward, on Thursday, CHARLES SHEEHAN, one of the crew who was furling the skysail, fell from aloft, and striking the foretopsail yard in his descent dropped overboard and was lost.

POWERS OF OUR NEW MAYOR.--We may congratulate ourselves not only on having elected a good man to the office of Mayor, but upon his having a better opportunity to exercise his ability under the amended Charter than he would have had under the old one.

From the Cincinnati Commercial of Thursday. During the past two or three days the people of Newport, Ky., have been profoundly agitated by the development of facts showing a design to murder an entire family by means of poison.

We have received a letter from Johanna, one of the Comoro Islands, in the Mozambique Channel, and dated the 23d of April last, in which the writer expresses his great joy at the election of "Old Buck" to the Presidency of the United States, news of which had just reached that outlandish region.

BRADY.-- In this City, on Thursday. Dec. 3. HENRIETTA, wife of James Brady, in the 37th year of her age. Pursuant to Circular, a meeting was held on Friday evening in the Clinton Hall, for the purpose of organizing a society whose object should be to provide for the present destitution of women About 25 ladies and the same number of gentlemen were present. The chair was occupied by Dr. L. T. WARNER, and Mr. D. C. VAN NORMAN officiated as Secretary.

We observe that sundry journals out of the City following the lead of the Herald, characterize the result of the recent election in this City as a defeat of tile Democratic Party. Few of them go so far as the Herald does, In. saying that it is a clear triumph of the Repub licans, and that it is to be considered as an approval by the people of last Winter's logislation concerning our municipal affairs.

MEETING OF ERIE BONDHOLDERS IN LONDON.--there was a meeting in London, on the 19th of last month, of Erie Railroad bondholders, to discuss the affairs of the Company and take measures for raising subscriptions towards the proposed loan of $3,000,000.

The America's mails from Boston reached this City yesterday afternoon. We give below full details of the important financial news, of which a telegraphic summary was received from Halifax. There is not much general intelligence from Europe by this arrival.

THE KANSAS CONSTITUTION.--We have received a copy of this document, but find in it nothing sufficiently new or interesting to render its publication at all worth while. Indeed, in all its leading features it is merely a transcript of the Constitutions of the other States, and especially of New-York.

From the Montgomery (Ala.) Advertiser, The following Joint Resolutions were reported by the Senate Committee on federal Relations, and were adopted on Monday, in the Senate of Alabama, by a unanimous vote. They will, doubtless, pass the other branch of our General Assembly unanimously.

ARREST OF A SUPPOSED BURGLAR.--THREE THOUSAND DOLLARS' WORLD OF WATCHES AND JEWELRY IN HIS POSSESSION.--Chief of Police HAINES of Jersey City, yesterday morning arrested a man at the Philadelphia Hotel on suspicion of having dishonestly obtained a large stock of watches and jewelry which was found in his possession.

LABOR AND LABORERS ON THE CENTRAL PARK.--We are gratified to see that the Commissioners of the Central Park are pursuing a judicious course for the advancement of this important undertaking. At present a large number of men are employed in breaking stone for the formation of roads.

The Democratic members of the House of Representatives will hold their ?? on Saturday evening next. As I have heretofore stated in my dispatches, there are serious symptoms of a breeze. The Administration is believed to be relieved of a heavy load by the defeat of mayor Wood, though they were nominally in his favor. The appointment of a District-Attorney in the place of Mr. KcKEON, upon the expiration of his term, has no reference to this matter.

A SLIGHT MISTAKE.--Among our out-of-town cotemporaries who have exhibited a lively interest in our late municipal election, no one has kept a sharper eye upon us than the Albany Argus and Atlas.

A large number of laborers are employed by the Eric Railroad Company, at their freight terminus, on the Hudson, at Piedmont, to unload barges and handle the freight which is received at that point. About 200 men are employed there the year round, except in the coldest part of Winter, when the ice obstructs navigation, and prevents the passage of their freight boats up the North River.

RAILROAD ACCIDENTS.-- No fewer than five railroad accidents, involving injury to passengers and considerable destruction of property, occurred on Friday morning within a few hours, on the Pennsylvania and Ohio Railroad between Pittsburgh and Crestline. The express train coming west at a high rate of speed, between Palestine and New-Waterford, at day break encountered a broken rail.

About eight days since the agents of Dr. VALIANDIGHAM, of Frankfort, Ky., captured a fugitive slave at Naples, Illinois, When en route to Kentucky the negro was taken under a writ of habeas corpus before Judge WALLACE, who liberated him. He was immediately re-arrested, and taken before United States Commissioner REA, who, after hearing the case, decided that the negro should go back to Slavery.

Mr. MIXER, agent of the Lake Navigation Company, received to day a letter from the Secretary at Buffalo, stating that news had just been received that the small boat and upper part of the cabin of the schooner Resolution, together with the captain's desk, containing his books, papers, a revolver, , had at floated ashore at Point Clark, on Georgian Bay, and that the schooner was no doubt lost, with all on board.

CUMMINGS SENTENCED TO BE HUNG FOR THE MURDER OF STUMPF.--The Albany Journal - says: "Judge COULD , this morning, in the Court of Oyer and Terminer, sentenced JOHN COMMINGS to be hung on the 28th of January next; between the hours of 12 and 2 P. M., for the murder of STUMP, in Bethlehem.

THE LATE BUILDING CASUALTY IN BETHUNE-STREET--ANOTHER DEAD BODY FOUND--THE CORONER'S JURY,--The laborers employed on Thursday in clearing away the barley and rubbish from the fallen building, corner of Bothune and West streets, exhumed another victim of the casualty about 5 o'clock in the afternoon.

The Cohoes Manufacturing Company recently entered into a contract with Mr. BOGUE to repair the dem actions the river at Cohoes. The work was documented by four F. enchmen under his employ. A raft was constructed, and while they were engaged, yesterday afternoon, in the planking, the water was rapidly, the rope attached to the raft soon after parted, when they were carried over the dam.

TEMPERANCE FESTIVAL.--The Bridge-street Juvenile Temperance Society, of Brooklyn, held their first social tea-festival on Wednesday evening, in the Primitive Methodist Church, Bridge-street, near Fillary-street, Ex-Mayor HALL presiding.

NAVAL AND ARMY EXPENSES--The appropriations which the Secretary of the Treasury demands for military purposes during the ensuing year are alarmingly large, but they will, of course, be granted without opposition, for the Administration must be allowed the necessary means to maintain the national defences, let them be what they will.

Congress meets to-day at noon, and will, without doubt, be promptly organized by the election of Colonel ORR, of South Carolina, as Speaker in the House of Representatives, and the appointment of a President pro tempore in tile Senate. The President's Message will probably be transmitted to Congress, and published in the TIMES to-morrow.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--Three of the largest houses were attracted to the Academy of Music, and witnessed the performance of MEYERBEERS's "Robert le Diable" last week. The same opera will be played to-night, and on Wednesday for the last time. Few works have been produced in a more creditable way than this, and the patrons of the Opera should certainly support a manager that displays energy and liberality.

The Democratic members of the House of Representatives held a caucus on Saturday evening, for the nomination of candidates for the officers of that body. All the nominations were made excepting for Printer, as follows; For Speaker, Col ORR, of South Carolina; for Clerk, Mr. ALLEN, of Illinois; for Postmaster, Mr. CLUSKEY, of Georgia; for Doorkeeper, Mr. HACKNEY, of Virginia; for Sergeant-at-Arms, Mr. GLOSSBRENNER.

The Belton (Texas) Independent records further Indian depredations in that vicinity. On the 11th they stole and drove away over one hundred horses. Mr. Lewis, son-in-law of Moses Jackson, was killed on Pecan Bayou by Indians, or men disguised as such. Others had been attacked by them, and there was a general disposition among the settlers to leave, unless immediate assistance was sent to them.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Your Saturday evening paper contained a decision emenating from the Court of Common Pleas, affecting this law. The Board of Port Wardens are anxious that the public should know that they were not parties to the suit of Tinekam vs. Wm. Tapscott, directly or indirectly,

The Court finds him " Not Guilty " on every charge affecting his personal reputation, and" Guilty " on the minor points relating to discipline or etiquette. SUPREME COURT--Circuit--Nos. 1203, ?? 1621, 1981, 2351, 2319, 325, 1008, 1624, 2534, 331, 259, 215, 216, 367. NOTICE--SUPREME COURT. On and after Dec. 7, Judge DAVIES will sit at Chambers, commencing at 1 o' clock A. M. , each day. Judge ROOSEVELT will open the December Term of the Special Term on Monday, Dec. 7, at 11 o'clock A.M. The whole calendar will be called.

MEETING OF THE SWISS BENEVOLENT SOCIETY.--The Swiss Benevolent Society held an annual meeting at DELMONICO'S, on Saturday afternoon. In consideration of the present condition of affairs, it was decided not to have the usual social dinner. There were some sixty members present. HENEY MAIRET, the President, took the chair.

A meeting of the citizens of Lawrence was held on the evening of the 10th inst. The meeting was organized by the election of Gen. E. B. WHITMAN, Chairman, and NORMAN ALLEN, Esq., Secretary. General LANE, being introduced to the meeting, took the stand, and made one of his most able and eloquent speeches. At his conclusion, the Chair appointed a Committee on Resolutions, consisting of the following gentlemen:

An Immense crowd assembled in the Senate Chamber this morning to hear the decision of Judge WALLACE in the fugitive slave case. He decided that he could not traverse the decision of the Commissioner, and that the negro must be remanded back to slavery. The United States Marshal started in the evening with the negro for Louisville, where he will hand him over to Dr. VALLANDINGHAM.

HORRIBLE SPECTACLE IN THE SUNKEN RUSSIAN MAN-OF-WAR.--Towards the end of last month by order of the Russian Government, the Russian vessel-of-the-line Lefort, of whose foundering in the Gulf of Finland, with 1,400 men on board, we had a report at the time, was searched for, found and examined by English divers, brought ?? for the purpose. se.

IN JOHN-STREET.--Shortly after 9 o'clock on Sunday morning a fire occurred on the third floor of building No. 120 John-street, occupied by ROTHSTEIN RAFFEL, cap manufacturers. the firemen were soon at the premises and extinguished the flames. the fire was caused, it seems, by some muslin which was placed too near the stove-pipe and caught fire.

The following is the Weekly Report of Deaths in the City and County of New-York, from the 28th day of November to the 5th day of December, 1857: Men, 89; Women, 90; Boys, 124; Girls, 110: Total, 413.* Adults, 179; Children, 234; Males, 213; Females, 200; Colored Persons, 13.

THE BURGLARY AT CINCINNATI--PROPERTY IDENTIFIED.--A telegraphic dispatch was received from Cincinnati by Mr. HAINES, the Chief of Police, Jersey City, containing a description of the property found in the possession of CHARLES E. WARREN, who was arrested, as stated in the TIMES, at the Philadelphia Hotel, on Friday morning. The watches and jewelry prove to be the property of Messrs. S. K. STREVE Co., whose establishment was robbed on Sunday night last.

Are you in reality the greatest grumblers in the world, or is your Police the worst in the world? That you go once a year to the polls and vote yourselves invariably the same Police, the same insecurity of life and property, the same garroting, head-splitting, pocket-picking system, shows that your grumbling is animmonse rumbling of hollow sounds

THE WEATHER. -- Yesterday was a damp, dreary, dingy, desolate and drowsy Sunday, and the Churches were in consequence nearly half desorted. It rained almost the entire day, and when it did not rain, it did worse--it drizzled. For three weeks past we have been favored with the finest Indian Summer weather we have enjoyed for years past; but carly on Saturday morning, a thin coating of snow lay upon the ??.

THE SPOILS. -- The scramble for office under the new City Government has already began and in the course of a week, we suspect it will become inconveniently active. Some of the Republican papers, which were most zealous in the advocacy of Mr. TIRMANN are already clamoring for the removal of the City Chamberlin,

WETMORE.--In this City, on Saturday, Dec. 5, suddenly, WILLIAM H. WETMORE, aged 30 years. His relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral, without further notice, from the residence of Dr. Abram Dubois, No. 13 West 11th-st., on Monday morning. at 10 o'clock. STEVENSON.--In this City, on Sabbath morning, Dec. 6, Mr. ELIZABETH STEVENSON, aged 51 years.

The United States Mail steamship Cahawba, J. D. BULLOOK, Commander, from New-Orleans vid Havana, arrived early yesterday morning, leaving left the latter port on the 1st inst. From Havana no news of particular interest offers Itself. The stock of Sugars has declined to 140,000 boxesprices less. Freights are a little more in demand,

A great diversity of opinion has been expressed both in this country and Europe as to the causes of the late panic, which resulted so disastrously for the commerce of the whole civilized world. The extravagance of the women, the gambling propensities of the men, the contractions of the banks of New-York, the expansions of the Bank of England.

FALSE PRETENCES.--Julius C. Marsh was brought before Judge RUSSELL, on a charge of obtaining $950 worth of eigars James Schott, who was the complainant, by means of false representations, Schott is an importer of cigars, doing business at No. 5 William-street, and made an affidavit to the effect that March went to his store on the 24th of November last, and said he wanted to purchase cigars of him;

MUNICIPAL RASOALTIES.--We have never winced under the terrible epithets which some of our provincial neighbors have occasionally bestowed upon New-York ; and when it has been called the metropolis of vice, and our Municipal government been held up as a model of villany, we have not ventured to resent the offensive judgments pronounced,

COMMENCEMENT OF THE NEW MAYORALTY TERM.--One of Mayor Wood's newspaper supporters intimates that his Honor intends to hold over until the 1st of January, 1859, on the pretence that the laws touching the subject do not specify when the first Mayor under the new charter shall be installed into office.

A rare and precious commodity in these days is candor; and certainly a rarer or more precious exhibition of it was never made in print, than is manifest in the Report of the Committee of Inquiry concerning the loss of the Central America, in the month of September Last. This characteristic, we say, pervades the entire document. You perceive it in the very title, " A Partial Report"

CANAL NAVIGATION CLOSED,--The Canals are closed for the season. We learn that at Amsterdam yesterday six horses could not start a boat on account of the ice, and along the valley of the Mohawk the canal to blocked by ice. The snow which fell here last night and this morning has so clogged the gates that it is impossible to lock a boat,.

The funeral of the celebrated American sculptor, THOMAS CRAWFORD, who died in London, after a protracted illness, on the 10th October, took place on Saturday. His remains were brought from England in the ship Southampton, and reached this port on Tuesday last. On the following day they were conveyed to the residence of his brother-in-law, Mr. CAMPBELL, No. 158 Grand-street, whence they were removed on Thursday to St. John's Church.

From the Evening Post of Saturday. Speculation is already rife in regard to the future disposition of the City's funds. That they will be removed from the Shoe and Leather Bank there is no doubt. That was a foregone conclusion when the Tiemann Committee refused to avail themselves of the $10,000, made, as was supposed,

From the St. Joseph (Mo.) Gazelle. During the past week we heard, through a gentleman living near this city, the following interesting account of the capture of eleven runaways. About a fortnight since a gentleman stayed at our informant's house on his return from Iowa, whither he had been in pursuit of the fugitives above alluded to.

A FORMIDABLE PARTY OF THIEVES.--There seems o be a formidable party of thieves In Brooklyn, who have for months past carried on their business very successfully and almost with impunity. It is composed of Irish servant girls, too lazy to work, but smart enough to steal. Recent investigations in the Third Precinct render it quite certain that the organization is large and formidable.

The Postmaster of Boston has received a letter from Mr. HOLDROOK, the Mail Agent Who effected the arrest of TUCKBRMAN at New-Haven, in which he states that he has obtained overwhelming proof of the guilt of TUCKBRMAN, and of his connection with all the robberies between this city and New-York for several month past.

The Santa Fe' Gazette has particulars of the recent expedition of Colonel BONNEVILLE against the Apaches. The number of savages killed was 48. The depot of the expedition was established on the west bank of the Gila River, nearly west from the "Adobe Wall", on the Rio Grande, and about twelve miles northwest from the San Lucien Springs.

The mails from the West come filled with news of wreeks and loss of life on the Lakes. The schooner Lark was struck by a storm in the Straits of Mackinaw. Her musts gave way, and in falling stove in her decks. The water dashed in and she was in danger of sinking. Fortunately the gale drove her ashore stern foremost. Some friendly Indian came to the beach and helped the crew and passengers

THE POOR IN BROOKLYN.--The agent of the Brooklyn Association for Improving the Condition. of the Poor, Is calling loudly for contributions. He says the demand for assistance the present season is much greater than usual, as every one will understand. He save:

A preliminary investigation was held to-day into the affairs of the Middlesex Mills, as connected with the failure of LAWRENCE, STONE Co. GEORGE II. KURK, the recently-appointed Treasurer, made a financial statement, which, by vote of the stockholders, was laid on the table.

WALLACE'S THEATRE.-The new drama called "The Poor of New-York" was not produced last evening. A stupendous announcement presented it. self in the lobby, to the effect that, at the request of the authors, the management had consented to give the work an additional rehearsal,

COTTON generally unchanged, Sales to-day 8,500 bales, SUGAR firm at 41/4C.@51/4c. FLOUR, $5 121/2. Red WHEAT, $1 10. LARD dull at 14c. RIO COPPER--Sales to-day 2,200 bags, at 9c. Other articles generally unchanged.

FIRE IN WEST TWENTY-EIGHTH-STREET.--Shortly after 2 o'clock yesterday morning a fire occurred in the frame dwelling house No. 163 West Twenty-eighth-street, occupied by a colored widow lady named Mrs. Cox, and her family. Mrs. Cox sustained a loss of about $500 on her furniture, which is covered by insurance of $800 in the Goodhue Insurance Company. Mr. WILLIAMS owned the building,

It was reported yesterday that the Mayor elect, Mr. TIEMANN, had indicated his purpose of settling the controversy concerning the Street Commissioner's office by superseding both DEVLIN and CONOVER and appointing a new man. He takes the ground that the duty of filling the vacancy rested with the Mayor, but that he could only exercise it for the remainder of his own term of office.

It is very widely stated in the Kansas journals, as our extracts from them will have shown, that Governor WALKER had promised to convene the Legislature in extra session, provided the members would pledge themselves not to take action upon any other subject than the Lecompton Constitution.

The warehouses of DAVIS STEEL, forwarders; LIVINGSTON Co., forwarders; HOEBRIDGES SONS, stable keopers; JEFFRIES SONS, coach-spring factory, and two dwellings on Market, above Eighth-street, were destroyed by fire this morning, Several other buildings were demaged.

ATTACHED BY "DEAD RABBITS."--At an early hour yesterday morning, as Solomon Mullholland was passing through mulberry-street, in the Sixth Ward, he was saddenly attached by two "Dead rabbits, " and his silver watch, valued at $17, and some change he had in his pockets, stolen from hi,. The fellows first knocked him down, but he was sufficiently conscious to be enabled afterwards to deseribe his assailanis accurately and procure their subsequent srret.

Fifty Senators were present when the body was called to order by the Secretary, who read a letter from the Vice-President, stating that he would not be able to reach Washington at the commencement of the session.

From the National Intelligencer. The attentive reader will observe that the "SOHEDULE" affixed to the Constitution, as now officially published, differs in some material respects from that which appeared in the Government paper of this City on the 18th of last month, and which we published on the following day. We indicate these variations by halicizing the portions which are omitted in the earlier copy of the Union.

M. PETIT, one of the oldest and most considerable of the cloth manufacturers of Louviers, has published in the Journal des Dibals a very interesting recount of the woolen trade and manufactures of France. M. PETIT says that the French cannot compete with England in the price of cloth of the best quality,

A correspondent of the Edgartown Gaxette writing from Stockton, California, says; "Agrical number of whalemen who came to this State daring the early perlod of th egold discovery, still remain here, and manifest a liverly interest in everthing concening whaling.

BELLEVUE HOUSE STOCK YEARDS.--Beef cattle were in better supply last week, with a fair demand for city use. Dutchers pay for good to choice, 5c.@sc.; for ordinary to fair, 2c.@21/2c. gross. Packers are not buying at these figures, and shippers are doing nothing at presetn.

The Board reassembled at 10 o'clock yesterday morning. Alderman HAERISH in the chair. The returns from the Eighth Ward were read: For Mayor--Wood, 1,871: Tiemann, 2,568. For Governors Aimshouse--Dugro, 1,927; Smith, 1,205; Wagner, 1,227. In the Eighth Ward Tucker has 1,153, and Bonsall, 995.

The 6th, 7th and 8th of this month will be memorable in the north of China (and, doubtless, in the south too) as a period when it and the seas adjacent were visited by one of the heaviest and longest-continued gales of wind ever known in this part of the world.

Yesterday was the first day of the first session of the Thirty-fifth Congress, and was, of course, devoted principally to the organization, which was effected without difficulty. The Senate was called to order by the Secretary, in the absence of the Vice-President, when fifty Senators answered to their names.

The English funds opening this morning at the firm prices fo yesterday, and, owing to continued investments of sums which the public are withdrawing from other channels, a further in provement subseqently took place.

The Board of Police Commissioners met yesterdasy at their establishment in Breome-street. All the members were present, Gon. NIE being in the Chair. The Chairman submitted a letter from the General Superintendent, which referred in terms of warm praise to the conducn of the Police force during the recent election, attributing to thier energy and fidelity to duty, the preservation of peace and order in the City.

For some years past the Congress of the United States has been gradually resolving itself into a grand caucus, in which rival aspirants for the Presidency toil night and day to found the Jacob's ladder of their dreams.

THE BETHUNE-STREET DISASTER.--The Coroner's Jury, in the case of the men who were killed by the falling of a malt-house in Bethunestreet, last week, have rendered a very proper verdict, in which they censure MATTHEW WHITE "for having taken the supervision of the construction of said building,

Our municipal election to-day has resulted in the reelection of G. H. DUNHAR, Republican, for Mayor, by 10 plurality over A. H. HOWLAND, the Citizens' cadidate. The whole Board of Aldermen and a majority of the Council were elected on the Citizens' ticket.

CONGRSSION OF THE CINOINNATI BUEGLAR.--One of the firm of S. K. STREVE Co., of Cineinnati, whose jewelry store was robbed about a week ago, arrived in Jersey City yesterday afternoon, and upon seeing the young man who was arrested upon susplcion of having committed the robbery, (who gave his name as CHARLIS E. WARREN,) at once recognized

The Senate Democratic caucus made no nominations except for President pro tem. The Republican Caucus--HALD, Chairman--nominated HAMLIN unanimously, and appointed Messrs. SEWARD, FOOT AND WADE a Committee to call future caucuses when desired.

A MAN SHOT BY THE PROPRIETOR--ARREST OF THE ACCOUSRD--CONFLICTING STATEMENTS--CORONER'S INQUEST. On Sunday night, a little before 12 o'clock, a party of five young men went into the porter-house of MICHAEL BARRY, corner of Avenue B and Thirteenth-street. While there the landlord became incensed at their conduct, and deliberately shot one of the young men, name JOHN S. KELLY, from the effects of which he died a few hours afterwards.

The members of the Ssaint Nocholas Society dined together, according to annual custom, at the Saint Nicholas Hotel last evening, and had a jovial time. At 6 o'clock the members and gues's assembled in one of the drawing-rooms, where the officers for the ensuing year,--Hon. GULIAN C. VERPLANCE, were installed.

The bark Milford, of Westport, Capt. STARES, from New-Castle Oct. 28, with coal. went ashore at 11 o'clock on Sunday night, during the heavy easterly blow, and now lies high and dry on the beach. The place where she struck was opposite the new lighthouse at Pond Quogue Point,

To the Editor of the Flag of the Entor, Jackson, Miss. SIR:--There appeared in the Jackson Mississippian, some time ago, a publication from the Hon. JEFFERSON DAVIS, which seems to require an answer. This would have been forthcoming at a much earlier date had it appeared in any paper likely to come under my observation.

COTTON generally unchanged. Sales to-day 8,500 bales, SUGAR firm at 4 1/4C.@51/4C. FLOUR, $5 121/2. Red WHEAT, $1 10. LARD dull at 14C. RIO COPPER--Sales to-day 2,200 bags, at 9C. Other articles generally unchanged.

AN OLD WHISKY SUCKER GONE.--Patrick Riley, well known to the Police of the First Ward, where he has made it his head-quarters for several years, died yesterday. At an early hour in the morning Officer Haskell, of the First Ward, found him in Pearl-street dead drunk, alongside a whisky barrel.He had a straw in his hands, and everything indicated that he had helped himself freely from the whisky...

By the arrival of the mail we have dates from all points as late as due. The Charleston papers announce that the steamer Welaka, of Savannah, was totally wrecked on St. Nicholas Bar, 3d inst. The crew, passengers and a part of her cargo were saved.

AN OLD MAN FOUND, STRUCK WITH PARALYSIS.--Last evening Officers PHILLIPS and VAN ARSDALS, of the Second Ward, found an old man lying on the pavement corner Nassan and John streets, suffering from a stroke of paralysis. He was taken to the Station-house, and a physician called, but he expired without being able to state his name or any particulars concerning himself.

U.S. District Court,--Nos. 45, 48, 49, 50, 51, 52, 53, 54, 56, 99, SUPREME COURT--Circuit--No Circuit till Wednesday. SUPREME COURT--Special Term--Nos. 2, 3, 54, and all causes not previously called between 60 and 305.

The Board of Aldermen met laste evening, President CLANOY in the Chair. A petition was received from a soldier of the 71st Regiment, stating that, in accordance with orders, he was on duty in the Governor's room, while the remains of General Worth lay there, and that, as direceted, he left his military overcoat there in the charge of a policeman, and that the said overcoat was stolen.

The United States Mail Steamship Baltic, Captain COMSTOCK, from liverpool, at about 2 o'clock on the afternoon of Wednesday, the 16th of November, arrived here yesterday morning.

President BUCHANAN'S first Message will be found in our columns this morning. It is a document of mere interest than importance, for while every one is curious to know the President's views upon the leading topics of public concern, they have nevertheless not the force of law, and carry but little weight except as expressions of personal opinion.

An express passed through this city yesterday for Washington, with dispatches from Colonel JOHNSTON. The Republican received letters this morning froth the army to Nov, 3d. The Mormons had run off six hundred cattle In sight of Colonel ALEXANDER'S camp, near Hams Fork, Green River.
