The organic act, organizing the Territory of Kansas, provided that the people should be left perfectly free to settle their domestic institutions for themselves.

WILLIAMS.--In this City, on Tuesday, Dec. 8, after a short illness. CHRISTOPHER C., youngest son of C.O. and Mary J. Williams. The friends and relatives are invited to attend the funeral, at 1 o'clock, to day, (Wednesday.) from No. 351 4th-av. His remains will be taken to Greenwood for interment.

We Americans are certainly a very odd people. If any unfortunate foreign scribbler ventures to question the perfection of our institutions, of our manners, oreven of our personal appearance, we fly out upon him with a sudden and irresistible fury, pluck him by the beard, make light of his mastaches, and as far as many be, defile the graves of his ancestors.

SIR: In compliance with the act of Congress eutitled "An supplementary to an act to establish the Treasury Department," approved May 10, 1800, I have the honor to submit the following report: the 1st July, 1856, being the commence.

A telegram from Mobile to JOHN D. JONES, Esq., President of the Atlantic Mutual Insurance Company, received yesterday, states that the ship National, from New-Orleans for Havre, was totally lost near Havana. No particulars are given. The National cleared from New-Orleans on the 20th of November-is an A 1 1/2 ship of 1,066 tons-commanded by Captain BOYD

The Message of the President of the United States was received and read. Mr. DOUGLAS submitted a motion for printing the usual number of copies of the Message and documents, and 10,000 copies thereof for the use of the Senate. He remarked that he concurred heartily and cordially in the views of the President therein expressed, with the exception of that portion relative to Kansas and the action of the Lecompton Convention.

Hon. Mr. BELMONT, who has been dispatched to Spain, by some of out cotempories, for the purpose of buying the island of Cuba, and by others commissioned to take charge of the property of the family of ROTHSCHILD, and inaugurate the triumphs of American finance over a prostrate Enrope, seems ot be singularly slow in awarding himself of the greatness thus thrust upon him.

THE MURDER OF JOHN SKELLY--VERDICT OF THE JURY.--The Corner's investigation into the cause of the murder of JOHN SKELLYM on Sunday night, in the porter-house of MICHAEL BARRETT, corner avenue B and Thirteenth-street, was concluded yesterday, at the City Hospital.

THE GUILLOTINE IN MOTION.--We understand from good authority that President BUCHANAN has decided to join Mayor Wood in punishing the "trallors" who voted for that other Democrat, Mr. TIEMANN, at the late election. He will begin with JOHN MCKZON, whose round, rosy, well-filled head will fall into the official basket this morning.

On Sunday afternoon FRANK S. McCLURE went Into the store of BEATTIE ANDERSON, for the purpose of talking over business matters with Mr. BETTIE. About an hour afterwards, McCLURE was seen to fall from the door of the building to the sidewalk, When picked up, It was found that his skull was fractured, He died on Monday night.

The stockholders of the Bay State Mills held a meeting to-day, to investigate the affairs of that corporation in connection with LAWRANCE, STONE Co. Mr. KUHN, the newly appointed treasurer, made a financial statement. Mr. F. B. CROWINGSHIELD asked how much had been embezzlement, and when the embezzlement commenced.

The Democratic General Committee met last night, at Tammany Hall. for the purpose of receiving and acting upon the list of the Committee for 1868, Trouble of a serious character was anticipated, and consequently there was a large outside attendance, and a considerable Police force in the side rooms and in the dining-saloon, besides a number she stood guard at the door of the Committee room.

The Board re-assembled at 10 o'clock this morning, Alderman HARRIS in the chair. The returns from the, Fifteenth Ward were takenup. For Mayor--Wood, 883; Tiemann, 2,929. For Almshouse Commissioner--Dugro, 986; Smith, 1,668; Wagner, 1,100.

The ship Eva Dorothea, GATGEAR, from Bremen, bound to Baltimore, is ashore near Cape Henry, She had on board 260 passengers, who with the crew, were saved. The vessel will probably be a total loss. LOSS OF THE SHIP NATIONAL. MOBILE, Tuesday, Dec. 8.

Report of the Secretary of the Treasury. The importance of this document ahs induced its publication at length on another page of this paper. A brief abstract of the figures of the Report may not be out of place, for reference.

Secretary THOMPSON'S report opens with an exhibit of the operations of the Land Bureau. A historical sketch is given of the methods by which the public domain was originally acquired, and then follows a schedule of the organization of the surveying system.

QUERY.--Would it not be possible for the Board of Police Commissioners to hold one session, without introducing the regular entertainment of a personal snarl between Mayor Wood and General NYE? These valiant champions of two political parties time in their private quarrels than they have any right to monopolize.

SMITH--WOODRUFF--In this City, on Tuesday, Dec, S. by Rev. Mancius, S, Hutton, at the Reformed Dutch Church, Washington square, CHARLES F. SMITH to Miss ANNIE Lr G. WOODRUFF, daughter of Amos Woodruff, Esq., all of this City.

A DEFAULTING BANK CASHIER--CHARGE OF EMBEZZLING $75,000 FROM THE COLCHESTER BANK--HIS ARREST AND ESCAPE,--Samuel F. Jones, Jr., late Cashier of the Colchester Bank, Conn., is charged with having embezzled $75,000 of the funds of the Bank, and appropriated the same to his own use. Some time since he resigned his position as Cashier, and came to this City.

MORE "DEAD RABBITS" IN THE FIELD.--JAMES COSTELLO, an Italian, was attacked at tile corner of Canal and Baxter streets, at 1 o'clock yesterday morning, by three " Dead Rabbits," They knocked him down and robbed him. COSIELLO shouted "Police," which brought Officers KNNEDY and IIYD?? to the spot, who arrested the scamps.

SUPREME COURT--GENERAL TERM. Before Judges Mitchell, Davies and Clerks. The Court-room was crowded yesterday morning long before the time of opening, it being believed that the Judges would overrule the exceptions taken on the two previous occasions by the prisoner's counsel. Cangemi, on being brought into Court, appeared more agitated than usual.

WALLACK'S THEATRE.--THE POOR OF NEW-YORK.--A new local drama in five acts and seven tableaux, called "The Poor of New-York," was produced here last night with overwhelming success. We are compelled by the pressure on our columns to postpone any extended notice of the work. The action, although purely local, is of the intenseat kind, and the situations, scenery and acting excited the audience to unusual demonstrations of approval.

Fellow Citizens of the Senate and House of Representatives: In obedience to the command of the Constitution, it has now become my duty "to give to Congress information of the state of the Union, and recommend to their consideration such measures" as I judge to be "necessary and expedient."

Dr. Livingston, the great African explorer, has left London for the purpose of consulting with the Portuguese government, through whose territories on the eastern coast of Africa he purposes passing to reach the heart of the great African continent to pursue his discoveries there, and to open Central Africa to Europe through the greater river Zambesi, which passes through the Portuguese possession, and empties itself into the Mozambique Channel.

Congress opens with decided indications of coming trouble in the Democratic ranks, growing out of the Kansas question. The President's Message was received and road in the Senate yesterday, and Senator DOUGLAS, in submitting a motion for printing, took occasion to except to the portion relating to Kansas and the action of the Lccompton Convention, which the President approved of the action of the latter. He gave notice that,

Resumed. The Central Bank, Brooklyn, which suspended during the panic, and for which a Receiver was appointed, has recently elected SEYMOUR L. HEUSTED, President of the Brooklyn Railroad Company, President, and has quietly resumed business again. BROOKLYN YOUNG MEN'S CHRISTIAN ASSOCIATION.--The December meeting of this body was held onTuesday evening. A number of new members

MEETING OF DRNTAL SURGRONS.-An adjourned meeting of the Dental Surgeons of New-York and vicinity was held last night at No, 57 Bond-street, The Chairman pro tem, was Dr. COVELL, the See. rotary, Dr. J. G. AMOLLER, The minutes of the last meeting having been read and approved, the report of the Committee on Constitutional By-Laws was was read and adopted.

THE STORM AND FOG. The Summer-like temperature of Monday, which was regarded s so unseasonable., proved a "weather breeder." It was followed on Tuesday night, and throughout the day yesterday, by one of the most disagreeable storms of the season thus far-the wind varying from east to northeast , and accompanied with heavy rain in the forenoon.

BIBLE REVISION.--The Board of Managers of the American Bible Society have for a month past had under consideration the subject of the revision of the Bible, made by direction of the Society in 1851, and the opposition movement started by the Presbyterians, (Old School.)

THE PRICE or HORSES.--A great many people from the country have come to New-York to buy horses recently, induced by the rumors which reached them of the low price of horse-flesh, as well as everything also in the metropolis. Most of them have been disappointed.

OLD MEN'S COMMITTEE. The following ??ons are the members of the Democratic Republican General Committee for 1858. They were first reported on Tuesday evening to the ?? resolution then went out of existence: First Ward--Thomas Byrnes, Patrick Curry, Edward Hogan, John H. Williams, Michael Burns. Second Ward--William Miner, James Leonard, John P. Howe, Alfred Chancellor, James Watson. s Watson.

We have received a copy of the Leavenworth City Times of Nov. 28. There was, on Friday, Nov. 27, a mass meeting in Leavenworth, ?? consult upon the issues of the day. The meeting was officered as follows: President, S. N. LATTA. Vice-Presidents-Black-Hdge of Tecumseh. Smith of Topeka, Atwood of Lawrence, and Sparks of Gardener; Whitney,

WHAT IS IT ALL ABOUT?--The ultra journals of the South are exulting over the prospect of a split on the Democratic party on the Kansas question. They treat the differences that have arisen between prominent members of the party in regard to the Lecompton constitution, as a direct contest between the South and the North,

Sea and Ship News. BARK MILFORD.--A letter received by ELWOOD WALTER, from southampton, 7th, states that the weather was fine, and the bark was lying in a good position, and with speedy assistance could be got off. She has 450 tons of coal on board. The storm of yesterday, it was thought, may have affected the vessel unfavorably.

A party of rowdies in Baltimore, about 3 o'clock on Sunday morning, awakened Mr. William Bodman, wholesale oyster dealer on Fort-avenue, near Fort Mellenry, and ordered him to open his house and give them something to cat, as they had been on a ducking expedition, and adding that they would give him some ducks.

At the annual meeting of the Horticultural Society, on Monday evening, the report of the Finance Committee was read and accepted. The receipts of the Exhibition and Festival this year accounted to $780 81, and the expenditures were $782 99--exceeding the receipts by $2 18. Besides this, $335 was the cost of the premiums given out. The following are the officers for the ensuing year:

THE SEWER QUESTION SETTLED,-The question as to whether it is the duty of the Water Commissioners or the Mayor and common council of Jersey City to issue scrip in payment for the construction of severs, which has been for some time under discussion by the two Boards, and upon which conflicting legal opinions have been given,

The loard of Aldermen met last evening, President CLANCY in the Chair. The report reorganizing the Finance Department, in accordance with the rcquirements of the new Charter, was again brought up and read, and its consideration again postponed. It is to come up on Monday next. The resolution concurring with the Councilmen to increase the salary of the Chief Engineer of the Fire Department to $5,000 a year, was taken up.

Persons who aro surprised at the enormous amounts of money expended under pretence of providing for the City Government, have read with care, we trust, the report of the discussions in the Board of Aldermen reported in tile TIMES of Tuesday morning. A proposition was made to stop the expenditure of money upon the Central Park.

The Globe of Nov. 7 devotes thirty columns to the publication of a statement prepared by Dr. R. MAYO, and intended to convict Hon. WM. CULLOM, lately Clerk of the House of Representatives, of having drawn large sums of money from the Treasury ostensibly for books to be furnished to members of Congress, but which he did not expend in the purchase of such books.

A RARE CHANCE LOST, --What abominable person was it who said that every young lady in American was bent like Miss WETHRELL'S heroines on marrying and if necessary, converting a young English nobleman? We would not, if we could remember the name of the wretch, but he must ?? his hands is ecstasy over the will of the late Earl FITZWILLIAM.

STRUCKMAN.--In this City, on Tuesday. Dec. 8, C. J. HENRY STRUCKMAN, nephew of Wm. Struckman, aged 21 years and 11 months. The funeral will take place from St. Nicholas Hotel, on 116th-st., Bloomingdale Road, this day, Dec. 10. Relatives and friends are requested to attend without further notice. LUXFORD.--In this City, on Wednesday morning, Dec. 9. EDWARD LUXFORD, in the 63d year of his age.

The last meeting of the Republican Central Committee, for 1857, was held last evening at the Stuyvesant Institute, Broadway, JOHN A. KENNEDY presiding. Mr. KELLY, from the Finance Committee, reported that all demands against the Central organization had been promptly paid in full, and that there was yet a handsome balance remaining.

DEFAICATION IN THE BAY STATE MILLS, AND POLITICAL BRIBERY.--The Boston Courter of Wednesday says: We observe that the President of the Bay State Mills, at the meeting of the stock ?? yesterday, stated a deficit to exist of $120,000, which "could not be traced." It is presumed he meant by the books of the concern. We hope no pains will be spared to trace it into whatever shape it may have assumed.

GOVERNOR WISE ON OYSTERS.-Governor WISE has sent another Message to the Legislature of Virginia on the subject of oysters; in fact the Governor appears to be in a constant oyster stew; and when we consider the marvelous productiveness of the sea-coast of the Old Dominion, In the luxurious article of bivalves, his anxiety to make the oyster beds of his native State yield a revenue to the Gov ernment is not surprising.

DANGEROUS POSITION OF MARGRAW'S EXPEDITION,--Some anxiety is felt, by those most familiar will the matter, concerning, MARGRAW'S expedition. it will be remembered that MARGRAW started from this place last Summer, to establish a wagon route to the Pacific under an act of Congress, We have already stated some of the difficulties which the expedition were forced to encounter,

Extract from the Annual Report of Hon. John B. Floyd. Secretary of War. ?? AND THE EXPEDITION THITHER. This subject has very recently assumed so extraordinary and important an attitude, that I deep it proper to dwell upon it somewhat more at length than, under other circumstances, would have been required.

A letter to tile ?? irom the Utah Expedition, the main points of which were telegraphed this morning, states that Colonel COOK'S command was 150 miles west of Fort Laramie Nov. 3. Thus far the traveling had been pleasant and easy, but now the weather was growing colder, provisions getting scarce, provender giving out, and it is apparent that great hardships are before us still.

CAPTURE OF SISAL BY THE REVOLUTIONISTS-HEAVY CANNONADING AT CAMPEACHY. From the Nex-Orleans Pioayune, Dec. 3. The Mexican tchooner Eduardo, Capt. LAFERLA, at New-Orleans from Tabasco, vid Vera Cruz, reports having been spoken on the 18th ult., latitude 25 north, by the Campeachy armed schooner Corinna, with three weeks' later intelligence from the

THE ANTI-SLAVERY FAIR--This Fair, the object of which is partly to aid fugitive slaves passing through New-York, and partly to aid in the support of the Anti-Slavery cause, was opened last Monday evening at Clinton Hall, Mercantile Library Building, Astor place. It was to have closed yesterday, put on account of the unpleasant weather it will continue open to-day.

On Jersey Prairie, in Illinois, a few days ago, there was a lively family set-to. A young man named shelby had paid attentions to a daughter of Judge Carier, and behaved himself in ?? way. A brother of the young lady, conceiving that the offence demanded punishment, went to Shelby's house, and assailed him with the butt of a horsewhip as he sat at dinner.

Yesterday's debate in the Senate was of marked interest and importance. Mr. DOUGLAS made a bold, manly, and high-toned opposition to the admission of Kansas under any Constitution which should not have previously received the sanction of its inhabitants.

The Board of County Canvassers reassembled at 10 o'clock yesterday morning, Alderman HARRIS In the Chair. On motion of Alderman FULLMER, the returns of the Fourth District of the Sixteenth Ward for Supervis. ors, the returns of the Seventh District for Civil Justico, and the returns of the Ninth District for Counclncen, were taken up and corrected.

To the Editor of the New- York Times: There can be no foundation for the rumor alluded to In the TIMES of to-day, that Mayor TIEMANN proposed, to avoid shouldering the responsibility of deciding between Mr. DEVLIN and Mr. CONOVES In reference to their respective claims to the office of Street Commissioner, by appointing a third man instead of either of them. The reason is obvious. Mayor Tiemann has no such power.

The Springfield Republican says that one of the Pleasant incidents of the hard times is the reception of a letter from an English firm by an manufacturer at Worcester, telling him that they have perfect faith in Ms Integrity, and do not wish him "to make such a pay us." They leave the time of setting to their debtor, although they acknowledge that they need the money.

The steamers Ocean Wave and Long Branch came in collision this afternoon at Sandy Hook. The Ocean Wave was bound to New-York and the long Branch to Ocean Port and Shrewsbury. The Ocean Wave put her freight on one side and saved the boat from going down. The Long Branch was the worst damaged and it was with great difficulty that she proceeded on her voyage.

The disaffected "citizens" have got a candidate in the person of FREDERICK W. LINCOLN, Jr. Mr. LINCOLN is a Whig, one of the bits of flesh that cling to the skeleton of that famous mastodon that figured in the pre-Adamite political ages under the name of the Whig Party. He is an excellent man, and would make a good Mayor.

THE MURDERER JONER AT SPRINGFIELD, MASS.-- The Springfield Republican says: JONES, the m ?? has scarcely changed his habits since the ?? which resulted in a sentence of death. He took a little food during the last day or two of the trial and ?? continued his abslemlousness until Monday evening when he asked for and me a large allow ?? of bread and milk.

A movement is in progress to procure a mitigation of the sentence of RODGERS, the murderer of SWANSTON. Ex-Judge STUART has drawn a petition to the Governor, in his behalf, urging that the boy was drunken and irresponsible when he committed the crime. It has already obtained several signatures. President King, of Columbia College

The Democrat this evening received letters from Kansas, containing two proclamations by Provisional Governor CALHOUN, specifying the manner in which the election of tile 21st inst,, for submitting the Constilution, and of the 1st Monday in January, for the election of State officers, will be held, and also giving the names of the County Commissioners for each County.

GRAND LODGE A. P. A. OF NEW-YORK.-The following named gentlemen were installed as the Grand Officers of this Lodge on Tuesday evening: W. G. Master-Nathan Nesbit, Mount Vernon Lodge No. 14. W .D .G. M.-James Heron, New-York Lodge No. 8. W. G. Secretary-Thomas M??, Malden City No. 32.

The report of the proceedings in Congress yesterday will be found highly interesting and important. In the Senate Mr. DOUGLAS delivered his promised speech in opposition to the indorsement of the Kansas Constitutional Convention, which was followed by a long debate between that gentlemen and Mr.RIGLER, which will repay perusal. The only business done in the House was the election of Printer-STEADMAN, of Ohio, being the individual selected.

Governor WISE, of Virginia, has transmitted three messages to the Legislature of that State: One on the present commercial crisis; the second against the repeal of the usury laws; and the third on miscellaneous subjects. The messages occupy the entire space of our Richmond exchanges of Tuesday. The Governor does not leave unnoticed any of leading topics of the day, in so far so they boar upon affairs in Virginia.

To the Editorof the New-York Times: It is a criminal aspersion to assert that the rich of this City, as a class, either oppress or neglect the poor. A glance over the statistics of New-York will show not only that the hand of poverty is in every one's pocket, but that, in tact, the wrong is the other way-the poor oppress the rich.

A new local drama in five acts (written by the "* * * * Club") with this oiling title, was produced at Wallack's Theatre on Tuesday night, and repeated last evening with complete success--the house on both occasions being crowded in its utmost capacity. It is a remarkable drama in many respects, and for powerful local interest has never bean surpassed in this city.

The galleries were densely crowded at tile hour of meeting. Mr. PUGH gave notice of his Intention to Introduce t bill for the Improvement of the navigation of the Ohio River, Mr. MASON offered a resolution, which was debated and passed, inviting the clergymen of the District of Columbia to officiate gratuitously as chaplains to the Senate.

The president to-day sent to the Senate the nomination of Gen. DENVER, now Commissioner of Indian Affairs, to be the Secretary of Kansas Territory--thus removing Mr. STANTON. The reason given therefor, is the fact that STANTON has convened the Territorial Legislature on the 7th of December, in consequence of the failure of the Constitutional Convention to submit the entire Constitution entirely to the people.

THE COURT-MARTIAL OF COL., SUMNER.--I will be recollected, that Col. E. V. SUMNER, of the First Cavalry, has recently been on trial at a general Court-martial, held at Fort Leavenworth. Although the rendition of the Court has not yet born officially promulgated, yet we learn from a ?? source, that he had been suspended from ?? and pay for the period of four months, and to be reprimanded by the General-in-Chief.

SUICIDE BY TAKING ARSENIO.--Coroner GAM. new hold an inquest yesterday on the body of Jane Murray, 24 years of age, who committed suicide at an early hour yesterday morning, at the Tenth Ward Station-house, by taking arsenle. The woman called at the Station-house for lodging, and shortly after she was shown to her room It was ascertalneil that she had taken arsenic.

FIRF. IN WATER-STREET,-Last evening, about 91/3 o'clock a fire was discovered in the wholesale drug warehouse of MORTON CO., No. 48 Waterstreet, near Old-slip. The alarm was immediately given, but the firemen, in consequence of a very heavy fog existing, found it somewhat difficult to find out the exact quarter of the fire, which in the meantime continued to burn with increased rapidity.

Two desperate characters named LUKE. WISELY and PHIL. MoGUIRE, entered the store of ADAM HEIDEMAN last night about 7 o'clock, and called for crackers and cheese. Mr. Mr. told them he would give them none until they had paid up an "old score" which they owed him. Immediately they threw scales, bottles, and everything within their reach at the grocer and his wife, wounding both severely.

Dr. CHARLES MACKAY delivered the second of Lie course of lectures on '" The National Songs of England, Ireland and Scotland" at Mozart Hall, Broadway, on Monday evening. The audience was much larger than on the former occasion, the room being early filed.

Mr. SEWARD Submitted a resolution, which lies over, directing the Joint Committee on Printing to inquire and report whether any new provisions of law are necessary to secure the faithful peiformance on, the part of Congress of the existing contracts which provide for accurate reports of the debates of the two Houses.

The following is a copy of a letter from Gen. LAFAYETTE to Gen. WASHINGTON, the original of which is in Washington. The superscription is in these words: "His Excellency General WASHINGTON, Mount Vernon, Virginia :" and its date is furnished by the following endorsement on its back in WASHINTON'S handwriting: " From the Marquis De la FAUETTE, August, 1784."

I.--PRESIDENT BUCHANAN'S FIRST MESSAGE--Entire. II.--ABSTRACTS OF REPORTS FROM DEPARTMENTS--War. Navy, Post-Office, , III.--STRIKE OF THE ERIE RAILROAD. IV.--EDITORIALS--The Message--England and Europe--The Treasury Report--Our ?? Produce--Causes of the Late Panic--Tuckerman the Rail-robber.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I see among the recommendations of the distinguished Secretary of War, one "That promotions to grades above the rank of Captain in the Army, should be by selection according to merit."

MORMONS IN PENNSYLVANIA.---The "Harrisburg Herald has been informed by a gentleman in Derry Township, that during the past year, two families in that section have left, with the object of joining the Mormons in Utah. Several other families near the line of Lebanon are preparing to pursue the same course.

Gen. HAMILTON, whose death by the steamboat disaster near New-Orleans we have already noticed, was about to be elected to the Senate of the United States. In another column will be found a letter written at NewOrleans, in which he proclaimed the objects which he should endeavor to accomplish, if lie should become a member of either House of Congrss.

General DENVER was to-day confirmed as Secretary of Kansas by a large majority. Senator DOUGLAS was absent during the vote. The impression prevails in some circles familiar with Kansas affair,, that the Legislature, when COM vened, instead of repealing the law authorizing the Constitutional Convention, will pass one for the submission of the. whole Constitution to the popular vote, and thus show how little it expresses the will of the people.

THE DECISIONS OF THE NAVAL COURTS OF INQUIRY.--The intimation in the Report of the Secretary of the Navy that the President had approved of all the findings by the Naval Courts of Inquiry which had been submitted to him, must create a feverish anxiety among the officers who have been examined,

To the Tremont-street Baptist Church : DEAR BHATHER : I herewith announce to you my resignation of the pastorate of the Tremont-street Baptist church. I give you an early notice, so that you will have ample time and a good opportunity to secure the services of my successor.

THE ENGLISH OPIUM EATER.-- Late letters from one to the members of DE QUINCEY'S family. speak of the great writer as being in prefect health and seemingly a much younger man than be appeared forty years ago. He is at present residing in Edinburg, on a visit. He has two sons in the army,

DEATH FROM AN ATTEMPT TO PROCURE AN ABORTION -- A CORONER FRIGHTENED BY IRISHMEN,--A very girl, affair occurred at Palmer, Mass., last week, (says the Springfield Republican,) in which a young Irish girl, named ANN BREEN. was the victim of a seducer, who not only deserted her, but gave her means to procure the drugs from whose action she died.

THE SHOOTING CASE ON STATEN ISLAND.--When the shot was fired which accidentally killed the buy who was shot on Staten Island, on Thanks, giving day, the larger stood in the garden on Mr. THECMAN CHILDS. Jr., Who was himself shooting at it with the boys. Only a board fence intervened between the larger and a public thoroughfere, and the shots pendangered several persons in the neighborhood.

On the 26t ult, the Virgina and North Carolina tobacco manufactures met in convention at Richmond, and adopted resolutions that agents for the sale of manufactured tobacco shall, after the first of July next, limit their credits to four months; shall make no allowance from the actual weights of tobacco; shall state the names of purchaser, and agents shall not deal in manufactured tobacco in their own account, or have any intervention with brokers.

ELIA, in one of his essays, expresses an earnest curiosity to know, authentically and historically, who was the greatest fool that ever lived. Of the present generation he intimates his confidence that he could designate " the party :-he was puzzled only when he attempted to carry his scrutiny into the past.

CONCERT FOR THE POOR OF HOROKEN.-A vocal and Instrumental concert, for the benefit of the poor of Hoboken, is to be given at Odd Fellows' Hall this evening, under the direction of Mr. H. C. TIMM. Madame OTTO, Mrs. BRUSH, Miss LINA BEIER, Messrs. HAGEN, URCHS, WALTER and the Harmonia Singing Society have volunteered for the occasion.

A NAVAL OFFICER VICTIMIZED AT A GAMBLING HOUSE--NATURAL DELICACUY.--A feature of New-York is its " gambling hells." One cannot go up Broadway without passing by a dozen. Only the initiated, however, know their location and the "open sesame" to their interior. Once within the portals there is the fullest freedom-freedom to gaze on the

We understand that a movement has been made in favor of RODGERS, the murderer of SWANSTON, and that Governor KING will be petitioned to commute his sentence. It is not our wish or intention to throw any obstacle in the way of these philanthropic efforts;-

A DANIEL COME TO JUDGMENT.--Mr. Justice FINN, who now occupies a seat on the Bench of the Superior Court, has published a correspondence between Judge DUER and himself, relative to his claim to wear the ermine, and his own letter, is, we presume, intended to make the public acquainted with his side of the case.

From the Washington Union. THE DRED SCOTT DECISION REPUDIATED. "Will the Times answer us? 'Does the Constitution carry Slavery anywhere?" That is more patent to the case than the 'words of any decision.'"--Journal. "No Slavery exists in several of the States under the Constitution. Other States and Territories may, under the Constitution, establish Slavery, but Slavery exists nowhere, nor is it carried anywhere, by virtue or operation of the Constitution."

The steamship Europa. now fully due at this port, with later news from Europe, had not been signaled at Sandy Hook up to 2 o'clock this Inorn ing. The report of proceedings in Congress yesterday is brief, though not devoid of interest.

The Mobile Register joins the Richmond Smith in declaring that "the Democracy of the South will never submit" to the rejection of Kansas by Congress, because her Constitution has not been offered to the popular vote. It says:

THE PHILADELPHIA BOARD OF HEALTH SWINDLER.--An exculpatory card from ROBERT LINDSAY, one of the Philadelphia Board of Health, appears in the papers, to defend that gentleman's reputation from the charges of dishonesty lately preferred against the members of the Board generally.

The Democrat has received letters from Kansas, to-night, containing the proceedings of the Delegates to the Convention held at Lawrence on the 2d inst. The entire Territory was represented. CHAS. ROBINSON was the President. Resolutions were unanimously adopted repudiating the Lecompton Constitution; pledging ceaseless hostility to it;

From the Lancaster (Penn.) Express of Tuesday. One of the most heartless and shocking cases of brutality we were ever called upon to record, came to light this morning. A woman, a fiend, named REBECCA JANE TOMLINSON, residing in East King-street, above Church, at the house known as the Indian Queen Tavern, was brought before Alderman LEONARD, to answer the charge of cruel and barbarous treatment to her step-child, JANE TOMLINSON, aged ten years.

The discussion in the Senate, to-day, was important and significant, though brief. When Senators DOUGLAS and STUART hurst the bonds of party, and proclaimed their entire dissent from the views expressed by the President on the Kansas question, it was easy to read the meaning of the frowns which at once spread over the faces of their Southern colleagues.

From the Washington Union of Thursday. The Secretary of War, members of the British, French, and Austrian Legations, officers of the Army and Navy, with many distinguished civilians, were present yesterday, by appointment, at the Washington Arsenal, to witness experimental tests of inventionsof great importance.

To the Editor of the New- York Times: My attention has just been called to an editorial in the columns of your paper of yesterday, (Tues. day,) in which you comment in no very mild terms on the verdict of the Coroner's Jury, and the cause of the falling of a portion of the floors in my malthouse, corner of West and Bethune streets, on the evening of the 2d inst.

GENERAL WALKER'S EXPEDITION.-On the night of the 11th of November, Gen WALKER was arrested in New-Orleans, upon the affidavit of a Custom. House officer charging him with being about to depart upon an unlawful expedition against a friendly power. The next day, the 12th, Mr. SOULE appeared

From the Pittsburg Gazette. A free colored man from this city, named CHAS. WEDLEY, was imprisoned in New-Orleans lately, in default of payment of a fine for some misdemeanor committed in that city, and, by the operation of one of the laws in that State regulating "the peculiar institution." was about to be sold into Slavery.

The fate which seems to impend over the expedition to Utah wears. in some sort, the aspect of retributive justice. It was delayed so long in Kansas, meddling in matters in which it had no business to meddle, that the Winter has caught it, while the advanced guard is still on this side the mountains.

AMERICAN MISSIONARY LOSSES IN INDIA.--The Calcutta correspondent of the Nonconformist, a journal published in London, gives the particulars of the losses incurred by various Christian missions is Upper-India. From his statement it appears that the Americans have been compelled to bear their proportion of suffering. Fear of our clergymen were massacred.

An attempt at murder and suicide occurred at Mllan, Mich, on the 29th alt. C.L. Southwick, from Meanville, Penn., had been engaged to a young lady, Laura A. Evans, of the former place. A few days since became to Mllan, to endeavor to induce the young lady to marry him, which she refused to do. He left for home but only went as far as Dexter, when he returned again to Milan.

MURDER IN WHEELING, VA.--The vicinity o wheeling appears now to be the resort of some desperate characters. It is but a short time since we recorded the circumstances of the murder of a girl near Sunfish, as we found it in the Wheeling papers. Another bloody deed was perpetrated in the same neighborhood on Tuesday evening last.

SHOCKING MURDER IN BALTIMORE.--About 8 o'clock on Tuesday night, a young colored man LEVEN LAKE LEE was shot and killed at the public house of ALEXANDER FARRELL, on Little Hughes, between Light and Charles streets. LEE, who boarded at No. 8 Barnum's-court, close by, had gone into the house at the hour named, as was his custom, for the purpose of getting his supper.

From the Cincinnati Enquirer. Our correspondent in the Utah expedition furnishes us with late advices from the Army. In a private note in us he expresses the opinion that Colonel JOHNSON will attack Salt Lake City this Fall. His letter is dated Fort Reany. Nov. 11: "I little supposed, when I wrote you a few days since, that we were on the eve of good news from the East.

NOT NEAR SO BAD AS WE SEEM.-The times cannot be quite so bad as they have been represented, and the sufferings of the rich, at least. must have been somewhat exaggerated. In all the statements which have been published respecting the sale of Mr. GIHON'S splendid furniture.

YOUNG MEN,S REPEBLICAN COMMITTEE-LAST MEETING,--The Young Men's Republican General Committee, which was organized a year ago, is not to be continued the coming year, the Central Committee not having made any provisions for its longer existence.

SUDDN DEATH AT THE PEOPLE'S BATIIING ESTABLIIMEN-T.-An unknown man who has been in the habit for some time of taking vapor baths at the People's Bathing establishment, No. 141 Mott-street, yesterday afternoon took ill while bathing and soon died.

CORLEEY--HALSEY.--In this City, on Thursday, Dec. 10, by Rev. A. A. Wood, at the Central Presbyterian Church, Mr. CHARLES G. CORLEY to Miss MARY E., daughter of the late Wm. A. Halsey. DONOHUE--BRADY.--In this City, on Thursday, Dec. 10, at St. Patrick's Cathedral, by most Rev. Archbishop Hughes, CHARLES DONOHUE and LUCY H. BRADY, daughter of Andrew Brady. Esq., all of this City.

The Board reassembled at 10 o'clock yesterday morning. Alderman HARRIS in the chair. The returns from the Eighteenth Ward were taken up. Vote for Mayor--WooD. 2,556; TIEMANN, 3,312. For Almshouse Commissioner-DUORO, 2,659; SMITH, 2,051; WAGNER, 99.

No. 7--Levi Morrell vs. John G. Myers.-In error from the Circuit Court of the United States for the District of Maine.-The writ of error was dismissed at the cost of plaintiff. No. 5-Before reported.-Argument continued for the appellees and concluded for the appellant.

GEOSSEOK.--In this City, suddenly, on Wednesday morning, Dec. 9, DAVID W. GROESSEEOK of Albany, eldest brother of the late William W. Groesbeeck. of this City, in the 86th year of his age. Funeral services will be held in the North Dutch Church, in the city of Albany, on Friday. Dec. 11, at noon. Friend of the family are respectfully invited to attend.

We Published Yesterday a telegraphic abstract of Senator DOUGLAS' speech, delivered on Wednesday, in denunciator, of the action of the Kansas Constitutional Convention, and also of the debate which followed between Senators BIGLER and DOUGLAS. Their importence warrants us in giving them this morning in full.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The above is the heading of an article from the Sandusky (Ohio) Mirror, which has been extensively copied in the public journals throughout the country, the purport of which is that the Norwalk Savings Company, of Norwalk, Ohio, of which Mr. COURTAND LATIMER was Treasurer, had failed and assigned, and that therefore the institution was a swindling shop, in whose operations Mr. LATIMER was chief expert.

I could quote many instances of unreasonable requests made of our naval commanders on this station, but the following will be sufficient to show what sort of occurrences go to the NewYork Press, as "outrages" which our Navy fails to redress.

Our Common Council this evening ordered the District-Attorney to commence criminal proceedings against the members of the Board of Health for forgeries, and for obtaining moneys fraudulently from the City Treasury. The City Solicitor was also directed to commence a civil suit against Messrs. KANE and SCHAFFER, the contractors for filling Prime-street lot, for an alleged overcharge.

CHANGES OF A SEASON.-Last year the Democratic organs were very busy in magnifying the importance of giving the people of Kansas the absolute right to manage their own affairs. This year they are equally busy in proving that it is a matter of very little consequence whether they are allowed to do so or not.

The Savannah Gecrgian says of the fugitive who lately claimed the attention of the City Court of Brooklyn: " JIM, while in Savannah, put up as a free-and-easy gentleman at a first-class hotel, swore at the " lazy niggers" that would not wait on him, spent his money like a lord and dressed in the last mode de Paris, and always chose the highest folks to converse with.

The steamship Tennessee has arrived at this port from Vera Cruz 7th instant, bringing advices from the City of Mexico to the 4th instant. The position of the Government was decidedly better than at the date of the last advices. The reactionary forces having been vanquished by the Government troops at Puebla and other points.

ALABAMA.--The Inaugural Address of Governor MOORE, of Alabama, promises the exercise of due vigilance over the best interests of the State, and arrives at the conclusion that "the recent Black Republican developments among the Professors in most of the Northern Colleges have convinced Southern parents of the impropriety of patronizing those Institutions."

The lecture room at Clinton Hall was crowded last night, on the occasion of a lecture by Hon. HORACE GREELEY, for the benefit of the Young Men's Philomathean Society. The subject was "Poetry and Poets." Mr. GREELEY commenced by announcing that his lecture would be rambling and desultory.

The Banks in this City, which, since the first of the present month, have been practically paying specie on their obligations, have new resolved unanimously to resume such payments in full, from and after this day.

A NEEDFUL CAUTION.--Persons in quest of employment well do well to keep a sharp lookout for the swindling schemes that will be commended to their notice. The advertising columns of the City papers team with seductive offers of all kinds.

In the case of DONNELLY, for the murder of MOSES at the Sea View House, Highlands, the Court of Appeals this afternoon affirmed the judgment of the Supreme Court. The vote stood, for affirmance, 6; reversal, 3. Chancellor WILLIAMSON read an opinion favoring a reversal, and Judge OGDEN read another for the affirmance.

The topsail schooner Sarah C. Shields, from Philadelphia, bound to Boston, with a cargo of 250 tons of coal, ran ashore on Wednesday morning about 3 o'clock, during the prevalence of a dense for, which prevented the Captain from seeing his position. The vessel fortunately struck within a quarter of a mile westward of the Life-boat Station No. 20, on Southampton Beach.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Permit me to state the circumstances of a case, with which I am personally familiar, which seems to me to show the injustice sustained by very many of those whose fathers lost their lives in securing the independence of their country.

The Associated Banks of the City of New-York unanimously resolved last night to resume payments in specie on all their obligations this day. The determination was not generally known in advance, but the price of Gold being only one-quarter to one-half of one per cent, premium, the full restoration of the Specie standard will make little alteration in the exchange.

Captains Perry and Stribbling 100 ; Unknown, Captain Mosely. supposed 50 ; Captain Mcllhenny, 75 ; Captain Moore. 30 ; Captain Keys, 30.

VERM'S opera of the "Traviata" was given here last night for the purpose we imagine, of bringing VERM into disrepute. It was weakly cast and weakly played even for the caste. MILE. RACHEL'S HEALTH.--The Memorial Bardcious publishes the following letter from Mlle. SARAH FELIX to her brother, RAPHAEL FELLS, dated Cannes, Oct. 29: MY DEAR BROTHER: RACHEL is much better. Providence led me to listen to the counsels of a strange lady. who wrote to me that her daughter had been saved by Dr. BERGONNIER, after being given up by five other physicians.

KINGSLAND.--At Union, Bergen Co., N. J., on Thursday, Dec 10, suddenly, of congestion of the brain, ANDREW T. KINGSLAND, in the 39th year of his age. The funeral will take place from his father's residence, on Sunday, Dec. 13, at 2 o'clock P. M. The friends and relatives are respectfully invited to attend, without further invitation.

WHITENING JUSTICE.--Workmen were engaged on the cupola of the City Hall, yesterday, in restoring the figure of Justice to its primal condition. It was found to have suffered very much during the past few years. A large quantity of verdigris had accumulated upon the scales, and materially affected the general appearance of the figure.

TICKET SWINDLING.--CHARLES W. Upon discovering the fraud, he made complaint at the office of the Detective Police.

THE SLAYER THAT WAS SEIZED AND LET GO.--Advices from the west coast of Africa to the 10th of October mention with much minuteness the seizure by the United States frigate Cumberland, on the 3d of October, of the schooner Cortes, of New-York, as a suspected slaver. The Cortes was lying at anchor off the river Camma, with her cargo broken up, and in sight of a slave barracoon.

It was in the East, and in the East alone, that he saw such visions as had stirred the souls of an Aloxander and a C??sar.

THE UNEMPLOYED.-The English journals are commenting with great fervor upon the domonstrations of the Unemployed in New-York. The Park meetings and the Tompkins-square speeches afford the basis for a great variety of salutary warnings about the weakness of democratic States and the fearful dangers of Socialism and Communism.

Our municipal election to.d y developed quite a spirited contest for Mayor, the opposing candidates being each nominated by a Citizens' Convention, and ratified by mass meetings in Faneul Hall. Mr. FRDERIC W. LINCOLN, Jr., was the successful candidate, receiving 8,000?? votes, against 4,188 cast for CHARLES B. HALL, the nominee of the first Convention.

The United States mail steamship Star of the West, A. G. GRAY, Esq., commanding, left Aspinwall Dec. 4, at 7 P. M., and arrived at Havana at 7 A. M. on the 9th. Left Havana at 12 M. same day, and arrived at Quarantine at 4 1/2 o'clock yesterday morning.

By the arrival at this port of the Star of the West, from Aspinwall, we obtain full particulars of WALKER'S successful landing at Panta Arenas. According to the report by the Purser of the Star of the West, WALKER landed at San Juan del Norte in broad daylight, and directly under the guns of the United States sloop-of-war Saratoga.

RESUMPTION OF SPECIE PAYMENTS BY OUR BANKS.--Yesterday ought to have been a most important day in New-York, and some unusual demonstrations might have naturally been anticipated, from the fact of its being the day on which all our Banks had resolved to resume specie payments on all their liabilities.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--BELLINI'S Opera of "I Puritanl" will be given to-night, for the benefit of the Hobrow Benevolent Association. The principal artists of the Academy are in the cast. BURTON'S THEATRE.--Mr. CHARLES MATHEWS commenced as engagement at this house last night, and attracted an audience which tailed off on the side-walk.

We have received by the Star of the West our full files of the Deseret News to the 7th of October. The news from Utah is important, as indicative of the temper of the Mormons and the threatening attitude now definitely assumed by BRIGHAM YOUNG.

FLOUR, $4 50@$4 75 for common to extra State. WHEAT is without material change. Sales today 14,500 bushels Chicago Spring, at 81c. CORN nominal. Lake imports to-day--1.200 bbls, of Flour; 1,400 bushels Wheat. Shipped by Railroad to Albany--5,000 bbls, Flour. FREIGHTS--Flour to Albany and Troy 45c. The weather to-day is clear and pleasant as Summer.

The Senate Democratic caucus to-day postponed the nomination of Printer until Wednesday. The Administration men are much alarmed. Their candidate, HARRIS, of the Union, would have been beaten by two votes today. It is understood that a high official under President BUOHANAN is a prospective partner of HARRIS--hence the President's interest for the latter.

The Board of Governors of the Almshouse met on Tuesday. The President, C. GODFREY GUNTHER, Esq., in the chair. The sum of $200 was appropriated for the purpose of giving the children of Randall's Island a good dinner on Christmas-Day and New-Years-Day. The sum of $75 was similarly appropriated for the benefit of the inmates at the Lunatic Asylum.

Troubles never come singly. The administration was badly boaten in the House contest over the Printer, and a Douglas combination slipped in and carried off this the most valuable spoil in the gift of the party. Now again there is danger in the Senate--the Executive citadel.

The Vanderbilt steamship North Star, of the Bremen and Southampton line, left the latter port on the 2d inst., and is now due here, with four days later news from Europe. She had not been heard from up to the time of going to press. The R. M. steamship Canada, from Liverpool on the 5th is also now about due at Halifax.

FIRE IN WATT-STREET-TEN HORSES SMOTHERED.--Shortly after 7 o'clock Monday evening a fire broke out in a frame stable, rear of No. 65 Watt-street, occupied by cartmen and others. The building was entirely destroyed, and ten horses were smothered to death. The horses belonged principally to poor cartmen, and the loss falls heavily on them, as none of the animals were insured.

GIFFIN--BALDWIN,--In this City, on Tuesday, Dec. 15, at St. James' Church, 15th st., by Rev. J. L. Sehock, C. H. GIFFIN, Jr., to Miss LOUISA J., daughter of James O. Baldwin, Esq., all of this City. ODDIE-SWEETSER.--In Brooklyn, on Tuesday, Dec. 15, by Rev. Rufus W, Clark, ORVILLE ODDIE to VICTORIA, daughter of Samuel Sweetser, Esq.

The Annual Message of President MONROE, for the year 1828, embodied two propositions, since known as the "Monroe Doctrine." The first was, that The American continents, by the free and independent condition which they have assumed and maintained, are hence forth not to be considered as subjects for future colonization by any European power."

We have already given full accounts of the kidnapping of two Negroes at Geneva, N. Y., the escape of one of them at Carlisle station, and the subsequent sale of the other, named JOHN F. HITE, in Kentucky.

From the Fifth Annual Report of the North western Dispensary, No. 511 Eight-avenue, we learn that the number of patients treated at the Dispensary and at their homes during the past year, was 12,957, of whom 5,289 were males and 7,668 females. Of these, 5,421 were born in the United States, 6,712 in Ireland, 251 in England, 371 in Germany, and 231 in Scotland and other countries.

The Union of this morning contains the official announcement of the appointment of Hon. J. W. DENVER, of California, to be Secretary of the Territory of Kansas, vice STANTON, removed. The appointment is discussed with great interest by those who understand the peculiar facts under which it was made, and which your correspondent has had an opportunity of ascertaining.

The weather here is pleasant, there being no snow and but light frosts--a thing unusual for this climate so late in the season. Owing to the absence of snow in the Canal, the water is not chilled, and does not freeze readily, and if it did, our efficient Superintendent and his Clerk would open it as usual--with promptness.

Everybody takes an interest in Jack Bunsby, for Jack Bunsby took an unobtrusive interest in everybody, and was the most unobjectionable adviser that ever lived. The views and opinions of Bunsby never could, by any possibility, run counter to any man's feelings, or thwart any man's purposes.

BOSTON JUBILANT.--There appears to have been a most exciting and joyous time in Boston yesterday, over the election of Mr. LINCOLN, the people's candidate" for Mayor. Both parties, however, nominated "people's candidates," and all party ties and distinctions were particularly odious.

A CURIOUS CASE.--In July last an officer of the Third Precinct, Brooklyn, arrested a man named CosSELLO, having in his possession ten bags of Coffee valued at about $200, under circumstances which led the officer to believe that the property had been stolen. COSTELLO was examined before a magistrate and discharged, there not being sufficient testimony against him to hold him for trial.

THE FAT-CATTLE SHOW AT THE CRYSTAL PALACE.--The Fat-Cattle Show at the Crystal Palace, under the direction of the American Institute, opened yesterday morning, and is to continue until the close of Thursday. The display yesterday was confined to the machine arcade, and to a very small number of cattle and sheep. Many more, however, were expected before the close of the day.

CORSO IN VENGEANCE.--M. ABBATUOOI, the recently deceased Minister of Justice in France, was admirable qualified, it would appear, by the experience of his own family history, to appreciate the advantages of a civilized system of jurispendence. The correspondent of an English Journal and writes of him:

AT THE NAVY YARD.--The number of workmen in the Navy Yard has been reduced from 1,700, which was about the force in October, to less than 1,200. There are now 1,400 nominally on the payroll, but not so many as that, by nearly 300, employed in the yard, The near completion of the Savannah, and the Suspension of work on the stores, renders this reduction necessary.

The ship Independence, of Bath, is now on the large sectional dock for repairs. She will be stripped, recaulked and newly coppered. The ship Jeremiah Thompson was yesterday morning taken on the large balance dock for examination. The clipper ship Flying Eagle Is also on the small balance dock. She will be stripped, recaulked and newly coppered.

Mason, Douglas, Slidell, Polk, Crittenden, Seward and Foot. Finance--Messrs. Hunter, Pearce, Gwin, Bright, Riggs, Fessenden and Cameron. Commerce--Messrs. Clay, Benjamin, Bigler, Toombs, Reid, Allen and Hamlin.

The game is settled. BRIGHAM YOUNG has decided the question, that so many persons have so long speculated upon--that is, what the Mormons intended doing, and what would be the best policy for the Government to pursue with regard to them. Colonel ALEXANDER received to-day a copy of BRIGHAM'S proclamation, which he issued to the Mormons.

ANDREW MILNE died in Charleston on the 3d. aged 74. He was a native of Aberdeenshire, Scotland, but early in life came to this country, of which he has been a resident for the last fifty-four years. He first went to New-Orleans, where fourteen years of his life was spent in the cotton trade, in connection with large houses in Glasgow and Liverpool.

THE FIRE DEPARTMENT.--At the annual meeting at Fireman's Hall, Monday evening, DAVID MILLIREN, Esq., President, was in the Chair. The Liberals of Sardinia, who have done so much within the last few years to make themselves, their nation and the Italian name respected throughout the world, are now putting themselves into sackcloth, and casting ashes upon their heads, on account of the unsatisfactory result of the Parliamentary elections which have just been hold in Piedmont.

JUVENILE TEMPERANCE SOCIETY.-An adjourned meeting of the friends of the Juvenile Temperance movement was held at 3 1/2 P.M. on Monday, in room No. 3, Bible House, Rev, T. L. CUYLER presided. A Committee appointed for that purpose at the Saratoga Convention reported a Constitution and list of officers of a Temperance Association, the organization of which was yesterday completed.

A telegraphic dispatch from the South informs us that Miss WHITE, the friend of MAZZINI and of Italian liberty, has at length been set at liberty, with the injunction to leave immediately the Italian States. This lady, as you will recollect, was compromised in the affair of Leghorn and Genoa in June last, and since that time has lain a prisoner in the ducal palace.

RELIABLE CRITICISM.--The admirable musical criticisms which Illuminate the columns of the Herald blazed forth with unwonted splendor on Tuesday. Old Potosi was determined not to be beaten. In his notice of the Academy of Music he states that FLOROW'S opera of Martha was given on Monday for the Second time to a splendid house.

From the Luzerue (Pa.) Union of Saturday. We are called upon to chronicle another horrible murder committed in this County. An honest old German, named JACOB MATTHIAS, living about seven miles from this borough, on the road to Bear Creek, was missed about ten days ago. He was in town the day previous and purchased a hog; he paid for it, and promised to call the next day and take it to his home.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The President says in substance that the Federal Constitution forbids the issuing of paper money by Banks under State authority; but that "unfortunately" a contrary "construction has now prevailed too long to be changed."

Owing to the continued indisposition of Hon FORMES, the Opera of the "Puritans" was not played last night--the "Trovatore" oeing substituted for it. The entertainment was for the benefit of the Hebrew Benevolent Society, and we are happy to say that the change of Opera, and the disappointment consequent on it did not visibly affect the very excellent attendance. It is expected that Mr. FORMES will be sufficiently well to sing in Thursday's oratorio.

To the Editor of the Net-York Times: DEAR SIR: It is understood that a number of persons, both men and women, are engaged in soliciting our citizens and our friends In the country for funds for the Children's Aid Society. The public should be informed that we have no collectors at present, and that these persons are impostors, who are making a disgraceful living on this imposition.

The Board met yesterday at 1 o'clock, P. M. Present Commissioners DILLON, COOLEY, RUSSELL, BUTTERWORTH, GRAY, FIELDS, GREEN and HOGG. The minutes of Dec. 8th were read and approved. The Chief-Engineer was ordered to report whether the hammers used by the stonebreakers are of sufficient weight, and if not, then to inform the Board the description of hammers to be used with advantage, and the probable cost thereof.

From the Washington star of Monday evening. yesterday afternoon, about 4 P.M., a most shocking murder was committed upon the body of the wife of BASIL HALL. residing in Alexandria County, Va., about five miles from this city. According to her deposition, her husband was walking over his farm, and the rest of the whites of the family were at church.

The Bank resumption in this State and New-England is working quietly. The Banks here are strong in Specie. The money is not all their own, but mainly the property of their depositors, who since the October suspension have collected and returned twenty-two million dollars to bank, raising the line of undrawn deposits as high as it stood this time last year.

CONTRADICTED.--We learn from parties who ought to know, that there is no foundation for the report that a small schooner privately left this part lst week, loaded with arms and ammunition for the use of General WALKHR'S army which she was to land at a point in Nicaragua agreed upon with the General.

Nos. 4 and 9.--Arguments for plaintiffs in the first case concluded. No. 10.--Goorge Law, representing the Mail Steamship Company, vs. Charles Hill et al., owners of the ship Ocean Qucen. The appeal was dismissed for want of jurisdiction, there being no final decree in the case.

Senator GREEN'S reply to DUOGLAS, to-day, was supertickal, though, under the circumstances, credit-able. DOUGLAS' reply was overwhelming. The speech of Mr. Cox, the new Democratic member of the House from Ohio, against the Le-compton Constitution, was a powerful effort, and attracted universal and respectful Interest.

A resolution was adopted that the Senate will, to-morrow, proceed to the election of a printer. On motion of Mr. GWIN, a resolution was adopted calling on the President for all correspondence between the Departments and the present Governor of Kansas, together with all orders and instructions which have been issued to said officer.

The Ladies Hospital Fair, which was opened oil Tuesday evening at the Infirmary, corner of Rleecker and Crosby streets, was well attended and very successful in a pecuniary point of view. The rooms are tastefully decorated, and the articles, among Which are a choice collection of water-color paintings by celebrated English artists, are well selected, and marked at very low prices.

PLINT MILLS edited a MS. journal on board the Vanderbilt during her passage cut, and and had two numbers printed in London--and very funny examples of marine wit and transatlantic journalism they are.

Acting-Governor STANTON was in Lawrence yesterday. The object of his visit was to settle with the members of the Legislature and the leaders of the Free State Party, the conditions upon which he would immediately issue a call for a special session of the Territorial Legislature.

A series of resolutions recommending the reopening of the African Slave Trade, has been introduced into the Texas House, by John Henry Brown, They Conclude as Follows: That our Senators in Congress be instructed and our Representatives requested to urge upon the Congress of the united States the repeal of all laws, and the abrogation of all treaties prohibiting the importation of African slaves into the slaveholding States and Territories of this Union;

THE DEATH OF COL. F. M. WYNKOOP.--Colonel FRANCIS M. WYNKOOP, late united States marshal for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania, was accidentally killed while gunning near Tamaqua Parish on Monday. He was hunting pheasants in company with his hired man, when the gun in the hands of the latter was accidentally discharged.

One of the unfavorable effects of the hard times has been a complete stoppage of improvements in Broadway, which have boon going on for the past five years at a most rapid rate, and on a sole of great magnificence. Five years more of prosperous times would have brought about splendid changes and made it really, what it is often even now said to be, the finest street in the world.

The attendance at the Fat Cattle show at the Crystal Palace was much larger yesterday than on either of the previous days of the exhibition. There were many ladies and children there during the day; the little ones appeared to be especially delighted with the species of pigeons cailed "Pouters," of which there were a number at the exhibition.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--There will be a matince today, commencing at 2 o'clock. BELLINI'S open of "Norma" will be performed with LA GRANGE, SIEDENBURG, BIGNARDI and GASSNER in the principal parts. NIBLO'S GARDEN.--One of the best pantomimes in the extensive repertoire of the RAVELS is the "Green Monster." This work was revived

A MISSING GIRL FOUND--SINGULAR CASE.--Annie Carr, a girl 16 years of age, disappeared from her home, No. 15 West-street, about four weeks since, in a very mysterious manner. Her parents, (Irish, of the laboring class,) sought for her in vain, and finally made the circumstances known to the Deputy superintendent of Police, who Instructed Detective Officer Bennett to seek for the missing girl.

NORTON-NORRIS.--In this City. on Thursday, Dcc. 17, at St. John's Chapel, by Rev. S. II. Weston, Mr. GEo. 11. NORTON to Miss MARY A. NoRRIs, all of this City. WARINO-FOSTER.--In Brooklyn. on Wednesday, Dec. 16, by Rev. W. Phraner. WM. C. WARING, ESQ.. of Yonkers, to SARAH E.. daughter of the late Robert K. Foster, of Sing Sing.

The House of Represontatives have moved Into the, new hall of Congress, of which we hear a good deal; but beyond tile deEeription which our own eorrespondeont gave some time since of tile, manner of illuminating it at night, we have not yet seen anything in the shape of a description which gives even a tolerably clear idea of what to hall resem bles.

The Republican has Kansas dates of the 10th Inst. The Legislature has done nothing towards carrying out the recommendations in Secretary STANTON'S Message. The election returns of Kickapoo had been declared fraudulent by a Committee of Investigation, and the Republican members admitted to their seats in the House.

GOVERNOR WALKER AND THE PRESIDENT.-- Governor WALKER has satisfied the anxious inquirers after his actual "stand-point." He has resigned his authority in Kansas, and he has given his reasons for that resignation. The whole of them culminate and sum themselves up in an alternative of duplicity or imbeeility forced upon the choice of President BUCHANAN

NEEDHAM.--The Buffalo Courier makes the following statement of the causes of the suicide of Mr. NEEDHAM, Jr., who communicated suicide in New-York on Friday night, was a son of JOSEPH P. NEEDHAM, formerly proprietor of the Seed and Agricultural store in this city, and a brother of Mr, NEEDIAM, of the firm of J. S. YEDDER CO.

THE DEMOCRACY.--The meeting in the Park was not as magnificent a display of popular enthusiasm as it was expected to be. It was small in numbers, exceedingly feeble in oratory, weak in enthusiasm, and strong only in its brass band. The leading spirit of the occasion was our old friend Coroner CONNERY, who is sure to turn up in any case of sudden and mysterious death--like those of Dr. BURDELL and Mayor WOOD.

We publish in another column Secretary STANTON'S Message to the Legislature of Kansas at the opening of its extra session. It is a clear, manly and admirable document. If the Legislature will act upon its suggestions, and avoid the points of danger which it signalizes, we cannot help thinking that the whole Kansas difficulty will be peacefully and satisfactory settled.

Mr. GWIN presented a memorial from a large number of the citizens of California and New-Mexico, praying for the establishment of the Territorial Government of Arizona; and subsequently introduced a bill for that purpose. On his motion a Senate Committe of nine was ordered to consider so much of the President's Message as referred to the subject of the Pacific Railroad, and subsequently he introduced a bill for its construction.

There are over two hundred and fifty vessels constantly employed in bringing live fish to this market. They are neat little crafts, varying from ten to eighty tons, sloops and schooners, which the year round, and through all weathers, traverse the neighboring coasts In quest of this indispensable article of food. By immemorial Usage, this fleet has found a common rendezvous in Fulton Market Slip:

A mass meeting of the Democracy, called by a Committee, which was headed by Mr. STEPUEN P. RUSSELL as Chairman, was held yesterday even:., ing in front of Tammany Hall, "to consider and respond to the policy of the National Administration as expressed in the first message of President BuCHANAN."

The first movement towards the authorization of the issue of Treasury Notes was made in Congress yesterday. A bill was reported from the Senate Committee on Finance by Mr. HUNTER, who asked its immediate consideration, and caused to be read a communication from the Secretary of the Treasury, giving a resume of the condition of this Department.

CAUGHT IN THE ACT.--Captain MILLER, of the Ninth Precinct, Brooklyn, early yesterday morning arrested a man named JOHN FRANSEN, while in the act of selling to a butcher in New-Brooklyn a cow which he had stolen in Flatbush. The accused was taken before Justice MOREHOUSE, and committed for examination.

FOUNDLINGS.--On Wednesday evening a young woman called at the residence of PATRICK DONAHCE, No. 125 1/2 Washington-street, having an infant child about a month old. She requested permission to leave the child for a few minutes, which was granted. But as no one camo again for the child, it was handed over yesterday to the Almshouse Governors, to be taken care of.

THE NEW-YORK SCOTT LEGION,--A second meeting of survivors of the different regiments which served in the Mexican War was hold last evening, at the Mercer-street House. About fifty new names were enrolled, after which officers were elected, as follows: President -- Gen. Ward B. BORNETT. Secretary-WM. B. PARRISAN. Treasurer-Frederick N. COOKE.

To HARLEM AND ASTORIA---The number of passengers between this City and Astoria is now on an average by the Golden Gale, about 300 daily, yielding, at the present rate of passage, about ?? per day. This is barely sufficient to pay the current expenses of the boat, and on the first of January, when the present communication tickets expire, the little Golden Gate will probably cease her trips.

The Cabinet is discussing the propriety of receiving Governor WALKER'S letter of resignation, the President dislikes exceedingly to place on the Government archives so sound a constitutional argument against his own policy, or such disagreeable citations of his own consistency.

The United States Mail steamship Tennessee, Capt. FORDES, from Vera Cruz the 7th inst., reached her wharf at an early hour yesterday afternoon, having crossed the bar at five in the morning. Advices are two weeks later, and of great interest and importance, as indicating the reestablishment of COMONFORT'S Government, temporarily at least, and the discomfiture of the Reactionary party--the result of the opportune grant to the Executive of dictatorial powers.

SHERWOOD.--In this City, on Wednesday, Dec. 16, MARGARET, wife of Geo. E. Sherwood, aged 32 years. The friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend he funeral, at the house No. 85 East 28th st., on Frida, Dec. 18, at 10 o'clock A.M. WESTON.--In this City, on Wednesday, Dec. 16, JAMES EDWARD, only child of James W. and Maranda A. Weston, deceased, aged 1 year, 1 month ad 8 days.

TWELFTH-WARD UNION WHIGS ARE invited to attend a meeting at Farrington's Hall, corner of 34 av. and 128th-st., on FRIDAY EVENING, Dec, 18 at 71/2 o'clock, to elect a Ward Committee for the ensuing years, A full attendance is desirable. ABRAHAM OVERHISER, Chairman, WM, OAKLEY, Secretary.

General GEORGE WASHINGTON, late of the State of Virginia, and twice President of the United States, upon his death-bed bequeathed the priceless boon of freedom to his slaves. He was generally esteemed in his own times a man of character and capacity, and his reputation with the more intelligent classes of mankind throughout the world has rather gained than lost with the night of years.

FIRE IN CHERRY-STREET--SEYEN HORSES BURNED.-At 5 o'clock yesterday morning, a fire broke out in the frame stable rear of No. 376 Cherry-street. The stable was entirely destroyed, and seven horses burned. The fire was caused by the carelessness of a drunken hackman.

THE LONG ISLAND RAILROAD.--The Long Island Railroad Company has been enterprising during the Summer, and by the judicious expenditure of labor and lumber, so fenced in the road throughout its whole length at every cut, that they have no longer any fears of snow-storms.

WESTERN ENTERPRISE.--The citizens of Ossawatomic, Kansas, have made arrangements for running a line of four-horse coaches from Jefferson City to that town, and are about to apply for the establishment of various new mail routes.

The Board of Aldermen met last night, President CLANOY in the Chair. An ordinance was passed and subsequently reconsidered and laid over, to grade Hamilton-square and to fill sunken lots and streets between Sixty-fifth and Fifty-seventh streets inclusive.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Permit me to notice some observations in your historical review of the Central American negotiations, in the TIMES of to-day. You say that Mr. CLAYTON was "self-deceived;"

SENOR D. M JEREZ, Esteemed General : In the beginning of October I sent you another letter vid Greytown, in which I gave you positive information of the preparation making by WALKER In these States. To-day the thing is a reality, and the annexed paper will inform you of the details of his departure.

From the Albany Atlas and Argus. JOHN CALHOUN went to Illinois in the year 1830, then about 23 years old. He established a High School in Springfield, and while successfully engaged in teaching "young ideas how to shoot," the Black Hawk War broke out. In the campaign against this Chieftain, he served as a volunteer, and on his return, was appointed County Surveyor by the Governor.

COL. RICHARDSON.---A rumor has been industriously circulated by the Administration Press, that Co,. RICHARDSON, before receiving the appointment of Governor of Nebraska, formally gave in his adhesion to the President's Kansas policy.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--The afternoon performance of "Norma," yesterday, attracted a brilliant audience, composed mostly of ladies. The entertainment appeared to give entire satisfaction; and it is evident that Mr. ULLMANN has touched a popular chord in thus providing for the fashionable unemployed.

Hon. J. B. Floyd, Secretary of Way: SIR: As the Immediate Commander of the Army, under the President, I have the honor to submit the annual report, on its general condition and wants. Our regiments, horse and foot, including artillery, (serving mostly as infantry) are, as I have remarked in former reports, anything but a pence establishment. ishment.

Governor WALKER'S career In Kansas is closed. His letter of resignation, which we published yesterday, gives very cogent reasons for surrendering tile office which, less than nine months ago, he accepted upon the urgent solicitation of President BUCHANAN. Under the circumstances of the case, we concur with Governor WALKER in the propriety of his resignation.

In London on Dec. 2 money continued in active demand, The Stock market was firm, caused by the arrival of the West India mall steamer with [Pound]300,000 in silver. The suspensions of the day wore MENDES, DAOSTA Co., In the london and West India trade, with liabilities amounting to [Pound]350,000 sterling, and KEISER Co., in the German trade, with liabilities amounting to [Pound]50,000.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: DEAR SIR: What shall be done for the uncomplaining-suffering, starving poor in this City ? After all our benevolent provisions for this numerous class of persons, we meet with many cases unrelleved, and that would not be known but for the pains-taking labor of the faithful missionary.

With the return of the season of gifts and good-will, we are glad to find that our cotemporaries of the Albion make no breach in their observance of a good old custom. They this year recognize the ties which unite them to their large circle of readers by the presentation of an admirable picture of "Dr. KANE at the grave of FRANKLIN'S men."

The Spanish Court refuses to accede to the demand of Mexico, that its envoy shall be received, as a necessary preliminary to the negotiation. The accounts from Cuba received at Madrid state that the squadron assembled there was ready to sail at a moment's notice, to act against Mexico or elsewhere.

Correspondence of the Newark Daily Advertiser. FLORENCE, Nov. 17.--Remote as we are from the whirlpools of trade, Italy feels the tempest which sweeps the commercial world. Several houses have been wrecked through their American relations, and the newspaper reports have served to reduce American credit generally much below par

It does seem as if the political agitation in Kansas would never cease. No sooner has one cause of excitement passed away than another is sprung upon us. In my last I gave the Proclamation of Acting-Governor STANTON, and the proceedings of the Delegate Convention in this City on the 2d inst.

Mr. DOUGLAS introduced a bill to authorize the people of Kansas to form a Constitution and State Government, preparatory to their admission into the Union on an equal footing with the original States. The resolutions submitted yesterday by Mr. PUGH and Mr. TRUMRULL, calling upon the President for further information in reference to Kansas affairs were agreed to.

The Navy Department received, by the last steamer from California, letters from Commodore PAULDING, Inclosing a letter from Captain CHOTAED, of the Saratoga, in reference to the Landing at Punta Arenas of the fillibuster force under General WALKER.

UNUSUAL DESTITUTION.--We learn that the pressure on the Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor is now greater than was ever before known so early in the season. Up to this time the expenditure has been more than double that of any previous Winter. This fact is the more remarkable in view of the mildness of the weather, and proves the extent of the present destitution.

The Concord, N. H., Congregational Journal gives the particulars of the death of a young lady, named HELEN M. KITTREDGE, of vigorous physical powers, at Nelson, N. H., suddenly while taking a rum sweat for some trifling illness.

From the Washington Union, It now appears that the newly-elected members of the Kansas Legislature have been Topekaized by the proclamation of Acting Governor STANTON, and that it is to readopt the Topeka Constitution, and place it in competition with the Lecompton Convention.

There was a large company of artists and amateurs at the rooms of the National Academy in Tenth-street, on Thursday night, attracted by an invitation to a private view of Mr. BELMONT'S pictures, previous to the gallery being opened to public inspection for the benefit of the poor of the City.

The Royal Mail steamship Canada, Capt. LANG, from Liverpool at 11 o'clock on the morning of the 5th inst., entered this harbor at 2 o'clock this (Friday) morning, but could not get up to her dock until after the America's departure, about 3 o'clock A. M. The advices brought by the Canada are one week later than those received by the Europe at New-York.

Some remarks appeared in Thursday's TIMES, copied from San Francisco journals, referring to the excitement in that city growing out of the loss of the central America, and rcflecling on the Pacific Mail Steamship Company's vessels.

private advices from the West coast of Africa, to Oct. 10, mention the arrest and temporary detention of the schooner Cortez, of NewYork, as a slaver, while lying at anchor off the river Camma, Kingdom of Loango, by boats from the United States frigate Cumberland.

ONLY ONE CENT TO WILLIAMSBURG.--It is a long time since it cost but one cent be cross the East River--so long that the loud expressions of indignation which greeted the rise to two cents has died into a sullen growl, and the traveling community has resigned itself to the extortion as to an evil for which there was no redress.

" Iranistan," the sumptuous residence created by Mr. P. T. BARNUM, near Bridgeport, Conn., some eight years since, was totally destroyed by fire at 11 on Thursday night. it is not known how the fire originated, but it is supposed to have been caused by the carelessness of workmen who were engaged in repairing and refitting the building.

Mercantile Library Association. A meeting of those interested in the formation of a Mercantile Library Association in Brooklyn was held at the Athenaeum on Thursday evening, the 17th instant. A. B. CAPWELL, Esq., was appointed Chairman, and Messrs. CHARLES S. FARLEY and BOWMAN secretaries.

The vessel seen ashore on Gardner's Island proves to be the hermphrodite bring brig Forest, hailing from some port in Nova Scotia, whither she was bound from New-York, with a cargo of beef, pork and flour. Having made a harbor under the point, she was caught on a lee shore by s sudden change of wind to northwest, blowing a gale, she parted her large chain, and went on the west side of the point.

The Davenport (Iowa) Gasette says the "Regulators" are again at work in Cedar County. Last week a young thief was arrested in Cedar County, and the "Regulators" became convinced that he was connected with a band of horse-thieves, and could give, if he would, some valuable information.
