By the arrived yesterday of the schooner Rafad, from Campeachy, we have received files of the Boletin del Espiritu Publico to the 27th ult. We learn from these papers that Campeachy is still in possession of the revolutionists. We cannot find any detailed account of the operations of the aboslegers.

From the New-Orleans Delta. The Canada, whose arrival at Halifax is announced in another part of this morning's paper, brings one week's later news from Europe. She reports the arrival of the Adriatic at Liverpool, after a fair passage of ten days and a half. The Improvement in the London Money market had not abated, though there have been further failures in different parts of Great Britain.

MACFARLANE.--In this City, on Thursday, Dec. 17, Miss MARY R. MACFARLANE, daughter of the late Robert Macfarlane, aged 22 years and 26 days. The relatives and friends of the family are invited to attend her funeral, this afternoon. at 1 o'clock, from the residence of her brother in-law, Elbert L. Buroham, No. 83 West 11th-St.

THE MAYOR REMOTES THE BELL-RINGERS--The occupants of some of the up-town belt-towers have offended his Hon or the Mayor, if the following letter, addressed to Messrs, CURRY and WAUGH of the Thirty-third-street tower, and Mr. GRIFFITHS (father of Alderman GRIFFITHS,) of the Union Market tower, may be taken in evidence of his Honor's feelings. We understand that the aforesaid CURRY, WAUGH and GRIFFITHS were strong Tiemann men at the late Mayoralty election.

But improved it must be and may, and very greatly Improved.

WE TREAD NO STEP BACKWARD!--We see in a prominent Eastern journal of our party, strong intimations that circumstance may soon arise in Kansas affording room for a change of ground on the part of those who have given decided expression of their views upon the affairs of that Territory.

Washington Corr. Richmond South. I am assured by Col. LOCKRIDGE, in person, that he entertains no idea of joining the Walker Expedition, as it was reported that he would do with reinforcements: but that he has dissolved all connection with Gen. WALKER and his enterprise, although still professing an ardent sympathy with both.

A FUGITIVE SLAVE CASE IN PHILADELPHIA, -- This morning, a hearing was had before Judge KANE In the case of a fugitive salve, named JACOB DUPEN, aged 30 years, the property of WILLIAM M. EDELIN, of Baltimore County, Maryland, DUPEN was arrested, yesterday, by Deputy-Marshals JENKINS and STEWART, about four miles from Harrisburg.

POLICE COURT CLERKS VISIT THE MAYOR.-On Saturday the Police Court Clerks, appointed by the Police Commissioners a few days ago, visited the Mayor and asked to be sworn in. The Mayor refused, saying he did not recognize the Police Commissioners as having the power. The Clerks then went to the Recorder and were sworn In by him.

FROM THE MOUNTAINS--RETURN OF LIEU WARREN'S PARTY.--The St. Joseph (Mo.) Journal announces the arrival in that city of Lieut. GEORGE K. WARREN, U. S. A., accompanied by Dr. F. V. HAYDEN of the Geological Survey. They were sent out to explore the region between Dakotah City and the head waters of the Running Water.

Yesterday afternoon, while Officer POLLION, of the First Ward. was endeavoring to restore quiet among a gang of rowdies, who had got into an altercation at No. 3 Greenwich-street, e was set upon by tile belligerents, and kicked and beaten till the blood gushed from his mouth and ears, and he was hardly able to stir.

Tile intelligence from China, published in this morning's issue, is interesting and important. It is now ascertained beyond a question that the United States, Great Britain or France will find it impossible to obtain from the Emperor any of the concessions to commerce and civilization that they demand.

The New-Haven Palladium has further particulars of the remarkable circumstances attending the supposed murder of young SAGE by the Irishman NUGENT, and the deliberate perjury of the Sailor BENSON. The Palladium recapitulates the history of the case, already given, and reproduces the original testimony of BENSON, on the strength of which NUGENT was indicted for murder. We copy:

FATAL ACCIDENT ON THE LONG ISLAND RAIL ROAD.--The name of the man announced as having been killed on the Long Island Railroad at Jamaica, on Friday last, was JAMES GORMAN. He was not instantly killed, but lived until Saturday afternoon, and then died in a carriage on Fulton-avenue, Brooklyn, while being conveyed to his late residence in Hickory-street, East Brooklyn.

NEW-ENGLAND IN NEW-YORK.-The enormous increase of the New-England element in New-York is shown by the great number of festivals to be held here to-morrow, in commemoration of the landing of the Pilgrims on Plymouth Rock. The day is to be celebrated in this City by three different New-England Societies.

ARRIVAL OF THE BLACK WARRIOR--LANDING OF MORE SLAVES--CROPS, BUSINESS, ETC. The United States Mail steamship Black Warrior, J. W. SMITH, Commander, sailed from New-Orleans on the 12th Inst., and Havana on the 15th ands arrived at this port early yesterday morning. From Havana we have nothing of political importance.

At a dance in house of ill-name in this city, last night, a party of rowdies forced their way into the house, when a butcher, named HARDING fired several times into the crowd with a revolver, shooting HUGHES WILSON, son of JOHN WILSON, member of the Provincial Parliament for this city, and also Messrs. SWEETHAN, STEVENS, MERRION, COATS, and two other men and a woman. WILSON has since died of his wounds.

Proceedings of the Leglsiature-Free-State Mass meeting at Lecompton-Opposition to the Lecompton constitution-Mr, Denver. From the Missouri Democrat, 17th. We are in possession of news from Kansas to the 12th instant. In the counties along the Missouri river attmpts were being made to get up companies of voters to go to Kansas on the 21st.

THE CANADIAN ELECTIONS.-The Parliamentary elections in Canada create immense excitement. The Montreal papers especially, usually not brilliant, are spicy to an extreine; abounding in abuse of rival candidates, and culling hard names without stint. The City of Montreal elects three memhers of Parliament, and there are six candidates.

THE ALLEGED ILLNESS OF GOV, WALKER,--We are Informed on good authority, that up to a late hour on Sunday night, Governor WALKER was in the enjoyment of perfect health and spirits, and that had he been suddenly attacked with illness, intelligence would have been sent to his intimate friends in this city.

COLONEL FORNEY. AND THE PRESIDENT.-It is of course not true, as every where telegraphed on Friday and Saturday, that the editor of the Press was denied admission at the Presidential mansion during his late visit to Washington. He was not only promptly but most kindly received, by the President, who knows too well the proprieties of life to regard on honest difference of opinion as a pretext for personal alienation,

FIFTY YEARS OF PREACHING.---Rev. Drs HOTTON and MACAULEY have invited Rev. Dr. MATHEWS, formerly Chancellor of the University, to deliver a discourse on the occasion of completing the fiftieth years of his preaching in this City. Dr. M. has accepted the invitation. We believe he is the only living clergyman who has preached for half a century steadily in the City.

SALE OF DIAMONDS.--The extensive sale of diamonds and fine jewelry, by order of the United States Marshal, opened at 10 o'clock Saturday, by SAMUEL OSGOOD, at No. 81 Nassau-street, Marshal RYNDERS made a brief speech, stating that the sale would be conducted upon fair and honorable principles to all, and requested the bidders to speak up distinctly, so that they could be heard.

Mr. CRITTENDEN submitted resolutions that in consideration of the financial condition of the country and the embarrassments of the Treasury, the rates of duty established by the tariff of March last ought to be materially increased; and also in favor of a substitution of a system of home valuation on important goods. The resolutions lay over. The Senate resumed the consideration of the Treasury Note bill.

GOVERNOR WALKER'S GREAT LETTER.--ROBERT J. WALKER wrote, probably, the most forcible letter in favor of JAMES BUCHANAN in 1856. Its style and its facts made a profound impression on the public mind. It was translated into German and French, and even into Spanish, Italian and Welsh. He wrote then as if he felt that upon the issue depended the preservation of the Union.

ORATORIOS AT THE ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--The first of the promised series of Oratorio performances was given at the Academy on Saturday evening, drawing an immense house, and cast with strength and shill, The "Creation" has been produced on many occasions, and by various musical Societies in this City, but never before with the effect that attended its representation in this instance.

The Washington Correspondent of the Charleston Mercury thus speaks of the position of affairs at the Federal Capital: " The posture of affairs on this subject is more crita cal than at any former time. Geographical lines are being formed as they never were before. The South is ??, whom can we trust? The North is exulting in a new Triumph.

THE BROOKLYN POST-OFFICE.--When the present Postmaster, Mr. WM. H. PEST. came into office, he removed most of the old attaches, and filled their places with more reliable party men. A number of the letter-carriers, who had been connected with the Office a number of years, not to be entirely thrown out of employment, solicited and received form the residents in the several districts order to take their letters from the office, and deliver them.

Kansas is not likely to be neglected at Washington. Two bills have already been introduced for the purpose of superseding the action of the Lecompton Convention,-one by the Democratic leader of the Senate, Mr, DOUGLAS, and the other by the Republican leader in the House, Ex-Speaker BANKS.

The Collins steamship Adriatic from Liverpool on the 9th instant, arrived at this port yesterday after a fair cup for this season of the year, of twelve days. We receive by the Adriatic four days' later news from Europe Financial affairs in London continued to Improve, though several more failures are reported.

E. Walter, Esq., Secretary Board of Underwriters, New-York. DEAR SIR; Dates have been received here this P. M., (via St. Thomas,) from Pernambuco, to 19th Nov by which I learn that the American ship Juniper Capt. LE FEVRE, from Rio Janeiro with I Cargo of Coffee, bound for New-York was totally lost on the 12th November on a reef about 10 miles south of Pernambuco; vessel and cargo a total loss. .

There is a full in the Kansas excitement here, and everybody is looking with exceeding anxiety to the election of to-morrow, upon which momentous events hang-- perhaps the question of a civil war, disastrous to the peace of the whole country

The few friends of Mayor Wood, here, are exceedingly disgusted with the barren victory achieved by them in the New-York district-Attorneyship case. They had hoped to secure the appointment of same nominee of the Wood party to fill the vacancy, and in that way seem to get a little personal sympathy from the President in behalf of the great defeated.

THE LATEST MYSTERY.--A very remarkable Instance of the unreliability even of what seems to be positive and conclusive evidence in criminal trials, is found in the mysterious affair which has just come to light in Connecticut. It strongly resembles the incident which caused so much excitement in Orange County in this State, when the body of a woman was found, supposed to be that of SARAH BLOOM.

BEGINNING TO CONFESS.--The Charleston Mercury thus frankly confesses its motive in urging the adoption of the Lecompton constitution: "We differ, too, with the President as to what is submitted to the vote of the people. We do not think that the question of Slavery or no Slavery is submitted to the vote of the people.

The following is tile Weekly Report of Deaths in the City and County of New-York,from the 12th day of December to the 19th day of December, 1857: Men, 66; Women, 70; Boys, 110; Girls, 105: Total, 351*. Adults, 130; Children, 215; Males, 176; Females, 175; Colored Persons, 7.

Mr. BIGLER, of Pennsylvania, yesterday took charge of the Lecompton movement in the Senate of the United States. What he said upon the points at issue had been much bettor said by Mr. GREEN, of Missouri, two or three days before. The whole ease of the Lccomptonites is one of legal casuistry.

Mr. L. B. WARD left his horse and rockaway at the Church door on Forty-second-street, between Seventh and Eighth avenues, Sunday morning. When he came out, a thief and his carriage had disappeared together. The reprobate had hopped in and played coachman so naturally that the Jehus were deceived, and believed his story when he told them he was going around the corner to water.

THE NEW POST-OFFICE.--The contract recently agreed upon by the Committee of the Common Council, with the General Government, for sale of a site for a City Post-Office, was sent last night to the Corporation Counsel for his opinion as to the legal power of the City Government to make the sale.

A Parliamentary Blue-Book has lately been issued in London, containing all the correspondence between Her Britannie Majesty's Ministers and Consuls and those of the United States, Spanish, Brazilian, and other Governments, relative to the traffic in slaves.

Mayor Wood's Opinion of the Tribune--He port of the New Post-Office Committee-Ten Thousand Dollars to pay the Mayor's Law Expenses. The Board of Alderman met last night, president CLANCY in the Chair.

NEW AND STRIKING,--Mayor Wood last night vetoed payment of a bill due the Tribune for advertising. He accompanied this act, sufficiently paltry in itself, with a message to the comment Council denouncing the Tribune as a scurrilous and immoral journal. The Mayor must be losing his wits as well as his temper.

Anniversary Oration by Rev. Dr. Storrs, The Fifty-second Anniversary Oration of the New-England Society in New-York was delivered last evening, by Rev. R. S. STORRS, D D., of Brooklyn, in the Church of the Messiah, (Rev, Dr. Or Good's)

Senabor BILGLER'S carefully-written speech on the Kansas today is generally to be semi-presidential. It threw no new light on the subject. In the subsequent debate with Senator DOUGLAS, the latter again bagered him severely, and he was quite vaquished.

The following officers have been restored to the active list of the Navy by the action of the naval courts and their nominations sent into the Senate: Captain.--Joseph Smith from leave pay. Commanders--Joseph R. Jarvis, leave; James Glyn, leave ; Robert Ritchie, leave ; C. Ringgold, leave ;

MERCANTILE LIBRARY ASSOCIATION OF BROOKLYN.---This young institution has already got a $10,000 capital subscribed, and the books of the Athenaeum Library, 5,000 in number, are to be presented, with the use, of the Library rooms. The election for officers will be held at the Athenaeum, in Atlantic-street, Brooklyn, on Wednesday, 23d inst.

Mr. Arthur T. Edwards, late of the firm of Din, Edwards Co., of this City, died at Dubuque, Iowa, on Friday, of fever. His age was 29. Mr. Edwards went. West a few months since, intending, we believe, to settle there permanently. His Unexpected death will cause sorrow to a large circle of friends.

Mr. WRIGHT introduced a hill to continue the improvement of the Harbor of Newark, New-Jersey. The bill was referred to the Committee on Commerce. Mr. Rioos submitted a joint resolution, which was adopted by a vote of 34 against 12, providing that when the two Houses adjourn on Wednesday next the adjournment continue till the 4th of January.

The telegraph announces the arrival at Norfolk, yesterday, of the bark Wm. G. Lewis, in thirty-five days from the coast of Africa as a price--she having been captured as a slaver in the Congo River, by Lieuts. WALKER and CUMMINS of the United States sloop-of-war Dale.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC --" Robert to Diable " was performed last night, for the benefit of Mine. LA GRANGE, and, strange to say, the house was not crowded, There was, however, a line, fashionable and appreciative audience, and the efforts of the most accomplished and faithful prima donna we have ever had in this country were rewarded with applause which Ind?? a genuine perception of their excellence.

DEATH OF A FEMALE SPIRITUALIST--SUPPOSED SUICIDE--Mrs. EVANS, a widow lady, residing at No. 10 Cottage-pace, died very suddenly yesterday afternoon, and , from the circumstances of the case, it is supposed that her death was the result of suicide from taking poison.

Some facts have come to my knowledge with in the past few days, which throw considerable light upon the recent policy of the Administration. Most people have expected the President to pursue a straightforward, Independent and patriotic course, because they say, he has attained the summit of his ambition, and does not look forward to a second term of office.

After a brief exemption from many of the cares and responsibilities, as well as the sears and wrinkles of the nations of the Old World, it discovers in us some of the indications of maturity,

The Fall River News has the following: "The Anawan, Fall River and Watuppa Cotton Mills Will resume operations about the first of January. These establishments employ about 450 hands. The American Print Works are now in full operation, and as they will probably continue running through the Winter, the starting of the cotton mills must soon follow.

Yesterday was Forefathers' day, 237th anniversary of the Pilgrims' landing at Plymouth. The New-England Society held its annual meeting at noon in the Astor, House. WM. CHAUNGY, Esq., was elected moderator. The Treasurer reported a balance on hand of $2,144. WM.

WHECK OF A BRITISH BACK--HERR CREW BROUGHT TO NEW-YORK.-The Hamburg ship Dorau, Captain MEYER, thirty-two days from Hamburg, With merchandise and 120 passengers, Consigned to E. BECK KESHARDT, arrived at this port yesterday, having on board the captain and crew (eighteen in number) of the British bark Davenport, Capt. McKenzie, of Plymouth, England, who had been picked up at sea.

Mr. DOUGLAS carries too many guns altogther for Mr. Bigler who again essayed to-day to answer the able speech of the Senator from Illinois in violiation of the night of self-government in the people of Kansas. The speech which Mr. B. gave as was carefully studied and written. Indeed it is said--and there need by little doubt of the fact--that it had been critically examined and indorsed by the President himself.

BOLD ROBBERY.--Yesterday morning the Southern Shades, kept by DAVID EASTGATE, on Hicks-street, between Atlantic and Pacific, Brooklyn, was robbed of a small trunk containing $221 50 In gold, $214 in bills and silver, a note for $1,200, bond for house and lot, and an insurance policy. The supposed thief has been in the habit of visiting the place about 10 A.M. every day for several weeks past.

ACADEMY or MUSIC.--"Robert to Piable" will be played to-night with La GRANAX, FORMES, BIONAEDI, c., in the cast. LAURA KEENE'S THEATRE.--The revival of the "Corsican Brothers" at this house on Monday, cannot be considered a success. Indeed the revival altogether was not calculated to this result, for the cast was by no means strong,

A singular case has been decided in Indiana, by which it is declared that marriage in that State requires no formalities to make it legal, except the mere agreement of the parties; that it is a evil contract only, and differs from other civil contracts merely in this--that it cannot be dissolved, even by mutual consent.

Among the mails stolen by Tuckerman on the Boston route was one dispatched from New-Orleans on the 7th all, for Boston. All the inland correspondence, including a large amount of drafts and bills, has been destroyed. Four or five hundred foreign letters have been recovered, with their seals unbroken, and were forwarded by the Liverpool steamer of the 5th inst. from New York.

The Senate had an Executive Session to-day, without resuming the consideration of the nomination of CLIFFORD to the Supreme Court. The Judiciary Committee have not yet decided in fit to be made. The President sent in a batch of Foreign appointments.

Labarte, are invited to attend the funeral, from the residence of her son in-law. Charles J. Evans. No. 16 Costage place , on Wednesday next, at 2 O'clock P.M. .M.

Capt. Reuben Butterfield, the oldest surviving settler of Farmington, Mass., died on the 1st inst., at the age of 93. He went from Dunstable in 1781, and settled in a wilderness. There was no mill within thirty -five miles, the nearest settlement twenty miles distant.

Mr. WILSON introduced a bill to secure to actual settlers the alternate sections of the public lands reserved in the grants to the States for railroad purposes. Mr. JOHNSON, of Tennessee, introduced a bill to grant every head of a family who is a citizen of the United States, a homestead of 160 acres of land, on condition of its occupancy and cultivation.

Col. Fremont visited Harvard College last week, and was received at the Law School Library by the students. He was escorted by Chief, Justice Parker. Prof. Parsons rose after Col. Fremont had spoken a few words, and remarked: "I have been honored by a request from Mr. Fremont to make his apology, which is highly complimentary to you and us all.

By telegraph we have rather startling news from Kansas, but it is not in such form as to command full credence. It is stated, on the authority of a latter in the St. Louis Democrat, that Gen. LANK was shot at Lecompton on the 15th, in a row growing out of a political controversy with a government official.

My attention has been called to a letter signed JOHN E. WOOD, United States Army, headed Troy, N, V., November, 1857, addressed to the editor of the Flag of the Union, Jackson, Miss., and published in a New-York paper of Dec. 8, 1857. It purports to be us reply to an exposition which I deemed proper to make, some time in the last Summer, to the unfounded slanders which the said WOOL had covertly.

SUPREME COURT--GENERAL TERM. Before Hon. Justices Mitchell Roosevelt, and Clerks. On Monday afternoon, as the Cretan Aqueduct case was on. His Honor, Mayor Daniel F. Themann, entered the General Term room, accompanied by Corporation Counsel Mr. Richard Busteed.

SIR: The letter of your Paris correspondent, of the 22d of October last., which appeared in the NEW-YORK TIMES of the 10th ult., contains errors, the result, no doubt, of want of acquaintance with some of the postal arrangements in this country, which I am sure you would desire to have corrected.

In the United States Senate, Yesterday, Mr. WILSON introduced his bill to secure to actual settlers the alternate sections of public land granted to States for railroad purposes, and Mr. JOHNSON introduced a bill granting to every head of a family who is a citizen of the United States a homestead of one hundred and sixty acres of land on condition of its occupancy and cultivation.

The most grateful announcement that I can make by this mail is, that the long-expected troops from I ?? are beginning to reach us. We, whose property and commercial interests have long been jeopar ized by the rebellious state of India, and particularly this part of India to which we are exited, welcome these reinforcements more heartily than we welcomed the breathless messenger who told us that Delhi had fallen.

The little girl, aged 12, of SMITH RULAND, of Patchogue, L. I., went early to school, on Monday morning, and helped to make the fire. Very soon after her clothes took fire. Rushing into the street, Mr. WILLIAM J. HORTON, who was passing, tore off his coat and wrapped it around her, thus smothering the fire and saving the girl's lilfe.

By the arrival of the bark Virginia and Estellina at this port, from Bahia, we have dates from Buenos Ayres to Nov. 2, Montevideo Nov. 5, Rio de Janeiro Nov. 11, and Bahia 15th. Everything was quiet at the Rio de la Plata. The new treaty between Brazil and the Republic of Uruguay haul not been ratified, and was strenuously opposed by a large party.

I have been allowed to read a letter dated Camp Rodgers, near Tampa, Dec. 3, which gives an account of Indian difficulties in that quarter. It says: "We have captured nineteen Indians and killed two. Our Company--MOSLEY'S, of Putnam Country--captured seven; Captain COVE'S, six; Captain STEWART'S, three, and Captain JONES', three. The Indians followed us, and fired occasionally, without damage, however, one ball lodging in one of our blankets.

THE GOVERNMENT AND THE FILLIBUSTERS.--Mr. McKEON seems to be still in office. Our City record narrates an official act on his part performed yesterday, in connection with Marshal RYNDERS, which does not look at all like the performance of a man with his head off. It seems that intelligence was sent from the State Department at Washington of the intended departure of a vessel from this port

Congress having agreed to take a recess from to-morrow until the 4th of January, we shall have only one day more of discussion on the Kansas Question before the Lecompton Constitution arrives, with the verdict of the people of the Territory upon it. Thus far only two Northern Senators stand publicly committed in favor of foreign that instrument upon people. End dragging Kansas into the Union under it as a State.

FALL OF A BUILDING IN SIXTH-AVENUE--NARROW ESCAPE.--At a few minutes to 1 yesterday morning, the large brick building at the corner of Sixth avenue and Forty-seventh-street suddenly fell to the ground with a tremendous crash. The noise occasioned by the fall was heard several blocks and woke up all the people in the neighborhood.

In accordance with the resolution of the Board of Aldermen, on Tuesday evening, the committee appointed to investigate the charges In relation to the disposal of stands in West Washington Market held their third meeting yesterday afternoon. There was as usual, a very large attendance, and when the proceedings commenced Aldermen BLINT, HOFFBIHE and ADAMS were present, Alderman McCONNELL came in soon afterwards, and Alderman DRAKE appeared before the close.

THE ABSCONDING PRESIDENT OF THE BANK OF PENNSYLVANIA.---The letter of Mr. ALLIBONE, the absent President of the Bank of Pennsylvania, who has been advertised as a defaulter, which was published yesterday by his brother, is a most remarkable document.

A BURGLAR CAPTURED.--At 12 1/2 o'clock yesterday morning Officer ROBERTS, of the Eighth Ward, discovered that the boot and shoe store of Mr. WIOHSTEAD, No. 329 Canal-street, had been broken open by burglars. He went into the store and succeeded in capturing one of the burglars, a negro, giving his name as GEORGE WILLIAMS. In the possession of the prisoner were a crow-bar and a double-barreled pistol heavily loaded.

Tile House of Representatives, yesterday, adopted a resolution declaring the Territory of Utah to be in a state of rebellion against the United States, and directing an inquiry into the propriety of excluding the delegate of that Territory from a seat in the House. This action strikes us as being much more hasty than wise.

The Legislature has only got ready to do the work for which they were convened, and a bill will probably be offered to-day, that will embody the essentials. On Saturday the Council took up the case of the Leavenworth County contestants, and It resulted the same as with the House, In throwing out the Pro-Slavery members holding certificates, and admitting the conlestants, who were immediately sworn in.

The murder of CHARLES W. LITTLES at Rochester, on Saturday last, is in all respects one of the most remarkable cases of crime on record. The assassination of Dr. BURDELL had enough of mystery about it to satisfy the abnormal longings of the most morbid fancy; but this tragedy, both in its results and antecedents, possesses features totally unlike that of any murderous transaction we have had to record.

SCALIGER used to give a thanks to the Almighty that "of His infinite goodness He had inspired some men with the Spirit of dictionary making," and many a scholar has since had occasion to echo the thought if not to repeat the speech.

The Police Commissioners met, on Tuesday, at their office, Broome-street, Mayor Wood alone being absent. The minutes of the last meeting having been read and confirmed, Mr. BOWEN stated that he had written to their counsel, Messrs., Brown, Hall Vanderpoel, asking their opinion as to the power of the Commissioners to appropriate the fines and penalties collected from policemen to the Police Contingent Fund, but as yet had not received a reply.

The various branches of the President's Message were appropriately referred. Mr. SIMMONS gave notice of his intention to introduce a home valuation bill. Mr. STUART addressed the Senate on the subject of Kansas. He said it was remarked by Attorney-General BUTLER, in the Arkansas case, that the power of Congress upon the subject of the admission of new States is plenary.

HIGHLY INTERESTING AND IMPORTANT.--An auctioneer advertises the sale of the plate chest of the Duke of BUCKINGHAM, with all his silver, and persons ambitious of possessing a piece of plate with a ducal coronet upon it are invited to attend the auction.

At a meeting of this Board on Tuesday, the draft of an act submitted at a previous meeting to divide the county into five Coroner's districts, was called up and adopted. A bill wits also adopted to divide the county into five districts for the election of Superintendents of the Poor.

VALENTINE, Clerk of the Common Council, specifying the names of the school officers elected at the charter Election was read and ordered to be filed. The Report of the finance Committee was read:

Tammany Hall was well filled last night, in response to a regular call of the General Committee of the Democratic Party, "for the purpose of declaring the sentiments of the Democracy of the City, relative to national politics, and reiterating the expression of their confidence is and support of the policy and administration of JAMES BUCHANAN."

DOCTORS DIFFERING.-It is sometimes pleasant to find people who ought to he well informed, quite as ignorant as those upon whom no such official obligation is imposed. It is very difficult to find, in the community at large, two persons who agree as to the causes and the probable duration of the financial crisis.

Rev. JOHN SEYS, who went to Liberia a few months since, clothed with the powers of a special agent of the American Colonization Society, has returned and made his report. It is published in the last number of the Society's periodical. The mission of Mr. SEYS had for its object a general view of the condition of the settlements in Liberia and the acquisition of new territory.

BLATCHFORD.-IN this City, in Wednesday, Dec, 23, JULIA, ANN, Wife of Richard M. Blatchford. The friends and relatives of the family are invited to attend her funeral, from her late residence, No e East 14th-st., on Saturday morning, at 0 1/3 o' clock. STRAHAN.-In this City, on Tuesday, morning, Dec, 22, JOHN STRAHAN, in the 60th year of his age.

THE APPOINTMENT OF BELL-RINGERS--EXPENSES OF TESTING THE METROPOLITAN POLICE BILL, The Board of Aldermen met last evening, President CLANOY in the Chair. A communication was received from the mayor, stating that he had received drafts to the amount of $500 from silas E. Burrows, Esq., late of New-York, to be placed to the credit of a fund to be raised for the relief of the poor, and especially the female poor, of New-York.

An express just arrived at Leavenworth from the Utah Expedition brings information that the whole force, with tile exception of Colonel Cook and his command, had concentrated at Black's Fork, and were moving towards Fort Bridger. Their progress was very slow, only two or three miles a day being sometimes made. The animals were giving out hourly, and it was thought that all would perish this Winter.

By letter to Ellwood Waiter, Esq. BALTIMORE, Wednesday, Dec. 23.--The schooner Mary A??, with 90 long soda, and schooner Home, with 90 tons soda and tin, have arrived from the ship Washington Rooth, the laiter having left the ship last night, and reports that everything was going on very well, and that they expected to get the ship off this morning. The cargo received is in good order.

The last day's session of Congress, previous to the holiday vacation, was marked by interesting proceedings in both Houses. The Kansas debate was continued in the Senate--Mr. STUART, Democratic member from Michigan, and Mr. BRODERICK, Democratic member from California, making speeches in opposition to the view of the President.

THE NEW GUANO ISLANDS.--A practical result has at length produced the discovery of the Kooria Mooria guano group. Those islands situated off the coast of Arabia, were discovered about two years ago by Captain ORD, a British officer, who obtained a lease or grant of them from the Imaum of Muscat. An examination of the guano was made at the time, and it was found to be most valuable.

To the Editor of the Standard: DEAR SIR: An article lately published in your paper has just come to our notice. It does great injustice to a man of estimable character. We believe our agent in Chicago to be incapable of making fraudulent representations to borrow money, whether for himself or his employers, nor has he to our knowledge, to ourselves or other, withheld money borrowed for our account.

Most men value their lives at least sufficiently to decline surrendering them at the pleasure of anybody else. The most reckless esteem the privilege of suicide precious long after they have grown indifferent to the charms, and contemptuous of the obligations, of existence.

HARVARD COLLEGE.--The Treasurer's annual report of the state of Harvard, reports that the receipts exceeded the ordinary expenditures and left a small surplus. The valuable theological library, principally the donation of Colonel BENJAMIN LORING, has been received from Germany, and placed in Divinity Hall. It is to be kept by itself, and to be called the Loring Library.

GRAMMAR SCHOOL, NO. 23,--The Second exhibition of Grammar School No. 23, took place on Wednesday, at the School-house Nos. 26 and 28 City Hall-Place. The exercises consisted of singing and recitations by the scholars, male and female. They generally acquitted themselves well.

Our notice of APPLETON'S New American Cyclopedia, published in the TIMES of yesterday, may have conveyed the idea that it was merely or mainly a compilation from other works of a similar kind. This is not the case. On the contrary, it is entirely original, every article in it having been expressly written for its pages, under the direct and immediate supervision of its editors.

Mrs. LUCY A. MYERS died suddenly on Tuesday, at her residence, No. 16 Cottage-place, and from the circumstances attending her death, The fact of the death was published in Tuesday's TIMES, but the name was wrongly reported as Mrs. EVANS. Yesterday Coroner GAMBLE held an inquest on the body.

The New-York City Trade Society held its thirty-first anniversary on Sunday night, at the Madisonsquare Church. the large building was completely filled, and great interest was manifested in the proceedings. It was announced that the President of the Society, Rev. Dr. DEWITT, would take the chair, but in his unavoidable absence, his place was supplied by the Pastor of the Church, Rev. Dr. ADAMS.

OPPOSITION SUPERVISORS SWORN IN.--The six candidates for Supervisors who received next to the highest number of votes at the last election were sworn in yesterday morning by Mayor Wood. According to the new law, the six candidates receiving next to the highest number of votes are to be appointed by the Mayor.

No. 46 of the December Term of 1856.--Augustus Hemmenway, claimant of ship Independence, Vs W. B. Fisher, Chief Justice TANEY delivered the opinion of the Court, overruling the motion for damages. No. 1--white, Stevens co. vs. Paschal Rose's administrators.--The judgment of the Circuit Court of the Eastern District of Louisiana, was affirmed with costs.

The dentists held their semi-monthly meeting on Wednesday evening, at No. 57 Bond-street, Dr. A. MOLAROV in the Chair. An animated discussion was kept up on the subject appointed at the previous meeting, viz: The comparative effects of the various methods used to retain artificial plate-teeth in the mouth, especially the relative merles of the various kinds of clasps.

Before Judge Ingersoil. William Heine vs. William H. Appleton et al --The complainant, by profession an artist, accompanied the late expedition to Japan and the China Seas, fitted out by the Government of the United States, and under the command of Commodore Perry, of the United States Navy. He was shipped us master's made, and served as such on board one of the public ships which accompanied the expedition.

The announcement was made yesterday that Mrs. SARAH LITTLES and her brother, IRA STOUT, have been held to answer for the murder of CHARLES W. LITTLES in Rochester on Saturday last. The remainder of the testimony produced at the Coroner's Inquest.

Gov. WISE AND THE MUSKETS FOR GOV. LIGON -In the day of Gov. LIGON's tribulations, when he feared an outbreak of infiniated in Baltimore, he seat a moving appeal to Gov. WISE, of Virginia, for aid, and the aid was sent in the shape of a lot of muskets. the Legislature of the Commonwealth lately requested Gov. WISE to explain the reason for this little act of comity.

The Board of Aldermen met last evening, President CLANOY in the Chair. Alderman MOSPEDON moved to take up the resolution to pay the expenses of all suits brought by or against the Mayor in the matter of testing the constitutionality of the Metropolitan Police Bill, c., and stated that if members would examine the resolution they would find nothing wrong in it.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The other morning I set off from the city, thinking to have a comfortable day of it, as the weather was fine, though cold, and my bronchitis less afflictive than usual. I set midway in the car,--was composedly reading the TIMES, when a lady entered, (I can't now give the name of the station,) and taking the seat before me, opened her window to its full height.

The following paragraph occurs in the instructions sent by the Secretary of State to the new Governor of Kansas: "The Territorial Legislature doubtless convened on the 7th inst., and, while it remains in session, its members are entitled to be secure and free in their deliberations Its rightful action must also be respected.

The Cabinet this morning had an extraordinary session in reference to the present condition of Kansas affairs. I have not learned what was the result if there was any at all. It is supposed that the Administration will wait, before taking any decided action, for the reports of its special agents, VAN VLIET and RUSSELL.

Governor CUMING'S Message to the Territorial Legislature in Nebraska was delivered on the 9th inst., The Governor notices the completion of arrangements for the construction of the second division of the Atlantic and Pacific Telegraph, under the direction of HENRY O'REILLY and other. The Banks of the Territory are safe and moderately prosperous.

REOPENING OF WARD SCHOOL NO. 31.--Thursday was an occasion of unusual interest to the citizens of the Seventh Ward, on account of the reopening of Public School No. 31, located at No. 1200 Monroc-street, JOHN J. ANDERSON, Principal. The building having been entirely rebuilt, and furnished with every convenience for educational purposes, the day was set apart to appropriate exercises. by way of its dedication.

Receiving are have manifested much eagerness to sell, and prices have notably declined,

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--There will be a day performance of "Norma" at this establishment, commencing at 1 o'clock. Some of the principal artists of the Academy are in the east. In the evening there will be a grand Oratorio performance of the "Messiah," in which Mine, LA GRANGE, Miss MILNER, Mine CARADORRI, Herr FORMES, Mr. PERRING and other great artists, supported by a chorus of three hundred, and an orchestra of sixty will perform.

This is Forefathers' Day, but, in consequence of the hardness of the times, (they were confounded sight harder in December, 1620,) it will not be formally observed--a breach in a venerable custom that is to be regretted. The dinner ought to have been had, even if 11 had been as lenten in quality and quantity as that with which the Pilgrims were forced to content themselves.

A requisition was made on the Treasury to-day for $630,000 for the pay of member of Congress from the 4th of March last, under the joint resolution recently passed. Of this amount over $120,000 has already been disbursed in gold. In addition to the Pawnco delegation of Indians, a delegation of the poucahs, from Nebraska, have arrived here, both on business with the Government.

The variety store of HENRY HART, No. 171 Main-street, was destroyed by fire at about 4 o'clock this morning, together with a stock valued at $20,000. Insured in Eastern Companies for $10,000. The building was owned by WM. A. SUTTON, valued at $10,000, and insured in the Buffalo Mutual Office for $2,800.

The expresses which have recently arrived at Fort Leavenworth, from the army of the West, bring information that the whole force, with the exception of Col. COOKE'S command, had concentrated on Black's Fork, and were moving towards Fort Bridger, from which they were distant only a few miles. The progress of the army was exceedingly slow,

Christmas this year, spite of the ravens that croak of hard times, passed off very much like the Christmas of more prosperous seasons. "On the night before Christmas" stockings were hung at the chimney corners as of yore; Santa Claus squeezed through many a stove-pipe to visit many a hearthstone, and filled many a house yesterday with blasts of penny trumpets and tin horns,

THE RESIGNATION OF MR. BANKS--NEW ELECTION ORDERED,--The resignation of Hon. N. P. BANKS of his sent as a member of Congress from the Seventh District of this State, was received at the State-House on Tuesday. The Governor has ordered a new election to fill the vacancy on Thursday, the 7th day of January next.

The Naval Courts of Inquiry have at last completed their labors and the results of their "findings" are published, excepting in two or three cases which have yet to be reported. Whatever cause of complaint there may have been in the burried and secret manner in which the Retiring Board accomplished its work, there can be no such accusations made against the Courts of inquiry.

The Stonington steamer C. Vanderbilt was badly damaged yesterday morning on her arrival here from Stonington. She was just rounding from the East Into the North River, and when opposite Whitehall one of the boats of the Atlantic Ferry came suddenly out of her slip under a fill headway. To avoid a collision the Vanderbilt was obliged to shut off steam to permit the ferry-boat to go ahead of her,

A THIEF SHOT.---Yesterday morning, FREDRICK MANSFELT was arrested by Officer HOLBROOK, of the Third Precinct, for shooting a boy named JOHN OSGOOD, in Myrtle-avenue, Brooklyn. It appears that MANSFELT drivers a baker's cart, and OSGOOD has frequently stolen bread from him. Yesterday he caught OSOOD in the act, and fired at him, wounding him in the leg.

A FRNCH SKETCH OF THE QUEEN AND PRINCE ALBERT--The Queen, whom every one saw as Paris, has a lively eye, a bright complexion, and prompt gestures; she becomes animated while speaking, and shakes her marabouts, which gives her more of merry gracefulness than of Royal dignity, especially as her forms, rounded by a nascent embonpoint, are better ?? for tranquillity.

The weather is cold, with indications of snow. There was much rowdyism in the streets last night. Several shooting affrays took place, two of which proved fatal, one of them at Manayunk, and the other between colored parties, at the corner of Seventh and South streets. It is reported that a woman cut her husband's throat.

I return again to-day for a moment to the subject of the suppression of the journal La Presse, because it is still the event of the day, and because some developments in connection with other journals, show that there is a new movement on foot in the Democratic party. The impression produced by the suppression of this important Republican journal is as lively as when the fact first became known.

Tile French conception of popularity seems to resemble the Roman notion of peace, and the Russian idea of order. We are constantly assured that the Government of NAPOLEON III. is extremely popular in France, and those who repeat this asseveration fortify it by appealing to the " voice of the French people."

ONE CITY NOT AFFECTED BY THE PANIC.--It should be a cause of congratulations to certain of our cotemporaries who attribute all our financial troubles to overtrading and too much enterprise, to know that there is one great City which has not been at all affected by the panic.

The annual performance of the " Messiah" took place last evening at the Academy of Music, and attracted a fine audience, We were glad to notice that the upper tiers were completely filled, This may indicate a popular relish for oratorio music, or a curious desire to see a number of famous singers in the " customer of the period" --we will not presume to say which.

The Royal Mail steamship Persia, Capt. JUDKINS, from Liverpool at about 3 1/2 o'clock on the afternoon of the 12tH December, arrived here yesterday morning. The steamship City of Baltimore would not leave Liverpool on the 16th December, so that the first vessel of that line to leave Liverpool would be the Kangaroo, on the 13th of January.

BENEFITS OF EARLY IMPROVIDENCE.--A Canadian gentleman, Mr. ISAAC BUCHANAN, who has just been elected a member of the Provincial Parliament, has created a sensation among his constituents by declaring himself in favor of the form of government existing in the United States, and this avowal of republican sentiments did not in the least diminish his popularity.

AN INTERESTING CASE TO RAILROAD TRAVELERS.--A case of much interest to railroad travelers came up in the Police Court, before Judge CUSSING, yesterday afternoon. The question was freely discussed as to whether a person purchasing a through ticket for a certain day, has a right to stop at a way-station over night, and resume his journey the next morning on the same ticket or its equivalent check.

Here we are in the gayest city in the world,--gay in its white houses, its laughing skies, its dancing bay, its harlequin costumes its cheerful, careless inhabitants--the home of maccareni and punchinello. But let us first say farewell to Rome--the mournful, the eternal. And why is Rome mournful? It is not in the centre of favored Italy, upon the banks of the classic Tiber, and on the seven hills, each crowned with deathless fame?

I learn from the highest authority that the Post-master-General will, under the authority given him by the acts of 3rd March, 1845, and 3d March, 1851, declare the streets of Philadelphia, New-York and Boston post routes. This proclamation, it will be at once perceived, aims to abolish the various penny post-offices in those cities under the control of private individuals.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR: In the editorial columns of the Tribune of the 16th inst., I noticed and article upon the Census, which appears to have been written under a misapprehension of facts in regard to the manner in which the Census was taken, and as therefore tending to mislead the public as to real responsibility for its error.

On the 9th of November Sir COLIN CAMPHELL telegraphed from Oude to Lord CANNING at Calcutta, "All right at Lucknow." The corner-stone of the new Church, in course of erection for the worshippers at the late Broadway Tabernacle, at the corner of Thirty-Fourth-street and Sixth-avenue, was laid yesterday in the presence of some hundreds of spectators, many of whom were ladies.

THE JUVENILE MISSIONARY SOCIETY.--The sixth anniversary of the Juvenile Missionary Society connected with the North Presbyterian Church, was celebrated at Rev. Dr. HATFIELD'S church, corner of Ninth-avenue and Thirty-first-street yesterday morning. The church was filled with the children,--of whom there are at present about seven hundred connected with the church,--and their friends.

NATURAL DEATHS.--One of our country cotemporaries last week contained a leader under this startling head: "Are we a Nation of Suicides?" Most decidedly we should say not; and not only are we not a nation of suicides, but we believe that statistics will show we have fewer suicides than occur among any other people.
The steamer Northern Light arrived at 10 o'clock, last night, with two weeks' later news from California. Central America, and upwards of Two Millions of Dollars in treasure on freight.

I understand that the Persia brought dispatches announcing an earnest protest by the British Government against the Yrissari Convention, as an Infringement on the Clayton-Bulwer Treaty. This brings the Administration directly to the issue when they must recede, or practically vindicate the monroo doctrine, Dispatches on the subject will be sent to Mr. DALLAS by Wednesday's steamer.

WHITING.--In this City, on Sunday morning, Dec. 27, HENRY SWAN WHITING infant son of Augustus and Sarah S. Whiting, aged 13 months and 9 days. The friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend his funeral on Tuesday morning, at 10 o'clock A.M., from the residence of his PARENTS, No. 36th East 14th-st., corner University place, without further invitation.

ARREST OF HOTEL THIEVES.--Last night a gentleman stopping Crooks' Hotel in Chatham-street has his room entered and his pocket-book stolen, contain $43. He soon discovered the robbery, and suspicion at once rested upon the occupants of the adjoining room. Officers McKAY and BAROLAY, of the Sixth Precient, were called, and searched the suspected parties, but found nothing on them of suspicious character.

A letter to the New-Orleans Picayune, from the Utah Expedition camp on the Sweetwater, furnishes some interesting details. The writer says: "BRIGHAM YOUNG has been very anxious to secure the aid and cooperation of the Indian tribes of Utah and its vicinity in his present treasonable and rebellious opposition to the Government of the United States.

New-York is certainly a strange City. Probably there is not another community upon the face of the earth in which the public welfare is so uniformly sacrificed to private interest and to personal resentments as here. In Baltimore, Philadelphia, New-Orleans, providence, and nearly all the other considerable cities of the union, the Federal Government has erected the public buildings which it requires for its won business purposes:

If Santa Claus paid his visits on Christmas Eve without his fans, he had to borrow a good woolen muffler early on Christmas morning, wherewith to return to his mysterious home. For shortly after midnight the wind blew from the North, presaging a cold holiday.

HOW THE MONEY GOES.--We understand that over four hundred thousand dollars have already been paid by the Comptroller to the gentlemen appointed two years ago by the Legislature as "Commissioners of Record,"--and according to present appearances three or four times that sum will be added to the disbursement.

This Legislature is a slow team, but they threaten to apply the spurs to-day adjourn ?? die to-nigh. From present appearances, this will not be possible, as the Council are considerably behind the House in their business. In the evening session of yesterday, a series of concurrent resolutions reaffirming our devotion to the Topeka Constitution, as the choice of the people, was adopted in the Council,

The United States Mail steamship Northern Light, which arrived at this port last night, brings the important intelligence of the capture of General WALKER and the breaking up of his entire expedition by the American squadron under Commodore PAULDING.

The steamship Tennessee has arrived here with dates from the city of Mexico to the 17th inst. Another revolution broke out on the 10th inst. The garrison at Ta uyba had pronounced against the dissolving of the Congress, the overthrowing of the Constitution, and the declaring of COMONFORT Dictator. Vera Cruz followed the example, and it was expected the rest of the States would also do so.

General WILLAM WALKER reached town last evening! He come in the steamship Northern Light, having been forcibly interrupted in his fillibustering operations in Nicaragua by Commodore PAULDING, who sent a force of American sallos on shore and compelled his immediate sailors on shore and compelled his immediate surrender, with all his men, as prisoners of war.

LATEST THOUGHTS ON THE INDIAN MUTINY.--The new volume of the Cambridge Essays was issued in London on Friday afternoon, the 11th, the day the mail left. A., of that university, son of the late well-known Sir FOWELL BUXTON, and author of a biography of that eminent philanthropist.

THE LETTER LIST.-Postmaster FOWLER gives notice that the claims of newspapers for the letter list will be received, with the evidence, until Monday, Jan. 4, at 3 o'clock P. M.; and other evidence, In contradiction, until Monday, Jan. 11.

Rumors of a Battle--?r. Hurt's narrative of his Escape--Departure of Mormons from California. The California papers give currency to a rumor which has reached San Francisco from Portland, Oregon,--to the effect that a battle and occurred between the troops and the Mormons. in which 160 men of the Government forces were killed.

RICE, United States Commercial Agent at Hakodadi, to Captain TOOKER, of the Ontario, in which he communicates some facts of interest. He writes under date of Sept. 10: "The Japanese are becoming less exclusive.

The subject of widening the streets north of Chamyer-st. and below Canal-st., is attracting considerable attention. The improvements contemplated are: 1. The Widening of Reade-st., east of Broadway. for this it is understood the Commissioners have their repot. ot.

MYSTERIOUS MURDER ON LAKE ERIE, The Evening Post has the following: "A friend, who has just returned from the West, gives us a singular account of certain very strange circumstances, which are said to have occurred on the shore of Lake Eric. A lady and gentleman. formerly residents of this City, had been spending several months in St. Louis, Missouri. They were in easy circumstances, and had a large circle of friends.

--The Committee some time since appointed by the Jersey City Common Council to examiner into and report upon needed Amendments to the City Charter--and to whom was referred the amendments suggested by the Charter Convention--have reported that they found the work imposed upon them required more deliberation than they were able to bestow, and recommended to the Board the appointment of a Committee of citizens to perform the work.

Secretary ?? denounces the arrest of WALKER and his ?? by Commodore PAULDING as illegal, inexcusscie and unauthorized. Commodore PAULDING will doubtless be court-martialed immediately. The Commodore's instructions were intended only to direct him to prevent WALKER'S landing.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: While on a visit to Europe, some ten years ago, at the time when the Great Britain steamship went ashore on the northern coast of Ireland, it was my fortune to suggest a plan for getting her off the rocks, upon which she thumped for some three or more months, which was first published in the Carmaethen journal, a provincial paper,

CALIFORNIA GRAPES.--The last arrival from San Francisco puts us in possession of the following startling piece of agricultural intelligence: "In the neighborhood of Colomn some grape vines have produced this year three crops of grapes; and some pear trees three crops of pears. Upon a plum tree were some branches twelve feet long of this year's growth."

THE CUNNINGHAM FAMILY.--Our Paris correspondent, in a letter published a day or two since, mentioned a rumor that the daughters of Mrs. CUNNINGHAM were residing in that city ; and Galignani adds the, report that Mrs. C. herself is also there.

A LEGAL DECISION.-We clip the following from the Paris correspondent of the Memphis Daily Appeal: Tile son of a wealthy Jew banker In London became much attached to a young Christian, with whom his father opposed his union. When the son found that the father could not be induced to give his consent to the match, he concluded to marry without It.

The Duncan Mills at Franklin (N.J) are again in full operation, An order for cotton machinery to the amount of $30,000 has been received by the Rogers Locomotive Co., of Paterson. The machinery is for the Mississippi Penitentiary, the convicts ceing employed on that description of labor.

This morning, at 11 o'clock, General WILLIAM WALKER surrendered himself, in compliance with the terms of his parole, to Marshal RYNDERS, at the office in College-place. Messrs., T. F. MEAGHER and MALCOLN CAMPBELL appeared as WALKER'S legal advisers. The General, accompanied by his friend, General WHEAT, drove down to the Marshal's office in a carriage.

ARTESIAN WELL-BORING IN TEXAS.-- Hon. FORBES BRITTON has introduced into the Texas Legislature a bill incorporating the "Western Artesian Well Company, and to promote internal improvements between the Nueces and Rio Grande," It gives the right to bore artesian wells on any of the routes from Corpus Chrisil to Brownsville, from Corous Chirsil to Rio Grande City and Roma,

A REBUKE TO GOVERNOR WALKE.-We naturally expect , the Richmond South and the Charleston Mercury to flare up at governor WALKER'S candor and national sprit, but hardly expected to find a New-England Whig organ reproving the ex-Governor for his desertion of the interests of the South. h.

Very few reputations, in this age of historical skepticism, can be regarded as established beyond all chance of controversy. German genius has for years been devoted to the task of proving HOMER to have been a myth; and MISS BACON is even now engaged in dispelling the illusion which attributes to SHAKESPEARE the authorship of the immortal dramas for which he has thus far had credit throughout the world.

MENDELSSOHN UNION.--This energetic young Society opened its fourth season at Mozart Hall last evening, with a performance of Moses in Egypt. The Moses is a Sacred Opera, rarely given complete and still more rarely performed by an amateur association.

BOARD OF ALDERMEN. The Board of Aldermen met last evening. President Glanoy in the chair. Alderman CORWIN offered a resolution directing the Committee on Laws and Applications to the Legislature: to memoristize the Legislature for the passage of an act to enable the members of the Common Connell for 1857 to receive pay for their services. The resolution was adopted.

A DARING BURGLARY IN BROOKLYN.--About 3 o'clock on Sunday morning, grocery store No. 15 Atlantic-street, kept by FREDERICK W. MEYERS, was entered by two burglars, by means of false keys, through the front door. They stole $162, and a gold watch and chain. The proprietor was asleep under the counter at the time the burglars entered, and was aroused by their choking him.

HORRID SPECTACLE AT AN EXECUTION-- GREENBURY O. MULLINIX was executed at Greencastle, Ind., on Friday last, for the murder of his wife. There was a large attendance from the county, although the execution took place within the walls of the prison. and was only witnessed by a few.

Nabia-Hagar Silsibs, the Rock of the Chain--Egyptian Travel. EGYPT, March. Below Assouan the aspect of the Nile changes. Nubia, I have before remarked, is very narrow. The mountains rise abruptly from the river's edge, and the cultivated land on each side is but a few rods in width.

NOVEL ATTACHMENT.-One of those singular cases of attachment which we occasionly hear of between animals of the most dissimilar natures, exists between a pig belonging to Mr. JOHN GROVER, of this city, and a half-grown cat. Shortly after purchasing the pig and placing him in his new quarters, a kitten less than two weeks old, belonging to a litter living in the loft above the sty, accidentally fell into the porker's premises.

Commodore PAULDING'S action in the arrest of WALKER is disavowed and denounced by the Government at Washington, and it is believed that he will immediately be tried by Court-Martial for violation of his instructions.

On Sunday evening, Mr. BEECHER gave notice of his intention to apply to the Trustees of his Church for the construction of a Baptistery in the building, after the manner of the Baptist denomination. He explained the immediate occasion of this proposed innovation upon Congregational customs. Numbers of persons had applied for membership, to whom immersion seemed the truest baptism.

From the Cincinnati Gazette. One of the most agreeable reunions, under peculiar circumstances, which has ever occurred in our city, took place at the time residence of NICHOLAS LONGWORTH, Esq., on Pike-street, last evening. It was the celebration of the Fiftieth Anniversary of the Wedding Day of the host and hostess.

The Legislature adjourned at a late hour last night and the members have gone home. The following bills were passed: A bill submitting the Lecompton swindle on the 11th of January, A bill for the organization of the Kansas Territorial Militia. A bill for the punishment of fraudulent voting and for the protection of the ballot-box.

We hear from Washington that the Administration does not approve of the arrest of WALKER by Commodore PAULDING. On the contrary, the Secretary of State is said to be open and vehement in denouncing the act as illegal and unauthorized.

From the San Francisco Herald. We had, yesterday, an interview with Mr. P. McD. COLLINS, who arrived in this city a few days ago, having traveled over land from St. Petersburg to the month of the Amoor River. The journey occupied exactly one year. Twelve months ago Mr. COLLINS left St. Petersburg, traveled from thence to Moscow, by railroad and, from thence through Siberia, in sledges and telegas, to Chetah,

The British brig B. K. Reese, Capt. SANDEN, from Demerara, bound to Baltimore, with a cargo of hides and $11,000 In specie, went ashore two miles below Currlluck on Sunday night last. A steam-tug has been sent from Norfolk to her assistance, The brig was built In Bermuda; 28 years old, and of a small value ; insured In Demerara ; cargo Insured at the same place.

IN BROADWAY. At 12 1/2 yesterday morning, a tire broke out in the cigar store BENOIT VIELX, No. 421 Broadway. The damage from fire and water was about $150, which is covered by insurance of $1,500 in the Bridgeport Insurance Company; $1,250 in the Mechanics and Tradesmen's Insurance Company. The fire extended to the millinery store of Mrs. BURKE in Canal-street damage $100-fully insured.

LIEUTENANT BEALE'S EXPEDITION--THE PACIFIC WAGON ROAD,--On Monday, Nov. 9. Lieut. E. F. BEALE, in charge of the Survey of the Pacific Wagon Road, arrived in Los Angeles, accompanied by Lieut. C. E. THORNBURN, U. S. N., the Superindent of the Topographical Department.

Alexander H. Pomcroy vs, The New-York and New Haven Railroad Company.--NELSON, C. J.--The question presented upon the pleadings is, whether or not the Court has jurisdiction to hear and determine the matters in controversy.

LABELING THE TELEGRAPH.--Mr. EZEA C. SEAMAN, a writer on political economy of some reputation, has discovered a cause of the late "panic" which has escaped the attention of all other investigators into the origin of the great financial revulsion.

The Womens' Protective Emigration Society of this City, organized about a month since, has opened its rooms at No. 20 Canal-street, for the reception of destitute working-women who desire to go West. A party of forty or fifty young women, who have been taken under the protection of the Society, left the City yesterday. in charge of ladies of the Society, for homes in Illinois and other States.

GRIFFIN, left New-Orleans on the 20th Instant, at 8 A. M., and arrived at Havana at sunrise on the 23d. ARREST OF A THIEF FROM PATERSON--Officer CLARK, of Jersey-City, yesterday, upon the arrival of the Paterson train at the Erie Railroad Depot, arrested a man named THOMAS STENOE, charged with stealing a watch, gold locket, snuff-box and three port-monnales from a gentleman named THOMAS COKELY, in Paterson.

DRESSING MILLSTONES.--The surfaces of all flour-grinding stones are grooved over by means of chisels, so as to leave a large number of sharp edges to assist in the fine pulverization of the grain; and when these edges become dulled from use, it is necessary to renew them by regrooving.

NEWS FROM THE MARQUZSAS.--The British steamship Vizen, which arrived at Honolulr on 21st october, nineteen days from nukahiva, Marquesas, reported that the French authorities at the Islands had had some difficulty with the natives in the celebrated valley of Typee, whore the cannibals desired to sacrifice a woman on the occnsion of some of their heathen orgies.

Gen. WALKIN arrived here to-night. He was resolved here, and at all the towns on the road, With great enthusiasm. Marshal RYNDERS repudiates the ?? of holding him as a prisoner. Capt. ENGLE delivered his dispatches from ?? to-day, and they were considered in Cabinet meeting. Secretary FLOYD is especially earnest in his opposition to the efforts to defeat the fillibusters.

That something is to be done with the East India Company seems t o be tolerably certain . Just what that something may eventually turn out to be, nobody in England has yet ventured distinetly to foretell, and the language of the Royal Speech on this head is more that usually vague and insignificant.

COMMODORE PAULING AND THE PRESIDENT.--The devotion of Mr. BUCHANAN to the strictest forms of the law is notorious. In his first Presidential Message he braved the sympathetic indignation of the whole fillibustering community, and branded the expeditions of General WALKER with the most emphatic phrases that the language of condemnation can supply.

' There are two ways of robbing the public, one of which is by taking money out of the Treasury, and the other, and by far the most serious and reprehensible, is by injuring the business facilities of the City whereby property is depreciated in value and the burden of taxation is increased.

SECTION 1. Continues the Corporation, now existing, and known by the name of "The Mayor, Aldermen and Commonalty of the City of New York" as a body politic and corporate under the same name. SEC. 2 Vests the legislative power of said Corporation in the Aldermen and Councilmen.

THE DELTA PSI FRATERNITY. --An oration. entitled "Our Nation's Pride," was delivered before this Society last evening, at Mozart Hall, by ORLANDO H. MORRIS, Esq. Commerce and literature, he held, were the genit which presided over American institutions, and plumed the wings of the national bird.

WALKER AT NEW-ORLEANS.--The New-Orleans Delta denounces the removal of F. H. CLACK, Esq., from the office of District-Attorney, for his alleged remissness in suffering General WALKER to take his departure for Nicaragua. The Della Asserts that this is not the true reason for his removal, and that as long ago as in May last Senator SLIDELL offered the place to another person.

THE ADRIATIC.---Extract of letter from Capt. L., B. MACKINSON, of the Royal Navy, dated of Liverpool, Thursday, Dec. 3, 1857, on board the Adriatic: "I am delighted with this magnificent ship; although we have been obliged to make the greatest portion of this passage under half-steam, I feel confident that she will eventually cross the Atlantic in twenty hours less than any other vessel afloat.

A HERESY IN MASSACHUSETTS.--ALPHEUS S. NICKERSON was announced to be ordained pastor of the Congregational Church in North Woburn, on Wednesday, last week. An ecclesiastical council was held the same day to examine Mr. NICKERSON to ascertain the soundness of his faith--as is usual on such occasions--when it was found that Mr. NICKERSON believed in the salvation of infants. His doctrine was that those who had committed no sin would not be eternally damned.

WALKER is recognized as only the accidential leader of the anti-Nicaraguan movement. The distinquished men under whose auspices the late Expedition was dispatched have no confidence in his capacity. They say he has perserverance, and that sort of romantic attractiveness of character which enables him to collect a company of adventurers and make a sudden descent, but he wanting in the qualities requistite for the government of an army and the conduct of a compaign.

Nothing could be more emphatic than the language in which the President, Secretary of State, and Secretary of the Navy protest that Commodore PAULDING greatly exceeded his instructions in invading Nicaragua, and arresting Gen. WALKER and his band of "emigrants." There are many who persist in believing that, after all, the has only done what he was secretly authorized to do.

The people of Niearagua are very much to be pitied. They occupy a position on the world's surface which exposes them to the interference of all the world with their domestic affairs, while it commands for them no sincere interest and no unaffected alliance in any quarter whatsoever.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--To-night BEETHOVEM'S celebrated opera, "Fidelio." will be given, with, Madamc ANNA CARADOLL, the new prima donna, as the heroine. Madame BERKEL, Mr. FORMES and Mr. PICANESER are also in the cast. A German musical society will assist in the choruses.

To the Editor of the New-york Times: Two successive correspondents of a City paper find fault with the report of the Conmmittee of Aldermen, recommending the southern corner of the Park for the New-York Post.Office, and ask why the City " should spoil the only green anti beautiful spot be. low Union.squarc, when hundreds of better places might be found-the Five Points for instance ?"

From the Charleston Mercury. The North has not got the legal control of Kansas. The Democratic party is not safe from defection at the North, and Mr. BUCHANAN stands forth in favor of its admission, whether or not abolitionized. The South may cause trouble if Kansas is rejected. Three States stand ready to resist. At this juncture Mr. DOUGLAS fulminates against the position of the President.

Mr. Samuel King, of Rising Sun, Indiana, died very suddenly on Tuesday. He became involved in financial difficulties, and his creditors in New-York came on with large claims and closed his store, On Tuesday he rowed his children across the creek to school, and returning, remarked to a neighbor that it was the last time he should cross.

Michael McMahon was put on trial charged with passing counterfeit money. The evidence tended to show that he passed two had half dollars upon an arrested other counterfeit coin was found on him. The Jury found him guilty and the Judge sentenced him to three years imprisonment in the State Prison and a dollar fine,

THE AMERICAN CHAPEL IN PARIS.--Galignam of the 10th inst. contains the following: "We are requested to state that the American Chapel in he rue de Berri will be completed to-morrow, on which day a payment of 15,000 frames will be due. If this cannot be met, possession of the building will not be given.

VISIT OF CALHOUN'S WINDOW TO US TOWN.-- The venerable window of the immortal CALHOUN visited the tomb of her husband, on Sunday last, at St. Philip's Church, after the congregation had dispersed, accompanied by one of the elder members if the church and vestry and two ladies.

El Restaurador gives dreadful accounts of depredations committed by the Indians in Nave-Leon and Coabuba. Several families on the northern borders of those States have been murdered, and a great number of ranches have been thoroughly stripped of everything in the way of stock and produce. Five men and three women were going from San Nicolas to Parras with horses and cattle, who were attacked and murdered.

Leavenworth, Kansas, advices of the 25th inst. give the vote of that city as 238 for slavery, and 9 against. Much excitement prevailed, there being many Missourians present, some of whom voted, after swearing in their votes. The form of eath administered was, "Are you at this instant an inhabitant of this Territory ?" Several Missourians had been arrested, and Judge LECOMPTZ had issued writs of habeas corpus for their release.

The following Record of the Fillibustering operations of General WILLIAM WALKER in Nicaragua, rom the time of his first expedition, in the early part of 1855, to the breaking-up of the second expedition during the present month, will prove useful for reference: 1855. May 4--WALKER leaves San Francisco for Nicaragua, with a force of 82 men.

A complimentary dinner was given to Senator SLOAN of the Second District, at the Pierrepont House, Brooklyn, Monday evening last. KINGS COUNTY BOARD OF SUPERVISORS.--An adjourned meeting of this Board was hold yesterday afternoon.

THE SONS OF NEW-ENGLAND ARROAD.--the scattered sons of New-England appear to have enjoyed the home festival of Forefathers' Day with remarkable zest, Banquets, speeches, toasts and orations were given in honor of the day at Montreal, Charleston, Chicago and other principal cities--not to mention the smaller township gatherings. At Montreal, Rev. ASA D. Smith, of this City, delivered on oration.
