CORRECTION.--We have been informed on good authority that Dr. STORES, in inviting Rev. Dr. HUNTINGTON to preach in his church, as stated in yesterday's TIMES, did not regard him as a "Unitarian." We have received, and have been requested to publish, sundry extracts, from his writings for the purpose of showing that he is not one in his religious belief.

From the Fifeshire (Scotland) Advertiser. The firm of Messrs. J. A. DENNISTOUN WA founded about seventy years ago by JAMES and ALEXANDER DENNISTOUN. ALEXANDER died at a comparatively early age, and took little interest in the business. Both brothers were natives of Catnpsie, their father being a farmer at Newmiln, about a mile from the village. JAMES left home when about 12 or 13 years of age, to push his fortune in Glasgow.

BUSINESS IN RHODE ISLAND.--The Providence Journal publishes a detailed statement of the effects of the panic on manufacturers in Rhode Island The number of cotton-mills which stopped entirely counted up a total of 502,201 spindles, and employed 9,661 operatives, all of whom were thrown out of employment. The cotton-mills still running number 216, 828 spindles, and employ 4,070 workmen.

From Parton's Life of Duty. BURR AND VANDERLYN. The interest which Colonel BURR took in the education of youth has been before alluded to. He always had a protege in training, upon whose culture he bestowed unwearied pains and more money than he could always afford. The story of VANDERLYN, that most distinguished protege he ever had, was one which he often related in these later years.

The result of the elections in Upper Canada, so far, is unfavorable to the Ministry, and in Lower Canada favorable. The elections will all be over in a few days, when Parliament will assemble Immediately. The wife of JOHN A. McDONALD, Premier, died at Kingston to-day.

CHARLES W. BARHYDT, of the firm of CHARLES W. and GILES S. BARHYDT, grocers of this city, was found dead in his store this morning about 7 o'clock, stabbed to the heart and with one of his breast. A pistol was found near him with the barrel bursted, also a dirk covered with blood. An Inquest was held on the body, and a verdlet was rendered that his death was caused by his own hands.

THE ARREST OF WALKER.--The Journal of Commerce justices Commodore PAULDING in his seizure of WALKER and says: "It is certain that, had Commodore PAULDING refused or hesitated to act as he did, the commander of the British squadron at Greytown would have taken the initiative, and used forcible means, if necessary, to compel WALKER to surrender and quit the territory of Nicaragua.

Adoption of the City-Hall Park Site for a New Post-Office--The Mayor Elect to Receive his Friends in the Governor's Room on New-Year's Day. The Board of Aldermen met last evening, president CLANCY in the chair.

THE MURDERER STROUBE.--The Hew-Haven Register, of the 28th, says ALBERT STROCBE, the West-field murderer, has been traced to that city. He was first seen at a boarding-house at Meriden, on Tuesday last, where he represented himself as a shipwrecked sailor, and showed a would on his left wrist, which he said he received in the shipwreck.

The Austrian Empire, in the person of its Consul at this port, Mr. LOOSEY, yesterday appeared in the United States Circuit Court of New-York, to prove that it had been falsely accused by the New-York Express of countenancing counterfeiters. The case was not concluded, and the proceedings, were some what confused by the withdrawal of Mr. McKEON from his station,

A NEW "TOBACCO QUESTION."--The Important question of the possibility of poisoning by cigars impregnated with arsenic has been raised by the recent death in France, of a priest, named BOTTARO, supposed to have been poisoned by another priest. An investigation has been undertaken, to ascertain whether it be possible of probable that arsenicated cigars can cause death by the inspiration of their smoke impregnated with volatilized arsenic??

Mr. STEWART, the dry goods merchant, understand very well the manner of throwing dust in the eyes of the public, when any special object is to be accomplished thereby. Having a post-Office site of his own, he is naturally opposed to the location of that establishment upon the lower angle of the Park.

The Salaries of Street Commissioner, Mr. Devlin, and his Deputy. Mr. Former, Overdrawn under Oath and Refunded. The Board of Aldermen met ?? evening. President CLANCY in the Chair and a very large lobby attendance. The Committee on Salaries and Offices

Mme. CHARLES LAFFITTK, wife of the banker, from whom she has been judicially separated since April, 1847, subscribed on the 5th of January, 1853, an authorization to Baron DE SALIGNAC FENELON, captain in the Lancers of the Imperial Guard, to receive out of arrears of an annual allowance which her husband made her, 26,00 francs, in payment of money lent.

The seizure and return of General WALKER has aroused a fierce excitement in his favor at New-Orleans and Mobile. Large public meetings are held, and several hundred men are already enrolled for a renewed expedition under his direction. The Administration would do well either espouse openly the cause of WALKER,

The public mind is seriously excited, just now, by the contemplation of a Post-Office individuals, who wish to pass for "levers of nature," gag about "vandallim," "pure air," "green sward," "Principles of beauty," etc., etc., etc., etc., and have whined themselves into a wish-washy state which is likely to result in their disappearance through the first spout they come near. Well, these spoons of sentiment are half right.

By the arrival at this port last evening of the United States mail steamship Arago, we receive four days' later intelligence from Europe. The Financial news from abroad offers nothing worthy of special comment. Affairs were much the same as at last advices. There had been further failures in Great Britain: in the North of Europe the crises continues with very little change.

The Arago, Capt. LINES, from Havre and Southampton on the 56th December, arrived at this port last evening. The Niagara, from Boston, arrive I at Liverpool on the 14th. The British Parliament adjourned its sittings on the 12th, until the 4th of February next, the royal assent having been previously given to the Bank Issues Indemnity bill.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR: Your admirably-written theatrical criticisms have convinced the that in your the Drama has a sincere and discriminating friend. This fact emboldens me to offer through your columns a suggestion which I feel assured would be attended with beneficial results to those managers who would give it a trial.

The steamship Tennessee has arrived from Vera Cruz with dates from the City of Mexico to the 17th inst. A revolution had taken place in Mexico, and ComONFORT been proclaimed Dletator. The Congress of the Republic has been dissolved, and the City of Mexico Is In arms:.

The Board met yesterday, Mayor Wood alone being absent. The minutes of the last day's meeting having been read and confirmed. Mr. BOWEN submitted the following rules and regulations for the government of surgeons of the Police force, which were adopted: RULES AND REGULATIONS FOR THE GOVERNMENT OF THE SURGEONS UP THE METROPOLITAN POLICE.

Deputy Superintendent CARPENTER yesterday received word from various sources that a prize fight would take place during the afternoon between MORRISSEY and JOHN HEENAN, better known as "the Benicia Boy," About 12 o'clock the following order was given by the Deputy Superintendent: "By order of the Deputy call at the Fifth Ward Station-house;

The State officers elect are all in the city. The Comptroller keeps in Mr. PHELPS as Deputy; appoints E. SLOAN, of Albany, and HENRY EVANS, of Buffalo, Tax clerks; restores E. A. BARBER, removed by the present Comptroller, and keeps in all the other clerks for the present, except the Insurance clerk, Mr. SKEELS, whose desk is offered to Mr. CHAMBERLAIN, of Jefferson County.

The tradesmen of New-Bedford held a meeting on Monday, when Mr. PARDON DEVOLL reported a series of resolutions, in substance recommending the adoption of a cash system as a general rule, and where any exception should be made, such accounts to be considered collectable semi-annually, on the 1st of January and of July. The resolutions were adopted unanimously.

The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Middlesex Mills was held to-day. The Investigating Committee made a lengthy report, which was unanimously adopted. The Committee recommend the company to ask a reasonable extension from its creditors, a reorganization of its management, and the resumption of manufacturing as fast as it can be done profitably, believing that the business, with economical management, can be profitably carried on.

Roman augurs are by no means the only men who must have found it difficult to look in each others' faces without laughing General CASS, who resembles the augur in other respects as well, must have felt the impalse, when Marshal RYNDERS, to whom not long ago he sent instructions to prevent the departure of fillibusters, introduced General WALKER to

In the midst of the fillibuster excitement we have another element turning up to plague the Administration and ? its embarrassments. "Extremes meet,"--and Nicaragua at one end and Kansas at the other, rush upon us with startling events at the same instant. The intelligence that the Constitution of Kansas has been ? with the Pro-Slavery clause is a bomb-shell which the Administration did not anticipate.

MY DEAR SIR: Agreeably to my note of the 2d inst., I have the pleasure of inclosing the narration of what passed between Mr. RUSH and the Provisional Government as to the recognition of that government and his visit to the Hotel de Ville. Thursday, 24th,--On the 24th February, 1848, the King abdicated in the morning, in favor of the Comtede Paris; the same day, at 2 o'clock P.M.,

Congress reassembles next Monday, and as a matter of course the Kansas question will again command their attention. The official returns of the late election will probably reach Washington within a week, and will show that the Constitution with Slavery received a majority of the votes cast.

The Neerology of 1857 is a crowded list of distinguished names. Statesmen, Jurists, warriors, literary men, famous explorers, scholars and sasans are among the dead of the year. Science loses the active zeal and indomitable energy of KANE, the industry of Huan MILLER, the patient study of ANDREW URX, and the research of SCORESBY and BEECHRY.

A CURIOUS MERCANTILE AFFAIR IN BOSTON,-- A firm dealing largely in the manufacture and sale of ready made clothing in Milk-street, is now suffering embarrassments of an unusual nature. The circumstances of the case so far as we are able to learn them, are these : The firm consists of three partners. The senior partner has been in the business?? eight or nine years, and has a capital in the concern of $32,000.

Before Hon. Justice Davies, Orrin Terry vs. The Mayor, , of New-York. --Yesterday Mr. Joseph Blunt moved for a perpetual injunction, restraining the Corporation from conveying to the Roman Catholic Orphan Asylum some 32 lots of land fronting on Fifty-first-street, and the Asylum from receiving it. It will be remembered that a similar motion was made before judge DAVIES a few

The indignation meeting called for this evening to discuss Nicaraguan affairs was adjourned until Saturday, on account of the non-publicity, of the call, notwithstanding several thousand persons were in attendance. The adjourned meeting takes place on Saturday evening. The enlistment is still going on, one hundred and thirty-two men having offered themselves to-day.

No. 13.--Christ Church of Philadelphia vs. The County of Philadelphia. Justice CAMPBELL delivered the opinion of the Court, dismissing the writ of error for want of jurisdiction. No. 8.--Wm. Wynn vs. C. B. Morris etal. Error to the Supreme Court of Arkansas. Justice CATBON delivered the opinion of the Court, dismissing the writ for want of jurisdiction.

The Kansas affair has been entirely supplanted by the new trouble in which the president is so unexpectedly involved by the rash, precipitate and unauthorized proceedings of Commodore PAULDING in the arrest of General WALKER within the territory of Nicaragua, and the breaking up of his enterprise. This incident threatens to kindie a new disscusion in the ranks of the Democracy.

General WALKER'S present intention is to proceed to New-Orleans and challenge a trial. The indications are that no efforts will be made from here to secure his prosecution, and that it will not be attempted even.

BROOKLYN HEIGHTS. GENTLEMEN: I have received from you a singularly beautiful inkstand, for which I desire to return you my hearty thanks, it is valuable as a more work of art. Indeed, in the line of ornamental useful articles it is by far the most chaste and beautiful bronze that I have ever seen it will be a perpetual feast to my eye.

Of the LUILES murder, the Rochester American says: "All the rumors of confessions made by in?? STOUT or his sister are without foundation. It is not even known by the District-Attorney whether either of the accused parties desires to make a confession, and if it is to be made upon condition that some promise of favor shall be given, it is very questionable whether it ought to be received at all."

The year 1857 is going out with us rather gloomily, in every way. It is dismal in the item of weather, and pleasant in no other respect. Down to and through Christmas, the weather was good. Then we have had snow enough to make slush, but not enough to make sleighing. Sunday it thawed a little, and yesterday a great deal, so that we paddled about the streets, and had gratuitous shower-baths from the roofs.

By Letters to Ellwood Walter, Esq., Secretary of the Board of Underwriters. PORTSMOUTH, Tuesday, Dec. 24. The schooner C. G. Waterbury, of New-York, (previously reported.) went ashore at 10 o'clock on the evening of the 21st. The wind was blowing a heavy gale from the southeast at the time. She lies head on near the undertow. 300 bbls, molasses, and 3 hhds, sugar have been landed.

My attention has been called to several articles in the opposition papers, making allusions to a letter which I addressed to the Tammany Hall Committee, In reply to their invitation to address the meeting of the 23d, inst., which letter I believe has not been published. The reference made in those articles to my position on the Kansas question, seems to made it necessary that position should be distinctly understood.

Johnson County, Kansas, gives 2,000 majority for Slavery. Thirteen hundred votes were cast at Oxford. Wyandotte gives 14 majority against Slavery. Governor DENVER had given up the Territorial arms to the militia, Various rumors were in circulation relative to affairs at Fort Scott, but none of them are of an authoritative character.

Mr. DENVER arrived here last week, and will enter upon the discharge of his official duties to-day. The people seem very much prejudiced against him because he comes here at this time to supersede Mr STANTON., From what I can learn of him I am sure that the President has made nothing by the exchange, for it is understood that Mr. Donver indorses all the official acts of both Gov. Walker and Secretary Stanton.

We need scarcely call attention to tile communication split to the Board of Aldermen last evening by the Corporation Counsel. It has a two-fold object-to meet certain censures that have been directed against the conduct of his department, and to expose the shameless manner in which the City Treasury has been defrauded by Mr. DEVLIN and his deputy Street Commissioner.

MANN-ROOME.-In this City, on Wednesday, Dec, 30. at St. Peter's Church. by Rev. Alfred B. Beach, D. D., DAVID MANN, of Troy, N.Y., to MARY E. ROOME of this City. YEOMANS-COLE.-In this City, on Thursday, Dec. 24, be Rev. J. W. Beach, ABRAM J. YEOMANS to MISS MARTHA A. COLE. Both of this City.

I give you the following account of the relief of Lucknow, as described by a lady, one of the rescued party: On every side death stared us in the face; no human skill could avert it any longer. We saw the moment approach when we must bid farewell to earth. Yet without feeling that unutterable horror which must have been experienced by the unhappy victims at Cawnpore.

The opinion has been expressed that General CASS has been led into a disavowal of Commodore PAULDING'S action with reference to General WALKER and his associates by the fear that this violation of the Nicaraguan soil, would clash with the principle asserted by the government in KOSZTA'S case, touching the jurisdiction of a government over its own subjects on foreign territory. The cases are not parallel.

PALMER.--In this City, on Thursday morning, Dec. 31, after a long and painful illness, JOHN D. PALMHB, in the 59th year of his age. The relatives and friends of the family, also Strangers Refuge Lodge. No. 4, I. 0 of 0. F.. are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, on Sunday, at 1 o'clock P. M., from his late residence, No. 201 Mott at., without further invitation.

The R. M. steamship Niagara, from Liverpool on the 19th ult, with three days' later news from Europe, and now fully due at Halifax, had not been heard from at a late hour last night. A heavy westerly gale was blowing off the coast, and the weather was otherwise unfavorable.

Those who mean to moralize for themselves the closing of one chapter in the book of human life, and the opening of another, will have done so already in the watches of last night; for all others the vicarious moralizing of the Press would have but little charm, and would bleed them less profit.

The tone of the Administration, relative to Commodore PAULDING, is materially modified, Captain E?OLE has received permission to delay his return to Aspinwall until the 20th of January. Commodore PAULDING will probably carry Minister LAMAR to Central America before his return, and then come home in his own ship, whose cruise will then be ended--thus relieving the Commodore without conveying a mortifying rebuke.

By the steamship Tennessee, Capt. FORBES, arrived this morning from Vera Cruz the 21st inst., we have most important news from the Mexican Republic. The new Constitution has been over-turned and done away with forever; the Federal Councils have been broken up and dispersed; COMONFORT declared sole and absolute Dictator,

There is no country in the world where more genuine enthusiasm exists for that noblest of all quadrupeds, the horse, than in the United States; yet all our equine literature being derived from Englard, we very naturally look upon that country as the paradise of horses, and undervalue our own achievements in the breeding of horseflesh.

The last meeting of the present Board of Education was held on Wednesday night at their rooms in Grand-street, ANDREW H. GAMES, Esq., President, in the Chair. The minutes of the previous meeting were read and approved. A communication was received from the school officers of the Twentieth Ward, asking for a female evening school. Referred to the committee on Evening Schools.

Our London Correspondent, writing under date Tuesday, Dec. 15, furnishes an interesting extract of a letter, received by the overland mail the day preceding, written by a gentleman possessed of the best possible means and opportunities for forming a sound opinion on what he speaks of, being himself personally engaged in the expedition in an eminent (civil) capacity.

The Bank of England is recovering a strong position with a rapidity that is almost marvelous, considering the state of weakness to which it had been reduced by the crists. On the 11th of November tile reserve of notes amounted only to [Pound]950,000, having stood at 6,014,160 on the 26th of September.

The Board of Aldermen for 1857 held their final meeting yesterday, commencing at 1 P. M. and adjourning at 8 P. M. There was a large lobby attendance during the entire session, and much interest was evinced in the proceedings soon after President CLANCY had called the Board to order. The Clerk, D. T. Valentine, Esq., was authorized to prepare the usual Corporation Manual for 1856, and $1,500 were appropriated to pay the expenses hereof.

The ship Hibernia, of London from Quebec, for Belfast, was water-logged and abandoned Dec. 6. Crow landed here by the Hermann. By Telegraph to Elwood Walter, Esq. NORFOLK, Wednesday, Dec. 30. The clipper ship Grey Eagle, of Philadelphia, from City Point for Rio, put in here dismasted.

On Monday at noon the government of the City changes hands, the old officers step out and tile new ones step in, with as little external ceremony as any private citizen displays in taking possession of a new house. The chief executive officer of the City took the precaution of saving his predecessor the trouble of swearing him in, as has usually been done,

Nos. 51 and 52.--Edwin M. Chaffee, Trustee, etc., vs. Nathaniel Hayward, and H. H. Day vs. National Hayward. Justice TANBY delivered the opinion of the Court, overruling the motion to dismiss the cases. No number.--The United States vs. Sanchez de Pacheco. Motion to docket and dismiss the case argued.

The following letter from the Secretary o the Navy to the Directors of the Trans-Atlantic Telegraph Company shows that our Goverment is disposed to continue its aid to that great enterprise: NAVY DEPARTMENT. Dec. 30, 1857. GENTLEMEN: Your communication of the 23d inst. has been received.

PASSED DIVIDENDS.--New-England capitalists must suffer severely this Winter from the suspension of dividends by nearly all the great manufacturing corporations in which so much money has been invested. Many a family will be deprived of their sole incomes by this financial passover of dividends.

The Newark Mercury of the 30th says: "A man named JOHN H. STAGG, about 65 years of age, who came to this city on Saturday evening, in the Philadelphia train and stopped at the Washington House, near the Market-street Depot, died at that place at an early hour yesterday morning, from the effects of laudanum. The deceased was very respectably connected, and the body was taken in charge by friends from New-York."

MR. THALBERG.--It is announced, in one of those extraordinary cards, for which Mr. ULLMANN is celebrated, that Mr. THALBERG will make his last appearance before a New-York audience on Saturday next. With an ingeniousness too seldom found in an impressario, Mr. ULLMAN gracefully acknowledges the obligations he has been under to the renowned pianist, and confesses that without his assistance the operatic season would have come to a disastrous end.

PLAIN TALK.--The Richmond South thus expresses its opinion of the sincerity and honesty of those Northern men who pride themselves upon being the special friends of the South: "So Mr. DOUGLAS has showed his cloven foot to the South at last, I never believed he was wholefooted. All that he has ever done has been to cajole the South to choose between evils, to take the best she can get,

IN VARICK-STREET.--The alarm of the fire for the Third District, about 7 o'clock last evening, was ?? by the explosion of a camphone-lamp in the premises of the second floor of building No. 112 Varick-street. The furniture caught fire and was damaged to the extent of about $200. No insurance.

A NEW COUNTERFEIT.--On Wednesday afternoon, an attempt was made in the Eighteenth ward to pass a new counterfeit, just issued. Information of the issue Broome-street, and theme the fact was telegraphed to every Station-house in the City, and a description of the bill given. The bill is a $5 counterfeit on the Onondaga Bank, of Syracuse, N.Y.

By the reformed Charter our new City Government commences its existence on the first Monday of January, at noon, and not on the first day of the year as appears to be generally supposed. We get rid of the old Common Council, however, to-day, and we shall enjoy a brief interregnum without any organized Government at all.

SIR : I have ordered Capt. ENGLE to proceed to Washington, and place in your hands the dispatches I have intrusted to his care. Any information that I may have omitted can be communicated by him. I have the honor to recommend Capt. ENGLE to your high consideration as an officer who has no superior in the Navy for skill and intelligence in the command of his ship.

The steamship Philadelphia, from New-York ?? Havana, arrived to-day. She brings the California mails of the 5th inst. JOHN TABOR, Esq., editor of ER Nicaraguense, was a passenger. He has consented to open the meeting to-morrow evening with a history of the capture of General WALKER and the following events.

The following letter form the Secretary of the Navy to the Directors of the Trans-Atlantic Telegraph Company shows that our Government is disposed to continue its aid to that great enterprise. NAVY DEPARTMENT, Dec. 30, 1857. GENTLEMEN: Your communication of the 23rd inst. has been received.

One woe doth tread upon another's heel Indications multiply that President BUCHANAN will be under the necessity of hunting up still another Governor for Kansas. We copied a paragraph from a Missouri letter in the St. Louis Republican yesterday, complaining bitterly of Gen. DENVER'S appointment.

I give you the following account of the relief of Lucknow, as described by a lady, one of the rescued party: On every side death stared us in the face; no human skill could avert it any longer. We saw the moment approach when we must bid farewell to earth, yet without feeling that unutterable horror which must have been experienced by the unhappy victims at Cawnpore.

MANN--ROOXE--In this City, on Wednesday, Dec, 21 at St. Peter's Church, by Rev. Alfred B. Beach, D. D., DAVID MANN, of Troy, N.Y., to MARY E. ROOXE, of this City. YEOMANS--COLE--In this City, on Thursday, Dec. 24, by Rev. J. W. Beach, ABRAM J. YEOMANS to Miss MARTHA A. COLE. both of this City.

The Board of Aldermen for 1857 held their final meeting yesterday, commencing at 1 P. M. and adjourning at 8 P. M. There was a large lobby attendance during the entire session, and much interest was evinced in the proceedings soon after President CLANCY had called the Board to order.

PASSED DIVIDENDS.--New-England capitalists must suffer severely this Winter from the suspension of dividends by nearly all the great manufacturing corporations in which so much money has been invested. Many a family will be deprived of their sole incomes by this financial Passover of dividends.

The steamship Philadelphia, from New-York via Havana, arrived to-day. She brings the California mails of the 5th inst. JOHN TABOR, Esq., editor of ??, was a passenger. He has consented to open the meeting to-morrow evening with a history of the capture of General WALEER and the following events. The feeling of indignation is increasing, and some favor the reinforcing of ANDERSON in spite of the Government.

COTTON.--1,000 bales sold to-day at a decline of 1/2. Middlings are quoted at 8 1/2@87/3. No business will be transacted to-morrow, the celebrations of New-year having already commenced, and out streets this evening present the appearance of high carnival. CHARLESTON, Thursday, Dec. 31. The sales of Cotton for the week have been 8,000 bales, at a decline in areas of 2/3@3/12.

The tone of the Administration, relative to Commodore PAULDING, is materially modified. Captain ENGLE has received permission to delay his return to Aspinwall until the 20th of January. Commodore PAULDING will probably carry Minister LAMAR to Central America before his return, and then come home in his own ship, whose cruise will then be ended-thus relieving the Commodore without conveying a mortifying rebuke.

SIR: I have ordered Capt. ENGLE to proceed to Washington, and place in your hands the dispatches I have intrusted to his care. Any information that I may have omitted cad be communicated by him. I have the honor to recommend Capt. ENGLE to your high consideration as an officer who has no superior in the Navy for skill and intelligence in the Command of his ship.

I have but little news to send you from Hong Kong by this mail. It seems probable, however, that within a month from now the inactivity which the British naval forces have preserved in China since last December will give place to active hostilities. Admiral SEYMOUR maintains a strict blockade of the Canton River, and a great fleet of vessels-of-war is lying in this harbor,

By the reformed Charter our new City Government commences its existence on the first Monday of January, at noon, and not on the first day of the year as appears to he generally supposed. We get rid of the old Common Council, however, to-day, and we shall enjoy a brief interregnum without any organized Government at all.

TUTHILL.--In this City, on Friday evening, Jan. 1, DANIEL L. TUTHILL, of has marriage of the langs, in the 45th year of his age. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral from his late residence. No. 29 1/2 Renwich st, on Monday, the 4th inst., at 2 o'clock. His remains will be taken to Greenwood.

FLOUR--The demand is restricted and buyers are reluctant to pay for large lots the prices claimed by the leading factors. Sales have been reported of 7,500 bbls., within Thursday's range.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--The Thalberg testimonial on Saturday was a brilliant affair, and must have been peculiarly gratifying to the amiable gentleman in whose honor it was got up. The morning performance of "Lucia" was crowded, and at night the sale of tickets had to be stooped. In consequence of this circumstance, Mr. ULLMAN, with his usual vivacity, announces another Thalberg Testimonial this afternoon and right.

The January Term of the Court of General Sessions will commerce this morning, before the City Judge, the new Recorder, Mr. BARNARD, not presiding before the February Term. Mr. SWEENEY is the new District-Attorney, and Mr. JOHN SEDGWICK, Assistant District-Attorney for the last three years, will still continue to fill that post.

THEODORE STARE, only son of GORGE STARE, Jr., of Danbury, aged 18 years, while skating on pond in this town this morning, broke through the ice and was drowned. He was a worthy and well-educated young man. JAMES BENJAMIN, son of Deacon EVERARD BENJAMIN, was killed this afternoon by being crushed by an engine turning a coner of George-street.

Miss ELIZA LESLIE, the well-known author of a variety of works on Domestic Economy, died at Gloucester, N. J., on New-Year's Day. aged 63. Miss LESLIE was a native of Philadelphia. Hor first published work was the volume of " Seventy-five Receipts," which was followed by sundry books for children, Magazine tales, " Pencil Sketches," "Amelia," the " Behavior Book" and others.

The eloquent Irish orator, SHIEL, once said that it was necessary, in order to do anything in the House of Commons, to repeat what you had to say three hundred time--the first hundred to make yourself heard, the second to be contradicted, and the third to convince them of the truth of what you said.

An Ex-Policeman named MICHAEL SHEEHAN, residing at No. 7 Rector-street, died on Thursday morning. Dr. MONELL gave a certificate that death was caused by delirium tremens, and on Saturday morning the friends of the deceased were proceeding with his burial.

At the special request of DONNELLY, Governor NEWLLI has changed the day of his execution from tile 8th to the 13th of January, the longest period, under the Constitution of New-Jersey, to which it could be delayed by the action of the Governor. Considerable excitement was caused this morning in the Park-street Presbyterian Church.
From the Cumberland Telegraph. The community was not a little startled, on Tuesday evening, at some astounding developments in regard to the affairs of the Mineral Bank of Maryland.

It snowed here nearly all day yesterday. Today the weather in fine and mild and clear. The thermometer stands at 20[degree] above zero. QUEBEC, Saturday, Jan. 2. The weather is cloudy here and the wind west. At Lower Town the thermometer at 6 o'clock this morning stood at 17 [degree] above zero; at Upper Town at the same hour it was 11 [degree] above.

A Convention of Delegates from all portions of the Territory is now discussing the question: " Shall the people vote for Legislative and State officers on the 4th of January." I have attended many Conventions In Kansas, but never one where there was so much earnest differ. ence of opinion as in the present.

A. REMARKABLE MAYOR.-Mayer RICE, of Boston, vacates his office at noon to-day, and the papers of that city are loud in extolling his praises. He has been but two years in office, and during that time, by his efficient administration, the debt of the City has been decreased a quarter of a million of dollars, while the public property of the city has been greatly augmented and increased in value.

Intimations come from Washington that in spite of General CASS and the letter-writers, the Administration is not quite perpared to crucify Commnedore PAULDING for having transcended the letter, in obedience to the spirit, of its instructions.

The festivities and brightness of New-Year's Day were not a little marred by the great numbers of beggars who availed themselves of the general hilarity to make their appeals for charity. Gay "callers" as they hurried from house to house, were beset by swarms of importunate little mendicants, who had the perseverance of study veterans in their business.

A great Nicaragua Indignation meeting was held to-night, at which resolutions were passed Censuring the Administration, and demanding WALKES'S restoration and the repeat of the neutrality laws. Many prominent Democrats were present and made speeches.

Senator PUGH, of Ohio, seems to be ambitious of pacifying Kansas. Apparently convinced of the injustice and impracticability of the Lecompton movement, and unwilling to follow in the wake of DOUGLAS, he has propared a scheme of his own, which he intends to press upon Congress.

THE CITY TAX.--Several very important ordinances were pending in one branch or the other of the Common Council at the hour of its demise on Thursday last. Among them was the one authorizing the tax lery for 1858. As that document came from the Comptroller it authorized a tax to the amount of $7,782,743.

Mr. PUGH intends, to-morrow, to give notice of a bill for the pacification of Kansas, providing for her admission as a state under the Locompton Constitution; that after the act passes the President shall certify the fact to the two Federal Judges of the Supreme Court of Kansas, who shall thereupon issue a proclama.

A NESY OF COUNTERFITERS DISCOVERED--FOUR, ARRESTS AND ONE ESCAPE--HONORA SHEFFARD AMONG THE GANG ARRESTED.--On learning the issue of the new counterfeit fives on the Onondaga Bank of Syracuse, N.Y., Sergeant Lefferts, of the Detective Police, detailed four of his men, Officers Wildey, Poole, Baldwin and Robb, to find out the parties who uttered the bill and secure their arrest if possible.

The American bark Sam Shck, from Boston for London, put into St. Michaels (Azores) on the 4th ult., leaky. Tile crow cut away the masts, and threw the cargo overboard. and were obliged ultimately to abandon her. She was also accidentally set on fire. She lies on the rocks four mires west of St Michaels, a total loss. The crew wore saved.

Contrary to general expectation, there were few of the members of the Legislature in town yesterday. For some reason, they were remarkably unanimous in staying away from the capital until the last moment.

From the Philadelphia Evening Journal. Among the disheartened fillibusters who were sent home in the Saratoga by Commodore PAULDING, the name of EDWIN P. BILES stands conspicuous. The owner of that name is a Philadelphia and his career has been so strange that we are tempted to give a sketch, embodying the principal incidents of it.

The managers of the House of Mercy at the foot of Eighty-sixth-street, North River, offer to receive a number of destitute young females and give them a home, and religious and other Instruction, during the Winter. The House of Mercy has recently been placed under the direction of Mrs. WM. RICHMOND.

The aspect of the Kansas question, within the Territory of Kansas, is not improved, but is becoming more ferocious than ever. There is, however, a gleam of hope that a conciliation will commence here when the subject shall come before Congress. The position of the Administration is unalterable.

We have often had occasion to remark upon the shill displayed by our American Jenkins in imitating his great English prototype. Within the last year or two the pupil has fairly outdone his master, and we venture to assert that in the account which he furnished in the Herald of Sunday of the doings at Post-master-General BROWN'S ball at Washington he fahty outdid himself.

In the last number of Hotsehold Words there is an article with the grotesque, title of " The City of Unlimited Paper," in which DICKENS has burlesqued in his happiest style the commercial condition of England.

The whole number of cases brought before the Court of Special Sessions since its reorganization under the new Charter, from May 1 to Dec. 31, 1857, is 4,522. Of these, 2,654 resulted in conviction, 441 in acquittal, 1,355 were discharged for various causes, and 69 were ordered to the General Sessions;

DEATH FROM CAMPHENE.---A woman named BRIDGET KELLY, 44 years of age, was burnt to death by camphene last night, in the rear of No. 55 James street. She went into the yard carrying the lamp in her hand, and the tube being loose the flame communicated with the tube being loose the flame communicated with the fluid, causing an explosion, an setting fire to her clothing.

Mr. DAVIS introduced a joint resolution to define the authority of the President under the act to amend the act to promote the efficiency of the Navy in respect to dropped and retired naval officers, and gave notice that he would call it up.

The United States Mail steamship Cahawba, J. D. BULLOCH, Commander, from New-Orleans rid Havana, arrived at this port yesterday morning, having left Havana on the 30th ult. From Havana nothing new is reported.

The murderer, JAMES P. DONNELLY, confined in the Monmouth County Jail, under sentence of execution on Friday next, for the murder of ALBERT S. MOSES, at the Highlands, on the 28th of August last, effected his escape about 10 o'clock last evening. The watchers employed to guard the jail for the night, Mr. OBADIAH LAMBERSON and JAMES BRUSNAHAN, had not entered upon their duties when the escape took place.

General WALKER will send to the Pre ??? morrow a very able and eloquent letter, reciting the principal events of his career In Nicaragua; earnestly, but respectfully, remonstrating against the unjus. . er erence of the Government of the United States, and closing with the declaration that no persecutions, interruptions, denunciations, epithets, or aught else, shall prevent him and his comrades from returning t Cen ral America, to complete the work they have begun.

At Boggs' Hotel in Syracuse, a day or two ago, a prostitute name CELIA HITCHCOCK, alias MONTROSE, attempted to commit suicide by taking strychnine, but was discovered in time to save her life. She was only 18 years old, a native of Cazenovia, and grief and shame were the causes of the attempt.

DESTRUCTIVE FIRE IN BOSTON. BOSTON, Monday, Jan. 4. A fire broke out hero this afternoon in the block on Charlestown, Cooper and Stillman streets, and the block was nearly destroyed. It was occupied by flour dealers, and by makers of sashes and blinds, etc.

NEW-YEAR'S DAY AT THE ASYLUM IN FLATBUSH. --The patients at the new Asylum for the Insane, at Flatbush, I had a very happy time, on Friday, under the superintendence of Dr. LANSING the Resident Physician, and Mrs. LUCAS, the Matron.

Three years ago a grant of ?100 was made by the British Government to the Liverpool Compass Committee, on condition that a report should be made to the Board of Trade at the end of the year. On the recommendation of Professor AIRY, the astronomer-royal, a similar grant was made in 1856, on the same conditions.

THE STREET COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE.---It will be seen by our legal record that Judge DAVIES yesterday, upon the application of the Corporation Counsel, enjoined the rival claimants to the office of Street Commissioner. and their respective employees, from claiming or suing for any money in payment of their salaries, until the title to the office shall be determined.

BOLD SURGICAL OPERATION--On the 8th inst. at noon, there was no small amount of excitement exhibited in the surgical ward and operating theatre of the Royal Infirmary, Edinburg, resulting from the expectation of a very formidable surgical operation taking place that morning. At 12 o'clock the room was crowded to excess, and numbers of medical men from all parts were assembled to witness it.

The Providence Journal contains an account of a large meeting of the manufacturers of Rhode Island, in that city, to consider the subject of Shortening the credit on sales of goods. Governor DYER presided, and on taking the chair made some seatble remarks relative to the propriety of the New-England Manufacturers establishing periodical fabs for the sale of goods, in a some what similar mode to that adopted in Europe.

The investigation in the case of the death of MICHAEL SHEEHAN, Ex-Policeman, was resumed by Coroner CONNERY yesterday morning, at 11 o'clock, at the First Ward Station-house in Trinity-place. Andrew More, of No, 16 Bowery, testified that he had examined the boots of the deceased, and that they were not perceptibly burned.,

From the Washington Union. The President's Message represents the Administration a; seeking, successfully, by treaty stipulations and amicable, honorable, and legitimate means, to obtain and secure rights of transit, commerce, and peaceful enterprise, for our people, in several portions of the Isthmus.

THE FIRST STEP TOWARDS ECLIPSING NEW-YORK--We have once or twice alluded to the scheme proposed by Mr. DUDLEY MANN, of Virginia, for creating at the South a great commercial entrepot as a rival to New-York, by which the Southern States might he rendered wholly independent of the North.

Our new Municipal Government was inaugurated to-day. The oath of office was administered to Mayor LINCOLN by Chief Justice SHAW: SAMUEL W. WALDSON, Jr., was chosen President of the Common Council, and WASHINGTON P. GREGG reflected Clerk,

STATE A.-The State Legislature inects to-day at Albany. If there should be no delay in the organization of the Assembly we shall probably be able to publish the governor's Message in thi TIMES of to-morrow morning.

The Academy of Science in New-Orleans has received a paper purporting to demonstrate the fact that the waters of the Gulf on the borders of South western Louisiana and thence to Texas, are the saltest which have been submitted to scientific test, and that by the process of evaporation in tanks, salt of a superior quality, equal to Turk's Island, may be obtained.

Congress was in session again yesterday; and, as expected, important events which have transpired during the recess occupied a great share of attention. Resolutions were adopted in both Houses calling on the President to communicate all the information in his possession relative to the arrest of General WALKER and his men by Commodore PAULDING.

The mails by the Niagara, at Boston, reached this City yesterday morning. Our advices from London and Liverpool, by this arrival, extend to the 19th of December. The financial news brought by the Niagara was very fully given in the telegram published in yesterday's issue.

The St. Louis Democrat says that passengers report that, on Friday, the 25th ult., news reached Leavenworth that an engagement had taken place between the troops of LANE, at Sugar Mound, and the dragoons. The officers ordered LANE to surrender,

IMPORTANT FACTS CONCERNING THE ROCHESTER MURDER. The Rochester Democrat insists that, in good time, all the facts of the LITTLES murder case will come to light. It claims to have received an authentic account of the causes of the murder and of the manner of its execution:

Very few complaints have as vet been entered in the complaint-book at the Police Commissioner' Office, No. 413 Broome-street. The book was opened last Summer, and has since remained in the office of the Chief Clerk of the Board, but the fact of its existence has not been generally known.

The weather is fine and clear this morning. KINGSTON, Canada, Monday, Jan. 4--8 A. M. A beautiful morning and very mild. BROCKVILLE, Canada, Monday, Jan. 4--8 A. M. Weather fine, clear and warm. OTTAWA CITY, Canada, Monday, Jan. 4--8 A. M. Weather clear and mild.

Operations, after a suspension of a few weeks, have been resumed at the Green Mountain Knitting Mills in Bennington. Vt., and will continue during the Winter without further suspension. Mr. BRADFORD, of Bennington, Vt., has commenced the operations of changing his Woolen Factory into a knitting Factory, and will employ 40 hand at once.

The past year has been the most disastrous one to the Boot and Shoe business experienced for a long time. Manufacturers commenced the year with stock of all kinds at unusually high prices, and the goods for the Spring trade were manufactured at a very high cost. The trade did not come up to expectation.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR: Is it not to be hoped that Congress will find time during the present session to consider the matter of an increase in the pay of the officers of the Navy? There is assuredly no branch of the public service demanding a greater sacrifice of personal feelings and comfort than this, yet there is no other receiving so inadequate a compensation. Since tile year 1835.

On motion of Mr. SEWARD, a resolution was adopted that the petition of Mr. MAILLARD, which was presented yesterday, be transmitted to the Secretary of State for the consideration of the President. The petition sets forth various grievances inflicted upon Mr. MAILLARD, an American citizen, by British civil officers and others, in Ireland, by which he claims to have had a large number of valuable cattle taken from him by a mob.

The Banks Convention in the Seventh Congressional District assembled yesterday, at South Reading, and was quite numerously attended, one hundred delegates being present. contrary to expectation, the Convention was harmonious, and the amount of sparring was small. An informal balloting was had, and icn persons were voted for, receiving 100 votes in all.

Mayor TIEMANN'S first Message will be found in our columns this morning. It is long, rather clumsily constructed, but sensible and reasonably interesting. The Mayor endeavors to present a full statement of the condition of the City, and in the attempt naturally introduces a great many figures, which are already familiar to the public, and a good many more which no one will ever take the trouble to examine.

We are glad to be informed that there is some prospect of an International Copyright arrangement between the United States and Great Britain. As our readers know, we have steadily opposed the scheme advocate by British publishers, and seconded by a few Utopian American authors, viz.: a mutual extension of full copyright privileges,

An order has been received from the Sacretary of the Navy directing the frigate Niagara to be got ready with all dispatch, to sail in March for England, to assist in laying the Atlantic telegraph cable. Chief Engineer EVERETT having been detached in order to take the di ection of the laying of the cable, JOSHUA FOLLANSBEE has been appointed in his place as Chief Engineer of the Niagara.

The caucus machinery moved very smooth last night, in each of the political divisions. The nomination for Clerk in the Senate Republican caucus was the only well-contested point. When the result was announced there was a perfect "surprise party," and probably none partook of this surprise more largely than the successful candidate Mr. ALLEN, who, I am confident, went to the caucus with but the faintest hopes of success.

A young bride came to her death in a remarkable manner lately, in Clark County, Ind. She married her cousin. Some young men came to the house for the purpose of charivaring the parties. The father of the parties asked them to desist, and they complied with the request. But shortly after they returned, and the bride being on horseback for the purpose of going to the home of the bridegroom,

CAPTURE OF A BURGLAR.--At an early hour yesterday morning, as Officer Vanduzer, of the Fourth Ward, was patrolling his beat, he discovered that the looking glass store of John S. Willard, No. 440 Pearl-Street, had been broken open. The Officer went into the store and found a man inside, and rested him. A quantity of looking-glass plates had been gathered together, and the culprit was on the point of leaving when the officer found him.

AN AUSTRIAN CONSUL IN TROUBLE.--Austrian Consuls seem to be rather unfortunate just at this time. While one is trying to heal with golden salve the wounds inflicted on his honor by an American newspaper in New-York, another is greatly distressed in Genoa, because a Piedmontesc mob would not break his windows.

FRANK HEATH, and his sister, MIRIAM YORK HEATH, have been arrested in DRACUT, near Lowell, for the murder of their father, JOSHUA HEATH, a blacksmith, between sixty and seventy years of age. The daughter, it is stated, confessed that she first attempt?? to poison her father, and that her brother, on Saturday night, shot him in the head, and afterwards buried the body where it was found by the officers.

BURNING OF THE SCHOONER LIVERPOOL. BARBINGTON, N.S., Tuesday, Jan. 5. The schooner Liverpool, just from Roston with a cargo of flour, sugar and merchandise, while lying at Robertson's wharf, in this place, last night took fire and burned to the water's edge. ]loss estimated at $10,000. No insurance.

Messrs. HUNTER and TOOMBS asked but the Senate refused to excuse them from services on the French Spoliatlon Bill Committee. The Senate then proceeded to the consideration of Mr. CRITTENDEN'S resolution in favor of increasing the duties on imports, and substituting home for foreign valuation.

The Board met on Tuesday at 1 o' clock. Present Commissioners DILLON, GARY, BUTTERWORTH, RUSSELL, GREEN, ELLIOT and STRONG. The clerk was directed to purchase necessary fuel for the office and the room in which maps for exhibition to competitors for plans are deposited.

Those who are familiar with the proceedings of the Democratic Party in this City, are aware that after the election of the Democratic Republican General Committee for 1858, that was recognized by and succeeded the Union General Committee of 1857, there was considerable dissatisfaction, and at length a call for the election of a new General Committee on the Ward primary system.

The warrant of Governor NEWELL, granting a stay of execution in the case of DONNELLY from the 8th to the 13th., has, we understand, never been signed, although it was the Governor's intention at one time to do so. Upon a more careful examination of the Constitution it is doubtful what the clause under which this power is derived means.

There was prayer in the House to-day, and then the records of yesterday were made historical, and then they tried several times to make a presiding officer. As they were at the beginning so they were at the end--and as yet there is no head of the House. It is possible that a night of reflection may bring on a change of sentiment that will to-morrow develop a presiding officer.

Our State Legislature is organized to-day. The Senate organized by the choice of lion. SETH SCAMMON of Saco, for President, and Mr. HALL, of Aroostook, for Secretary. In the House J. H. DRUMM0ND, of Waterville, was elected Speaker, and G. W. WILSON, of Dixmount, Clerk.

ARREST OF SUSPECTED RIVER THIEVES,--Between 4 and 5 o' clock morning officers Reeves and Duffy, of the Eleventh Ward, saw three suspicious looking fellows going up Avenue C foot of seventeenth-street, where they commenced loading their wagon with firkins of butter, and costs of tea and other groceries.

THE WILLIAMSBURG FERRIES.--The competition between the rival ferries to Williamsburg grows interesting. On Monday, at 11 o'clock, the order came to reduce the fare on the Peck-slip Ferry to one cent for foot passengers.

All the trains on the Marietta and Cincinnati Road stopped running to-day, and the Company suspended business. Matters with the Company have been unsatisfactory for some time past. The employes are on a strike for wages due them.

The Massachusetts Legislature organized about 12 o'clock to-day. CHARLES W. UPHAM, Republican, was elected President of the Senate, receiving 37 votes, all that were cast, S. N. GIFFORD, Republican, was reflected Clerk, by 34 votes, against 3 for S. R. GLEN, Democrat.

SIR: On the 15th of June last I had the honor to address you a letter relating the manner in which I emigrated from California to Nicaragua, the events which followed my presence in Central America, and the unjust and illegal acts by which I was forced for a time to abandon my adopted country.

The ship Serampore, STONE, from New-Orleans for Boston, with a cargo of flour and molasses, went ashore during the show-storm this morning on Black Ledge, Cohasset. The Captain and crew were saved, but they were badly frost-bitten.

The only incident in the history of our Navy which bears any resemblance to the affair of Commodore PAULDING in removing WALKER and his men from Nicaragua, was the attack by Commodore PORTER, some thirty years ago, on the town of Foxardo, in the Spanish Island of Porto Rico.

General WALKER is still here lying upon his oars and watching the turn of events. He feels confident that public opinion in the South will force the Administration to remunerate him and reinstate him again at Punta Arenas with all his men and supplies. His statement of particulars shows that he has been deprived of $140,000 worth of property--cash valuation in Niearagua, by Captain DAVIS and Commodore PAULDING.

The topographical and sectional maps of the Central Park are now on exhibition at the rooms of the Commissioners, where they can be examined by persons who wish to compete for the premiums offered by the Board for the four desigrs for laying out the grounds, which may be chosen by them.

In Executive Session, the Senate to-day considered the nomination of Mr. SEDGWICK as DistrictAtterney, rice McKEON. After an earnest debate of thare hours, they adjourned without a vote. The Administration men were challenged to defend the course of the President in removing MOKEON, but not a man undertook the task.

The Atlantic, with four days later news from Europe, arrived at this port yesterday afternoon. The President's message, taken out by the Africa, was published in all the London papers on the 22d ult. It meets with general approbation from our foreign contemporaries.

The result of the consultation has not transpired, nor will it be known until the President communicates his views and those of his Administration in a special message to Congress.

The Collins steamship Atlantic, Captain EDDRIDGE, which sailed from Liverpool at about noon on the 23d of December, arrived here at 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon. The Cunard steamship Africa, Capt. SHANNON, arrived out at Liverpool at 5 P. M. on the 20th.

On Tuesday evening last messengers arrived from Gen. LANE'S camp, bringing the following particulars: They had traveled 100 miles and had been in the saddle 20 hours. They report that Gen. LANE has 185 men under his command, and was strongly fortified at Sugar Mound,

Mr. SEDGWICK was to-day confirmed as Attorney-General, vice McKEON, after a protracted debate. The test vote on a motion to table was 16 to 18--THOMPSON, of Kentucky, and HOUSTON voting with the Administration. This is considered indicative of their intention to sink into the Administration Party on the Kansas question and all else.

THE PASHA OF EGYPT'S STEAM YACHT.-It is pretty generally known that an iron steamship has been built in Boston for the Pasha of Egypi,'and the public doubtless feel considerable interest in respect to the matter, it being the first attempt in this country to construct a sea going ship of iron of any kind.

ARRIVAL OF THE SLOOP-OF-WAR CYANE AT NORFOLK--RAVAGES OF THE FEVER. NORFOLK, Thursday, Jan. 7. The sloop-of-war Cyane has arrived at this port in twenty days passage from Port an Prince, via Havana, Her officers are all well, but fourteen of her crew are sick.

To the Editor of the New- York Times: One of the issues of the New-York Herald, shortly after the reception of the European news in New-.York on the 21st November, contained an article which treated of the effects, both present and future, of the great financial crisis through which our country has just passed.

APPOINTMENTS BY THE NEW DISTRICT-ATTORNEY.--The District-Attorney has made the following appointments in his office: JAMES M. SWEENY. Chief Clerk. JOHN C. LORD, in place of JAMES W. OLSON. JOHN HEALY. in place of IRA FLOYD. Mr. SWEENY is a brother of the District-Attorney.

The Free-State Party in Kansas has split upon the question of taking part in the election of State officers. A majority of the members of the Convention was opposed to voting, on the ground that it would involve a recognition of the "bogus" Constitution.

SHAP PURACTICE.-Messrs. SNELL and COZINE, Coroners, of Brooklyn, have had an exciting time of it thus far this year. Failing to unite, as heretofore has been the caste, and divide the fees of office equally between them, each acts Independent of the other, Both have offices in the City Hall, and frequently some ludicrous scenes are witnessed in the contest to secure a case.

We copied lately from a Washington letter in the Boston Traveller a paragraph concerning the emancipation of the slaves of the late Mr. CUSTIS. which we are glad to find corrected in the following letter: ARLINGTON, Monday, Jan. 4, 1857. My attention has been called to an article frol the Boston Traveller, dated Washington, 24th December, republished in the NEW-YoRK TIMEs of the 30th, under the caption of ' The Slaves of Mr. CUSTIS.

The Democratic Republican General Committee that follows the General Committee of 1857 in the regular line of succession, met in Tammany Hotel

Mr. ULLMAN'S experiment of a cheap opera night is completely successful, so far as attendance is concerned. The performance of "Martha" last night was witnessed by a very large audience, evidently drawn from classes that are not in the habit of patronizing the Opera at regular prices, either because they can't afford or don't think it worth the money.

The President yesterday sent to Congress his Message in response to the call for information relative to Central American affairs, and the arrest of WALKKR and his men by Commodore PAULD, ING. He says the Commodore committed a great error in making the arrest, but thinks he was actuated by patriotic motives, and a desire to promote the interests and vindicate the honor of his country.

"The TIMES fancies its logic smart in demonstrating that as we 'printed.' on the outside, we intended to 'publish' the Message whether delivered or not, on Tuesday.

A large quantity of snow fell here last night. The weather is cloudy this morning, and at 8 o'clock the thermometer marked 6C above zero. QUEBEC, Can,. Thursday, Jan. 7. At 8 o'clock, this morning, the mercury indicated 6[Degrees] below zero. Snow is falling fast, and an East wind is blowing.

The President, in a message sent to the Senate yesterday, takes precisely the ground suggested in the TIMES upon the first news of General WALKER'S seizure on foreign soil,namely, that Commodore PAULDING was guilty of a wrong;-but that the wrong consisted in the invasion of the territory of Nicaragua, and that Nicaragua, therefore, is the only party in the ..case which can justly complain.

The Comptroller's Report opens with an estimate of the expenditures of the government for the fiscal year commencing Oct. 1, 1857, which amounted 20 $3,701,417, to which must be added the deficiency of revenue last year, $3,786,119.

UNJUST AND UNFAIR,--The Albany Evening Journal says: "The Governor, after consultation with Senators of both parties, transmitted his Message to that body to-day. It appears, therefore, in our columns. The infamous breach of confidence by the New-York Express will compel the State Executives, hereafter, to withheld early copies of their Messages from the Press, a courtesy long practised, and never before abused."

ACADEMY OF MEDICINE-ELECTION OF OFFICERS.--The annual meeting of the Academy was ?? in the small Chapel of the University on Wednesday evening. The following gentlemen were elected its officers for the ensuing year:

JOHNSTON.--In this City, on Thursday morning. Jan. 7. FRANCIS U. JOHNSTON, M.D., in the 62d year of his age. The funeral services will take place at St. Mark's Church in the Bowery, on Saturday, Jan. 9, at 3 1/2 o'clock P. M. The relatives and friends of the family, and those of his sons-in-law, Charles F. Zimmermann and George Bradish, are respectfully invited to attend, without further notice.

The debate in the House this morning was opened by Hon. DANIEL E. SICKLES, of New-York, who delivered his maiden speech, taking bold and deided ground against the filibusters, and offering an argument in reply to the views presented yesterday by Messrs. QUITMAN and STEPHENS. The effort was a and sustained the honorable gentlean's reputation as a public debater.

The spare troops from Kansas and elsewhere are to be ordered to concentrate immediately for the reinforcement of the utah Expedition. [FROM THE REPORTER FOR THE ASSOCIATED PRESS.] WASHINGTON, Friday, Jan. 8.

POLITICAL LETTER-WRITING--TOO MUCH OF A GOOD THING.--The business of political letter writing is overdone. It is getting to be a nuisance, and Tammany Hall is, to a very great extent, responsible for it.

Mr. SICKLES said: Mr.Chairman, it was not my desire to take ally part in this discussion in its present stage, nor should I have allowed myself to be diverted from that purpose, but for the extraordinary turn which tile debate took yesterday.

The Senate not being in session to-day, the House became the centre of attraction. The session there was of brief duration, and ended with a resolution to postpone the ballot for Speaker until Monday evening, and an adjournment until that time was carried.

The Republican has just received letter from Fort Kearney, 23d ult., stating that Col. JOHNSTON was at Fort Bridger, Nov, 26, Col. Cook, with his whole command, had also arrived. The grass had all been burned, and the animals were dying at the rate of one hundred a day.

The trial of THOMAS WASHINGTON SMITH for the murder of RICHARD CARTER is now in progress before the Court of Over and Terminer, in Philadelphia. This case has peculiar features of interest. The murder was committed at the St. Lawrence Hotel, in Philadelphia, on the 4th of last November. the victim, Mr. CARTER, was President of the Tamaqua Bank, at Tamaqua, Penn.,--it man of wealth and respectable standing.

The city of Chicago is only 26 years old. The town was laid out in 1830; and the first sales of lots were made in 1831. Its growth s extraordinary. The annual statements of the extent of its commerce and trade are every year more surprising;

Just about a year ago an enthusiastic gentleman of Liverpool, one Mr. ARROWSMITH by name, fitted a poisoned dart to a very long bow, and discharged it into the very centre of the escutcheon of the State of Georgia.

We have not been in the habit of looking to Virginia for specimens of pure and undefiled Democracy. But we commend the letter of Governor HENRY A. WISE to the Tammany Hall Committee, which will be found in another column of this morning's TIMES, as one of the soundest and most admirable papers upon the Kansas question which has yet been given to the public.

KANSAS.--We are advised of the receipt of information at Washington to the effect that nearly, or quite, seven thousand votes were east at the election of the 21st ult., in Kansas, upon the Lecompton Constitution. This is thought to be a majority of all the votes in that Territory.

The Forty-third Anniversary of the Battle of New Orleans was celebrated in Tammany Hotel last evening, by Tammany Society, or the Columbian Order, by a grand ball and banquet. Unusual exertions had been made by the several Committees, under the supervision of Col. DANIEL E. DELAVAN, Grand Sachem to render the occasion, if possible, more gratifying t the guests and friends generally than any of the former anniversary celebrations of this ancient Society.
Two very remarkable discoveries were made in the Senate of the United States during the debate on the President's message in regard to the arrest of WALKER.

A Convention of Soldiers of the War of 1812 was held here to-day. A memorial was adopted asking Congress to make appropriations to the soldiers of the War of 1812, and of the frontier Indian war of the same period.
THE LIQUOR TRIALS--In the Brooklyn City Court, before judge CULVER and Supervisors SMITH and STUDWELL, the following parties have been convicted the present week FOR SELLING LIQUOR ON SUNDAY:

The Legislature organized this morning. All the American caucus nominees were elected. J. SUMMERFIELD BERRY, of Baltimore County, is the Speaker of the House, and J. VAUGHAN SMITH, of Somerset County, the Clerk.

The Sons of New-York in the city of Keokuk, Iowa, had a grand jollification at the Billings House on the 29th ult. One hundred guest sat down to a banquet ; letters were received from ex-President VAN BUREN, GULLAN C. VERPLANN. JAS. C. PAULDING, and others ;

RIOT AT DEBCQUE-ONE MAN KILLED, Two MORTALLY WOUNDED AND TWENTY OTHERS INJURED--A bloody it occurred at West Dubuque on New Year's night, at a German ball that was in progress at the West Brewery Hall. It seems that a party of drunken men forced their way into the hall at a late hour, and disturbed the ball with their boisterous conduct. It was deter mined to expel them from the ball;

The Democratic Convention, for the nomination of State officers, assembled in the Hall of Representatives this morning, and after considerable confusion, organized by electing Governor WILLARD President.

By the Mexican schooner Arrogante, Captain CABADA, arrived yesterday, we hve advices from Campeachy to the 20th ult., the very latest possible. The news is important. The Barrera, or Government party, had sued for peace, and their propositions had been indignantly rejected--an incident in the war which at least gives evidence of the ability of the revolutionists to maintain their ground, it not ulitmately to triumph.

A little after 12 o'clock yesterday morning, MICHAEL WOGAN, Jr., who professes to be a private watchman for several stores in Oliver, James and Cherry streets, got into an altercation with a young man named EDWARD KENNEDY, in the German dancehouse No. 98 James-street. After a few angry words they passed into the street, where the quarrel was renewed.

SACKETT.--In this City, on Friday, Jan. 8. WASHINGTON 1., Second son of Josephine and Wm. Edgar Sackett. aged. 8 years, 2 months and 20 days. The funeral services will take place at the parents' residence, 4th av., third house above 35th St., tomorrow (Sunday,) at 1 1/2 o'clock P. M. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend.

ROSSINI'S buffo opera of "L'baliana in Algien was successfully produced here last night. It is some years since this work has been heard, and owing to its depending on the contraito voice, it may be many years before it can be heard again for there are few contraltos of the present day who can undertake the mechanism of Rossini's florid early style.

The weather is clear here, the mercury markIng 30 above zero this morning. The river is falling rapidly, and its depth in the channel is now 21 feet. PHILADELPHIA, Friday, Jan. 8.

A regular meeting of the Historical Society was held on Tuesday evening in the Society's new building corner of Tenth-street and Second-avenue. The attendance was pretty large. Hon. GUTHER BRADISH, the President, occupied the Chair.
DANCER TO THE ICE CROP.--May weather in mid-Winter is very pleasant, and a great blessing to the poor, as well as to invalids; but it is not profitable, nor healthy, in the long run.

The R. M. steamship Africa, from Liverpool on the 26th with three days' later news from Europe, is now fully due at this port. She had not been signaled at Sandy Hock, up to the time of going to press.

JAMES P. DONNELLY was yesterday executed for the murder of ALBERT S. MOSES. The circumstances attending the commission of the crime for which he has suffered,--full account of them, as developed at the trial, was published in the TIMES,--the respectable connections, prepossessing appearance, talents and acquirements of the unfortunate, young man, while they have produced a feeling of deep commiseration throughout this community, have yet rather added to than softened the feeling against him.

THE BOARD OF EDUCATION.--The newlyelected Board of Education meets next Wednesday for the purpose of organization. It is understood that the President, Mr. A. H. GREEN, declines to be a candidate for reelection.

Correspondence of the Philadelphia Press. It is stated that General WALKER refuses to yield up his command of filibuster movements against Nicaragua, and that unless he does, and a full complement of men and munitions of war are provided. General HENNINGSEN declines to take part in the next expedition for that quarter.

The number of arrivals from foreign ports during tile past thirty days has been unusually small. The steamers Niagara at Halifax, and Atlantic and New-York, at this port, report having experienced tremendous heavy westerly weather, which may account for the long passages of some of our absent packets.

The schooner Monte Cristo has arrived here with Tampico advices of the 26th ult. The news of COMONFORT having assumed the Dictatorship reached Tampico on the 20th. A proclamation expressing adherence to the new order of things was issued on the same evening. All was quiet when the Monte Cristo left.

The Board of Commissioner of the Metropolitan Police met on Saturday at 3 P. M. All the members, including the new Mayor of this City, were promptly in attendance. There was a dense throng of spectators, among whom were Governor Gather of the Almshouse, and Ex-Recorder Smith.

THE CARTER MURDER IN PHILADELPHIA. The trial of THOMAS W. SMITH for the murder of RICHARD CARTER in Philadelphia is still in progress. Much additional evidence has been produced for the defense, all sending to show that the birth of the child produced a remarkable change in SMITH: that his brain seemed unsettled, his language incoherent, and his manner mighty.

The following documents accompanied the President's Message: The Secretary of the Navy to Lieut. Almy. NAVY DEPARTMENT, Oct. 3, 1857. SIR: There is reason to believe that unlawful military expectations are preparing in certain ports of the United States against the territories of Mexico, Nicaragua, and Costa Rica; and that they may rendezvous in the harbor of Chiriqui or Bocas del Toro on the coast of Costa Rica.

On Saturday afternoon, about 25 gentlemen, members of the New-York Academy of Medicine, met in the smaller chapel of the University to pay the last honors to the memory of their departed associate, the late Dr. FRANCIS U. JOHNSTON. Dr. MOTT was called to the Chair, Dr. HAYWARD officiating as Secretary. A Committee of three was proposed to draft resolutions, Drs. BUCK, WATSON and JAMES W. SMITH being selected.

Genera! Orders, No. 1: The General-in-Chief, with the approbation of the War Department, directs the following movements: 1. The army of Utah will be reinforced, as soon as practicable, by the Ist Regiment of Cavalry, 6th and 7th Regiments of Infaitry, and Light Companics A and M.2d Artillery.

THE WOOL DUTY AND THE NEW-YORK PRESS-Several of our City newspapers are making a dreadful outcry about the statement in the recent report of the Middlesex Company, that money was paid in New-York for editorialal scrviccs" in connection with the repeal of the duty on wool.

The Cunard steamship Africa, Captain SHANNON, which sailed from Liverpool at about 2.30 on the afternoon of the 26th ult., arrived at this port at 10 o'clock yesterday morning. The screw steamship Antelope, from Portland, arrived at Liverpool at 3 o'clock on the afternoon of the 23d, and the Fulton, from New-York, reached Southampton the same night.

There are but two possible modes (apart from the mere influence of exaple) of asceessful expansion for our institations southward; first, by the peaceful emigration of individuat citizens for the purpose of prossecuting legitimade pursuits of businesss in new countries, as occurred in the case of Terxas; and second, by the action of the Government in military operations, or through peaceful treaties, as occurred in the cases of Florida and California.

To the Editor of the Chicago Times: SIR: A paragraph from your paper, stating that the Chicago Democrat had represented me as disagreeing with Judge DOUGLAS on the Kansas question, has just lallen under my notice. You did right in giving a prompt and emphatic contradiction to it. and I think you for it. Instead of dissenting from him, I fully and heartily indorse his views, and shall stand by them to the last.

THE WOMAN'S HOSPITAL.--At the Annual Meeting of the Woman's Hospital Association,held at 12 o'clock Saturday at the Institution, No. 87 Madison-avenue, Mrs. MASON presided, and Mrs. Dr. BARKER acted as Secretary.

SPEAKING IN THE HOUSE OF COMMONS.-In the English House of Commons they will not hear a man speak at length who is not known beforehand to have something to say. They cheer him down, cough him down, laugh him down, clap him down, stamp him down, or go down them selves to dinner. Long, speeches are an abomination.

UNITED STATES DISTRICT-ATTORNEY'S OFFICE. -Yesterday morning lion. THEODORE SEDGWICK was sworn in by Judge BEITS, in the United States District Court, and entered upon the discharge of his duties as District-Attorney of the United States. The District-Attorney retains P. J. JOACHIMSSEN, Esq., as his associate, (that gentleman having held the like position under Mr. McKSON.) Messrs. LEOPOLD C. NEWMANN and JAMES W. McCARTY are, also, retained as clerks.

MARYLAND. The Message of Governor LIGON sets forth a satisfactery financial condition, the Sinking Fund having increased to Learly four milions. With the exceptin of the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal, which countinues involved in misfortune, the public works are prosperous. The Governor dwells upon the subject of the financial orisis, and denounces the recetn breach of faith towards the people," which challenges decisive action on the part of the Legislature.

FIRE IN THE ST. NICHOLAS HOTEL--About 5 1/2 O' clock last evening a window curtain in a room on the second floor of the St. Nicholas Hotel caught fire from the grate. An alarm of fire was given, and for some time considerable consternation prevalled among the guests of the house. A number of engine companies arrived promptly on the ground, but fortunately the servants of the house succeded in puting out the fire

Mr. JOHN UPTON, a well-known Express agent on the Albany youte, and Segeant-at-Arms to the Congressional Investigating Committee in Kansas, died at Amsterdam, N.Y., on Saturday, His health was shattered by server exposure while protecting his trucks in the Express car of the Hudson River railroad at the time of the Spayten Duynil accident when the extenex was interseiy cold.

The Seaview House at the Highlands, where the murder of MOSES by DONNELLY was committed, together with the cottage occupied by Mra. JASVIS was totally destroyed by fire about 9 o'clock on Sunday night, The fire was first discovered bursting from the third-story windows, and in ten minutes the whole house was in flames, The house has not been occupied since September, and the fire was doubtless the work of an incendiary.

The people of Kansas are now moving in the right direction. The voting will be general, on Monday next, for State officers and members of the Legislature under the Lecompton Constitution, for the purpose of crushing and defeating that Consitution should the Democractic Party admit Kansas under it. A pleasant two-act piece, called "A Bachelor's Wife," was produced here last night with success. The plot is very slight, and not at all dramatic. A bachelor calls on a married friend at a moment when the latter is enraged with his spouse, and when, in consequence of her extravagance, a serious rupture seems probable.

SHEAWOOD FORRSY, MY SON: My exchequer plan will be found, in Hance, in a report made by Mr. FONWARD, then Secretary of the Preasury, to the Senatc, in the Winter of 1841-12. My message of December, 1841, presents is outlines, and that of December, 1842, repeats the recommendation for its adoption, and briefly answers the most prominent objections which had been urged to it. The report which accompanies the plan is worthy of deliberate study.

THE BATTERY EXTENSION.-When the scheme for extending the Battery was first projected the chief opposition made to it was based on the supposition that so important a change of the water-line of the City would have a damaging effect upon the channels of the harbor and tend to the injury of tile commerce of the port.

The late revulsion in Great Britain has brought to light some very curious commercial experiences, and revealed the existence of romantic rascals among the plodding merchants of England and Scotland, whose exchants in trade are almost as entertaining and exciting as the histories of the bucaneers in the days of King JAMES, or the gay gentlemen of the road of the last century.

The bark Mary O. Dyer, which ran ashore on Barnegat Beach on Saturday, belonged to Messrs. PECK CHURCH, of his City, and others. She was built in-Cherryfield, Me., in 1856, was about 370 tons burden, and valued at $18,000, partly insured in this City. To the Editor of the. New- York Times: In perusing your account of the execution of DONNELLY, in Saturday's TIMES, I was completely horror-stricken on learning that just before being led to the scaffold he drank four glasses of brandy ! Allow me just to inquire by whose direction or permission this was given him, and also if this is a necessary preparation for a man to make under these circumstances.

DEATH OF THE, LAST PRESIDENT OF TEXAS.-The telegraph today brings report of the death of Dr. ANSON JONES, Ex-President of Texas. He committed suicide at Houston, on the 8th inst., by shooting himself. Dr. JONES has been prominently connected with public affairs in Texas for many years. Ho was a native of Louisiana, but emigrated to Texas in 1833, and at once took part in the struggles of the Republic for independence.

The New-York State Military Association meets at Albany on Tuesday, the 19th January. Some may inquire: What is this Association ? what are its aims ? We answer: First-To unite in one great Military brotherhood, where no distinction of rank but perfect equality prevails, every officer in the State who has at heart the interest of the service.
