The Board of Supervisors met yesterday afternoon, President PURDY in the Chair. Mr. TWEED moved that the Board proceed to the election of a Sergeant-at arms, who should also do the duty of Messenger. He nominated Henry J. Mathews, of he Eighteenth Ward. Mr. BLUNT thought, as there were members absent, the election had better be postponed. He moved an amendment to that effect, and the motion as amended was carried.

THE SCHOONER MAINE LAW IN DISTRESS. NEWPORT, Tuesday, Jan 12, The schooner Maine Law, of and form Camden foe New-Orleans, put into this port this afternoon in distress, her cargo of lime having been on tire since the 10th inst.

SUGAR-GROWERS COVENTION.-A Convention of Northwestern Sugar-growers assembled at Springfield, Ill., on the 7th inst. The meetings were heldin the State House and were largely attended. Judge CATON presided. Letters were received from cultivators of the Chinese cane in Kentucky, Ohio, Indiana, and other States; all expressing satisfaction at the results of culture.

Our advices from Great Salt Lake City by way of San Francisco are to the 3d of November. The proposition to declare BRIGHAM YOUNG" Prophet, Seer and Revelator" of the Mormon people, was sustained unanimously in the Tabernacle.

On New-Year's night, in Troy, a quarrel occurred in a house near the Stone Bridge, between an old man, named JOHN TUFT and HENRY HAYES, his son-in-law, which resulted in the death of an old man. An ill feeling existed, growing out of an alleged interference in family affairs.

The United States Mail steamship Star of the West A. G. GRAY, Esq, Commander, left Aspinwall Jan, 4, at 4:30 P.M., and arrived at Quarantine at 9 o' clock last evening. Experienced very heavy head winds and a bad sea in crossing the Caribbean. She brings the California mails of Dec. 21, $1,607, 440 in treasure on freight and 187 passengers.

NATHAN CLIFFORD has been confirmed as an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States! Comment is scarcely necessary. A weak man, without force of character enough to make personal or political foes, his nomination aroused a host of indignant protest against it, because of the unfitness the nominee.

In Boston, on Monday, Judge MERRICK, of the Supreme Court, gave a decision on the exceptions in the case of Wm. S. TUCKERMAN, on conviction of embezzlement of money, as Treasurer of the Eastern Railroad Company.

THE INDIANA DEMORACY.-It was announced a few days since, in a special telegram to the TIMES from Washington, that the Democratic State Convention of Indiana, had adopted resolutions sustaining Senator DOUGLAS in his position upon the Kansas question.

The Valley of Wyoming is classic ground. Its history is full of interest, and many of its truthful tales far exceed the fictions of romance in the strangeness of their circumstances. Much has been written of Wyoming, in both prose and verse -many things which are true and some which are not true.

THE NEW SUPREME COURT JUDGE-Hon. NATHAN CLIFFORD, confirmed on Tuesday as Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States, to fill the vacancy occasioned by the resignation of Judge CURTIS, is a native of New Hampshire and 53 years of age,

Governor HICKS was inaugurated to-day at noon. His address opens with a reference to the evils of foreign immigration and the naturalization question, and quotes the farewell address of WASHINGTON against foreign influence. He says the people of Mary land have declared, in a way riot to be misunderstood, their appreciation of these evils and their determination to remedy them.

The steamship Star of the West, with the California mails of Dec. 20 and over $1,600,000 in treasure, arrived at this port last evening. She brings particulars of the surrender of Colonel ANDERSON, with the remnant of the Walker army on the San Juan, to Captain SANDS, of the Susquehanna.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The miserable controversy got up in reference to the Egyptian steamer, only calculated to injure the reputation of American engineers at home and abroad, has its origin in two causes, and is now kept alive by as many sets of men.

A few minutes after 9 o'clock, last evening, a negro suddenly fell in front of the Astor House, and, on examination, was found to be dead and covered with blood. It was at first supposed that he had just been stabbed, and that the murderer had fled, but the whole affair, even to the name of the deceased, is thus far involved in mystery.

KEEP COOL.-We understand that the ice companies are getting excited, and their expectations in regard to prices next Summer are running up to fever heat. They refuse to make any contracts for the next season, and are warming themselves with the thought of disposing of their commodity at unheard-of prices in July and August.

The Senate Committee on Territories have postponed until Saturday any vote on reporting the Minnesota Constitution. Some members of the Committee avow the purpose to keep it back until the Kansas Constitution is ready, so as to let the Senate act on both simultaneously. This is now evidently the policy.

DEATH OF A CONDEMNED MURDER IN PRISON, --The Boston Transcript says of the death of CATER, the murderer of Warden TENNEY, in prison, while awaiting execution, that his death was caused by hemorrhage of the lungs, CATER was only 23 yeas of age. He commenced his career o crime when quite young, and for several years past has been an ?? of some prison.

OPERATION ON AN ELEPHANT.--During the late visit to Hull of WOMEWELL'S menagerie, the elephant Chubby underwent an operation which deserves a place amongst surgical records. For twelve or fifteen months previously, a tumor had been gathering on Chubby's off side thigh. Chubby sickened, lost his appetite, and piled away.

ARISTOCRACY HORRIFIED. -- To the horror of the Almanach de Gotha, and all the hoffraths of broad Deutschland, a Prince RODOLPHE VON TOUR and TAXIS, having lately graduated with distinction as a law student, has sought and got a professor's chair at the University of Prague, and crowned this misdemeanor by marrying the daughter of his tutor, and worse still, with the consent of the half sovereign bond of that semi-royal house.

OUR CITY AFFAIRS.-It seems impossible to exaggerate the ignorance and knaveTr which pervade the management of our City affairs. The slightest attempt to look beneath the surface in any department discloses facts utterly disgraceful to the parties concerned.

The Secretary of the Treasury has made official reply to the request of the collector of Galveston for authority to place the lifeboats of the district in a more efficient state of service. He states that there is now no money in the treasury applicable to that object, and that a new appropriation by Congress must be awaited.

An auspicious sun and large attendance of members, delegates from other societies, and members of Congress, combine to render the commencement of this sixth annual gathering of the United States Society full of cheerful promise. The case excites great interest in Rochester, where the parties are well known, and have always occupied a highly respectable position. The circumstances are of unusual character.

The second term of the Collegiate year opened last Wednesday. Commencements and prize debates are giving students, just at present, something beside studies to think of; but let no one imagine that Yale has been taking the world by surprise in transferring the time for her annual jubilee from July to January.

East Brooklyn Drainage. The Board of Sewer Commissioners of Brooklyn meet next Monday (18th) to her objections to the proposed plan of sewerage and drainage for that part of Brooklyn which is now naturally drained by River-street. SABBATH SCHOOL ANNIVERSARY-The Fourteenth-street Presbyterian (Dr. SMITH'S) Church was filled to overflowing last night by the members and friends of the Sabbath School Missionary Association attached to that Church, which celebrated its second anniversary there. The children attached to the Sabbath School and their teachers occupied the pows in the centre of the Church.

The reduction of fare on the Peck-slip and South Tenth-street Ferries has caused a falling-off in the receipts of the Fulton Ferry, and also of the Brooklyn City Railroad Company, on the two routes to East Brooklyn. SEASONS STABBING AFFAIR--Officer MALLORY, of the Second Precinct, on Saturday, arrested SOLOMON BULL, of No. 125 Tillary-street, Brooklyn, on a charge of stabbing WILLIAM McDONALD, who resides in the same house. Bill and wife were engaged in a pugilistic encounter, when McDONALD interfered to quell the disturbance, and get stabbed for his trouble, The knife entered the left breast, and the wound is considered a dangerous one.

REPTILE WRIGGLINGS.--A snake's tail is the last part of him that dies, and as our country readers know, from experiments of their boyhood, it will often wriggle and twist for hours and even days after life is out of the reptile's head. The Herald has a similar idiosyncracy. Its brains deserted it long ago, and nothing is now left, resembling vitality, but the slimy and imbecile wrigglings of its tail.

The Poolville Parricide--Fall Particulars. From the Utica Herald. That our readers might be fully posted in all the particulars of the recent horrible parricide at Poolville, Madison County, one of the editors of the Herald yesterday visited the scene of the murder for the purpose of giving an authentic account of the awful affair. It is a crime without precedent in its enormity--and without parallel in its terrible and unnatural details.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--MOZART'S opera of "Don Giovanni" will be played here to-night for the second time. Tile public should remember that there will be but one more performance this season, and that, so far as this opera is concerned, it may be many seasons before It can be produced with similar brilliancy, Sensation revivals of popular operas are mostly objectionable and unjudicious when carried to an excess, but Mr. ULLMAN has hit the happy medium.

The difficulty relative to the Minnesota constutution will be arranged by having the copy signed by the Republican branch of the Convention also certified and placed on the records of Congress, The two original instruments are identical. The Committee will probably report the bill for the admission of Minlnesota on Tuesday.

The Royal Mail steamship America, Capt. LOTT, from Liverpool 10 1/2 o'clock on the morning of the 2d instant, arrived here at 10 o'clock this (Saturday) morning, Her dates are three days later than those received by the North American at Portland. Among the passengers by the America are Madame LOLA MONTEZ, Countess of LANDSFELDT, (who was recently married to the Prince SHALOSKY in Paris,) and suite;

District-Attorney MANN addressed the jury today in the case of SMITH, charged with killing RICHARD CARTER, President of the Tamaqua Bank, at the St. Lawrence Hotel. He said he deeply sympathized with the accused, and that he had never been engaged in a case where his duty and his sympathy so conflicted.

The ship Cambridge, of Boston, Wm. CHASE master, which sailed from New-York on the 10th of December, bound to New-Orleans, ran upon the Newjack reef, Island of Abaco, on the 14th ult., and bilged in a few minutes. The officers and crew reached Nassau about the 23d, whence Capt. CRASH called for New-York, arriving on Friday night. The Cambridge was 1,333 tons register, of three decks,

Mr. MILLER, of Utica, has received the appointment of Consul to Hamburg, but declines it. The Pacific Railroad Committee of the Senate have agreed upon a bill substantially as I foreshadowed on the 13th.

Mr. SEWARD presented a petition of 98 citizens of Phelps, N. Y., praying that some measures be adopted for a peaceful and gradual extinction of Slavery by making compensation out of the public treasury. Laid on the table. From the Albany Evening Journal. The trial of Cashier ROBERTSON, on an indict. ment for an attempt to suborn a physician to poison his wife, as it progresses, develops features similar to those belonging to a trial which occurred in this city some forty years ago.

The meeting was called to order at 10 o'clock by President WILDER, who proceeded to read a letter from the "Maryland Institution for promotlog the Mechanic Arts," asking for the location of the next fair of the United States Agricultural Society near the city of Baltimore in the month of October next. The Board of Aldermen met last evening, President CLANCY in the Chair. The first matter of interest was the announcement, by the President, of the appointment of PETER L. FERRIIY Reader of the Board, in place of JOHN CREIGHTON, resigned.

Congress has determined to make a fresh attempt to detect and expose the corruption which is charged upon its members. WVe heartily approve of this proceeding. It will involve a good deal of shame and disgrace, beyond a doubt,-but it will do something toWards curing an evil from which the country suffers more than from all others combined,the dishonesty and corruption of the men to whom is committed the management of its public affairs.

NAVAI..-The Government is now shipping men at the Naval Rendezvous in this City, for the steam frigate Niagara, to go on the Telegraph Laying Expedition in the Spring. The men are to be shipped expressly for the Niagara, for the term of twelve months, unless sooner discharged. We are glad to hear that the Government is now getting for general service the very best men ;

Within the past few months there have been several cases before the Courts of alleged lunatics, whose release from confinement in asylums for the insane, was sought by real or pretended friends. In all such cases the public is naturally very much interested. Silt" is a small word, and represents something still smaller; but both the name and the thing deserve the careful attention of this City and its neighborhood. The time may come when silt will sound as terribly in the ears of New-York, as Hessian Fly sounds in the cars of a Western farmer.

The House of Representallves has added still another to its Committees of Investigation. RAPER.-- In this City, on Sunday, Jan. 17, MARY SHIELD, wife of Bogart W. Raper. in the 41st year of her age. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, at 2 o'clock, on Tuesday afternoon, from her late residence, No. 23 Hester-st. BARNE.--in this City, on Sunday morning. Jan. JEREMIAH BARNE, formerly of Hudson, Columbia Co., in the 61st year of his age.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.-The second performance of " Don Giovanni " last evening attracted an overflowing house-better than the first. The performance was excellent, and elicited well-merited ap. plause. An extensive work like this necessarily improves by repetition, and we are sorry that the close of the season will not permit of its being given many times.

The little town of Dracut, Mass., is supping on horrors. A few days ago there was a horrible case of parricide there. On Thursday last, a young man of 26m JONATHAN HOLLOWELL, cut his throat at his father's house. The cause is supposed to have been depression of spirits, caused by ill health. HALLOWELL had a wife in Rhode Island.

EDWARD BOYLE was this morning brought before the Police Court of this city, charged with the willful murder of his wife, ISABELLA R. BOYLE, in ??, about six miles from here, on Friday night. She was found dead in her home on Saturday morning, her head terriby bruised. BOYLE has made several contradictory statements, and circumstances are very strong against him. him.

ARREST OF PICKPOCKETS.-Twelve pickpockets, eleven males and one female, all English, were arrested last night at the Academy of Music, while professionally engaged. Upon all of them were found one or more wallets, containing sums of money. Eight of the prisoners were taken to the Eighteenth Precinct Police-slation. The rest were conveyed to the Deputy's office.

Mr.HALE made a capital speech in the Senate to-day, on the Kansas question, full of humor and honeyed sarcasm-all tile more effective because of its good nature. Ridicule Is a most effective weapon when handled to advantage, and the Senator from New-Hampshire uses it most skillfully, exposing errors of fact or logic so that it is impossible for the dullest hearer not to understand, whether he chooses to be convinced or no.

The jury in the case of THOMAS W. SMITH, charged with the murder of RICHARD CARTER, came into Court this morning with a verdict of acquittal, and the prisoner was discharged. SMITH'S acquittal was on the ground of insanity. is sister applied to the Court to have charge of him. The matter is held for argument on Thursday.

The St. Louis Republican corrects the Evening Post's story of a mysterious murder at the West. The missing man is David Houton, of Barton, who has relatives in St. Louis. He died at Cleveland while on his way to St. Louks, having fallen into a stream of water while temporarily insane, and receiving injiries which prevented him from rescuing himself. His body was recovered fifteen days afterwards, and taken to Boston, where he was buried.

WM. A. HAM, employed upon a freight train of the New-Jersey Railroad, was accidentally run over and killed by the cars, about 11 o'clock on Monday night, near the depot in Jersey City. The train had just arrived, and he had gone to the rear car for the purpose of removing the red light, when the train was suddenly backed, knocking him down, and all the cars passed over his body.

BURGLARY IN WILLIAMBURG.-On Tuesday morning, between 4 and 5 o'clock, the house of Wm. S. CONANT, Esq., No.28 South Tenth street,Williamsburg, was entered through the front door by means of a skeleton key, by some accomplished burglar. Descending into the basement, with the key of the front door he opened the doors and pantries, and made a general reconoissance of the premises.

The inauguration of Gov. PACKER took place today in front of the Capitol. The oath of office was administered by the Speaker of the Senate. The audience was immense.

THE INVESTIGATION INTO CONGRESSIONAL CORRUPTION.-Our Boston correspondent poohpoohs the inquiry which Congress has ordered into the disposition made of the $80,000 expended by the Middlesex Company in securing the passage of the Tariff act of 1857.

MAY A RAILROAD COMPANY BE HELD RESPONSIBLE FOR THE ESCAPE OF A SLAVE?--The Supreme Court of Illinois decides that it cannot. The base is that of a slave who escaped over the road last Summer. His master pursued him ineffectually, and then sued the Company for "aiding and abetting" the escape. The Supreme Court, Judge SKINNER presiding, has just rendered a decision in favor of the Company. On the 19th December, the London Times published a leading article on the feasibility and propriety of supplying the British West Indies with free emigrant labor from the East Indies, or the Coast of Africa, in the course of which the philanthropists of Exeter Hall were somewhat tartly taken to task for the alleged disastrous results of their experiment of emancipation upon the prosperity of the British Antilles.

We publish this morning some additional European intelligence from our files by the America, whose arrival at Boston was announced in our impression of yesterday. It is considered by the majority of reliable London journals that the great monetary panic has completely subsided.

Holcomb, which resulted in the death of Depriest.

Monsieur Blondel, whose appointment as Belgian Minister to the United States is announced, is the gentleman who represented Belgium at the Court of the Sultan from the Spring of 1849 to the Summer of last year, when, owing to his alleged undue Interference in the Danubian Principalities question, his recall was requested by the Turkish Government.

To their Editor of the, New- York Times: Just so long as it remains so difficuit in your City to procure the conviction and execution of a murderer as it now is, just so long may you look for your almost daily homicides. To the Editor of the New- York Times: That the mild season with which we have been so far blessed has in a large degree mitigated the sufferings of the poor, is not to be doubted, but that it has lessened their number, we may well question, when we peruse the " appeal " lately made ,by the Association for "Improving the Con. edition of the Poor."

MURDEROUS USE OF A SHOT GUN.--TWO MEN SHOT.--HENRY HERRMAN, a German keeping a disreputable house at No. 987 Eighth-avenue, was arrested about 1 yesterday morning, charged with shooting FREDERICK BECKON, of No. 317 Ninth-avenue, and EDWAD LATTEMORE, of No.237 West Thirty-third-street. The two men attempted to get into HEERMAN'S place, but finding the door locked went away.

MOCK-AUCTION SWINDLES.--James P. Lowry, of Newark, N. J., John Henderson, of Stamford, Conn., Michael Jacobs, of No. 456 Grand-street, and Jacob Huglman, of No. 9 Broome-street, complained yesterday at the Mayor's office, of having been swindled at the auction stores No. 53 Cortlandt-Street, No 100 Broadway, corner Park Row and An-street, and No. 166 Broadway. Officers were dispatched to the offices and the keepers compelled to disgorge.

After a season of unprecedented effort and vieissitude, the regular performances at this house came to a close last night. And it was a triumphant close. The house presented a gorgeous appearance; filled in every part with the fashion, beauty, talent, and everything else of the City. Altogether it was a better assemblge than we have seen this season, and a better paying one, we fancy.

Message of the Governor of Wiisconsin-The State " Short." Governor RANDALL'S Message to the Legislature of Wisconsin announces a large increase in the State expenditures. The estimate for 1858 is $525,824,while tile estimated receipts are only $455,578. The probable deficit for the coming year will therefore be $ 0,345. In 1849, the expenditures were only $70,085-not equal to the deficit for this year.

A FOOL AND HIS MONEY, DROVER LOSES $800.-A cattle-drover named LEIGH, from Steuben County, New-York, was robbed near the Ferry in Hoboken, on Tuesday Night, of about $800 in bank bills, the proceeds of a drove of cattle that he had sold in New York on Monday. He had been drinking freely, and had indiscreetly exhibited his money in several bar-rooms.

TKLLING TALES OUT OF SCHOOL.--The Washington correspondent of the Charleston Mercury is a very dangerous friend of the Administration. He seems to be thoroughly posted in the movements and motives of the Southern wing of the Democratic Pary, and he tells what he knows without the slightest considcration of the effect its disclosure may haveupon tile course of public affairs.

It will be noticed that the Pacific Railroad bill, reported to-day by Dr. GWIN, from the Senate's Select Committee on that subject, looks to tile location of the road along the great Central Emigrant route. If this bill becomes a law, the Central is the route sure to be selected, unless it should prove to present insurmountable physical difficulties, which is not anticipated.

PREMATURELT JUBILANT.-The recent escapade of our London namesake on the subject of Slave labor has created a regular furore among our cotemporaries south of Mason and Dixon. Among the most excited and jubilant of them is the South-Side Democrat, which fairly effervesces with joyous delight at theimagined prospect of a return to Slave labor in the British West Indian provinces.

DEATH FROM BURNS.--Coroner CONNERY held an inquest yesterday, at No. 480 Madison-street, upon the body of ANNA WALSH, a child three years of age, who died from the effects of burns received the evening previous. The mother had left the deceased and an infant sister in the room together, and on her return found the room filled with smoke and the eldest child fatally burned.

During the session of the State Military Association to-day an ineffectual effort was made by Col. KING for the passage of a resolution providing for the appointment of a Committee to amend the military laws of the State. A resolution was unanimously adopted against any change in uniforms being allowed, except to the regulation uniform.

Naples has been so often described that it would seem like carrying pepper to Hindostan, to attempt another sketch of it. Yet, familiar as I had supposed myself with every feature of its physiognomy, it struck me with all the force and vivacity of novelty. It is a much handsomer and fresher city, in its general aspect, more elegant and imposing, than I had imagined.

The rural districts of Massachusetts send practical men to the Legislature. A Boston paper tells the following: "One of our merchants while sitting in his counting-room, cogitating upon the hard times, had his reveries disturbed by the entrance of a gentle-man. 'Do you want any last-rate brooms? `No,' he replied, 'we have a full supply.' 'I've got some very cheap,' was the rejoinder. 'I made 'em myself, and I'm a member of the Legislater.' "

Returns of the Kansas election, received in St. Louis, as published over the signature of Gov. DENVAR and the presiding officers of the Territo. rial Legislature, show that the Free-State men elected their entire State ticket by an average majority of 415. The majority against the Constitution, counting in the alleged frauds in Oxford, Shawnee, Kickapoo, and other places, is 1,226.

From the Chicago Press Sheriff RAYMOND, of Kendall County, arrived in this city last evening, having in custody one JOHN BRANNER, charged with the murder of ANTOINE CONRAD, near Newark, in that County, on Friday, the 15th inst., under circumstances of the most cold blooded brutality. The parties are both Germans. CONRAD was a respectable farmer and a man of family.

To the Editor of the New-York Times : Dr. SPENCER cites my synoptical history of the war for Independence, entitled Seventeen Hundred and Seventy Sir, in support of statements in his History of the United States, concerning the Wyoming Massacre. That work was prepared in the year 18-16, and published in June, 1847.

The bill to increase the Army, reported in the Senate to-day, added two new companies to each regiment, bat authorizes no new regiments. The report is to be finally acted upon by the Committee on Monday next.

THE CENTRAL PARK COMMISSIONERS.--No one who has had any experience in the management of either public or private affairs, will deny the truth of the homely old adage that too many cooks spoil the broth. When there are many men there must necessarily be many minds, and many minds in all affairs of business infallibly create confusion, and lead to the obstruction of work.

I am aware that there is still afloat about in the community a vague prejudice against what is called book-learning. One sometimes hears doubts expressed of the utility of public libraries; opinions that they are rather ornamental than necessary or useful: and the fact that our time-honored city has subsisted more than two centuries without one, is a sufficient proof that, until within a very few years, their importance has not been practicaliy felt.

The valedictory Message of Governor GRIMES, of lowa, congratulates the Legislature upon the continued prosperity of the State. The Legislature meets this year under the new Constitution. From Le Follet. We have not yet arrived at the cold season, when fur becomes absolutely necessary; but we already observe that it is much used as a trimming for basquints, paletots, and certainty nothing can have a more elegant appearance than a handsome pardessits of velvet, ornamented with this material. The basquine is made shorter than those of taffetas worn in the Autumn. Even the burnous is sometimes trimmed with fur.

Small-Pox. To the Editor of the New-York Times: Much excitement exists at the present time throughout the City in regard to this loathsome disease, and many very exaggerated reports are daily circulated respecting it. The increase of deaths in the last week's report of the City Inspector seems to have increase the excitement. In numberless instances the question is asked, "Is re-vaccination necessary?"

From the London Illustrated News. The hotels in the great cities of America in New-York, Philadelphia, Baltimore, Washington, New-Orleans, Chicago, Boston, conducted on a peculiar system, and in a style of much magnificence. The British Isles possess no such caravanserais. Even the monster Hotel du Lonvie. In Paris, is not to be compared with such establishments as the St. Nicholas, the Metropelitan, the Lafarge House, the Astor House, and many others in New-York.

RANDOM REFLECTIONS.-Next to that of umbrellas. the ownership of books is perhaps the least respected. Hence the philosophical though rude remark that fools lend books, and wise men borrow them. The value of a "good thing" depends on him who utters it. The joke of the host is certain to be laughed at ; that of the poor relation is scarcely even listened to.

" NOBODY TO BLAME!" Coroner SNELL'S inquest on the bodies of three of the children suffocated at the fire in Public School Building No. 14, was concluded yesterday, and the Jury rendered a verdict. TROUBLE AT THE RED RIVER SETTLEMENT.--A correspondent of the Toronto Globe, writing from the Red River Settlement of the North, states that an actual ?? bellion has taken place in the settlement against the Hudson's Bay Company, which claims not only a monopoly of the trade, but the monopoly of the soil.

ATTEMPTED SUICIDE.--An Englishman named WHITEHOUSE attempted to commit suicide on Thursday night, at his boarding house, No. 44 York-street, Jersey City, by cutting his throat with a razor. Mr. WHITEHOUSE is about 60 years of age, has been in this country for 30 years, and was for many years, until July last, employed in the establishment of BATES Co., in Maiden-lane.

On Thursday night some excitement arose among our people on account of a report that WM. STRICKLAND was yet in the city. The police had failed to ascertain whether the report was true or not, and, in order that all excitement might be allayed at once and forever, it was resolved that a meeting of the citizens be called the next day at 11 o'clock.

Rev, WM. MILBURN, well known as "the blind preacher," has delivered two of a series of three lectures on "Christian, Poetry," before respectable, though not very large audiences, in the new chapel of the M. E. Church, corner of Fourth-avenue and Twenty-second-street. The second lecture, on ",Christian Hymns to the end of the Reformation," was given last evening.

BEVERLY L. CLARKE, of Kentucky, appointed minister resident of the United States to the Republic of Guatemala; to be also minister resident of the United States to the Republic of Honduras, pursuant to the Ninth section of the act of Congress of the 18th of August, 1856, entitled "An Act to regulate the diplomatic and consular systems of the United States."

THE LAST DODGE:--A lady from Mamaroneck came into town the other day, and went shopping up Broadway, as young ladies sometimes will, When she came out of a store with several small bundles she dropped one, and instantly picking it up started on. A well-dressed man stepped up to her politely and informed her that she had picked uP his bundle. She protested that it was her own, but he insisted.

INOFFENSIVE LAWS---Two years ago an act was passed by Congress, which seemed so entirely free from objectionable features that the most factious person could not have thought it necessary to oppose its passage. It was simply a law, empowering the Secretary of the Navy to change the names of ships at the request of their owners.

We have already noticed Senator DOHERTY'S bill for reducing the number of the Central Park Commission, and for conferring the appointment of its members upon the Mayor and Aldermen of this City. The principle of his proposed amendment is undoubtedly just. This is purely and exclusively a City Commission, and should be appointed by the City authorities.

Mrs. CORA HATCH made her appearance at the Stuyvesant Institute last evening, to speak on any topic elating to Spirit life which might be selected by the audience. The audience was large, intelligent and attentive. A Committee, selected for the purpose, propounded the following as the text for Mrs. HATCH: "We desire a detailed account of the scenery, amusements and employment of the angels." The lady went into her trance, and spoke for an hour

The 4 P.M. train from New-York on the New-Haven road on Thursday, when between Corse Cob and Stamford, ran over a man, cutting both legs off. The train backed up to him, by which time he was dead. His name was NEWMAN. He resided in the neighbohood. They say he was a sober-good man; but how he came to be walking on the track is unknown.

WALLACK'S THEATRE.-Mr. LESTER one of the best light comedians of the age, and who is entirely Without an equal in this City, takes his benefit tonight. THEODORE PARKER DISCHARGES HIS "MUSKET" AT THE SOUND MEN OR BOSTON.--Mr. THEODORE PARKER DISCHARGES HIS "MUSKET" AT THE SOLID MEN OR BOSTON.-Mr. THEODORE PARKER delivered a lecture at New-Bedford on Tuesday night, and among other things wise and witty he said: "The aristocratic families of Boston began from some bare-legged and bare-footed ancestors, and by-and-by will become bare-legged and bare-footed again."

From the Picayune 10th At about 2 o' clock yesterday afternoon a young tornado burst upon the city, accompanied by rain, which fall in torrents. doing, for the time is lasted, an immensity of damage. ships and steamboats were torn from their moorings ; signs, slates and awnings were huarled from their positions and seat waltzing trough space ; trees and horses were blown down,

THE LEGISLATURE.-The State Assembly has spent three weeks in trying to elect a Speaker. They came very near it on Saturday, and it is not impossible that they may succeed to-day. The first business that should be done, when the Legislature gets into working order, is providing for the election of Speaker hereafter by a plurality vote,-after a certain number of unsuccessful trials for a majority.

A meeting of the Board of Commissioners of Metropolitan Police was held on Saturday at 3 P. M. at their office, corner of Broome and Elizabeth strocts. The proceedings were unusually brief. All the members of the Board were present. Mayor TIEMANN was not in attendance at the commencement of the session, but entered subsequently and took his seat.

Mr. DELANEY thought the journal should not be amended. He thought the Journal was correct as it as, and that the ruling of the Clerk was right.

LAW FOR THE PROTECTION OF GAS CONSUMERS.-We do not know the precise number of gas consumers, or rather gas customers, there may be in New-York and Brooklyn, but whatever the number may be, there will be just so many persons who will rejoice in knowing that a bill has been introduced into our State Senate to protect them from the impositions and extortions of the gas companies.

To the Editor of the Express: Some two years previous to the death of Colonel BURR, who was then residing at the corner of Go?? and Fulton streets, sick and bed-ridden, I went, accompanied by his relative and staunch friend, the late Mr. OGDEN E. EDWARDS, to see him, and found him helpless, and needing greatly the attention that woman only can bestow.

The tables on the Kansas question seem to be turned. The Free-State ticket at the late election has put an entirely new aspect upon the Lecompton Constitution. Hitherto its adoption by Congress has been advocated by the south, and resisted by the North. It has been regarded as the only means of fastening slavery upon Kansas, and throwing her political weight into the Pro-Slavery scale.

Mr. FRANCIS P. BLAIR, JR., in his speech on the President's Message, discussed a topic to which the Slave Power, were it not blinded and maddened by its last for university dominion, would open wide its eyes. It was based on a proposed resolution of inquiry as to the expediency of our Government acquiring some portion of Central or South America, for the ultimate colonization therein of the emancipated slaves of the United States.

The Senate Committee on Foreign Relations will report probably on Monday next, unanimously in favor of preserving the Neutrality laws just as as they are--and all the members of the Committee, save Mr. DOUGLAS, will be found to concur in the construction of the law of 1818, which extends the right and power of the Government to follow persons suspected of having violated it anywhere upon the high seas.

It is reported that it was yesterday decided that Lieut.-Gen. SCOTT should proceed to the Pacific shore for the purpose of organizing, in California and Oregon, another expedition for Utah, to cooperate with that which is now in Winter quarters at Fort Bridger. Whether he is to raise a regular or a volunteer force will depend upon the action of Congress.

The annual Ball, in behalf of the Fire Department Fund, tool place at the Academy of Music last evening. Fifteen hundred tickets were sold, and about $5,0010 were netted for the Fund. The loss by the total destruction of Mr. THRAL'S building, at the corner of Asylun and 'High streets, on Friday night last, will foot lip in ToundAnumbers about $100,000. The building is a complete mass of ruins, and nothing remains standing but a portion of its walls.

Our last advices are of the 19th instant, Our Money Market remains in the same easy condition. On the Stock Exchange the demand for State Stocks and solid securities has been more moderate; whilst at the same time some speculative demand has been manifested for Railroad Shares land for other values of a speculative nature.

CITY RAILROAD ACCIDENT.--WM. KAMP, a butcher residing at No. 120 Dey-street, had his left foot run over at 11 o'clock Sunday evening by one of the Eighth-avenue Railroad cars, and so horribly mangled that it is feared amputation will be necessary.

Private dispatches received here to-day seem abundantly to confirm the statement that Gen. CALHOUN has counted in all the Pro-Slavery State officers of Kansas and a Pro-Slavery majority of the Legislature. Senator DOUGLAS failed to get the floor to-day to report the bill to admit Minnesota, but it is all ready.

Being on the eve of starting for Hong Kong, and not expecting on our arrival there to have time or opportunity to write to you before the departure of the Overland mail, I deem it best to take time by the forelock and give you a summary of North China and Japan news. Your correspondent being attached to a ship whose motions are notoriously eccentric and uncertain, must be excused for occasionally anticipating the same.

RACHEL was the title by which the great Tragedienne was usually known. Were her full cognemen given, it would be ELIZABETH RACHEL FELIX. No record of her birth exists, save that she saw light in a wretched Swiss tavern. Her parents were specimens of that nomadic tribe of Israelites who go about the world, gipsy-like, finding a living by any means promising the return of a pittance.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: We have had so many glowing accounts of the strength if the Costa Rican force on the San Juan River, and of the preparations being made, both in Costa Rica and in Nicaragua, to meet the fillibusters, that the success of Col. ANDERSON seems to have surprised every one except those practically acquainted with Central America and Central Americans.

The Bums Club of this City celebrated the ninety-ninth anniversary of the great Scottish poet's birth, at the Metropolitan Hotel last night. About one hundred and fifty persons partook of a fine dinner, the Highland piper, Mr. WILLIAM CLELLAN), dressed in the Gaelic costume, playing, from time to time, on the bagpipes some stirring national marches.

MEYER,-In this City, on Sunday, Jan. 24, suddenly of hemorrhage of the lungs, SARAH M. HOPPER, wife of John S. Meyer.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR: I observe in your issue of Saturday, 28th, a statement by a correspondent that the name of Sir WALTER RALEIGH is pronounced by Englishmen, Rally. I beg to say that the statement is wholly erroneous:

The House met at 11 o'clock. Mr. HOWELL asked that the journal might be read slowly so that all might understand what was done during the exciting session of Saturday. After reading the journal, several motions were made to amend it, and the time of the House was occupied till 12 o'clock in making corrections.

To the Editor of the New-York times: One cause adds largely to the aggregate of individual suffering this Winter. Hundreds of men are walking our streets unatic to procure employment who, prior to the 15th April last, when the Metropolitan Police act took effect, were members of the City Police , and are so still, though not recognized as such by the Board of Police.

Street Commissioner CONOVER sent another Commication to the Common Council last 1ight, exposing some of the scandalous frauds which he has discovered in the archives of his Department. and showing how systematically tile people of New-York have been cheated, swindled, bamboozled and plucked, by the coniractors for street grading and paving,

LARGE HAUL OF COUNTERFEIT MONEY--A MYSTERY. --TWO Irish laborers, named MITCHELL and SMITCHETT, on Sunday afternoon stumbled on $700 of counterfeit live-dollar bills on the Morris County Bank , N. J., which they found concealed in a stone fence in Fifth-avenue, near Seventy-first-street.

INCREDIBLE.-It is stated by some of the Washington correspondents of the Press that the President intends to recall one. of our Ministers now abroad, on the ground that he is " not qualified for the duties of the place." We do not give the slightest credit to the report.

The ostensible motive for the arrest of JACK HENDERSON, here, was a charge of tampering with the election returns. The charge was no doubt true, and his arrest legal ; but the Free State men had another motive for preventing his leaving the Territory just at this time.

Our readers will bear us witness that the TIMES has constantly and steadily endeavored to put the best construction which a regard for truth and justice would permit, upon the action of the Administration in regard to Kansas.

GIRLS TO THE WEST.--The Children's Aid Society sent out yesterday, under charge of Mr. C. C. TRACY, a party of 70 poor children and unemployed trades' girls to the West. This girls' emigration is turning out very successful. The girls are very much liked in the West, and write home the best accounts of their situation.

A STARVING WOMAN.--A lady passing down Broadway, near Fourteenth-street, a few days since, when opposite a butcher's stand, was startled by the excited appearance of an intelligentlooking woman rushing toward her, with clasped hands and a look of despair, exclaiming "I am hungry, I am hungry " Stepping inside the store the lady procured for her some potatoes and a piece of meat.

CHARITABLE CONCERT.--A concert will be given th is evening at the chapel of the Home of the Friendlees, No. 29 East Twenty-ninth-street, to which we desire to call attention. The entertainment will be attractive in a musical point of view, but it appeals to the public on other and wider grounds. The charity, in aid of which the concert is given,

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The questions of Currency and Credit are once more the order of the day, and the means of so regulating them as to prevent those violent revulsions which periodically derange the business world have been widely discussed.

Mr. DOUGLAS, from the Committee on Territories, reported a bill for the admission of the State of Minnesota into the Union. It was read and placed on the calendar. A message was received from the House. announce ing the death of Messrs. BRENTON and LOCKHART, elected to the former Congress from Indiana.

The steamship Tennessee has arrived from Vera Cruz, 21st inst., bringing highly important news from Mexico. The country was in a complete state of anarchy. Nearly all the mail stages between Vera Cruz and the capital had been robbed.

At the meeting of the Board of Supervisors, yesterday afternoon, President PURDY in the Chair, resolutions were adopted to refer the subject of appropriations for the River and Mounted Police to the appropriate committee. The following communication was then received from the Mayor and referred, and then the Board adjourned to Tuesday Next, at 3 P. M.:

THE POWER OF PUBLIC OPINION IN ENGLAND.--Not long since the London Times, or some other London paper, expressed the conviction that there was no such thing as an influential public opinion in this country, which had a restraining or stimulating effect upon our Executive; and the occasion of the remark was an appointment, we believe, made by Mr. BUCHANAN.

Rev. W. H. Milburn's lecture on Aaron Buric. The fourth of the course of seven lectures for the benefit of the "Ladies' Union Aid Society for Aged and Infirm," was delivered last evening in Clinton Hall by Rev. by Rev. W. H. MILBURN.

MURDER AND LYNCH LAW AT BROWNSVILLE, TEXAS.--E. J. McLANE, Esq.. Justice of the Peace for Brownsville, was murdered a few days since, by a Mexican. The Mexican and his wife were quarreling, when Mr. McLANE, happened to pass by their jacal, and entering, interfered.

From the Albany Evening Journal. The errors in Mr. PARTON'S Life of Buff, which we sought to correct in a former article, were found in newspapers. We had not than, nor indeed have we yet. read the book. One of as loose and irresponsible in money matters-is to be corrected in a new edition.

STEWART.--In this City, on Tuesday, Jan. 26, at his residence. No. 74 West 20th St., JOHN STEWART, a native of Perthshire, Scotland, in the 61st year of his age. The friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend his funeral, on Thursday, Jan. 28, at 2 o'clock P.M. HENRY.--In this City, on Tuesday evening, Jan. 26, MARIA ANNE, wife of Michael Henry.

LOTTERY POLICY DEALERS.--The crusade commenced against dealers in lottery policies is being prosecuted with vigor. WM. T. MORTON, whose office is in Avenue B, between Sixth and Seventh streets; CHARLES MILLER, of No. 26 Sheriff-street, and JOHN EDWARDS, of No. 100 Whitehall-street, were yesterday brought before the Mayor charged with selling lottery policics, and committed to answer the charge in $1,500 bail each.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR: I take advantage of the general feeling of horror in the community in regard to the Brooklyn school calamity, to call the attention of the proper parties to another building, where, under the present arrangement, a similar accident is not at all improbable.

CURIOUS ASSERTIONS OF GENERAL WALKER RELATIVE TO GOVERNMENT ACTION. MOBILE, Tuesday, Jan. 26. An enthusiastic meeting was held here on Monday night, at which speeches were made by WM. WALBER, Parson BROWNLOW and others. WALKER disclosed the secret of the Government opposition to his Nicaraguan schemes, which was a rejection of their proposition that he should go to Mexico, and incite war there,

Mr. BERNHISEL, the delegate from the Territory of Utah, seeks a peaceful settlement of the difficulties between the Mormons and the United States Government. He alleges that, had it not been for the troops which were sent to that region with hostile intentions, there would have been presented now "no horrid front of civil war ;" that they exasperated the people there.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In the NEW-YORK TIMES of the 21st inst. you did me the honor to publish my letter in relation to "The Perils to our New-York Harbor." On the 22d you published another letter from an anonymous writer in reply to mine;

REPORTED BOMBARDMENT OF VERA CRUZ.--A rumor was circulated about the City yesterday afternoon to the effect that the Spanish fleet had bombarded Vera Cruz. This was caught up by certain parties, and telegraphed to Boston and many other places as reliable intelligence, and, as a matter of course, created quite a sensation.

OMNIBUS DRIVERS BEFORE THE MAYOR.--The passage of the recent ordinance prohibiting omnibus drivers from stopping in front of theatres and places of amusement to solicit passengers, happily is not likely to prove a dead letter. SAMUEL McKEE, of the Fourth-avenue Line,

ARREST OF THE GOSHEN BANK ROBBERS.--The Cleveland Plaindcaler says: Sometime in November the Goshen Bank of New-York was robbed of $30,000 in bills of that Bank. Hearing that money of this description to quite an amount had been offered to some of our bankers,

AN UNPARALLELED HONOR.--A mark of respect was shown yesterday to the memory of General HAVELOCK which was worth more than a peerage. The flags of the shipping in our harbor, and on our public buildings, were displayed at half-mast during the day, as a token of grief for his loss.

SCHOOL CHILDREN.--The teachers of Public School No. 5 found a strange panic prevailing among their scholars, yesterday morning. Several of the smaller ones were crying all the morning, while the stouter ones were discussing at all possible opportunities the methods they should adopt in case of a fire. On inquiry,

A ROYAL WEDDING.--It is eighteen years since the heart of John Bull was made happy by a Royal wedding, though during that time he has had the felicity of enjoying a good many Royal christenings. But day before yesterday all England was made merry by the wedding of one of the Royal family,

According to the official documents the necessary expenses incurred for the suppression of the Indian hostilities in Washington Territory were nearly $1,500,000, and the total expenses unpaid in Oregon or similar purposes are $4,500,000. For the maintenance of the volunteer force in the former, not including the pay of the volunteers, the expense was $961,000, and in the latter over $3,000,000.

The report made to-day by the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations is likely to provoke an interesting discussion, when the subject is again taken up next month--although the fact that the Committee propose no amendments, giving more efficiency to the law of 1818, has a tendency to reconcile the fillibusters to the Committee's action.

JACKSON-STREET FERRY FRANCHISE.--A tenyears' lease of the franchises for running a ferry from Jackson-street, East River, to Hudson-avenue, Brooklyn, was sold yesterday by the Comptroller, and was purchased by JAMES WILSON, at $500 a year. The conditions under which this sale is made are the same as those of the Union Ferry Company, as far as applicable.

Mr. Zebedee Cook died at his house, at South Framingham, Mass., on Sunday evening, aged 72. He had been for some years a resident of the City of New-York, but, for the greater part of his active life, he did business in Boston, and resided here or in the neighborhood. His commanding figure and amiable countenance are yet freshly remembered amongus.

NEW-YORK, 12 M.--Mild and showery, Wind S. Ther. 52[degrees], Barometer 30-160. NEW-YORK, 2. P. M. --Ther. 55[degrees] Fahr : barometer 30[degrees]; falling rain all morning; Winds S. W., very light. NEW-YORK, 6 P. M. --Raining. Wind S. Ther.55[degrees]. NEW-YORK, 9 P.M.--Cloudy and rainy. Wind S. Ther, 52[degrees].

A GOOD DEED IN A NAUGHTY WORLD.--A little incident springing from the kindly natures and habits of Sunday-School No. 69, attached to the Seventh Presbyterian Church in this city, (Rev. Mr. SMITH, pastor,) deserves record. It appears the pastor of the Presbyterian Church in West Hoboken, N.J., (Rev. Mr. EGBERT,) was for many years a much cherished and active teacher in this School, and since his settlement in the ministry has not been forgotten.

There was a large meeting of the corporators, of the Methodist Episcopal Church, Johnstreet, in the Lecture-room of the building, on Monday evening, to hear the report of the Committee. The Chair was occupied by Mr. ROBERT CURTIS, and Mr. WM. KELLY acted as Secretary. After prayer the report was read.

SUNDAY OBSERVANCE.--A meeting of the evangelical clergymen of the City was held in Spingler Institute on Monday evening to consult as to what measures can be taken to secure the enforcement of existing laws for the prevention of labor, travel, and amusement, on the First day of the week, and the enactment of new and more stringent laws to that effect;

SUICIDE IN A PISTOL GALLERY.--A shocking suicide occurred last night at the pistol-gallery of Mr. OITIGNON, in Broadway, adjacent to Lafayette Hall, by a young man, whose name is unknown. It appears that about a quarter to 9 o'clock the deceased entered the above place, and after firing a round of eight or ten shots with a pistol, which he paid for, he stated that he would shoot a couple of shillings worth.

Governor VIDAURRI, of Nuevo Leon and Coahuila, has declared for resistance against the recent coup d'etat at the Capital, and issued a proclamation calling his people to arms in support of the Constitution of 1857, by it overturned. Matamoras also, and the people of Tamaulipas generally, with Governor GARZA at their head, had refused to accede to the new order of things, and civil war seemed inevitable.

On Thursday last, I wrote that unless the Republicans should on the next day succeed in electing their candidate for Speaker, they would not at any future period be able to effect that result. They ad journed on that day without having effected an organization, and to-day my prophecy has been verified, by the defeat of every one of their caucus nominees for the various officers of the House.

By the brig N. Stetson, Captain TRENIS, arrived yesterday from Campeachy the 6th inst., and Sisal the 10th, we have several days' later advices from that distracted country, the very latest possible. Negotiations for peace between the two politicalparties have thus far proved utterly fruitless, and the general relations of the combatants show no material change.

MR. HICKS' EULOGY ON CRAWFORD.--THOMAS HICKS, the artist, delivered a fitting eulogy, before a fit audience, last evening, on the life and works of the late THOMAS CRAWFORD, the sculptor, at the Century Club. Mr. HICKS was a personal friend of the subject of his eulogy, as were the greater number of his hearers,

AT THE NAVY YARD- The Niagara was taken into dock on Saturday: considerable difficulty was experienced on account of there not being sufficient water at her stern: notwithsanding the active use, for some time past, of dredging machines to deepen the channel. Her copper remains uninjured. They are encasing her stern in heavy composition plates, to protect it against the chain when the anchor is overrun.

FALSE LIGHTS.--The people of the South have recently had their attention called to the acquisition of territory in Central America; and the hero of Nicaragua has been the cause of great expenditure of Southern indignation against an Administratinn which, by the force of circumstances, now stands forth for Southern rights and justice in Kansas, and staggers under blows inflicted, in consequence, by politicians and States of the North.

VIRGINIA CIVILIZATION.--If some future historian, while investigating the manners and customs of Virginia, in 1858, should happen to encounter the documents which will be found in another column of this morning's TIMES, from two of the prominent public men of that State, he would probably come to the conclusion that the Old Dominion had not then emerged from barbarism.

REVISING AND REVILING THE PRESS.-Rev. Mr. KALLOCH, of Boston, and Hon. WINTER DAVIS, of Maryland, have both of them lately, and almost simultaneously, expressed opinions in relation to the morality and the mission of the Press which were not by any means complimentary to the "lever of public opinion," but quite the reverse.

ATTEMPTS TO PASS COUNTERFEIT MONEY.--An Irish woman, Catharine Kingsley, was arrested yesterday by Officer Bumsted, of the Nineteenth Ward, charged with attempting to pass a counterfeit $5 bill on the Morris County Bank, New-Jersey. She offered the bill at five different places, was told in each place that it was bad, and finally Mr. Samuel Cardwell, of No. 463 Third-avenue, had her arrested.

THE UTICA FIRE.--The Utica Herald gives the following account of the damage by the recent fire in Genesee-street: The building destroyed belonged to E. M. GILBERT, and was insured for $2,000 in the Etna Insurance Company. Loss is estimated at $4,000.

Act for another Constitutional Convention. A bill for another Constitutional Convention had been introduced into the Kansas Territorial legislature. This Convention is to meet at Topeka, on the third Monday in March, and the Constition will be framed and submitted to the people in time to be sent up during the present session of Congress.
WAR IS MEXICO.--It will be seen, from a telegram published in our columns this morning, that civil war in Mexico is in full blast. The event has been, for some time, anticipated.

MATRIMONIAL INFELICITY. ---There is a curious difficulty now in progress in one of our colored churches, the facts of which we give as nearly as we can from a some what roundabout hearsay. Two members of the church---man and wife---are so unfortunate as to live unhappily.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Sir: In your paper of this morning, I perceive that from the story of a robbery on Third-avenue, you derive the wholesome moral for travelers who " carry weight " that they should " take a cab." Certainly the advice is excellent.

AN INFERNAL "INFERNAL MACHINE."-WM. SMITH and WM. PEAK, nail-makers, were arrested, Thursday, charged with attempting to take the lives of GEORGE and ROBERT CARTER and JOHN A. FARRELL, by the use of an infernal machine. PEAK is engaged in the nail-making business at the Point. A few weeks since, GEORGE CARTER, who had been in his employ, opened a shop and carried on a rival business at No. 109 Pennsylvania-avenue, Third Ward.

THE EQUESTRIAN STATUE OF WASIIINGTON SAFE ON ITS PEDESTAL.-It gives us (Richmond Enquirer) inexpressible pleasure to announce that yesterday, in the presence of thousands of citizens of our own and other States, CRAWFORD'S equestrian statue of WASHINGTON was elevated to its summit-pedestal on the monument.

PAWNBROKERS'SHOPS.-The '; Mont de Piete is now a recognized institution in all the principal cities of Europe. Being neither more nor less than a loan office or Pawnbroker's shop, its naTne will probably sound inappropriate to American ears. But the "Mont de Piete," we believe, was originally created in Paris for the benefit of the hospitals, and hence its designation.

The United States Mail steamship Moses Taylor, JOHN McGOWAN commanding, arrived at this port last evening, having left Aspinwall on the 19th inst. The steamer John L. Stevens, from San Francisco at 12 M. on Jan. 5, connected with the Moses Taylor at the Isthmus.

ARREST OF MODEL ARTISTS.--Mayor Tiemann, through his squad of Special Police, commenced Warfare on Tuesday night against model artist establishments in the City. The place selected for the first official visit was the establishment known as the Francisco Hotel, at No. 13 Howard-street, kept by a German, named August Myer.

The ship Sylvanus Blanchard, Capt. LAWRENCE, which sailed hence on the 27th for New-Orleans, got ashore, at 7 o'clock the same right, upon Honier Shoal, where she remained thumping badly for over nine hours. The stearn-tugs Huntress and Hercules succeeded in hauling her off yesterday morning, at 4 1/2 o'clock, after which she was towed up to Atlantic Dock. She will go on to the Dry Dock for examination.

SIR: As required, I have the honor to report that, in obedience to instructions from the Colonel commanding the army for Utah, I marched in command of six companies Second Dragons three miles from Fort Leavenworth, and encamped on the afternoon of the 17th of September.

The Secretary of the Treasury, in response to the resolution of Senator WILSON, has communicated to the Senate a statement showing the amounts of revenue collected during the six years to June last, together with the expenses and number of employes. The total amount is $355,500,000, and the expense of collection was $21,752,000. In 1852 the number of employes were 2.530. and in 1853 3.088.

By the arrival of the Cunard steamship Canada at Halifax, we receive three days later intelligence from Europe. Our readers will be gratified to learn that the missing steamship Ariel, about the safety of which there was some anxiety, has met with no very serious accident. After she had been several days out from Southampton she broke her shaft, and was compelled to put back to Cork, under sail, for repairs.

A CITY POST-OFFICE.--Several of the City journals are suggesting various sites and plans for a City Post-Oflice,--one recommending the present City Hall another the Astor House, a third the Hospital, , All these suggestions may be very wise, but they are quite useless, for the simple reason that the money appropriated by the Government will not suffice to buy them.

THE LAWS OF MARRIAGE.--Marrying in haste, the old proverb says, is very apt to lead to repentance at leisure. The young lady, whose clandestine marriage has occupied the attention of our Courts for several (lays past, seems to have discovered the folly of her elopement, after the comparatively brief space for reflection which these proceedings afforded.

Mr. JEFFERSON DAVIS' bill, providing for the increase of the national army by five new regiments, for the ostensible purpose of enabling our troops in Utah to rescue the Administration from the melancholy plight into which it has so senselessly plunged itself, is now on its trial before the Senate.

Mr. FOOT introduced a proposition as an amendment to Mr. DAVIS' Pacific Railroad Bill, in case that of the majority of the Select Committee shall fail. The latter bill had his concurrence in the Committee, but if it was defeated he wished to add a clause for a northern route to the bill of Mr. DAVIS. Mr. DAVIS said that his bill did not specify any route.

THE DEMOCRACY AND THE LECOMPTON CONSTITUTION.--The Washington Union has a long and vehement appeal "to every true Democrat, North and South, in and out of Congress. in the Union,"-intended evidently to foreshadow the President's Message on. Kansas Affairs, and to inform the Democratic Party that this question is to be made a test of party fidelity.

STATEN ISLAND ENJOYMENTS.-The Staten Islanders this Winter have not only enjoyed the freedom of navigation on the Bay, which the mild and open season has insured against ice and storms, but they are unusually "jolly" at home. The old Staten Island Historical Society have supplied weekly free lectures, alternately, at Factoryville and Port Richmond.

The steamship Isabel, from Havana on the 25th instant, has arrived here. The Mail steamship Philadelphia, from New-York on the 19th instant, for Havana and New-Orleans, and the English Mall steamer, had not arrived at Havana on the 25th instant. The steamship Grenada, from Aspinwall, arrived at Havana on the 23d inst.

ARE THEY SAFE?--At the last meeting of the Board of Education a resolution was adopted, instructing the Committee on Buildings to visit and examine into the construction and arrangement of the heating apparatus of the several public schools, and also whether the width and formation of the stairs are such as to afford safe egress for the children in case of alarm from fire or otherwise;

Dock Masters to be appointed by the Mayor and Aldermen--Progress of the Street Department Investigation. BOARD OF ALDERMEN. The Board of Alderman met last evening, President CLANCY in the chair. A communication was received from Rev. Mr. Pease, of the Five Points House of industry, asking an appropriation of manure to be used on the farm of that Institution, in East Chester. The communication was referred to the Committee on cleaning streets.

FIRE IN BROADWAY-NARROW ESCAPES.Early yesterday morning a fire broke out in the fourth story of No. 691 Broadway. kept by Mr. A. PETELER as confectionary saloon and boarding house. Tile smoke was seen by Officer ROE, of tile Fifteenth Ward, issuing from the upper windows. After giving an alarm the officer rushed immediately up stairs and awoke the occupants of the place, who barely had time to escape with their lives.

CHICHESTER.--In this City, on Thursday, Jan. 28, Mrs. ELIZABETH CHICHESTER, in the 84th year of her age. The friends and relatives, also those of her sons and sons-in-law, are respectfully invited to attend her funeral from the house of her son-in-law, Wm., H. Harbeck, No. 287 5th av., on Saturday, Jan. 30, at 1 o'clock P. M. MILLER.--In this City. on Wednesday evening, Jan. 27, JOSEPHINE.

The steamer Fanny Fern, bound to St. Louis from Pittsburg, with 400 tons of produce, 15 cabin and 20 deck passengers, exploded her boiler at 2 o'clock this afternoon, 18 miles below this city. Fifteen lives are reported to be lost, including Capt. WOODWARD, several deck hands and firemen, and three ladies.

Before Justices Osborn and Kelly. The Court was opened at 9 1/2 o'clock. There were 34 prison cases, 5 suspended cases, and 11 bail cases---50 altogether---on the Calendar. William Scott (colored) was arraigned on a charge of stealing five dozen files, Jan. 27. Robert Elder was the complainant. The prisoner was found guilty.

Whether the world has, or has not, reached the actual circumstances of the case,

A German named LOUIS WETTERHAHN, in the employ of Mr. J. McDONALD, pie-baker in Columbia-street, Newark, on Thursday night took a large dose of arsenic, from the effects of which he died yesterday afternoon. Family difficulties are assigned as the cause. Capt. ROBERT COOPER, of Freeport, Pa., committed suicide by drowning on Friday night last, at Mr. JOHN KARN's landing, in the Allegheny river.

THE LAND REFORMERS.--The Executive Committee of the Land Reform Association met on Wednesday evening, at No. 454 Broadway. JOHN COMMERFORD, the President, read a letter from the President of tile United States, in reply to a communication from the Association to him proposing a plan of building the Pacific Railroad.

LUCY STONE has recently been making herself more than usually conspicuous by refusing to pay her taxes, and having her goods sold out in due course. Some people are in a great rage with her, because, being married, she continues to assert her independence of her husband by refusing to obey the law;

The House met at 11 o'clock, as per order, and in more order than usual. After some minor proceedings Mr. ALVORD was conducted to the Speaker's desk. His appearance brought from his political friends a round of hearty cheers, showing that he had ardent adherents in the thronged galleries.

The R. M. steamship Canada, Capt. LANG, left Liverpool at 10:20 o'clock on the morning of the 16th instant. Called off Cork on the morning of Sunday, the 17th, and took in the mails and sixty-six passengers of the disabled ship Ariel, proceeded about noon of the same day, and arrived at Halifax at 4 o'clock this morning.

From the Washington Union. The Government is now in the hands of the Democrats. Its President, its Cabinet, its Congress are Democratic, and have been made so by the voice and vote of the individual Democrats throughout the nation. A common responsibility, therefore, rests on all Democrats, as well in office as out of office, to quell these rebellions, and to restore law and order to both Kansas and Utah.

Those who fancy that the ages of chivalry are indeed past, and who complain of the level monotony of modern life, will be not a little startled by the account which we publish to-day of the defence of Lucknow. It comes to us in the formal shape of a Brigadier's report to his commanding officer, and it was evidently written by a man more familiar with the sword than with the pen;

The Kansas correspondent of the Democrat says that the Territorial Legislature have decided not to give way for the Topeka Government, but to proceed to the enactment of an entire code of laws to supersede all laws passed prior to the special session of the Legislature.

A plate of raspberries was gathered on Christmas eve, in the open air, in the garden of Mr. John Wood, of Kingsthorpe, near Northampton, Eng. An old farmer, who had four plows at work in one field on the 28th ult., said he had never known such weather; his land was in April order. The attack on Canton-which it was supposed would have been commenced on the 17th inst.-has, for various reasons, been deferred, and is now expected to take place about the 1st of next month. The principal reason for delaying it is that there is now being held, at Macao, a conference of the several representatives of the United States, English, French, Dutch and Spanish Governments, the result of whose deliberations Admiral SEYMOUR waits upon.

ILLNESS OF JUDGE BOSWORTH.--While presiding at the trial of a cause in the Superior Court, on Wednesday, Judge BOSWORTH became suddenly ill with pleurisy, and was conveyed to his residence in a carriage. A fatality appears, of late, to attend those who preside in this Court.

THE NORFOLK EPIDEMIC.--The report of the Howard Association of Norfolk contains facts in relation to the ravages of the yellow fever in 1855. The whole amount of cash contributions from all sources was $157.237 52. Of this amount Maine contributed upwards of $1,600; Massachusetts $10,600; New-York $35,500; Pennsylvania $20,000; District of Columbia, $11,500; Virginia $33,500;

MORTALITY OF NEW-ORLEANS--The total mortality of New-Orleans during the year past was 6,067, which is an excess of 373 deaths over the year 1856, and 1656 less than the last eight months of 1855. The deaths from yellow fever last year numbered 199. How this fever originated is a question which it is difficult to determine.

The annual Message of Gov. BENSON to the Legislature of Liberia, was delivered on the 10th of December. The recepts of the Republic in 1857 were $47,556; expenditures, $47,048--balance in hand, $507. The foreign debt is $8,000. Foreign relations are quiet. GIRARD RALSTON, an American, residing in London, has been appointed and recognized as Consul-General of the Republic in England.

DEAR BROTHER: I arrived here on the 8th inst.. alter a boisterous passage of thirteen days. It was cold when we left New-Haven, the thermometer being at 35?, but in a few days we ran into a warmer latitude, and had the weather at 65?. In the Gulf Stream I found the water of the ocean 74?. The temperature here has been since I landed, 76? at 8 A. M., and 82? at one o'clock.

Reynolds and Henry Slingerland vs. Philip Smith.--This was an action against the defendant as the drawer of a check for $58 on the Island City Bank, dated Sept. 1, 1858, payable to the order of the plaintiffs. THE RECENT MURDER AT CRANEVILLE, N. J.-- The Newark Mercury has further particulars of this affair: "The murder was committed by an Irishman named MICHAEL MURPHY, the victim being a Russian, named GEORGE A. VAN MULLER who was 30 years old, and a shoemaker by trade. MURPHY, while in a state of intoxication, entered VAN MULLER's shop, and after behaving boisterously for some time. and upsetting the stove, was ejected.

SERVANTS PLENTY AT LOW WAGES.--Fully to realize the prostration of business, one must go to the Emigrant Employment office, in Worth-street, At this institution daily can be seen several hundred Lewly-arrived emigrants, mostly Irish, who are seeking employment; but few find it. Last Winter it was not uncommon to send out to places from this office as many as one hundred and fifty,

Professor TIMOTHY CHILDS relates, in the Amer can Medical Monthly, a curious case of fatal apoplexy of the cerebellum. In the Summer of 1853, a young lady, aged 19, in taking care of her sister's infant, amused it by shaking her own bead rapidly and violently a great number of times. Faintness and vomiting followed, and she was confined to her bed several days. On going out again, she could not walk without staggering.

The annual statement for 1856 of the English Board of Trade, which has recently beer, issued, shows that the computed real value of the imports from the United States during that year was no less than [Pound]36,047,773, being more that onefifth of the whole imports of the year, more than six millions sterling in excess of 1854, and over ten millions above 1855.

What is more charming than a charming letter? not instructive and gossiping letters, like those of HOWELL-not showy and caustic like those of WALPOLE--not elaborately careless and malice prepense letters like those of Lady MARY WORTLEY MONTAGUE-but such graceful and natural effusions as the intimate letters of GARY-such unpremeditated and fantastic letters as the letters.

LATE AT THE CHRISTENING.--A family residing in State-street, Brooklyn, determined to have their youngest christened at one of the churches yesterday, and with that end in view green BRIDGET was directed to take the baby and start for the church a little in advance of its parents. BRIDGET was not acquainted with the city, and, of course, lost her way.

In Western Massachusetts the sleighing is excellent, the snow in many places being two feet deep.

A MEAN-SPIRITED ACT.--The Captain of the American bark Adriatic has done a very discreditable thing in running away from Marseilles, where he had been held to answer for damages in running down a French steamer, and had been allowed his liberty on parole. IIis exploit is noted in some quarters, we observe, as an instance of American smartness:

FIRE IN GRAND-STREET.--At 8 o'clock Saturday morning a fire broke out in the basement of No 419 1/2 Grand street, but was speedily extinguished. the damage being only trifting. The fire originated from a child setting fire to some rags in a basket in the room. FIRE IN EAST TWENTY-EIGHT-STREET.--At 1 1/2 P.M. yesterday, a fire broke out in the dwelling-house No 143 East Twenty-eight-street, occupied by CYRUS SHERMAN.

THE MARRIAGE IN HASTE.--The sunday Atlas, noticing the recent clandestine marriage which has occupied the attention of our Courts for a few days past, remark: "What the friends of Mrs. TAYLOR expect to gain by the course they have pursued, we are at a loss to discover. The marriage is unquestionably legal, and there exists no cause for a divorce.

Schieffelin, of this City DRAKE--PEST--At Port Richmond, on Wednesday, Jan. 27, by Rev. James Brownlee HENRY M. DRAKE to BARBARA POST. all of Staten Island.

REDUCED VALUE OF REAL ESTATE.---At the meeting of tile committee of the Board of Councilmen on Friday last, it was stated by Mr. SCHIEFFELIN, aS an argument against carrying certain projected street improvements, in the Third and Fifth Wards, that the value of real estate had fallen so low the owners of the property to be benefited would be unable to pay the amount for the improvements.

The State Board of Agriculture of Massachusetts met at the State House last week, and set two days. A large portion of the time was occupied in considering the report of the Committee to visit the ?? Farm at Westboro' and report a plan for its management.

GALES AND DIETEORS AT SEAMEN DROWNED AND KILLED. The ship Arctic, Capt. ZEREGA, which sailed from Liverpool Nov. 24, and arrived at this port on Saturday last, has experienced the most boisterous passage of the season, lost two seamen overboard, and narrowly escaped foundering. Cant.

Dr. Jackson, the elder, of Boston, meeting his old friend Josiah Quincy (both eighty years of age,) on the sidewalk, accosted him with--"Well, Mr. Quincy, how much longer do you intend to live?" "Till I send for a doctor," was the quick reply. "And when did you send for one last ?" inquired Dr. J. "Just eighty-six years ago" answered Mr. Quincy, adding the precise date of his birth.

From the Washington States (Democratic.) It is beyond doubt that a large majority of the Northern Democracy is opposed to the Lecompton Constitution, on the ground that the people of Kansas who have a right to choose their ownistitutions are opposed to it. The press of the Democracy tell us so; and Democratic Legislatures, in a member of instances, have instructed their Senators and members of Congress to oppose it.

ANOTHER DESCENT ON GAMBLING HOUSES.--The Mayor's Police squad, with Sergeant Birney at their head, made a descent on two gambling houses saturday afternoon. The first place visited was No. 203 Bowery, kept by a man named John D. Whick off. The offices were at first refused admittance there, as it was supposed they belonged to a gang haiting from Brooklyn, known as the "Rock Boys."

The Southern Mail, from all points, as late as due has been received. The steamship Empire City was aground on the bar on the 23d. Three steamships were attempting to haul her off. The Galveston News, of the 19th, Says, 7,800 bales of Cotton were sold yesterday, at 8 1/2 c.@ 8 1/4c. for Middling.

The Special Committee of tile Board of Councilmen, appointed to investigate the alleged frauds in the office of the Comptroller, and the general condi tion of that department, met by adjournment in the Library of the City Hall, on Saturday, at 3 o'clock. Councilman GENET in the chair.

The death of Lieutenant-General William Smelt, C. B., is announced at Bath, on the 10th inst.. in his 76th year. General Smelt entered the service in 1798. He served in the American war, and was present at tile taking of Pluttsburg, storm and capture of Oswego, action of Lundy's Lane, and storming of Fort Erie, where he was wounded.
