MASON AND THOMAS'S MATINEE.--Messrs. WM. MASON and THEODORE THOMAS, assisted by Messrs. MOSENTHAL, MATZKA and BRAUNER, gave the first of a series of classical matinees on Saturday at the Spingler Institute, Union-square. The hall is a convenient little place for such entertainments, but the entrance should be made more encouragingly public.

About two o'clock yesterday afternoon, the stern-wheel steamer fanny fern, Captain BEN. WOODWARD, on her way from St. Louis when just at the head of Bosley's Bar, above North Bend, about with 16 miles below this city, burst her middle boiler, with a most terrific noise. The exploded part was forced up and forward, carrying with it all but three rooms in the short cabin, the lorward guard, the Texas and the pilot-house.

MARTIN--In this City, on Friday, Jan, 29, HUGH MARTIN, in the 58th year of his age. The relatives and friends of the family are requested to attend his funeral, from his late residence, No. 25 NoranMogre, st., on Monday Feb. 1, at 10 o'clock A.M., without further invitation. His remains will be take to Railway, N. J., for ??.

From the ?? The French Protestants are not, it would Deem, allowed schools enough to carry on the education of the young members of the communion The French law provides nominally the amplest liberty on this point ; but, as a writer in the Journal des Debats observes, French laws take away in one part the liberties which they allow in another.

THE ATLANTIC TELEGRAPH.--A letter from GEORGE SAWARD, Esq., Secretary of the Atlantic Telegraph Company, dated at London, Jan. 15, says: "Our arrangements here for the completion of the work we have in hand are progressing satisfactorily, and I trust and believe that our next attempt will be crowned with success.

The attempt of the Administration to secure the admission of Kansas under the Lecompton Constitution, is not without a very strong and a very plausible motive. The President desires to end the Kansas controversy.

The Independence correspondent of the Republican gives some additional items from the Utah Army. Captain MAROY was expected back about the middle of April, and soon thereafter transportation would be effected, and Colonel JOHNSTON wouLd make an effert to enter Salt Lake City. Colonel JOHNSTON'S impression from the demonstrations made in the valley is that the troops will have to fight.

No. 36.--J. M. Mattingly vs. David D. Boyds, Administrators.-Justice CATRON delivered the opinion of the Court, reversing the decree of the Circuit Court of the United States for the Western District of Tennessee, and remanding the cause for further proceedings.

THE IMPROVEMENT OF BURR'S REPUTATION.-AARON BURR'S reputation is in a very fair way of being essentially improved. Mr. PARTON'S half-way championship of his character has stimulated several persons to still more adventurous undertakings in the same direction.

SUBLIMATED SNOBBERY.--One of our City contemporaries, whose name we will not have the unkindness to mention, says that "Mrs. NAPIER, styling herself Lady NAPIER in a Republican country, is an insult to the women of America, by assuming a superiority over them."

WAREHOUSE BURNT AT IOWA CITY. CHICAGO, Monday, Feb. 1 The warehouse of THOMPSON Co., Iowa City, was destroyed by fire on Thursday night. Loss $100,000 Insurance not known. FIRE IN LOUISVILLE, Monday, Feb, 1. Messrs. J. BARBER Co.'s alcohol works, in this place, were destroyed by fire this morning. They were fully insured.

HEDLEY-STURGES.--In this City, on Wednesday, Jan. 20. at Trinity Church, by Rev. Dr. Eigenbrodt, JOHN N. HEDLEY to Annie, daughter of George W. Sturges, and neice of Caleb Bartlett. BASSETT--GIDDINGS--In Brooklyn. on Monday, Feb. 1, by Rev. G. S. Gilbert, MARCUS E. BASSETT to SUSIE E., daughter of Senter M. Geddings, Esq., of Brooklyn.

BOARD OF ALDERMEN. The Board of Aldermen met last evening, President CLANCY in the Chair. A petition was received from sundry persons resident in the Seventeenth Ward, complaining that ??tous persons are in the habit that Policeman be detailed for that locality. The petition was referred.

A CONTROVERSY DECLINED.--The St. Louis Leader is publishing a series of letters from " It Segretario," who has long been known as a cor, respondent of the Press, addressed to Mr. CREELEY, the editor of the Tribune. It seems that the writer some months since proposed a controversy with Mr. GREELEY, in the columns of his own paper, upon a variety of the heresies of which Mr. G. was supposed to be the advocate.

To the Editor of the Evening Post: So many instances have occurred of a similar character to that recorded in the accompanying paper, that I think it worth while to make it public mainly for the purpose of calling the attention of others to the subject, to see if by many and repeated observations some discovery may not yet be made that will be ultimately of value.

FIRE IN CHERRY-STREET-THE PREMISES FIRED BY BURGLABS.-Between 3 and 4 yesterday morning a fire was discovered in the flour store of VALENTINE SONS, corner of Cherry and Market streets. Some officers of the Seventh Ward, who first saw the fire, went into the building, when they ascertained that the place had been set on fire by burglars.

COTTON--Sales to-day 1,400 bales, the market closing buoyant. Middling Fair, 101/4c@107/8c. SAVANNAH, Monday, Feb. 1. COTTON-Sales to-day 1,200 bales, the market closing active at an advance of 1/2c. Middling Fair, 103/4 c. MOBILE, Monday, Feb. 1.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Will you permit an old subscriber, who is fortunately, or unfortunately, a stockholder in Gas Companies, to respectfully remonstrate against the course of your paper in regard to then. I have held stock in these Companies for several years, and before making the investment I was at considerable pains to investigate the whole theory and practice of the business.

Senator DOOLITTLE yesterday presented a petition signed by ninety-seven citizens of the United States, praying that Congress should take measures for the immediate purchase of the Island of Cuba, and for the annexation of that piece of property to our Union.

QUACKENDOS.--In this City, on Sunday evening, Jan. 31, at the residence of his son, George Payn Quackenbes. No. 124 Leroy St., GEORGE C. Quackenbos, M. D., in the 74th year of his age. The friends of the family are invited to attend his funeral, at the above address, on Tuesday. Feb. 2, at 2 o'clock.

The Platte (Mo.) Argus of the 22d, announces the arrival in Weston, on the 21st, of Mr. DAVIDSON from Utah, who was accompanied by Mr. IRVIN, of KINCAID LIVINGSTON'S concern, and by a few teamsters. Mr. DAVIDSON brings intelligence from Camp Scott, of the 14th of December, which is four days later than any previously received.

Among all the matters of interest in this "boiling caldron" in which we dwell, nothing is more deserving of note than our lovely Spring-like weather. To-day has been as warm as September-no fires have been needed in offices since morning, and this evening our store doors are standing open without fires.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SRI: I read in the last Atlantic Monthly, Mr. LONGFELLOW'S poem on GOETILE and SCHILLER, for I am sure by the style it must be by him; and though I agree in doing honor to genius, I dissent from him in respect to GOETHE.

The Cabinet is in extraordinary council this morning, having for the first time an authenticated copy of the Lecompton Constitution before them. The President's Special Message to accompany its transmission to Congress has already been prepared, but it may not be communicated till to-morrow.

Details of the Mexican news, brought to NewOrleans by the Tennessee, are important and exciting. When the mail left Vera Cruz there had been several days' fighting in the Capital between President COMONFORT and the Constitutional Party on the one hand, and the Pronunciados, including the Conservadores, Santanistas and the Church on the other.

LAURA KEENE'S THEATRE.--A cruel version of Mr. CHARLES READE'S wordy novel called "White Lies" was played at this house last night. It has been prepared for the stage by a gentleman of this City, who, we fancy, must have fitted himself for the task by intently and fondly studying that remarkable sensation-drama called "Birds of Prey,"

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The American community of New-York and Boston have paid to the memory of my brave countryman, General HAVELOCK, such a tribute of respect and admiration, as could only have emanated from high-minded and generous natures of kindred spirits and kindred blood.

From the Courrier des Etats Unis. From whatever light we may view it, the attempt presents itself as an inexcusable crime, not in any way to be palliated. But the attempt of the 14th January by far exceeds all its predecessors in the hateful nature which characterizes it.

SOMETHING IN DENMARK NOT ALTOGETHER ROTTEN.--It is announced that a new law has recently been passed in Denmark prohibiting newspapers from copying the articles of other journals without giving credit for them. This speaks well for the Danish authorities, but it is not quite creditable to Danish journalists.

We publish in another column a remonstrance from a stockholder in a Gas Company, against the remarks we have made from time to time upon the management of some of these establishments. As our correspondent frankly confesses that he has a pecuniary interest in the business, we have the advantage

The United States Post-Office Agent, Mr. HOLBROOK, on Saturday night last arrested JOHN MILLER, a baggage-master of the Hartford and Providence Railroad, for robbing the mails. The robberies have been going on for some time past. A decoy-mail was made up on Saturday at Willimantic, and on the arrival of the train at Hartford, MILLER was arrested, and packages found on him which were known to have been in the bag.

A PLEASANT INCIDENT.--A few years since, when Mr. WESTERVELT was Mayor of this City, a very pretty and intelligent little girl was seen daily about the City Hall, with a basket on her arm, retailing apples. Her fine appearance and proper demeanor attracted the Mayor's attention, and he one day called her into his private office and questioned her.

AMERICANISM IN CONNECTICUT.--Three hundred voters of the American Party in New-Haven feeling aggrieved at the action of the Union Convention, called a public meeting last week. at which resolutions were adopted, opposing the extension of Slavery, condemning the frauds in Kansas, demanding a modification of the Revenue laws so as to afford protection to home industry,

An interesting case has been on trial before Judge MOGEROOM, in the Circuit Court for some days, and was terminated by a princely verdict on Saturday night. The action was against TOWNSEND, of New-York, the well-known sarsaparilla millionair.

THE STABBING AFFRAY AT TAMMANY HALL.-- A squad of the Second Ward Police, under officer Niven, were engaged yesterday morning in hunting up the parties who were engaged in the affray at Tammany Hall. Sunday night, in which Train, a waiter, was stabbed.

We are requested by the Committee of Management for Mr. EVERETT'S Lecture this evening, to state that the report which has been widely circulated that all the eligible seats were disposed of, is entirely untrue. Over two thousand of as good seats as can be desired, are still to be procured.

NEW-YORK, Noon.-Cloudy. Wind E. Ther. 35[Degrees]. Barometer 30,355. NEW-York, 2 P.M.--Thermometer 34[Degrees]. Barometer 30.2; falling. Wind N. W. Clouldy and threatening rain or snow. NEW-YORK, 9 P. M.--Raining and hailing. Wind N. E. The rain freezes as it falls, making the streets as slippery as glass.

NO MORE UNLICENSED VEHICLES.--In one of the ordinances by which Gotham is governed, Provision is made for the licensing of all public carts, and it is declared that "every cart, truck, wagon, dray or other vehicle, drawn by one or more horses or other animals, which shall be kept, used, driven or employed for the transportation or conveyance of anything whatsoever from place to place,

Mr. DOOLITTLE presented the petition of 97 citizens of the United States praying that measures be taken for the purchase of the Island of Cuba, and for its annexation to the United States. Mr. BIGLER introduced a joint resolution for the completion and preservation of the Digests and Statistics of mines and manufactures, collected in the taking of the last census.

RELIGIOUS.--A spirited revival has been in progress, for a number of weeks, at the Sixth-street Methodist Episcopal Church, in Jersey City, under the pastoral labors of Rev. Mr. VAN HORN. About seventy professions of conversion have already been made, and many more are under conviction.

Those famous Southern Conventions, which have so much amused the rest of mankind, are, after all, about to vindicate themselves by bearing precious fruit. That unsleeping sentinel of Southern rights, the Argus, of Norfolk, Va., has discerned afar off a glorious phenomenon, the existence of which it made known to the world on Saturday morning last.

To the Editor of the Express: SIR: It is with pleasure that I comply with your request. Some time during the year preceding the death of Col. BURR, when on my way to visit him in company with my kinsman, tile late OGDEN E. EDWARDS, we were told that it was reported there were among his papers letters from reputable females which compromised their characters.

From the Philadelphia Bulletin of last Evening. The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Bank of Pennsylvania was held in Grigg's Building, Walnut-street, below Third, this afternoon. The room in which the meeting was held was crowded, and the countenances of the persons present were indicative of their feelings at the sad prospect there is for the Bank.

The following is the WEEKLY REPORT OF DEATHS in the City and County of New-York, from the 23d day of January to the 30th day of January, 1858: Mon, 79; Women, 75; Boys, 162; Girls, 138: Total, 454*. Adults, 154; Children, 300; Males, 241; Females, 213; Colored Persons, 12.

VALUABLE DONATION TO UNION COLLEGE.--It has been rumored in private circles for some time, that Union College was about to receive a magnificent present of a Cabinet of Minerals and Shells, for which she was to be indebted to the liberality of our townsman, E. C. DELAVAN, ESQ.

The Councilmen's Committee on the Croton Aqueduct Department, to which the estimates received by the Croton Aqueduct Board for the construction of the new Reservoir were referred, met yesterday in the City Hall Library. Councilman GENET in the Chair.

An Antwerp paper mentions that Queen Victoria who has of late devoted much time and displayed great talent in the art of photography, has lately sent the Empress Eugenie, as a New Year's present, a charming album full of photographs taken by herself.

CANADIAN SEAT OF GOVERNMENT.--The Toronto Globe announces the selection of the town of Ottawa by the Imperial authorities, as the future scat of government for Canada, and expresses much indignation threat.

The speech made by General WALKER at Mobile, which will be found in extenso in another part of this morning's TIMES, merits general attention. It embodies the damaging disclosures of a person who is satisfied that he has nothing further to hope or expect from powerful accomplices.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: When I addressed my first letter to you, in relation to the subject of "The Perils of the New-York Harbor," I had not the remotest idea of producing, and certainly I had no intention to provoke any kind of controversy.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Some of your readers may be interested to know how the temperature of the past month compares with that of former years. The best mateTials for this comparison with which I am acquainted are furnished by the register which has been kept at Union Hall Academy, Jamaica, Long Island, since 1826.

An interesting case has been brought to tile notice of Mayor TIEMANN, in which there is alleged the kidnapping of a colored man, who formerly lived in this City, and the selling of him in Virginia as a slave. The name of the alleged kidnapper is MASON THOMAS, and that of the colored man GEORGE ANDERSON.

Mr. BUCHANAN has deliberately forced upon tile Congress and the people of the United States the most intense and absolute issue of sectional interests and sectional feeling to which we have yet been brought in tile history of this country.

EXTRAORDINARY CASE OF KIDNAPPING.--The Mayor of Richmond, Va., has sent a letter to Mayor TIEMANN, which we publish this morning, giving him information of an attempt, on the part of a free negro in that city, to sell a young colored man as a slave, who represents himself as a native of New-York.

ANOTHER SCHOOL-HOUSE ON FIRE--ESCAPE OF THE SCHOLARS.--At about 21/4 P. M. yesterday, the High School building in Watertown was discovered to be on fire and was badly damaged, the roof and upper portions being destroyed. The High School. which occupied the upper rooms, had been dismissed a short time previously.

CONCERT.--Miss E L. WILLIAMS, the Welsh Nightingale, is to be the recipient of a complimentary concert, which comes off to-night at the Mozart Rooms. Mr. APTOMMAS, the celebrated harpist: Mr. J. R. THOMAS, the popular ballad singer, and other artists, have profferred their services for tile occasion, Miss WILLIAMS is one of the best ballad singers we have had, and fully merits the support of the public.

I do not know the date of my last letter, my dear MARIO ; but it is right to prepare you now for the fatal denouement of which I have long had a presentiment. On Friday, while we were exchanging the compliments of the New-Year, poor RACHEL embraced me with such extreme fervor that I perceived at once that, in her mind, she was bidding me an eternal adieu.

On Monday night, in compliance with the published request of a large number of well-known and respected citizens, Rev. Dr. BELLOWS delivered, in Clinton Hall, for purposes of charity, the first of a course of lectures on pauperism and crime, which have been received with much commendation else. where. The audience was large, in spite of the Weather.

Mr. W. A. WHEELER was made President pro tem., during the necessary absence of Mr. HALSTED. PETITIONS. By Mr. STOW. for the removal of quarantine and the appointment of new Commissioners. By Mr. STOW, to incorporate the South Pacific Steamship Company. Also, to amend the law for the sale of the lands of non residents for taxes.

The modern doctrine of laissez-faire in political economy has been as yet very imperfectly and partially applied to some of the most important interests ofSociety; and while human affairs continue to be governed, as at present they are, by the influences of several incongruous and hostile theories, it is impossible to expect of them any steady, regular and accurate action.

The State Medical Society met here this morning. About eighty delegates were in attendance: among them Dr. James L. Phelps, R. Fordyce Parker, John H. Griscoin, John McNulty, John G. Adams, Edward H. Parker, and Peter Van Buren, of New-York City; William W. Strew, of Oyster Bay, Queens County ; George Cochran, of Brooklyn.

The bark Mary C. Dyer, from Cette, recently ashore at Barnegat, was floated of on Friday last, and the steaming Ajax, Capt. THOMAS MARSHALL, was dispatched to tow her to this City. She left the inlet on Monday, with the bark in tow, and after having got as far as 18 miles South of the Highlands, was, owing to the easterly blow and heavy sea, obliged to let her go.

To the Editor of the New- York Times: SIR: In her charming Legends of the Madonna, (p. 351,) Mrs. JAMESON,than whom no better authority in matters of artistic history exists, speaks of the care which must be taken to " distinguish in the pictures of MURILO, and in all pictures painted after 1616, between the Assumption and the Immaculate Conception."

A shocking affair transpired last evening in the Fourth Ward. GADFEN GROSS, a German aged about 25 years, lived with his wife in a cellar under the Shakespeare Hotel, corner of Duane and William streets, where he kept a lagor-bier saloon. Finding business of late to be very dull, he expressed his intention of removing to Washington alone in hopes of bettering his fortune.

BIGAMY.--A young, good looking Irishman, named Henry Beers, was arrested yesterday on a charge of bigamy. He is said to have married, Sept. 30, 1855, Phebe Tully, the marriage service being performed by Rev. Alexander Master, at the Church of St. Francis Xavier, in West Thirty-first-street; and on the 28th of June, 1857, it is alleged he married Ann Hanbury, at the Church of the Nativity, Rev. Mr. Everet officiating.

The Ashtabula County Infirmary, at Kingsville. was burned to-night, having been got on hire by an inmate. One life was lost, and sixty paupers rendered homeless. FIRES IN NEW-ORLEANS. NEW-ORLEANS, Monday, Feb. 1.

At the opening of the House this morning, Mr. Speaker ALVORD announced the following as the Standing Committees for the session. I have marked the Democrats in italics and the Americans in small capitals, to show the political formation of the various Committees: On Ways and Means--Messrs. Laning, Van Valkenburg, Hubbard. Lord, Duryea.

The Hartford County Savings Institution held its annual meeting on the 26th January. It was proposed, at a meeting of the Directors that evening, that a Committee be appointed to thoroughly investigate the affairs of the Company, and look especially into Its securities.

Probably from the New-York Tribune. We find in an exchange the following unacknowledged article of a singular and surprising interest to historians and military men, and we think we can hardly be wrong in attributing it to the same astute and martial critic who has favored the world with his views of the Crimean war-of the siege of Delhi, and of the Defence of Lucknow, through the columns of one of our City cotemporaries.

Hon. F. P. STANTON, lately Secretary of the Territory of Kansas, is in the City, where he will spend a few days previous to his return to Washington. He considers the action of the Administion in regard to the Lecompton Constitution, as certain to involve the Territory in serious and protracted difficulty.

The President's Message, sent to Congress today, has fallen stillborn here. The opponents of Lecompton achieved a victory in the House, twice defeating motions to adjourn, because determined, first, to let HARETS, of Illinois, get in his proposition for the reference of the Message to a Select Committee.

Hon. JOHN ROBERTSON, a distinguished lawyer of Virginia, is publishing a series of articles upon the threatened predominance of the Free States in the federal government. Minnesota, Oregon and Kansas, which are ready for admission to the Union, will all prohibit Slavery, and will give the Free States a majority of eight in the federal Senate.

THE COLLINS STEAMERS NOT TO BE SOLD.--We are happy to state that we have authority for contradicting the report published in the Journal of Commerce yesterday, respecting an intended sale of to Collins steamers to the British Government.

To the Editor of the New-York Times. I observe in a late number of your paper a paragraph in which you say that the most humiliating feature of the present crisis is the stupidity and misconception which exist as to its causes. The London Times, which is read by everybody, and governs our opinions more than we suppose, is the great cause of misconception on this side of the water.

TAME LIZARDS AND QUIET. EARTHQUAKES.-At the last meeting of the Natural History Dcpartment of the Brooklyn Institute, various varieties of the lizard tithe were exhibited by Ex-Consul PIKE., who observed that Portugal might be said to be a country of earthquakes and lizards.

Mr. WILLIAM WALKER appeared before the United Stated District Court this morning, when Judge McCALES said there was nothing against him, the Grand Jury having refused to find a bill against him. WALKER then asked to be put on trial for a violation of the neutrality laws, which the judge refused, as the District-Attorney said there was nothing against him, unless new instruction were received from Washington.

On Saturday evening a young man by the name of JOHN MILLER, employed as baggage-master on the Hartford and Providence Railroad. was arrested at the depot on Asylum-street, upon the arrival of the train from Providence, on a charge of robbing the mails. The proof against him seems to be conclusive.

The current topics of, the day at present here, are the departure of the English Minister, Lord STRATFORD DE REDCLIFFE, which took place on Saturday last, after a residence of many years in this country, and that of Hon. CARROLL SPENCE, our Minister resident for the last four years.

Mr. WILSON presented the memorial of E. R. LIVINGSTON, of Massachusetts, to be appointed to superintend and aid in the preparation of the catalogue, abstract and index of the original documents and papers of the United States. He said that Mr. LIVINGSTON has indexed the official papers of Massachusetts from 1774 to 1857, on an original plan which met the commendation of the official authorities and literary men.
The Board of Councilmen met on Tuesday afternoon, CHARLES H. HASWELL, Esq., in the chair. Several comparatively unimportant petitions and resolutions were referred to their appropriate Committees.

MISS HOSMER, THE SCULPTOR.--MISS HOSMKR seems younger than her years. She is small and rather slight, yet looks vigorous and muscular. She is a bundle of healthy nerves, energy and will. She has a fine, strong head, carried with infinite spirit, and crowned with beautiful hair, short and curling Her face is delicate, fresh and piquant, but full of force and character.

Sergeants CROFT and BIRNEY, of the Mayor's Office, with a portion of their squads, made another descent last night upon several of the most notorious gambling "hells." They first visited No. 8 Barclay-street, at 10 1/2 o'clock. Only three or four persons were present and they seemed waiting for customers, for they were amusing themselves with a small game at cards.

The German man and woman residing at No. 237 William-street, whose deaths, caused by taking poison, were reported in yesterday's TIMES, were not a married couple. The name of the man was ?? GROSS, and that of the woman ROSA ELIZABETH MARKS. She lived with GROSS as his mistress. s.

LIGHTBODY.--In this City, on Tuesday, Feb. 2. after a protracted illness, Mr. JAMES LIGHTBODY, a native of Hamilton, Scotland, aged 77 years and 16 days. His relatives and friends, as also those of his sons, Colin, James C. John G., George and Andrew, are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, from his late residence No. 255 West 31th st., at 1 o'clock P. M., on Sunday. Feb 7.

CAPTURE OF A BURGLAR AND DISCOVERY OF STOLEN PROPERTY.--At 2 o'clock on Tuesday afternoon, a burglar, who goes by the names of " Killer Tom," alias Thomas Weston, alias Wall, alias Walpole, was discovered in the act of robbing the unoccupied house No. 122 West Thirty-seventh-street, and after a hard chase, was finally captured in Thirty-sixth-street. To the Editor of the New-York Times: I see by your issue of to day, that the Common Council are demanding pay for their services. The demand, I fear, gives bad augur for the future. Once upon a time, the seats of the present Board were filled with gentlemen who had a stake in the community, and a resolution from one of its members, for compensation, would have been an insuit to the rest.

The Senate was not particularly industrious today, although the session extended over a longer Period than usual. SAVINGS BANKS, Had notice that Senator ELY would urge the passage of a bill to restrict their temporary deposits to an amount not exceeding 20 per cent. of the actual deposits, and in no case exceeding $100,000.

If last night had been sufficiently cold, we should have had a snow-storm that would have made up for past deficiencies. As it was, a day somewhat cold, but of brilliant sunshine, was followed by a night of wind and rain of the most superior quality. There was a snow-flurry to start

ROBERT J. WALKER holds tile sword of Damocles over the head of the President. He unquestionably has in his possession a private letter written to him by Mr. BUCHANAN, which, if it finds its way to the public eye, will make the nation blush for the downright hypocrisy of the functionary whom it honored with its confidence.

If Mr. HENRY AVIS is fond of notoriety, as his enemies assert, he must be highly gratified by tile notice he is now receiving at the hands of the Press. Almost every newspaper in the country is pouring upon his head the vials of its wrath. He provoked this storm of indignation by proclaiming in a Congressional speech his utter contempt for the " political Press" of the country.

THE MARINE BANK AFFAIR.--Mr. LOUIS M. VAN ELTON, the President of the Marine Bank of Hoboken, who was arrested last week upon complaint of Messrs, CLARK and LYON, charged with embezzling the funds of the Bank, had an examination on Monday afternoon and evening, before Justice CRANE, which resul ed in his discharge. The Administration is evidently alarmed at the tactics of the opposition of Lecompton,--consequently three members of the Cabinet-Conn, BROWN and BLACK-were in the House all day electioneering industriously. Mr. KIDBEN's defection brought BLACk to his side for two hours.

Capt. MARSHALL, who returned from the wreck of his steamer on Tuesday night, gives the following account of the disaster. The Ajaz left Barnegat Inlet at 8 1/2 o'clock on Monday morning, with the bark Mary C. Dyer in tow. At 12 o'clock she had made less than ten miles, and the tug, by hard laboring, had sprung a leak;--the gale also increased, and a heavy head sea was running.

Several Committees are diligently at work exploring the subject of Congressional bribery. One is charged with the special duty of finding out what votes for the Tariff of 1857 were bought by LAWRENCE, STONE Co., and at what price. It is reported that one member, who seemed to be acting as broker, offered 25 votes for the moderate sum of $25,000.

THE KIDNAPPING CASE--Mayor TIEMANN sent yesterday to the Mayor of Richmond, Va., an affidavit of GEORGE T. TREMBLE, Esq., with regard to GEORGE ANDERSON, the colored man who was recently sold in Richmond by a man named MASON THOMAS, claiming him as his slave.

A NEW PUBLIC SCHOOL-HOUSE.--A Maew school edifice on Twenty-eight-street and Ninth-avenue, in the Twentieth Ward, to be known as No. 33, has been informally opened and the organization of the school commenced. The structure is unlike any other school building in a City, and is designed for a girls' Grammar School, and a mixed Primary.

EISFELD'S CLASSICAL SOIREE.--The second concert of Mr. EISFELD'S interesting and valuable series took place on Tuesday evening at Dodworth's Rooms, and was, we are happy to state, well attended. A good quartette party like Mr. EISFELD'S should not be allowed to languish, even in the worst of times,

On Sunday night a serious and probably fatal affray occurred in a house of ill fame, in Troy. A gambler, James Gallagher, kept at this place a woman who goes by the soubriquet of "showy Moll." but whose name is Mary Davis, During that day, he did not think proper, in consideration of his relations he sustained towards her.

The storm of Monday night was very severe on this coast, but there are no vessels reported ashore south of this as yet. The Ajax lies here in the undertow all broken up. Nothing belonging to her will be saved, except, perha ps, part of her machinery. The telegraph wires here were prostrated by the storm.

Rev. George E. Fisher, dismissed by council from the Congregational Church at North Amherst, preached a farewell sermon, in which he expressed his opinion with perfect freedom of the opposition which procured his dismission.

Mr. COLE, an assistant Sergeant-at-arms, has summoned J. W. WALCOTT, of the house of LAWANCY, STONE Co., and T. F. HOLDEN, book-keeper of the firm, to appear before the Congressional Committee at Washington. This morning Mr. COLB started for Bath, Maine, to summon Mr. JAEVIS SLADE, who has nearly recovered his health, to appear before the same Committee.

It is a question of interest whether Minnesota is not already a sovereign State within the Union, and there does not need a formal act of Congress to authorize her representatives to take their seats, and speak, act and vote for her in the councils of the Nation. This is not an entirely unsupported view of the case.

From the Hartford Times, 2d. The fact that the twenty six Directors of the Hartford County Savings Institution, generally able and Wealthy individuals, permitted their names to be used, without personally knowing the real condition of the corporation, will meet with no defence. But still it is a custom, practiced in this and other States, to a great extent.

Farmers' club, American Institute. The Farmers' Club met on Tuesday, the President, R. L. PELL, Esq., in the chair. The Secretary, Hon. J. Mares, read an interesting translation from one of the current horticultural European journals, the Revise Horticale of Paris: CRAPES IN BURGUNDY.

The Steamship Delta, from St. Thomas on the 26th, and Bermuda on the 31st Ultimo, arrived here to-day. The ship cabinet, forty-two days from Marseilles, for New-York, put into St. George's on the 12th ult., peaky and disabled in spars, and with spring foremast, foretopmast and maintopsail-yard. The ship Horatio, 62 days from shields for New-York arrived at Bermuda on the 12th ult., in want of sails, spars, water, etc.

People of all shades and sections of opinion have been pretty unanimous in their condemnation of the late atrocious attempt upon the life of the French Emperor, at Paris. MAZZINI'S gospel of assassination has not only made no converts that are likely to advance his cause, but has been indignantly repadiated by every man in Europe and America, whose voice could render it any real service.

From the Buffalo Commercial Advertiser, The following spicily written letter from an officer of the army of Utah, runs in a more cheerful vein than we bad anticipated from the dolorous at rounds reaching us less directly. It gives a better loca of the real condition of the army than many more elaborate accounts, simply because it is written to a dear friend, with an entire freedom of comment on men and things.

TEXTURE OF COLORS--A conversation lecture on the "Texture of Colors," which came off last evening, at the Mechanics' Institute, elicited, among others, the following items of information, from Professor MAPES: That there are a dozen different shades to every general color of paint, and so many modes of forming, them, that it would confuse the most well. disciplined mind to systematize and do them justice. Many colors are permanent, and many are fugitive.

We give considerable space this morning to a debate, of peculiar interest, between Senators SEWARDAND HALE, upon the proposition to increase the standing Army of the United States. The speeches are in themselves able, and upon a topic of marked interest and importance.

The Democratic Counts Convention adjourned since die this evening after passing strong Lecompton resolutions. The Convention was a scene of Confusion from its commencement to its close. The President declared the resolutions carried amid confusion created by their introduction.

The world is not yet in its dotage, as many persons suppose, and judging from the innumerable things it has yet to learn, it would be safe to assume that it has not yet even arrived at that sagacious age when the process of cutting eye-teeth commences.

Gen. CALHOUN has returned to Weston, accompanied by Judge, CATO, Colonel ISAACS , EX-Sheriff JONES, and other leading citizens of Kansas. He was escorted to Lecompton and back, by Major GRAHAM and party troops. On arriving at Lecompton a subpoena was served upon him, to attend the examination of JACK HENDERSON, at Lawrence. He declined to recognize the authority of the judicial officer who issued it.

The entire character of the code of Procedure is being rapidly changed, under the persistent and rapid assaults of the limbs of the law who are instrusted with seats in the Legissaure. Hardly a day passes that we do not have at east a brace of bills to amend the code of Procedure." We had three Yesterday , two to-day, and to-morrow a half-dozen more may be reasonably looked for.

"Our city, within this period, has increased its own numbers 60 per cent. In spite of all the adverse circumstances which have, from time to time combined to depress and retard it.

INFAMOUS OUTRAGE UPON A YOUNG WOMAN.--Joseph Lang and his wife, residing at No. 38 City Hall place, were brought, yesterday, before Justice CONNOLLY, at the Lower Police Court, charged with belong accessory to the abduetion and rape of a young German woman named Henrietta Van Derheyden. The complainant alleges that, some days ago, a man accosted her in Houston-street, and asked her if she wanted to do housework in a respectable family.

A romor comes to us from Fayetteville, Arkansas, that a fearful insurrection had occurred near that place, said to have been incited by two white men. The negroes are represented to have attacked two settlements, killing twenty-three persons, burning houses and killing cattle. The insurrection was finally subdued by the organization of a force of volunteers, who killed seven, and captured eighteen of the insurrectionists. The truth of the rumor was doubted.

THE NEXT FIGHTING GROUND.--The repeal of the Missouri Compromise, and the proclamation of popular sovereignty, of necessity makes every new Territory the scene of a new struggle between Slavery and its enemies. A very skillful operation was performed by Dr. MOTT last week. Two years ago a lady, attempting to dine on fish, lodged a large bone in her throat. She suffered intensely, could get no relief and during the two years had not spoken a loud word. The inflamniation created by the obstruction produced ulcers. It was found that she could not live long unless the hone was removed from her throat.

From the Louisville (Ky). Democrat. We cannot but regard the proposition to force Kansas into the Union with the Lecompton Constitution oas the most extraordinary ever made since the formation of the Federal Constitution. Events, as they transpire, expose is monstrosity more and more.

The Lecompton question has taken a new shape in Congress. Instead of voting directly, and blindly, upon the admission of Kansas, it is preposed in the Hous of Representatives to refer the subject to a Committee, for the purpose of inquiring whether the people of Kansas have really made application for admisison into the Union or not.

EXCEPTIONS TO REPORT--COLLISION--RULE DAMAGES. Jedediah Chapman vs. The Steamboat Empire State. --This case came up on exceptions to a Commissioner's report. Some of our Banking Institutions, finding that it is useless for them all to attempt single. handed the great battle against the Spanish Bank and each other, have at last concluded to join hands and form but one. So far six have manifested a willingness to enter into this arrangement, and it is to be presumed others will follow the example.

A man named WM. W. GURNEY, and his sisterin-law, ELVIRA BATES, were arrested here to-day, chargedd with counterfeiting United States coin. After their examination before the police magistrate they were held to bail.

UNJUST RUMORS CONCERNING A SIXTH WARD POLICEMAN.-As to the case of the Policeman charged with burglary, which we published on Saturday, we find, on further examination, that the whole story has the following foundation only: Early in January, Mr. Carland made a statement concerning the robbery of his drinking-saloon, No. 25 Chambers-street. to the Deputy Superintendent.

VALUABLE BEQUESTS.---The late Rev. CHARLES AVERY. of Pittsbmg. Penn., left an estate valued at $400,000. He bequeathed $20,000 of stock in the Monongahela Navigation Company, which pays good dividends, as a fund for the support of super-annuated clergymen of the Methodist Protestant Church; $20,000 to the Oberlin Institute in Ohio; $25,000 to a school for colored children.

It is little surprising that so accomplished a scholar as Mr. EVERETT should have committed himself in his agreeable lecture on Charity, which he delivered on Tuesday last at the Academy of Music, to a common delusion in respect to the charitable institutions of Pagan Antiquity.

THE NEW RAID ON THE GAMBLERS.--A new Mayor when he first enters upon the discharge of his official duties in New-York must feel considerably embarrassed, as he surveys his field of operation, in deciding where to begin the work of reforming abuses. The City is such a hot-bed of corruptions that it is not easy to decide on what class of evil-doers it will be best to make the first attempt at extermination.

DECREPITUDE.-The shaky and dilapidated old Herald says the Union is to be dissolved, if the president's Message on Kansas goes to a Committee in the House of Representatives. It is not quite easy for people of ordinary nerves to see any connection between the two events,--but after people pass a certain age it takes very little to frighten them.

FIRE IN CEDAR STREET.-At 6 o'clock Saturday night a fire was discovered in the attic of the fourthstory brick building No. 26 Cedar street. The flames were confined to the attic and roof. Messrs, CLAYTON FERRIS, steam printers, who occupied the third fourth and atric floors, had their stock damaged by water to the extent of about $300, which is covered by insurance.

From the Boston Advertiser. Captain DURHAM has put to sea in a vessel which is under the sentence of a foreign Court, and without papers. He can hardly claim or obtain any protection from bib national character under these circumstances; while, even if he were secure from all danger of detention, he is shut up in the Mediterrancan, with hardly a chance to escape.

Some new developments were made on Saturday before the Mayor, in the case of GEORGE ANDERSON, the coloreo man alleged to have been inveigled from the City to Richmond, Va., by a man named MASON THOMAS, and there sold as a slave. The United States sloop-of-war Dale, Captain MOBLAIR, arrived at St. Helena on the 17th of December, in 9 days from Benguela, west coast of Africa, on a cruise for recruiting her men. ALLOWANCES TO JUDGES.---The decision of comptroller CHURCH, refusing to audit a charge by a Justice of the Supreme Court for making a report and certifying notes in case of a capital conviction, which decision we published yesterday, is undoubtedly correct. It is on the ground that the Constitution permits no payment to Judges beyond their salary of $2,500 per annum.

The House took up the resolution offered by Mr. RANDALL, Republican, to instruct the Kansas Committee not to report on the 15th March. Mr. McCLURE raised the point of order, that Committees having special questions referred to them, the House cannot instruct them relative thereto.

CHILD MISSING.--A girl, 13 years old, was sent from the residence of her parents, No. 242 Henry-street, Brooklyn, yesterday morning, to purchase a newspaper at a store in Atlantic-street, and has not been seen by her friends since.

The jewelry store of J. S. NETTERVILLE, in Jersey City, was entered yesterday afternoon by means of prying open a rear-hall door and robbed of jewelry to the value of $700 or $800. The store has been always watched, but a death in the family has caused the temporary absence of the watchman.

DR. COREY'S CHURCH.-In the Baptist Church corner of Fifth-avenue and Thirty-fifth-street, Sunday evening, the pastor, Rev. SYDNEY A. COREY, contradicted the statement of one of the morning papers, that arrangements had been made to lease the Church for two years to disaffected members of Dr. TYNG'S Church, for $4,560 per annum, with a reservation that the Baptist congregation and its pastor should have the use of the Church in the evening.

Among the " Rules for the Court of General Sessions of the City and County of New-York," recently issued by Recorder BARNARD and Judge RUSSELL, (p. 4,) is the following : " The placing upon the calendar of an indictment for trial, within two days after it has been found; the

The whole of the sumptuous preparations and decorations in connection with this all--important event have at last been brought to a close, and even the Chapel Royal is declared to be complete. Yesterday afternoon Her Majesty, with the Princess Royal and their Royal Highnesses the Prince and Princess of Prussia, paid a long visit of inspection to it,

THE FIGHT IN CONGRESS-EXPLANATIONS.It will be seen that Mr. KEITT apologized yesterday, for his gross breach of order in the House of Representatives on Saturday morning, He takes fully and unreservedly upon himself all the blame of that disgraceful occurrence, confessing himself the aggressor, and acknowledging the full weight of responsibility attaching to the fracas.

LOST ON NANTUCKET.--The bark N. G. Hichborn, Capt ELLIS, from Matanzas, bound to Portland, Me., with a cargo of molasses, was driven ashore on the south side of Nantucket, at 5 o'clock on Tuesday morning last, and was totally lost. The Nantucket Inquirer says:

To the Editor of the New-York Times: My attention has been called to a paragraph in your paper of the 5th inst., representing me as having said, in substance as follows: "That of the votes I represented, not over 5,000 are in favor of Lecompton; but that I should nevertheless vote for it, all the way through"

Rio (Jan. 16) Correspondence of the Manchester Guardian. The monetary crisis has, of course, extended to this capital; and, although matters are not in a very bad position, they might have been in a much better one, but for the delay of the Medway, and the want of business men in the management of the National Bank. ew days before the arrival of the mail

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In a TIMES, dated late in December, you state as follows: "We are informed on authority whose accuracy we have every reason to credit that the amount of bills which the house of PEABODY Co. was under acceptance for when assistance was obtained from the Bank of England, exceeded the almost inconceivable sum of six millions sterling."

There is a calm before the storm which to-morrow must witness--and we have little to-day beyond speculations as to the probable result of the great through peaceful contest which is impending--and some further comments upon the fisti-cuflian encounter on Saturday morning. The opponents of the Lecompton swindle are firm and united.

GENERAL ENGAGEMENT BETWEEN TWO GANGS OF BALTIMORE ROWDIES.--Another of those disgraceful exhibitions which have been too often enacted took place about 3 1/2 o'clock yesterday afternoon on Loudenslager's Hill, in the immediate vicinity of Baltimore-street. It appears that for some time past a fend had existed between the runners with the Lafayette and Columbias fire companies,

The triumph in the House to-day was complete notwithstanding some treachery, as usual. BURN and PENDLETON, of Ohio, who have over and over gain been pledged against Lecompton, yielded-the former at the solicitation of STEEDMAN, the House Printer, who besieged him in his seat until the perspiration poured from him in streams.
AN IMPORTANT ANNOUNCMENT.--The Journal of Commerce, of yesterday, says: " At 4 o'clock this morning a full-grown and vigorcus mosquito made his appearance in the editorial roon of this paper."

THE POOR.--The Association for Improving the Condition of he poor, an excellen Sociey, makes appeal to-day for further aid in exteding the field of it operation. The demands upon the Society exceed its present resources; some fifteen thousand destitute persons having been reported within the past three weeks, in addition to the numbers prov!ously recorded,

" What is to be done with the Mormons" is becoming a question of general interest. If in so brief a time they have become so formidable to the Government that an increase of the Army, and an additional cost of our military preparations to the extent of some ten millions of dollars annually, are required to keep them in subjection,

SUICIDE OF A BLIND MAN.--Coroner CONNERY held an inquest, yesterday, at No. 96 Ridge-street, upon the body of PHILIP GROMPORT, a German, twenty-four years of age, who committed suicide, late Monday night, by cutting his throat with a razor. The deceased was blind, and for several months had been drinking to excess.

DEATH OF BISHOP WAUGH -- A telegram from Baltimore this morning, announces the death of Rev. BEVERLY WAUGH, D. D., senior Bishop of he Methodist Episcopal Church. The Bishop's age was about 70 He entered the Methodist ministry in the year 1809, and has been in active service for a period of forty-six years.

DISUNION AND THE SOUTH.--The Southern sky is again dark with threats of disunion. Unless Kansas can be compelled to receive a Constitution which nine-tenths of her people had no band in framing, which they abhor and would repudiate, then we are told the dire contingency has arisen in which the Slave States must sever the bonds of confederacy and establish an independent empire.

Professor DAVIES, the new appointed Professor of Mathematics in Columbia College, delivered his inaugural address to an large and intelligent audience last evening at Mozart Hall. His subject was "The Nature and Utilities of Mathematical Science," and he discussed, at some length and with great clear-ness and force, the forms of the language which it employs,

WITHDRAWING BANK SECURITIES--In the report of Assembly proceedings for Saturday last we find that Mr. LANING moved " that the Superintendent of the Bank Department furish the name of all Banks that have withdrawn securities below the amount required by law," which motion was laid over.

There is a very general and a very carnest movement on foot to promote the better observance of Sunday. We have already noticed tile meeting of clergymen, held a few days since at the Spingler Institute, for the consideration of this subject.

WALLACK'S THEATRE.--A neat and amusing little comedy, called "The Crown Prince; or, the Buckle or Brilliants," was produced here, last night, with complete success. It is a dramatic version of one of ??RICH ZSCHOKKE'S best tales, and has already been played in this City.

VEYBASSAT -- In this City, on Sunday, Feb. 7, Mrs. REZIA S VEYRASSAY, eldest daughter of Euos II, and Eliza M. Weed. aged 34 years. The friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend her funeral from the residence of her parents, No. 167 Monroe st., on Wednesday morning at 11 o'clock. WOOD--In this City, on Tuesday. Feb. 9, DORCAS M., daughter of David Wood, aged 32 years.

UNPRECEDENTED WEATHER ON LAKE SUPERIOR.--We (Cleveland Herald) have before us a letter of Jan. 11. from Dr. TOMPKINS, at Portage Lake, in which we are informed that the Winter has been as remarkable there as here. The chickens and turkeys usually purchased from the last boat of the season have been spoiled by warm weather.

Orders have been received that the store-ship Relief be got ready for sea, to carry provisions to the feet at Aspinwall, She will have to go into dock. The work on the Niagara progresses rapidly. Her topsail yards and fore and main topgallant masts have been made heavier, and have been sent up. Her officers will be the same who went in her on the previous voyages, with two or three exceptions.

The Washington Union is in some trouble about the prospects of its party. In an article which we copy in another column, it asks " is our national party to be proserved?"--and gives a column of reasons for thinking that It is not.

Various petitions and memorials, including one from Iowa, praying for reimbursement of the expenses of the Indian War at Spirit Lake, and that the volunteers in that war receive grants of public land were presented. Mr. DOUGLAS, from the Committee on Foreign Re nations, reported a resolution granting authority to the President to settle all difficulties with Paraguav.

THE HERALD ON REAL ESTATE -- Poor BENNETT is in trouble. He is alarmed about Real Estate. The revulsion has reached Washington Heights Land bought for $90,000 is no likely to sell for half that sum. "Real estate and rents," says the Herald, "must come down."

A letter of nearly four columns from Governor WISE, in response to an invitation to attend the AntiLecompton meeting held here last evening, will be published in the Press to-morrow morning. Governor WISE says that a careful review of the President's Message constrains him to differ with the President of his choice.

The Leavenworth correspondent of the Democrat says that a bill providing for a Constitutional Convention had passed the Kansas Legislature. Lawrence letters in the Leavenworth papers contain the proceedings of the Board of Commissioners to investigate the election frauds.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I have to ask the privilege of a brief rejoinder to your article of the 2d inst. in relation to gas companies. I do not profess to be a controversialist, much less a skillful one. My intention was simply to vindicate gas companies from what I believed to be unjust aspersions.

ALLEGED MURDER ON BOARD AN AMERICAN SHIP.--An examination of the Captain and part of the crew of the American ship America took place at Cork, about the 20th etc., in reference to the alleged murder of one of the seamen, (a Greek, whose name is not known,) by BURNS, third mate.

At a meeting of the General Committee held last evening, JOSIAH W. BROWN in the Chair, it was resolved, on motion o EMANUEL B. HART, that a standing Committee of one member of the General Committee from each Ward be appointed by the Chair to investigate all alleged frauds at primary

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I saw in your paper a short time since, and in various other city journals, an appeal to the charitable public in behalf of a Society for the relief of the poor. The appeal was eloquent, argumentative, persuasive--every thing hut explicit. It did not tell me where I could send the $5 which I resolved, on reading it, to send to the Society.

MR. KEITT AND HIS FRIENDS.--The candor exhibited by Mr. KEITT in assuming the entire blame of the encounter with Mr. GROW is considerably greater than his backers were prepared for. Among those placed in an awkward predicament by his explanation is the Richmond South.

NICHOLL--REYNOLDS.--In this City, on Tuesday, Feb. 9. by Rev. Thos I Sawyer, D. D, Mr. GEO R NICHOLL to Miss AMELIA REYNOLDS, daughter of Harvey Reynolds, Esq. of this City BALCH--MELVILLE--In this City on Tuesday, Jan, 19, at the Bleecker-st Church by Rev. Wm. S. BALCH, WM. DELOS BALCH to ELLEN MELVILLE MELVILLE, eldest daughter of Henry R Melville all o his City.

We understand that a petition is about being presented to the Legislature to have shorthand reporters appointed for all the Courts in this City. The reporters are to take everything on the trial, from the calling of the case to the rendition of the verdict.

PRIVATE CHARACTERS.--Our legal record this morning contains the examination of LOLA MONTEZ concerning the personal antecedents and private character of one D. WEMYSS JOBSON, who professes to have been Dentist to the British Queen and the Royal Family, but in whom the Countess of LANDSFELDT asserts that she recognizes a very different personage.

A double game is being played on the Kansas question. The President is constantly assuring the Northern Democrats privately that be knows the Free-State Legislature to be returned elected. CALNOUN, who ostentatiously declares that he has not seen the president, Is constantly assuring the Southern men that in any event the Pro Slavery men will have the control of the State.

FORGERIES BY AN OLD MAN.--Thomas S. Whittaker Wm. Brown, a man nearly 70 years of age, formerly a prosperous down town merchant, but who failed some time ago, was arrested yesterday by Captain Weed, of the Second Ward, charged with forging the signatures of various merchants of the City upon checks upon different banks.

The losses by the fire of Jan. 31 in New-Orleans, (reported by telegraph,) were as follows: Magazine-street Market; corner of Magazine and St. Mary's streets--loss $15,000; ROBINSON'S dry goods store--stock valued at $6,000--insured for $4,000; a coffee house kept by J. HAAS; J. HOFFMAN'S dry goods store in St. Mary's street--stock insured for $5,000;

ALARMING SCARCITY OF LIGHT READING.--The Boston Daily Advertiser says that there have been so few new books published this season, that fathers of families have been driven to the necessity of reading aloud for the amusement of their home circles such works as PIERCES's Celestial Dynamics, while young ladies, for the lack of new novels, have eagerly availed themselves of the recent distribution of the Patent Office Report.

DON'T WANT IT.--The Brooklyn Common Council. on Monday evening, almost by a unanimous vote, adopted the report of a Special Committee, urgently protecting against the passage of the Assessment bill presented by Senator SPINOLA of Brooklyn. The report was ordered to be published in the Corporation papers, and also in pamphlet form, and the City Clerk was directed to circulate 250 copies among the Members of the Legislature.

A SUGGESTION WORTH CONSIDERING.--It used to be the custom in this City in leasing houses to name a certain rent, and taxes, let them be what they might, the tenant taking the chance. But this system has, of late years, fallen into disuse, and the landlord now, in almost every case, pays the taxes on his Property and adds to the rent, so that the tenant never know precisely what rent he pays.

The friends of Temperance assembled last evening at The Academy of Music, to listen to an address from lion. NEAL Dow, who was announced to give an act count of his late mission to England. At 7 o'clock there were only about 200 persons in the house; the number afterwards increased to about 400.

The Cincinnati Commercial contains the following dispatch: MEMPHIS, Feb, 5.--The steamer Col. Crossman, Capt. J. CHEEVER, bound from New-Orleans for St. Louis, with a cargo of about four hundred tons of groceries, and two hundred passengers, was entirely consumed by fire, on Thursday night, 4th inst. at 9 o'clock, in the Mississippl Rive, a short distance below New-Madrid, Missouri.

The Correo Mercantil, of Rio de Janeiro, in its issue of Dec. 27, publishes the address of Mr. MEADE, United States Minister, upon the presentation of his credentials to the Emperor of Brazil, and his Majesty's reply thereto.

A NOVEL SUGGESTION FROM E. M.--The last time that the yellow fever made its appearance in this city as an epidemic, was in the year 1822, and ever since that period its return has been annually predicted, and very philosophical reasons given why it should come. But it never has come yet.

The Board of Supervisors. THE MOUNTED AND ARMED POLICE -- ACCOMMODATIONS FOR IMPRISONED WITNESSES. The Board of Supervisors met yesterday afternoon, President ?? in the Chair. A message was received from the Mayor, inclosing a communication from the Clerk of the Metropolitan Police Commissioners, setting forth the action of the Board in reference to the provision of accommodations for he detention of witnesses who are unable to furnish security for their appearance in criminal cases.

In the U. S. Senate yesterday, Mr. DOUGLAS again made an effort to include a consideration of ?? Kansas resolution calling for the returns of the elections, etc., bat the Senate refused, by a vote of 30 to 23, to ?? the consideration of the Army bill, which was debated until the adjournment.

Gen. CALHOUN has been here several days and has had interviews with the President and with Senator DOUGLAS, and other prominent men on both sides of the Kanas question. Numbers of persons have called upon him, and he is very frank in his communications on the subject of the election on the 4th of January.

General Order day in the House, and the reference of the Governor's Message the particular matter under consideration. Mr. WOOLFORD, Republican; Mr. CAANLER, Democrat; Mr. AUSTIN, Republican; and Mr. DELANEY, Democrat, occupied the time intervening between 11 and 2 o'clock.

General WALKER, appeared yesterday before Hon. T. H. McCCALEB, U. S. District Judge of this District, and stated that having been bound over to appear before his Court, he desired to make his appearance and ascertain whether there was any charge against him. The Judge stated that the Jury had ignored the bill against Gen WALKER, and therefore there was no accusation against him.

Delivered at the Ant-Lecompton Meeting in Philadelphia, Feb. 8. From the Philadelphia Press. Mr. PRESIDENT AND GENTLEMEN OF PHILADELPHIA I regret that Governor WALKER has not yet arrived in the city--for two reasons; first, because at will deprive you, at least for a time, of a much abler explanation of the subjects which are before you than I shall be able to give; and again,

This has been an eventful day-and the faithful band of patriots who stood together this morning in resisting the precipitate consummation of the crime against Kansas, have succeeded, in all probability, In averting the horrors of civil war. I have little to add to my dispatch upon this subject, beyond a comment or two In relation to the course of the New-York delegation. Not amen of them all is In favor of the Lecompton scheme.

Smith and John Fitzpatrick , who are, on affidavit of the Comptroller, held responsible for some of the errors in the Finance Department, appeared before the Recorder yesterday afternoon for examination Mr. John Graham appeared as Counsel for Mr. Smith, whose case was on; and Ex-Judge Whiting,

CRAWFORD --In this City, on Wednesday, Feb. 10 ETHERLINDA, wife of Nathaniel Crawford, aged 51 years The friends and relatives of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, this (Thursday) evening, at 7 o clock, from her late residence, No, 66 West 10th st. Orange County papers please copy. JOURNEAY, -- In this City, on Wednesday, Feb. 10, JAMES JOURNEAY.

Opinion of Mayor Tiemann-Interesting Proceedings. The Aldermanic Committee on Lands and places, Alderman MURRAY, Chairman, met yesterday afternoon, under Alderman TUCKER'S resolution, to consider the matter of purchasing that portion of Ward's Island that is yet in the hands of private par. ties.

Tuesday's Tribune contains a report of Mrs. LUCY STONE'S speech on "Taxation without Representation," delivered on Monday last, "in a little hall in the village of Orange, N. J.," where LUCY resides, and where we are told she has "bought a home for herself and her husband," Mr. HENRY BLACKWELL.

This is, less one day, the completion of the fifth week of the session of our Legislature, which expects to rise on the 6th of March, just two months from the date of its meeting. Should it rise then, the session will be one of the shortest, and therefore one of the most popular, in the memory of the present generation.

MORE TOM-FOOLERY.--Our Common Council has appropriated $2,000 towards the reception of the Turkish gentleman who is coming t his City to sea about having some ships built for the Turkish navy. Our ship-builders will be very much obliged to our City Fathers for their services as runners, and "touting" dinner givers, for their benefit.

Mr. HARRIS said, in the remarks with which he prefaced his resolutions that " the truth never harmed any party on a great public question of this character." Evidently the Southern members do not agree with him. On the contrary they know that nothing else could be so fatal to their plans,

From the Albany Evening Journal. Did you ever see LAWRENCE M. KEITT ? Did you ever watch him when parading the hall, his head thrown back with the conceited air of a London cockney, his lascivious eye staring brazenly at the ladies' gallery, his thrust-out elbows see-sawing like dancing Jack's under a vigorous pulling of the string, and daintily treading the floor, much as a peacock with tail-feathers wide.

STRANGE OPINIONS OF BANK OFFICERS.-The Evening Post says: "Many Bank officers, to our certain, knowledge, consider that the strength of the houses who passed though the storm without suspension was so far expended that they might as well have suspended at once."

The steamship indian, Capt. JONES, arrived here at 1 o'clock this morning. She left Liverpool at 9 o' clock on the morning of the 27th ult. Her dates are consequently four days later than those by the Arabia at New-York. The steamship City of Baltimore also sailed on the 27th ult. from Liverpool, and the North Star was to ?eave Southampton on the same day for New-York.

The Canadian Steamship Indian from Liverpool on the 27th ult., arrived at Portland yesterday morning. Her advices are four days later than those brought by the Arabia. The most interesting feature in the news is the marriage of Prince FREDERICK WILLIAM, of Prussia, to the Princess Royal of England.

On Saturday last, acting in behalf of the portion of our citizens desiring an expression of public sentiment on the pending question in our Federal politics on the subject of the Lecompton Constitution, I made an engagement with the person charged with the letting of the Academy of Music for the use of that building for a public meeting on Friday, the 12th inst., at a stipulated rent of $300.

The funeral of Bishop WAUGH, of the Methodist Episcopal Church, took place this afternoon. The services were performed at the Light-street Church, where an immense throng assembled. The funeral sermon was preached by Bishop JAMES.

To-day the Executive mansion was stormed by the Border Ruffians in a body. By an arrangement previously made about seventy-five or a hundred Missourians repaired to the White House and called upon the President.

WHTLOWS--Dr. GUINER, Professor of the Faculty of Medicine at Montpelier, has just published a letter in the Abeillc Medicalc, in which he describes a peculiar method of stopping the progress of a whitlow in its first stage. A whitlow generally begins with a dull sensation of heat in the affected finger, near the nail; a rose-colored spot marks the seat of disease. This point.

WOODEN SHOES AND THE POPE OF ROME.--It would hardly strike a careless observer that there is any vital connection between the siege of Londenderry and the marriage of the Princess Royal of England. Nevertheless, there can be no doubt that the "holy, blessed and glorious memory of WILLIAM of Orange" came up from the limbo of the past on the evening of the 25th of January,

The State Treasurer yesterday communicated a statement to the Legislature, from which it appears that Messrs. LAWRENCE, STONE Co.'s paper, to the amount of $50,000, is among the securities of the tr Western Railroad Sinking Fund.

THE PARAGUAY EXPEDITION.--The following named officers connected with the Expedition for the survey and exploration of the rivers Paraguay and Parana, sailed yesterday in the bark Dawn for Buenos Ayres, vis.: CHAS. P. McGARY, R. R. CARTER,

A dispatch from Marysville to the Commercial, says that the extensive establishment known as the Union factory, recently erected for the manufacture of coal oil, was entirely destroyed by fire at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon. The loss is estimated at from $40,000 to $50,000. No insurance. FIRE IN ST. JOHN, N. B. ST. JOHN, N. B., Wednesday, Feb. 10.

OPEN TO CONVICTION.---The Richmond South, in announcing "the defeat of the Administration," in the vote upon Mr. HARRIS' motion, takes heart and exclaims; "But the Black Republican-Douglas majority was so small that we are sanguine of ultimate success. Surely more than three men on the other side are "open to conviction."

Mr. HARLAN presented the credentials of Hon. .1, W. GRIMES, the new Senator from Iowa. Mr. DOUGLAS attempted to bring up his Kansas resolutions. Mr. DAVIS objected, and called for the Yeas and Nays, Mr. DOUGLAS proceeded to give reasons why the resolutions should be considered now.

BELIMAN--STRACHAN.--In this City, on Friday, Feb. 5, by Rev. James Prostly, VINCENT SELLMAN to MARGARET, eldest daughter of Robert Strachan, Esq. all of this City. LYON--PEBKING.--In this City, on Tuesday, Feb. 5, by daughter of Jacob Perkins, all this City. Philadelphia papers please copy. MORGAN--HITCHCOCK.--On Wednesday, Feb. 10, by Rev.

CAPTURE OF THE ADRIATIC.--We are happy to find that the Boston Courier repudiates with just and natural indignation the singular complacency with which the "Yankee trick" of Captain DURHAM was received by another Press of that city. The Courier finds it as difficult as we find it disagreeable to believe that an American Captain could have been guilty of so superlatively mean a transaction,

The St. Louis Republican, of Monday, has the particulars of the loss of the Col. Cressman, the Prominent points of which we have had by telegraph. We condense the Republican's account. At the time of the disaster, the Col. C. was making her first trip from New-Orleans to St. Louis, having, during her previous services, been in the Missouri River trade.

ALTOGETHER UNNECESSARY --It was not at all necessary for poor BENNETT to inform his readers that he could not approve of Mr. GROWS ideas on the subject of self-defence, and that he does not approve of striking back when he is hit. Poor BENNETT has too often given illustrations of his theory in practice, to make it necessary for him to state what his opinions are on that subject.

The schooner C. R. Vickery, from Attakapas, reports that in latitude 34? 34' longitude 81? 14', saw a vessel supposed to be a brig of 300 or 400 tons burden, turned nearly to the water's edge, abandoned. On the first day out, THOMAS HODGDEN, of Bath, Me., mate of the C. R. Vickery, fell overboard and was drowned.

The State Agricultural Society has possession of the Assembly chamber from 12 o'clock to day. Previous to the adjournment, a resolution was passed tendering to Mr. STANTON the use of the hall on Saturday evening, while he should explain to the congregated wisdom of the state the actual condition of Kansas.

ARREST OF A MAIL ROBBER IN CHICAGO.-In Chicago, last week, HENRY VAN GEESON, a clerk in the Post Office, was arrested for mail robbery. He began his thefts in the month of July last, as he sated after his arrest Since this time registered letters have been frequently missed, and most of them from mules going west from Chicago.

At a meeting of the Stockholders of the Pennsylvania Bank, it was announced that Mr. ALLIBONE had assigned his property for the benefit of the Bank. A resolution for an assignment by the Bank was adopted, as, also, were resolutions censuring President ALLIBONE and DANIEL DEAL, as colluding together in the common plunder of the Bank, and desiring that whatever punishment the criminal law inflicts on such dishonesty should be enforced.

The Richmond Enquirer thinks that we must have been actuated by a subtle and secret hostility to the institutions and the independence of the South in giving utterance, a few days since, to the satisfaction which we felt on learning that Mr. WM.

RAISING EGGS IN THE CITY.--A gentleman residing in this City, and who has but so much of s single City lot as a good sized house on it leaves uncovered, during the year following. Thanksgiving, 1856, kept an average of 15 hens, and received from them 2,008 eggs.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Allow me through your columns, to solicit the attention of the public, and of the young especially, to the free lectures of Professor DUBOIS. At the present day an acquisition of the French language is increasingly valuable as a handsome and creditable accomplishment not only, but, also, as furnishing facility for lucrative employment.

ACCIDENTS AND NARROW ESCAPES.--MICHAEL GRIFFIN, a boy thirteen years of age, residing at No. 29 Old-slip, while flying a kite Tuesday afternoon on the roof of the five-story building No. 31 Old-slip, accidentally stumbled off the roof and fell into the back yard. He was severely injured internally, but no bones fractured. Officer HAERINGTON, of the First Ward, took him to City Hospital.

The vote in the Senate to-day upon Mr. DOUGLAS' resolution calling for the returns of the Kansas election, was significant, and rendered the more so by the cool insolence with which Mr. MASON intimated that the power of the majority to stifle all investigation was to be exerted as a matter of course, and by agreement.
The river is now fulling. The water in the canal is six feet in depth.

The harmony of college life has been again broken in up on by an affray between the students and firemen, in which one of the latter was seriously, if not fataliy, wounded. The reputation of the college will perhaps suffer less by an immediate statement of facts than by the exaggerated stories which are likely to gain currency at such times. The feud between students and townies,"
A bill was reported in the House to-day requir.

Hon. David Paul Brown has accepted the appointment of "Knight of Mount Vernon" for Pennsylvania, recently tendered him by the "Southern Matrons." The Boston Traveller has the following: A farce by F. B. Goodrich, a son of "Peter Parley," and one of the successful * * * * Club of New-York, has been accepted by the management of the Howard Athenaeum.

Last night, Madame LOLA MONTEZ delivered the third of her course of lectures in this City--subject "Callantry." The building (Hope Chapel) was crowded. The history of the beginning of the reign of gallantry would carry us back. She said, to the creation of the world, for she believed that the first thing that man began to do after he was created, was to make love to woman.

No. 37.--Ann C. Smith. , vs. The Corporation of Washington.--Justice GRIER delivered the opinion of the Court, affirming the judgment of the Circuit Court of the District of Columbia, with costs. No. 21.--Robert Hudgins et al. vs. Wymdlyn Kemp.--Justice NELSON delivered the opinion of the Court, affirming the degree of the Circuit of the United States for the Eastern District of Virginia, with costs and interest.

YOUNG MEN'S CHRISTIAN ASSOCIATION.--The Brooklyn Young Men's Christian Association met on Tuesday evening, at Rev. Mr. HOGARTH'S Church, in Henry-street. Mr. GEO. A. Bell presided. The Essay of the evening was read, by J. T. CONCKLING, M.D., subject--"Right vs. Wrong." An animated discussion followed the reading. On motion of Mr. THEODORE TILTON
The United States Coast Survey steamer Walker, Capt. SANDS, has arrived here from Atichifayala Bay All on board of her are well.

The steamer Tennessee, from Vera Cruz, is coming up the river, and Generals COMONFORT and GARCIA CONDE are passengers. The Tennessee will be up at 5 P. M. NEW-ORLEANS, Wednesday, Feb. 10--P. M. The Tennessee left Vera Cruz on the 7th inst.

NEW-York, Wednesday, Feb. 10, 2 P. M.-Barometer 29.6 inches. Thermometer 47? Wind W. N. W. Clear wea ther. The weather was the most disagreeable that we have had during the present season. A high wind started the dust early in the morning, and kept it flying about, to the serious annoyance of eyes, mouths and noses, during the remainder of the day.

The suicide of a blind man named Philip Gonpertz, who out his throat with a razor, was noticed in yesterday's TIMES. After the Coroner's inquest in the caso had been concluded the body brother of the decessed NO, 06 Ridge street, and laid out ready for burial. On looking into the room yesterday morning the body was found to have been removed.

There was a curious discussion at the meeting of the Police Board a day two since. It was proposed by Mr. STRANAHAN that Mr. Cornelius Woglom, a Sergeant of the Fifth Precinct, be appointed Inspector. There was to be said in his favor that his election would give great satisfaction to the people of his district,

VERY AGREEABLE'.--- A man, with the small-pox well developed, took one of the Fulton cars, in the Ninth Ward, Brooklyn, Wednesday, and rode as far as Raymond-street, on his way to be Hospital,. the car was crowded at the time. As the sick man was leaving the car, a curious gentleman asked the conductor what disease the man had; when he was coolly answered " Only the small-pox."

There is a singular affinity between Utopianism and fatalism, which has not escaped the observation of the students of human nature, ad which has frequently confounded all the anticipations of political reasoners and practical statesmen.
