ANTI-LECOMPTON MEETING--The difficulties in the way of the meeting at the Academy of Music to-night, having been removed, we are authorized by Mr. STANTON to announce, that although saflering from hoarsoness, occasioned by the peculiar circumstances under which he addressed the meeting in Philadelphia, he will yet speak this evening at the Academy of Music, and to-morrow evening before the Legislature at Albany.

The debates in the Senate this morning were pungent and amusing, but neither dignifies nor instructive. On the bill directing the Canal Appraisers to ascertain what damage HORACE ALLEN sustained, by reason of the improvement of Rackett River, Senator SPINOLA "sailed in on general principles."

NEW-YORK, Thursday, Feb. 11, 2 P. M.--Thermometer 26??. Barometer 30 inches. Wind W. N. W. There was a real touch of Winter yesterday. Windows had a sugar-coated appearance, and hardware dealers had the hardihood to expose skates for sale at their shop-doors. In back streets, the police kept their fingers warm in comfortable quarters,

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR: I have just been shown a copy of your issue of yesterday, in which I notice in a letter of your Washington correspondent, signed "S." under date of the 7th inst., after alluding to the disturbance in this Hall on Friday morning, this language: "Mr. WALBRIDGE, of Michigan, cried 'Shame,' 'Shame,' and was kicked for his pains by Mr. WRIGHT, of Georgia I believe."

LOSSES OF CATHOLICS IN INDIA.--The rebellion in India appears to have affected the interests of the Roman Catholic Missions in that country not less than others. Bishop PERRIDO, VicarApostolic of Hindostan, has addressed a letter to Archbishop HUGIIES, setting forth the sufferings of the clergy and laity at Agra, and beseeching prompt aid from the church abroad.

The Kansas correspondent of the Leader says that Governor DENVER will probably veto all the acts of special legislation of the Territorial Legislature. It is stated by the friends of the bill providing for another Constitutional Convention that they have sufficient friends to carry It over the Governor's veto. The propriety of repealing all the statutes of the first Legislature is giving rise to much discussion.

CHARGE OF EMBEZZLEMENT.--Charles Brestnen, several years employed as cuttor in the clothing establishment of James Wilde Co., No. 27 park place. was arrested Wednesday charged with steating from his employers, at different times, cloths, cassimeres, and other goods of considerable value, A portion of the goods was found at the house of the accused, No. 24 City Hall place. His wife was also arrested.

IMPORTANT DECISION--We call the attention of ship owners and furnishers of supplies to ships, to the decision of Judge BETTS, published in our columns this morning in the case of the Albany, as being a clear statement of the revolution effected by the United States Supreme Court last Winter, in the law of liens upon vessels.

Mr. BEWARD presented a memorial from citizens of Albany, offering to raise a regiment of volunteers for the Army of Utah. Mr. MASON offered a joint resolution conferring authority on the President to make appropriate arrangements for the reception of a distinguished naval officer now on his way to America. Mr. BIGGS objected to its reception.

The deserts of journalism blossom to-day with the rose and the myrtle; and we sadly fear that many, at least of our fairer readers, will turn with a sigh of relief from the sterner and graver questions of the world political--from the realities of finance and the solemrities of social economy---to the romance of a royal marriage, and the brilliant frivolities of courtly pageantry and heraldic pomp which decorate our columns with an unwonteed sheen.

THE SHIP MACKINAW ASHORE. CHARLESTON, Thursday, Feb. 11. The ship Mackinaw, from Liverpool for Charleston, is ashore near ossibaw. She has a cargo of coal and salt, by the removal of which ??l is though she can be saved. THE SCHOONER M. WRIGHTINGTON IN DISTRESS. NEWPORT, R. I., Thursday, Feb. 11.

The Philadelphia Evening Journal of Saturday says: This morning a man named ROBERT P. KIRKPATRICK, who resides at the corner of Eleventh and Wallace streets, in the Fourteeth Ward, was brought before Alderman ENEU, on very-serious charges preferred against him by his brother, Mr. EDWIN KIRKPATRICK. EDWIN KIRKPATRICK had for several years past been annoyed by the reception of anonymous letters which were designed to destroy the domestic peace of his family.

LIVINGSTON AND BROOME APPORTIONMENT.--Attorney General TREMAIN has furnished an opinion responsive to a resolution of the Assembly, to the effect that the apportionment by the Act of April 13, 1857, is unconstitutional and void, so far as relates to the counties of Broome and Livingston; and that the present Legislature has the power to make a new one of these counties.

THE ALLEGED KIDNAPPER TO BE BROUGHT TO NEW-YORK--MAYOR TIEMANN INVITED TO RICHMOND, VA., TO CELEBRATE WASHINGTON'S BIRTHDAY. A CITY HALL FOR JERSEY CITY. -- The Board of Aldermen of Jersey City have appointed a Committee, consisting of Aldermen Hankies, Sinclair, McComb Tilden, for the purpose of visiting Trenton and obtaining from the legislature such supplement to the Charter as will enable the city to borrow money for the purchase of a site and the creation of a City Hall and other public buildings.

BURNS, Who died from compression of the brain, produced by a fail whist wrestling, The evidence showed that the deceased was wrestling on Monday night, corner of Watts and Greenwich streets, with a friend named PATRICK McCOUN, when he was thrown heavily to the pavement, his friend falling on top.

The Board of Aldermen met last evening, President CLANOY in the Chair. A petition was received and read from sundry property-owners against the extension of Albany-street. RECEPTION OF MOHAMMED PASHA. A resolution was offered appropriating $2,000 to defray the expenses of the proposed reception of Mohammed Pasha. Alderman TUCKER opposed the resolution.

The screw-steamship City of Baltimore, from Liverpool at about 91/2 A. M. on the 27th day of January, arrived at this port yesterday morning. The City of Baltimore brings advices of the same date as those received by the Indian. Nothing further of importance had been developed in regard to the recent attempt to assassinate the Emperor.

A gentleman, who styles himself WM. W. WATERMAN, Attorney-at-Law, and Magistrate at Binghamton, N. Y., sent yesterday to Mayor TIEMANN a judicial decision, recently rendered by himself, touching the shutting-up of gambling-houses and dens of prostitution in Binghamton.

Further intelligence by the Tennessee is to the effect that eleven days' fighting took place in the City o Mexico before Gen. ZULOAGA triumphed, but only a few persons were killed. Gen. ZULOAGA received 26 out of 28 votes of the Council of Notables, for Provisional President. Puebla and a few other points had recognized the new Government, but the whole country was in confusion.

RELIGIOUS REVIVALS.--There is an unusual religious interest manifested in the churches of both New-York and Brooklyn. To Dr. WOOD'S (Broome-street Presbyterian) Church, 52 persons were admitted on profession last Sabbath; to Rev. Mr. HASTING'S (Carmine-street) Church 80; to Rev. Dr. ADAMS' (Madison-square) 1st and lately to Rev. Dr. PARKERS' (Fourth-avenue) 9, More than 50 confirmed in Rev. Dr. HAWKS' last Sunday.

The examination of witnesses with reference to the late riot between the students and firemen was commenced to-day. Those called thus far belong principally to the company of firemen which was concerned in the affray. Their testimony is quite contradictory. Nothing has as yet been elicited to invalidate in any material point the statement I forwarded this morning.

FIRE IN A TENEMENT HOUSE--At a little before 1 yesterday morning a fire broke out in the five story brick ?? house No. 218 East Seventeenth-street. Great alarm prevailed among the inmates of the house. Fortunately by the prompt arrival of the firemen the fire was confined to the room where it originated, which was on the second floor, The occupants of the room lost on their furniture about $30??, No insurance.

IRREVRENCE.--- A practise prevails among newspapers and their Albany correspondents which we feel called upon to reprehend. The bad habit to which we refer consists in making fan of the Legislature. Now what have the thirty-two Senators and one hundred and twenty-eight Assemblymen done? Simply nothing.

Appearances indicate the ultimate adoption of the Lecompton Constitution. The Administration is fully and irretrievably committed to that policy--and it has an encouraging field for the exercise of the power and patronage at its command. The Senate is clearly in favor of admission, and in a very full House the resolution of inquiry into the facts of the formation of the Constitution was carried by a majority of only three votes.

Much indignation is expressed at ORR'S arrangement of the Select Committee on Kansas. Not only has he given the Lecomptonites a majority, thus vlolating the parliamentary custom, but has totally disregarded the wishes of the Anti-Lecomptonites, and composed the minority of the Committee very weakly. In view of the closeness of the vote, however, no attempts will be made to force a reconstruction.

MAILS FOR CENTRAL AMERICA, (PACIFIC SLOPE.) -We (Union) are requested by the Post-Office Department to direct public attention to the arrangement made in January, 1857, for dispatching a regular monthly mail to San Jose de Guatemala, La Union, Aajulta, Realejo, San Juan del Sur, and Panta Arenas, seaports on the Pacific slope of Central America.

A letter received in London, by the Royal Mail steamer Medway, which arrived at Southampton on Jan. 19, gives a favorable ascount of the aspect of affairs in the Argenline Provinces. All was quiet in the political world, and with tranquillity the country was progressing in prosperity. Every month was adding to the population by the arrival of immigrants, chiefly from the Basque Provinces of Spain.

Ex-GOVERNOR BERB, OF OHIO.--It will be remembered that ex-Governor BERB, of Ohio, settled near Rockford, Winnebago County, in Illinois. Some months since a wedding was held at his house. While it was in progress, a crowd of men, on the outside, commenced making noises in the usual charivari style. Every effort was made to get them to leave.

The steamship Empire City, from New-York 2d inst, vid Havana 9th inst., is coming up the river. She connected at Havana with the steamship Granada, from Aspinwall, and brings the California mails of the 20th ult. The steamship Star of the West left Aspinwall on the 3d inst for New-York, with the mails and two hundred and fifty passengers from California, and $1,325,000 in treasure.

M. WILLIAM MILES, the fireman wounded in the late riot, died this morning about 2 o'clock. Yesterday afternoon he was reported to be better, and hopes were indulged of his recovery. His death, of course, gives the investigation the form of a Coroner's Inquest. The July were impanneled this morning, and after viewing the body adjourned to meet this afternoon at Justice BENNETT'S office.

THOMAS charged him. A friend of the prisoner proposed to see that he went to sea.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Allow me to correct your impressions as to the prevalence of Yellow Fever at Bay Ridge during the Summer of 1856. With the exception of three cases the sickness was confined entirely to the shore, and to that part of it where bedding, clothing and other articles, thrown overboard from the infected vessels, had drifted and landed.

Business men here are finding a worse time of it than they expected. On account of the low price of cotton it has been kept back, the planters thinking that they could force consumers to terms, but they are now beginning to hurry it forward, so that there is more cotton coming into Memphis than at any former period.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In my last article I showed, first, that money was not wealth, but merely the representative of it,-a conventional sign used to facilitate the exchange of product ; and, second, that any material or substance can be used for money, provided the issues are properly regulated.

The difficulties seem to be renewing at For Scott, but from what cause it is difficult to learn. One thing is sure. These are no "designing politicians' in that vicinity, and whatever they do is done from no some light upon the subject.

THE RHODE ISLAND MIRACLE.--The story of Mr. BOURN'S miraculous paralysis of sight and speech, and of his restoration by direct divine interposition, is going through the papers again, with this heading. It was, as long since explained in this paper, simply a case of sun-stroke, cured by the skillful application of the ordinary remedies of medical science.
The southern mail has been received. The bark Thomas Allibone, at New-Orleans, saw a bark, streaked black and white, ashore at Orange Key. The rigging was standing. Wreckers were around her.

Dentist,. at No. 30 Bond-street, appeared before Justice QUAKCNEBUSH at the Jefferson Market Police Court, and preferred a charge of libel against D. Wemyss Jobson. The Justice issued a warrant, and placed it in the hands of Officer Leighton, detailed at his Court. About 9 o'clock Saturday morning, the officer arrested the accused and brought him before the Magistrate.

SPRITIUALISTS' BALL AND LEVEE. --Dancing succecds Rapping. The Spiritualists of Charlestown, Mass., treated themselves to a Ball, at Washington lHall, in that city, on Wednesday evening last. One hundred couples assembled on tle occasion. There was singing by the MYERS sisters, and other, the like, exercises, after which caine a supper. THE MORMONS GROWING PACIFIC.-- A variety of unreliable rumors concerning the Mormons and their doings reach us by every California mail. These reports are generally to the effect that the United States troops have been cut up by large body of Mormons. We see that some such statements have been again circulated by the San Francisco papers,

Dr. HARRIOTT K. HUNT is, much to her own regret, a woman. She is by profession a physician, and resides in Boston. Dr. HUNT is one of the dozen women in the United States who pine because Nature did not make them men. This unfortunate circumstance is the standing grievance of their lives.

Between 6 and 7 o'clock on Saturday evening, Mr. GEORGE H. SIMONSON, of Brooklyn, was attacked by three ruffians at the door of STEPHEN STORY'S saloon, on Pierrepont near Fulton-street, and so badly injured that he died between 4 and 5 o'clock yesterday morning.

Drs. KNIGHT and JEWETT, Yesterday, made a port Mortem examination of the body of WILLIAM MILES, Jr., the deceased fireman. The pistol ball entered the edge of hip, some two inches from the 'spine It passed through a portion of the large intestine into the stomach, and thence into the small intestines, where it was found. Inflammation of the bowels, produced by the pistol ball, was the immediate cause of death.

The R. M. steamship Niagara, Capt. MILLER, from Liverpool at about 10 o'clock A. M. of Saturday, the 30th ult., arrived at Halifax at,71/6 o'clock A. M. of Sunday, the 14th inst. Among her passengers are his Excellency the Hon. the Earl of MULGRAVE, the newly-appointed Governor of Nova Scotia. his family and suite.

This was a noble example of respect for the laws and institutions of society, and we are pleased to see that it has not been altogether thrown away upon the world. MILLS.--In this City. on Thursday evening, Feb. 11, Mr. JAMES MILLS. aged 75 years, late President of the Bowery Savings Bank, who for a quarter of a century devoted his time to its interests. and faithfully discharged the duties of his office. Few men have passed through life more honorably. and few leave behind them a more unblem ished reputation.

NARROW ESCAPS OF THE INMATES. We mentioned in our second edition Saturday, that the Hospital on Blackwell's Island had been endirely destroyed by fire. The fire originated in the private kitchen of the resident physician, and was discovered by one of the watchmen at 3 1/2 o'clock Saturday morning. The alarm was immediately given.

The United States Mail steamship Star of the West, A. G. GRAY, Esq., commanding, left Aspinwall Feb. 3, at 2 o'clock P. M., and arrived at this port on Saturday afternoon. She brings the California mails of Jan. 20, $1,348,507 in treasure, on freight, and 219 passengers.

The Royal Mail steamship Niagara, from Liverpool on the 30th of January, arrived at Halifax yesterday, bringing three days' later news from Europe, a week's later news from India, and intelligence from China to Dec. 16. Parliament was to assemble on the 4th inst. Heavy drafts of troops were under orders to embark for India. The Bank of England,

Volumes of. dust were rolled up like smoke from the dirt streets,

Mr. SEWARD presented a memorial from the Commissioners of Emigration of New-York, complaining of the abuses to females by officers of ships, and gave notice that he would introduce a bill relating to the subject.

To the Editor of the New- York Times: The Tribune and Observer have recently contained editorials, condemnatory of the sale of books on the gift principle. In reply to which I wish, through the columns of your paper, to offer a few words in defence of my business.

THE SOUTH AND EDWARD EVERETT.--That chivalrous journal, the Richmond South, waxes more southern than usual, on learning that Mr. EDWARD EVERETT has been invited to attend the celebration on the 22d, when he is to be presented with Gen. WASHINGTON'S cane, in behalf of the Mount Vernon Association.

At Indianapolis, on Saturday night, two Trizhmen entered a liquor saloon, and being refused liquor attempted to raise a disturbance with the persons present. The barkeeper, named HOHE, and a moll named CASTILLO interfered to prevent a fight, when the Irishmen fired into the crowd. CASTILLO was shot twice, and died last night.

In consequence of the appointment of a new Justice, It was ordered that the following allotment be made: For the First Circuit, Nathan Clifford; for the Second, Samuel Nelson; for the Third, Robert G. Grier; for the Fourth, Roger B. Taney;

THE: STAR OF THE SOUTH AND THE THOMAS SWANN AT SAVANNAH. SAVANNAH, Monday, Feb. 15. The Star of the South arrived here in 72 hours from New-York. All well. The screw-steamship Thomas Swann, of CROMWELL'S line, arrived here early this morning.

To-day, the Territorial Legislature has made commendable progress in the dispatch of bills, giving 'exclusive privileges to whoever was so fortunate as to get their measures before the respective Houses for action.

DAILY PRAYER MEETINGS.--There are held daily at noon, for one hour, Prayer Meetings at the Dutch Reformed Churches, on Fulton and Ninth streets, both of which are thronged by Christians of all denominations and from all classes in society.

MARKETING.-It is a curious fact, and one that. needs explanation, that most market stuffs can be bought cheaper of the grocery stores two or three miles up town, and in the suburbs of Brooklyn, than of the retailers in either Fulton or Washington market, while the purchaser is rather surer of an article of good quality in the places first named than in the markets.

OBSEQUIES OF Mr. JAMES MILLS.--The remains of Mr. JAMES MILS, Ex-President of the Bowery Savings Bank, who died on Thursday, of disease of the heart, aged 75 years, were yesterday interred is Greenwood Cemetery. The funeral services took place at 11/2 o'clock P. M., from the late residence of the deceased. No. 100 Fourth-avenue. Rev. Dr. PHILLIPS officiated.

The excitement caused by the death of Mr GEORGE H. SIMONSON at STORY'S saloon, No. 128 Pierre pont-street, Brooklyn, on Saturday night last, did no abate yesterday. The friends of the deceased have retained the legal services of Ex-District-Attorney UNDERHILL, and by consent of the District-Attorney he Is associated with that officer in ferreting out the perpetrators of the outrage.

BREADSTUFFS are weaker under the steamers news, but no quotable decline can be noted. FLOUR dull; Ohio extra $5. WHEAT quit; red $1#1 05; white $1 25@$1 27. CORN is quiet; sales 25,000 bushels at 59c. WHISKY is firm at 20. 1/2c.@21c. Quereitron Bark is Searce at $29. BALTIMORE, Monday, Feb. 15. FLOUR dull, and a little weaker.

Last night, before a very large audience, in Hope Chapel, Mme. LOLA MONTEZ delivered her lecture on "Strong-Minded Women and the Heroines of History." In Attempting, she said, to give a definition of strong-minded women, I find myself embarrassed between all just ideas of strength and what is now more particularly denominated "strong-minded" in the Woman's Rights movement.

MARINES FOR THE NIAGARA.--A party of ten marines, drafted for service on board the frigate Niagara, arrived by the 2 o'clock train, yesterday, from tne Washington Navy Yard. Thirty will also be drafted from the Philadelphia Navy Yard Corporal RILEY, in charge of this detatchment, was in the Niagara on her first voyage, and is ordered for service on her second expedition; all the rest of the party were new hands.

A certain Louisiana 'Senator, ST. PAUL by name, has undertaken to make himself the Apostle of Africa in the Southwest, and is pleading with the Legislature of his native State in behalf of a scheme for swindling the wretched free blacks of the Guinea Coast out of their licentious liberty into a condition of Slavery and civilization.

That notorious organ of the Sadducees, the New-York Tribune, deals very sternly with the New-York TIMES, the Boston Courier, and a number of other American journals, because of their cruel and ungenerous criticisms passed upon the captain of the bark Adriatic,

The House Select Committee on Kansas had a meeting this afternoon, and had a stormy time of it. The majority voted-down every proposition looking so a fair investigation of the facts. It is evident that the intention is to override every consideration of common decency in order to style investigation, and to crowd a vote on the Kansas question before the facts can be brought out.

In the United States Senate yesterday, a memorial was presented by Mr. SEWARD from the New-York Commissioners of Emigration, complaining of the abuse of women by the officers of emigrant ships. Mr. SEWARD gave notice that he should introduce a bill on the subject.

LEXJI LABLACHE, whose death was prematurely reported a few months since, has really died at last, and the Italian lyric stage has lost a singer whose place will probably never again be filled in the present age.

One at least of the few foreign envoys whom Mr. BUCHANAN has found time to select, appoint and accredit, has already made his mark upon the diplomatic history of the nation, and has asserted in the broad field of our external relations the doctrines which Mr. BUCHANAN is endeavoring to enforce upon our domestic policy.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The communication from Albany in this morning's Herald betrays gross ignorance or stupidity, thus: It affirms that the bill referred to the Attorney-General for his opinion, proposes to add $1,000 to the salaries of the Judges, in addition to the $3,500 now allowed. This is an entire mistake.
A gentlemen presented a lace collar to th, object of his adoration, and, in a jocular way said: " Do not let any one else rumple it." "No, my dear," said the lady, "I will take it off."

BANK SECURITIES WITHDRAWN.--It appears from a report made yesterday to the Assembly by the Superintendent of the Bank Department that the amount of securities withdrawn from the 30th of September last to the 1st of January was $3,274,708 42; and the amount deposited during the same period was $342,148.

About 61/2 o'clock last evening, a party of mutual acquaintances entered the lager-bier saloon of JOHN MULLER, No. 108 Canal-street, and drank together. Soon thereafter a dispute occurred among them, which led to a general fight. Deadly weapons were used, and T. DYCKINK, Foreman of Hook and Ladder Company, No. 4 was shot in the abdomen with a pistol in tile hands of J. FREDERICK BODENBOSS, Constable of the Tenth Ward.

ROBERTON.--In this City, on Sunday morning, Feb. 14, MARGARET H., only daughter of the late Wm. Roberton, aged 2 years and 6 months. Friends are invited to attend the funeral, from No, 10 West 10th st., this day. (Tuesday,) at 1 o'clock P. M. Glasgow papers please cody.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR: In the columns of your paper of the 11th inst. we notice an article under the heading of "Seduction of Young Women at Sea," followed by a memorial to Congress for such an amendment to the Passenger laws as may prevent, by severe punishment for the act, the recurrence of this increasing evil and wrong."

The report that the Governor has decided to nominate Mr. LEAVENWORTH as Auditor has no official foundation. Gov. KING has decided to nominate a Republican for that office, but has not made known the gentleman'ss name.

MAYOR TIRMANN'S SECOND VETO.--The Mayor sent another veto message to the Common Council yesterday, giving at considerable length, and with peculiar cogency, his reasons for returning, without his signature, a resolution instructing the Corporation Counsel to memorialize the Legislature for an alteration of the City Charter, so as to give the members of the Common Council a salary of a thousand dollars a year.

The British steamer Valdivia was wrecked near Maule on the 11th ult. ; passengers and crew saved. The Chilian war steamer Maria Isabel was lost a few days since in the Straits, She had gone to relieve the Sardinian bark George; siruck sunken rock, and all hands had just time to save their lives, getting on board the vessel they went to rescue, in which they arrived here safely 36 hours ago.

A VIGILANCE COMMITTEE AT LAST.--There has been a good deal of talk during the past two years of the necessity of a Vigilance Committee in this City to protect the lives and property of the citizens.

Those melancholy millionaires who mean despondingly over heaps of unemployed bullion, may comfortably and economically ease their minds, by appealing to any "gentlemanly and obliging" theatrical treasurer for the statistics of she past week.

No Salary for the Common Council--Negotiations for a Post-Office to Front on Chambers-street--The Police Commissions' Counsel Fees. The Board of Alderman met last evening, President CLANOY in the chair.

THOMAS ANDERSON BROUGHT TO NEW-YORK, AND THE FORMER LOCKED UP FOR THE. Sergeant CROIT and officer MCARTHUR, of the Mayor's Police squad, arrived by the steamer Roanoke yesterday with MASON THOMAS, the colored man, in their, custoday.

President BUCHANAN is correct, in the statement in his late Message, that there is reason to believe that Gov. YOUNG has long contemplated his present rebellious attitude. To prove this, and give your readers a clearer view of causes that have hastened the rebellion, it will be necessary for me to state, at length, some circumstances preceding the present state of affairs.

DESTRUCTION OF THE NEW BAPTIST CHURCH AT MIDDLETOWN POINT BY FIRE. KEYFORT, N. J., Monday, Feb. 15. The new Baptist Church at Middletown Point, two miles from this place, took fire yesterday minorning just before the services had commenced, and was totally destroyed.

Beals, Esq., of the former place.

The Governor has made the following territorial appointments: AUGUSTA DE MARLE, Auditor of Public Accounts. CHARLES BLUMNER, Territorial Treasurer. BAMON LUNA, Major General of the Third Division of Militia of New-Mexico, In place of General J. J. McCARTHY, resigned. Colonel JOHN W. GAERETSON, Deputy-Surveyor, and Company, arrived In Santa Fe on Thursday last from below. He reports the Indians quiet.

KANSAS LEGISLATIVE STATISTICS.--The members of the House, now in session at Lawrence, 7 were born in Ohio, 7 in Pennsylvania, 5 in New-York, 4 in Virginia, 2 in New-Hampshire, 2 in Kentucky, 2 in Indiana, 1 in Maine, 1 in Illinois, 1 in Massachusetts, 1 in Georgia, 1 in Connecticut, 1 in Prussia, 1 in Scotland.

From the Washington Union. The opposition newspapers, more especially the Philadelphia Press and NEW-YORK TIMES, are assailing Mr. ORR with great bitterness of invective for the manner in which he thought fit to constitute the Harris Committee on the Lecompton Constitution. It is pretended that some ancient and inviolable parliamentary rule has been disregarded in the selection of this Committee.

To the Editor of the New- York Times: SIR: As my good or evil fortune (for on that subject as on most others, I suppose, one may always s have two opinions) has detained me a few days in this city of clean streets and celestial butter, of unimpeachable Madeira and melancholy window-shutters,

CALHOUN still remains in this city, when his duties require his presence in Kansas. If I mistake not, he is Surveyor-General of Kansas and Nebraska, and, if this be so, it is somewhat strange he should absent himself from his post so long.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Last month a meeting was held in Philadelphia, for the purpose of getting up a memorial to Congress to increase the number of chaplains in the Navy, and to introduce certain reforms. There is no doubt that sailors and officers too need a great deal of moral and religious teaching.

Last night, in Clinton Hall, before a very considerable audience, the last of the course of lectures in aid of the Ladies' Union Aid Society, was delivered by Rev. 0. H. Tiffany, of Baltimore. Ills subject was " Work and its Worth." He had no apology, he said, to offer for his theme, though it had been treated again and again, under various titles, until, perhaps, it seemed to have become trite and commonplace.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: When he Vigilance Committee shall have seen the last severity of the law inflicted on the murderers of Mr. SIMONSON, and the righteous anger which now swells the public heart shall be pacified with the punishment of the assassins, there will be something more for us to do.

If the remark were limited to a particular class of our City residents, it might be true:--but we take leave to doubt its

From the Albany Evening Journal. A majority of the Railroad Committee of the Senate, Messrs. BRANDBRETH and HUBBELL, unite in a report against repeating section three of the act passed last winter, which provides that where the rate of fare divices the half-time, the company may received the whole of the half.

Late advices from Kansas state that a party of LANE'S men had visited Westport, Mo., to search for Mr. DANFORTH, a member of the Lecompton Convention. The Missouriane made no resistance. Mr. STOVER, the Democratic representative from Leavenworth Country, was recovering from the wounds received in the late attempt to murder him.

One of the best signs of tile present Kansas controversy in Congress, is the fact that ordinary party lines are not strong enough to bind tile consciences or action of men. There are just two parties to this controversy, and no more.

AN EX-GOVERNOR TRIED FOR MANSLAUGHTER.--One of the most extraordinary criminal trials of the day is that of Hon. WILLIAM B?? for manslaughter which took place at Rockford, Illinois, and terminated on the 8th inst., in the acquittal of the accused.

CONCERTS,--Miss C. A. DINGLEY gave her first Concert last evening, at Dodworth's Saloon, assisted by Miss HAWLEY, Messrs. CONKEY, PEELING, and MORGAN, and an excellent chorus from the Mendelssehn Union, Miss DINGLEY was complimented by the presence of a large audience, by whom her reception was extremely cordial.

SUICIDE IN HOBOKEN.--Mrs. ELIZABETH HEPPE, residing in the house corner of Washington and Third-streets, Hoboken, committed suicide on Sunday morning by taking arsenic. She procured the poison herself, at a drug store near by, on Saturday night, between the hours of 9 and 10 o'clock, and after retiring to her room took a heavy dose.

LONG.--In this City. on Saturday, Feb. 13, MARIA M. LONG, wife of Capt. H. C. Long, of Louisville, ky., in the 21st year of her age. The relatives and friends of the family are invited to attend her father, at the residence of her father. D. A. Webster, Esq., No. 160 East 32d st., at 1 o'clock P. M., on Wednesday, Feb, 17. Services at Trinity Chapel, at 11/2 o'clock P. M.

From the London Times. What is to be the future destiny of the great race which inhabits the opposite shores of the Atlantic ! Springing from the old English stock. and ingrafting on itself schools from every European people, it is advancing with unprecedented rapidity to power and wealth. We ourselves are of the optimists ;

CONNECTICUT BANK ROBBERIES.--The Hartford Press states that the Quinnipiac Bank of New-Haven suffered a loss of some $300, in the same way that the Hartford County Bank was taken in. Master CALTER was the high-priest who should have burned these bills to ashes;

The sloop-of-war St. Louis, lately arrived from the Coast of Africa, has hauled to the Navy Yard and will go out of commission in a day or two, Poor Jack will be obliged to wait the slow motions of Uncle Sam before he gets his pay, and then it wilt probe ably be in quarter-dollars, and those in metal about equal to block tin.

Mr. HOUSTON presented a resolution instructing the Committee on Foreign Relations to inquire into the expediency of the Government establishing a Protectorate over Central America and Mexico. The subject was laid over. Mr. HALE offered a resolution instructing the Committee on Post-Offices and Post-roads to inquire whether the transmission of the mail between Washington and Boston cannot be expedited so as to prevent twelve hours detention in New-York, which was adopted.

Advices from Key West to the 10th inst. mention the sailing of the United States frigate Waeask on the 2nd for Havana. The new Yacht Wanderer sailed in company with the frigate for Havana. She made the run from Charleston to Key West in 62 hours, and from New-York in 120 hours, running time.

The steamship Niagara arrived at Boston yesterday forenoon, and her mails for this City were forwardeded over the New-Haven Railroad by the 3 o'clock train. anti arrived shortly after midnight. Our dispatch from Halifax comprises all the news of importance.

To the Legislature of the State of New-York: The Auditor of the Canal Department, as required by statute, submits to the Legislature the ANNUAL REPORT Of the tolls, trade and tonnage of the Canals of this State during the season of navigation for the year 1857, and all the matters and statistics which are required to be presented to the Legislature, will be found fully and particularly set forth in the accompanying tables.

From the Richmond South. As a class, the leaders of the Black Republican Party exhibit very time sagacity in the practical administration of affairs. For the most part, they are either sha?? diagogues, intent only upon petty schemes of individual ambition, or crazy fanatics, without a definite purpose or a system of operations.

A Southern gentleman, long resident in Paris, and probably more famillar with the political world of France than any other American, inn writing to a friend in this City, makes some very interesting remarks upon the character of the present Emperor of the French, which we are permitted to publish.

Large Fire in Brooklyn--Accidents. Between 2 and 3 o'clock yesterday morning, a fire broke cut at No. 42 Fulton-street, which quickly communicated to No. 44, adjoining. Both buildings were destroyed, and the adjoining premises, Nos. 40 and 46, were considerably injured.

MARSHAL OF THE NORTHERN DISTRICT.--SIMEON B. JEWETT. Esq., who has been confirmed as Marshall of the Northern District of New-York, is recognized as one of the most astute political managers in the State. In 1818 he took a prominent stand in CASS' defeat, and was a leading Free-Solider during the life-time of that branch of the Democratic Party.

The President has removed Mr. PRICE, Postmaster at Chicago, and reappointed Mr. Cook, his immediate predecessor. He has also removed Mr. MILLER, Post Master at Columbus, Ohio, and appointed Ex-Governor MEDARY in his place. Messrs. PRICE and MILLER were appointed during the recess of Congress. I General CALHOUN, to-day, placed in possession of the Seneve's Committee on Territories his statement relative to the late election. He is preparing an address to the public.

JOKES OF THE BAR.---We find the following in the New-York correspondence of the Boston Journal: "Judge EDMOND is both a wit and a poet. The Courts in New-York are interminably tedious. Judge DAVIES, who has more of Young America in him than any Judge on the Bench, does all he can to make the tardy advocates of Justice hurry up their march.

The Board of Governors of the Tuesday, the President, WASHINGTON the Chair. It will be seen from the weekly re? are now 30 patients in the small-pox Hospital, being an increase of 14 over last week's return.

STATEN ISLAND---ITS AMUSEMENTS.--Another charitable concert similar in its success to the one recently reported on the Clifton side, took place at Belmont Hall, New-Brighten, on Monday evening. It was chiefly under the auspices of two lady amateurs, Mrs. K. and Miss V., both of whom appeared in several pieces in the course of the evening to fine advantage at the piano.

THE KIND OF WORK WHICH AN "ORGAN" IS EXPECTED TO DO.--We ask the Special attention of our readers to an article which we copy this morning from the Washington Union, concerning Speaker ORR'S appointment of the Kansas Special Committee.

MY DEAR COLONEL: I wrote you some months since on a point very interesting to the water line, which you know I regard as not only practicable, but as a sine qua non to the complete success of Virginia in her noble enterprise to develop her own rich resources, and in the competition for the rich volume of trade produced in the valley of the Mississippi and its tributaries.

The flight of General COMONFORT is deeply to be deplored. He was the only man of political eminence in Mexio who had at heart the liberty of his country. He was earnest and honest in his desire to promote wholesome reforms. But there was a still more important work to be done than that of inaugurating reforms.

A correspondent of the New-York Evening Post corrects, in that journal, a statement bor. rowed from the NEW-YORK TIMES in regard to Mr. EVERETT'S recent election to be a foreign correspondent of the French Academy of Moral and Political Sciences, by adding the name of Prof.

Mr. SEWARD has given notice of his intention to introduce a bill in the Senate, to reorganize the United States Supreme Court and the Circuit Courts, in such manner that the several States be represented by Judges more nearly on tile basis of their federal population, and also that the administration of justice shall be made more speedy and efficient.

TOLLS ON RAILROADS.--In the perspicuous report of lion. N. S. BENTON, Canal Auditor, which appeared in yesterday's TIMES, he takes decided ground in favor of reimposing canal tolls upon the competing Railroads, which measure he urges as one of justice to the State, whose revenue has been seriously impaired by the removal of tolls from the Railroads in 1851.

At 11 o'clock last night a fire broke out in No. 44 Union-street, which was nearly destroyed, together with Nos. 40 and 46, and also a small building in tile rear, fronting on Friend-street. A fire earlier in the evening destroyed No. 137 Hanover-street, corner of Union.

A schooner was discovered this morning sunk about half a mile from the beach off Long Branch. One dead body was discovered in the rigging, and was taken off by Captain JOSEPHs H. WEST with a wrecking boat.

The full details of the English operations before Canton, furnished by the correspondent of the London Times, in a letter which we this morning publish, confirm in every particular the views which we yesterday took of the actual position and probable progress of affairs in the East, and throw into the strongest relief the impracticable,

It seems probable that public curiosity, which has for a long time past been impatiently expecting the recommencement of hostilities against Canton, is soon to be gratified. The next mail will doubtless carry the news of the attack, and probably of the capture of that great city.

DOUGLAS IN THE SENATE--Mr. DOUGLAS is receiving a sample of "plantation manners" at the hands of the Southern Senators, Whenever he rises to call for his Kansas resolutions. half-a-dozen members on the Democratic side of the Chamber start up from their seats to put him down.

From the Harrisburg Telegraph of Friday Evening. We regret to announce one of the most painful accidents that has ever occurred in Dauphin County. It appears that the large furnace, called " Union Deposit Furnace," situated in South Hanover township some two miles from Hummellstown, was in full blast and working satisfactorily until within a few days past, when something interfered with its operations.

NEW-JERSEY'S ULTIMATUM.--There is a resolution before the Legislature at Albany for the appointment of a new set of Commissioners, consisting of three prominent citizens of the State, to proceed to New-Jersey, and endeavor to complete a negotiation with the authorities for the permission to locate our Quarantine at Sandy Hook.

THE LAW'S DELAY.--A Select Committee of the Assembly, of which Hon. JAMES S. SLUYTER is Chairman, made a report yesterday on the delays and other abuses in our Courts of Justice. This report, published in the TIMES of to-day, contains some sensible suggestions, which we commend to the attention of the Bench and the Bar.

The Board met last evening, the President, WK. H. NELSON, in the Chair. The Clerk proceeded to read the minutes, when Mr. SINLAIR interrupted him. The President of the Board of Aldermen, and acting Mayor in the absence of the Mayor, Mr. CLANOY, was present, and Mr. SINCLAIR moved that he be invited to take a seat beside the President.

THE READING FUGITIVE.--Mr. HUGGINS, of Lovejoy's Hotel, assures us that the story we published on the authority of the New-York Police, concerning the arrest on Tuesday morning of an alleged fugitive from Reading, was all wrong. The fugitive was at Lovejoy's, though not known, and the Clerk offered to render to the New-York Officer all possible aid in arresting him, when identified.

The sensation created by the late attempt upon the life of the Emperor, is far from subsiding. New developments serve to show that the conspiracy was not an, isolated one, or at least that the few individuals concerned in the attempt of the Rue Lepelletier, were not animated simply by personal passion in endeavoring to destroy the life of the Emperor. The Anti-Lecompton meeting, postponed from last Friday evening, through a misunderstanding with certain of the shareholders of the Academy of Music, took place last evening at the Chinese Assembly Rooms. The meeting was called for 7 1/2 o'clock, by which the time the hall was filled.

VESSELS IN PORT.-There were in this port and Brooklyn on Tuesday, 20 steamers, 118 ships, 64 barks, 67 brigs, and 277 schooners; total, 546. Of these there are up for foreign ports 103; for distant ports in the United States, 61, total, 164; leaving 382 vessels of all kinds lying at our docks without any particular employment or destination.

PETITIONS. By Mr. SLOAN, against abolishing the City Court of Brooklyn. Also, to release the Central Park Commissioners from the payment of interest on the Arsenal purchase money. By Mr. SLOAN, to shorten the term of office of certain Brooklyn City officials.

To the Editor of The N. Y. Tribune. SIR: I think it a public duty to call attention to the deception and incompetency of the reporter who pretends to give abstracts of two of my recent lectures in your columns. In the Tribune of Tuesday, Feb. 9, appeared the following paragraph:

About 7 o'clock last night (Wednesday) a fire was discovered in the six-story building No. 56 Maiden-lane and No. 25 Liberty-street. The building extended through from street to street, and was about 40 feet front. The firemen were soon on the ground, but notwithstanding their exertions the fire spread with great rapidity, and in a very short time the entire edifice was in flames.

Congress was not prolite of interest to-day. In the'Senate, after further discussion, it was decided to give the Indiana Senators ninety days in which to take the inmaterial testimony which they ask to have. In ether words, they hive been voted into their seats until after the Kansas question shall be disposed of,-for their votes can not be spared with safety when that. crisis arrives.

The Kansas Committee of Investigation met again to-night. Every proposition for the reception of testimony outside the official record was voted down--thus perpetuating the concealment and consequences of every fraud perpetrated under the forms of law, no matter how base.

In the House, to-day, there was an extra amount of work marked out, but not much accomplished. The most important matter presented was the report of the Select Committee appointed by the last House to inquire into the causes of the delay which arises in our Courts, and to devise a remedy for the evil.

It is generally understood that President BUCHANAN chafes exceedingly under the delays and embarrassments of the Kansas imbroglio. The Kansas carriage stops his way ! He came into office eager and determined to render his Administration illustrious by the acquisition of Cuba, and by other practical applications of the principles of the Ostend manifesto.

The Board of Councilmen met on Wednesday in the Chamber of the Aldermen. City It all, the Presl dent, C. II. HASWELL, Esq., in the Chair. Petitions were presented for remission of personal taxes, and also by parties soliciting to be appointed Commissioners of Deeds. Also, by Mrs. Maria Camman for remuneration for a fence destroyed on election day.

BULL.--In this City, on Tuesday, Feb. 16, RACEEL, daughter of the late John Bull, aged 69 years. The relatives and friends of the family are invited to attend her funeral, from her late residence. No. 101 Varick st., on Friday, Feb. 19, at 3 1/2 o'clock P. M., without further notice. REILLY.--In this City, on Wednesday, Feb. 17, RICHARD REILLY. late of Gallanboy, near Kingscourt, County Cavan, Ireland, in the 34th year of his age.

On the 13th there was reported to our State Senate a bill which, under pretence of consolidating the Probate Courts and the Insolvent Courts, provides for the execution of Judge LORING. LORING is Judge of the Probate Court of Suffolk County, the most important tribunal of the kind in New-England, and the best paid.

Hon. JOHN A. McCLKRNAND publishes in the Springfield (Ill) State Register an elaborate argument against the Lecompton iniquity. Four years ago, he took ground against PIERCE'S Administration for the repeal of the Missouri Compromise.

POLITICAL FRACTURES.--We require a new cement wherewith to mend broken parties and overcome imperfect adhesions. Party organizations are liable to crack as much as crockery. Sometimes a collision causes a new fracture, but oftener an old one believed to be closed up, covered over, and varnished so as to deceive the most critical eye, will spread and yawn in a very dangerous manner.

GOODWIN.--In this City, on Thursday morning. Feb. 18, MARIA. youngest daughter of Henry C. and Maria Goodwin in the 5th year of her age. The friends of the family, and members of Benevolent Lodge No. 28. F. A. M., are invited to attend the funeral, from the residence of her parents. No. 65 3d-av., near 12th-st.. on Sunday afternoon, at 2 o'clock.

We have received correspondence and exchanges from the City of Mexico to the 2d inst. The previous mail, our readers will remember, brought down our news from the capital to the 19th ult., on which day, after an armistice of forty-eight hours, the fighting between the puros headed by Gen. COMMONFORT, and the conservadores, was renewed.

THE BAKER DIVORCE SUIT IN AURURK.---The suit of BAKER vs. BAKER excited considerable attention in the Court yesterday. and drew a large crowd of idle men to listen to the stories of a woman's dishonor. and have their prurient curiosity gratified with testimony of weakness and frailty. Happily, for want of such testimony, the greedy audience were not cutirely gratified.

The Collins steamship Baltic, Capt. COMSTOCK, from Liverpool, at about I P.M. on the 3d instant!, arrived, at Quarantine last night, bringing 30 passengers. The Cunard steamship Africa arrived out at Liverpool at 111/2 P. M. on Saturday, the 30th of January.

Mr. GREEN, from the Committee on Territories, reported a bill for the admission of Kansas, submitting therewith a long report, which was not read. Messrs. DOUGLAS and COLLAMER severally presented minority reports. The reports were all ordered to be printed. Mr. GREEN gave notice that he should call up the matter at an early day.

Though now in a certain degree retired from public notice, we are certain that the KOSSUTHS in this country still hold a warm interest in the hearts to thousands among us. We are glad, therefore, to know that after many severe trials incident to their forced exile and sudden change of circumstances, land and language, they are now in a great degree sheltered from the cruel storms that have swept over them.

The Aldermanic Committee on Frauds, of which Alderman ADAMS is chairman, met again yesterday, and continued the investigation of the charges of frauds in the Street Department, reported by Mr. D. D. CONOVER Mr. JAMES W. BEEKMAN called the attention of the Committee to the act of March 4, 1846.
Mr. CRAWFORD'S equestrian statue of WASHINGTON has just received a meed of praise, which is praise-indeed, from a critic who ought to be the best judge of heroes on horseback that ever existed.

ARMS FOR THE POLIC.--A few weeks ago the Superintendent of Police sent a letter to the Commissioners recommending that a certain number of patrolmen should be provided with revolvers, and yesterday there was an occurrence that proved the necessity of the measure.

Rev. Dr. HAWKS repeated in Niblo's Theatre, last evening, by request, his lecture recently delivered in the lecture-room of the Historical Society, entitled "Old America's Message to Young America." It was listened to by a large audience, who manifested their satisfaction by continued applause.

THE FIRE IN MAIDEN-LANE-LIST OF INSURANCE.--The origin of the extensive fire in Maldenlane and Liberty-street, on Monday night, has not yet been discovered. Incendiarism is suspected by some, though no proof has thus far been obtained, giving strength or tangibility to the suspicion.

THE DEFENDER OF LUCKNOW--Colonel INGLIS, the defender of Lucknow, India, is a grandson of Rev. Dr. CHALES INGLIS, who was rector of Trinity Church, New-York, from 1777 to 1783. He was a violent Tory during the whole revolutionary contest; and upon the conclusion of peace in 1783.

REMOVAL OF QUARANTINE.-The Jersey City Common Council have passed a series of resolutions, favoring the removal of Quarantine from its present location to sandy Hook, and have appointed a Committee to visit Trenton, and urge upon the Legislature the granting of the site asked for by the New Commissioners.

The winning horse at the Metarie course, New-Orleans, this season, is Alarm, once celebrated under the title of O'Blennis. The Picayune says: "Some five or six years ago, when he was young and sound, he trotted with great success, beating such nags as Lady Suffolk, Lady Jane, and many other first-class animals. In this race the "Old Horse" appeared to be "himself again," and trotted with apparently all the fire and vigor of by-gone days.

ARREST OF MODEL, ARTISTS,--Some of the Mayor's Police, headed by Sergeant BARNEY, made a descent last evening on a private model artist establishment at No. 463 Broome-street. The officers kept their" shields" out of sight until a portion of the evening's performances were over.

The Board of Aldermen met yesterday afternoon, President CLAROY in the Chair. A petition was received from the inhabitants of Staten Island asking for a ferry clip at the Battery. The communication was referred to the Committee on Lands and Places.

REMOVAL OF THE CAPITAL.-This subject turns up every session, usually upon a motion of some member from the rural districts, in favor of Utica or Syracuse. But now it appears in another shape. Mr. HANFORD has given notice in the Assembly, of a bill for removal to this City.

One of the Paris correspondents of Le Nord, of the 28th of January, endeavors to appreciate the political import of the family alliance just concluded between the royal families of Prussia and England, with a view of showing that the sombre reflections of some of the continental journals on the subject are without foundation.

It needs no ghost to rise from the grave to tell the world that Mexican liberty is dead, and that Republican institutions have become an empty sham in a land given over to the unscrupulous ambition of reckless theorists by the weakness of the enlightened few, and the obstinacy of the ignorant many.

A SPIRIT UP IN WETCHESTER.-We learn from The Spiritual Telegraph that the spirit of J. P. DONNELLY, who was recently hung for the Seaview House murder, was last heard from in Tarrytown, where it took possession of a "medium" in "a circle of eighteen intelligent persons" at "the house of Mr. ALFRED LISTER."

This extraordinary case was resumed yesterday Thursday pursuant to adjournment, before Mr. JOHN H. W WHITING, the Referee. In consequence of the understanding that the cross examination of Madame LOLA MONTEZ would be resumed on the part of the plaintiff, the Referee's apartments were inconveniently crowded.

COOK's nomination as Postmaster at Chicago will be resisted, on the ground that he is already a defaulter to the Government. Kansas will not be considered in the Senate before the middle of next week.

The Collins steamship Baltic, from Liverpool on the 3d inst., with four days' later news from Europe, arrived at Quarantine last night, and will come up to her dock this morning. Her advices are interesting, though not specially important. There is nothing from India or China additional to what was brought by the Niagara. Continued eae is reported in the London Money Market.

JOHN BROUWER, Esq., formerly President of the East River Insurance Company, but lately doing business as a Real Estate broker at No. 72 Wall-street, committed suicide by hanging himself Wednesday night in his own office.

HAS ITS HANDS FULL.--The Washington Union is kept exceedingly busy now-a-days. It has to defend the Administration at so many points, and under such extreme disadvantages, that its abilities are taxed to the utmost. In its Wednesday's issue its leading editorial is devoted to demonstrating that "to increase the present army is to diminish its cost."

HAYWARD.--In this City, on Friday, Feb. 19, ELIZABETH LYDIA, youngest child of John and Almyra Hayward, aged 7 months. The relatives and friends of the family are requested to attend the funeral. on Sunday, Feb. 21, at 2 o'clock P. M., frem the residence of her parents, No. 268 Grand-st., without further notice.

HEAD HIM OR DIE.-This admonition is intended for the Richmond South, and refers to EDWARD EVERETT. That obnoxious individual has recently received invitations to deliver his WASHINGTON lecture in several places in the Southern States. It strikes us as possible that he may have the audacity to comply.

The Senate was engaged on the private Calendar for some time. The Army bill was taken up. Mr. IVERSON said that Mr. DAVIS wished to reply to some remarks of others, before the vote was taken. He moved a postponement, which was agreed to, and the Senate adjourned till Tuesday.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The practical question which underlies the recent movements for Sunday observance, is virtually this: Shall we have Rest or no Rest? A holy day or a holiday ? An American Sabbath or a European Sunday ? The alternative has been thrust upon the friends of good morals by the persistent and shameless violation of the laws of the State, and of the rights of its citizens.

PITY THE SORROWS, BENNETT is in a pickle. Troubles multiply on his hands. He is sorely exercised about the grades of the City avenues. He fears the Municipal Government is about to " desecrate" that ninety-thousanddollar real estate speculation of his by compelling him to grade part of it for streets to meet the wants of this rapidly growing metropolis.

Last evening Rev. Dr, BELLOWS delivered, at Clinton Hall, the last of his Lowell Lectures on "Pauperism and Crime." The house was quite two-thirds full. The subject of the evening was the "Causes of Crime." The lecturer commenced by enumerating the six causes that ar given by FRRDERICK HILL, but the thought them all reducible to the four followiing: Bad training, bad appetites, want and bad legislation.

The United States steam frigate Wabash, the flag-ship of the Home Squadron, and bearing the broad pennant of Commodore PAULDING, has been in commission about 18 months. Her last cruise occupied seven months, and was an eventful one. She sailed from New-York on the 29th of July, under orders for Aspinwall, with reference to the unsettled state of Central American affairs;

Mr. Silsbee, the new Mayor of Salem, Mass., has put forth his views touching the Temperance question, greatly to the astonishment of the people, He opposes prohibitory laws, and adds: " I have not only studied this subject at home, but in various nations abroad; and have invariably found those the most temperate where the vine grew best, and where all had the freest enjoyment of its blessings.

The weather, which had been growing cooler and cooler since the cool "snap" set in at the beginning of the present week,-and which actually was cold enough for two or three nights to freeze the Cro ton-pipes and coat the windows with a fanciful cov ering of froat,-resolved yesterday to give us the first snow-storm of the season.

Tile United States Mail steamer Star of the West, Captain GREY, leaves for Aspinwall this day at o'clock, from the foot of Warren-street, with the California and passengers. The fare by this steamer, and by the regular steamer of the 5th of March, is for first cabin, $300; second cabin, $200; steerage, $130, which have been the established rates.

The removal of the Anti-Lecompton Postmasters at Chicago, 111., and Columbus, Ohio, affords sad evidence of Mr. BUCHANAN'S recklessness, and establishes the fact that in his eyes no offence of a public officer is so grave as his refusal to indorse a fraud, and no test of fitness for public place complete unless accompanied by subserviency.

During a thirteen years' experience Ihave never witnessed the discussion of any subject in Congress, in which the feelings of gentlemen were so deeply and earnestly enlisted as they are now in the question of the admission of Kansas with the Lecompton Constitution. The present is no contest " for Buncombe." The Anti-Lecompton men, at all events.

The Hon. Mr. ZOLLICOFFER, is a member of Congress from Tennessee,--aman of clear and vigorous intellect, of good character, and of marked influence, both at home and in the body of which he is a member. Hie attached himself to the American party during the brief existence of that organization, and felt accordingly somewhat aggrieved by the assault made upon it by Mr. HATCH, of Bufalo, on Thursday last.

THE ARRESTED MODEL ARTISTS.-The troupe of model artists arrested on Thursday night at No. 463 Broome-street, were yesterday forenoon taken before the Mayor. After a reprimand from the Mayor, and a promise to follow some more reputable business in future, the girls were let off with giving bonds in $500 each to keep the peace. Before Hon. Justice Sutherland. DECISIONS. Alex. Duncan et al. vs. J. C. McGregor.--Motion granted, with $10 costs. C.E. Larned vs Robert M. Masterton et al.--Motion denied, with $10 costs. W.W. Bishop vs. Lonis J. Doyle et al.--Motion denied, with $10 costs.

WHEN IGNORANCE IS BLISS.--Gen. CALHOUN says that he had no reason to suspect anything Wrong in the return of votes from Delaware Crossing, but he promises, if the Judges will make oath that only forty-three votes were polled, to amend the count accordingly.

No public business whatever was done by Congress yesterday. After consideration of the pri. vate calendar in the Senate, the Army bill was taken up, but nothing was done with it. The House was engaged all day in the discussion ot question of privilege. Both branches adjourned until Monday.

WRECK OF THE SCHOONER R. DRUMMOND--ALL HANDS LOST.--The messenger sent by Messrs. BIRD NEILSON to ascertain about the unknown schooner lost off Long Branch, returned yesterday, and confirms the previous opinion that she is the B. Drummond, one of HERBERT BENNET'S wrecking vessels, which has been engaged in securing the cargo of the wrecked bark Clara Brookman, at Squan.

A TEST.-The Washington Union declares that support of the Lecompton policy is at the present time the " test " of Democracy. And, acting upon this dogma, which he, doubtless, authorized the Union to promulgate, President BUCHANAN has commenced the removal of postmasters who reject the test.

The Senate had a session last evening for the purpose of considering the General Orders. Senator STOW'S bill to prohibit the giving of free tickets to State Officers, Members of the Legislature, , was the nucleus for much legislative buncombe. An amendment, offered by Mr. NoxoN, that all railroads be required to carry all the members of the Legislalure, , free, during the session of the Legislature, was much more sensible.

The French Army, in several of its recent addresses to the Emperor, congratulating him on his escape from assassination, has signified an intense desire to be led in pursuit of the conspirators into "their haunts," meaning thereby, Camberwell, Islington and other quarters of London, in which distinguished foreigners of damaged reputation and limited means are wont to seclude themselves and their patriotic plans.

The great case of Jobson against Griffins came to an abrupt and untimely end on Thursday night. Yesterday's TIMES contained a full report of the closing scenes of this great engagement. By one of those accidents which will sometimes happen, even in the best regulated law-suits, both the character of the proceeding, and the parties to it, underwent a serious change before the affair was over.

Yesterday, at the Toombs, before Judge WELSH, Mr. DAVID WEMYSS JOBSON appeared to answer the complaint of Mr. FREDERICK D. SEELY for assault and battery, perpetrated on Thursday at the office of Mr. JOHN N. WHITING. the referee appointed to take the testimony in the case of HARVEY, assignee of GRAHAM, vs. D. W. JOBSON.

RECEIPTS OF PRODUCE--Since noon of yesterday: 41 bbls. Ashes. 2,937 bbls. Flour; 20,869 bushels Corn; 100 bags Malt; 569 pkgs. Provisions, and 50 bbls. Whisky. ASHES--Continue quiet at previous prices. Pots, $6 25; Pearls, $6 50, ?? 100 lbs.

A ROGUE CATCHING A ROGUE.--Poor BENNETT makes some exposures of himself now and then which would be amusing if they were not indecent. He says that the Abbe McMASTERS, of the Freeman's Journal, abuses Mr. BUCHANAN because he did not give him a foreign mission.

I am constrained to withhold my assent from the conclusion to which the majority of the Committee have arrived, for the reason that there is no satisfactory evidence that the Constitution formed at Lecompton is the act and deed of the people of Kansas, or that it embodies their will.

In addition to the European news published in yesterday's impression, we derive some farther intelligence from our files by the Baltic. Our advices from Liverpool and London are to the 3d of February, inclusive. There was an on dit in Liverpool that the Russian Government had purchased the Adriatic, of the Collins line of mail steamers. Tile purchase money is variously stated to be from [Pound]150,000 to [Pound]200,000.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I observed, a few days since, in your paper an editorial article from the Richmond South, the subject-matter of which was the recent remarks of Mr. SEWARD on the Army Bill. The Richmond paper says the views of Mr. SEWARD are far-reaching and statesman-like.

One of the fruits of the new marriage law in England promises to be an appeal to the Courts on behalf of the authoress of Cheveley or The Man of Honor, against her husband, the author of the Last of the Barons, for conduct rather too baronial, according to her statement, for the usages of the latter half of the nineteenth century.

Last evening, about 7 o'clock, the Methodist Protestaut Church, on Sixth-street, near Race, was partly destroyed by the explosion of defective gaspipes. At the hour mentioned some fifteen persons were assembled In the basement for meetings, when a strong odor was perceived, and an effort made to discover the leakage.

The published statement that General HARNEY is going to the Pacific to take command of an expedition against the Mormons is erroneous. The War Department has no plans at present for the conduct of a campaign from the Pacific side; and if it had, it is not likely that HARNEY would be sent out to supersede his superior officer, Gen. CLARKE.

AID FOR THE POOR.--Mr. W. H. SMITH, of No. 386 Broome-street, New-York Conference Missionary, acknowledges the receipt of the following donations for the aid of the mission for the relief of the poor, which was commenced in this City a few months since; From a friend, $20; from Box 2,742 General Post Office, $3; from a friend to the poor. Providence, R L. $5, from a former contributor, $10; and from WINTHROP S. GILMAN. $10.

Believing that there must be some truth in the typical idea which every nation gives of itself in the symbolical figures by which it, represen a its nationality, we must confess that the emblematic Yankee is not calculated to engender feelings of pride and vain glory in our bosoms.

A stampede occurred at the Sing Sing Prison, on Thursday evening, as the men were passing into the Prison, to be locked up for the night. The break was fortunately confined to one gang, but for a moment it seemed probable that the entire body were to unite in the attempt to escape. As usual the men of the saw shop halted while those who have precedence were passing into the prison.

FIRE IN A PUBLIC SCHOOL BUILDING IN HARLEM--SAFETY OF THE CHILDREN--PRAISEWORTHY COOLNESS OF THE TEACHERS,__About 10 o'clock Friday morning, Mr. WARNER, Principal of the Twelfth Ward School No.39, in Harlem, discovered smoke issuing from one of the flues connected with the main register. Without alarming the scholars, he immediately notified the teachers in the various departments, and instructed them to dismiss their respective pupils, giving as the reason that it was WASHINGTON'S birthday.

TOADS IN HOLES--The toad "ugly and enumous" has long enjoyed a much greater consideration in the world than either his personal beauty or his public services would have otherwise commanned for him, in virtue of two popular notions about his physical constitution. The belief that he bears a precious jewel in his head has been long exploded,

A LECOMPTON MEETING.---We understand that a paper is in circulation for signatures calling a meeting of the Administration Demacrats who are in favor of the Lecompton movement. The meeting will probably be held during the present week. We venture to suggest that Gen. CALHOUN be invited to make a speech.

The Police records of this City are, after all, the strongest argument that any KnowNothing can advance for the faith that is in him. We are almost tempted to say that they are an unanswerable argument. No candid and intelligent man will deny that they point out a necessity for sweeping reforms;

HOW THEY PUNISH DEUNKENNESS IN FRANCE. --We find the following paragraph in one of our French exchanges:-- "The mayor of Douai has just published an order that persons who get shamefully drunk in public houses, and the proprietors of gach establishments who allow them to become so, shall be fined and imprisoned, It appears that of late years drunkenness has become remarkably prevalent in the north of France."

SHYSTERING POLICEMEN.--Officer Henry Voos, of the Tenth Precinet, was arrested on Saturday, charged with exporting four dollars from a poor woman under pretense that he would secure the release of her husband from the Essex Market Prison, where he was locked up on suspicion of burglary. The name of the prisoner was James P. Davis.

This morning ex-Lieutenant A. C. RHIND posted Commander BOUTWELL as a liar and a coward, near the Navy Department. It is understood that the difficulty between them originated several years ago on the Pacific, but was recently renewed before the Naval Court of Inquiry. WM. CALDWELL has been reappointed Postmaster of Cambridge, Mass.

When Mr. BROWN, of Mississippi, congratulated the country upon the nomination of Mr. BuCHANAN by the Cincinnati Convention, he gave it as a reason for the joy that was in him, that the Sage of Wheatland had uttered to himself, in person, these memorable words:

The Ship Diamond State, formerly called the James Ray, took fire during the night and is still burning. It is supposed to be a total loss. The ship lies aground near the West Jersey ferry landing, Camden. She was built in Wilmington, Del., is valued at $16,000, owned by STETSON Co., and is fully insured. PHILADELPHIA, Sunday, Feb. 20-41/2 P. M. The Diamond State has become a total loss.

KEEN SCENTED--The Richmond South must be gifted with most extraordinary olfactories to enable it to smell the taint of abolitionism in the garments of Mr. BUCHANAN'S friend CALHOUN, from Kansas. "We observe," says the South, of Saturday, "from a 'Cara' in the Washington Union of Yesterday, that JOHN CALHOUN is resolved to throw the State of Kansas into the hands of the Abolitionists.

The Pacific Hotel, in this place, was burned at 3 o'clock this morning. Eight or ten persons were killed, and many others seriously injured, by jumping from the windows. It is at present impossible to ascertain the names of the killed and wounded. EIGHT O'CLOCK, P.M. The burning of the Pacific Hotel proves a much more terrible calamity than was reported this morning.

THE CANAL-STREET HOMICIDE--VERDICT OF THE JURY---Coroner CONNERY concluded on Saturday the investigation in the case of JAMES P. DUYCKINCK. who was shot last Monday evening by J. FREDERICK BADENKOPP. at the lager-bier and billiard saloon No. 108 Canal-street. Many witnesses were sworn, but nothing important was elicited additional to the evidence heretofore published.

RIGHTS OF SEPULTERE.--Senator WADSWORTH has introduced a bill in the Legislature of this State designed to protect graves from such violation as is often witnessed1 when a change of ownership of burial grounds takes place by sale or by operation of law. Not only are the feelings of surviving relatives, but the public sense,

Mr. Elijah Fletcher, a native of Vermont, but a journalist in Virginia for the past 20 years, died last week near Amherst C. H., Va. He was formerly editor of the Lynchburg Virginian. Mrs. Winnie Lannister died at Jacksonville, Fla., on the 28th ult., aged 130 years. She was a native of North Carolina, and was married in the colony many years before the Revolution.

BRUTAL MURDER AT BUSKIRK'S BRIDGE.-Onthe the 16th inst., between the villages of Eagle Bridge and Buskirk's Bridge N. ., two men named WALLIS, aged 20 years, and McENTEE, aged 50, (Irishmen,) were passing the evening together arousing in a saloon. The elder of the two was known to have $20 in bank bills, and was prevailed upon by WALLIS to accompany him to his home and pass the night with him.

MR. SEWARD'S SUPREME COURT MOVEMENT. --The New-York Tribune professes itself "indifferent "to Mr. SEWARD'S "plan of reconstructing the Judicial Districts of the United States with a view of taking a larger proportion of the Judges of the Supreme Court from the Free States ;"

The accusation has been openly made, by sundry learned and unlearned persons, and as yet.

The Cunard steamship Africa, from Liverpool on the 6th inst., arrived at this port at an early hour yesterday morning The news, which is three days later, is not of any special importance. The repressive measures of NAPOLEON, and the refugee question, continued to occupy public attention.

COMERON--In the City, on Sunday morning. Feb. 21, suddenly, Miss ELIZA CAMERON. In the 64th year of her age. MARGARET ANN FREEMAN, wite of Erastus freeman, aged 51 years, 6 months and 22 days.

The Democrats have a majority of one in the Onondaga Board of Supervisors this year. Jefferson County has elected 17 Republican to 4 Democratic and I American, in the Board of Supervisors. Cortland County gives a Republican majority for supervisors. In Daleware County there is a tie: 8 Republicans and 8 Democrats in the Board.

The news of President BUOHANAN'S Message reached us last night, and, as might have been expected, the most violent expressions of indignation seemed to fall from every tongue. He has repeated the oft-told scandal and insult against our people, and tells us we are as much under the dominion of Slavery as is Georgia or South Carolina. It is much easier brandishing such a statement than proving it.

The U. S. Mail Steamer Black Warrior, J. W SMITH, Commander, from New-Orleans 12th inst., and Havana 15th, arrived on Saturday evening, having encountered strong head winds and seas the entire run from Havana. Two cargoes of negroes have been landed since last advices. The American ships Kate Hooper and Challenge had arrived with cargoes of coolies.

The Royal Mail steamship Africa, which sailed from Liverpool at about 1 o'clock on the afternoon of Saturday, the 6th of February, arrived at her dock in Jersey City at an early hour yesterday morning. The Africa, on the 12th inst., lat. 470 40' N., long. 360 W., exchanged signals with the Hamburg ship Andorinha Secunda, bound east;

The Independence correspondent of the Republican, under date of the 16th inst., says that the Salt Lake mail arrived there last night. Conductor DENVER reports the snow from one to six feet deep on the mountains, and the weather intensely cold. He left Camp Scott Jan. 1, and the troops there were in good spirits, earnestly wishing to make a descent on Salt Lake City.

The Territorial Legislature practically closed its session at 12 o'clock last night, and Gov. DENVER closed all communication with them at that hour, as he claims that the forty days to which they are limited by the organic act, expired at that time. This is probably correct, as they came together on the 4th of January, and forty days from said day was out on the 12th of February.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In your issue of to-day I find an account of an interview held by a "medium" with the spirit of J. P. DONNRLLY, recently hung for the Seaview House murder. I beg to inform your readers that this "medium" and "circle of eighteen intelligent persons," do not reside in Tarrytown, but in the adjoining village of Beekmantown, near Sleepy Hollow.

Drummond, which was sunk off the Tavern-Houses, and the stranding of the Charles Colgate, (since got off and arrived at this City,) we do not learn of any disasters on the coast, near this port. From the Tribune. Various versions are given of the collision between Hon. JAMES B. CLAY and Gen. CULLOM yesterday, but following out the facts with a view to impartiality, I find this to be the more probable story: CULLOM entered the bar-room of Brown's Hotel, where CLAY, HAWKINS and MASON were standing. He proposed an old fashioned Kentucky drink,

THE DUELS AND ROWS AT WASHINGTON.Our national capital seems to be given over for the moment to violence and blackguardism. Two or three duels are talked about,-prodigious efforts are made to stop one of them,charges are filed in the War Department against one army officer for sending a challenge to another,

SETTLEMENT OF THE HISPANO-MEXICAN DISPUTE.--Our Havana correspondent, in a letter which we published yesterday, stated that the long-pending difficulty between Spain and Mexico had been peaceably adjusted. Our readers will remember that the immediate cause of the quarrel was the assassination and indiscriminate plunder of Spanish subjects in Mexico by the soldiers of General ALVAREZ.

THE NEW-YORK FERRY INVESTIGATION. The House Committee on Commerce and Navigation propose to confine their investigation in regard to ferries between New-York and Brooklyn to the current business of each separate ferry for each of the last seven years.

A DESPERATE OFFENDER.--An examination was had yesterday, before Justice KELLY, at the Jefferson Market Police Court, in the case of George Abrahams alias Cobb Gunnion, charged with picking the pocket of Samuel Parker of a gold watch and chain while standing at the corner of Broadway and Bond-street. Mr. Parker identified the accused as the person who robbed him of his watch and chain,

The most expeditious of all dramatists, and best - Mr. DION BOURCICAULT - produced another play last night at this popular house. Notwithslanding the sleighing attractions outside, an audience over whelming in numbers was drawn together by annouascement.

Robert Trought committed suicide at Alexandria, Va., last week, and left a letter, addressed to his landlady, containing these directions and explanations: "Make me a common box, and put me ina cart and deposit my remains in the northern burying-ground; but let not any of my friends know any thing about me. I have loaned money here; I have divided with those who were in need;

Time, which solves most entanglements, seems to complicate the Kansas question.
