LECTURE ON INDIA.--Mr. LEONARD WBAY delivered last evening in Clinton Hall, before a very respectable audience, the first of his course of lectures on "India." He was accompanied to the rostrum by the Chairman of the Lecture Committee of the Mercantile Library Association, under whose auspices the series will be given. He described the physical and political geography of the Indian Peninsula,

The Committee of the Chamber of Commerce, to whom was referred the petition of the importers of the City of New-York and its vicinity, to the Honorable Secratery of the Treasury, praylag for relief from the delay and expense they now saffer in the dispatch of goods at the Custom House, have examiled the subject, as carefully as the limited time allowed them has permitted.

THE CANADIAN CAPITAL.-We perceive by our Canadian exchanges that general dissatisfaction prevails in respect to the selection of Ottawa City as the future seat of Government. The sum of [Pound]225,000 is said to be in the hands of the Executive, applicable to the construction of public buildings at Ottawa. But as much more will be needed for their completion ;

The experiment of self-government has proved a failure in the adjacent Republic of Mexico. Since her revolt from Spain, she has passed through revolutions without number, and has no end of different rulers But her progress has been constantly backward. Government, by whomsoever administered, has failed to fulfil its functions.

RAPE.--A man named THOMAS McGUIRE was arrested in Jersey City yesterday, charged with committing a rape upon the person of ELLEN PARKER. It is but lately that the accused came out of jail, where he had beer, for some time confined for misconduct, and Recorder BEDFORD send him back again to a wait the action of the next Grand Jury.

lion. CLARKSON F. CROSBY died in this City yesterday morning, after an illness of some months' duration. It has already been stated that he had but recently returned from the South, whither he had journeyed for the benefit of his health, and that on reaching this City he found himself too feeble to proceed to his home in West Troy.

We have received copies Nos. 1 and 2 of the American Commercial and Chemical Journal, published every Monday by J. M. DEMELLS Co., No. 36 Beckman-street. One man takes pleasure in accumulating a fortune for the sake of bequeathing it to charitable institutions at his death, while another finds pleasure in giving as he goes; one endows a hospital while another founds a library;

MY DEAR SIR: In compliance with your request I shall endeavor to write down for you the views upon Currency I have lately expressed to you in conversation. 1. As regards the medium to be used by any nation or State for the convenience of the every-day business of life, I think I can prove that paper currency, properly secured, is the only safe and convenient medium that can be used.

SATISFACTION.-A curious thing is this same "satisfaction." For example: Yesterday morning Lieutenants BELL and WILLIAMS went to Bladensburg to find it. BELL " fired at the word ' one.'" His bullet penetrated WILLIAMS' hat. WILLIAMS, having given "satisfaction," fired his pistol "into the snow," and the belligerents were "reconciled."

From the Richmond Enquirer. General SCOTT entered the Senate Chamber at about 1 o'clock. Long before his entrance the seats of Senators were nearly filled by ladies, to whom in courtesy they were surrendered. When the veteran soldier entered the door he was hailed with loud applause both from the densely crowded gallery and the floor of the chamber.

An excitement exists in Cleveland in regard to the sudden death of a colored girl named Rebecca Stanton, who resided with a Mrs. Tillman. The girl was engaged to a young colored man of Niagara Falls, named Lee, and was to have been married last Wednesday. It is stated that Mrs. Tillman was bitterly opposed to Rebecca's marrying this man, and strongly advised her never to marry at all.

From the Cincinnati Times SAMUEL PAUL is 58 years of age. SAMUEL PAUL is the keeper of a second-hand furniture store on Western Row, a few doors above Elizabeth-street. He was until about six months ago, a disconsolate widower-then he became a happy bridegroom, and now he is again wifeless. Some eight months ago SAMUEL PAUL became acquainted with a dashing widow, lately arrived from Chicago.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The Herald is devoting considerable space to the Patent law, and to the parties seeking extensions of old Patents, and, in order to affect excessive virtue for itself, is busily engaged in throwing dirt and dust upon others. This is an old dodge of that incorruptible sheet, and is not likely to answer the purpose.

FROM ST. DOMINGO--A correspondent of the Boston Post, writing from St. Domingo City on the 18th ult., says: There is no blockade on any of the ports of the Island. This City is besieged, and there is occasionally firing of Shot and Shells from both Sides. No likelihood of a Settlement between the ?? parties,

If our readers have not already forgotten that a frightful catastrophe by fire occurred on Friday morning last, in a hotel at St. Louis, involving the instant and horrible death or the permanent mutilation and maiming of nearly one-half the guests within the house, it may be worth while to call their attention to the similar and equal risks which are nightly incurred by all who frequent our places of public amusement in New-York.

MR. WOLCOTT AND THE CORRUPTION COMMITTEE.--Mr. WOLCOTT seems to be in a tight spot-both literally and figuratively. The Washington Jail is tolerably and uncomfortably tight,-but his escape from it would not improve his condition very much, if the statement of our Washington correspondent is correct.

THE LECOMPTON PET.-Since Lecompton has been put at nurse in the hands of Speaker ORR'S Southern Committee, dissensions are said to have arisen among the gossips; and consequently the child is not yet presentable. High words are heard to proceed from the nursery. The vexed question seems to be, whether the baby may or may not be dressed again before 1864.

There has been no fight yet between Messrs. CLAY and CULLOM. The most earnest efforts to effect a reconciliation have been making all day, and rumors were current at one time that they had been successful. This is erroneous. It is understood that CULLOM, being assured by his friends that he was wrong in striking CLAY, expressed his willingness to apologize therefore, but could not do so while the challenge was pending.

The steamship Arago, from Havre and Southampton, Feb. 10, arrived early this morning with four days' later news. Among her passengers are JOSIAH PIERCE, Esq., Secretary of Legation at St. Petersburg, and ELISHA RIGGS, Esq., Bearer of Despatches. The Arago brings a large number of passengers for the season, and her passage is the shortest that any steamer has made during the Winter.

A registry has, for the past twenty years, been much desired by a large portion of the people of this State, as a safeguard against the illegal voting which so notoriously prevails in all cities, large villages, and even in the rural districts. Some of the New-England States have long enjoyed the benefits of such a measure, and found no difficulty in its practical operation.

Everybody regrets the unfortunate difficulty between General CULLOM and Mr. CLAY-the more as all efforts to bring about a reconciliation have entirely failed. Of course, there are half a dozen different stories as to the origin of the difficulty, and it is not easy to get a perfectly certain and reliable account of it.

IMPORTANT GOVERNMENT DISPATCHES STOLEN.--In Mobile, Ala., last Friday, some daring thief went on board the steamboat St. Charles, just as she was about leaving the wharf, and made free with the baggage of Admiral ZERMAN, one of the prominent Mexicans who accompanied COMONFORT from Mexico, who had taken passage on board the St. Charles for Montgomery, having with him dispatches of the greatest importance to the United States Government.

NOTICES OF BILLS. Mr. SCHELL, gave notice of a bill to amend the law relative to insecure buildings. Mr. PATTERSON, of a bill relative to better registration of marriages and deaths. Mr. SCHELL introduced a bill classifying New-York supervisors, and making them elective alternate years.

The Cincinnati papers of the 12th contain an account of the horsewhipping of a Mr. MEYERS on the steps of a hotel, by Mrs. E. H. BARRY, M. D., who is described as a lady under 30, of fair complexion blue eyes and a handsome figure. Mrs. Dr. BARRY detailed the subjoined facts, the tragic portion of which is corroborated by witnesses. Mrs, BARRY.

A Mass Convention of the Democrats of Indiana, opposed to the Lecompton Constitution, assembled at Masonic Hall at 10 o clock this morning. Col. N. M. McCARTY was chosen President, and made a brief and pertinent address. He was followed by Judge JOHNSTON, of Kansas; 11. B. PAYNE, of Ohio; Judge WICK, Gen. DRAKE and others.

We published yesterday a letter from a correspondent. on the tediousness of the proceedings in our courts of justice, apropos of the recent report of the Committee, appointed by the last Legislature, recently presented by Mr. SLUYTER. "B." is somewhat indignant at the charge of "procrastination," which the Committee brings against the lawyers of this district, and resolves the whole difficulty into a scarcity of judges.

ARREST OF A CONFIDENCE OPERATOR.--The arrest of a shrewd confidence operator, named J. W. Walsen, alias J. C. Davis, has just been effected by ex-officer Bowyer, formerly a detective under Chief Matsell. Some time age, while Mr. Bowyer was in Philadelphia, he learned that a gentleman, calling himself J. W. Watson, had "done" a Philadelphia merchand, named E. H. Shee,

SHOOTING AFFAIR AT THE PARKER HOUSE, BOSTON.--Yesterday afternoon, about 2 o'clock, the usual quietness which pervades the Parker House, Schoolstreet, was disturbed by tile discharge of a pistol. We learn that a gentleman from New-York, Mr. F. BIRGE, had occasion to go to a privy, and while there, Mr. L. D. MERRILL, of this city, went there,

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Sin: Noticing your leader to-day on this subject, permit a cosmopolitan to remark: " Revolvers" if you please, but, at the same time, to recommend for our night police that truly-efficient accompaniment of the London police, the " bull's-eye" lantern in their belt or hand, dark or light, ad libitum.

The Senate passed the bill to amend the act of March 3, 1851, limiting the liabilities of ship-owners. Mr. BELL presented the resolutions of the Legislaturelof Tennessee respecting his opposition to the Nebraska bill, indorsing the Lecompton Constitution,and intimating that he ought to resign. He referred to the date of tile resolutions, Feb. 10, 1858, four years after his vote which they censored,

That famous locally known as Jackson's Hollow, situated in the Seventh Ward, Brookly, is a strip of low land extending from Flushing-avenue southward to DeKalb-avenue, and bounded by Classon-avenue on the east, and Ryerson-street on the west. This, however, is not the extent of the peculiar settlement which has sprung up there, for the "city of shanties" extends over the whole length of what was the old Jackson farm, across Fulton-avenue.

CONCERT.--There was a very pleasant entertainment at Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER'S Church, last evening,-no less than a concert of sacred and secular music, given by the young folks of the Church's Sabbath schools. The house was as full as it comfortably could be, and the little people who occupied the choir end of the gallery were in full feather and capital voice.

The morning performance of "L'Italiana in Algeri" attracted a moderate audience yesterday, Tonight MOZART'S opera of "Don Giovanni" will he played for the last time, with all the combined and auxiliary forces which made its production so memorable. EISFELD'S SOIREE.--Mr. EILFELD'S thid classical soirce took place last night, and was well attended. The programme was excellent, and opened with OUSLOW'S Quartet, (opus 4, No. 1.) The composer is but too little known in this country:

Mr. GEO. W. KENDALL of the New-Orleans Picayune writes from his sheep ranche in Texas: I have pasturage for 20,000 sheep and any number of horses and cattle, and to see all this space covered, is not what I am working for. I don't bother my mind a moment about Kansas or BRIGHAM YOUNG, or politics of any kind--don't care who is President--fear God and hate the Indians--am indifferent about

Mr. DOUGLAS having abandoned the democratic Party, and thrown himself entirely into the arms of Republicanism and fanaticism, it is becoming a duty for the friends of the time-honored organization of Democracy to treat him as its enemy: and those who have followed his lead will discover before long that they have sold their political faith and honesty for less than a "mess of pottage."

As, in common with many of our cotemporaries, both in Europe and America, we had allowed ourselves to infer, from the avowed policy of MAZZINI, his active complicity with the conspirators of the Rue Lepelletier, we take especial satisfaction in expressing our belief that great injustice has been done to the illustrious but impracticable Triumvir of Rome in that imputation.

COU??NHOVEN,--In this City, on Sunday night, Feb. 21, CHRISTIAN COU??NHOVEN, late Lieutenant of the Veteran Corps of Artillery, in the 80th year of his age. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend his funeral from the house of his son-in-law, Robert Clark, No. 42 East 30th St., on Wednesday, Feb. 24. at 1 1/2 o'clock, P. M. precisely.

General HOUSTON'S resolution, Submitted in he Senate some ten days ago, pointing to a Protectorate for Mexico and centrall America, embraces a subject of the utmost importance, and one which presses upon tile attention of the American people.

?? Wright has arrived from Montevideo, Dec. 25. She reports having left in port the Mary C. Jones, for New-York, loading. The following is from the files of the British Packet and Argentine News: Owing to the disastrous commercial and financial advices from Europe and the United States, trade was prostrated and produce had considerable declined.

To the Editor of the New-York Times : I notice in your paper the fact that the Secretary of the Navyhas ordered the naval officers on the NewYork station to show the ships, shops, and everything else of interest at the Navy Yard, to the Turkish Admirall, who comes to the United States on a mere errand of business. As a matter of taste I have nothing to say touching the propriety of this order;

The conviction which we yesterday expressed that NAPOLEON III. would exert himself to the utmost to repair the mischief done by his indiscreet ministers, and his more than indiscreet soldiery, in their unbridled appeals against the people and the Government of Great Britain, is fully confirmed by the European news which we this morning publish, and which reached this City last night per the steamer Anglo-Saxon, at Portland.

There have been found drifted up on the beach three more bodies, making the whole number thus far found of the wrecked with the ship John Milton, eleven. The bodies were all taken to East Hampton, where the Coroner has been holding Inquests over them. No one of them has been certainly identified yet. Four persons went down by Railroad from New-York yesterday to see if friends of theirs were among the lost.

A Site for the State Woman's Hospital ??--An Application to be made for the Repeal of the police Law--A Conference Committee on the Tax Levy--Report of the Fire Marshal. The Board of Aldermen met last evening, President CLANCY in the Chair. The report in favor of appropriating $1,000 for the reception of Rear Admiral

Hon. C. F. CROSHY'S funeral was attended yesterday morning by a large concourse of relatives and friends at the Reformed Dutch Church in Market-street, of which, previous to his removal from this City, he was an active member. The religious exercises were conducted by Chancellor FE?BIS and Rev. T. L. CUYLER, and the remains were then taken to Greenwood.

RENTS IN THE CITY.--The financial panic of tile last Fall lhas not. as yet very sensibly affected real estate. Sales are constantly made, though not to as large an amount, yet at quite as high prices, as usual. Rents of dwellinghouses are no lower,-and the number of desirable dwellings for small families which are offered to rent is less than hitherto.

In steamship Marion, for Charleston--Jno, Knox, Edward T. Cone and lady. Thos. Rosseru. H. Heyward, lady and 4 children. Mrs. J. H. Hallett, Miss Conkey. Mr. Story lady and child Miss Story. W. Hull, Daniel Cooper, Wm. B. Cooper, C. P. Ralli J. H. Butterworth, T. Tompkins, the Steerage.

The NEW-YORK TIMES recently gave a graphic description of the hanging of a negro woman at Alexandria, D. C., from a special correspondent, but unfortunately for the paper the hanging did not come off and the woman is still alive, Such misfortunes will occasionally occur.--Albany Evening Journal.

The Topeka Legislature, after a recess of three weeks, reassembled on the 10th inst. The Codifying Committee have made their report. The Code is composed of such laws as are necessary to render the government complete, as it may be determined to put into operation, in the event of Kansas being admitted under the Lecompton Constitution.

The R. M. steamship America, now in her twelfth day out from Liverpool, and due at Halifax, with three days' later news from Europe, had not been heard from at 10 o'clock last night. We publish this morning some additional European news from our files by the Arago.

We obtain some further intelligence of interest from our European files by the Arago. Our advices from London and Liverpool are to the 10th of February inclusive. The telegrams containing the India and China news were fully reported in our impression of yesterday.

SENT BACK TO SING SING.--CHARLES HAMPSON, convicted in the Kings County Court of Sessions of passing a counterfeit $3 bill on the Essex County Bank, New-Jersey, was yesterday sentenced to 5 years and 3 months imprisonment in the State Prison at Sing Sing. HAMPSON, a few years ago, was an overseer in the same prison. HONOBA SHEPHERD was in the prison at the time,

The first object which attracts tile attemtion of foreign travelers in this country is the hotel bar-room of our great cities; the great, glaring, gaudy, spacious, brilliant apartment, with its marble floor, its gilded ceiling, and pictured walls, its large mirrors, bronzes, and candelabras, with its excited crowds either smoking or " taking something,"

The CLAY and CULLOM difficulty was settled today, as will be seen by the following correspondence. of course there was considerable negotiation not presented on the face of these papers. It should be stated that Messrs CRITTENDEN and TOOMES called 'Senator KENNEDY into the reference from the beginning. CLAY and COLON both returned to town to-day CLAY had been out near BLAIR'S place, practicing with the rife.

At the annual meeting of the Children's Aid Society, held at their rooms last evening, the Secretary, Mr. C. L. BRACE, read the Annual Report, and the report of the Treasurer, after which the Society went-into an election of five trustees, when the following gentlemen were unanimously elected; GEO. BIRD, B. J. HOWLAND, WM. C. GILMAN, HOWARD PORTER, J. L., PHELPS, M. D.

Y.; Mrs. Murphy, Miss Estes, Mr. Murphy Jr., Mr. Murphy, Jr., Mr. Hoyt, Mrs. Hoyt, Mr. Cleveland, Mrs. Cleveland, Miss Lewis, Mr. Halsey, Mrs. Halsey, Mr. Redfield, Mr. Carr. Mr. Mitchell, Mr. Henrique, all of New-York; Major Johnson, Miss Johnson, Cincinnati;

It is proposed to take off enough from the large county of Tazewell, in Virginia, to form two new counties, one to be called Buchanan and the other Breckinridge. In the county of Buchanan, that is to be, there are said to be three slaves, and in the proposed Breckinridge it is added that there will not be a slave owned.

A THEATRICAL JOURNAL.--We have to announce, on the authority of no less a person than the Nena Sabib, the advent of a new competitor in the field of journalism. But, as our fresh rival proposes to go back to first principles, aud to ignore the art of printing, and as it will, moreover, be strictly an evening publication, we are not seriously alarmed at the prospect before us.

It is a difficult business to complete a negotiation, where one of the parties to it bases his demands on his personal pride. Pride is a most stubborn, unreasoning and unreasonable feeling in individuals, and equally as perverse and hard to deal with in a State.

The shock of the golden earthquake is making itself felt, it would appear, in the conscience of the mercantile world, and for the first time in many years the season of Lent is kept with something of the ancient devotion by the business men of the busiest city of tile New World.

THE WRITE FEATHER.--There appears to be a general disposition to accuse General HARNEY of showing the white feather in not accepting the challenge of Colonel SUMMER. But, if that is to be the way whenever a man refuses to fight, no one will have the courage to decline a challenge.

DINNER AT SOUTH DANVERS IN HONOR OF MR PEABOLY.--The Hoston Journal says that on Thursday, 18th inst., the 63d birthday of GEORGE PEAROLY the citizens of South Danvers, his native place, celebrated the event by a banquet. Hon. A. A. ABROTT presided. Toasts were given, speeches made, and there was a grand festival.

THE LECOMPTON MEETING--We understand that the call in circulation for a Lecompton meeting is being rapidly signed by influential and well-known names. The meeting will come off at an early day. We hope the managers will not overlook our suggestion that Gen. CALHOUN be invited to attend, and set forth the merits of the case.

It is always much easier, in public as well as in private affairs, to say what ought to be done, than to find the ways and means of doing it. Everybody acknowledges that the POLICZ Department of tills City ought to be kept entirely aloof from party politics;-but no mode of accomplishing this desirable result has yet been discovered which satisfies the sentiment of the public at large.

PARTY ASPECTS OF THE LECOMPTION MOVEMENT.--The Richmond Enquirer, in an article which we copied yesterday, protests against the attempt of the Administration to make the Lecompton Constitution the test of fidelity to the Democratic Party.

The duels, past or prospective, still occupy by jar the largest share of public attention, The affair between CLAY and CULLON-New pending nearly four days-of course excites the greatest interest, and everybody on the quivive for any intelligence in regard to its progress. I have little to add to my telegraphic dispatch of to-night upon this subject,

No. 45.--Eugene Leitensdorfer et al. vs. Jas. J. Webb.--Justice DANIEL delivered the opinion of the Court, affirming the judgement of the Supreme Court of the Territory of New-Mexico, with costs and interest. No.5.--Adolphus Durant vs. Saml. Lawrence et al.--The decrce of the Circuit Court for the District of Massachusetts affirmed, with costs.

Yesterday evening the Joint Committee of the New-Jersey Legislature to which was referred the matter of the application for the appointment of a Legislative Commission to investigate and report on the advisability of the removal of the Quarantine ground from Staten Island to Sandy Honk, sat in the Assembly Chamber of the capitol at Trenton to hear arguments pro and con.

THE RELIEF COMMITTEE.-The Ward Committees appointed at a recent meeting of citizens of Jersey City, to solicit donations for the relief of the poor, have succeeded in collecting altogether the sum of $556 87 in cash, and orders for $80 worth of groceries; $116 25 has been subscribed which has not yet been paid in. A sub-Committee of one from each Ward, consisting of Charles Fink, M. C. Smith, J. B. Haight

SOUTHERN OBJECTIONS TO REORGANIZING THE SUPREME COURT--The Carolina Daily Times of Saturday last denounces with all the energy of chivalric wrath Senator SEWARD'S proposition to give the Free States their due weight in the United States Supreme Court, and bestows upon us for favoring that scheme a shower of unsavory epithets.

Brevet-General HARNEY, Colonel of the 2d Dragoons, has communicated to the War Department his hostile correspondence with Col. SUMMER, of the 1st Cavalry. By those military men who have seen the letters, I am told that HARNEY shows the white feather in retreating behind the cover of his brevet grade to avoid either explanation or satisfaction.

Both Houses came back to work last night, according to adjournment. In the Assembly, the general orders were under consideration in Committee of the Whole. Almost the entire session of to-day was occupied in receiving petitions, notices of bills, etc. It was "a general jail delivery."

The trip of the Jamestown hither from New-York, has been a very quick and pleasant one, not withstanding the unfavorable weather which prevailed at the hour of starting on Saturday. The Bay was full office as far as Sunday Hook, through which we plowed our way with some difficulty; and throughout the night a heavy southeast swell kept the steamer in lively motion.

BEATTIE,--In this City, of Wednesday morning Feb. 21. of consumption, JAMES BEATTIE, son of the late Rev Robert Beattie, of the County of Furmanagh, Ireland, in the 28th year of this age. The friends and relatives of the family are respectfully invited to attend his funeral. from his late residence. No 163 2d-st., on Friday, Feb. 26. at 1 o'clock P.M. His re mains will be taken to the Evergreens Cemetery.

Mr. MALLORY introduced a bill authorizing the construction of a Naval Dry Dock. Mr. GREEN's motion making the Kansas bill the Special order for to-morrow, was taken up. Mr. DOUGLAS asked whether the current report was true that Senators STUART and BRODERICK had been read out of the party by the Democratic caucus. Mr. ALLEN knew nothing about it.

EXTORTIONATE LANDLORDS.--Mrs. Burns, a widow lady, made a complaint yesterday at the Mayor's office against the landlord of the "Golden Flecce," No. 13 Liberty street. She stated that she arrived; with her two children, in this City two days ago from Ohio, on her way to England, and was induced to stop at the Golden Fleece, with the understanding that she should be charges $ 1 50 a day.

The last performance of "Don Giovanni" attracted a good audience, although riot so crowded as the merits of the occasion demanded. It was an excellent performance in every respect; all the artists being in good voice, and more than good spirit, particularly Herr FORMES, whose comic acting was immense.

From a conversation with Admiral ZKRMAN, of the Mexican navy, who arrived here last evening, di. rect from the City of Mexico, I have gleaned some interesting facts relative to the events which resulted in the recent overthrow of President CoMONFORT, the present condition of the Church and Liberal Parties in that country, and the means by which the Liberals hope to regain entire possession of the country and its Government.

To the Editor of the London Times: SIR: Certain persons have, as you know, commenced a crusade against London prostitutes, and, it one of that abandoned sisterhood may presume to address you, grant me your attention. The precept and example set me by parents. now, thank God, in their graves; the education likewise "thrown away" upon me,

Once upon a time Mr. JOHN MINOR BOTTS, of Virginia, made himself reasonably conspicuous in the field of American politics. He "stumped" the country pretty extensively, and in one way or another saved the Union, as the manner of such is-though how or why, from what danger or in whose behalf and interest, we cannot at this moment precisely recall.

The Buffalo Express tells a story of a Quaker who was charged the exorbitant sum of seventeen dollars for a horse and buggy for a short drive, and, upon being presented with the bill, simply remarked, "Thou mistakest me; I do not wish to purchase thy vehicle, but only to hire it." A clergyman was recently rebuked by a brother of the cloth for smoking.

To Dr. GUILMETTE belongs the credit of having provided the most attractive concert of the season-a concert of real stirring interest in every musical point of view. We are glad to add that there was a good attendance. Dodworth's Saloon never presented a more gay and animated appearance than it did last evening, and on few occasions has contained so critical an audience.

The Clerk of the Weather must have been wholly oblivious as to what has been going on in Richmond, or else entirely indifferent to the wishes of Virginians, for, very much to the vexation of everybody, that capricious official, not satisfied with sending us a cold snow-storm on WASHINGTON'S birthday, most contemptuously ordained a fine sunny day on each side of it.

MATTESON arrived here to-day. His friends say that the reference to a Select Committee is satisfactory because it gives him an opportunity for trial. Governor WALKER has written a letter to the Indiana Convention, which I an assured is in more earnest opposition to the President's course on Incompion than any thing he has heretofore published. His friends deny any reconciliation with the president.

On the 27th of January, the same day that Lord PALMERSTON issued the usual circular to his supporters, reminding them of the reassembling of Parliament being fixed for the 4th of February, there was published, in London, by Mr. BENTLEY a volume entitled Parliamentary Government and Reform of Parliament,

PFREMPTORY CHALLENGE OF JURORS.--Senator PATERSON has introduced a bill to give to the prosecution, in all criminal trials where the offence charged is punishable with death, or imprisonment for ten years in the State Prison, the right of peremptorily challenging ten, and where the offence is punishable by less than ten years, three of the jurors.

" After us the end of the world !" Each carnival brings with it the same masquerades, the same thread-bare jests, the same sorry attempts at being funny. There is nothing more ludicrous than the manner in which each generation of youths attempt to maintain the reputation of their predecessors. The-carnival,;with its follies. is a doomed institution, but it kicks hard against the inroads of the three per cents, the cashmeres and the crinoline.

The steamship Tennessee has arrived here, bringing Vera-Cruz dates to the 21st inst. Little political change had yet occurred, although the Government was violently opposed by General MESIA, who was also committing terrible outrages upon the people of Sierra Blanche. They had applied to the Constitutional Government at Guanaxuato for aid against him.

E. G. BROWNE, the Utah correspondent of the New-York Tribune, arrived here last night, in company with U. S. Attorney HOCKADAY. They left Camp Scott on January 5. The health of the army continued good, and the weather was remarkably mild for the region. Very little snow had fallen, and In the immediate vicinity of the camp the ground was almost bare.

The Leavenworth Times says that the Judges and Clerks of the Electlon at Shawnee have been arrested, and that they testified under oath before the Investigating Committee that the poll-book of Shawnee was taken to Westport, and three hundred names added thereto in that place. J. J. CLARKSON, Postmaster at Leavenworth, was burned in effigy on the 15th inst., and threats were made to hang him, if caught.

The Court of Claims is a tribunal, theoretically, of high character and dignity. Its office is to adjudicate upon established legal principles, within the limits of a well-defined jurisdiction, the claims of individuals against the Government. Practically, it is made a commission of Clerks, with no authority and no respect whatever.

Why is the letter U the gayest in the alphabet ? Because t is always in fun. Yes, but why is it the most unfortunate in the alphabet ? Because it is always in trouble and difficulty. THE WHEEL OF FORTUNE.-It must have belonged originally to an omnibus-for it is continually "taking up" and "putting down " people. --Punch.

RETURN OF THE INAUGURATION VISITORS FROM RICHMOND.-The pickpockets made an extensive haul while the procession was moving, as well as at the scene of the celebration. Mr. ZEBLER, a shoe dealer of Philadelphia, lost his overcoat and memorandum book containing $115, with many orders for goods; another person lost $900; and another $1,500.

H. and Miss Bancon, Joseph Antona Jacques Andri. James Robertson. E. Baurfield Madame Larrin, Mr. and Mrs. Robinson, H. G. Bourbeach--total 23.

The beautiful weather makes Broadway uncomonly brilliant in the afternoon. There is no street in the world where so many handsome ladies can be scen in an hour's walk as Broadway. The fact that the walks are muddy and the walking bad, does not diminish the number in the least.

WHAT IS TO BECOME OF PARTY DISCIPLINE? --Matters at Albany are somewhat loose, in a party sense. We by no means insinuate that there is any other looseness, whether of principle or practice, at that famous capital. But, evidently, party men do not toe the mark as they did in years gone by.

Mr. MASON presented resolutions asking information as to the condition of the Navy for many Years past; also, relative to captures of vessels and prize money during the last war. Mr. CRITTENDEN presented a letter from Mr. SHELDS. and moved that he take his seat as Senator from Minnesota. The letter argues that Minnesota Is a sovereign State,

The belligerent temper which prevails at Washington seems to have reached New-York, where, however, it affects a different class of persons. It is mainly in the literary world that it makes itself manifest. A very readable story recently appeared in the. Atlantic Monthly, called "The Diamond Lens," which excited considerable attention,

If our readers would like to see some striking illustrations of the extent to which the partisan ultraism of the day goes in exacting service of its adherents, we refer them to two articles which we copy this morning from the Charleston Mercury and the Philadelphia Bulletin.

Washington Correspondence of the Philadelphia Press. The Democratic delegation to the House from Pennsylvania had a meeting last evening. There was a large attendance. After much consultation on both sides, they adjourned without concluding definitely on any point.

CHARLES L. TAYLOR, a??us SANDERS, has been arrested for setting fire to the Pacific Hotel, after murdering EPHRAIM DOANE, one of its Inmates. Dr. STEADER, the landlord, arid CHARLES WALDRUP, the watchman, have also been arrested. The examination takes place to-morrow, when it is supposed that one of the most atrocious and diabolical acts ever committed will be developed.

LATE POLITICAL INTELLIGENCE -We feel authorized to announce that Senator STEPHEN A. DOUGLAS, of Illinois, familiarly styled the Little Giant," is no longer a Democrat. It is from the Pennsylvanian-President BUCHANAN'S Philadelphia organ-that we learn this startling fact. Up to the last month Mr. DOUGLAS was a Democrat, dyed in the wool-that and nothing else.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: We have heard no little said about the protest put forth recently against the action of the Board of Managers of the American Bible Society in regard to its standard Bible. The action of the Board in legard to this protest we have heard rather strongly condemned by some as the denial of a right; by others as wanting in courtesy.

SUDDEN DEATH OF AN OLD STEAMBOAT CAPTAIN.-About 9 o'clock Wednesday evening, as Mr. ABRAHAM HITCHCOCK, formerly commander of several North River steamboats, was passing up Hudsonstreet near Laight, he was suddenly seized with a fit, and fell to the sidewalk. A gentleman who saw him fall conveyed him to an apothecary's shop, and sent for a physician; but before the latter arrived, Mr. HITCHCOOK expired.

In relation to the Lecompton Constitution, you may rest assured that a majority of the Free-State men in the Territory are now willing to see Kansas admitted as a State under that instrument, either with or without Slavery; provided, the first and any subsequent Legislature shall have the power of calling a new Convention to alter or amend it.

The drawing-room had a wet day last Saturday, but the brilliancy of the assembly indoors compensated for any fogginess outside. The Princess FREDERICK looks remarkably well, I hear. I can vouch for her good looks the previous evening at the opera. That was the gayest night Her Majesty's Theatre had seen for many years.

From the Charleston Mercury. We lay before our readers today, the most extraordinary letter of President CALHOUN, published in the Washington Union. It is a marvellous proper specimen of political jugglery. Although Mr. CALHOUN has had the returns of the elections regularly made and sworn to by the managers, he does not give the certificates of election to the Legislature whilst in the Territory.

PAUL HERNANDEZ, a native of Mexico, who kept a low eating and drinking saloon in the basement No. 83 West Broadway, corner of Leonard street, yesterday morning shut his wife with a pistol while she was shifting near the stove. The report of the pistol was heard by several persons in the building, and the Fifth Ward Police were notified of the occurrence.

FROM PORTO RICO.--Schooner Wm. L. Richardson, from Mayaguez, P. R., arrived here yesterday. We have advices to the 7th instant. The market was overstocked with provisions of all descriptions coopers stuffs. a drug, four large cargoes remain without sale;

No. 55-Eliphas Spencer vs. John W.Lapsley.-Justice CAMPBELL delivered the opinion of the Court, affirming the judgement of the Circuit Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana, with costs. No.41- The United States vs. Gotlieb Brestling.-Chief Justice TANEY delivered the opinion of the Court, reversing the judgement of the Circuit Court for the Southern District of Alabama, and remanding the cause with directions to award a writ of venire facias de novo.

The steamship America, now in her thirteenth day, had not been seen at Halifax at a late hour last night. In the United States Senate yesterday, Mr. MAS0N, Chairman of the Committee on Foreign Relalations, presented a series of resolutions calling for information relative to the condition of the Navy for many years past, and also relative to captures

I.-THE LECOMPTON CONSTITUTION IN CONGRESS-Abstracts of the Majority and two Minority Reports from the Special Committee of the Senate-Proceedings in Congress thereon. II.-THE STRUGGLE IN MEXICO-Particulars of the Overthrow and flight of Gen. COMONFORT. III.-THE PERSONAL DIFFICULTIES AT WASHINGTON-Rhind vs. Boutwell, Clay vs, Cullem, Bell ?. Williams, A Duel.

To the Editors of the Evening Post: I have to excuse myself for again troubling you about a matter which has already occupied more than its share of the public attention. Your paper was the first to give currency to a report that I am not the author of the story entitled the "The Diamond Lens," published in the January number of the Atlantic Monthly.

THE CLAY AND CULLOM DUEL.-We 'can hardly blame foreigners for considering us only a half-civilized people. It would be difficult for any person who reads the history of, the recent " difficulty" between CLAY and CULLOM to come to any other conclusion. It smacks from beginning to end of the half-savage and the half-civilized.

NASSAU WATER WIRKS-The contractors for these works, having had the benefits of an extraordinarily mild winter, have so far improved the oppodity that the work on the entire contract is in a great state of forwardness, and is in advance of the time allotted. The engines are alone behindhand. but these will be in readiness as soon as wanted.

LEE - AVENUE LECTURES.--The last of a course of lectures at the Lee avenue Church, Brooklyn, the benefit of the Sabbath Missionary enterprise, was delivered on Wednesday evening by MATTEW HALE SMITH, Esq. It was a very Pleasant lecture, and the house, which was well filled received it with warm applause.

The Senate had an evening session last night, 20 consider Senator DIVEN'S resolutions of instructions on Kansas affairs. Senator DIVEN made a brilliant speech in denunciation of the course of the Administration, and challenged a rejoinder from the other side of the House. But the other side of the House were not in a condition to accept the challenge.

The Republican State Committee of Rhode Island has called a State Convention to meet the 17th of March, at Providence. Schohatie County has elected 12 Democrats and 4 Republican Supervisors. The Supervisors elected in Schuyler County are a majority in favor of Walkins as the County-seat.

Mayor TIEMANN'S Message, calling upon the Common Council to supervise Albany legislation, affecting the City, occasions some remark here, and is producing an effect not anticipated from it, New York complains of injustice done her by the country. Admitting this complaint to be well-founded who is properly chargeable with it? New-York has in the Assembly seventeen representatives-in the Senate four.

B. F. Shumard, President of the St. Louis Academy of Science: MY DEAR SIR : I have had the pleasure of examining a small collection of fossils from Kansas, made by Major F. HAWN, of the United States Survey of that Territory ; and as they show the development of a geological system not known to exist in the West, it may interest your Academy to know the results.

BIRTHS, MARRIAGES AND DEATHS.--These events, though personal, are not therefore strictly private. The community has an interest in them. In some countries accurate registers are kept, by which any person can inform himself respecting the births, marriages and deaths within a certain district.

The Legislative Committee on Quarantine have reported adversely to the application of the New York Commissioners. Their duty to the State, justice to their own citizens and the dictates of humanity, forbid their allowal of the proposed location of Quarantine at Sandy Hook. The Committee argue the subject at length.

The Albany correspondent of the Syracuse Journal, (a Republican paper,) in adverting to Governor KINO's unsuccessful effort to oust Mr. BENTON from the Auditorship, says: "The conviction is general that the Governor, by a too strict adherence to a rule that obtained, in past days, has made too great a sacrifice to party.

At the Navy-Yard. The United States steam-frigate Wabash went out of commission on Wednesday last, her crew having been paid off and discharged. She is to be recommissioned, probably for the Mediterranean. Tile Marine guard were transferred to the Marine Barracks.

From the Evening Post. Governor KING has made something of a sensation in political circles by nominating new Harbor-Masters in the place of three whom we have been accustomed to regard as good Republicans, and two of whom, at least, we know to be good officers. What is the matter? We hope the Governor is not permitting himself to be made unwittingly an instrument of the Sandy Hook Quarantine speculators.

An incident in The Virginians, representing WASHINGTON as ready to accept a challenge, has led Leslie's Illustrated Paper to reprint the following pertinent anecdote from Weems' Gossipping Lift of Washington : " In 1784, WASHINGTON was stationed at Alexandria with his regiment, the only one of tile colony, of which he was Colonel.

A lecture was delivered last night, at the Stuyvesant Institute, by F. A. CONKLING, Esq., at the request of the Hardware Dealers' Board of Trade, on the " Commercial Revulsion, and its Relation to the Jobbing Interests of the City." As was to be expected, the audience were all male, and principally composed of leading merchants, hardware dealers,

At 3 P. M., yesterday, Judge EDMONDS Sat in the Special Term room of the Supreme Court, to investigate the facts of the contempt alleged to have been committed by Mr. Frederick D. Seely, and Mr. David Wemyss Jobson, in the presence of Mr. John N. Whiting, who was Referee in a case in which Mr. Jobson was the plaintiff's assignee and principal witness, and Mr.

Mr. GREELEY is here to testify before the Tar?? Committee of Investigation. He will deny that he every had any conversation with MATTESON, or authorized any one to deposit money in his hands, to effect the passage of the Tariff modification. Judge RUSSELL and Postmaster FOWLER are here, operating against Collector SCHELL. Some ?? screw is loose.

The Governor-General's opening speech was delivered to-day. In it he alludes to the Indian rebellion, and anticipates the success of the British arms and the reestablishment of British rule in India. He congratulates the country on the prudence of our commercial men, and on the good position of the Banks, recommends improvement in commercial legislation,...

THREE PERSONS BURNED TO DEATH.--A sad tragedy occurred at Clinton, Mass., to-day. At about 2 o'clock a large barn containing hay, on the Stewart place, was discovered to be on fire, and was entirely destroyed. Soon after this fire had been been put out. an alarm was given that a small dwelling house in that part of Clinton, Known as " California," was on fire. When the firemen reached the spot, the build.

Among the new writers of fiction who have recently appeared in Great Britain, we should place GEORGE ELIOT the author of Scenes of Clerical Life, at the head. The three stories filling the volume of this title, which has been republished by HARPER BROTHERS, originally appeared in Blackwood's Magrazine.

From Yesterday's Washington Union. TREASON TO DEMOCRACY CONFIRMS ITS POWER, That vanlting ambition Which "o' erlcape itself and falls on 'toiner Side" never yet in so short a space of time worked such havoc with hopes, prospects and pretensions of presidential aspirants, as it has done since the last autumal frosts stripped the leaves from the forest. The grave- digger is abroad in the land.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR: Observing a controversy in you paper with respect to an alleged manuscript production of the late WILLIAM NORTH, which bears most a remarkable, if not identical, similarity with a recent performance of a Mr. FITZ-JAMES O'BRIEN, I beg to add my personal testimony as to the correctness of the correspondent in your issue of this morning.

BAUSH.--In this City, on Friday morning, Feb. 26, ?? relict of the late Capt. John Baush, aged 70 years. The friends of the family, also those of her sons, John, Jacob and William, are respectfully invited to attend her funeral, from her late residence. No. 78 West 43d-st., on Sunday, Feb. 28, at 1 o'clock P. M., without further invitation. Her remains will be taken to Greenwood Cemetery for interment.

THE TAX-ROLLS.--The twelve deputies appointed by the Commissioners of Taxes, under the new tax law, to make assessments, represent that the value of real estate in this City, for the year 1858, is greater than last year by $17,134,100. In every Ward except the Second there has been an increase since last year.

The Senate not in session. HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES. WASHINGTON, Friday, Feb. 26. The further consideration of Mr. HOARD'S resolution for the appointment of a Select Committee of Inquiry as to whether Executive influence has been exerted for the control of the votes of members of the House, was postponed till Thursday next.

By the arrival at Boston of the bark Young Turk from Cape Town. Cape of Good Hope, papers are received to the 29th of December. The people of the Cape are gratified, after various failures of English Steam Companies, at the splendid voyage of the steamer Norman, of the New Union Company, which had made the passage from London in three and a half days less than contract time.

PHOTOGRAPHER DRAWINGS ON WOOD.--M. LALLEMAND is the author of a process for photographing drawings upon the wood on which it is to be engraved in relief. The wood is first placed with its surface on a solution of alum, and dried; it then receives with a soft brush a coating composed of animal soap, gelatine and alum upon all its faces.

From the St. Louis Democrat, 23d. During yesterday the workmen at the mournful scene at Seventh and Pollar streets, continued their excavation. By nightfall, the charred and mutilated remnants of five more of the victims were exhumed. They were borne to the stable-loft on Franklinavenue, where the others were deposited. A considerable portion of the ruins remains yet to be explored,

MULTIPLICITY OF CHARITABLE SOCIETIES.-There is a movement on foot to consolidate several of the leading Religious Societies for the purpose of increased economy in expenditure. It might very profitably be extended to our charitable associations of all kinds. There are too many of them.

To the Edtior of the New-York Times: That a large portion of the capital now comparatively idle will sooner or later be invested in real estate, is almost certain. So many have suffered from investments in railroads, they now seek the most substantial securities-something which a panic cannot sweep away.

HON. ROBERT J. WALKER.--The Evening Bulletin of Wednesday has an editorial alleging that Governor WALKER has ceased his opposition to the Lecompton fraud, and suggesting certain motives. We have no authority to speak for Mr. WALKER, but, our life for it, inproper time and fitting place, Mr. WALKER will speak for himself.

The receipts of the Boards of the Presbyterian Church for January were ?? Missions, $9,751; Education, $6,262; Foreign Missions. $19,254; Publication, $5,267; Choral Extension Committee, $2,372, Total, $42,950. Gov. King has appointed the following Commissioners to expend money raised for certain charitable institutions.

A text now lies before us from which, were we disposed to do so, we might easily extract a very lengthy, true and tedious sermon. It is neither more nor less than a copy of the London Times, No. 5,081, being that for April 17, 1801. At the first glance any reader of newspapers might readily take this infant Thunderer for a copy of the Bengal Hurkaru, or the New-York Sun.

At 12 o'clock last night there were no signs of the America at Halifax. She is now in her fourteenth day, and overdue. The U. S. Senate was not in session yesterday. In the House, the further consideration of the resolution introduced by Mr. HOARD, providing for a Select Committee to inquire relative to Executive influence in controlling votes in the House, was postponed until Thursday of next week.

We see it stated in the North Wales Chronide, on authority, that Holyhead has been fixed upon as the port from which the Leviathan will start this Spring. VESSELS OVERDUE.--There are a large number of vessels from ports in Europe for this port now due and overdue. The following have been out sixty days and over:

Mr. Thomas L. Yonug, a member of the Palmetto regiment during the Mexican war, recently died at Winnesboro', South Carolina. He was scarcely sixteen when the war broke out, yet he was so full of the war spirit that he ran away from his home to join the regiment. He passed through all the dangers of the campaign without receiving a Wound, and was always at his post.

BURYING THE BONES OF TREASONABLE DEMOCRATS.--We copy in another part of this paper an article from yesterday's Union, bitterly denunciatory of DOUALAS and WISE, whom, without naming, it characterizes, the one as " a bold, adventurous legislator and partisan giant," the other as " an orator of dashing, slashing, headlong eloquence," and both of whom it consigns to the " catacombs" where rest the remains of " departed politicians."

Upon receiving the cane of WASHINGTON, which was presented to him at Richmond, Mr. EVERETT thus returned his acknowledgments: " SIR: I want words adequately to express the emotions of satisfaction and gratitude with which I receive this most interesting personal relic of the ' Father of his Country'-invaluable in itself, and rendered, if possible, still more precious, by the circumstances under which it comes into my possession.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.-- There will be a cheap performance at this house to-night, the opera being " Ernani," with D'ANGRI, LA GRANGE, BIGNAEDI, GASSIER, , in the cast. LAURA KEENE'S THEATRE.--Mr. BURNETT, the efficient stage manager of this house, takes his benfit to-night. He has provided an excellent bill, and should be remembered.

The Investigating Committee having procured information that required the presence of the Judges of Election at Shawnee and Oxford Precincts, in Johnson County, their Marshal,the fighting preacher, Mr. STEWART, was sent with warrants for their arrest. The Prairie City Rifles acted as a posse, and on Monday morning last started for the scene of action.

MURDERS IN NEW ORLEANS.--The New-Orleans Picayune of the 18th has particulars of a wife-murder and suicide, committed in a house on Craps-street. At the time of the occurrence it was supposed that the wounds would immediately prove fatal but such does not appear to have been the case, as they were still alive this morning. The man is HEINRICH J. HAAS, a native of Holland, and about 41 years of age.

Marriages are scarce in these times. A Newark clergyman states that he has married but one couple since Thanksgiving Day; his usual average was formerly one a week. The papers show a general falling off under tile head of " Marriage" notices. Tile inference is that happy couples are waiting for business to collie up.

ADMISSION OF STUDENTS Yesterday the examiners (Messrs. John F. Doyle, Jas. C. Carter, and A. J. Vanderpool,) appointed to examine applicants for admission to the bar, reported in favor of admitting the following gentlemen: Horatio G. Abbey, Edward Cammann, James Donohue, John V. Dexey, Madison Earle, James 0. C. Fabb, Lewis Johnston,

We have more than once expressed doubts as to the wisdom of tile policy acted upon by our Government in paying large subventions to ocean steamers for the transportation of the mail. But no one can look with satisfaction upon what is certain to be the result of the abandonment of that policy. Within five years from the present time, under such circumstances, we shall not have a first-class ocean steamer afloat upon the Atlantic.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--To-night, ROSSINI'S opera of "Otello" will be performed with a strong distribution of characters. Mr. ULLMANN, the indefatigable manager, has issued the following circular in relation to the forthcoming production of MEYERBEER'S opera of the "Iluguenots," It is worthy of attention:

The State Convention of the Democracy of Indiana, held at Indianapolis on Tuesday, the 23d of February, was one of the most important end significant incidents of the political history of the day. Delegates were present from sixty counties. Speeches were made by the most prominent and influential Democrats of the state, and a platform of principles was adopted, upon which the entire Democratic Party of the North and West will probably unite.

Arrival of the Empire City. The Empire City, Capt. S. P. GRIFFIN, left New-Orleans Feb. 20, arrived at Havana at sunrise on the 23d, left for this port at 11/2 o'clock P. M the same day, and arrived here yesterday morning. She brings a large freight from New-Orleans, and 49 passengers.

THE LAST OF THE NEGOTIATION FOR SANDY HOOK.--The report of the New-Jersey Legislative Committee in relation to the application of New-York for permission to use Sandy Hook is exactly what we predicted it would be a flat refusal to listen to any terms whatever.

CENTRAL RAILROAD EXTNSION--MEETING IN JERSEY CITY.-In pursuance of a call issued by Mayor WESCOTT, at the request of the Common Council, a meeting of citizens of Jersey City was held at Park Hall Friday evening, for the purpose of an expression upon the proposed extension of the New-Jersey Central Railroad to Jersey City.

Members of Congress are becoming excessively fastidious as to the character of their associates. It is exceedingly edifying to read the debates in the House upon the Matteson case, and to note the alarm and consternation of gentlemen lest they should be contaminated by the presence at Washington of a man who is popularly supposed to be no better than he should be.

A VIRGINIAN'S EXPERIENCE IN NEW-YORK--SINGULAR INFATUATION.-- Mr. J. Franklin langley, a resident of Norfolk, Virginia, forty years of age, arrived in the City a few days ago from California, and stopped at the Astor House. Last Monday night he fell in with two abandoned young females, Emma Howard and Mary Morris.

It is a little amusing to see tile alarm of the ultra Republican journals lest Senator SWARD should go over to the South. The Tribune and Evening Post scarcely conceal their apprehensions, and are becoming very open and aboveboard in their denunciations of him.

Tile Judiciary Committee in the United States Senate has been instructed to inquire whether Minnesota is not now a State, and a member of the Union. Gen. SHIELDS, one of its Senators elect, thinks it is, and Mr. CRITTENDEN, of Kentucky, agrees with him. Mr. HUNTER, of Virginia, thinks not. So the matter is to be investigated.

More than one-half of the session is scored off, without perfecting more than half a dozen bills, and with little prospect of much being done in the 45 days yet remaining. In the Senate 205 bills have been introduced, 126 reported to the Committee of the Whole, and 56 read a third time and passed.

HOW NOT TO TELL IT.--The ingenuity with which witnesses summoned by Congress conccal the truth is an interesting study. They begin by not knowing anything. Next, they refuse to tell anything. Thirdly, they fall back upon their constitutional rights. And, lastly, they go to jail. Anything is better than telling tales. The disbursement of cash to members of Congress is confidential business.

Two men, JAMES M. SPEER and JOHN KIRK, are under examination at Chicago, for an alleged conspiracy to seduce the daughter of a respectable resident of that city, MARY McCARTHY, a girl 16 years of age, to prostitution. The girl is the principal witness. The Boston Courier has been sued for libel by a shipbuilding firm.

The following is the Weekly Report of Deaths in this City and County of New-York, from the 20th day of February, to the 27th day of February. 1858: Men, 75; Women, 81; Boys, 191; Girls, 156: Total. 503*. Adults, 156; Children, 347; Males, 266; Females, 237; Colored Persons, 9.

The churches were unusually well attended yesterday, and more solemnity than usual was observed in many of them. The profound religious excitement that we have often already remarked, seems deepening and widening. Rev. Mr. HOVEY, of the Eleventh Presbyterian Church, corner of avenue C. and Fourth-street, preached a sermon to Firemen last evening, by request.

MORE SORROWS OF WERTER.--Poor BENNETT is in trouble again. He is unhappy because the Administration presses do not appreciate his devotion. The Washington Union snubs him,-and when it comes to that, we must confess, the case seems hard. It is bad enough to be kicked, but to be kicked by the Union, is an additional injury.

We surrender a large portion of our space this morning to a report of the proceedings of the recent State Convention of the Democrats of Indiana. This is one of the most important political movements of the day. It indicates unmistakably the tendency of opinion in the ranks of the Democratic Party throughout the Northern States, and foreshadows the policy which will unquestionably be adopted in its future action.

The Senate Democratic Committee, yesterday, became satisfied of the possibility of carrying Lecompton on its own merits, and agreed to couple it with Minnesota. HENRY WASHINGTON, who killed himself to-day, was the editor of JEFFERSON'S papers. It is believed that his death was accidental. S.

The United States mail steamship Moses Taylor, JOHN McGOWAN, Esq., Commanding, from Aspinwall via Jamaica, with the California mails of the 5th inst., and $1,600,000 in treasure, arrived at this port on Saturday afternoon. The Moses Taylor left the wharf at Aspinwall at 2 P. M. on the 19th inst.; arrived at the wharf at Kingston, (Jamaica,) at 1 1/2 P. M. 21st; coaled, and left same evening at 9 P. M.

At a few minutes before 1 o'clock on Saturdaymorning a fire broke out in the attic of the brick build ings Nos, 638 and 640 Broadway, corner of Blceckerstreet. The firemen were quickly on tile spot, but before the flames could be extinguished, the upper part of three buildings was destroyed, and three men burned to death.

The Cunard steamship America, from Liverpool on the 13th ult.. arrived at Halifax on Saturday. We print elsewhere an extended telegraphic summary of her news, which is three days later. A collision had occurred near Liverpool, between the Caradian screw steamship North American and the bark Leander, of Maine, from the effect of which the latter instantly sunk.

The Royal Mail steamship America, Captain MOODIE, from Liverpool on the morning of Saturday, the 13th inst., arrived at Halifax at 51/2 o'clock this afternoon. The America experienced heavy weather during tile whole passage, and was detained for nine hours to the southeast of Sable Island by ice.

FIRE IN BROOKLYN.--Friday night last a four-story brick building at the corner of Warren and Nevins streets took fire, and was soon consumed. The frame buildings adjoining, on Warren-street, were partially consumed. The brick house was owned by Mrs. FARRELL--loss $3,000. It was occupied by a number of families, and a corner as a barroom. Nearly everything was destroyed. Loss $1,000. No insurance. The frame buildings were owned by WM. A. COIT. LOSS $1,000. Insured.

Drune vs. Koehler.--Motion for leave to consolidate denied, with costs. Same vs. Same.--A like decision. Allen vs. Walters.--More than one year having elapsed since the death of defendant. motion for leave to continue on supplemental complaint granted.

A private letter from Bishop Payne, received in Philadelphia, and written from Cape Coast Castle, Jan. 1, mentions the death of Mrs. Payne on the 4th Of December. Intelligence has been received at Boston of the death of Mrs. Harriet Harding Williams, a Missionary of the American Board at Mosul, on the 25th of December.

The friends and partisans of Gen. SANTA ANNA are expecting the arrival of the English steamer from St. Thomas, on which vessel they suppose he has taken passage for this place, whence he will proceed in a Spanish war steamer to assume the presidency for the "last time." It was first contemplated to send him in the Benenzuela, but she having sailed yesterday,

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I do not regret your criticism of my former communication, notwithstanding your difference with me in opinion, for I think the subject requires careful investigation, and 1 am satisfied that its discussion in the columns of your paper will be more likely to lead to a good result than any other means that can be resorted to.

It is many years since ROSSINI'S opera of "Otello" was played-and very well played-in this City. It is a fact that operas bearing Shakesparean titles do not succeed with Anglo-Saxon audiences. A variety of legitimate and illegitimate reasons may be given for this, but the best reason is that our audiences do not like them.

The Senate met at 7 1/2 o'clock P. M. Mr. ELY presented a memorial from the Common Council of the City of New-York, asking the passage of a bill for the protection of gas consumers. The annual report of the Marine Hospital was presented. The bill in relation to the local assessments in Brooklyn came up from the Assembly amended.

A communication was presented from the Legislature of Kentucky, offering a regiment of Volunters for the Utah Army. Mr. HENDERSON, of Texas, appeared, was qualified, and took his seat. Several memorials from the Legislature of Iowa, making for lands for railroad purposes, were received. Mr. KING reported a bill granting the Home Arsenal to the State of New-York.

WHAT SHALL VIRGINIA DO FOR LABORERS? --The Richmond Whig commences an elaborate leader by saying that it hears " great complaints from various parts of the State of the Scarcity of labor." Now this would constitue a serious appeal to our benevolent sympathies, if the Whig meant what it said.

The R. M. steamship America--the news by which, as telegraphed from Halifax, we published yesterday morning--arrived at Boston yesterday, and her mails were forwarded in the afternoon over the New-Haven Railroad, and reached this City about 1 o'clock this morning. Our files contain nothing additional of importance.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Your Havana correspondent speaks of a difference having occurred between Commodore PAULDING and the Consul-General at Havana. I can assure you that the Consul was saluted by the Wabash upon a former visit to Havana, and that it is not customary to salute those officers more than once from the same ship.

The Board of Aldermen. The Board of Aldermen met last evening, President CLANCY in the Chair. A communication was received from the Mayor, accompanying a report of the financial affairs of the Sailors' Snug Harbor, as before published.

1857 is numbered with its fellows of the past. It died out slowly, sadly and tearfully. Every one seemed glad that it was over. A morning paper, in writing the old year's obituary, says that is leaves Chilli a prey to a thousand terrors, the play thing of caprice, wretchedly poor, divided against herself, and unable to find a secure harbor in which to rest from her wretchedness.

The charges preferred recently by Gen. HARNEY against Col. E. V. SUMNER, will probably be withdrawn. The sentiment among the army officers is quite unanimous against the General for having preferred them; the more so because it is not considered that his Brevet rank of General constitutes a sufficient reason for his refusal to meet Col. SUMNER in the field.

Many nominations were sent to the Senate today, including that of Dr. JONES, as Postmaster at Washington, and B. F. WASHINGTON as Collector at San Francisco. There is no nomination for Marshal yet, but it is now said that ROBERT OULDS, of Georgetown, will be appointed. The nomination of Cook, as Postmaster at Chicago, was considered,

To the Editor of the New- York Times: At noon to-day the horn sounded through the streets, which is the signal to look out for a whale. In a few minutes tough old whalemen enough had mustered on the beach to man several boats, and push out into the surf in chase of three whales which were spouting in the leisurely offing.

We commend those presses which have been so much concerned about Governor WALKER'S position on the Kansas question to his Indiana letter, which will be found in another column. If his most virulent enemies can find in that document anything to countenance the report that he had been bought over by the President to the support of the Lecompton fraud, they would do well to bring it to the notice of the public.

GRATITUDE OF THE FRENCH PRESS.--The editors and proprietors of the Paris journals recently entertained the managers of the railroads of France at a dinner at the Trois Frcrcs, as an acknowledgment of the favor conferred upon them by the permission to travel free upon all the lines leading from Paris.

HOPEFUL.--It is supposed that the City treasury will reap some benefit from the prevailing religious revival. Quite a number of th ex-Aldermen and ex-Councilmen who have been connected with the fraudulent trausactions of the past few years, are among those who have experienced a change of heart.

New-Orleans papers of Tuesday of last week are to hand, and contain the details of the Mexican news brought by the steamer Tennessee, at that port, also the latest news from Texas. The correspondent of the Eco National writes from Cuernavaca, on the 29th of January, that 300 bandits attacked Iguala, and were repulsed. GAOXA, one of their leaders, was killed.

In steamship Borussia, for Hamburg--Mrs. Caroline Gennert, Messrs Hager, Brodusen, J. Schuberth, M. Leon, Von Auro, B. Rosen, Hoffmann, G. O. H, Gartichs, A. Lippmann, Chas. Wagner and lady, Mrs. Vetin and family, C. B. Richard, Capt. Von Santen, Miss R. Louis, Jas. T Bacon Miss Buck, Miss Jacob Miss Nierenberg, Miss Lonise Ohlrogge C. Breton and family, John Paul and daughter, C. Kunemann, J. Roberts,

The Leader learns from Father DESMET, a Catholic Missionary, who has spent many years among the Indian tribes, that on either-slope of the Rocky Mountains there is a perfectly practicable and easy route north from Salt Lake to the British Possessions. Father D. has traveled the route several times with light wagons.

Further News by the America. We obtain some further European intelligence from our fies by the America, whose arrival at Boston was announced in yesterday's impression. The Brussels correspondent of the London News says that in political circles there is much talk about a projected expedition against Morocco.

The John Milton--How Many were Lost. The body of Captain HARDING, which has been staying, will probably be removed to New-Bedford to-day for burial Captain HASKELL, of the ship Independence, from Macro spoke the John Milton on the 25th January, in ??. 17?? 50', .

MEETING OF THE ETHNOLOGICAL SOCIETY.--There was a special meeting of the Ethnological Society at the house of Hon. GEORGE FOLSOM, In Secondavenue, on Friday night last, when a highly interesting paper was read by Dr. WILIS DE HASS, on the small stone tablet found some years since in the Grave creek Mound on the Ohio River.

From the New-Orleans Picayune. By the schooner Mary Clinton, Captain RYAN, which arrived yesterday from Vera Cruz we have received a file of the Heraldo, from the City of Mexico, to the 3d inst. They are a week later than those previously received. By the issue of the latest date, we perceive that Senor PAVON has been appointed President of the Supreme Court, and that Senor HOMERO, who had been appointed Vice-President, had died.

AT THE NAVY YARD.--The frigate Niagara is all ready for sea, and only waiting for some eighty or ninety men to complete her crew. The Secretary of the Navy has been written to, and he will probably detach that number from the general-service men on board the North Carolina.

PREFERRING KANSAS TO CUBA.--The Charleston Mercury, more than any other paper the organ of Southern feeling, speaks of the proposed purchase of Cuba as merely " an attract. ive bait.,"--" a red rag" to deceive and cajole the South, while Kansas slips away from its grasp; and it exhorts Southern statesmen not to be beguiled by Cuba into giving ground on the Kansas issue.

TOMPKINS PARK.--The adjourned meeting of the opponents of Tompkins Park, on Saturday night, was large and warm. Mr. A. G. BADGER was chosen Chairman, and Mr. JOHN FITZSIMMONS Secretary. Remarks were made by JOHN M. PHELPS. WILLIAM H. TITRALS and others, owners of property in the district of assessment, who recounted the injustice and Elegality of the attempt to fasten upon them an enormous assessment for the benefit of one or two speculators.

From the Union of Sunday. The Senate of the Uuited States have by a very large and decisive vote defeated the proposition for an increase of the United States Army. The Commanding General of the Army asks for additional troops; the Secretary of War concurs fully in the demand; and the President urges it upon Congress as a matter of public necessity. The Senate says no; and the Senate have a right to speak.

The British North American Provinces are rapidly approaching the condition of an independent power. Their increase in population, in wealth, in all the requisites for national greatness, is nearly equal to our own. The same blood flows in the veins of their people; a like Anglo Saxon spirit animates them; their laws and liberties are similar to ours.

PROHIBITION OF BONDS AND MORTGAGES AS BANK SECURITIES -The Bank Committee of the Assembly has reported a bill which, if it passes, will work an important change in the General Banking Law. It prohibits the deposit of bonds and mortgages as security for bank-note circulation, thus making stocks alone a legal basis.

The contractors for the great overland Pacific Mail are here, after additional legislation for their benefit. It is very questionable whether it can be obtained. They are bound by contract to have their line In active operation by September next, and if they fail the contract will be assuredly forfeited. The prospect, I regret to say, is not very flartering.

In the House this morning, we has some proceedings that should attract the attention ot the public. Senator SPINOLA'S Brooklyn Assessment bill came down from the Senate with a non-concurrence In the amendments which the House had made to it. A motion was made to adhere to the amendments, and to ask for a Conference Committee.

In the United States Senate yesterday, the bill which has already passed the House, making an appropriation to enable the President to carry out the treaty stipulations for the abolition of the Sound Dues, was passed. POOR BENNETT, it seems, is to be provided for. A Washington correspondent of the Tribune says he is to be appointed Charge at Vienna as soon as Congress adjourns. This is tardy justice:-why not give him the appointment now?

On Monday, at Bellevue Hospital, d. VALENTINE MUTT, on behalf of Dr. JAMES R. WOOD, the donor presented two prizes. one of fifty dollars, and the other of twenty-five, to the makers of the best two of the anatomical preparations presented for deposit in the museum founded by Dr. WOOD in the Hospital to which he is attached as Surgeon.

DISSOLUTION OF THE UNION.--We are no longer to enjoy a monopoly of this exciting topic. It has been taken up in a very earnest way by the Canadian press, as adapted to their own condition,--the precise question being whether the union of the Upper and Lower provinces shall be dissolved.

A large anti Lecompton meeting is being held this evening at Smith Nixou's Hall, in the room where Mr. BUCHANAN was nominated for President Every seat in the room was filled. Hon. ADAM N. RIDDLE, who presided at the first meeting n this county at which was presented the name of Mr. BUCHANAN as a candidate for the Presidency, was chosen Chairman.

In his admirable book on Africa, Dr. LivINGSTONE tells us that the Dutch huers who inhabit the frontiers of the Bechuana country live in a perpetual terror of disturbances and of disorder, and that they devote themselves to keeping the peace among their native neighbors by a perpetual series of onslaughts and irruptions upon the savage territory about them.

Mr. SEWARD, of New-York, introduced a hill to amend the act of March 3, 1857, regulating the carriage of passengers in steamships and other vessels. Referred.

The Santa Fe Mail has arrived, but the general news brought by it is of an unimportant description. Captain MARCY reached the vicinity of Santa Fe on. Feb. 2. His trip had been long, and attended with the loss of a large number of mules, and great hardship.

SPARKS.--In this City, or on Tuesday morning, March 2 ELIZABETH CAROLINE PLATT, wife of Samuel J. Sparks, in the 29th year of the her age. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, from the residence of her husband, 5th av., corner of 52d-st, on Thursday, March 4, at 2 o'clock.
