MY DEAR: I remember to have received your very kind letter a short time before leaving Fort Leavenworth, but pressing business matters, preparing for this expedition, prevented me then, fatigue and care, anxiety and responsibility since, from replying.

In the United States Senate, yesterday, Mr. SEWARD made his expected speech on the Kansas ?? on, which will be found reported in full elsewhere. He was followed by Mr. THOMPSON, of New-Jersey. in favor of the admission of Kansas under the Lecompton Constitution. In the House, the Senate resolution authorizing the President to appoint any officers affected by the action of the Naval Retiring Board to their former positions, was passed by seventy-one majority.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Do advise your readers, if they wish to make a good Investment, to do as I have done of late, by laying a wager that " Lecompton" will be defeated, because the New-York Herald supports it. I took that course at the last Presidential Election by betting " two to one" on the election of Mr. Buchanan, be cause the New-York Herald opposed him,

The speech of Hon. WILLIAM H. SEWARD, delivered yesterday in the United States Senate, on the Kansas Question, which we give in this morning's TIMES, will be read with all the interest due to the importance of the subject and the ability with which he has discussed it.

The Democratic State Convention met here today. J. D. PHELPS, of Simsbury, was chosen President. ?? T. PHATT, of Hariford County, and formorly member of Congress, was nominated for Governor on the first balls. The vote was as follows:

The verdict in the case of ELA vs. SMITH and others settles the dispute about the right of slavehunters to hack and hew innocent men in the streets when the Union is to be preserved. If Mr. ELA had been a disturber of the peace or had been engaged in unlawful conduct, there would have a color of justification for the process of mauling him to the verge of death ;

It was so cold all day yesterday that the ice in tbe gutters scarcely melted for an hour, and the dry snow lay on the housetops without Drawing. Perhaps this cold snap may be accounted for by the fact that the Knickerbocker Companies have just got 200,000 tons of Ice into their houses.

TWO BOYS MURDER THE SUSPECTED PARAMOUR OF THEIR MOTHER.--The Wheeling Intelligence says : " We are ?? liaoly informed that a murder was committed at Lytueton Station, on the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, last Sunday night. Mrs. MANLY, A widow woman, resides with her two sons near Lyttleton.

From the Charleston Mercury. THE RED RAG OF CUBA FOR THE SOUTIH-From time to time it has been stated in the newspapers, North and South, the Administration intends to purchase Cuba from Spain. And of late the attention, particularly of the Southern public, has been studiously invited to this most agreeable subject.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The decision of Judge HARRIS, allowing Banks to withdraw their securities from the Bank Department for the amount of their bills surrendered, is founded in justice, and has proved a vast benefit to the whole community from the time of the decision until now, and will continue to do so as long as it shall be permitted to operate in the manner it has.

A COWHIDING AFFAIR IN LOUISVILLE.-The Louisville Courier has a cowhiding item. It says: " Such an affair occurred yesterday in a popular Third-street bookstore, creating considerable excitement. The parties to the transaction are a very youthful grass widow, whose domestic troubles occesioned a separation last year from her liege lord, and the young gentleman whom she invested with strik.

PETITIONS. By Mr. SLOAN, from the Supervisors of Kings County, for the repeal of the Metropolitan Police Law. By Mr. MATHER, from the New-York Medical College, asking for an appropriation of $20,000. REPORTS. By Mr. SCOTT, by bill, to provide for the payment of interest on protested Canal drafts.

Our city election yesterday passed off ha??niously, though greater interest than usual was manifested, and the Aldermania ?? was very close. The Board stands 13 Republicans and 9 Democratic Aldermen. CHAS. II. CLARK, Democrat, was secred Mayor by about 500 majority.

Under the Senate joint resolution, which passed the House to-day, It is understood that the President is prepared promptly to nominate for restoration to the active list of the Navy many of the officers stricken down by the action of the Naval Board. The Senate confirmed numerous pending appointments to-day, including W. ROWLAND, formerly of Brooklyn, as Consul to Riga, in Russia, and Mr. WASHINGTON as Collector at San Francisco.

To Stewart Brown, Henry Grinnell, and others who have signed the call for the meeting at Tammany Hall: GENTLEMEN: The call to your fellow-citizens of New-York, " without distinction of Party," may be understood as an invitation to all loyal citizens: and as such Its quotations of the language of President BUCHANAN, and its general tenor, as a public indorsement of his course towards our fellow-citizens, render it a proper subject for comment.

THE LECOMPTON MEETINGS-TIMIDITY OR TREACHERY OF THE DEMOCRACY.--The Mozart Hall meeting was a failure. We gave a very full and impartial report of the proceedings in yesterday's TIMES, and any person who read them must have observed that they were fame and spiritless.

By the arrival of the mail, as late as due, we have New-Orleans papers containing additional Mexlean news, brought by the steamer Tennessee, at that port. The Legitimists of Guanaxuato, Queretaro and Zacatec as were at Ceiaya at latest accounts, and a general action with ZULOAGA'S forces was expected within a week.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In the illustrated London News of 13th of February it is stated that " Mr. WHITWORTH is engaged in constructing a monster printing machine for the London Times." The truth is, this press is being constructed by Messrs. R. HOE Co. of this City, at Mr. WHITWORTH'S machine shop, and is their patent.

Every season of the year makes its peculiar demands upon the humanity of man to his follow.man--for with every season the point of pressure varies of those wants and pains which make up almost the whole of life to so many in every land. The heats of Summer relieve the poor from the terrors of the famine and of frost, only to afflict them with the perils of pestilence;

It is no secret that railroads make a practice of giving free passes to a large number of persons, whose in?? it is deemed prudent to conciliate. Among those favored in this way are public officers, members of the Legislature, the Press, and it is fair to presume that the privilege is expected to be paid for by some sort of service rendered to the roads. s.

Mr. HAMMOND, of South Carolina, introduced a joint resolution authorizing the Secretary of the Navy to pay the officers and seamen of the expedition in search of Dr. KANE, under Capt. HARTSTEIN, at the same rate as has been allowed to the officers and seamen of Lieut. On HAVEN'S expedition.

VISCOUNT BURN AND THE HUDSON'S BAY COMPANY.--Viscount Body, who lately held an appointment in Canada, and has, since his return to England. contributed a series of articles on that country to a monthly magazine, has placed a notice upon the books of the House of Commons relating to the Red River settlement and the Hudson's Bay Company.

SMITH--GUNNING.--In Brooklyn, on Wednesday, March 3, at St. Ann's Church, by Rev. B. C. Cutter, D. D., and Rev. James Thomson, Rector of St. John's Church, Somerville, N. J., WELFORD R. SMITH to SARAH E., youngest daughter of the late Edward Gunning, Esq., all of Brooklyn.

Just twelve months ago to-day, Mr. BUCHANAN took the oaths of office as President of the United States. He was the elect, not indeed of the nation, but of a great national party, strong in the North and in the South. He had been supported throughout the most exciting canvass which this country has ever seen, by a combination of Northern statesmen.

DEATH OF FREEMAN HUNT.--The editor and proprietor of Hunt's Merchants' Magazine, FREEMAN HUNT, died at his residence in Brooklyn, yesterday morning, after a brief illness. Mr. HUNT was, in many respects, a man of remarkable character, and he is entitle to the credit of an inventor in publishing.

ANOTHER COURT-HOUSE IN THE PARK.--The Committee of the Board of Supervisors, who have had under consideration the petition of the Bar praying for suitable rooms for the accommodation of the Superior Court, have submitted a resolution directing application to be made to the Common Council for the immediate erection of a new Court-house on the northern corner of the Park, fronting Chambers-street, tile cost of which shall be $800,000.

The steamship Tennessee, Capt. FORBES, arrived at the Levee at 101/2 o'clock last night from Vera Cruz, which place she left on her regular day, the 21st inst., to which date we have files of papers by her. On freight the Tennessee brings $26,998 in specie. Captain FORBES reports that the American bark Flash arrived at Vera Cruz, on the 18th inst., from New-York;

HUDLER-KEYS.--In this City, on Wednesday, March 3, by Rev. Charles C. Keys, at the residence of the bride's father, EDGAR HUDLER, of Rondout, N.Y., to Miss HANNAH KEYS, of New-York City. RYDER--SPAIGHT--In this City, on Tuesday, March 2, by Rev, Jcs. B. Wakely, JAMES M. RYDER to MARY LOUISA SPAIGHT, both of New York City.

Spencer's Row, in this village, took fire last evening, and burned to the ground. The principal losers are Messrs. MOULD TALLMADGE, booksellers and druggists; ALDGATE SPENCER, merchants; PRESCOTT, jeweler; MORRIS, merchant tailor; HOWARD, dentist, and W. LANSING, proprietor of the Northern Standard.

IRVING.--In this City, on Wednesday morning, March 3, ROBERTINE BLACKWELL, wife of George Irving. The funeral services will take place at the residence of his mother. Mrs. J. T. Irving, No. 23 East 22d st., on Sunday next, at 2 o'clock P. M. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend without furtherinvitation.

The Westport (Mo.) correspondent of the Republican states that Mr. KITCHEN, who has arrived there from New-Mexico, brings intelligence of a desperate fight between the Pawnee and Arapahoe Indians on Pawnee Fork, in which ten of the former were killed and many wounded.

It will be seen by reference to the Assembly proceedings of yesterday in another part of this paper, that on motion of MR. DURYEA, of Brooklyn, an Investigating Committee has been ordered with powers to send for persons and papers, to examine into a charge that the sum of $10,000 had been raised to corrupt members of the Legislature in reference to the Brooklyn Assessment bill.

The affairs of Mexico are attracting a good deal of attention here, and the Administration is frequently discussing plans for the relief of our sister republic, which for want of a stable Government seems to have fallen into chronic decay.

There are a good many noticeable points in Senator SEWARD'S speech, which we published yesterday. Without changing his principles, or his general opinions of public affairs in the least, it is evident that he does not belong to that impracticable class of visionary politicians who refuse to change their point of view, no matter what changes or revolutions may take place around them.

The removal of the County seat of Alleghany was the special order in the House to-day. It occupied much time, and was finally carried. Under the order of reports of Committees, the Committee on Commerce and Navigation reported in favor of ordering a select committee to inquire into the affairs of the Commissioners of Emigration, and to investigate the manner in which the landing and forwarding of the emigrants is conducted at Castle Garden.

FOR CALIFORNIA--SATURDAY.-.In anticipation of a reduction in the fare to California, on account of the competition, a large number of persons, hoping to better their condition, has e rushed to the City to take passage. Some hundred Italian organ-grinders have engaged passage by the steamers of the mall line.

Both Houses of the Legislature have adjourned over till Monday. The Democratic State Convention accordingly assembled in the Chamber of the House of Representatives. VICTOR E. PIVELETT was chosen Chairman.

Mr. STUART reported adversely on the bill to amend the act of March 3, 1853, granting bounty lands to certain officers, soldiers, etc. The Senate at 1 o'clock took up the special assignment--the Kansas bill.

All old lady, named Dorothea Davis, over 80 years of age, was burned to death in Philadelphia on Tuesday morning. Dorothea and her sister Susannah (also aged,) occupied the second story back room of the dwelling No. 13 North Thirteenth-street, above Market.

The new Unitarian Church lately dedicated at the corner of Clinton and Congress streets, cost $18,000, and is calculated to seat 700 persons. It is of brick, overlaid with mastic, painted brown-a curious taste, which the Brooklyn people are crazy withIt looks well for a year or two, but when weatherworn, the bogus character of what did appear to be sand-stone is revealed, and unless very diligently repaired. the edifice looks prematurely shabby.

Our Washington correspondent writes at length concerning a plan which is discussed at the Capital for regulating the internal affairs of Mexico. He sets forth a variety of cogent reasons why the United States should at once assume the protectorate of that country,

It is a maxim of moral pathology that depraved natures always avenge the faults of their enemiesupon the persons of their friends, and poor BENNETT has just given us a signal illustration of the truth of this painful doctrine.

The announcement of the death of Commodore PERRY will be received by his countrymen with regret. He died at his residence, West Thirty-second-street, in this City, yesterday morning, at the age of 63.

There will be no performance at this house tonight, Mr. ULLMAN has judiciously closed his doors, so that there may be ample opportunities for full rehearsals of the " Huguenots," which-every one knows--will be produced on Monday.

An old "Elizabeth shilling" bearing date 1561, was passed at a store in Hartford, a few days since, by an Irish giri. The Philadelphia "Nurse Society" has received 13 pupils during the past year; 32 nurses reside in the house, of whom 26 are graduates of the institution.

Intelligence received Wednesday morning from Capt. GAGER, of the steamship Atlanta, reported ashore, states that the vessel lies safe, without having received any damage to either hull or machinery. She lies aground, but protected from the sea by the outer bar, and is discharging her cargo in good order, which will be forwarded to Charleston forthwith.

To the Editors of the Evening Post: The tardy candor which Mr. AUGUSTUS MAVERICK displays in a letter concerning the authorship of " The Diamond Lens," published in your paper of last Thursday, compensates some what for the evasive character of his remy to my first note.

The Republican State Convention met here this Morning, and the following nominations were made: Judges of the Supreme Court.-Horace P. Biddle, Q. W. Hendricks, Simon Yandes. Attorney-General.-W. T. Otto. Treasurer of State.-John A. Harper. Auditor.--Mr. Lange. Secretary of State, -W. A. Peele, Superintendent of Public Instruction.-John Young.

Five Timothys, from Ohio, viz: TIMOTHY LEAHY, 1st, TIMOTHY LEAHY, 2d, TIMOTHY DALEY, TIMOTHY KING, and TIMOTHY BURNS, all bound to California, fell yesterday into the clutches of the ticket-swindlers, and lost, jointly, $425. Having heard of the wicked ways of New-York, they obtained a letter of introduction to a business house, Messrs. NEWELL, HAEMAN McDONALD, No. 35 Murray-street.

The meeting of the Democracy in Tammany Hall, last evening, called for the purpose of celebrating the anniversary of the inauguration of President BUCHANAN, and to sustain his Kansas policy, was very large, and there was much enthusiasm.

The investigation into the alleged frauds in the Comptroller's office (FLAGG vs. SMITH) was continued yesterday before the Recorder at his office. The first witness was NATHANIEL G. BRADFORD, who testified that he had examined, as directed, the books of the Bowery Bank, in relation to any notes of Messrs. SMITH, DEVLIN, or FITZPATRICK, falling due in November.

FIRE IN FORTY-SIXTH-STREET.--At 61/2 o'clock yesterday morning a fire broke out' in the cabinet shop of Messrs. ELTING Co., in Forty-sixth-street, between Second and Third avenues. The damage was about $100. No insurance. The fire originated from the steve-pipe passing through the fire-board.

Contrary to the position assumed by General SHIELDS and other prominent gentlemen, the Senate's Committee on the Judiciary have completed a report, concluding with a resolution that Minnesota is not a State in the Union.

BUCKSTONE'S immortal Adelphi piece, the "Green Bushes," was successfully revived by Miss KEENE on Wednesday night, and with the sanction of one of the largest houses of the season. The drama is too well known to need analytical discus. sion-it is one of the best of its kind, and affords abundant opportunities for the principal artists of a company like Miss KEENE'S.

The questions raised by the sudden and stupendous revolt of the Bengal Army in India have now been deliberately transferred, by the action of the English Government, from the Northwestern Provinces of Hindostan to St. Stephen's, in London, and from the arbitrament of battle to the decision of debate.

MUST AN ASSEMBLYMAN RESIDE IN HIS DISTRICT?--Attorney-General TR?MAIN says not. Few people, we imagine, have thought so. Yet such is the opinion of the State law officer, as rendered to the Assembly on Tuesday. Is the Attorney-General right? Let us see.

The Democratic State Convention assembled this morning. The Committee on Resolutions unanimously reported, declaring that the principle Involved in the repeal of the Missouri Compromise, and asserted in the Kansas-Nebraska act, " that the people of the Territories shall have the exclusive control of their domestic in. atitutions," is the only sure guarantee against agitation in the nation, in regard to the local institution of the States and Territories;

THE ELECTIVE FRANCHISE--Connected with our elections are two great evils, illegal ballots, and the neglect of good citizens to vote The first, bad enough in itself, is made tenfold worse by the second. Who does not know that the corrupt and dishonest are sure to attend the polls;

The following incident of family history is told by the Baltimore Sun: " The late Wm. Bodman of this city dictated a will, bequeathing over $100,000. When the will was opened, it was found that after providing for his immediate family to the extent of $40,000, the testator had left the balance, $65,000, to a nephew Mr. Charles Bodman, of Cincinnati, Inspector of the Tobacco Inspection Warehouses of at city.

To the Editor of the New-York times: SIR: In your article relating to the decease of Commodore PERRY, which appears in your edition of this morning, you remark that "his son, OLIVER H. PERBY, is Counsul at Hong Kong." I think this an error, as Mr. O. H. PERBY was appointed our Consul to Canton,

The trial of HIRAM COLE, indicted for poisoning his wife in September last, was commenced at Chardon, Geauga County, Ohio, on the 1st inst. The trial is held in the Court of Common Pleas; Judge WILDER presiding. COLE is defended by Messrs. THRASHER and BLAKESLEY. He looks well, and has gained in flesh during his five months' imprisonment. A Jury was sworn in the course of the day;

The screw steamship New-York, from Greenock on the 14th ult., arrived at this port yesterday. Her European advices are one day later than those received by the America. No news of importance is reported.

To the Editor of the New- York Times: MY DEAR SIR: In a late number of your paper I find the following: "The Deaf, Dumb and Blind Asylum of Illinois has 62 mutes and 28 blind pupils-total 90. A new building is needed, the present accommodations being insufficient.

The "deck passenger" on board the steamer which plies between Panama and the Central American ports, who claimed to be the bearer of the certified Yrisarri treaty to Washington, as noted by your Intelligent Panama correspondent, must have been a humbug.

An opportunity was yesterday offered by the City Fathers to all the City Mothers and Daughters for doing a patriotic deed. In token of the respect which the metropolis feels for a distinguished naval officer, who served his country well, in peace and war alike, the banner of the City was hoisted at half-mast upon the City Hall.

We had a rumor, some days since, that Governor BANKS had appointed MARCUS MORTON, Jr., to the seat on the Bench of the Superior Court made vacant by the resignation of Judge ABBOTT. The latter gentleman, who knew that the Court even when full is overworked, notified his resignation some weeks in advance, so that government might fill the vacancy.

Some startling and significant facts have come to our knowledge. We Save hesitated to disclose them--but, after inquiry, examination and consultation, we are convinced that both duty and policy demand disclosure. The facts. we say, are startling; they are crucial.
The rumor that Gen. HARNEY'S charges against Col. SUMNER were withdrawn was erroneous. A General Court-Martial is ordered to assemble at Carlisle Barracks on the 10th inst., for Co,. SUMNER'S trial.

THE EAST INDIA CIVIL SERVICE.--The number of corenanted civil servants of the East India Company receiving annuities for past services is, according to a return lately made to Parliament, 456, of whom 414 receive annuities of ??1,000, viz.: 242 in Bengal, 98 in madras, and 74 in Bombay.

STILL ANOTHER PICTURE.--Decidedly we are in the tide of artistic good fortunes. As we lose one Murillo from the west of Broadway, another appears on the east. The Horse Fair of Rosa BONHEUR gives way to a French Gallery; the Belmontpictures are removed from the public eye only to make room for a collection of " Old Masters ;"

The steamship New-York, from Greenock Feb. 14, at 6 P. M., arrived at this port yesterday. She experienced heavy westerly gales all the passage. On the 18th was struck by lightning, which split the fore-royal mast.

It was unusually cold yesterday--the coldest day of the year thus far-the thermometer landing at 13 [degrees] above zero at 2 o'clock. The wind was strong from the northeast, and there was a great deal of cost a-living, notwithstanding that many streets are yet paved inches deep with packed snow and ice.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: You will please insert the enclosed advertisement in your daily paper to-morrow morning I wish it to be repeated as many times as you can possibly insert it, even if it should cover five or sls pages. During the past year, as you are aware, I advertised the Ledger some what extensively;

CONDITION AND POPULATION OF MEXICO.--The foreign country whose future condition most nearly concerns us is Mexico. The Richmond Whig justly objects to the character of the Mexican population in the following paragraph : "Sociatly and geographically, Mexico is the most desirable country to us on the face of the earth.

MURDER IN ONEIDA COUNTY.--The Utica Herald says that on Saturday night a terrible wife murder was committed in Manchester, Oneida County. The victim was Mrs. RACHEL ORR, and the murderer was HUGH ORR. They were Irish, but had resided in Manchester for twenty-five years.

Gen. CASS wrote a letter to the Tammany Hall Committee fully indorsing tile President's Lecompton views. and saying that the admission of Kansas will give the inhabitants the chance of at once changing their Constitution if they sec fit. He says upon this point:

The Thirteenth-street Presbyterian Church (Rev. Dr. BUNCHARD'S) was throngedyesterday afternoon by the friendsofthelamented Miss SARAH L. LEWIS, the teacherin the Sixteenth ward Primary School, (No. 39,) who was burned to death. In order that the teachers might attend the funeral, all the schools in the Ward were closed.

PETITIONS. By Mr. ELY, to remove the North River Steamboat landings to above Canal Street. REPORTS. By Mr. WADSWORTH, favorably, relative to dividends of stockholders in academies and other institutions of learning.
There was a good deal of floating ice in the rivers yesterday, though not enough to detain the ferry-boats. This ice comes down the North River, and most of it, probably, from below Newburg.

The daily prayer meetings in the City continue to be attended by great numbers, and with increasing interest. New meeting are established every week, and the attendance on none of them has been larger than during the present week. The morning meet.

The investigation into the charges made against MARCUS CICERO STANLEY, arrested on Thursday as a policy-dealer, was commenced yesterday, before Recorder BARNARD. Ex Recorder SMITH appeared on the part of the prosecution, and Mr. R. D. HOLMES for the defence. The only witness examined was CHARLES MCBEVAN.

NATIONAL SHOOTING MATCH--A three days' prize pigeon shooting match, in which a large number of crack shots from Philadelphia, Baltimore, Western New-York and different parts of New-Jersey participated, has just been concluded at Jersey City. The prizes offered were : First day. $200, $00 and $10. Second day, $100, $30 and $20.

A correspondence of a curious nature was, lately laid before the British Parliament, having reference to the case of a Sepoy of the Bengal army, who, in 1819, was removed from his regiment, then stationed at Meerut, in consequence of his having embraced Christianity.

Our advices from Mexico City are to tile 18th, and from Vera Cruz to the 21st inst. The papers add little to the information previously received by telegraph. Civil war undoubtedly exists in the unhappy Republic. Two distinct Governments are organized--one at Mexico, under the administration of ZULOAGA, the head of the Revolutionary Party;
The Board of Aldermen met on Thursday afternoon, the President, JOHN CLANCY, Esq., in the Chair. The following communication was received from the Mayor: MAYOR'S OFFICE, March, 1858.

Rear-Admiral MOHAMMED PASHA, NASUR SAID SULIMAN, (C. E.,) and Captain THESSAN, and Lieut. SADICK, of the Ottoman Navy, arrived by the Europa, on Saturday evening, and were escorted to their rooms at the St. Nicholas Hotel, by Alderman BOOLE, Chairman of the Reception Committee.

A HIGH-TIME IN THE ASSEMBLY--On Saturday the Assembly of this State enacted, with success, the part of an excited Ward caucus. The performance was witnessed by a crowd of spectators, who pronounced the act perfect. Mr. DURYEA introduced an Anti-Leeompton resolution, and moved the previous question.

It is expected that Mr. STEPIIHKNS will make report from the House Select Committee on Kansas to morrow or Tuesday. Whenever he does, the minority will raise a question of privilege that the Committee have failed to obey the order of the House to Investigate, and will move a resolution referring the subject back, with specific instructions to make inquiry relative to special points.

If the Italian assassins of the Rue Lepelletier failed in their attack upon the life of NAroLEON III., they may, at least, congratulate themselves upon the singular and unpremeditated success of their assault upon the stability of his throne, and the perpetuation of his dynasty Not by any wisdom of theirs,

By the arrival at this port of the Cunard steamship Europa, from Liverpool on the 20th ult., we receive one week's later news Proceedings in the British Parliament have been especially interesting. Lord PALMERSTON had obtained leave in the House of Commons to introduce his new India bill by a considerable Majority.

A WORD IN SEASON, HOW GOOD IT IS !--We infer from the following, which we find in the Journal of Commerce, that the Superintendent of the Assay Office has some difficulty in reconciling his friendships and his office. His special regard for Mayor WOOD nearly cost him his place, and now his love of WALKER exposes him to a similar peril.

The flags of the shipping in the harbor and on the public buildings and hotels which were flying at half mast on Friday out of respect for Comnodore MATTHEW C. PERRY, who died the day before, were displayed also on Saturday, for it had been arranged that on that day, In the graveyard of St. Mark's Church, Second-avenue, corner of Tenth-street,

HAVERSTICK.--In this City, on Saturday evening, March 8, after a protracted illness. FREDERICK J. HAVERSTICK. of the firm of B. M. E. A. Whitlock, in the 35th year of his age. The friends are respectfully invited to attend his funeral, from the Dutch Reformed Church, (Dr. Huttou's,) Washington-square, at 1 o'clock, on Tuesday, March 9. The remains will be taken to Greenwood.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I am sure there can be no foundation for the statement that President BUCHANAN has backed out of his original intention to give poor BENNETT a foreign mission. It must be a weak invention of that venerable editor's enemies.

There is no feature in Southern society more frequently commented upon than its low estimate of the value of human life. This is evidenced not so much by the number of affrays in which c is lost. as by the way in which these incidents are dealt with by the law.

The principal event of the week in the World of Amusement will be the production to-night of MEYERBEER's Opera of "Les Huguenots" at the Academy of Music. Mr. ULLMAN intends by this revival to test the public appreciation for this kind of amusement--in which the show is at least as important as the music.

No boats from Pittsburg have passed down since the 12th of February. The steamer Messenger, from Pittsburg, is fastened in the gorge near Steubenville. There are seven boats on this side the gorge, bound for Pittsburg. The river below Wheeling is open, and all boats due have arrived and the freights gone east. The steamers Metropolis and Allamont arrived here yesterday.

JOBSON, THE UNDAUNTED.--We clip the following item of intelligence from the journal of Commerce: " DAVID WEMESS JOBSON, nothing daunted by his two days' residence in jail for contempt of Court, is out with the prospectus of a weekly paper, which he proposes to publish, entitled The Red Flag. It is "intended to explain and extend Red or Bright and True Republicanism."

Secret Meetings--Significant Circulars--Public Sentiment on States Island--Movement for aPermanent Police Force at the Marine Hospital During the Quarantine Season. The receipt lately to anonymous letters by the Health Officers and Commissioners of Emigration, announcing that an attempt would be made to burn the Quarantine buildings at Stapleton, Staten Island, and warning them to remove the sick outside of the inclosure, has renewed some of the excitement of last Summer.

PETITIONS. By Mr. HUBBELL, to enlarge the powers of assignees. By Mr. SCHELL, to amend the act incorporating the New-York Warehouse Company. By Mr. SLOAN, against the railroad on South Ninthstreet, Brooklyn. Also, to establish a boundary line between Flatbush and Brooklyn.

The following-named Americans were presented at the French Court by the American Minister, on Sunday evening, Feb. 14: Miss Mason, Virginia, daughterr of Minister;) Miss Smith, Pennsylvania; Mrs. O. S. Eastman, Wisconsin; Dr. Bryan, Missouri; Dr. Webster Lindsly. Washington City: Dr. Hall Curis, Boston; Dr. Samuel M. Sargent, Cleveland, Ohio; Mr. Hawley, New-York; Mr. and Mrs. Hallett, New-York; Dr. Hunt, Boston; Mr. Whitney, New-York; Mr. Whaley, Virginia; Mr. Fred.

The announcement that Gen. HARNEY has not withdrawn his charges against Col. E. V. SUMNER. and that an unusually imposing Court-Martial has been ordered to convene at Carlisle Barracks, to try the case, will be hailed with surprise, mortification and regret, by the Army everywhere, if we may judge by the very general expression of sentiment by army officers who are within reach.

THE WHALING FLEET. According to the latest statistics, as contained in the Whalemen's Shipping List, of New-Bedford, there are, of all kinds, engaged in the whale-fishery at that place, 323; Dartmouth, 10; Westport, 20; Sippican, 5; Wareham, 1; Sandwich 1; Fairhaven, 48; Mattapoisett, 19; Nantucket, 37; Edgartown, 19; Holmes Hole, 2; Falmouth, 3; Provincetown, 28; Orleans, 4; Beverly, 2; Salem, 1;

Quite an excitement was created among some of Mr. BEECHER'S congregation after service yesterday morning, upon the discovery on the plate for the poor of a massive gold ring, which was at once identified as belonging to the wife of the most Prominent politician in the Presidential canvas of 1856.

THE. NEW KANSAS APPOINTMENTS.--As much interest is manifested, both in that Territory and here, concerning the Federal appointments which must, not long hence, be made for Kansas, we have to say that the following appear likely to succeed Of course there is as earnest and lively contention for the Federal offices in Kansas as elsewhere: Mr. SCHROEDER, for Receiver, and SAMUEL J. JONES, for Register of the District land Office at Fort Scott.

The Washington correspondent of the Journal of Commerce Writes as follows:-- "The amendment which Mr. PUGH, of Ohio, proposes to offer to the Kansas-Minnesota bill, provides that nothing in the act shall be construed to impair the right of the people to alter their form of government at all times, provided the form be republican.

WHAT ARE PURE LIQUORS ?--A bill is before our State Senate for the incorporation of a Pure Milk Company, a most laudable object, and a kind of incorporation which no one will be likely to object to; pure milk being one of the most difficult of all liquids to procure within the lamp-and-gas districts.

ANOTHER SCHOOL EXCITEMENT-AN INCONSIDERATE FIREMAN.--About 21/2 o'clock yesterday afternoon there was an alarm of fire for the First District, caused by the falling of a stovepipe in Public School building No. 14, in East Twentyseventh-street, between Second and Third avenues After the accident occurred the teacher in the room where it happened quietly dismissed his scholars in order to have the fallen pipe directly replaced.

Civic HOSPITALITY.--To treat a man "worse than a Turk," is a piece of proverbial cruclty which, in the mind of Christendom, is the very extreme of barbarism. We fear that our distinguished visitor from Constantinople must have thought that he was being used worse than a Turk ought to be, yesterday.

DAVIS.--In this City, on Monday. March 8, of consumption. Mr. ROBERT E. DAVIS, in the 38th year of his age. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend his funeral services, at his late residence, No. 203 West 15th st., this (Tuesday) evening, at 7 1/2 o'clock. His remains will be taken on the following morning to Remsen. Oneida Co.. for Interment.

Mr. GREEN'S notice of his intention to press a vote on the Kansas bill in the Senate on Monday next, is a change in the Lecompton tactics which indicates that the Lecomptonites are alarmed at the effect of the debate on the country, and are accordingly desirous to choke it off.

The frequency with which new trials are granted to convicted criminals, by the Judges of our Supreme Court, very naturally causes alarm in the public mind, and unavoidably provokes a suspicion that either the Court, by which the criminal was first tried, or the one granting the new trial, must be incompetent or corrupt.

EDUCATIONAL--Bishop DELANCEY has laid before the Committee on Colleges in the State Senate a plan for testing and stimulating College education. He proposes that in each College which receives aid from the State. the names of the ten best scholars in each class shall be sent to the Board of Regents :-that from this list the Board shall select one of each class by lot;

BUCHANAN'S HOME ORGAN DOUGLAS.-We copy a significant article from the Pennsylvanian, announcing that Senator DOUGLAS can never more belong to the Democratic Party. Grace and pardon will be extended to "the rank and file which have been seduced." They may return, but " the head conspirator" never.

Yesterday morning at 6 o'clock the carnival died at the doors of the Grand Opera. It died with a night of revelry more canaille than the others; it was Mardi-gras, the apprentice night, the night of the gamins de Paris. We are to have now three weeks respite from the street horns and the mob of mythological deities.

In steamship Cahawba, from New-Orleans and Ravana--Mrs. T. F. Hedges. C. C. Wayland, Mrs. Slingerland, Mrs. T. Hall, Miss Distanlt and servant, E. B. Gibson, John S. Stoddard, J. Coppin. A. V. H. Ellis. J. Finley. R. F. Nirodis. M. Danulo. J. Ronconi. Mrs. Birubio and daughter G. D. Hamill, E Showereff, T. Morilius and daughter J. Toloro. J. P. Morilius. M. Grovenhort, F. Powers, H. Abbott, W. Humer. J. Sadlee.

NEW-HAMPSHIRE ELECTION.--The annual State election in New-Hampshire, in which a Governor and Legislature are to be chosen, takes place to-day. For Governor, the Republican candidate is WILLIAM HAILE, of Hinsdale, and ASA P. CATE, of Northfield, is the Democratic nominee.

The Richmond Whig states the motive of tile South in pressing the admission of Kansas under the Lecompton Constitutior, and it cannot be said that the information is gratuitous. It was, in fact, greatly needed, for Northern men were puzzled to guess it. We quote: " It is obvious to all, and admitted by all, that Kansas is obliged to be a Free State.

Capt. Marcy's Mission to New-Mexico-Dreadful Sufferings on the Way-The Men Forced to Subsist on Starved Mules, Through the politeness of Dr. E. E. MARCY, of this City, we have been favored with the perusal of an interesting letter from his brother, the gallant Captain R. B. MAROY, whom Col. JOHNSTON, the commander of the Utah Expedition, had dispatched to New-Mexico,

From the Louisville Journal. It has been announced that Captain TRAVIS has accepted a wage, to shoot, at three shots, three oranges, placed upon the head and hands of a boy. It is certainly a most remarkable feat, only equaled by that of the great WM. TELL, with his" cross-bow and arrow," shooting an apple off his son's head.

SUICIDE BY A YOUNG WIFE.--Yesterday morning, Mrs. Barnts, residing on Eighth-street, near Federal, shet herself through the heart with a revolver. She and her husband, JAMES BARNES, had only been married about four or five months. The parties did not live happily in consequence of a rumor being circulatecting regard to a former intimacy of one of the couple.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: It is acknowledged that the payment of interest on deposits by the City Banks, and the consequent necessity of lending those deposits in order to make the business profitable, is one cause of excessive expansions.

Yesterday the case of The People rs. JOHN T. BALDWIN, for printing and publishing advertisements of the Lottery of SWAN Co., Georgia, in this City, came before Recorder BARNARD, at Chambers. Ex-Recorder SMITH appeared for the defence, and argued that the publication of the number drawn, as issued by Mr. BALDWIN, was not an indictable offence under the statute. He therefore moved for a discharge of the defendant.

The appointments by the Canal Board were made to-day; Erie Canal-Collectors-John Harrison, New-York; W. C. Marshall, Albany; S. H. Waterman, West Troy; John Brodt, Schenectaday; W. N. Clark, Fultonville; James Hart, Little Falls; W. H. Green, Utica; Giles Hawley, Rome; Charles H. Tucker, Jordan; Hiram Titus, Monteguma; S. Lewis, Lyons;

From yesterday's Pennsylvanian, (Buchanan;s Home Organ.) It is a popular delusion which has led many Democrats in error, that STEPHEN A. DOUGLAS differs from the President only on the Kansas question, so that if the latter be once out of the way, he will again act harmoniously with the Democratic Party. We doubt very much whether Judge Douglas ever contemplated any such thing.

The United States mail steamship Cahawba, J. D. BULLOCK, Commander, from New-Orleans via Havana, arrived at this port yesterday morning. The Cahawba left Havana on the 2d inst. At Havana everything was very dull ; business was quiet. Stock of Sugars 80,000 boxes, with some advance in figures. Shipped last week 2,500 boxes. Freights improved in demand, but not in prices.

A Correspondent of the Missouri Republican, writing from Westport, gives the following interesting information gained from a Mr. KITCHEN, who recently came through from New-Mexico: At the lower Cimarone Spring he met a large war force of Camanches. A long Indian talk ensued. They expressed the best feelings for the white brother.

CHARTER AND TOWN ELECTIONS---The Democrats have carried the city of Rochester, CHARLES ?? CLARK (Lecompton Democrat) being elected Mayor by 500 majority. The Board of Supervisors stands 14 Democrats to 14 Republicans, and 2 Americans. In Oswego, the Democratic Mayor (L. B. CROCKER) is elected. The Board of Supervisors of Erie County stand 22 Democrats to 16 Opposition.

Mr. WILSON offered a resolution instructing the Military Committee to inquire into the propriety of amending the law punishing the crimes of desertion by soldiers of the United States Army. Passed. Mr. JOHNSN offered a resolution providing for printing 10,000 copies of the Patent Office Report of last year. Laid over.

A three-story brick house, No. 45 Union-street, was destroyed by fire about 1 o'clock yesterday morning It was owned by A. F. HADLEYY, whose loss is $1,500, covered by insurance in the Atlantic Insurance Company. The basement story was occupied by J. C. HILL, boot and shoe dealer. The upper stories, where the fire originated, were not occupied.

The evidence for the prosecution, in the case of HIRAM COLE, indicted in Geauga County, O., for strong array against the prisoner. The points which the prosecution proposes to establish are as follows: That ADELIA COLE came to her death, Sept. 9 last, by poison, administered to her by her husband, the said HIRAM COLE. That arsenic had been administered to the deceased but a few days crevious to her death.

The somewhat starting suggestions of tile TIMES, in favor of an American Protectorate for Mexico, have attracted attention here, and already excited a good deal of interest. Even those who, on the first glance at the proposition, thought they were opposed to it, as impolitic and chimerical, are compelled to admit that the views you have expressed are sound and practical-and that a

The Relief Committee, of Jersey City, held their regular weekly meeting at the City Clerk's Oftice yesterday morning, with Mr. CHARLES FINK in the Chair. The sum of $41 was reported as tile amount of collections since the last meeting, which makes $755,87 received since the organization of the Committee. The Treasurer reported that there was yet about $200 in his hands.

A ROMANTIC GIPSRY STORY.--A story is afloat that some gossip has been occasioned in Cumberland County, Penn, by the following circumstances: Mr. GEORGE FRY, of Shippensburg. married a gipsy girl, belonging to a gang who were haunting the neighborhood, about three years ago. the gipsey girl's father was so enraged at this that he kidnapped her and sent her parts unknown. Mr. FEY mourned her less two years, and then married again.

In the United States Senate, yesterday, the Military Committee were instructed to inquire into the propriety of amending the law to punish the crime of desertion in the Army. Mr. GREEN, from the Committee on Territories, gave notice that he would call for a direct vote on his bill for the admission of Kansas under the Lecompton Constitution on Monday next.

THE TRIBUNE ON MEXICO.--The New-York Tribune's views of the Mexican question are characteristic, and we are happy to say somewhat different from our own. It sees nothing in the present or future of Mexico but the indebtedness of that Republic to certain "British stock-jobbers."

WALLACK'S THEATRE, Broadway and Broome-JESSON BROWN. BROADWAY THEATRE. Broadway--MADAME LOUISE TOURNAIRE--VAN AMBUROH'S MENAGERIE. PURDY'S NATIONAL THEATRE, Chatham-street--CINDER-NELLY-WILD KNIGHT--HAWK THE HIGHWAYMAN--YANKEE HEIRESS.

We give place with pleasure to the following communication, because it is certainly desirabie that specific honors conferred by foreign natins on American ability and acquirements should be specifically estimated and understood. And it is a gratifying circumstance that while the French Institute was extending its recognition to Mr. EVERETT, the Scottish Literary Institute,

In the Physiologe du Goul, by BRILLAT-SAVARIN, that gustatory author gives an account of a dinner he was Invited to in this City half a century ago, as an example of American civilization and the progress of art and refinement in the New World. There was, of course, more solidity than art in the feast, for the French cook was not, in those days, like the schoolmaster, abroad.

It is a curious circumstance that while we are always afflicted with a superabundance of one kind of gas at Albany for which we have no earthly use whatever, we should at the same time be just as regularly distressed at New-York by a deficiency in the supply of gas of another kind, for which we have a constant necessity.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: If your correspondent "S." will inquire at the Adjutant-General's office, Washington, he may learn that there is at least one case of the trial of an officer under the 25th Act. The charge was preferred by Col, SNELLING, 5th Infantry, against a lieutenant. The latter was acquitted on the ground that the Colonel waived his rank when the note was presented to him.

The Topeka humbug seems at last to have exploded. As it never had any legal validity, it has been kept afloat merely because it served as the rallying point of a political party. But it is now openly abandoned by those who have hitherto professed to regard it as the only legitimate government in Kansas.

Mr. MEYERBEER's grand opera of the Hugnenots" has been twenty years crossing the Atlantic, but battling through a snow-storm it came safety into port last night; and of this composer it may be honestly said that he has always received the fullest justice at the hands of our operatic managers. Not only in this work, but in every other that has been offered to the American public,

COURAGE OF THE EMPRESS EUGENIE.--You know the invariable composure of LOUIS NAPOLEON on the 14th ult., and ever since; the London Morning Past, in its dramatic narrative, used the phrase-- "he handed out his trembling Empress." This has given some umbrage, for at the moment, a police officer. Bleeding in the face, rushed to open the door of the imperial carriage; the Empress supposing him, from his ghastly visage, to be one of the assassins,

The Frauds Reports on the Fifty-second street Case, and that of Henry Erben, Adopted--Stopping the Pay of the Metropolitan Police. The Board of Aldermen met last evening, President Clancy in the Chair.

A grand farewell banquet, previous to his departure for Africa, was given to Dr. LIVINGSTONE, in London, on the 14th ult. Many distinguished personages, including scientific and literary men and members of Parliament, were present.

SMALL-POX IN THE CITY-The small-pox has carried off an average of 18 persons per, week in this city, so far this year. From the weekly report s of the City Inspector, it appears that the number of deaths per week from this cause, for two months past, have been as follows:

I came southward expecting to see the wheatfields glisten in the Spring sunshine, the trees arrayed in their bright vernal liveries, and the flowers in the public grounds here at the metropolis beginning to display their beauties. But I find that " the Winter of our discontent is not made glorious Summer," but continues to chill" the lap of Spring," whose colors, thus tar, are decidedly an invisible green.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: A good deal of consideration has been given latterly to the buildings erected for our public schools, in consequence of the many distressing catastrophes by fire that have followed each other in such rapid succession this present Winter. Though I am but a very insignificant unit in the community of NewYork, yet as a parent who has five children in our Ward School.

A MAN MISSING.---PETER COHILL, a man fifty years of age, residing at No. 164 Perry-street, disappeared last Tuesday evening, and is still missing. he is said to have left his house in company with his brother-in-law, PATRICK KONE, and PETER B. GASTKONE says that the last he saw of him was on Thursday evening, about 9 o'clock, at the corner of Washington and Charles streets,

For several meetings past the Brooklyn Aldermen have been quit lively in the matter of salaries--increasing them 20 and 25 per cent., on the suggestion of officials. Last Monday evening a gentleman who had been missed in the general raise applied to be placed on an equal footing with his more favored as sociates.

Mr. HOUSTON presented the joint resolutions of the Texas Legislature relative to a Southern State's Rights Convention, In the event of the rejection of the Lecompton Constitution. Mr. MASON, of Virginia, moved for the further consideration of the bill for the relief of Commodore JONES.

The Republican learns that an attempt has been made to abduct tile Judges of the Election at the Delaware Crossing precinct to prevent their giving in their evidence to Gov. DENVER as requested by CALHOUN; and that ISAAC MUNDIE, one of the Judges, was shot in the head and killed.

The New-Orleans Picayune says that " the accomplished daughter of a fellow-citizen, a lady whose fame as an amateur of tile piano-forte is familiar to a wide circle of friends and acquaintances. is on the eve of going to Paris to become a pupil of the Conservatoire, for the purpose of perfecting herself as a performer on her favorite instrument."

FREE NEGROES IN KANSAS.--During the debate of Monday last in the United States Senate, Mr. FOSTER, of Connecticut, made it one of his objections to tile Lecompton Constitution that it forbade the residence of free negroes in Kansas. To this Mr. GREEN, of Mis, souri, retorted that the Topeka Constitution contained a like prohibition.

From the Boston Journal. The following letter, from Rev. WALTER DICKSON to his son, gives the particulars of the horrid ou rage from which he and his family were sufferers, of which we have already had some account. The STEMBECKS (FREDERIC and JOHN) alluded to in the letter married the daughters of Mr. DICKSON:

The following petition was presented to Mayor TIEMANN yesterday: To Hon. Daniel F. Tiemann, Mayor, , President of the Board of Health of the City of New- York: The undersigned respectfully of commerce conare engaged in various branches of commerce connected with the port of New-York; that in the transaction of their business they have often been compelled to submit to the burdensome exactions of the Quarantine laws and regulations;

The Senate Committee on Territories, which was to have reported the bill creating the Gadsden Territory before this, has laid the subject over again until Thursday next, having disagreed upon the question of boundary. Advices by the Overland Mail, just arrived from Arizona, state that the people, in mass meetings, have thoroughly sustained Lieut.

PETITIONS. By Mr. SPINOLA, from the Supervisors of Brooklyn to abolish the City Court. Also, to amend the charter of Brooklyn by regulating tile trade of tinkers and peddlers. REPORTS. By Mr. ELY, favorably, to amend the Brooklyn Water Act.

Extracts from n Letter to Governor Cumming, by Dr. Hurt, Indian Agent in Utah. Dr. HURT, Indian Agent in Utah, has written a letter to Governor CUMMING, giving an elaborate representation of the condition of affairs in the Territory, from which we make the following extracts:

A large vote was thrown at our State Election to-day. WM. HAILE, the present Governor, was supported by the Republicans and Asa P. CATE, Of Northfield, by the Democrats. The returns so far indicate the reelection of Mr. HALE, for Governor, by an increased majority over that of last year, when he received 34,474 against 31,235 given for Mr. WELLS, the Democratic candidate.

THE ABOLITION CONVENTION.--Itreally seems to do our Abolition fellow-citizens good to get together once or twice a year and free their minds. Such a gathering was held in Albany on Monday. It was about equally divided between the colors and the sexes. The President was Rev. SAMUEL J. MAY.

A PATRIARCHAL CONTROVERSY.--Mr. HENRY EDMOND SPRING RICE, presumably a Briton, and avowedly a friend of the late Col. WADE HAMPTON, of South Carolina, writes a letter to the New-York Evening Post in vindication of the character of that gentlemen from a charge, preferred by some Western journal, of cruelty in the treatment of his slaves.

More News from Kansas. Speaker ORR'S Kansas Concealment Committee, though doing their best to suppress information, are not able, wholly, to succeed. They manage to dam up the official channels only; the telegraph and the press are beyond them.

CAMPBELL--In this City, on Monday, March 8, in the 24th year of his age, SAMUEL CAMPBELL. His friends, and those of his father, john Campbell, and of his grandfather, Dr. John Augustine Smith, are requested to attend his funeral, at the Church of the Ascension, corner of 5th av. and 10th st., at 10 o'clock 03 Wednesday morning, without further invitation.

JOHN H. To the Editor of the New-York Times: If you wish well to your advertising subscribers, would it not be proper for you to give them a gentle hint, that when one advertisement occupies a whole column, and sometimes a whole page, it is sure to prevent the sale of the article which they thereby hope to effect ? The old adage instinctively rises to the mind--" Good wine needs no bush."

MARGARET CAMERON made affidavit before the Mayor that her husband. ALEXANDER CAMERON, was held a prisoner in the house No. 19 Washington street by MARY BOYD and MICHAEL HART, and that she feared he would suffer bodily harm, or be robbed of a California passage-ticket, worth $100, which he had in his possession. An officer was sent, who arrested HART and MARY BOYD, ogether with CAMERON, and brought them up.

After the stormy session of Saturday, the House settles down to work, apparently, with a will, but with little ability to make progress. Two sessions a day are to be held in future. To-day it was "general orders," and in their order only two or three bills of minor importance were considered. IN THE SENATE there is more work done, or rather projected, than in the House.

DESTRUCTIVE FIRE IN TROY. TROY, N.Y., Tuesday, March 9. A fire broke out at about 8 o'clock this morning, in the Troy Bleach Works, on Ida Hill, owned by WILLIAM R. YOWART. The main building was entirely destroyed, but the storehouse, containing several thousand dollars worth of goods,and the drying house, were saved.

BROOKLYN CONCERT.--The citizens of Brooklyn, in spite of the cold weather, are working themselves into a fever of enthusiasm in favor of a new singer, Miss MARIE ELINA COWRAN, who is to make her debut in a concert at the Brooklyn Athenaeum next Thursday evening. She is a pupil of the celebrated BASSINI, who has consented to grace the occasion by his presence, and who is announced to accompany her upon the piano.

We find in the last Anderson (s. C.) Gazette a lengthy letter from Col. ORR, in response to a communication addressed to him by J.P. REED, R F. SIMPSON and others, requesting him again to be a candidate for Congress at the October election Col. ORR acknowledges the compliment conveyed in the request, but positively declines acceding to the wishes of his friends.

THE UTAH EXPEDITION--A CORRECTION CONCERNING THE RATIONS--The St. Louis Republican says "J. M. HOCKADAY, Esq., District-Attorney of the United States for the Territory of Utah, was in this city yesterday, on his way to Washington, having dispatches for the Government. Mr. HOCKADAY lett Camp Scott early in January, and Henry's Fork of Green River about the 10th, and suffered no inconvenience from the weather until his arrival at Fort Kearney.

A printed copy of Mr. SLUYTER's report to the Assembly on the " causes of delay in Courts of Justice" has just reached us, and a reperusal of it suggests one or two remarks upon the points recently raised by our correspondent "B."

From the Knoxville Whig, When WALKER was arrested, and held to bail in the sum of $2,000, to appear at the Federal Court in New-Orleans, Colonel SLATTER, a rich old bachelor in the city, went his bail. SLATTER is the owner of the City Hotel and the New-Orleans Arcade, two houses which he rents for about $40,000. He has $40,000 in the Nicaraguan enterprise, and has been the friend of WALKER all the time.

THE REPORTERS EJECTED.--We begin to have hopes of the Assembly. Yesterday, being the sixty-third day of the Session, that body expelled the Reporters. Wisdom is manifestly on the increase in Albany. Pity that the hundred days are more than half run out. Otherwise we should witness marvels at the Capital.

The contemplated movement to get to get the House to instruct the Select Committee on Kansas to make specific investigations was abandoned to-day, from a conviction that if it was attempted it would give STEPHENS an opportunity to make his Lecomptonite report, and get before the country to preoccupy the public mind before the vital facts are out.

Doctor WILLIAM TURNER, who died at his residence in this City on Monday last, after a brief illness, was a native of New-York, and at one time a prominent politician when the Whig Party was in the ascendency. He was a son of the publisher of the old New-York Gazette, once the the lead. ing daily paper of this City, and was for several years connected with it in an editorial capacity.

We have already chronicled the effect of the foul weather of Monday upon the nerves and aspirations of Alderman BOOLE and Councilman VAN TINE, the principal members of the Committee appointed to do honor to Vice-Admiral MOHAMMED PASHA and suite. They were very much affected-so much so that they -spent the entire of the following night in bewailing the climatological misfortunes of the day, and in beseeching Old Winter to smile upon them.

FREAKS OF THE STOCK MARKET.--In the original "Autocrat of the Breakfast Table," which appeared twenty years ago, the witty author published that ingenious fable about all the world having once agreed to give a simultaneous shout on a specified day and moment, under the belief that the noise would be so great that it could be heard by the men in the moon, who would probably give a shout in response.

The lady's grave was green, And I car it oftentimes was seen A gentle boy, with thoughtful mien.

At the Deaf and Dumb Asylum in this City the influence of the religious revival which is now progressing has not been unfelt, The pupils manifest increasing interest in their Bible lessons and religious exercises.

The New-Hampshire State election took place yesterday, and, from the character of the returns received at a late hour last night, there is no doubt but the Republicans have again carried the state. One hundred and twenty-nine towns heard from gives HILE, Republican, 23.892 votes, and CATS, Democrat, 20,001. The Republicans have elected 146 Representatives as far as heard, and the Democrats but 72.

THE LATE STABBING AFFRAY.--PRIER, the German, who was stabbed in an affray at a lagerbier saloon in Jersey City last week, is improving, and it is thought that he will recover. CHARLES BACHMAN, one of the men arrested for the assault, has been admitted to bail by Coroner MC NNALLY, but CHRISTIAN WARNER is still kept in jail.

ROBERT T. BYRNE was brought before Justice BLACHLEY yesterday, on a warrant charging him with fraud. The accused waived an examination, and in default of bail was committed to jail, to await his trial in the Court of Sessions The brother of accused has been doing business in Detroit, and, it is alleged, recently made a sham failure.

We have had cold weather for the past 30 hours; cold for this climate, though the mercury ranged no lower than about 22 [degrees] or 24 [degrees] for a short time this morning. Have had an unusually warm Winter until this present "term," which makes us the more susceptible to it. In February the fruit of the mulberry tree ripened: a thing not noticed here for many years before.

THE NEW CAPITAL OF CANADA.--The London Globe officially announces the selection of Ottawa as the new Capital of Canada. The Post also, a semiofficial print, does not believe that the Canadians will be satisfied with the choice. That journal says: "We do not believe that the cities which have unsuccessfully claimed metropolitan hours, will, without respectful remonstrance, submit to her majesty's decision. A discussion took place upon the resolution offered by Mr. JOHNSON, of Arkansas, for the printing of 10,000 copies of last year's patent report.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Employment is scarce! This is the general cry, risen by a fearful realty. Especially among females, there are many idle hands, longing for some kind of work to enable them to provide for themselves and those dependant on their efforts, but "No work" is almost the only answer they receive.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The destitution and consequent suffering in the City, and particularly in the Fourth Ward, is more alarming than it has been in any previous year or season, and except immediate rellel is benevolent by some benevolent friends, the number of deaths by starvation and exposure will soon fearfully increase.

USE OF DETECTIVES--The recent discovery of a heavy defalcation in the Union Bank is said to have been made through the instrumentality of one of the Detective Police Officers, who gave information that one of the book-keepers of the bank was in the habit of frequenting a certain gambling-house.

Several bills are pending in our State Legislature intending to remscy the alleged abuses in the measurement of gas in the several cities of the State. The following is a synopsis of the most important of them: MR. DATIGN'S BILL IN THE ASSEMBLY.

James Rodgers, Platn?? in error vs. The People, Defend?? in error--SUTHERLAND, J.--Although the statute under which this case has been brought here by writ or error, gives this Court the power to grant a new trial, if the Court were satisfied that the verdict against the prisoner was against the weight of evidence, (Laws of 1855, p. 613. ??) yet we cannot say in this case, that the verdict was against the weight of evidence.

FIRE IN A TENEMENT HOUSE--SUPPOSED INCENDIRISM.--About 10 o'clock Tuesday evening a fire was discovered in the basement of the tenement house No 394 Ninth-street. One of the rooms in the basement was unoccupied, and a large quantity of shavings had been piled against one of the board partitions and then set fire to.

HARRISON.--In this City, on Wednesday evening, March 10 after a short illness, JOSEPH W HARRISON, printer. Due notice will be given of the funeral. SHAW.--In this City on Tuesday, March 9, at his late residence, No. 352 Bowery, GEORGE M. SHAW, son of Wm. G Shaw, M. D., of Wickford. R I. Friends and relatives are invited to attend the funeral, at St. Bartholomew's Church on Friday, 12th inst., at 12 o'clock, without further notice.

An Anti-Lecompton State Convention assembled here at 11 o'clock this morning. Col. MONYPENNY presided. Letters were read from Governors WISE and WALKER. In the afternoon Ex-Secretary STANTON made a powerful and an effective address of three hours length. He was listened to with marked attention. A series of resolutions, expressing the sense of the convention, were unanimously adopted.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: DEAR SIR: I live in the country, and enjoy that mode of existence. Still I am your constant reader and take an interest in city affairs. I perceive you allow people to ask you all sorts of questions, and are kind enough to give the information they seek. Now I want to ask you a question.

THE UNION BANK DEFALCATION.--It seems that the officers of the Union Bank have been warned almost daily, for the last two or three weeks, that their book-keeper was robbing them, and yet they took no precautions, and in fact paid no attention to the warning whatever.

REPORT OF THE KANSAS INVESTIGATING COMMITTEE.--Yesterday Mr. ALEXANDER H. STEPHENS attempted to present the majority repot of the Committee appointed on Mr. HARRIS' motion in reference to the frauds attending the Lecompton Constitution. Objection was made by Mr. SHERMAN, of Ohio. Mr. STEPHENS remarked that, as his report would not come up in its regular order for a month, he would print it on his own responsibility.

The Court-Martial ordered by the President for the trial of Col. E. V. SUMNER, U S. A., on charges preferred against him by Gen. HARNEY, will open at the Barracks in this place to-morrow. The trains which are just in, this afternoon, bring a large majority of the officers detailed to constitute the Court-Martial.

Senator HAMLIN, of Maine, concluded his speech against Lecompton this afternoon. It is the ablest senatorial effort of his life. His vindication of the laboring classes of the North against the aspersions of Senator HAMMOND was a splendid success. In the House, Mr. BASKIN, of New-York, made a powerful speech against Lecompton.

A few short months since and PALMERSTON was the fancy man of England. Few statesmen had ever been borne to her councils on a prouder or broader swell. His name was as a charm to dispel all misgivings and disarm all doubts. His star has, however, at least for a moment, fallen from its ascendant place. The nation has had its dream and is awakening.

The final decision of the New-Jersey Legislature against locating Quarantine at Sandy Hook, has opened the whole matter afresh among the property holders and other citizens of Staten Island. The two sections of the Island, however, are now arrayed in determined hostility to each other as to the line of policy to be pursued, notwithstanding the efforts made within a few months to reconcile conflicting interests, and harmonize the opposition.

BENJAMIN K. BROTHERSON, first book-keeper in the Union Bank, charged with embezzling over $100,000 of the funds belonging to the Bank, has not yet been arrested, though slace his sudden disappearance, on Monday, vigilant efforts have been made by the Police to learn his where about. He is believed to have smuggled himself on board the steamer which left yesterday for Aspinwall.

To the Editor of the New-York Times : We are glad to see a Movement to reform existing abuses and defects in legal administration Our judicial system is decidedly the worst that our State ever had We have eight Judicial Districts. each expounding law and the code varionsly, sometimes by one Justice and sometimes by the General Term of four Judges with three sitting Judges ;

VOICE OF THE GRANITE STATE.-- New-Hampshire pronounces emphatically against Lecompton. HAILE, the Republican candidate for Governor, will have the large majority of five thousand. If Mr. BUCHANAN'S Administration is hereafter to retain any sort of foothold in the Free States, it must be by the defeat of its insane Kansas policy.

By the arrival of the Kangaroo at this port and the Cunard steamship Canada at Halifax, we are placed in possesion of one week's later advices from Europe. The news is great interest and importance. We received by the Eurepe, and printed in our edition of Monday, the debate in the British Parliament on the Conspiracy Bill, which, our readers will remember, resulted in the defeat of the Ministry.

The ship Underwriter, Capt. ROBERTS, from Liverpool Jan. 23, arrived yesterday afternoon, bringing 25 Mormons, all Americans, who have been on a visit to various points of England and the Continent, as missionaries of the Church of Latter Day Saints, and upon business affairs. There is only one lady among them.

The steamer Delta, from St. Thomas on the 23d ult., and Bermuda on the 2d inst., arrived here last night. The ship Samuel Appleton, from Australia for Boston, called off Bermuda on the 15th ult. and landed her captain, who was sick, and then proceeded on her voyage.

The principal Market Places are WASHINGTON DROVE-YARDS, 44TH-STREET: BROWNING's, on Sixth-street; CHAMBERLIN'S, on Robinson-street; and O'BASH's on Sixth street. Out reporters refer to those regular markets. Irregular sales are sometimes made at Bergen Hill, N. J., and from the Hudson River Boats.

THE TEN-THOUSAND-DOLLAR BRIDERY CASE--The investigation into the Brooklyn Assessment Corruption charge has been dropped by the Select Committee of the Senate, in whose hands it proved to be an exceedingly hot potato. Mr. DAYTON, of the Assembly, professed himself able and willing to sustain it. But the Committee couldn't wait.

HARRISON.--In this City, on Wednesday evening, March 18 after a short illness. Mr. JOSEPH W. HARRISON, printer, aged 51 years, 2 months and 22 days. The relatives and friends are invited to attend his funeral from the Church of the Messiah, on saturday afternoon March 13, at 2 o'clock, without further notice The remains will be taken to Greenvard.

The steamer Tennessee with dates from Cruz to the 7th and from the City of Mexico to 5th inst., has arrived here. The papers are filled with the details of civil in the States of Guerrero, Michoican, Queretera Guanajua to which display the strongest disaffection to the new Government.
The Earl of DERBY is filling at this moment in England a position which he has once before occupied, but which it can hardly be agreeable to a statesman of spirit and ambition to hold.

The steamship Tranessee arrived at New-Orleans yesterday with news from Vera Cruz to the 7th, and from the City if Mexico to the 5th inst. The condition of affairs in the county is growing worse and worse civil war is raging in four or five of the States, and the disaffection towards the Zu oaga Government serious to be gaining strength every day.

The British mail steamship America left for Liverpool rid Halifax, at 3 1/2 o'clock, P. M., as announced yesterday. She was detained a short time by touching on the mud, the tide being unfavorable, which is the extent of her being aground. She passes Boston Light 4 1/2 o'clock.

FIRE IN LIBERTY-STREET.--About 6 o'clock Wednesday evening a fire was discovered in the basement of No. 108 Liberty-street, occupied by PONANS BROTHERS, shirt manufacturers. The stock was damaged about $500 worth. Insured for $2,000 in the Manhattan; and $1,500 in the Irving. The first floor was occupied by A. FRANK Co., fancy dry goods.

The truest Democrats of the North nesicated to accept the issue, and for a time it was doubtful whether the Administration would not be deserted by the entire party in the North.

The most striking proof of the desperate of Lord PALMERSTON'S position at the see reading of the Conspiracy bill, has been forded by the nature of the aid the thought proper to call in when the battle was already lost.

The Turkish Admiral and suite made an excursion down the bay yesterday on board the new Revenue latter Harria Lane, after paying a visit to the Navy-Yard, and as the day ?? remarkably fine, and the objects he inspected were of the kind he came to see, his Highness must have felt himself more at ease and enjoyed himself better than on any other occasion since his arrival.

The steamer Phincas Sprague, from Boston for Philadelphia, ran foul of the schooner Chelsea, off Nauset, on the night of the 9th inst., and sunk her immediately. The crew were taken off, and landed at Holmes Hole next day. The schooner was loaded with oak timber.

At a meeting of the American Geological and Statistical Society, Thursday evening, HENRY E. PIEHREPONT, Esq., presiding, the section of the Society on Meteorology was organized. A paper was read by J. DISTURNELL on the influence of climate upon civilization, and the distribution and condition of the animal and vegetable kingdoms.

ANTE-MORTEM EXAMINATION.--Coroner CONNERY, yesterday, took the ante-mortem examination of Mrs. BARBARA HANDE, who was stabbed in the head with a pair of shears a few days since, at her residence, No. 86 Avenue, B, by JOSEPH BECK, a journey-man tailor in the employ of her husband.

No clue has as yet been obtained to the when abouts of BROTHERSON, the Bank Defaulter, Mr. JAMES , H. MOTT, his alleged accomplice, was yesterday take before the recorder, and his examination set do for to-day at 2 P.M.

The coup d'elat of the South Americans in the House to-day, has greatly confused the Democracy. Lecompton was the test, and the Administration was beaten by the votes of Messrs. DAVIS, HARRIS and RICAUD, of Maryland; UNDERWOOD and MARSHALL of Kentucky; and GILMER, of North Carolina.

Some of our City cotemporaries are severely exercised in their minds on the question of the extradition to the French Government of Colonel ALLSOT, the Englishmen accused of complicity with PIEERI and ORSINI in the recent affair of the RUE Lapelletier and who combines in his own person the curiously contradictory character of stock-broker and fanatic, The fanatic advocates his surrender.

Some days ago Mr. LANING, of Erie, offered a resolution raising a Committee to ascertain whether any money had been sent from this State to aid the freemen of Kansas in the defence of their rights. The resolution indicated the Kansas Aid Society as the party guilty of the heinous offence of sympathizing with freemen in a struggle against the encroachments of Slavery.

Rev. NATHANIEL W. TAYLOR, S. T. D., a telegraphic notice of whose death we published yesterday morning, was a native of New-Milford, Luchfield. County, Conn., and was born in June, 1786. His ?? father, Rev. NATHANIEL TAYLOR, was pastor of the Congregational Church in New-Milford for more than fifty years.

Mr. HARRIS TRIUMPH.--The vote of 112 to 97, by which the House of Representatives yesterday refused to permit Speaker ORR and Mr. STEPHENS to silence Mr. HARRIS, is a significant indication of the feeling of the body.

Yesterday the Board of Commissioners of the Metropolitan Police met at their office, in accordance with previous adjournment. All the members were present, and an immense concourse of applicants and spectators crowded the room, the hall and the street in front, even to the opposite sale. The minutes of the former meeting were read and, after a verb a correction at the instance of Mr. BEWIN, were approved.

Mr. CAMERON presented a memorial from citizens of Pennsylvania, favoring a line of mail starters between the city of Philadelphia and the Empire of Brazil. Mr. CAMERON also presented a resolution, calling on the President for the instructions sent to the U.S. Marshal in Utah. Mr. HUNTER withdrew his motion for an evening session.

The New-York Chamber of Commerce held a special meeting on Thursday evening at Clinton Hall, P. PERIT in the Chair. The special order was the new location, and the motion to reconsider the resolution approving of the warehousing system.

IMPORTANT METEOROLOGICAL DISCOVERY.--The Secretary of the Navy has received a letter from Lieutenant MAURY respecting a plan for computing the force of the wind, by which the latter gentleman thinks it probable that the liability to disasters on our Northern lakes may be obviated to a considerable extent.

Our readers are aware that movements have been for some time on foot in the extreme Southern States for a restoration of the African slave trade. One branch of the Louisiana Legislature has passed a bill authorizing the importation of free blacks as apprentices for fifteen years.

The Subjugation of Canton is an event in which the commercial world is deeply interested. It is pregnant with important results. With the fail of the imperial city, the war, in all probability, was at once opened and closed, for we do not anticipate that any serious opposition will again be offered to the Anglo French arms.

That the Enquirer miters the sentiment.

A special meeting of the Common Council was held last evening, to receive reports of Committees. The Finance Committee, to whom was referred the general subject of salaries, reported in favor of fixing the pay of Special Deputy Collectors of Taxes at $3 per day, for one hundred days.

The Harbor Police, which have been interrupted in their operations by the lee, will put their boats in use to-light, and probably continue without any further obstruction. The force consists of 26 men, who have done patrol duty along the piers of the North and East Rivers, half the number being on duty at time.
