SCHOONER METAMORA ASHORE--LOSS OF CARGO. NEW-LONDON, Conn., Friday, March 12. The Schooner Metamora, of Providence, from Elizabethtown, N. J. Bound to Providence with a cargo of coal, went on to Barlletl's Reef at about 2 o'clock this morning. Cargo a tolal loss.

The Special Committee on the affairs of Castle Garden met at 3 P. M. Mr. DEVLIN appeared, and stated that he was requested by the Commissioners of Emigration to attend before the Committee, to protect their interests. He asked permission to attend the meetings.

REPORTS. By Mr. DARLING, favorably, to allow the New-jersey Northern Railroad Company to lay a portion of their road in this State. By Mr. AHES, (by bill,) to allow HENRY RUGGLES to build piers and bulkheads in Brooklyn, near the Navy Yard.

Advices from Salt Lake to Jan. 25 have been received, by the arrival at Council Bluffs of Mr. WINGATE, who came through the Mountains by a route known only to the Mormons, and passable only in single file for a great distance. There was no snow in Salt Lake Valley, and very little inthe mountains.

The Canada brings us the names of the new British Ministry, as finally formed and published in the London journals of Feb. 26. They do not differ materially from the list reported by the telegraph, with the single and not unimportant exception that the name of Lord STANLEY, of Alderley, turns out to have been substituted for that of Lord STANLEY.

The contest in the House to-day is not claimed as a triumph by either side. The question was upon sustaining the Char, and involved a delicate point. Three Anti-Lecompton Democrats- GROESHESK, HALL and LAWRENCE, OF Ohio--voted against laying she appeal on the table, under a companies that to would be withdrawn, which HARRIS OF Illinois unwisely agreed to.

The mail with Galveston dates to the 2d inst is to hand. The steamer Governor Pease, with l,400 bales o cotton, was burned in Trinity River on the 28th ult Six hundred bales of the cotton were insured. No lives were lost. There was a fire at Liberty on the same day, and property amounting to $10,000 was destroyed.
The Tribune persists in thinking a Mexican Protectorate " absurd," and says a protectorate "means precisely a conquest, and nothing else." It does not mean that " precisely," or that at all.

The Court-Martial reassembled at 9 o'clock this morning. Col. FRANCIS LEE took his seat, having recovered from his temporary illness. The Court is, therefore, full, with the exception of Gen. Wool, who will not be here at all, for reasons explained yesterday.

The Council Bluffs Bugle, of the 3d, says that Mr. WINGATE has just arrived, from Salt Lake Jan. 25, and reports that there was no snow in Salt Lake Valley, and very little on the mountains. He came by a route known only to the Mormons, through the mountains, by which only horsemen in single file can pass. The army has not discovered any trace of it.

Our report of the proceedings of the Court Martial now silting upon Col. SUMNER at Carlisle Barracks, published in another column, gives a complete view of the difficulty between that officer and Gen. HARNEY.

JACOR H. MOTT, arrested as an accomplice of BROTHERSON, the defaulting book-keeper of the Union Bank, was, on Thursday evening, delivered into the custody of the Sheriff, and is not confined in Eldridge-Street Jail.

STATE FINANCES.--The Journal of Commerce in an editorial upon the deplorable condition of the State Finances, shows that the debt is constantly increasing, while the Canal revenues, from which it is be paid, are steadily diminishing.

Before Judge Hall. The Grand Jury brought in indictments in the following cases: The United States vs. Ferdinand Crocker.--An indictment for manslaughter. Another indictment was found against this defendant for cruel and unusual punishment.

The unexpectedly early arrival of Col. HARRIS, from New-York, enabled the Court-Martial to complete its proceedings this afternoon. Col. SUMMER having waived the privilege of calling Col. CROSSMAN from St. Louis, in order to avoid delay, the labors of the Court have been summarily disposed of.

The thrice-illustrious Chevalier WIKOFF, of Terpsichorean, diplomatic and matrimonial renown, is now, for the comfort of his country and the preservation of the peace of Europe, present in the city of Paris, where he is busily occupied in cementing afresh the somewhat shattered ties of the Anglo-French alliance.

The Emperor NAPOLEON III, is very fond of quoting the sentiments and the language of his illustrious Uncle. The MOTT BROTHERS' last failure was in John-street, and the present MOTT resides, not in Thirty-second-street, but in No. 67 West Thirtyseventh-street. The MOTT estate, located between Fiftieth and Sixtieth streets,

MARCUS CICERO STANLEY went before the Re border on Saturday and purged himself of contempt He did not appear on Thursday last when summoned to appear as defendant in the lottery examination now ending, and was accordingly held by His Honor on a charge of contempt of Court. On Saturday he made an affidavit, in which he stated that it was not his intention to disregard the subpoena,

The subject of imposing canal tolls upon railroads, which has been more or loss discussed for several years, is now placed before the Senate in the form of a bill from the Chairman of the Standing Committee on Canals, lion. H. J. STOW, of Niagara County.

RESIGNATION OF SENATOR DOUGLAS--THE RUMOR CONTRADICTED-There is no foundation for the rumor telegraphed to the Sunday Herald that Mr. DOUGLAS was about to resign his scat in the Senate. This statement is distinctly contradicted on the best authority that of Mr. D. himself.

THE SUBMISSION CLAUSE.--An unusually lively scene occurred in the United States Senate on Saturday. Mr. WADE, of the Ohio, had been speaking on the Kansas question, and alluded to the statement made on the 9th of December last, to the effect that in the original draft of Mr. DOUGLAS' Enabling Act there was a clause providing for submitting the Kansas Constitution to the people,

The large hall in the Medical College, corner of Twenty-thirty-street and Fourth-avenue, was not half large enough to contain the would which endeavored to occupy it, Thursday night, in the occasion of the annual Commencement. These ?? and gentlemen who were early enough to get seats within, listened to a very eloquent Valedictory addressed to the graduates, delivered by Dr. CHANDLLE R. GILMAN, one of the Professors of the Institution.

FIRE IN TENTH-AVENUE.--At 11 1/2 o'clock, Saturday night, a fire was discovered in the basement of the three-story frame house No. 411 Tenth-avenue. MICHAEL QUINN occupied the lower part of the building as a feed-store, and the upper part as a dwelling. Mr. QUINN sustained, by fire and water a loss on his mock and furniture of 81,000, which is fully covered by insurance in the North River Insurance Company.

BRUTAL ASSAULT UPON A RUNNER.-THOMAS MALONE, who is employed as a runner at the Northern Hotel, foot of Cortland-street, was shockingly heaten and kicked early on Saturday morning, by DAVID Cox, one of the Short Boys who hails from a Grib in Cedar-street. The assault was make in the bar-room of the hotel, and MALONE says without provocation; his eyes were blackened and very must swollen,

Some of the Maine people are already discussing the Senatorial question, as Mr. FESSENDEN'S time will be out in 1859, and there are those who are anxious that he should go out with his time. Gov. MOREILL is named for his successor, and they have got so far as to discuss what is to be done about a new Governor. One of the WASHBURNS is named for the place that Gov. MOREILL now holds.

The schooner E. Freeman, from Provincetown for New-York, with a cargo of-fish, was run into off Cape Cod this morning and sunk, by the schooner Gen. Veazie, from Port an Prince for Boston. The crew of the Freeman were taken off by the Gen. Veazie, and landed here.

In the United States Seuate on Saturday Mr. WADE of Ohio spoke on the Northern side of the Kansas Questioy, defending the North from the charge of aggression, and asserting that on the other hand the South committed great aggressions, in the annexation of Texas, the Fugitive Slave law, and the repeal of the Missouri Compromise.

A destructive fire occurred in this city this morning, consuming the row of wooden buildings on Genesee street, opposite the Central Hotel. They were occupied by GEO. W LEWIS Co., boots and shoes; H. J. WOOBHUULL, merchant tailor, and Mrs. BROWNE, milliner, Loss $15,000 to $20,000--party insured.

The plan of the Executive with reference to Cuba is to send special Commissioners to Spain with comprehensive powers to demand redress for alleged injuries, but to offer to compound for them by the payment of a nearly liberal indemnity for the cession of the Island. The speech of General Dix, at Tammany Halt, referred to this project. The appointment of the Commission will be mace within thirty days.

FATAL FALL AND VERDICT OF CORONER.--Coroner CONNERY held an inquest yesterday at the City Hospital, upon the body of an unknown man, who died from injuries received by falling through the sidewalk hoistway in front of the store No. 92 Readestreet.

The consecration of FRANCIS P. MCFARLAND, as Bishop of Hartford, the diocese comprising the States of Connecticut and Rhode Island, took place in this city to-day. The event was marked with unusual pomp and ceremony. Archbishop HUGHES, seven Bishops and a great number of priests were in attendance. The sermon was preached by Bishop McCLOSKEY of Albany.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Am I mistaken in saying that among Mrs. GASKELL'S sins of omission and commission in her biography of CHALOTTE BRONTE, is the neglect to mention that Rev. PATRICK BRONTE had early in life aspired to the honors of authorship? I have not the book at hand to confirm my impression.

Three performances of the "Huguenots" were given last week at the Academy of Music. The houses have steadily increased from the first night, and on Friday reached the highest practicable point. Every seat was taken, and-that abomination of crowded houses-the aisles were filled up with chairs and tools, For to-night all the principal seats have been secured,

A private correspondent in London informs us of a vivacious proceeding on the part of those wags of the Clubs--the Foreign-Office clerks--which may lead to results of the most stupendous character. Our readers who refresh themselves habitually With the hebdomadal vivacities of Mr. Punch,

you will comprehend, by the events which have just occurred in Enyland, all the importance which has been attributed in political parties here to the late attempt on the Emperor's life. I was not mistaken, therefore, in endeavoring to keep your readers well informed in a general way on the progress of the complications which grew out of that event; for, for judeed, from the commencement the gravest results were apprehended.

THE ASSEMBLED WISDOM.--No very deep impression is effected upon the public mind of the Empire State by the hundred and sixty gentlemen assembled in Albany for legislative purposes. Certain interests indeed turn their eyes to the Capital, some with apprehension, others it may be with hope, but few with veneration.

SIR: No one is better informed than I of the facts with regard to Mr. WALKER'S visit to Washington, and I think It my duty to make the truth on that subject known, particularly since the sentiments Which the American President entertains towards the Fillibuster Chief have been frequently misrepresented by the English journals.

Recent proceedings at Washington afford a striking illustration of the relations of the Press to the organized legislative bodies of the country. I left Philadelphia on Wednesday on a hurried Visit to Some friends here, and will return God Willing, by this evening's train. Carrying with me this burried letter, which must take the place of my usual word in the Press of to-morrow. what a difference between March, 1857, and March, 1858! I dwell upon it with Surprise and grief. One year ago the Country was full of Content, and at peace with itself.

If the six South Americans who voted the other day in favor of compelling the Kansas Special Committee to investigate fairly can be rolled upon, there will be no difficulty in still securing that result, The plan is to permit the Committee to report, and then to submit a resolution recommitting the whole subject, and adding one South American and one AntiLecompton Democrat to the Committee.

We have received correspondence and papers from Hong Kong, China, to the 15th of January. The United States steamer Mississippi arrived at Hong Kong on the 12th of January, having left Singapore on the 2d. The Minnesota arrived at Hong Kong from Macao, on the 11th, with Commissioner REED.

The Mayor's Police have succeeded in winding up a pretended lottery agency, which has been doing a wholesale and very profitable business of swindling for some time. The swindlers issued a circular, headed the "Empire City Bulletin," announcing themselves as "Lottery and Exchange Brokers," and "General Agents and Managers of the Safety-Fund Lotteries." Officer Black was instructed to ferret out the parties and arrest them.

Mr. WADE spoke on the Kansas question, defending the North from the charges of aggressions upon the South, and contending that the aggressions were all the other way. lie, in this connection, charged d that the seizure of Texas and her admission into the Union in violation of the Constitution of the United States, was an enormous aggression upon the tights of the North.

ARTISTS OF THE JAPAN EXPEDITION--In the bill authorizing the Japan Expedition, no provision was made for the employment of artists. Commodore PERRY, however, appreciating the importance of having their services, engaged several, enlisting them as master's mates at twenty-five dollars a month, with the understanding that Congress would make a suitable compensation upon their return.

We learn ;from a reliable quarter that the result of the recent Court Martial upon Col. SUMNER, at Carlisle Barracks, was the acquittal of Col. S. upon both the charges preferred against him by Gen. HARNEY.

If anybody wishes to understand the Chinese character, or rather to understand that nobody not a Chinese can understand it, we advise him to bestow his attention upon the narrative of YEH's capture by the British sailors at Canton, which we published yesterday.

The Senate is still sitting, at 10 o'clock P. M. The Lecomptoultes are determined to maintain a continuous session until they get a rote, unless the antis agree to take a vote some time this week, which they decline going, as many still desire to speak, and the illness of Senator DOUGLAS renders it uncertain when he will be able to proceed.

Our readers doubtless remember the controversy in Dr. CHEEVER'S Church, growing out of a letter from a number of the members requesting him to resign. We understand that about fifty of the members who disapproved the course pursued by Dr. C. have applied to the proper authorities of the church for a letter of dismissal.

We have received, by way of California, files of the Deseret News to the 7th of January inclusive. It is reported that BRIGHAM YOUNG has been instisating the Oregon Indians to rebel. He has offered to pay them a certain sum per head for every horse or mule they may capture and bring to him.

The market for Breadstuffs has ruled exceedingly quiet since our last semi-monthly report, and a slight reaction in prices has taken place In consequence of the cessation of operations. The decline however is by no means marked, for scarcely any of that disposition has been manifested by holders to realize, which is usually exhibited in this market after an article has rapidly advanced in value,

The Mayor's squad descended upn a gambling-house in Houston-street, near Avenue B, on Sunday night. Their coming was announced to the gamblers from the outer door by the ringing of a secret bell which gave them time to escape out of a window by a shed in the rear.

PHTITIONS. For the imposition of tolls upon Railroads. For traveling expenses to the Judges of the Supreme Court. For uniform rates of freight on Railroads. A resolution of Mr. DIVEN'S, restricting the speech-es of Senators in debating questions to ten minutes, was adopted.

EQUALIZING TAXATION.--Mr. DARLING gave notice of a bill in the Senate, on Thursday, to equalize taxation. The following are its principal provisions: 1. Appointment of three Tax Commissioners, to continue in office three years, to be appointed by the Governor and Senate.

To the Editor of the New-York Times. Will you allow me to correct an error in a number of the TIMES a few days age, in reference to the burning of our Mission Hall, Union-street. It was intimated that it was done by some of the mischievcus Mission-School boys.

To the people of Kansas Territory; I have this day been shown a circular, purporting to be "Instructions to Enrolling Officers,: for enrolling the Kansas Militia, and signed by one "J. H. LANK, " dated" Headquarters Kansas Militla, Lawrence. Feb. 16, 1858," and also a commission issued by the same individual, appointing S. J. Willis, "Enrolling Officer of Kansas Territory."

BRANCH PAID--THE AGONY OVER.--BRANCH has got his money. Being told that tile Mayor was willing'" at last, BRANCH callced yesterday on his Honor with a witness, received a brief lecture for tile insinuations of his last petition, to which he answered not a word, and then saw the Mayor's signature affixed to the warrant that gives him $2,000 for services as " outside Secretary " to the MATSELL Birth-Investigating Committee.

DETERMINATION TO SUPPORT THE ZULOAGA GOVERNMENT. From the New-Orleans Picayune. By the arrival of the schooner Elizabeth Segar, Capt, SMITH, at Mobile, from Tampico, we have a copy of the Union, of the latter city, of the 18th ult, We gather from it that the garrison of the famed Santa Anna de Tamaulipas had decided in favor of the Zuloaga Government on the previous day.

The Navy Department has received dispatches from Commodore ARMSTRONG, dated long Kong, Jan. 14. IIe reports everything now quiet in Canton, and all along the whole coast to Shanghae. He also says his health is still very feeble, and that he shall leave for the United States on the arrival of Capt. TAYNALI.

Palmer's Marine News Room and Telegraph Office was opened at No. 83 State-street this morning, and bids fair to be liberally supported by the Board of Underwriters and a large majority of the more respectable merchants of the City.

SHIP CANAL AROUND THE OVERSLAUGH.--The project of a ship canal to avoid the obstruction inthe Hudson River, near Albany, known as the Overslaugh, is again discussed. According to the plan now proposed, the expense of the canal, or rather of several short canal covering a space of some twelve miles, would be only $200,000.

Day, also the members of the 16th st. Baptist Church. are respectfully invite to attend the funeral, on Wednesday afternoon. March 17, at 1 1/2 o'clock, from the Baptist Meeting House in 16th-st., near 8th-av., without further invitation.

DESPERATE ATTEMPT TO LYNCH.--A letter from Vandalia, Ill., dated March 6, says: "On Friday morning last our town was thrown into quite an excitement by a rumor that a large mob were congregating at the Bluff, about two miles from this town, for the express purpose of hanging BEACH.

THE EXECUTIVE DEPARTMENT--The Judiciary Committee of the Senate (Messrs. NOXON, DIVEN and WILLARD) have reported favorably a bill providing that a record of decisions shall be kept by the Governor, and a history of his official acts to be left in the Department,

Reports, memorials, etc., were presented relative to the Kansas bill. Mr. WADE gave way to Mr. BRODERICE, who said he had seen Mr. DOUGLAS, who had intended to be here to-day, but who was still prevented by sickness. While he (BRODERICE) was up he would refer to the correspondence of the New-York Herald, which represented him (BRODERICK) as having been rebuked for impertinence by the Senator from Pennsylvania.

Almost every fact in human life, we are told, has its serious and its comic sides, and each deserves attention. Of the availabilities of crinoline, considered comically, perhaps enough has now been made.

The steamship Star of the West from Aspinwall, with the California mail of Feb. 20, and $1,279,134 in treasure, arrived at this port yesterday afternoon. We have no news of importance to report. In the California Legislature, a bill to suppress mobs and insurrections had been introduced, and had excited much angry discussion. It was specially aimed at the late Vigilance Committee.

ESCAPE OF AMERICAN SLAVES TO THE BERMUDAS-A correspondent of the Savannah Republican, writing from Nassau, N.P., on the 26th of February, says : " A week previous to the sailing of our schooner, Ann M. still, from Savannah to this port, notice was given in the Savannah papers that a number of slaves in Key West, Fla., had succeeded in stealing a boat from the light-house, and escaping from their rightful owners.

A regular meeting of this Board was held last evening. A communication was received from Ex. Corporation Counsellor WABING, demanding a Committee to investigate the charge of defrauding the city, made against him in a report of the Assessment Committee to the last meeting. His request was complied with. A report of the Railroad Committee relative to steam on Atlantic-street, with the following resolutions, were adopted.

Hon. W. W. Drammond, late Justice of the Supreme Court in Utah, is now prostrate with bron chitis at his residence in Chicago. But little hope is entertained of his recovery, as he has not spoken distinctly for the last ten days. Judge D., in health, was a bold party man, a fast friend of senator Douglas, and in all his social relations a kind hearted man, but to his enemies bitter and unrelenting.

The Board met on Monday evening, the ??dent, C. H. HASWELL, Esq., in the Chair. The President presented a resolution granting the use of the Chamber temporarily to the Board of Supervisors. Carried. A position was presented by Councilmen VANTINE from butchers and others in Centre Market,

PROPOSAL TO AMEND THE STATE CONSTITUTION--On Saturday Mr. STOW introduced a bill in the Senate, to take the sense of the people on the subject of revising and amending the Constitution of this State. The bill provides for a vote at the November election--the result to be reported by the Secretary of State to the Legislature in January next.

RECEIPTS OF PRODUCE--Sine noon of Friday : 114 bbls. of Ashes; 2,745 bbls. Flour : 27,691 bushels Corn; 1,377 bushels Barley ; 777 bushels and 515 bags Malt ; 402 bags Feed ; 6,618 pkgs. Provisions, and 1,933 bbls. Whisky.

The Alton Courier of the 10th has the following additional particulars of the Penitentiary tragedy, an account of which was given yesterday: "The convict HALL was laid on a mattress in the prison hall. He said that he hoped CEABE would live, and in the next breath that he had put five men in the same fix he was himself. Dr. McMASTERS was present, and endeavored faithfully to turn his attention to immediate death.

THE IMPROVEMENT IN BUSINESS.--Business of all kinds is steadily and rapidly reviving. Our advertising columns, which are a very good barometer of general business movements, afford unmistakable evidence of the fact. Our daily cash receipts for advertisements are larger than they have ever been before.

SHORT SPEECHES.--A very sensible thing was done in the Senate at Albany yesterday. On motion of Mr. DIVEN, a ten-minutes rule was adopted. What a blessed relief to know that no speaker can hold the floor more than ten minutes!

There are questions of constitutional interpretation, and of governmental policy, which become so settled as to preclude any rational idea of reopening them; and it is the wisdom of practical statesmanship to accept what is thus irrevocably fixed, without criticism or quarrel, as to its accordance with preconceived theoretical opinions.

The United States steamship Star of the West ALFRED G. GRAY, Esq., Commanding, left Aspinwall March 6, at 4:50 P.M.,and arrived at Quarantine at 12:30 o'clock P. M. yesterday. She brings the San Francisco mails of Feb. 20, $1,279,134 In treasure on freight, and 199 passengers.

The Spanish war steamer Francisco de Asis arrived here from Vera Cruz on the 6th inst., with the news that the town still held out against ZULOAGA'S Provisional Government. Bodies of troops had left Mexico against the rebellious Vera Cruza. nos, as the reduction of the place was considered to be of vital importance.

CHAUNCEY SCHAFFER, the renowned South American politician of the last Presidential election, preached an eloquent sermon to the firemen in the North Fifth-street Methodist Church of Williams burg Sunday evening last. A daily prayer meeting, established by the united efforts of the Franklin-avenue Presbyterian,

The New-Mexican mail of the 15th ult., has arrived here. Capt. MARCY would leave about the 1st of March for Camp Scott, taking flour, salt, corn and animals. Owing to the fact of his taking wagons he would return rid Bent's Fort, taking a more circuitous north-easterly route than previously traveled. He is reported to have said that the supplies could be furnished Camp Scott much easier and from New-Mexico than elsewhere.

The fact that Col. JOHNSTON declined a present of a quantity of salt. sent him by BEISPLAM YOUNG for the use of the Army, has been already stated. BERIGHAM'S letter, accompanying the gift, has not been published. It was as follows: EXECUTIVE DEPARTMENTS. GREAT SALT LAKE CITY. U. T.. NOV. 26, 1857. Col. A. S. Johnston, U.S.A. (if the has arrived on Black's Fork.) or Col. E. D. Alexander. U. S. A.:

A LITTLE OUT OF TIME.--The Evening Post is enlarging on the objectional character of the new "Privy Seal" of the British Ministry, and Remarks that "CLANRICARDE'S appointment raises a cry of indignation." And so it did, some months ago, when Lord PALMERSTON, in the wantonness of his power, appointed the obnoxious nobleman to a seat in the Cabinet, outraging thereby the moral sense of the whole country.

DISCOURAGING TO DIPLOMATISTS.--Our Minister to Berlin, Mr. WRIGHT, of Indiana, has gained as much notoriety in the Prussian Capital by his strict temperance and economical habits, as his predecessor from the same State, Ex-Senator HANEGAN, did by his recklessness and gross intemperance. But, notwithstanding the very temperate and economical habits of our Minister,

LAURA KEENE'S THEATRE.--Mr. BUCKSTONE'S strong dramas appear to find an appreciative audience at this house. The" Green Bushes" enjoyed a succcssful run, and now we are favored with the "Flowers of the Forest," which seems destined to remain on the bill for some time. Mr. BUCKSTONE'S productions are scarcely worthy of the excellent "revival" which has awaited them at Miss KEENE'S excellent house.

Reports from Florida state that the Indians there have signified their willingness to emigrate. The Tampa papers are sanguine that the Florida war will soon be terminated. A party of six persons, including Captain HUNTER and Messrs. HOUSE and WYATT, it is supposed, were drowned while on their way to Manatee.

SUFFRAGE OF COLORED CITIZENS.--Negroes are recognized as citizens by the Constitution and statutes of this State, but are not placed upon the same footing as white citizens in regard to voting. We publish this morning the annual report of the State Engineer and Surveyor, upon the Railroads of the State. The document is interesting and instructive,--but it has only a qualified value as an official record of the great Railroad interest, owing to the fact that it Is partial and incomplete. Out of 88 Railroad corporations in the State, only 39,--less than one-half,

On Tuesday evening a gentleman, named MOSES MANTHER, quietly passing along Atlantic-street, was attacked by two raseals, one of whom grabbed his watch and chain and made off with them, while the other prevented him from making a successful pursuit. A complaint was promptly made to the police, and during the night officer McLAUGHLIN, of the First Precinet, arrested PETER CONROY, a notorious State street thief and rowdy,

THE OMNIBUSES.--Mayor TIEMANN is endeavoring to persuade the omnibus proprietors to Stop most of their stages at the lower end of the Park.

DESTRUCTIVE FIRE NEAR PHILADELPHIA--NEARLY SIXTY HEAD OF CHOICE CATTLE DESTROYED.--About 2 o'clock this morning, flames were discovered bursting from the large stone barn and stables on the country place of THOMAS P. REMINATON, Esq., on the Lancaster Turnpike, between the five-mile and six-mile stone, just over the line of Montgomery County.

The Canadian Serew Steamship Company's meamer North American, with Idverpool advices of the 3d inst.--four days later than the Canada Halifax--arrived at this port last night. The Cunard steamer Arabic, from New-York on the 17th alt, arrived at Liverpool on Sunday, the 28th. The North American sailed from Liverpool at about noon on the 3d inst., and brings 120 passengers.

The Senate had a protracted session on Monday, Commencing at noon, it did'not end until 9 o'clock on the morning of Tuesday. It was enlivened by one or two of those delighiful little personal scrimmages which from time to time vary the monotony of legislation:--but in spite of this it must after all, have been rather dreary business.

From the St. Louis Demcraf. The steamer Lady Walton arrived yesterday morning from Arkansas River, having carried from Fort Smith to Jefferson Barracks a detachment of the 7th Regiment of United States troops. They number about two hundred, and the officers are Col. P. MORRISON, Captains LITTLE and WAYMAN, Dr. WILLIAMS, and Lieuts, BROOKS and O'CONNOR. They are destined for Utah, and will be joined immediately by other detachments.

Late arrivals from Kansas state that the Anti-Topekaites had trumped up a Free-State Convention at Leavenworth, and succeeded in nominating a candidate to the Constitutional Convention. They had also nominated a Douglas Democratic ticket. The election on the 9th inst passed off quietly as far as known. The estimated number of quietly as far as known. The estimated number of the votes polled is from eight to ten thousand.

CITY POST-OFFICE.--We see it stated that negotiations are still pending with the General Government for the site of a City Post-Office. It is very singular that nothing practical can be done in regard to a matter of so much importance. The whole City is interested in having a suitable Post-Office building, in a convenient location.

A history of bank defalcations in this City, embracing the more remarkable cases of the past forty years, would furnish an exceedingly interesting and instructive volume, which would be as full of thrilling events and curious developments of crime as the Newgate Calendar or a sensation novel.

There are many rumors afloat to-day in regard to the future course of the South Americans upon the Lecompton question, all of which need to be taken with caution. I telegraphed you the most important of these to-night--to wit, one which ascribes to Mr. CHITTENDEN the intention to make a speech which Will lay down a platform upon which his political associates can stand in opposition to the admission of Hansas with the Lecompton Constitution.

On the contrary they express entire confidence in their ability to protect themselves against any force which

The vote in the House to-day on sending MONTGOMERY'S bill to a Select Committee, is considered the most significant yet of tile inherent weakness of Lecompton, and greatly encourages its opponents. MOHAMMED PASHA arrived to-night. I understand that he had not been at Willard's Hotel twenty minutes before his room was broken open,

PRAYER MEETING AT BURTON'S OLD THEATRE--The young men of the Christian Association have leased Burton's Theatre for a limited time to be used daily for a prayer meeting, between the hours of 12 and 1. Rev. T. L. CUYLER took the lead of the services at the first meeting, which was held yesterday After prayer by Dr. HATFIELD,

The death of Rev. Dr. TAYLOR has naturally created a profound sensation in this community. Though his years and failing health have given a forewarning of the inevitable result, the blow has nevertheless seemed to fall suddenly. His long services as a minister of the gospel, the position he has held for over thirty years,

The "graterm return of Spring and the soft south wand" upon the brief interjectional Winter to which we have just been subjected, after months of mildest temper, and which we have borne as badly as prosperous people usually bear a trivial misfortune, will make us all, no doubt, very genial and happy, and dispose us to believe that nobody can possibly be ill off in this "best of worlds".

SULLIVAN--In this City, on Wednesday, March 17, WILLIAM BENJAMIN SULLIVAN. The relatives and friends of the deceased, and those of his brother, Sylvester J. Sullivan, are hereby invited to attend the funeral, without further notice, on Friday afternoon, at 1 o'clock, from his late residence, No. 36 Watts-st. Lockport, N. Y., papers please copy.

The steamer Empire State, Captain BRAYTON, of the Fall River line, left Fall River on Tuesday evening, shortly after 7 o'clock, with a fair freight and the average number of passengers, of whom only a dozen or fifteen were ladies. On passing Newport a thick fog set in, and continued quite dense through the night, obliging Captain BRAYTON to proceed with great caution.

DAUCHY--RUNDALL.--In this City, on Wednesday evening, March 17, at the Metropolitan Hotel, by Rev. Henry Bromley, Mr. HENRY C. DAUCHY, and Miss KATZ P. RUNDALL, both of Amenia, Dutchess Co., N. Y. HAMILTON--WEED.--In Brooklyn, on Tuesday, March 16, by Rev. J. E. Rockwell, MARY TAYLOR, daughter of Wm. H. Weed, to WOODMAN C. HAMILTON, of Fond du Lac, Wisconsin.

The Medical Department of the University of Maryland has undergone some changes Professor Thomas resigns the chair of Obsteries, which he held for ten years. To the vacancy. Professor G. W. ?? lenberger, who before occupied the chair of Materia Medica and Therapeutics, has been appointed. ?? Frick, M.D., of Baltimore, is elected Professor of Materia Medica and Therapeuties, in place of Prof. Miltenberger.

The preliminary business transacted, embraced nothing of importance. The memorial of the Legislature of Utah was ordered to be printed. Mr. HALE had a personal explanation with Mr. BENJAMIN, (La.) The latter said in his speech the other day, that the former approved Mr. TOOMBS' bill.

UNPAID APPROPRIATIONS.--During the last few years the Legislature has appropriated large sums to Educational and other Institutions, to be paid when there should be money in the Treasury applicable to such purposes.

Yesterday, the preliminary examination of Mr. JACOB H. MOTT, arrested on suspicion of being associated with BENJAMIN K. BROTHERSON, in the recent heavy defalcation in the Union Bank of this City, was commenced before Recorder BARNARD, at his chambers. The examination, on the part of the presentation, was conducted entirely by the Recorder, who was himself what Mr. Malaprop called "three gentlemen at once"--District--Attorney, clerk and committing magistrate.

THE CANAL-STREET SHOOTING CASE.--DEATH OF EX-ALDERMAN SMITH.--Ex-Alderman ISAAC II. SMITH, of Booklyn, who was shot in the arm last Sunday evening, while passing through Canal-street, in company with his wife, on their way to church, died at 7 o'clock yesterday morning, at his residence No. 20 Beach-st. The arm was amputated Monday afternoon.

Colonel Samuel Colt, of Hartford, has purchased the famous "Charter-Oak Chair," refused by the Corporation of the City on account of its extravagant price. The Colonel paid $500. The chair is made from pieces of the Old Charter Oak, which exists no longer, except in scattered fragments. The recusant witness Wolcott, says the Union, remains an inmate of the keeper's office at the Washington Jail, having the privilege of taking out-of-door exercise.

The St. LOUIS Republican says Troops are concentrating at Jefferson Barracks from remote sections of the country, preparatory to the Spring expedition to Utah. They are coming from the recruiting stations in the East, and from Texas, and the southwestern frontier. This policy has been rendered absolutely necessary by the refusal of Congress to increase the army.

For once the 17th of a March was warm, pleasant day, and the Irish made the most of it. All of the Celtic military companies turned out in honor of Ireland's Patron Saint, and to the music of fife and drum proceeded to New York, where they joined their brethren. Last evening the annual dinner of St. Patrick's Society came off as usual at Montague Hall.

Contrary to the expectation, but in consonance with the earnest hopes of all who glory in the patronage of ST. PATRICK, the weather of yesterday was delightful, and the advantages for celebration all that the most enthusiastic Hibernian could desire. Unusual preparations had been made for the display of numbers and of the usual appurtenances of such an occasion.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: An advertisement of a new work, entitled Sartaroe, by JAMES A. MAITLAND, repeated in the journals and in circulars, contains chat purports to be a letter from Mr. WASHINGTON IRVING. Will you permit me the room to state that some one counected with the book has been grossly imposed upon, for no such letter has been written by Mr. RvIRVING?

The Castle Garden Committee met this afternoon. Mr. HAMILTON attended and testified that emigrants were charged no more for tickets inside than they would be outside the depot. Dr. E. HARRIS, subpcenaed as a witness, brought up with him a document showing how the assessment of a per centage on railroad tickets sold inside the depot was to be divided, and amongst whom.

COMMISSIONERS OF EMIGRATION.--The Commissioners of Emigration met yesterday, when Messrs, PURDY and CARRIGAN were deputed to proceed to Albany, to give any explanations which hare been refused by the Superintendent and the Cashier of Castle Garden, in the inquiry which is now pending. No other business was transacted. The following is the usual weekly statement:

THE LITTLE GIANT.--Mr. DOUGLAS is expected to make the closing Anti-Lecompton speech in the Senate on Monday next. Illness has kept him from his seat for several days past; but his friends at Washington report that he is in such a stage of recovery as justifies the expectation of his addressing the Senate at the conclusion of the Kansas debate.

ALEXIS DE TOCQUEVILLEone of her wisest teachers and the best of moncannot have failed to perceive that the era of revolutions in that country began at a period far earlier than 1789, and that,

A writer in one of the recent numbers of De Bow's Review, which, as our readers probably know, is the planted but, as yet, unfruitful germ of a new Southern political economy, has just been startling some of our Southern cotcmporaries by an elaborate article in exposition of the errors and fallacies of Democratic Government, and in favor of the establishment of a monarchical rule upon this Continent.

GREAT BRITAIN. The New Premier's Ministerial Statement. In the House of Lords, on the 1st inst., the Eari of DERBY rose to make his statement of the Ministerial policy. Having alluded to the importance of the duties that had devolved on him, he described the incidents preceding and following the resignation of the late Government.

A Straight Republican State Convention was held in this City to-day. Hon. THOMAS DAVIS, late M. C., presided. It was small in numbers, and composed of those opposed to the action of the late Republican State Convention in changing the name of the party to that of American Republican.

At 1 o'clock yesterday morning a collision occurred on the New-Haven Railroad, between Locker's Corner and Stamford, thirty miles from New-York, between the midnight Express train which brought the North American European mails and a freight train. Both were coming towards New-York, but the freight train had been forced off the track by the breaking of a flange of one of the wheels of the first car, and was thus delayed half an hour.

In the U. S. Senate, yesterday, after some unimportant preliminary business, the Utah Memorial was ordered to be printed. Mr. HALE had a perasonal explanation with Mr. BENJAMIN, in which he corrected a statement of the latter respecting Mr. HALE'S remarks on a former occasion. Mr. CRITTENDEN spoke on the Kansas question.

The Board met at 5 P. M. yesterday, the president, WILLIAM H. NEILSON, Esq., in the chair. The journal of the last session was read, amended, and approved. The minutes of the last meeting of tile Executive Committee on Evening Schools were read. A communication from tile School Inspectors of the Thirteenth Ward was read, representing that the school-houses in the Ward, with few exceptions, were perfectly safe.

DESCENT ON A DISORDERLY HOUSE-THIRTY PERSONS CAPTURED.-About 11 o'clock last night, twelve of the police attached to the Mayor's Office, under command of Sergeant CROFT, made a descent upon the notorious resort No. 108 Bowery, which has been for a long time a rendezvous for thieves of all kinds, and prostitutes of the lowest grade. The police were in plain clothes, and when they entered the place secured the doors so that none could escape.

THROWING BRICKS FROM HOUSETOPS--A DESPERATE CHARACTER.--Several persons, in passing through park-street on Tuesday afternoon, were hit with bricks and severely injured. It was supposed at first that the bricks accidentally tumbled off the tops of the buildings, but on investigation a man was discovered on the top of a five-story building, with a large pile of bricks by his side, which he was leisurely throwing at the passers-by underneath.

Senator CRITTENDEN'S speech to-day created a great sensation. It was a bold, able and eloquent exposition of the Lecompton fraud, which he characterized in unmistakable terms. The Lecomptonites are greatly alarmed this evening, and will change their tactics immediately.

ROBBERY IN THE PARK BANK.-On Monday last $115 in bills were stolen from the Cashier's desk of the Park Bank in Beekman-street. Captain WEED, of the Second Precinct, was informed of the robbery, and officer MICHAELS was instructed to investigate the affair. This officer made diligent inquiries, but could only learn that three little boys had been seen loitering about the Bank on the afternoon of the robbery.

In compliance with a call of the " Sabbath Committee," a meeting was held last night in the Lectureroom of the Historical Society, for the purpose of devising means whereby " to rescue the sacred day from desecration and our City from consequent demoralization." The attendance, though not exceeding two hundred persons, comprised many gentlemen of intelligence and influence.

Senator CRITTENDEN made a capital speech yesterday on the Kansas bill. It was clear, forcible and patriotic. It discussed the merits of the question upon the broadest ground, instead of dealing with technicalities and niceties of legal construction. It was addressed to the common sense of the country,--and not to their sectional prejudices or partizan resentments.

COMMON PLEAS.--Part I.--Nos. 114, 117. 126 to 142. Part II.--Nos. 5, 6, 9, 14, 17, 36, 37, 38, 42, 73, 74, 50, 116, 121, 124, 143, 144 to 148. UNITED STATES CIRCUIT COURT. Before Judge Hall. John Fredericks was put on trial this morning on a charge of making counterfeit coin. Ex-Judges Beebe and Steward appeared for the defendant.

Our British cousins frequently complain of the inordinate length of our Presidential Messages, inaugural and others, and possibly not without some show of reason. The Queen of England, at least in her speeches from the Throne, sets the wholesome example, whenever she has nothing particular to say, of saying it as briefly as possible.

The New-Orleans Picayune publishes the following extract of a letter from E. K. COLLINS, Esq., to J. C. BROCKSMIT, of New-Orleans: NEW-YORK, Feb. 22, 1858. I have the pleasure to acknowledge receipt of your favor of the 12th inst., and feel under great obligations for the interest taken by you in the Collins steamers.

The Tauney, living on Bear Creek, Texas, recently shot and killed Mr. Edwards, who lived in the same neigborhood. Both parties belong to respectable families. The journeymen shoemakers of Philadelphia have held a meeting to demand a restoration of prices to the standard in use before the recent panic.

To the Editor of the New-York Times. SIR: Knowing that you will met object to making your columns the medium for advocating the cause of those helpless and miserable little objects of humanity-the children of the degraded-I take the liberty of calling your attention to the subjoined paragraph, cut from the TIMES of yesterday.

JOHN MURPHY and JOSEPH KELLY, the two men who were stabbed on Monday night in a porterhouse affray corner of First-avenue and Eleventhstreet, were alive last evening, but their recovery is still regarded very doubtful. Coroner CONNERY yesterday took their anle-mortem depositions. Joseph Kelly sworn-I was in Mr. Bryne's store, No. 169 First-avenue, on Tuesday morning about 1 o'clock, when Lalor, O'Connell and' two others came in.

BY AUG. BLAUVELT. Now aged Winter on the breast Of maiden March confides his head. And oft her gentle eyes suffuse, The while he sinketh to the dead. She soon will lift him tenderly, And bear and hide him in his tomb; Then cause in haste, above his sleep.

In recent articles respecting the proposed imposition of canal tolls upon railroad freight, we have stated that the principal lines in this State have for years been carrying freight at a loss-that is to say, the cost of freight-trains has exceeded the receipts for transportation. Divers motives have prompted the roads to take this suicidal course.

A scientific controversy of considerable warmth has grown out of a review in the NewHaven Journal of Science of a work on the Creation by Mr. T. A. DAVIES of this City, in which the scientific portions of the book were treated with a good deal of severity.

We have already stated that Col. SUMNER as acquitted by the Court-Martial upon every specification of every charge preferred against him. It will be seen by the Army Order, which we publish in another column, that the War Department disapproves of this finding of the Court-Martial, and assigns sundry reasons therefore.

We approach the vernal equinox, which is the true beginning of Spring, with weather remarkable for its warmth and softness, the cold spell having departed, and melted snow, ice and mud having set up a very brisk business, which does not in the least promote one's well-being. The snow went like a dream, as if it bad no business here, and I am certain that its presence afforded no pleasure.

Yesterday at 3 P. M. the preliminary examination in the matter of the charge against JACOB H. MOTT, of complicity in the at eges deficiations of BENJAMIN J. BROTHERSON, the ab-condend Bank-keepr of the Union Bank, was resumed before Recorder BARNARD at his office in Chambers-street. Ex-Judge Foste and Mr. John Foot appeared as counsel for the prosecution.

The prompt punishment of the Directors of the Royal British Bank, at the head of whom was the notorious HEMPHREY BROWN, a member of Parliament, will doubtless have a very wholesome effect upon the commercial community of Great Britain, though the degree of punishment awarded to the culprits may be considered very light for their offences.

A FIGHT IN THE ASSEMBLY.--Congress is not to enjoy a monopoly of the fighting. Yesterday, in the Assembly at Albany, two members from this City indulged themselves in a set-to. Mr. DELANY struck Mr. CHATFIELD. Mr. CHATFIELD took Mr. DELANY by the throat. By-standers prevented Mr. CHATFIELD from striking Mr. DELANY.

Mr. BREVOORT, special aid to the Deputy-Superintendent, arrived in the City yesterday morning from Poughkeepsie, having in his custody MILTON W. GRAY, who stands charged by a Coroner's Jury of Poughkeepsie with having caused the death of Miss JHMIMA BENWAY, of that place, by an attempted abortion upon her at No. 218 Grand-street, in this City.

Senator BELL, of Kentucky, ably supports the patriotic stand against Lecompton assumed by Mr. CRITTENDEN yesterday. Senator TOOMBS, foreseeing the defeat of Lecompton, supposes that the time has come to strike his blow for disunion. The effect if his speech to-day is already apparent. It has startled the conservative Union-lovers of the South,

The Leavenworth, Kansas, correspondent of the Leader says that the Free-State vote for delegates to the Constitutional Convention in that city was 650 against 1,196 cast for State officers, on the 4th of January. Correspondence of the Cincinnati Gazette. QUINDARO, K. T., Thursday, March 11. The election of Delegates to the Constitutional Convention, so far as heard from, has passed off quietly.

REPORTS OF BILLS. By Mr. FOOTE, favorably to allow the Mechanics Bank of Williamsburg to reduce its capital aud change its name. NOTICES OF BILLS. By Mr. ELY, to cause the removal of obstructions in the Harlem River, Also, a bill to provide for the removal of Macomb's Dam.

SWAN--In this City, at his residence, No. 20 Macdougal-st., on Thursday afternoon, March 18, Mr. JAMES SWAN. in the 7th year of his age. Due notice of the funeral will appear in Saturday's papers. JACKSON--In this City on Thursday evening, March 18, JAMES HARVEY. son of John and Dorettica Jackson, aged 18 years 2 months and 2 days.

In the United States Senate yesterday a letter was received from the War Department recommending the sale of Rock Island, as being no longer required for military purposes. Mr. COLLAMER made a report respecting expenses of courts in Utah. Messrs. GWIN and HOUSTON adverted to the subject of the Indian massacre in Utah. Mr. TOOMBS spoke on the Kansas question.

The arrival of the time for the departure of another mail brings me to the rehearsal of the sad news of this poor country, distracted and decaying from the loose passions of her sons. Since the 19th of last month, the date of my last letter, changers have taken place, but whether for better or worse cannot yet be foreseen.

A letter was received from the Secretary of War, saying that Rock Island is not required any longer for military purposes, and asking that steps be taken for its sale. Mr. WILSON said the informal agreement was that the Senator from Georgia (Mr.TOOMBS) should take the floor on the Kansas bill. He also proposed an evening session, which was agreed to.

The Coroner's investigation in the case of Ex-Alderman ISAAC H. SMITH, who was shot last Sunday evening in Canal-street while going to church with his wife, was concluded yesterday morning at 10 1/2 o'clock. at No. 26 Beach-street, the late residence of the deceased. The following is the additional evidence and the verdict of the Jury:

Very unexpectedly, Mr. HOHN HARTNETT, Secretary of the Territory of Utah, arrived in this city Saturday night, from Camp Scott. He left that post Jan, 26, bringing us news from the army two or three weeks later than our direct advices. At the time he left the entire command was in very comfortable condition, enjoying excellent health, and, considering all things, getting along pleasantly.

It is now stated that General CALHOUN has decided upon giving the certificates of election to the Free-State members of the new Kansas Legislature. Few persons will give him any credit for honesty of purpose, even in this act. His past conduct in the matter proves that some other motive than a desire to do right has prompted him to take this course.

THE VIRTGE OF WAITING.--At the opening of the present Imperial Parliament, the comic chronicler of British affairs gave one of its funny cartoons illustrating the then condition of the party in defeat.

The announcement by Mr. JOBSON that he would lecture upon LOLA MONTEX and her fancies in Stuyvesant Hall, last evening, attracted to that building nearly forty persons, two of whom were females. The lecture we do not propose to report; for that portion of it that was not too vulgar to be heard, was altogether too stupid to be read.

According to the recent Report of the Bank Superintendent, the Savings Banks in this State hold on deposit upwards of forty-one millions of dollars, belonging to 203,804 depositors. The average to each depositor is $203 24. During the last year upwards of two millions of dollars was paid as interest.

We observe that in the House of Representatives, on the last private-bill day, Mr. TAYLOR, from the Committee of Claims, made reports in thirty-four cases adverse to the judgments of the Court of Claims, in favor of the claimants. These reports were referred to a Committee of the whole House, with a minority report from Mr. DAVIDSON, of Louisiana, which was ordered to be printed.

I.--POETRY.--March: By AUG. BLAUVELT. II.--INTERESTING FROM FRANCE--The Trial of the Conspirators, III-THE FRENCH EMPIRE--By a "States" man. IV.--OUR WASHINGTON CORRESPONDENCE--The South Americans in Congress-Cuba--Lecompton.

THE PRINCE IMPERIAL.--The Paris correspondent of the London News gives the following interesting sketch of the imperial Prince: " I have never seen it stated in print," says the writer, " that the Imperial Prince had been seen to walk alone.

About 10 o'clock Wednesday night, a man named DENNIS REYNOLDS was instantly killed in his own house, on Pacific-street, near Vanderbilt avenue, Bedford, by his brother. CHRISTOPHER REYNOLDS, who was formerly a member of the Ninth Ward Police. The ceceased was a married man, and his brother boarded with him.

THE LANCASTER (PA.,) MURDERERS.--ANDERSON one of the murderers of Mrs. GARBER and Mrs. REAM, has written to Rev. GEORGE JAMES, pastor of the African Church, Strawoerry-street, requesting to have his body interred in the burying ground attached to that church. ANDERSON preserves a studied silence in regard to the murders.

The Philadelphia papers speak hopefully of business prospects. The Inquirer says: "Business in Market and Third streets has been somewhat backward thus far, but it is beginning to revive. Our leading hotels and boarding houses are filling up, and affairs generally are assuming a more cheerful aspect.

As the morning train from Peekskill was passing Forty-fifth-street at 9 A. M. yesterday, a young Irishman named THOMAS FINTCH, in attempting to jump on to one of the cars, missed his hold, fell under the wheel and was run over. His body was nearly cut in two. The affair immediately created a great deal of excitement in the neighborhood.

NATHAN JACKSON, Esq., of this City, has celebrated his 76th birth-day, by making a gift to Williams College, Massachusetts, of $14,000 in cash, and nine acres of land, with suitable buildings thereon, adjoining the College grounds in Williamstown, for which he paid $6,000 in addition, though the land is worth more than its original cost.

STATE OF THE RIVERS.--The Hudson is clear, and boats will commence running between this City and Albany to-day. The Missouri River has been navigable for a week or more: the Illinois is open from its mouth to Pooria: and the Mississippi as high us Burlington in Iowa. At Dubuque and Fulton the ice was starting on Monday.

SIR: I regret that, after having given publicity to Mr. MAVENICK's Claborate impeachment of my literary integrity, you should have found yourself unable to insert my reply establishing my claim to the authorship of " The Diamond Lens." I will now endeavor to condense the chief points of that letter in the scanty space which you allow me.

The case of GEORGE MIDDLETON, charged with canspiring with JOHN ??? to take the lite of MARCOS CICERO STANLEY, came again before the Kesorder, at His chambers, yesterday. The Recorder read a letter from Mr ROBERT D HOLMES, the counselor, stating that he was too sick to attend, and asking for a postponement of the case.

REMOVAL BY ADDRESS.--In the ancient Commonwealth of Massachusetts judges are removed "by address." That is to say, both branches of the Legislature unite in an address requesting the Governor to remove a judge from office. This course of procedure is just now adopted in respect to Judge LORING.

The Profits of Mr. Everett's oration on Washington delivered at Philadelphia on the 4th of February, were $1,020. The sum was paid to the Treasurer of the Pennsylvania Historical Society, for the benefit of the Mount Vernon Fund. The funeral of Rev. Dr. Croswell, at New-Haven on Tuesday, was attended by an Immense concourse of people. Two Bishops and forty six clergymen of the Episcopal Church were present.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR: Are fog signals not used on railroads in this country? If not, why not It was startling to read, in your account of the above accident in this day's TIMES, than on the break-down of the freighttrain, and the consequent stoppage of the way, the coming Boston Express was attempted to be signaled by men running with "lanterns" in a dense fog;

THE STORY THAT WAS A LIBEL.--An examination was commenced yesterday before Justice KELLY, at the Jefferson market Police Court, in the case of Mr. Lewis Beach, arrested on a charge of libel preferred by Mr. Joseph Eddie. The complainant lives in St. Louis, and the defendant at the corner of Thirty-fifth street and Fifth-avenue.

BRAM.--In this City, on Friday, March 19, RACHEL wife of Martin R. Beam, aged 55 years, 3 months and 16 days. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend her funeral, from her late residence. No 164 West 20th-st., on Sunday afternoon, at 4 1/2 o'clock. Her remains will be taken to remains for interment. CHURCHWARD.--In this City, on Friday, March 19, ELIZABETH CHURCHWARD, aged 74 years

The controversy concerning the authenticity of a letter from WASHINGTON IRVING, extravagantly praising a book lately published at Philadelphia, ?? already drawing down to very sharp edge. Messrs. PETERSON Co.'s card, which is among our advertisements this morning, clearly shows that if the living letter was a forgery, their house was outrageously imposed upon.

A bill has passed both Houses of the Maine Legislature in relation to marriage, which repeals the existing law, and requires that parties intending marriage shall deposit a notice of their intention with the Clerk of the towns in which they respectively reside, and he to enter the same in a book kept for that purpose ; said notice to remain on file five days,

There is little of interest here at present outside the debate on the Kansas bill-of which distant readers probably have had a surfeit. Here, however, the flagging interest has been revived by the speeches of Mr. CRITTENDEN yesterday, and Messrs. TOOMBS, CRITTENDEN and BELL to-day. The Senator from Georgia probably cares as little for the Lecompton bill as any man in Congress,

Mr. PHELPS, of Missouri, the Chairman of the Committee on the Pacific Railroad, on Tuesday last Introduced a bill which was referred to that Committee, to aid in the construction of a railroad from St. Louis to San Francisco. It proposes to pass through Albuquerque, the Zurio villages and the Tejon Pass. One-half of the road is to be built by the State of California, and the other

A good performance of the "Huguenots" was given last night, in spite of a drawback which every one regretted. This was the indisposition of Madame LA GRANGE, who, we are sorry to say, is laboring under that prevalent complaint, the influenza. Other members of the company were also on the sick list, but they struggled valiantly to save one of the best houses of the season.

Driven from point to point by the unrelenting persecution of justice and common sense, the extreme Southern advacates of the Lecompton Constitution have at last taken up their position boldly upon the issue which, we are given to understand, they have from the first designed to make. They speak by the mouth of Senator TOOMBS,

The inquest on the body of DENNIS REYNOLDS, murdered Wednesday night last by his brother CHRISTOPHER REYNOLDS, an ex-policeman of the Ninth Ward, was concluded yesterday. The accused was of course held to answer. He pretends to think that his brother is not dead, and that the story is got up to frighten him.

After a week on the shelf, I am again able to renew my correspondence. A man loses mush in a week anywhere, but here, in that period of time, he sets sadly behind. I shall hardly attempt to bring up the bacd work, but shall endeavor to keep somewhere within hall until the Legislature runs into Summer quarters.

A young man named NEWELL H. WHITTLESEY was arrested at the Jersey City Railroad Depot on Thursday evening, upon a charge of robbing the office of the Treasurer of warren County, Penn. He was locked up for the night, and a telegram having been sent on identifying him, he was yesterday morning sent back in charge of an officer. The amount of the robbery was $150.

It is not often that the Daily Press feels called upon to chronicle the spiritual movements of the public mind. Those are assumed, of course. It is felt that all the best part of society visible to the world-its merality, and order, and benevolence-rests on an unseen basis; but into that foundation we are not generally disposed to pry.

Before Judge Hall. The trial of John Frdericks, indicted for making counterfelt money, was concluded by a veruict of guilty, with a recommendation to mercy. MANSLAUGHTER. Capt. Ferdinand Crocker. Of the bark Esther Frances was put on trial, charged with the manslaughter of a seaman named Brown, on board the bark, by IIImeatment of him when sick.

REMOVAL OF JUDGE LORING.--Yesterday Governor BANKS complied with the Address of the Massachusetts Legislature, by removing Judge LORING. It is seldom, in this country, that a Judge is turned out of office for a decision confessedly according to law. Indeed, we are not aware that a parallel case has ever occurred.

Mayor TIEHANN is devoting a portion of his valuable time--very sensibly--to the reformation of the omnibus lines. He is trying to liberate the lower part of Broadway from the crush of a vast number of superfluous vehicles daily parade in a vain show of empty seats, and at a funereal pace, from the Battery up to the Park.

The prayer-meeting at Burlon's old ?? Chambers-street, was more largely attended, if possible, yesterday, than it was the day before. It was literally crammed. it reminded one of the occasion of some eminent actor's benefit, in old times, at the same place. These Monday meetings are "benefits," it in to be hoped, for all who attend them,

Commissioners WHITE and BETTS issued warrants this day for the arrest of the members composing the firm of Mestayer Co., viz. Paul Mesaver Omer Pergeline, John Stouvenel, Sebastian Rose and Dedine. These gentlemen were arrested on the complaint of Messrs.

The R. M. steamship Arafia, from Liverpool on the 6th inst., with advices three days later than those brought by the North America at Portland, is now due at this port. She had not been seen at Sandy Hook at 2 o'clock this morning. In the United States Sentate yesterday, Mr. GWIN'S resolution relating to the massacre of California emigrents was adopted.

The Albany Atlas and Argus brings forward in an article which we copy this morning, what we presume is to be considered the Democratic plan for completing the State Canals. It states from official documents that about four millions of dollars will be needed for this purpose, -- while there is already a floating Canal debt of over a million and a quarter to be provided for.

A NEW WAY TO PAY OLD DEBTS.--IN THE MATTER OR JONES vs. PERSSE BROOKS.--A tedious investigation has been going on for some time before Judge MITCHELL, as referee, regarding certain circumstances connected with the failure and assignment of PERSSE BROOKS, the well-known paper--makers, by which the rights of the plaintiff, as a creditor, have been supposed to be violated.

The United States Mail steamer Star of the West, Capt. GRAY, leaves at 2 o'clock to-day for Aspinwall, with the usual number of passengers and the California mails. Col. FREMONT and family take passage in her, to be absent a few months, the absence of opposition has afforded fewer cases than usual for bulinding in the way of tickets, although serveral cases have occurred,

We learn from the Bridgeport Farmer that an interesting divorce case is soon to be tried before the Superior Court. The parties are Mr. and Mrs, Theodone Hubbell, of Bridgeport, Mrs. H. being plaintiff. She is the eldest sister of the celebrated General Tern Thumb, Mr, and Mrs. H. returned from England a few days since in separate steamers.

Governor BANKS, in a message to the Legislature to-day, removes Judge LORING, in accordance with the vote of the two branches of the Legislature. A motion to refer the message to a Select Committee, led to an exciting discussion between Messrs. CUSHING, of Newburyport, and ANDREWS, of Boston;

Lost Chapters Recovered From the Early History of American Methodism is not a title which promises much entertainment for lay readers ; but Rev. J. B. WAEELEY has complied an extremely interesting volume of some six hundred pages from such materials. The Lost Chapters are the records of the foundation and early struggle of the Methodist Church in this country,

From the thirty-seventh annual report of the New York Eye Infirmary, just published, it appears that during the past year 3,466 patients, suffering from various diseases of the eye and ear, have been prescribed for in the Institution. Of these patients 1,966 were foreigners, and 1,460 natives. The surgeon says: The receipts of the Institution for 1857, were, from the State Legislature.

THE BATTLE ROYAL IN THE ASSEMBLY.---Mr. CHATFIELD would do well to take lessons of THOMAS HYER. A course of instruction under the competent direction of that celebrated pugilist could not fail to improve him. He should learn the rules of the ring and the laws of the fancy.

THE RETURN OF THE TURKISH COMMITTEE.--The celebrated Committee, appointed to receive Vice-Admiral MOHAMMED PASHA and suite, have returned from Washington, and areas well as can be expected. Alderman BOOLE says there was some mistake in the telegraphed reports of the attempted robbery of the Turkish gentleman. He says it was not the Admiral's trunk that was cut open.

Mr. GWIN's resolution of inquiry concerning the massacre of the California emigrants in Utah, was passed. The Vice-President laid before the Senate a joint resolution of the Legislature of New-Mexico, concurring in the President's views relative to the reorganization of the Territory of Arizona, and suggesting the boundaries of the same.

Last night about 11 o'clock a very successful descent was made on a notorious gambling hell and resort for burglars, thieves, , at No. 86 Lispenardstreet, by Sergeant CROFTS, accompanied by Officer BLACK and seven other men. The Sergeant and Officer BLACK entered the premises first, and immedlately seized the apparatus, consisting of a faro box and other implements of the business.

The Legislature has passed a bill appropriating $800,000 for a loan to the Covington and Ohio Railroad. Appropriations have also passed the Assembly amounting to $1,200,000, divided between the Orange and Alexandria, Manassas Gap, Alexandria, Hampshire and London, and Norfolk and Petersburg roads. It is believed that there will be no difficulty in passing these through the Senate.

About 12 o'clock Saturday night last, Officer RUSSELL, of the First President, discovered smoke issuing from tenement house No. 112 Jay-street. He forced open the basement door and entered the apartments occupied by JOHN McKEOWN and family. Here he found Mr. and Mrs. McKEOWN in a beastly state of Intoxication in a bed, and by them were two of their children in a sound sleep.

The Albany Evening Journal of Saturday has the following; Gov. KING has commuted the punishment of MAURICE O'CONNELE, now under sentence of Death, for Life. this act of clemency was geared upon a showing which renders it entirely proper. O'CONNELE was the youngest and least guilty of the parties implicated.

The royal mail steamship Arabia, Capt. STONE, which sailed from Liverpool about noon on the 6th of March. arrived at this port on Saturday morning. The screw-steamship City of Baltimore, from New. York, arrived out at Liverpool at 3 A. M. on the 5th inst. The members of Parliament who had accepted office under Lord DEABY were being reflected to their seats, and generally without opposition.

Another of those agreeable incidents which throw so pleasing a light upon the mysteries of a certain kind of life in New York, occurred on Saturday last. ANOTHER KANSAS REPORT.--The Republican members of Mr. HARRIS' Investigating Committee have published their minoriuty report-- a full abstract of which is contained in the TIMES of this morning. It will be recollected that the majority report by Mr. STEPHENS was published some days ago.

The Supreme Court of Louisiana has finally disposed of the points in controversy about the partition of the McDonogh estate. The division of the proper by between the tow cities of Baltimore and New-Orleans in confirmed, subject to some equitable charges, 10 carry into effect a part of the intentions of the leslator.

NAPOLEON III. is exerting himself to the uttermost to recover the ground which has been lost for him by his lieutenants. He has made the amende to England for the violent and inconsiderate language of DE MORNY and WALEWSKI: he was put a stop to the minatory effusions of his legionaries;

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--This is the last week of the "Euguenois," and the last week but one of the Academy season. Three more performances of MEIERBERR'S masterpice are all that may be looked for, It is stated officially that Madame LA GRANGE has entirely recovered from her indisposition, and will resume her role of Valentine to-night

By the arrival of the Cunard steamship Arabin at this port on Saturday, we have received London and Liverpool advices to the 6th inst -three days later. The political news is not of a very interesting character. Most of the members of the Derby Cabinet had been reflected, but otherwise there was a complete full in politics.

F. G. Q. UMSTED, a layer, of No. 14 Wall-street, was arrested on Saturday and held on a charge of attempting to kill WM. H L BARNES, a member of the bar, whose office is at No. 61 Wall-street, BAENES swears that about 10 o'clock on Saturday morning he called at the office of a friend at No. 14 Wall-street, and left him a few minutes afterward,

Mr. WILSON announced his intention to speak on the Kansas question this evening. Mr. FOOT, of Vermont, earnestly protested against the Lecompton Constitution; the creature, he said, of a long series of frauds and outrages, and unmitigated rascality. It was a question rising for above party; once in which he was willing to strike hands with conservative, honorable men of all parties, both North and South.

The Administration men are working desperately to control the stampede in the House against Le compton There are some five millions of dollars worth of contracts in connection with the Utah campaign, which are being used as levers, as far as possible, to affect votes. How and where, will be clearly apparent when the vote comes to be taken.

The United States Mail steamship Black Warrior, J. W. SMITH, Commander, from Mouth of Mississippi River 13th inst., and Havana, has arrived, bringing dates from the latter place to 16th inst. Captain-General CONORA has returned from a tour of the south side of the Island and Isle of Pines. He was well received everywhere, even in the districts that were previously most disaffected.

CALHOUN HAS SPOKEN.- The letter of JOHN CALHOUN, in respect to the election of members of the Kansas Legislature under the Lecompton Constitution, is published the Lecompton Constitution, is published in this morning's TIMES. Mr. CALHOUN rejects the returns from the Delaware Crossing, and expresses his intention to" Issue the certificates of election to the persons having the highest number of votes in Leavenworth County, irrespective of the Delaware Crossing Precinct."

THE REV. HENRY WARD DEECHER AT BURTON'S. The noon prayer meeting at Burton's Theatre, on Saturday, was conducted by the Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER. An immense audience assembled; many more pressing at the doors for admission than the house could possibly accommodate.

The NEW-YORK TIMES is hardly correct in stating that the grounds of the address of the two branches of the Massachusetts Legislature to Gov. BANKS to remove Mr. E. G. LORING from his office of Judge of Probate is " a decision of Judge LORING some years since enforcing the Fugitive Slave law."

ARSON IN WEST THIRTY-SIXTH-STREET.--On Thursday night a genteel-looking man, named GUSTAVUS LUDWIG, was arrested by Officer CLOWS, of the Twentieth Precinct, on the charge of attempting to burn the house NO. 180 West thirty-sixth-street, corner of Eighth-avenue.

ANOTHER FIGHT AMOUNT THE FIREMEN,--The fight between firemen that occurred at 4 1/2 o'clock yesterday afternoon was resumed at 8 1/2 o'clock last evening, at which hour a silent alarm for the Seventh District was given. The members of Engine No. 20 attacked 18 Hose, drove away its members and ran away with the carriage.

As there has been great anxiety to learn the result of the late election for members of the State Legislature, under the Kansas Constitution now before Congress, I think it proper to state that recent information, through Governor DENVER and others, leaves no doubt that the returned vote from the Delaware Crossing Precinct, in Leavenworth County, should be rejected, and that certificates of election should be issued without reference to the vote of the percent.

PLANS FOR THE CENTRAL PARK.--The public had been led to expect that the processes of laying out the Central Park were so arranged that a drive of some kind would be opened within its inclosure the coming Summer. But there is very little prospect of such a boon being granted to the people even during the next two years.

Mr. DOUGLAS spoke this evening three hours to an overcrowded audience. He first reviewed his own course on the Slavery question, since 1843, to show not be had acquiesced in the Missouri Compromise until the principle of popular sovereignty was introduced, when he embraced it, and afterwards applied t to Kansas. All he asked now was that it should be fairly carried out,--and this, he went on to show, the Lecompton Constitution did not do.

PATRICK McLAUGHLIN alios "Paudeen," who was mortaliy wounded early on Saturday morning, in a dance house in Howard-street, died at 10 o'clock yesterday morning at the City Hospital. He did not appear to be suffering greatly in his last moments. During the previous night he was, at times, ??, and while in this state made use of expressions of shocking profanity and blasphemy. hemy.

Mr. STUART, of Michigan, said he would not discuss the Kansas question on the abstract principles Slavery, but on the ground the action of the Lecompton Constitution was an Intentional fraud upon the people. and did not express the will of the people, He then followed with considerable clearness the clauses of the President's Message, contending that in some cases the reasoning was fallacious and in others absurd.

There has been a storm among the Lecomptonites here, during the last twenty-four hours. Yesterday afternoon Gen. CALNOUN'S official manifesto was published, declaring the Free-State majority in the Legislature of Kansas; and this morning the document was copied into the official organ, the Unionan incident full of significance in times like these, when a breath has the weight of a blow.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: An article, scurrilous in its nature, but nevertheless amusing to us who, living in Constantinople, know all about the matter, has recently appeared in the New-York Tribune and other papers, under the above title.

The long-vexed question of Kansas is now rapidly drawing to the issue of a Congressional decision. Many, indeed we think we may venture to say most, of our readers, will be so thoroughly delighted to believe that this is so, as to become quite indifferent to the particular form which the decision may take.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: GENTLEMEN: The story of the vexations and annoying letter which Mr. JAMES A. MAITLAND has confessed to be an undoubted and entire forgery, has been aggravatingly mystified. Plain language, however disagreeable, seems to be necessary to stop at once a gross imposition on the public.

Burton's old Theatre was again completely filled yesterday. In the lower boxes were a great number of ??. On the platform were about twenty gentlemen, meet of them ministers of various denomination,--among them the Rev. Dr. THOMPSON, who presided, the Rev. H. W. BEECHAN, the Re. Mr. WHITE HEAD, the Re. Mr. COVILLE, the Rev. Messrs. WARD and WOLFE, of the New-Jersey Conference, the Rev. H. C. FISH, of Newark, and others.

The correspondence that has taken place between the British Colonial Office, on the one side, and the Government of Canada and the Hudson's Bay Company on the other, in consequence of the report of the Select Committees on the affairs of the Company, which sat during the last session of Parliament, has been printed by order of the House of Commons, on the motion of Mr. ROEBUCK.

GENERAL CALHOUN.--We COPY from the Albany Statesman a letter from ANDREW H. CALHOUN, Esq., explaining and defending the position of his brother, the President of the Lecompton Convention. We give place to this defence in a spirit of fairness and justice; for the public should

Ever since the obstinacy and insolence of the Chinese authorities forced the questions at issue between them and the "foreign barbarians" to the solution of the sword, we have steadily advocated the propriety and necessity of such action on the part of our own representatives in China as should compel the Chinese to recognize the American flag as equally respectable and important with the ensigns of England, Russia and France.

In the Senate of the United States, yesterday morning, Mr. STUART, of Michigan, had the floor, and spoke at length on the Kansas question, taking the ground that the Lecompton Constitution was fraudulent. He expresses astonishment that the President should desire to bring Kansas into the Union, after saying in his message that she was in a state of rebellion.

The Jesuitical doctrine that the good motive of an ill deed qualifies the wrong done into a positive merit, has never we believe beer form ally accepted as a principle of administration in this country. In fact, most of the ill deeds of our various rulers have been performed without even the pretext of a righteous intention.

Mr. DOUGLAS IN THE SENATE CHAMBER.--During the delivery of Mr. STUART'S Anti-Le-compton speech of yesterday, Mr. DOUGLAS, who it is well known, has been confined to his home by illness for a week or more, made his appearance in the Senate Chamber, and was observed to be in close private conversation with Mr. GREEN, of Missouri.
