To the Editor of the New-York Times: I noticed a day or two since, an article signed by "A General Book keeper," denouncing in a wholesale manner, Bank Cashiers generally, as incompetent and unfamiliar with double entry, and asserting that he could show up a system whereby fraud could not be practiced.

Loss of a Schuooer - Rescue of her Crew. GEERIEE ports that when 35 miles S. E. from Halifax he fell in with the schooner Dant, of Lunenberg, bound to Peters, Miquelon, from Hallifax on the 12th in loaded with lumber.

By the arrival of the steamer St. Mary's (bringing Col. GARRETT and Mr. JOHNSON) we are in posse-sion of the following Indian news: On the evening of tile 10th February a warrior of BOWLEGS' party, and a negro belonging to that chief, approached the station occupied by the delegation of friendly Indians.

The election for Ward and City Officers of Brooklyn takes place on Tuesday, April 6, under a new law. Hereafter, but one Alderman, instead of two, is to represent each Ward. The Common Council have ordered the election and given the required notice. It was feared that the election would go by default, ad then Democratic of course.

ANNOYANCES IN RAILROAD CARS--A correspondent complains, in a communication which we publish to-day, of sufferings endured from open windows in cars. Many passengers, and especially ladies, he avers, are in the habit of greatly discommoding those around them by pertinaciously keeping open the windows next which they sit,

The hat and fur store of Mr. WM. WARD, corner of Montgomery and Warren streets, Jersey City, was entered by burglars during Monday night an robbed of goods to the value of about $200. The coal office of Mr. R. B. WAKEMAN, in Hudson-street, was also entered the same night, but the thieves failed in getting any booty. The safe, however, bore evidence of having been well tried.

Fine by degrees and beautifully less grow the points upon which Mr. BUCHANAN is making his stand against the disorganizers of the Democratic Party, and the rapidly-growing demonstrations of the popular sentiment of the nation. At seven o'clock last night, the Dymock of the reigning dynasty, Mr. GREEN, of Missouri, flung down his champion's gauntlet in the arena.

The Senate is again crowded to-day. The preliminary business was unimportant. Mr. GREEN commenced by denying the assertion of the Senator from Michigan (STUART) that the friend, of Lecompton have been driven from their positions The Senator from Illinois (DOUGLAS) implied the same thing, but it is not so, and the Committee's re port stands unchallenged.

Colburn, and the members of the New-York Typographical Union No. 6, are respectfully invited to shield the inneral from the residence of her parents. No. 110 Essex-st. at 12 o'clock this day. ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--The "Huguenots" will be given to-night for the last time but one . Mme, LA GRANGE has entirely recovered from her indisposition, and will sing the music of Valentine. EISFELD'S SOIREE.--Mr. EISFELD'S fourth classical ?? (eighth season) was given last evening at Dodworth's rooms.

The Faculty of Yale College have at length determined upon the dismission of three members of the Junior Class on account of their connection with the unfortunate affray last February between the students and the firemen. As the most serious charge brought against any one of them is firing a pistol loaded only with powder, it is not worth while to mention names.

JONES vs. PERSSE BROOKS.--A paragraph appeared in the TIMES of Saturday, alluding to certain proceedings before the Reverse in the case of JONES vs. PERSSE BROOKS, the well-known paper makers . That any such statement as that contained in the offer in the paragraph referred to could be substantiated, is, we are assured, u edy fate.

The President appointed the following gentlemen as a Grinding Committee: Messrs. Noxon, Ely, Sloan, O. B. Wheeler, Foote, W. A. Wheeler, Williams and Wadsworth. The bill to improve the discipline and promote the efficiency of the Militia, was ordered to a third reading. NOTICE OF BILL. By Mr. SPINOLA, a bill for the protection of hotel keepers.

The steamer St. Lawrence, from Pittsburg for New-Orleans, struck on the rocks near Pomeroy Ohio, on Sunday and sunk. The boat was valued at $20,000, and is a total loss. A portion of the cargo will be recovered in a damaged condition. No lives were lost.

It was the "general orders" in the House this morning. The most important bill considered was that exempting the firemen of the several villages from taxation on all property the assessed value of which does not exceed $500. I confess my inability to see any good reason why such a law should be enacted.

SIGNS OF RETURNING BUSINESS.--The pleasantest intelligence we receive from the neighboring States, and from the interior towns in our own State, in that in relation to the resumption of work by the various manufacturing establishments that have been lying idle the past four months.

Honorable CALER CUSHING lately delivered a lecture before some Democratic Association in Boston, in which he attempted to explain the cause of the chaotic condition of governmental affairs in all the Spanish American Republics on this Continent, but especially in relation to the Republic of Mexico, which has the finest country and the worst government of them all.

Captain DURHAM, of tile bark Adriatic, has now published his own version of his own story. Divested of all technicalities, the account which he gives of himself and his proceedings may be very briefly summed up in a single phrase. He is, by his own confession, a fugitive from justice.

The liabilities of those who are subject to military duty, who do not belong to any military organization, and who are not exempt from duty by the laws of this State, or of the United States, do not appear to be clearly understood, if we judge from the number of correspondents who ask for information.

Senator DOUGLAS made a speech of characteristic boldness and power on Monday night. He went to the Senate from a sick bed, suffering greatly from physical debility, to discharge his duly by opposing the Lecompton bill. The chamber was thronged, as it is only on great occasions. Galleries, lobbies, floor, even the seats of members, were filled with spectators.

The Royal Mail steamship Niagara, with one week's later news from Europe, is now due at Halifax from Liverpool. She had not been heard from at that port at a late hour last night. To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR: In your paper of to-day I notice an article, under the caption of "Foundling Hospitals Needed," in which some severe reflections are cast upon the Captain of the Third Precinct for allowing the child of ANN MURRAY to be put in the cells with her on the occasion of her arrest on Saturday night, March 6.

The Leavenworth Times of the 19th says that yesterday morning two companies of infantry and two of cavalry left the Fort for Utah. They design overtaking Col. HOFFMAN and the escort of the supply train for Col. JOHNSTON'S army, from Fort Laramie. This train consists of 160 heavily loaded wagons.

The American bark Adriatic, which became famous from her disastrous collision with the French steamer Lyonnais, in November, 1856, and still an object of interest from her recent seizures by French authorities at Marseilles, her confiscation the Court of Admiralty, and her subsequent escape arrived safely at this port at an early hour yesterday.

SOLITARY AND ALONE.--The Boston Bee claims to be the only paper in that city which "unqualifiedly indorses" the removal of Judge LORING. Considering that there are several other able and respectable journals of the same party in Boston, the fact of which the Bee boasts should inspire both it and Governor BANKS with sincere regret.

A GRINDING COMMITTEE.-Information comes from Albany that the President of the Senate has "appointed the Annual Grinding Committee." Have the conscript fathers gone into the milling business? Capitol Hill would be an excellent site for a wind-mill. Is wind the moving power in legislative grinding? Some there are who say so.

The Lecomptonite Senators held a caucus this morning, at which it was agreed not to yoke Minneseta with Kansas. This was done because Kansas alone will be less objectionable to the South Americans in the House. It was also agreed to make an amendment substantially like PUGH'S, relative to the right of the people to alter the Constitution.

In the Recorder's Office yesterday the Case of JAMES B SMITH, Charged by Comptroller FLAGG with inserting false entries in the books belonging to the Street Department, was again brought before his Honor. At the Commencement of proceedings, Mr. GRAHAN moved that Mr. FLAGG himself, the Complanant, should be sworn and cross-examined on his own effidavit Judge WHITING strenuously objected. ected.

The Board of Aldermen met last evening. President CLANCY in the Chair. A communication was received from the Mayor, stating the fact that the records in the Registrar's office had been injured by water from the Street Commissioner's office, which had been left running during the night before. He recommended that the water should be cut off, similar accidents had occurred before.

Coroner CAMBLK, with his deputy, PHILIP O'HANLON, commenced an inquest upon the body of Paudeen at 10 o'clock A. M. yesterday. The following are the names of to Jurors. N. A. Everybody who has ever been charmed by the rich voice and refined method of Miss NATHELE in the concert room, or by the inimitable religious vocalism of Mrs. BODSTEIN in Grace Church,will be glad to know that the congregation to whose service this accomplished lady has of late years de. voted her talents, propose to pay her the welldeserved honor of a complimentary concern.

SUPREME COURT--Special Term.--Nos. 149, 66, 84, 95 120, 23, 79, 128, 67, 103, 153, 154, 155, 155 1/2, 156, 158, 115, 131, 139, 28. UNITED STATES CIRCUIT COURT.--March 28. Before Judge Hall. A noble prosequa was entered this morning in the case of William woods, made of the bark Esco??, indicted for an assault with intent to commit a rape upon the person of Maria Josephs, stewardess of the bark.

The people of Staten Island are not asleep. some time ago a few gentlemen of the Rev. Mr. THOMPSON'S church formed Young Men's christian association on the island, which is now in efficient operation, At a meeting on Saturday evening the young men concluded to open their rooms on Beach-street, at Stapleton, opposite Mr. LUDLOW'S store. for a union Prayer-meeting.

The monument to the memory of the tragedian, J. B. Booth, preparing in Boston, is an obelisk nine feet high, upon a pedestal five feet six inches high and is rapidly advancing to completion. The profile bead surrounded with laurels, with which the front of the obelisk is to be embellished, is completed in plaster. The monument is to be ready for delivery next month, and will be placed in the cemetery in Baltimore.

The Sub-Committee appointed by the Tammany Hall General Committee, to Investigate and report in relation to the Secret organizations of members of the Democratic Party of this City, are now engaged in collecting what information they can obtain preparatory to making a report.

PETITIONS. By Mr. SCHELL, Of Underwriters and Merchants of the City of New-York, against the removal of quarantine. REPORTS. By Mr. Ames, adverse to any change In the Hell Gate Pilot law. Agreed to. Also, to complete the incorporation of the Long Island Steamboat Company.

SIR: It affords me great pleasure to present to you, in the name of the People of the State of NewYork, the Gold Medal struck in your honor, in obedience to the Joint Resolution of the Legislature of this State at its last session.

To the House of Representatives: An Address of both Houses of the Legislature was presented to me yesterday by a Committee appointed for that purpose, requesting the removal of EDWARD GRERIEY LORING from the office of Judge of Probate for the county of Suffolk. The reasons which moved the Legislature to this request were not stated in the Address.

MORE TROUBLE WITH THE POLICE.-The Jersey City Common Council, during the past year, have granted only a few licenses to sell liquor, and in almost every Instance where license was refused it has been followed by selling without it.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In reply to "Accountant," who assumes that I propose to detail "two or more clerks to do the work now done by one," I will only say that I propose no such thing. Neither do I claims superior wisdom.

MOUNT VERNON--LETTER FROM GOV. WISE--GOV. WISE has written the following letter to the editor of the Vicksburg Whig: RICHMOND, Va., Wednesday, March 3, 1858. DEAR SIR: My opinion is that Virginia will never allow the remains of WASHINGTON to be removed from Mount Vernon, except to her own monument to his memory at Richmond.

ARMSTRONG--DU BOIS.--At Evansville, la., on Thursday, March 18, by the Rev. Mr. Wilbur, ABRL W. ARMSTRONG, of Evansville, to SARAH JANE, oldest daughter of the late Peter Du Bois of this City.

Mr. SEWARD presented the resolutions of the Legislature of New-York in opposition to Lecompton. They were ordered to be printed. Mr. SEWARD quoted the remarks of the Duke of ARGYLE at the banquet given to Dr. LIVINGSTONE, denying the truth of the opinion that the British Government is tending towards the reestablishment of Slavery.

Hall, the Alton Penitentiary convict, died on Saturday morning. For sixteen hours previous to his death he was paralyzed and insensible. From the time he was shot till he died paralysis made slow but certain work upon him. His two confederates, the convicts who have been missing since the calling of the roll last Friday evening, were found on Wednesday.

BURIED ALIVE--A DISTRESSING CASE--A letter dated Holland, Erie County, Pa., March 15, says: A very afflictive dispensation of Providence has taken place within twenty miles of this place. A Presbyterian minister named REED was going t attend a meeting of the Presbytery. He stopped overnight with another minister at private house. Mr. REED was taken with a fit in the night, and it was supposed he had died.

THE CONTESTED ASSEMBLY SEAT.- The seat of Mr. JOHN G. SEELEY, a member of the Assembly from this City, is contested by Mr. JAMES A. DOLAN, on the ground that Mr. SEELEY did not reside, at the time he was elected, in the District he represents. It is understood that while Mr. S. does business in this City, his residence is in Westchester County.

INTERNAL IMPROVEMENTS IN VIRGINIA.--The Virginia House of Delegates, on Saturday last, passed internal improvement bills, making the following appropriations: To the Norfolk and Petersburg Railroad, $300,000--Yeas 79, Nays 30. To the Covington and Ohio Railroad, $800,000--Yeas 78, Nays 54.

The Washington letter-writer of the Richmond South, under the date of March 18, says: The feeling of Southern members of Congress at the prospect of the admission of Kansas is various, and by no means one of unmixed satisfaction.

The condition and prospects of the magnificent Territories which are now given up to Mexican misrule, and to all the chances of a permanent state of chaos, are not absolutely matters of indifference to all the world beside ourselves.

From the Rochester Union. About a month since a poisoning case, said to have occurred in Henrictta, was hinted at in the city papers. The matter has rested until to-day, when an application was made to Police-Justice BARDWELL for a warrant for the arrest of a wife charged with attempting to destroy her husband.

From the Pittsburg Gazette, 10th. The immense cannon foundry known as the Fort Pitt Works was destroyed on Thursday morning. The fire broke out about 4 o'clock, and the whole extensive square occupied by these celebrated works was land in ruins in a few hours. These works have enjoyed a just celebrity for a long time, from the great superiority of their manufactures.

It says:
The following is an entirely correct copy of the Lecompton Bill, in the shape in which it passed the Senate on Tuesday: A Bill for the admission of the State of Kansas into the Union.
The Committee of the Common Council on Repairs and Supplies have reported adversely to the Mayor's proposition for the erection of a building in the Park to contain the Courts and the Post-Office.

A letter by the overland mail vid El Paso and San Antiono to Lieutenant MOWRY, dated Arizona, Feb. 7, states that Gen. GANDARA, the leader of the rebellion at Sonora, has been entirely successful, having defeated the Government troops in several battles. At the last accounts GANDARA had surrounded PESOHIERA, the Governor, so as to cut off all hopes of escape.

The Utah correspondent of the Leader, writing under date of Jan. 31, says that Mr. MOWETT and SOL GEE, who started for the Flathead country on the 24th of December, had returned. They reached the encampment of Capt. MAGRAW'S command on the Popongie branch of Wind River, where their march was arrested by deep snow.

THE LOUISIANA SCHEME OF AFRICAN APPEENTICESHIP.--Some time ago, as our readers are aware, a bill was introduced in the lower House of the Louisiana Legislature to authorize the importation of 2,600 negroes from Africa, as " apprentices," for a term of fifteen years. The bill passed the House with little opposition.

A small shanty at the foot of Court-street was destroyed by fire Tuesday night. While the firemen were going to this fire, JoHN T. DAYTON, of Engine Company No. 20, was run over and severely injured internally. MICHAEL BRADY, of Engine No. 16, had his ankle dislocated.

The bill for the admission of Minnesota will evidently pass the Senate promptly, without material objection. Mr. CLARK'S speech on Kansas in the House, today, was listened to with marked attention. It was able and ingenious, showing how a Democrat may vote against Lecompton without losing his party position.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Will you have the Kindness to suggest to the Commissioners of Police that they allow the number on the Policeman's cap to be abolished, as it is very evident the time consumed by them in endeavoring to conceal it must interfere seriously with their duties;

BURIAL OF PAUDEEN. DANIEL CUNNINGH M who shot Paudeen on Saturday morning last at the dance-house No. 23 Howard-street, was brought before Coroner GAM??, at the Tombs, yesterday, at 12 M., this being the hour assigned for an examination upon the question of admitting him to oail Only some half dozen persons were present during the proceedings.

We have not yet arrived at the millenium of municipal affairs, but another step has been taken towards it; the Sir Toby Belches of the Almshouse Department, the Ten Governors, have virtuously resolved, as though they were so many Malvolios, that they would no longer indulge in cakes and ale at the public expense. And that ginger should never more be hot in the mouths of visitors to Prisons and Hospitals.

THE INTERIOR TRADE OF THE COUNTRY.--Apparently we are to have an early commencement of Canal and River business. The Hudson has been navigable for several days. The ice has left the upper Mississippi. so that from St Paul to New-Orleans, that great artery of trade, is open. Its chief branches, the Missouri and the Ohio, have been navigable for weeks.

HOW many financial operations will be necessary to enable the truism to penetrate the cabezas of officers and Directors of our Banking Institutions that the best and only security worth baring is to make it for the interest f a man to be honest?

An immense Democratic Anti-Lecompton meeting was held at the City Hall to-night. G. F. GILLMORE, the late editor of the Post, presided, assisted by forty-four Vice-Presidents and fourteen Secretaries.

The Santa Fe Mail arrived at Independence on the 22d inst. Capt. MARCY was to leave Fort Union for Utah on the 25th inst., with a thousand head of mules. Lieut. BEALE came passenger from Santa Fe. He left Los Angelos, California, Jan. 10, with twentytwo men and mules, having sent the camels back from the Colorado River.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: DEAR SIR: You have doubtless often, when traveling on our railway cars, remarked the ridiculous notion that prevails amongst most passengers as to their right of opening windows, when sealed near them.

NEWSPAPER CHANGE.--The Albany Statesman of Tuesday, announces that Messrs. MUNSELL Co. have transferred their entire interest in the paper to JAMES B SWAIN Co. "In making the official announcement of the change, (the new proprietors say,) they retrain from the `professional of faith' usual on such occasions, further than to say that its future will not stultify its past history.

WHY COUSINS SHOULD NOT MARRY.-In the annual report of the Superintendent of the Kentucky Institution for the Deaf and Dumb, we find the following conclusive argument against the marriage of consins: " From ten to twelve per cent. of deaf mutes are the children of cousins. It is greatly to be regretted that the law forbidding the marriage of first cousins did riot pass the recent Legislature.

TIMBER FOR THE ENGLISH GOVERNMENT. -We understand that there are now in this city several gentleman, who came here agents for the British Government, for the purpose of contracting for the furnishing of three millions feet of timber, to be used in the construction of vossele-of-war for her Majesty's navy.

Life in a garrison town like Carlisle shows some curious features. Carlisle itself is an ancient, quiet burgh, the second town in age in Pennsylvania--Philadelphia only outranking it. It is a town of 4,000 inhabitants, the centre of Cumberland Country, and dignified by the advantages of a county seat. All day it is solemn and Orderly. When the evening shadows fall, it takes another character.

WINES--In this City, on Tuesday afternoon, March 23, HANNAH, wife of Salem Wines, of this City, aged 68 years. The Friends of the family are respectfully invited to at her the residence, No. 84 Monroe st. PUNT.--In this City, on Tuesday, March 23, Mrs. ZILLAH PUNT, daughter of the late Wm. McLaughdin, aged 37 years, 7 months and 13 days.

LAND SALES IN KANSAS.--The President has issued his Proclamation, No. 601, which appears in this morning's paper, for sales of public lands at the land offices at Kickapoo and Lecompton, Kansas Territory, in July next. The first sale at Kickadoo on the 5th July, embraces 798,095 acres, and that on the 19th, 701, 082 acres.

The bill authorizing the importation into Louisiana of 2,500 Africans, after passing the House with little or no opposition, has been rejected in the Senate, at the close of a most violent and exciting debate, by a majority of two. The measure is, therefore, for the present essentially defunct.

The steamer Empire State was floated off the rocks at Matinnacock Point on Tuesday evening. At low water some additional oil casks were placed under her after guards, and at high water she floated. The Neptune towed her down to Hart Island, where she remained anchored until yesterday morning, when the William I, Webb took her In tow, and brought her to the wharf of the Novelty Works.

The Mount Vernon Ladies' Association of the Union bare been incorporated by the Legislative of Virginia and authorized to purchase. Mount Vernon, which is to revert to the Coromoweatlh, if from any cause the Association shall sense to exist. It is understood that Col. WASHINGTON will now consent to seli Mount Vernon to the Association.

From Yesterday's Albany Atlas and Argus, The Committee of Ways and Means in the Assembly are preparing bills which will be presented soon for the consideration of the Legislature, to carry out the plan agreed upon by the Democratic State Officers and members of the Legislative, to complete the unfinished public works.

CAPITAL OF PENNSYLVANIA.--The Senate of Pennsylvania has adopted are solution authorizing the appointment of a Committee to inquire into the propriety of removing the seat of government from Harrisburg to Philadelphia. There is nothing very improbable in this change, or in a similar one in our own State. In these days of railroad traveling one or two hundred miles of distance is little regarded

LECOMPTON IN THE HOUSE--THE DAY FIXED--On Thursday, April 1, at one o'clock, Mr. STEPHENS, of Georgia, will move to take the Senate Kansas bill from the Speaker's table, and then immediately move the previous question thereon.

The annual examination of the Public Schools of Jersey City, was concluded yesterday with the Primary Department of No. 1. Much interest has been manifested by the public, and the exercises have been witnessed by crowded assemblages of citizens. The total number of pupils registered in the two schools during the year was 2,019, and the average attendance was 1,353.

Men like POZZO DI BORGIIO, TALLEYRAND, and METTERNICH made themselves important in their day and generation, and carried a world-wide reputation for superior ability, by carrying on a system of such profound rascality in the relations of nation with

The Legislature of this young and vigorous State is now in session in this City of Lakes. For some weeks past the Joint Committee of Investigation to inquire into the frauds connected with the disposal of the land grants have been employed In taking testimony.

The business of the morning hour was unionportant, with the exception of the presentation of some Anti-Slavery resolutions from the State of Maine. Mr. MASON, of Virginia, objected to them in strong terms, as disrespectful to Congress, the Judiciary and the President.

SECTIONALISM-WHAT IS IT?-A few days since, the New-York Journal of Commerce laid the charge of " Sectionalism" at the doors of all who approve the passage of the Lecompton Constitution, and expressed its regret to find many who formerly professed nationality of views and principles among the opponents of that measure.

NEW REVENUE CUTTER IN COMMISSION.--The United States Revenue steam-cutter Harriet Lane has been accepted by the Government, and went in commission yesterday. A list of her officers has already been published. She left the foot of Seventh-street, E. R., on Wednesday, at 12 o'clock, and proceeded down the Bay on her final trial trip.

It is the general understanding among the members of the House that the vote will be taken on the Kansas question on Thursday next. It is believed by the opponents of the bill that they will leave seven majority in favor of the proposition made by Mr. CRITTENDEN in the Senate, but there is reason to fear that certain three Republicans will not vote for fear bill even if thus amended.

It is curious to what an extent public attention here at the capital is absorbed by Kansas affairs. Nobody, in or out of Congress, talks or thinks of anything else. At dinners, in the streets, even at evening parties, the fate of Lecompton is the leading theme of conversation.

RECOVERY OF FOUR MORE BODIES FROM THE WRECK OF THE SHIP JOHN MILTON..--S. W. CAREY, Esq., has furnished us with the following extract from a better to CRAS. A. LUCE, Esq., from Dr. HUNTINGTON, the Coroner at East Hampton. EAST HAMPTON, Sunday, March 21, 1858. Within the past week I have buried four more of the crew of the John Milton.

The Mobile Advertiser, speaking of Parson Brownlow, holds the following complimentary language: "What must be the impression as to the character of the Southern people upon the minds of the ignorant masses of the North when they behold and listen to this blackguard Tencesseean, and are told that he is a minister of the Gospel, and the chosen champion of Southern institutions. seat among them by the people of the South?

To the Editor of the New- York Times: Will you allow a plain man, one who is not a politician, to call your attention to a phase of this Kansas affair, which he has not seen noticed before. The American public must be well satisfied by this time that the Lecompton Party will not, as it has not heretofore, stop at any fraud that will give them power.

The Lee-avenue Church was crowded again last night, as it is every Thursday, with old and young men, women and children, attending the " Boys, meeting," over which Mr. JEREMIAH JOHNSON presides. The room, which will pack, in an emergency, not less than 1,200, is still decorated with the Christmas wreaths and mottoes, which add greatly to its beauty.

Neither the Fulton, duo at this port, nor the Niagara, due at Halifax, had been heard from up to the time of going to press. The former is now in her sixteenth day, and the latter in her thirteenth. The California steamship Moses Taylor is also about due.

The Commissioners of Metropolitan Force met yesterday, at 3 P. M., in accordance with the previous adjournment:. All the members of the Board were present. The minutes of the previous meeting were read and approved. The charge against Frederick Mariott, of the Eighth Precinet, Brooklyn, was, on motion of Mr. CHOLWELL, dismissed.

VALENTINE--In this city, on Wednesday evening, March 2d RICHARD C. VALENTINE, aged 42 years. The relatives and friends of the family and the members of Oriental Lodge. No. 68, I ?? of O F., are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, on Saturday. March 27 at 2 o' clock P. M. from his late residence, No. 206 East Broadway. The remains will be taken to Greenwood for interment.

The steamship Tennessee has arrived, from Vera Clus 21st inst., with advises from the City of Mexico to the 16th. It is very difficult to obtain reliable information, but the following is probably pretty near correct: Several battles has been fought between the Constitutional forces and those of the Zutoaga Government. The latter claim a triumph but it don't amount to much.

Bourbon County continues a theatre of excitement and bloodshed, and from latest news, still further troub es are anticipated. "Preacher STEWART', was in our city a few days since, fresh from the scene, and represents that about sixty Pro-Slavery men have been under arms the last fortnight, and the settlers along the Little Osage have suffered greatly from their robbery and outrage.

In Lent the violins are still, the dancers cease their dancing, the costumes are folded away, the fat oxen have terminated their three days' triumph by an ignominious death in the butcher's shop, the chicards and the mohicans are poring over their desks or toiling in their shops. Of what shall I talk to-day ?

In the Chancery Court, at Louisville, Judge Logan has rendered a decision in an important telegraphic suit. A suit was entered by A. E. CAMP against the Western Union Telegraph Line to recover damages for loss resulting from erroneous transmission of a message. Plaintiff ordered a certain amount of whisky by telegraph, at the rate of fifteen conis.

THE AMERICAN POSITION IN CHINA..-A letter from on board the Minnesota, dated Hong Kong Jan. 14, and published in the Philadelphia Evening Journal says: "Our position here is regarded as exceedingly awkward. As long as the difficulties with the Chinese were the subjects of negotiation the American Commissioner was treated with respect by all parties.

The Pittsburg Post, speaking of business prospects, says: "Our manufactories are again at work, and in all departments talent, energy and enterpirse, and the profitable employment of capital, are gradually and healthfully triumphing over the hard times. Everything looks encouraging, and before the Spring is open everything will be moving calmly in its accustomed channel."

PETITIONS. By Mr. WHEELER, against any radical change in the banking laws. By Mr. ELY, to amend the Brooklyn Water Works act. By Mr. AMES, to increase the depth of water in the Hudson River opposite Troy. By Mr. BRANDEETH, to amend the Charter of the Excelsior Collge.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.-- Mr. FORMES takes his first American benefit to-night, and plays in the "Huguenots," which opera will be given for the last time. The magnificence of the misc en scene, the excellence of the general distribution, but more particularly the admirable performance of Mr. FORMES as Marcel, has given this opera a vast amount of popularity.

A recent letter from President BENSON, of Liberia, dated Feb. 1, says: "I feel greatly encouraged amidst the pecuniary pressure. I feel that our citizens are approaching true independence nearer than ever. The number and quality of the articles exhibited at the fair for exceeded the expectations of the most sanguine: and the whole enterprise has astonishingly stimulated the citizens throughout the Republic.

The Senate had an active sitting to-day. There was some old work finished up, some considerable that is new laid out, and some work that had beer badly finished was reconsidered and sent back where it could be retouched and made more nearly to con form to the actual condition of things.

Col. BENTON is confined to his bed, with cancer of the stomach. He works upon his Abridgement of the Congressional Debates as steadily as ever, and hopes to live long enough to finish it. [FROM THE REPORTER FOR THE ASSOCIATED PRESS.] WASHINGTON, Friday, March 25. The Secretary of the Treasury has appointed a commission to examine into the state of navigation of Cape Fear River.

The Senate is not in session, having yesterday adjorned till Monday. HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES. WASHINGTON, Friday, March 26. On motion of Mr. WASHBURNE, of Illinois, a resolution was adopted instruction the Committee on Public Lands to inquire whether the main truck of the Dubuque and Sioux City Railroad is completed,

It really seems as if there was no chance of getting the Executive arid a certain portion of the public to look upon criminals in any other light than as ill-used and greatly-to-be pitied individuals. The sympathies of juries are notoriously, for the most part, not with the victims of crirne, but with the perpetrators of it.

The Royal Mail Steamship Niagara, Captain WICKMAN, left Liverpool about 9 A.M. on Saturday, the 13th inst., arrived at Halifax at 6 A.M. of the 26th. The Niagara reports, March 13, passed the American ships Rochester, Isaac Webb and American Union, bound into Liverpool; 14th, off Arklow, exchanged signals with a large steamer; 15th, off Cape Clear, exchanged signals with a large steamer, supposed to be the Africa.

Schenck and Fowler and others for a terry from Desbrosses-street, North River, to Jersey City. The petition was referred. SANTA ANNA ON HIS WAY TO MEXICO. --Our Aspinwall correspondent informs us that Ex-President SANTA ANNA, accompanied by his family, embarked on the 12th instant, at Carthagena on board the British mail steamship Clyde, for ST. Thomas and Havana. He was, doubtless, on route for Mexico.

The (Baptist) Examiner of this week savs : "Our revival summary for three weeks past, though imperfect, of necessity shows a great advance. Over seventeen thousand conversions are therein specified, and the ingathering, on probation and otherwise, reported in our Methodist exchanges during the same period, announces, by our own count, to over twenty thousand more."

If the difficulties which arose out of an III advised correspondence between the authoritative satellites of NAPOLKON III. and the apologetic Cabinet of Lord PALMESTON had ever been in any just sense of the word, national difficulties between France and England, we might now regard them as satisfactorily arranged.

The following private letter to a gentleman in this City, illustrates the temper of the Mormon people, and proves very clearly that they are determined to obey their chief even to the extremity of war:

SECRET MEETING OF THE MEMBERS OF THE CHURCH OF THE PURITANS.--Yesterday evening, at the close of the prayer-meeting in the lecture room of Dr. CHEEVER'S Church. a meeting of members was held for the purpose of discussing the questions arising out of the request of a number of their body, who were anxious to separate from it, for letters of recommendation to other churches.

The United States Mail steamship Moses Taylor, JOHN MCGOWAN, Esq., commanding, from Aspinwall on the 18th inst. at 5 o'clock P. M. arrived at this port yesterday morning. The Moses Taylor brings the California mails of the 5th inst., and passengers brought down from San Francisco by the Pacific Mail steamship Golden Age.

Shortly alter 1 o'clock, yesterday afternoon, the south will of the late Arbeiter Hall Building, No. 5 South Frederick-street, fell with a tremendous crash, catching six boys under it. all of whom were seriously, and, it is feared, two of them fatally, hurt. From an early hour in the morning the wall had been thought to he in a dangerous condition, and the police officers several times drove away the boys.

About 1 o'clock on Sunday morning, the Police of the Fifth Precinct made a descent on the house known as the "Fulton House," situated at No. 119 Fourth-street, and arrested eighteen persons, who were engaged in playing faro, bluff, and other games for money. The apparatus consisting of a dealing and cue box, together with cards, checks, and $3 11 in silver, were seized and confiscated to the use of the Police Insurance Fund.

The United States Mail steamship Fulton arrived at this port yesterday morning. She left southampton on the 11th, and brings London papers of that day. Her advices have been anticipatedby the Niagara at Halifax; but from our files of papers, which are five days later than any yet received, we obtain some further intelligence of interest.
Santa Fe papers of the 27th ult., are received, but they contain no news of special importance. Some Indian depredations and several wanton outrages by the Mexicans against the Indians are reported.

BILLS REPORTED. By Mr. FOOTE, a bill to appropriate moneys to General WARD B. BUENETT, for moneys expended by him in raising a regiment of volunteers during the late war with Mexico. By Mr. NOXON, a bill to allow the Corporation of the City of New-York to grant titles of land under water.

GEAHAM--MOTT,--In this City, at the Church of the Ascension, on Thursday, March 25, by the Rev, G.T.Bedell. D.D., CLINTON GRAHAM to LOUISA M. RING, daughter of Samuel F. Mott all of this City.

EXCITEMENT ABOUT A WILL.--The will of the late JOSEPH PAUL,a wealthy farmer of Warrington township, Bucks County, is just now the subject of much surmise and remark. Mr. PAUL was killed by falling from a barrack. He left a widow, a lady who, at the time of her marriage, was possessed of $1,000 or $3,000 In her own right, but no children.

Those of us who have been in the habit of regarding the American Union as a tolerably substantial reality, founded upon the good sense, the justice, the patriotism, and the common interest of the States which compose it, have something yet to learn.

Spring is fairly here at last, and the bright sunshine tempts forth troops of fair ones every morning, many of them wearing the daintiest bonnets and the prettiest robes is quitte that expressmen have ever brought from your metropolis.

THE SING SING CONVICT POISONING CASE.-Coroner HILLS held an inquest yesterday, at No. 297 West Twenty-eighth-street, upon the body of MICHAEL MARVIN, the convict who died on Monday last at Sing Sing Prison, Mr. BEARDSLEY, warden of the Prison, testified that the deceased first complained on Sunday; that on Monday, while in the workshop, he was taken suddenly ill, and was removed to the Hospital. where he died tour hours afterwards.

The Great Awakening. Perhaps it was partly in consequence of the advertisement that the Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER was expected to deliver an address, that the effort of the main admission into Burton's old Theatre on Saturday was most unprecedented.

The Staten Island Chronicle states that Dr. BISSELL, Physician of the Marine Hospital, has reconstructed and very much enlarged the Quarantine Light-house. The improvement was very much needed. While an increased intensity of light at Quarantine will thus be advantageous to commerce, it cannot help being of service in protecting the public health.

IMPORTANT ARREST OF COUNTERFEITERS--Mr. CARPENTER, the Police Deputy Superintendent, aided by detectives WILDEY and KING, have been some time on the ?? look-out for the balance of the gang of ?? connected with the notorious Joe lane and Honora Shephard. Since the escape of Lane and the disappearance of Honora, there has been a comparative l?? in the business.

JOHN COCHRANE was Chairman of the Democratic caucus on Saturday evening. STEPHENS, of Georgia, made a strong speech to show that the only hope of the Union was in the unity of the Democratic Party, and that everything possible should be done to preserve this harmony.

ACADEMY 0F MUSIC.--Mr. FRY'S opera of "Leonora" will be produced here to-night for the first time in this City. It will be repeated on Wednesday, and then--. We desire to call particular attention to this event, because it is of a kind which requires especial recognation.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I must differ with "A Book-Keeper's Wife," as to what is "a living salary" in New-York City; and cannot think it the least shadow of a palliation for dishonesty in a book-keeper, that he gets a salary of only $1,500, while he wants $2,000 at least, to "live respectably."

Letters received here from the Secretary of the Michigan Southern Railroad, and other parties, state that the recent counter-circular of Messrs. JERVIS, OLYPHANT, and RIGGS, three Directors of the Michigan Southern Railroad, asking for proxies for the annual election in April, is not sanctioned by the Board. The only authorized circular is signed by WM. WALCOT, Secretary.

Some of his suggestions are interesting: " Of the complaints made, some are found to be without any reasonable cause, having their origin in the peculiar disposition of the Individual.

Arrival of the Empire City--Capture of a Slaver by a British Cruser--Increase of Chinese Immigration to Havana--The Slave Trade--Business, The Empire City, Captain, S. P. GRIFFIN, from Havana on the 23 inst., arrived at this port yesterday morning.

The residence of Mr. RUFUS K. TERRY, No. 137 Mercer-street, Jersey City, was entered by burglars during Friday night, and robbed of jewelry, clothing, and money to the value of about $1,000. The house was thoroughly ransacked, and every article of value taken. The inmates were not disturbed, and It is thought that chloroform was administered.

NIAGARA SHIP CANAL.--Four or five years ago a Company, embracing some of the most influential citizens of Western New-York and of this City, was organized for the purpose of constructing a Ship Canal around the Falls of Niagara. It is proposed that the work shall commence about three miles above the Falls, and terminate in the vicinity of Lewiston, making its length six or eight miles.

The steamship St. Louis, W. H. HUDSON, Commanding, left New-York at P. M. of the 6th inst., with 631 passengers and full cargo for San Francisco. On the second day after leaving New-York she encountered a severe gale which lasted 52 hours, during which the St. Louis displayed sea-going qualities of high order.

Judge BETTS has rendered decisions in the following cases heard before him. The pressure of business prevented his Honor from writing any detailed opinions on them. We shall give a summary of the points decided: Adman hissam vs. The brig Albert.--Libel dismissed, with costs King Benjamin vs. The schooner Watchman.--Libel dismissed, with costs

The Senate is not in session. HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES. WASHINGTON, Saturday, March 27. The House proceeded to the consideration of the report of the Special Committee in regard to the Matteson case, which concludes with a resolution that it is inexpedient to take further action in regard to tte resolution for his expulsion.

There is nothing new, to-day, in connection with the Lecompton swindle. Its friends and opponents are working like beavers, to get their forces into good working order for Thursday next, when it is fully expected that the vote will be taken.

The United States Mail steamship Fulton, from Havre and Southampton, arrived at this port yesterday morning. The Fulton was unable to leave Have until Thursday, March 11, 6 P. M., in consequence of there not being sufficient water in the docks, caused by the easterly gales blowing at that port for some time.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The controversy going on with reference to the approaching election of Directors for the Michigan Southern and Northern Indiana Railroad Company seems likely to bring out some facts of general interest. May I ask your correspondent "Countryman" from what part of the country he hails? He has not yet found there three honest then.

Mr. FRY'S OPERA OF LEONORA --Mr. ULLMAN proved that he is the Napoleon of managers, by keeping his word, last night, in a dangerous undertaking. An average manager would have backed down at the last moment; he would have invented an insolent excuse, and a lowed Mr. FRY'S "Leonora' to gather a little more dust in that limbo whence it has been rescued.

We have had a quiet week in our Colonial and Foreign Produce markets, with little alternation in prices. MONEY continues very easy. Consols 96 3/4@96 1/2 both for money and the account. Bar SILVER 5s. 1 ?d., nominal. Mexican DOLLARS 5s., nominal. DOURLOONS, South American 74s. 9d.; Spanish 76s. 3d. EAGLES 76s. 3 1/2d.

The Morris Canal was opened for navigation yesterday. The prospects for a heavy business on this Canal the coming Summer are unusually flattering, and the Company, in view of an expected increase in the coal business, have during the past Winter made a large number of repairs and improvements along the line of the canal.

The parties who were arrested hy the Police o the Fifth Precinct. on Sunday morning last, having been found gambling in tile house No. 119 Fourthstreet, were yesterday brought before Justice ALLEN. Their counsel moved the discharge of all the prisoners except JARVIS, who, he contended, could be held only as an agent of the proprietor.

The Senate of the United States yesterday elected Mr. FITZPATRICK. of Alabama, President pro tem. Vice-President BRECKENRIDGE being called to visit his family at the South. The vote stood for FITZPATRICK. 41 ; for FESSENDEN, 28; for HAMLIN, 1.

Mr. MONTGOMERY, of Pennsylvania, will introduce a bill extending preemption rights to settlers on the half-breed reservation bordering the Mississippi and Lake Pepin. There are eight thousand settlers on the land, which they have improved, and there is a conflict between them and the speculators, who bought Indian warrants and claim a right to locate on these lanes.

There is a great deal of very confident prediction, on both sides, as to the vote in Congress on the Kansas bill. The Herald and Journal of Commerce proclaim, with increased emphasis every successive morning, that the Senate bill is sure to pass:--while the Express, Tribune, and other journals of the opposite party are equally vehement in asserting that it will be defeated.

The senate old not meet until 7 1/2 o'clock P.M. The New-York Central Railroad reported the amount of foreign iron imported by them at sixty-two dollars and a half-per ten. Since the consolidation the amount is $1,375.000. The Grinding Committee put forward a large number of bills.

UNCLAIMED DEPOSITS - Mr. LAW'S bill respecting Unclaimed Deposits was, yesterday made the special order for Friday next, at 12 o'clock , in the Assembly. This bill contemplates a kind of legislation unprecedented in this State.
Mr. FITZPATRICK informed the Senators present that the Vice-President had been compelled to leave for his family in the South, and that the Senate must elect a President pro tem.

The citizens of the Seventh Ward and of the Eastern portion of the City, who are opposed to the longer exclusive use and possession of their Slips and Piers by the eleven dry docks which now occupy them, assembled in mass-meeting last evening in Pike-slip.

The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully ?? to attend the funeral. on Wednesday March 31 ?? A. M. from her late residence, No. 469th st., with ?? further invitation.

NOT WHITEWASHED--In the report of Saturday's proceedings in the House of Representatives, it was stated that the resolution of Mr. SEWARD, of Georgia, respecting the case of O. B. MATTESON, was adopted. That resolution declared it inexpedient to take further action in regard to Mr. MATTESON'S expulsion. s was enterely erroncous Mr. SEWARD'S resolution did not pass.

The Board of Aldermen met last evening, President CLANOY in the Chair. The following communication was received from the Mayor, laid on the table, and ordered to be printed: MAYOR'S OFFICE, March 29 1858. To the Honorable Common Council:

The mails by tile Niugara reached this City yesterday morning. Our files of London papers are only one day later than those received by the Fulton. The most interesting news by this arrival comes from France, where the continued number of arrests, the relations with England, the late outbreak at Chalons, and the approaching execution of the conpirators, are the chief topics of discussion.

ANOTHER "DEAD RABBIT" RIOT--ATTACK UPON A FIRE COMPANY--SEVERAL INJURED.--Another Dead Rabbit riot occured yesterday afternoon about 6 o'clock. It began at the corner of Chatham and Mulberry streets, at which place Engine Company No 31, while going home from an alarm of fire, was assailed by a large number of Sixth Ward ruffians.

DREADSTUFFS are generally ??, with the exception of Corn, which is in active demand. PROVISIONS firm; Mess Pork $17, Prime 814. BACON and bulk meats unchanged. LARD, 10 1/2 via 12c. WHISKY firm, 21c. @22c.

On Saturday afternoon the following important affidavit was made before Recorder BARNACD, at his office, relative to the assault on John McCarthy, at the corner of Broadway and Houston-street, on Wednesday last: The People vs. Andrew Hines, Cyrus Shay, John N. Riggs,--Briggs, John Doc and others, whose James are unknown.

The steamship Northern Light, E. L. TINKLE PAUGH Commanding - from Aspinwall on the night of the 21st, with treasure, and 645 passengers form California and the mails from the south Pacific--arrived at the Quarantine Station at 4 o'clock , A. M., yesterday.

One of the expedients by which the President expects to extricate himself and his party from the complications into which the Lecompton enterprise has thrown him, is to make a political issue of the acquisition of Cuba. It is alleged that he has ready for transmission to Congress " a war message."

SYMPTOMS OF THE CHIVALRY.--The honorable Mr. W. SMITH, of Virginia, announced on Saturday that he should make public use of any private conversation which any person might hold with him upon public affairs, if he thought it conducive to the public welfare, unless it was expressly stated at the time that it was confidential.

The noon-day prayer meeting at the Chambers-street Theatre was an exceedingly large one. The doors were opened at 11 1/2 o'clock, and immediately the throng. which was gathered outside, entered and filled the building almost immediately. With the first stroke of the City hall bell, announcing that the hour for holding the meeting had arrived, the leader, the Rev. RUFUS W. CLARK, of Brooklyn, arose and ?? the congregation to hearken to its tones.

W. ??, The Novelty Iron Works, William brown D. C. Brown and James C. Willett, Sheriff of New York -- ?? was a motion for preliminary injunction.

A dispatch from Leavenworth, 26th inst., says that the Kansas Constitutional Convention had adjourned from Minneola and met at Leavenworth on the evening of the 25th. Charges of corruption were prevalent. Gen. LANE had resigned the Presidency
The aspect of affairs as well within as without the French Empire, is far from promising a continuance of those halcyon days which the Western Alliance was designed to secure to Europe and the world.

Col. BOSTON is about closing his long and evental career. He is almost the last of the old veterans the men who were in the height of their glory during the days of JACKSON, and who then made the whole country ring with the ccho of their contending follows. He has been confined to his room for the last few weeks.

The House is in Committee of the Whole to-day it has considered one or two bills, and has done at least one good thing. It has put a quietus to the bill to prohibit the deposit at the Bank Department, of bonds and mortgages as a basis for circulating notes.

New-York is probably the only City in the world that considers Commerce a nuisance; but here business crowds upon us so much faster than we can find accommodations for it that it becomes in reality a nuisance.
Nothing of interest took place during the morning hour, except the presentation by Mr. DOOLITTLE of the joint resolution of the Wisconsin Legislature in favor of the admission of Minnesota.

ENGLISHMEN AND FRENCHEMN.--"If I know myself," sasy John Bull, in PAULDING'S satire, "I have no national prejudices. But I do bate a Frenchman." And this abnormal sentiment obtrudes itself in the most palpable manner in all the comments of our British eotemporaries on the other side of the Atlantic, in relation to the recet "difficulty" with the French Government.

At a late term of the Probate Court of Choctaw County, Miss., a case was being argued before the Probate Judge. In which Win. Brantley represented one side, and Messrs. Nowland and T. W. Davis the other. In the course of his argument Brantley became very personal, and said that Nowland and Davis were rascals, who would steal,

GEORGE CROWELL, of Norwalk, Virginia, was attacked on Monday night by three men as he was passing through Water-street. One of them came up stealibily behind him and seized him by the neck and held him while the others robbed him of his portmomale, containing $20.

All adjourned meeting of the Board of Supervisors was held yesterday afternoon. A large number of bills were ordered paid. A new roof was ordered to be put on the jail, and some improvements were directed to be made in the County Clerk's office. Pending an attempt to fix the salary of the Superintendent of the Poor, Superintendent STUDWELL went out, leaving the Board without a quorum.
Yesterday the case of Comptroller Flagg vs. James B. Smith and John Fitzpatsick came again, for the fifth time, before Recorder BARNARD, in his Chambers.

The body of STOUBS who murdered his wife and two children in this place on Tuesday, in December last, was found to day in a pond, known as Cowle's mill-pond, about a mile and a quarter from the village green.

The trial of SIMON BERNARD at London for his complicity in the plot for which ORSINI and PIERRI have just suffered at Paris, has already brought forward some curious and interesting developments in regard to ALLSOP, the frantie ex-stock-broker, by whom the not less frantic Italians were aided, abetted and comforted in their enterprises.

A COMMENDABLE LEGISLATURE - It is not often that a State Legislature receives any praise at the time of dissolution, for our legislators are too apt to do, those things which they ought not to do and to leave undone the things which they ought to do.

The Royal Mail Steamship Persia, Captain JUDKINS--which sailed from Liverpool at about 11 1/2 on the morning of the 20th of March-arrived here at an early hour this morning-bringing 54 passengers. The steamship Arago arrived at Southampton on the afternoon of the 18th March.

There has been trouble between the United States troops stationed at Fort Smith, Ark., and the police of that place. On Saturday night week, the police were attacked and fired into by a party of troops. The police returned the fire pretty warmly, compelling the attacking party to beat a hasty retreat to the garrison, wounding six soldiers prerty badly.

The City of Baltimore from Liverpool on the 17th inst, brings news of great interest from Europe. The difficulties between France and England have been Satisfactory adjusted, and amicable relations between the two Governments are restored.
The reports from Washington indicate increasing strength on the part of the opponents of the Lecompton fraud. The Democratic caucus of Saturday night seems to have failed of its purpose.

BILLS ORDERED TO A THIRD READING. Bill to allow the Syracuse Lodge of Free and Accepted Masons to establish a school for destitute orphan children. Bill to amend the charter of the Provident Fund Society in the City of New-York.
The Democratic caucus met in the hall of the House to-night. JOHN COCHEANE was again Chairman. A report was submitted from the Committee of Conference.

Judge LORING has published a letter in regard to his removal from the Probate Court. He acknowledges that he disobeyed the State law of 1855, which prohibited a State Judge from holding a federal office, and assets that be did so because he deemed it unconstitutional.

Before the Hon. Justice Clerke. William W. Warden vs. The Country Clerk.--This case, which is for a mandsmus compelling the County Clerk to allow the applicant to publish the names of judgement debtors, was indefinitely paste poned yesterday, owing to Mr. Noyes being engaged in the Court of Appeals.
The screw steamship City of Baltimore, which sailed from Liverpool on the morning of the 17th March, arrived at this port at an early hour yesterday morning.

The Galveston News publishes the following card: HO! FOR MEXICO!--WHO WILL GO? NEW ORLEANS, La., March 13, 1558. To the Editors of the News: SIRS: I will leave for Texas on the Berwick's Bay Northern Mexico, for the purpose of emigrating to Northern Mexico, and rare facilities will be offered to all those who wish to join me for that destination.
The screw steamship Atlanta arrived here this morning, to take in coal. She got afloat yesterday morning, and will leave this afternoon for New-York. She is not making any water.

SHARDLOW.--In this City on Tuesday March 30, GEORGE SWEET, eldest son of Samuel and Anna Shardlow, aged 8 years, 8 months and 19 days Relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral at No. 35 5th-st., on Thursday, April 1. at 1 1/2 o'clock P. M.

It is not easy, in reading the graphic story of his fate, to repress a feeling closely analogous to sympathy with the leading actor in that terrible tragedy which began on the 14th of January in the Rue Lepelletior and ended on the 13th of March in the Piace de L'Hotel de Ville at Paris.

A regular meeting of the Board was held last evening, President PIERSON in the chair. ASSESSORS' BLUNDERS. The Collector of Taxes and Assessments sent the following interesting communication: OFFICE COLLECTOR OF TAXES AND ASSESSMENTS, BROOKLIN, Monday, March 29, 1858.

The Novelty Iron Works, at Harrisburg, Pa., have resumed operations. The Mount Savage Iron Company in Alleghany County, Md., contemplate beginning operations in the rolling mill in a short time. The sheet-iron department of the Crescent Mill at Wheeling, Va., has resumed operations, and the oil cloth factory in the same place is to resume this week.

Lent draws rapidly to an end, and Easter week will bring with the 8th of April the most brilliant fite of charity which has ever delighted the world of New-York. The preparations of the Hunter Woodis Benevolent Society's Committee for their magnificent entertainment at the Crystal Palace are going on most successfully.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC--The performance of the "Messiah" by the Harmonic Society, last night, attracted a crowded house. The distribution of parts was essentially the same as on the occasion of the last performance, Mr. SIMPSON singing the tenor, instead of Mr. PERRING, Mr. SIMPSON has a good voice, and deserves evidently to be brought forward in a more preminent manner.

Dispensations are granted by the dignitaries of Mother Church "to all whose duties are of an exhausting or laborious nature." but the more elevated decimals of society are expected to pay due reverence to the edits, Roman or Episcopal; so our ball-musicians rest from their labors, and the cooks brighten their casseroles for the coming Easter campaign.

ANOTHER MAIL ROBBER ARRESTED.--The Hartford Times says: "Letters from various towns in this State addressed to offices between New-London and Stonington, not having been received, it became evident that some depredator was at work;

The Royal Mail Steamship Persia, ??Captain JUDKINS-which sailed from Liverpool at about 11 1/2 on the morning of the 20th of March-arrived here a an early hour yesterday morning-bringing 134 pas sengers. The steamship Arago arrived at Southampton on the afternoon of the 18th March.

Whenever an American citizen happens to get into a difficulty in the Chinese waters, on the Coast of Madagascar, or in the Sandwich Islands, our Government is always taunted with its cowardly and shameful indifference to the rights of Republicans; and the throatening face of the British lion is usually held up in terrorem to frighten a timid President, and startle a lazy Cabinet into emulation of that noble and watchful beast.

The city of Wheeling is up in arms against the Gas Company, on account of exorbitant charges, and large numbers of citizens have inaugurated the use of candles. carbon oil, and other illuminators instead, at a saving. They refuse to pay over $2 per 1,000 feet, for gas.

An election was held, to-day, for the Pittsburg, Fort Wayne and Chicago Railroad Company, and the regularly nominated ticket was elected by a large majority, as follows: G. W. Cass, J. Edgar Thomson, W. Robinson, Jr., and W. Wade, of Pennsylvania; John Farwell, G. W. Bailey, C. M.

GENERAL WEBB AND THE REGULAR SERVICE.-The Richmond South, in commenting upon the charges of the Courier and Enquirer against the Secretary of War, mentions a visit of Gen. WEBB to the Secretary, and adds the following: "Then, by a sudden stroke of energetic importunity, he besought the Secretary to revoke an order whereby his son had been detailed for service against the Mormons in Utah.

Collector SCHELL is here for a two-fold purpose: First, to look after his nomination, which appears to be in a desperate situation; second, to clear himself of imputations relative to the Willett's Point sale. There is great danger that his name will not be sent to the Senate. The Administration is disposed to hoid him responsible for the course of CLARK and HASKIN on Lecompton.

Judge CULVER, of the City Court, has commenced a libel suit against Deacon JOHN WESTERVELT of the First Baptist Church, and one of the Committee appointed to investigate the charges of immoral conduct preferred against the Judge. The alleged libel is contained in a preamble and resolution entered on the Church books, in which the guilt of Judge CULVER is assumed as a matter proven.

By the arrival of the Persia at this port early yesterday morning. We have received three days later advices from Europe. The news is not of an important character Our Paris correspondent, whose letter we publish elsewhere, gives some additional details of the execution of PIERRI and ORSINI on the 13th ult He describes some scenes and incidents which other writers have not touched upon.

Mr. DOUGLAS presented the Constitution of Oregon; also petitions from the citizens of Dacotah asking the organization of that Territory. Mr. BIGLER presented a memorial from AMOS KENDALL and others. interested in the Morse Telegraphs asking protection against competing Telegraph Companies. Referred to the Committee on the Judiciary.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.---The last night of the season should be an interesting occasion, particularly as it is also the last night of MEYERBEER'S "Huguonots," and. Herr FORMES. After a season of unprecedented success, the opera closes to night, and Fourteenth-street will be deserted until Wednesday of next week, when Monsieur MUSARD commences his engagement as conductor of the promenade concerts and bals masquis.

At the election here to day the whole Anti Lecompton ticket succeeded. H D. ROBERTSON, Esq, is elected Supervisor by 140 majority, notwithstanding the most bitter opposition of tile Lecomptonites. This town in the District represented by the Hon. JOHN B. HASKINS.

AN ALLEGED ENGAGEMENT.-Among the spectators at the Boston Museum last week, to witness the tragedy of "Jane Shore," was an affectionate pair of lovers, who had visited the theatre evidently not for the purpose of seeing the play, but to pass away the time in sentimental proximity--in other words, in "courting."

A number of prominent Masons, having at heart the erection of a monument to ELISHA KEST KANE, met at the Clinton Place Hotel on Monday evening last. The Hon. ALEX. C. MOBTON was called to the chair, and GEORGE O. BARTLETT, Esq., acted as Secretary. The Committee on Permanent Organization reported for President, the Hon. ROB-IT L. DE COIN;

Far more than half the quarrels of the world are, in truth, mere misunderstandings; but this fact, so far from cheering the prospect of human affairs, sadly darkens it: for almost anything seems to be easier for men than the comprehension of the characters and motives of their fellow-men with whom they have to deal.

Yesterday the office of the Recorder was filled to overflowing with the principal fighting-men of the City, to hear the preliminary examination of CYRUS SHMAY, JOHN N. BRIGGS, SAMUEL E. BRIGGS and ANDREW HINES, on a charge, made through the affidavit of WILLIAM H.RACEY. of committing and aiding to commit a desperate assault on JOHN MACCARTHY--thy said parties having been, as it is alleged, hired to commit the assault by MARCUS CICERO STANLEY.

One of the wisest of the Proverbs of Solomon declares that the "wrath of a fool is presently known. but that a prudent man covereth shame." The sagacity of this apothegm is daily vindicated, not only in private but in public life ; and in the recent difficulty between France and England it has received several noteworthy illustrations.

THE KANSAS QUESTION IN CONGRES S.-We sel dom quarrel with the Express, or even complain of its misrepresentations. It hasa chronic infirmity which prevents it from being accurate, even in quoting statements and opinions from other journals. Fortunately, this constitutional disability is so well understood by the public that no harm is ever done by its sprawling perversions of the language of its neighbors.

ANOTHER STABBING AFFRAY -- A German named WILLIAM KOHLER, who resides at No. 45 Bowery, was stabbed several times about the face and head. about 12 o'clock last night, at the grocery, corner of Walker and Church streets, by a Fifth ward rowdy, named ANDREW SHAW. KOHLER accused SHAW of taking a brush from his pocket. This accusation led to a dispute ; whereupon, SHAW used his knife.

MOTT AT THE ELDRIDGE STREET JAIL.--JACOB H.MOTT is held in close custody in the Eldri??ge street Jail. The impression that he has been balled, or is only in the nominal custody of the Sheriff, is a mistake, as he has only been out of prison since, his arrest on two or three occasions, when he went before the Recorder.

The Senate considered the special order, being MT. STOW's bill to reimpose tolls on Railroads. Immediately after the reading of the journal Mr. STOW occupied the time of the Senate for three hours in an able and eloquent argument in favor of the bill. At the conclusion of his speech the Senate made the bill the special order for Saturday at 12 o'clock.

In compliance with a resolution of the Senate, the Canal Auditor, on Monday, transmitted to that body a report: " The amount of drafts drawn on the Auditor by the Canal Commissioners from April 1, 1856, to Feb. 28, 1858, in payment upon contracts for the construction or enlargement of any of the Canals, was $6,191,270 04.

We have had an open Winter, and thus far, a pleasant Spring; both which facts are favorable to an early commencement of Canal navigation. Much work must always be done in March and April. When the ground is frozen this is necessarily performed at a disadvantage, the banks being filled with ice and snow.

From the Milwaukee Daily Wisconsin. We have some painful ?? to narrate about a woman who was lately found in this City, in a most wretched and degraded condition. A simple sketch of her antecedents will show now rapid is one's going downward, after the first step is taken, and how mercilessly rebution follows after wrong-doing and crime.

Beadle, No. 42 Bleecker st., on Friday after noon. at 4 o'clock.

Before Judge Belts. SALVAGE--PURCHASE OF VESSEL BY SALVOR. King Benjaman VS. The Schooner Watchman.--This was a libel for salvage compensation. The vessel was stranded off Fire Island in October, 1857. She was loaded with stone and sinking in the sand, and her master and crew considered her as bilged, and being unable to get her off abandoned her and sold her to the libelant for $187.

Mr. THOMAS TOOKE, F. R. S., has just died in London, at the advanced age of 81. Mr. TOOKE was one of the first statisticians of the age, and one of the ablest Economical writers of Great Britain. He had for some years been a corresponding member of the French Academy of Moral and Political Sciences:

During the fog yesterday morning, at 9 o' clock, the steamboat keyport. from Keyport for this City, ran her guards on the top of the dock at Fort Hamilton, but received no material damage. The steam-tugs Dr. Kane and O. M. Pellet went to her assistance, but could not get her off. The O. M. P. will bring her passengers to the City.

CANAL PROJECTS.--Canada on the one side, and Pennsylvania on the other, are reaching for the trade of the Mississippi Valley. The former proposes to make a canal, uniting Lake Huron with Lake Ontario, via Lake Simcoe, thus affording a short water route to Chicago.

THE SCREW STEAMSHIP ATLANTA--The screw steamship Atlanta arrived at her wharf on Wednesday under her own steam and perfectly sound, both i her hull and machinery. This vessel has been ashore near Hatteras, since the 22d February, and coming off as she has, proves her to be a vessel of extraordinary strength. She will be recaulked and painted throughout, and will be running in a few days.

The last days of the first Massachusetts Legislature under the district system, were not very creditable to it. There was a regular row, on Friday, between Mr. PRESCOTT, of Salem, and General CUSHING, of NEWburypert, which would have made sensation even Congress. Mr. PRESCOTT brought up against General CUSHING the charges of Abolitionism and inconsistency, and proved them, too;

At the noonday meeting at Burton's Theatre, yesterday, a request was handed to the President asking that prayer might be offered for Congress, and especially for a happy issue to their present deliberations. A young man in the gallery immediately rose and prefaced some general remarks on the study of the word of God with the observation "Lot us take care of ourselves, God will take care of the nation.

The people in the vicinity of South Eleventhstreet will in a few days have no longer cause to complain of the awful stench arising from the deopt of the offal contractors, L. R. CORNELL Co., at the foot of South Eleventh-street. The lease of that dock having expired, the contractors have procured other wharves at a distance from the present one.

CARS LIGHTED BY GAS--A locomotive and six cars go out nightly over the New-Jersey Railroad to Philadelphia, lighted by gas, and the difference between the gas-lighted and the candle-lighted gives to the former the appearance of an illuminated train shooting off through Jersey on some gala occasion. The gas is forced by a pump at the depot through small iron pipes into a strong wrought-iron and brazed cylinder,

CONNECTICUT ELECTION.--The annual State election in Connecticut takes place on Monday next. Governor, Lieutenant-Governor, Secretary of State, Treasurer, Comptroller and Legislature are to be chosen. The two tickets for State officers are :

Fifty-two bills were reported this morning, over forty of which were ordered to a third reading, mainly local bills. Among those of general interest were bills: To amend the law relative to partition of lands. To amend the Revised Statutes relative to suits against devisees and heirs at law. Relative to Constables in the City of New-York.

CLAPP -- In this City, on Wednesday, March 31, of drepsy, HENRY H. CLAPP, in the 55th year of his age. His relatives and friends and the friends of the family, are invited to attend his funeral, at his late residence, No. 737 8th-av., this morning, at 10 o'clock. MOTT.--In this City, on Wednesday, March 31, FRANCIS N. F., infant son of Richard Mott, aged 8 months and 28 days.

IN A TIGHT SPOT.-The Washington correspondent of the Journal of Commerce writes as follows: "The passage of such a bill-admitting Kansas and recognizing the Lecompton Constitution-will be a great triumph to the Administration. It will not increase their strength at the South, and may decrease their strength in the North;

JAMES T. BRADY, Esq., delivered a lecture on " The Legal Disabilities of Woman" last night, in Mozart Hall. This is the first of the course of addresses on "Woman considered in her Legal, Social and Political Rights," which have been expressly prepared at the request and for the benefit of the " Shirt Takers' and Seamstresses' Union"--a commendable and well-conducted charity.

Parson BROWNLOW seems to have abandoned his intention of coming North to instruct the natives on the subject of Slavery. His attention, at all events, seems to have been temporarily diverted from this subject, for we find in his paper, the Knoxville Whig, a letter describing the delights and marvels of rather a unique entertainment at the Gayoso House in the city of Memphis.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--Mr. ULLMAN'S ?? successful Spring season came to a close last evening, with a good house and the last performance of METERBEER'S "Huguenots." There will be a pause at the Academy until Saturday, when Mr. THALBEEG, who has returned to the City, will give a " Matinee. On Wednesday of next week MUSARD will commence his series of Promenade Concerts.

JORDAN, and the plaintiff, ALBERT G. THOMPsor, is one of the Judges of the Marine Court. The Judge charges HARDENBROOK with the publication of a libel against him,

To the editor of the New-York Times: SIR: Allow me to correct an article in your TIMES. to-day, headed " A Defaulting Railroad Conductor." He was a Station-agent, and not a conductor. The conductors on the road, (Naugatuck,) as a body, without exception, are men of moral rectitude and integrity, not surpassed by men anywhere to be found,

The manner in which this result was reached, and the vote upon it,

DECAYED ARISTOCRATS.-A curious study has been made concerning the decay of some great European families, and the result is most ridiculous and sublime. A Duchess DR SAINT SIMON is a femme de manage at Belleville! The history of her decay is most wonderful The heir of the last Doge of Venice is a perfumer at Saint Denis.
