To the Editor of the new-York Times: In the sad account from the Milwankee Daily Wisconsin, published in Yesterday's TIMES, of the degradation of a young woman, it is said that she was formerly a member of my family, and an adopted daughter. Neither Statement is true. The young lady was a member of my parish, and received an education under the direction of friends in the church;

A meeting, this afternoon, of merchants anti others opposed to removing the post-office to Sunnerstreet, chose a Committee to report at an adjourned meeting to-morrow; and in the meantime to consult with Postmaster CAPEN. WM. MCNULTY, a convict In New-Hampshire State Prison for burglary, has been identified as one of the murderers of Policeman HODSON, at East Boston,

The three steamships of the Collins line, the Baltic, the Atlantic, and the Adriatic, were sold at auction yesterday by the Sheriff, for a sum considerably less than the cost of one of them. As there were some contested liens upon the ships the price at which they were sold can hardly be regarded as any test of their actual value.

In this extremely agreeable Spring weather it is not easy to retain a vivid sense of disagreeable facts, and we doubt whether many of our readers are poignantly conscious that at this moment hundreds of able-bodied men are absolutely unable to earn the means of supporting themselves and their families in this City.

The morning business was unimportant. Various ineffectual attempts were made to vote down Mr. IVERSON'S motion to take up the Army bill, and to consider, instead, the Minnesota bill. The Army bill was considered, and various verbal amendments made without altering its principle.

EMANCIPATION IN MISSOURI.--The New-Orleans Crescent concedes that Missouri must become a free State in ten years. On this subject it says: "We have frequently expressed the opinion in times past, that Missouri was gradually, but surely, approaching a condition that would secure a triumph of the emancipation cause in that State,

The hour for the departure of another mail has arrived, and the civil war still rages in the land. if it be possible to style the anarchy in the country a 'civil war. Since my last letter to the TIMES, this Government Party has apparently gained ground. Commanderin-Chief OSOLLO has advanced with little interruption into the very heart of the coalition in the interior,

Nothing is talked of but the result of the great struggle and the success of the Anti-Lecompton alliance. The Opposition are jubilant. Some Southern Democrats profess not to care much about it. Opinions are freely expressed that the Senate will finally recede. The design, however, of the Administration Senators is to insist on the Senate bill, and if the House insist also,

The business transacted during the morning hour was of an unimportant description. The Kansas bill from the House was taken up. The amendments were read, whereupon Mr. GREEN submitted a motion, without comment, to disagree to the House's amendment to the Kansas bill.

MR : An article in your paper of the 26th ult., in regard to matter furnished by " A Correspondent of the Post," has just been placed before me. It is, I presume, a fact, that an attempt was made to tax the Teachers of tile evening schools, but it is not a fact that any moneys so raised were contributed to the family of the late Miss LEWIS.

Decision in Admiralty. UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT. Before Judge Hall. SUPPLIES--POREIGN VESSEL--PLEADINGS. John E. Brown vs. The Propeller Albany.This was a libei filed to recover $325 for supplies furMished by the libelant to the vessel, which he alleged was a foreign vessel and without credit in this port. The steamer was American built, ana was enrolled,

The Journal of Commerce seems unable to think of a newspaper except as the leader, the champion, or the tool, of some political party. Its own position probably colors its conception of the position of other journals, and it accordingly treats our comments of Thursday last, upon the tendency of party organizations, the disclosure of a "new combination which

The bill fixing the first of May for the resumption of specie payments, has passed both Houses. The bill requiring parent banks to redeem the notes of their branches in specie, and requiring indenendent banks to establish an agency at Richmond or Baltimore for the redemption of their notes, has also finally passed, and takes effect in April, 1859.
The Deficiency bill will be voted upon to-morrow, and it is in great danger of rejection. It contains about ten millions of dollars, viz.:

AMERICAN BIBLE SOCIETY.--The stated meeting of the Managers was held at the Bible House, Astor Place, April 1, at 4 1/2 o'clock; Hon. LUTHER BEADISH in the chair. Rev. Dr. McLEOD read the 25th Psalm, and Rev. Dr. SPRING offered prayer. Four new societies were recognized, two in Missouri one in Arkansas, and one in Texas.

The Philadelphia Inquirer has the following concerning Mr. Edwin Forrest: "Mr. Forrest, some time since, made a professional visit to St. Louis, where he experienced the most signal success. Before his return home he was seized with an attack of inflammatory rheumatism, from which he has not yet fully recovered. He is now at his residence on Broad-street, in this city, and is gradually improving.

The opponents of the Lecompton swindle exulted loudly last night, with cannon and fireworks in the Park, over the defeat of the Kansas bill in the House of Representatives. The rejoining was quite natural and perfectly proper;--we only hope it may not prove to have been premature. The crisis of the Kansas bill is not passed.

The steamship Hammenia arrived at this port on Thursday night bringing London evening papers of the 20th. and London morning papers of the same day. Advices by this steamer are therefore one day later that those received by the Persia. Consols closed on Saturday at 2 P. M. at 96 7/8 for money, and 96 7/8@97 for the 8th April.

The decision to employ two volunteer regiments for the Utah service, has created quite an excitement ameng the military men of this City. Some six military organizations here have volunteered, and the President is said to have expressed a willingness to accept of the services of the regiment known as Col. BURNHAM'S. It is also stated that the other regiment will be accepted from Pennsylvania.

DESTRUCTIVE FIRE IN BURLINGTON, VT. BURLINGTON, Vt., Friday, April 2. The Pioneer Mechanics' Shop, a large manufacturing establishment of this place, was burned this morning at 9 o'clock. Loss, about $130,000. The principal losers are, H. P. Hickok, builder and machinery, $60,000 ; C. Kilburn Co., chair manufactory, $40,000 ; Kendall, Wright Co., doors and sashes, $5,000; E. W. Chase, doors and sashes, $4,000; Wing Smith, last makers, $4,000 : L.

On Thursday afternoon about 2 o'clock a boatman, who follows the business of dragging for old rope, , while opposite the foot of Beekman-street, hauled up the body of a young man, which had evidently lain but a short time in the water. Attached ?? by a strong cord was a stone weighing some 50 pounds, which was ingeniously slung by places of bedord, part of hemp and part of manila.

I observe in the Daily Globe of this morning that the Hon. WILLIAM SMITH is reported as having said in the House, on yesterday, "that the delegation from Illinois, or a portion of them at any rate met together here, when Congress assembled, to consider the course which a certain gentleman in the other end of the Capital should pursue, and the means he should use to secure his reelection to the United States Senate.

THE NUISANCE OF BEGGAES.--Why do not the police interfere to stop-or at least to check--the enormous and increasing nuisance of street-beggars ? There is scarcely a street in the upper part of the City which is not filled with them. Ladies and gentlemen walking in the Fifth-avenue, Broadway and Union Square, are constantly beset by men, women, and especially children,

THE KANSAS BILL IN THE SENATE.--When the Kansas bill came up in the Senate yesterday, Mr. GREEN, of Missouri, immediately moved to disagree with the House amendment. After remarks by Messrs. BIGLER and PUGH, in support of the motion, and by Mr. DOUGLAS against it, the question was taken, and Mr. GREEN'S motion prevailed-yeas, 32; nays, 23.

GREGORY.--In this City, on Friday afternoon, April, after a short and severe illness, JOHN GREGORY, late Alderman of the XVIth Ward, aged 46 years. The funeral services will be held at St. Peter's Church, in 26th st., near 9th av., this day, (Saturday.) at I o'clock P. M. The friends and relatives of the family are respectfully invited tu attend without further invitation. ARBUTHNOT.--In this City, on Friday, April 2, WILLIAM ARBUTUNOT, aged 56 years.

The "army of lions" have found at last a lion to lead them. Sir COLIN CAMPBELL has been following up his debut in India with the steady and triumphant perseverance of a great man and a great General. Military writers have already paid their tribute to the masterly skill with which he moved his forces upon Lucknow through a country swarming with enemies;

The Chamber of Commerce held its Quarterly meeting on Thursday evening, at Clinton Hall. Several gentlemen were admitted members of the Chamber. The annual dues of the members were increased from $3 to $10. The President announced that there was $1,600 in the Treasury. The committee on Location reported that rooms had been hired in the new building corner of Cedar and William streets.

By the Hamburg steamship Hammonia, which arrived at this port on Thursday night, we have received London evening papers of the 20th ult., and obtain from them some interesting details of the last news from India. Sir COLIN CAMPBELL, having broken up his camp at Futtyghur, arrived at Cawnpore on the 4th of February. His army, amounting to some 15,000 men, with 140 guns, tollowed with all possible speed.

DEFEAT OF THE REVOLUTIONISTS--BUTCHERY OF THE PRISONERS BY ORDER OF THE GOVERNMENT--INTERCESSION OF THE FOREIGN MINISTERS--REMOVAL OF THE UNITED STATES CONSULATE FROM MONTEVIDEO. We published on Thursday advices from Montevideo to the 4th of February,

PAYING THE POLICE.--The members of the Police Department yesterday morning received pay for their last month's services. The amount of money paid out is a trifle over $68.000, which is divided among 1,168 men,the present number on the pay-roll. ALTERING BANK BILLS.--Captain Speight. of Twenty-first Ward, arrested yesterday morning Wm. Howe. whom he caught in the act of altering bank

Both Houses were engaged to-day in the third reading of bills. None of the bills passed were of any general interest. The business of the State is being done up in short order, and in much the way that It has been in times past. Everything is going on the lightning train -but not all in one direction. Some goes throughsome goes to the table, and some goes to the-well where the bad folks go.

The Anti-Lecompton victory in the House of Representatives was celebrated last evening, by an impromtu display of fireworks in the Park, and a salute of 120 guns at the Battery. The demonstration was suggested by a few leading Republicans, after the receipt of the news from Washington on Thursday. JOHN JAY, Mr. GREELEY, Mr. MANIEERN, of the Young Men's Republican Club, and others, superintended the display.

THE PARK.--We observe workmen busy in planting new trees in the Park. They will never attain old ago or great size. The Park is needed and destined for other uses. It will, undoubtedly, be mainly preserved as an open space, though one or two handsome public buildings may hereafter be erected upon it. But it is not needed as an ornamental square,

A few weeks ago the discovery at Nismes, in France, of the 51st Asteroid, a small planet revolving between the orbits of Mars and Jupiter, was announced--the first discovered in 1858. But last week a circular from the Paris Observatory stated that on the 4th of February yet another, or the 52d, had been well known for his great success in this department of astronomy.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.-- A Matinee on an extended and excellent plan will he given here to-day, commencing at 1 o'clock. It is the first occasion of Mr. THALBERO'S appearance in New-York since his successful tour in the South and West. Mr. H. C. COOPER and Miss MILNEE will also assist Mr. THALBERO as soloists, and an orchestra, under the direction of CARL ANSCRUTZ, will play several instrumental pieces.

The Democrats nominated yesterday Dr. QUACKENROS, who was the contestant of the party for the Mayoralty last year, as their candidate for Mayor. The report that the Anti-Lecomptonites had nominated JOHN N. WILDER for Mayor is incorrect. No nomination has yet been agreed upon.

The United States Mail steamship Cahawba, J. D. BULLOCK, Commander, from New-Orleans via Havana, arrived last evening, after a very tmpestuous passage. She left the latter place on the 10th ult. At Havana, great preparations were being made to do honor to the heir-apparent.

In steamship cahawba, from New-Orleans and Havana--Jas. King. Capt Kennedy, B. A. Vickins. J. Quintana, Miss Fanny Blabe Mrs Allen and 2 daughters, Col. Allen and net hew. Mrs. C. E. Starr, Mrs. J. M. Eadie, Mrs. M. E. Stewart, J. H. Graves, F. Newhall, L. H. Howley, J. Spinry, J. Jines, From Havana--J. Castata J. A. Viloajo. P. Olmps, J. T. France, C. Smith, J. B. Miaick J. M. Thayer, E. Bordinabe and servant,

REDUCTION OF CANAL TOLLS--The Canal Board adopted a very important measure on Friday, by reducing the tolls on merchandise from four mills to two mills per thousand pounds per mile, and on flour from three mills to two mills. This change will tend to make a large increase in Canal business.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The articles recently written for your paper by persons employed as book-keepers, have interested me so much as to induce me to give those interested in the matter the result of an examination, made last evening, of my expense book.

CORONER SPEER, of Bergen, on Saturday held an inquest upon the body of a unknown man who was found drowned in the Hacker-sack River, near the Erie Railroad ??. Deceased was about 45 years of age, 5 ?? 8 inches high was dressed in light tweed pants, black cloth coat and rest, and area comforter about the neck. The body, was not fully identified.

Mr. MOSES R. ROSS, of No. 208 South First-Street, and his son, a lad 15 years old, were almost instantly killed between 8 and 9 o'clock Saturday night last, by driving in a wagon over an embankment on Sixth-street, near Norman-avenue, between Green Point and Williamsburg, on what is known as the meadows on the Meserole estate.

We observe that a great outcry is made about a bill pending in the State Legislature, to permit (with the assent of our Common Council,) the construction of a Railroad through streets running parallel to Broadway, on the west side.

The Boston Journal says: "Marcus Cane, a German Jew Pedler, of the firm of Wm. Cane Brother, of Bleecker street, New - York City, was arrested in January, 1857, by Officer J.C. Brown, of Watarbury, VL., after a pursuit of 49 days, through five States, as one of a gang concerned in the robbery of the store of Stacy Courtis,

Quarantine has been established for the season and arrangements have been made by the Health Officer to enforce the health laws rigidly. Since the first of April, all vessels arriving are subject to a visit of inspection. To assist the Health Officer, a police force has been detailed, which will be always on duty within the inclosure.

Colonel STEVENSON, of Kentucky, has assurances from the President that a regiment of volunteers will be accepted from that State, and a strong pressure is made in behalf of a regiment from Ohio--which, if only two are to be raised, will, of course, exclude New-York.

To the Editor of the Union: It is widely circulated in the telegraphic news from Washington that on the 11th ult., Senator BIGGER presented "the memorial of AMOS KENDALL and ??hers, interested in the Morse telegraph lines, ask end pretectun against competing telegraph lines."

The close of the Opera season and the temporary cessation of musical hostilities at the Academy of Music, leaves us for the time at the mercy of Mr. ULIMAN'S pen, and it will be seen by the advertisements elsewhere, that that gentleman is not show to types advantage of the opportunity.

Everything has been lost sight of this week except the Delegate Constitutional Convention which assembled at Minneola, the town without buildings, on the 23d inst. About fifty of the members passed through our city, on their way to the capitol.

After a mild and open Winter, the Spring has fairly set in, and under its bright sunshine the buds and grass begin to exhibit signs ot returning life. The ice in the Missouri River, as far up as Fort Randall and hence to the mouth, has all disappeared, and navigation is resumed. The first steamer of the season, the Platte Valley, reached our wharf Saturday afternoon, and met with a most cheering reception.

ACCIDENTALLY POISONED.--Coroner PERRY held an inquest yesterday on the body of CHARLES FOLEY, and ?? 50 years of age, who died from taking ??. His wife purchased the portion to kid rate with, and the ceased are some of it unwittingly. Verdict.

I would respectfully ask all those interested in the great religious movement now spreading itself throughout the length and breadth of our favored land, to take some decided and well-accerted steps to carry this work more into the midst of the lower classes, and with this object in view to organize a Committee in every-Church throughout this City and

It is pleasant to see the special organs of the Administration putting so cheerful a face upon The Lecompton vote. in the House of Representatives. The Washington Union, which has come to be only an offshoot of the Herald in this City, has adopted the option of that intelligent journal, that both houses agree upon the main point, and only differ in regard to unessential and unimportant forms.

The new schism in Tammany Hall has a deeper significancy than the "skirmishes of kites and crows" which usually disturb the harmony of the party. Mayor WOOD and his foresters have fled to their Medina in no temporary exile. Henceforth Mercer Hall will be classical ground-the head-quarters of a rebel. lien which is destined to exercise a great and perhaps fatal influence upon the fortunes of the Democratic Party.

It is more than probable that the Derby Ministry will await the result of SIMON BERNARD'S trial in the Central criminal Court, before introducing their edition of the Conspiracy Bill. Lord PALMERSTON'S opponents in reality joined issue with him on two points.

We are glad to learn that the PostmasterGeneral has concluded a contract with JOHN M. HOCKADAY and others, for the transportation of a weekly mail between St Joseph's Mo., and Salt Lake City. This route has long been in the hands of inefficient or incompetent parties, who have utterly failed to render any service worth naming.

For some time past complaints have been made to the Mayor of an extensive swindle practiced upon country merchants by parties designating themselves "Oliphant, Barilett Co.," 208 Broadway, and representing themselves to the proprietors of a West India Coffee manufactory. The matter was given incharge to Sergeant BIRNEY.

The Detroit papers have a story of the career of a young girl, which rivals the narrative of the young Irish woman from Brooklyn. a gentleman arrived in Detroit last week, in search of a young woman who absconeed from Cleveland nearly a year since, and from whom nothing was heard until a former acquaintance ?? her in Detroit. Her family are wealthy who respectable, residing in Cleveland.

The position of parties here on the Lecompton question has been involved in some confusion by the passage of the so-called Crittenden amendment in the House, so that in fact it is even harder now to predict what will be done than it was a week ago, although it is not so hard to say what ought to be done.

The libel suit of Judge Thompson vs. Mr. William A. Hardenbrook was again resumed on Saturday, before Recorder BARNARD. Augustus Maverick, examined by Mr. Townshend--I am an Assistant Editor of the NEW-YORK TIMES; the defendant. Mr. Hardenbrook, called on me at the TIMES Office about ten days or two weeks ago;

BURTON'S old Chambers-street Theatre, which has been leased by the United States Government for fifteen years at a rent of $16,000 per annum, will be immediately fitted up for the use of the United States Courts and offices of the Government in this City.

In the State Senate, on Saturday, a report was made in favor of amending the Charter of this City, so as to provide for paying members of the Common Council four dollars per day for their services. A bill was introduced by Mr. SPINOLA, to repeal the law establishing the Brooklyn City Railroad Company.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Will you allow me to correct an error in the Hon. JAMES T. BRADY's lecture of Thursday evening, in which, in referring to the capacity of woman for he medical profession, he stated that "the last report of the New-York Infirmary contained mention of the labors of two female physicians whose efforts were equal in success to those of the most

By the last mail from Europe we received information that M. ISTURITZ, President of the Spanish Council had formally announced that the Mexican President had promised to satisfy the demands of Spain. We published on Thursday, the text of the Minister's speech, and its tone left no room to doubt that, as far as Spain was concerned, she would prefer to settle her difficulties with Mexico by negotiation rather than by war.

The printing establishment of H. O. HOUGHTON Co at Cambridge, Mass., was burned on Saturday. The premises were owned by LITTLE, BROWN Co., Boston publishers who occupied them for the storage of books in sheets, and street type plates. The damage by water was greater than that caused by the fire. Most of the stock of LITTLE, BROWN Co.

ALLEGED ATTEMPT AT ARSON IN ELEVENTH-AVENUE.--The alarm of fire at a few minutes afternoon yesterday, was caused by the burning of some shavings in the basemen of the dwelling-house at the south west corner of Eleventh avenue and Thirtieth-street, occupied by LAWRENCE GARVING. The fire was exceguished before any material damage was done.

It is a matter of considerable interest as well as surprise, to notice the large increase in circulation of the New-York dailies within the past few years. A traveler cannot visit a city, village, town or hamlet in any of the Northern, Middle, Western or Eastern States, accessible to railroads, but that he hears the. cry of the newsboy, "'Ere's the New-York 'Erald, TIMES and Tribune."

MILLS.--In this City, on Sunday morning, April 4 suddenly, of inflammation of the brain. GEORGE PHILLIP, youngest son of Egbert and Mary Mills, aged 3 years. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend his funeral, this (Monday) afternoon, at 4 o'clock, at the residence of his father No. 94 West 39th St. His remains will be taken to Smithtown, L. L., toy interment.

The Senate last night adjourned at 1 1/4 o'clock, after having ordered a final vote to be taken on the Half-Dime bill on Monday evening at 8 o'clock, without debate. REPORTS. By Mr. DARLING, favorably, to authorize the State Engineer and Surveyor to call on railroads for extra reports, when in his judgment the interests of the State requires the same.

Sir: As all informatoin relative to the movements of the "saints" is at present interesting to the public. I send you the following, which is reliable. A party of Cherolees, six in numbe, that left the nation in November last week, and report that twenty-three days' travel south from the Salt Plains they can on a large Limber of Camanche, Kiowah.

The following is the Weekly Report of Deaths in the City and County of New-York, from the 27th day of March, to the 3d day of April, 1858: Men, 74; Women, 81: Boys, 164; Girls, 127: Total. 446. Adults, 155; Children, 291; Males,238; Females, 208; Colored Persons, 16.

GENERAL ORDERS--No. 7. I. Officers absent from the Department of NewMexico, and whose leaves expire on or before the 1st of July, will report at Fort Leavenworth by the 15th of May next, to proceed, with an escort, to rejoin their regiments.

In Steamship Fulton, for Havic--Mrs. C. Hutton. child and servalt. Edward Center Mr. and Mrs. Slondin 3 children and servant Mr. A. De is Forest, friend and 3 children, French Consul of Philadelphia. Mrs. C. Dord and Maid. Mr. and Mrs R Arnold. Miss McClaskey. A. C. Denison, Capt. S. W. Godon Robert Smith and lady,

Charles L. Samuels Believed to have been Murdered in Brooklyu-Continuation of the Coroner's Inquest-No evidence against the Accused-Burial of the Deceased. The mystery enveloping the death of Mr. CHAS. L. SAMUELS, the young man who was found in the East River on Thursday afternoon last, fatally stabbed to the heart, and with a stone weighing some 60 pounds tied to his body, continues to deepen.

The Coroner's Investigation in this case was resumed at 11 o'clock yesterday morning at the Second Ward Station-house. As on the previous days of the examination there was a large attendance of spectators and friends of the deceased. The following is the additional evidence:

THE REVIVAL OF BUSINESS.--The improvement in every department of business continues to be steady and decided. Trade increases in nearly every branch, and it is conducted upon a much safer basis than it has been for the past ten or twelve years.

The following are the names of the person known to be lost by the burning of the steamer Sultan: James Pogue, Albert Pogue, Mrs. Julius Pogue, of Lagrange, Mo.; Mrs. Cheatham, of Baton Rouge; S. B. Wolfolk, of Scottville, Ill.; Henry Ely, D. D. Moore, Joseph Blackburn, Dennis Callahan, and Augustus Praudein, all of St. Louis.

Various petitions were presented and referred, among others one from the citizens of New-York in favor of the passage of a general Bankrupt law, and one from the Chamber of Commerce of New-York against the abolition of the Light-House Board. The joint resolution of the Legislature of NewYork in favor of paying revolutionary debts was referred.

Some three or four months ago a revival commenced in the Methodist Church in One Hundred and Twenty-fifth-street, and has continued with more or less vigor until the present time, resulting in the conversion of over one hundred persons.

To the Editors of the New-York Times: In a letter of Mr. EDWIN O. LITCHFIELD, published in the morning papers of Saturday, that gentleman fully sustains his reputation as a writer, having great power of expressing himself in classic English. One cannot but regret that his gem of composition refuses to sparkle in a setting of fairness.

REMONETRANCES. By Mr. SCHELL of the Chamber of Commerce, against increasing the rates of wharfage in NewYork and Brooklyn ; also of the Chamber of Commerce, against taking from the New-York Common Council the right to regulate the steamboat piers arid landings. REPORTS.

A NEW STATE--ONTONAGON.--The prolific Northwest is apparently about to give birth to another member of the American family of States. We may expect soon to "welcome the advent of a little stranger" on the borders of our greatest lake.

The market was quite buoyant at the opening of the week, with an advance in all qualities of 1/8d.@ 3/4d., but the America's advices, which reached us on Tuesday, checked the upward movement, and the market closed yesterday quiet and steady. Sales for the three days 28,000 bales, of which 3,000 were taken by speculators, and 1,000 for export.

To the editor of the New-York Times: It is reported, in this City, that the United States Government will recommend the appointment of a U. S. Naval Engineer to superintend are designing and construction of the machinery for the steam fripate which the Turkish officers, lately arrived in this country, are about contracting for.

The body found floating in the water, near the Sea-Side House on Jamaica Bay, on Sunday morning, is five feet, seven inches in height, and has sandy hair, whiskers and moustache, and a light complxion. It was dressed in black cassimere pantaloons, marked "W. C. McKee," a shirt marked "W. C. McK.," and boots nearly new. It had no coat or vest on.

The hundred days, during which the Constitution contemplates the annual exercise of legislative wisdom, draws to a close. That term will end with Thursday of next week, the 15th Instant. Ninety days of the hundred have already gone.

The Canadian Company's screw steamer Indian from Liverpool at 3 o'clock P. M. of Wednesday, March 24, arrived at Portland at 41/4 P. M., 5th inst. She brings 239 passengers. The Royal Mail steamship America, from Boston vid Halifax, arrived at Liverpool at 51/4 P. M. of the 22d.

PREPARATIONS FOR WAR IN TAMPICO AND MATAMORAS---VICTORY BY VIDAURRI'S FORCES--- MATAMORAS DECLARED A FREE PORT, ETC. By the arrival of the steamship Gen. Rusk al New-Orleans from Brazos Santiago, we have received Brownsville Papers to the 24th ult. The Gen. Rusk brought $45,253 in specic on freight. The Brownsville Flag of the 17th says:

VOLUNTEERS.--It is rumored that the Presi dent intends to accept the services of a regiment of volunteers from New-York for the Utah war. Unless he has some special spite against New-York, we trust he will not inflict upon us this very questionable favor.

The condition of the federal metropolis has became a subject of just alarm to its citizens and a source of discredit to the country. Mr. BROWN, of Mississippi, in his capacity of chairman of the District Committee of the Senate, proposes to remedy some of the defects of the present Police system by conferring increased power upon the executive division of tile General Government.

The Washington Union is regaling its readers with highly exciting accounts of the opposition of Gov. CHASE and other Ohio Republicans to voting in favor of the Kansas bill, with the Crittenden amendment.

Collector SCHELL has again been dragged from his duties at the receipt of Customs to attend to political and personal exigencies here. 1 understand that his case is looking brighter, in consequence of concessions made to the New-York Delegation, hitherto resisted, but involving the sacrifice of HORACE F CLARK and his numerous appointees in the CustomHouse-who may accordingly prepare for decapitation.

Tie vote of Hartford for Governor is as follows: PRATT, Democrat, 1,937; BcBrxKNOUAM, Republican, 1,806. Two Democratic Representatives are elected by 300 plurality, and one by 100 majority. DwlaUT W. PAROEE, Democrat, is elected Senator from the First District.

SALES OF STOCKS AT PHILADELPHIA.--Tuesday -- Closing Prices.--United States 6s, 68, 114: Philadelphia 6s, 93 1/2 @ 93 3/4; Philadelphia 6s, R.R. 93 1/2 @ 93 3/4; Philadelphia 6s, new, 99@99 1/2: Pennsylvania 5s, 87 @87 1/2; Reading Railroad, 21 3/4@22; Reading Railroad Bonds, 270, 72@75; Reading Railroad mortgage 6s '44, 88@90; Reading Railroad mortgage 6s, '86, 65@67;

Every citizen of Brooklyn who does his duty will stop long enough to vote before going to business this morning. An Alderman, a Supervisor and a Constable for each Ward, and an Assessor, (for each of the oddly numbered Wards,) are to be elected. The issues are of great local importance.

The Utah man which left Camp Scott March l, has arrived. The troops continued in fine health, and were awaiting the determination of their Commander to proceed to Salt LaKe. Col. JOHNSTON had a regular effective force of 1,800 men, and a thousand animals in good condition, with a large volunteer force, and the general impression was that he would not wait for reinforcements before making the attack.

The steamship Indian, from Liverpool on the afternoon of the 24th ult., arrived at Portland yesterday, bringing four days' later intelligence from Europe. On the day previous to the Indian's departure, the United States steam-frigate Niagara arrived at Portsmouth with her machinery slightly damaged. She experienced a succession of heavy southerly gales during the passage out.

Mrs. Ellen Harrington was taken suddenly ill in Pearl-street, Saturday afternoon, and Alice McDonald, who was passing, kindly assisted her and took her to No. 74 Reade-street, where she remained some time in a state of insensibility. After wards she was conveyed to her own house. No. 68 Crosby-street. Arrived there, she discovered that she had been robbed of $247 worth of jewelry and money Alice McDonald, Mary Van Camp,

The Western mail is very irregular, and Leavenworth papers from the 26th to the 30th ult. have not been received. In the Constitutional Convention, on the 30th ult., the Committee appointed to frame a schedule reported one.

Both Houses wee busy much of the day in the doing of routin business. The third readng of bills was the order in the Assembly, interrupted only by an effort made by Dr. HURRARD to get up the bill to facilitate the removal of the Quarantine station. The effort failed.

ARREST AND PUNISHMENT OF THE CRIMINALS. Our readers have not forgotten the dreadful outrages recently committed upon the family of Mr. DICKSON, American citizens residing in Jaffa. As soon as they were related to Mr. EDWIN DE LEON, our Consul-General for Egypt and its dependencies, resident at Alexandria, he at once embarked on board the Austrian steamer and started for Jaffa to investigate the affair.

We have already announced to our readers tile burning of the steamer Sultant on the Mississippi, near Genevieve, on Friday morning last. We take the following particulars from the St. Louis Democrat: "When five miles above St. Genevieve, early on Friday morning, the boat was discovered to be on fire. The fire originated in the watchman's locker.

In the U. S. Senate yesterday, Mr. SLIDELL, of Louisiana, stated that, availing himself of the rules, he should request the Clerk of the Senate to hold back the Kansas bill from the House of Representatives three days, and claimed a right to do so. Mr. STUART, Mr. BAYARD and Mr. DOUGLAS. denied this right.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--The Concerts Musard will not commence until Monday next, owing to the extensive decorations and arrangements which are in progress, and which will not be finished until that day. The sale of tickets begins on Thursday at 9 o'clock.

The case of MCCARTY against HINES, BRIGGS and SHAY, for the assault committed on McCARTY, at the corner of Howard-street and Broadway, on the evening of March 24, came again before Recorder BARNARD yesterday.

THE MAJESTY OF THE LAW I--We clip the following item from the Baltimore Sun: "WALTER KENNEDY, a lad, was yesterday brought before Justice BOYD, by Officer HAUSE, of the Southern District Police, charged with peddling oranges and lemons without a license. The lad, who is not more than 10 or 12 years of age, had been previously warned by the Police.

Recover BARNADR, yesterday, in his charge to the Grand July, besides calling their attention to the five particular stereotyped subjects which the law makes it his duty to bring to their notice, also directed their attention to a few of the more malignant cockatrice nests in which a very considerable number of our rogues are hatched.

WHITTEMORE.--In this City, on Tuesday morning, April 6, HOMER WHITTEMORE, of Asteria, in the 71st year of his age. The friends of the family are respectfully invited, without further notice. to attend his funeral. on Thursday next. at 2 1/2 o'clock P. M., from the residence of his son Horace Whittemore. at Astoria. L. I. The steamboat Liberty will leave Peck slip at 1 o'clock P. M.

During most of Monday, the time of both branches of Congress was occupied with a Police bill for the City of Washington. It was proposed to raise a patrol force of one hundred nen, and to appropriate one hundred thousand dollars by way of defraying the expense. Bills for this purpose were introduced in both Houses. The Senate bill passed.

THE ELECTION IN BROOKLYN. Arrest of an Alderman Elect for Illegal Voting - His Discharge by the County Judge. The first independent Charter Election in this city under the act of 1857,took place yesterday, when one Alderman, and one Supervisor and one Constable was elected in each Ward, and one Assessor in each of the odd Wards.

" Holy week" has been very generally observed at the metropolis. The Israelites, (who number nearly 400 souls,) have eaten unleavened bread, and chanted their songs of Zion; the evangelical denominations have held some half-a-doyen prayer meeting each day;
STEAM FOR THE CANALS.--It is necessary now to think of propelling canal-boats by steam. The experiment has indeed been tried and failed many times within the last twenty years.

MY DEAR SIR: As you well know, I have been from the first an attentive reader of the Herald. I drew mainly form its columns the material of the first executive appeal to the legislative assembly in favor of the actual people of Kansas against the Missouri invaders. Deep, however, as was the interest with which I then perused its pages, it was not greater than that with which I have scanned your recent numbers.

PAPER BY THE HON. GEORGE BANCROFT, ON THE BATTLE OF LEXINGTON. The usual monthly meeting of the New-York Historical Society was held last evening in the lecture-room of the Society's building, Tenth-street and Second-avenue. The attendance was unusually large.

A stranger reading our political newspapers just now, might imagine that the political millennium had arrived. The organs of all parties either are, or affect to be, equally pleased with the result of the vote in Congress on the Kansas bill.

OWEN McGRATH, a gardener from Putnam County, arrived in the City on Monday afternoon. On leaving the cars at Thirty-first -street he was accosted by three strange men, with whom he soon became quite intimate, and drank several times.

One hundred and twenty-two members of the Tammany Society, who are opposed to the Wood or "Forester" faction, had an adjourned caucus last evening at the Westchester House, corner of Broome street and Bowery. ANDREW H. MICKLE, EX-Mayor, presided and made a speech.

At our Municinal Election yesterday, the entire Anti-Lecompton ticket was elected, by majorities ranging from 2,200 to 3,900. Thirteen out of this seventeen Councilmen are Anti-Lecompton. ST. LOUIS MUNICIPAL ELECTION. ST. LOUIS, Tuesday, April 6.

The Senate consumed this morning in complete ing a bill directing the payment of interest on protested drafts of the Canal Commissioners, and upon the awards of Canal Appraisers and the Canal Board, and reported progress. The Committee was then discharged, and the bill referred to be reported complete.

FIRE IN LERAY. N. Y.--A WHOLE FAMILY BURNED TO DEATH. WATERTOWN, N. Y., Tuesday, April 6. A fire occurred in the neighboring town of Leray, on Sunday night, destroying the dwelling of DANIEL COMSTOCK. COMSTOCK, his wife, and their four little children perished in the flames. The names of the children are MAEY, MAEIA, SALOME and COEA, all under ten years of age.

The disposition manifested by Southern Senators to delay the admission of Minnesota into the Union, or make its admission as a Free State dependent upon that of Kansas as a Slave State, is likely-if these gentlemen succeed in their objects-to raise some very profound and interesting question as to the status occupied by the Territories of the United States and their rights.

The Coroner's investigation into the cause of the death of CHARLES L. SAMUEL was resumed at 11 1/4 o'clock yesterday morning, at the Second Ward Station-House. Two Jurors were absent when the inquest was reopened,

The mail from the States has at length reached us in our exile, and the brow of care and anxiety is relaxed, the fatigue of military discipline and exposure is forgotten, and even the hollow mirth at the wine glass and the beart.corroding excitement of the gaming table are thrown off, and all hearts are softened with thoughts of home, of absent friends.

Mr. BIGLER, of Pennsylvania, presented from AMOS KENDALL, Chairman, etc., a supplementary memorial asking further protection against competing Telegraph Companies. The business of the Senate to-day, although it occupied a long time, can be expressed in a few words.

CINCINNATI, Wednesday, April 7.

The total vote cast at the charter election in Brooklyn, Tuesday, was about 20,000. The election for Aldermen resulted in the choice of seven Democrats, four Independent Democrats, three Americans, and five Republicans. Thirteen persons were arrested for illegal voting. In the Nineteenth, Mr. FRED. SCHOLES was reelected Alderman, and not Mr. COCHROFT, as was at first reported.

A CHECK TO STOCK-GAMBLING.--The bill to legalize stock-contracts on time passed the Assembly yesterday, at Albany, and if it should become a law it will have a much better effect towards the prevention of stock-gambling than any restrictive measure could possibly do.

A lengthened discussion took place upon the report of the Committee on Printing against the printing of eulogies of recently deceased Senators. Messrs. BROWN. FESSENDEN, HALE and others spoke against unnecessary printing. Mr. CAMERON said in behalf of the Committee that all picture books would be rejected in future, and that from thirty to forty thousand dollars had already been saved by the Committee's economy.

The April dividends of our city banks amount to nearly $1,200,000, on capitals that sum up $31,960,000. Five per cent. (semi annual) is the highest dividend, and but few hanks reach to that; and seven banks, with the aggregate capital of $4,050,000, pay but 3 per cent. Several banks show a falling off compared with their October dividends of 1857. On the whole, however, the holders of bank stocks have little to complain of.

THE ADMINISTRATION IN CONGRESS--The Democratic revolt on the Kansas question is extending to other relations between the President and Congress. In the House of Representatives there is a manifest disposition to withhold the supplies. It is the ancient and efficient English mode of humbling the Crown.

REGISTRY BILL IN THE SENATE.--Yesterday Senator WHEELER reported the bill to prevent illegal voting throughout this State, and it was made the special order for this afternoon. The final vote is to be taken on Saturday morning.

At 11 o'clock last night. there were no signs of the America, how in her thirteenth day out from Liverpool and due at Halifax. In the United States Senate yesterday, some discussion was had upon extravagance in the printing expenditures of the body. It arose upon the motion of Mr. HOUSTON to print eulogies on Senators recently deceased. After remarks by Mr CAMERON, Mr. HOUSTON, Mr. MASON and Mr. SEWARD, the motion was lost.

Per bank W. K. Teylor, arrived in Hampton Roads, we have Laguyra dates of the 20th March, and important intelligence in reference to the revolution in Venezuela. General MONAGAS, President of the Republic, fearful of being overthrown by the revolutionary party, sent his resignation to Congress on the 15th March, which was accepted, and a Provisional Government recognized, at the head of which is General CASTRO.

The Emperor NAPOLEON has just replaced the Count DE PERSIGNY as his Ambassador at London, by the Marshal Duke DE MALAKOFF. This diplomatic change has a double significance of no slight importance in the actual position of European affairs. It illustrates at once the reality of the Emperor's wish to conciliate England, and the urgency of his own domestic difficulties.

The members of the Tammany Society who are now known as " Forresters," met at the Mercer House last evening for the purpose of discussion and to prepare for the approaching election of Sachems. The Chair was occupied by Mr. JESSIE WEST, who spoke at some length of the absolute necessity of a change in the government of the Society in order to preserve its true character, its property and even its existence.

Accounts from below state that much damage has been done by a great rise in the Mississippi and Arkansas Rivers. From the mouth of White River to the Louisiana line, there are but few places that will escape being submerged. Whole cotton plantations are now under water. The town of Napoleon is completely inundated from the depth of two to ten feet.

A regular meeting of the Board of Education was held on Wednesday evening, in the Hall corner Grand and Elm streets. Mr. WILSON, the President, occupied the Chair. The minutes of the previous meeting were read and approved. The award of the contract for the building of a school-house in the Twenty-second Ward, accompanied by a resolution providing for the appropriation of $24,277 therefor, was submitted for adoption by the School officers of that Ward.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR : The Post--Office Department has contracted with a foreign vessel, the British screw steamer City of Baltimore, to carry the United States mails to and from England at sea postage for the round voyage the very moment that the American steamship Vanderbilt, the fleetest and safest steamer on the occan lies in port ready to take the malls on the same terms.

Last evening the second of the course of lectures in aid of the " Shirtmakers' aad Seamstresses' Union," was delivered by GEO. W. CURTIS, ESQ,, befor a large and intelligent audience. Mr. CURTIS chose for his subject: " Fair Play for Woman." He began by congratulating himself that on the there he had chosen, there was no lyceum, no church, no party, not even a committee, to be compromised by any plain speaking.

The Leavenworth correspondent of the Republican says that the Constitutional Convention adjourned on the night of the 3d. Under its action, negroes are allowed to vote on the Constitution, and at the first election thereafter a vote is to be had on the question of universal suffrage. Foreigners having declared their intention of becoming naturalized are also allowed to vote.

De Lamartine has written a letter to La Presse, in which he denies that there is any plaglarism in his work of Graziella. The distinguished litterateur says that the passages against Bonapartism in 1811, which characterize his book, ought to convince his accusers that he has not robbed M. De Forbin of his opinions.

It is not always the most important topic which is the most interesting. The fate of a French dynasty, or the result of the Chinese war, unquestionably affects wide regions of the earth, and influences the career of nations for years to come.

The House of Representatives is becoming rebellious. It voted yesterday plumply against two prominent and important measures of the Administration. It decided, 119 to 112, that it would adhere to its amendment of the Kansas bill, in spite of the President and the Senate; and it also voted, 124 to 106, that it would not permit Mr. BUCHANAN to expend three millions of dollars in subduing the Mormons.

DEFEAT OF THE REGISTRY BILL.--The " Act to prevent illegal voting throughout this State" came to a final vote in the Assembly yesterday, and was defeated, there being but sixty-three votes in its favor to fifty-three against it. A majority of the whole House (sixty-five) was necessary to pass it; and thus, lacking two votes, it was lost. All the Americans were present and voted for the bill.

I have seen an article copied in several of the leading papers, taken from the Chicago Democrat, which reads as follows: " The attempt to establish direct communication between Chicago and Liverpool, by sailing vessels, has failed. Mr. KERSHAW, the gentleman who spent most money In striving to accomplish it, having given it up in despair, after losing large sums of money in it."

Chloroform has been recently applied to a new purpose quite successfully. The hog thieves now go armed with a vial of this article, and administer it to the unsuspecting grunter while asleep, and carry him off without creating a disturbance. PAT FAGAN, a green thief, tried the experiment in the Tenth Ward, Wednesday night last, but before he got home the Police lodged him in the cells.

COST OF LIVING IN THE UTAH EXPEDITION.--A private letter from an officer of the Second Dragoons, on service in Utah, has been communicated to the Boston Journal. The writer gives a statement of army prices-current. The cost of supplies, other than regular rations, seems to be respectably heavy. Salt was selling at $3 per pound; green tea was $2 50, and black $2 a pound; course boots were $12 per pair;

The passage of the Deficiency bill to-day was achieved by a liberal use of inducements as to the acceptance of new regiments. Kentucky gave several votes on this consideration, and Ohio two or three. I think the vote to-day nearly settles the proposition that the Ohio and Kentucky regiments will be accepted. The Administration feel greatly relieved and elated.

COL. THOMAS H. BENTON.--The Telegraph yesterday afternoon announced the death of Col. BENTON. The same announcement was made in the House of Representatives, and that body at once adjourned. The report, however, proved to be premature. At the latest advices last night, Col. BENTON was still alive, but in a very feeble condition, and it is quite certain that his end is near at hand.

We have received no intelligence whatever from the missing brig Bloomer, from Boston for NewFoundland, except the rumors from St. Johns, N. F. which are clearly without any foundation beyond the fact that she was much overdue at Placentia Bay. If she was wrecked, the disaster probably occurred upon Sable Island,

An effort will be made by several of the newly elected Aldermen, to have the sessions of the Common Council held in the afternoon next year, instead of in the evening, as heretofore. The proposed change finds favor with all classes, excepting, perhaps, the lobby. The Corporation Counsel has reported to Superintendent TALLMADGE that "there are no ordinances particularly applicable to the observance of Sunday."

The St. Joseph's Gazette announces the arrival at that place of ALEXANDER CONSTANT, from Fort Kearney 30th ult. Mr. CONSTANT reports that BRIGHAM YOUNG had notified Col. JOHNSTON to leave the Territory of Utah by the 10th of March, otherwise his troops would be annihilated. YOUNG had also tendered to the army sufficient provisions to last them to the States.

James Bogardus vs. The Mayor, , of the City of New-York.--The plaintiff in this action sues for damages for an infringement of a patent issued to him in May, 1850, for improvements in the construction of the frame, room and floor of iron buildings. It seems that the City advertised for bids for the building of an iron bell tower at Mount Morris some eighteen feet in diameter, and some thirty feet high.

The recent outrage upon American missionaries in Jaffa furnishes an admirable illustration of the value of Turkish reforms and the binding force of the Hatti Hamayoun which the Paris Conference presented to the world in 1856 as the crowning triumph of the Russian war. The real difficulty in the way of "Turkish regeneration" lies in the fact that there is no necessary connection whatever between the sayings and the doings of the Government.

An infernal machine was last weekly set in the basement of the Cincinnati Type foundry, in Centrestreet, for the purpose of killing Mr. Lee, the engineer. It proved to be a very ingeniously contrived apparatus, consisting of a piece of gas-pipe, seveneights of an inch in diameter, eight inches long, filled with explosive material, and weldod with wroughtiron plugs at each end. Mr. Lee picked it up,

It had been carefully drawn up in the Committee of Ways and Means, and its items pared down to the lowest amounts consistent with the necessities

The Solons of Kansas are now in Convention at this place for the purpose of framing a constitution for the people of Kansas, under a law of the late Territorial Legislature. As already reported, this Convention adjourned last week from Minneola to this place, where they have been making commendable progress to the present time. A majority of the standing committees have reported,

FATAL ACCIDENT.--Coroner GAMBLE held an inquest, yesterday, at the City Hospital, upon the body of GEORGE H. RICHER, a young man ho, while in a state of somnambulism, prceipitated himself street, and died shortly afterward from the injuries received. A verdict was rendered of "Death from a fracture of the skull." The deceased was 25 years of age, and a native of Boston.

It is intimated, with increasing condence, in semi-official quarters, that the Administration is not disinclined to capitulate on tile Kansas question and assent to enaotment of the Crittenden substitute for the Kansas bill. The President and his friends must have become convinced of their inability to force the Lecompton Constitution upon the House of Representatives or the people of Kansas.

By the arrival of the steamship Tennessee at New-Orleans from Vera Cruz, we have received late and important news from Mexico. Gen OSOLLO, acting in behalf of the Zuloaga Government, had taken the City of Guadalajara, capturing the entire Government of JUABER. The officers of the latter were permitted to leave the country. Vera Cruz is now the most important place that holds out for the Constitutionalist party.

Dr. BAYARD, the President of the Homoeopathic Medical Society of the County of New-York, delivered the annual address before that body and a pretty large promiscuous audience, in the lectureroom of the Historical Society, on Saturday evening last.

From the Philadelphia Press, Saturday. Yesterday the negroes, ALEXANDER ANDERSON and HENRY RICHARDS, convicted of the murder of Mrs. GAREER and Mrs. REAN, expiated their crime on the gallons, at Lancaster. The prisoners, at an early hour in the morning, were making their final preparations for the awful moment, and were spending their few last minutes with their spiritual advisers.

Because it will put a step to the issues pending between the Courts and the floating Dock Companies.

The following is the Weekly Report of Deaths in the City and County of New-York, from the 3d day of and, to the 10th day of April, 1858: Men, 84; Women. 76: Boys, 145; Girls, 130: Total, 435.* Adults, 160; Children, 275; Males,229; Females, 206; ?? Perrsons, 6.

Judge RUSSELL, in the court of General Sessions, on Saturday, sentenced WILLIAM QUINN, convicted of manslanghter in the fourth degree, to six months' imprisonment in the Penitentiary. A dispute had arisen between QUINN and a neighbor, respecting the pasturage of some cows, and the neighbor made an assault upon him. QUINN, in defending himself, struck him on the head with a pitchfork, and caused his death.

To Samuel Houston, Esq., Senator in Congress from the State of Texas, and George W. Jones, Esq., Representative in Congress from Tennessee: To You, as old Tennessee friends, I address myself to say, that in the event of my death here, I desire that there shall not be any notice taken of it in Congress.

We are more frequently moved to congratulate our legislators at Albany on leaving undone things which, had they meddled with them, would almost certainly have been ill done, than on doing things which everybody agrees it was becoming that they should do. On Saturday last, however, the Solons of the State earned an exceptional tribute of honor.

By the bank N. H. Gasion. of this port, we have a Barbadoes price current of March 24. There is a fair demand for Breadstuffs and Provisions. The Market is moderately supplied, and with an improved local consumption, Corn Meal has advanced in value 50c. to 75c. per barrel; the similar rates having been refused for a lot to arrive.

The Southern mail brings particulars of the crevasse in Arkansas, reported previously by telegraph. The levees on the Mississippi below Napoleon gave Way last week, and the break grew rapidly larger nnthe whole neighboring country became submerged. Large plantations, valued at $50 per acre, were completely covered, and nearly all tile live stock swept away; all, in fact, save the few who congregated upon little patches of rising ground here and there,

The steamship Tennessec, from Vera Cruz, 7th inst., is coming up the river. She brings intelligence of the highest importance from Mexico. General OSOLLO, acting in behalf of the Zuloago Government, had taken the City of Guadalajara, capturing the entire Government of JUAREZ. JUAREZ and his officers were permitted to leave the country.

The new Board of Aldermen will be composed of 19 members, politically divided as follows: Democrats, 7; Independent Democrats, 4 ; Americans, 5; Republicans, 3. The Democrats are exerting themselves to secure the cooperation of the Independents, but with only partial success.

Some of our contemporaries find fault with our views on the China question, and the Tribune, in particular, defines our statement that Americans in China have been outraged in person and property, as a random assertion. It is unnecessary to inform the readers of the TIMES that our remarks upon this subject were founded on facts in current history.

GEO. A. BENEDICT, Esq -- Dear Sir: I observed in the extracts from Washington correspondence, published in the Evening Herald of March 30, that the correspondent of the New-York Courier and Enquirer places my name among those of the Republicans who Mere against the proposed union of all parties on CRITTENDEN'S amendment to STEPHEN'S Lecompton Constitution bill. I desire to say that the statement is without the shadow of foundation.

Hon. THOMAS H. BENTON died at 7 1/2 o'clock on Saturday morning. The bill of Senator WILSON, which is set down for consideration to-morrow, authorizes the Secretary of War to contract for the construction of a telegraph from a point in Missouri to the Army at Salt Lake. A company, headed by Mr. O'REILLY.

PRATT (one of the twelve apostles of the Salt Lake Mormon Church,) was killed by Mr. McLAIN, after he had taken the wife of Mr. McLAIN UNTO himself. Senator WILSON recently applied at the State Department for a passport for D. J. s. ROCK, a colored citizen of Boston, and received the following reply from the Secretary: DEPARTMENT OF STATE, WASHINGTON, April 2, 1858. To the Hon. Henry Wilson, Senate Chamber: SIR: I have had the honor to receive your note of yesterday with its accompaniments.

SCIENTIFIC CONVENTION.--The Spring meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science will open in the Maryland Institute at Baltimore, on Wednesday, April 28. The session will probably continue for a week. The entertainers on this occasion will be the Corporation of the Maryland Institute and the Directors of the Maryland Historical Society.

The voting in the House of Representatives on Thursday was but an epitome of the voting of the whole session. The two leading questions of the present Congress are those of Utah and of Kansas. On both aid the House place itself in opposition to the views of the Administration.

REPORTB. Relative to the Superior and Common Pleas Courts in New-York. To confirm the official acts of THOMAS G. TALLMADGE, Loan Commissioner of Kings County. Tabled. To amend the law for the benefit of married women insuring the lives of their husbands. To amend the charter of the Harmony Fire Insurance Company.

SUPERIOR COURT -- GENERAL TERM. Before Hon Justices Hoffman, Slosson, Woodruff and Pierraepoot. DECISIONS -- WHAT CONSTITUTES A NON RESIDENT? Barry vs. Bockover. -- In this case a warrant of attachment was granted against the defendant, as a non-resident. Motion was made at Special Term to vacate the warrant on the ground that defendant was a resident.

A well-attended public meeting was held here at noon to-day, for the purpose of making appropriate arrangements to do honor to the memory of the late Hon. THOMAS H. BENTON. Brief eulogies were pronounced by several gentlemen, appropriate resolutions were adopted, and a Committee of prominent citizens appointed to take such action as may be necessary for a public demonstration of respect to the remains of the deceased, when brought hither for interment.

From the Washington States. On Thursday evening Mrs. GWIN received her guests with a courteous affability that set them at ease at once, and removed the embarrassment naturally attendant on enering lighted saloons in fancy dress. Her dress was that of a Lady of the Course of Louis Quatorze, composed of a skirt of white moricamtque, trimmed with flounces of ponite d daguille:

The forthcoming report from the Committee of the House appointed early in the session to investigate the cost of the public printing, the profits of the pointers, ,-a Committee most imperatively called for by the numerous startling stories of corruption existing in this department of governmental expenditure,

The Constitutional Convention at Leavenworth probably adjourned yesterday, or this morning, as the work was nearly completed on Thursday, the 1st, except enrolling and signing. Two or three test votes were to be taken however, yesterday, when upon the final passage, the result of which I have not yet learned.

THE MASQUERADE BALL.-Police Justice WELSH has addressed an epistle to Mr. ULLMANN, warning him against giving the grand masquerade ball which has been for a long time in course of preparation at the Academy. He refers him to the law of the State which forbids all such exhibitions, and requires every person to show his face at all public places as a guarantee of his good behavior.

ORGANIC ASTUTENESS--To be an Adminis traction organ is little short of being inspired In proof of this, just look at the Washington Union. That miraculous sheet has made a discovery which must astonish the country. It is, that unless the political friends of the President support him, he will be beaten. For lack of such support, the Union says, the Administration was twice beaten on Thursday.

MOSER.--In this City, on Saturday, April 16, of consumption. ELIZA, widow of the late Samuel H. Moser, aged 46 years. The relatives and friends, also of her brother, john Ferguson are invited to attend her funeral, form No. 286 West 35th st., on Tuesday afternoon, April 13, at 2 o' clock, without further notice.

ANOTHER CHANCE FOR PHILADELPHIA.--The Pliladelphians are growing excited on the subject of steam communication with Europe. It has been the fate of all the attempts made to establish a line of European steamers from our sister City, that no sooner have the ships commenced running than stern necessity has compelled their transfer to New York.

There were in the port of New-York on Friday 86 steamers, 110 ships, 08 barks, 71 brigs and 200 schooners, total 545, of which there were cleared, Thursday, 2 ships, 4 brigs, 4 schooners. Up for foreign ports 112, of which 17 are regular packets; for distant ports in the United States 46, of which 33 are regular packets.

The Canal Board to-day reduced the tolls on Wheat and Flour from Flour mills to two mills per thousand pounds per mile, and also made a reduction on marble partly wrought, of one-half mill; also, a reduction on stoves and cast-iron ware of one mill.

FISH--JENNINGS--In this City on Wednesday, April 7, at the Church of the Divine Unity, by the Rev Dr. Chapin. Mr. WM. L. FISH of the A??tor-place Hotel, to Miss EMILY S., daughter of William T. Jennings, Esq., ail of this City. BRIGGS--CHAMPNEY--In Brooklyn, on Wednesday, March 24 by the Rev Stephen A. Tyag D. D. the Rev. O. W. BRIGGS and Mrs MARY AUGUSTA CHAMPNEY, all of Brooklyn.

IMPORTANT FROM MEXICO --The news from Mexico which we publish this morning is of considerable importance. It proves that the new Government, of which General ZULOAGA is the temporary head, is made up of stronger materials than many people supposed. The new Government has given evidence of its strength in a manner that cannot fail to exercise a weighty influence on the future destinies of the Republic.

It is now manifest that in Congress and throughout the country the Lecompton Constitution is gaining strength every day. All doubts of its success have vanished, and the only uncertainties upon the subject, are, first, the precise majority in each House in favor of the bill; Secondly, the day of its passage in each House;

From the Grand Rapids Eagle, 7th. At about 11 o'clock last evening our citizens were alarmed by the cry of fire, and with it the whole city was almost immediately illuminated by the flames which burst out and shot up from a sash factory nearly adjoining the bridge, on the North side and at the East end of it.

It is early in the season to be talking of a midsummer campaign, but circumstances have precipitated the contest upon us, and we feel no hesitation in giving our views of its character, at the same time that we invite the attention of the people of every County of the State to what we have to say.

Colonel ST. VRAIN arrived here yesterday from Santa F with the advance mail. He reports that Captain MARCY left the came ground, forty miles from Fort Union, on the 18th of Marsh. He had about twelve hundred animals, mostly mules, ?? abundant supply of forage, and plenty of provision for his men.

In the Court of General Sessions yesterday, before Recorder BARNARD, HENRY MEYER pleaded guilty to an attempt at grand larceny, and was sentenced to two years in the State Prison. JAMES JOHNSTON, an old offender, pardoned out of the State Prison by Governor CLARK, pleaded guilty to an attempt at grand larceny, and was sentenced to four years in the State Prison the Recorder observing that he did not deserve any leniency.

Before the Hon. Justice Sutherland. Yesterday morning, while Judge SUTHERLAND was sitting at Circuit, Mr. James T. Brady appeared and obtained from him the following order, commanding Conover to deliver up possession of the Street Commissioner's Office:

Never, since the masquerade so fatal to GUSTAVUS of Sweden, has there been an entertainment en costume about which so much has been said, and will be said, as that which was given last night (and prolonged late into this morning) by Mrs. Senator GWIN, of California. For the past month it has been the staple topic of metropolitan gossip, and "what to wear" has been discussed even more than the Lecompton Constitution.

DECLINE OF SLAVERY-THE COMING ISSUE IN MISSOURI.--An article in the St. Louis Republican asserts that the general election in Missouri on the 2d of August next, is to turn upon the distinct issue of emancipation. It does not appear that any specific measure will then be presented by the opponents of Slavery,

DEATH OF GENERAL THOMAS.--We regret to receive, by private letters from Paris, news of the death of Gen. J. ADDISON THOMAS, of this City. He died at his residence, No. 26 Champs Elysees. Paris, on the evening of March 21, of typhoid fever, after an illness of several weeks. General THOMAS graduated at West Point in 1834, and after serving in the army was appointed commandant of a corps of Cadets at that place.

THE LITTLES MURDER TRIAL AT ROCHESTER.--The telegraph announces that the above trial commenced yesterday. IRA STOUT and his sister, Mrs. SARAH LITTLES, are arraigned for the murder of CHARLES W. LITTLES, the woman's husband. Public opinion in Rochester is settled in the belief of their guilt. LITTLES was a lawyer, a dissolute young man, who had separated from his wife, but who continued to annoy her with his visits.

The Atlantic Telegraph. STOWING THE CABLE ON BOARD THE AGAMEMNON From the London Times, March 26. The operation of stowing the wire for a second. effort commenced on Friday last, 19th, on board her Majesty's ship Agamemnon, in Keyham basin. An extra place for deposit has been constricted on her upper deck, abaft the foremast, capable of taking 21-5th miles each flake or layer.

The river still continues very high. The water run over the levees in several places on this side the river, near the city, but the damages have been repaired. On the opposite side a crevasse of 300 feet is overflowing the plantations. Other crevasses are reported above. A heavy rain yesterday completely flooded the streets. The wind to-day is very high.

It is not yet determined to dispatch Civil Commissioners to Utah along with the Commander-in-Chief of the Army. The subject has been discussed in the military committee of the Senate for more than two months. The recommendation was made by Col. DAVIS, the chairman of the committee, in his elaborate speech, favoring an increase of the army early in February.

MOSER.--In this City, on Saturday, April 10, of consumption, ELIZA, widow of the late Samuel H. Moser, aged 46 years. The relatives and friends, also of her brother, John Ferguson, are invited to attend her funeral,

The elections for Municipal officers of Jersey City and Hoboken take place to day, and the prospects are that the contest will be spirited in both places. In Jersey City the polls will be open from 7 o'clock in the morning until 7 o'clock in the evening, and in Hoboken from 8 in the morning to 7 in the evening.

THE ADJOURNMENT.-The Albany Atlas and Argus of yesterday says, that although the hundied days to which the session of the Legislature is practically restricted, by the constitutional limitation of the compensation to that term, will expire to-morrow, it is probable the two Houses will give to the State the benefit of their services for two days beyond that time, if not to the end of tile present week.

Tile mail from all points South, as late as due, is to hand. The accounts of the crops from Texas are encouraging. Wheat and corn were beyond the danger of rains. The ship National Guard had cleared from Galveston for Liverpool, with 3,000 bales of cotton.

Our annual City Election came off to-day and was hotly contested on both sides. The Democrats ran for Mayor JOHN A. TAINTOR, and the Republicans TIMOTHY M. ALLEN. The latter was elected Mayor by 212 majority. The Democrats elect a Collector, two city Sheriffs, and carry three Wards. The Opposition elect their Mayor, City Clerk, Auditor, and Water Commissioner, and carry three Wards.

Affairs at Canton remain in statu quo, nothing of interest having transpired since the departure of the last mail. The City still stands as of yore, is quietry occupied by the Allies, and ruled by its Tartar Governor. The complete success of the British arms in the Province of Kwangtung, together with the little resistance experienced from the Chinese,

Senator SPINOLA declared in the recent debate on the Police Bill, that some twenty-five or thirty individuals, friends and connections of the Police Commissioners, are in receipt of pay as policemen, without doing duty: in other words, that they draw $800 a year of the public money for nothing.

NICHOLE--LEWIS.--In this City, on Wednesday, April 7, at 2 o'clock P. M., at the Central M. E. Church by the Rev. D.S. Brown, Mr. EDWARD A NICHOLS to EMELINE, daughter of Sylvanus Lewis, Esq., all of this City. McGEE--RIORDAN.--In Brooklyn, on Monday, April 5, by the Rev. Father Keegan, JAMES EDWARD McGEE, Esq., Counsellor at Law. New-York, to LIZZIE M., daughter of Eugene Riordan Esq.. of Brooklyn.

A PROPHET IN HIS OWN COUNTRY.--The Evening Post of yesterday entertains its readers with Mr. HAWTHORNE'S excellent story of "The Unpardonable Sin," which, certainly, well deserves to be riot a twice, but even a thrice-told tale, and, with something more of politeness than of patriotism, credits the romantic narrative to the London Illustrated News.

The advent of MUSARD has been surrounded by so many extraneous circumstances by the "little Napoleon" of the Opera-house that it is difficult to make a beginning in noticing the event. Whether we ought to begin with the handsome and distinguished maestro, or the orchestra of one hundred and twenty professors, or the fascinating ladies "of prepossessing appearance" in the refreshment saloons

THE VERDICT OF THE CORONER'S JURY IN THE CASE OF YOUNG SAMUEL.--The Corner's inquest in the case of young SAMUEL, of Brooklyn, after sitting nearly a week, rendered their verdict yesterday, and were dismissed. No evidence whatever was furnished to afford a clue to the perpetrator of the murder, or to throw any light on the motive for the deed, and the verdict was in accordance.

At 10 1/2 o'clock Sunday night the store of A. M. BENNET, No. 244 Fulton street, under the Globe Hotel, caught fire, and before the fire could be extinguished about $3,000 worth of stock was destroyed. Insured sufficient to cover the loss, in the Phenix and Firemen's Insurance Compaies.

The Jury impanneled to inquire into the cause of the death of CHARLES L. SAMUEL, of Brooklyn, reassembled yesterday morning, at 11 1/2 o'clock, at the Second Ward Station-house. There was a numerous attendance of the friends of the deceased and others as on the previous days of the investigation.

Saturday and Mondays are always blue days in the Real East market. No public sales to-day, except a Referees' sale of two houses and lots south side Forty-second-street, 200 feet east of Ninth avenue. Houses four stories brick, 25x45, lots 25x98.9, free and clear of all incumbrance. The first sold for $2.825,

The Senate was engaged all the morning in the passage of bills. The bill relative to Wharves and Slips in the City of New-York, which may be leased to steamboat Companies, was passed. as was the bill relative to the classification, , of the New-York Supervisors. The Public Printing bill was laid over, and the bill to incorporate the Central American Commercial and Industrial Company received similar action.

The Cabinet had a close session to-day, from 9 until 1 o'clock, but I cannot learn on what subject. It is evident from various indications that something important is on the tapis, and rumor is busy in determining whether it is a Spanish war message, the affairs of Mexico, a new Kansas bill, our treaty relations with England, or Utah.

LAST REQUEST or BENTON.--When the dying veteran was within a few hours of his end, he addressed a letter to Gen. HOUSTON and the Hon. GEO. JONES, requesting that Congress would take no notice of his impending death. The request was characteristic, both for its modesty and its egotism; but is chiefly interesting as showing how the last thoughts of his active and stormy spirit instinctively turned to the associates of his youth.

A message was received from the House announcing its adherence to its vote on the Kansas bill; also, that it had passed the Deficiency Appropriation bill. Mr. GREEN, of Missouri, gave notice that he would move to take up the Kansas bill to-morrow at 1 o'clock.

The inclement weather of last night prevented so large a gathering as was anticipated at the Crystal Palace, on the occasion of the first annual festival of the Roman Catholic Orphan Asylum. But notwithstanding the weather, and notwithstanding also that the Hunter-Woodis Ball took place only last Thursday, with its immense crowd, and its very bad management,

The America's mails reached this City yesterday morning from Boston, but the telegram from HALIFAX, published on Saturday, embraced all the principal feature of the news, Beyond the confirmation of the announcement received by the previous steamer. of the appointment of the Duke DE MALKAOFF as French Ambassador to England,

SEDUCTION AND ATTEMPTED SUICIDE.-As one of the Ninth Ward Police was patrolling his beat at an early hour yesterday morning, a woman suddenly jumped from the wharf into the river. The officer at once rushed to her aid and succeeded in effecting her rescue. The rescued female proved to be a young German girl.

FLOUR dull--City Mills $4 25. WHEAT dull. Yellow CORN. 67c. @68c. PROVISIONS--An advancing tendency. Bulk Shoulders, 6 3/8c. @7c. Mess PORK, $18. LARD, 10 3/8c.@10 1/2c. The Street Commissioner's Office. The decision of the Court of Appeals, which reinstates DEVLIN as Street Commissioner, drew to the Park a crowd of persons who bear a striking resemblance to those who were seen in and about the City Hall during the disturbances in which Mayor WOOD-acted so prominent a part.

Bear witness, remunerating publishers, that I do not omit my required Saturday epistle, but this Revve de la Semaine will be like the play of "Hamlet" with the part of the princely Dane omitted-for the chief topic of gossip faithfully chronicled for the TIMES, was sent North yesterday afternoon.

A mass meeting of the friends of HENRY CLAY and opponents of the Administration was held at National Hall this evening, for the purpose of celebrating his birth-day and moving for the establishment of a National Party. The meeting was not very large, the weather being extremely inclement.

MASQUERADES AND FANCY BALLS.--A very grand fancy dress ball has recently been given at the national metropolis by the lady of a California Senator, and we are threatened with a real masquerade on the Parisian plan at the Academy of Music next week. We do not seriously apprehend there is any danger of each entertainments becoming popular or frequent here, but there are two very good reasons why they might.

The year 1857-8, which will hardly be chronicled in letters of gold upon the commercial and political annals of our country, must certainly be marked " with a white stone" on the records of Art and Religion.
