The Senate will to-day send to the House a request for a Committee of Conference on the Kansas bill. Reports differ as to the probability that this request will be granted. On the one hand it is asserted with confidence that every man of the Anti-Lecompton party will vote against a conference:

REPORTS. To amend the law relative to Foreign Insurance Companies. To incorporate the Youatt Lyceum, New-York. Relative to the New-York Institution for the Blind. To authorize the conveyance of land to the Woman's State Hospital. Legalizing the action of tile Supervisors of NewYork relative to HENRY TIMSON.

The screw-steamship City of Washington from Liverpool on the 31st ult., arrived at this port yesterday, bringing four days' later intelligence from Europe. In England the journals are discussing, to the exclusion of other subjects, the bill amending the Government of India.

JOSEPH WOOD, the Democratic candidate for Mayor, and the whole city Democratic ticket, with a majority of the Council, has been elected. The majority on the city ticket is about 150. ELIZABETHTOWN, N. J., Tuesday, April 13. At the charter election held in this city, yesterday, the entire Anti-Lecompton ticket was elected by about 200 majority.

Our Albany correspondent, some days since, sent us a condensed synopsis of Senator SPINOLA'S speech upon the Metropolitan Police Law, embodying sundry statements made by him concerning the appointment of political friends and personal relatives of the Republican members of the Board.

Nothing of interest occurred up to 1 o'clock. At that hour the Kansas bill came up, and Mr. GREEN, of Missouri, without any remarks, moved that, as the House had disagreed, the Senate would insist and ask a Committee of Conference, in lieu of resolving to adhere.
Mr. Commissioner CHOLWELL occupies a good deal of our Space this morning with a reply to what he styles an " abusive personal attack upon him and his relatives " in the TIMES of yesterday morning.

BURNING A MAN ON A HOT STOVE.--WILLIAM DE GOLIA, an Italian, residing at No. 9 Centre Market Place, was violently assaulted and beaten on Sunday morning, by two Irishmen named MICHAEL FOLEY and PATRICK McNULLY.
Tile determination to postpone Kansas in the House is changed, and it is expected to come up tomorrow, when a Committee of Conference, say the Democrats, will certainly be carried.

The U. S. Mail steamship Star of the West, ALFRED G. GRAY, Esq., Commander, left Aspinwall April 4, at 1 P. M., and arrived at Quarantine at 1 o'clock P. M. yesterday. She brings the California mails of March 22, $1,352,912 in treasure on freight and 163 passengers.

There was another meeting of the Democratic Regulars, at the Westchester House, Bowery, last evening, at which Mr. A. J. MICKLE presided. On a motion having been carried that all who had not and would not sign the roll, should leave the room, four gentlemen who had been considered Forresters or Wood men, went forward and signed.

A recent letter in the New-York Herald, purporting to be written here, and pretending to give a history of the sale, to Government, of some land in the vicinity of New-Bedford, for war purposes, has, most unfortunately for the apparent objects of the writer, excited inquiries which have resulted in exposing a clue to some very important and interesting developments.

The Charter election for City and Ward officers in Jersey City took place yesterday, and, with few exceptions, passed off in a quiet manner. Up to 12 o'clock last night, only about half of the votes had been canvassed.

The steamship City of Washington, which sailed from Liverpool at 11 o'clock on the morning of the 31st of March, arrived at this port yesterday at 2 o'clock P. M. The Europe arrive out at Liverpool at 8 3/4 on the morning of the 29th ult. The screw steamer New-York arrived at Glasgow on the 27th. .

THE ORSINI AND PIERRI SYMPATHIZERS.-There was a meeting at No. 291 Bowery last evening, of the delegates from the various nationalities, that propose to celebrate the death of ORSINI and PIERRI. The Chair was occupied by Mr. LISEN CASE, and Mr. WM. TRAUB acted as Secretary.

SIR: In your issue yesterday you made me and my relatives the subject of a grossly abusive personal attack; and, to inflame the indignity, you gave to the assault the greatest prominence you could, by making it the editorial leader for the day. I believe it has been considered due to the readers of a public journal to devote its leading column to leading events, or matters of general concern.

The British steam propeller Saladin arrived at this port on the 31st ult., from Liverpool, having touched at Savanilla on the 29th. An English passerger on board, Mr. DUFFIELD, who left Bogota on the 9th March, says that the Convention between New-Granada and the United States was ratified by the Senate, under the following circumstances:

The third reading of bills occupied the Senate to the exclusion of almost all other business, except what was done in Executive session. In the House, the third reading of the bills which make up the Chancellor's Budget was the special order at 11 o'clock.

WHITNEY.--In this City. on Monday, April 12, the Hon.THOMAS R. WHITNEY, in the 51st year of his age. The funeral will take place from his late residence, No. 199 East Broadway, on Thursday, April 15. at 2 o'clock P. M. His relatives. friends, friends of the family, chancery and members of the 0. U. A., are respectively invited to attend.

In steamship Star of the West. from Asvinwall.--George Campbell, F. W. Brooks, wife, infant and servant, Mrs. Chauncy Taylor and child, Jomes Wilson and wife, Mrs. Werner. L. Fleishman, wife and three children, Dr. Daniel Dustin and wife, Mrs. Hutchins and child, Mme. Vallette. R. M. Hooley, Esq., John Davidson, A. J. Reed, Lieut La Rhett, L. Livingston, U. S. A.,

Considerable excitement yesterday morning at the New-Jersey Freight Depot (foot of Cortlandt street) grew out of the rumor that a box had been left there to be forwarded over the road, containing the mutilated remains of a human body. The box in question was directed to "W. B. VAN WORST, New-Brunswick."

A NEST OF CORRUPTION.--According to tile statements of our Washington Correspondent, some of our prominent Administration officeholders and their friends in this City, have been doing a thriving business in the way of land speculations.

The Leavenworth correspondent of the Republican says that Messrs RUSSELL, MAJORS WADDELL have received orders to start one hundred and ten trains and twenty-six wagons for Utah. These trains take upwards of 3,000 teamsters and 11,000 mules. A company of Sappers and Miners from West Point had reached Fort Leavenworth.

The steamship Daniel Webster, MINER, commander, from New-Orleans on the 5th, and Havana on the 8th inst., arrived at this port yesterday. The steamships Empire City and Granada were at Havana on the 8th. The former, as we learn by telegraph from New-Orleans, arrived at that port yesterday, with the California mails and passengers.

WHAT IS TO BE DONE WITH THE COLLINS STEAMERS?--There seems to be great doubt asto the ultimate destination of these magnificent steamers. Philadelphia thought of buying them to run between that city and Liverpool. Norfolk has been in a state of great anxiety for a long time past to establish a line of steamers between Virginia and France.

CORRUPTION OF CORPORATIONS--CINCINNATI OUTDOING NEW YORK--Very curiousdevelopments have been made public in Cincinnati, concerning recent regotiations of the officers of the Ohio and Mississippi Railroad Company with the City corporation. The railroad company wanted to sell a wharf properly to the city, and in order to accomplish this purpose proceeded to buy up votes in the common council.

Not the least curious, and certainly the most useful, of the vast system of improvements now in execution at Paris, is the underground operations for sewerage, and water and gas purposes. Like the distribution of the vessels of the human body, this vast plexus of subterranean communication forms the secretary and excretory ducts, which give life and energy to the city.

The clipper-ship Sunny South, Capt. STEPHEENSON, arrived at this port last evening, from Santos Brazil, having on board Mr. WOOD and two children, of Honolulu, S. 1.. Mr. EDWIN B. FORD, of Brooklyn, N. Y., and Mr. SHERWOOD, of Boston, passengers of the late ship John Gilpin, foundered at sea off Cape Horn.

The ceremonies of Holy Week passed off this year with greater eclat than on any former occasion. The clouds were kind enough to dispense with their customary showers, so that all the out-door operations, including the visit to the sepulchres and the grand burial of Christ, were gone through with in strict accordance with the ritual of Holy Mother tile Church.

It is explained at the Treasury that the first six millions of Treasury notes, issued in January, were not included in the general receipts of the last quarter, which amount, as heretofore stated by me, to $13,521,000. Nearly the whole of that issue was paid out to the Government creditors upon warrants, and tile proceeds, being simply debts canceled, were not reckoned receipts into the Treasury.

The Vice-President presented a memorial from the Legislature of Utah, setting forth their grievances. It is semi-defiant in style. Laid on the table, by 32 to 13. Mr. OWIN presented resolutions from the Legislature of California, asking for the admittance of Kansas under the Lecompton Constitution.
THE TRACT SOCIETY CONTROVERSY.-As the time for the annual election approaches, the controversy in the American Tract Society concerning the publication of tracts upon Slavery,waxes warmer.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR: BOOK-keepers and accountants are good in their way, bark defaults the contrary. But, Sir, it does not follow that the latter are only to be obviated by the medium of the former. I recollect, when in England a few years ago, on the oceasion of numerous disastrcus ship creeks, considerable correspondance with the Press took place as to the most efficacious mode of preventing such calamities.

Mexico can scarcely be regarded any longer as " the sick man" of America, for she is in the article of death, if riot already deceased. The designation more properly belongs to New-Granada, which, like most of the Spanish-American Republics, is inevitably drifting into ruin and dissolution.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: An amusing letter, excelling Micawber in his best vein, intended to enlighten the obstinate and benighted mind of the Director of the Academy of Music on the law and masquerade balls, has appeared in several of the City papers, over the signature of a Police Justice named WELSH. This communication is full of mistakes, which are pardonable,

SIR: Many persons having written on the subject of Mormonism, it cannot be considered improper for me to write a few things that I am personally knowing to be true. Many persons have written upon mere surmises, or bearsay statements; some with a desire that what they write might be true, and some write, bring influenced by a spirit of wickedness.

To the Editors of the National Intelligencer: In a letter of the 8th inst., signed "Janius," to the "Baltimore Patrtol and Commercial Gazette," and published in that paper on the 9th inst., is the following sentence: "It is stated that JAMES L PETTIREW, of South Carolina. , I as written to Senator CRITTENPEN from Charleston that the masses of the Southern people condianly adept his proposition on the Kansas question."

The block of buildings on the corner of Western Row and Canal-street, occupied by a coffee-house, by Mr. WOOD's feed store, WM. FISHER'S mahogany. chair store, and various others, was destroyed by fire last night. The establishment of Messrs. ROOT COE, adjoining, was considerably damaged. The total loss is estimated at $35,000, a portion of which is covered by insurance.

The leading Canal Bill, which proposes a loan of $3,800,000 to complete the enlargeinent, provided the consent of the people shall he obtained at the ensuing November Election, passed the Assembly on Tuesday, and may be regarded as a law.

PIKE,--In this City, on Tuesday, April 13, Mrs. MARY PIKE, in the 75th year of her age. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, from her late residence, No. 116 West 24th st, this (Thursday) afternoon, at 3 o'oclock, without further invitation.
The Rev. Dr. COOK, first President of the French Wesleyan Conference, died at Lausanne, Switzerland, in the latter part of February. He had been in the ministry for forty-one years.
In steamship Roanoke, for Portsmouth, Pomeroy Miss Anna Vail, J. This. T. Schreiner. Mrs. Em. Wymen, John Foster and lady, G. Griswold, G. K. Pread,

OCKERSHAUSEN--FIELD.--In this City, on Tuesday, April 13, at the residence of her grandmother, Mrs. George Taylor, by the Rev. R. M. Hatfield. JOHN H. OCKERSHAUSEN, of the firm of A. F. J. H. Ockershausen, to ELIZABETH T., daughter of the late Benjamin Field of this City. CASS-SHEEWOOD.--In this City, on Tuesday evening. April 13, by the Rev. A. D. Gillett, Mr. JAMES CASS, of Williamsburg to Miss FANNY E. SHERWOOD, of this City.

Letters from Paducah to the Missouri Republican say, that that usually quiet city was a few days ago thrown into quite an excitement by the arrest of a Prussian subject by the name of EDWARD DESLING, under the extradition treaty existing with that Government and the United States, under a charge of forgery and fraud.

BELIEF FROM AN EMBARRASSMENT.--The famous Surveyor-General CALHOUN finds it difficult to resume the duties of his office in Kansas, on account of the public hostility aroused by his proceedings in that Territory. To accommodate him in this matter, the President has ordered the removal of his office from Lecompton into Nebraska Territory.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--Mr. MUSARD'S third concert last evening was attended by a fine audience, and the programme was executed with immense spirit and effect. The performers are becoming familiar with their new chef, and know how to interpret his significant nod; this is as it should be. To. night there will be an almost entire change of pro-. gramme, and Mr. ANSCHUTZ will assist in the direction of the orchestra.

By and with the advice and consent of the Senate. COLLIONON OF CUSTOMS. Jesse J. Simkine, Norfolk, Va, vice Sawyer. SURVEYOES OF THE CUSTOMS. Charles Shelton New-Haven, Cona, respaotated, Water Havens, Greenport, N. Y., reappointed. Sidney S. Norton, Port Jefferion, N. Y., reappointed.

The Late Election-Ignorant Inspectors, On Monday afternoon last, the Board of Aldermen met to canvass the votes cast at the recent charter election. The returns were opened, when they were referred to a Special,Committee of five,(consisting of Aldermen Del VecchIo, Rowe, Walsh, Schols and Marvin,) to examine and report at a special meeting to be held this (Thursday) evening.

A MUNITICENT BEQUEST.--The late CHARLES McMICKEN, of Cincinnati, has bequeathed to the Corporation of that city the sum of $800,000 for the foundation of two Free Universities, one for boys and other for girls. Orphan children, between the ages of five and fourteen are to be received, supported and educated out of the funds of the Colleges.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Reports calculated to bring the Central Park into disfavor have been propagated in certain quarters of late, probably to serve some private purpose. Currency is given to these reports in a recent article is the Sunday Leader.

The mails from all points South, as late as due, are to hand. Passenger trains on the Virginia Central Railroad are now running through Blue Ridge Tunnel for Stanton. Capt. HUNTER and party, reported lost In Florida, have returned safe.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR: Many of your readers may be under the impression, from the approach of more genfal weather, that the suffering and poverty of the Winter have almost passed away. The very opposite is the fact; and many families are suffering now more extreme privation than they did at any time during the Winter.

Frightful consequences are likely to ensue along the Lower Mississippi, which is now higher in some places than ever known before, by the accession of the combined floods from the upper rivers running from the Mississippi, which are rising from St. Paul's down. The Missouri and Illinois Rivers are both high and rising, and all their tributaries are at flood height.

CARBONIC DRAWING.--A London paper describes a valueble invention--that of carbonic drawing. The material employed is pure charcoal, reduced to fine powder by friction upon paper. This is applied by a silk velvet stump, whose glossy surface is well adapted to hold any quantity of the charcoal duet, and to apply it to the paper in greater or less volume, at the will of the artist.

In the United States Senate yesterday, a memorial from the Mormon Legislature was presented, setting forth their grievances in the peculiar style of the Saints. It was laid on the table. Mr. GWIN presented the resolutions of the California Legislature, indorsing the Lecompton Constitution. Mr. BRODERICK said they did not express the sentiment of the people of that State.

There has just been issued, in London, by order of the House of Commons, a thick "blue book" of papers relating to the measures taken since 1847 to promote the cultivation of cotton in India, among which we find much interesting correspondence and statistical matter in reference to the experiments conducted by Messrs. J. O. PRICE and F. J. TERRY.

A MYSTERIOUS AFFAIR.--What has happened to the Herald's Jenkins? - That estimable and ornamental personage, upon whom the world relies for its knowledge of all sorts of fashionable gossip, seems not only to have deserted the columns of our amiable neighbor, but to have in some way or other fallen under his evil eye. He is scolded and berated as if he were a pickpocket or a sheep-tHief.

The House of Representatives, yesterday, granted the Senate's request for a Committee of Conference upon the rejected Kansas bill. The Committee is not yet appointed, but there is no reason to expect anything but the grossest unfairness and the most unscrupulous deference to partisan necessities on the part of Mr. Speaker ORR.

DELVIN AND THE MAYOR.--The Police force of the Mayor's office, remained all day Tuesday at the Hall of Records to prevent Mr. DEVLIN and his clerks, or any outsider, from entering the office of the Street Commissioner. The Sergeant is armed with the Mayor's written suspension of DELVIN, and stands ready to present it to Mr. DELVIN the moment he makes his appearance.

FEEBLE-MINDED CHILDREN.--We have looked over the fifth annual report of the Pennsylvania Training School for Feeble-Minded Children; and the document had the more interest and attraction from the fact that we have recently had an opportunity to witness what most satisfactory results may be produced.

The interest in the House to-day was intense, after the test question indicated the closeness of the vote. At the Anti-Lecompton Democratic meeting this morning, and among others of the Opposition, the disposition to vote for the Committee of Conference was strong, and overcome only by the necessity of presenting an undivided front.

Townsend, alias McHenry, has been sent to prison again, at Cayuga, (Canada,) to be arraigned for the murder of Mr. Nelles, the jury not having agreed on the former trial. It is not known as yet whether the Government will go on with the prosecution. The Assizes at Cayuga commence on the 20th.

The Broadway Railroad bill was discussed in Committee of the Whole, and made the special order in the afternoon. REPORTS. By Mr. W. A. WHEELER, adverse to incorporating the People's Loan and Relief Company in the City of New-York. Agreed to. By Mr. AMES, favorably, with amendments, relative to the Screw Dock Company.

THE CUBAN QUESTION.--The Charleston Mercury urges Southern statesmen not to permit their attention to be diverted from the Kansas question by the talk about Cuba. It quotes a recent article from our columns for the purpose of showing that the North is after all more interested in the annexation of that island than the South, and regards the question as a device to turn away Southern sentiment from the pending issues concerning Slavery.

The Washington Star of Saturday has a detailed account of an attempt to assassinate the Rev. ELEAZER WILLIAMS, during his sojourn in Washington. Mr. WILLIAMS is the gentleman whose identity with the "lost BOUBBON" was some time since a matter of controversy.

The sixth American edition of The Homoeopathic Domestic Physicain, by CONSTANTINE HEING, M. D., has been published by RASSE, of this City, containing additions from the Eleventh German Edition, and forming a complete manual for family practice of the homoeopathic treatmen: indeed the dircetions are so full and so easily understood that every man may be his own physician--on the homoeopathic system.

MEETINGS UNDER FALSE PRETENCES.--The common impertinence of getting up a public meeting under the pretence that distinguished speakers are expected, was exemplified in Philadelphia, on Monday evening, when it was published and telegraphed that Mr. CRITTENDEN, the Hon. HUMPHREY MARSHALL., Mr. FILLMORE, GOV. SEWARD, and the Hon. EDWARD BATES, would address a meeting to be held in commemoration of HENRY CLAY'S birthday, and for the organization of a new political party.

There seems to be a good deal of mystery about the movements of our Government in regard to Utah. While troops are rapidly hurried forward to reinforce the army now on its way to Salt Lake, and Congress is urged to make liberal appropriations for the prosecution of the war, it is reported that two or three gentlemen have been despatched to Utah on some mysterious errand by the President.

The following letter from Lady FRANKLIN was written in reply to one from SIDNEY KOPMAN, Esq., informing her that a new Masonic Lodge was to be formed in this City, the main object of which was to erect a monument to Dr. KANE:

The "chivalry" are showing us a new phase of their character. Last year, and in fact in all time past, they figured as the fighting men of the federal capital-the "bloods " of the metropolis-who avenged all insults at the sword's point, or the pistol's mouth. They absolutely howled for battle.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I observe in your paper of yesterday a communication under the above head, making a very uncalled-for attack upon the Engineer Corps of the Navy, and as I am a member of that Corps, I beg leave to make a few remarks thereon.

The New-York correspondent of the Boston Transcript writes of one of our artists: "Chevalier Fagnam returns to Europe on the first of next month; a few of his pictures will be disposed of this week by auction; one of them is a three quarter portrait of Gavazzi.

The application of Kansas with a Pro-Slavery Constitution, as presented by nor people, and passed by the United States Senate, has been rejected in the House. The South has suffered defeat on a vital principle, involving her destiny in the Union. What five appointed Governors successively failed to achieve, the treachery of CALHOUN, insligated by Southern spoilsmen, has finally accomplished.

Rev. Daniel Webb, now a resident of New-Bedford, Mass., and who reached his 81st birthday on the 13th inst., is believed to be the oldest Methodist minister in ibis country, perhaps in the world. He was located at Newport for fourteen years prior to 1822, where he preached and taught school.

SUPERIOR COURT.--NOS. 340, 214, 354, 362, 378, 382,210, 1719, 1743. 372, 373, 394, 395, 398, 399, 1731, 1732.

The third of the series of lectures in aid of the " Shirtmakers' and Steamstresses' Union" was delivered last night in Mo art Hall, by Rev. Dr. CHAPIN, on " Woman and her Work." The audience was large, and comprised several members of the Board of Ten Governors and other public functionaries,

From the New-Orleans Bee. Black Republicanism may well shout an exulting paean. Connecticut has followed hard upon New-Hampshire, and gone with a rush against Slavery; while, unkindest cut of all, St. Louis, a Southern city of a Southern State, has, at its recent municipal election, reiterated its semi-abolition sentiments by the election of the Free Democratic ticket.

By the bark Eliza Barrs we have dates from Bermuda to the 6th instant. Considerable injury had been done to the potato crop in exposed parts of the Island, by a recent heavy southerly gale. The quantity of that esculent planted this season does not equal that of last year.

The Board of Aldermen. The Board of Aldermen met last evening, President CLANCY in the Chair. The first matter of interest presented was the following message from the Mayor, in relation to the removal ofChas. Devlin from the office of Street Commissioner:

By an arrival at this port to-day later advices from Antigua have been received, reaching to March 27, and giving full particulars of the insurrection on that island. A letter says: " We have had a most serious disturbance with the negroes, originating amongst some Barbwoa people and our town negroes, who set the Police at defiance, and attacked the Police office at about 8 o'clock on the night of the 25th inst.

Speaker ORR, contrary to our expectations, and in striking contrast to his former action, has appointed a fair and a good Committee of Conference on the Kansas question. Mr. ENGLISH, as the mover of the resolution, was entitled to the Chairmanship of the Committee; Messrs. STEPHENS and HOWARD,

EFFECT OF LECOMPTON ON THE SOUTH AND THE ADMINISTRATION.--The New-Orleans Bee in an article which we copy to-day, takes a melancholy view of the policy of the Administration. "Truly," says the Bee, "the Kansas measure has proved a disastrous blow to the South." Our New-Orleans contemporary is altogether too gloomy.

THE FORRESTER.--There was another caucus of the "Forester" or Wood branch of the Tammany Society last evening at the Mercer-street House. JESSE WEST presided. Speeches were made by Ex. Mayor WOOD, Police Justice BROWNELL, Col. IRELAND, CHAS. A. MAY, WM. B. ATKINS and Col. J. M. THORNER. The Committee on Organization made a lengthy report.

The clipper ship, John Gilpin, whose loss off Cape Horn, in January last we have already detailed, was built at Boston in 1852, was owned by HUNNEWELL BREWER, was 1,088 tons burthen, rated A 2, and valued at $55,000. She was principally insured in Boston, and there were also large insurances in New-Bedford and New-York on her cargo, which was valued at about $350,000.

Brooklyn Horticultural Society. The Spring Exhibition of the Horticultural Society of Brooklyn opened on Wednesday, at the Athenaeum, with an excellent assortment of the choicest of floral beauties. This Society is running a very close race with the one in New-York. Indeed, it would be a difficult task to set forth a more tempting show than that which covers the tables over tile
BENEFITS OF ADVERTISING.--Readers of the TIMES may remember the letter from WM. H. CARR, of "Eagel Grove, Franklin County, Ky.," published in October last, and advertising for a wife.

ANOTHER YOUNG MAN MISSING.--It was reported at the Coroner's Office yesterday that JOHN MOORE, a young man who resided at No. 179 East Twenty-third-street, has been missing since the 11th ult. His friends are fearful that he has been murdered. He had in his possession when he left home a valuable gold watch and chain, a diamond ring, and other jewelry, besides a considerable quantity of money.

THE LABOR QUESTION IN THE SLAVE STATES.-The German population of St. Louis have con tribute very largely to the discussion of the economical relations of Slavery, which is now producing its legitimate fruits in the freelabor victories of Missouri. Wherever that class of our foreign population settle, the same results will follow.

The United States steam-frigate Susquehanna, Capt. JOSHUA R. SANDS, arrived at this port last evening from Nicaragua, via Port Royal, (Jam.,) where 6 officers and 57 men were landed, sick with yellow fever. She has had 155 cases in all, and 17 deaths are known: She is now detained at Quarantine. The following are the names of those who fled, as far as known:

In the United States Senate yesterday, on motion of Mr. FESSENDEN, of Maine, a resolution was adopted asking information concerning contracts for the Utah War. Mr. FESSENDEN offered a resolution, which was laid over, that when the Senate adjourns in June, it adjourn to Nov. 1. The Diplomatic and Consular Appropriation Bill was passed. Mr. CRITTENDEN moved a reconsideration of the vote postponing the Utah Telegraph Bill till December.

If we believed the relations of France with England and with Europe to be absolutely dependent upon the tone of the leading journals on either side of the Channel, we should regard the definite rupture of the Anglo-French alliance as a near impending certainty, and the outbreak of a great European war as a crisis close at hand.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Congress having called for copies of the instructions furnished our Minister to China, the Hon. Mr. REED, and late information having been received of his uniting with the English, French and Russian diplomatists, in their ultimatum addressed to the " Celestial" Court, public attention here is again directed to the important commercial interests involved,

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In answer to the question put in your editorial of the 7th, I will simply state that the Corporation of Washington has a Police of its own, how large I do not know; but, as a property-holder there, I know that I am taxed therefore.

STRIKING DISCLOSURES--A NEWSPAPER QUARREL.--How little the world knows of its truly great men ! How seldom it recognizes the real authors of the great events which engross public attention, and perhaps decide the fate of nations ! Our law reports, yesterday, lifted one corner of the veil and gave the public a peep into the internal economies of one of our leading organs of public opinion.

Mayor TIEMANN, during a recess of the Common Council, suspended CHARLES DEVLIN from the office of Street Commissioner, and asked the assent of the Board of Aldermen to his removal. By the distinct and explicit language of the Charter he has this power, provided the removal is for cause :

SERIOUS ACCIDENT TO REV. DUDLEY A. TYNG. On Tuesday morning, the Rev. DUDLEY A. TYNG, the eloquent and popular divine of this city, left his study at Brookfield, bear Conshohocken, to look at the operation of a corn-shelling machine in the vicinity. Stepping on the inclined plane, he placed his hand on that portion of the instrument known as the "mule," which spreads out the corn.

We have files of the Feuille du Commerce, from Port au Prince, to March 27th. The papers are filed with refutations of a letter which appeared in an ignorant New-York journal, giving a deplorable picture of the distress caused in the Island by the failure and defalcation of REIMBAUD.

The Methodist East Conference held its second session yesterday, at the Mariners' Church, in Hubert-street. Rev. Dr. CLARK, of Middletown, led the religious services, and Bishop BAKER presided. The session was mainly occupied in the examination of the characters of tile Elders of the Conference. As the name of each is called he retires, and the presiding Elder of his District speaks for the person under examination.

JOHN HOGAN.--This distinguished Irish sculptor died at Dubiin on the 27th of March last. At 23 he visited Rome for tile purpose of study, and before he returned to Ireland he had given evidence of the highest genius in his art. His "Drunken Faun," "Dead Christ," and " Eve on her Expulsion from Paradise," are among his greatest works; his statue Of O'CONNELL, in Limerick, is world-renowned.

O'CONNELL to CATHARINE L, daughter of the late Francis Anthony KIPP both of this City. ROBERTS--TITUS.--In this City, on Thursday, April 15, by the Rev. Dr. Bellows, Mr. WALTER B. ROBERTS to MISS E. TITUS, all of this City.

The bill to complete the lateral canals was reported to the Senate precisely as it came from the House, and in that form it was ordered to a third reading by 16 to 12. The Senate consumed the entire morning hour on the bill for the completion of the lateral canals of the State.

The Conference Committee of the two Houses held an informal meeting this evening, Messrs.GREEN, HUNTER and SEWARD on the part of the Senate, and Messrs. ENGLISH, HOWARD and STEPHENS on the part of the House. They merely exchanged views in conversation, but took no vote. They adjourned to 11 o'clock to-morrow morning. No report will be looked for until Monday.

The annual time appointed by the Government a day of fasting and prayer has been observed as usual, by a total suspension of business churches, in most of which religious exercise place, were crowded, and the afternoon and performances at the theatres liberally pat The Common also attracted thousands to various athletic exercises by the young me city.

Mr. FESSENDEN, of Maine, offered a resolution requesting the Secretary of War to give information respecting all contracts for supplies to the army in Utah, which have been made without public notice, which was agreed to. Mr. FOOT offered a resolution that, when the Senate adjourns on the first Monday in June, (which, it seems, it has already agreed to do,) it be to meet on the 1st of November. The resolve was laid over.

I.--DEATH OF THOMAS H. BENTON-Sketch of his Life and Public Services. II.-FASHION AT WASHINGTON-The Fancy Ball at Mrs. Senator GWIN'S, in Washington-Who were there, what they wore, and how they enjoyed themselves, with Arabella's Opinions. By our own correspondent.

SEAMAN.--In this City, on Thursday evening, April 15, GEORGE HENRY, only son of Wm. A and Julia A. Seaman, aged 5 years, 5 months and 15 days. The friends are invited to attend the funeral services at No. 90 Perry st., at 7 1/2 o'clock, this (Friday) evening. The remains to be removed to Newcastle on Saturday morning.

CHILD DROWNED IN A TUB OF WATER.-A little child, two years old, named MARY JANE GAHAGAN, whose parents reside at No. 36 Newark-avenue, Jersey City, was drowned, on Thursday afternoon, by falling into a tub of water which was sitting in the room. The mother was present, but so intoxicated that she was not conscious of the occurrence.

An absurd charge has been publicly made in England, against Mr. Edward Miall, Editor of the (London) Nonconformist. A foreigner, styling himself the Baron De Camin, has been delivering lectures in Birmingham on the " Errors of Romanism," and, by way of illustrating the growth of Jesuit principles in England, asserted that Mr. Miall was an enrolled Jesuit, and" had signed the bond with his own blood."

REGENT OF THE UNIVERSITY.--The Journal of Commerce, speaking of the recent election of a Regent, says: "It is a position for which Mr. BEYANT is admirably qualified; but his absence in Europe will prevent his giving any attention to the duties of the office for some lime to come."

JENKINS--McCREADY.--In this City, on Thursday, April 15, at St. Bartholomew's Church, by the Rev. Dr. Cook, THOMAS HARPER JENKINS to ANNIE, daughter of Frederick McCready. SMITH--BATEMAN.--In this City, on Thursday, April 15, by the Rev. A. C. Foss, Pastor of the 30th st. M. E. Church, HARMAN T. SMITH, of Paterson, N. J. to Miss MARY A. BATEMAN, of this City.

THE SEMI-ANNUAL EXHIBITION OF WARD SCHOOL No. 35 took place Thursday, commencing at 9 A. M. J. B. VARNUM, Jr., presided, and speeches were made by Messrs. HASKETT, BENEDICT, the Hon WM. TAYLOR, Dr. BEADLE, and others. The exercises in composition, declamation and singing, and the examination of classes, were highly satisfactory to the large audience which was assembled.

KATE CONRAD, a servant girl, sued Mrs. BLEIDOM to recover $5,000 damages for calling her a thief. The case was tried in the City Court, yesterday. The defendant was acquitted. The servant girl, MARY ANN WAUGH, who was arrested for Igrand larceny, as mentioned in the TIMES yesterday, has been fully committed for trial The property stolen from her employer and already recovered, is valued at $1,500.

At 10 o'clock this morning the remains of Mr. BENTON were taken from the hall of the Mercantile Library to the second Presbyterian Church, where the funeral ceremonies were performed by the Rev Mr. COWAN, assisted by the Rev. Dr. ANDERSON and the Rev. Mr. BROOKS. When the services were concluded the body was placed in the hearse and was followed to the Belletontaine Cemetery by the most imposing procession ever formed in St. Louis.

By and with the advice and consent of the Senate. Samuel Ward, of New-York, Consul of the United States at Bristol. Albert G. Catlin, of Massachusetts, Consuel of the United States at Prince Edward's Island. Caleb Croswell, of Wisconsin, Consul of the United States at St. Petersburg.

The House was mainly engaged on private bills today. Mr. CLINGMAN, of North Carolina, in responding to, a former remark of Mr. LEITER, explained that he left the Whig Party because it became Abolitionized and since then he had found Captain RYNDERS to be an honorable man who had been badly slandered.

The following bills were ordered to a third read ing: To amend the Code of Procedure. To extend the power of the State Engineer. To incorporate the company to colonize certain portions of Mexico, with the consent of the Mexican Government. To incorporate the People's Loan and Relief Company, New-York.

THE FRIGATE BENT BELOW--THE SICK TO THE MARINE HOSPITAL--A POLICE FORCE DETAILED TO QUARANTINE. Yesterday, at an early hour, Dr. THOMPSON, the health officer of the port, sent a communication to the Mayor staling the situation of the Susquehanna and her crew, and stating that, with the concurrence of the Mayor and Health Commissioners, he should send her to the Lower Bay. The following is a copy of the letter:

The plans for the Central Park are now undergoing examination at the hands of the Commissioners, and it is perfectly fair to suggest one or two points which deserve more notice than they are likely to receive, in arriving at any decision on the merits of the competing schemes.

STREET COMMISSIONER--THE MOTION FOR A WRIT DENIED.--In the Supreme Court, Special Term, Mr. Justice DAVIES denied the motion of Mr. DEVLIN'8 counsel for a writ directed to the Sheriff to put DEVLIN in possession of all matters and things appertaining to the office of Street Commissioner.

By the arrival of the Cunard steamship Africa at this port, yesterday, we receive London and Liverpool advices to the 3d inst.--four days later. Parliament having adjourned, the political intelligence from Great Britain is without any importance.

The steamship Africa, Capt. SHANNON, from Liverpool on Saturday the 3d inst., at about 11 A. M., arrived at this port at 10 1/2 A. M. yesterday. The screw steamship Kangaroo arrived out at Liverpool at midnight on the 1st of April. Political and commercial affairs were quiet during the observance of the Easter holidays.

Mr. HASCALL, the editor of the Kalamazoo (Mich.) Gazette, who is also Register of the Kalamazoo Land Office, ($500 a year,) recently came out for Lecompton. The following letter from SAMUEL YORK AT LEE, an office broker at Washington, explains the matter:

STILL ANOTHER CHANGE FOR PHILADELPHIA.--If our ambitious neighbors on the Delaware have not yet completed their arrangements for the purchase of the Collins steamships, they will be pleased to learn that another very eligible opportunity is offered to them to purchase a first-class vessel to put on the Line between that port and Liverpool,

THE FIRST WARNING.--The arrival of the United States steam-frigate Susquchanna in our harbor, with the yellow fever on board, at this early season of the year, should have the effect of opening the eyes of our public authorities to the absolute necessity of taking efficient steps to prevent the introduction of this much-dreaded disease among us the coming Summer.

The Court of Appeals has determined to have a ??eargument of the appeal on the constitutionality of the Port Wardens' law. On the case to determine whether the old police Force wexe properly dismissed, the Court stands four to four. It will be reargued at the next term. Both Houses are in session, with a prospect that they will work all night.

IN BROADWAY-NARROW ESCAPE.-A fire was discovered at a few minutes after 4 o'clock yesterday morning by the Fifteenth Ward Police in the oyster saloon of JAMES WILLIAMS, in the basement of No. 869 Broadway. JAMES A. WILLIAMS, who slept in the place, was found sound asleep and his bed on fire. He was considerably under the influence of liquor, and it was a difficult matter to awaken him.

CONGRESSIONAL ADJOURNMENT--THE DAY FIXED.--Both Houses of Congress have voted to close the present session on Monday, the 7th of June, the Senate having on Thursday concurred in a joint resolution to that effect previously adopted by the House of Representatives.

THIRD DAY.--The Conference reassembled yesterday, Bishop BAKER presiding. The Rev. Mr. MITCHELL opened tile exercises with prayer. The Conference proceeded to the examination and election of deacons. Some discussion ensued in reference to an attempt to elect a local preacher to deacon's orders without requiring the usual probationary term to be served.

THE MEXICAN PROTECTORATE QUESTION.Some time in February, General HOUSTON introduced a resolution in the Senate proposing that the United States should assume a Protectorate over Mexico and the Central American States. He gave notice on Thursday that he would call up this resolution on Monday next, when it is understood that Senator HOUSTON will so modify it as to limit its application to Mexico.

C. A. WOODWORTH, a member of the Minneola or Leavenworth Constitutional Convention, arrived here to-day, bringing dispatches from the Convention, and a copy of the Constitution, which he delivered to Mr. PARROT. He says that the organization of the Militia by the Free-State men is so complete that the exact number of voters and the political sentiments of each voter in the Territory are ascertained, and that the Pro-Slavery men are only two thousand.

Some disappointment has been manifested, more on the part of the Democrats, however, than the Opposition, that Mr. GIDDINGS was not placed on the Conference Committee, instead of Mr. HOWARD, of Michigan. It was urged on the Speaker by Democrats, to appoint GIDDINGS, for what reason you must indulge in a Yankee habit to find out, and some of them say that Mr. ORR committed a mistake in not selecting him.

MASON AND THOMAS' MATINEE.--The last entertainment of the season takes place to-day at the Spingler Institute, beginning at 1 o'clock. There are four pieces on the programme; a Quartette by BEETHOVEN; Solo, (Handel and Mendelssohn,) by Mr. Wm. MASON; Solo for violin by Mr. THOMAS, and Quintetie by Mr. SCHUMANN.

A FEDERAL UNION FOR CANADA.--Mr. GALT, a prominent member of the Canadian Legislative Assembly, now in session at Toronto, has prepared and published a series of resolutions, three in number, which he is about to offer in that body, in favor of a Federal Union for the two Canadas, in lieu of the Legislative Union now existing; and contemplating also a general confederation of all the British North American Provinccs.

Last Sunday a portion of the Southern delega tion in Congress was deeply agitated by a report that the Government had received a dispatch confirming the fugitive rumor that the Spanish Ministry had agreed upon the project of a decree for the abolition of Slavery in Cuba, which was to be laid before the Cortes.

THE MAYOR SENDS THE CHARGES BEFORE THE GRAND JURY--MEETING OF THE SPECIAL COMMITTEE. The excitement in relation to the proposed removal of CHARLES DEVLIN from the office of Street Commissioner, was very great, in and about the City Hall, on Saturday.

To-day has been the first day for quite two months which has been devoted to the business set down for Fridays, namely the consideration of the private calendar, and the business of private claimants has consequently been very sadly neglected, intentionally, there is too much reason to suppose, so far as some members are concerned.

The meeting of the Conference Committee, on Saturday, resulted only in obtaining from the Senate side the promise of offering a plan of compromise Mr. ENGLISH. on the part of the House managers, gave notice that they should await propositions from the Senate branch;

In the U.S. States on Saturday, the Deficiency bill was ma?? special order for to-day at 12 1/2 o'clock. M. B. N AMIN of Louisiana made a motion to postpone the further consideration of the Pacific Rail road bill until December, which motion, after an earnest debate, was carried, 25 to 22. In the House, the greater part of the session was consumed in the consideration of private bills.

FOURTH DAY--SATURDAY. The Conference was opened on Saturday with the usual exercises. After the transaction of some routine business, the discussion on Slavery was resumed, the speakers being the Rev. Messrs. HATFIELD, HEMAN, BANUS, and Dr. CROOKS. The Rev. Mr. LONG, of Philadelphia, warmly supported the following resolution:

SMITH--In this City, on Friday, April 16 HERREET ROLT, only child of Charles H and Mary F. Smith, aged ?? and 23 days. The friends of the family are invited to attend his funeral this day. (Monday, at 2 o'clock from the Hamilton House corner of ground way and 2 it-st. "Suffer little children to come us to me."

FIRE IN THE HOUSE OF INDUSTRY.--At 7 1/2 o'clock P. M., Friday a fire broke out in the House of Industry, No. 100 West Sixteenth-street. The damage to the stock was about $300 and to the building $100, which is covered by insurance in the New-York Fire Insurance Company and in the Eagle Insurance Company.

On Saturday the ground for the new reservoir at Eighty-sixth-street and Fifth avenue was formally broken. The event was appropriately celebrated. Various members of the Common Council, of the Central Park Commission, of the Croton Aqueduct Board, and several other public functionaries, were in attendance. About 1 o'clock the large assemblage left the office of Capt. GREEN,

From the Richmond Smith. Throughout life Mr. EDWARD EVERETT has been a consistent Abolitionist When he was appointed Minister to the Court of St, James, the Committee on Foreign Affairs in the Senate, of which the wise and conservative WILLIAM R. KING was Chairman, reported against his confirmation on the ground of his extreme antagonism to the institutions of the South.

We publish, this morning, copious details of Mexican news, brought to New-Orleans by the steamship Tennessee. The intelligence is decidedly the most important that has been received from the neighboring Republic since the overthrow of General COMONFORT.

The Republican learns, from a source entitled to credit, that an express messenger passed through this city about two weeks ago with instructions from the war Department to General JOHNSTON, ordering him not to commence offensive operations against the Mormons before the arrival of the Peace Commissioners.

Telegraphic dispatches, for three days past, have posted our readers on the progress of the Littles murder trial at Rochester. The time from Wednesday morning until Friday, was occupied with the attempt to impannel a jury. An average of eight out of every ten talesmen declared that "they had read the newspaper accounts of the murder, and had formed opinions"--and so were set aside.

Wife Murder in Brooklyn. Coroner SNELL will to-day hold an inquest on the body of ROSE KEILY, who died Saturday at the City Hospital, from injuries indicted with a knife by her husband, JOHN KELLY. The husband, it is said, has been a worthless, dissolute fellow for some time, and frequently quarrelled with the deceased, who, it is represented, was an industrious woman and by her exertions supported herself and three children.

The Board of Aldermen are on the eve of solving a very important problem. It has often been said, and it is to-day believed by very many persons, that self-government in a large city is an impossibility:--that the scoundrels outnumber the honest men in every such community, and that where universal suffrage prevails, they will obtain authority and propetuate their rule by using the very power which possession of the Government confers upon them.

A large number of those who favor the present management of Tammany Society, met at she Westchester House on Saturday evening, for the purpose of nominating a ticket of Sachems to be vored for by the members of the Society, at the election that is to take place to-day, and of making such arrangements as might be deemed most serviceable in securing its success.

Doctor WALKER. Deputy Health Officer of the Port, appeared on Saturday before Justice WELSH, at the Lower Police Court, and made an affidavit, charging Captain SANDS. Commander of the United States steam frigate Susquehanna, with violating the quarantine laws.

In steamship Roanoke, from Portsmouth, Geaner, Mr. Banon and lady, John H. Greaner, Thos. Powell, J. Lorsch, Mrs. R Austin, Wm. Knock, E. W. Manning. J. Little, J. Merritt Adolph Sugar, Chas H. Bagley, Miss R. Billyard, E, Waterhouse and lady, J. Semple, Col. R. E. De Russy--and 24 in the steerage.

By the steamship Tennessee, at New-Orleans, we have received advices from the city of Mexico to the 1st, and from Vera Cruz to the 7th, inst. At the date of previous advices, the Zuloaga forces, under OSOLLO, and those of the coalition, then commanded by Generals PARERDI and DUBLADO, were concentrated at and near Celaya.

The following is the weekly report of deaths in the city and country of New-york, from the 10th day pf April to the 17th day of April, 1858, Men. 107 Women, 77; Boys, 119; Girls, 133; Total, 416. Adults, 154; Children 282; Males, 256; Female, 210; Colored persons, 10.

THE RICHMOND SOUTH ON MR. EVERETT.--That section of our happy land lying beyond Mason and Dixon's line, where the days are sunny and the men sooty, is blest with numerous newspaper organs specially devoted to its interests and institutions. Preeminent among these, in zeal as in name, stands the Richmond South.

The Senate Considered the NEW-YORK Tax bill. Mr. ELY moved to strike out the mandatory clause, compelling the payment of the Coroner's law expenses, and salaries of his subordinates. Mr. MATHER moved to amend by adding that said sum be deducted from the amount payable by the City of the State General Fund.

Mr. FOOT withdrew his resolution that the Senate reassemble on the first Monday in November, and introduced the same proposal in the shape of a bill, which was read twice and laid over for future consideration.

SUICIDE, OR MURDER?--The dead body of a man about 23 years of age was found on the hill adjoining the Pavilion Hill, States Island, on Saturday morning, shot near the heart. He is supposed to be a German. He was dressed in a brown ribbed frock-coat, black ribbed pants, brown vest-gray woolen under-shirt, and new black cloth cap; has a light brown moustache and auburn hair.

In the case of Tinkham vs. Tapscott, the judgment of the Supreme Court is reversed, and judge ment given for the defendant, with costs. This fully sustains the law. The Court stood five in favor of this decision, and two dissenting--Judges PRATT and ROOSEVELT. Judge COMSTOCK did not hear the argument. and has no opinion.

The subject of a Pacific Railroad has again been thrown overboard in Congress. The Senate, by a vote of 25 to 20. voted to postpone it until December next, upon the plea that they could not agree upon a route. The leading friends of the Administration were the active advocates of the postponement. So this most important question goes over to another year.

In the United States Senate yesterday, memorials were presented form citizens of New-Orleans and Philadelpbia. and from the Chamber of Commerce of the former city. asking aid for the Collins steamers. The deficiency bill was considered, but nothing was done with it. A bill for the relief of the chaimans in the case of the privateer brig General Armstrong was reported form the commistee on Foreign Relations.

The Late Wife-Murder in Navy-street-Coroner's Investigation. Coroner SNELL, yesterday afternoon, commenced an investigation into the circumstances attending the death of ROSANNA KELLY, who was stabbed by her husband, JOHN KELLY, on Friday night last, at a house in Navy near Prospect-street. The following persons were sworn as Jurors:

FOR CALIFORNIA.--The steamship Philadelphia, Captain HARRISON, left at 2 o'clock on Saturday with a large number of California passengers, via Havana. The steamship Star of the West, Capt. GRAY, will leave at 2 o'clock this afternoon, with the remainder of the passengers and the mails. Both companies meet at Panama, and proceed thence by the steamer John L. Stephens.

RASINES.--In this City, on Sunday. April 18, J. ANTONIO RASINES, native of Spain, aged 43 years. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, without further notice on Wednesday morning, at 10 o'clock. from his late residence No. 51 West 11th-st . The remaining will be taken to Westchester for interment. MORRIS.--In this City, on Sunday Evening. April 18.

THE NATIONAL QUARENTINE CONVENTION.-The Board of Health yesterday appointed a Committee to attend the National Quaractine Convention, in Baltimore, on the 29th inst, and it is said the Chamber of Commerce will also send delegates to attend the Convention, so that the interests of this City will be properly represented on the occasion.

MR. OLMSTED AND THE CENTRAL PARK.--We see with pleasure, in a recent number of the Leipsic Grensbloten, that Mr. OLMSTED'S "Texas Journey," originally published in these columns under the title of "Letters from the Southwestern Frontier," has been translated into German. This excellent work is reviewed with great discrimination by the German journals,

Odell, of New-York, appraiser of merchandise, under the act approved march 2, 1851 vice S. D. Dillaye, removed; Charles A. Davis, of Virginia, to be a Chaplain in the Navy, vice Wm. McKenney, deceased ; Algernon S. Garrett. of Virginia, to be Assistant Surgeon:

Our Washington Correspondent, under date of 15th inst., telegraphed as follows: "Mr. J. J. CISCO, now Assistant - Treasurer at New - York , is said to be seeking an appointment as Collector in place of Mr. SOHELL, who is in danger of dismissal on account of his connection with the Willett's Point affair. Efforts are made to involve Postmaster FOWLER in Mr. SCHELL'S fate."

BAD FOR BOSTON.--We had supposed that New-York was one of the most expensive cities in the world to live in, not because the necessaries of life cost more, for the raw materials of a comfortable existence are much cheaper here than in many other cities, but in consequence of the habitual extravagance which is indulged in by all classes,

FIRST PARADE OF THE SCOTT LIFE GUARD.-This newly-organized corps, composed of citizens of this State who served in the War with Mexico, celebrated the eleventh anniversary) of the battle of Cerro Gordo yesterday, by a parade, review, collation, and visit to the theatre. They assembled in the morning at the Mercer House, and thence proceeded to the United States Army Headquarters,

According to promise, Mr. GREEN submitted several propositions of compromise to the Conference Committee this morning. Among them it was proposed to strike out of the Senate bill the Pugh Proviso, and insert in the preamble a declaration, in the language of the Bill of Rights, that the people have the power to change their form of Government.

Our worldly neighbors of the Tribune are hardly so wise in their generation as that child of light, the late Lord THURLOW. When an ignorant nephew of that distinguished man (whose head was declared to be a living lie, since no man could possibly he so wise as he looked,) was appointed to an Indian Judgeship, the surly Chancellor advised him to give his decisions without hesitation,

WALLACK'S THEATRE.--Miss MARY GANNON, one of the most natural and charming soubrettes in this--or any other--country, took her first benefit last night, and was honored by the attendance of a military company and a very fair representation of the civil population. A new play was produced for the occasion--the "Love Knot," by Mr. J. STIELING COYNE.

The United States Mail steamer Black Warrior, J. W. SMITH, commander, from New-Orleans on the 11th and Havana on the 14th inst., arrived at this port yesterday morning. To the Editor of the New-York Times: Will you please to call attention to the condition of the streets in the Eighteenth Ward ? They were cleaned on the 12th of last November, and again some time in December, since which neither shovel nor broom has been near them from the street cleaners, according to the best of my knowledge and belief. Mr. EDwArD COOPER is Street Commissioner. He was nominated last night by the Mayor, and confirmed unanimously by the Board of Aldermen, after that body had concurred, 10 to 5, in the removal of CHRLES DEVLIN for cause. It is needless to say that we rejoice very heartily in this result.

The annual election of the Sacherns and other officers of the Tammany Society was held list eveniing according to announcement, at Tammany Hall. The presence of two opposing factions in the field with their respective candidates, both claiming to be "regular," and the uncertainty which was felt as to the result, imparted unusual interest to the election,

AUCTION OF UNCLAIMED PROPERTY.--The first auction sale of unclaimed property, under the management of C. J. WARREN, Property Clerk of the Metropolitan Police, was held on Saturday, A. J. BLBECKER, SON Co., auctioneers. No goods were sold but such as were in custody and unclaimed before November. 1857, yet about 250 lots were sold for the round sum of $525.

RAILROAD FROM HOBOKEN TO PIERMONT--This road, known as the "Northern Railroad of New-Jersey," which has been in contemplation since 1852, is at last in a fair way to be constructed. The surveys for the route have been completed, and the contract for building the load has been given to Messrs. JAMES M. TOWER and BHADFORD SEYMOUR, of Oneida Conory, N. Y. Ground was broken a few days since,

The Common Council this evening canvassed the late election returns, and without a dissenting vote awarded the Mayoralty certificate to the Hon. ELI PERRY, and also certificates to all the candidates on the Union ticket. No attempt was made to throw out tile vote of the Western District of the Ninth Ward, where the boxes were destroyed.

Cavazos et al.--On motion of the counsel for the appellees the appeal of the District Court for the Southern District of Texas. was dismissed with costs.

HEALTH OF CHARLES SUMNER.--Our Washington correspondent writes as follows in a letter just received, in regard to the health of Mr. SUMNER: " Don't be alarmed by the reports in regard to Mr. SUMNER now afloat in the papers. He has been slightly indisposed, but is about as well now as when he reached here two weeks since. On last Wednesday, while in the Congressional Library,

GARROTING AND ROBBERY.--As Wm. G. Newman of No. 756 Greenwich-street, was passing the corner of Hudson and Broome streets, at a late hour Sunday night, he was attacked by five Eighth Ward "short boys." Three of the gang held him by the neck, while the other two robbed him of his porte-monnaie, containing $ 6 40, and of his breast pin and watch chain, after which they fled. Mr. NEWMAN started after them.

SEIZURE OF SMUGGLE D JEWELRY.--A seizure of jewelry , suppressed by the Custom-House officers to have been smuggled, was made on Friday at the Cunard Wharf, under somewhat singular circumstances. It appears that on Friday night Inspector ABRAHAM WEEKS observed a gentleman go on board the Royal Mail steamship America, with a carpet-bag, which he supposed was comparatively empty.

The fifth day of the Conference (yesterday) was opened with prayer by the Rev. J. J. MATTHIUS, at 9 1/2 o'clock A. M. Resolutions were adopted recommending the " Superannuated Preachers' Fund" to the sympathy of the people; and providing for the appointment of a committee to consider at once the expediency of organizing and supporting a mission to include the whole unoccupied field within New York City.

Those timid beings who permitted a shower of rain to keep them from the Musard Concerts last night certainly missed a treat. Rarely have we heard a programme so excellently rendered; the orchestra and artists appeared to be animated by one (un) common desire to impart the greatest amount of delight to their scanty audience-and in particular that monarch of the violin, VIEUXTEMPS,

The Commissioners of the Central Park have not yet made their decisions on the plans offered for the improvement of the Park, and will not do so under a week from the present time. In the meantime the plans have been strictly guarded from the examination of all persons except the Commissioners; a course which is very obviously just and proper.
It is Said that an express passed through this city on Sunday night with Government dispatches from Gen. JOHNSTON, commanding the Utah army. No news transpired here.
