In the Committee of Conference to-day, Mr. ENGLISH presented his bill to Mr. SEWVRD, it having been previously adopted by Messrs. ATWATER, GREEN and STEPHENS. The bill refers the ordinance concerning the public lands, embracing only the same grants made to all the States entering into the Union as a master of course, to the people of Kansas.

The Legislature has adjourned, after a turbulent, discreditable, and fruitless session. It has done many things which it ought not to have done, and has left undone nearly everything which it ought to have done. It has ordered a a vote upon forming a new Constitution, without the slightest public necessity or public necessity or public demand,

The tide of gaiety, momentarily checked by the decrease of Colonel BENTON. is again rushing merrily onward, and the beau mon ?c is fully occupied in the enjoyment of present and anticipation of future gaities. The prominent parties of the week now drawing to a close have been hymeneal.

In steamship Saxonia, from Hamburg--M. Uhrig, Mrs. S. Uhrig, Mrs. Augusta Vogl. Louis Negbaner, Mrs. Amelia, Negbaner, C. Scbwindier, Chas Herrmann, L. Vogel, B. Veserlein, Lubbers Meyer. G. Sauter. Miss Maria Fruse, Madnicde Laubse, H. ??mann, M. Seylor. M. Garlichs, Mrs. Garlichs, T. Neghauer, Henry Raff, Mrs. Hill, Mrs. Elizabeth Hill, Mr. Parker Mrs. Esther Parker, Thos. C. Wright, Mrs. Elizabeth Wright. T. L. Benseldt.

A select company of cosmopolitan sympathizers, who would be utter savages were they not absolute simpletons also, and who now honor this City with their presence, have organized a demonstration, (we think that is the phrase,) for to-morrow evening, in honor of the heroic martyrdom of ORSINI and PIERRI, and in glorification of the sacred office of assasSination. lost of these persons appear,

A NOVEL SALUTE.--A salute of a hundred guns was fired in the Seventh Ward last night by the mechanics and workingmen in that part of the City to express their jollity at the passage of the law by our Legislature " legalizing the business of repairing vessels." It is not often that powder is burned in so good a cause,

It is reported from Washington that a majority of the Kansas Conference Committee have agreed to a compromise proposed by Mr. ENGLISH, and assented to by Messrs. GREEN, HUNTER and STEPHENS. It submits the Lecompton Constitution to the popular vote. If that is approved, Kansas comes in immediately;

Mr. HOUSTON, of Texas, spoke in favor of our Instituting a protectorate over Mexico. After pointing out the difference between the Northern and boundary States of the Union, he went on to define his plan, and to show the benefits which would accrue both to the Union and Mexico.

ARRIVAL OF THE SAXONIA.--The Steamship Saxonia, from Hamburg and Southampton on the 6th instant, arrived at this port yesterday morning. Her advices are anticipated by the simultaneous arrival of the Arago, which brought one day's later news. The excursion up the Mediterranean seems to have been abandoned, not more than half a dozen berths having been taken up to the 14th.

H. D. STONE, who was arrested in springfield on Saturday, for forgeries in this city, was held to bailto-day in the sum of $2,000. He was also arrested for debts amounting le $70,000, and in default of bail to the amount of $14,000, was committed to jail. The case is one of much interest.

The Rochester Union publishes full reports of the trial of IRA STOUT, at Rochester, from which we copy. On Friday afternoon Coroner QUIN was cross-examined. HENRY B. HAPGOOD was sworn, and testified to the recognition and examination of the body of Mr. LITTLES, confirming the evidence of the Coroner.

Yesterday was the sixth day of the Conference and to-day will probably be the last. The Conference met at 9 1/2 o'clock, Bishop BAKER, of New Hampshire, in the Chair. The exercises were opened with prayer. The Rev. Mr. CHOCKS read the report of a Special Committee indorsing the principles of the Colonization Society. It was adopted.
Major-General A. H. FARNHAM died at his residence here yesterday afternoon.

We obtain some further European intelligence from our files by the Arago, whose arrival at this port was announced in yesterday's issue. Paris journals are discussing just now, with some warmth, the occupation by Great Britain of the Island of Perime The Times makes rather a contemptuous reply to these observations, and declares that England will not submit to any European interference in

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Is our City always to be disgraced by some public exhibition ? For the sake of decency, do call the attention of our City authorities to the exhibition of coffins, skulls and decayed bodies lying exposed on the corner of Fiftieth-street and Fourth avenue. I learn this is the spot formerly called "Potter's Field."

A correspondent of the Philadelphia Bulletin says: "Colonel Benton (contrary to the general opinion of his means) has died poor. Some time since his house, on C street, was burned down, and he went to the expense of having it rebuilt, but there is a mortgage of $10,000 on it, which will almost absorb the value of the property.

Kansas is at a dead lock in Congress, and no one can predict the result. Should both houses remain firm, and Kansas not be admitted, I shall visit Fitchburg, I think, next week ; but, should either House yield, I shall return immediately to Kansas, without going to Massachusetts.

A meeting of the Broadway Association was held at HAUGAWOUT Co.-store, corner of Broadway and Brocme streets, Monday evening at which a letter was read from Mr. SMITH, the contract or for cleaning Broadway, in which he proposed to clean Broadway and one block east and west of each street which crosses it, every day, for $350 per week.

The Navy-street Murder-Verdict of the Coroner's Jury. The Jury summoned by Coroner SNELL to investigate the circumstances attending the death of ROSANNA KELLY, reassembled last evening, at 7 o'clock, when the following testimony was taken: Catharine Hackett, sworn--Saw Kelly stab deceased; saw no man in front of the house. Mary Kelly, sworn--Is a daughter of deceased; fifteen years old; father and mother always kept house together until Sept. 14, last;
The majority for the Five Million Loan bill in Minnesota will probably exceed 20,000.

BRITISH POSTAL ARRANGEMENTS FOR THE TRANSMISSION OF BOOKS AND NEWSPAPERS-In the annual report of the British Postmaster-General, which was printed last month, he says: "The great intercourse, both commercial and social between this country and the United States Renders the present high rate of postage,

Although the appointment of Mr. EDWARD COOPER as Street Commissioner is, in every respect, unexceptionable, and gives satisfaction to all honest and order-loving citizens, it was not the one originally intended by Mayor TIEMANN. The Mayor had resolved, from the moment he became aware of Mr. DEVLIN'S malfeasance, to remove him from office,
Judge STEVENS, one of the oldest residents of our city, and brother to the Hon. THADDEUS STEVENS, of Pennsylvania, died suddenly last evening.

COMING TO REASON.--We are happy to hear that poor BENNETT has taken our advice and settled his little bill with his editorial assistant -JOBSON. The suit has, therefore, been discontinued,-and everything has been amicably arranged. JOBSON'S sparkling productions will again garnish the congenial columns of the Herald, and he will get his pay, we hope,

The increasing volume of the Mississippi River, the occasional breaking of the levees, and tile consequent overflow of the waters below Vicksburg, are occupying much attention in New-Orleans, The Vicksburg Whig of Saturday says that the river was rising at the rate of an inch in twenty-four hours, and was then within twenty-two inches of the high water mark of 1850.
The U.S. mail steamship Columbia, Capt. BERRY, from New-York, arrived here at 3 o'clock this afternoon.

We obtain some further intelligence from our miles by the Arogo. whose arrival with four days' later European news, was announced in yesterday's issue The chief political topic of Interest is the occupation of the Island of Perim by Great Britain-a proceeding which appeals to be unfavorably regarded by the Paris press.
The R. M. steamship America, Capt. MOODIE, will sail for Liverpool via Halifax at about 1 P. M. to-morrow. Her mails close at the Post-Office at 10 o'clock A. M.

At Milwaukee, last Thursday, a tidal wave ruhedinto the river, upsetting a steam ferry-boat, and doing other damage. An equally rapid fall of tile water succeeded the sudden rise. The phenomena was more marked on the beach of the lake. At one pier, the water, before the fall, was within three feet of the floor of a warehouse, when it retired rapidly, leaving dry ground under the building.

I beard of a inelancholy event this morning, which shows the hard times affect individuals. A man living in Chelsea. held in trust for a young woman $10.000, which. some time ago, he loaned to a great firm in Boston, a firm whose note was considered much better than hard gold. Well, the firm failed last October, and the impression is that it was rotten years before it failed.

SEIZURE OF SMUGGLED JEWELRY.--A seizure of jewelry, supposed by the Custom-House officers to have been smuggled, was made on Friday at the Cunard Wharf, under somewhat singular circumstances. It appears that on Friday night Inspector ABRAHAM WEEKS observed a gentleman go on board the Royal Mail steamship America, with a carpet bag, which he supposed was comparatively empty.

The last news from Mexico is not regarded here as decisive of the success of the Zuloaga Government. Ills ablest General has beaten JUAREZ, the Constitutional successor of COMONFORT; but OSOLLO himself will probably next be heard from as "pronouncing" for the President on a new platform, made of planks taken from the deceased Constitution, and the yet undeveloped plans of the Monarchists and Churchmen.

This sad event took place yesterday afternoon, at the residence of the lamented dead, near Conshohohocken. The painful result is calculated to cast a gloom over the entire community. The deceased was beloved by his congregation, and was respected by all who knew him, for his talents, his zeal, his energy, and his untiring devotion to the Christian faith.

THOMAS.--In this City, on Tuesday morning, April 20, after a brief illness, Mrs. CATHARINE THOMAS. widow of the late John C. Thomas, aged 5 years and 9 months. The friends of the family and of her son in law James S. Edwards, are invited to attend her funeral this (Wednesday) afternoon, at 4 o'clock, from her late residence, No 314 Bowery.

It might be interred from the perfect cessation of the cry concerning the "corruption of the lobby," and the silence of the Washington correspondents on the subject, that the corruption Committees have entirely scared away the lobbyites, corrected the legislation of Congress, and converted Washington into a sort of moral New-England village.

CORONERS AND SUPERINTENDENTS OF THE POOR.--An act was recently passed by the Legilsature dividing Kings County into four Election Districts, in each of which a Coroner and a Superintendent of the Poor is to be elected, each of the former to act only in the District in which he is chosen. It is a question whether the new enantment applies to the officers now in power, or only to those to be here after elected.

In the Court of General Sessions, Yesterday, the libel case of Hon. RICHARD BUSTEED, Counsel to the Corporation, against Hon. THOMAS N. CARR, formerly Consult to Alglers, came before the Court. It will be remembered that Mr. CARR charged Mr. BUSTEED with malfeasance in office, and that the latter procured Mr. CARE to be indicted by the Grand Jury.

VIOLATION OF THE NEUTRALITY LAWS.--IMPORTANT ARREST.--United States Deputy Marshal LEVI H. WILLIAMS yesterday morning arrested two Germans, named respectively, JOHN ZIMMERMAN and JOSEPH THURINGER, charged with enlisting, or in retaining with the intention to enlist, within the limits of the United States, soldiers for the service of Her Majesty.

GOVERNMENT SUBSIDIES TO PHILADELPHIA.-The Philadelphians are determined to make the most of their opportunities while they are blessed with a "Pennsylvania President," as one of their papers calls Mr. BUCHANAN.

United States Steam Frigate Fulton, Lieutenant ALNT, Commanding, arrived at Key West, 30th of March, from Aspinwall via Havana; after coaling she sailed for Tampico on the 3d, to look after the interests of American shipping, which have been seriously interfered with in that quarter.

THE MYSTERIOUS BARREL.--The Chicago Times, speaking of the mysterious barrel which was found at the railroad depot, in this City, containing the managed remains of a female baby, says: "The barrel in question was brought to the Michigan Central freight house, in this City, on the 16th of March, by a person who took a receipt for it in the name of John Miller.'

SELLING WHISKY WITHOUT A LICENSE AT QUARANTINE.--The police detailed for the Quarantine Station arrested, on Monday, JEREMIAH McLYMAN, alias Brogues, for selling whisky to the seamen of the United States frigate Susquehanna, quartered in the Hospital grounds.

The following is the conclusion of the testimony of Mrs. JANE STOUT. sister in law to the prisoner. This witness gives evidence establishing the fact that the brother and sister came home, on the night of the murder, with broken limbs and bruised bodies.

A young man named JACOBS died suddenly, at Hartford, from the bursting of the carotid artery, on Saturday noon. The Press says he had been troubled with a some throat and a boil and formed within his throat.

By an arrival at this port we have Puerto Cabello papers to the 20th, and Caraccas dates to the 31st of March. The overthrow of MONAGAS was complete, but it was not yet decided what was to be done with him. The people clamored loudly for his banishment, and some called for his execution as a traitor to his country.

General MOURAVIEFF has made his name doubly memorable in the Russian history. By his capture of Kars in Asia Minor, which capitulated to the army under his command almost at the same time that Sebastopol was stormed by the Allies, he opened the way to an honorable peace between the Czar and his Western antagonists;

CITY SWINDLERS.-Our friends in the rural districts ought to feel themselves under infinite obligations to Mayor TIEMANN for his vigorous onslaught upon all the organized schemes, which have been so prolific in New-York, for the express purpose of swindling simpleminded country people out of their money.

THE NEUTRALITY CASE AT BUFFALO.--At the examination of witness in the case of THURINGER and ZIMMERMAN, arrested for an alleged violation of the neutrality laws the evidence taken pointed pretty conclusively to the guilt of the prisoners.

Calling names is not a very dignified, nor a very satisfactory, manner of conducting a dispute, but it is very easy; it comes as natural as life to a vulgar nature; it saves the trouble of thinking, and is not the least dangerous.

THE EX-STREET COMMISSIONER.--Mr. CHARLES DEVLIN is certainly a man of energy and pluck. He is still in pursuit of the Street Commissioner's Office, and shows almost as much ingenuity-though we trust he will have less success-in the endeavor to get it as he did in his attempts at filling his purse out of the public treasury.

The hostility of GREEN, QUITMAN, GARNETT, and others of extreme Southern sentiments, is the hardest obstacle to overcome by the Committee of Conference. They would have reported to-day if QUITMAN could have been secured.

THE NEw CITY HALL.-By the provisions of the act recently passed by the Legislature providing for the erection of anew City Hall in the Park behind the old City Hall, the Mayor and Common Couacll are to appoint the Commissioners who are to superintend the work without compensation.

A methodist missionary in the Puget's Sound District, writes that iris charge embraces an extent of country 200 miles long, 150 of which has to be travcled in an ocean steamer. No country West of us; Lo preachers beyond us. We have 14,000 Indians and about 7,000 whites, and 100 church members.

STUPENDOUS SWINDLING SCHEME -- FRAUDS UPON THE STATE SCHOOL FUND -- The Rochester Union of Monday, says: "One of the most extensive schemes of fraud and swindling ever devised by wicked men, has recently come to the knowledge of the prosecuting officers of this State. We say extensive, because it has been practiced in almost every county by the same organized gang of swindlers.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: It is false, as published in your paper of to-day that my case against the proprietor of the New-York Herald was dismissed yesterday by Judge THOMPSON, in consequence of an arrangement having been made between the parties on the previous day.

THE TWO EXTREMES.--The St. Louis Democrat has the following paragraph, upon the arrival of Col. BENTON'S remains in that city: "By its side was the little coffin containing the body of the Statement's grandchild, McDOWELL JONES. Each body was inclosed in an air-tight zinc case, which was laid within a mahogany coffin. A lid was raised so as to allow friends to took through a glass on the faces of the dead.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--The fine weather brought out thousands of the musical last night, and the concerts of MUSARD were all ended as they always should be. The performance was so perfect that we have nothing whatever to say concerning it. To-day M. MUSARD gives a morning concert; the programme composed entirely of his best pieces. Should the day be bright there will be an exhibition of Spring fashions worth beholding.

Mr. FLORENCE, of Pennsylvania, has given noLice of his intention to introduce a bill to establish certain ocean post-routes between the United States and Europe, and to regulate the transportation of the mails thereon, and to reduce the expense thereof.

The members of the Conference reassembled Wednesday morning at 9 1/2 o'clock, Bishop BAKER in the Chair. After the usual devotional exercises, the debate on Slavery was resumed. The Rev. Mr. ROACH, of Allen-street, spoke upwards of two hours, advision the Conference to avoid any action condemnatory of their Philadelphia brethren.

The bombshells strewn about the city during the liege are still doing the work of death. No less than eight deaths, I think, have been caused by explosions of these missiles since my arrival, hardly a year since. Only a few days ago, two seamen belonging to the English steamer Beurout, came on shore near our shipyard, and for a few minutes were conversing with Mr. GOWEN.

To the Editor of the New- York Times: In your columns of the 19th my attention has been directed to a lengthy article in relation to the Pacific Railroad and the Overland Mail route to California, which I purpose briefly to answer, having no other object in view than submitting a few facts which seem not to be generally known, and which may be Interesting to many of your readers.

Our " season" is almost over, and the announcement that the drawing room of to-night was to be the last, insured a full attendance, although the weather was emphatically what the cockneys term "nasty." The rain fell in torrents,

The English amendment to the Kansas bill is likely to pass both Houses of Congress and become a law. Our advices from Washington state that a large portion of the Anti-Lecompton Democrats, nearly half, will support it,and as there can be no doubt of its receiving the Administration votes, its final passage is nearly certain.

In steamship Marion, for Charleston--The Hon. Fernando Wood and lady, the Hon. Judge J. Vanderbilt and lady. Mrs. Wood Master Wood, Dr, Cutting and lady, Mrs. C. Brainard, N. Orchard and lady, J. S. Perkins, E. Ewing, G. De Witt, Mr. ??, J. A. Freeman, A L. Moulton, C. Bogert, Mrs. Wallace and 2 children D. O. Comstock, Mrs. C. Nolan and child--and 7 in the steerage.

ANOTHER ATTEMPT AT A NEW CITY HALL.-For a splendid example of the governmental art, " How not to do it," we doubt if it would be possible to produce anything more striking and satisfactory, than the efforts made during the past twenty years on the part of our municipal authorities to erect a new City Hall.

N. P. Willis is said to be lying seriously ill at idlewild. A bilious fever, and a return of his old trouble of the lungs, have combined in a prostration, against which his usual active resistance to disease has succumbed for the present. It will probably be some little while before he is able to resume his pen.

From time to time charges have been made in the public papers that AMIN BEY, who visited this country in 1850, ostensibly on a public mission from the Turkish Government, was an impostor, and that his pretensions to a public character, though utterly unfounded, were countenanced by officers of the American Government.

The mining news from Lake Superior is favor ble. The Toltec have started their stamp mill, which had been idle for two months. At the Aztec they have cut, in the adit, a vein showing copper. The Adventure has much improved. The stampmill is again at work, and the amount of work for it is twice that of its capacity.

NORTHFIELD, Vt., 8 A. M.--Wind west. Snowing. Eight inches fell last night. ST. JOHNSBURY, Vt., 8 A. M.--Wind west. The snow measures ten inches, and is still falling. WHITE RIVER JUNCTION. Vt., 8 A. M.--Two inches of snow fallen. Clearing off.

The Washington Union objects to our going for "popular sovereignty; "it says we have no right to appropriate Democratic principles. The reason does not sustain the objection. The Democrats abandoned the doctrine before we took it.

CHARTER ELECTION IN HUDSON CITY.--The annual election for municipal officers of Hudson City, come off on Tuesday, and resulted in the success of what was known as the "Carpenter Ticket" by considerable majorities. Several knock-downs occurred at the polls during the day, but they were not serious in their consequences.
The Royal Mail steamship Canada, from Liverpool on. the 10 ?? inst, with three days' later advices from Europe. is now fully due at Halifax. She had not been head from at a late hour last night.

The defeat of the Auxiliary Guard bill has deeply disappointed a large crowd of hangers-on about the fountains of official patronage, who hoped to be quartered on the new force; and has, besides, defeated the aspirations of a number of individuals who aimed to be the Fouche of the proposed Bureau of Police.

DESPERATE AND FATAL FIGHT.--A desperate and fatal fight occurred at Darrsville, Ind , last Saturday, between a desperado named CLIFFORD, who was accused of burning a barn, and three men, respectively named MOSE KEENY, FRANK HARPER and KELLY, Who sought to arrest him. The Sheriff had failed to make the arrest, and employed KEENY to do It.

SERIOUS RAILROAD DISASATER.--We regret to announce one of the most serious Railroad disasters that has occurred in many years. The powerful locomotives " Dean Richmend" and "Erastus Corning" run off the track of Central Railroad. Before their headway could be arrested,. both of the locomotives were prcipitated into the Erie Canal, and entirely submerged.

Numerous memorials and resolutions were presented, among others one by Mr. CAMERON from citizens of Philadelphia for aid to a line of steamers between Philadelphia and Southampton. Mr. DUBKEE presented the resolutions of the Legislature of Wisconsin against the Lecompton Constitution.

The only business of interest in the morning hour was the presentation, by Mr. SEWARD, of a reply by the American Telegraph Company, in refutation of the allegations contained in the recent memorials of AMOS KENDALL and the Morse telegraphic interest. The document was referred to the same Committee, (the Judiciary,) and ordered to be printed. The remonstrants object to the action of Congress on the said memorial, for these among other reasons:

Assassination had its apotheosis last night in our City. A grand and really imposing torchlight procession marched through our principal streets, to pay honor to the men who attempted to murder LOUIS NAPOLEON and who died on the scaffold in punishment of their crime. Not less than 2,000 persons marched under the red flag,

At 11 o'clock last night there were no signs of the Canada at Halifax. She is now in her thirteenth day. The demonstration of the French, Germans,-Italians and others, foreigners resident in the City, to the memory of ORSINI and PIERRI--executed a short time since in Paris, for the attempted murder of the Emperor--took place last night.

DIPLOMATIC GATHERING.--We trust no serious complication may suddenly arise in the Department of State at Washington. For no small proportion of the diplomatic force of Europe is now doing social duty in the Metropolis. The Bachelor's Ball. at Niblo's Saloon, was last night honored with the presence of France, England, Prussia, Mexico and Spain.

The Conference resumed its sittings on Thursday. The building was crowded. After the usual introductory exercises, The report of Committee on Tract Society was read and adopted. A discussion arose as to the question of the discontinuance of the National Magazine, edited by Dr. FLOY, on the plea that it did not pay its expenses.
UNION COURSE. L. I.--TROTTING, Thursday, April 22, 1858, Match $500; mile heats, best three in five, in harness.

The Conference Committee meets to-morrow, and will adopt a plan for submitting the land ordinance to the popular vote, instead of the Constitution. The subject will be called up in the House tomorrow, but may not be decided until Monday. Ten Douglas Demecrats go with the Lecomptonites. QUITMAN has paired off. HILL, TRIPPE, and ZULLICOFFEE. South Americans, oppose the new plan.

One of the evils of the telegraph is, that it is made to report opinions in advance of the facts upon which those opinions should be based. Something of this sort has occurred regularly whenever any new movement has been made upon the Kansas bill. Instead of reporting precisely and accurately what the movement is,

The funebral torch-light procession, in veneration of the memories of ORSINI and PIERRI, recently guillotined at Paris, for the attempted assassination of the Emperor NAPOLEON, took place last night; and, all circumstances considered, was a much more imposfing affair than was generally anticipated. In the first place, the demonstration, as projected, was unpopular, not only among our native population, but among a majority of resident foreigners,

Harding, of this City. PENTZ--HAIL--In this City, on Tuesday, April 20. at Calvary Church. 23d st., by the Rev. A. D. Gilliete Mr. WM. A. PENIZ to Miss LIZZIE A., daughter of the late Herbert Hall.

We are not of the number of those who read the fate of nations in a Minister's eyebrow, or infer the course of coming history from the interpocular harongues of amiable gentleman, well-dressed, wed-dined, and. therefore. well disposed towards the whole human race in general and their husts of the moment in particular.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: DEAR SIR: Having lately seen a published account of a gross and wanton outrage of the Peruvian Government on the personal and international rights of Dr. CHARLES EASTON, of Pennsylvania, I profit by the occasion to add to that one a statement of a similarly disgraceful transaction, equally notorious, and strikingly illustrative of the injustice and circumvention of Peruvian diplomacy.

Last night, in Mozart Hall, Mrs. LUCY STONE delivered the fourth of the course of lectures in aid of the "Shirt-sewers' and Seamstresses' Union," Her audience was very large, and frequently expressed its appreciation of her remarks.

The United States vs. O. O. Larraway.--This was a case, in which Capt. Larraway, of the schooner Fred. Howell, is charged by Hugh Morrison, mate of said schooner, with having. on her late voyage to Port-au-Prince, left three of the crew in that port, contrary to law. It appeared in evidence that the three sailors had learned, upon their arrival at Portau-Prince, that they could obtain better wages by deserting,

CLERKS FOR THE COURT OF SPECIAL SESSIONS.--The Police Justices held a private meeting at noon yesterday, at the Special Sessions Court Room, at the Tombs, for the purpose of appointing a clerk and deputy-clerk for the Court of Special Sessions, in accordance with the recent act of the Legislature. ROBERT H. JOHNSTON, for the past eight years a Police Clerk was appointed Clerk, and PETER L. PETRTY.

This morning, the Hon. Geo. TAYLOR, of NewYork, from the Select Committee on Printing of the House, appointed Dec. 9, 1857, presented a full and elaborate report on the subjcct-matter embraced in the resolution, accompanied by a bill for the establishment of a Bureau in the Department of the Interior, to be called the Bureau of Public Printing, and providing for the execution of the entire printing. binding, engraving,

ACADEMY OF MUSIC--The Musard Matinee was fully and fashionably attended yesterday, and the programme clicited enthusiastic applause, considering the fair and indolent bands that had to bestow it. No better provision can be made for these bright Spring mornings than these entertainments, at which you may talk about the fashions without being frowned at by a surly amateur,

The Board of Police Commissioners met yesterday at 3 P. M., all the Commissioners present, and General NYE in the chair. Mayor TIEMANN presented a petition purporting to be signed by inhabitants of the Seventeenth Ward, demanding that Inspector JEDIDIAH W. HART, of the Seventeenth Precinct, be removed from office, charging him with "Insubordiuation," "Conduct unbecoming a gentleman."

THE FRONT-STREET BURGLARY--Officers McDougal, Shangle and Roach, of the Detective Police, Yesterday arrested Thomas McCoy, alias Sullivan, Alexander Watson and Thomas Miller, on suspicion of being engaged in the late burglary upon the grocery store of Dater Co., No. 161 Front-street. The prisoners were taken before Justice WELSH, but shortly after their arrest a writ of habcas corpus was served on the Magistrate, and all the prisoners, except McCoy, taken before Judge RUSSELL.

In a notice which the Commercial the other day was kind enough to take of my discourse at SMITH NIXON'S, on "Temperance," it was stated that I had embraced Christianity, from which it has been inferred that I had joined some religious sect. I am receiving letters containing abundance of pious exhortations, prayers, , which annoy me exceedingly. I have joined no church, and have not the most remote idea of doing so.

The Buchanan and Douglas State Democratic Conventions met here to-day, and organized separately. In the former, twenty-eight counties were represented, and resolutions strongly indorsing the Administration passed. In the latter ninety-seven counties were represented, and resolutions indorsing the course of the Illinois delegation in Congress were adopted without a dissenting voice.

Mr. FLORENCE'S OCEAN MAIL BILL--It has been stated that Mr. FLORENCE'S bill for the tablishment of Ocean Mail routes was framed in accordance with the wishes of his Philadelphia constituents; but, if the provisions of the bill have been correctly reported, we do not see that our neighbors will have any special reason for congratulating themselves on its passage.

Yesterday was the seventy-second anniversary of the foundation of the St. George's Society, of this City. The day was celebrated with becoming honors. In tile morning, in St. Thomas' Church, religious services appropriate to the event were solemnized. The congregation was large and fashionable, including many Episcopal clergymen and several of the more distinguished of the Society's guests.

The Conference met at 8 1/2 o'clock A. M. Friday. The exercises were opened with prayer. After the transaction of official business, the debate on the Slavery resolutions was resumed. No. 113. John Holroyd vs. Levi Pumphreys.The matters in controversy having been agreed to and settled, it was ordered that the writ of error from the Circuit Court for the District of Columbia be dismissed with costs.

ANOTHER VERDICT.--The Jury in the case of JAMES W. COLSTON vs. The Brooklyn City Railroad Company, held in the City Court, to recover damages for injuries sustained on Third-avenue, rendered a verdict yesterday morning, awarding $250 damages to tile plaintiff. Dr. BRENDLE, whose case was noticed yesterday, will give bail to-day in the sum of $1,500, to await the result of the argument upon the writ of error in his case.

SUDDEN DEATH OF EX-ALDEEMAN DELAMATER.--About 6 1/2 o'clock yesterday morning the wife of Mr. SAMUEL DELAMATER, residing in Twenty-third-street, was awakened by a groan, and, turning to ascertain the cause, found her husband lying in the agonies of death beside her. He expired almost immediately. His death was caused by apoplexy.

ADVANCE IN COTTON-DECLINE IN CONSOLS. HALIFAX, Friday, April 23. The R. M. steamship Canada, Capt. W. J. C. LANG left Liverpool at 4 P. M. on Saturday, the 10th inst., and arrived at Halifax at 11 A. M. of the 23d. The Canada has $47,750 in specie. The Canada went south of Sable Island to avoid the fields of ice, which were observed inside.

The vote to-day on ENGLISH'S bill, I find on conversation with both sides, this evening, is not regarded as a positive test of its ultimate fate. It is believed that HILL and TRIPPE, as also one or two Anti-Lecompton Democrats, who voted for the postponement, will not vote for the bill on its passage; that not more than two Southern Democrats will continue to stand out.

Those Democrats who have hitherto opposed the Lecompton Instrument on the ground that it was neither formed nor adopted by the people of Kansas, and who now intend to accept the proposition of Mr. ENGLISH, deny that the latter is an Administration triumph. They assert that, on the question which has, during this session, divided the Democracy, the Executive has been defeated and the minority section prevails.

The agents and owners of vessels upon the Jakes held a large meeting at the Chicago Board of Trade Rooms, on the 10th inst., to report upon a method of organization to protect their Interests, in the matter of freight charges, which they allege have become ruinously low.

We have at length begun to see the end of the trial of IRA STOUT for the murder of LITTLES--the testimony for the prosecution has closed--the opening for the defence has been made, and the struggle between the law and the prisoner has been narrowed down to murder or manslaughter--the accused taking the latter position in open court.

Mr. MORRILL'S Agricultural College bill was read twice and referred to the Committee on Public Lands. The Private Calendar was then taken up. The Deficiency bill was taken up and discussed, but no action was had on it. Mr. GREEN then asked leave to make a report from the Conference Committee on the subject of Kansas.

GEO. B. CHEEVER, of New York, will preach the service. The Rev. RUFUS W. CLARK. of Brooklyn ; the Rev JOSEPH P. THOMPSON, of New-York ; and the Rev, W. B. BROWN, of Newark, will also participate in the services.

ANOTHER SEVERELY BEATEN BY ROWDIES--Mr. THOMAS THOMAS, of Eleventh-street, near Fifth-avenue, Gowanus, while going home between 11 and 12 o'clock Saturday night last, was attacked on Fifth-avenue near Sixteenth-street, by three men, who beat him so severely that he is considered dangerously injured.

The steamship Cannda arrived at Boston yosterday, and her mails will reach this city at an early hour this morning. In the United States Senate. on Saturday, Mr. SEWARD presented JAMES C. JEWETT'S petition in reference to a non-fulfillment of engagements by the Peruvian Government.

Dr. JOHN ?? Holmes, a member of the British College of Surgeons and noted for several valuable inventions, died in wretched poverty, a few days ago, at the house of a negro woman in Evan-ville, Ind. Dr Holmes was formerly in the employ of the Hudson's Bay Company, and was the intimate friend of Capt. Parry, the Arctic Navigator. In his later years he became blind and paralyzed, and finaly died in misery and obscurity.

The Richmond Examiners, in consideration of the "prospect before us," administers "a caution to the North." That caution is substantially, that we of the Free States should beware of driving our Southern brethren to desperation, as some of them have it seriously in mind to take an alarming step in the contingency of the Lecompton Bill being defeated.

The official vote of Connecticut at the April election has been declared. BUCKINGHAM, Republican candidate for Governor is elected by a plurality of 2,754 over PEATT. The full vote was as follows BUCKINGHAM, 36,29S : PRATT, 33,544 ; Scattering, 285. The double-headed Democratic Convention (DOUGLAS and BUCHANAN) of Illinois met as Springfield on the 21st Instant.

BENJAMIN GRAHAM, a colored waiter at the Brandreth House, corner of Broadway and Canalstreet, was shot on Friday evening at 10 o'clock by one of the guests of the house, and almost instantly died. William J. Eschmann and Henry Brown, who occupied room No. 145, ordered some drinks for themselves and two friends at their room.

A General Convention of the Young Men's Christian Associations was held at Charleston, from the 17th to the 21st inst. Mr. FREDERICK A. SHELTON, of Troy, N. Y., was chosen President. Delegates were present from New-York, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Georgia, Washington, Virginia and other points. The four days were divided between speeches. religious exercises and excursions.

LETTINGS OF MAIL CONTRACTS.--On Monday. the 26th inst., at 10 A. M., the Postmaster-General will announce his decisions on the proposals received, under the advertisement of Dec. 31, 1857, for conveying the mails, for four years from the 1st of July next, in the States of Alabama, Mississippi, Louisiana, Arkansas, Texas, Kentucky, Tennessee, Missouri Iowa, Illinois, Indiana, Michigan, Wisconsin, and Minnesota, Nebraska and Kansas Territories, in the order here mentioned.

A threatening petition from Roman Catholic citizens of Torento, has been presented in the Provincial Parliament. The petitioners wind up a very emphatic statement of grievances by requesting the appointment of a special commission to inquire into the cause of these deplorable failures of justice--and that your honorable House would furthermore be pleased to enact that no man sworn into the Secret Orange Society shall be competent to hold the Commission of the Peace,

I have such pleasure in the receipt of yours of the 23d inst. While I thank you and Mrs.--with all my heart, for the kind home you have expressed, that the recent rumor with regard to my highest welfare may be true, I am constrained to say, that rumor is in this, as in most matters that pertain to me, most pitifully in error--there is not one word of truth in it.

ASSASSINATION BY CONTRACT.--A rabid Red Republican, who has long disgusted the sensible portion of the German population by his fierce tirades in the Pioneer, of which paper the person in question is editor, has undertaken to assassinate LOUIS NAPOLEON, provided "his expenses are paid," and to do the deed within two months of his arrival in Paris.

The city is filled with rumors to-day relative to the result of the vote to-morrow. One of the most important is, that a new defection on the part of Southern men towards ENGLISH'S bill has occurred, which threatens a complete dissolution of party harmony. On the other hand, doubts are circulating relative to the course of the Anti-Lecompton men, reaching even MORRIS, of Illinois. Both sides are accordingly at sea.

SNOW AT ALBANY AND VICINITY. ALBANY, Saturday, April 24. Snow fell this morning, here and at Schenectady, and other points in this vicinity. FROST IN GEORGIA. AUGUSTA, Sunday, April 25. Frosts are reported in middle and upper Georgia yesterday morning, and fears are entertained of injury to the wheat crop.

From the Chicago Times. Mr. J. R. COUDRY, Deputy United States Marshal, of Wisconsin, arrived in this city yesterday, having in custody a German named CHARLES REISSER. alias CHARLES HENRY, who is charged with the crimes of burglary, robbers arson, and murder, in la Crosae Wisconsin. REISNEE was arrived at Peoria, where, under the name of ??, he has been carrying on the business of a butcher.

The contest recurs in Congress to-day upon the Compromise Kansas bill of the Conference Committee. The question to be taken is upon the motion to postpone the subject until the second Monday in May. That motion was carried on Friday, but on Saturday it was reconsidered, and, to prevent the question being taken again, the House adjourned.

AN EARTHQUAKE--Captain GADD, of the ship Pacific, from New Orleans, reports : April 17, at 8:45 P. M, lat. 07[Degrees] 25, lon. 79[Degrees] 25[Degrees], with son perfectly smooth, felt a severe like distant Thunder, and kept increasing until it scunded like a heavy cannonade some few miles away.

CITY amount of the City Tax Levy authorized by the Legislature is $3,441,095. This includes $100,000 for building a hospital on Blackwell's Leland $16,000 for the Police Commissioners expense, in successfully litigating the new Police bill against Mayor WOOD; $30,000 for payment of salaries to CONOVER and his men, and $13,800 for CONOVER'S law expenses.

MURDER AND ROBBERY IN PHILADELPHIA.--About seven o'clock this morning the body of a genteely dressed man was found floating in the Schuylkill, under Market-street bridge. The remains were towed into Arch-street wharf, and Coroner FENNER was sent for to hold an inquest. That official immediately proceeded to the spot, and upon examining the body be was satisfied that a murder had been committed.

Certain of our City cotemporaries have improved the occasion to he "Orsini demonstration" to read a lesson of stern rebuke to the people of France for their destarilly imbecility in succumbing to the despotic rule of the Third NAPOLEAN.

JEWEIT, asking that a demand be made on the Government of Peru for non-fulfillment of its engagement in reference to the Lobos Islands, Referred to the Committee on Claims. Mr. YULEE, of Florida, presented a petition from EDWARD D TIPPET for aid to test his "cold-water steate engine." Referred to the Committee on Commerce.

The Project--often started but never carried out--of running steamers between the United States and Brazil, is of me more importance to this country than any of the European mail-routes which Mr. FLORENCE proposes to establish.

The following is the weekly report of deaths in the City and County of New-York, from the 17th day of April to the 24th day of April, 1858. Men, 74; Women, 91; Boys, 115; Girls, 119; Total, 390 Adults, 165; Children, 234 ; Males, 189 ; females, 210 ; Colored persons. 10.

THE ETERNAL NAVY RETIRING BOARD.--We had flattered ourselves that we had got rid of that Congressional incubus of the past two years, the action of the Navy Retiring Board, but, as the flunkey in the play says, we were premature.

We are a progressive people. Our national boundaries require continued extension, and our fundamental laws frequent revision. The Anglo-Saxon plow runs to land, and the Anglo-Saxon mind to change. Nothing in the way of novelty comes amiss to us. A new province and a new constitution are alike to our taste.

PAYING REPORTERS--A SPASM OF VIRTUE.--We find the following paragraph in yesterday's Tribune; "The Common Council, we gladly observe, under stands that the Tribune pays its own reporters, and does not allow them to receive pay from other s for work cone in behalf of this journal.

Mr. MERIAM published a letter in the Courier and Enquirer, yesterday morning, in which he stated that be had "received a letter from Governor TOUCEY, Secretary of the Navy, and had addressed him a fourth communication, saying that Mayor Tiemann will dismiss the prosecution against the officers of the pestilence frigate Susquehanna, if that vessel will go to the North Sea."

There was an assignces' sale, by P. R. WILKINS, of nine lots on the southeast corner of Thirty-fourthstreet and Tenth-avenue, being six on the avenue and three on he street adjoining. It was one of a multitude of public sales at the Exchange which furnish little or no guide to the public of the actual fair value of lots. The lots were the full usual size.

The Brooklyn Yacht Club met at their rooms at Penny Bridge on Friday last, and elected the following gentlemen officers for the ensuing year; Commodore, E. PILCUER; Vice-Commodore, G. L. HAIGHT; Secretary, G. A. COOPER; Treasurer, H. S. WOOD; Measure, J. M. SAWYER.

The Canada's mails, with Liverpool and London papers to the 10th inst., reached this City yesterday morning. The news from India, which had only been received by telegraph in England, was given in full in our dispatch from Halifax. Particulars of the grand attack upon Lucknow are looked for with great eagerness.

The Quarantine buildings at Seguine's Point were entirely destroyed by fire during Sunday night. The buildings, which were erected about eight months ago--tw hospitals, a wash house, and a small cock-house--were of wood, the walls filled in with brick resting on brick foundations.

PETER B. SWEENEY, Esq., has gone to Europe for his health. Tile duties of the District-Attorney's office. during his absence, will be performed by Mr. SEDGWICK, assisted by the Hon. JOHN McKEOS. The Police Commissioners have reconsidered their action suspending Captains LEONARD and DOWLING. of the old force. Both are efficient officers, and will, we trust, be restored to tile service.

In addition to the usual musical attractions of such an entertainment, (the programme cortains many of the best known names in the City,) Mr. BURTON, Mr. BROUGHAM and Mr. WALCOT committee their services.

The result of the vote on the question of postponement in the House, the Administration men say, has entirely settled all doubts of the final passage of the bill. Mr. STEPHENS expects to get it through on Wednesday by at least the same majority as to-day. Mr. STEPHENS knows of no defection of Southern men, and has no confidence in the rumor to that effect.

Very interesting intelligence from Utah will be found in the letter or our special correspondent from Fort Leavenworth, which we publish this morning. He gives the statements and the opinions of a gentleman of education and ability, Mr. F. LOBA, who has just made his escape from Salt Lake City, and who gives very different accounts of the condition of the "Saints" from those which have hitherto been current.

EXCITEMENT AT THE ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--Messrs. WILKES and DARCY, of Porter's Spirit of the ??, were arrested last evening at the Academy of Music, on a warrant issued by City Judge RUSSELL, on Complaint of Mr. ULLMAN, who alleged that he ?? the parties would create a disturbance at the Academy. .

The news from Europe by each mail seems to indicate that LOUIS NAPOLEON is fast drifting into the necessity, which many people have long prophesied for him--of fighting some body, for the purpose of keeping up the spirits of the nation.

An Irishman named DANIEL LONG, residing at the corner of Nichols and Grand streets, was shot by an Irishman named MICHAEL HEALY, about 12 o'clock last night. LONG was a tenant of HEALY'S, and about one week since the wives of the parties had some family quarrel, which resulted in a notice from HEALY for LONG to move out of his (HEALY'S) house.
FINALE OF THE REVOLUTION IN PERU--The news from the South Pacific is almost always of an uninteresting character, but that received from Peru yesterday forms an exception to a very general rule.

The screw steams ip Memphis of Cromwell's line, arrived here this morning, from New-York after a run of 59 hours to wharf. SAVANNAH, Tuesday, April 27. The United States mail steamship Alabama, from New-York, arrived at her wharf at 7 o'clock this morning, all well.

It is not often that we read a bill so filled with promise as that issued by Mr. BUETON on Monday Light for the first performance of a five-act piece called "Life Among the Players in England and America," and it seldom happens that we are so grievously disappointed in the realization.

The United States Mail steamship Moses Taylor, JOHN MCGOWAN, Esq., commanding, from Aspinwall on the 19th inst. with the California mails of the 5th inst., treasure and passengers brought down by the Pacific Mail steamship John L. Stephens, arrived at this port yesterday morning.

The Mayor's Police squad, under Sergeant Crofts, made fifty-eight arrests yesterday forenoon, of persons charged with being engaged in the policy business. The arrests were sudden and simultaneous, and the result of a skillful and concerted plan of action.

The Board met on Monday evening, the President, Alderman CLANCY, in the chair. Among the communications received, was the following from the Mayor, which, in the first instance, was referred to the Committee on Police: To the Honorable the Common Council:

OUR RELATIONS WITH NEW-GRANADA.--By the arrival of the Moses Taylor at this port from Aspinwall, we learn that the rumor, received by a former steamer, to the effect that the Cass-Herran treaty had been ratified by New-Granada, was altogether premature.

One of those shocking calamities to which we become accustomed by continual repetition, and in which guilt enters no less than misfortune, occurred on Thursday, the 22d inst., on the Mississippi River, about five miles above the city of St. Louis.

It is intended to get a vote on Kansas in the 'Senate tomorrow, if possible, but there are a number of Senators yet who desire to debate, and it is rather unlikely. In the House, the previous question will be demanded, but it is doubtful if it is sustained. Some will vote against that who will vote for the bill. GILMER, American, and GOODE, Democrat, absent without pairing, arrived to-day.

The United States Mail steamship Moses Taylor, with the California mails of April 5, and $1,486,665 in treasure, arrived at this port yesterday morning. The news from California is unimportant. Rains had fallen plentifully all over the State, and were of great benefit both to the mining and agricultural interests.

COURT CALENDAR--WEDNESDAY. SUPREME COURT--Circuit.-Nos. 3606, 432, 447, 433, 437, 440, 441, 443, 448, 449, 450, 19, 425, 308, 436, 285, 36, 403. 449, 81, 421. Special Term--Adjourned to 28th, at 10 A. M. Decision in Admiralty. UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT. Before Judge Betts. Charles H. Jones et al. vs. The Proceeds of the Cargo of the Ship Richmond.

OPENING OF THE CANALS--This is the day designated by the Canal Commissioners for the commencement of navigation on all the Canals of this State, except the Champlain Canal, which was opened on the 20th instant. The water was let into the Erie Canal a week ago, and the banks are in excellent condition.

RIGHTS AND WRONGS.--Mrs. LUCY STONE has achieved a work if not a triumph. She has treated the public to a course of lectures designed to introduce women to the hustings. In the advocacy of this "reform" LUCY has invoked the aid of several able and eloquent men. Mr. BRADY spoke for the bar; Dr. CHAPIN for the pulpit; and Mr. "Howadji" CURTIS represented the RepUblic of Letters.

PETER B. SWEENEY, Esq., District-Attorney, has been directed by his physician to take a sea voyage for the benefit of his health. He expects to be gone about four weeks, during which time JOHN MCKEON, Esq., late United States District-Attorney, will perform his official duties.

ALARMING TO PROFESSIONAL POLITICIANS.-No small consternation has been crested among the hangers-on of the City Hall in consequence of a report having been circulated that the new Street Commissioner has resolved to appoint no man to an office who is not practically familiar with the duties thereof.
RATIFICATION OF THE YRISARRI TREATY.--In spite of the most determined hostility in Nicaragua to the Yrisarri treaty, it has passed the Legislature of the State by the necessary two-thirds vote.

BLACK.-In this City, on Tuesday morning. April 27, suddenly AUGUSTA, youngest daughter of Joseph and Mary Black. aged 19 months and 3 days. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral. from the residence of her parents. No 116 Eldrigde-st.. this (Wednesday) afternoon, without further invitation.

Nothing of interest transpired during the first half hour of the session. At 121/2 o'clock the report of the Conference Committee came up, whereupon Mr. CRITTENDEN took the floor. He said that the offer made by the Conference substitute is merely equivalent to a bribe of public lands to accept the Lecompton Constitution.

Gen. QUITMAN proposes the enactment of a law prohibiting the admission of any new State into the Union, until it shall have population sufficient to entitle it to one member in the House of Representatives. The principle is a good one. It is a wrong to the old States to admit new ones upon any other terms.

Circuit Calendar for this day: Nos. 142,143,148,151,152,154,155,157,158,159,161,163,165,166,167,168,169, IMPORTANT TO INSOLVENTS.--A suit was bought in the Circuit Court, yesterday, by B. M. STILLWELL, against NICHOLAS VAN BRUNT and another, to recover the amount of a promissory note.

The Republican has just received letters from Independence, stating that the Santa Fe mail of April I arrived on the 22d. Between Fort Union and the Arkansas River the party encountered violent snowstorms, which were followed by cold so severe as to freeze some of the animals of the incoming trains. The outrages on the Indians, in the southern part of the Territory, continued.

The chaste halls of the Academy of Music were profaned on Monday evening by the enacting of a scene which was not set down in the programme. and which under no circumstances should have been provoked by those whose duty it is to preserve the hitherto unsullied character of the house.

The Coroner's July met again last evening, but nothing of importance was ellcited beyond the fact that HEALY and PAT CARROL were seen in turn on the night after the murder (Sunday last) COENELIUS RYAN testified to having seen them about 10 o'clock on that night, on Dubois-street, (outskirts of the village,) and talked with them.

INCENDIARY FIRES IN TROY. TROY, N. Y.. Tuesday, April 27. The West Troy Exchange, a large wooden building, the principal hotel in the village, was destroyed by fire at an early hour this morning. It was owned and occupied by E. H. POWELL, and had been recently repaired and enlarged.

In lieu of the annual festival dinner of this Association, a public meeting of the Board of Directors was held yesterday at I P. M., in the Metropolitan Hotel. The attendance was small, comparatively, though the pleasurable interest with which these demonstrations have herebefore been invested, did not appeal in any way to be diminished.

Mr. GREGORY, who has been in charge of the State property at Seguine's Point since October last, states that he occupied the wash-house, which, being of two stories and having windows on all sides, afforded the best place for an observatory. On Saturday night last he had occasion to visit the boarding house belonging to the candle factory.

The following persons, known to have been passengers in the Ocean Spray, burned on the Mississippi last week, are still missing: Miss Thompson, residence unknown ; Miss Johnson, residence unknown ; Maria Carroll, (colored,) chambermaid ; Stephen T. THE NEW DEPOT OP THE NEW-JERSEY RAILROAD.-The large and commodious new depot of the New. Jersey Railroad and Transportation Company, at Jersey City, which has been in course of construotion for the last eight months, is rapidly approaching completion. The work of laying tracks across Hudson street is now progressing, and they will in a few days be connected with those coming into the old depot.

If our National Government were but onehalf as amiable and argumentative in dealing with our domestic difficulties as in handling our foreign quarrels, we should long since have heard the last of the Kansas imbroglio, and we should never have heard at all of a great many noisy individuals whose notoriety has contributed neither to the good sense of the nation nor to their own permanent renown.

We published, on Monday, a copy of the bill for the establishment of six new ocean mil routes, which Mr. FLORENCE has introduced into Congress. It differs, in several partieniars, from the reports which have heretofore been published in regard to it.

BURGLARY.-A thief entered the house of Mrs. PAULINE RICHTER, No. 263 Court street, Tuesday evening, during the temporary absence of the family, and carried off $ 125 worth of jewelry. The thieves were kind enough to leave untouched $250 in gold, which was in the same drawer with the jewelry. About 2 o'clock, yesterday morning, two thieves attempted to enter house No. 144 Schermerhorn street, when they were frightened off by a private watchman.

GAGE.--In this City, on Wednesday, April 28, LUKEGAGE, Esp. in the 57th year of his age, deeply and universaily regretted by a large circle of afficted relatives and friends. The funeral will take place from his late residence. No. 696 Greenwich-st., on Friday the 30th inst., at 1 o'clock P. M., precisely. His friends and relatives are invited to attend. without further notice.
Nothing proves more clearly the evasive, tricky and sneaking character of the English bill for the admission of Kansas, than the disputes which prevail concerning its real character and meaning.

During the session of Congress Washington is always a city of excitements. There is continually some fruitful topic of a national character, upon which the public mind may speculate. For instance, the gossips are much exercised at present upon the question of the acquisition of the Island of Cuba, and the means to be employed for the accompllshment of that end.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: If the New-York Horald's issue of the 13'h tast., there is a communication from Mr. JOHN C. TEAUTWINE, Chief Engineer of the Honduras Railroad, deprecating any rumor as to his having as yet estimated the cost of the Road.

Before Judge Hall. Benkard Hutton vs. Hugh Maxwell.--This was an action to recover back an excess of duties imposed by the defendant as collector upon certain importations of plaid flannels, which the defendant considered liable to a duty of 30 per cent. as a non-enumerated article, Instead of a duty of 25 per cent. as flannels.

It appears from the report of the Postmaster General of Great Britain for 1857, that the average cost per mile of the postal use of railways is 9 1/4d, being nearly double the charge made in the United States ; while the average payment per mile for the use of mail coaches and carts is 2 1/2d., which is about 40 per cent. less than with us.

The Select Committee of Five, appointed early the present session, on motion of Hon. ROBERT SMITH, of Illinois, to investigate into the facts and charges relative to the sale of the Fort Snelling Reservation in Minnesota, presented to the House this morning two elaborate reports, accompanied by a formidable mass of testimony, embodying all the facts in the case, with the separate conclusions at which the two branches of the Committee have arrived.

The month of May has always been remarkable for mortality among a peculiar class of people-the national office-holders, to wit. Why they are turned out then more numerously than at other times, I know not; but such, statisticians say, is the fact, and, if report be correct, the coming crop of Custom- House Mayflowers will be duly plucked.

Mrs. SARAH LITTLES, jointly indicted with IRA STOUT for the murder of her husband, declines t enter a plea of guilty of manslaughter, (the course recommended by her counsel,) and demands a trial by jury. The Court refused to entertain the plea for the second degree, but intimated that a plea of guilty in the first degree would be accepted. This the prisowner refuses. The Court will take up no other busl-

ALBERT STAUB, the murderer of Mr. LAUEBMANN, was executed at Chicago on Thursday last. STAUB was a Swiss. His victim was a German, a farmer, and had formerly employed STAUB. They met afterwards, when both were intoxicated, and in a quarrel which suddenly sprang up, LAUSEMANN was shot. The murderer left the following letter, written the day before his execution:

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR: In the TIMES of Monday, among the reports of the cases tried in the Court of General Sessions is that of a servant girl, indicted for grand larceny in minister's house in New-Jersey, in which her offence is ascribed to her " ignorance," and the minister's statement is described as " quite unsatisfactory," and so declared by Recorder BARNARD.

Will. you please call the attention of our good Mayor and his associates to the following nuisance: Every day herds of cattle are driven through the Fifth-avenue, to the great discom. Fiture of the ladies. For my own part, I like cattle when they are in the field, but I just don't like them when they attempt to share the sidewalk with myself.

Two conceits were given on Tuesday evening, one by Mr. J. G. MAEDER, a well-known professor; the other by Miss BRAINERD, a favorite concert singer. Mr. MAEDER was assisted by several of his pupils, and by a number of distinguished artists-particularly on the bills. It is Mr. MAEDER'S intention to make this an annual affair.

The house of Mr. ORSON STOWE. of Southington, was struck with lightning during the storm of Thursday morning. The effects were very peculiar, the force being so equally distributed throughout the building It seemed to follow the space enclosed

To the Editor of the New-York Times: An outrage has occurred here to-day which astounds by its audacity, and causes a thrill of indignation in the breast of every respectable person. It is Alike a disgrace to Missouri, and the public sentiment of a town which will admit of such an occurrence. I refer to an attack upon Gen. POMEROY, by Col. Titus and some of his confreres resident in Kansas City.

MISS ESMONDE ON IRISH POETRY.--Last evening, in Mozart Hall, Miss TERESA ESMONDE entered the field of criticism with Dr. CHARLES MAUKAY, whose disparaging allusions to Irish poetry she, with true Celtic spirit, vigorously rebutted.

The Opposition consider the result in the House to-day as an indication of the defeat of the English bill, and gain great confidence from it. It was evident that STEPHENS did not feel confident of being able to put the bill through, otherwise he would have pressed a vote.

The steamship Isabel has arrived here with Havana and Key West da'es to the 25th inst. It was rumored at Havana that General CONOHA had resigned the Governor- Generalship of Cuba, and that General CONDE MARMADE (Mirasol?) had been appointed his successor.

Madame Orsini has left Paris to return to the Italian village, where she has long been established as schoolmistress. Friends helped to administer comfort by subscribing handsomely to the widow and fatherless, and a sum of 2,500 francs was placed in Madame Orsini's hands at the moments of departure, to which the principal subscribers are English. .

THE TIMES BUILDING.-The building for the NEW-YORK TIMES establishment is now nearly completed, and on or before the 1st of May it will be occupied by that paper. It is probably the most complete printing-office in the United States, if not in the world. Money has been lavishly spent in making the building just what it ought to be. Every convenience imaginable is to be found within its walls.

REMARKABLE CONFESSION OF A MURDER.--The Atlanta (Ga) papers furnish particulars concerning the murder of SAMUEL LANDRUM, about three miles from that city, on Thursday, the 8th inst. One of the parties implicated was RADFORD CROCKETT, who made off into Alabama on horseback, and was followed to Talladega on his way to Texas. His arrest was effected 24 miles west of Talladega.

The schooner Eliza Jane, from Rockland for Boston, with lime, went ashore last night on Nantasket Beach, near Cohasset. Crew saved. The vessel is a total loss. The two schooners at anchor near Seituate rode out the storm in safety. The steamer R. B. Forbes went down this morning to tow them up.

What declaimer upon the floor of Congress was it who, despairing of getting any facts in regard to this region, not evidently exaggerated by partisan writers or interested speculators, protested at last that he did'nt believe there was any Kansas? Your correspondent, though never so incredulous, must confess the difficulty, while participating in the discussion of the Kansas question at Washington for months and years past, of fully realizing what the future was and is.

Plans have been selected for the reabody institute, at Baltimore. The building is to be located on Mount Vernon and Charles streets, 150 feet on the latter. The height is 60 feet, divided into two stories. A music half, 100 by 60 feet, occupies the ground floor. The second story will contain the rooms of the Maryland Historical Society and the Peabody Library. The front is Brunswick stone.

Rarely is the public sense of morals and decency so severely shocked as by the trial of IRA STOUT for the murder of CHARLES W. LITTLES, just concluded at Rochester, and which has resulted in the conviction of the accused. His victim was the husband of his sister, and that sister was an accomplice in the murder.

He spoke till nearly 3 o'clock, when only twenty-two Senators were present.

The widow of the murdered man lives in Brooklyn, and states that his name was JOHN, and not A. D. FINNEGAN. The bark put into Palermo to bury the mate. SUSTICIOUS GRATITUDE.-It appears that a large party of successful bidders for mail contracts at the South and Southwest, after having ascertained their good fortune on Tuesday night, marched to the Presidential mansion with a band of music, and testified their re- dell spect for the Chief Magistrate by giving him a serenade.

This has been a quiet week. You have enticed a goodly delegation of our fashionable society to New-York,-the fair lady who presides over the hospitalities of the Executive mansion has gone to Philadelphia,-and scarcely had the grave been closed over the lovely daughter of Commander DAHLGREN, of the Navy, ere intelligence arrived of the death of the only surviving son f Sir GORE OUSELEY.

A bill to provide for the general introduction of an international code of marine signals has been reported to the Senate by the Committee on Commerce. The object is to give to the shipmasters of the United States, as well as to those of foreign Countries, a universal language for signalizing upon the ocean. The system is the invention of HENRY J. ROGERS, Esq., of Baltimore, and consists of two parts.

Before the Hon. Justice Sutherland. THE GLASS BALLOT-BOX--DISMISSAL OF THE COMPLAINT. Jordan L. Mott, Jr., Assignee of Samuel C. Jollie, vs. The Beard of Supervisors of the County of New-York.--This was an action brought to recover $60,000, alleged to be due as the price of 4,000 Glass Ballot-Boxes, furnished and delivered by Jollie to the Metropolitan Police Commissioners in October last, under a contract between Jollie and the said Commissioners, executed in August, 1857.

There are prevaient misapprehensions respecting the recent treaty with Nicaragua While it is assumed by some to be a Protectorate of that Republic, others aver that it is nothing less than virtual annexation. The treaty is neither the one nor the other. It does not in the least disturb the nationality of Nicaragua, and it is a Protectorate of the Transit route simply,--not of the country through whose territory that route passes.

Strong hopes are entertained by the Administration men of getting a vote to-morrow on the Kansas bill in both Houses. If so, it will doubtless be carried. Cx, LAWRENCE and GILMER--the latter hitherto steadily voting with the Opposition-are certain now to vote for the bill.

The Royal Mail steamship Arabia, Captain STONE, from Liverpool at about 10 o'clock on the morning of the 17th of April, arrived at this port yesterday morning. No steamer from the United States had arrived on since the departure of the Kangaroo, which sailed for New-York on the 16th of April.

The St. Louis Republican has a letter from the camp of the Overland Mail Expedition, on the Rio Pecos, April 10. The Expedition left Fort Chadbourne on the 26th March, and reached the camp of the Artesian Well Expedition, on the Pecos, on the 10th inst. Captain POPE'S experiments in the boring of Artesian wells, on the route across the plains seem to be going on successfully.

At the meeting of the Board of Commissioners of the Central Park, Wednesday evening, held at 6 o'clock, at their room, No. 637 Broadway, Commissioners Gray, Diilon: Russell, Butterworth, Hutchins, Fields, Green, Strong, Elliott, Logg, Belmont, were present.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--A fine performance of MENDELSSOHN'S oratorio of "Elijah" was given last night by the New-York Harmonic society, assisted by Mme. D'ANGEI, MISS MILNER, Herr FORMES, Mr. PER RING, The solos were excellently rendered, and the choruses went with more steadiness than we have been accustomed to expect from the previous performances of this Society--showing that a generous effort to please the public is, after all, the best art master.

THE PROCEEDS OF THE COLOSSAL FETE-From the report of the Treasurer of the Executive Committee of the Crystal Palace Charity Fete, Mr. J. V. DE FORREST, we learn that the whole number of, tickets received at the door on the night of the fete was 6,365; of which 4,805 were double tickets, 861 ladies' tickets, and 696 complimentary tickets.

The Canals. A NEW LOAN OF HALF A MILLION--OFFICIAL NOTICE WITH RESPECT TO DRAFTS. Special Dispatch to the New-York Times. ALBANY, Thursday, April 29. The Commissioners of the Canal Fund will issue proposals to-morrow for a loan of $500,000 at 5 per cent. LEO.

WEST-POINTERS.--The practical benefit to the country of such an educational institution as the Military Academy at West Point, where the pupils are so thoroughly trained in their scientific studies, is not confined solely to the army. Some of our best civil engineers are graduates of the "Point," and it is a remarkable circumstance that three of them are now at the head of our three great City improvements.

TELFORD.-- In this City, on Wednesday evening, April 28. after a short illness, Mrs. DORCAS TELFORD, aged 71 years. Her relatives and friends, and those of her son. James F. Telford and son-in-law, John Morton, are requested to attend her funeral this (Friday) morning.) at 9 1/2 o'clock, from the residence of her son in-law, No. 384 Canal-st., without further notice.

DESTRUCTIVE GAS EXPLOSION.--An explosion of gas occurred in the residence of Mr. HENRY JAHNE, corner of Barrow and York streets, Jersey City, about 9 o'clock Wednesday evening, which resulted in the almost entire destruction of the building and furniture, and the serious, though not fatal, injury of Mr. JAHNE.

The steamship Empire City. Capt. S. P. GRIFFIN, from Havana, arrived at this port yesterday morning. The Empire City left New-Orleans April 20, and arrived at Havana on the 23d at sunrise. After connecting with steamship Granara, left for New-York on the following day at 8 A. M.; three hours later saw steamer Philadelphia, bound in from New-York.

By the arrival at this port yesterday of the Cunard-steamship, Arabia, we receive seven days later-intelligence from Europe. No political news of any importance is reported. Much interest is manifested in the trial of SIMON BERNARD in London for the attempt to assassinate the Emperor of the French On the day the Arabia left Liverpool, the trial had been in progress for a week and was not then complete.

The Court-martial on General TWIGGS reassembled this morning at 11 o'clock, at Newport Barracks, General JESSUP presiding. General TWIGGS objected to Colonel FAUNTLEROY'S sitting as a member of the Court, on account of former difficulties between them. The latter said the differences had been long since discarded, but asked permission to withdraw, which was granted.

The friends of the Administration are exulting with joy over the double success of passing the Kansas and the Deficiency bills on the same day, and some powder has been burned in consequence. The passage of the Kansas bill was managed to have a dramatic effect, by making it pass both Houses nearly simultaneously, and by the same majoritynine. Both Houses immediately adjourned, and a general scene of congratulation followed.

The country can breathe again. Whatever may be their opinions of the Conferenoe Kansas bill, we are confident that nine-tenths of the community will be glad to learn that it has been disposed of, and that Congress can now have a chance of attending to some other business.

WINE SELLERS AND CELLARS--At a Scientific Congress now sitting in Baltimore, one of the members, Professor SWALLOW, whose name would seem to be indicative of his specialty, read a paper on Missouri wines, from which we learn that when nature designed the State of Missouri as a wine-producing region, she also created the right kind of receptacles for stowing the precious juices of the soil.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In your paper of the 26th ult. you published the testimony of some of the crew of the A. Z., before the United State Commissiener, charging the Captain with cruel and unusual treatment of one of the crew-, thereby causing his death.

The Arago sails to-day for Southampton and Havre; she carries over 8CO passengers. The new screw steamer Saxonia also leaves for Hamburg vi? Southampton, with nearly 500 passengers, making to gether probably the largest number that ever left this port for Europe in any two steamers in one day.

THE COOLY TRADE.--Mr. Commissioner REED's circular against the exportation of Coolies in American ships, was published in yesterday's TIMES. He very justly takes the ground that this traffic is but one form of the Slave-trade, and calls upon our Consuls in China to arrest its progress.

The acquisition of Cuba, by purchase, has for some time been discussed, and is important to our whole country. The reasons in its favor are so strong, that it will soon be a settled principle of American policy.

The bark Champion has been for several days at the Worcester Railroad wharf, Boston, taking on board a number of cars manufactured to the order of the Viceroy of Egvpt, for use upon the railroad of that country. The cars are from an establishment in Springfield, and consist of four first and six second class cars of the same pattern of those used in this country. They cost. the former about $3.500.

Both Houses of Congress, yesterday, were occupied with the Kansas bill, and the English Conference report passed both the Senate and House of Representatives ;-the former by a vote of 30 to 22, and the latter by 112 to 103. So the Lecompton bill is at rest so far as Congress is concerned. The people of Kansas now have the floor.

Mr. BUCHANAN, the Chief Agent at Quebec of the British Government for the superintendence of emigration to Canada, in his official report to the Right Honorable Sir E. HEAD, Governor-General of the British North American Provinces, on the immigration of last year, calls attention to the bad treatment of passengers who make New-York their port of disembarkation, and the frauds which are frequently practiced on the unwary.
