C., requesting him to resign, and that the Church had voted to give them letters somewhat different in form from those usually given to retiring members.

The Administration Party is rejoicing vociferously over the passage of the Kansas bill. The Washington Union opens its leading editorial with the announcement that both Houses have adopted the bill "admitting Kansas into the Union under the Lecompton Constitution." It strikes us that this is slightly premature. There is a trifling formality to be gone through with yet, before the process of admission can be considered complete.

The Courrier de Paris, which is a sort of servant out of livery, or gentleman's gentleman in the now Imperial Press of France, is extremely agitated, arid very angrily excited, because certain "Yankee filibusters" have seized upon the Island of Navaza--" a barren rock lying between Jamaica and Hayti, anti belonging to the latter empire;"

Of the distinguished hospitality of Baltimore, no member of the Scientific Convention of 1858 will fail to speak to his latest descendants. It were impossible, unless each guest's faculties were duplicated, for a host to furnish him more social enjoyment of the public order. To see any more of Baltimore's beauties, he must needs be furnished double eyes;

NEWSPAPER MOVEMENTS.--May day took unusual effect this year upon the newspapers. No less than four of the City dailies changed their quarters. Our own removal vacated the quarters occupied by the TIMES hitherto, which were immediately taken possession of by our Democratic morning contemporary, the Daily News.

THE CHILDREN'S AID SOCIETY.--This Society which was organized about two years ago-and at first under the agency of Rev. J. B. ROOT, but more recently in charge of Mr. BURDICK,--on Friday last closed the office in the basement of the City Hall, and discharged the agent and visitors. This has been brought about, as we understand, by some disagreement in the Board of Directors as to the general plan of operations.

THE MISERIES OF MOVING--New-comers in New-York from foreign countries and the rural districts, who happen to be here on the first of May, seeing how recklessly and good naturedly half the population change their residences and place of business on that day, conceive the wild idea that New-Yorkers rather enjoy the miseries of moving and change their domiciles for the mere fun of it.

The court martial, ordered to convene at New Port (Kentucky) Barracks, for the trial of Major General DAVID E. TWIGGS, met on Wednesday. In consequence of the non-arrival of General JESUP, President of the Court, (the same officer who presided at Carlisle at the trial of Colonel SUMNER) the opening of the proceedings was delayed until Thursday. On that day, the Court being full,

The Musard Concerts have endured for three weeks, and, contrary to common managerial experience, increase in public interest and patronage. Mr. ULLMAN will, we think, find it to his advantage to continue the series for a longer period than was at first contemplated. An entertainment of this peculiar kind requires to be Introduced:

The steamship Borussia, from Southampton on the 18th of April, arrived at this port on Saturday morning. The Borussia has brought London papers of the afternoon of the 17th ult., being one day later than those received by the Arabia. The steamship Fulton arrived at Southampton on the evening of the 17th ult.

BROOKLYN AHEAD.--Our neighbors across the East River have taken a step in advance of us in a very important measure of municipal reform. The Brooklyn Common Council passed an ordinance on Friday night abolishing the existing Fire Department, and substituting in its place a system of paid firemen.

Dr. THOMPSON, the Health Officer of the port, with a party of gentlemen interested in Quarantine affairs, made an excursion to the lower bay on Saturday, visiting the various localities which have been indicated as suitable sites for Hospital and Quarantine purposes. The party, including several ladies and unprofessional persons, went on board the steamboat May Flower at 11 o'clock, With the band formerly attached to the frigate Susquehanna.

The President has received authentic information that a large body of Indians, of various hostile tribes, are collected on the head-waters of the Red River, though not so large as at first reported. Their encampments, however, extend along the banks of the river a hundred and fifty miles.

WM. S. TUCKERMAN, indicted for the robbery of the U. S. mails between Boston and New-York, pleaded guilty on Friday. He will be sentenced tomorrow. The trial has occupied the U. S. Circuit Court at New-Haven since Tuesday. The chain of evidence was complete. It was clearly proved that the robberies were committed in Connecticut.

MURDEROUS ASSAULT BY BOATMEN--A CAPTAIN OF A VESSEL THROWN OVERBOARD AT THE BATTERY.--About 6 1/2 o'clock Saturday night, Captain STILMAN SNOW, of the schooner B. W. eldridge, of Harwich, and his Mate, JAMES SNOW, came ashore at the Ballery, and without provocation were attached and severely beaten by a party of boatmen.

CITY IMPROVEMENTS.--Notwithstanding the check to investments, occasioned by the commercial revulsion of last Fall, building in New-York is moving with considerable briskness, and we hear of many contracts for first class and medium houses under way. The newly-introduced drab or buff colored stone is a favorite material in the proposed buildings, and is called for in a large number of specifications.

Mr. SLIDEL'S recent speech is correctly regarded as an unofficial exposition of the policy of the present Administration towards Cuba. Ideas of public and private war for its acquisition have been abandoned. The diplomatic world of Europe and the plainers and other Euripean residents of Cuba are advertised of that change.

A SENSIBLE VIEW--EDWARD EVERETT in a letter apologizing for not attending the dedication of a new school house, closes his letter thus: "We must not rest satisfied with a general impression that our schools are in a very satisfactory condition.

Whereas, By virtue of an act of the Genera Assembly of the Territory of Kansas, passed at the January Session, 1858, an election was held throughout the Territory for delegates to a Convention to form a Constitution for the State of Kansas, and authority given to said Convention to provide for the submission of the Constitution it should form to a vote of the people for their ratification or rejection;

The screw steamship Anglo-Saxon, from Liverpool on the 21st ult., passed Riviere du Loup on her way to Quebec yesterday afternoon, and her news is telegraphed to us from that point. The most interesting intelligence by this arrival is of a financial character.

The President's principal argument in recommending the admission of Kansas under the minority Constitution was, that thereby the contention would be taken out of Congress and localized, that is, confined to the Territory most immediately concerned in it. This, too, was the basis of the Senate report on the Message. In this desire and hope, enough members voted for the English bill to turn the scale. They proceeded upon an entire mistake.

A fire broke out this morning in the upper part of a large seven-story granite building on Federal-street, occupied in the lower stories by the Douglas Axe Company, and in the upper part by Messrs. SANBORN, BAZIN ELLSWORTH as a printing office and bindery. This building was entirely destroyed, only a portion of its walls being left standing.

I have had a charming visit in Boston, and intended to have written you before this; but the hospiltalities of the Puritan City (?) have kept me constantly employed, and at night I have been glad to sink to repose. I wish I could give you a detailed account of my visit to the studios of the artists. There are so many female artists in Boston, that they have an Art-Club by themselves,

The Canadian Steamship Company's screw steamer Anglo-Saxon, from Liverpool at about 2 o'clock P. M. on the 21st ult., passed this point at 2 o'clock this afternoon, on her way to Quebec. The principal point of her news is the presentation to the British House of Comnons of the Budget showing an excess of four millions sterling of expenditures over estimated receipts, and recommending the taxation of Irish whisky and stamped bankers checks.

FIRE.--The alarm of fire about 1 o'clock yesterday morning, in Jersey City, was caused by the burning of an old shed in the rear of Newark-avenue between Barrow-street and Jersey-avenue. Damage about $50.

A stranger who should visit Paris only for the Holy Week would think favorably of the church-going habits of its people. This year, more than usual, the churches have been crowded with worshipers, and the theatres on the other hand deserted. During Lent the Catholic Church lost the last of its great preachers in activity--the Father RAVIGNAN.

Sabbath morning last will no doubt be long remembered as a great day in the annals of Mr. BEECHER'S Church. Never have we seen the building more densely crowded. The occasion was the reception of not fewer than 190 persons into the fellowship of the Church, of whom 163 were by profession, the remainder by letter. It was known that various iadividuals, about 50 in number, would receive baptism.

RIOT AT QUEBEC--THE MILITARY CALLED OUT, --At Quebec, on the night of the 26th ult., the City Hall was the scene of a disgraceful riot. The Council held a special meeting to consider a proposal to increase the taxes on immovable estate. The acting Mayor had taken tile precaution to assemble the police force, and to require a picket of troops to be under arms.

Before the Hon. Justice Ingraham. Mary Cramer vs. John H. Cramer.--Judgment of divorce granted. Roberts vs. Voorhies.--Motion granted without costs. Before the Hon. Justice Davies. Rosa Maretzek Marini vs. Ignacio Marini.-Judgment of divorce granted. Seamen's Savings Bank vs. Duncan Maefarian.-Order to reappoint Edward Timpson receiver of mortgage premises.

Wm. Lloyd Garrison wrote a letter to the Orsini sympatbisers in Boston last week. In it he held the following language: Your meeting will receive no sanction from the American press, people, or Government. How can America sympathise with any struggle for freedom in the Old World ? She holds every seventh person of her vast population in fetters of iron, as a brute beast, as an article of merchandise.

DECREPITUDE.--Our dilapidated old friend of the Herald seems to be greatly concerned about our Western correspondence. As we were able to give the public the benefit of Mr. FREDERICK LOBA'S experience among the Mormons in advance of all our cotemporaries, and a great deal in advance of the Herald, that invalid sheet in quite sure the news cannot be true, or at all events that it is not of the least importance.

The Duke DE MALAKOFF had hardly arrived in London when a notable opportunity was afforded him for observing the effect produced upon the public feeling of Great Britain by the recent demonstrations of his master at the Tuileries and of his subalterns in the army.

In steamship New York, from Glasgone-Mrs. MCArthut, Mrs.Ducan and 2 children, Mrs.Farlene, Mrs.Alexander, Mrs.Turner. Miss J.Main ,miss Moore Miss Main, Dr.Getty, The Rev, Win Robertson, The rev. Thos Pullar, the Rev. Thos J.Scott. Mr. Andrew Main, Frederick Fall, Chas. Gardinar, Robt. McFarlane. G. Moody. A. S. Waite, Robt. Collarb, John Lander. Adam Pearson, John L. Blakie, James Lindsay, James Black.

The Anniversary of the Board of Foreign Missions was celebrated last evening at the Scotch Presbyterian Church in Fourteenth-street near Sixthavenue. The exercises were opened with religious services, after which an abstract of the annual report was read.

A PATRIOT WITHOUT AN ORGAN.--Mr D'ARCY McGEE is an unfortunate gentleman. Having forsaken the people of Boston to found a newspaper establishment in Montreal, he secured an election to Parliament before he had fairly warmed the New Era into life; and now, having been sent to Parliament, he sees his paper die a natural death, for lack of a locum tenens.

WALLACE--FERGUSON.--In this City, on Monday, May 3, at the Church of the Divine Unity, by the Rev. E. H Chapin. THOMAS WALLACE to Miss CHRISTIANA FERGUSON, all of this City. BEACH--MAHER--In this City, on Sunday, May 2, by the Rev. Dulcan Dunbar, D. J. BEACH to Miss CECELIA MAHER, all of this City.

Under foreclosure, Mr. A. H. MULIER sold tile two-story brick house and lot south side Twenty-firststrect, 90 feet-east of Second-avenue, lot 20x92, for $3.000. CHARLES E. STRONG, referee. Mr. Gus. A. CONOVER has commenced excavating the 33-feet lot east side Fifth-avenue, between Thirtyfourth and Thirty-fifth streets, with a view to erect either one large $40,000 house, or two small ones. He will probably decide in favor of the smaller size, as being a safer investment.

POLITICAL.--One of the City Democratic Clubs fired a salute in the park Last night in honor, we believe, of the passage of the Kansas bill. Through some misunderstanding as to the precise object of the demonstration, or some lake of expertness on the gunner's part., the intervals between the discharges were somewhat long-and the effect was not unlike that of minute guns at funerals.

To the Editor of the Union: I ask you to publish the enclosed letter of Governor WALKER in justification of my vote and that of my colleague , Mr. LAWNENCE, to - day , in favor of the Conference Bill. The letter explains itself. It is a manly vindication of our much - abused judgment. I understand that it meets with Gov. STANTON'S approval. I hope so.

The Board met at 1 o'clock P. M. yesterday, all the Commissioners present, and Gen. NYE in the Chair. Hon. THOMAS B. STILLMAN, the newly ap. pointed Police Commissioner, took his seat with the Board for the first time. The minutes of the last meeting were read and approved.

One of the stereotyped sarcasms with which patriotic journalists delight to flog our dilatory diplomats is borrowed from the brilliant "foreign" practice of the English Government. Our own authorities,

FLOUR quiet and firm. WHEAT dull, $1 08@$1 12 ; White, $1 15@$1 25. CORN less active, 69c.@ 70c. WHISKY steady. PROVISIONS unchanged. BALTIMORE, Monday, May 3. FLOUR dull at 84 25@54 37 1/2. WHEAT steady. CORN higher--Yellow 65c.@66c. PROVISIONS dull and drcoping. Bulk Shoulders, 6 3/4c.@7c.

ROW IN AN EATING SALOON.--Between 2 and 3 o'clock on Sunday morning, Sebastian Velaisne and Peter Ansing, two Italians, got into an altercation with a Spanoiard named Ascarlio Silvia, at the eating saloon No. 150 Church street. The Italians beat Silvia badly, and stabbed him in the arm and shoulders so severely that it was necessary to take him to the City Hospital.

We took the pains to obtain this forenoon from our city banks, who courteously furnished the information, their respective conditions to-day in circulation, deposits and specie. These are the most important items, and the statement is a fortnight in advance of the Comptroller-General's report.

Edward Dessling, the Prussian, charged with forgery, whose case has caused so much comment and excitement, was tried at Paducah on the 27th ult., and acquitted, Judge Williams deciding that the depositions taken in Prussia could not be admitted as competent evidence. Directly after the result was known, Mr. Lepau, and the Prussian police officer, were arrested upon a charge of false imprisonment.

No. 75.--Francis Warner v. Cephas H. Morton at al.--Justice McLEAN delivered the opinion of the Court, affirming the judgment of the United States Court for the Northern District of Illinois, with cost and interest.

A correspondent of the Spiritual Telegraph writes from Philadelphia that the famous Dr. Hare is experiencing manifestations in his laboratory of a very extraordinary character. It is no less a performance, according to this credulous gentleman, than the fulfillment of the dreams of the days of alchemy.

The following is the Report of the number o Deaths in the City during the week ending on Saturday last: Men, 72; women, 82; boys, 131; girls 122; total, 407, Adults, 154; children, 253; males,' 203; females, 204; colored persons, 7. DISEASS.

LECTURE ON THE HORSE AND HORSEMANSHIP. This evening, (Tuesday,) at the Medical College in East Thirteenth-street, Capt. RALSTON, formerly a Veterinary Surgeon in the British Cavalry, will deliver a second and concluding lecure upon the

THE VICTIMS AT THE BOSTON FEDERAL-STREET PIRE BOSTON, Monday, May 3. It has been ascertained that CUTTING and TurTLE, both firemen, were the only two persons killed outright at the Federal-strect fire on Sunday morning. They will be buried this afternoon from the Harvard-street Baptist Church, and the entire fire department is expected to attend the obsequles.

We publish, in another part of this morning's impression, an important letter from our correspondent, on the present condition of Mexico. The people of this country know, full well, that the Republic on the other side of the Rio Grande is and has been wretchedly misgoverned.
LOUISIANA AND MAINE.--The monotony of Executive life in Louisiana has been agreeably diversified by a series of letters which have passed between Governor WICKLIFFE and His Excellency of Maine.

Capt. Dow, of the Panama Railroad Company's Steamer Columbus, writes to Mr. HOADLEY that during his last voyage up the coast, he found, at several of his usual points of call, much difficulty in effecting a landing on account of an unusually heavy surf which prevailed, and which was not peculiar to any one part of the coast. He arrived at Acajutla, on his return trip, on the 27th of March.

Congress did not distinguish itself greatly yesterday. Whether from exhaustion occasioned by the Kansas struggle or some other cause, there was little disposition to work in either house. Members hardly seem to realize that only five weeks of the session remain.

STREET COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE--NEW APPOINTEES SWORN INTO OFFICE-THAT PRIVATE SAFE.Yeaterday forenoon DANIEL E. DZLAVAN, Esq., appointed by Mr. COOPER, Deputy Collector of Assessments, and JOHN B. CORLIES, Esq., the newly appointed Superintendent of Repairs and Supplies, having given the required bonds, presented themselves before the Mayor, and were duly sworn into office.

LAWSON.--In this City, on Monday, may 3. after a lingering illness. Mrs. PAMELIA, relict of Capt. charles Lawson, in the 53d year of her age. A funeral service will be held at the residence of her son-in law. Jas J. Hull. No. 2 4th-st., this evening. at 8 o'clock. The remains will be taken to Tarrytown for interment. BROWN.--In this City, on Monday, May 3, GEORGE E. BROWN, in the 36th year of his age.

There was a considerable number of persons in the Park, last evening, who fired Marshall RYNDERS' cannon, and otherwise exhibited their gratification at the passage of ENGLISH'S Kansas bill. The cannon firing; commenced at 7 o'clock, and 112 guns were fired, this being the affirmative number of votes cast in the House, in favor of the bill.

Before Judge Russell. The May Term of the Court of General Sessions commenced yesterday, before Judge RUSSELL. The calendar is quite heavy, including 26 cases of grand larceny, 19 of burglary, 3 of murder, 5 of arson, and various other charges, making 94 in all. The following gentlemen were impanneled as a Grand July:

An injunction was issued this morning, at the suit of THURLOW WEED Co., proprietors of the Evening Journal, prohibiting GIDEON J. TUCKEE, Secretary of State, SANDFORD E. CHURCH, Comptroller, and ISAAC VANDERPOOL, State Treaurer, from designating a new State paper instead of the Journal.

The task of keeping up a correspondence with you--of illustrating, by every semi-monthly mail, the changes and gyrations in Mexican politics and Government--is one that turns stale and distasteful on your correspondent's hands, from the entire want of one ray of hope, and from the absence of one favorable feature in the dying throes of this distracted and misgoverned country.

There are no prominent features to notice in the past week. The news which we have received from Europe since our last advices of 27th April is unimportant in commercial matters, and the position of our market is without change. The same superabundance of money continues to rule, also the same dullness in business generally, absence of speculation at the Stock Exchange, and very limited demand for investment securities.

The morning hour was occupied in a discussion on a motion by Mr. CHANDLER, of Michigan, to appropriate $50,000 to finish the channel of St. Clair Flats. The debate assumed somewhat of a party color, the Republicans wishing to make it a test vote on the question of internal improvements.

The Board of Councilmen met on Monday evening, Councilman CORNELL in the Chair. An ordinance appertaining to running steam cars in New-York, was read, and referred to the Committee on Ordinances. Its principal feature is the limitation of speed to five miles within the hour. The report on paving Fifty-second-street was read and adopted.

In Comptroller FLAGG'S report of the receipts and expenditures of the Corporation of the City of New-York, for the year 1853, he directs the attention of the Common Council to a newly-discoverd piece of land, lying west of West-street, and which it was supposed the City had a right to claim as its property. The Comptroller says, in his report:

The STATE PRINTING.--Another legal controversy is threatened about the State Printing. The Legislature in April, 1854, passed a law authorizing the Secretary of State Comptroller and Treasurer to contract with the publisher of a daily newspaper at Albany for the publication of all legal notices at certain stipulated rates.

During last week I was engaged in traveling over a portion of the Territory, visiting Lawrence, Shawnee, Lecompton, Tecumseh and Topeka, with a view of talking with men of all parties in different sections, hearing their views, and thus judging for myself what really is the sentiment of the people of the Territory in relation to the contest between Free and Slave Labor, which still impends here, though it is nearly over.

The steamship Ariel, from Southampton on the afternoon of tile 21st ult, arrived at this port yesterday afternoon. We receive, by the Ariel, London papers of the 21st of April, and obtain from them some additional intelligence of interest. The Acquittal of Simon Bernard. We have already published a full abstract of the trial of Dr. BERNARD, in London, for complicity in the Orsini murders of the 14th of January last.

The Royal Mail steamship Europa, Capt. LEITCH, left Liverpool at 4 1/2 o'clock P. M. of Saturday, April 24, and arrived at Halifax at 10 o'clock A. M. on Tuesday, May 4. The Europa reports, April 24, passed the American ships S. R. Mallory, of Key West, Ocean Pearl, of Portland. West Point, of New-York, City of New-York, and British ship Talavora, all bound into Liverpool.

GENERAL TWIGGS DEFENCE BEFORE HIS COURT MARTIAL. In February, Gen. TWIGGS addressed the following letter to the Secretary of War, after receiving the order to publish the censure upon himself. It was read on the last day of the Court martial at Newport Bamacks: SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Feb. 6, 1858.

Saturday was a brilliant day for the Association. The morning meeting was the most interesting of the session thus far, while the excursion of the afternoon was deliciously fresh and novel in its display. There was a spice of personality about the meeting that gave it zest, while the discussion in the Zoological Section was a treat equally agreeable to the scientific and the popular parts of the audience.

On May Day the citizens of Dedham, Mass., celebrated the anniversary by assembling to set out fifty young trees along the public highway. The trees were mostly elms. When the job was done the amateur agriculturists adjourned to the Agricultural Hall, where a repast was set out, to wind up the ceremony of setting up.

THE STREET COMMISSIONER'S APPOINTMENTS-DAVID KISSNER AND GERSHON COHEN, appointed by Mr. cooper Deputy Collectors of Assessments, and JAMES TAILOR appointed Keeper of the City Hall, having given the requirred hands. Gunover and R.P.COMPTON gave the required sureities for Mr.courn William became surety for Mr. TAYLOR.

ANDESSON, in which three. fourths of the combatats were killed on both sides.

JENEINS--OBBOHN.--In this City, on Sunday, May 2 by the Rev. Chas. J. Jones, HENRY JENKINS to FANNY A. M., eldest daughter of Capt. Morris Osborn, all of this City.

About 1 1/2 A.M., on Sunday, an officer of the Second Police District discovered flames issuing from the book-bindery and printing office of BYRAM BINLEY, (formetl) SANBORN, BAZIN ELLSWORTH,) from an upper room, known as the " Girls' room," No. 137 Federal street. This building and the one adjoining were five-stories in height, new, and with a substantial front of granite.

Information of the most confidential nature, from a source entitled to the very highest credit, confirms me in the supposition which was suggested in a letter to the TIMES last week, to the effect that LODA, the Mormon. whose statements you have published, is really a cunningly disguised agent of BRIGHAM YOUNG.

The President sent to the Senate a communication from the Secretary of State, inclosing the correspondence relative to the recent outrage on the American missionary family at Jaffa. Laid on the table to be printed. A resolution was adopted that from Monday next the Senate meet daily at 11 A. M.

We received the following letter from Mr. JOHN VAN BUREN, in relation to the Mayor's action in the Devlin matter: To the Editor of the Tribune: DEAR SIR.--Will you allow me a little space in your paper to reply to the charges against Mayor TIEMANN, which are contained in your editorial columns today.

GASSIN.--In this City, on Monday, May 3, ELIZA, widow of the late James Gassin, aged 75 years. The friends of the family are respectfully invite to attend her funeral, from her late residence. No. 57 Franklin-St, this (Wednesday afternoon, at 2 o'clock. McKAY.--In this City, on Tuesday, May 4, of measles, ISABEL McKAY, youngest daughter of Hugh and Mary McKay.

The Cunard steamship Europa, from Liverpool on the 24th ult.. arrived at Halifax yesterday, bringing three days' later advices From Europe. The news by this arrival is not specially important, but presents some features of interest. In the British Parliament the Government had declared that no further proceedings would be taken against Dr. BERNARD.

The accession of FORMES to the concert forces of the Academy is a decided step in the right direction--which means the popular direction. On the operatic stage, Mr. FORMES is more remarkable as an actor than as a singer--his reputation in the last respect depending on a few moments of electrical splendor.

We need scarcely commend to public attention the letters of our Special Correspondent in Kansas. The reports hitherto received from that Territory, not only by us, but by most of our Eastern cotemporaries, have been so deeply tinged with party feeling as to command little confidence from the distant and dispassionate community to which they were addressed.

The Vanderbilt steamship Ariel, of the Bremen and Southampton Line, arrived at this port yesterday with a large number of passengers, after an absence of about four months. It will be remembered that she put back to Cork in January with a broken shaft, after experiencing one of the severest gales of Winter.

An open rapture look place to-day between the President and Scator PUGH, concerning the Marshal for the Northern District of Ohio, and other Ohio appointments. The President used very severe languange, and PUGH left in disgust and very angry. The President is writing a message on Cuba, based on the ideas of the Ostend Manifesto.

The affairs of the Street Commissioner's office attract an unusual and very gratifying degree of public attention. The contest in which it has been involved for the past year will not be without good results if it shall have the client of impressing the public mind with a sense of the importance of this Department, and of the necessity of having its affairs conducted with a paramount regard to the public good.

SINNING AGAINST A SINNER.--John Jordan, of Ashtabula County, Ohio, on Sunday night encountered Catherine Long, a disreputable female, and accompanied her to her den in Church-street. On coming away he found he had been robbed of $110. The woman was arrested and locked up for trial, but the money was not recovered.

The Government of Mr. BUCHANAN will have it all their own way now for a brief period of time. They have only to decide what they will do, and to let the country understand what it is. They have shuffled off the "mortal coil" of Kansas for a few months, no matter at what expense to the Democratic Party which lives by the breath of their nostrils;

The vessel reported in the foreign news by the Europa as fallen in with abandoned, and a mate and three men put on board by the Louise at Queenstown, is supposed to have been the ship Harvest Queen, from this port April 4 for Liverpool. She belongs to CHAS. 11. MARSHALL'S line of Liverpool and Ne w-York packets.

Board of Education--The New Members Present. A regular meeting of this Board was held last evening, President SMITH in the Chair, and a quorum of members present. The newly elected members were present, and took their seats.
Our Army in Flanders never swore worse than various gentlemen interested in the new volunteer regiments have to-day, over the decision of the President in regard to them.

The transfer of the Kansas question from the Capitoline Hill to the "grave-yard of Governors" has been the engrossing topic during the week now. drawing to a close, and, as I write, the Marine Band are playing "Hall Columbia" beneath the window of Senator BROWN, of Mississippi.

The case of WM. FULLER, charged with an attempt to negotiate a forged draft upon the PostOffice department, was resumed yesterday before Mr. Commissioner BETTS. The arrest was made a week ago. The draft was for $5,000, dated Nov. 1, 1834,

We are progressing slowly with the Cable. Stoppages are frequent, and in answer to our inquiries we are told that it is caused by experiments; but the real cause is, we coil much faster on board our vessel than they do on board the Agamemnon, and to prevent our getting ahead of them, they cause a delay.

THE TRANSATLANTIC TELEGRAPH.--Preparationsforrenewingthe attempt to lay down the wires for this great enterprise are making very good progress. Meantime the experiments that are made upon the cable are not calculated to remove all doubt as to the feasibility of telegraphic communication through three thousand miles of submerged wire.

SIR : I have read a printed copy of your speech, delivered in the Senate on the 8th inst., sent to a gentleman of this city under your frank. It is, therefore, a copy, I presume, approved by yourself.

The Harlem Steam Navigation Company, which placed a little passenger boat called the Sylvan Shore on the route from this City to Harlem, a year ago, in opposition to the Railroad, have found the experiment so satisfactory that they had another built-almost a copy of the first--to run in conjunction with her. She is called the Sylvan Grove, and was built by TUOMAS COLYER. The two will perform hourly trips,

SHEPARD.--In this City, on Wednesday, May 5, HENRY C., son of Rlisha H. Ruth Cary Shepard, aged 8 months and 2 days. The funeral will take place from the residence of his ??. No. 130 West 39th-st., on Friday morning, at 10 o'clock. The friends of the family are invited to attend. CASHMAN.--In this City, on Tuesday, May 4, Miss REBECCA M., youngest daughter of the late Daniel Cashman.

The Chairman, at 1 1/2 P. M., introduced to the Assembly Dr. HAYES, of the Kane Aretic Expedition. The Doctor--who is a man of prepossessing personal appearance, not large, though considerably larger than Dr. KANE--was received with repeated rounds of applause. He stated that his purpose in appearing before the Association was to direct attention to a profitable field of scientific inquiry.

The following appointments in the Street Commissioner's office were announced yesterday. We give the name, salary, and political complexion, as far as known, of each: Contract Clerk--Charles W. Lawrence, Rep., $2,000. First Book-Keeper--Charles M. Livingston, Rep., $2,000.

We have already mentioned that on Saturday night a crowd of people serenaded the President, congratulating him upon the passage of the Kansas bill. The President appeared on the balcony, and addressed the multitude as follows: GENTLEMEN: I feel very much honored by the kindness which you have displayed in coming in such respectable numbers to give me a serenade.

The Senate proceedings yesterday were unusually interesting, the principal subject discussed being the Oregon Bill. But before this was taken up, a joint resolution introduced by Mr. SEWARD, was adopted, granting to the widow of Captain HERNDON three years' full pay of her husband, amounting to $7,500. The resolution passed by a vote of 32 to 8.

The following was accidentally omitted in the transcribing for the Press of the foreign news by the Europa last night: The Madras import market was pretty active, but there was rather less demand for money. Exchanges for documents 2s. 1 1/2d.

The morning hour was occupied in the consideration of private bills relating to California. A joint resolution, of which Mr. SEWARD was the author, giving three years full pay of her deceased husband to the widow of Captain HERNDON, amounting to $7,500, was taken up. Messrs. IVERSON, of Georgia, and SLIDELL, of Louisiana, opposed it.

TUCKERMAN, THE MAIL ROBBER.--On Tuesday, Judge INGERSLL, of the United States Circuit Court, sitting at New-Haven, sentenced WM. S. TUCKERMAN to twenty-one years at hard labor in the Connecticut State Prison.

VIRGINIA RAILROADS AND THE VIRGINIA PRESS.--We learn from the Richmond Examiner that the managers of Virginia railroads have abolished the dead-head system, as far, at least, as the Press is concerned; whereupon that paper declares that "it is just what might have been expected of selfish, heartless, soulless corporation."

The United States steamship Cahawba, J. D. BULLOCK, Commander, from New-Orleans via Havana, arrived at this port yesterday, having left the latter place on the 30th ult. From Havana very little of importance presents itself.

We are glad that some change is to be made in the mode of doing the public printing for the Government at Washington. There is no department of the public service which has been more completely under the control of plunderers and jobbers than this.

The theatrical season is drawing rapidly to a close, and artists of all denominations are preparing for a migratory flight to other shores. Mr. BURTON announces that the present campaign will terminate on Saturday-a hard-fought one, and not more than Crimean in its results, we fear. The Broadway is already closed-when to reopen we know not. Mr.

The Special Committee of the House on the Pacific Railroad will meet to-morrow, in the hope of agreeing to a report comprising a bill for the commencemert of the work. But the diversity of opinion is so great that there is no reasonable expectation of combining a majority of the Committee in favor of any one project. The Chairman, Mr. PHELPS, of Missouri, is an able advocate of the Central route plan.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Sir, in a paragraph in your paper of April 30, there is a statement of the Court of Kentucky having awarded a mandamus to compel the City of Marysville to coliect taxes to pay interst due on the Bonds by said city. Your publication is all right in its description, but the mistake is the name of the city. It should be Maysville, instead of Marysville,

I.--ANSAS POLITICS-State of Public Setitiment in the Territory-Lecompton certain to be Rejected.--From our Sperial Correspondent. II.--THE SCIENTIFIC CONVENTION AT BALTIMORE--Notices of the Papers Read-The Festivities of the Occasion, our Special Correspondent.

The Europa's mails reached this City, from Boston, last evening. We receive, by this arrival, London and Liverpool papers of the 24th ult. There is not much intelligence in addition to that published in our telegram from Halifax. Two debates, that took place in the British Parliament, will be found interesting. One, in the House of Lords, is on telegraphic communication between Europe and America.

ANOTHR FIGHT IN KANSAS.-There has been another bloody fight in Kansas, in the vicinity of Fort Scott. The Chicago Tribune has the details, and gives the point as follows: "Dr. BLAKE LITTLE, of Fort Scott, a member of the Felon Convention and ex-officio U. S. Marshal made a foray with a company of U. S. troops on a band of fifteen or twenty FreeState men.

SIR: Your communication of the 5th ultimo,on the subject of Ocean Mail Steamship Service, has been received. You name the following routes, memorials for the establishment of which, you state, have been referred to your Committee, viz.: Between New-York and New-Orleans and San Frnncisco.

TIME'S CHANGES.--The Albany papers of yesterday record the death, in that city, of the venerable ARCHIBALD MCINTYRE, one of the most respectable citizens of the State, who filled some of the most important public offices, and during his long and active career preserved his reputation free from taint or reproach.

Report of the Joint Committee on Frauds--Rear Admiral Pasha's Reception--Correspondence. The Board of Aldermen met last evening, President CLANCY in the Chair. A resolution was offered by Alderman MURRAY to allow the Superintendent of Lands and Places $250 for a horse and wagon to enable him to discharge his duties. Referred.

SHOTWELL.--In this City, on Thursday, May 6, ABRAHAM SBOTWELL in the 93d year of his age. His relatives and friends. and those of his family are invited to attend his funeral, without further invitation, from hi late residence. No 218 West 28ch-st., on Saturday, Msy 8 at 3 o'clock P. M.

THE KINGS COUNTY TRUANT INSTITUTION.--This institution was first opened on the 24 of December last, at Flatbush, since which time 73 boys and 10 girls, ranging in age from 5 to 14 years, have been admitted. Of this number 13 have been discharged. Of the whole number 56 were placed there for truancy 14 homeless, 2 for intoxication, and 11 for petit larceny.

BENNETT--SHAPTER,--In this City, on Thursday at the Church of the Holy Communion, by the Rev. Dr. Mublenberg. Mr. JOHN W. BENNETT of Minnesota, to R. JENNIE SHAPTER, daughter of the late Peter Shapter, of New - York. TAYLOR--DEXTER,--In this City, on Wednesday evening, May 5 by the Rev. Jesse T. Peck, D. D., Wm. M. TAYLOR, to LYDIA J. UEXTER, both of this City.

The business transacted during the morning hour was of an uninteresting nature. The bill for the admission of Oregon was postponed and that for the repeal of the fishing bounties act taken up. Mr. HAMLIN, of Maine, addressed the Senate in opposition to the bill. He objected to Mr. CLAY'S sneer, that the fisheries are merely a local interest.

[The First Day's proceedings will be found on the Second Page of this morning's TIMES. The following letter reached us at too late an hour to be given in its proper place.] The session reopened at the Smithsonian Institution's Lecture-room this (Wednesday) morning, with an act of courtesy--inviting Dr. DELAFIELD, of NewYork, to a seat on the platform. In my last letter I told you that the McClintock grief was assuaged.

It is now eleven years since the American Medical Association held its first session. It was an experimcnt-a spirited effort to see whether the annual convocation of physicians, for which Dr. N. S. DAVIS, then of Binghamton, and now of Chicago, had been agitating for so long, was practicable.

The crevasse opposite our city continues in full force. The water is still spreading, and there are other very serious crevasses above the city, which are doing immense damage to the crops. The river as yet, shows no signs of falling. NEW-ORLEANS, Thursday, May 6. The crevasse still continues, and all efforts to stop it seem to be abandoned.
A short time back the Hon. HENRY WILSON submitted, in the Senate, the following resolution, which was considered by unanimous consent, and agreed to:

Bogert, Eadie.

The Fairfield Races, at Richmond, were largely attended on Monday. The Dodwell stakes were run for ; nett proceeds, $7,250. T. T. W. DODWELL'S brown colt, by Revenue, won the race easily in two straight beats, over four competitors. 1:48.

The far-famed city of Lawrence is 30 miles distant from this point by staging over one of the finest natural roads in the world, except for a distance of a few miles, in crossing a strip of bottom land, evidently once the bed of a river.

CLINGMAN'S resolution to abrogate the ClaytonBulwer Treaty was killed in the House by its ostensible friends to-day. Just as the vote was being taken, word was privately passed around on the Democratic side that the Administration really did not wish it to pass, and enough votes were accordingly changed to put it out of the way for the present.

The accident to the steamer James Adger, which resulted in the death of three of the firemen, occurred 40 miles north of Frying. Pan Shoal. LAW RENCE WALLACE died in six hours after receiving the scalds, and was buried at sea. JEREMIAH BBIDGWOOD and PETER RILEY, died, one in 20, and the other in 40 hours after the accident. They were buried in Charleston on Sunday, May 2.

In cases of impeachment, sworn charges have, in the first instance, to be sent in to the Governor of the State, who, thereupon, gives notice to the party implicated. No charges whatever against Judge RUSSELL, as has been intimated in a New-York paper, have reached the Executive Department.

Prior to his departure he will give three operatic entertainments at Burton's Theatre, commencing on Monday next. The conductor is redoubtable MAX MARETZEK, and Mr. RONCONI, associate artists will be Mme.

The Rochester papers publishes the following curious letter from MARION IRA STOUT, now under sentence of death for the murder of CHARLES W. LITTLES: The trial is past. It is these terrific ordeals that either sweep the immortal mind from its proud throne, and crush it in the dust, or else call forth its vast energies to meet the killing storm, with a firmness which nothing can overturn.

NEGROES AND CHINAMEN IN OREGON.--The Constitution under which Oregon is asking admission to the Union prohibits free negroes from entering its territory. It also contains a clause denying citizenship to natives of China. The prohibition in respect to persons of African descent was made the ground of animadversion and objection in the debate which occurred on the Oregon bill in the Senate last Wednesday.

STARTLING EXPOSURE OF THE MILK TRADE OF NEW-YORK AND BROOKLYN. Are you aware what kind of milk you are drinking? Are you aware that over seven thousand children die every year in New-York and Brooklyn from drinking swill milk?

OLD ENGLAND REVIVED IN NEW-ENGLAND.The old English custom of going a-Maying on the first day of May, appears to have been pretty generally observed in Massachusetts this Spring by all sorts of out-door jollities among the rural populations. The Postmaster-General has written a letter to the Chairman of the Committee on Post Roads in the House urging the diminution of revenue from the falling off in our commerce as a reason for making no new appropriations for ocean mail service.

Every new disclosure of frauds upon the City Treasury is considered an occasion for flesh surprise. The Comptroller sends in a fresh report,-a fresh committee is appointed,--fresh exclamations go up from the public, and then we wait patiently, knowing we shall not be obliged to wait long, for the "next customer." Our surprise is misplaced.

A TROUBLESOME INDIVIDUAL.--Mr. ELI THAYR is a very large thorn in the side of our Southern brethren. They worry and frighten themselves with him beyond conception or belief. In fact he answers the same purpose for the chivalry as a church-yard ghost among children.

HAGGART.--In this City, on Friday, May 7, Mrs. CATHBINE, wile of Duncan Haggart, in the 51st year of her age. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend her funeral, from her late residence, No. 181 West 21st-st.. to-morrow (Sunday) afternoon, at 4 o'clock. Her remains will be taken to Lastchester, on Monday morning, tor interment.

To the Editor of the New - York Times: The Independent has played its last card. Having exhausted its appeals to sectional and political prejudice, it is suddenly silent on the Slavery issue, and in this week's number confines itself to the Finance and Colporteur departments of the Tract Society.

FIRE DEPARTMENT ELECTION.--The annual election of the Jersey City Fire Department took place on Wednesday night. The following were the successful candidates: For Chief Engineer-Samuel A. French; no opposition. Assistants-First Ward-Adrian B. Reynolds. Second Ward-James McLonghlin.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In your edition of yesterday, your Baltimore correspondent, detailing incidents connected with the excursion of the Scientific Association, speaks of DEAKE as the author of the "Star Spangled Banner." He should have said KEY, not DRAKE. JOSEPH RobMAN DRAKE'S "Ode to the American Flag" must have been floating through his memory. "Honor to whom honor Is due."

The Anniversary of some of the important Benevolent Societies commences to-morrow. The Rev. Dr. ANTHON preaches before the New-York Bible Society in the Rev. Dr. TYNG'S Church; the Rev. Dr. SHAW, of Rochester, preaches before the Ameriican Home Missionary Society in the Rev. Dr. CHEEVER'S Church: and the Rev. Dr. MCDONALD,

I learn authoritatively that the Mormon Peace Commissioners have no authority to offer any proposition to BRIGHAM YOUNG in order to avoid a conflict. They are sent solely for the purpose of apprising BRIGHAM YOUNG of the Government's determination to put down resistance on his part by force, to warn him of the consequences, and to advise him to submit.

CLASSIFICATION OF THE ALDERMEN.--The members of the present Board of Aldermen from the Wards with odd enumerations hold office for one year; those from Wards with even enumerations hold office for two years. Hereafter each alderman will be elected for two years.

A WESTERN JUDGE CONGRATULATING A HOMICIDE.--A young man, named HARDESTY, a year ago, in Boone County, Ky., killed one GRUBB, who had seduced HARDESTY'S sister. Mr. Bright on the Case of the Imprisoned English Engineers in Naples. Mr. BRIGHT, M. P., has written the following letter to a friend in Glasgow: DEAR SIR: I am not surprised at the sympathy felt and expressed in Glasgow for the English Engineers who have suffered so much in Naples. I hope I need not say that I fully unite with you and your neighbors in that sympathy.

THE AMERICAN ASSOCIATION.--The scientific body which has just closed its annual session at Baltimore, is to migrate Northward next year. It will next sit at Springfield, Mass. None of its sessions have been held in Massachusetts since the meeting in Cambridge, eight years ago.

The Third Day of the Session was not as spirited as the preceding, still it had many sharp passages, and there were some interesting exercises of a more purely professional nature. There was no disposition, however, to listen to prosy or merely valuable papers.

THE POWHATAN AT CAPE TOWN.--A letter from Lieut. HABERSHAN, published in the Philadelphia Ledger of yesterday, gives particulars of the voyage of the Powhatan from St. Helena to Cape Town. She arrived at the latter port on the 19th of February, after a passage of eighteen days.

The public will be gratified to learn, from the correspondence published yesterday, between FUAD PACHA and Mr. BROWN, and Mr. BROWN and Mayor TIEMANN, and Mayor TIEMANN and the Common Council, that Messrs. BOOLE and VAN TINE, with their ham-sandwiches and sherry, have been the means of strengthening those harmonious relations which exist between the Turkish Government and our own.

DEATH OF A VETERAN ENGLISH EDITOR.The last English mail brought intelligence of the death of ROBERT STEPHEN RINTOUL, with whose editorial labors American readers have long been familiar, though from the strictly anonymous principle adopted in British periodicals, very few is this side of the world knew to whose master mind they were indebted. Mr. RINTOUL was one of the oldest and most able of London editors.

A WOMAN'S RIGHT WHICH OUGHT NOT TO BE QUESTIONED.--Among the important questions which have been debated by the Scientific Convention in Baltimore is one, whether women generally shall be eligible to membership of their body.

Criminal proceedings were instituted yesterday against ABRAHAM D. RUSSELL, City Judge, BERNARD ULLMAN, Lessee and Manager of the Academy of Music, and five men acting as officers of the Court of Sessions, for their alleged illegal action connected with the recent arrest at the Academy of Music, of Mr. GEORGE WILKES, Editor of Porter's Spirit of the Times, and Mr. JOHN DARCIE, the musical and dramatic critic of the paper.

The first message of Governor BUCKINGHAM to the Connecticut Legislature, delivered the 5th inst., is mainly taken up with State affairs. Economy in the expenditure of the public funds is strongly recommended. Scrutiny of claims preferred against the State is urged as indispensable. Last year the expenses of Government were $271,470. The Governor omits to mention the receipts.

Our ship the Niagara's sailing qualities, and her performances under steam during the passage to this port, were all that any one could desire or her admirers possibly hope for. She was tried under canvas alone, under a press of sail, as well as under light and easy sail, then under steam only, and again with both canvas and steam united, in fact under all circumstances, and her performances were truly wonderful.

In spite of the fuss made about the right of the people in every new State to regulate their own affairs, the current debates in Congress show how little importance attaches to theoretical systems and platforms, when they conflict with desired action upon specific subjects.

Mrs. PHOEBE WESTLAKE, a widow residing in this place, was yesterday arrested on suspicion of poisoning several persons in the village, and last night destroyed herself by taking arsenic. Before the suicide, she confessed that she had administered poison at different times to a Mrs. FIELDER, who died about two weeks since very suddenly.

RECIPROCITY WITH CANADA.-Complaints are made by the Canadians that the objects of the Reciprocity Treaty, so far as they are concerned, have of late been thwarted by a Mr. MOORE, claiming to be the American ConsulGeneral at Montreal.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I would ask tile privilege, through your valuable columns, to call public attention to a few suggestions in connection with what I have understood to be the plan determined on respecting the " Croton Reservoir," or, as some term i, "Manhatta Lake," in the proposed new Central Park.

The elects of the Mayor's crusade against the gamblers and policy dealers are being neutralized in a very curious manner. One, at least, of the Magistrtes of this City devotes himself steadily to the business of setting the prisoners at liberty immediately after their arrest, without any examination and without assigning any reason.

For instance, you make the Vanderbilt's time to the Needles 9 days, 17 hours, 45 minutes, when, in fact, according to your own figures, it is 9 days, 19 hours, 45 minutes.

A CONGRESSIONAL CYCLOPEDIA.--This is preeminently the era of dictionaries and cyclopedias; popular information of all kinds assumes the encyclopaedic form of publication, and the newspaper has become the most comprehensive of all cyclopaedias. But newspaper are too comprehensive for common use, when they are bound into volumes, so it is necessary to condense them into more convenient dimensions.

TESTIMONIAL TO AN EDITOR.--Mr. B. D. KILLIAN, late editor of the Tablet-(a Catholic Journal published in this City)-and a gentleman of varied accomplishments, was presented with a gold watch, accompanied by an appropriate address, on the evening of the 5th instant, by the Young Men's Catholic Institute, of Jersey City.

In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. MASON presented the credentials of the Hon. THOMAS L. CLINGMAN, appointed a Senator from North Carolina, by the Governor of that State, to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of the Hon. ASA BIGGS. Mr. BIGGS was appointed the other day United States District Judge.

The quiet which has prevailed all the previous part of this session, relative to the application of Oregon for admission into the Union, has probably led the public to suppose that there would be little or no opposition to her coming in as a matter of course, but this idea has already been dispelled.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--M. MUSARD gives another of his pleasant matinees to-day, commencing at 2 o'clock. As a gallant inducement, the handsome maestro presents to each lady patroness a copy of one of his most celebrated pieces. All the principal soloists assist. WALLACK'S THEATRE.--A new comedy, called "Americans in Paris, or a Game at Dominoes," will be produced here to-night.

On the 8th of July, 1856, in the town of Rockport, Mass., some two hundred of the women o tile place got together, proceeded to the different liquor shops, entered them by force, and destroyed the contents of kegs, demijohns and bottles. There was a great time in town that day, and the female mob was not interrupted until its work had been accomplished.

Mr. MASON, of Virginia, presented the credentials of Mr. CLINGMAN, as Senator from North Carolina in place of Mr. BIGGS. In consequence of the death of Senator EVANS, of South Carolina, the Senate immediately adjourned. HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES. WASHINGTON, Friday, May 7.

Six hundred and thirty-six more or less creditable combinations of form and color upon canvas, make up the formidable aggregate of the works to which the National Academy of Design invites the attention of the public and the criticism of connoisseurs. If one were called upon to judge this vast collection gravely in detail, life would be too short and steam-presses too little durable for the due fulfillment of the task.

Major-General SMITH has issued elaborate orders relative to the movement of the trains and troops of the Utah forces. The trains are to be divided into divisions of two hundred and twenty-six wagons each. and the troops will be organized into columns, each column constituting the escort of a division. A general supply train, and the first column, under command of Lieut.-Col. ANDREWS, are already organized, and ordered to march.

A GREAT FUSS ABOUT NOTHING.--Poor old Mr. BENNETT is losing his temper, as well as his teeth. He flies into a fearful passion because we mentioned BONNER'S advertising sheet, issued from the Herald office on Thursday morning. He says there were other advertisements in his newspaper that day as well as BONNER'S. Very well.

Inquest on the Body of the Female Poisoner. CHESTER, Orange Co., N. Y., Saturday, May 8. ?? An inquest was held yesterday, by Coroner FENTON, upon the body of Mrs. PHCEBE WESTLAKE. Verdict-" Death by taking arsenic." On Sunday morning last, the day previous to her death, she made a confession of administering poison to several others, and causing the death of two ladies, and the dangerous illness of several other persons.

We have no desire to spon the plans of pon ticians who take special comfort in making themselves miserable; but we should like to know why it is that the Republicans persist in pretending to be unhappy about the passage of the Kansas bill.

The Steamship Vanderbilt, from Southampton on the 28th ult., with four days' later news from Europe, is announced below as we go to press with our First Edition. The proceedings connected with the death of Senator EVANS, of South Carolina, occupied both houses of Congress on Saturday.

The steamship Vanderbilt arrived here early this morning, from Southampton on the 29th ult. The steamship Hammonia arrived at Cewes on Tuesday morning. The news by the Vanderbilt is four days later than that brought by the Europa.

ARREST OF SABBATH BREAKERS.-Yesterday af ternoon the Jersey City Police arrested four young fellows from 16 to 20 years of age, in the Fourth Ward, for playing ball and pitching pennies in an open lot near the street. Their names are MICHAEL MARTIN JAMES CLARK, MICHAEL SHAYS and OWEN CON??. They were committed to the City Prison.

The Clayton-Bulwer Treaty should, undoubtedly, be abrogated. It is an obstacle to the natural and legitimate expansion of the Republic, and this, we tale it, is an amply sufficient reason for its removal. But we must not forget that two parties are as indispensable to destroy as they are to originate a contract.
