The boundaries proposed for the new Territoly are the thirty-fourth parallel of latitude, with New-Mexico on the North;

To the Editor of the New- York Times: In your article headed " City Market Property," contained in your paper of the 7th inst., you state: " And the developments in regard to the management of our City markets offer another very striking illustration of the incapacity which presides over the financial department of the City Goverement."

FATAL. ACCIDENT ON SHIPBOARD.--Coroner GAMBLE held an inquest on Saturday on the body of a boy named DANIEL McCARTY, of No. 74 Allen-street, who fell from the main-vard of the ship Constellation, fracturing his skull and breaking his neck. The deceased had been employed by a sail-maker. and during the dinner hour went with some other boys to play on the Constellation, when the accident occurred. A verdict of accidental death was rendered.

WALLACK'S THE ??TRE.--An exceedingly amusing little comedy, entitled " Americans in Paris; or, a Game at Dominoes," was produced at this theatre on Saturday night. It is an adaptation from a French piece, but the dialogue is new, throughly American, and as local as anything placed in Paris can be.

The following is the Report of Deaths in the City for the week ending the 8th day of May. It shows an increase of 23, as compared with the previous week: Men, 94, women, 75; boys, 154; girls ??; total 430.* Adults, 109; children, 261; males, 240; females, 182; colored persons, 10.

REPUTATION OF CITIES.-BY a very common generalization the Press and the people attribute to cities the characteristics of a few notorious individuals. This is a very natural and facile, but at the same time unjust proceeding. In the rural districts our own metropolis is largely judged of in the light of its police reports, and the New-Yorkers are often classified into two grand divisions, the garroters and the garrpted.

The recent victories of the Emancipation party in St Louis, Jefferson City, and Kansas City, are a continuation of the triumphs of the Free-Soil movement which found a first expression in the election of FRANK BLAIR to represent the St. Louis Congressional District two years ago.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Your paper, a short time ago, contained some remarks on the convenience of one-horse cabs, such as are used in Europe, especially in London. traversing the City in all directions at very moderate fares.

Some time since our readers will remember an announcement in the New-York papers that a barrel marked "W. H. Jennings, No. 185 Leonard-street, New-York," containing the mangled remains of a female, was found in the Hudson River Railroad Depot at New-York City. An inquest was held upon the body at that place, and the officers commenced investigations. Telegrams were sent through Canada, and it was found that the barrel had crossed the Suspension Bridge.

MYSTERIOUS DISAPPEARANCE--SUPPOSED ?? PLAY--A CLAIRVOYANT AND HIS "HOUSEKEEPER" ARRESTED.--Mr. SAMUEL SMITH, of No. 168 Third-avenue, New-York, left his residence on Wednesday morning last to go to his work-shop, No. 17 John-street, since which time he has not been seen by any member of his family.

Dr. Rhuder, physician, has set to music the palpitations and irregular beatings of the heart of a female, who is a patient in the hospital at Upsal, in Sweden. "This disease, written in musical notes. with quavers and semi- quavers, forms a kind of waltz, and is one of the greatest curiosities of pathological anatomy."

The witness, SLADE, examined in Philadelphia, accounted for the destination of the total eighty-seven thousand dollars expended by LAWRENCE, STONE Co. in procuring the passage of the Tariff bill. Between sixty and seventy thousand was shown to have been put in WALCOTT'S hands. There are no traces of this amount beyond that; and whether he paid it out or pocketed it, is not known.

The West Wahington Market Oifficulty? The Executive Committee of the West Washington Marketmen, on Saturday morning visited Messrs. TAYLOR BRENNAN, the State lessees of the market property, at their office in Pine-street. The latter promised the marketmen that they would not charge them exorbitant rents, if the latter chose to acknowledge the validity of their title, and pay their rents to them.

Professor W. G. SHEDD, of Andover, derivered the Anniversary Address before the Society of Religious Inquiry, of the Union Theological Seminary, last evening, at Dr. ADAMS' Church, on Madison. square. His subject was "the Relations of the Preacher and the Hearer"-the tone with which the one should preach, and the temper in which the other should listen to religious truth.

That Short and ready method of getting out of pecuniary difficulties, known as a fraudulent assignment, bids fair to be at last put an end to by Mr. TOOMBS' Bankruptcy law, now under discussion in Congress. The evil it proposes to remedy has long been the scandal not only of our legislation, but, of our trade and commerce.

The Convention Catted to nominate state officers under the new Leavenworth Constitution met at Topeka last Wednesday morning. The attendance was large-88 out of 100 delegates being present. A selfcongtituted Committee of five gentlemen, prior to the assembling of the Convention, addressed letters of inquiry upon certain points connected with the future policy of the Free State Party, to several of the most promment candidates to come before the Convention.

ROGERS.--In this City, on Sunday morning, May 9. MILTON AUGUSTUS, only child of Joshua and Mary Jane Rogers ages 2 years and 4 months. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend his funeral, on Monday, May 10. at 1 o'clock from the residence of his parents. No. 716 Washington-st.

The official report of receipts and expenditures for the quarter ending March 31, issuing from the office of the Register of the Treasury, differs very materially from the statement said to have been furnished by the Secretary to the Committee of Ways and Means a fortnight ago. In that paper the receipts of revenue from sales of public land were given as $3,046,236, but are now officially stated at $480,936.

The difficulty which has occurred between Senator PUGH, of Ohio, and the President, is apparently irreconcilable, though efforts have been made to patch up a peace. The quarrel has gone so far that PUGH declares he will never again enter the White House while BUCHANAN is President, and the President is reported to have said that he regards PUGH as no better than HALE.

VULTEE--In this City. on Saturday, May 8, GERTRUDE, relict of Capt. Frederic L. Vultee, aged 70 years, 2 months and 23 days. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend her funeral. on Tuesday, at 2 o'clock P. M.. from her late residence, No 77 West 37th st., without further invitation.

Mr. SEWARD presented the petition of Mayor TIEMANN, of New-York, and the Mayors of Brooklyn and Jersey City, being a Committee appointed to consider plans for the improvement of the drainage of those cities. The petition asks action of the Government towards forming wharves along the water lots. Referred to the Committee on Commerce.

ITALIAN OPERA.---It is scarcely credible to the leading musical institution of our City that an artist like Singer RONCONI should have been compelled at the last moment to provide for himself at Mr. BURTON'S Theatre in order that he might have an opportunity of playing once or twice to a metropolitan audience before his departure for Europe. There are circumstances, however, which may in a measure account for this.

AN UNFOUNDED CHARGE.--The Richmond Whig publishes a long extract from Gov. WISE'S letter to the New York Democrats upon Know-Nothingism, and the same language precisely from one of HAZLITT'S Essays. The Whig and other journals which have noticed the matter, charge the Governor with plagiarism.

The steamship Vanderbilt, P. E. LEFEVRE Commander, from southampton on the evening of the 28th ult. arrived at her dock at an early hour yesterday morning. Her news was published in a large portion of yesterday morning's edition. We obtain, however, from our foreign files some further intelligence of interest.

A dispatch from Independence announces the arrival there of Mr. MASON. He left Camp Scott March 3. The news he brought was unimportant. General JOHNSON was anxiously awaiting the arrival of Capt. MARCY. The health of the army was remarkably good. Provisions were becoming scarce, but supplies were expected from Fort Laramie.

Several Santa F6i merchants arrived here on Saturday, but they brought no news of importance. They suffered terribly from heavy storms and cold weather, and a greater or less number of the animals attached to each train perished. All the streams were high, and water covered the plains. The Indians whom they met reported the loss of nearly all their animals by extreme cold.

In steamship Vanderbill, from Havre--A. N. Chrystie Madame Lucadon. Miss Birdsall and maid. J. A. Simmons and lady, daughter and maid, Madam Meslin, 3 sons and nurse. Madam Breha, Mr. Moses. Mr. Austin, the Rev. R. Hecker, Mr. A.R. Brandon and lady, Mr. Hissey, G.G. Granger, R. Ingram, P.L. Gusteranus and lady, the Rev. J.P. Donnelan, the Rev. Jas. Donnelan,

AMERICAN DRAMATIC FUND ASSOCIATION.--The American Dramatic Fund Association held their annual election for officers yesterday afternoon, at the office of the Association, No. 15 Crosby-street. The following are the officers elected for the ensuring year: For President--James T. Brady.

THE ONLY EFFECTUAL METHOD OF GETTING RID OF THE PUBLIC MARKET DIFFICULTIES.-We understand that Mayor TIEMANN has signified his determination to take the West Washington Market difficulty by the horns, and make a thorough examination into the whole affair, to see how much money is collected from the hucksters who occupy the disputed territory, and ascertain what becomes of it.

ASSUALT IN A DRINKING SALOON.--Thomas Burke, a young man, residing in Forty-sixth street, about 2 o'clock yesterday morning went into the drinking saloon in Howard-street, known as the "Magnet Shades." Seeing a person sitting in a chair smoking a cigar. whom he supposed that he knew, in sport he ?? the cigar from his mouth. Upon discovering that he had mistaken the person, he apologized for the rudeness, but the apology was not accepted,

Last evening, pursuant to the call of a printed circular, a meeting was held in room No. 6 Clinton Hall, for the purpose of conferring and deciding on the most advisable course to be pursued at the annual meeting of the American Tract Society on Wednesday next. This circular was as follows: (PRIVATE AND CONFIDENTIAL.) NEW-YORK, April 16, 1858.

THE WEST WASHINGTON MARKET DIFFICULTY.The Executive Committee of tile West Washington, Market men visited Messrs. TAYLOR and BRENNAN, the State lessees of the market property, at their office, No. 48 Pine-street, yesterday morning, at 10 o'clock' The Committee informed them that they had decided acting under the advice of their counsel, Ex-Judge WHITING;

A NEW ALTERED BILL.--Okes altered to tens on the New-York Bank, made their appearance in the City yesterday morning. The alteration Is skillfully made. Information of the fact was communicated to the Police head-quarters, and notices sent by telegraph to the Police to put storekeepers on their guard. One arrest has been made of a person offering these bills in Canal-street.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In the TIMES of Saturday you make a very severe, and, as i hope to convince you, a very unjust, attack upon Justice BRENNAN for alleged illegal interference to discharge from custody, without trial or examination, persons under arrest and in custody. I submit the following refutation of each of the three points you have made against him:

JUSTICE BRENNAN AND THE POLICE.--A letter from a correspondent, which we publish in another column, protests against the injustice of our comments on the conduct of Justice BRENNAN in releasing from custody persons arrested for offences against the law.

A meeting of the Board of Aldermen was held last evening. President PIERSON in the Chair. The following communication from His Honor the Mayor, vetoings the Paid Fire Department Ordinance, was presented, read and ordered printed: MAYOR'S OFFICE, May 10, 1858.

The estimates which have been sent in to the Committee of Ways and Means, for raising and maintaining three regiments of volunteers for eighteen months, must sound largely to the ear of Congress, and, if rumors are true, are intended to startle that body at the increased expense of that action which it has insisted in forcing upon the President, spite of his predilections for regulars.

ARREST OF A SWINDLING COLLECTOR.-THOMAS J. DOWDEN was arrested on Saturday, in Chambersstreet, by Officer WILDEY, of the detective force, on a charge of obtaining moneys under false pretences, for the benefit of the Home of the Friendless.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The annual meeting of the American Tract Society will be held to-morrow in the Reformed Dutch Church in Lafayette-place, commencing at 9 o'clock. It will be preeminently the great meeting of Anniversary Week.

Chief Justice TANEY announced that the Court would adjourn on the 20th inst., and that it would not hear any argument on the merits of a case after Wednesday, and hear no motions after next Friday. No. 78.--James Stinson vs. Hercules L. Consman. -Justice CAMPBELL delivered the opinion of the Court, affirming the judgment of the Supreme Court of Minnesota, with costs and interest.

The Cincinnatti Gazette publishes a letter from an Indiana Congressman, verbatim et literatim. Mr. FOLLY is a new member of the House, elected from the Fourth District: "Washington, Aprile, 22 58 "Dear friend : Your kind favor of the 14 inst. is to hand. I was glad to here from you the indication the Kansas trebles will be settle to-day by the democrat party.

The Board of Aldermen met last evening, President CLANCY in the Chair. Before proceeding to business the President announced that in consequence of the resignation of Peter L. Feirty, reader to the Board, he had appointed Mr. Henry Morford to that position.

" Ater us the deluge," seems to be the motio of the actual Administration. Not to settle, hut to evade, postpone, shake off, and thrust into the indefinite future any question that may embarrass their present action, or too severely tax their limited resources of intellect or character, is the policy dear to the hearts of those who now direct the affairs of the first and freest State of the New World.

FAULKNER, of Virginia, has in contemplation a bill to establish a Naval Academy of Surgery for the education of Surgeons in the Navy, the same as cadets are now educated-the appointments to be given to the Congressional districts. It is definitely settled that the new regiments will not be sent to Utah, but will be employed on the frontier.

We obtain some further intelligence of interest from our files by the Vanderbilt, which arrived at this port at an early hour yesterday morning London journals received are to the 2S,h ult., inclusive. The debate in the House of Commons on the new Government of India bill, appointed to take place on the 30th, was looked forward to with much interest.

THE CENTRAL PARK COMMISSION.-ANDREW H. GREEN, Esq., was last night elected, by his associates, President of the Board of Commissioners of the Central Park. The Commissioners, a majority of whom are Republicans, have thus given renewed evidence of their disposition to make their great work a notable exception to the general rules of our civic enterprises.

FLOUR, lower--demand only for the interior. Sales 1,200 bush at $3 50@$3 70 for Superfine Upper Lake, Indian and Michigan ; $3 75@$4 for extra do.; and $4 12@$4 225 for double extra. WHEAT dull. Sales 25,000 bush, Chicago Spring at 70c. CORN dull, at 53c.@54c. OATS rather easier. Sales 30.000 bush. At 33c @33 1/2c. WHISKY lower. Sales 700 bbls. at 18 3/4c.@19c., closing at the inside price.

The United States steamer Michigan sailed from Cleveland for the upper lakes, on the 10th inst. She carries eighty-six men, all told. The following is a list of her officers: JOSEPH LANMAN, Commander: Jas. H. Spotts, R. B. Lowry, Jas. E. Jewitt, Jas. W. Shirk, lieutenants; Jas H. Watmough, purser: Jas. F. Harrison, passed assistant surgeon;

In the absence of any political changes of importance the force of money continues to manifest itself in the Stock markets, and Consols have closed today at a further advance of 1/2 [pound] cent. They left off last evening at 97@1/3 and the first bargains this morning were at 97 1/8@1/2.

The public are again shocked by a wholesale destruction of life on one of tile great thoroughfares of travel. It occurred yesterday morning on the New-York Central Railroad. at a point about three miles West front the City of Utica.

ITALIAN OPERA.--The great lyric--artist, Signor RONCONI--the greatest we have ever had in this country--appears to-night for the second time as Figaro, the immortal barber, in the opera of the "Barber of Seville.' LA GRANGE. and TIBERINI, and COLLETTI, sustain the other toles. We hope, for the sake of genuine art, there will be a proper attendance.

The Independence Messenger, of Saturday, mentions the arrival there of three men direct from Camp Scott. They reported that the troops were in good health, but that provisions were scarce, with the exception of poor beef. Gen. JOHNSON would not be able to move forward until a fresh supply of animals was received.

THE UNITES STATES AND SPAIN--We published, a few days ago, a statement to the effect that some excitement had been occasioned in Madrid by the rumor that the President of the United States entertained hostile intentions towards Spain. We were told that the Government had been questioned on the subject in the Cortes.

BURROWES.--In this City, on Sunday. May 9. ELIZABETH MORRELL. daughter of Enos and Eliza Burrowes. The friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend her funeral this (Wednesday) afternoon, at 3 o'clock from her late residence, 81st st., five doors west of 3d-av. MACKAY.--In this City, on Sunday, May 9. of congestion of the brain, SARAH M. MACKAY. daughter of Daniel Mackay in the 22d year of her age.

The Steamship Tennessee, from Vera Cruz till inst., has arrived at this port, bridging advises from the city of Mexico to the 4th inst. The news indicates the speedy downfall of the Zuloaga Government.

The Southern Commercial Convention assembled in this city at noon to-day. WILLIAM L. YANCEY called the assemblage to order at that hour. A temporary organization was effected by the choice of ALLEN F. OWEN, of Georgia, as chairman. The Convention is composed of over 300 delegates, representing North Carolina. South Carolina, Virginia, Mississippi, Tennessee, Florida, Alabama and Georgia.

GEORGE SANDERS nomination has not yet been sent to the Senate, as reported. There is still a hitch about it. Captain RYNDERS' nomination is in. but there is some opposition to his confirmation on the Administration side. The opposition to SCHELL is about quieted.

THE MAYOR AFTER SWILL MILE.--The Mayor had a conference with FRANK LESLIE, yesterday, upon the subject of swill-fed milk. and came to the conclusion to cooperate in the movement to suppress the sale of the poison in the City. He gave directions to an officer to detail a policeman to each ferry, with orders to arrest the drivers of all milk wagons who enter this City without a name and number on their wagon.

The Cunard steamship Persia, after a remarkably rapid passage from Liverpool of less than ten days, arrived at this port early yesterday morning. The news is three days later than that brought by the Vonderbilt. In the House of Commons, on the 30th ult., the debate on the new Government of India bill was commenced.

The twenty-fifth anniversary of this Society commenced yesterday morning at 10 o'clock at Mozart Hall, Broadway. The spacious room was crowded with an audience usual to such occasions, composed of Quakers from the City and country, a liberal show of colored people, a plentiful display of hirsute appendages, and the rank and tile. numbeing some hundreds. as well as the principal leaders, of the Garrisonian, Union-dissolving, Anti-Slavery movement.

Captain HOWES, of the schooner Mobile, arrived last light from Mobile, reports, 29th ult., when 25 miles south of Key West saw a steamship to windward bearing down for us. Hove to to speak her, and when within rifle shot distance, she commenced firing rifles at us, the balls from which passed between the men on deck. and lodged in the bulwarks.

The Cunard steamship Persia, Capt. JUDKINS from Liverpool about 10 1/2 o'clock on the morning o May 1, arrived at this port yesterday morning. The steamship North Star was due at Southampton (in her fourteenth day,) but she had not been Telegraphed when our dispatches were closed.

MEETING OF THE TRACT SOCIETY.--On many accounts the meeting of the American Tract Society to-day will be one of great interest. The opponents of the present management of the Society are not agreed on the action that ought to be demanded of the government.

Before Judge Betts. EXCEPTIONS TO REPORT--COLLISION--DAMAGES--COMMON CARRIER INSURANCE. Alfred H. Hovey vs. The Steamboat Sarah E. Brown.--This case came up on exceptions to the Commissioner's report. The action was for injury done by the steamboat to a vessel called the Mist, then in possession of the libelant, and to the merchandise put on board her by its owners, and committed to the libelant's charge as a common carrier.

It is too late in the session to expect that Congress will digest and adopt any comprehensive and permanent system for the service of our Ocean Mails. Such a system is greatly needed, and no subject could more worthily or usefully engage the attention of our Government.

A frightful accident occurred this morning, at 6 1/2 o'clock, on the Central Railroad, by the crushing of a bridge over the Sauquoit Creek, some three and a half miles west of this city, near Whitesboro' Seven or eight persons are already dead, and fire or six others are barely alive. The injured number forty or more.

THE DEGRADATION OF GOVERNOR YEH.--The Imperial edict degrading that haughty official, Governor YEH, is calculated to give a higher opinion of the Emperor of the Flowery land than previous State papers from the same source would warrant.

Various petitions of an uninteresting character were presented and referred. On motion of Mr. BENJAMIN, of Louisiana, the bill for the final adjustment of private land claims in Florida, Louisiana, Arkansas and Missouri, was considered. The bill excited considerable debate on its minutia, and finally, with unimportant amendments,

Yesterday Morning at 9 A.M. the private meeting of members of the American Tract Society, called by circular, and adjourned over from the previous evening, was resumed in room No. 6, Clinton hall." Mr. John TAPPAN, of Boston, in the Chair.

" Grace, I am dying! Come, nearer, daughter. that I may speak to you, with the little strength that remains, my parting words. It is hard, hard to leave my unprotected children to struggle alone amid the vicissitudes of life. "Oh, mother, mother, do not speak such terrible words.

The New-Orleans True Delta of the 2d has the following : "Messrs. TOM S. McCAY and MAT EDWARDS, well-known legal gentlemen of this city, have had a quarrel, which resulted in their having recourse to the "code of honor." A meeting was determined on,

FIRST DAY. COURT OF GENERAL SESSIONS. Before the City Judge. Yesterday, the rather prominent suit of Richard Busteed, Corporation Counsel, vs. Thomas N. Carr, for libel, was commenced in the Court of General Sessions, before the City Judge.

The controcersy which has so greatiy distracted the Tract Society for the past two or three years came to a climax, yesterday, and resulted in the complete and overwhelming triumph of the Managers of the institution. Our readers are aware that the all-pervading topic of Slavery was the causa telerrima belli.

There is some prospect that the most disgracoful nuisance of the metropolis is about to be abated. The "Swill Milk," as it is most appropriately denominated--that bluish, while compound of true milk, pus and dirty water, which, on standing, deposits a yellowish, brown sediment, that is manufactured

From the St. Joseph (Mo.) Gazette. On last Saturday, the mail of Salt Lake, under the new contract left this city promptly at the designated lime. This argues well for the efficiency of the company now having the matter in hand. Within 18 days from the time of signing the contract, the line has been stocked with over 300 mules, coaches procured, stations provided, and the service commenced.

CENTRAL RAILROAD SLAUGHTER.--The results of the disaster near Utica are now definitely known. Eight lives have been lost, and 55 persons were injured who will probably survive. The last death was that of Mr. WM. H. PERKINS , OF Rochester, who expired yesterday morning.

At the battle of Poictiers, fought in the year 1856, the English armv, cummanded by Prince Euward, did not amount to twelve thousand men; while that of the French, unmder King John, exceeded sixty thousand. Notwithstanding so great a disproportion of numbers, the courage of the English, and the good conduct of the prince, gained the Victory.

DEATH OF ADMIRAL CARDEN.-Americans were at one time deeply interested in the fate of this gallant officer, though his name is now scarcely remembered or known in the United States. He it was who commanded the Macedonia (48) in 1812, when, after a stubborn resistance, which brought the ship to ahopcless wreck, she was compelled to surrender to the United States. Captain CARDEN, when he reached

Fashion is a strange master-a whimsical tyrant. It prefers variety to comfort, and novelty to convenience. It will hare any sort of change in preference to a monotony of good taste. It scorns prudential philosophy, and laughs at economical habits. It cannot be said that it has nothing to wear.

The Convention met at 9 A. M. After prayer had been offered and the minutes of yesterday's proceedings had been confirmed, Mr. RUFFIN, of Virginia, reported a resolution recommending the South to adopt discriminations against the produce and manufactures of the North, by means of taxes and licenses.

A communication was received from the Secre tary of War relative to the proposed purchase of the site of a fortification for the protection of the harbor of San Francisco. Mr. FESSENDEN, of Maine, objected to the price demanded, ($200,00,) and thought the necessity not so urgent that Congress should submit to such an enormous imposition.

To the Editor of the New- York Times: For once, the Quaker City has got the start of New-York. We have had long discussions, and profound, in regard to the best means of reaching the destitute masses of this City with the Gospel, during the ensuing Summer.

There are few who have reached the age of twenty-five that have not stores of such treasures. And we all have days of looking over these eloquent mementoes of our beloved dead. How mourntul they are ; with what a louching, though voiceless cty. do they move their hearts. even when we know that the life of the dear writer was gladness, and his death peace.

I have been called to an account by a friend whom I both love and respect, for an article in "Fresh Leaves" on "Lady Doctors." My friend charges me in this article with a want of sympathy for this class, and with throwing obstacles in the way of their success.

The commencement of hostilities between the United States and Spain, as recorded in my last Saturday's revue de la semaine, has naturally attracted the attention of the metropolitan gossips, and the less delicate and less truthful chronicles in other New-York papers have but added fuel to the flame.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR: I, with many of your subscribers, have been much interested in a subject which recently you have brought before your readers, and upon which the same class of readers are desirous of still further information. I refer to the China Cooly Trade.

The undersigned Committee on "The Benton Monument," respectfully invite the citizens of St. Louis to a public meeting, to be held on Saturday, the 24th inst., at half-past seven o'clock P. M., in the Rotunda, to take measures for the carrying out of the objects for which the Committee was appointed.

In the Senate yesterday, a communication was received from the War Department on the subject of purchasing a site for a fort at the Golden Gate, near San Francisco. It has a ranch, or farm, and the proposed price is $200,000. Mr. BRODERICK said it was not worth over $7,000.

Before entering into a description of the mode of chase adopted with regard to this formidable animal, we may give the reader some insight into the make and character of the lion, and more, particularly, the lion of Africa.

An Extra of the Utica Evening Telegraph contains complete lists of the names of the killed and injured, as follows: KILLED. 1. Avery Mack, aged 12 years, daughter of Abraham Mack. 2. David A. Brayton, of Phelps, Ontario County. 3. A negro, about 40 years of age, name unknown.

Business here is dull,--very little freight arriving and less departing. The emmigration up the Missouri River to Kansas, Nebraska, and Western Iowa, is the principal redeeming feature for the boat trade. Every boat going up the Missouri River has a good quota of passengers, both steerage or deck and cabin. Most of these are farmers or artizans, both classes go ing out prepared for cultivating the rich prairie soi or to prosecute their mechanical labors.

THEY ALWAYS CARRY TURPENTINE ON MISSIS SIPPI BOATS.--The circumstances of the burning of the Ocean Spray on the Mississippi are still fresh in the memory. The United States Commissioner at St. Louis is engaged in an investigation, and this is the testimony of one Mississippi steamboat Captaia:

To the Editor of the New- York Times: I have read, with much satisfaction, your able article in this morning's paper on the subject of Senator TOOMBS' Bankruptcy bill, and would beg, in this connection, to call your attention to an excellent provision contained in the bankruptcy laws of Great Britain, and, I think, those of nearly all Continental Europe.

I informed you, in my last letter, that we were about to leave for Manila. We left for the above-named place on the 7th of February last, having male a fine run of about 85 hours, stopping in the meantime for some six hours to fire at target with shot and shell. At Manila we exchanged the usual salutes.

The Medical Convention is over. The Northern members have mostly gone home, unwilling, for the sake of a jolly time over the grave of WASHINGTON, to lose their chance of reaching their homes before Sunday, the Committee of Arrrangements being unable to assure them that the excursion to Mount Vernon could be ended In time to take the evening cars northward.

Once in a few months the City is shocked into a transient excitement by the perpetration of some terrible and mysterious murder. During the Coroner's investigation the public mind is kept in a state of feverish excitement; but this soon passes away, and the murder is only remembered by the friends of the victim.

MURDER IN NORFOLK BY SAILORS FROM THE U. S. BRIG BAINBRIDGE.--On the 6th, at Norfolk, Virginia, a young man, named THOMAS BURNE, was killed by two sailors, named JAMS F. MARTIN and WILLIAM PRICE, from the United States brig Bainbridge, who were on shore engaged in a debauch.

SWILL MILK--The Mayor's Police, yesterday, arrested fourteen milkmen whom they fournd driving carts having no numbers upon them. The names of the arrested parties were John Browning, Martin Barney. Nathan N. Rollin, Oliver govey, Edward Jones, James Doneghan, John Black, Joseph Oliver, Peter Clark, Patrick Filzpatrick, Samuel Miller,
We publish this morning a clear and concise statement from Captain HOWE, of the American schooner Mobile, relative to the recent extraordinary outrage committed by the British war-steamer Styx.

Under this caption the New-York Evangelist says: "The course of the secular journals on the Sabbath question, now so prominently before tile public, must be regarded with lively interest by every friend of sound morals. With few exceptions, their tone is all that could be desired.

The Toronto Globe contains an appeal to the Canadian public from the prisoners in Hamilton jail confined for debt. Their statements present a sorry picture. Among other things, they say: "There are, at this moment, eleven debtors confined in two small cells communicating with each other, 14x10 feet each, which we are never allowed to leave under any pretext whatever.

BENNET.- In this City, on Wednesday morning, May 12. of lingering illness, WINFIELD S., the twin son of Barnes and Susan Bennet in the 8th year of his age. The relatives and friends of the femily are respeocfully invited to attend his funeral, from the residence of his parents, No. 88 Mobroe-st.. on friday, at 2 O'clock P.M. JARVIS.-In this City, on Tuesday, May 11, SARAH JARVIS, aged 64 years.

Groershead. Pat. Bremner. Mathew Bremner, James Gray. Alex. Purse, Henry Morgan. Mrs. Graham. Mrs. Firbes and Miss Rhoda Forbes. Miss Jane M. Anderson. Lo! the poor Indian, whose untutored mind Sees God in clouds. or hears him in the wind; His soul proud science never taught to stray Far as the solar walk or Milky way; Yet simple nature to his hope has given Behind the cloud-topt hill an humbler heaven;

There has never before been such a "sacrificing" of fast horses and matched teams as during the last month. The reckless extravagance of many families having been checked by lack of cash and credit, their "establishments" have collapsed and shrivelled up like a toadstool under the blaze of the noonday sun.

The freshest and most perpetual of all comic operas, the "Barber," was performed iast night at BURTON'S, to a fine and fashionable audience. Madame LA GRANGE was the Rosina, (it was in this character that she made her debut in New-York,) and sang with more than her usual animation and success.

To the Editor of the New- York Times: "YEH'S conduct is condemned, and he is degraded and a successor appointed. The latter is to settle disputes with the barbarians who, excited to wrath by YEH, had entered the city." Such is the announcement by telegraph of news Just received from Hong Kong, dated the 15th March last.

WILSON--STARBUCK.--In this City on Tuesday, May 11, by the Rev. C.S. Burchard. at the residence of the bride's father. Mr. JAMES T. WILSON to Miss JOSEPHINE STARBUCK all of this City.

I telegraphed you last week that the House Committee on Territories were about to report a bill for the organization of a new Territory, called Nevada, out of the western portion of Utah-one of your enterprising cotemporaries had the news in his telegraphic columns two or three days afterwards.

Most people are fond of having pleasant company, but very few people know how to make their company feel at home. A great deal is said on the subject of hospitality, and great exertions are frequently made to prove one's richness in this regard.

The British House of Commons has again, after discussion, decided in favor of striking out the words, "on the true faith of a Christian," from the oath administered to Members of Parliament. There was a majority of two to one in favor of this measure. Its fate has been, hitherto, year after year, to be rejected by the House of Lords.

SAD CASE OF SEDUCTION AND MURDER.-The Chicago papers have accounts of the murder of a young English girl, whose name was unknown, in the town of Joliet, Illinois. The girl had been living with her mother, but had been seduced by one RICHARDS, a house carpenter, 40 years of 'age, wellknown in Joliet, and who has hitherto borne a good character.

From the Washington Union. All the accounts from the theatre of prepara- a tion represent the appointments for reinforcing our army in Utah to be most ample and thorough. Nothing has been trusted to hazard. No pains, or trouble, or expense has been spared to insure the success of the expedition.

SPEECHES OF THE REV. DR. MAGIE, BISHOP MCILVAINE, THE REV. DR. TYNG, THE REV. DR. BACON, THE HON. JUDGE JESSUP, THE REV. DR. BETHUNE. THE REV. DR. THOMPSON, THE REV DR. COOKE, THE REV. DR. DENNISTOUN, THE REV. DR. JOHNS, THE REV. DR. CHEEVER, THE REV. DR. A. D. SMITH, AND OTHERS.

The British screw-steamship Saladin, Captain MIDDLETON,arrived at this port yesterdayin 10 days from Kingston,Jam. She is bound to Liverpool, and put into this port to land 61 of the crew and officers belonging to the United States steam-frigate Susquehanna, who were sent ashore from that vessel at Kingston, they being sick with yellow fever.

All the Plans received by the Commissioners for the Central Park are now on exhibition at No. 637 Broadway. They ought to attract general attention,--not only on account of their int:insic interest, but because the admission fund is to be distributed among the unsuccessful competitors and forms the only compensation for their labor.

Mr. PHILLIPS, of Pennsylvania will, to-morrow, present the credentials of Messrs. CAVANAGH and PHELPS, members elect for Minnesota, and ask that they be sworn in. Opposition is threatened, the ground of objection being that three members were elected, and that they had no right to determine which should take seats. There was a disposition to day, to attempt sending them all back for a new election.

The brave only know how to forgive; it is the most refined and generous pitch of virtue human nature can arrive at. Cowards have done good and kind actions-cowards have even fought, nay, sometimes conquered ; but a coward never forgave; it is not in his nature;

The panic in financial circles has been so severe and long continued that its effects will probably be operative and visible for many months to come. And, on the whole, we think it has done, is doing, and will continue to do, much good.

This is by no means an elegant or very perspicuous saw, and never was to our taste. It has become more contemptible than ever in our estimation since a lady friend, yesterday, sent us three specimens of what her nine pound hens had been producing. They have laid-not set-egg samples which the whole barn-yard community ought to emulate.

How much misery may be abated, how much suffering may be removed, by the simple tone and expression of the human voice ! Upon the heart that is lone and desolate, that feels itself, as it were, shut out of the world. wrapped up in gloomy imaginings, how sweetly falls the voice of sympathy and consolation !

Miss Elizabeth Dye, a young lady in Newport, Ky., personated Louisiana in a Know-Nothing celebration in the campaign of '56, when a tableaux of the States of the Union formed a part of certain jubilee ceremonies; and for the excellent manner in which she performed that somewhat conspicuous service, has received a present of a magnificent diamond bracelet from the grateful K. N.'s of New-Orleans.

The trial of WM. M. CONNELLY, formerly a Reorter in this City, on a charge of "having harbored and concealed two fugitive slaves," was commenced the United States Court at Cincinnati on Thursday, Judge LEAVITT presiding.

MAY-DAY AMONG THE JOURNALS.--We have lost form the corner of Beekman-street a very friendly neighbor; but our loss is our neighbor's gain. The NEW-YORK TIMES have migrated from its late quarters to a new and splendid stone-fronted abode--the stone, by trhe way,is from Nova Scoth--at the northern extremlty of the ground formerly occupied by the venerable Brick Chruch.

BLATCHFORD, SEADUET BRKWETER, and STEWART BROWN, of the firm of BROWN, BROTHERS , charging DWIGHT with embezzlement, perjury and eonspiracy, with a view to defraud.

OUR THIRTY-SECOND STATE.--The perfectly quiet and unobtrusive manner in which another great State has been added to our confederacy indicates more foreibly, perhaps, than the loudest demonstration possibly could, the greatness at which we have arrived as a nation.

SUPREME COURT. THE BULKLEY DIVORCE CASE.--The suit of Mr Bulkley against his wife for divorce is NOT discontinued, as was reported in the TIMES of the 11th inst. The two suits have simply been consolidated by order of Court, to avoid separate trials.

ARRIVAL OF THE PHILADELPHIA--CONTINUED OUTRAGES BY BRITISH VESSELS OF WAR. The United States mail steamship Philadelphia, GUSTAVUS HARRISON commanding, left New Orleans on the 5th inst., arrived at Havana at sunrise of the 8th, and sailed again at 9 A. M. of the 9th for NewYork.

?? IN CONVENTION AT CHICAGO.-The National Typegraphical Union met in Chicago on the 3d inst. Robert C. Smith, of Philadelphia, ?? chosen President, and Geo. W. Smith, of New-York, Recording Secretary. It was resolved to hold the next meeting in Boston. A communication received from Philadelphia suggested the establishment of an asylum for aged and indigent printers.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: As one of that unfortunate class of individuals whose business pursuits compel their personal attendance in the City both Winter and Summer, I am naturally inquisitive in regard to our sanitary prospects for the coming season. Some ten days ago the United States frigate Susquehanna arrived at this port with nearly two-thirds of her crew either sick or disabled, from yellow fever;

From the meeting of the Senate, at 11 A. M., until 1 P. M., the discussion was upon what to take up-Mr. CLAY urging the Fishery bill, Mr. POLK wanting the Homestead bill, and Mr. HUNTER insisting on the general Appropriation bill, which was finally taken up by a vote of 33 against 30. The bill, containing thirty-seven pages, was then read.

WHAT HAS BECOME OF THE PORE COUNTRY MILK COMPANY?-A company was incorporated at the last session of the Legislature for supplying New-York with fresh milk. But we have not yet heard of its going into operation. The present is a most favorable time for it to commence business.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC, - MENDELSSOHN'S oratorio of Elijah will be repeated to - night, for the last time, by the combined forces of the Harmonic Society and Mr. ULLMAN'S Company. The solos will be sung by D'ANGRI, MILNER, FORMES, PERRING, SIMPSON, The orchestra and chorus will consist of upwards of four hundred voices.

COURT OF GENERAL SESSIONS. Before the City Judge. This trial was resumed yesterday morning. The Court-room was even more crowded than on the previous day. Mr. Bennett, of the Herald, was the first witness. He appeared a little nervous on taking the oath, but on the whole, gave his evidence in a composed manner. He was examined by Mr. John Graham:

A Prodigious Crowd and a Memorable Time. The annual Congregational Collation last night was an immense gathering of ladies and gentlemen, to all of whom, if we may judge from the constantlyshifting physiognomy of the audience, it was an occasion long to be remembered.

SPIGGOT-SAVING AND WASTING AT THE BUNGHOLE.--It is curious how lavish our Government is in some directions, and how penurious it is in others. lion. I.--TERRIBLE DISASTER ON THE NEWYORK CENTRAL RAILROAD-Complete List of Names of Killed and Injured. II.--ANNIVERSARY WEEK-Sketches of the Proceedings at the Anniversaries of the Religious and Charitable Associations. III.--UTAH AND THE MORMONS--Further statements by Mr. FREDERICK LOBA.

The long-delayed explosion in the case of the House Doorkeeper occurred to-day, and excited considerable sensation. The most gross charges against him, however, were not reported by the Committee on Accounts. The regular Doorkeeper-Investigation Committee have evidence before them showing that he has compelled contributions from even the boy-pages, besides an affidavit of a female, making a charge of a still more disgraceful sort.

The United States Mail steamship Star of the West, A. G. GRAY, Commander, from Aspinwall on May 4, with the California mails of April 20, passengers, and $1,615,351 94 in treasure, arrived at this port yesterday morning. The Pacific Mail Steamship Company's steamer Golden Age, with the California mails, Passengers and treasure, arrived at Panama on the night of the 3d inst.

The Mayor's squad of Police made a large number of arrests yesterday of milkmen driving their wagons into and about the City, without any name or number painted on them. They were all brought before the Mayor, and each fined $2. The following are the names of the arrested parties: Martin Hallakan, John Rogers, William Wogan, James Wogan.

Serious Affray between two Swill-Milk Men. About 7 1/2 o'clock last evening, a quarrel took place in the Silliman-street Swill-Milk Stables, between MICHAEL CONWAY and PETER DREHER, when both were so seriously injured that there is no hopes entertained of their recovery.

The United States Mail steamship Star of the West, from Aspinwall on the 4th of May, arrived at this port yesterday with the California mails of April 20 and $1,615,351 in treasure. There is not much news by this arrival. The California Legislature had resolved to adjourn on the 26th of April. A law for the better observance of the Sabbath had been passed.

HAMlLTON.--In this City, on Wednesday, May 12, GEORGE S. HAMILTON, aged 62 years, late of Halifax, N. S. and for 26 years a resident of this City. The funeral will take place on Friday afternoon, at 2 o'clock, from his late residence. No. 48 West 32d-st.. near Broadway The friends and acquaintances of the family are respectfully invited to attend.

BLOCKADE AND BOMBARDMENT OF PORT-AU-PLATTE BY A DOMINICAN FLEET. By the schooner Montezuma, Capt. TURNER, arrived yesterday, we have advices from Port-au-Platte to the 3d inst. On the 23d April, a fleet of Dominican vessels, consisting of a bark and five schooners, arrived off the port, the commanding officer of which sent letters on shore to the different Consuts and the authorities, requesting an interview on board the bark.

The Board of Aldermen met last evening. President CLANCY in the Chair. The following was offered by Alderman TUCKER: Wards not under contract, have not received any pay since the 1st of January last, and in consequence of which they are compelled to sell their claims at a discount of from 25 to 33 per cent.

The Southern Commercial Convention assembled in this town at 12 o'clock to-day, in the Depot of the Montgomery and West Point Railroad, which was fitted out for that purpose. The number of delegates in attendance is said to be below that of former Conventions, and consists, according to my estimate, of not more than six or seven hundred.

SUPREME COURT-GENERAL TERM. Before the Hon. Justices Davis, Ingaham and Sutherland. The Court have appointed Barzillai Slosson Richard Busteed and Benj. F. Dunning, examiners. to examine applicants for admission to practiceThey will meet in the General Term room, on Thurs ay, May 20, at 3 o'clock P. M., for the purpose of examining those who present themselves. Applicants must file their papers on or before Wednesday, the 19th instant.

We publish in another column an explanation from Gov. KING of the influences which prevailed upon him to commute the sentence of MAURICE O'CONNELL, who was convicted of murder,--the act being perpetrated in the endeavor to commit rape upon an old woman in this City.

Looking at the proceedings of the Woman's Rights Convention, which was held here on Thursday. with an anxious desire to learn precisely what the rights are which its members were so very clamorous for, we find it very difficult to get at the knowledge we were in pursuit of.

Audi alteram partem is a good maxim, especialy for an independent journal like the TIMES, which bears all sides. In previous correspondence I have xpressed doubts as to the real character of LOBA the escaped Mormon-the tendency of his story, etc. For this doubt I have a certain warrant, and alnough in view of the information I possess, I confess that it is not by any means dispelled,

Several excellent Bostonians, filled with admiration of the distinguished integrity, ability and wisdom of our Mayor TIEMANN, have forwarded to him a letter of compliments, a handsome harness and an elegant chaise, as a token of their appreciation. To which Mayor TIEMANN has modestly replied.

To the Editor of the New-York Times. In your list of abuses which you are so laudably endeavoring to correct, allow me to call attention to the inconvenience and annoyance theatrical managers impose on their patrons. It is an impossibility often to ascertain at what time the performances commence. without seeking some " poster," or taking a journey to the theatre during the day.

KIRKHAM--ELLIOT--In this City, on Wednesday, May 12 at Zion Church, by the Rev. Dr. Cox, SAMUEL R. KIRKHAM to MARTHA A. ELLIOT, all of this City.

TRYING TO MAKE IT PLEASANT ALL ROUND.The passage of the Kansas bill imposes new duties upon the retained organs of the Administration Democracy. The bill, as presented by the Conference Committee,was intended to be a cheat,-and it was precisely what it was intended to be.

ATWOOD.--In this City. on Friday morning, May 14, suddenly, SUSAN A. SLATER, wife of John M. Atwood, in the 21st year of her age. Relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to-attend her funeral. this (Saturday) afternoon, at 3 o'clock. from the Church of the Transfiguration, 29thst., near 5th-av. Her remains will be taken to Greenwood for interment.

The testimony given at the Coroner's Inquest, held in Utica on the bodies of the victims of the Central Railroad slaughter, develops facts bearing strongly against the Company. We copy from the report of the Utica Evening Telegraph:

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The gentleman who reported for you my speech at the Tract meeting on Wednesday, makes me apply the term flarulent to speakers who had preceded me. Permit me to say that I could not be guilty of so great a rudeness; and certainly no speech of the day deserved any such epithet.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I wish to call your attention, and that of the public, to the frequent insults offered, by scamps disguised in the dress of gentlemen, to ladies who may walk out unattended in tile streets of this City. Yesterday my wife went down to East Broadway, and while at a street crossing, was grossly insulted by an apparent gentleman.

SECOND DAY. Mozart Hall was half filled with men and women at twenty minutes past 10 Wednesday morning, when Mr. GARRISON said : "The Society will please come to order." As the day advanced, however, people flocked in, and the room was soon quite full. A letter from Mr. A. D. MAYO, apologizing for his absence, was read.

SECOND DAY. Mrs. ANTHONY called the Convention to order about 10 1/2 A. M. With permission of the audience, she said she would occupy a brief portion of the morning hour. The basis of her remarks was the proposition that wherever there were women, there also was plenty of woman's work to do.

No. 11-JOHN B Irwin vs. Wm. B. Marshall et al. -Justice DANIEL delivered the opinion of the Court reversing the decree of the Supreme Court of the Territory of Minnesota, with costs, and remanding the cause for further proceedings.

From the Albany Evening Journal. CASE OF MAURICE O'CONNELL. Erroneous statements have, from time to time, appeared in the public prints in relation to the commutation of the sentence of O'CONNELL. A statement of the facts and circumstances presented to the Governor, and which induced him to commute the sentence from death to Imprisonment for life, is herewith submitted.

There was little business done of general interest in Congress yesterday, it being private-bill day. In the Senate, after several private bills had been passed, a resolution was unanimously adopted asking information concerning the search or seizure of American vessels in the Gulf of Mexico, or adjacent seas, by foreign cruisers.

On the 18th ult., the American schooner Virginia Antoinette, SBISA, master, cleared for sea, with all her papers from the United States Consulate, from the custom-house of this port, in due form, and from all the existing authorities.

THE TRACT SOCIETY VOTE.-It has been stated that the action of the Tract Society on Wednesday was decided by the votes of New-York merchants and others in this City and Brooklyn supposed to sympathize with their views upon Slavery.

The alarm of fire at South Brooklyn yesterday morning proceeded from the burning of the threestory brick building, known as the cotton factory, near the corner of Van Brunt and Commercial streets. The building was about 400 feet long and three stories high; it was entirely consumed, and but little of the walls are standing; although from 700 to 800 hands are usually employed there; there were comparatively few engaged at present.

A SPECIAL REQUEST.--Will not the Detroit Free Press, the Albany Atlas and Argus, and other papers of the same stamp, relinquish their habit of styling the TIMES a "leading Black Republican journal ?" It is not true, in the first place.--and it hurts the feelings of our Republican brethren, which is another consideration of some importance.

The private Calendar was taken up, and several unimportant bills passed. A resolution was submitted that the President be requested, as far as compatible with the public interest, to communicate to the Senate any information which may have been received concerning the recent search or seizure of American vessels by foreign armed cruisers in the Gulf of Mexico or adjacent seas; and also, what measures, if any, have been taken in relation thereto. Adopted unanimously.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In your paper of May 8. under an article headed "A Western Judge Congratulating a Homicide," you remark, " If such are the Judges, what wonder that scoundrels abound ?" It appears to me that Homicide is the only chance to punish such crimes as seduction of daughters and wives, and laws give no adequate redress for a crime worse than murder.

ITALIAN OPERA.--"Linda di Chamounix" was played last night to a magnificent house. It was in every respect a memorable performance. The magnificent acting and equally magnificent singing of RONOONI created the most genuine furore we have ever witnessed in an opera house.

The outrages by British cruisers upon American merchant vessels continue, and almost every day we are called on to record fresh offences. From Boston we learn that the brig Robert Wing (which arrived at that port on Thursday morning) had been overhauled and her papers examined.

PICKETT'S factory, in this city, was wholly destroyed by fire this morning. It was occupied by E. P. HAND, wall paper maker, and PIERCE HUGHES. carriage bow makers, and owned by JOSEPH BATTIN. The total loss is $14,500, and the insurance $7,100. The steam engine, owned by W. R. INSLEE, of Brooklyn, was also destroyed; it was valued at $3,500. The fire is supposed to have been accidental.

Among the good effects of the late financial crisis has been a lapse in the supply of new light reading, and a consequent recourse to standard literature. The Waverley Novels, as issued in TICKNOR FIELDS' beautifulHousehold edition, have been re-perused by thousands.

The disease which is now attracting most attention at Quarantine is the small-pox, several vessels having arrived lately with cases on board. The ship Universe, arrived on the 8th inst. with 300 passengers, and several being sick with the disease, it became necessary to have all the emigrants and their baggage landed, for the purpose of cleansing the ship.

Criminals stand a chance to get punished in Massachusetts. The authorities don't even object to banging murderers. A strenuous effort has been made to obtain from the Governor's Council the pardon of the Irishman McGee, who killed Deputy Warden Walker in State Prison a year ago. The Council, after due consideration of the appeal, recommended to the Governor to order the execution of McGee for Friday, 20th June.

Before the City Judge. This trial was resumed yesterday. The first witness-called was Mr. GEORGE PURSER, whose evidence was resumed from the preceding day. He testified that the sum which he paid for the assignment of Mr. Carr's claim on the Commissioners, for the opening of Fifty-ninth-street, was $779; Mr. Carr's assignment was for $820, and the balance was the interest he received for the assignment.

AMENDING THE CONSTITUTION.-A writer in the Utica Observer specifies the elective Judiciary and the restrictive financial policy as the features in the present Constitution which most urgently require to be changed.

The new Catholic edifice in Fourteenth-street, known as the Church of the Immaculate Conception was solemnly consecrated yesterday by Archblshop HUGHES, assisted by Bishop BARRY of Savannah, Bishop LOUGHLIN of Brooklyn, Very Rev. Father STARRS, Vicar- General of New-York; Rev. Mr. RYAN, the pastor of the new church, and a large representation of the priesthood of this and the neighboring cities. Among these were the Venerable Archdeacon

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR: I have seen some allusion in the public papers, to the supposed insanity of the proprietor of the Ledger. For my own part, I think it is a very clear case. I have known the gentleman in question, a long time, and I have good reasons for believing him to be stark mad. He certainly does things which no man in his senses ever did before.

MEETING AT WASHINGTON MARKET.--The occupants of West Washington Market held a meeting on the market-ground, on Saturday, at 3 o'clock, Mr. L. BOOERT in the Chair. The minutes of a former meeting were read and approved.

TORNADOES AT THE WEST-A RAILROAD TRAIN BLOWN OFF THE TRACK-LIVES LOST, ST. Louis, Saturday, May 15. A violent tornado blew the passenger train of the Chicago, Alton and St. Louis Railroad off the track at Lexington, Mo., on Thursday night, and several persons were seriously injured.

Saturday Night Row in the Sixth WardA Policeman, being Assalled by Rowdies, Shoots one of them. That portion of the Sixth Ward side of the Bowery extending from Chatham-square to Canalstreet, is generally known as the rowdies' retreat. Almost every door-step is crowded with "fancy" and "fighting men," who delight in exhibiting themselves to the passers in a manner not at all agreeable to decent folk.

Our friend of the Albion is quite inclined to pooh-pooh the "outrages" of British men-ofwar, in arresting, overhauling and examining the papers of American vessels upon the American coast. He questions the accuracy, in sundry points, of the account furnished to the TIMES, reported by Captain STORE, of the Mobile.

Pleasant weather at last, after a rainy season of great length, which has created an unusual demand for umbrellas, while the parasol trade has been correspondingly dull. There have been some very pleasant entertainments, however,-among them. one on Monday evening, by Mrs. LENOX, of your City, whose small yet exquisitely-furnished drawing-rooms were packed like so many drums of figs.

To the Editor of the New- York Times: The "statement" which you say you "have received " (it came from the Tract House did it not?) as to the vote in the Tract Society, on Wednesday, is hardly warranted either in its statements or in its conclusions. Every one who was at the meeting knows that there was no count at all of those who voted against Dr. TYNG'S motion.

Barker, Francis Devene, John G. Middendorf, Charles Metty, Charles Harrold, C Heisenbuttle, P. Riley, and Pat. Seery; all fined $2 each.

THE TRACT SOCIETY.--The Indepentant, the only one of the religious papers of last week which reported the final action of the Tract Society, considers the action taken by that body as retrograde, and appeals to the Churches not to receive its secretaries and agents, and to pastors not to adult them to their pulpits.

HENNINGSEN AND LOCKRIDGE IN COMMUNICATION WITH GEN. VIDAURRI - LOCKRIDGE'S SERVICES REFUSED. From the Corpus Christi (Texas) Valley. We have the following important news from Northern Mexico, furnished by Capt. DAN HASTINGS, just in from Rio Grande City :

DIRECT TRADE BETWEEN OUR LAKE PORTS AND EUROPE.--It was stated a few days since that the brig Black Hawk, Capt. TAYLOR, was to sail from Detroit for Liverpool direct, on Saturday evening, with staves and lumber. Other vessels in the same trade, it is said, are to follow.

AN OPEN CANAL OR A COVERED CONDUIT ? To the Editor of the New- York Times: Most of your readers are no doubt aware that the good people of Brooklyn (now, be it remembered, a city of 230,000 inhabitants) are soon to possess, at municipal cost, that great desideratum, a copious supply of pure water. The works are expected to be finished by the ensuing Fall.

Mrs. HOEY'S benefit, on Saturday night, was an event of which she may justly be proud, the recollec tion of which will, we trust, abide with her in Europe, and direct her footsteps homeward with gladness. Wallack's Theatre was filled with an audience composed of the most fashionable and refined classes of the City, and the two dramatic pieces were listened to with unflagging interest to the end.

Mr. GWIN, of California. presented the memorial of the Legislature of California, calling on the Executive to take up the case of JUAN, ENSEY, who was seized by an armed band of Mexicans in Arizona, and carried to Sonora, where he is still held captive. The California delegation had written to President COMONFORT, who gave orders to have the prisoner released, but his order being disregarded, he professed himself unable to enforce it.

Gen. CASS has already made strong representations to Lord NAPIEE with regard to the outrages on American vessels in the Gulf and at Sagua la Grande. The most intense indignation exists here on the subjest, and several members are only restraiued from moving strong resolutions in the House by assurances that the Government has already taken the initial and a steps to demand redress.

An express has just arrived from Camp Scott It left the camp on the 10th of April. The Mormons were leaving Salt Lake City for the White River Mountains. Governor CUMMING had gone to the city by invitation. FURTHER DISPATCHES FROM GEN. JOHNSTONDOUBTS OF THE AUTHENTICITY OF THE ABOVE DISPATCH.

Gen. Peter Sken Smith, formerly, for a number of years, it resident of Philadelphia, died on the 6th inst., in Springfield, Mass., aged 63. He had recently taken up his residence in Springfield. Gen. Smith served in early life in the United States army, and was extensively known from his connection a few years back with the American movement.

It is commonly supposed that the public has a tolerably effectual guarantee against the culpable carelessness of railroad companies, in the power of suing them for damages for injuries sustained-and so a simple and clear statement of the law on the subject would certainly warrant any one in believing.

There will be next week a warm and exciting contest over the New-York nominations. None of them have yet been reported from the Committees to which they were referred. The only opposition to Mr. SCHELL will be founded upon his connection with the Willett's Point affair.

SHERMAN--STREMMELL.--In this City on Thursday evening, May 13, at the Church of the Epiphany by the Rev. Lot Jones, Mr. JOHN SHERMAN, of New-York, to Miss ELIZABETH STREMMELL, of Newark, N. J. BILLIN-HRNWOOD.--At St. Ann's Church, Wilton, Morrisania on Thursday, May 13, by the Rev. J. C Huckel, Mr. HENRY RILLIN of this City to Miss BESSIE HENWOOD. daughter of R. Henwood. Esq. of Morrisania.

BONNER IN TROUBLE!--BONNER, the advertiser, is in trouble. He has aroused the wrath of New-Jersey. He advertised last Thursday that his Ledger would be for sale at daylight "in the United States, New-Jersey and the Sandwich Islands"--whereupon the Trenton True American calls attention to the " slur cast upon the State of New-Jersey in connecting it with the Sandwich Islands apart from the United States,"-and it thus appeals to the patriotism of Jerseymen:

BROOKLYN WATER WORKS.--There is a difference of opinion in Brooklyn upon the question of making the new Aqueduct a covered conduit all the way, or leaving about eight miles of it an open canal. A correspondent, in another column,

THE PHILADELPHIA CASE OF JEALOUSY, ATTEMPTED MURDER AND SUICIDE. The suicide of GEORGE F. L. GOODWIN in Philadelphia last week, after an unsuccessful attempt to murder his mistress, has developed a ourious history. We condense from a long account in the Philadelphia Press: GOODWIN was of a highlyrespectable family in Boston.

The steam-tug Hercules, at 10 minutes to 11 o'clock, Friday night, while lving at the dock, at Sandy Hook, took fire near the smoke stack, and in 15 minutes was in a perfect blaze. The crew, after considerable difficulty, succeeded in getting her clear of the dock, when she went ashore on the beach, below the dock. and was entirely consumed. Her engine will be saved, it having been but very slightly damaged.

AMERICAN BOOKS IN CHINA.--An American Missionary in China, writing from Macao to a friend in Brooklyn, says: " Soon after my arrival In China I saw a copy of the American Antartic Exploring Expedition. which was presened by tile United States Government to the Emperor of China. or at least sent to him. It was found by a merchant In a bookstall in Canton.

The Albany Evening Journal, to refute the accusation of having treacherously betrayed Governor HUNT, publishes the following private letter, which was written when it was proposed that the Whigs of this State should join in the fusion movement which had previously led to the organization of the Republican Party in Eastern and Western States:

Mr. Hayes, late of the Philadelphia firm of Hayes Dreer, has bequeathed $50,000 for the foundation of an asylum for aged mechanics in Philadelphia. The institution is to receive the title of "Hayes' Mechanics' Home;" nine gentlemen are named as trustees, and large sums in addition to the legacy are promised by wealthy Philadelphians.

WARD -In this City, on Sunday morning, May 16. after a few hours's illness. CLARA PRICE, only child of Mortimer and Mary Jane Ward, aged 2 years, 6 months and 16 days. The friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral. from the residence of her father. No. 33 Delancy st.. on Tuesday. the 18th inst., at 3 o'clock P. M Her remains will be taken to Trinity Cemetery for interment.

AMERICAN WOMAN'S EDUCATIONAL CONVENTION.--The annual meeting of this Convention was held at the house of Mrs. Professor WEBSTER, No. 14 Lexington avenue, Saturday. In the absence of the President Mr. J. W. BAKER called the meeting to order at 12 1/2 o'clock. The Rev. W. L. PARSONS, the

The arrest of Captain JUDKINS, of the Persia, on the complaint of the Revenue Inspectors, alleging that the Captain, in carrying out the orders of the Health Officer, obstructed them in the lawful discharge of their duties, is likely to engage the serious attention of the City Government, as well as that of the Custom-House Department.

The Mercantile Library Association, at its last annual meeting, determined, by way of testing the public sentiment of Its membership, to have a vote taken at the coming election-day, (the 18th inst., OK the proposition to increase the annual fee from $2 to $3. This vote will be simply informal. The question is to be decided formally at the adjourned annual meeting on the 27th inst.

A shocking accident occurred on the Lafayette and Indianapolis Railroad last night. As the Cincinnati night express train, bound north, was crossing a bridge 22 miles east of Lafayette, it gave way, precipitating the whole train into the water. The fireman and engineer were killed, and it is reported that many others were killed and wounded. Particulars are expected momentarily.

There are some curious political straws floating in the wind, which are worth while submitting to E. MEBIAM, of Brooklyn Heights. since no less a philosopher will hardly venture to say what they mean.

His offence was the violent seizure of the poll-book of the Parish of St. Sylvestle, from the hands of the returning officer. Mr. O'FARRELL, who is

For a people who pride themselves upon a remarkably fill development of their eye-teeth, our confidence in corporations is wonderful. If an individual asks us to trust him, we are sharp enough as a general rule, and can smell even a small rat at any reasonable distance. But when it comes to dealing with corporations the case is entirely changed.

The Southern mail brings New-Orleans dates of the 11th inst., and all other points as late as due. The Now-Orleans papers contain details by the Tennessee. Nothing decisive has occurred at Fort Scott, since my last, but affairs are all tending towards a general conflict. Immediately after the repulse of the troops under Capt. ANDERSON, on the Marmaton, they sent to Fort Leavenworth, (through the Governor,) for reinforcements, and two companies of artillery reached Fort Scott last Monday.

Weekly report of deaths in the City and County of New-York, from the 8th day of May to the 15th day of May, 1858: Men, 88; Women, 74; Boys, 138. Total, 404*. Adults, 162; Children, 242; Males, 226; Females, 178; Colored persons, 13.

DAILY, No. 73 South Third street, fell from a second story window of its father's residence to the pavement, and sustained serious in juries. DARING ROBBERY.-The house occupied by BENJAMIN WRANG, corner of Myrtle-avenue and Jaystreet, was entered by thieves on Saturday afternoon, and robbed of property valued at $400, $200 in gold coin, about $50 in silver coin, and two watches. The mails from all points South, as late as due, are to hand. A severe hail storm had occurred in Virginia, five miles in width, covering portions of Powhattan and Chesterfield Counties. It was also severe at Fredericksburg. The grain and fruit crops were believed to be totally destroyed.

PUNISHMENT OF ENGLISH CRIMINALS.--The prompt punishment of criminals in England, whether of high or low degree, offers a strange contrast to the lax treatment of crime in this country. The contrast is greatly to the disadvantage not only of our Courts, but the state of public sentiment throughout the country. Rank,

NEW BUILDINGS.--A large warehouse is about to be erected for Mr. JOHN STEWART, Jr., fronting on State. Bridge and Pearl streets, extending 125 feet on the first, 60 feet on the second, and 50 feet on the last mentioned street. The building will be of fine Philadelphia brick, with sand-stone facings. The site which it will occupy is at No. 15 State-street and No. I Pearl-street.

The steamship North American, from Liverpool, at about 11 o'clock A. M. of Wednesday, the 5th inst., passed this port this forenoon, on her way to Quebec. The steamship North Star, from New-York April 17, arrived at Southampton on the afternoon of the 1st of May. The R. M. steamship America from Boston 21st April, vid Halifax, arrived at Liverpool at midnight of May.

BANK NOTE ENGRAVING.--An important step towards securing the Bank Note Currencyfrom its vicissitudes, has been taken by the firms engaged in bank note engraving and printing. They have all united, and formed a company, which is to be managed by trustees, and conducted upon a basis calculated, as they say,

The tone of the Stock market has not altered since the 11th inst., the date of our last advices. Transactions have been on a very moderate scale, but prices are well sustained, particularly those of State Stocks and other solid securities. Large amounts of capital lie idle, and will probably remain so until business revives and a fresh impulse will have been given to public enterprise.

THE TEN GOVERNORS.--A meeting of the Governors of the Almshouse is to be held this evening. The principal business will probably be the consideration of a resolution, laid over from the last meeting, restoring to offices in connection with the City establishments two clerks, who, some months since, were unanimously removed.

HENRY WILLIAM HERBERT, better known as "Frank Forrester,"committed suicide yesterday morning about 2 o'clock, at his room in the Stevens'House Broadway, opposite the Bowling Green. During Sunday he had sent for his friend Mr. PHILIP HONE ANTHON, saying that he was very lonely, and begging him to spend as much time as possible with him.

The Republican received a dispatch late last night, stating that an express reached Fort Leavenworth On the 13th inst., from Camp Scott April 10, bringing intelligence that the Mormons had laid down their arms. Governor CUMMING, on invitation of BRIGHAM YOUNG, had entered Salt Lake City without an escort. Many of the Mormons had gone to the southern part of the Tearitory, and the women and children were preparing to follow.

JUSTICE BRENNAN AGAIN --The letter which we published a few days since, vindicating Justice BRENNAN from certain acts with which he haa been charged, and our editorial comments thereon, should have satisfied him, as we are confident they did the public, of our readiness to repair whatever injustice may have been done through our columns.

It is a matter of honorable pride to Americans that the initiatory move for the abolition of the Danish Sound dues was made by the United States. We labored, and labored successfully, not merely in behalf of our own commerce. but in behalf of the commerce of the world.

On Opening Streets--Messrs. Greene, McDonald, Wilson.

But we do not remember that any such case has been made public. The violators of contracts have been innumerable;

THE TIMES NEW BUILDING.--The New-York TIMES comes to us this morning as a large double sheet, (or rather as two double shects.) printed at its new and spacious place of business, on the site of the old Brick Church, in Chatham, near Beekman-street. Of the TIMES we can truly say that we regard it as one of the best papers in this country or in the world.

LAURA KRENE'S THEATRE.--Mrs. D. P. BOWERS' company, from the Walnut-street Theater, Philadelphia, appeared here last night. The leading members of this troupe are well known in this City, and Mr. CONWAY and Mr. CHAPMAN, and others of like repute were welcomed by tile audience with warmth.

The Kickapoo correspondent of the Republican says that the bandits in the neighborhood of Fort Scott number two hundred and fifty, and are commanded by the notorious Capt. MONTGOMERY. They are thoroughly armed and mounted on fleet horses and defy the United 'States troops, swearing that they will not be taken. Upwards of one hundred and fifty families have been robbed and driven by them into Missouri.

We have to-day what seems to be a substantial confirmation of the report published in yesterday's TIMES, that the Mormon campaign has practically terminated,--that the leaders have fled to the mountains, and the mass of their followers have surrendered and acknowledged the authority of the United States.

NEWSPAPER CHANGES.--The Boston Bee yesterday changed its issue from evening to morning, and its title from the Bee to the Atlas and Daily Bee. GenWM. SCHOULER, formerly Editor of the Boston Atlas, and recently of the Cincinnati Gazette, resumes the editorship, after five years' absence from Boston. The new Paper is Republican in polities.

ADJOURNING THE ADJOURNMENT.--There are indications that Congress will postpone the day of its adjournment. Monday, the 7th of June, was fixed upon, about a month ago, for the closing of the present session, and for a short time after the passage of the joint resolution by which that day was designated, an increased activity was manifest in both Houses. But it did not last long.

We learn from Washington that orders have been sent to the squadron in the Gulf of Mexico and in the Central American waters not to permit the boarding and examination of American vessels by British cruisers. It is not easy to see what less decisive step could possibly have been taken by our Government under the circumstances;

Why the one should rejoice and the other regret, I cannot understand. The sentence is as follows:
