KENNARD--YEAMANS,--In this City, on Thursday evening, May 13, by the Rev Duncan Dunbar. Mr. SAMUEL D. KENNARD to Miss ELMIRA YEAMANS, all of New-York. VANDUZER--HAMBLETT--In this City, on Saturday evening May 15, by the Rev. L. Parmelee, Mr. JAMES VANDUZER to Miss AUGUSTA E. HAMBLETT. .

Although important dispatches are said to have been received here from Utah, the War Department will not publish any part of them, which determination is exciting unfavorable comment. It is believed, however, that no official confirmation of the Leavenworth dispatches have been received, but residents of Utah now here credit a portion of the news.

WOMEN'S RIGHTS.--What the rights of women really are, as understood by the Conventions which have them in charge, is a vexed and somewhat uncertain question. At the recent convocation of the strong-minded in this City, a little light was shed upon this subject by that cloquent Divine in petticoats, the Rev. ANTOINETTE L. BROWN.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The communication in your paper of to-day calls for a few remarks, not for its own value, but because you have given it room in your columns. The statement of your correspondent of Feb. 17, to which he refers, showed, if I remember tightly, a million of bales surplus out of the present crop above all possible requirements.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I beg, through you, to address the following communication to the stockholders of the Lexington and Danville Railroad Company and the public, before whom I nave recently been arraigned in the report of the President of the Company, Gen. LESLIE COMBS.

FLOUR quiet, but steady at last quotations--sales 2,000 bbls. WHEAT--nothing doing. OATS held at 42??. afloat, for prime samples--some lots sold at 4lc. CORN good demand; supply limited; sales 12 000 bushels at 70??. for Illinois River afloat. WHISKY dull at 21c. The two first boats from Buffalo--the C. G. Spalding and G. D Moore, have arrived, the former with 1,250 bbls. Flour, and the latter with 5,000 hushels of Wheat. Large arrivals are expected.

CONCERT IN BROOKLYN.--Mr. ALFRED SEDGWICK gave an interesting Concertina Soiree, last evening, at the Brooklyn Music rooms, assisted by several artists of the City of Churches, and, also, by his son and pupil, CHARLES SEDGWICK,--a fine little fellow who plays upon the bass concertina.

The Rev. BENNET TYLER, D. D., Ex-President of the Theological Institute of Connecticut, died suddenly this evening, after an illness of a few hours. He was out this forenoon, but took a cold which caused a neuralgia which settled upon his lungs, and a speedy death ensued.

THE SOUTH AND THE SLAVE-TRADE.--It will be seen by our reports of the proceedings of the Southern Commercial Convention, that the members of this body are not by any means agreed upon the proposition to reopen the Slave-trade, as brought forward by Mr. SPRATT and advocated by Mr. YANCEY.

Soon after the meeting of the Convention this morning, the consideration of the pending question, which was the report submitted on yesterday by Mr. SPRATT, of South Carolina, on the Slave-trade, was proceeded with.

Spring has opened with us most promisingly, and we are now letting about in the sunshine, enjoying the awakening of all nature from its Wintry sleep. Since my last communication the weather has grown milder, and at present there is no snow to be seen except on the mountain sides; these alone stand out in bold relief in their white mantles, spotted here and there with dark groves of cedar or pine

The rapidity with which Railroad structures and property depreciate is not understood by the public generally; although it is a fact interesting both to the traveling community and to those who purchase stocks for investment. Within a few days we have had an impressive example of the speedy decay of bridges, which may possibly direct attention for the moment to that of Railroad property generally.

The comments of the Southern press upon Mr. EVERETT'S action in reference to the assault of PRESTON S. BROOKS upon Senator SUMNER, has led to the publication of the following letter from him upon the subject: MEDFORD, Mass., Oct. 31.

The Democratic (Administration) State Committee of Illinois have issued an address upon the position and prospects of the party. They rehearse the history of the Kansas agitation, and insist that fidelity to the principle of Popular Sovereignty, requires them to sustain the Lecompton Constitution.

THE THIRTY-THIRD STATE--Oregon is virtually a sovereign State of this Union. yesterday the Senate passed the bill for her immediate admission, by a vote of 35 to 17. In the House it will encounter no effectual opposition, and before the close of the session she will constitute the thirty-third member of the Confederacy.

Touching the " Rejected Tract" (On the Family Relation as Affected by Slavery) it is announced by way of a reminder, that the premium for it was not offered by the Tract Society. An American gentleman resident in Scotland offered the premium of $200, and selected the Committee of Awards.

THE SEARCH QUESTION.--Congress has acted promptly in the matter of the British visitation of American vessels. The House of Representatives has adopted a resolution calling upon the President for information, and the Senate has instructed one of its Commitees to report whether any further legislation is needed to protect American commerce from these visits of inquiry or of search.

The Board of Aldermen met last evening, President CLANCY in the Chair. The Committee having it in charge to inquire and report why the laborers on the streets had not been paid, that the delay had been occasioned by the large number of bills, which required a long time for examiration. They found that the laborers were now receiving their money as fast as possible,

BARPER.--In this City, on Tuesday, May 18, Mr. THOMAS HERPER, after a protracted illness, aged 38 years. The friends of the family. the members of Blooming Grove Lodge. No. 182 I. 0. of 0. F., and the members of the "Caledonian Fusileers" are respectfully invited to attend his funeral, from his late residence. corner of 36thst. and 11th-av.. to-morrow. (Thursday, at 1 o'clock P.M. His remains will be taken to Cypress Hills Cemetery for interment

It appears from our Mexican correspondence, published in yesterday's TIMES, that very many of the public men of that country are looking abroad for that protection against incessant internal commotion which it seems impossible for them to secure through any unaided efforts of their own.

SHREWD ROBBERY AND SINGULAR DETECTION.--Two young fellows giving their names as James Burns and James Quino, were arrested yesterday in a very singular manner. They had managed adroitly to rob the money-drawer of the grocery store of Edward Lyons, corner of Seventh-avenue and Thirty-sixth-street, of its contents, containing $140 in bills, and to get out of the way sometime before the money was missed.

To the Editor of the New- York Times: Allow me to make public the careless manner in which stage-drivers snap their whips, sometimes at the urchins who "jump behind," and anon for their own amusement.

The reported surrender and fight of the Mormons do not seem to be fully confirmed by the more recent intelligence. It is now stated that Governor CUMMING has indeed been permitted to enter Salt Lake City, with a few personal attendants, but, without an army escort;

The annual election for officers of the Mercantile Library Association took place at Clinton Hall yesterday. The polls were opened in the hall of the first floor at 8 A. M., and closed at 9 P. M. Up to 7 P. M., only about 70 votes had been polled. In the evening the members assembled in large numbers, and the electioneering was spirited.

THE BATTLE OF SAN LUIS POTOSI--SEVERE SLAUGHTER--THE ZULOAGA GOVERNMENT IN A TIGHT PLACE--RESTRICTIONS ON THE PRESS. The steamship Tennessee, at New-Orleans, brings further particulars of the battle of San Luis Potosi, which appears to have been a bloody engagement. The New-Orleans Crescent says: "The news indicates the speedy downfall of the Zuloaga or Church Government.

The Derby Government have passed, by an overwhelming majority in the House of Commons, the first of the series of resolutions setting firth the principles upon which the new India Government is to be constructed.

At the election of Door-keeper to-day, about all the Douglas Democrats having voted for WRIGHT, the Democratic nominee, this is taken as a confirmation of the idea that they are all going back to the Administration Democracy. HASKIN'S candidate, QUEENSDALE, was only withdrawn this morning, the Opposition failing to unite on him. and HASKIN getting assurance that he should be provided for.

The recent outrageous attacks upon American vessels by British cruisers are without explanation in facts, or causes known to this Government. General Cass has, no doubt, as reported, addressed to Lord NAPIER suitable representations on the audacious conduct of his countrymen towards our vessels on the coast of Cuba.
KANSAS AFFAIRS.--We should like to hear from the Washington Union some explanation of the removal of District-Attorney WEIR and the appointment of another person in his place.

THE TIMES BUILDING.-We had the pleasure, the other day, of going over the New TIMES Building, in New-York, with one of its proprietors. It is one of the most conspicuous and elegant buildings in the City-is admirably located-is fitted up internally with every convenience-and is, we suppose, beyond question, the most complete Newspaper establish ment in the country, if not in the world.

From the Scottish American Journal On the 1st of May the TIMES establishment was removed to a new office occupying the angle at the corner of Nassau-street, Spruce and Park-row. The building is a very handsome one, and has been erected expressly for their own use by the proprietors of the paper.

The new propeller Austria arrived at this port yesterday from Hamburg, via Southampton Her dates are to the 4th inst., one day earlier than the North American's advices. Some interesting details of news are contained in our foreign files. The particulars of the news from India reach us by this arrival.

Mr. RING, the City Marshal of Chicago , it is knows, came to New-York empowered to collect all the information he could find concerning the mysterious barrel and its, mutilated human contents, with a view to using the testimony on the trail of the supposed murder. Mr. RING sought the assistance of the National Police Gazette organization, who deputed H. MASTERSON to look up the matter.

The case of the Persia, detained at Quarantine on account of Small-Pox on board, and the conflicting jurisdiction of the Custom-House and Health Officers, has led to a correspondence, of which the following is the substance. Dr. THOMPSON's letter rehearses the history of the-case. Mayor TIEMANN'S expounds the law in the matter.

GENERAL ETHAN ALLEN.--The Legislature of Vermont, at its session last Fall, made an appropriation to erect a suitable monument in which to place the bones of this famous patriot and soldier of the Revolution. Money in aid of the object was also liberally contributed in various parts of the State, for the Vermonters cherish the memory of the sturdy old hero with becoming pride.

The new propeller Austria, of the New-York and Han burg line arrived yesterday morning, having touched at Southampton. Her dates from London are to the 4th inst., not so late by one day as the news by the North American at Quebec. The latter, however, has received us by telegraph only. The files of papers by the Austria are three days later than the Persia's.

At a late hour last night, Mr. ANSON G. PHELPS, while sitting in his own house, suddenly fell dead. Although for some time past Mr. PHELPS had occasionally experienced a strange sensation about the heart, we understand that his health had been good, and that his decease was most sudden and unexpected.

Mr. SEWARD'S resolution of inquiry into the outrages on American vessels by British cruisers in the Gulf of Mexico, which was postponed yesterday, was unanimously adopted. Mr. DOUGLAS moved that the Oregon bill be taken up, upon which motion the Yeas and Nays were called for.

We have just received a private note from Monterey, which informs us that Gen. HENNINGEEN had arrived in that city, and was received with distinguished honors by Governor VIDAURRI and General GALLINDO, who immediately called upon him to confer on the objects of his mission, and afterwards addressed him a complimentary letter. The same authority gives us some information concerning the defeat of MIRAMON.

On the arrival of the morning papers, our citizens were very much affected by the announcement of the death of our beloved friend, ANSON G. PHELPS, Mr. PHELPS owned a fine country residence in the neighbelhood of our village, and as the time approached for his removal to the City on each autumnal reason, his friends-and they were many-were sorry to have him leave.

HALLETT--WILSON.--In this City, on Tuesday, May 18, by the Rev. H. D. Ganse, Mr. GEORGE C. HALLETT to Miss ADDIE WILSON. all of this City. BACHE--HASWELL.--In this City, on Tuesday, May 18, by the Rev. Dr. Hobart, at St John's Church, J. HENRY BACHE to FANNIE R., second daughter of Charles H. Haswell. Esq all of this City.

The Royal Mail steamship Niagara, Captain WICEMAN, left Liverpool at 3 P. M. of the 8th inst., and arrived at Halifax at 11 o'clock on the morning of Wednesday, the 19th inst. The Niagara reports, off Tuskar, 9th inst., at 9 A. M., passed the steamship Africa, from New-York for Liverpool; 10th, lat. 51[degree], long. 11[degree],

Our Government, it seems, has been by no means inactive in regard to the recent visitations of American merchant vessels by British cruisers. Congress was informed yesterday that strong representations on the subject have already been made to the British Minister at Washington and to the American Minister in London, and that steps have been taken to prevent such occurrences hereafter.

KINGS COUNTY BOARD OF SUPERVISORS.--An adjourned meeting of this Board was held in the old Court room, County jail, yesterday afternoon. President CAMPBELL occupied the chair and a quorum of members was present. The Chair announced the following STANDING COMMITTES: On Accounts of Superintendants of the Poor.-Messrs. Salem, Ralph, Cross.

BURNING OF THE MACHINE SHOPS OF THE NEW ALBANY AND SALEM RAILROAD--LOSS $250,000.--The New-Albany (Ind) Tribune Extra of the 14th says: About one o'clock this morning a fire broke out in the machine shops of the New-Albany and Salem Railroad Company, in this city, which spread, with such fearful rapidity that it was impossible to save anything, and in less than an hour the entire buildings, covering a square of ground, were in ruins.

The rapid growth of our empire on the Pacific renders it important that we should avail ourselves of every feasible crossing place, by which business and emigration may pass from ocean to ocean. We have already secured the Isthmus of Panama, across which a railroad has been constructed.

The Commissioners of Education met last evening. Mr. NEILSON, the President, in the Chair. A resolution was offered to rescind one previously adoptedd by the Board, which (we mean the first in point of time) confirmed the award of a contract to the amount of some $3,100 or upwards for repairs to school No. 38 in the Eighth Ward.

Week before last, there were were three duels in the neighborhood of New-Orleans. We have published accounts of two ; the third took place on the 6th inst., on the Gentilly road. The antagonists were F. W. SEYMOUR and A. MORRIS; the weapons, small swords. At the second pass, MORRIS, the challenger, was wounded in the groin, and " honor" was satisfied.

SENSIBLE VIEW.--The Charleston Mercury thus speaks of the discussion now going on in the Southern Commercial Convention upon the subject of reviving the Slave-Trade: "The agitation of this question here, is breeding great dissension in the Convention.

The New-York Express train on the Elmira Canandaigua and Niagara Falls Railroad, which left Suspension Bridge yesterday morning at 20 minutes to 6 o'clock, ran off the track a half mile west of Penn Yan Station. The accident was caused by the equalizing bar on the tender breaking, which fell on the track, thereby. throwing the baggage and two passenger cars off the track, stripping the latter of their seats.

The New-Haven Register announces the arrival of TUCKERMAN at the State Institution in Wetherfield, safe and sound He takes the affair coolly and philosophically, and is evidently under the sanguine hope or belief that he will not be a boarder there for the full term of his sentence--21 years-- she requested that his clothes might be laid down in camphor. so as to be sweet and whole when he should emerge from prison again.

Dr. HAMILTON, from near Fort Scott, arrived here today, bringing dreadful accounts of the troubles in that region. The notorious Capt. MONTOGOMERY, who destroyed the ballot box at one of the polls suring the election on the 4th of January last, had driven every Pro-Slavery and conservative Free-State man out of Linn and Bourbon counties.

When Captain SANDS, of the steam-frigate Susquchanna, was arrested last month, for refusing to comply with the orders of the Health Officer at Quarautine, it was shown that he was guilty of a misdemeanor which subjected him to the penalty of fine and imprisonment, and he at once yielded to the Quarantine authorities.

PHELPS.--In this City, on Tuesday evening, May 18, suddenly ANSON G. PHELPS. The friends of the family are respectfully requested to attend the funeral services, on Thursday afternoon, at the Mercer-st. Church, at 4 1/2 o'clock, without further invitation. KING--In this City, on Wednesday, May 19, CHARLES B. KING, of Chicago aged 49 years.

There is generally abundant matter for condemnatory comment in the proceedings of our City Courts. The degeneracy which seems to mark every department of the public administration on which the City Government and CitY Politics exercise any influence, has not kept clear of the judgment hall any more than any other hall.

The Turkish Admiral and suite visited the NavyYard at Portsmouth, N. H., yesterday, where they were received by a salute. They partook of a collation at the house of the commandant. and afterwards dined at Rockingham House, the Mayor presiding. The Turks expressed themselves greatly pleased with the yard, especially with the three-decker Franklin, which they examined throughout.

DISEASED SWILL-FED BEEF--Three men named MARTIN WILLIAMSON, MICHAEL WILLIAMSON and NICHOLAS PRIOR,were brought before the Recorder on Tuesday, on suspicion of having killed and prepared the meat of a diseased swill-fed cow for the butcher's stall. It appears that one of FRANK LESLIE'S detectives visited Jersey City for the purpose of inspecting the swill-milk institutions.

Our Washington dispatches this morning will be found highly important. The President yesterday sent to the Senate, in response to a resolution of that body, the documents relative to the recent outrages by British cruisers in the West Indian waters in detaining and firing into American vessels, and setting forth the action taken by the Administration in regard to them.

The Lecture Room of the Historical Society was crowded Tuesday evening by the announcement that Hon.GULIAN C. VERPLANCK would read a paper entitled "Reminiscences of JOHN RANDOLPH, of Roanoke." Prominent among those present were Mayor TIEMANN, Judges DAVIES and ROOSEVELT, and AUGUSTUS SCHELL.

The frigate Wabash has everything in readiness for sea, and will sail for the Mediterranean on or about June 1, unless, as there is some reason to expect, her destination may be temporarily changed to the Gulf Squadron. The Secretary of the Navy telegraphed to Norfolk too late to detain the Colorado, she having already sailed from Hampton Roads for the Gulf, as the flag-ship of the Home Squadron.

The long agony is over! Lecompton is driven from Congress in spite of the President. He who proudly said that the Lecompton Constitution "should be passed in thirty days," and, in his haughty arrogance, declared that "Kansas is a slave State," has been compelled to submit to a Waterloo defeat on his own chosen ground. Kansas is not a slave State, nor never will be.

Funeral Rites Denled Hin-Public Sentiment at Newark. The remains of HENRY WILLIAM HERBERT, the "Frank Forrester" of the periodicals, whose suicide we announced Monday, were, yesterday, interred at Mount Pleasant Cemetery, Newark, N. J. Mr. MILES I'ANSON, the personal friend and neighbor of the wretohed man during the latter part of his life, came to this City, yesterday morning, and prepared to convey the body to Newark.

AN INTOLERABLE QUANTITY OF LAGER.--We had supposed that the non-toxatious nature of lager bier had once been settled by our Courts of law ; but it seems that the Brooklyn decision on this point is not deemed conclusive.

Senator CLAY, of Alabama, has a mission. He is devoting himself with great zeal to securing the repeal of the law which since 1789 has encouraged the catching of codfish by a system of bounties.

The Southern Commercial Convention closed its session to-day, and I venture to assert that never in the history of Southern Conventions was there witnessed such an exhibition of low, contemptible demagogueism and political cant. These assemblages seem to be degenerating, both in the character of their aims and purposes, as they move southward.

Of all public men ,in Mexico, SANTIAGO VI DAURRI is the ablest, the most energetic, and, perhaps, the most dangerous opponent of FELIX ZULOAGA. His influence, it is true, is limited to the States of Nueva Leon, Coahuila and Tamaulipas; but these States are able to maintain in the field an army of 8,000 men, who are decidedly superior in morale to the troops of more Southern districts.

The following resolutions were submitted to the State Temperance Society yesterday by AMASA McCOY, of Albany, and were adopted this morning unanimously, after much debate. Whereas, By an act of the Legislature for 1858, the question is to be submitted to the people on the second of November next, whether there shall be a Convention to revise the Constitution and amend the same ;

The U. B M. steamship Black Wrarrier, J. W. SMITH Commander, from Havana on the 10th inst., arrived at this port early yesterday mornings The aggressions of the English gun-boats continue. A few days since they landedd a detachment of marines at one of the out-ports of the Island, and searched the plantations in the vicinity for Bzal negroes, but found none.

It is out of fashion to call disagreeable things by their right names. When a man eheats his creditors by a dishonest bankruptcy, it is styled a commercial embarrassment. If a speculator finds it. convenient to hide his asseis in the bands of a friend, it is simply making an assignment to protect his own interests.

Our shoemakers in some parts of the State are organizing into lodges and leagues, their object being to make a grand strike for an advance of wages. Time was when they would have been indicted for such conduct, but we have become too wise for action of that kind.

DECLINE OF OUR RURAL POPULATION.-The population of the rural portions of this State is decreasing, not merely in a relative sense, but absolutely. If we take pains to foot up the inhabitants of villages, counting 3,000 each and upwards, together with those of other cities, we shall find that such places contain more than half the people of the State.

The State of Wisconsin must be a model Commonwealth. In these days of general corruption, it is scarcely safe to assume that one State is much worse than another; but Wisconsin, so far as the public has yet been informed upon official authority, is certainly entitled to the glory of being the most. shamelessly debauched member of the Federal Union.

PRESENTATION.--After the adjournment of the Common Council, on Tuesday evening. alderman TILDAN, on behalf of SAMUEL COOPER, presented to SAM'L A. FRENCH, Chief Engineer of the Fire Department, a heavy silver and gold badge. Alderman TILDEN alluded to the valuable services performed by Mr. FLEACH, and the confidence reposed in ??im by the Department and the citizens for his urbanity, ability, promptness and efficiency.

We have dates from Rio de Janerio to April 17. The schooner North Point sailed from that port April 10, for New-York, and the bark Japonica, no date given, for Philadelphia. The bark Morning Star also sailed for New Orleans in April, but was lost off Cape Frio. All hands were saved.

It is long since I addressed the readers of the NEW-YORK TIMES,-and since then grave questions and interesting discussions have occupied the public mind. I have taken some part in them, but not so much, I trust, as to obscure my vision or delude my judgment.
One of our Philadelphia contemporaries indulged itself yesterday in some very dismal platitudes on the state of public feeling in this State in respect to "criminals of the most atrocious stamp."
